zh: 神秘岛
en: The Mysterious Island

zh: 第一部分 高空遇险
en: Part 1—Dropped from the Clouds

zh: 第一章
en: Chapter 1

zh: “我们又上升了吗？”“没有。恰恰相反。”“我们在下降吗？”“比那还要糟糕，上尉！我们正往下掉！”“天哪，赶紧扔掉压舱物！”“瞧！最后的一袋都空了！”“气球上升了吗？”“没有！”“我好像听到了海浪的冲击声。吊篮下面是大海！离我们不超过500英尺！”“快扔掉所有占重量的东西！……所有的！”
en: “Are we rising again?”“No.On the contrary.”“Are we descending?”“Worse than that, captain! we are falling!”“For Heaven’s sake heave out the ballast!”“There! the last sack is empty!”“Does the balloon rise?”“No!”“I hear a noise like the dashing of waves.The sea is below the car!It cannot be more than 500 feet from us!”“Overboard with every weight!...everything!”

zh: 这就是1865年3月23日下午四点钟回荡在辽阔、荒凉的太平洋上空的响亮、惊人的喊叫声。
en: Such were the loud and startling words which resounded through the air, above the vast watery desert of the Pacific, about four o’clock in the evening of the 23rd of March, 1865.

zh: 那年春分前后，从东北方向吹来的骇人暴风令人难忘。从3月18日到26日，风暴肆虐，片刻不停。它给美洲、欧洲和亚洲造成了严重灾害，从北纬35度斜穿赤道到南纬40度，掠过了1800英里的地带。城市被摧毁，树木被连根拔起，堤岸被汹涌而来、排山倒海的巨浪冲毁。根据已经发布的数字，被抛上陆地的船只数以百计；水龙卷经过的地方，整个地区被夷为平地，一切都被摧毁了；好几千人被压死在陆地上，或是溺死在大海中。这就是那场毁灭性的风暴疯狂肆虐后留下的痕迹。1810年10月25日哈瓦那和1825年7月26日瓜达卢普的灾情固然可怕，可这一次却是有过之而无不及。
en: Few can possibly have forgotten the terrible storm from the northeast, in the middle of the equinox of that year.The tempest raged without intermission from the 18th to the 26th of March.Its ravages were terrible in America, Europe, and Asia, covering a distance of eighteen hundred miles, and extending obliquely to the equator from the thirty-fifth north parallel to the fortieth south parallel.Towns were overthrown, forests uprooted, coasts devastated by the mountains of water which were precipitated on them, vessels cast on the shore, which the published accounts numbered by hundreds, whole districts leveled by waterspouts which destroyed everything they passed over, several thousand people crushed on land or drowned at sea; such were the traces of its fury, left by this devastating tempest.It surpassed in disasters those which so frightfully ravaged Havana and Guadalupe, one on the 25th of October, 1810, the other on the 26th of July, 1825.

zh: 就在陆地和海洋惨遭浩劫之时，激荡的高空也上演着同样惊心动魄的戏剧。
en: But while so many catastrophes were taking place on land and at sea, a drama not less exciting was being enacted in the agitated air.

zh: 事实上，一只气球像被带入水柱顶端的皮球一样，卷入了一股气流的漩涡中，以每小时90英里的速度掠过天空，仿佛被空中漩涡紧抓住，转个不停。
en: In fact, a balloon, as a ball might be carried on the summit of a waterspout, had been taken into the circling movement of a column of air and had traversed space at the rate of ninety miles an hour, turning round and round as if seized by some aerial maelstrom.

zh: 气球下面摆着一只吊舱，里面有五个人，由于浓雾中混着海洋表面悬浮的水花，人们几乎看不清楚他们。
en: Beneath the lower point of the balloon swung a car, containing five passengers, scarcely visible in the midst of the thick vapor mingled with spray which hung over the surface of the ocean.

zh: 也许有人会问，这个被暴风捉弄的玩具从哪里来的？它又是从世界的哪个角落升起的？当然，它是不可能在风暴肆虐时飞起的。但是，暴风已经肆虐了五天，并且18日那天就已经有了要起风暴的征兆。毫无疑问，气球是从很远的地方飞来的，因为气球一昼夜的飞行不会少于2000英里。
en: Whence, it may be asked, had come that plaything of the tempest?From what part of the world did it rise?It surely could not have started during the storm.But the storm had raged five days already, and the first symptoms were manifested on the 18th.It cannot be doubted that the balloon came from a great distance, for it could not have traveled less than two thousand miles in twenty-four hours.

zh: 这些乘客没有作为向导的标记，无论如何也没法计算自启程以来他们走过了多少路线。不同寻常的是，尽管狂风肆虐，他们还是安然无恙。他们被暴风抛来抛去，转来转去，却丝毫没有感觉到旋转，也没感觉到颠簸。
en: At any rate the passengers, destitute of all marks for their guidance, could not have possessed the means of reckoning the route traversed since their departure.It was a remarkable fact that, although in the very midst of the furious tempest, they did not suffer from it.They were thrown about and whirled round and round without feeling the rotation in the slightest degree, or being sensible that they were removed from a horizontal position.

zh: 他们的视线没法穿透吊篮下面弥漫的浓雾。浓厚的水汽包围着他们。阴云密布，他们无法辨别是白天还是黑夜。此时他们悬浮在高空，既看不见地面的反光，也听不到人类居住地传来的声音，就连海洋的怒吼声也听不见，周围一片昏暗。只有当他们急剧下降时才意识到自己身处波涛汹涌的险境中。然而，当弹药、枪支和食物等重物被扔掉后，气球承载的重量变轻，升得更高了，悬浮在4500英尺的高空。航行的人们发现气球下面是伸展开的大海，觉得上面的危险较之下面没那么可怕，甚至毫不犹豫地扔掉了他们最有用的东西。与此同时，他们尽量不让气体漏掉一点，这可是他们冒险计划的命根子，它能让他们继续悬浮在无底深渊的上空。
en: Their eyes could not pierce through the thick mist which had gathered beneath the car.Dark vapor was all around them.Such was the density of the atmosphere that they could not be certain whether it was day or night.No reflection of light, no sound from inhabited land, no roaring of the ocean could have reached them, through the obscurity, while suspended in those elevated zones.Their rapid descent alone had informed them of the dangers which they ran from the waves.However, the balloon, lightened of heavy articles, such as ammunition, arms, and provisions, had risen into the higher layers of the atmosphere, to a height of 4,500 feet.The voyagers, after having discovered that the sea extended beneath them, and thinking the dangers above less dreadful than those below, did not hesitate to throw overboard even their most useful articles, while they endeavored to lose no more of that fluid, the life of their enterprise, which sustained them above the abyss.

zh: 他们战战兢兢地度过了黑夜，如果是胆小的人，也许早就吓死了。白昼再次来临，风暴也随之渐渐缓和下来。从3月24日清晨起，暴风有了减弱的迹象。拂晓时分，朵朵轻云升上高空。几小时过去后，飓风变为清风，也就是说，大气层流动的速度减弱了一半。这时的风虽说还是水手们所说的“紧帆风”，但是恶劣天气的狂暴之势毕竟减弱不少了。
en: The night passed in the midst of alarms which would have been death to less energetic souls.Again the day appeared and with it the tempest began to moderate.From the beginning of that day, the 24th of March, it showed symptoms of abating.At dawn, some of the lighter clouds had risen into the more lofty regions of the air.In a few hours the wind had changed from a hurricane to a fresh breeze, that is to say, the rate of the transit of the atmospheric layers was diminished by half.It was still what sailors call “a close-reefed topsail breeze,” but the commotion in the elements had none the less considerably diminished.

zh: 快到十一点钟时，低空明显晴朗了。大气散发出阴冷的潮气，雷雨过后总是如此。暴风似乎不再向西吹了。它好像已经筋疲力尽。它会不会像电流一样，顷刻间消失殆尽，就像有时候印度洋上的台风那样？
en: Towards eleven o’clock, the lower region of the air was sensibly clearer.The atmosphere threw off that chilly dampness which is felt after the passage of a great meteor.The storm did not seem to have gone farther to the west.It appeared to have exhausted itself.Could it have passed away in electric sheets, as is sometimes the case with regard to the typhoons of the Indian Ocean?

zh: 然而就在此时，气球很明显地再次慢慢匀速下降。看来它似乎正在一点一点瘪下去，气囊愈伸愈长，从球形变为椭圆形。将近正午，气球在距海面仅2000英尺的上空盘旋。气囊能容纳50000立方英尺气体，正因如此，气球才得以长时间悬浮在空中，尽管它理应向上升得很高，或者可能被抛向水平位置。
en: But at the same time, it was also evident that the balloon was again slowly descending with a regular movement.It appeared as if it were, little by little, collapsing, and that its case was lengthening and extending, passing from a spherical to an oval form.Towards midday the balloon was hovering above the sea at a height of only 2,000 feet.It contained 50,000 cubic feet of gas, and, thanks to its capacity, it could maintain itself a long time in the air, although it should reach a great altitude or might be thrown into a horizontal position.

zh: 乘客们意识到自己面临的危险，扔掉了最后几件压低吊舱的物品，包括保存的少量存粮，也扔掉了所有东西，甚至是随身携带的小刀。有一个人爬到套着网索的圆环上，试图把气球的下部系得更牢靠些。
en: Perceiving their danger, the passengers cast away the last articles which still weighed down the car, the few provisions they had kept, everything, even to their pocket-knives, and one of them, having hoisted himself on to the circles which united the cords of the net, tried to secure more firmly the lower point of the balloon.

zh: 然而，这些旅行者们都很清楚，气体越来越少，气球不可能再悬浮在更高的地方。他们必然死路一条!
en: It was, however, evident to the voyagers that the gas was failing, and that the balloon could no longer be sustained in the higher regions.They must infallibly perish!

zh: 气球下面看不见大陆，甚至连个小岛也看不见。这片辽阔的水域没有一丁点陆地，也没有一处坚实的地面可供他们抛锚。
en: There was not a continent, nor even an island, visible beneath them.The watery expanse did not present a single speck of land, not a solid surface upon which their anchor could hold.

zh: 就在这辽阔的海面上，惊涛骇浪咆哮不止！即使人们在高处俯瞰，视野扩大至方圆40英里，海洋仍是一望无际。这流动的广阔平原被暴风毫不留情地鞭挞，洋面犹如一群群狂怒的战马，它们凌乱的白色鬃毛在风中飘动。看不到陆地，也看不到一艘船！必须不惜一切代价阻止气球继续下落，避免卷入波浪。旅行者们把全力全身力气用在这个紧急任务上。但是，无论他们如何努力，气球仍在下落，同时以极快的速度顺着风向移动，也就是说从东北向西南方向移动。
en: It was the open sea, whose waves were still dashing with tremendous violence!It was the ocean, without any visible limits, even for those whose gaze, from their commanding position, extended over a radius of forty miles.The vast liquid plain, lashed without mercy by the storm, appeared as if covered with herds of furious chargers, whose white and disheveled crests were streaming in the wind.No land was in sight, not a solitary ship could be seen.It was necessary at any cost to arrest their downward course, and to prevent the balloon from being engulfed in the waves.The voyagers directed all their energies to this urgent work.But, notwithstanding their efforts, the balloon still fell, and at the same time shifted with the greatest rapidity, following the direction of the wind, that is to say, from the northeast to the southwest.

zh: 这些不幸的人们所处的境地的确很可怖。很明显，他们已经无法掌控气球。他们的一切努力都于事无补。气球的气囊越来越瘪。气体不断外泄，没法堵住。很明显，气球下降的速度越来越快，正午过后，吊篮离洋面不到600英尺了。
en: Frightful indeed was the situation of these unfortunate men.They were evidently no longer masters of the machine.All their attempts were useless.The case of the balloon collapsed more and more.The gas escaped without any possibility of retaining it.Their descent was visibly accelerated, and soon after midday the car hung within 600 feet of the ocean.

zh: 阻止气体外泄已经毫无可能，它从丝布气囊的一条大裂缝向外冲。吊篮里的重物全都扔掉了，重量轻了，因此乘客们还可以在空中支持几个钟头。但这仅仅是延缓了不可避免的灾难而已，如果天黑之前还没有陆地出现，乘客、吊舱和气球必然会葬身海底。
en: It was impossible to prevent the escape of gas, which rushed through a large rent in the silk.By lightening the car of all the articles which it contained, the passengers had been able to prolong their suspension in the air for a few hours.But the inevitable catastrophe could only be retarded, and if land did not appear before night, voyagers, car, and balloon must to a certainty vanish beneath the waves.

zh: 这时，他们只能求助于仅存的应急手段。他们都是勇敢无畏的人，知道如何面对死亡。他们没有一句怨言。他们决心奋战到最后一刻，想方设法延迟气球坠落。吊舱只是一种柳树干做的篮子，无法浮着，他们也不可能想办法将其维持在海面上。
en: They now resorted to the only remaining expedient.They were truly dauntless men, who knew how to look death in the face.Not a single murmur escaped from their lips.They were determined to struggle to the last minute, to do anything to retard their fall.The car was only a sort of willow basket, unable to float, and there was not the slightest possibility of maintaining it on the surface of the sea.

zh: 又是两个小时过去了，气球离水面不过400英尺了。
en: Two more hours passed and the balloon was scarcely 400 feet above the water.

zh: 这时，一声洪亮的声音传来，从声音就知道，恐惧接近不了这人的内心。回答他的声音也没有流露出丝毫不坚定。“所有的东西都扔掉了吗？”“没有，还有2000金币。”一个沉重的袋子立刻落入海中。“气球上升了吗？”“上升了一点儿，但是一会儿还是要下降的。”“还有什么可以扔掉的吗？”“没了。”“对了，还有吊舱！”“让我们抓住网索，把吊舱扔到海里去吧！”
en: At that moment a loud voice, the voice of a man whose heart was inaccessible to fear, was heard.To this voice responded others not less determined.“Is everything thrown out?”“No, here are still 2,000 dollars in gold.”A heavy bag immediately plunged into the sea.“Does the balloon rise?”“A little, but it will not be long before it falls again.”“What still remains to be thrown out?”“Nothing.”“Yes! the car!”“Let us catch hold of the net, and into the sea with the car.”

zh: 事实上，这是最后也是唯一能够减轻气球重量的方法了。割断系着吊舱的绳索后，气球随之上升了2000英尺。五位乘客吊在气球网上，紧抓住网眼，凝视下方的无底深渊。
en: This was, in fact, the last and only mode of lightening the balloon.The ropes which held the car were cut, and the balloon, after its fall, mounted 2,000 feet.The five voyagers had hoisted themselves into the net, and clung to the meshes, gazing at the abyss.

zh: 大家知道气球对于重力的增减很敏感。即使扔下最轻的东西，也足以改变它在垂直方向的位置。这个在空中的装置就像一个极为精确的天平。不难理解，只要减轻任何相当重量的东西，它就会立刻急剧上升。此时的情形就是如此。但是，在高处悬浮不久之后，气球又开始下降，气体从根本没法修补的裂缝向外跑。
en: The delicate sensibility of balloons is well known.It is sufficient to throw out the lightest article to produce a difference in its vertical position.The apparatus in the air is like a balance of mathematical precision.It can be thus easily understood that when it is lightened of any considerable weight its movement will be impetuous and sudden.So it happened on this occasion.But after being suspended for an instant aloft, the balloon began to redescend, the gas escaping by the rent which it was impossible to repair.

zh: 这些人尽了全力。现在人力已不能挽救他们。
en: The men had done all that men could do.No human efforts could save them now.

zh: 他们必须依靠统领一切的上帝的仁慈。
en: They must trust to the mercy of Him who rules the elements.

zh: 在四点钟的时候，气球离海面仅仅不到500英尺。
en: At four o’clock the balloon was only 500 feet above the surface of the water.

zh: 一声响亮的犬吠声传来。一只狗陪伴着旅行者，它紧紧地挨着主人，抓在网眼上。
en: A loud barking was heard.A dog accompanied the voyagers, and was held pressed close to his master in the meshes of the net.

zh: “托普看见什么了。”一个人大声喊。紧接着，又有一个人大声喊：
en: “Top has seen something,” cried one of the men.Then immediately a loud voice shouted,—

zh: “陆地！陆地！”气球一直随风向西南漂行，从天亮到现在走了很远的距离，大概有几百英里，一个相当高的陆地其实已经出现在前方了。但是这片陆地还在30英里以外。要到达那里至少要一个小时，那么就有可能驶向背风面。
en: “Land! land!”The balloon, which the wind still drove towards the southwest, had since daybreak gone a considerable distance, which might be reckoned by hundreds of miles, and a tolerably high land had, in fact, appeared in that direction.But this land was still thirty miles off.It would not take less than an hour to get to it, and then there was the chance of falling to leeward.

zh: 一个钟头！气球里仅存的一点气体会不会在到达那里之前全跑光呢？
en: An hour!Might not the balloon before that be emptied of all the fluid it yet retained?

zh: 这个问题很严峻！乘客们已经清晰地望见了坚实的陆地，他们不惜任何代价也要到达那里。他们并不知道那里是什么地方，是岛屿还是大陆？因为他们不知道飓风将他们吹到了地球的哪个角落。但是他们必须到那块陆地，不管那里是有人居住还是没有人烟，也不管那里欢迎他们与否。
en: Such was the terrible question!The voyagers could distinctly see that solid spot which they must reach at any cost.They were ignorant of what it was, whether an island or a continent, for they did not know to what part of the world the hurricane had driven them.But they must reach this land, whether inhabited or desolate, whether hospitable or not.

zh: 很明显，气球已无法支持下去。好几次，巨大的浪花顶端轻轻拍打气球网的下部，气球更加沉重，悬浮在半空中，像一只翅膀受伤的鸟。半小时后，他们距陆地不过一英里之遥，但是气球已经耗尽气力，软绵无力、褶皱不堪地悬在那里，唯有上方还余下一些气体。乘客们紧紧抓住气球网，但气球仍是太重，不久半个身子就浸在水里了，汹涌的海浪拍打着他们。气囊又一次鼓起，在风力的作用下，它像船一样前行。没准它能这样到达陆地?
en: It was evident that the balloon could no longer support itself!Several times already had the crests of the enormous billows licked the bottom of the net, making it still heavier, and the balloon only half rose, like a bird with a wounded wing.Half an hour later the land was not more than a mile off, but the balloon, exhausted, flabby, hanging in great folds, had gas in its upper part alone.The voyagers, clinging to the net, were still too heavy for it, and soon, half plunged into the sea, they were beaten by the furious waves.The balloon-case bulged out again, and the wind, taking it, drove it along like a vessel.Might it not possibly thus reach the land?

zh: 但是，当离岸只有两英寻远时，四个人同时惊声尖叫起来。原以为绝不能再上升的气球，在一个巨浪的拍打下，竟出乎意料地再次上升。瞬间，气球似乎释放了一部分重量，高升到1500英尺的高空，又遇到一阵风，这阵风非但没把它吹向岸边，反而使它沿着和陆地几乎平行的方向飞去。
en: But, when only two fathoms off, terrible cries resounded from four pairs of lungs at once.The balloon, which had appeared as if it would never again rise, suddenly made an unexpected bound, after having been struck by a tremendous sea.As if it had been at that instant relieved of a new part of its weight, it mounted to a height of 1,500 feet, and here it met a current of wind, which instead of taking it directly to the coast, carried it in a nearly parallel direction.

zh: 两分钟后它又斜转回来，最后降落在一块海浪冲击不到的沙滩上。
en: At last, two minutes later, it reproached obliquely, and finally fell on a sandy beach, out of the reach of the waves.

zh: 乘客们互相帮助，从网眼中挣脱出来。气球失去了他们的重量，被风吹起，像一只受伤的鸟马上恢复了气力，消失在空中。
en: The voyagers, aiding each other, managed to disengage themselves from the meshes of the net.The balloon, relieved of their weight, was taken by the wind, and like a wounded bird which revives for an instant, disappeared into space.

zh: 吊篮中原本载了五个人和一条狗，可是气球只留下四个人在岸上。
en: But the car had contained five passengers, with a dog, and the balloon only left four on the shore.

zh: 失踪的那个人一定是在海浪冲击气球网时被冲走了，也正是这个缘故，重量减轻的气球最后一次上升，不久就着陆了。这四个遇险的人一踏上坚实的土地就都想到失踪的这个人，他们异口同声地喊道：“他大概会游上岸的。我们去救他，我们去救他！”
en: The missing person had evidently been swept off by the sea, which had just struck the net, and it was owing to this circumstance that the lightened balloon rose the last time, and then soon after reached the land.Scarcely had the four castaways set foot on firm ground, than they all, thinking of the absent one, simultaneously exclaimed, “Perhaps he will try to swim to land!Let us save him! let us save him!”

zh: 第二章
en: Chapter 2

zh: 这些被飓风抛到海岸上的人既不是专业气球驾驶员也不是业余驾驶员。他们曾经是战俘，大胆的劲儿促使他们用这种奇异的方式逃跑。
en: Those whom the hurricane had just thrown on this coast were neither aeronauts by profession nor amateurs.They were prisoners of war whose boldness had induced them to escape in this extraordinary manner.

zh: 多少次他们都差点丧命！多少次他们都差点从破了的气球上摔下来，掉进深海中！但是因为奇怪的命数，上帝保全了他们的性命。他们3月20号从尤利西斯·格兰特率军包围的里士满城中逃了出来，现在离弗吉尼亚州的首府已经有7000英里了。在恐怖的南北战争中，弗吉尼亚是南军的大本营。他们已经在空中飞行了整整五天。
en: A hundred times they had almost perished!A hundred times had they almost fallen from their torn balloon into the depths of the ocean.But Heaven had reserved them for a strange destiny, and after having, on the 20th of March, escaped from Richmond, besieged by the troops of General Ulysses Grant, they found themselves seven thousand miles from the capital of Virginia, which was the principal stronghold of the South, during the terrible War of Secession.Their aerial voyage had lasted five days.

zh: 正是下面不可思议的情形让这些战俘成功逃跑：
en: The curious circumstances which led to the escape of the prisoners were as follows:

zh: 就在同一年，1865年的二月间，为夺取里士满，格兰特将军组织了多次突袭行动，结果有一次以失败告终，他手下的几个军官都沦为战俘，被扣押在里士满城中。这其中最杰出的人就是赛勒斯·哈丁上尉。他是马萨诸塞州人，一个一流的工程师，在战争期间，曾受政府委托，管理当时极为重要的铁路系统。一个地地道道的北方人，瘦骨嶙峋，大约四十五岁，一头短发和胡子——只留了一撮的浓密的八字须，都已经变得灰白了。他的脸长得很端正，似乎生来就为了铸在勋章上，眼神犀利，嘴角严肃，一看就是军校出身的智多星。他也是从舞锤弄斧开始干起的工程师，就像普通士兵出身的将军一样。他不但智力超群，而且心灵手巧。他的肌肉使他显得非常强壮。他既是一个思想家，也一个行动家，他精力充沛，性情乐观，什么事情都难不倒他。他博学多识，冷静务实，在任何紧要关头都能拥有确保成功的三个条件——灵活的大脑和身体、强烈的愿望和坚强的意志。他将17世纪威廉三世的话当作座右铭：“即使没有一丝成功的希望，我也要负责并坚持下去。”赛勒斯·哈丁就是“胆量”的代名词。他参加过那场战争的每一场战役。他的军旅生涯从伊利诺斯州做志愿者开始，作为尤利赛斯·格兰特的手下，他参加过帕迪尤卡、贝尔蒙特战役，匹兹堡登陆战，以及科林斯、吉布森港、布莱克里弗、查塔努加、莽原和波托马克河包围战。在这些战役中，他始终骁勇善战，没有辜负格兰特将军说过的“我决不计算我军的伤亡”这句话。哈丁上尉有上百次都差点成为可怕的格兰特将军不计算在内的将士中的一员，但是在他身先士卒的这些战役中，好运一直伴随着他，直到在里士满附近的战场上受伤被俘为止。与此同时，在同一天，另一个重要人物也落入南军的手中。这不是别人，正是《纽约先驱报》的记者吉迪恩·史佩莱，他奉命跟随北军进行战地报道。
en: That same year, in the month of February, 1865, in one of the coups de main by which General Grant attempted, though in vain, to possess himself of Richmond, several of his officers fell into the power of the enemy and were detained in the town.One of the most distinguished was Captain Cyrus Harding.He was a native of Massachusetts, a first-class engineer, to whom the government had confided, during the war, the direction of the railways, which were so important at that time.A true Northerner, thin, bony, lean, about forty-five years of age; his close-cut hair and his beard, of which he only kept a thick mustache, were already getting gray.He had one of those finely-developed heads which appear made to be struck on a medal, piercing eyes, a serious mouth, the physiognomy of a clever man of the military school.He was one of those engineers who began by handling the hammer and pickaxe, like generals who first act as common soldiers.Besides mental power, he also possessed great manual dexterity.His muscles exhibited remarkable proofs of tenacity.A man of action as well as a man of thought, all he did was without effort to one of his vigorous and sanguine temperament.Learned, clear-headed, and practical, he fulfilled in all emergencies those three conditions which united ought to insure human success—activity of mind and body, impetuous wishes, and powerful will.He might have taken for his motto that of William of Orange in the 17th century: “I can undertake and persevere even without hope of success.”Cyrus Harding was courage personified.He had been in all the battles of that war.After having begun as a volunteer at Illinois, under Ulysses Grant, he fought at Paducah, Belmont, Pittsburg Landing, at the siege of Corinth, Port Gibson, Black River, Chattanooga, the Wilderness, on the Potomac, everywhere and valiantly, a soldier worthy of the general who said, “I never count my dead!”And hundreds of times Captain Harding had almost been among those who were not counted by the terrible Grant; but in these combats where he never spared himself, fortune favored him till the moment when he was wounded and taken prisoner on the field of battle near Richmond.At the same time and on the same day another important personage fell into the hands of the Southerners.This was no other than Gideon Spilen, a reporter for the New York Herald, who had been ordered to follow the changes of the war in the midst of the Northern armies.

zh: 吉迪恩·史佩莱就像那些不屈不挠的英美编年史人员——比如斯坦利和其他人，不惜一切代价获取准确信息，并在最短时间里将信息传到报社。联邦的许多报纸，如《纽约先驱报》，都有真正的实力，它们的记者不可低估。吉迪恩·史佩莱是那些记者中首屈一指的，他具备很多优点：精力充沛，随机应变，满脑子都是主意；他曾环游世界，是一位战士也是一位艺术家；会议上激情洋溢，行动起来坚定不移，不怕麻烦、劳累和危险；在追踪战况时，首先满足自己的需要，再为报社考虑；他对各种新奇的话题都有涉猎，许多没有发表过、别人不知道也没法采访到的事情他都知道。他就是那些不畏艰险的战地观察员之一，在枪林弹雨中报道，危险就是他们想要的报道资料。
en: Gideon Spilett was one of that race of indomitable English or American chroniclers, like Stanley and others, who stop at nothing to obtain exact information, and transmit it to their journal in the shortest possible time.The newspapers of the Union, such as the New York Herald, are genuine powers, and their reporters are men to be reckoned with.Gideon Spilett ranked among the first of those reporters: a man of great merit, energetic, prompt and ready for anything, full of ideas, having traveled over the whole world, soldier and artist, enthusiastic in council, resolute in action, caring neither for trouble, fatigue, nor danger, when in pursuit of information, for himself first, and then for his journal, a perfect treasury of knowledge on all sorts of curious subjects, of the unpublished, of the unknown, and of the impossible.He was one of those intrepid observers who write under fire, “reporting” among bullets, and to whom every danger is welcome.

zh: 他参加过各次战役，在前线报道时，一手握着左轮手枪，一手拿着笔记本，葡萄弹也不会使他手中的笔颤抖。他不像有些记者没话找话说，没完没了的电报使线路陷入疲劳，他的每一篇报道都简短有力、中心明确，对关键点做了清晰的阐释。此外，他也不乏幽默感。就是他在布莱克里弗战役后，决心不计任何代价保证电报局窗口的位置，向报社报道完战役结果后，又用两小时拍发了“圣经”的前几章。虽然花了2000美元，但是《纽约先驱报》首先刊登了这个消息。
en: He also had been in all the battles, in the first rank, revolver in one hand, note-book in the other; grape-shot never made his pencil tremble.He did not fatigue the wires with incessant telegrams, like those who speak when they have nothing to say, but each of his notes, short, decisive, and clear, threw light on some important point.Besides, he was not wanting in humor.It was he who, after the affair of the Black River, determined at any cost to keep his place at the wicket of the telegraph office, and after having announced to his journal the result of the battle, telegraphed for two hours the first chapters of the Bible.It cost the New York Herald two thousand dollars, but the New York Herald published the first intelligence.

zh: 吉迪恩·史佩莱个子很高。他不止四十岁。淡红色的胡须围绕着他的脸庞。他的目光沉稳而充满生气，变化迅速。他的眼睛习惯于一眼就把握事件的所有细节。他体格健壮，能够适应各种气候，就像一根在冷水中淬硬了的钢棍。
en: Gideon Spilett was tall.He was rather more than forty years of age.Light whiskers bordering on red surrounded his face.His eye was steady, lively, rapid in its changes.It was the eye of a man accustomed to take in at a glance all the details of a scene.Well built, he was inured to all climates, like a bar of steel hardened in cold water.

zh: 他担任《纽约先驱报》的记者有十个年头了，他的文字和插图丰富了报刊的内容，他的绘画功底和写作功底一样出色。他被捕时正在写报道、绘战役素描。他笔记本的最后几个字是这样的：“一个南军正拿枪对着我，但是——”尽管如此，他素来有好运气，南军没有射中他，在这次事件中他毫发未伤。
en: For ten years Gideon Spilett had been the reporter of the New York Herald, which he enriched by his letters and drawings, for he was as skilful in the use of the pencil as of the pen.When he was captured, he was in the act of making a description and sketch of the battle.The last words in his note-book were these: “A Southern rifleman has just taken aim at me, but—” The Southerner notwithstanding missed Gideon Spilett, who, with his usual fortune, came out of this affair without a scratch.

zh: 在此之前，赛勒斯·哈丁和吉迪恩·史佩莱没有交情，只是耳闻对方大名，现在他们都被带到里士满。工程师的伤很快就痊愈了，他在康复期间结识了这位记者。随着交往的深入，两个人都互相赏识起来。很快他们就有了一个共同的目标，那就是逃出里士满，重新加入格兰特的军队，和联邦军队并肩战斗。
en: Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett, who did not know each other except by reputation, had both been carried to Richmond.The engineer’s wounds rapidly healed, and it was during his convalescence that he made acquaintance with the reporter.The two men then learned to appreciate each other.Soon their common aim had but one object, that of escaping, rejoining Grant’s army, and fighting together in the ranks of the Federals.

zh: 从一开始，他们两个就决心抓住每一个机会逃跑。尽管他们获准在城中自由走动，但里士满戒备森严，似乎没有逃跑的可能性。在此期间，哈丁上尉与昔日的仆人重逢，这个仆人对他忠心耿耿、生死不渝。这个无畏的家伙是一个黑人，就出生在工程师家里，父母也都是奴隶，但是赛勒斯是一个忠实的废奴主义者，早已经给他自由。这个昔日的的“奴隶”即使恢复自由身，依然不愿离开自己的主人。他情愿为主人而死。他大约三十岁，精力充沛，积极活跃，聪明伶俐，温顺稳重，时而又有天真的一面，总是很开心，是一个热心助人又实在的人。他叫纳布甲尼撒，但只习惯别人叫他的简称纳布。
en: The two Americans had from the first determined to seize every chance; but although they were allowed to wander at liberty in the town, Richmond was so strictly guarded, that escape appeared impossible.In the meanwhile Captain Harding was rejoined by a servant who was devoted to him in life and in death.This intrepid fellow was a Negro born on the engineer’s estate, of a slave father and mother, but to whom Cyrus, who was an Abolitionist from conviction and heart, had long since given his freedom.The once slave, though free, would not leave his master.He would have died for him.He was a man of about thirty, vigorous, active, clever, intelligent, gentle, and calm, sometimes naive, always merry, obliging, and honest.His name was Nebuchadnezzar, but he only answered to the familiar abbreviation of Neb.

zh: 当纳布听到主人被俘的消息后，毫不犹豫地离开马萨诸塞州前往里士满，他凭着计谋和精明，20多次冒着生命危险潜入被围的城中。哈丁见到仆人和纳布找到主人的喜悦之情是无法言表的。
en: When Neb heard that his master had been made prisoner, he left Massachusetts without hesitating an instant, arrived before Richmond, and by dint of stratagem and shrewdness, after having risked his life twenty times over, managed to penetrate into the besieged town.The pleasure of Harding on seeing his servant, and the joy of Neb at finding his master, can scarcely be described.

zh: 虽然纳布能够潜入里士满城，但是再次出城就是另外一回事了，因为北军的俘虏在这里被严密地看管起来。不管成功的几率怎样，他们都需要碰到特别的机会为此一搏。不过这种机会不但不会自己送上门来，还很难寻找到。
en: But though Neb had been able to make his way into Richmond, it was quite another thing to get out again, for the Northern prisoners were very strictly watched.Some extraordinary opportunity was needed to make the attempt with any chance of success, and this opportunity not only did not present itself, but was very difficult to find.

zh: 在此期间，格兰特继续率领军队骁勇作战。格兰特为彼得斯堡的胜利付出了沉重代价。在到达里士满之前，他的部队与巴特莱的部队联合进攻都不能取得胜利，没有什么事能给战俘带来早日释放的希望。
en: Meanwhile Grant continued his energetic operations.The victory of Petersburg had been very dearly bought.His forces, united to those of Butler, had as yet been unsuccessful before Richmond, and nothing gave the prisoners any hope of a speedy deliverance.

zh: 对于记者来说，这枯燥乏味的俘虏生活没有一点值得记录，他再也忍受不下去了。他向来活跃的大脑现在只想着一件事——不惜任何代价逃出里士满。他先前几次尝试出城，但被无法克服的障碍挡住了。围困还在继续着，不仅战俘们急于逃回格兰特的军队，被围困的人们肯定也急于与南军会合。乔纳森·福斯特就是其中的一员，他是一个坚定的南方人。事实上，在北军的重重包围下，如果南军的俘虏们无法逃出城，南军自身也是束手无策的。里士满总督与李将军失去联系已经有很长时间了，他非常希望将里士满的局势告知将军，以使援军尽快来救他们。于是乔纳森·福斯特萌生了升起气球的想法，这样就可以越过包围线到达南军营地。
en: The reporter, to whom his tedious captivity did not offer a single incident worthy of note, could stand it no longer.His usually active mind was occupied with one sole thought—how he might get out of Richmond at any cost.Several times had he even made the attempt, but was stopped by some insurmountable obstacle.However, the siege continued; and if the prisoners were anxious to escape and join Grant’s army, certain of the besieged were no less anxious to join the Southern forces.Among them was one Jonathan Forster, a determined Southerner.The truth was, that if the prisoners of the Secessionists could not leave the town, neither could the Secessionists themselves while the Northern army invested it.The Governor of Richmond for a long time had been unable to communicate with General Lee, and he very much wished to make known to him the situation of the town, so as to hasten the march of the army to their relief.Thus Jonathan Forster accordingly conceived the idea of rising in a balloon, so as to pass over the besieging lines, and in that way reach the Secessionist camp.

zh: 总督批准了他的计划。他们造了一只气球供福斯特使用，另外还派了五个人做陪同。为这些人配备了武器和食品，以备降落时自卫和航程延长时使用。
en: The Governor authorized the attempt.A balloon was manufactured and placed at the disposal of Forster, who was to be accompanied by five other persons.They were furnished with arms in case they might have to defend themselves when they alighted, and provisions in the event of their aerial voyage being prolonged.

zh: 气球定在3月18号起飞。起飞需要在夜间进行，还要有和缓的西北风。据飞行员估计，他们在几个小时之内就可以到达李将军的军营了。
en: The departure of the balloon was fixed for the 18th of March.It should be effected during the night, with a northwest wind of moderate force, and the aeronauts calculated that they would reach General Lee’s camp in a few hours.

zh: 但是西北风不仅仅是微风。从18日起它分明已经变成飓风了。风暴很快变得猛烈，福斯特动身的日期只好推迟，因为在这样的恶劣天气下，不能拿气球和乘客的生命冒险。
en: But this northwest wind was not a simple breeze.From the 18th it was evident that it was changing to a hurricane.The tempest soon became such that Forster’s departure was deferred, for it was impossible to risk the balloon and those whom it carried in the midst of the furious elements.

zh: 充满气的气球拴在城中的大广场上，只要风力一减弱就会起飞，被困在城中的人们当然非常焦灼地等着暴风变弱。
en: The balloon, inflated on the great square of Richmond, was ready to depart on the first abatement of the wind, and, as may be supposed, the impatience among the besieged to see the storm moderate was very great.

zh: 18、19号都过去了，天气还是没改变。将气球拴在地面都变得相当困难，因为咆哮的狂风冲撞撕扯着气球。
en: The 18th, the 19th of March passed without any alteration in the weather.There was even great difficulty in keeping the balloon fastened to the ground, as the squalls dashed it furiously about.

zh: 19号晚上过去了，但是第二天暴风更加猛烈了。气球起飞是不可能了。
en: The night of the 19th passed, but the next morning the storm blew with redoubled force.The departure of the balloon was impossible.

zh: 那天，工程师赛勒斯·哈丁在城中的街道上被一个素未谋面的人叫住了。这就是水手潘克洛夫，他大约在35到40岁之间，体格强壮，皮肤被晒得黝黑，两眼炯炯有神，帅气十足。潘克洛夫是美国人，来自北方，航遍了各大洋，凡是两条腿没翅膀的生物所能冒的险他都冒过，甚至包括那些我们不可能经历的冒险。不用说，他是大胆、勇猛的家伙，随时准备历险，对什么都不会大惊小怪。潘克洛夫年初时带着一个15岁男孩来里士满出差，男孩是新泽西州人，前船长的儿子，现在是个孤儿。潘克洛夫疼爱他就像是疼爱自己的亲生骨肉一样。在里士满第一次被围攻之前，他没能离开，等到发觉自己已经被困时，他相当懊丧，但从不向困难低头的他决心想法子逃出去。他早就听过这位工程师军官的大名，深知他坚韧外表下被抑制住的焦灼苦闷。因此，那天他没有拐弯抹角，毫不犹豫地向他打招呼，问道：“上尉阁下，你在里士满呆够了吗？”
en: On that day the engineer, Cyrus Harding, was accosted in one of the streets of Richmond by a person whom he did not in the least know.This was a sailor named Pencroft, a man of about thirty-five or forty years of age, strongly built, very sunburnt, and possessed of a pair of bright sparkling eyes and a remarkably good physiognomy.Pencroft was an American from the North, who had sailed all the ocean over, and who had gone through every possible and almost impossible adventure that a being with two feet and no wings would encounter.It is needless to say that he was a bold, dashing fellow, ready to dare anything and was astonished at nothing.Pencroft at the beginning of the year had gone to Richmond on business, with a young boy of fifteen from New Jersey, son of a former captain, an orphan, whom he loved as if he had been his own child.Not having been able to leave the town before the first operations of the siege, he found himself shut up, to his great disgust; but, not accustomed to succumb to difficulties, he resolved to escape by some means or other.He knew the engineer-officer by reputation; he knew with what impatience that determined man chafed under his restraint.On this day he did not, therefore, hesitate to accost him, saying, without circumlocution, “Have you had enough of Richmond, captain?”

zh: 工程师直愣愣地盯着眼前说话的这个人，对方又低声补充道：
en: The engineer looked fixedly at the man who spoke, and who added, in a low voice,—

zh: “哈丁上尉，你打算逃跑吗？”
en: “Captain Harding, will you try to escape?”

zh: “什么时候？”工程师很快问道，很显然工程师是不假思索地说出这句话，因为他至今还没审视这个说话人。他敏锐的目光细细打量着说话人的面孔后，确信面前的这个人是诚实的。
en: “When?” asked the engineer quickly, and it was evident that this question was uttered without consideration, for he had not yet examined the stranger who addressed him.But after having with a penetrating eye observed the open face of the sailor, he was convinced that he had before him an honest man.

zh: “你是谁？”他简短地问道。
en: “Who are you?” he asked briefly.

zh: 潘克洛夫作了自我介绍。
en: Pencroft made himself known.

zh: “好吧，”哈丁答道，“你打算怎么走？”
en: “Well,” replied Harding, “and in what way do you propose to escape?”

zh: “用那只热气球，它在那里闲着没用，我看它似乎是特意为我们预备的……”
en: “By that lazy balloon which is left there doing nothing, and which looks to me as if it was waiting on purpose for us—”

zh: 水手没有必要把话说完。工程师马上明白了他的意思。他抓住潘克洛夫的手，将他拉到自己的住处。在那里，水手详细地说了自己的计划，计划实在是再简单不过了。实行计划除了有生命危险外，也没有其他风险了。毫无疑问，飓风正奋力肆虐着，但是对像赛勒斯·哈丁这样聪明又胆识过人的人来说，操纵气球是易如反掌的事。假如潘克洛夫对飞行技术像对航海那样熟悉，他一定早就毫不犹豫地带着他的小朋友赫伯特出发了，他习惯了惊涛骇浪，不会因为飓风而停住。哈丁上尉一言不发地听着水手的计划，但眼中闪烁着满意的光芒。这正是他寻觅了很久的机会，他不会错失良机。计划是可行的，但必须承认的是，它也十分危险。尽管有看守，但他们可以趁夜晚靠近气球，潜入吊舱，然后割断系住吊舱的绳索。毋庸置疑的是他们可能被打死，但另一方面，他们也可能成功，如果没有这场风暴该多好啊！但如果没有这次飓风，气球早就起飞了，他们苦苦寻觅的机会也就不复存在了。
en: There was no necessity for the sailor to finish his sentence.The engineer understood him at once.He seized Pencroft by the arm, and dragged him to his house.There the sailor developed his project, which was indeed extremely simple.They risked nothing but their lives in its execution.The hurricane was in all its violence, it is true, but so clever and daring an engineer as Cyrus Harding knew perfectly well how to manage a balloon.Had he himself been as well acquainted with the art of sailing in the air as he was with the navigation of a ship, Pencroft would not have hesitated to set out, of course taking his young friend Herbert with him; for, accustomed to brave the fiercest tempests of the ocean, he was not to be hindered on account of the hurricane.Captain Harding had listened to the sailor without saying a word, but his eyes shone with satisfaction.Here was the long-sought-for opportunity—he was not a man to let it pass.The plan was feasible, though, it must be confessed, dangerous in the extreme.In the night, in spite of their guards, they might approach the balloon, slip into the car, and then cut the cords which held it.There was no doubt that they might be killed, but on the other hand they might succeed, and without this storm!—Without this storm the balloon would have started already and the looked-for opportunity would not have then presented itself.

zh: “我不是一个人！”哈丁最后说道。
en: “I am not alone!” said Harding at last.

zh: “你会带多少人？”水手问道。
en: “How many people do you wish to bring with you?” asked the sailor.

zh: “两个，我的朋友史佩莱，还有我的仆人纳布。”
en: “Two; my friend Spilett, and my servant Neb.”

zh: “那就是三个人了，”潘克洛夫说，“加上赫伯特和我一共是五个人。气球能载六个——”
en: “That will be three,” replied Pencroft; “and with Herbert and me five.But the balloon will hold six—”

zh: “那就行了，我们动身吧。”哈丁坚决地说。
en: “That will be enough, we will go,” answered Harding in a firm voice.

zh: 这个“我们”包括史佩莱，因为哈丁非常了解这位记者不是临阵退缩的人，当史佩莱听到这个计划之后，完全同意了。最让他惊奇的是，这么简单的想法自己以前竟然没有想到。至于纳布，不管他的主人去哪儿，他都会跟着。
en: This “we” included Spilett, for the reporter, as his friend well knew, was not a man to draw back, and when the project was communicated to him he approved of it unreservedly.What astonished him was, that so simple an idea had not occurred to him before.As to Neb, he followed his master wherever his master wished to go.

zh: “就今天晚上出发吧，”潘克洛夫说，“我们就在那里会面。”
en: “This evening, then,” said Pencroft, “we will all meet out there.”

zh: “今天晚上十点钟，”哈丁答道，“上天保佑，在我们出发之前风势不要减弱。”
en: “This evening, at ten o’clock,” replied Captain Harding; “and Heaven grant that the storm does not abate before our departure.”

zh: 潘克洛夫辞别了工程师和记者，回到了自己的寓所，年轻的赫伯特·布朗还呆在那里。这个勇敢的少年知道水手的计划，焦急地等待着工程师的答复。就这样，这五个意志坚定的人决定将命运交在暴风手中了！
en: Pencroft took leave of the two friends, and returned to his lodging, where young Herbert Brown had remained.The courageous boy knew of the sailor’s plan, and it was not without anxiety that he awaited the result of the proposal being made to the engineer.Thus five determined persons were about to abandon themselves to the mercy of the tempestuous elements!

zh: 没有！暴风雨没有减弱！乔纳森·福斯特和他的朋友们都没想到要在脆弱的吊舱中冒这么大的风险。
en: No! the storm did not abate, and neither Jonathan Forster nor his companions dreamed of confronting it in that frail car.

zh: 这将是一场可怕的旅行。工程师只担心一件事，那就是拴在地面上、受风蹂躏的气球会被撕扯成碎片。他在几乎无人的广场上逛了好几个小时，仔细检查着这只气球。潘克洛夫也做着同他朋友一样的事情，他把双手插在口袋里，不时打着哈欠，好像一个不知怎样消磨时间的人，但实际上，他心里和工程师一样恐惧，害怕风把气球刮跑或把气球撕裂。夜幕降临了。夜非常黑。像乌云一样的大雾弥漫着大地。雨夹着雪从天上落下，天气冷极了。浓雾笼罩着里士满，暴风雨似乎使攻守双方休战了，大炮的声响在怒吼的狂风中也一点也听不到了。城市的街道上不见一个人影。在这么恶劣的天气下，政府甚至都觉得没有必要对气球所在的广场设岗看守。一切都对这些囚徒的逃跑有利，但是，他们在狂风暴雨中谋划的危险旅程会有什么结果呢？
en: It would be a terrible journey.The engineer only feared one thing; it was that the balloon, held to the ground and dashed about by the wind, would be torn into shreds.For several hours he roamed round the nearly-deserted square, surveying the apparatus.Pencroft did the same on his side, his hands in his pockets, yawning now and then like a man who did not know how to kill the time, but really dreading, like his friend, either the escape or destruction of the balloon.Evening arrived.The night was dark in the extreme.Thick mists passed like clouds close to the ground.Rain fell mingled with snow. it was very cold.A mist hung over Richmond. it seemed as if the violent storm had produced a truce between the besiegers and the besieged, and that the cannon were silenced by the louder detonations of the storm.The streets of the town were deserted.It had not even appeared necessary in that horrible weather to place a guard in the square, in the midst of which plunged the balloon.Everything favored the departure of the prisoners, but what might possibly be the termination of the hazardous voyage they contemplated in the midst of the furious elements?—

zh: “烂天气！”潘克洛夫叫喊着，一拳压住了头上的帽子，“哼，我们照样会成功的！”
en: “Dirty weather!” exclaimed Pencroft, fixing his hat firmly on his head with a blow of his fist; “but pshaw, we shall succeed all the same!”

zh: 九点半时，哈丁和他的同伴从各个方向悄悄潜入广场，汽灯被大风吹灭了，广场上一片漆黑。连那只几乎被吹倒在地面上的大气球都看不见了。网索单独系在砂囊上，吊舱通过一根结实的缆线系在人行道的铁环上。五个人在吊舱旁会合了。没人发现他们，周围一片漆黑，他们甚至看不见彼此。
en: At half-past nine, Harding and his companions glided from different directions into the square, which the gas-lamps, extinguished by the wind, had left in total obscurity.Even the enormous balloon, almost beaten to the ground, could not be seen.Independently of the sacks of ballast, to which the cords of the net were fastened, the car was held by a strong cable passed through a ring in the pavement.The five prisoners met by the car.They had not been perceived, and such was the darkness that they could not even see each other.

zh: 哈丁、史佩莱、纳布和赫伯特一言不发地各自上了吊篮，潘克洛夫按照工程师的指示把绑在砂囊上的网索一一解开。不用几分钟功夫，水手就回到他的同伴身边了。
en: Without speaking a word, Harding, Spilett, Neb, and Herbert took their places in the car, while Pencroft by the engineer’s order detached successively the bags of ballast.It was the work of a few minutes only, and the sailor rejoined his companions.

zh: 现在系着气球的只剩下那根缆线了，只要工程师一声令下就可以起飞了。
en: The balloon was then only held by the cable, and the engineer had nothing to do but to give the word.

zh: 就在这时候，突然有一只狗一跃跳进吊篮里。原来是工程师的爱犬托普。这个忠诚的小家伙挣断了锁链，跟上了它的主人。哈丁担心狗的重量会妨碍气球上升，想打发它走。
en: At that moment a dog sprang with a bound into the car.It was Top, a favorite of the engineer.The faithful creature, having broken his chain, had followed his master.He, however, fearing that its additional weight might impede their ascent, wished to send away the animal.

zh: “多了它不会有什么两样，可怜的畜生！”潘克洛夫又将两袋沙子扔了下去，说话间他已经松开缆索，气球斜着升上天空，撞上了两个烟囱后，就消失在空中了。
en: “One more will make but little difference, poor beast!” exclaimed Pencroft, heaving out two bags of sand, and as he spoke letting go the cable; the balloon ascending in an oblique direction, disappeared, after having dashed the car against two chimneys, which it threw down as it swept by them.

zh: 之后，飓风的强大威力完全显现在这群航行者面前。那天夜里，工程师不敢想象如何降落，拂晓的时候，下面的大地被浓雾遮得一点也看不见。
en: Then, indeed, the full rage of the hurricane was exhibited to the voyagers.During the night the engineer could not dream of descending, and when day broke, even a glimpse of the earth below was intercepted by fog.

zh: 五天以后他们才从云隙中看到下面浩瀚的大海，现在狂风已在海上卷起惊涛骇浪。
en: Five days had passed when a partial clearing allowed them to see the wide extending ocean beneath their feet, now lashed into the maddest fury by the gale.

zh: 我们的读者都知道发生在这五个人身上的事，他们在3月20号乘气球开始这场冒险旅程。五天过后，他们中的四个人被抛在荒凉的海岸线上，离自己的国家有7000英里。但是他们中的一个不见了，这个人就是他们的领袖，他们的精神向导——工程师哈丁！他们一起身，就赶紧跑到海滩上，打算去帮助他。
en: Our readers will recollect what befell these five daring individuals who set out on their hazardous expedition in the balloon on the 20th of March.Five days afterwards four of them were thrown on a desert coast, seven thousand miles from their country!But one of their number was missing, the man who was to be their guide, their leading spirit, the engineer, Captain Harding!The instant they had recovered their feet, they all hurried to the beach in the hopes of rendering him assistance.

zh: 第三章
en: Chapter 3

zh: 工程师从网眼掉下去之后就被海浪冲走了。他的狗也不见了。这只忠诚的狗主动跳了出去救它的主人。“往前走啊！”记者喊道，紧接着这四个人——史佩莱、赫伯特、潘克洛夫和纳布忘记了疲劳，开始寻找。可怜的纳布流下痛苦的泪，一想到可能已经失去了世界上他唯一敬爱的人，就陷入绝望。
en: The engineer, the meshes of the net having given way, had been carried off by a wave.His dog also had disappeared.The faithful animal had voluntarily leaped out to help his master.“Forward,” cried the reporter; and all four, Spilett, Herbert, Pencroft, and Neb, forgetting their fatigue, began their search.Poor Neb shed bitter tears, giving way to despair at the thought of having lost the only being he loved on earth.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁失踪两分钟之后，他的伙伴们就着陆了。因此，他们希望能及时赶过去救他。纳布喊道：“我们去找他！我们去找他！”
en: Only two minutes had passed from the time when Cyrus Harding disappeared to the moment when his companions set foot on the ground.They had hopes therefore of arriving in time to save him.“Let us look for him! let us look for him!” cried Neb.

zh: “好的，纳布，”吉丁·史佩莱回答道，“我们也一定会找到他！”
en: “Yes, Neb,” replied Gideon Spilett, “and we will find him too!”

zh: “他一定还活着，我确信！”
en: “Living, I trust!”

zh: “一定还活着！”
en: “Still living!”

zh: “他会游泳吗？”潘克洛夫问道。
en: “Can he swim?” asked Pencroft.

zh: “会，”纳布回答道，“再说，托普也跟他在一起。”
en: “Yes,” replied Neb, “and besides, Top is there.”

zh: 水手注视着拍岸的惊涛骇浪，摇了摇头。
en: The sailor, observing the heavy surf on the shore, shook his head.

zh: 工程师是在海岸的北部失踪的，与这群落难者着陆的位置相隔将近半英里。因而这也就意味着，他距离能够上岸的最近的海滩足有半英里。
en: The engineer had disappeared to the north of the shore, and nearly half a mile from the place where the castaways had landed.The nearest point of the beach he could reach was thus fully that distance off.

zh: 这时候已经快六点钟了。浓雾使天色愈加昏暗。这群落难者朝这块陆地的北部走去，他们落到这块土地上纯属偶然，这是一个未知的区域，他们甚至无从猜测其地理位置。他们在混杂着石头、看上去寸草不生的沙地上行走着。地面高低不平，一些地方满是坑洞，行走起来极为痛苦。从这些坑洞中不停地飞出一些大鸟，笨拙地朝四面八方飞去。还有一些动作灵敏的鸟像云一样，成群地从他们的头上掠过。水手觉得自己认出了海鸥和鸬鹚，它们的尖叫声盖过了海浪咆哮的声音。
en: It was then nearly six o’clock.A thick fog made the night very dark.The castaways proceeded toward the north of the land on which chance had thrown them, an unknown region, the geographical situation of which they could not even guess.They were walking upon a sandy soil, mingled with stones, which appeared destitute of any sort of vegetation.The ground, very unequal and rough, was in some places perfectly riddled with holes, making walking extremely painful.From these holes escaped every minute great birds of clumsy flight, which flew in all directions.Others, more active, rose in flocks and passed in clouds over their heads.The sailor thought he recognized gulls and cormorants, whose shrill cries rose above the roaring of the sea.

zh: 这群落难者时不时地停下来呼喊，听海上有没有回应。因为他们认为，如果工程师已经上岸，而他们离那里不远，即便哈丁自己无法传递他还活着的信号，他们也能听到托普的吠声。他们停下来细听，但是没有声音盖过奔涌的海水和怒吼的海浪声。他们一群人又接着朝前走，找遍了海岸的每个角落。
en: From time to time the castaways stopped and shouted, then listened for some response from the ocean, for they thought that if the engineer had landed, and they had been near to the place, they would have heard the barking of the dog Top, even should Harding himself have been unable to give any sign of existence.They stopped to listen, but no sound arose above the roaring of the waves and the dashing of the surf.The little band then continued their march forward, searching into every hollow of the shore.

zh: 大约走了20分钟之后，这四个落难者看到脚边就是翻滚着泡沫的巨浪，突然停了下来。这里已是陆地的尽头。他们发现自己已经到了一个岬角的顶端，海浪正猛烈地冲击着这里。
en: After walking for twenty minutes, the four castaways were suddenly brought to a standstill by the sight of foaming billows close to their feet.The solid ground ended here.They found themselves at the extremity of a sharp point on which the sea broke furiously.

zh: “这是个海角，”水手说，“我们必须原路返回，靠右边走，这样我们应该能返回陆地了。”
en: “It is a promontory,” said the sailor; “we must retrace our steps, holding towards the right, and we shall thus gain the mainland.”

zh: “但是说不定他就在那里。”纳布指着黑暗中白浪翻滚的大海说道。“好吧，我们再喊几声试试。”于是他们又一同大喊了几声，但是依旧没有回应。他们稍停了一下，又接着喊了几声，但还是没有回应。
en: “But if he is there,” said Neb, pointing to the ocean, whose waves shone of a snowy white in the darkness.“Well, let us call again,” and all uniting their voices, they gave a vigorous shout, but there came no reply.They waited for a lull, then began again; still no reply.

zh: 这群落难者只好沿着海角的另一面路返回了，脚下的土地依然遍布沙子、崎岖不平。但是，潘克托夫观察到这边的海岸线比较平直，地面也越来越高，他说这里由一个长长的斜坡通向一座小山。透过浓雾，他认为能隐隐约约看到小山宽大正面的轮廓。海岸的这边，鸟儿没那么多了，海水也没那么喧嚣了，而且他们发现翻滚的巨浪也渐渐平息了。海浪的嘈杂声也几乎听不到了。显然，海角的这一面形成了一个半圆形的海湾，海浪冲击着海角的尖端，将他隐藏起来。但是沿着这个方向走下去就是南面了，正好与哈丁可能着陆的那部分海岸相对。行走了一英里半之后，他们发现海岸上没有返回北面的拐角。这个海角一定是和大陆相连的，他们曾经在这里转过方向。虽然这群落难者已经筋疲力尽了，但他们还是鼓起勇气往前走，每时每刻都希望能突然遇到一个拐角，将他们带回原来的方向。他们步履艰难地走了将近两英里后，到了一个满是滑溜溜岩石的高地上，而前面的大海再次挡住了去路，他们感到非常失望。
en: The castaways accordingly returned, following the opposite side of the promontory, over a soil equally sandy and rugged.However, Pencroft observed that the shore was more equal, that the ground rose, and he declared that it was joined by a long slope to a hill, whose massive front he thought that he could see looming indistinctly through the mist.The birds were less numerous on this part of the shore; the sea was also less tumultuous, and they observed that the agitation of the waves was diminished.The noise of the surf was scarcely heard.This side of the promontory evidently formed a semicircular bay, which the sharp point sheltered from the breakers of the open sea.But to follow this direction was to go south, exactly opposite to that part of the coast where Harding might have landed.After a walk of a mile and a half, the shore presented no curve which would permit them to return to the north.This promontory, of which they had turned the point, must be attached to the mainland.The castaways, although their strength was nearly exhausted, still marched courageously forward, hoping every moment to meet with a sudden angle which would set them in the first direction.What was their disappointment, when, after trudging nearly two miles, having reached an elevated point composed of slippery rocks, they found themselves again stopped by the sea.

zh: “我们是在一个小岛上，”潘克托夫说道，“而且我们已经从它的这一头勘察到另一头了。”
en: “We are on an islet,” said Pencroft, “and we have surveyed it from one extremity to the other.”

zh: 水手的话没错，他们坠落的地方不是一个大陆，也不是一个岛屿，而是一个长度不超过两英里的小岛，宽度就更不用说了。
en: The sailor was right; they had been thrown, not on a continent, not even on an island, but on an islet which was not more than two miles in length, with even a less breadth.

zh: 这片海鸟栖息的荒凉贫瘠之地，遍布石头，寸草不生，它是不是还和比较重要的群岛相连呢？这还很难说。他们在吊舱里的时候，曾透过浓雾看到了陆地，但是没能充分勘察清楚。但是潘克洛夫那双水手的眼睛能透过黑暗的夜色，他几乎可以断定西边那难以辨认的大团黑影就是隆起的海岸。但是在黑暗中，他们不能确定这到底是一个孤岛，还是和其他岛屿相连。由于周围都是大海，他们也没有办法离开这里，因而他们不得不等到第二天再接着寻找工程师。天啊！他们听不到一声呼喊，不知道工程师是否还活着。
en: Was this barren spot the desolate refuge of sea-birds, strewn with stones and destitute of vegetation, attached to a more important archipelago?It was impossible to say.When the voyagers from their car saw the land through the mist, they had not been able to reconnoiter it sufficiently.However, Pencroft, accustomed with his sailor eyes to piece through the gloom, was almost certain that he could clearly distinguish in the west confused masses which indicated an elevated coast.But they could not in the dark determine whether it was a single island, or connected with others.They could not leave it either, as the sea surrounded them; they must therefore put off till the next day their search for the engineer, from whom, alas! not a single cry had reached them to show that he was still in existence.

zh: “我们的朋友没有动静，但这并不能说明什么，”记者说，“也许他晕倒了，或是受伤了，不能马上回应我们，所以我们不要绝望。”
en: “The silence of our friend proves nothing,” said the reporter.“Perhaps he has fainted or is wounded, and unable to reply directly, so we will not despair.”

zh: 接着，记者提议在小岛上点燃一堆火，这样可以给工程师提供信号。他们试图寻找一些树枝或是干枯的荆棘，但是却一无所获，这里尽是些沙子和石头。纳布和伙伴们都非常担心勇敢的哈丁的安危，他们的悲伤之情用文字不足以表达，只能靠读者的想象了。显然他们无力帮助他了。他们拿出白天的忍耐力来等待。工程师要么已经自救了，在海岸的某个地方找到了安身之处，要么就永远消失了。时间一分一秒地过去，漫长而痛苦。寒气逼人。这群落难者的处境十分糟糕，但是他们几乎没有意识到这些。他们甚至没有想过休息一会儿。他们将一切置于脑后，一心只想着他们的首领，怀着希望，或者说尽量往好处想，继续在这块贫瘠的土地上来回走动，总是回到小岛的北边——离出事地点最近的地方。他们听着、叫着、一同呼喊着，尽力使喊叫声更加响亮，传到远方。风声渐渐平息，大海的喧嚣声也开始减弱了。甚至在纳布的一次呼喊后，似乎还传来了回声。赫伯特提醒潘克洛夫注意纳布的回声：“那说明西边有海岸，而且距离应该不远。”水手点了点头，况且，他的眼睛也不会欺骗他。如果他发现了陆地，无论看起来多么模糊，那肯定就是陆地。但是从远处传来的回声就是对纳布呼喊的唯一回应了，而小岛的整个东部都笼罩在黑暗之中。
en: The reporter then proposed to light a fire on a point of the islet, which would serve as a signal to the engineer.But they searched in vain for wood or dry brambles; nothing but sand and stones were to be found.The grief of Neb and his companions, who were all strongly attached to the intrepid Harding, can be better pictured than described.It was too evident that they were powerless to help him.They must wait with what patience they could for daylight.Either the engineer had been able to save himself, and had already found a refuge on some point of the coast, or he was lost for ever!The long and painful hours passed by.The cold was intense.The castaways suffered cruelly, but they scarcely perceived it.They did not even think of taking a minute’s rest.Forgetting everything but their chief, hoping or wishing to hope on, they continued to walk up and down on this sterile spot, always returning to its northern point, where they could approach nearest to the scene of the catastrophe.They listened, they called, and then uniting their voices, they endeavored to raise even a louder shout than before, which would be transmitted to a great distance.The wind had now fallen almost to a calm, and the noise of the sea began also to subside.One of Neb’s shouts even appeared to produce an echo.Herbert directed Pencroft’s attention to it, adding, “That proves that there is a coast to the west, at no great distance.”The sailor nodded; besides, his eyes could not deceive him.If he had discovered land, however indistinct it might appear, land was sure to be there.But that distant echo was the only response produced by Neb’s shouts, while a heavy gloom hung over all the part east of the island.

zh: 同时，天空也渐渐变得澄澈。将近午夜的时候，天空中的星星闪烁着光辉，如果工程师同他的伙伴们在一起，就会告诉他们那些星星不是北半球会有的。这里看不到北极星，星座也不是他们在美国经常见到的那些了，南十字星座在天空中闪耀着明亮的光辉。
en: Meanwhile, the sky was clearing little by little.Towards midnight the stars shone out, and if the engineer had been there with his companions he would have remarked that these stars did not belong to the Northern Hemisphere.The Polar Star was not visible, the constellations were not those which they had been accustomed to see in the United States; the Southern Cross glittered brightly in the sky.

zh: 黑夜过去了。3月25日早上将近五点的时候，天空渐渐亮了起来，但地平线处还是一片黑暗。然而，随着黎明的到来，海上升起了浓雾，他们很难看清楚约20英尺以外的地方。最后，浓雾渐渐在波浪翻滚的海上弥散开来。
en: The night passed away.Towards five o’clock in the morning of the 25th of March, the sky began to lighten; the horizon still remained dark, but with daybreak a thick mist rose from the sea, so that the eye could scarcely penetrate beyond twenty feet or so from where they stood.At length the fog gradually unrolled itself in great heavily moving waves.

zh: 但是不幸的是，这群落难者还是看不清楚周围的东西。当记者和纳布将注意力投向海面时，水手和赫伯特急切地向西面张望，希望在那里看到海岸。但是，依旧看不到一丁点陆地。“不要紧，”潘克洛夫说道，“虽然我看不到陆地，但是我感觉到……它在那里……那里……一定有陆地，就像我确信我们现在不在里士满一样。”雾气不久就停止上升了，这只是晴天的雾霭。不久，炙热的太阳就穿过小岛表面。大约六点半，也就是日出后三刻钟的时候，雾霭变得越来越稀薄。上层空气中的雾霭越来越厚，但是下面的雾气已经消散了。不久，小岛看起来就像从云中降下来的那样，周围的海面也显现了出来，向东面伸展开去，但是西面则被突起的、陡峭的海岸挡住了。
en: It was unfortunate, however, that the castaways could distinguish nothing around them.While the gaze of the reporter and Neb were cast upon the ocean, the sailor and Herbert looked eagerly for the coast in the west.But not a speck of land was visible.“Never mind,” said Pencroft, “though I do not see the land, I feel it...it is there...there...as sure as the fact that we are no longer at Richmond.”But the fog was not long in rising. it was only a fine-weather mist.A hot sun soon penetrated to the surface of the island.About half-past six, three-quarters of an hour after sunrise, the mist became more transparent.It grew thicker above, but cleared away below.Soon the isle appeared as if it had descended from a cloud, then the sea showed itself around them, spreading far away towards the east, but bounded on the west by an abrupt and precipitous coast.

zh: 是的！陆地在那里。他们的安全至少暂时得到了保证。小岛和海岸被宽约半英里的海峡隔开了，海峡中奔涌着湍急的水流。
en: Yes! the land was there.Their safety was at least provisionally insured.The islet and the coast were separated by a channel about half a mile in breadth, through which rushed an extremely rapid current.

zh: 但是，这群落难者中有一个人按捺不住心中的冲动，立即跳进了急流，甚至没有同他的伙伴们商量，也没有说一句话。那就是纳布。他急于到对面，向北爬过去。谁也没有办法使他回来。潘克洛夫也没能喊住他。记者准备跟着纳布过去，但是被潘克洛夫阻止了。“你想要穿过这个海峡吗？”他问道。“是的。”史佩莱回答道。“好吧！”水手说，“等一下，纳布一个人过去帮助他主人就足够了。如果我们冒险跳进海峡里，就有可能被水流冲进大海里去，水流现在正急，但是，如果我没猜错的话，现在是退潮。看，沙滩上的潮水退下去了。我们再忍耐一下，等到水位下降了，我们就可能找到一条趟过去的路了。”“你说得对，”记者回答道，“我们不能分开，这样才好互相照应。”
en: However, one of the castaways, following the impulse of his heart, immediately threw himself into the current, without consulting his companions, without saying a single word.It was Neb.He was in haste to be on the other side, and to climb towards the north.It had been impossible to hold him back.Pencroft called him in vain.The reporter prepared to follow him, but Pencroft stopped him.“Do you want to cross the channel?” he asked.“Yes,” replied Spilett.“All right!” said the seaman; “wait a bit; Neb is well able to carry help to his master.If we venture into the channel, we risk being carried into the open sea by the current, which is running very strong; but, if I’m not wrong, it is ebbing.See, the tide is going down over the sand.Let us have patience, and at low water it is possible we may find a fordable passage.”“You are right,” replied the reporter, “we will not separate more than we can help.”

zh: 与此同时，纳布正在与急流奋力抗争。他正斜着穿过海峡。他每划一次水，就能看到他黝黑的肩膀从水中显露出来。虽然水流快速地把他向下游冲去，但是他还是游向对岸。从小岛穿过海峡到对面的陆地用了半个多小时，他到达的海岸距对面的出发点有几百英尺远。
en: During this time Neb was struggling vigorously against the current.He was crossing in an oblique direction.His black shoulders could be seen emerging at each stroke.He was carried down very quickly, but he also made way towards the shore.It took more than half an hour to cross from the islet to the land, and he reached the shore several hundred feet from the place which was opposite to the point from which he had started.

zh: 他在一块高大的花岗岩石壁下上了岸，用力抖了抖身上的水，然后就奔跑起来，不久就消失在岩石一角的后面了，这个岩石角与小岛北端的高度几乎持平。
en: Landing at the foot of a high wall of granite, he shook himself vigorously; and then, setting off running, soon disappeared behind a rocky point, which projected to nearly the height of the northern extremity of the islet.

zh: 纳布的伙伴们十分担心，焦急地看着他这一大胆的举动。当他的身影消失之后，他们一边吃着沙滩上散布的贝类动物，一边将注意力集中到陆地上，那是他们的安全得到保证的希望。这些食物十分糟糕，但总比没有强。对面的海岸形成了一个巨大的海湾，南边被一个尖尖的海角阻断了，那里寸草不生，完全是一派荒凉的景象。这个海角与海岸毗邻，那里高大的花岗岩石形成了奇形怪状的轮廓。相反，越向北去，海湾就愈加宽阔，那边的海岸看起来更加曲折，从西南向东北延伸，形成了一个狭长的海岬。构成弓形海湾的两端相距约八英里。小岛距离海岸有半英里，有点像一条死去的巨型鲸鱼。最宽的地方也不过四分之一英里。
en: Neb’s companions had watched his daring attempt with painful anxiety, and when he was out of sight, they fixed their attention on the land where their hope of safety lay, while eating some shell-fish with which the sand was strewn.It was a wretched repast, but still it was better than nothing.The opposite coast formed one vast bay, terminating on the south by a very sharp point, which was destitute of all vegetation, and was of a very wild aspect.This point abutted on the shore in a grotesque outline of high granite rocks.Towards the north, on the contrary, the bay widened, and a more rounded coast appeared, trending from the southwest to the northeast, and terminating in a slender cape.The distance between these two extremities, which made the bow of the bay, was about eight miles.Half a mile from the shore rose the islet, which somewhat resembled the carcass of a gigantic whale.Its extreme breadth was not more than a quarter of a mile.

zh: 小岛对面的海滩底层是沙子，海水渐渐退去，沙子上的黑石正一点一点地显露出来。沙子上层被垂直的花岗岩峭壁隔开，顶部高低不齐，至少有300英尺高。峭壁绵延了三英里，右边被突兀的悬崖阻断，悬崖看起来就像是人工凿开的一样。而左边，海角顶端的位置，奇形怪状、参差不齐的峭壁垂到地面，形成了一个长长的砾岩石坡，与南端的地面相接。海岸的高地上，一棵树也没有。高地十分平坦，像是好望角上的开普敦，只不过小一些而已，至少从小岛上看起来是这样。但是，悬崖的右边却是一片翠绿。他们可以轻易辨别出那是一片杂乱的树林，树木高耸，一望无际。他们的眼睛因看久了绵延的花岗石而疲劳不已，这片翠绿的树林使眼睛得到了放松。最后，在高地的远处，西北方向七英里开外，一座山峰在阳光下闪耀着。那是一座高山，山顶白雪皑皑。
en: Opposite the islet, the beach consisted first of sand, covered with black stones, which were now appearing little by little above the retreating tide.The second level was separated by a perpendicular granite cliff, terminated at the top by an unequal edge at a height of at least 300 feet.It continued thus for a length of three miles, ending suddenly on the right with a precipice which looked as if cut by the hand of man.On the left, above the promontory, this irregular and jagged cliff descended by a long slope of conglomerated rocks till it mingled with the ground of the southern point.On the upper plateau of the coast not a tree appeared.It was a flat tableland like that above Cape Town at the Cape of Good Hope, but of reduced proportions; at least so it appeared seen from the islet.However, verdure was not wanting to the right beyond the precipice.They could easily distinguish a confused mass of great trees, which extended beyond the limits of their view.This verdure relieved the eye, so long wearied by the continued ranges of granite.Lastly, beyond and above the plateau, in a northwesterly direction and at a distance of at least seven miles, glittered a white summit which reflected the sun’s rays.It was that of a lofty mountain, capped with snow.

zh: 这块土地是一座孤岛，还是同大陆相连，目前还无法确定。但是如果地质学家看到左边震落的石堆，那么他们会毫不犹豫地指出那是由于火山爆发形成的，因为这些石块无疑是大地内部震动的产物。
en: The question could not at present be decided whether this land formed an island, or whether it belonged to a continent.But on beholding the convulsed masses heaped up on the left, no geologist would have hesitated to give them a volcanic origin, for they were unquestionably the work of subterranean convulsions.

zh: 吉丁·史佩莱、潘克洛夫和赫伯特仔细查看了这块土地，他们可能要在这里生活许多年。假如这里远离船只的惯常航道，他们可能真的会死在这座岛上，事情很可能是这样。
en: Gideon Spilett, Pencroft, and Herbert attentively examined this land, on which they might perhaps have to live many long years; on which indeed they might even die, should it be out of the usual track of vessels, as was likely to be the case.

zh: “嗨，”赫伯特问道，“潘克洛夫，你怎么想？”
en: “Well,” asked Herbert, “what do you say, Pencroft?”

zh: “跟其他事情一样，有好的一面，也有不好的一面。”水手回答道。“我们先看看再说。但现在明显是在退潮。三个小时之内，我们就能尝试这条通道，一到那边，我们就能试着摆脱困境了，希望能找到上尉。”潘克洛夫预料得没错。三个小时后，水位下降，海峡底部的大部分沙子都显露出来了。小岛与海岸之间只有一道窄窄的海峡，毫无疑问，他们可以轻松地过去。
en: “There is some good and some bad, as in everything,” replied the sailor.“We shall see.But now the ebb is evidently making.In three hours we will attempt the passage, and once on the other side, we will try to get out of this scrape, and I hope may find the captain.”Pencroft was not wrong in his anticipations.Three hours later at low tide, the greater part of the sand forming the bed of the channel was uncovered.Between the islet and the coast there only remained a narrow channel which would no doubt be easy to cross.

zh: 大约十点钟的时候，吉丁·史佩莱和伙伴们把衣服脱掉，捆好顶在头上，然后就冒险跳进不足五英尺深的水中。对于赫伯特来说，水太深了，但他像条鱼一样，灵活地游过去了。他们三个都顺利到达了对岸。他们在涉水的时候避免衣服碰到水，很快，就在阳光下晒干了身子，穿上了衣服，然后坐下来一同商议下一步要怎么办。
en: About ten o’clock, Gideon Spilett and his companions stripped themselves of their clothes, which they placed in bundles on their heads, and then ventured into the water, which was not more than five feet deep.Herbert, for whom it was too deep, swam like a fish, and got through capitally.All three arrived without difficulty on the opposite shore.Quickly drying themselves in the sun, they put on their clothes, which they had preserved from contact with the water, and sat down to take counsel together what to do next.

zh: 第四章
en: Chapter 4

zh: 突然，记者跳起身来，对水手说他会回来与他们在原地会合，然后便顺着黑人纳布几个小时前爬过的方向攀过悬崖。由于十分想知道朋友的下落，焦急之情加快了他的脚步，很快，他就绕过悬崖的拐角消失不见了。赫伯特想和他一起去。
en: All at once the reporter sprang up, and telling the sailor that he would rejoin them at that same place, he climbed the cliff in the direction which the Negro Neb had taken a few hours before.Anxiety hastened his steps, for he longed to obtain news of his friend, and he soon disappeared round an angle of the cliff.Herbert wished to accompany him.

zh: “孩子，你别去，”水手说，“我们要准备露营，还要找点比贝类更好吃的东西。他们回来时肯定想吃点东西。每个人都有自己的事要做。”
en: “Stop here, my boy,” said the sailor; “we have to prepare an encampment, and to try and find rather better grub than these shell-fish.Our friends will want something when they come back.There is work for everybody.”

zh: “听你的吩咐。”赫伯特回答说。
en: “I am ready,” replied Herbert.

zh: “很好，”水手说，“这样才对嘛！现在我们要开始有秩序地干活了。我们又冷又累又饿，所以我们要找到住的地方、柴火和食物。森林里有木柴，鸟巢里有蛋，我们唯一要做的就是找住的地方。”
en: “All right,” said the sailor; “that will do.We must set about it regularly.We are tired, cold, and hungry; therefore we must have shelter, fire, and food.There is wood in the forest, and eggs in nests; we have only to find a house.”

zh: “那行，”赫伯特回答说，“我将在岩石缝中找洞，我肯定能找到让我们容身的洞。”
en: “Very well,” returned Herbert, “I will look for a cave among the rocks, and I shall be sure to discover some hole into which we can creep.”

zh: “那好，”潘克洛夫说，“去吧，孩子。”
en: “All right,” said Pencroft; “go on, my boy.”

zh: 他们走到海滩边的巨型岩石下，潮水已经退到很远的地方了，不过他们没有往北走，而是往南走。潘克洛夫注意到离着陆点几百英尺远的地方有一个狭窄的通道，也许那就是河流或溪水流出的地方。现在对他们来说，重要的是在河岸边安顿下来。另外，赛勒斯·哈丁有可能被激流冲到了岸边。
en: They both walked to the foot of the enormous wall over the beach, far from which the tide had now retreated; but instead of going towards the north, they went southward.Pencroft had remarked, several hundred feet from the place at which they landed, a narrow cutting, out of which he thought a river or stream might issue.Now, on the one hand it was important to settle themselves in the neighborhood of a good stream of water, and on the other it was possible that the current had thrown Cyrus Harding on the shore there.

zh: 之前已经说过，悬崖高达300英尺，不过整个悬崖都很完整，即便是最底部也很少受到海水的冲刷，所以连作为容身之所的小小缝隙都没有。这是座坚硬的花岗岩墙，就连海浪都不曾磨损它。一群群海鸟围着山顶飞来飞去，尤其是那些蹼足鸟类，它们的嘴又扁又长，并且向外突出，还叫个不停。也许这是人类第一次侵犯它们的领地，看到人它们一点也不害怕。潘克洛夫认出了贼鸥，其中还有许多贪吃的小海鸥，它们都躲在花岗岩的裂缝里。只要开一枪，就能打死很多海鸥，不过前提是要有一把枪，可是潘克洛夫和赫伯特都没有。况且，小海鸥和其他海鸥几乎不能吃，海鸥蛋的味道也不怎样。但是，赫伯特向左挪了几步，突然之间他碰到了长满海草的岩石，几个小时后它们就会被潮水掩盖。在石头上，滑溜溜的海草里藏满了贝类，饿着肚子的人是不会放过它们的。赫伯特喊了潘克洛夫，他就马上过来了。
en: The cliff, as has been said, rose to a height of three hundred feet, but the mass was unbroken throughout, and even at its base, scarcely washed by the sea, it did not offer the smallest fissure which would serve as a dwelling.It was a perpendicular wall of very hard granite, which even the waves had not worn away.Towards the summit fluttered myriads of sea-fowl, and especially those of the web-footed species with long, flat, pointed beaks—a clamorous tribe, bold in the presence of man, who probably for the first time thus invaded their domains.Pencroft recognized the skua and other gulls among them, the voracious little sea-mew, which in great numbers nestled in the crevices of the granite.A shot fired among this swarm would have killed a great number, but to fire a shot a gun was needed, and neither Pencroft nor Herbert had one; besides this, gulls and sea-mews are scarcely eatable, and even their eggs have a detestable taste.However, Herbert, who had gone forward a little more to the left, soon came upon rocks covered with sea-weed, which, some hours later, would be hidden by the high tide.On these rocks, in the midst of slippery wrack, abounded bivalve shell-fish, not to be despised by starving people.Herbert called Pencroft, who ran up hastily.

zh: “这都是贻贝！”水手喊道，“没有鸟蛋，这些也可以充饥呀！”
en: “Here are mussels!” cried the sailor; “these will do instead of eggs!”

zh: “这不是贻贝，”赫伯特答道，他一边仔细检查岩石上的软体动物一边说，“是茨蟹。”
en: “They are not mussels,” replied Herbert, who was attentively examining the molluscs attached to the rocks; “they are lithodomes.”

zh: “好吃吗？”潘克洛夫问道。
en: “Are they good to eat?” asked Pencroft.

zh: “非常好吃。”
en: “Perfectly so.”

zh: “那我们就吃点茨蟹。”
en: “Then let us eat some lithodomes.”

zh: 水手完全可以相信赫伯特的话，这位少年不仅对博物学特别了解，还很热爱这门科学。他爸爸曾经鼓励他在这方面多多学习，还让他旁听波士顿知名教授的讲座，这些人都非常喜欢这个聪明勤奋的小伙子。渐渐地，他对博物学的了解不止一次给了他很大的帮助，这回也不例外。这些茨蟹有椭圆形的贝壳，它们成群地粘在岩石上，十分牢固。它们属于穿孔类软体动物，即便是最坚硬的石头，它们也能在里面打洞。这些软体动物的壳两端浑圆，这在普通的贻贝中是不多见的。
en: The sailor could rely upon Herbert; the young boy was well up in natural history, and always had had quite a passion for the science.His father had encouraged him in it, by letting him attend the lectures of the best professors in Boston, who were very fond of the intelligent, industrious lad.And his turn for natural history was, more than once in the course of time, of great use, and he was not mistaken in this instance.These lithodomes were oblong shells, suspended in clusters and adhering very tightly to the rocks.They belong to that species of molluscous perforators which excavate holes in the hardest stone; their shell is rounded at both ends, a feature which is not remarked in the common mussel.

zh: 这些茨蟹在阳光中半开着壳，成了潘克洛夫和赫伯特的一顿美餐。不过，他们是拿这些茨蟹当牡蛎来吃的，这种蟹本身就带有很重的辣味，所以不用任何调料，吃起来就很可口。
en: Pencroft and Herbert made a good meal of the lithodomes, which were then half opened to the sun.They ate them as oysters, and as they had a strong peppery taste, they were palatable without condiments of any sort.

zh: 这样一来，他们的饥饿感也不那么强烈了，但是口渴的程度却有增无减，特别是在吃过这些“天然香辣”的软体动物之后。他们必须要找点干净的水喝，在这样一个气候多变、地形崎岖的地方，找不到水的可能性并不大。潘克洛夫和赫伯特打算备足吃的，他们在口袋和手帕里装满了茨蟹，接着就启程返回了悬崖下面。
en: Their hunger was thus appeased for the time, but not their thirst, which increased after eating these naturally-spiced molluscs.They had then to find fresh water, and it was not likely that it would be wanting in such a capriciously uneven region.Pencroft and Herbert, after having taken the precaution of collecting an ample supply of lithodomes, with which they filled their pockets and handkerchiefs, regained the foot of the cliff.

zh: 走了两百多步后，他们来到了裂缝旁，果然如潘克洛夫猜想的那样，裂缝里流出了一条小溪，只不过溪水是不是淡水还不清楚。在这里，岩石墙似乎被某种猛烈的地下作用力给分隔开来了。岩石底部由于一条小溪凹陷进去，溪水的尽头形成了很急的弯道。这条水路在那一段只有一百英尺宽，两岸的高度也不到20英尺。溪水在两座花岗岩墙之间变得非常凶猛，近乎笔直地流淌，而一到河口水流就平缓下来了，接着溪水突然拐了一个弯，消失在大约半英里外的矮树林中。
en: Two hundred paces farther they arrived at the cutting, through which, as Pencroft had guessed, ran a stream of water, whether fresh or not was to be ascertained.At this place the wall appeared to have been separated by some violent subterranean force.At its base was hollowed out a little creek, the farthest part of which formed a tolerably sharp angle.The watercourse at that part measured one hundred feet in breadth, and its two banks on each side were scarcely twenty feet high.The river became strong almost directly between the two walls of granite, which began to sink above the mouth; it then suddenly turned and disappeared beneath a wood of stunted trees half a mile off.

zh: “这里有水，那边有我们要的木柴！”潘克洛夫喊道，“太好了，赫伯特，现在我们只需要找个住的地方了。”
en: “Here is the water, and yonder is the wood we require!” said Pencroft.“Well, Herbert, now we only want the house.”

zh: 溪水清澈见底。水手确定此时此刻是低潮，也就是涨潮没有来临的时候，溪水还是可以饮用的。确信这重要的一点之后，赫伯特就开始寻找作为容身之所的洞穴，但是徒劳无功，因为整座岩石墙都很光滑、平坦，而且是垂直于地面的。
en: The water of the river was limpid.The sailor ascertained that at this time—that is to say, at low tide, when the rising floods did not reach it—it was sweet.This important point established, Herbert looked for some cavity which would serve them as a retreat, but in vain; everywhere the wall appeared smooth, plain, and perpendicular.

zh: 不过，在河口涨潮也不会淹到的地方，自然的震动形成的不是一个洞穴，而是一堆巨型石头，这在花岗岩丰富的国家十分常见，人们把它们叫做“石窟”。
en: However, at the mouth of the watercourse and above the reach of the high tide, the convulsions of nature had formed, not a grotto, but a pile of enormous rocks, such as are often met with in granite countries and which bear the name of “Chimneys.”

zh: 潘克洛夫和赫伯特进入了岩石深处，沿着沙子小路走着，这里有光线，它从岩石留有的孔里射进来，有的岩石奇迹般地保持着平衡。伴随阳光进来的还有一股风——经常吹的穿堂风，带来了外面的寒气。不过，水手想要是把石头和沙子混在一起填上一些空当，这些“石窟”就能住人了。他们的几何计划将这里改造成类似于“＆”（也就是拉丁文“和”的缩写）这个符号的结构，只不过要分开符号上面贯通强劲的西风和南风的口，这样他们就能利用下面的部分了。
en: Pencroft and Herbert penetrated quite far in among the rocks, by sandy passages in which light was not wanting, for it entered through the openings which were left between the blocks, of which some were only sustained by a miracle of equilibrium; but with the light came also air—a regular corridor-gale—and with the wind the sharp cold from the exterior.However, the sailor thought that by stopping-up some of the openings with a mixture of stones and sand, the Chimneys could be rendered habitable.Their geometrical plan represented the typographical sign “&,” which signifies “et cetera” abridged, but by isolating the upper mouth of the sign, through which the south and west winds blew so strongly, they could succeed in making the lower part of use.

zh: “这就是我们的工作，”潘克洛夫说，“如果我们能再看到哈丁上尉，他会知道怎么改造这座迷宫。”
en: “Here’s our work,” said Pencroft, “and if we ever see Captain Harding again, he will know how to make something of this labyrinth.”

zh: “我们肯定会再见到他的，潘克洛夫先生，”赫伯特喊道，“他回来的时候一定会看到一个舒服的窝。我们在左边的通道弄个壁炉，然后留个出烟的通风口，这样就可以了。”
en: “We shall see him again, Pencroft,” cried Herbert, “and when be returns he must find a tolerable dwelling here.It will be so, if we can make a fireplace in the left passage and keep an opening for the smoke.”

zh: “孩子，我们可以做到，”水手说，“这些石窟也够我们用的了。我们开始干活吧，不过得先找点木柴。我想树枝可以很好地挡住这些口，寒风从这些口吹过的尖声跟无数鬼一样。”
en: “So we can, my boy,” replied the sailor, “and these Chimneys will serve our turn.Let us set to work, but first come and get a store of fuel.I think some branches will be very useful in stopping up these openings, through which the wind shrieks like so many fiends.”

zh: 赫伯特和潘克洛夫离开了石窟，越过了拐角，然后开始爬上左边的河岸。这里的水流十分湍急，枯木漂在水面上。高涨的潮水已经可以明显地看到了，这块木头很可能会被潮水用力地冲到很远的地方。然后，水手想到他们可以利用这次退潮运送重物。
en: Herbert and Pencroft left the Chimneys, and, turning the angle, they began to climb the left bank of the river.The current here was quite rapid, and drifted down some dead wood.The rising tide—and it could already be perceived—must drive it back with force to a considerable distance.The sailor then thought that they could utilize this ebb and flow for the transport of heavy objects.

zh: 走了一刻钟后，水手和男孩来到了河水向左拐的弯道口。河水从这里继续向前流淌，沿途是一片参天大树。虽然已近深秋，这些树仍然郁郁葱葱，因为它们属于“松柏科”，遍布全球各地，北部气候区到热带都有这种树。这位年轻的博物学家认出了其中的“喜马拉雅杉”，这些杉树在喜马拉雅山地带十分常见，它们周围散发出十分宜人的香气。这些好看的树木中间还伸出一丛丛冷杉树，它们不透明的大树枝像伞一样朝四周延展开来。经过长长的草地时，潘克洛夫感觉到脚下踩碎了的干树枝发出像鞭炮一样的噼啪声。
en: After having walked for a quarter of an hour, the sailor and the boy arrived at the angle which the river made in turning towards the left.From this point its course was pursued through a forest of magnificent trees.These trees still retained their verdure, notwithstanding the advanced season, for they belonged to the family of “coniferae,” which is spread over all the regions of the globe, from northern climates to the tropics.The young naturalist recognized especially the “deedara,” which are very numerous in the Himalayan zone, and which spread around them a most agreeable odor.Between these beautiful trees sprang up clusters of firs, whose opaque open parasol boughs spread wide around.Among the long grass, Pencroft felt that his feet were crushing dry branches which crackled like fireworks.

zh: “孩子，”潘克洛夫对赫伯特说，“如果我不知道这些树的名字，我认为至少可以把它们叫做‘燃木’，眼下我们最需要的就是它了。”
en: “Well, my boy,” said he to Herbert, “if I don’t know the name of these trees, at any rate I reckon that we may call them ‘burning wood,’ and just now that’s the chief thing we want.”

zh: “那我们备一些吧！”赫伯特答道，说完立马开始动手。
en: “Let us get a supply,” replied Herbert, who immediately set to work.

zh: 他们很容易就集到了足够的木柴。他们都没必要到树上去折，因为脚边就有大量的枯木。不过即便木柴有了，如何运送它们还是一个问题。这些木柴很干，很快就能烧起来，所以有必要把大量的木柴运到石窟，可是两个人的负荷量是不够的。赫伯特注意到了这个问题。
en: The collection was easily made.It was not even necessary to lop the trees, for enormous quantities of dead wood were lying at their feet; but if fuel was not wanting, the means of transporting it was not yet found.The wood, being very dry, would burn rapidly; it was therefore necessary to carry to the Chimneys a considerable quantity, and the loads of two men would not be sufficient.Herbert remarked this.

zh: “孩子，”水手说，“一定有办法运这些木柴，做任何事总有解决方法的。要是我们有辆手推车或一艘船就好办多了。”
en: “Well, my boy,” replied the sailor, “there must be some way of carrying this wood; there is always a way of doing everything.If we had a cart or a boat, it would be easy enough.”

zh: “可我们有这条河啊。”赫伯特说。
en: “But we have the river,” said Herbert.

zh: “你说得对，”潘克洛夫回答说，“这条河对我们来说就像运输线，它可以帮我们运木柴，木筏造出来不是一无是处的。”
en: “Right,” replied Pencroft; “the river will be to us like a road which carries of itself, and rafts have not been invented for nothing.”

zh: “只不过，”赫伯特说，“现在这条路的方向可不对，正涨潮呢！”
en: “Only,” observed Herbert, “at this moment our road is going the wrong way, for the tide is rising!”

zh: “我们等到退潮就好了，”水手回答说，“到时候我们就可以利用它把燃料带到石窟那儿了。我们先把木筏准备好吧。”
en: “We shall be all right if we wait till it ebbs,” replied the sailor, “and then we will trust it to carry our fuel to the Chimneys.Let us get the raft ready.”

zh: 水手朝河的方向走过去，后边跟着赫伯特。他们都各尽所能将成捆的木柴运过去。他们还在岸边的草丛里发现了许多枯树枝，兴许这里从来都没有人类踏足过。潘克洛夫马上开始做木筏。河岸的一角阻断水流形成了一个小湾，水手和少年在这里放好了一些大小合适的木头，然后用蔓藤把它们捆在了一起。木筏很快就做好了，上面堆满了他们收集到的所有木柴，这些木柴至少要20个人才能搬完。一个小时后他们就干完了所有的活，然后把木筏停在岸边，等着退潮。
en: The sailor, followed by Herbert, directed his steps towards the river.They both carried, each in proportion to his strength, a load of wood bound in fagots.They found on the bank also a great quantity of dead branches in the midst of grass, among which the foot of man had probably never before trod.Pencroft began directly to make his raft.In a kind of little bay, created by a point of the shore which broke the current, the sailor and the lad placed some good-sized pieces of wood, which they had fastened together with dry creepers.A raft was thus formed, on which they stacked all they had collected, sufficient, indeed, to have loaded at least twenty men.In an hour the work was finished, and the raft moored to the bank, awaited the turning of the tide.

zh: 离退潮还有几个小时，潘克洛夫和赫伯特达成一致决定上高处呆着，这样就能将周围地势收入眼底。
en: There were still several hours to be occupied, and with one consent Pencroft and Herbert resolved to gain the upper plateau, so as to have a more extended view of the surrounding country.

zh: 离河流拐角两百英尺远的地方是岩石墙，被下落的岩石挡住，渐渐成了缓坡，延伸至树林的边缘。这是一座天然的阶梯。赫伯特和水手开始往上爬，他们肌肉的力量很强大，没用几分钟就爬到了山顶，继而到达了河口的上方。
en: Exactly two hundred feet behind the angle formed by the river, the wall, terminated by a fall of rocks, died away in a gentle slope to the edge of the forest.It was a natural staircase.Herbert and the sailor began their ascent; thanks to the vigor of their muscles they reached the summit in a few minutes; and proceeded to the point above the mouth of the river.

zh: 一到山顶他们就将目光投在海上，他们不久前还十分艰难地横渡那片海。他们激动地发现，整个北部海岸就是灾难发生的地方。就是在那里，赛勒斯·哈丁失踪了。他们想看看是不是能找到气球的残留部分，也许会有一个人还抓着它。但什么都没有！大海就是一望无际的荒凉水域。海岸上也没有一个人影。到处都看不到记者，也看不到纳布。但也有可能他们此时离得太远，一时看不见而已。
en: On attaining it, their first look was cast upon the ocean which not long before they had traversed in such a terrible condition.They observed, with emotion, all that part to the north of the coast on which the catastrophe had taken place.It was there that Cyrus Harding had disappeared.They looked to see if some portion of their balloon, to which a man might possibly cling, yet existed.Nothing!The sea was but one vast watery desert.As to the coast, it was solitary also.Neither the reporter nor Neb could be anywhere seen.But it was possible that at this time they were both too far away to be perceived.

zh: “我有种感觉，”赫伯特喊道，“像哈丁上尉这样健壮的人，是不会像其他人那样让自己溺水身亡的。他肯定是到了岸上的某个地方，你不这样认为吗，潘克洛夫先生？”
en: “Something tells me,” cried Herbert, “that a man as energetic as Captain Harding would not let himself be drowned like other people.He must have reached some point of the shore; don’t you think so, Pencroft?”

zh: 水手悲伤地摇了摇头。他几乎不抱希望再次见到赛勒斯·哈丁，但还是想给赫伯特留一线希望，“肯定的，肯定的，”他说，“即便世上所有人都屈服了，我们这位工程师也会走出困境的。”
en: The sailor shook his head sadly.He little expected ever to see Cyrus Harding again; but wishing to leave some hope to Herbert: “Doubtless, doubtless,” said he; “our engineer is a man who would get out of a scrape to which any one else would yield.”

zh: 他一边说一边仔细地观察整片海岸。他们脚下延伸的是一片沙滩，一直到河口的右边就被一排排浪花挡住了。冒出来的岩石看上去就像在海浪里休息的两栖怪物。礁石那边，大海在阳光下闪闪发亮。南边突起的一块地方阻断了地平线前方的视线，大陆是不是朝那个方向延伸还看不太清楚，而如果它朝东南或西南方向延伸，那整个海岸就会变成一座长长的半岛了。在海湾最北端，海岸的轮廓延伸至远处，形成更宽的弧线。那部分海岸又低又平，旁边没有悬崖，只有潮水波及不到的巨大沙滩。潘克洛夫和赫伯特又向西行进。这时，他们的注意力第一次被六、七英里外顶部白雪皑皑的高山吸引住了。从山坡开始下斜到离海岸两英里以内的地方都是成片的树林，常青树形成的大片绿色给树林增加了别样的魅力。树林的边缘与海岸之间有块平原，一片片树丛稀稀疏疏、不规则地分布着。左边的林间空地有小河的水流流过，在阳光下闪闪发光。他们能沿着山的支脉追溯它弯曲的路线，似乎在那中间就是河流的发源地。水手放木筏的地方就是两座花岗岩石墙矗立的地方，不过如果说左岸的岩石还算清晰、陡峭的话，那右岸的岩石墙就完全相反，它缓慢下沉，刚开始还是一面巨型石墙，渐渐地变成了孤立的岩石，岩石变成了石头，最后石头变成卵石，直到终点。
en: In the meantime he examined the coast with great attention.Stretched out below them was the sandy shore, bounded on the right of the river’s mouth by lines of breakers.The rocks which were visible appeared like amphibious monsters reposing in the surf.Beyond the reef, the sea sparkled beneath the sun’s rays.To the south a sharp point closed the horizon, and it could not be seen if the land was prolonged in that direction, or if it ran southeast and southwest, which would have made this coast a very long peninsula.At the northern extremity of the bay the outline of the shore was continued to a great distance in a wider curve.There the shore was low, flat, without cliffs, and with great banks of sand, which the tide left uncovered.Pencroft and Herbert then returned towards the west.Their attention was first arrested by the snow-topped mountain which rose at a distance of six or seven miles.From its first declivities to within two miles of the coast were spread vast masses of wood, relieved by large green patches, caused by the presence of evergreen trees.Then, from the edge of this forest to the shore extended a plain, scattered irregularly with groups of trees.Here and there on the left sparkled through glades the waters of the little river; they could trace its winding course back towards the spurs of the mountain, among which it seemed to spring.At the point where the sailor had left his raft of wood, it began to run between the two high granite walls; but if on the left bank the wall remained clear and abrupt, on the right bank, on the contrary, it sank gradually, the massive sides changed to isolated rocks, the rocks to stones, the stones to shingle running to the extremity of the point.

zh: “我们是不是在一个岛上啊？”水手低语道。
en: “Are we on an island?” murmured the sailor.

zh: “不管怎么说，这个地方似乎够大。”小伙子回答说。
en: “At any rate, it seems to be big enough,” replied the lad.

zh: “岛屿再大它还是岛啊！”潘克洛夫说。
en: “An island, ever so big, is an island all the same!” said Pencroft.

zh: 不过这个重要的问题还不能回答。只有作更全面的调查才能解决这个问题。至于这个陆地本身——称作岛也好，称作洲也好——看上去十分肥沃，从各个方面来说，这里条件都很不错，物产也比较丰富。
en: But this important question could not yet be answered.A more perfect survey had to be made to settle the point.As to the land itself, island or continent, it appeared fertile, agreeable in its aspect, and varied in its productions.

zh: “这里真令人满意，”潘克洛夫评论道，“我们应该感谢上天在我们身处不幸时对我们的眷顾。”
en: “This is satisfactory,” observed Pencroft; “and in our misfortune, we must thank Providence for it.”

zh: “谢天谢地！”赫伯特回应道，他虔诚的心充满了对造物主的感激之情。
en: “God be praised!” responded Herbert, whose pious heart was full of gratitude to the Author of all things.

zh: 潘克洛夫和赫伯特仔细地看了看他们落脚的这个地方，不过，通过这样仓促的观察来预测他们的未来，难度很大。
