en: Pencroft and Herbert examined for some time the country on which they had been cast; but it was difficult to guess after so hasty an inspection what the future had in store for them.

zh: 他们开始沿着花岗岩石墙面的南端返回，长长的边缘是参差不齐的岩石，都奇形怪状的。几百只鸟住在石洞里，赫伯特一跳上岩石就吓着了这群长着翅膀的小家伙。
en: They then returned, following the southern crest of the granite platform, bordered by a long fringe of jagged rocks, of the most whimsical shapes.Some hundreds of birds lived there nestled in the holes of the stone; Herbert, jumping over the rocks, startled a whole flock of these winged creatures.

zh: “啊！”他叫起来了，“这些鸟不是沙鸥，也不是海鸥！”
en: “Oh!” cried he, “those are not gulls nor sea-mews!”

zh: “那它们是什么？”潘克洛夫问道。
en: “What are they then?” asked Pencroft.

zh: “依我看，可能是鸽子！”
en: “Upon my word, one would say they were pigeons!”

zh: “应该是，不过它们兴许是野鸽子或山鸽子。我认得这种鸟，它们翅膀上有两条黑带，尾巴是白色的，而羽毛则是青灰色的。要是山鸽子肉好吃的话，那它的蛋肯定也不错，我们快看看它们的窝里有多少蛋！”
en: “Just so, but these are wild or rock pigeons.I recognize them by the double band of black on the wing, by the white tail, and by their slate-colored plumage.But if the rock-pigeon is good to eat, its eggs must be excellent, and we will soon see how many they may have left in their nests!”

zh: “我们不给它们时间来孵蛋了，除非它们孵出来的是荷包蛋的形状！”潘克洛夫高兴地回答道。
en: “We will not give them time to hatch, unless it is in the shape of an omelet!” replied Pencroft merrily.

zh: “但是你要用什么煎荷包蛋呢？”赫伯特问道，“在你的帽子里？”
en: “But what will you make your omelet in?” asked Herbert; “in your hat?”

zh: “好啦！”水手说，“我可不会变戏法，孩子，我们必须下到洞里去拿蛋，我就搞定那些最难的吧！”
en: “Well!” replied the sailor, “I am not quite conjuror enough for that; we must come down to eggs in the shell, my boy, and I will undertake to despatch the hardest!”

zh: 潘克洛夫和赫伯特非常认真地查看花岗岩的石洞，他们真的在其中一些洞穴里发现了鸽子蛋。他们捡了十几个蛋放进水手的手帕里，这时满潮就要来临，潘克洛夫和赫伯特又从岩石上下来，朝河流走去。他们到那里时，已经是正午后的一小时了。这时，潮水已经退了。他们要利用退潮的机会把木柴运到河口处。潘克洛夫不会听任木筏没有向导在水流中走，也没有想过要登上木筏亲自掌控方向。即便没有缆绳或绳索，这也不会难倒身为水手的潘克洛夫，不一会儿，他就用干蔓藤拧成了几英寻长的绳索。水手将这条蔓藤绳系在了木筏的尾部，一只手抓着绳子，而赫伯特则用一根长长的木杆将木筏推到水流中。一切都成功完成了。满载木柴的木筏顺着水流漂下去。沿岸地势没有起伏，所以他们不用担心木筏会搁浅。不到两点，他们就到达了离石窟几步远的河口。
en: Pencroft and Herbert attentively examined the cavities in the granite, and they really found eggs in some of the hollows.A few dozen being collected, were packed in the sailor’s handkerchief, and as the time when the tide would be full was approaching, Pencroft and Herbert began to redescend towards the watercourse.When they arrived there, it was an hour after midday.The tide had already turned.They must now avail themselves of the ebb to take the wood to the mouth.Pencroft did not intend to let the raft go away in the current without guidance, neither did he mean to embark on it himself to steer it.But a sailor is never at a loss when there is a question of cables or ropes, and Pencroft rapidly twisted a cord, a few fathoms long, made of dry creepers.This vegetable cable was fastened to the after-part of the raft, and the sailor held it in his hand while Herbert, pushing off the raft with a long pole, kept it in the current.This succeeded capitally.The enormous load of wood drifted down the current.The bank was very equal; there was no fear that the raft would run aground, and before two o’clock they arrived at the river’s mouth, a few paces from the Chimneys.

zh: 第五章
en: Chapter 5

zh: 潘克洛夫从木筏上卸下干柴后，第一件事便是把所有灌风的洞口都堵上，使山洞适宜居住。他用沙子、石头、弯曲的树枝和湿粘土堵住了南风的通道口。旁边只留下一道狭窄弯曲的口子，用以通烟、引火。这个山洞就这样被分成了三四个房间（如果称得上房间的话），恐怕连驴子都不愿住在里面。但里边比较干燥，至少位于中央的主屋有足够直起身子的空间。他们在地上铺了细沙，一切安排妥当后，他们非常满意，因为没有比这里更好的地方了。
en: Pencroft’s first care, after unloading the raft, was to render the cave habitable by stopping up all the holes which made it draughty.Sand, stones, twisted branches, wet clay, closed up the galleries open to the south winds.One narrow and winding opening at the side was kept, to lead out the smoke and to make the fire draw.The cave was thus divided into three or four rooms, if such dark dens with which a donkey would scarcely have been contented deserved the name.But they were dry, and there was space to stand upright, at least in the principal room, which occupied the center.The floor was covered with fine sand, and taking all in all they were well pleased with it for want of a better.

zh: “兴许，”赫伯特一边和潘克洛夫干着活，一边说，“我们的伙伴已经找到更好的地方了呢。”
en: “Perhaps,” said Herbert, while he and Pencroft were working, “our companions have found a superior place to ours.”

zh: “很有可能，”水手回答说，“但是，既然我们现在还不知道，就必须照常工作。未雨绸缪总是好的！”
en: “Very likely,” replied the seaman; “but, as we don’t know, we must work all the same.Better to have two strings to one’s bow than no string at all!”

zh: “噢！”赫伯特感叹道，“要是他们能够找到哈丁上尉，并把他带回来该有多好啊！”
en: “Oh!” exclaimed Herbert, “how jolly it will be if they were to find Captain Harding and were to bring him back with them!”

zh: “是啊，确实如此！”潘克洛夫说，“要是他还活着，就真算个了不起的人。”
en: “Yes, indeed!” said Pencroft, “that was a man of the right sort.”

zh: “活着！”赫伯特大声说，“难道你已经绝望地认为再也见不到他了吗？”
en: “Was!” exclaimed Herbert, “do you despair of ever seeing him again?”

zh: “但愿不会如此！”水手答道。他们很快干完了活，潘克洛夫对自己十分满意。
en: “God forbid!” replied the sailor.Their work was soon done, and Pencroft declared himself very well satisfied.

zh: “现在，”他说，“我们的朋友随时都可以回来。他们有一个很好的安身之所了。”
en: “Now,” said he, “our friends can come back when they like.They will find a good enough shelter.”

zh: 现在他们只需造个壁炉，准备一顿晚饭，这是件轻而易举的小事。他们在保留下来的狭窄洞口放置了几块大的平板石。只要烟不把里面的热气带出去，这就足够使洞内保持适当的温度。他们把木柴储存在其中的一间屋子，水手在壁炉旁放了一些木柴和树枝。水手正忙着的时候，赫伯特问他有没有火柴。
en: They now had only to make a fireplace and to prepare the supper—an easy task.Large flat stones were placed on the ground at the opening of the narrow passage which had been kept.This, if the smoke did not take the heat out with it, would be enough to maintain an equal temperature inside.Their wood was stowed away in one of the rooms, and the sailor laid in the fireplace some logs and brushwood.The seaman was busy with this, when Herbert asked him if he had any matches.

zh: “当然有，”潘克洛夫回答说，“我可以很高兴地说，如果没有火柴或者火绒，我们就会陷入困境。”
en: “Certainly,” replied Pencroft, “and I may say happily, for without matches or tinder we should be in a fix.”

zh: “我们还可以像野人那样取火，”赫伯特说，“就是拿两根干木棒互相摩擦。”
en: “Still we might get fire as the savages do,” replied Herbert, “by rubbing two bits of dry stick one against the other.”

zh: “好，你试试吧，孩子！除了能活动一下你的胳膊外，看能做成什么事。”
en: “All right; try, my boy, and let’s see if you can do anything besides exercising your arms.”

zh: “哼，这个太简单了，太平洋岛屿上的人就经常用这种方法。”
en: “Well, it’s a very simple proceeding, and much used in the islands of the Pacific.”

zh: “这一点我不否认，”潘克洛夫回答说，“但是野人应该知道怎么做或者使用了什么特殊的木头，因为我曾经好几次尝试过这种方法，却从没有成功。我不得不说还是火柴好用些。哎呀，我的火柴呢？”
en: “I don’t deny it,” replied Pencroft, “but the savages must know how to do it or employ a peculiar wood, for more than once I have tried to get fire in that way, but I could never manage it.I must say I prefer matches.By the bye, where are my matches?”

zh: 潘克洛夫伸手去坎肩口袋里找火柴盒，他是个老烟枪，平时总把它放在那里。他没有找到，他翻遍了裤子的口袋，但令他吃惊的是，找不到火柴盒。
en: Pencroft searched in his waistcoat for the box, which was always there, for he was a confirmed smoker.He could not find it; he rummaged the pockets of his trousers, but, to his horror, he could nowhere discover the box.

zh: “糟糕！”他看着赫伯特说，“火柴盒一定是从口袋掉出来，弄丢了！赫伯特，想必你一定有火绒盒之类的生火用具吧？”
en: “Here’s a go!” said he, looking at Herbert.“The box must have fallen out of my pocket and got lost!Surely, Herbert, you must have something—a tinder-box—anything that can possibly make fire!”

zh: “我没有，潘克洛夫。”
en: “No, I haven’t, Pencroft.”

zh: 水手冲了出去，孩子跟在后边。他们在沙滩上、岩石缝里和河岸附近仔细寻找，但都没有找到。火柴盒是铜制的，应该很容易看到。
en: The sailor rushed out, followed by the boy.On the sand, among the rocks, near the river’s bank, they both searched carefully, but in vain.The box was of copper, and therefore would have been easily seen.

zh: “潘克洛夫，”赫伯特问，“你没有把它从吊篮里扔出去吗？”
en: “Pencroft,” asked Herbert, “didn’t you throw it out of the car?”

zh: “我记得很清楚，没有丢，”水手回答说，“但是这么个小东西很容易在我们经历的颠簸中丢失的。我倒宁愿丢掉的是烟斗。该死的火柴盒！它哪儿去了呢？
en: “I knew better than that,” replied the sailor; “but such a small article could easily disappear in the tumbling about we have gone through.I would rather even have lost my pipe!Confound the box!Where can it be?”

zh: “瞧，现在退潮了，”赫伯特说，“跑到我们着陆的地方看看吧。”
en: “Look here, the tide is going down,” said Herbert; “let’s run to the place where we landed.”

zh: 要找到火柴盒几乎是不可能的，涨潮的时候，海浪把沙滩上的鹅卵石都冲过了，不过试一下也好。赫伯特和潘克洛夫快速走到昨天着陆的地点，这里离山洞大约两百英尺远。他们在鹅卵石堆里和岩石缝隙中搜寻，但是什么也没有找到。如果火柴盒丢在这个地方，那么一定被海浪冲走了。退潮后，他们搜寻了每一个狭小的裂缝，但仍一无所获。按照他们当时的情况来说，这真是巨大、无法弥补的损失。潘克洛夫无法隐藏自己的苦恼，他看起来很着急，但是一句话也没说。赫伯特尽量安慰他说，即使找到火柴，也很可能被海水浸湿，不能用了。
en: It was scarcely probable that they would find the box, which the waves had rolled about among the pebbles, at high tide, but it was as well to try.Herbert and Pencroft walked rapidly to the point where they had landed the day before, about two hundred feet from the cave.They hunted there, among the shingle, in the clefts of the rocks, but found nothing.If the box had fallen at this place it must have been swept away by the waves.As the sea went down, they searched every little crevice with no result.It was a grave loss in their circumstances, and for the time irreparable.Pencroft could not hide his vexation; he looked very anxious, but said not a word.Herbert tried to console him by observing, that if they had found the matches, they would, very likely, have been wetted by the sea and useless.

zh: “不可能，孩子，”水手说，“火柴是装在盖得严实的铜盒子里，现在我们该怎么办？”
en: “No, my boy,” replied the sailor; “they were in a copper box which shut very tightly; and now what are we to do?”

zh: “我们一定会找到生火的办法！”赫伯特说，“哈丁船上尉或者史佩莱先生身上不会没有火柴的。”
en: “We shall certainly find some way of making a fire,” said Herbert.“Captain Harding or Mr. Spilett will not be without them.”

zh: “有道理，”潘克洛夫回答说，“可是现在没有火，我们的伙伴回来也就吃不上像样的东西了。”
en: “Yes,” replied Pencroft; “but in the meantime we are without fire, and our companions will find but a sorry repast on their return.”

zh: “可是，”赫伯特很快说道，“你认为他们会不会也没有火绒或火柴啊？”
en: “But,” said Herbert quickly, “do you think it possible that they have no tinder or matches?”

zh: “我看不一定有，”水手边摇头边回答说，“因为纳布和哈丁上尉都不吸烟。至于史佩莱先生，我认为相比火柴盒他更情愿留下笔记本。”
en: “I doubt it,” replied the sailor, shaking his head, “for neither Neb nor Captain Harding smoke, and I believe that Mr. Spilett would rather keep his note-book than his match-box.”

zh: 赫伯特没有回答。弄丢火柴盒的确让人感到可惜，但是这个孩子仍然相信能用其他方法来生火。经验更为丰富的潘克洛夫从不会因为或多或少的不满而自寻烦恼，但这次他却没那么乐观了。不管怎样，他们只有一件事情可做——等待纳布和通讯记者回来。但是，他们必须放弃原本准备好吃熟蛋的计划。不论对他们自己还是对其他人来说，生吞活咽不是一件愉悦的事情。
en: Herbert did not reply.The loss of the box was certainly to be regretted, but the boy was still sure of procuring fire in some way or other.Pencroft, more experienced, did not think so, although he was not a man to trouble himself about a small or great grievance.At any rate, there was only one thing to be done—to await the return of Neb and the reporter; but they must give up the feast of hard eggs which they had meant to prepare, and a meal of raw flesh was not an agreeable prospect either for themselves or for the others.

zh: 火是肯定无法找到了，在回洞前，水手和赫伯特捡了一些牡蛎，然后静静地沿着原路返回了他们的住所。
en: Before returning to the cave, the sailor and Herbert, in the event of fire being positively unattainable, collected some more shell-fish, and then silently retraced their steps to their dwelling.

zh: 潘克洛夫两眼紧紧地盯着地面，还在寻找他的火柴盒。他甚至爬上了河的左岸，从河口一直找到停泊木筏的地方。他又返回高地，到处仔细检查了一遍，森林边缘上高高的草丛里也搜了一遍，还是徒劳无功。
en: Pencroft, his eyes fixed on the ground, still looked for his box.He even climbed up the left bank of the river from its mouth to the angle where the raft had been moored.He returned to the plateau, went over it in every direction, searched among the high grass on the border of the forest, all in vain.

zh: 晚上五点钟的时候，他和赫伯特再次回到洞中。不用说，他们把洞里最黑暗的角落都彻底翻了个遍，才不得不绝望地放弃寻找。接近六点钟，太阳正从西边的高地落下去的时候，在海滩来回踱步的赫伯特示意纳布和史佩莱回来了。
en: It was five in the evening when he and Herbert re-entered the cave.It is useless to say that the darkest corners of the passages were ransacked before they were obliged to give it up in despair.Towards six o’clock, when the sun was disappearing behind the high lands of the west, Herbert, who was walking up and down on the strand, signalized the return of Neb and Spilett.

zh: 他们自己回来的！那个少年的心一下子沉了下去，水手的预测没有错，果然没有找到工程师赛勒斯·哈丁！
en: They were returning alone!....The boy’s heart sank; the sailor had not been deceived in his forebodings; the engineer, Cyrus Harding, had not been found!

zh: 记者回来后就坐在岩石上，一言不发。他已经筋疲力尽，饿得要死，所以连说话的力气也没有了。
en: The reporter, on his arrival, sat down on a rock, without saying anything.Exhausted with fatigue, dying of hunger, he had not strength to utter a word.

zh: 至于纳布，他那通红的双眼说明他哭得厉害，眼泪止不住地往下流，一切都清楚地说明他已经失去所有希望。
en: As to Neb, his red eyes showed how he had cried, and the tears which he could not restrain told too clearly that he had lost all hope.

zh: 记者描述了他们竭力寻找塞勒斯·哈丁的整个经过。他和纳布沿着海岸一直找到八英里之外的地方，这个距离远远超出了气球最后一次着陆的范围，就在那次降落后，工程师和他的狗托普就失踪了。海岸上冷冷清清，没有一丝踪迹。鹅卵石一块都没有动过，沙滩上没有任何痕迹，那一带的海滩上连个人的脚印都没有。显然，从来就没有人踏足过这一带的海岸。大海和陆地一样荒凉，那里一定是工程师的葬身之地——离海岸几百英尺的水域。
en: The reporter recounted all that they had done in their attempt to recover Cyrus Harding.He and Neb had surveyed the coast for a distance of eight miles and consequently much beyond the place where the balloon had fallen the last time but one, a fall which was followed by the disappearance of the engineer and the dog Top.The shore was solitary; not a vestige of a mark.Not even a pebble recently displaced; not a trace on the sand; not a human footstep on all that part of the beach.It was clear that that portion of the shore had never been visited by a human being.The sea was as deserted as the land, and it was there, a few hundred feet from the coast, that the engineer must have found a tomb.

zh: 史佩莱讲述完后，纳布一下子跳了起来，他的喊叫表现了内心希望的抗争，“不，他没死！他不可能死！别人也许会死，但是他绝不会！什么困境他都能摆脱！”接着他有气无力了，喃喃地说：“啊！我无能为力了！”
en: As Spilett ended his account, Neb jumped up, exclaiming in a voice which showed how hope struggled within him, “No! he is not dead! he can’t be dead!It might happen to any one else, but never to him!He could get out of anything!”Then his strength forsaking him, “Oh!I can do no more!” he murmured.

zh: “纳布，”赫伯特跑到他身边说，“我们一定能找到他的！上帝会把他还给我们的！但是，现在你饿了，必须吃点东西。”
en: “Neb,” said Herbert, running to him, “we will find him!God will give him back to us!But in the meantime you are hungry, and you must eat something.”

zh: 他一边说，一边抓几把牡蛎递给了这个可怜的黑人，这些牡蛎实在是难以下咽，又不饱腹。纳布已经有几小时没有吃东西了，但还是不肯吃。没了主人，他不能也不愿独自活下去。
en: So saying, he offered the poor Negro a few handfuls of shell-fish, which was indeed wretched and insufficient food.Neb had not eaten anything for several hours, but he refused them.He could not, would not live without his master.

zh: 吉迪恩·史佩莱狼吞虎咽地吃了牡蛎，就躺在岩石脚下的沙子上睡着了。他很虚弱，但很镇定。赫伯特走到他身边，握着他的手说：“先生，我们已经找到一处住所，比躺在这里好多了。黑夜已经来临。走，去休息一下！明天我们到更远的地方去找找。”
en: As to Gideon Spilett, he devoured the shell-fish, then he laid himself down on the sand, at the foot of a rock.He was very weak, but calm.Herbert went up to him, and taking his hand, “Sir,” said he, “we have found a shelter which will be better than lying here.Night is advancing.Come and rest!To-morrow we will search farther.”

zh: 记者站了起来，跟着男孩往山洞走去。在路上，潘克洛夫用最自然的口吻问他身上有没有火柴，哪怕只有一两根也好。
en: The reporter got up, and guided by the boy went towards the cave.On the way, Pencroft asked him in the most natural tone, if by chance he happened to have a match or two.

zh: 记者停下脚步，在口袋里摸了一阵，但是没有找到，他说：“我本来是有的，可能让我扔掉了。”
en: The reporter stopped, felt in his pockets, but finding nothing said, “I had some, but I must have thrown them away.”

zh: 水手又向纳布问了同样的问题，得到的答案是一样的。
en: The seaman then put the same question to Neb and received the same answer.

zh: “该死！”水手大声喊。
en: “Confound it!” exclaimed the sailor.

zh: 记者听到后，一把抓住他的胳膊，问：“你没有火柴？”
en: The reporter heard him and seizing his arm, “Have you no matches?” he asked.

zh: “一根也没有，这下没法生火了。”
en: “Not one, and no fire in consequence.”

zh: “唉！”纳布喊道，“如果主人在，他一定知道做什么！”
en: “Ah!” cried Neb, “if my master was here, he would know what to do!”

zh: 这四个落难的人站在那里一动不动，不安地看着彼此。赫伯特首先打破沉默说：“史佩莱先生，你是吸烟的，身上总带着火柴，也许你没仔细找，再试试看，一根就足够了！”
en: The four castaways remained motionless, looking uneasily at each other.Herbert was the first to break the silence by saying, “Mr. Spilett, you are a smoker and always have matches about you; perhaps you haven’t looked well, try again, a single match will be enough!”

zh: 记者又在他的裤子、坎肩和大衣的口袋里搜了一遍，令潘克洛夫极为惊喜的是，最后记者摸到一小块木棒缠在坎肩内层。他隔着衬里捏着它，但就是拿不出来。如果这真的是一根火柴，并且是唯一的一根，那么不要碰掉上面的磷尤为重要。
en: The reporter hunted again in the pockets of his trousers, waistcoat, and great-coat, and at last to Pencroft’s great joy, no less to his extreme surprise, he felt a tiny piece of wood entangled in the lining of his waistcoat.He seized it with his fingers through the stuff, but he could not get it out.If this was a match and a single one, it was of great importance not to rub off the phosphorus.

zh: “让我来试一下，可以吗？”男孩说。他非常灵巧地将不值钱但是珍贵的小木棒完好地拿了出来，它对这些可怜的人来说十分重要。这是一根还没有用过的火柴。
en: “Will you let me try?” said the boy, and very cleverly, without breaking it, he managed to draw out the wretched yet precious little bit of wood which was of such great importance to these poor men.It was unused.

zh: “好哇！”潘克洛夫大声喊起来，“有这一根就像有一整船货一样！”他拿着火柴，往洞里走去，后面跟着他的同伴们。
en: “Hurrah!” cried Pencroft; “it is as good as having a whole cargo!”He took the match, and, followed by his companions, entered the cave.

zh: 这样短小的木棒，在有人居住的地方，大多会被毫不吝惜地浪费掉，并且也不值钱，但在这里，这一根却要极为小心地使用。
en: This small piece of wood, of which so many in an inhabited country are wasted with indifference and are of no value, must here be used with the greatest caution.

zh: 水手首先确定它是干的，然后说：“我们需要些张纸。”
en: The sailor first made sure that it was quite dry; that done, “We must have some paper,” said he.

zh: 史佩莱犹豫了片刻后，从他的笔记本上撕下一页，说：“给。”
en: “Here,” replied Spilett, after some hesitation tearing a leaf out of his note-book.

zh: 潘克洛夫接过记者递给他的那张纸，跪在壁炉前。他在柴火下面垫了几把草、树叶和干燥的苔藓，这样空气容易流通，干柴能很快点着。
en: Pencroft took the piece of paper which the reporter held out to him, and knelt down before the fireplace.Some handfuls of grass, leaves, and dry moss were placed under the fagots and disposed in such a way that the air could easily circulate, and the dry wood would rapidly catch fire.

zh: 于是，潘克洛夫将纸卷成圆锥的形状，像在有疾风的地方吸烟似的，把纸筒插到苔藓里。接着他拿起一小块粗糙的石头，仔细地擦了擦，心怦怦直跳。他屏住呼吸，拿火柴在上面轻轻一划。第一次尝试没有成功。潘克洛夫没有用力划，生怕擦掉上面的磷。
en: Pencroft then twisted the piece of paper into the shape of a cone, as smokers do in a high wind, and poked it in among the moss.Taking a small, rough stone, he wiped it carefully, and with a beating heart, holding his breath, he gently rubbed the match.The first attempt did not produce any effect.Pencroft had not struck hard enough, fearing to rub off the phosphorus.

zh: “不行，我点不着，”他说，“我的手发抖，火柴划不着，不行，这活我干不了！”他站起来，要换赫伯特来点。
en: “No, I can’t do it,” said he, “my hand trembles, the match has missed fire; I cannot, I will not!” and rising, he told Herbert to take his place.

zh: 这个孩子长这么大一定从未这么紧张过。当时普罗米修斯到天上偷火种的时候也不会这么紧张。但是，他毫不犹豫地直接划起火柴。
en: Certainly the boy had never in all his life been so nervous.Prometheus going to steal the fire from heaven could not have been more anxious.He did not hesitate, however, but struck the match directly.

zh: 只听见火柴哧的一声响，然后就升起一小团蓝色火苗，冒出一股呛鼻的烟。赫伯特快速转了一下火柴以使火苗更旺些，接着他把火柴塞进纸筒里，几秒内，纸和苔藓都燃了起来。
en: A little spluttering was heard and a tiny blue flame sprang up, making a choking smoke.Herbert quickly turned the match so as to augment the flame, and then slipped it into the paper cone, which in a few seconds too caught fire, and then the moss.

zh: 水手使劲地用嘴吹，一分钟后，干柴发出噼里啪啦的响声，一堆熊熊烈火在黑暗中燃烧起来。
en: A minute later the dry wood crackled and a cheerful flame, assisted by the vigorous blowing of the sailor, sprang up in the midst of the darkness.

zh: “终于成功了！”潘克洛夫站起身来，大声说，“我有生以来从未这样紧张！”
en: “At last!” cried Pencroft, getting up; “I was never so nervous before in all my life!”

zh: 平板石构成一个顶好的壁炉。壁炉里冒出的烟很容易通到狭窄的洞口，烟囱抽着火，不一会儿，洞里就变得舒适温暖了。
en: The flat stones made a capital fireplace.The smoke went quite easily out at the narrow passage, the chimney drew, and an agreeable warmth was not long in being felt.

zh: 现在他们必须十分小心不让火熄灭，并且总是保留一些火种。他们有很多木柴，而且随时可以补充燃料，因此仅需时刻留意就可以了。
en: They must now take great care not to let the fire go out, and always to keep some embers alight.It only needed care and attention, as they had plenty of wood and could renew their store at any time.

zh: 潘克洛夫首先想到的是用火准备一顿比牡蛎更富有营养的晚餐。赫伯特拿过来两打蛋。记者斜靠在一个角落，静静地看着这些准备工作。他脑中萦绕着三个问题。塞勒斯还活着吗？如果他还活着，那么他在哪里呢？倘若他坠落之后大难不死，那他为什么不想办法让我们知道他还活着呢？至于纳布，他正独自一人在海滩上徘徊。他就像丢了魂一样。
en: Pencroft’s first thought was to use the fire by preparing a more nourishing supper than a dish of shell-fish.Two dozen eggs were brought by Herbert.The reporter leaning up in a corner, watched these preparations without saying anything.A threefold thought weighed on his mind.Was Cyrus still alive?If he was alive, where was he?If he had survived from his fall, how was it that he had not found some means of making known his existence?As to Neb, he was roaming about the shore.He was like a body without a soul.

zh: 潘克洛夫知道五十种做蛋的方法，但是这次他别无选择，只能自得其意地把蛋放在热火灰里烤。几分钟内饭就准备好了，水手把记者喊过来共进晚餐。这是遇难者在这个未知的海滩上的第一顿美餐。这些煮熟的蛋很好吃，并且包含了人类不可缺少的各种营养，这些可怜的人感到很满足，吃完后，身体也恢复了能量。哎！要是这顿饭没有缺一个人该多好啊！如果从里士满逃脱出来的五个人都在，坐在堆积的岩石下，前面是明亮、噼啪作响的火堆，他们会怎样感谢上苍啊！但是他们一致公认的领袖，最机灵、最博学多才的塞勒斯·哈丁失踪了！他死后连个安安身之地也没有。
en: Pencroft knew fifty ways of cooking eggs, but this time he had no choice, and was obliged to content himself with roasting them under the hot cinders.In a few minutes the cooking was done, and the seaman invited the reporter to take his share of the supper.Such was the first repast of the castaways on this unknown coast.The hard eggs were excellent, and as eggs contain everything indispensable to man’s nourishment, these poor people thought themselves well off, and were much strengthened by them.Oh! if only one of them had not been missing at this meal!If the five prisoners who escaped from Richmond had been all there, under the piled-up rocks, before this clear, crackling fire on the dry sand, what thanksgiving must they have rendered to Heaven!But the most ingenious, the most learned, he who was their unquestioned chief, Cyrus Harding, was, alas! missing, and his body had not even obtained a burial-place.

zh: 3月25日就这样过去了。夜幕已经降临。洞外狂风怒号，海浪拍击着岸边，发出单调的声音。海浪来回卷着沙石，发出震耳欲聋的声响。
en: Thus passed the 25th of March.Night had come on.Outside could be heard the howling of the wind and the monotonous sound of the surf breaking on the shore.The waves rolled the shingle backwards and forwards with a deafening noise.

zh: 记者简单地记下了当天的事件后，就到一个黑暗的角落里休息了。他记下刚到这片新土地的景象、他们领袖的失踪、海岸的搜寻和火柴事件等等，由于太过劳累，他设法用睡眠来忘记自己的忧伤。赫伯特也直接去睡了。至于水手，整晚他都在用一只眼睛盯着火苗，并不停地给它补充燃料。但是，有一个落难者没有在洞里睡觉。他就是伤心欲绝的纳布，不论同伴怎样劝他休息一下，他还是整夜在海岸徘徊，呼唤着他的主人。
en: The reporter retired into a dark corner after having shortly noted down the occurrences of the day; the first appearance of this new land, the loss of their leader, the exploration of the coast, the incident of the matches, etc.; and then overcome by fatigue, he managed to forget his sorrows in sleep.Herbert went to sleep directly.As to the sailor, he passed the night with one eye on the fire, on which he did not spare fuel.But one of the castaways did not sleep in the cave.The inconsolable, despairing Neb, notwithstanding all that his companions could say to induce him to take some rest, wandered all night long on the shore calling on his master.

zh: 第六章
en: Chapter 6

zh: 从云端被抛到这个看似无人居住的海岸后，这些落难者很快把自己的物品清点了一下。他们除了落难时身上穿着的衣服外，就什么也没有了。然而，必须提一下，吉丁·史佩莱还留有一个笔记本和一只手表，这些无疑是他在不经意间留下来的。他们没有一样武器，一件工具，甚至连把小折刀都没有。在吊舱的时候，为了减轻气球的重量，他们把所有的东西都扔出去了。即使是丹尼尔·笛福或怀斯的小说中虚构的英雄，以及在胡安·费尔南德斯和奥克兰群岛上遭遇海难的塞尔扣克和雷纳，也绝不像他们处于这样的绝境。那些人能从自己搁浅的船上取出丰富的物资，如粮食、家畜、工具、弹药，或是在海岸找到别人丢弃的物品，从而能为他们提供生活急需品。但在这里，没有任何工具，一个器皿也没有。他们必须从零开始，为自己创造一切。
en: The inventory of the articles possessed by these castaways from the clouds, thrown upon a coast which appeared to be uninhabited, was soon made out.They had nothing, save the clothes which they were wearing at the time of the catastrophe.We must mention, however, a note-book and a watch which Gideon Spilett had kept, doubtless by inadvertence, not a weapon, not a tool, not even a pocket-knife; for while in the car they had thrown out everything to lighten the balloon.The imaginary heroes of Daniel Defoe or of Wyss, as well as Selkirk and Raynal shipwrecked on Juan Fernandez and on the archipelago of the Aucklands, were never in such absolute destitution.Either they had abundant resources from their stranded vessels, in grain, cattle, tools, ammunition, or else some things were thrown up on the coast which supplied them with all the first necessities of life.But here, not any instrument whatever, not a utensil.From nothing they must supply themselves with everything.

zh: 可是，如果赛勒斯·哈丁和他们在一起，如果这位工程师能把他知道的实用科学、创造思维运用起来，也许他们还有一线希望。唉！他们一定再没指望见到赛勒斯·哈丁了。这些落难者不能期待任何事情，只能寄希望于他们自己以及上帝了，他绝不会抛弃有真诚信仰的人。
en: And yet, if Cyrus Harding had been with them, if the engineer could have brought his practical science, his inventive mind to bear on their situation, perhaps all hope would not have been lost.Alas! they must hope no longer again to see Cyrus Harding.The castaways could expect nothing but from themselves and from that Providence which never abandons those whose faith is sincere.

zh: 但是他们该不该在这个岸边住下来呢？他们还不知道这里属于哪个大陆，有没有人居住，或者他们是不是处在一个荒岛的海岸。
en: But ought they to establish themselves on this part of the coast, without trying to know to what continent it belonged, if it was inhabited, or if they were on the shore of a desert island?

zh: 这是个很重要的问题，必须毫不拖延地尽快解决。有了答案，他们才知道要采取什么措施。但是，潘克洛夫建议最好还是先等上几天，再进行勘探。事实上，他们必须准备一些食物，找到比鸟蛋和软体动物更能增强体力的食物。探险者们必须先恢复体力，才能做新的体力活。
en: It was an important question, and should be solved with the shortest possible delay.From its answer they would know what measures to take.However, according to Pencroft’s advice, it appeared best to wait a few days before commencing an exploration.They must, in fact, prepare some provisions and procure more strengthening food than eggs and molluscs.The explorers, before undertaking new fatigues, must first of all recruit their strength.

zh: “石窟”目前还足以供他们容身。火生起来了，保存炭火就很容易。岩石缝里和沙滩上有不少鸟蛋和贝壳类软体动物。高地上空有上百只鸽子在飞翔，用棍子或石块都很容易打下几只。附近森林的树上也许还有供他们食用的果子。最后，这里还有淡水。
en: The Chimneys offered a retreat sufficient for the present.The fire was lighted, and it was easy to preserve some embers.There were plenty of shell-fish and eggs among the rocks and on the beach.It would be easy to kill a few of the pigeons which were flying by hundreds about the summit of the plateau, either with sticks or stones.Perhaps the trees of the neighboring forest would supply them with eatable fruit.Lastly, the sweet water was there.

zh: 于是他们决定在“石窟”里呆几天，为探险做些准备，要么沿着海岸，要么深入岛内。纳布特别赞同这个计划。他坚持自己的想法和预感，不想马上离开这个海岸——他们出事的地方。他不相信，也不愿意相信赛勒斯·哈丁已经死了。不会的，纳布认为，像他这样的人似乎不会以这么普通的方式离去——被海浪冲走，淹死在离海岸几百英里的水里。只要海浪没把工程师的尸体冲上岸，只要他——纳布，没有亲眼看见主人的尸体，没有亲手触摸到主人的手，他不会相信主人死了！这种想法已经在他坚决的心中里扎了根，比以往更深。或许，这只是一种幻想，但却是值得尊重的幻想，因而水手也不想点破。至于水手自己，则不抱任何希望，但和纳布争辩也是无济于事的。纳布像一条小狗，不愿离开埋葬主人的地方，而且似乎悲恸得活不下去了。
en: It was accordingly settled that for a few days they would remain at the Chimneys so as to prepare themselves for an expedition, either along the shore or into the interior of the country.This plan suited Neb particularly.As obstinate in his ideas as in his presentiments, he was in no haste to abandon this part of the coast, the scene of the catastrophe.He did not, he would not believe in the loss of Cyrus Harding.No, it did not seem to him possible that such a man had ended in this vulgar fashion, carried away by a wave, drowned in the floods, a few hundred feet from a shore.As long as the waves had not cast up the body of the engineer, as long as he, Neb, had not seen with his eyes, touched with his hands the corpse of his master, he would not believe in his death!And this idea rooted itself deeper than ever in his determined heart.An illusion perhaps, but still an illusion to be respected, and one which the sailor did not wish to destroy.As for him, he hoped no longer, but there was no use in arguing with Neb.He was like the dog who will not leave the place where his master is buried, and his grief was such that most probably he would not survive him.

zh: 3月26日早晨，天刚刚亮，纳布就从海岸出发朝北走去，他回到出事的地方，不幸的哈丁就是在这里被大海吞没的。
en: This same morning, the 26th of March, at daybreak, Neb had set out on the shore in a northerly direction, and he had returned to the spot where the sea, no doubt, had closed over the unfortunate Harding.

zh: 那天的早饭吃的仅仅是鸽蛋和石蛏。赫伯特在岩石凹处找到一些由于海水蒸发而沉积下来的盐，这种矿物质来得正是时候。
en: That day’s breakfast was composed solely of pigeon’s eggs and lithodomes.Herbert had found some salt deposited by evaporation in the hollows of the rocks, and this mineral was very welcome.

zh: 吃完饭后，潘克洛夫问记者愿不愿意陪他和赫伯特一起去森林，他们准备去那里打猎。但考虑再三，他们认为必须要有人留下来照看火堆，并且在纳布需要帮助时及时搭把手，尽管他找到赛勒斯·哈丁的可能性很小。于是，记者决定留了下来。
en: The repast ended, Pencroft asked the reporter if he wished to accompany Herbert and himself to the forest, where they were going to try to hunt.But on consideration, it was thought necessary that someone should remain to keep in the fire, and to be at hand in the highly improbable event of Neb requiring aid.The reporter accordingly remained behind.

zh: “打猎去吧，赫伯特，”水手说，“我们应该在路上找些弹药，在树林里造些武器。”但是就在要出发的时候，赫伯特提议，既然他们没有火绒，也许可以用其他东西来替代，这样更稳妥一些。
en: “To the chase, Herbert,” said the sailor.“We shall find ammunition on our way, and cut our weapons in the forest.”But at the moment of starting, Herbert observed, that since they had no tinder, it would perhaps be prudent to replace it by another substance.

zh: “什么东西呢？”潘克洛夫问道。
en: “What?” asked Pencroft.

zh: “烧焦的亚麻布，”少年回答说，“在必要时可作为火绒使用。”
en: “Burnt linen,” replied the boy.“That could in case of need serve for tinder.”

zh: 水手觉得这个主意很不错。唯一的麻烦是需要牺牲一块手帕。但这个办法值得一试，于是潘克洛夫的大格子手帕很快被烧成一块半焦的布。他们把这块易燃的焦布放在洞中间一块岩石小洞的底部，那里可以避风挡潮。
en: The sailor thought it very sensible advice.Only it had the inconvenience of necessitating the sacrifice of a piece of handkerchief.Notwithstanding, the thing was well worth while trying, and a part of Pencroft’s large checked handkerchief was soon reduced to the state of a half-burnt rag.This inflammable material was placed in the central chamber at the bottom of a little cavity in the rock, sheltered from all wind and damp.

zh: 这时是上午九点钟了。天气恶劣，刮着东南风。赫伯特和潘克洛夫绕过“石窟”的拐角，时不时地看一看从岩石顶部冒出的袅袅轻烟，然后他们沿着河的左岸而上。
en: It was nine o’clock in the morning.The weather was threatening and the breeze blew from the southeast.Herbert and Pencroft turned the angle of the Chimneys, not without having cast a look at the smoke which, just at that place, curled round a point of rock: they ascended the left bank of the river.

zh: 进入树林后，潘克洛夫就从迎面的一棵树上扳下两根粗壮的树枝，做成木棍，而赫伯特则在一块石头上把棍子的两头磨平。哦！要是能有一把刀，他们会不惜一切代价去换取的！
en: Arrived at the forest, Pencroft broke from the first tree two stout branches which he transformed into clubs, the ends of which Herbert rubbed smooth on a rock.Oh! what would they not have given for a knife!

zh: 随后，两位猎人沿着河岸在深草丛中前行。河流朝西南方向拐了个弯，便渐渐变窄了，两岸很高，上面的树枝形成一座双拱门。为了不迷路，潘克洛夫决定沿着河往前走，这样总能把他们带回到出发的地方。但是岸上的路并不好走，有些地方柔韧的树枝垂到水面上，而有些地方爬藤和荆棘丛生，需要用棍子开路。赫伯特常常像一只灵巧的小猫，在断掉的树桩里跑来跑去，一会儿又消失在矮树丛中。但潘克洛夫马上把他叫回来，并央告他别走远了。同时，水手仔细地观察着周围的情况和动静。河岸左边，地势平坦，多沼泽，向内陆缓缓升高。这里看起来像一片水网，这些水无疑是通过一些地下沟渠流向河里。有时会有一条小溪流过矮树丛，但他们要跨过并不费事。河的对岸更加崎岖不平，而峡谷却清晰可见，河水就从峡谷底部流过。一座小山，上面长满了树木，形成一道屏障，挡住了视线。在河岸右边行走会很困难，因为这里的斜坡突然变陡，弯向水面的树木全靠根部支撑着。
en: The two hunters now advanced among the long grass, following the bank.From the turning which directed its course to the southwest, the river narrowed gradually and the channel lay between high banks, over which the trees formed a double arch.Pencroft, lest they should lose themselves, resolved to follow the course of the stream, which would always lead them back to the point from which they started.But the bank was not without some obstacles: here, the flexible branches of the trees bent level with the current; there, creepers and thorns which they had to break down with their sticks.Herbert often glided among the broken stumps with the agility of a young cat, and disappeared in the underwood.But Pencroft called him back directly, begging him not to wander away.Meanwhile, the sailor attentively observed the disposition and nature of the surrounding country.On the left bank, the ground, which was flat and marshy, rose imperceptibly towards the interior.It looked there like a network of liquid threads which doubtless reached the river by some underground drain.Sometimes a stream ran through the underwood, which they crossed without difficulty.The opposite shore appeared to be more uneven, and the valley of which the river occupied the bottom was more clearly visible.The hill, covered with trees disposed in terraces, intercepted the view.On the right bank walking would have been difficult, for the declivities fell suddenly, and the trees bending over the water were only sustained by the strength of their roots.

zh: 不用说，这片树林和已勘探过的海岸一样，都没有人类生活的迹象。潘克洛夫只发现了一些四足兽的足迹，这是动物新近留下的脚印，但他辨别不出究竟是什么动物。可以肯定的是——这也是赫伯特的看法——有些脚印是凶猛的野兽留下来的，这无疑会给他们带来麻烦。不过他们并没有发现树上有斧子砍过的痕迹，也没有火堆的余灰，更没有人类的足迹。这一点或许值得他们庆幸，因为在太平洋中央的任何一个岛屿上，有人出现也许更可怕。赫伯特和潘克洛夫几乎都不说话，由于路很难走，前进很慢，一个小时后，他们才勉强走了一英里多。到目前为止，打猎还一无所获。不过，枝叶间还有小鸟在鸣叫着飞来飞去，显得非常胆怯，似乎看到了人类，引发了它们本能的恐惧。在树林的一片沼泽地带，赫伯特指出其中一种鸟很像翠鸟，嘴又长又尖，虽然羽毛有着金属般的光泽，却并不好看。
en: It is needless to add that this forest, as well as the coast already surveyed, was destitute of any sign of human life.Pencroft only saw traces of quadrupeds, fresh footprints of animals, of which he could not recognize the species.In all probability, and such was also Herbert’s opinion, some had been left by formidable wild beasts which doubtless would give them some trouble; but nowhere did they observe the mark of an axe on the trees, nor the ashes of a fire, nor the impression of a human foot.On this they might probably congratulate themselves, for on any land in the middle of the Pacific the presence of man was perhaps more to be feared than desired.Herbert and Pencroft speaking little, for the difficulties of the way were great, advanced very slowly, and after walking for an hour they had scarcely gone more than a mile.As yet the hunt had not been successful.However, some birds sang and fluttered in the foliage, and appeared very timid, as if man had inspired them with an instinctive fear.Among others, Herbert described, in a marshy part of the forest, a bird with a long pointed beak, closely resembling the king-fisher, but its plumage was not fine, though of a metallic brilliancy.

zh: “那一定是啄木鸟。”赫伯特一边说，一边试着靠近。
en: “That must be a jacamar,” said Herbert, trying to get nearer.

zh: “这可是个尝啄木鸟味道的好机会，”水手说，“就看它愿不愿意让我们烤一烤啦！”
en: “This will be a good opportunity to taste jacamar,” replied the sailor, “if that fellow is in a humor to be roasted!”

zh: 就在这时，少年灵巧地扔出一块石头，击中了啄木鸟的翅膀，但并没有把它打下，鸟儿迅速飞走，一转眼就消失了。
en: Just then, a stone cleverly thrown by the boy, struck the creature on the wing, but the blow did not disable it, and the jacamar ran off and disappeared in an instant.

zh: “我真笨拙！”赫伯特喊道。
en: “How clumsy I am!” cried Herbert.

zh: “不，不，孩子！”水手回答说，“你这下子扔得很准，别人兴许还打不中呢！算了，别气恼了。改天我们会逮住它的！”
en: “No, no, my boy!” replied the sailor.“The blow was well aimed; many a one would have missed it altogether!Come, don’t be vexed with yourself.We shall catch it another day!”

zh: 猎人们继续往前走，树木越来越稀疏，许多树都很漂亮，只是结的果子都不能食用。潘克洛夫寻找着一些在日常生活中用途很广的珍贵棕榈树，但徒劳无功，这种树木只能生长在北纬40度与南纬35度之间的地带。这片森林只有针叶树，比如赫伯特已经认出来的喜马拉雅雪松，类似于长在美洲西北部海岸的洋松，以及高达150英尺的冷杉。
en: As the hunters advanced, the trees were found to be more scattered, many being magnificent, but none bore eatable fruit.Pencroft searched in vain for some of those precious palm-trees which are employed in so many ways in domestic life, and which have been found as far as the fortieth parallel in the Northern Hemisphere, and to the thirty-fifth only in the Southern Hemisphere.But this forest was only composed of coniferae, such as deodaras, already recognized by Herbert, and Douglas pine, similar to those which grow on the northwest coast of America, and splendid firs, measuring a hundred and fifty feet in height.

zh: 这时飞来一群小鸟，长着漂亮的羽毛，长尾闪着光亮，随后，它们分散开来立在枝头，身子一抖，羽毛纷纷落下，仿佛为地面铺上了一层上好的鸭绒。赫伯特捡起几根羽毛，看了看——
en: At this moment a flock of birds, of a small size and pretty plumage, with long glancing tails, dispersed themselves among the branches strewing their feathers, which covered the ground as with fine down.Herbert picked up a few of these feathers, and after having examined them,—

zh: 然后说：“这些是锦鸡。”
en: “These are couroucous,” said he.

zh: “我倒宁愿是松鸡或珠鸡，”潘克洛夫说，“不过，假如它们好吃的话……”
en: “I should prefer a moor-cock or guinea-fowl,” replied Pencroft, “still, if they are good to eat—”

zh: “它们很好吃，肉质也很嫩，”赫伯特回答说，“而且，如果我没记错的话，可以很容易靠近它们，用棍子把它们打死。”
en: “They are good to eat, and also their flesh is very delicate,” replied Herbert.“Besides, if I don’t mistake, it is easy to approach and kill them with a stick.”

zh: 水手和少年爬过草丛，来到一棵树下，这棵树靠近地面的枝丫上歇满了锦鸡。它们正等着捕食爬过来的昆虫，这是它们的养料。锦鸡用它们的毛爪勾住细小的树枝，以此立在树上。
en: The sailor and the lad, creeping among the grass, arrived at the foot of a tree, whose lower branches were covered with little birds.The couroucous were waiting the passage of insects which served for their nourishment.Their feathery feet could be seen clasping the slender twigs which supported them.

zh: 此时，猎手站起身来，像使用镰刀一般挥动他们的棍子，打下一排的锦鸡，它们都没想过要飞走，就呆呆地任凭被打落在地。等到剩下的锦鸡想到要飞走时，地上已堆积了上百只。
en: The hunters then rose, and using their sticks like scythes, they mowed down whole rows of these couroucous, who never thought of flying away, and stupidly allowed themselves to be knocked off.A hundred were already heaped on the ground, before the others made up their minds to fly.

zh: “好啊！”潘克洛夫说，“这种猎物倒是很适合我们这样的猎手。我们只要伸手逮住它们就可以了。”
en: “Well,” said Pencroft, “here is game, which is quite within the reach of hunters like us.We have only to put out our hands and take it!”

zh: 水手将锦鸡穿成串，像柔软细枝上的云雀，之后他们又继续勘探。河水朝南拐了个弯，但这个弯不大，因为河水的源头肯定就在山里，由覆盖主峰的积雪融汇而成。
en: The sailor having strung the couroucous like larks on flexible twigs, they then continued their exploration.The stream here made a bend towards the south, but this detour was probably not prolonged for the river must have its source in the mountain, and be supplied by the melting of the snow which covered the sides of the central cone.

zh: 他们这次远足的特殊任务已经说过了，就是要给“石窟”的居民提供尽可能多的猎物。必须承认，到目前为止，这个任务还没有完成。因此水手还在积极搜寻，突然，有只动物窜进草丛中，他还没来得及看清是什么，便大喊起来：“要是托普在就好了！”但是托普和它的主人同时失踪了，大概他们一起死了。
en: The particular object of their expedition was, as has been said, to procure the greatest possible quantity of game for the inhabitants of the Chimneys.It must be acknowledged that as yet this object had not been attained.So the sailor actively pursued his researches, though he exclaimed, when some animal which he had not even time to recognize fled into the long grass, “If only we had had the dog Top!”But Top had disappeared at the same time as his master, and had probably perished with him.

zh: 快三点的时候，他们看见一些树上又飞来一群鸟，它们正在啄食杜松的芳香果实。突然，林子里回响起一阵喇叭似的长鸣。这种奇怪又响亮的鸣声是由一种在美国被称作松鸡的猎鸟发出来的。他们很快就看到了好几对，这种松鸡身上的羽毛是鲜艳的栗色，夹杂着深褐色的斑纹，尾巴也呈深褐色。赫伯特认得公鸟的脖子上凸起的两片像翅膀似的肉瓣。潘克洛夫打定主意至少要逮到一只松鸡，因为这种鹑鸡类动物大小和普通的鸡差不多，可肉质胜过笋鸡。不过要抓住它们却很困难，因为它们不让人靠近。试了几次，一点收获也没有，只是把松鸡给吓跑了，于是水手对少年说：
en: Towards three o’clock new flocks of birds were seen through certain trees, at whose aromatic berries they were pecking, those of the juniper-tree among others.Suddenly a loud trumpet call resounded through the forest.This strange and sonorous cry was produced by a game bird called grouse in the United States.They soon saw several couples, whose plumage was rich chestnut-brown mottled with dark brown, and tail of the same color.Herbert recognized the males by the two wing-like appendages raised on the neck.Pencroft determined to get hold of at least one of these gallinaceae, which were as large as a fowl, and whose flesh is better than that of a pullet.But it was difficult, for they would not allow themselves to be approached.After several fruitless attempts, which resulted in nothing but scaring the grouse, the sailor said to the lad,—

zh: “很显然它们飞的时候我们抓不着，那必须设法用绳子来逮了。”
en: “Decidedly, since we can’t kill them on the wing, we must try to take them with a line.”

zh: “像钓鱼一样吗？”赫伯特听了这个提议后，惊讶地叫了起来。
en: “Like a fish?” cried Herbert, much surprised at the proposal.

zh: “就像钓鱼一样。”水手非常严肃地回答道。潘克洛夫在草丛里发现六个松鸡窝，每个窝里有三四只蛋。他小心翼翼，尽量不碰到窝，因为窝的主人迟早会回来。他就打算在这些窝旁布置绳索——不是罗网，而是真正的钓线。他把赫伯特带到离松鸡窝不远的地方，在那里十分谨慎地准备好他的特殊装置，这是艾萨克·沃尔顿的弟子曾经使用过的办法。赫伯特饶有兴趣地看着他工作，虽然心里非常怀疑这能否成功。钓绳是用结实的爬藤一根接一根绑在一起的，长为15至20英尺。潘克洛夫从一棵矮小的刺槐树丛上扳下粗大坚固的倒刺，绑在爬藤的一头，当作钩子。地上爬行的红色大毛虫作为钓饵。
en: “Like a fish,” replied the sailor quite seriously.Pencroft had found among the grass half a dozen grouse nests, each having three or four eggs.He took great care not to touch these nests, to which their proprietors would not fail to return.It was around these that he meant to stretch his lines, not snares, but real fishing-lines.He took Herbert to some distance from the nests, and there prepared his singular apparatus with all the care which a disciple of Izaak Walton would have used.Herbert watched the work with great interest, though rather doubting its success.The lines were made of fine creepers, fastened one to the other, of the length of fifteen or twenty feet.Thick, strong thorns, the points bent back (which were supplied from a dwarf acacia bush) were fastened to the ends of the creepers, by way of hooks.Large red worms, which were crawling on the ground, furnished bait.

zh: 做完这些后，潘克洛夫穿过草丛，隐藏得很好，把绳子装有钩子的一头放在松鸡窝附近，然后回到原处，拿着绳子的另一端，和赫伯特一起躲在一棵大树后面。他们耐心地等在那里，不过说实话，赫伯特对潘克洛夫这项发明的成功，并没有抱太大的希望。
en: This done, Pencroft, passing among the grass and concealing himself skillfully, placed the end of his lines armed with hooks near the grouse nests; then he returned, took the other ends and hid with Herbert behind a large tree.There they both waited patiently; though, it must be said, that Herbert did not reckon much on the success of the inventive Pencroft.

zh: 整整半个小时过去了，都没什么动静，但不一会儿，不出水手所料，几只松鸡回窝里来了。它们走来走去，啄食地上的东西，丝毫没有怀疑附近有猎手，而猎手们特意躲在了松鸡的下风向。
en: A whole half-hour passed, but then, as the sailor had surmised, several couple of grouse returned to their nests.They walked along, pecking the ground, and not suspecting in any way the presence of the hunters, who, besides, had taken care to place themselves to leeward of the gallinaceae.

zh: 少年此刻感到分外有趣。他屏住呼吸，而潘克洛夫瞪着两眼，张着嘴，双唇前伸，好像他就要品尝一块松鸡肉似的，大气也不敢出。
en: The lad felt at this moment highly interested.He held his breath, and Pencroft, his eyes staring, his mouth open, his lips advanced, as if about to taste a piece of grouse, scarcely breathed.

zh: 这时，松鸡在钩子旁走来走去，丝毫没有注意到钩子。于是潘克洛夫轻轻拉了拉绳子，钓饵也微微一动，仿佛这些虫子还是活着的。
en: Meanwhile, the birds walked about the hooks, without taking any notice of them.Pencroft then gave little tugs which moved the bait as if the worms had been still alive.

zh: 水手的心情显然比钓鱼的人还激动，因为钓鱼的人看不见鱼在水中上钩的情景。绳子动了后，很快就引起了松鸡的注意，它们用嘴啄钩子。三只贪吃的松鸡同时把钓饵和钩子都吞下去了。潘克洛夫突然敏捷地把绳子一拉，松鸡扑腾着翅膀——它们被逮住了。
en: The sailor undoubtedly felt much greater anxiety than does the fisherman, for he does not see his prey coming through the water.The jerks attracted the attention of the gallinaceae, and they attacked the hooks with their beaks.Three voracious grouse swallowed at the same moment bait and hook.Suddenly with a smart jerk, Pencroft “struck” his line, and a flapping of wings showed that the birds were taken.

zh: “好哇！”他边喊边朝猎物跑去，很快就成了鸡的主人。
en: “Hurrah!” he cried, rushing towards the game, of which he made himself master in an instant.

zh: 赫伯特拍起手来。他还是第一次看见用绳子捕鸟，但水手很谦虚地说，他不是第一次这么干，而且这发明不是他的功劳。
en: Herbert clapped his hands.It was the first time that he had ever seen birds taken with a line, but the sailor modestly confessed that it was not his first attempt, and that besides he could not claim the merit of invention.

zh: “不管怎样，”他说，“以我们现在的处境，我们必须多想想其他的办法才行。”
en: “And at any rate,” added he, “situated as we are, we must hope to hit upon many other contrivances.”

zh: 他们绑住了松鸡的爪子，潘克洛夫很高兴不至于空手回去见他们的伙伴，并且看看天色也不早了，觉得最好返回住处。
en: The grouse were fastened by their claws, and Pencroft, delighted at not having to appear before their companions with empty hands, and observing that the day had begun to decline, judged it best to return to their dwelling.

zh: 这条河为他们指明了方向，他们只需顺着河走就行，快六点的时候，赫伯特和潘克洛夫由于远足而精疲力尽，回到了“石窟”。
en: The direction was indicated by the river, whose course they had only to follow, and, towards six o’clock, tired enough with their excursion, Herbert and Pencroft arrived at the Chimneys.

zh: 第七章
en: Chapter 7

zh: 吉迪恩·史佩莱双臂环抱在胸前，一动不动地站在岸边，注视着大海。海平面的东边被一团厚厚的乌云遮住了，乌云正往天的高处迅速地扩散开来。风已经刮得很猛，随着日头一点点落下，风力也愈来愈大。整个天空呈现出一幅可怕的景象，明显看得出，这是暴风雨来临的先兆。
en: Gideon Spilett was standing motionless on the shore, his arms crossed, gazing over the sea, the horizon of which was lost towards the east in a thick black cloud which was spreading rapidly towards the zenith.The wind was already strong, and increased with the decline of day.The whole sky was of a threatening aspect, and the first symptoms of a violent storm were clearly visible.

zh: 赫伯特进了“石窟”，潘克洛夫朝记者走过去。史佩莱正在凝神思考，没有注意到有人过来。
en: Herbert entered the Chimneys, and Pencroft went towards the reporter.The latter, deeply absorbed, did not see him approach.

zh: “我们要度过狂风暴雨的一晚了，史佩莱先生！”水手说，“海燕就喜欢在风雨中。”
en: “We are going to have a dirty night, Mr. Spilett!” said the sailor: “Petrels delight in wind and rain.”

zh: 记者这才转过头来，看见了潘克洛夫，第一句话就是：
en: The reporter, turning at the moment, saw Pencroft, and his first words were,—

zh: “你觉得海浪把我们的同伴卷走的时候，吊舱距海岸有多远？”
en: “At what distance from the coast would you say the car was, when the waves carried off our companion?”

zh: 水手没料到他会问这个。他想了一会儿，答道：
en: The sailor had not expected this question.He reflected an instant and replied,—

zh: “最多有两锚链长。”
en: “Two cables lengths at the most.”

zh: “那一锚链有多远？”吉迪恩·史佩莱问。
en: “But what is a cable’s length?” asked Gideon Spilett.

zh: “大概有120寻，就是600英尺吧。”
en: “About a hundred and twenty fathoms, or six hundred feet.”

zh: “那么，”记者说，“赛勒斯·哈丁消失的地方离海岸至多有1200英尺了？”
en: “Then,” said the reporter, “Cyrus Harding must have disappeared twelve hundred feet at the most from the shore?”

zh: “差不多吧。”潘克洛夫回答道。
en: “About that,” replied Pencroft.

zh: “那他的狗也是吧？”
en: “And his dog also?”
“Also.”

zh: “我感到吃惊的是，”记者接着说，“虽然承认我们的同伴死了，托普也死了，怎么狗和它主人的尸体都没有被冲到海岸上呢？”
en: “What astonishes me,” rejoined the reporter, “while admitting that our companion has perished, is that Top has also met his death, and that neither the body of the dog nor of his master has been cast on the shore!”

zh: “海浪这么大，这也没什么奇怪的。”水手答道，“况且，也可能海浪沿着海岸向下，把他们卷到更远的地方去了。”
en: “It is not astonishing, with such a heavy sea,” replied the sailor.“Besides, it is possible that currents have carried them farther down the coast.”

zh: “那么，在你看来，我们的朋友已经死在大海里了吗？”记者又问道。
en: “Then, it is your opinion that our friend has perished in the waves?” again asked the reporter.

zh: “我想是这样。”
en: “That is my opinion.”

zh: 吉迪恩·史佩莱听了说：“潘克洛夫，虽然我佩服你的经验，但我觉得，在赛勒斯和托普一起彻底失踪这件事上，不管他们现在是死是活，都有点不可思议，不太可能。”
en: “My own opinion,” said Gideon Spilett, “with due deference to your experience, Pencroft, is that in the double fact of the absolute disappearance of Cyrus and Top, living or dead, there is something unaccountable and unlikely.”

zh: “我真希望我也能像你这么想，史佩莱先生，”潘克洛夫回答，“不幸的是，在这个问题上，我的想法已经不会改变了。”说完，水手回“石窟”了。炉架上的大火烧得噼里啪啦地响。赫伯特刚刚往上面扔了一抱干木柴，火焰发出的光就把通道里最暗的地方都照得通红。
en: “I wish I could think like you, Mr. Spilett,” replied Pencroft; “unhappily, my mind is made up on this point.”Having said this, the sailor returned to the Chimneys.A good fire crackled on the hearth.Herbert had just thrown on an armful of dry wood, and the flame cast a bright light into the darkest parts of the passage.

zh: 潘克洛夫立马开始准备晚饭。大伙都需要增强体力，所以，要是能添一些充饥的食物，似乎再好不过了。他们把穿成串的锦鸡留到明天吃，给一对松鸡拔了毛，很快就叉在木棍上，放在熊熊的火焰上烤着。
en: Pencroft immediately began to prepare the dinner.It appeared best to introduce something solid into the bill of fare, for all needed to get up their strength.The strings of couroucous were kept for the next day, but they plucked a couple of grouse, which were soon spitted on a stick, and roasting before a blazing fire.

zh: 晚上七点钟时，纳布还没有回来。黑人这么长时间都不在，潘克洛夫很担心他。他担心黑人可能在这片未知的岛上遭遇了什么意外，或者这个伤心的家伙因为绝望，做了什么傻事。不过，赫伯特得出的结论却大不相同。他觉得，纳布之所以这么晚还没回来，是因为发现了一些新情况，这才引着他继续寻找下去。而且，任何新情况都肯定对赛勒斯·哈丁有利。除非是有希望引着纳布继续寻找下去，要不他为什么还不回来？或许他发现了什么标记，一串脚印，或者某种痕迹，正领着他往对的地方去。他可能此刻正往某个地方去。甚至可能离他的主人没几步了。
en: At seven in the evening Neb had not returned.The prolonged absence of the Negro made Pencroft very uneasy.It was to be feared that he had met with an accident on this unknown land, or that the unhappy fellow had been driven to some act of despair.But Herbert drew very different conclusions from this absence.According to him, Neb’s delay was caused by some new circumstances which had induced him to prolong his search.Also, everything new must be to the advantage of Cyrus Harding.Why had Neb not returned unless hope still detained him?Perhaps he had found some mark, a footstep, a trace which had put him in the right path.Perhaps he was at this moment on a certain track.Perhaps even he was near his master.

zh: 孩子这般推测着。然后说出自己的想法。他的同伴们听着他讲。只有记者一个人打了个手势，表示赞同。但是，潘克洛夫认为最有可能的是，纳布在海岸上的搜寻范围比昨天还要远，因此才没有时间赶回来。
en: Thus the lad reasoned.Thus he spoke.His companions let him talk.The reporter alone approved with a gesture.But what Pencroft thought most probable was, that Neb had pushed his researches on the shore farther than the day before, and that he had not as yet had time to return.

zh: 赫伯特被一种说不清的预感搅得心神不宁，几次表示要出去寻找纳布。但潘克洛夫使他确信，这是做无用功，外面一片漆黑，天气恶劣，他不可能寻到纳布的踪迹，最好还是等着。要是纳布第二天还没回来的话，潘克洛夫会毫不犹豫地和他一起出去搜寻。
en: Herbert, however, agitated by vague presentiments, several times manifested an intention to go to meet Neb.But Pencroft assured him that that would be a useless course, that in the darkness and deplorable weather he could not find any traces of Neb, and that it would be much better to wait.If Neb had not made his appearance by the next day, Pencroft would not hesitate to join him in his search.

zh: 吉迪恩·史佩莱同意水手的观点，认为大家最好还是不要分开，赫伯特应该被迫放弃他的计划，但两颗大大的泪珠却从他的眼中流了下来。
en: Gideon Spilett approved of the sailor’s opinion that it was best not to divide, and Herbert was obliged to give up his project; but two large tears fell from his eyes.

zh: 记者情不自禁地将这个善良的孩子搂在怀里。
en: The reporter could not refrain from embracing the generous boy.

zh: 天气现在变坏了。东南方刮来的一阵强风，扫荡了海岸。大海咆哮着，捶打着礁石。倾盆大雨被狂风冲撞着，好似漫天灰粒。一大团激起的水汽沿着海岸长驱直下，岸边的砾石痛苦地发出哗啦啦的声响，仿佛被一大车一大车往外倾倒似的。大风卷起砂石，像是在水中掺进了矿质的尘土，这种联合袭击实在让人难以承受。在河口和峭壁底端之间，风如漩涡般回旋着，大风抽打着狭窄峡谷间的流水。“石窟”中冒出的烟也通过缝隙倒灌进来，填满了通道，让人在里面呆不下去。
en: Bad weather now set in.A furious gale from the southeast passed over the coast.The sea roared as it beat over the reef.Heavy rain was dashed by the storm into particles like dust.Ragged masses of vapor drove along the beach, on which the tormented shingles sounded as if poured out in cart-loads, while the sand raised by the wind added as it were mineral dust to that which was liquid, and rendered the united attack insupportable.Between the river’s mouth and the end of the cliff, eddies of wind whirled and gusts from this maelstrom lashed the water which ran through the narrow valley.The smoke from the fireplace was also driven back through the opening, filling the passages and rendering them uninhabitable.

zh: 因此，松鸡烤好后，潘克洛夫就让把火灭了，只把几块木炭埋在了灰烬下面。
en: Therefore, as the grouse were cooked, Pencroft let the fire die away, and only preserved a few embers buried under the ashes.

zh: 到了八点，纳布依然没有回来。不过，毫无疑问，单是这可怕的天气，就能将他拦挡在外头了，他一定在哪个山洞里避着，打算等到暴风雨停了，或至少第二天再回来。现在去接他，或是到外面找找他，都是不可能的。
en: At eight o’clock Neb had not appeared, but there was no doubt that the frightful weather alone hindered his return, and that he must have taken refuge in some cave, to await the end of the storm or at least the return of day.As to going to meet him, or attempting to find him, it was impossible.

zh: 松鸡是晚餐上唯一的菜，肉很鲜美。潘克洛夫和赫伯特经过了一天的长途跋涉，都饿极了，无比满足地狼吞虎咽。
en: The game constituted the only dish at supper; the meat was excellent, and Pencroft and Herbert, whose long excursion had rendered them very hungry, devoured it with infinite satisfaction.

zh: 吃完晚饭，每个人都回到自己前一天晚上歇息的角落睡觉。水手四仰八叉地躺在火堆旁边，赫伯特紧挨着他，很快就睡着了。
en: Their meal concluded, each retired to the corner in which he had rested the preceding night, and Herbert was not long in going to sleep near the sailor, who had stretched himself beside the fireplace.

zh: 外面，夜慢慢变深，暴风雨也更大了，最后变得跟把这群俘虏从里士满带到这个太平洋小岛上来的情况差不多了。春秋分时常有暴风雨，而且这种天气经常会带来大的灾难，在这一望无际的海洋上，它们肆无忌惮地咆哮着，因此显得尤为可怕。当狂风拍打在毫不设防的海滩上时，那种可怕的力量简直难以形容。
en: Outside, as the night advanced, the tempest also increased in strength, until it was equal to that which had carried the prisoners from Richmond to this land in the Pacific.The tempests which are frequent during the seasons of the equinox, and which are so prolific in catastrophes, are above all terrible over this immense ocean, which opposes no obstacle to their fury.No description can give an idea of the terrific violence of the gale as it beat upon the unprotected coast.

zh: 令人高兴的是，构成“石窟”的岩石很坚固。整个“石窟”由巨大的花岗岩石构成，其中有几块不大牢固，似乎在底部颤动。潘克洛夫把头枕在石块上时，可以感觉到头底下快速的震动。不过，他不停地劝慰自己——也有道理——没什么可怕的，他们的避难所不会倒塌的。然而，他听到高地的顶上有石头被风刮走，噼里啪啦地落在了海岸上。有几块甚至滚到了“石窟”的顶上，还有的被风直上直下地扔下去，七零八碎地四下乱飞。水手两次爬起来，借助通道的入口处挡住身子，好在安全处看一眼外面的情况。这些从天而降的“石块阵雨”并没有多少，用不着害怕，因此他又回到火堆前躺下，灰烬下的木炭还在发着红光。
en: Happily the pile of rocks which formed the Chimneys was solid.It was composed of enormous blocks of granite, a few of which, insecurely balanced, seemed to tremble on their foundations, and Pencroft could feel rapid quiverings under his head as it rested on the rock.But he repeated to himself, and rightly, that there was nothing to fear, and that their retreat would not give way.However he heard the noise of stones torn from the summit of the plateau by the wind, falling down on to the beach.A few even rolled on to the upper part of the Chimneys, or flew off in fragments when they were projected perpendicularly.Twice the sailor rose and intrenched himself at the opening of the passage, so as to take a look in safety at the outside.But there was nothing to be feared from these showers, which were not considerable, and he returned to his couch before the fireplace, where the embers glowed beneath the ashes.

zh: 尽管外头狂风暴雨在咆哮，雷声隆隆，赫伯特还是睡得很熟。潘克洛夫最后也终于睡着了，水手生涯使他对一切都习以为常。只有吉迪恩·史佩莱因为担忧一直醒着。他责备自己没有跟纳布一起去。显然他还没有放弃所有希望。让赫伯特心神不宁的预感也同样使他担心不已。他现在满脑子想的都是纳布。纳布怎么还没回来？他在自己的沙床上辗转反侧，几乎完全没理会外面的狂风暴雨。有时，他会合上因疲劳而沉重的眼皮，但不一会儿，就会因为某个突然闪现的念头，马上又睁开眼睛。
en: Notwithstanding the fury of the hurricane, the uproar of the tempest, the thunder, and the tumult, Herbert slept profoundly.Sleep at last took possession of Pencroft, whom a seafaring life had habituated to anything.Gideon Spilett alone was kept awake by anxiety.He reproached himself with not having accompanied Neb.It was evident that he had not abandoned all hope.The presentiments which had troubled Herbert did not cease to agitate him also.His thoughts were concentrated on Neb.Why had Neb not returned?He tossed about on his sandy couch, scarcely giving a thought to the struggle of the elements.Now and then, his eyes, heavy with fatigue, closed for an instant, but some sudden thought reopened them almost immediately.

zh: 夜色越来越浓了。离天亮差不多有两个钟头的时候，还在呼呼大睡的潘克洛夫被猛烈摇醒了。
en: Meanwhile the night advanced, and it was perhaps two hours from morning, when Pencroft, then sound asleep, was vigorously shaken.

zh: “怎么了？”他醒过来，叫道,以水手素有的敏捷恢复了神志。
en: “What’s the matter?” he cried, rousing himself, and collecting his ideas with the promptitude usual to seamen.

zh: 记者正俯着身子，对他说：
en: The reporter was leaning over him, and saying,—

zh: “听，潘克洛夫，听！”
en: “Listen, Pencroft, listen!”

zh: 水手努力张开耳朵，但是除了暴风雨的声音，什么也听不到。
en: The sailor strained his ears, but could hear no noise beyond those caused by the storm.

zh: “是风声。”他说。
en: “It is the wind,” said he.

zh: “不是，”吉迪恩·史佩莱回答，又听了听，“我想我听见了……”
en: “No,” replied Gideon Spilett, listening again, “I thought I heard—”

zh: “什么？”
en: “What?”

zh: “狗叫声！”
en: “The barking of a dog!”

zh: “狗！”潘克洛夫跳起来，喊道。
en: “A dog!” cried Pencroft, springing up.

zh: “是的，狗在叫。”
en: “Yes—barking—”

zh: “不可能！”水手回答，“何况是在咆哮的暴风雨里。”
en: “It’s not possible!” replied the sailor.“And besides, how, in the roaring of the storm—”

zh: “等一下，你听。”记者又说。
en: “Stop—listen—” said the reporter.

zh: 潘克洛夫又更加仔细地听了一会儿，在风雨间歇的片刻，他觉得真的听见了远远的狗叫声。
en: Pencroft listened more attentively, and really thought he heard, during a lull, distant barking.

zh: “太好了！”记者说，使劲握了握潘克洛夫的手。
en: “Well!” said the reporter, pressing the sailor’s hand.

zh: “是……是啊！”潘克洛夫回答。
en: “Yes—yes!” replied Pencroft.

zh: “是托普！是托普！”刚刚醒来的赫伯特喊着，三个人一起冲到“石窟”的入口处。他们要出去实在是太困难了。狂风直把他们往后推。最后，三个人终于出来了，可也只能把身体靠在岩石上，才能站立。他们四处张望着，但无法张嘴说话。天色非常暗。大海、天空和陆地全都变成黑漆漆的一团，看不到一丝光亮。
en: “It is Top!It is Top!” cried Herbert, who had just awoke; and all three rushed towards the opening of the Chimneys.They had great difficulty in getting out.The wind drove them back.But at last they succeeded, and could only remain standing by leaning against the rocks.They looked about, but could not speak.The darkness was intense.The sea, the sky, the land were all mingled in one black mass.Not a speck of light was visible.

zh: 记者和同伴们这样站了几分钟，狂风堵住了他们的去路，他们浑身都被雨水淋透了，视线被沙子挡住了。
en: The reporter and his companions remained thus for a few minutes, overwhelmed by the wind, drenched by the rain, blinded by the sand.

zh: 然后，在风雨声稍小的时候，他们又听到了狗叫声，断定声音离这里还有一段距离。
en: Then, in a pause of the tumult, they again heard the barking, which they found must be at some distance.

zh: 肯定是托普！不过是只有托普自己，还是有人和它一起呢？很可能只有托普自己，因为，如果纳布在旁边，肯定会直接朝“石窟”这边来的。因为同伴无法听见他说话，水手使劲捏了一下记者的手，意思是让他“等一下”，然后转身又进了通道。
en: It could only be Top!But was he alone or accompanied?He was most probably alone, for, if Neb had been with him, he would have made his way more directly towards the Chimneys.The sailor squeezed the reporter’s hand, for he could not make himself heard, in a way which signified “Wait!” then he reentered the passage.

zh: 不一会儿，他拿着一束点燃的木柴出来了，然后把木柴扔进黑暗里，响亮地吹了一声口哨。
en: An instant after he issued with a lighted fagot, which he threw into the darkness, whistling shrilly.

zh: 似乎远处一直在等待这个信号，瞬时间狗叫声越来越近了，不一会儿，一只狗冲进了通道。潘克洛夫、赫伯特和史佩莱跟在它后头进来了。
en: It appeared as if this signal had been waited for; the barking immediately came nearer, and soon a dog bounded into the passage.Pencroft, Herbert, and Spilett entered after him.

zh: 他们往火炭上加了一抱干木柴，整个通道都被熊熊火焰照亮了。
en: An armful of dry wood was thrown on the embers.The passage was lighted up with a bright flame.

zh: “是托普！”赫伯特喊道。
en: “It is Top!” cried Herbert.

zh: 真的是托普，一只漂亮的盎格鲁-诺曼杂种狗，它从祖先身上同时继承了速度敏捷、嗅觉灵敏的优点，这些都是猎狗最优秀的特质。它的主人就是工程师——赛勒斯·哈丁先生。可是，现在只有它自己！纳布和他的主人都没有和它在一起！
en: It was indeed Top, a magnificent Anglo-Norman, who derived from these two races crossed the swiftness of foot and the acuteness of smell which are the preeminent qualities of coursing dogs.It was the dog of the engineer, Cyrus Harding.But he was alone!Neither Neb nor his master accompanied him!

zh: 它的直觉是怎么直接把它引到“石窟”来的？它可不知道这个地方。特别是，外头这么黑，还刮着暴风雨，这似乎太难以解释了！但更令人无法解释的是，托普不累，也不疲惫，全身甚至被泥或沙子弄脏！赫伯特唤它到身边来，拍着它的头，托普把脖子轻轻地在孩子的手上摩挲着。
en: How was it that his instinct had guided him straight to the Chimneys, which he did not know?It appeared inexplicable, above all, in the midst of this black night and in such a tempest!But what was still more inexplicable was, that Top was neither tired, nor exhausted, nor even soiled with mud or sand!—Herbert had drawn him towards him, and was patting his head, the dog rubbing his neck against the lad’s hands.

zh: “狗找到了，狗的主人也可以找到！”记者说。
en: “If the dog is found, the master will be found also!” said the reporter.

zh: “上帝保佑！”赫伯特回答，“我们出发吧！托普会为我们领路的！”
en: “God grant it!” responded Herbert.“Let us set off!Top will guide us!”

zh: 潘克洛夫没有反对。他觉得，托普的到来推翻了他的猜测。“那就走吧！”他说道。
en: Pencroft did not make any objection.He felt that Top’s arrival contradicted his conjectures.“Come along then!” said he.

zh: 潘克洛夫小心地把炉架上的木炭盖好。又往里加了几块木柴，好让火能一直维持到他们回来的时候。然后，托普走在前面，急急地叫了几声，似乎在邀请大伙跟着它走，潘克洛夫用手帕把剩下的晚餐包好，跟着狗冲了出去，记者和孩子跟在后面。
en: Pencroft carefully covered the embers on the hearth.He placed a few pieces of wood among them, so as to keep in the fire until their return.Then, preceded by the dog, who seemed to invite them by short barks to come with him, and followed by the reporter and the boy, he dashed out, after having put up in his handkerchief the remains of the supper.

zh: 暴风雨此刻凶猛无比，可能正是最厉害的时候。透过云层，看不见一丝月光。想直线前进是不可能的。最好是依靠托普的直觉了。他们这样做了。记者和赫伯特紧跟在狗的后面，水手走在最末。三个人之间不可能说话。虽说雨并不太大，风还是很猛烈。
en: The storm was then in all its violence, and perhaps at its height.Not a single ray of light from the moon pierced through the clouds.To follow a straight course was difficult.It was best to rely on Top’s instinct.They did so.The reporter and Herbert walked behind the dog, and the sailor brought up the rear.It was impossible to exchange a word.The rain was not very heavy, but the wind was terrific.

zh: 不过，有一件事情倒是对水手和他的同伴们有利。风是从东南方向吹来的，这样一来，就吹在他们的后背上。如果风从相反方向吹来，扬起的沙尘会让他们难以承受，但吹在背后，就不会阻碍他们的进程。简而言之，他们有时不由自主地快步走，要稳住脚步都很困难，然而希望赋予了他们力量，因为，这一次他们在海岸前行有了清晰的目标。他们毫不怀疑纳布已经找到了主人，他才打发这条忠实的狗来找他们。可是工程师还活着吗？还是纳布只是把同伴们叫来，使他们能给不幸的哈丁遗体尽上最后一份职责？
en: However, one circumstance favored the seaman and his two companions.The wind being southeast, consequently blew on their backs.The clouds of sand, which otherwise would have been insupportable, from being received behind, did not in consequence impede their progress.In short, they sometimes went faster than they liked, and had some difficulty in keeping their feet; but hope gave them strength, for it was not at random that they made their way along the shore.They had no doubt that Neb had found his master, and that he had sent them the faithful dog.But was the engineer living, or had Neb only sent for his companions that they might render the last duties to the corpse of the unfortunate Harding?

zh: 过了悬崖，赫伯特、记者和潘克洛夫都小心翼翼地站到一边，停下来喘息。岩石的拐角为他们挡住了狂风，。经过了这段跋涉，更准确地说是15分钟的奔跑，他们终于可以喘口气了。
en: After having passed the precipice, Herbert, the reporter, and Pencroft prudently stepped aside to stop and take breath.The turn of the rocks sheltered them from the wind, and they could breathe after this walk or rather run of a quarter of an hour.

zh: 他们现在可以听到对方说话，也可以作出回应了。孩子刚提到“赛勒斯·哈丁”的名字，托普就发出几声短促的叫声，好像在说它的主人已经获救了。
en: They could now hear and reply to each other, and the lad having pronounced the name of Cyrus Harding, Top gave a few short barks, as much as to say that his master was saved.

zh: “他得救了，不是吗？”赫伯特反复说着，“是不是得救了，托普？”
en: “Saved, isn’t he?” repeated Herbert; “saved, Top?”

zh: 托普叫了几声，表示回答。
en: And the dog barked in reply.

zh: 他们再一次出发了。海水开始涨潮，在狂风的推动下，潮水可能涨得异乎寻常的高，这是春潮了。滔天巨浪发出轰隆声，如此狠劲地拍打着礁石，以至于整个小岛好像都被淹没了，在此刻他们完全看不见。海岸不再有防波堤保护，直接暴露在大海的袭击之下。
en: They once more set out.The tide began to rise, and urged by the wind it threatened to be unusually high, as it was a spring tide.Great billows thundered against the reef with such violence that they probably passed entirely over the islet, then quite invisible.The mole no longer protected the coast, which was directly exposed to the attacks of the open sea.

zh: 水手和同伴们刚一离开悬崖，狂风卷土重来，对他们又展开了攻势。尽管被风吹得弯下了腰，他们还是走得很快，托普在前面，没有犹豫往哪个方向走。
en: As soon as the sailor and his companions left the precipice, the wind struck them again with renewed fury.Though bent under the gale they walked very quickly, following Top, who did not hesitate as to what direction to take.

zh: 他们往北边走去，左边是无边无际的滔滔巨浪，发出震耳欲聋的响声，右边是一片漆黑的陆地，猜不出是什么样子。但他们觉得这块土地相对平坦，因为风完全从他们头顶上吹过，没有像吹到悬崖那样又折回来。
en: They ascended towards the north, having on their left an interminable extent of billows, which broke with a deafening noise, and on their right a dark country, the aspect of which it was impossible to guess.But they felt that it was comparatively flat, for the wind passed completely over them, without being driven back as it was when it came in contact with the cliff.

zh: 早上四点钟的时候，他们估算大概已经走了五英里路。云稍稍上升了，风不那么潮湿了，但依然凛冽、寒冷。因为身上的衣物不够防寒，潘克洛夫、赫伯特和史佩莱都冻得难受，但谁也没抱怨一声。他们决定就跟在托普后面，不管这个机灵的畜生想把他们领到什么地方。
en: At four o’clock in the morning, they reckoned that they had cleared about five miles.The clouds were slightly raised, and the wind, though less damp, was very sharp and cold.Insufficiently protected by their clothing, Pencroft, Herbert and Spilett suffered cruelly, but not a complaint escaped their lips.They were determined to follow Top, wherever the intelligent animal wished to lead them.

zh: 将近五点的时候，天开始亮了。头顶上的雾相对较薄，云周围有一道道阴影。在一片晦暗的天空下，一道亮光清楚地将地平线标志出来。巨浪的尖顶上闪烁着强烈的白光，泡沫又重新变成白花花的。同时，左边丘陵状的海岸也看得见了，虽然不是很清楚。
en: Towards five o’clock day began to break.At the zenith, where the fog was less thick, gray shades bordered the clouds; under an opaque belt, a luminous line clearly traced the horizon.The crests of the billows were tipped with a wild light, and the foam regained its whiteness.At the same time on the left the hilly parts of the coast could be seen, though very indistinctly.

zh: 六点时，天已经完全亮了。云层迅速上升。水手和同伴们此时已经离“石窟”约有六英里了。他们现在正沿着平坦的海岸前进，边界上是礁石，几乎没有露出水面，因为它们在深深的海水里。左边的陆地看起来像一大片广阔的沙丘，蓟草林立。这里没有悬崖，除了一连串形状不规则的小丘外，海岸上没有任何屏障。不时会冒出两三棵树，一律朝西倾斜着，它们的枝丫也朝着这个方向伸展。在西南方向，森林的边缘伸向很远的地方。
en: At six o’clock day had broken.The clouds rapidly lifted.The seaman and his companions were then about six miles from the Chimneys.They were following a very flat shore bounded by a reef of rocks, whose heads scarcely emerged from the sea, for they were in deep water.On the left, the country appeared to be one vast extent of sandy downs, bristling with thistles.There was no cliff, and the shore offered no resistance to the ocean but a chain of irregular hillocks.Here and there grew two or three trees, inclined towards the west, their branches projecting in that direction.Quite behind, in the southwest, extended the border of the forest.

zh: 这时，托普变得非常兴奋。它跑到前面，又折回来，像是在请求大伙加快脚步。然后，它离开了海滩，靠着非凡的直觉，毫不迟疑地径直跑进了那片沙丘。他们跟在后面。这一带好似荒漠一般。看不见一个生灵。
en: At this moment, Top became very excited.He ran forward, then returned, and seemed to entreat them to hasten their steps.The dog then left the beach, and guided by his wonderful instinct, without showing the least hesitation, went straight in among the downs.They followed him.The country appeared an absolute desert.Not a living creature was to be seen.

zh: 这片沙丘面积很大，杂乱无章地分布着小丘，甚至还有小山。整片地形像瑞士在沙中的模型，也只有具备令人惊叹的直觉才可能找到路。
en: The downs, the extent of which was large, were composed of hillocks and even of hills, very irregularly distributed.They resembled a Switzerland modeled in sand, and only an amazing instinct could have possibly recognized the way.

zh: 离开海岸五分钟后，记者和两个同伴到了一个类似山洞的地方，这是从一个很高的土堆后面挖空的。托普在这里停住了，发出清楚、响亮的叫声。史佩莱、赫伯特和潘克洛夫冲进了山洞。
en: Five minutes after having left the beach, the reporter and his two companions arrived at a sort of excavation, hollowed out at the back of a high mound.There Top stopped, and gave a loud, clear bark.Spilett, Herbert, and Pencroft dashed into the cave.

zh: 一个人直挺挺地躺在草席上，纳布正跪在旁边。
en: Neb was there, kneeling beside a body extended on a bed of grass.

zh: 那人正是工程师——赛勒斯·哈丁。
en: The body was that of the engineer, Cyrus Harding.

zh: 第八章
en: Chapter 8

zh: 纳布一动不动。潘克洛夫只大声地问了一句。
en: Neb did not move.Pencroft only uttered one word.

zh: “还活着？”他喊道。
en: “Living?” he cried.

zh: 纳布没有回答他。史佩莱和水手的脸色顿时变得惨白。赫伯特紧握双手，呆呆地站在那里。可怜的黑人陷入极度的悲痛之中，显然没有看见他的同伴，也没有听见水手的话。
en: Neb did not reply.Spilett and the sailor turned pale.Herbert clasped his hands, and remained motionless.The poor Negro, absorbed in his grief, evidently had neither seen his companions nor heard the sailor speak.

zh: 记者跪在工程师一动不动的身体旁边，先解开他的衣服，然后把耳朵贴在他的胸前。
en: The reporter knelt down beside the motionless body, and placed his ear to the engineer’s chest, having first torn open his clothes.

zh: 一分钟过去了，好像一个世纪那么漫长！在这期间，他努力听着，想听到哪怕是极其微弱的心跳。
en: A minute—an age!—passed, during which he endeavored to catch the faintest throb of the heart.

zh: 纳布微微站直了身子，凝视了片刻，却什么也没有看见。绝望完全改变了他的面容。纳布筋疲力尽，伤心欲绝，人们几乎认不出他了。他以为他的主人已经死了。
en: Neb had raised himself a little and gazed without seeing.Despair had completely changed his countenance.He could scarcely be recognized, exhausted with fatigue, broken with grief.He believed his master was dead.

zh: 经过一番长时间的仔细检查之后，吉丁·史佩莱终于站了起来。
en: Gideon Spilett at last rose, after a long and attentive examination.

zh: “还活着！”他说。
en: “He lives!” said he.

zh: 潘克洛夫赶紧跪到工程师旁边，他也听到了心跳声，他的脸颊甚至还感觉到微弱的呼吸。
en: Pencroft knelt in his turn beside the engineer, he also heard a throbbing, and even felt a slight breath on his cheek.

zh: 赫伯特听到记者的话后，跑出去找水。他在100英尺外发现了一条清澈的小溪，似乎是因为下雨，水上涨了很多，沙粒把溪水过滤得干干净净。但是他找不到容器来装水，沙丘上甚至连一个贝壳都没有。男孩只好把他的手帕浸泡在溪水里，然后捧着手帕急速地跑回山洞。
en: Herbert at a word from the reporter ran out to look for water.He found, a hundred feet off, a limpid stream, which seemed to have been greatly increased by the rains, and which filtered through the sand; but nothing in which to put the water, not even a shell among the downs.The lad was obliged to content himself with dipping his handkerchief in the stream, and with it hastened back to the grotto.

zh: 好在湿手帕足够吉丁·史佩莱用的了，他只想把工程师的嘴唇润湿。冷水几乎立刻就产生了作用。工程师的胸部开始上下起伏，似乎有话要说。
en: Happily the wet handkerchief was enough for Gideon Spilett, who only wished to wet the engineer’s lips.The cold water produced an almost immediate effect.His chest heaved and he seemed to try to speak.

zh: “我们必须要救活他！”记者大声地说。
en: “We will save him!” exclaimed the reporter.

zh: 听了这句话，纳布心里的希望又振奋起来。他解开了主人的衣服，检查他是否受伤。令人奇怪的是，他的头部、躯干和四肢都找不到一点伤痕。原以为他一定是撞在了石头上，可是连他的手都没有受伤，这就很难解释他是怎么到达破浪拍打不到的地方，而身上没有一点痕迹。
en: At these words hope revived in Neb’s heart.He undressed his master to see if he was wounded, but not so much as a bruise was to be found, either on the head, body, or limbs, which was surprising, as he must have been dashed against the rocks; even the hands were uninjured, and it was difficult to explain how the engineer showed no traces of the efforts which he must have made to get out of reach of the breakers.

zh: 不过他们之后就能知道答案。等赛勒斯能说话的时候，他会告诉大家发生了什么。现在的问题是怎样才能使他苏醒过来，看上去按摩可能起到这种效果，于是他们开始用水手的运动衫给他按摩。
en: But the explanation would come later.When Cyrus was able to speak he would say what had happened.For the present the question was, how to recall him to life, and it appeared likely that rubbing would bring this about; so they set to work with the sailor’s jersey.

zh: 经过剧烈的按摩，工程师苏醒了，他微微地动了下胳膊，呼吸也逐渐恢复正常。他由于筋疲力竭，有些虚脱。可以肯定的是，要不是记者和他的同伴们及时赶到，赛勒斯·哈丁就活不过来了。
en: The engineer, revived by this rude shampooing, moved his arm slightly and began to breathe more regularly.He was sinking from exhaustion, and certainly, had not the reporter and his companions arrived, it would have been all over with Cyrus Harding.

zh: “你以为你的主人死了，是不是？”水手对纳布说。
en: “You thought your master was dead, didn’t you?” said the seaman to Neb.

zh: “是的！我以为他死了！”纳布答道，“要不是托普找到了你们，并把你们带到这里，我应该已经把主人埋了，然后死在他的坟上了！”
en: “Yes! quite dead!” replied Neb, “and if Top had not found you, and brought you here, I should have buried my master, and then have lain down on his grave to die!”

zh: 对于赛勒斯·哈丁来说，这可真是死里逃生！
en: It had indeed been a narrow escape for Cyrus Harding!

zh: 于是纳布讲述了事情的经过。前一天的黎明时分，他离开了“石窟”，沿着海岸朝北方的高处走，一直走到他曾经去过的那一带海岸。
en: Neb then recounted what had happened.The day before, after having left the Chimneys at daybreak, he had ascended the coast in a northerly direction, and had reached that part of the shore which he had already visited.

zh: 纳布承认，他在那里没有抱任何希望，找遍了海岸、岩石堆和沙滩，只为得到能引导他的一点点线索。他尤为仔细地检查了那些涨潮时海水冲不到的地方，因为靠海的一带，潮水总是会把所有的痕迹都冲刷掉。纳布并没有指望能找到活着的主人。他只想找到主人的遗骸，好亲手安葬他！
en: There, without any hope he acknowledged, Neb had searched the beach, among the rocks, on the sand, for the smallest trace to guide him.He examined particularly that part of the beach which was not covered by the high tide, for near the sea the water would have obliterated all marks.Neb did not expect to find his master living.It was for a corpse that he searched, a corpse which he wished to bury with his own hands!

zh: 他找了很久，没有一点结果。这片荒凉的海岸好像从来没有人类到访的痕迹。海水冲不到的高水位线处，布满了成百万的贝壳，都没有被人碰过。没有一个贝壳是破损的。
en: He sought long in vain.This desert coast appeared never to have been visited by a human creature.The shells, those which the sea had not reached, and which might be met with by millions above high-water mark, were untouched.Not a shell was broken.

zh: 于是纳布决定沿着海岸再走几英里。可能海浪把尸体冲到很远的地方去了。通常，如果尸体在低海岸附近漂着的话，迟早会被潮水卷到岸上来。纳布清楚这一点，他希望能和他的主人见上最后一面。
en: Neb then resolved to walk along the beach for some miles.It was possible that the waves had carried the body to quite a distant point.When a corpse floats a little distance from a low shore, it rarely happens that the tide does not throw it up, sooner or later.This Neb knew, and he wished to see his master again for the last time.

zh: “我沿着海岸又走了两英里，无论是高水位处还是低水位处，我都仔细地检查了一遍，但是一无所获，我已经绝望了。可就在昨天晚上五点钟左右，我看见沙滩上有脚印。”
en: “I went along the coast for another two miles, carefully examining the beach, both at high and low water, and I had despaired of finding anything, when yesterday, above five in the evening, I saw footprints on the sand.”

zh: “脚印？”潘克洛夫大声地说。
en: “Footprints?” exclaimed Pencroft.

zh: “是的！”纳布答道。
en: “Yes!” replied Neb.

zh: “这些脚印是从水边开始的吗？”记者问。
en: “Did these footprints begin at the water’s edge?” asked the reporter.

zh: “不是，”纳布回答，“都在高水位线附近之上，其他的肯定都被潮水冲掉了。”
en: “No,” replied Neb, “only above high-water mark, for the others must have been washed out by the tide.”

zh: “接着说吧，纳布。”史佩莱说。
en: “Go on, Neb,” said Spilett.

zh: “看见这些脚印，我简直快要乐疯了。脚印非常清晰，一直到沙丘那边。我顺着脚印跑了四分之一英里，并留心不要破坏了它们。五分钟之后，天渐渐地黑了，我听见了狗的叫声。是托普，是它把我带到了这里，带到了我的主人身边！”
en: “I went half crazy when I saw these footprints.They were very clear and went towards the downs.I followed them for a quarter of a mile, running, but taking care not to destroy them.Five minutes after, as it was getting dark, I heard the barking of a dog.It was Top, and Top brought me here, to my master!”

zh: 纳布最后说道，他找到这个毫无生气的躯体时是多么悲伤，他看来看去也没有发现任何生命的迹象。既然他找到主人的尸体，他希望主人能活着。他所有的努力都白费了。什么都做不了，他只有对这个他如此深爱的人尽自己最后的一次责任！这时纳布想起了他的同伴们。毫无疑问，他们肯定希望再看一眼这个不幸的人。托普就在那里。难道他信不过这个忠实的牲畜的智慧吗？纳布把记者的名字反复说了几遍，在他所有的同伴之中，托普最熟悉的就是通讯记者。
en: Neb ended his account by saying what had been his grief at finding the inanimate body, in which he vainly sought for the least sign of life.Now that he had found him dead he longed for him to be alive.All his efforts were useless!Nothing remained to be done but to render the last duties to the one whom he had loved so much!Neb then thought of his companions.They, no doubt, would wish to see the unfortunate man again.Top was there.Could he not rely on the sagacity of the faithful animal?Neb several times pronounced the name of the reporter, the one among his companions whom Top knew best.

zh: 然后，他伸手指向南方，托普便朝着他指的方向跑去。
en: Then he pointed to the south, and the dog bounded off in the direction indicated to him.

zh: 我们已经知道，托普是如何凭着它那被认为是不可思议的直觉找到他们的。
en: We have heard how, guided by an instinct which might be looked upon almost as supernatural, Top had found them.

zh: 纳布的同伴们聚精会神地听着他的描述。
en: Neb’s companions had listened with great attention to this account.

zh: 他们很难理解为什么赛勒斯·哈丁穿过乱石堆，努力从大浪中逃脱出来，身上却一道擦伤都没有。工程师如何走完从海岸到沙丘的山洞这一英里多的路，同样也是无法解释。
en: It was unaccountable to them how Cyrus Harding, after the efforts which he must have made to escape from the waves by crossing the rocks, had not received even a scratch.And what could not be explained either was how the engineer had managed to get to this cave in the downs, more than a mile from the shore.

zh: “照你这么说，纳布，”记者说，“不是你把主人带到这里来的？”
en: “So, Neb,” said the reporter, “it was not you who brought your master to this place.”

zh: “不，不是我。”黑人答道。
en: “No, it was not I,” replied the Negro.

zh: “很显然，是上尉自己到这里来的。”潘克洛夫说。
en: “It’s very clear that the captain came here by himself,” said Pencroft.

zh: “事实固然很明显，”史佩莱说，“但这也太让人难以置信了！”
en: “It is clear in reality,” observed Spilett, “but it is not credible!”

zh: 事情的真相只有等工程师亲自来解释，他们必须要等到他可以开口说话。按摩使血液循环重新畅通。赛勒斯·哈丁的胳膊又动了一下，接着头动了一下，随后他说了谁也没听懂的几个字。
en: The explanation of this fact could only be produced from the engineer’s own lips, and they must wait for that till speech returned.Rubbing had re-established the circulation of the blood.Cyrus Harding moved his arm again, then his head, and a few incomprehensible words escaped him.

zh: 纳布弯着身子和他说话，但是工程师似乎没有听见，依旧紧闭着双眼。大家只能通过他的动作知道他还活着，他的意识还没有完全清醒过来。
en: Neb, who was bending over him, spoke, but the engineer did not appear to hear, and his eyes remained closed.Life was only exhibited in him by movement, his senses had not as yet been restored.

zh: 因为没有火，也没有取火的东西，潘克洛夫感到十分懊恼。不幸的是，他忘记把焦布带在身上，要不然撞击两块打火石，迸出的火花很容易就可以把焦布点着。工程师的口袋里什么东西都没有，只有坎肩口袋里有一块表。眼下必须把哈丁抬到“石窟”去，而且越快越好。在这一点上，大家的意见完全一致。
en: Pencroft much regretted not having either fire, or the means of procuring it, for he had, unfortunately, forgotten to bring the burnt linen, which would easily have ignited from the sparks produced by striking together two flints.As to the engineer’s pockets, they were entirely empty, except that of his waistcoat, which contained his watch.It was necessary to carry Harding to the Chimneys, and that as soon as possible.This was the opinion of all.

zh: 这时，大家殷勤的照顾使工程师恢复了知觉，这比他们预计的要快了很多。用来润湿嘴唇的水使他逐渐苏醒过来。潘克洛夫想起带在身上的松鸡，想把鸡肉汁加在水里。赫伯特跑到海边去，带回了两个大蚌壳。水手把调好的水送到了工程师的嘴里，他睁开了眼睛，迫不及待地吞咽着。
en: Meanwhile, the care which was lavished on the engineer brought him back to consciousness sooner than they could have expected.The water with which they wetted his lips revived him gradually.Pencroft also thought of mixing with the water some moisture from the titra’s flesh which he had brought.Herbert ran to the beach and returned with two large bivalve shells.The sailor concocted something which he introduced between the lips of the engineer, who eagerly drinking it opened his eyes.

zh: 纳布和通讯记者弯腰俯向他。
en: Neb and the reporter were leaning over him.

zh: “主人！主人！”纳布喊道。
en: “My master! my master!” cried Neb.

zh: 工程师听见了叫声。他最先认出了纳布和史佩莱，然后认出其他两位同伴，并轻轻地握了他们的手。
en: The engineer heard him.He recognized Neb and Spilett, then his other two companions, and his hand slightly pressed theirs.

zh: 他又说了几个字，可以看得出即便是在这样的时刻，他的大脑依旧没有停止思考。这一次大家听懂了他的话。毫无疑问，这就是刚才他想说的话。
en: A few words again escaped him, which showed what thoughts were, even then, troubling his brain.This time he was understood.Undoubtedly they were the same words he had before attempted to utter.

zh: “这是孤岛还是大陆？”他低声地说。
en: “Island or continent?” he murmured.

zh: “管他是不是大陆，”潘克洛夫急忙喊道，“我们有的是时间把这里看个遍，上尉！只要你还活着，其他的我们什么也不在乎。”
en: “Bother the continent,” cried Pencroft hastily; “there is time enough to see about that, captain! we don’t care for anything, provided you are living.”

zh: 工程师无力地点了点头，然后又渐渐睡了过去。
en: The engineer nodded faintly, and then appeased to sleep.

zh: 他们没有去打扰他的睡眠，记者立即着手准备把哈丁抬到一个舒服一点的地方去。纳布、赫伯特和潘克洛夫离开了山洞，朝着一座突起的小山头走去，山顶有几棵歪歪扭扭的树。一路上，水手情不自禁地重复着：
en: They respected this sleep, and the reporter began immediately to make arrangements for transporting Harding to a more comfortable place.Neb, Herbert, and Pencroft left the cave and directed their steps towards a high mound crowned with a few distorted trees.On the way the sailor could not help repeating,—

zh: “孤岛还是大陆？只剩下一口气了，还在考虑这个问题！真是个了不起的人啊！”
en: “Island or continent!To think of that, when at one’s last gasp!What a man!”

zh: 爬到了小山顶上后，潘克洛夫和两位同伴开始忙活起来。他们什么工具都没有，只好用手劈下一棵树上的主枝。这是一棵海枞树，已经快要枯死了。他们打算用这些树枝做一副担架，上面再铺些草和树叶，就能用它抬工程师了。
en: Arrived at the summit of the mound, Pencroft and his two companions set to work, with no other tools than their hands, to despoil of its principal branches a rather sickly tree, a sort of marine fir; with these branches they made a litter, on which, covered with grass and leaves, they could carry the engineer.

zh: 他们花了大概40分钟把担架做好，十点钟的时候，他们回到了赛勒斯·哈丁身边，史佩莱一直都没有离开过他。
en: This occupied them nearly forty minutes, and it was ten o’clock when they returned to Cyrus Harding whom Spilett had not left.

zh: 工程师刚好醒来，或者说是从昏睡中醒来，梦中，同伴们找到了他。他的脸色一直像死人那样惨白，直到这个时候才逐渐恢复血色。他稍微抬起了身，环顾四周，看上去是想问自己在什么地方。
en: The engineer was just awaking from the sleep, or rather from the drowsiness, in which they had found him.The color was returning to his cheeks, which till now had been as pale as death.He raised himself a little, looked around him, and appeared to ask where he was.

zh: “你听我说话的时候觉得累吗，赛勒斯？”记者问。
en: “Can you listen to me without fatigue, Cyrus?” asked the reporter.

zh: “不累。”工程师说。
en: “Yes,” replied the engineer.

zh: “在我看来，”水手说，“如果哈丁上尉再吃些松鸡冻，他听你说话肯定更省力点。我们有松鸡，上尉。”他一边说，一边给哈丁一些肉冻，这次他还加了一些鸡肉。
en: “It’s my opinion,” said the sailor, “that Captain Harding will be able to listen to you still better, if he will have some more grouse jelly,—for we have grouse, captain,” added he, presenting him with a little of this jelly, to which he this time added some of the flesh.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁只吃了一点松鸡，剩下的由他的同伴们分着吃了，他们几个都饿坏了，这顿早饭不够他们吃的。
en: Cyrus Harding ate a little of the grouse, and the rest was divided among his companions, who found it but a meager breakfast, for they were suffering extremely from hunger.

zh: “对了！”水手说，“‘石窟’里面有足够的食物，你知道的，上尉，从这里下去，在南边我们有一座房子，里面有房间，有床，还有壁炉，食品室里有几十只鸟，我们的赫伯特管它们叫锦鸡。担架已经准备好了，等你恢复了力气，我们就把你抬回家。”
