en: “Well!” said the sailor, “there is plenty of food at the Chimneys, for you must know, captain, that down there, in the south, we have a house, with rooms, beds, and fireplace, and in the pantry, several dozen of birds, which our Herbert calls couroucous.Your litter is ready, and as soon as you feel strong enough we will carry you home.”

zh: “谢谢你，我的朋友，”工程师回答，“再等一两个钟头我们就动身。现在你说说吧，史佩莱。”
en: “Thanks, my friend,” replied the engineer; “wait another hour or two, and then we will set out.And now speak, Spilett.”

zh: 于是记者给他讲了前前后后发生的事情。只要是赛勒斯不知道的，他全都讲了一遍：气球是怎样最后一次下坠的，是怎样落在这片看上去像荒漠一样的陌生土地上（不管它是什么，孤岛还是大陆），他们是怎样发现“石窟”的，怎样寻找工程师的，他当然不忘讲述了纳布的一片赤诚之心，忠实的托普表现出来的智慧和一些其他的事情。
en: The reporter then told him all that had occurred.He recounted all the events with which Cyrus was unacquainted, the last fall of the balloon, the landing on this unknown land, which appeared a desert (whatever it was, whether island or continent), the discovery of the Chimneys, the search for him, not forgetting of course Neb’s devotion, the intelligence exhibited by the faithful Top, as well as many other matters.

zh: “可是，”哈丁问道，他的声音依旧很微弱，“不是你们把我从海岸上救起来的吗？”
en: “But,” asked Harding, in a still feeble voice, “you did not, then, pick me up on the beach?”

zh: “不是。”通讯记者答道。
en: “No,” replied the reporter.

zh: “不是你们把我带到这个山洞里来的？”
en: “And did you not bring me to this cave?”

zh: “不是。”
en: “No.”

zh: “这个山洞离海有多远？”
en: “At what distance is this cave from the sea?”

zh: “大概一英里，”潘克洛夫答道，“如果你感到惊讶，上尉，我们在这里看见你，感到同样奇怪！”
en: “About a mile,” replied Pencroft; “and if you are astonished, captain, we are not less surprised ourselves at seeing you in this place!”

zh: “的确，”工程师说，这时他已经逐渐恢复过来了，对这些细节表现出极大的兴趣，“这的确太奇怪了！”
en: “Indeed,” said the engineer, who was recovering gradually, and who took great interest in these details, “indeed it is very singular!”

zh: “可是，”水手接着说，“能告诉我们你被海水卷走之后都发生了什么事吗？”
en: “But,” resumed the sailor, “can you tell us what happened after you were carried off by the sea?”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁陷入沉思。他能记起的事情很少。大浪把他从气球网上卷到了海里。起初他下沉了几英寻。在回到水面的途中，他隐隐约约觉得有一个生物在旁边挣扎。是托普，它从气球上跳下来救他。他已经看不见气球了，因为减少了他和狗的重量，气球像箭一样飞走了。
en: Cyrus Harding considered.He knew very little.The wave had torn him from the balloon net.He sank at first several fathoms.On returning to the surface, in the half light, he felt a living creature struggling near him.It was Top, who had sprung to his help.He saw nothing of the balloon, which, lightened both of his weight and that of the dog, had darted away like an arrow.

zh: 他掉在波涛汹涌的大海中，距离海岸至少有半英里。他奋力游着，尝试着和巨浪斗争。托普咬着他的衣服，使他露出水面，但是一股激流迎面而来，冲着他一直向北。在挣扎了半个钟头后，水流把他和托普拖进了大海深处。从那一刻直到他刚刚苏醒过来，发现自己躺在朋友的怀中，这期间发生的事情他什么都记不清了。
en: There he was, in the midst of the angry sea, at a distance which could not be less than half a mile from the shore.He attempted to struggle against the billows by swimming vigorously.Top held him up by his clothes; but a strong current seized him and drove him towards the north, and after half an hour of exertion, he sank, dragging Top with him into the depths.From that moment to the moment in which he recovered to find himself in the arms of his friends he remembered nothing.

zh: “不管怎样，”潘克洛夫说，“你肯定是被海水冲到了岸上，而且肯定还有力气走到了这里，因为纳布发现了你的脚印！”
en: “However,” remarked Pencroft, “you must have been thrown on to the beach, and you must have had strength to walk here, since Neb found your footmarks!”

zh: “是的……当然……”工程师若有所思地回答，“你们在海岸上没有发现人类的痕迹吗？”
en: “Yes...of course replied the engineer, thoughtfully; “and you found no traces of human beings on this coast?”

zh: “一丝痕迹都没有，”记者回答说，“再说，假使你真的遇到了什么人在紧要关头救了你，把你送过来，他为什么把你从海浪中救出来，又把你扔在这里呢？”
en: “Not a trace,” replied the reporter; “besides, if by chance you had met with some deliverer there, just in the nick of time, why should he have abandoned you after having saved you from the waves?”

zh: “你说得没错，亲爱的史佩莱。告诉我，纳布，”工程师转向他的仆人，接着说道，“难道不是你……你会不会是一时失去了知觉……在那段时间……不，这太荒谬了……那里现在还有脚印吗？”哈丁问。
en: “You are right, my dear Spilett.Tell me, Neb,” added the engineer, turning to his servant, “it was not you who...you can’t have had a moment of unconsciousness...during which no, that’s absurd....Do any of the footsteps still remain?” asked Harding.

zh: “有的，主人，”纳布答道，“这里，入口的地方，小山背后，还有风雨吹打不到的地方。暴风雨把其他的都冲掉了。”
en: “Yes, master, replied Neb; “here, at the entrance, at the back of the mound, in a place sheltered from the rain and wind.The storm has destroyed the others.”

zh: “潘克洛夫，”赛勒斯·哈丁说，“你能拿上我的鞋，去对照一下那些究竟是不是我的脚印吗？”
en: “Pencroft,” said Cyrus Harding, “will you take my shoe and see if it fits exactly to the footprints?”

zh: 水手照着工程师的要求去做了。纳布带着他和赫伯特去往有脚印的地方，赛勒斯对记者说：
en: The sailor did as the engineer requested.While he and Herbert, guided by Neb, went to the place where the footprints were to be found, Cyrus remarked to the reporter,—

zh: “这件事实在是太奇怪了！”
en: “It is a most extraordinary thing!”

zh: “完全无法解释！”吉丁·史佩莱答道。
en: “Perfectly inexplicable!” replied Gideon Spilett.

zh: “现在先别说这件事了，亲爱的史佩莱，我们以后再谈吧。”
en: “But do not dwell upon it just now, my dear Spilett, we will talk about it by-and-by.”

zh: 过了一会儿，其他人走了进来。
en: A moment after the others entered.

zh: 这件事情毫无疑问了。工程师的鞋和脚印完全吻合。因此，沙滩上的这些脚印就是赛勒斯·哈丁斯留下的。
en: There was no doubt about it.The engineer’s shoe fitted exactly to the footmarks.It was therefore Cyrus Harding who had left them on the sand.

zh: “好吧，”他说，“刚才我还认为纳布失去了知觉，现在看来，失去知觉的肯定是我自己了。我肯定像个梦游者似的，不知道我自己的步子，一定是托普把我从海浪中拉了上来，然后把我带到这儿来的……过来，托普！过来，老伙计！”
en: “Come,” said he, “I must have experienced this unconsciousness which I attributed to Neb.I must have walked like a somnambulist, without any knowledge of my steps, and Top must have guided me here, after having dragged me from the waves...Come, Top!Come, old dog!”

zh: 这头出色的牲畜叫着，跳到了它的主人身边，哈丁毫不吝啬地爱抚了它一番。大家一致同意，除此之外没有别的理由可以解释赛勒斯·哈丁是如何得救的，这件事情完全归功于托普。
en: The magnificent animal bounded barking to his master, and caresses were lavished on him.It was agreed that there was no other way of accounting for the rescue of Cyrus Harding, and that Top deserved all the honor of the affair.

zh: 快到十二点的时候，潘克洛夫问工程师，他们现在可不可以把他抬走。哈丁没有回答，却凭着坚强的意志，一卯劲站了起来。可是他不得不靠在水手身上，不然他就会摔倒了。
en: Towards twelve o’clock, Pencroft having asked the engineer if they could now remove him, Harding, instead of replying, and by an effort which exhibited the most energetic will, got up.But he was obliged to lean on the sailor, or he would have fallen.

zh: “太好了！”潘克洛夫喊道，“快把上尉的担架抬过来。”
en: “Well done!” cried Pencroft; “bring the captain’s litter.”

zh: 担架抬来了，横向排列的树枝上铺着树叶和长草。哈丁躺在上面，潘克洛夫和纳布各抬着担架的一头，就这样开始向海岸走去。要走八英里的路，但是，因为他们不能走快，而且又可能必须经常停下休息，所以他们估计至少要六个钟头才能走到“石窟”。风依旧很大，所幸这时已经不下雨了。工程师虽然躺在担架上，但是他还是用手肘撑着身子，观察着海岸，特别是内陆地区。他没有说话，两眼注视着周围，毫无疑问，这片土地的外貌，包括高低不平的地势、森林和各种物产，都印在了他的脑海中。然而，走了两个钟头之后，疲惫不堪的他睡着了。
en: The litter was brought; the transverse branches had been covered with leaves and long grass.Harding was laid on it, and Pencroft, having taken his place at one end and Neb at the other, they started towards the coast.There was a distance of eight miles to be accomplished; but, as they could not go fast, and it would perhaps be necessary to stop frequently, they reckoned that it would take at least six hours to reach the Chimneys.The wind was still strong, but fortunately it did not rain.Although lying down, the engineer, leaning on his elbow, observed the coast, particularly inland.He did not speak, but he gazed; and, no doubt, the appearance of the country, with its inequalities of ground, its forests, its various productions, were impressed on his mind.However, after traveling for two hours, fatigue overcame him, and he slept.

zh: 五点半的时候，这一小队人马走到了悬崖边，不久之后就到了“石窟”。
en: At half-past five the little band arrived at the precipice, and a short time after at the Chimneys.

zh: 他们停了下来，把担架放在了沙上，此时赛勒斯·哈丁在熟睡中，还没有醒过来。
en: They stopped, and the litter was placed on the sand; Cyrus Harding was sleeping profoundly, and did not awake.

zh: 令潘克洛夫大为吃惊的是，可怕的暴风雨已经使这里的面貌改变了很多。这里发生了巨大的变化，沙滩上有很多大块的石头，上面覆盖着一层厚厚的水草、海藻和其他冲上岸的植物。很显然，海水曾经漫过小岛，一直冲到巨大的花岗石壁底下。山洞前的泥土已经被汹涌的海浪冲走了。一种可怕的预感在潘克洛夫的脑子里一闪而过。他急忙冲到通道里，但马上又回来了，他一动不动地站在那里，盯着他的同伴们……火已经灭了，被水泡过的灰烬成了一滩泥，用来当火绒使的焦布不见了！海水已经流到了通道的最深处，“石窟”里的所有东西都被水冲倒、破坏了。
en: Pencroft, to his extreme surprise, found that the terrible storm had quite altered the aspect of the place.Important changes had occurred; great blocks of stone lay on the beach, which was also covered with a thick carpet of sea-weed, algae, and wrack.Evidently the sea, passing over the islet, had been carried right up to the foot of the enormous curtain of granite.The soil in front of the cave had been torn away by the violence of the waves.A horrid presentiment flashed across Pencroft’s mind.He rushed into the passage, but returned almost immediately, and stood motionless, staring at his companions....The fire was out; the drowned cinders were nothing but mud; the burnt linen, which was to have served as tinder, had disappeared!The sea had penetrated to the end of the passages, and everything was overthrown and destroyed in the interior of the Chimneys!

zh: 第九章
en: Chapter 9

zh: 总之，吉迪恩·史佩莱、赫伯特和纳布都知道发生了什么事。这次意外，在潘克洛夫看来是极其严重的，而忠实的水手的伙伴们则有不同的反应。
en: In a few words, Gideon Spilett, Herbert, and Neb were made acquainted with what had happened.This accident, which appeared so very serious to Pencroft, produced different effects on the companions of the honest sailor.

zh: 纳布沉浸在找到主人的欢喜中，根本没听，或者说是不愿意因为潘克洛夫说的事情费心。
en: Neb, in his delight at having found his master, did not listen, or rather, did not care to trouble himself with what Pencroft was saying.

zh: 赫伯特多少和水手有同感。
en: Herbert shared in some degree the sailor’s feelings.

zh: 至于记者，他只是简单地说：
en: As to the reporter, he simply replied,—

zh: “说实在的，潘克洛夫，我一点儿也不在乎！”
en: “Upon my word, Pencroft, it’s perfectly indifferent to me!”

zh: “但是，我要重申，我们没有火了！”
en: “But, I repeat, that we haven’t any fire!”
“Pooh!”

zh: “也没有任何办法再生火了！”
en: “Nor any means of relighting it!”

zh: “胡说！”
en: “Nonsense!”

zh: “但是我要说，史佩莱先生……”
en: “But I say, Mr. Spilett—”

zh: “赛勒斯不是在这里吗？”记者答道。
en: “Isn’t Cyrus here?” replied the reporter.

zh: “我们的工程师不是活着吗？他很快会想办法给我们取火的！”
en: “Is not our engineer alive?He will soon find some way of making fire for us!”

zh: “用什么？”
en: “With what?”

zh: “什么也不用。”
en: “With nothing.”

zh: 潘克洛夫还有什么好说的？他没有什么好说的了，因为他打心底里和伙伴们一样相信赛勒斯·哈丁。在他们心目中，工程师就是个小宇宙，是一切科学的综合，通晓人类全部的智慧。和赛勒斯呆在荒岛上，也比独自在美国最繁荣的城市里要好。有了他就什么也不缺了，有了他就永远不会绝望。假如有人告诉这几个勇敢的人，火山喷发将要摧毁这块陆地，它要下沉到太平洋深处，他们会镇静地回答：
en: What had Pencroft to say?He could say nothing, for, in the bottom of his heart he shared the confidence which his companions had in Cyrus Harding.The engineer was to them a microcosm, a compound of every science, a possessor of all human knowledge.It was better to be with Cyrus in a desert island, than without him in the most flourishing town in the United States.With him they could want nothing; with him they would never despair.If these brave men had been told that a volcanic eruption would destroy the land, that this land would be engulfed in the depths of the Pacific, they would have imperturbably replied,—

zh: “赛勒斯在这儿！”
en: “Cyrus is here!”

zh: 然而，由于一路上经受的颠簸，工程师躺在担架上，又一次陷入无意识状态，因此他们没法求助于他的智慧。晚餐只能将就吃一点。事实上，松鸡肉已经吃光了，现在又没有办法烹调其他的猎物。并且贮存的锦鸡也不见了。他们必须考虑下一步应该怎么办。
en: While in the palanquin, however, the engineer had again relapsed into unconsciousness, which the jolting to which he had been subjected during his journey had brought on, so that they could not now appeal to his ingenuity.The supper must necessarily be very meager.In fact, all the grouse flesh had been consumed, and there no longer existed any means of cooking more game.Besides, the couroucous which had been reserved had disappeared.They must consider what was to be done.

zh: 首先，他们把赛勒斯·哈丁抬到过道中央。在那里，他们用比较干的海藻给他铺了一张床。熟睡可以使工程师很快恢复体力，这无疑比吃任何营养品都更有好处。
en: First of all, Cyrus Harding was carried into the central passage.There they managed to arrange for him a couch of sea-weed which still remained almost dry.The deep sleep which had overpowered him would no doubt be more beneficial to him than any nourishment.

zh: 黑夜降临了，风向转为东北方向，气温也随之降低，又变得十分寒冷。海水冲毁了潘克洛夫在过道上分成的隔间，由于寒风直灌进来，这个石洞里几乎不能住人了。要不是伙伴们没把自己的外套和坎肩小心地盖在工程师的身上，他的情况就更加糟糕了。
en: Night had closed in, and the temperature, which had modified when the wind shifted to the northwest, again became extremely cold.Also, the sea having destroyed the partitions which Pencroft had put up in certain places in the passages, the Chimneys, on account of the draughts, had become scarcely habitable.The engineer’s condition would, therefore, have been bad enough, if his companions had not carefully covered him with their coats and waistcoats.

zh: 赫伯特和纳布从海滩上捡了一大堆茨蟹，它们当然是晚餐的主角。然而，除了这些软体动物外，男孩从高处的岩石上搜集到一些可以食用的海藻，只有涨潮的时候，海水才冲得到这些高处的岩壁。这种海藻，是一种昆布，属于马尾藻类，晒干后产生一种胶状物质，营养极其丰富。记者和他的伙伴们吃了很多茨蟹，又吸了一些昆布的汁，味道还很不错。东方一些地带的居民经常吃这种食物。“不用担心！”水手说道，“上尉很快就可以帮助我们了。”这时天气更冷了，更糟糕的是，他们没有任何御寒的办法。
en: Supper, this evening, was of course composed of the inevitable lithodomes, of which Herbert and Neb picked up a plentiful supply on the beach.However, to these molluscs, the lad added some edible sea-weed, which he gathered on high rocks, whose sides were only washed by the sea at the time of high tides.This sea-weed, which belongs to the order of Fucacae, of the genus Sargassum, produces, when dry, a gelatinous matter, rich and nutritious.The reporter and his companions, after having eaten a quantity of lithodomes, sucked the sargassum, of which the taste was very tolerable.It is used in parts of the East very considerably by the natives.“Never mind!” said the sailor, “the captain will help us soon.”Meanwhile the cold became very severe, and unhappily they had no means of defending themselves from it.

zh: 水手十分焦急，试遍了各种取火的方法。纳布也来帮忙。他找来一些干燥的苔藓，用两块鹅卵石砸出火星来，但是苔藓不易燃，点不着，这种火星虽然明亮耀眼，却不像击打火石迸发出来的火星那么持久稳定。因此，试验没有成功。
en: The sailor, extremely vexed, tried in all sorts of ways to procure fire.Neb helped him in this work.He found some dry moss, and by striking together two pebbles he obtained some sparks, but the moss, not being inflammable enough, did not take fire, for the sparks were really only incandescent, and not at all of the same consistency as those which are emitted from flint when struck in the same manner.The experiment, therefore, did not succeed.

zh: 虽然潘克洛夫对这种做法毫无信心，可他还是照着原始人的做法，拿着两块干木头摩擦起来。按照新的理论，他和纳布所做的运动如果转化为热能，就足以烧开汽轮上的锅炉了！但是，他们的努力并没有奏效。木块虽然磨热了，可是要与这两位试验者身上的热量相比，简直是小巫见大巫。
en: Pencroft, although he had no confidence in the proceeding, then tried rubbing two pieces of dry wood together, as savages do.Certainly, the movement which he and Neb exhibited, if it had been transformed into heat, according to the new theory, would have been enough to heat the boiler of a steamer!It came to nothing.The bits of wood became hot, to be sure, but much less so than the operators themselves.

zh: 干了一个小时后，潘克洛夫大汗淋漓，厌恶地把木块扔在地上。
en: After working an hour, Pencroft, who was in a complete state of perspiration, threw down the pieces of wood in disgust.

zh: “不管他们怎么说，我怎么也不相信原始人是用这种方法取火的，”他大叫道，“再摩擦下去我的胳膊要着火了！”
en: “I can never be made to believe that savages light their fires in this way, let them say what they will,” he exclaimed.“I could sooner light my arms by rubbing them against each other!”

zh: 水手看不起摩擦取火这种办法确实错了。原始人就是经常快速摩擦来点燃木头的。但不是任何木头都可以摩擦起火。此外，除了一般的方法，还有一个“诀窍”，潘克洛夫大概不懂这个“诀窍”。
en: The sailor was wrong to despise the proceeding.Savages often kindle wood by means of rapid rubbing.But every sort of wood does not answer for the purpose, and besides, there is “the knack,” following the usual expression, and it is probable that Pencroft had not “the knack.”

zh: 潘克洛夫的坏脾气并没有持续多久。赫伯特捡起潘克洛夫扔下的木块，用力摩擦起来。这个强壮的水手看见少年继续干着他已经失败的事，忍不住大笑起来。
en: Pencroft’s ill humor did not last long.Herbert had taken the bits of wood which he had turned down, and was exerting himself to rub them.The hardy sailor could not restrain a burst of laughter on seeing the efforts of the lad to succeed where he had failed.

zh: “摩吧，孩子，摩吧！”他说。
en: “Rub, my boy, rub!” said he.

zh: “我是在摩，”赫伯特笑着说，“但我不是想做别的，只是想让身体暖和一点儿，不至于瑟瑟发抖，我一会儿就会和你一样热了，我的好潘克洛夫！”
en: “I am rubbing,” replied Herbert, laughing, “but I don’t pretend to do anything else but warm myself instead of shivering, and soon I shall be as hot as you are, my good Pencroft!”

zh: 不一会儿，少年身体暖和起来了。但是，他们不得不放弃，至少是在今天晚上，他们不再尝试取火了。吉迪恩·史佩莱重复了至少20次，因为他觉得不能为这一点小困难去打扰赛勒斯·哈丁。这时，他躺到一个通道的沙床上，伸展开来。赫伯特、纳布和潘克洛夫也躺了下来，托普睡到它主人的脚边。
en: This soon happened.However, they were obliged to give up, for this night at least, the attempt to procure fire.Gideon Spilett repeated, for the twentieth time, that Cyrus Harding would not have been troubled for so small a difficulty.And, in the meantime, he stretched himself in one of the passages on his bed of sand.Herbert, Neb, and Pencroft did the same, while Top slept at his master’s feet.

zh: 第二天是3月28日，大约早上八点时，工程师醒了，他看见伙伴们都围在周围看着他，还是像前一天一样，他开口便问：
en: Next day, the 28th of March, when the engineer awoke, about eight in the morning, he saw his companions around him watching his sleep, and, as on the day before, his first words were:—

zh: “我们在荒岛还是大陆？”这对他来说最为重要。
en: “Island or continent?”This was his uppermost thought.

zh: “哦！”潘克洛夫答道，“我们一点也不清楚，上尉！”
en: “Well!” replied Pencroft, “we don’t know anything about it, captain!”

zh: “你们还不知道？”
en: “You don’t know yet?”

zh: 潘克洛夫又说道：“等你带我们去内陆后，我们就知道了。”
en: “But we shall know,” rejoined Pencroft, “when you have guided us into the country.”

zh: “我想我可以试试。”工程师说着，毫不费力地就站了起来。
en: “I think I am able to try it,” replied the engineer, who, without much effort, rose and stood upright.

zh: “这才是最重要的！”水手大声喊道。
en: “That’s capital!” cried the sailor.

zh: “我觉得非常虚弱，”哈丁说道，“朋友们，给我点吃的，我不久就会恢复过来。你们有火，对吗？”
en: “I feel dreadfully weak,” replied Harding.“Give me something to eat, my friends, and it will soon go off.You have fire, haven’t you?”

zh: 他们没有立即回答他。但是，几秒钟后——
en: This question was not immediately replied to.But, in a few seconds—

zh: “哎！我们没有火，”潘克洛夫说，“更准确地说，上尉，我们再也没火了。”
en: “Alas! we have no fire,” said Pencroft, “or rather, captain, we have it no longer!”

zh: 水手把前一天发生的事向赛勒斯详细叙述了一遍。他给工程师讲了那仅有的一根火柴的趣事，然后又说了他试图用原始人的方法取火，但未能成功。
en: And the sailor recounted all that had passed the day before.He amused the engineer by the history of the single match, then his abortive attempt to procure fire in the savages’ way.

zh: “我们来仔细想想，”工程师说道，“如果我们找不到跟火绒差不多的东西……”
en: “We shall consider,” replied the engineer, “and if we do not find some substance similar to tinder—”

zh: “那么？”水手问道。
en: “Well?” asked the sailor.

zh: “那么，我们可以做火柴。”
en: “Well, we will make matches.

zh: “化学火柴吗？”
en: “Chemicals?”

zh: “化学火柴！”
en: “Chemicals!”

zh: “这并不比昨天你做的事更难。”记者拍了拍水手的肩膀，大声说道。
en: “It is not more difficult than that,” cried the reporter, striking the sailor on the shoulder.

zh: 水手并不认为这件事这么简单，但是他并没有反驳。所有人都出去了。天气变得风和日丽。太阳正从地平线上升起来，高大的悬崖上，一层层岩石被阳光照得金灿灿的。
en: The latter did not think it so simple, but he did not protest.All went out.The weather had become very fine.The sun was rising from the sea’s horizon, and touched with golden spangles the prismatic rugosities of the huge precipice.

zh: 工程师迅速环顾四周，在一块石头上坐下来。赫伯特给他一些蛤蜊和马尾藻，对他说：
en: Having thrown a rapid glance around him, the engineer seated himself on a block of stone.Herbert offered him a few handfuls of shell-fish and sargassum, saying,—

zh: “我们只有这些了，哈丁上尉。”
en: “It is all that we have, Captain Harding.”

zh: “谢谢你，孩子，”哈丁答道，“这就够了……起码够今天早晨吃了。”
en: “Thanks, my boy,” replied Harding; “it will do—for this morning at least.”

zh: 他津津有味地吃着这些糟糕的食物，用大贝壳从河里舀过来一些淡水，喝几口咽下这些食物。
en: He ate the wretched food with appetite, and washed it down with a little fresh water, drawn from the river in an immense shell.

zh: 他的伙伴们默默地看着他。过一会儿，赛勒斯·哈丁感觉精神恢复了一些，交叉着双臂说：
en: His companions looked at him without speaking.Then, feeling somewhat refreshed, Cyrus Harding crossed his arms, and said,—

zh: “那么，我的朋友们，你们还不知道命运把我们扔到了一个荒岛上还是大陆上，是吗？”
en: “So, my friends, you do not know yet whether fate has thrown us on an island, or on a continent?”

zh: “是的，上尉。”少年回答他。
en: “No, captain,” replied the boy.

zh: “明天我们就知道了，”工程师说，“到那时就没有别的事做了。”
en: “We shall know to-morrow,” said the engineer; “till then, there is nothing to be done.”

zh: “有。”潘克洛夫答道。
en: “Yes,” replied Pencroft.

zh: “什么？”
en: “What?”

zh: “取火。”水手说，水手一直对这件事念念不忘。
en: “Fire,” said the sailor, who, also, had a fixed idea.

zh: “我们会取到火的，潘克洛夫。”哈丁说。
en: “We will make it, Pencroft,” replied Harding.

zh: “你们昨天抬着我的时候，是不是看见西边有一座山可以俯瞰这片土地？”
en: “While you were carrying me yesterday, did I not see in the west a mountain which commands the country?”

zh: “是的，”史佩莱答道，“那座山肯定相当高……”
en: “Yes,” replied Spilett, “a mountain which must be rather high—”

zh: “好吧，”工程师说，“明天我们就爬到山顶上去，那时候我们就可以看到这片土地是荒岛还是大陆了。我再重复一遍，到那时，就没有事干了。”
en: “Well,” replied the engineer, “we will climb to the summit to-morrow, and then we shall see if this land is an island or a continent.Till then, I repeat, there is nothing to be done.”

zh: “有，取火！”水手再次倔强地说。
en: “Yes, fire!” said the obstinate sailor again.

zh: “他会给我们取火的！”吉迪恩·史佩莱说道，“耐心点，潘克洛夫！”
en: “But he will make us a fire!” replied Gideon Spilett, “only have a little patience, Pencroft!”

zh: 水手看了史佩莱一眼，似乎在说：“如果靠你取火的话，我们就别想马上吃上烤肉了。”可是他什么也没说。
en: The seaman looked at Spilett in a way which seemed to say, “If it depended upon you to do it, we wouldn’t taste roast meat very soon”; but he was silent.

zh: 这时，哈丁上尉没有做任何回答。他好像一点也不为取火的事发愁。他沉思了好几分钟，然后说：
en: Meanwhile Captain Harding had made no reply.He appeared to be very little troubled by the question of fire.For a few minutes he remained absorbed in thought; then again speaking,—

zh: “我的朋友们，”他说，“我们的处境也许悲惨，但是无论如何，事情很明显。我们所处的地方，不是大陆，就是岛屿。如果这是大陆，我们就可以找到有人居住的地方，只不过是花费力气多少的问题而已。如果是在荒岛上，假如岛上有人，我们可以在岛上居民的帮助下脱离困境，如果岛上没有人，我们只好靠自己逃出去了。”
en: “My friends,” said he, “our situation is, perhaps, deplorable; but, at any rate, it is very plain.Either we are on a continent, and then, at the expense of greater or less fatigue, we shall reach some inhabited place, or we are on an island.In the latter case, if the island is inhabited, we will try to get out of the scrape with the help of its inhabitants; if it is desert, we will try to get out of the scrape by ourselves.”

zh: “当然，这是再明显不过的事情了。”潘克洛夫说。
en: “Certainly, nothing could be plainer,” replied Pencroft.

zh: “可是，不管是荒岛还是大陆，”吉迪恩·史佩莱问道，“赛勒斯，你认为风暴把我们扔到什么地方了？”
en: “But, whether it is an island or a continent,” asked Gideon Spilett, “whereabouts do you think, Cyrus, this storm has thrown us?”

zh: “我也说不准，”工程师答道，“我猜是太平洋的某块陆地。事实上，我们离开里士满时，刮的是东北风，风力很强，这说明风向应该没有改变。如果一路上风一直是从东北吹向西南，那么我们就飞过了北卡罗莱纳州、南卡罗莱纳州、佐治亚州、墨西哥湾、墨西哥本土的狭窄地带，然后到了太平洋的某个地方。我估计热气球至少飞出六、七千英里了。即使风向改变了45度，我们也一定被带到了曼达瓦群岛，或者帕摩图群岛，或者，如果风力比我猜想的还要大，那么可能会到了新西兰。如果是到了新西兰，我们就能轻而易举地回家了。无论是英国人还是毛利人，我们总能找到交流的人。假如事情正好相反，从山顶俯瞰四周，看到这是个小群岛中的荒岛，那时我们永远也出不去了，就要考虑在这里好好住下来了。”
en: “I cannot say exactly,” replied the engineer, “but I presume it is some land in the Pacific.In fact, when we left Richmond, the wind was blowing from the northeast, and its very violence greatly proves that it could not have varied.If the direction has been maintained from the northeast to the southwest, we have traversed the States of North Carolina, of South Carolina, of Georgia, the Gulf of Mexico, Mexico, itself, in its narrow part, then a part of the Pacific Ocean.I cannot estimate the distance traversed by the balloon at less than six to seven thousand miles, and, even supposing that the wind had varied half a quarter, it must have brought us either to the archipelago of Mendava, either on the Pomotous, or even, if it had a greater strength than I suppose, to the land of New Zealand.If the last hypothesis is correct, it will be easy enough to get home again.English or Maoris, we shall always find some one to whom we can speak.If, on the contrary, this is the coast of a desert island in some tiny archipelago, perhaps we shall be able to reconnoiter it from the summit of that peak which overlooks the country, and then we shall see how best to establish ourselves here as if we are never to go away.”

zh: “永远？”记者喊道，“你说‘永远’，我亲爱的赛勒斯？”
en: “Never?” cried the reporter.“You say ‘Never,’ my dear Cyrus?”

zh: “开始的时候最好做最坏的打算，”工程师答道，“把最好的结果留作一个惊喜。”
en: “Better to put things at the worst at first,” replied the engineer, “and reserve the best for a surprise.”

zh: “说得对，”潘克洛夫说道，“如果这是个孤岛的话，我希望它不在船只的航线以外，要是那样就太倒霉了！”
en: “Well said,” remarked Pencroft.“It is to be hoped, too, that this island, if it be one, is not situated just out of the course of ships; that would be really unlucky!”

zh: “在没有到达山顶之前，真不知道该指望什么。”工程师说。
en: “We shall not know what we have to rely on until we have first made the ascent of the mountain,” replied the engineer.

zh: “但是明天，上尉，”赫伯特问道，“明天上山您不会觉得疲惫吗？”
en: “But to-morrow, captain,” asked Herbert, “shall you be in a state to bear the fatigue of the ascent?”

zh: “我希望可以，”工程师回答说，“孩子，这要看你和潘克洛夫是不是反应迅速、聪明机灵的猎人了。”
en: “I hope so,” replied the engineer, “provided you and Pencroft, my boy, show yourselves quick and clever hunters.”

zh: “上尉，”水手说，“既然您说到猎物，那么我能保证，回来的时候，只要能烤，我就能把野味带回来……”
en: “Captain,” said the sailor, “since you are speaking of game, if on my return, I was as certain of roasting it as I am of bringing it back—”

zh: “还是先把猎物搞到手吧，潘克洛夫。”哈丁说。
en: “Bring it back all the same, Pencroft,” replied Harding.

zh: 大家最后达成一致，工程师和记者留在“石窟”里，观察海岸和上面的高地。纳布、赫伯特和水手返回森林，一方面，继续搜寻木柴以作储备，另一方面，只要遇到动物，不管飞禽走兽，到手就抓。
en: It was then agreed that the engineer and the reporter were to pass the day at the Chimneys, so as to examine the shore and the upper plateau.Neb, Herbert, and the sailor were to return to the forest, renew their store of wood, and lay violent hands on every creature, feathered or hairy, which might come within their reach.

zh: 于是，早上十点钟左右，他们出发了。赫伯特信心十足，纳布兴致勃勃，潘克洛夫在一旁低声说：
en: They set out accordingly about ten o’clock in the morning, Herbert confident, Neb joyous, Pencroft murmuring aside,—

zh: “如果我回来后发现有火，我肯定那是雷电点燃的。”三个人爬上了河岸，他们走到河流拐角时，水手停住脚步对他的两个伙伴说：
en: “If, on my return, I find a fire at the house, I shall believe that the thunder itself came to light it.”All three climbed the bank; and arrived at the angle made by the river, the sailor, stopping, said to his two companions,—

zh: “我们是先打猎还是先找木柴？”
en: “Shall we begin by being hunters or wood-men?”

zh: “打猎，”赫伯特答道，“托普已经在搜寻猎物了。”
en: “Hunters,” replied Herbert.“There is Top already in quest.”

zh: “那我们就先打猎吧，”水手说，“然后我们再回来捡木柴。”
en: “We will hunt, then,” said the sailor, “and afterwards we can come back and collect our wood.”

zh: 大家达成一致后，赫伯特、纳布和潘克洛夫就从一棵小枞树的主干上掰下三根粗枝，在深草丛中跳来跳去的托普跟在后面。
en: This agreed to, Herbert, Neb, and Pencroft, after having torn three sticks from the trunk of a young fir, followed Top, who was bounding about among the long grass.

zh: 这一次，猎人们没有顺着河道前进，而是直接进入了森林中心。这里的树木也是一样的，大部分属于松柏科。有些地方的树木比较稀疏，一丛一丛地长在一起，这些松树都很高大，从它们的生长情况来看，似乎这个地方的纬度比工程师想象的要高一些。林间的空地上有很多树桩，长年累月渐渐秃了，这里到处是干柴，简直有用不完的燃料。过了林间空地后，矮丛林逐渐变密，几乎穿不过去了。
en: This time, the hunters, instead of following the course of the river, plunged straight into the heart of the forest.There were still the same trees, belonging, for the most part, to the pine family.In certain places, less crowded, growing in clumps, these pines exhibited considerable dimensions, and appeared to indicate, by their development, that the country was situated in a higher latitude than the engineer had supposed.Glades, bristling with stumps worn away by time, were covered with dry wood, which formed an inexhaustible store of fuel.Then, the glade passed, the underwood thickened again, and became almost impenetrable.

zh: 没有现成的路，在这片树林中想找条路走确实不容易。所以水手走几步就要折断树枝，这样回来时可以很容易辨认出路径来。但是这次他和赫伯特没有像第一次远足那样沿着河道走，也许是走错了路，走了一个小时，什么动物也没有看见。托普在树枝下乱跑，只遇到一些小鸟，还没走近，鸟就给惊飞了。就连锦鸡也没有看到，看情形水手只能回到森林的沼泽地去，上次他在那里兴致勃勃地展现了他的捕鸡技。
en: It was difficult enough to find the way among the groups of trees, without any beaten track.So the sailor from time to time broke off branches which might be easily recognized.But, perhaps, he was wrong not to follow the watercourse, as he and Herbert had done on their first excursion, for after walking an hour not a creature had shown itself.Top, running under the branches, only roused birds which could not be approached.Even the couroucous were invisible, and it was probable that the sailor would be obliged to return to the marshy part of the forest, in which he had so happily performed his grouse fishing.

zh: “潘克洛夫，”纳布略带讽刺的口吻说道，“假如这就是你答应带给我主人的猎物，那倒是不用多大的火来烤！”
en: “Well, Pencroft,” said Neb, in a slightly sarcastic tone, “if this is all the game which you promised to bring back to my master, it won’t need a large fire to roast it!”

zh: “耐心一些，”水手回答，“回去之后，需要的恐怕不是猎物。”
en: “Have patience,” replied the sailor, “it isn’t the game which will be wanting on our return.”

zh: “你难道对哈丁上尉没有信心吗？”
en: “Have you not confidence in Captain Harding?”

zh: “是的。”
en: “Yes.”

zh: “你不认为他会生起火来吗？”
en: “But you don’t believe that he will make fire?”

zh: “等我看到木柴在炉子里燃烧，我才会相信。”
en: “I shall believe it when the wood is blazing in the fireplace.”

zh: “既然我主人那样说，火一定会烧起来。”
en: “It will blaze, since my master has said so.”

zh: “走着瞧吧！”
en: “We shall see!”

zh: 这时候，太阳还没有升到正当空。因此，他们继续搜寻。赫伯特发现一棵树上的果子可以吃，总算有些成果了。这是一棵石松，松子非常好吃，是欧美温带地区的珍品。这棵树上的松子正好熟透，大家一边尽情地吃着，一边听赫伯特讲。
en: Meanwhile, the sun had not reached the highest point in its course above the horizon.The exploration, therefore, continued, and was usefully marked by a discovery which Herbert made of a tree whose fruit was edible.This was the stone-pine, which produces an excellent almond, very much esteemed in the temperate regions of America and Europe.These almonds were in a perfect state of maturity, and Herbert described them to his companions, who feasted on them.

zh: “嗨，”潘克洛夫说，“拿海藻当面包，生蛤蜊当肉吃，松子当饭后点心，这对于口袋里没有一根火柴的我们，肯定是不错的一餐了！”
en: “Come,” said Pencroft, “sea-weed by way of bread, raw mussels for meat, and almonds for dessert, that’s certainly a good dinner for those who have not a single match in their pocket!”

zh: “我们不应该抱怨。”赫伯特说。
en: We mustn’t complain,” said Herbert.

zh: “我不是在抱怨，孩子，”潘克洛夫回应道，“我只是重复一遍，这顿饭中肉太少了。”
en: “I am not complaining, my boy,” replied Pencroft, “only I repeat, that meat is a little too much economized in this sort of meal.”

zh: “托普找到什么东西了！”纳布喊着，向树丛中奔去，托普已经钻到中间看不见的地方了，不停地叫着。托普的叫声中夹杂着一种奇怪的咕哝声。
en: “Top has found something!” cried Neb, who ran towards a thicket, in the midst of which the dog had disappeared, barking.With Top’s barking were mingled curious gruntings.

zh: 水手和赫伯特紧跟着纳布跑过去。如果那里有什么猎物，现在应该考虑的是怎样抓住它，而不是讨论怎样烹调。
en: The sailor and Herbert had followed Neb.If there was game there this was not the time to discuss how it was to be cooked, but rather, how they were to get hold of it.

zh: 猎人刚进入灌木丛，就看见托普和一个动物争斗着，咬着它的一只耳朵。这是个类似于猪的四足动物，近两英尺半长，身体呈黑褐色，肚子下的颜色较浅，浑身的毛又稀又硬。它的足趾紧紧按在地上，趾间似乎有蹼连接。赫伯特认出这种动物是水豚，是啮齿动物中最大的一种。
en: The hunters had scarcely entered the bushes when they saw Top engaged in a struggle with an animal which he was holding by the ear.This quadruped was a sort of pig nearly two feet and a half long, of a blackish brown color, lighter below, having hard scanty hair; its toes, then strongly fixed in the ground, seemed to be united by a membrane.Herbert recognized in this animal the capybara, that is to say, one of the largest members of the rodent order.

zh: 这时，水豚并没有和狗争斗。它笨拙地转动着眼珠，眼睑很厚。也许这是它第一次见到人类。
en: Meanwhile, the capybara did not struggle against the dog.It stupidly rolled its eyes, deeply buried in a thick bed of fat.Perhaps it saw men for the first time.

zh: 然而，纳布正握紧棍子想把它打倒，这时水豚却挣脱了托普的牙齿，因为托普只咬住了它的耳朵边。水豚发出了有力的一声，向赫伯特冲去，差点儿把他撞倒，然后消失在树林里。
en: However, Neb having tightened his grasp on his stick, was just going to fell the pig, when the latter, tearing itself from Top’s teeth, by which it was only held by the tip of its ear, uttered a vigorous grunt, rushed upon Herbert, almost overthrew him, and disappeared in the wood.

zh: “该死的畜生！”潘克洛夫喊道。
en: “The rascal!” cried Pencroft.

zh: 三个人跟着托普快速追上去，可是他们刚赶上托普，水豚就跳到一个古松覆盖的大池子里了。
en: All three directly darted after Top, but at the moment when they joined him the animal had disappeared under the waters of a large pond shaded by venerable pines.

zh: 纳布、赫伯特和潘克洛夫站住了，一动不动。托普纵身跳进水中，可是水豚躲在水底不出来。
en: Neb, Herbert, and Pencroft stopped, motionless.Top plunged into the water, but the capybara, hidden at the bottom of the pond, did not appear.

zh: “我们等等吧，”少年说，“它很快就要到水面上呼吸。”
en: “Let us wait,” said the boy, “for he will soon come to the surface to breathe.”

zh: “它不会淹死吗？”纳布问道。
en: “Won’t he drown?” asked Neb.

zh: “不会的，”赫伯特回答说，“因为它长着蹼，几乎算是一种两栖动物。看住它。”
en: “No,” replied Herbert, “since he has webbed feet, and is almost an amphibious animal.But watch him.”

zh: 托普还是在水里。潘克洛夫和他的两个伙伴站在河边不同的地方，切断水豚的退路，托普在水面上寻找水豚。
en: Top remained in the water.Pencroft and his two companions went to different parts of the bank, so as to cut off the retreat of the capybara, which the dog was looking for beneath the water.

zh: 赫伯特的话果然不错。没过几分钟，水豚就露出了水面。托普一下子跳到它身上，按住它不让它继续下沉。过了一会儿，水豚被拖到岸边，纳布一棍子就把它打死了。
en: Herbert was not mistaken.In a few minutes the animal appeared on the surface of the water.Top was upon it in a bound, and kept it from plunging again.An instant later the capybara, dragged to the bank, was killed by a blow from Neb’s stick.

zh: “哈哈！”潘克洛夫呼喊道，他总是第一个发出胜利的欢呼。
en: “Hurrah!” cried Pencroft, who was always ready with this cry of triumph.

zh: “只要给我火，就可以把这只猪啃得只剩骨头！”
en: “Give me but a good fire, and this pig shall be gnawed to the bones!”

zh: 潘克洛夫把水豚扛在肩上，他看了看太阳，估摸着有两点钟，就给出返回的手势。
en: Pencroft hoisted the capybara on his shoulders, and judging by the height of the sun that it was about two o’clock, he gave the signal to return.

zh: 托普的直觉对猎人们很有帮助，多亏了这个聪明的家伙，他们才能找到回去的路。半小时后，他们到达了河边。
en: Top’s instinct was useful to the hunters, who, thanks to the intelligent animal, were enabled to discover the road by which they had come.Half an hour later they arrived at the river.

zh: 如果没有火，一切都是徒劳。虽然如此，潘克洛夫像以前一样，很快做了一个木筏顺流而下，一直漂向“石窟”。
en: Pencroft soon made a raft of wood, as he had done before, though if there was no fire it would be a useless task, and the raft following the current, they returned towards the Chimneys.

zh: 水手还没走50步就站住了，他指着悬崖的转角，扯开嗓门欢呼道：
en: But the sailor had not gone fifty paces when he stopped, and again uttering a tremendous hurrah, pointed towards the angle of the cliff,—

zh: “赫伯特！纳布！快看！”他大喊道。
en: “Herbert!Neb!Look!” he shouted.

zh: 只见岩石中，一缕轻烟袅袅升起。
en: Smoke was escaping and curling up among the rocks.

zh: 第十章
en: Chapter 10

zh: 几分钟以后，三个猎人来到了噼啪作响的篝火前。上尉和记者就在旁边。潘克洛夫瞧瞧这个，望望那个，手里拿着水豚，一言不发。
en: In a few minutes the three hunters were before a crackling fire.The captain and the reporter were there.Pencroft looked from one to the other, his capybara in his hand, without saying a word.

zh: “不错吧，我的勇士。”记者喊道。
en: “Well, yes, my brave fellow,” cried the reporter.

zh: “火，真的是火，完全可以烤熟这只大肥猪，我们马上就可以美餐一顿了！”
en: “Fire, real fire, which will roast this splendid pig perfectly, and we will have a feast presently!”

zh: “可这是谁生的火呢？”潘克洛夫问道。
en: “But who lighted it?” asked Pencroft.

zh: “太阳！”
en: “The sun!”

zh: 吉迪恩·史佩莱回答得很到位。这股热量竟是太阳提供的，这让潘克洛夫感到惊奇。水手简直不敢相信自己的眼睛，他太惊讶了，都没想到问问工程师。
en: Gideon Spilett was quite right in his reply.It was the sun which had furnished the heat which so astonished Pencroft.The sailor could scarcely believe his eyes, and he was so amazed that he did not think of questioning the engineer.

zh: “你有聚光镜吧？”赫伯特问哈丁。
en: “Had you a burning-glass, sir?” asked Herbert of Harding.

zh: “没有，孩子，”他答道，“可是我自己做了一个。”
en: “No, my boy,” replied he, “but I made one.”

zh: 于是他把自己做的聚光镜装备给大家看。仅仅是用了工程师和记者两块手表上的玻璃。工程师在两片玻璃中间注入水，用黏土把边缘粘在一起，就制成了一个正规的聚光镜，利用它将太阳光聚在干燥的地苔上，地苔很快燃烧起来。
en: And he showed the apparatus which served for a burning-glass.It was simply two glasses which he had taken from his own and the reporter’s watches.Having filled them with water and rendered their edges adhesive by means of a little clay, he thus fabricated a regular burning-glass, which, concentrating the solar rays on some very dry moss, soon caused it to blaze.

zh: 水手细细打量了这个装备，然后凝视着工程师，一句话也不说，唯有从他的表情可以明显看出，在他的眼里，赛勒斯·哈丁即便不是一个奇才，也绝非普通人。终于他开口了，大声喊道：
en: The sailor considered the apparatus; then he gazed at the engineer without saying a word, only a look plainly expressed his opinion that if Cyrus Harding was not a magician, he was certainly no ordinary man.At last speech returned to him, and he cried,—

zh: “记下来，史佩莱先生，记在你的本子上。”
en: “Note that, Mr. Spilett, note that down on your paper!”

zh: “记下来了。”记者答道。
en: “It is noted,” replied the reporter.

zh: 接着纳布协助水手准备了肉叉，好好清理了水豚，很快就在明亮、噼啪作响的篝火上像烤猪似的烤起水豚来。
en: Then, Neb helping him, the seaman arranged the spit, and the capybara, properly cleaned, was soon roasting like a suckling-pig before a clear, crackling fire.

zh: “石窟”里变得更加舒适，不仅因为有篝火温暖着过道，而且还有木头和泥巴重新建起的隔板。
en: The Chimneys had again become more habitable, not only because the passages were warmed by the fire, but because the partitions of wood and mud had been re-established.

zh: 很明显，工程师和他的伙伴们这一天干得不错。赛勒斯·哈丁几乎完全恢复了体力，从他能爬上高地这点就能看出。他站在高地顶端，用他那擅长目测高度和距离的眼睛长时间地注视着山锥，他想明天爬到锥顶去。这座山坐落在西北方向，离这里大约六英里，据他估计，在海平面以上3500英尺。因此，如果一个观察者站在山顶上，视线可覆盖半径达五十英里的范围。因此，哈丁也就能轻易解决这里究竟是“荒岛还是大陆”的问题，这可是他非常关心的。
en: It was evident that the engineer and his companions had employed their day well.Cyrus Harding had almost entirely recovered his strength, and had proved it by climbing to the upper plateau.From this point his eye, accustomed to estimate heights and distances, was fixed for a long time on the cone, the summit of which he wished to reach the next day.The mountain, situated about six miles to the northwest, appeared to him to measure 3,500 feet above the level of the sea.Consequently the gaze of an observer posted on its summit would extend over a radius of at least fifty miles.Therefore it was probable that Harding could easily solve the question of “island or continent,” to which he attached so much importance.

zh: 他们晚餐吃得丰盛至极。水豚肉的美味赢得了大家的一致赞赏。马尾藻和石松子让这顿晚餐锦上添花，吃饭的时候工程师很少讲话。他满心盘算着第二天的计划。
en: They supped capitally.The flesh of the capybara was declared excellent.The sargassum and the almonds of the stone-pine completed the repast, during which the engineer spoke little.He was preoccupied with projects for the next day.

zh: 潘克洛夫有一两次提出一些想法，建议接下来最好怎么做。赛勒斯·哈丁虽然考虑问题明显很有条理，但他只是摇摇头，却不开口。
en: Once or twice Pencroft gave forth some ideas upon what it would be best to do; but Cyrus Harding, who was evidently of a methodical mind, only shook his head without uttering a word.

zh: “明天，”他重复道，“我们就知道应该指望什么了，然后采取相应行动。”
en: “To-morrow,” he repeated, “we shall know what we have to depend upon, and we will act accordingly.”

zh: 晚饭过后，他们又在篝火上添了新柴，“石窟”里的全体居民，包括忠诚的托普在内，很快进入了熟睡状态。
en: The meal ended, fresh armfuls of wood were thrown on the fire, and the inhabitants of the Chimneys, including the faithful Top, were soon buried in a deep sleep.

zh: 这一夜平安无事，第二天是3月29号，他们从睡梦中醒来，精神饱满，准备开始决定他们命运的一次远征。
en: No incident disturbed this peaceful night, and the next day, the 29th of March, fresh and active they awoke, ready to undertake the excursion which must determine their fate.

zh: 一切准备妥当。剩下的水豚肉足够哈丁和他的伙伴们吃上至少一昼夜。
en: All was ready for the start.The remains of the capybara would be enough to sustain Harding and his companions for at least twenty-four hours.

zh: 另外，他们希望能在路上找到更多食物。放大镜上的玻璃又安回工程师和记者的表上，潘克洛夫烧了一些亚麻布，当作火绒取火。至于火石，在这种火成岩的地区是不会缺少的。早晨七点半，这些探险者带着木棍离开了“石窟。”大家同意了潘克洛夫的意见，走森林里已经开辟的小路似乎是最好的，回来时再寻别的路。这也是到高山去最直接的道路。他们转过南面的拐角，沿着河的左岸走，走到河流折向西南的地点，那里形成了一个急弯，然后就离开了河道。他们在常青树下找到旧路，九点钟的时候，赛勒斯·哈丁和他的伙伴们已经到达了森林的西部边缘。地面始终很少有起伏，起初尽是沼泽，然后是干燥的沙地，形成了缓坡，从岸边一直升起，直到陆地内部。森林里可以看见些胆小的动物。托普迅速地扑向它们，但是它的主人很快把它喊回来，因为现在还不是开始打猎的时候，要等到稍后再说。工程师可不是一个允许自己改变既定计划的人。甚至可以说他从不去观察这个地方，不管是地势，还是这里的自然物产，他的伟大目标是要登上眼前的这座高山，因此他就一直朝着那个方向前进。十点钟时，大家休息了几分钟。走出森林以后，高山的地势就呈现在这些探险者眼前。山有两个山锥，其中一个的锥顶好似被削过似的，高约2500英尺，被许多拱柱似的石头支撑着，好像一只巨爪站在地上，足趾撑开。峡谷镶嵌其间，谷里树木丛生，最后的一丛树木耸入较低的锥顶。面向东北的山坡似乎树木稀疏一些，可以看见一条条很深的罅隙，那毫无疑问是水道。
en: Besides, they hoped to find more food on the way.As the glasses had been returned to the watches of the engineer and reporter, Pencroft burned a little linen to serve as tinder.As to flint, that would not be wanting in these regions of Plutonic origin.It was half-past seven in the morning when the explorers, armed with sticks, left the Chimneys.Following Pencroft’s advice, it appeared best to take the road already traversed through the forest, and to return by another route.It was also the most direct way to reach the mountain.They turned the south angle and followed the left bank of the river, which was abandoned at the point where it formed an elbow towards the southwest.The path, already trodden under the evergreen trees, was found, and at nine o’clock Cyrus Harding and his companions had reached the western border of the forest.The ground, till then, very little undulated, boggy at first, dry and sandy afterwards, had a gentle slope, which ascended from the shore towards the interior of the country.A few very timid animals were seen under the forest-trees.Top quickly started them, but his master soon called him back, for the time had not come to commence hunting; that would be attended to later.The engineer was not a man who would allow himself to be diverted from his fixed idea.It might even have been said that he did not observe the country at all, either in its configuration or in its natural productions, his great aim being to climb the mountain before him, and therefore straight towards it he went.At ten o’clock a halt of a few minutes was made.On leaving the forest, the mountain system of the country appeared before the explorers.The mountain was composed of two cones; the first, truncated at a height of about two thousand five hundred feet, was sustained by buttresses, which appeared to branch out like the talons of an immense claw set on the ground.Between these were narrow valleys, bristling with trees, the last clumps of which rose to the top of the lowest cone.There appeared to be less vegetation on that side of the mountain which was exposed to the northeast, and deep fissures could be seen which, no doubt, were watercourses.

zh: 第一个火山锥的上面还有另外一个，略呈弧形，稍稍斜向一边，像是一顶歪戴在头上的大圆帽。苏格兰人应该会这样形容：“他的无边呢帽怎么戴歪了。”这个火山锥看来全是由泥土构成，间或有红岩突出表面。
en: On the first cone rested a second, slightly rounded, and placed a little on one side, like a great round hat cocked over the ear.A Scotchman would have said, “His bonnet was a thocht ajee.”It appeared formed of bare earth, here and there pierced by reddish rocks.

zh: 他们想爬上第二个山锥，沿着支脉的山脊爬上去看来是最好的方式了。
en: They wished to reach the second cone, and proceeding along the ridge of the spurs seemed to be the best way by which to gain it.

zh: “我们来到火山地带了。”赛勒斯·哈丁说完后，他的伙伴们跟着他，开始沿着一个支脉一步一步向上爬，这个支脉蜿蜒地通向第一个高地，因而走起来更容易些。
en: “We are on volcanic ground,” Cyrus Harding had said, and his companions following him began to ascend by degrees on the back of a spur, which, by a winding and consequently more accessible path, joined the first plateau.

zh: 这里显然曾经经历过地震。到处可见乱石、大量的玄武岩和浮石的碎片。枞树三五成群地生长，几百尺以下的狭窄峡谷深处被茂密的树叶遮挡着，几乎透不进一丝阳光。
en: The ground had evidently been convulsed by subterranean force.Here and there stray blocks, numerous debris of basalt and pumice-stone, were met with.In isolated groups rose fir-trees, which, some hundred feet lower, at the bottom of the narrow gorges, formed massive shades almost impenetrable to the sun’s rays.

zh: 爬山的第一阶段，赫伯特说到地上的足迹，能看出是一些庞大的动物最近留下的。
en: During the first part of the ascent, Herbert remarked on the footprints which indicated the recent passage of large animals.

zh: “也许这些野兽不愿意放我们过去。”潘克洛夫说。
en: “Perhaps these beasts will not let us pass by willingly,” said Pencroft.

zh: “是啊，”记者答道，他曾在印度打过虎，在非洲猎过狮，“我们很快就会学会如何应付它们的。但目前还是小心为上！”
en: “Well,” replied the reporter, who had already hunted the tiger in India, and the lion in Africa, “we shall soon learn how successfully to encounter them.But in the meantime we must be upon our guard!”

zh: 他们慢慢地爬上山去。
en: They ascended but slowly.

zh: 道路曲折，障碍颇多，他们不能直接爬上去，因此，实际距离是很远的。有时，地面突然下降，他们走到近前才发现已临深渊，只好绕道而行。因此，他们折回原路，寻找可以通行的道路，用了大量时间，白白花了气力。十二点钟的时候，这一小队探险者在一大丛枞树底下停下吃饭，附近有一条山涧，流水顺流直下形成一个瀑布。他们发现离第一个高地还有一半的距离，天黑之前几乎不可能到达那里了。从这个角度看，海洋要辽阔得多，但是右边一个高耸的海角却挡住了他们的视线，没法看见那边是否有陆地。左边，视线可以延展到北方几英里以外，但是向西北方向他们居住的地方望去，视线就被一道山脊截住，那是一个形状奇特的山脊，构成了中央山锥的有力支撑。
en: The distance, increased by detours and obstacles which could not be surmounted directly, was long.Sometimes, too, the ground suddenly fell, and they found themselves on the edge of a deep chasm which they had to go round.Thus, in retracing their steps so as to find some practicable path, much time was employed and fatigue undergone for nothing.At twelve o’clock, when the small band of adventurers halted for breakfast at the foot of a large group of firs, near a little stream which fell in cascades, they found themselves still half way from the first plateau, which most probably they would not reach till nightfall.From this point the view of the sea was much extended, but on the right the high promontory prevented their seeing whether there was land beyond it.On the left, the sight extended several miles to the north; but, on the northwest, at the point occupied by the explorers, it was cut short by the ridge of a fantastically-shaped spur, which formed a powerful support of the central cone.

zh: 一点钟的时候，他们继续爬山。他们斜着向西南方向行进，又走进了一片浓密的灌木丛。树阴下，几对雉科的鹌鸡类飞禽拍打着翅膀。它们是角雉，喉咙下悬着肉瓣，眼睛后面有一对圆形的小冠毛。这类飞禽和家鸡差不多大，雌鸟通身褐色，雄鸟羽衣鲜红，白色斑点点缀其间，非常绚丽。吉迪恩·史佩莱捡起一块石头，巧妙有力地投射出去，一下子就打死了一只角雉。潘克洛夫被新鲜的空气刺激了食欲，两眼贪婪地盯着它们。
en: At one o’clock the ascent was continued.They slanted more towards the southwest and again entered among thick bushes.There under the shade of the trees fluttered several couples of gallinaceae belonging to the pheasant species.They were tragopans, ornamented by a pendant skin which hangs over their throats, and by two small, round horns, planted behind the eyes.Among these birds, which were about the size of a fowl, the female was uniformly brown, while the male was gorgeous in his red plumage, decorated with white spots.Gideon Spilett, with a stone cleverly and vigorously thrown, killed one of these tragopans, on which Pencroft, made hungry by the fresh air, had cast greedy eyes.

zh: 离开灌木丛地带，他们这一伙人相互搭着肩膀翻过了一段约100英尺的斜坡，来到了一片平地。此地树木稀疏，土壤好像是火山土质。爬这个斜坡需蜿蜒向上才比较容易，因为此处很陡峭，每一步都摇摇欲坠，必须十分谨慎小心。纳布和赫伯特在前，潘克洛夫在后，工程师和记者居中。此处有很多动物留下的痕迹，经常到这一高岗上来的动物一定是那些能够站得稳、脊骨柔软的羚羊或山羊。他们看见了几只，但是名字可不是潘克洛夫叫的那样，他突然大喊：“绵羊！”
en: After leaving the region of bushes, the party, assisted by resting on each other’s shoulders, climbed for about a hundred feet up a steep acclivity and reached a level place, with very few trees, where the soil appeared volcanic.It was necessary to ascend by zigzags to make the slope more easy, for it was very steep, and the footing being exceedingly precarious required the greatest caution.Neb and Herbert took the lead, Pencroft the rear, the captain and the reporter between them.The animals which frequented these heights—and there were numerous traces of them—must necessarily belong to those races of sure foot and supple spine, chamois or goat.Several were seen, but this was not the name Pencroft gave them, for all of a sudden—“Sheep!” he shouted.

zh: 大家都停下脚步，50英尺开外的地方，有六只体形庞大的动物，它们的角强壮有力、向后弯曲、顶端扁平，蓬松的绒毛隐藏在黄褐色、光滑的长毛下。
en: All stopped about fifty feet from half-a-dozen animals of a large size, with strong horns bent back and flattened towards the point, with a woolly fleece, hidden under long silky hair of a tawny color.

zh: 它们不是普通的绵羊，而是在温带山区常见的物种，赫伯特称其为摩弗仑羊。
en: They were not ordinary sheep, but a species usually found in the mountainous regions of the temperate zone, to which Herbert gave the name of the musmon.

zh: “那能把它们做成羊腿和羊排吗？”水手问道。
en: “Have they legs and chops?” asked the sailor.

zh: “能。”赫伯特回答。
en: “Yes,” replied Herbert.

zh: “好吧，那它们和绵羊有什么两样！”潘克洛夫说。
en: “Well, then, they are sheep!” said Pencroft.

zh: 这些动物站立在大块的玄武岩中间，一动不动，诧异地盯着人们，好像是第一次看见人类这种二足动物。它们突然感到了恐惧，飞快地跨过山石，消失了。
en: The animals, motionless among the blocks of basalt, gazed with an astonished eye, as if they saw human bipeds for the first time.Then their fears suddenly aroused, they disappeared, bounding over the rocks.

zh: “再见了，改日再会。”潘克洛夫望着它们嚷嚷道，那滑稽的语调令赛勒斯·哈丁、吉迪恩·史佩莱、赫伯特和纳布都禁不住大笑。
en: “Good-bye, till we meet again,” cried Pencroft, as he watched them, in such a comical tone that Cyrus Harding, Gideon Spilett, Herbert, and Neb could not help laughing.

zh: 他们继续登山。熔岩随处可见。有时含硫的泉水挡住了去路，他们只好绕道而行。有些地方，硫在其他物质中形成结晶，例如由无数小长石晶体构成的白色火山岩渣滓里。
en: The ascent was continued.Here and there were traces of lava.Sulphur springs sometimes stopped their way, and they had to go round them.In some places the sulphur had formed crystals among other substances, such as whitish cinders made of an infinity of little feldspar crystals.

zh: 临近第一高地的时候，爬山已十分困难，高地是由较低的火山锥顶部削平而成。快到四点钟的时候，他们已走过最后一片林区。现在只是有几棵歪歪扭扭的矮松，它们长在如此高的地域显然很艰辛，时常要抵抗海上刮来的狂风。让工程师和他的伙伴们感到庆幸的是，天气晴好，气流平稳。如果在海拔3000英尺的地方，即使是一阵微风，也会阻挡他们攀行的脚步。大气纯净，天高云淡。周围一片静谧。他们看不见太阳，高火山锥笼罩了西方的半边水平线，挡住了太阳，山锥的庞大阴影延展至海滩，随着红日西坠，影子拉得愈来愈长。东方出现水汽——与其说是云，还不如说是雾，在阳光的照射下，呈现出绚丽夺目的光芒。这群探险者距离高地仅有500英尺，他们打算到那里扎营过夜，然而蜿蜒的道路使这500英尺的路程成了两英里多。他们脚下的土壤好像在往下滑。
en: In approaching the first plateau formed by the truncating of the lower cone, the difficulties of the ascent were very great.Towards four o’clock the extreme zone of the trees had been passed.There only remained here and there a few twisted, stunted pines, which must have had a hard life in resisting at this altitude the high winds from the open sea.Happily for the engineer and his companions the weather was beautiful, the atmosphere tranquil; for a high breeze at an elevation of three thousand feet would have hindered their proceedings.The purity of the sky at the zenith was felt through the transparent air.A perfect calm reigned around them.They could not see the sun, then hid by the vast screen of the upper cone, which masked the half-horizon of the west, and whose enormous shadow stretching to the shore increased as the radiant luminary sank in its diurnal course.Vapor—mist rather than clouds—began to appear in the east, and assume all the prismatic colors under the influence of the solar rays.Five hundred feet only separated the explorers from the plateau, which they wished to reach so as to establish there an encampment for the night, but these five hundred feet were increased to more than two miles by the zigzags which they had to describe.The soil, as it were, slid under their feet.

zh: 这里的山坡大多很陡峭，经过风化的石头不能提供有力支撑，一踩上去就会滑落。夜幕渐临，赛勒斯·哈丁和他的伙伴们花了七个钟头，耗尽了力气，才爬上了第一个火山锥顶的高地，此时天几乎已经完全黑了。他们必须准备宿营，首先吃饭，然后睡觉，才能恢复体力。第二个火山锥底部有许多岩石，很容易找到安身之所。周围柴火不多。幸好，高地上的一些地方覆盖着地苔和干枯的灌木，可以用来生火。水手准备用石头围成一个火炉，纳布和赫伯特则忙着收集柴火。他们很快就满载着干柴归来。用火石打出火星，焦布沾到火星燃起来，纳布吹了几口气，几分钟后，在岩石的避风处，一团烈火噼啪作响地燃烧起来。他们生火的目的仅是为了抵御夜间的寒冷，既然不是为了烤鸟肉，纳布就把打来的鸟留到第二天。剩下的水豚肉和几十个石松松子就成了他们的晚餐。不到六点半，他们就吃完了晚餐。
en: The slope often presented such an angle that they slipped when the stones worn by the air did not give a sufficient support.Evening came on by degrees, and it was almost night when Cyrus Harding and his companions, much fatigued by an ascent of seven hours, arrived at the plateau of the first cone.It was then necessary to prepare an encampment, and to restore their strength by eating first and sleeping afterwards.This second stage of the mountain rose on a base of rocks, among which it would be easy to find a retreat.Fuel was not abundant.However, a fire could be made by means of the moss and dry brushwood, which covered certain parts of the plateau.While the sailor was preparing his hearth with stones which he put to this use, Neb and Herbert occupied themselves with getting a supply of fuel.They soon returned with a load of brushwood.The steel was struck, the burnt linen caught the sparks of flint, and, under Neb’s breath, a crackling fire showed itself in a few minutes under the shelter of the rocks.Their object in lighting a fire was only to enable them to withstand the cold temperature of the night, as it was not employed in cooking the bird, which Neb kept for the next day.The remains of the capybara and some dozens of the stone-pine almonds formed their supper.It was not half-past six when all was finished.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁打算趁着半亮的天色，去观察一下支撑较高火山锥的圆形底层。在休息之前，他想先去了解一下，如果火山锥的周围过于陡峭无法爬到顶部，是不是有可能从它的底部绕行。这个问题占据了他的心神，从帽锥倾斜的方向看，也就是向北倾斜，高地可能无法走通。如果从这边没法爬上山顶，又不能从火山锥底部绕行到另外一边，也就无法观察西边的陆地了，那么他们登山的目标，在某种程度上是完全无法实现了。
en: Cyrus Harding then thought of exploring in the half-light the large circular layer which supported the upper cone of the mountain.Before taking any rest, he wished to know if it was possible to get round the base of the cone in the case of its sides being too steep and its summit being inaccessible.This question preoccupied him, for it was possible that from the way the hat inclined, that is to say, towards the north, the plateau was not practicable.Also, if the summit of the mountain could not be reached on one side, and if, on the other, they could not get round the base of the cone, it would be impossible to survey the western part of the country, and their object in making the ascent would in part be altogether unattained.

zh: 因此，工程师留下潘克洛夫和纳布安排睡铺，吉迪恩·史佩莱记录当天发生的事情，自己则不顾疲惫，开始沿着高地的边沿往北走去。赫伯特陪在他的身边。
en: The engineer, accordingly, regardless of fatigue, leaving Pencroft and Neb to arrange the beds, and Gideon Spilett to note the incidents of the day, began to follow the edge of the plateau, going towards the north.Herbert accompanied him.

zh: 夜色优美宁静，光线并不太暗。赛勒斯·哈丁和男孩紧挨着一起走，一句话也不说。高地的某些地方很开阔，他们没遇到阻碍顺利前行。有些地方被岩石挡住去路，只有一条小窄路，两人不能并排走过。走了20分钟，赛勒斯·哈丁和赫伯特不得不停下了脚步。此处两个火山锥的斜坡合为一处。没有山肩隔开山的两部分。斜坡将近70度，此路不通了。
en: The night was beautiful and still, the darkness was not yet deep.Cyrus Harding and the boy walked near each other, without speaking.In some places the plateau opened before them, and they passed without hindrance.In others, obstructed by rocks, there was only a narrow path, in which two persons could not walk abreast.After a walk of twenty minutes, Cyrus Harding and Herbert were obliged to stop.From this point the slope of the two cones became one.No shoulder here separated the two parts of the mountain.The slope, being inclined almost seventy degrees, the path became impracticable.

zh: 但是，如果工程师和少年不得不放弃绕行的想法，他们反而有机会爬到火山锥顶了。
en: But if the engineer and the boy were obliged to give up thoughts of following a circular direction, in return an opportunity was given for ascending the cone.

zh: 事实上，他们的面前有个深洞。那是高低不平的火山口，火山处于活动期时，喷发的液体物质曾经由此处喷出。凝固的熔岩和硬结的火山渣形成了天然的宽阶梯，这样爬到山顶就十分便利了。
en: In fact, before them opened a deep hollow.It was the rugged mouth of the crater, by which the eruptive liquid matter had escaped at the periods when the volcano was still in activity.Hardened lava and crusted scoria formed a sort of natural staircase of large steps, which would greatly facilitate the ascent to the summit of the mountain.

zh: 哈丁匆匆瞥了一眼，毫不犹豫地进入了巨大的深洞，少年紧随其后。越往里走，光线愈暗。
en: Harding took all this in at a glance, and without hesitating, followed by the lad, he entered the enormous chasm in the midst of an increasing obscurity.

zh: 距山顶还有1000英尺的距离。能不能顺着火山口的斜坡往里走呢？很快就能见分晓了。意志坚定的工程师决心继续登山，直到无法前行为止。幸运的是，斜坡一直顺着火山内部蜿蜒而上，他们俩顺利地爬了上去。
en: There was still a height of a thousand feet to overcome.Would the interior acclivities of the crater be practicable?It would soon be seen.The persevering engineer resolved to continue his ascent until he was stopped.Happily these acclivities wound up the interior of the volcano and favored their ascent.

zh: 毫无疑问，这是一座死火山。没有一缕烟飘出，深洞里也没有一丝火光，没有轰隆声，也没有轻响，这口黑井甚至连一丝颤动也没有，也许一直通到地壳的深处。火山口的空气里没有硫磺水汽的味道。这不仅是一座沉睡的火山，还是一座完全熄灭了的死火山。赛勒斯·哈丁的计划可以成功了。
en: As to the volcano itself, it could not be doubted that it was completely extinct.No smoke escaped from its sides; not a flame could be seen in the dark hollows; not a roar, not a mutter, no trembling even issued from this black well, which perhaps reached far into the bowels of the earth.The atmosphere inside the crater was filled with no sulphurous vapor.It was more than the sleep of a volcano; it was its complete extinction.Cyrus Harding’s attempt would succeed.

zh: 他和赫伯特一步步爬上内壁，头顶上的火山口越来越开阔。圆形天空的半径在火山锥的框架下越来越大。两位探险者每迈出一步，就有更多的星星进入他们的视线。南方天空的星座漫天闪耀。天蝎座的主星在上方熠熠发亮，不远处是人马座的阿尔法星，据说它是离地球最近的星星。然后，随着火山口不断扩大，又出现了南鱼座的北落师门和南三角座。最后，在接近南极的地方，南十字座闪耀星空，它的位置相当于北半球的北极星。
en: Little by little, Herbert and he climbing up the sides of the interior, saw the crater widen above their heads.The radius of this circular portion of the sky, framed by the edge of the cone, increased obviously.At each step, as it were, that the explorers made, fresh stars entered the field of their vision.The magnificent constellations of the southern sky shone resplendently.At the zenith glittered the splendid Antares in the Scorpion, and not far was Alpha Centauri, which is believed to be the nearest star to the terrestrial globe.Then, as the crater widened, appeared Fomalhaut of the Fish, the Southern Triangle, and lastly, nearly at the Antarctic Pole, the glittering Southern Cross, which replaces the Polar Star of the Northern Hemisphere.

zh: 当赛勒斯·哈丁和赫伯特到达火山锥顶最高点时，已经将近晚上八点了。
en: It was nearly eight o’clock when Cyrus Harding and Herbert set foot on the highest ridge of the mountain at the summit of the cone.

zh: 此时夜色漆黑，他们的视线无法看到两英里以外的地方。是大海包围着这块未知的陆地，还是西接着太平洋的某个大陆呢？此时无法得知。西方的水平线上，一条带状的云清晰可见，使这里显得愈加昏暗，肉眼无法判断海天是否在同一个圆圈里相接。
en: It was then perfectly dark, and their gaze could not extend over a radius of two miles.Did the sea surround this unknown land, or was it connected in the west with some continent of the Pacific?It could not yet be made out.Towards the west, a cloudy belt, clearly visible at the horizon, increased the gloom, and the eye could not discover if the sky and water were blended together in the same circular line.

zh: 可是水平线上突然透出一丝微弱的光芒，随着乌云向头顶移动，光线慢慢投射向大地。
en: But at one point of the horizon a vague light suddenly appeared, which descended slowly in proportion as the cloud mounted to the zenith.

zh: 是一弯新月正在西沉，但是它的光亮足以清楚地照亮水平线，乌云移开以后，工程师看见新月映在水面，倒影荡漾。赛勒斯·哈丁抓住少年的手，严肃地说：
en: It was the slender crescent moon, already almost disappearing; but its light was sufficient to show clearly the horizontal line, then detached from the cloud, and the engineer could see its reflection trembling for an instant on a liquid surface.Cyrus Harding seized the lad’s hand, and in a grave voice,—

zh: “一个荒岛！”恰在这时，这弯新月消失在水波之下。
en: “An island!” said he, at the moment when the lunar crescent disappeared beneath the waves.

zh: 第十一章
en: Chapter 11

zh: 半小时之后，赛勒斯·哈丁和赫伯特回到了宿营地。工程师仅告诉他的伙伴们，命运将他们扔到的地方是一个岛，明天他们将讨论这件事情。于是大家都尽力安定下来，在那个海拔2500英尺的山洞里，这些岛上的居民在静谧的夜中，安然地睡了一觉。
en: Half an hour later Cyrus Harding and Herbert had returned to the encampment.The engineer merely told his companions that the land upon which fate had thrown them was an island, and that the next day they would consult.Then each settled himself as well as he could to sleep, and in that rocky hole, at a height of two thousand five hundred feet above the level of the sea, through a peaceful night, the islanders enjoyed profound repose.

zh: 第二天是3月30日，匆忙地吃过只有烤角雉的早餐，工程师想再去一次火山顶，以便更加细致地观察一下这个荒岛，如果荒岛离任何陆地都很远，或者在往来太平洋各群岛的航线之外，那么他们很有可能会困在岛上一辈子。这一次，他的伙伴们跟着他一起开始了新的探索。他们也想看看这个荒岛，因为他们还要依靠岛上的物产来满足生活所需。
en: The next day, the 30th of March, after a hasty breakfast, which consisted solely of the roasted tragopan, the engineer wished to climb again to the summit of the volcano, so as more attentively to survey the island upon which he and his companions were imprisoned for life perhaps, should the island be situated at a great distance from any land, or if it was out of the course of vessels which visited the archipelagoes of the Pacific Ocean.This time his companions followed him in the new exploration.They also wished to see the island, on the productions of which they must depend for the supply of all their wants.

zh: 早晨七点左右，赛勒斯·哈丁、赫伯特、潘克洛夫和吉丁·史佩莱离开了宿营地。大家似乎并未对自己的处境感到焦虑。毫无疑问，他们相信自己，但是必须指明一点，哈丁和他的伙伴们的信心基础不一样。工程师有信心，是因为他认为能够在这片荒岛上获取他和伙伴们的一切生活所需，而伙伴们之所以毫无畏惧，是因为赛勒斯·哈丁与他们在一起。尤其是潘克洛夫，自从生火事件后，他不曾有过片刻的悲观失望，即使在一块光秃秃的石头上，只要工程师在他身边，他就无所畏惧。
en: It was about seven o’clock in the morning when Cyrus Harding, Herbert, Pencroft, Gideon Spilett, and Neb quitted the encampment.No one appeared to be anxious about their situation.They had faith in themselves, doubtless, but it must be observed that the basis of this faith was not the same with Harding as with his companions.The engineer had confidence, because he felt capable of extorting from this wild country everything necessary for the life of himself and his companions; the latter feared nothing, just because Cyrus Harding was with them.Pencroft especially, since the incident of the relighted fire, would not have despaired for an instant, even if he was on a bare rock, if the engineer was with him on the rock.

zh: “呸！”他说，“我们没有官方的许可，不也离开了里士满！更何况这里肯定没有人阻拦我们，想逃不出去都难！”
en: “Pshaw,” said he, “we left Richmond without permission from the authorities!It will be hard if we don’t manage to get away some day or other from a place where certainly no one will detain us!”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁循着前一晚走过的路行进。他们绕过火山堆，沿着形成山肩的高地向巨大的深洞走去。天气晴好。太阳高挂在晴空，阳光洒满整个东面的山。
en: Cyrus Harding followed the same road as the evening before.They went round the cone by the plateau which formed the shoulder, to the mouth of the enormous chasm.The weather was magnificent.The sun rose in a pure sky and flooded with his rays all the eastern side of the mountain.

zh: 他们来到了火山口前。这里和工程师在夜间所辨认出的完全一致，也就是说，像一个巨大的漏斗由下至上延展，越来越宽，一直延伸到高地上方1000英尺的地方。洞口下方，一道道又宽又厚的熔岩顺着山的边缘蜿蜒而下，标记出当初火山喷发出的物质流向低谷的路径，使荒岛北部形成褶皱。
en: The crater was reached.It was just what the engineer had made it out to be in the dark; that is to say, a vast funnel which extended, widening, to a height of a thousand feet above the plateau.Below the chasm, large thick streaks of lava wound over the sides of the mountain, and thus marked the course of the eruptive matter to the lower valleys which furrowed the northern part of the island.

zh: 火山口内部的斜坡不过35度到40度，对于爬山者来讲，构不成任何困难或障碍。古老的岩浆留下的痕迹依然可见，这些岩浆有可能是在旁边的洞口开出新道以前，从山顶溢出来的。
en: The interior of the crater, whose inclination did not exceed thirty five to forty degrees, presented no difficulties nor obstacles to the ascent.Traces of very ancient lava were noticed, which probably had overflowed the summit of the cone, before this lateral chasm had opened a new way to it.

zh: 火山通道贯通了底层和火山口，因为火山隐藏在朦胧中，其深度无法目测。但是确定无疑的是，火山已完全熄灭。
en: As to the volcanic chimney which established a communication between the subterranean layers and the crater, its depth could not be calculated with the eye, for it was lost in obscurity.But there was no doubt as to the complete extinction of the volcano.

zh: 八点之前，哈丁和他的伙伴们聚集到火山口顶端，站在北边隆起的锥形小丘上。
en: Before eight o’clock Harding and his companions were assembled at the summit of the crater, on a conical mound which swelled the northern edge.

zh: “大海，到处是海！”他们喊着，似乎他们的嘴唇不能阻止言语冒出来，这句话使他们成了岛上的居民。
en: “The sea, the sea everywhere!” they cried, as if their lips could not restrain the words which made islanders of them.

zh: 的确，大海形成一望无际的环状水域围着他们！赛勒斯·哈丁也许原本心存希望，想再次爬上火山锥顶时能够发现某个海滨和岛岸，因为前一晚在黑暗中没能看清。然而，直到地平线的最远端也没有任何东西出现，也就是说，方圆50多英里内什么都没有。没有一片陆地。没有一叶孤帆。在这一望无际的空间里只有海洋是可见的，荒岛就占据着这个似乎无边无际的圆形中心。
en: The sea, indeed, formed an immense circular sheet of water all around them!Perhaps, on climbing again to the summit of the cone, Cyrus Harding had had a hope of discovering some coast, some island shore, which he had not been able to perceive in the dark the evening before.But nothing appeared on the farthest verge of the horizon, that is to say over a radius of more than fifty miles.No land in sight.Not a sail.Over all this immense space the ocean alone was visible—the island occupied the center of a circumference which appeared to be infinite.

zh: 工程师和他的伙伴们默默地站在那里，一动不动，用几分钟时间仔细地观察了海洋的每一个方向，直到最远的边际。甚至连眼力好得出奇的潘克洛夫也没看见任何东西，如果水平线上有陆地，即使它像水汽一样模糊不清，水手也一定能发现，好像他的眉毛下天生就带着一副正规的望远镜。
en: The engineer and his companions, mute and motionless, surveyed for some minutes every point of the ocean, examining it to its most extreme limits.Even Pencroft, who possessed a marvelous power of sight, saw nothing; and certainly if there had been land at the horizon, if it appeared only as an indistinct vapor, the sailor would undoubtedly have found it out, for nature had placed regular telescopes under his eyebrows.

zh: 他们的视线从海洋转移到能够俯瞰的整个荒岛，吉丁·史佩莱率先想到了一个问题：
en: From the ocean their gaze returned to the island which they commanded entirely, and the first question was put by Gideon Spilett in these terms:

zh: “这个荒岛大概有多大？”
en: “About what size is this island?”

zh: 在这片广阔无际的海洋中间，它的确显得并不太大。
en: Truly, it did not appear large in the midst of the immense ocean.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁思索了几分钟，他留心地观察了一下海岛四周，将自己所在位置的高度考虑在内，然后说：
en: Cyrus Harding reflected a few minutes; he attentively observed the perimeter of the island, taking into consideration the height at which he was placed; then,—

zh: “朋友们，我想自己应该不会估计错误，这个海岛周长大概有100多英里。”
en: “My friends,” said he, “I do not think I am mistaken in giving to the shore of the island a circumference of more than a hundred miles.”

zh: “那么面积有多大？”
en: “And consequently an area?”

zh: “那很难估计，”工程师回答，“因为这个岛的地势太不平坦。”
en: “That is difficult to estimate,” replied the engineer, “for it is so uneven.”

zh: 如果赛勒斯·哈丁估计得正确，那么这个海岛几乎和地中海里德马耳他岛或赞得岛差不多大，但同时，这个岛的地势更为不规则，海角、地岬、地角、港湾和河流却更为稀少。奇怪的地形吸引了众人的目光，吉丁·史佩莱听从了工程师的建议，画下了海岛的轮廓，他们发现它很像某种奇异的动物，如同一只庞大的海怪平躺着，睡在太平洋的海面上。
en: If Cyrus Harding was not mistaken in his calculation, the island had almost the extent of Malta or Zante, in the Mediterranean, but it was at the same time much more irregular and less rich in capes, promontories, points, bays, or creeks.Its strange form caught the eye, and when Gideon Spilett, on the engineer’s advice, had drawn the outline, they found that it resembled some fantastic animal, a monstrous leviathan, which lay sleeping on the surface of the Pacific.

zh: 海岛的形状确实如此，知道这点很重要，记者立刻就准确地勾勒出了海岛的一幅草图。
en: This was in fact the exact shape of the island, which it is of consequence to know, and a tolerably correct map of it was immediately drawn by the reporter.

zh: 海岛的东岸形成一个开阔的海湾，这里就是落难者们登陆的地方，海湾尽头是一个突出的海角，潘克洛夫第一次探险的时候漏掉了这里，因为它被隆起的地角挡住了。东北方向有另外两个海角围着海湾，中间有一条狭长的海峡，看上去像是一只半张着下巴的恐怖角蛟。
en: The east part of the shore, where the castaways had landed, formed a wide bay, terminated by a sharp cape, which had been concealed by a high point from Pencroft on his first exploration.At the northeast two other capes closed the bay, and between them ran a narrow gulf, which looked like the half-open jaws of a formidable dog-fish.

zh: 从东北到西北海岸呈弧形，如同动物的扁平头盖，接着海岸向上突起，高出地面一大块，但是这部分海岛并不像任何特定形状，海岛中间被火山占据。
en: From the northeast to the southwest the coast was rounded, like the flattened cranium of an animal, rising again, forming a sort of protuberance which did not give any particular shape to this part of the island, of which the center was occupied by the volcano.

zh: 从这里开始，海岸从南到北十分规则，在沿岸三分之二处被一条很窄的小溪隔开，海岸在此处成了长尾形，好似短吻鳄的尾突。
en: From this point the shore ran pretty regularly north and south, broken at two-thirds of its perimeter by a narrow creek, from which it ended in a long tail, similar to the caudal appendage of a gigantic alligator.

zh: 尾巴这里形成规则半岛，延伸到海里30多英里，是从已经提过的海岛东南海角算起的。半岛弯曲，形成一个开放的抛锚处，标记出这块形状奇特的海岛的低海岸部分。
en: This tail formed a regular peninsula, which stretched more than thirty miles into the sea, reckoning from the cape southeast of the island, already mentioned; it curled round, making an open roadstead, which marked out the lower shore of this strangely-formed land.

zh: 海岛最狭窄的地方，也就是从“石窟”到同纬度的西海岸的小河之间，只有十英里远。然而，海岛最狭长的地带，也就是从东北的峡口到西南端的半岛尾部，距离至少有30英里。
en: At the narrowest part, that is to say between the Chimneys and the creek on the western shore, which corresponded to it in latitude, the island only measured ten miles; but its greatest length, from the jaws at the northeast to the extremity of the tail of the southwest, was not less than thirty miles.

zh: 海岛内陆的情形大致是这样的，从高山到海岸的南部一带树木茂盛，北部则干燥多沙。在火山和东海岸之间，赛勒斯·哈丁和他的伙伴们惊异地发现一个湖泊，湖边还有许多常绿树木，这可出乎他们的预料。从山顶望去，湖面似乎和海面持平，但是工程师思索后向大家解释道，这片水域的高度一定在300英尺左右，因为湖泊在高地上，而高地是由海岸延伸而成的。
en: As to the interior of the island, its general aspect was this, very woody throughout the southern part from the mountain to the shore, and arid and sandy in the northern part.Between the volcano and the east coast Cyrus Harding and his companions were surprised to see a lake, bordered with green trees, the existence of which they had not suspected.Seen from this height, the lake appeared to be on the same level as the ocean, but, on reflection, the engineer explained to his companions that the altitude of this little sheet of water must be about three hundred feet, because the plateau, which was its basin, was but a prolongation of the coast.

zh: “这是淡水湖吗？”潘克洛夫问道。
en: “Is it a freshwater lake?” asked Pencroft.

zh: “当然，”工程师回答道，“因为湖水一定是高山上流下的水供给的。”
en: “Certainly,” replied the engineer, “for it must be fed by the water which flows from the mountain.”

zh: “我看见了一条小河流入湖里。”赫伯特指着一道狭长的溪水说道，很显然溪水来自西边一带。
en: “I see a little river which runs into it,” said Herbert, pointing out a narrow stream, which evidently took its source somewhere in the west.

zh: “是啊，”哈丁说，“既然小河为湖泊供给了水源，那么在海边附近很可能有一个出口，多余的水会从那里排出去。我们可以在回去的时候看看。”
en: “Yes,” said Harding; “and since this stream feeds the lake, most probably on the side near the sea there is an outlet by which the surplus water escapes.We shall see that on our return.”

zh: 这条曲折的小河道和前面已经提过的河流，构成了岛上的水系，至少在探险家们看来是如此。然而，海岛有三分之二的土地都被树木覆盖，形成一片广阔的森林，所以很可能有其他河流从树丛底下流入海洋。甚至可以这样推断，从这片区域就能看出，海岛上瑰丽的温带植物品种着实丰富。没有迹象显示北部有流淌的河水，也许东北部的沼泽地带会有些死水。但是，除此以外就是一些沙丘、沙滩和干燥的土地，这和海岛上那些草木丰茂的地带形成鲜明的对比。
en: This little winding watercourse and the river already mentioned constituted the water-system, at least such as it was displayed to the eyes of the explorers.However, it was possible that under the masses of trees which covered two-thirds of the island, forming an immense forest, other rivers ran towards the sea.It might even be inferred that such was the case, so rich did this region appear in the most magnificent specimens of the flora of the temperate zones.There was no indication of running water in the north, though perhaps there might be stagnant water among the marshes in the northeast; but that was all, in addition to the downs, sand, and aridity which contrasted so strongly with the luxuriant vegetation of the rest of the island.

zh: 火山不在海岛中央，相反，它矗立在西北地带，好似两个地带的分界线。在西南、正南和东北地带，第一部分的支脉完全被翠绿的树木笼盖。北部地带则恰恰相反，人们可以清楚地看见山脉的分支，一直延展到沙地的平原上才收尾。当初火山喷发时，就是在这一边冲开了一个大的通道，大量的熔岩蔓延到狭窄的出口处，形成了东北方向的港湾。
en: The volcano did not occupy the central part; it rose, on the contrary, in the northwestern region, and seemed to mark the boundary of the two zones.At the southwest, at the south, and the southeast, the first part of the spurs were hidden under masses of verdure.At the north, on the contrary, one could follow their ramifications, which died away on the sandy plains.It was on this side that, at the time when the mountain was in a state of eruption, the discharge had worn away a passage, and a large heap of lava had spread to the narrow jaw which formed the northeastern gulf.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和他的伙伴们在山顶呆了一个小时。在他们的视线下方，海岛一览无余，如同一幅彩色的平面图，绿色的是森林，黄色的是沙地，蓝色的是水域。他们纵览了海岛的全貌，除了绿荫覆盖的土地、凹陷的山谷和火山裂口的内壁。
en: Cyrus Harding and his companions remained an hour at the top of the mountain.The island was displayed under their eyes, like a plan in relief with different tints, green for the forests, yellow for the sand, blue for the water.They viewed it in its tout-ensemble, nothing remained concealed but the ground hidden by verdure, the hollows of the valleys, and the interior of the volcanic chasms.

zh: 一个重要的问题仍然悬而未决，而问题的答案对这些落难者们的未来却有着极大的影响。
en: One important question remained to be solved, and the answer would have a great effect upon the future of the castaways.

zh: 这个岛上是否有人居住？
en: Was the island inhabited?

zh: 这个问题是记者提出的，经过他们一番仔细检查之后，答案似乎是否定的。
en: It was the reporter who put this question, to which after the close examination they had just made, the answer seemed to be in the negative.

zh: 到处都没有发现人类开拓过的迹象。海岸上没有一簇茅舍，没有一个小屋，也没有一处渔场。岛上也没有袅袅上升的轻烟，证明无人居住。当然，距探索者们最远的地方——向西南方向延伸的半岛，大概有将近30英里——即使对于潘克洛夫，也很难发现那里有没有住宅。岛上四分之三的土地都被森林覆盖，所以他们也没法掀开层层的草木，看看底下是否藏着稀疏的村舍。但是总体看来，他们落在了太平洋上一个狭小空间的土地上，这里似乎完全是个荒岛。
en: Nowhere could the work of a human hand be perceived.Not a group of huts, not a solitary cabin, not a fishery on the shore.No smoke curling in the air betrayed the presence of man.It is true, a distance of nearly thirty miles separated the observers from the extreme points, that is, of the tail which extended to the southwest, and it would have been difficult, even to Pencroft’s eyes, to discover a habitation there.Neither could the curtain of verdure, which covered three-quarters of the island, be raised to see if it did not shelter some straggling village.But in general the islanders live on the shores of the narrow spaces which emerge above the waters of the Pacific, and this shore appeared to be an absolute desert.

zh: 要想确定岛上究竟有没有居民，只有进行更为全面的探索才能水落石出。但是附近岛屿上的居民会不会经常光顾这里呢？哪怕只是偶尔也好。这个问题很难回答。方圆50英里之内看不见一处陆地。无论是对于马来人的快速三角帆船，还是波利尼西亚人的大独木舟，横渡50英里的距离简直轻而易举。一切都取决于海岛的位置，它是孤立地立于太平洋上，还是靠近什么群岛？赛勒斯·哈丁能否不借助工具就计算出它们所处的经纬度呢？这很困难。既然他对此心存怀疑，最好还是谨慎为妙，未雨绸缪，防范土著居民突然出现。
en: Until a more complete exploration, it might be admitted that the island was uninhabited.But was it frequented, at least occasionally, by the natives of neighboring islands?It was difficult to reply to this question.No land appeared within a radius of fifty miles.But fifty miles could be easily crossed, either by Malay proas or by the large Polynesian canoes.Everything depended on the position of the island, of its isolation in the Pacific, or of its proximity to archipelagoes.Would Cyrus Harding be able to find out their latitude and longitude without instruments?It would be difficult.Since he was in doubt, it was best to take precautions against a possible descent of neighboring natives.

zh: 海岛探索之旅结束了，形状确定了，地势清楚了，大小计算好了，河流和山的分布也查清了。记者大致画下了森林和平原的位置。他们现在只需再次下山，并从矿物、动物和植物这三个角度来考察这片土地的情况。
en: The exploration of the island was finished, its shape determined, its features made out, its extent calculated, the water and mountain systems ascertained.The disposition of the forests and plains had been marked in a general way on the reporter’s plan.They had now only to descend the mountain slopes again, and explore the soil, in the triple point of view, of its mineral, vegetable, and animal resources.

zh: 但在示意伙伴们动身之前，赛勒斯·哈丁以一种平静而严肃的口吻说道：
en: But before giving his companions the signal for departure, Cyrus Harding said to them in a calm, grave voice,—

zh: “朋友们，是上天将我们抛在这一小块土地上。我们将要生活在这里，或许要住很久。或许会有意外的帮助，如果恰巧有船只路过此处。我说‘恰巧’，是因为这是一个毫不知名的小岛，甚至连个可以泊船的港口也没有，恐怕它处于惯常航线之外，也就是说，对于那些经常往返于太平洋各群岛的船只来讲，这里太偏南了，但对于绕过和恩角到澳洲去的船只来讲，这里又太偏北了。我丝毫不打算对你们隐瞒我们的处境……”
en: Here, my friends, is the small corner of land upon which the hand of the Almighty has thrown us.We are going to live here; a long time, perhaps.Perhaps, too, unexpected help will arrive, if some ship passes by chance.I say by chance, because this is an unimportant island; there is not even a port in which ships could anchor, and it is to be feared that it is situated out of the route usually followed, that is to say, too much to the south for the ships which frequent the archipelagoes of the Pacific, and too much to the north for those which go to Australia by doubling Cape Horn.I wish to hide nothing of our position from you—”

zh: “你是对的，亲爱的赛勒斯，”记者兴奋地说，“你身边的人都是男子汉。他们都信任你，你也可以信任他们。是不是这样，朋友们？”
en: “And you are right, my dear Cyrus,” replied the reporter, with animation.“You have to deal with men.They have confidence in you, and you can depend upon them.Is it not so, my friends?”

zh: “我完全遵从你的指挥。”赫伯特握住工程师的手说道。
en: “I will obey you in everything, captain,” said Herbert, seizing the engineer’s hand.

zh: “你是我永远的主人，无论在哪里！”纳布喊道。
en: “My master always, and everywhere!” cried Neb.

zh: “至于我嘛，”水手说道，“如果我有任何抱怨，我就不叫杰克·潘克洛夫，只要你愿意，我们就在这座岛上开辟出一个小美国！我们要建立城池，我们要铺设铁路，开通电报。等到某天岛上发生了巨大的变化，一切都秩序井然，变得文明的时候，我们就去把它献给联合政府。我只有一个要求。”
en: “As for me,” said the sailor, “if I ever grumble at work, my name’s not Jack Pencroft, and if you like, captain, we will make a little America of this island!We will build towns, we will establish railways, start telegraphs, and one fine day, when it is quite changed, quite put in order and quite civilized, we will go and offer it to the government of the Union.Only, I ask one thing.”

zh: “什么？”记者问。
en: “What is that?” said the reporter.

zh: “那就是，我们不要把自己看作是落难者，而是拓荒者，我们来这里是为了定居的。”哈丁禁不住笑了起来，水手的建议被采纳了。他感谢了他的朋友，并补充说，他会依靠大家的力量，并依托上天的保佑。
en: “It is, that we do not consider ourselves castaways, but colonists, who have come here to settle.”Harding could not help smiling, and the sailor’s idea was adopted.He then thanked his companions, and added, that he would rely on their energy and on the aid of Heaven.

zh: “好了，现在我们回‘石窟’吧！”潘克洛夫喊道。
en: “Well, now let us set off to the Chimneys!” cried Pencroft.

zh: “等一下，朋友们，”工程师说道，“我认为应该给这个海岛起个名字，还有我们看到的海角、地岬、河流，也要起个名字。”
en: “One minute, my friends,” said the engineer.“It seems to me it would be a good thing to give a name to this island, as well as to, the capes, promontories, and watercourses, which we can see.”

zh: “太好了，”记者说道，“以后我们要发指令和遵循指令的时候，就简单多了。”
en: “Very good,” said the reporter.“In the future, that will simplify the instructions which we shall have to give and follow.”

zh: “的确如此，”水手说道，“我们已经能够表达出自己去往何处，或从何处来了。起码听起来像个地方。”
en: “Indeed,” said the sailor, “already it is something to be able to say where one is going, and where one has come from.At least, it looks like somewhere.”

zh: “比如说‘石窟’。”赫伯特说道。
en: “The Chimneys, for example,” said Herbert.

zh: “完全正确！”潘克洛夫回答，“这个名字最实用了，这可是我自己想出来的。我们就把第一次宿营的地方叫‘石窟’吧，赛勒斯先生？”
en: “Exactly!” replied Pencroft.“That name was the most convenient, and it came to me quite of myself.Shall we keep the name of the Chimneys for our first encampment, captain?”

zh: “好的，潘克洛夫，既然你给了它名字，就这么叫吧。”
en: “Yes, Pencroft, since you have so christened it.”

zh: “太棒了！至于其他的也很容易，”水手兴致勃勃地说，“赫伯特经常给我讲起鲁宾逊的故事，我们就模仿他，给这里起名吧，比如上苍湾、鲸鱼岬、失望角！”
en: “Good! as for the others, that will be easy,” returned the sailor, who was in high spirits.“Let us give them names, as the Robinsons did, whose story Herbert has often read to me; Providence Bay, Whale Point, Cape Disappointment!”

zh: “不如就用哈丁先生的名字来命名吧，”赫伯特说，“还有史佩莱先生的名字，纳布的名字……”
en: “Or, rather, the names of Captain Harding,” said Herbert, “of Mr. Spilett, of Neb!—”

zh: “还有我的名字！”纳布喊道，露出他雪白发亮的牙齿。
en: “My name!” cried Neb, showing his sparkling white teeth.

zh: “有何不可？”潘克洛夫说，“纳布港，很好啊！还有吉丁角——”
en: “Why not?” replied Pencroft.“Port Neb, that would do very well!And Cape Gideon—”

zh: “我更愿意借用祖国的地名，”记者说，“这会让我们时刻不忘美国。”
en: “I should prefer borrowing names from our country,” said the reporter, “which would remind us of America.”

zh: “好，对于重要的地方，”赛勒斯·哈丁接着说道，“我十分赞成这样命名海湾和海洋。比方说，我们可以把东边的大海湾叫做联合湾，南边的大海湾就叫华盛顿湾，我们所处的这座山就叫富兰克林山，我们眼下延伸的湖就叫格兰特湖，这样再好不过了，朋友们。这些名字会让我们想起自己的祖国，想起那些为祖国增光的伟大公民。至于我们从山顶看到的这些河流、海湾、海角和地岬，选的名字要能体现它们的独特形状。这样印象更深刻，也更实际。海岛的形状太奇特了，我们不必劳神想象它与什么东西相似。至于那些我们尚不知道的溪流，它们分布于森林各处，我们将来要去进一步探索，这些以后发现的溪流，我们在发现之时再命名。这样如何，朋友们？”
en: “Yes, for the principal ones,” then said Cyrus Harding; “for those of the bays and seas, I admit it willingly.We might give to that vast bay on the east the name of Union Bay, for example; to that large hollow on the south, Washington Bay; to the mountain upon which we are standing, that of Mount Franklin; to that lake which is extended under our eyes, that of Lake Grant; nothing could be better, my friends.These names will recall our country, and those of the great citizens who have honored it; but for the rivers, gulfs, capes, and promontories, which we perceive from the top of this mountain, rather let us choose names which will recall their particular shape.They will impress themselves better on our memory, and at the same time will be more practical.The shape of the island is so strange that we shall not be troubled to imagine what it resembles.As to the streams which we do not know as yet, in different parts of the forest which we shall explore later, the creeks which afterwards will he discovered, we can christen them as we find them.What do you think, my friends?”

zh: 工程师的提议赢得了伙伴们的一致赞成。海岛在他们的眼下铺展，如同一幅地图，他们只差给各角各点起个名字了。吉丁·史佩莱记下这些名字后，海岛的地理名字也就正式被采纳了。正如工程师建议的那样，他们首先将两个海湾和高山命名为联合湾、华盛顿湾和富兰克林山。
en: The engineer’s proposal was unanimously agreed to by his companions.The island was spread out under their eyes like a map, and they had only to give names to all its angles and points.Gideon Spilett would write them down, and the geographical nomenclature of the island would be definitely adopted.First, they named the two bays and the mountain, Union Bay, Washington Bay, and Mount Franklin, as the engineer had suggested.

zh: “现在，”记者说道，“我建议将海岛西南的半岛叫做盘蛇半岛，半岛末端的弯尾巴就叫爬虫角，因为它很像一个爬虫的尾巴。”
