en: “Now,” said the reporter, “to this peninsula at the southwest of the island, I propose to give the name of Serpentine Peninsula, and that of Reptile-end to the bent tail which terminates it, for it is just like a reptile’s tail.”

zh: “同意。”工程师说道。
en: “Adopted,” said the engineer.

zh: “那么，”赫伯特指着海岛的另一端说，“我们就把那个海湾叫做鲨鱼湾吧，它很像张开的大鱼嘴。”
en: “Now,” said Herbert, pointing to the other extremity of the island, “let us call this gulf which is so singularly like a pair of open jaws, Shark Gulf.”

zh: “妙极了！”潘克洛夫喊道，“我们就把嘴的两部分叫做颚骨角吧，这样就完全匹配了。”
en: “Capital!” cried Pencroft, “and we can complete the resemblance by naming the two parts of the jaws Mandible Cape.”

zh: “但是还有两个海角呢。”记者发现。
en: “But there are two capes,” observed the reporter.

zh: “好吧，”潘克洛夫答道，“我们可以分别叫它们北颚角和南颚角。”
en: “Well,” replied Pencroft, “we can have North Mandible Cape and South Mandible Cape.”

zh: “都记好了。”史佩莱说道。
en: “They are inscribed,” said Spilett.

zh: “只有海岛西南角没命名了。”潘克洛夫说。
en: “There is only the point at the southeastern extremity of the island to be named,” said Pencroft.

zh: “是联合湾的末端那个吗？”赫伯特问道。
en: “That is, the extremity of Union Bay?” asked Herbert.

zh: “就叫爪角吧。”纳布脱口喊道，他也想成为某部分领域的教父。
en: “Claw Cape,” cried Neb directly, who also wished to be godfather to some part of his domain.

zh: 事实上，纳布确实起了个十分贴切的名字，因为海岛的奇异形状像是一只怪兽，这个海角十分像是这只怪兽的强大利爪。
en: In truth, Neb had found an excellent name, for this cape was very like the powerful claw of the fantastic animal which this singularly-shaped island represented.

zh: 潘克洛夫对于事情的进展非常满意，他们很快就给河流起了个名字，因为气球将他们降落在河水附近，他们才可以喝到淡水，所以为了感谢上苍的眷顾，他们给这条河命名为慈悲河。落难者们首次登陆的小岛叫做安全岛，高耸在“石窟”上方的花岗岩峭壁顶端是一块高地，站在那里放眼望去，整个宽阔的海湾尽收眼底，于是他们就把这个高地叫做眺望岗。
en: Pencroft was delighted at the turn things had taken, and their imaginations soon gave to the river which furnished the settlers with drinking water and near which the balloon had thrown them, the name of the Mercy, in true gratitude to Providence.To the islet upon which the castaways had first landed, the name of Safety Island; to the plateau which crowned the high granite precipice above the Chimneys, and from whence the gaze could embrace the whole of the vast bay, the name of Prospect Heights.

zh: 最后，他们又把覆盖盘蛇半岛、不能穿越的整片森林命名为远西森林。
en: Lastly, all the masses of impenetrable wood which covered the Serpentine Peninsula were named the forests of the Far West.

zh: 海岛上看得见和已知的地方的命名告一段落，以后发现新地点时会继续命名。
en: The nomenclature of the visible and known parts of the island was thus finished, and later, they would complete it as they made fresh discoveries.

zh: 至于各个部分的方位，工程师根据太阳的高度和位置粗略地做了测定，将联合岛和眺望岗定位在正东方向。但是第二天，通过日出和日落的准确时间和记录太阳在正午的位置，他准确定位了海岛的正北方向，因为海岛位于南半球，正午时分太阳处于南方，而不是北方，这跟在北半球所看到的太阳有所不同。
en: As to the points of the compass, the engineer had roughly fixed them by the height and position of the sun, which placed Union Bay and Prospect Heights to the east.But the next day, by taking the exact hour of the rising and setting of the sun, and by marking its position between this rising and setting, he reckoned to fix the north of the island exactly, for, in consequence of its situation in the Southern Hemisphere, the sun, at the precise moment of its culmination, passed in the north and not in the south, as, in its apparent movement, it seems to do, to those places situated in the Northern Hemisphere.

zh: 一切工作已经完毕，居民们只等着走下富兰克林山回到“石窟”了，这时，潘克洛夫突然喊叫起来：
en: Everything was finished, and the settlers had only to descend Mount Franklin to return to the Chimneys, when Pencroft cried out,—

zh: “天啊！我们太傻了！”
en: “Well! we are preciously stupid!”

zh: “怎么了？”吉丁·史佩莱合上笔记本正准备离开。
en: “Why?” asked Gideon Spilett, who had closed his notebook and risen to depart.

zh: “怎么了！我们的岛！我们竟然忘记给它起名字了！”
en: “Why! our island! we have forgotten to christen it!”

zh: 赫伯特正准备提议用工程师的名字来命名，伙伴们会鼓掌赞成的，但这时赛勒斯·哈丁简单地说道：
en: Herbert was going to propose to give it the engineer’s name and all his companions would have applauded him, when Cyrus Harding said simply,—

zh: “我们就用一个伟大公民的名字命名它吧，朋友们，这个公民正为捍卫美利坚合众国的统一而作斗争！我们就叫它林肯岛吧！”
en: “Let us give it the name of a great citizen, my friend; of him who now struggles to defend the unity of the American Republic!Let us call it Lincoln Island!”

zh: 工程师的提议得到了大家的三次叫好声。
en: The engineer’s proposal was replied to by three hurrahs.

zh: 那晚睡觉前，新的开拓者们聊起了他们阔别的祖国，谈到了恐怖的血腥战争，他们确信南方军很快就会被打败，而北方的事业是正义的事业，加上格兰特将军和林肯的领导，一定会取得胜利。
en: And that evening, before sleeping, the new colonists talked of their absent country; they spoke of the terrible war which stained it with blood; they could not doubt that the South would soon be subdued, and that the cause of the North, the cause of justice, would triumph, thanks to Grant, thanks to Lincoln!

zh: 这是发生在1865年3月30日的事情。他们从未想到16天以后，华盛顿会发生一件恐怖的罪行，在耶稣受难日那天，亚伯拉罕·林肯竟死在一个丧心病狂的暴徒手下。
en: Now this happened the 30th of March, 1865.They little knew that sixteen days afterwards a frightful crime would be committed in Washington, and that on Good Friday Abraham Lincoln would fall by the hand of a fanatic.

zh: 第十二章
en: Chapter 12

zh: 他们现在开始下山。顺着火山口向下走，绕过火山锥，他们回到了前一晚的宿营地。潘克洛夫觉得应该是早饭时间了，于是就看了看记者和工程师的表，确定一下时间。
en: They now began the descent of the mountain.Climbing down the crater, they went round the cone and reached their encampment of the previous night.Pencroft thought it must be breakfast-time, and the watches of the reporter and engineer were therefore consulted to find out the hour.

zh: 吉丁·史佩莱的表没有浸过海水，因为他是被抛向了海浪不能到达的沙滩上。这块表质量上乘，是一只完好无缺的怀表，记者每天都不忘小心翼翼地上发条。
en: That of Gideon Spilett had been preserved from the sea-water, as he had been thrown at once on the sand out of reach of the waves.It was an instrument of excellent quality, a perfect pocket chronometer, which the reporter had not forgotten to wind up carefully every day.

zh: 至于工程师的表，当然是他在沙丘上的那段时间内停的。
en: As to the engineer’s watch, it, of course, had stopped during the time which he had passed on the downs.

zh: 工程师现在给他的表上了发条，根据太阳的高度估计应是上午九点，他就把表调到了那个时间。
en: The engineer now wound it up, and ascertaining by the height of the sun that it must be about nine o’clock in the morning, he put his watch at that hour.

zh: “不，亲爱的史佩莱，等一下。你的表显示的是里士满的时间，是吧？”
en: “No, my dear Spilett, wait.You have kept the Richmond time, have you not?”

zh: “是啊，赛勒斯。”
en: “Yes, Cyrus.”

zh: “那么，你表上的时间是根据里士满的子午线确定的，里士满和华盛顿几乎处于同一子午线，是吗？”
en: “Consequently, your watch is set by the meridian of that town, which is almost that of Washington?”

zh: “的确如此。”
en: “Undoubtedly.”

zh: “很好。不要动它。记住每天给它上发条，调准确，但不要拨动表的指针。这也许对我们有用处。”
en: “Very well, keep it thus.Content yourself with winding it up very, exactly, but do not touch the hands.This may be of use to us.”

zh: “这样做有什么用处呢？”水手暗自琢磨。
en: “What will be the good of that?” thought the sailor.

zh: 他们痛快地吃了一顿，余下的猎物和松子都吃光了。但是潘克洛夫一点也不担心，他们在路上可以找到吃的。托普吃的那份很符合它的口味，它知道怎样在灌木丛里寻找新的猎物。此外，水手想起可以让工程师制造一些火药或一两只猎枪，他认为这对工程师来讲简直是小菜一碟。
en: They ate, and so heartily, that the store of game and almonds was totally exhausted.But Pencroft was not at all uneasy, they would supply themselves on the way.Top, whose share had been very much to his taste, would know how to find some fresh game among the brushwood.Moreover, the sailor thought of simply asking the engineer to manufacture some powder and one or two fowling-pieces; he supposed there would be no difficulty in that.

zh: 离开高地之后，工程师向伙伴们提议另选一条道路回到“石窟”。他想观察一下格兰特湖，它被丛林环抱，十分壮观。于是，他们沿着一个支脉的山顶行进，也许能在这些支脉之间发现供给湖水的河流源头。在聊天时，居民们已开始引用他们自己起的新地名了，这给他们交流想法带来了极大便利。赫伯特和潘克洛夫——一个年轻，一个孩子气——都着了迷，水手边走边说道；
en: On leaving the plateau, the captain proposed to his companions to return to the Chimneys by a new way.He wished to reconnoiter Lake Grant, so magnificently framed in trees.They therefore followed the crest of one of the spurs, between which the creek that supplied the lake probably had its source.In talking, the settlers already employed the names which they had just chosen, which singularly facilitated the exchange of their ideas.Herbert and Pencroft—the one young and the other very boyish—were enchanted, and while walking, the sailor said,

zh: “嘿，赫伯特！听起来多棒啊！这样我们就不会走丢了，孩子，因为不管我们是朝着格兰特湖的方向走，还是沿着慈悲河穿越远西森林，我们一定能到眺望岗，然后就会到达联合湾！”
en: “Hey, Herbert! how capital it sounds!It will be impossible to lose ourselves, my boy, since, whether we follow the way to Lake Grant, or whether we join the Mercy through the woods of the Far West, we shall be certain to arrive at Prospect Heights, and, consequently, at Union Bay!”

zh: 大家达成一致，一定要等到人员聚齐了再走，谁都不可以单独行动。海岛的茂密森林中一定有危险的野兽出没，谨慎起见，还是要小心提防为好。通常，都是有潘克洛夫、赫伯特和纳布先行，托普带路，他总是钻进灌木丛里，用鼻子嗅嗅。记者和工程师并排前行，吉丁·史佩莱随时准备记录下每一个事件，工程师大部分时间都很沉默，有时会走到一旁，捡起些东西——一块矿物，或是某些植物，他总是将捡回来的东西装进口袋里，不发一言。
en: It had been agreed, that without forming a compact band, the settlers should not stray away from each other.It was very certain that the thick forests of the island were inhabited by dangerous animals, and it was prudent to be on their guard.In general, Pencroft, Herbert, and Neb walked first, preceded by Top, who poked his nose into every bush.The reporter and the engineer went together, Gideon Spilett ready to note every incident, the engineer silent for the most part, and only stepping aside to pick up one thing or another, a mineral or vegetable substance, which he put into his pocket, without making any remark.

zh: “他都捡了些什么东西啊？”潘克洛夫小声说，“我想找些值得弯腰去捡的东西，可是一无所获。”
en: “What can he be picking up?” muttered Pencroft.“I have looked in vain for anything that’s worth the trouble of stooping for.”

zh: 快到十点的时候，小队跨下了富兰克林山的最后一级山坡。到目前为止，这里的灌木丛和树木分布稀疏。他们走过一片淡黄色的石灰质地面，这种土壤形成一个平原，几乎长达一英里，一直延伸到森林的边缘。大块的玄武岩分散在平原上，在某些地方分布得非常混杂，根据毕斯可夫的学说，这种玄武岩需要经过三亿五千万年才能冷却成型。然而，这里却没有熔岩的痕迹，熔岩在北部的山坡上极其常见。
en: Towards ten o’clock the little band descended the last declivities of Mount Franklin.As yet the ground was scantily strewn with bushes and trees.They were walking over yellowish calcinated earth, forming a plain of nearly a mile long, which extended to the edge of the wood.Great blocks of that basalt, which, according to Bischof, takes three hundred and fifty millions of years to cool, strewed the plain, very confused in some places.However, there were here no traces of lava, which was spread more particularly over the northern slopes.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁希望不出意外地到达小河的河道，他认为河道应在平原边缘的森林脚下，这时他却看见赫伯特匆忙地跑回来，纳布和水手则躲在岩石后面。
en: Cyrus Harding expected to reach, without incident, the course of the creek, which he supposed flowed under the trees at the border of the plain, when he saw Herbert running hastily back, while Neb and the sailor were hiding behind the rocks.

zh: “怎么了，孩子？”史佩莱问道。
en: “What’s the matter, my boy?” asked Spilett.

zh: “烟，”赫伯特回答道，“我们看见石头堆里冒着烟，就在离我们一百步远的地方。”
en: “Smoke,” replied Herbert.“We have seen smoke among the rocks, a hundred paces from us.”

zh: “难道这里有人？”记者喊道。
en: “Men in this place?” cried the reporter.

zh: “在不知道要应对谁之前，我们绝不能暴露自己，”赛勒斯·哈丁说道，“我认为这里没有原住民，我最担心的就是遇到他们。托普在哪里？”
en: “We must avoid showing ourselves before knowing with whom we have to deal,” replied Cyrus Harding.“I trust that there are no natives on this island; I dread them more than anything else.Where is Top?”

zh: “托普在前面。”
en: “Top is on before.”

zh: “它没有叫吗？”
en: “And he doesn’t bark?”

zh: “没有。”
en: “No.”

zh: “这就奇怪了。无论如何，我们都要把它叫回来。”
en: “That is strange.However, we must try to call him back.”

zh: 没多久，工程师、吉丁·史佩莱和赫伯特与他们的另外两个伙伴会合了，他们也藏在了玄武岩石堆的后面。
en: In a few moments, the engineer, Gideon Spilett, and Herbert had rejoined their two companions, and like them, they kept out of sight behind the heaps of basalt.

zh: 从那里，他们清楚地看见一缕淡黄色的烟升向天空。
en: From thence they clearly saw smoke of a yellowish color rising in the air.

zh: 托普的主人轻轻吹了声口哨把它喊回来，他向伙伴们打了个手势，叫他们等着，接着就从岩石中溜了出去。开拓者们一动不动，焦急地等待着探索的结果，这时工程师的一声叫喊使大家都急忙冲向前。他们很快就来到工程师面前，立刻感觉到空气中弥漫着一股刺鼻的怪味。
en: Top was recalled by a slight whistle from his master, and the latter, signing to his companions to wait for him, glided away among the rocks.The colonists, motionless, anxiously awaited the result of this exploration, when a shout from the engineer made them hasten forward.They soon joined him, and were at once struck with a disagreeable odor which impregnated the atmosphere.

zh: 这怪味很容易辨别，工程师一闻就已经猜到刚才那股烟源自哪里了，工程师起初看见烟时很吃惊，这并不是没有理由的。
en: The odor, easily recognized, was enough for the engineer to guess what the smoke was which at first, not without cause, had startled him.

zh: “这火，”他说，“或者说这烟是自然生成的。那里有一个硫磺泉，泉水有治疗咽喉痛的功效。”
en: “This fue,” said he, “or rather, this smoke is produced by nature alone.There is a sulphur spring there, which will cure all our sore throats.”

zh: “上尉！”潘克洛夫喊道，“我没有感冒是多么可惜啊！”
en: “Captain!” cried Pencroft.“What a pity that I haven’t got a cold!”

zh: 于是居民们向着冒烟的地方走去。他们在那里看到了一个硫磺泉，大量的泉水在岩石之间涌出，散发出一股强烈的硫酸味，这是因为吸收了空气中氧气的缘故。
en: The settlers then directed their steps towards the place from which the smoke escaped.They there saw a sulphur spring which flowed abundantly between the rocks, and its waters discharged a strong sulphuric acid odor, after having absorbed the oxygen of the air.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁用手蘸了泉水，感觉很油腻。他尝了尝，发现味道十分甘甜。至于水的温度，他估计有华氏95度。赫伯特问他是根据什么算出来的。
en: Cyrus Harding, dipping in his hand, felt the water oily to the touch.He tasted it and found it rather sweet.As to its temperature, that he estimated at ninety-five degrees Fahrenheit.Herbert having asked on what he based this calculation,—

zh: “很简单，孩子，”他回答道，“因为当我把手伸进水里时，既不感到烫，也不觉得冰。因此，它的温度和人的体温相当，也就是95度左右。”
en: “Its quite simple, my boy,” said he, “for, in plunging my hand into the water, I felt no sensation either of heat or cold.Therefore it has the same temperature as the human body, which is about ninety-five degrees.”

zh: 硫磺泉对于居民们没有什么实用价值，于是他们继续前行，朝着几百步以外的密林边缘走去。
en: The sulphur spring not being of any actual use to the settlers, they proceeded towards the thick border of the forest, which began some hundred paces off.

zh: 正如他们所推断的，清澈明亮的河水正是从这里流出，两边的河岸很高，都是红土，这种颜色表明土里含有氧化铁。根据土壤的颜色，这条小河马上被命名为红河。
en: There, as they had conjectured, the waters of the stream flowed clear and limpid between high banks of red earth, the color of which betrayed the presence of oxide of iron.From this color, the name of Red Creek was immediately given to the watercourse.

zh: 这是一条大河，水深且清，由山涧汇合而成，一半是河水，一半是湍流，时而平缓地流过沙石，发出潺潺的响声，时而冲击岩石，或是从高处直泻下来形成瀑布，流向湖泊。河水长达一英里半以上，宽达30到40英尺。河水甘甜，想来湖水也是如此。这里是福地，如果能在湖边找到一个比“石窟”更舒适的居所就好了。
en: It was only a large stream, deep and clear, formed of the mountain water, which, half river, half torrent, here rippling peacefully over the sand, there falling against the rocks or dashing down in a cascade, ran towards the lake, over a distance of a mile and a half, its breadth varying from thirty to forty feet.Its waters were sweet, and it was supposed that those of the lake were so also.A fortunate circumstance, in the event of their finding on its borders a more suitable dwelling than the Chimneys.

zh: 河水流出几百英尺以外，两岸树阴如盖，这些树木大多是美国和塔斯马尼亚温带地区的常见品种，而非他们在离眺望岗几英里一带探索时所看见的松柏科树木。此时正值四月伊始，相当于北半球的十月，也就是初秋，树木的枝叶仍然很丰茂。林中主要是些木麻黄和桉树，其中有的树种明年就会产出一种香甜的甘露蜜，和东方的甘露蜜类似。倾斜的河岸上澳洲杉丛生，河岸上还覆盖着一种很高的草，在新荷兰被称为“袜草”。然而，太平洋各群岛盛产的椰子在这个岛上却不见踪迹，毫无疑问，是因为纬度太低了。
en: As to the trees, which some hundred feet downwards shaded the banks of the creek, they belonged, for the most part, to the species which abound in the temperate zone of America and Tasmania, and no longer to those coniferae observed in that portion of the island already explored to some miles from Prospect Heights.At this time of the year, the commencement of the month of April, which represents the month of October, in this hemisphere, that is, the beginning of autumn, they were still in full leaf.They consisted principally of casuarinas and eucalypti, some of which next year would yield a sweet manna, similar to the manna of the East.Clumps of Australian cedars rose on the sloping banks, which were also covered with the high grass called “tussac” in New Holland; but the cocoanut, so abundant in the archipelagoes of the Pacific, seemed to be wanting in the island, the latitude, doubtless, being too low.

zh: “多可惜啊！”赫伯特说，“那么有用的树，又有那么好的果实！”
en: “What a pity!” said Herbert, “such a useful tree, and which has such beautiful nuts!”

zh: 鸟聚集在桉树和木麻黄稀疏的枝杈间，枝杈并没有遮住它们的翅膀。黑的、白的和灰色的凤头鹦鹉，五颜六色的长尾小鹦鹉，浑身闪耀绿色光泽的红头翠鸟，蓝色的吸蜜小鹦鹉，还有其他各种各样的飞禽遍布周围，如同透过一个棱镜，鸟儿们扑扇着翅膀唧唧喳喳地叫着，发出震耳欲聋的喧嚣声。突然，一阵不和谐的奇怪合奏突然响起，在密林中回荡。居民们先后听到了鸟叫声、四足兽的吼叫声，还有一种他们认为是从土著人嘴里发出的声音。纳布和赫伯特冲入灌木丛，甚至连谨慎为上的基本原则也抛之脑后了。幸好，他们在那里既没发现什么可怕的野兽，也没发现什么危险的土著，只看见六只擅长模仿各类叫声的飞禽，也就是山雉。他们用一根棍子精准地挥打了几下，立刻中断了鸟儿们的合奏，也正好可以用它们准备一顿丰盛的晚餐。
en: As to the birds, they swarmed among the scanty branches of the eucalypti and casuarinas, which did not hinder the display of their wings.Black, white, or gray cockatoos, paroquets, with plumage of all colors, kingfishers of a sparkling green and crowned with red, blue lories, and various other birds appeared on all sides, as through a prism, fluttering about and producing a deafening clamor.Suddenly, a strange concert of discordant voices resounded in the midst of a thicket.The settlers heard successively the song of birds, the cry of quadrupeds, and a sort of clacking which they might have believed to have escaped from the lips of a native.Neb and Herbert rushed towards the bush, forgetting even the most elementary principles of prudence.Happily, they found there, neither a formidable wild beast nor a dangerous native, but merely half a dozen mocking and singing birds, known as mountain pheasants.A few skillful blows from a stick soon put an end to their concert, and procured excellent food for the evening’s dinner.

zh: 赫伯特还发现了一些美丽的鸽子，翅膀是青铜色的，有的冠毛绚丽多姿，有的颜色通身碧绿，和麦夸里港的鸽子十分相像。可是想要抓住它们，或者那些成群飞行的乌鸦和喜鹊却是不可能的。
en: Herbert also discovered some magnificent pigeons with bronzed wings, some superbly crested, others draped in green, like their congeners at Port-Macquarie; but it was impossible to reach them, or the crows and magpies which flew away in flocks.

zh: 本来只要短程射一枪就可以打死一大群鸟，但是猎人们的武器只限于棍棒和石头，这些原始武器实在是无法满足需要。
en: A charge of small shot would have made great slaughter among these birds, but the hunters were still limited to sticks and stones, and these primitive weapons proved very insufficient.

zh: 一群四足动物在丛林中连跑带跳地穿梭，一跃就是30英尺，是真真正正的“飞兽”，它们在密林中飞奔，跳得又快又高，以至于人们会认为它们从一棵树跳到另一棵树，像松鼠一样，这时武器的不足愈发凸显出来。
en: Their insufficiency was still more clearly shown when a troop of quadrupeds, jumping, bounding, making leaps of thirty feet, regular flying mammiferae, fled over the thickets, so quickly and at such a height, that one would have thought that they passed from one tree to another like squirrels.

zh: “袋鼠！”赫伯特喊道。
en: “Kangaroos!” cried Herbert.

zh: “它们好不好吃？”潘克洛夫问道。
en: “Are they good to eat?” asked Pencroft.

zh: “炖着吃，”记者说，“它们的肉比得上最好的野味！”
en: “Stewed,” replied the reporter, “their flesh is equal to the best venison!—”

zh: 吉丁·史佩莱还没说完这句激动人心的话，水手就循着袋鼠的足迹冲出去了，纳布和赫伯特跟在后面。赛勒斯·哈丁在后面想喊回他们，但无济于事。但猎人想要追上这些敏捷的猎物也是白费力气，它们弹跳起来像是皮球一样。追了五分钟后，他们已经上气不接下气，同时袋鼠也不见了，消失在丛林里。托普也不比它的主人好到哪里去。
en: Gideon Spilett had not finished this exciting sentence when the sailor, followed by Neb and Herbert, darted on the kangaroos tracks.Cyrus Harding called them back in vain.But it was in vain too for the hunters to pursue such agile game, which went bounding away like balls.After a chase of five minutes, they lost their breath, and at the same time all sight of the creatures, which disappeared in the wood.Top was not more successful than his masters.

zh: “上尉，”工程师和记者赶上来之后，潘克洛夫说，“上尉，你看得很清楚了，我们不造几支枪就过不下去了。能不能造出来啊？”
en: “Captain,” said Pencroft, when the engineer and the reporter had rejoined them, “Captain, you see quite well we can’t get on unless we make a few guns.Will that be possible?”

zh: “也许吧，”工程师答道，“可是，我们首先要造些弓箭，我相信你会像澳洲的猎人一样熟练地使用它们。”
en: “Perhaps,” replied the engineer, “but we will begin by first manufacturing some bows and arrows, and I don’t doubt that you will become as clever in the use of them as the Australian hunters.”

zh: “弓箭！”潘克洛夫不屑地说道，“那可都是小孩子们用的玩意！”
en: “Bows and arrows!” said Pencroft scornfully.“That’s all very well for children!”

zh: “别太自负了，我的朋友潘克洛夫，”记者说，“弓箭可是多少世纪以来使大地染上鲜血的工具。火药不过是近来才有的，可是不幸得很，战争自有人类以来就存在了。”
en: “Don’t be proud, friend Pencroft,” replied the reporter.“Bows and arrows were sufficient for centuries to stain the earth with blood.Powder is but a thing of yesterday, and war is as old as the human race—unhappily.”

zh: “千真万确，那是事实，史佩莱先生，”水手说，“我讲话总是不假思索。你多包涵！”
en: “Faith, that’s true, Mr. Spilett,” replied the sailor, “and I always speak too quickly.You must excuse me!”

zh: 这时候，赫伯特继续谈论他一向喜欢的博物学，话题又转到了袋鼠身上，他说：
en: Meanwhile, Herbert constant to his favorite science, Natural History, reverted to the kangaroos, saying,—

zh: “此外，我们现在要对付的是最难捕捉的一种动物。它们长着灰色的长毛，如果我没记错的话，应该还有黑色和红色的袋鼠，岩石袋鼠和鼷鼠，这些都要好捉些。据估计大概有12种。”
en: “Besides, we had to deal just now with the species which is most difficult to catch.They were giants with long gray fur; but if I am not mistaken, there exist black and red kangaroos, rock kangaroos, and rat kangaroos, which are more easy to get hold of.It is reckoned that there are about a dozen species.”

zh: “赫伯特，”水手以说教式的口吻说道，“在我看来，袋鼠只有一种，那就是‘肉叉上的袋鼠’，而我们今晚偏偏没有捉到这种袋鼠。”
en: “Herbert,” replied the sailor sententiously, “there is only one species of kangaroos to me, that is ‘kangaroo on the spit,’ and it’s just the one we haven’t got this evening!”

zh: 大家听了潘克洛夫大师的新分类法后，不禁大笑起来。对于落到只能吃会唱歌的山雉的地步，诚实的水手无法掩饰心中的遗憾，但是幸运又一次眷顾了水手。
en: They could not help laughing at Master Pencroft’s new classification.The honest sailor did not hide his regret at being reduced for dinner to the singing pheasants, but fortune once more showed itself obliging to him.

zh: 事实上，托普为了自身的利益着想，到处去搜寻，强烈的食欲加倍刺激了它的灵敏直觉。如果托普私自去打猎，那么很有可能猎物只会落在它的爪牙之下，绝不会留给猎人们一点。可是由于纳布看着它，它只好本本分分。
en: In fact, Top, who felt that his interest was concerned went and ferreted everywhere with an instinct doubled by a ferocious appetite.It was even probable that if some piece of game did fall into his clutches, none would be left for the hunters, if Top was hunting on his own account; but Neb watched him and he did well.

zh: 将近三点时，狗消失在灌木丛中，不时的咕哝声表明它在和什么动物对峙。纳布跟着它冲了进去，不久就看见托普迫切地吞食着一个四足动物，如果晚到十秒钟，就要被它整个吞进肚子里了。好在托普攻击的是一窝，除了它正在吞咽的那只，还有另外两只，瘫倒在草地上，我们说的这几只动物都是属于噬齿类动物。
en: Towards three o’clock the dog disappeared in the brushwood and gruntings showed that he was engaged in a struggle with some animal.Neb rushed after him, and soon saw Top eagerly devouring a quadruped, which ten seconds later would have been past recognizing in Top’s stomach.But fortunately the dog had fallen upon a brood, and besides the victim he was devouring, two other rodents—the animals in question belonged to that order—lay strangled on the turf.

zh: 纳布又出现了，一手拎着一只啮齿动物，凯旋而归。它们的体积要比兔子稍大，毛是黄色的，中间夹杂些绿色的斑点，它们的尾巴发育得不完全。
en: Neb reappeared triumphantly holding one of the rodents in each hand.Their size exceeded that of a rabbit, their hair was yellow, mingled with green spots, and they had the merest rudiments of tails.

zh: 这些美国公民并未被这种噬齿动物的正确名称难住。它们是长耳豚鼠，是刺鼠的一种，要比热带地区的同种和普通的美国兔子稍大些，长着一对长耳朵，下巴两边各长了五个臼齿，这点能让人们辨认出它们。
en: The citizens of the Union were at no loss for the right name of these rodents.They were maras, a sort of agouti, a little larger than their congeners of tropical countries, regular American rabbits, with long ears, jaws armed on each side with five molars, which distinguish the agouti.

zh: “哈哈！”潘克洛夫喊道，“烤肉来啦！现在我们可以回家了。”
en: “Hurrah!” cried Pencroft, “the roast has arrived! and now we can go home.”

zh: 他们停了一小会儿，又继续赶路。木麻黄、山龙眼和高大的橡胶树形成一个拱形门，清澈的红河水从下面流过。美丽的丁香树高耸，高达20英尺。还有许多年轻的自然学家不知道的树木种类，它们低垂在小河上，可以听到河水在葱郁的绿荫下潺潺流动。
en: The walk, interrupted for an instant, was resumed.The limpid waters of the Red Creek flowed under an arch of casuannas, banksias, and gigantic gum-trees.Superb lilacs rose to a height of twenty feet.Other arborescent species, unknown to the young naturalist, bent over the stream, which could be heard murmuring beneath the bowers of verdure.

zh: 同时，河水在这里变宽了许多，赛勒斯·哈丁估计他们很快就能到达河口了。果不其然，当他们从一丛美丽的密林下钻出来的时候，河口赫然呈现在他们眼前。
en: Meanwhile the stream grew much wider, and Cyrus Harding supposed that they would soon reach its mouth.In fact, on emerging from beneath a thick clump of beautiful trees, it suddenly appeared before their eyes.

zh: 探险者们来到了格兰特湖的西岸。这里的景色很值得驻足观赏。湖延伸到周围七英里的地方，面积约有250英亩，湖岸边静静生长着各类树木。向东边望去，一帘翠绿的屏障美丽如画，分布在几处较高的湖岸，透过屏障可以看见一片海洋闪烁着光芒。湖岸北面线条曲折，与其低处的陡峭轮廓对比鲜明。许多水禽经常栖息在这个小小的安大略湖畔，离南岸几百英尺的湖面有许多岩石浮出水面，它们很像美国安大略湖里的“千岛”。几对翠鸟相处和睦，栖息在一块石头上，神情严肃，一动不动地等着鱼儿，如发现目标，就尖叫一声冲进水里，然后用喙衔着猎物重新浮出水面。岸上和小岛上，有许多水禽大摇大摆地漫步，其中有野鸭、 鹈鹕、水鸡、红嘴鸟，以及舌头像刷子的水鸟和一两只琴鸟科的美丽水鸟，它们的尾巴张开时就像竖琴一样优雅。
en: The explorers had arrived on the western shore of Lake Grant.The place was well worth looking at.This extent of water, of a circumference of nearly seven miles and an area of two hundred and fifty acres, reposed in a border of diversified trees.Towards the east, through a curtain of verdure, picturesquely raised in some places, sparkled an horizon of sea.The lake was curved at the north, which contrasted with the sharp outline of its lower part.Numerous aquatic birds frequented the shores of this little Ontario, in which the thousand isles of its American namesake were represented by a rock which emerged from its surface, some hundred feet from the southern shore.There lived in harmony several couples of kingfishers perched on a stone, grave, motionless, watching for fish, then darting down, they plunged in with a sharp cry, and reappeared with their prey in their beaks.On the shores and on the islets, strutted wild ducks, pelicans, water-hens, red-beaks, philedons, furnished with a tongue like a brush, and one or two specimens of the splendid menura, the tail of which expands gracefully like a lyre.

zh: 湖水甘甜清澈，颜色很深，水面上常有几处泛着水泡，同心的涟漪在湖面交相碰撞，由此可见，湖里游鱼肯定很多。
en: As to the water of the lake, it was sweet, limpid, rather dark, and from certain bubblings, and the concentric circles which crossed each other on the surface, it could not be doubted that it abounded in fish.

zh: “这个湖真美！”吉丁·史佩莱赞叹道，“我们最好住在湖畔！”
en: “This lake is really beautiful!” said Gideon Spilett.“We could live on its borders!”

zh: “我们会住在这里的！”哈丁答道。
en: “We will live there!” replied Harding.

zh: 居民们打算从最近的路回“石窟”去，于是就沿着湖岸南边会合处形成的拐角向下走去。但是从未有人用手扒开这里的灌木和密林，所以要想从这里开辟出一条道路来绝非易事。于是，为了到达眺望岗的北边，他们向海岸走去。他们在这个方向清出了两英里的道路，然后穿过最后一片树林幕帐，眼前出现了高地。高地上覆盖着一层厚厚的草地，前方就是那一望无垠的海洋。
en: The settlers, wishing to return to the Chimneys by the shortest way, descended towards the angle formed on the south by the junction of the lake’s bank.It was not without difficulty that they broke a path through the thickets and brushwood which had never been put aside by the hand of men, and they thus went towards the shore, so as to arrive at the north of Prospect Heights.Two miles were cleared in this direction, and then, after they had passed the last curtain of trees, appeared the plateau, carpeted with thick turf, and beyond that the infinite sea.

zh: 要想回到“石窟”，只需斜穿过高地走一英里，然后向下走，直到慈悲河第一个绕行道形成的急弯处。但是，工程师迫切地想要了解溢出的湖水从何处泄出，又是怎样泄出的，于是他们就穿过树林，继续向北探索，前行了一英里半。附近极有可能存在瀑布，而且肯定是从花岗石缝中倾泻而下的。简而言之，这个湖是一个极大的中心盆地，由小河的流水渐渐灌注而成，湖水必然是通过瀑布流入大海的。如果真是如此，工程师认为，也许可以利用瀑布，借用它的力量，要不它也是白白被浪费掉。于是，他们继续沿着格兰特湖前进，爬上高地，可是沿着这个方向走了一英里，赛勒斯·哈丁仍未能找到这个瀑布，但是它必然存在于某处。
en: To return to the Chimneys, it was enough to cross the plateau obliquely for the space of a mile, and then to descend to the elbow formed by the first detour of the Mercy.But the engineer desired to know how and where the overplus of the water from the lake escaped, and the exploration was prolonged under the trees for a mile and a half towards the north.It was most probable that an overfall existed somewhere, and doubtless through a cleft in the granite.This lake was only, in short, an immense center basin, which was filled by degrees by the creek, and its waters must necessarily pass to the sea by some fall.If it was so, the engineer thought that it might perhaps be possible to utilize this fall and borrow its power, actually lost without profit to any one.They continued then to follow the shores of Lake Grant by climbing the plateau; but, after having gone a mile in this direction, Cyrus Harding had not been able to discover the overfall, which, however, must exist somewhere.

zh: 这时已经四点半了。为了准备晚餐，居民们必须回到他们的住所。于是，这一小队人马按原路返回，赛勒斯·哈丁和他的同伴们沿着慈悲河左岸回到了“石窟”。
en: It was then half-past four.In order to prepare for dinner it was necessary that the settlers should return to their dwelling.The little band retraced their steps, therefore, and by the left bank of the Mercy, Cyrus Harding and his companions arrived at the Chimneys.

zh: 篝火生起来了，纳布和潘克洛夫一个是黑人，一个是水手，厨师的职责自然转交给了他们，他们很快就准备好了烤刺鼠肉，大家对他们的手艺赞不绝口。
en: The fire was lighted, and Neb and Pencroft, on whom the functions of cooks naturally devolved, to the one in his quality of Negro, to the other in that of sailor, quickly prepared some broiled agouti, to which they did great justice.

zh: 晚餐终于吃完了，大家正准备睡觉，赛勒斯·哈丁却从口袋里掏出几块小矿石样本来，他开口说道：
en: The repast at length terminated; at the moment when each one was about to give himself up to sleep, Cyrus Harding drew from his pocket little specimens of different sorts of minerals, and just said,—

zh: “朋友们，这是铁矿石，这是黄铁矿石，这是粘土，这是石灰，这是煤。自然界给了我们这些东西。我们要好好地加以利用。明天我们就动手干吧。”
en: “My friends, this is iron mineral, this a pyrite, this is clay, this is lime, and this is coal.Nature gives us these things.It is our business to make a right use of them.To-morrow we will commence operations.”

zh: 第十三章
en: Chapter 13

zh: “那么，哈丁先生，我们从哪里入手呢？”第二天早晨，潘克洛夫向工程师询问道。
en: “Well, captain, where are we going to begin?” asked Pencroft next morning of the engineer.

zh: “从头开始。”赛勒斯·哈丁回答道。
en: “At the beginning,” replied Cyrus Harding.

zh: 事实上，居民们也不得不“从头开始”。他们甚至连制造工具的基本用具都没有，而且他们也不像大自然那样，“有的是时间，可以慢慢来”。他们没有时间可以消耗，因为他们必须准备生存所缺的急需品，虽然他们有许多经验，不需要发明创造，可一切都得亲自动手。铁和钢材只是处于矿石的状态，陶器不过是粘土的状态，亚麻布和衣服还只是纺织原料的状态。
en: And in fact, the settlers were compelled to begin “at the very beginning.”They did not possess even the tools necessary for making tools, and they were not even in the condition of nature, who, “having time, husbands her strength.”They had no time, since they had to provide for the immediate wants of their existence, and though, profiting by acquired experience, they had nothing to invent, still they had everything to make; their iron and their steel were as yet only in the state of minerals, their earthenware in the state of clay, their linen and their clothes in the state of textile material.

zh: 然而必须指明一点，这些居民们都是完整的人，而且智力超群。工程师哈丁再也找不到比他们更为聪明的同伴，也找不到比他们更为热诚和充满奉献精神的同伴了。他已经彻底地试探了他们。他知晓每个人的能力。
en: It must be said, however, that the settlers were “men” in the complete and higher sense of the word.The engineer Harding could not have been seconded by more intelligent companions, nor with more devotion and zeal.He had tried them.He knew their abilities.

zh: 吉丁·史佩莱是一个才思敏捷的记者，他无所不通，所以无所不谈。他的智慧和双手在开拓孤岛的过程中，可以做出巨大的贡献。他面对任何工作都不会退缩，这个意志坚定的运动健将，会把自己一向当作消遣的事情变成自己的职业。
en: Gideon Spilett, a talented reporter, having learned everything so as to be able to speak of everything, would contribute largely with his head and hands to the colonization of the island.He would not draw back from any task: a determined sportsman, he would make a business of what till then had only been a pleasure to him.

zh: 赫伯特是一个勇敢的孩子，他的自然科学知识已经相当丰富，这可以给他们共同的事业带来更大的益处。
en: Herbert, a gallant boy, already remarkably well informed in the natural sciences, would render greater service to the common cause.

zh: 纳布是忠诚的化身。他聪明、睿智，不屈不挠，身强体壮，有着钢铁一般的体魄，而且还懂得一些打铁的技术，所以一定会在开拓的过程中大展拳脚。
en: Neb was devotion personified.Clever, intelligent, indefatigable, robust, with iron health, he knew a little about the work of the forge, and could not fail to be very useful in the colony.

zh: 至于潘克洛夫，他航行过各个海洋，在布鲁克林的造船所里当过木匠，在州船上当过助理裁缝，假期里还做过园丁、耕种者等等。像所有的水手一样，他什么都能干，而且知道怎么干。
en: As to Pencroft, he had sailed over every sea, a carpenter in the dockyards in Brooklyn, assistant tailor in the vessels of the state, gardener, cultivator, during his holidays, etc., and like all seamen, fit for anything, he knew how to do everything.

zh: 这样的五个人凑在一起是很难得的，他们都很能和命运作斗争，而且取得胜利的可能性很大。
en: It would have been difficult to unite five men, better fitted to struggle against fate, more certain to triumph over it.

zh: “从头做起。”赛勒斯·哈丁已经说过了。工程师所谓的开头，就是先制造一个装备，可以用来改变天然的物质。热能在物质改变过程中所起的作用是人所共知众所周知的。目前燃料——木柴或是煤炭——可以随时取用，必须造一只炉子来利用这些燃料。
en: “At the beginning,” Cyrus Harding had said.Now this beginning of which the engineer spoke was the construction of an apparatus which would serve to transform the natural substances.The part which heat plays in these transformations is known.Now fuel, wood or coal, was ready for immediate use, an oven must be built to use it.

zh: “做炉子干什么用？”潘克洛夫问道。
en: “What is this oven for?” asked Pencroft.

zh: “用来烧制我们需要的陶器。”哈丁回答。
en: “To make the pottery which we have need of,” replied Harding.

zh: “那用什么做炉子呢？”
en: “And of what shall we make the oven?”

zh: “用砖头。”
en: “With bricks.”

zh: “哪里有砖头？”
en: “And the bricks?”

zh: “用粘土做。开始吧，我的朋友们。为了省事，我们要把制造厂建在原料产地。纳布负责运送食物，会有足够的火来烹饪食物的。”
en: “With clay.Let us start, my friends.To save trouble, we will establish our manufactory at the place of production.Neb will bring provisions, and there will be no lack of fire to cook the food.”

zh: “不，”记者回应道，“如果没有打猎的工具，怎么会有吃的东西呢？”
en: “No,” replied the reporter; “but if there is a lack of food for want of instruments for the chase?”

zh: “啊，要是有一把刀就好了！”水手喊道。
en: “Ah, if we only had a knife!” cried the sailor.

zh: “是吗？”赛勒斯·哈丁问道。
en: “Well?” asked Cyrus Harding.

zh: “是啊！有了刀我就可以立刻做一副弓箭，那样我们的食品室里就有大量的猎物了！”
en: “Well!I would soon make a bow and arrows, and then there could be plenty of game in the larder!”

zh: “是啊，一把刀，一把锋利的刀。”工程师自言自语道。
en: “Yes, a knife, a sharp blade.” said the engineer, as if he was speaking to himself.

zh: 这时他的视线落到了托普身上，托普正在岸边四处奔跑。突然哈丁的脸变得神采奕奕了。
en: At this moment his eyes fell upon Top, who was running about on the shore.Suddenly Harding’s face became animated.

zh: “托普，过来！”他说道。
en: “Top, here,” said he.

zh: 托普听见主人在叫它，就跑了回来。主人用两手托住托普的头，解下了它脖子上戴着的项圈，他将项圈折成两段，说：
en: The dog came at his master’s call.The latter took Top’s head between his hands, and unfastening the collar which the animal wore round his neck, he broke it in two, saying,—

zh: “这有两把刀，潘克洛夫！”
en: “There are two knives, Pencroft!”

zh: 水手兴奋地欢呼了两声，作为回应。托普的项圈是用薄薄的回火钢片制成的。他们只需将它在沙石上磨锋利，并在较平滑的石头上磨出刀刃来就可以了。沙滩上有许多沙石，两个小时以后，聚居地的工具储备里就有两把快刀了，还很轻松地就装上了结实的刀柄。
en: Two hurrahs from the sailor was the reply.Top’s collar was made of a thin piece of tempered steel.They had only to sharpen it on a piece of sandstone, then to raise the edge on a finer stone.Now sandstone was abundant on the beach, and two hours after the stock of tools in the colony consisted of two sharp blades, which were easily fixed in solid handles.

zh: 他们欢呼第一批工具成功制成了。这的确是他们宝贵的劳动成果，而且完成得恰是时候。他们出发了。
en: The production of these their first tools was hailed as a triumph.It was indeed a valuable result of their labor, and a very opportune one.They set out.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁提议，他们应该去格兰特湖西岸，前一天他曾在那里注意到了粘土地面，还带回了一个标本。于是他们沿着慈悲河，穿过眺望岗，又走了五英里多的路，到达了一块林间空地，距离格兰特湖有200英尺远。
en: Cyrus Harding proposed that they should return to the western shore of the lake, where the day before he had noticed the clayey ground of which he possessed a specimen.They therefore followed the bank of the Mercy, traversed Prospect Heights, and alter a walk of five miles or more they reached a glade, situated two hundred feet from Lake Grant.

zh: 赫伯特在路上发现了一种树木，南美洲的印第安人利用它的树枝制成弓。这就是克里井巴树，属于棕榈科，不能长出可食用的果实。他们砍了些又长又直的树枝，捋掉了树叶，削细了两头，中间则比较粗壮，只要再找到一种合适的植物做弓弦就大功告成了。结果他们找到了一棵木槿树，它的纤维非常结实，可以与动物身上的筋腱相媲美。于是，潘克洛夫就得到了一张相当有力量的弓，现在只缺箭了。箭杆倒是很容易做，只要找些又硬又直并且没有节的树枝就行。但是他们必须配备的箭头，也就是一些铁的代替品，却不太好找。但是潘克洛夫说他已经完成了自己分内的事，至于剩下的事情就要碰运气了。
en: On the way Herbert had discovered a tree, the branches of which the Indians of South America employ for making their bows.It was the crejimba, of the palm family, which does not bear edible fruit.Long straight branches were cut, the leaves stripped off; it was shaped, stronger in the middle, more slender at the extremities, and nothing remained to be done but to find a plant fit to make the bow-string.This was the “hibiscus heterophyllus,” which furnishes fibers of such remarkable tenacity that they have been compared to the tendons of animals.Pencroft thus obtained bows of tolerable strength, for which he only wanted arrows.These were easily made with straight stiff branches, without knots, but the points with which they must be armed, that is to say, a substance to serve in lieu of iron, could not be met with so easily.But Pencroft said, that having done his part of the work, chance would do the rest.

zh: 居民们来到了前一天刚刚发现的地方。遍地的粘土对于制造砖瓦非常有用，对于他们正在讨论的事情也很有帮助。这项工作并不困难。只要用沙子滤掉粘土中的杂质，然后把粘土铸成砖形，接着用柴火的热度烧制就可以了。
en: The settlers arrived on the ground which had been discovered the day before.Being composed of the sort of clay which is used for making bricks and tiles, it was very useful for the work in question.There was no great difficulty in it.It was enough to scour the clay with sand, then to mold the bricks and bake them by the heat of a wood fire.

zh: 通常来说，砖坯都是用模具成型的，但是工程师只能用手工制作。接下来的两天，他们一直在从事这项工作。粘土浸在水里，制作工人们手脚并用，把粘土搅拌好，然后把它们分成同等大小的方块。一个娴熟的工人不用机器，可以在十二个钟头里做一万块左右。可是，林肯岛上的这五位制砖工人，两天的时间里只做了不到三千块，这些砖坯一块块挨在一起，等到它们被完全烧干后，就可以用来砌炉子了，也就是说大概要三四天时间。
en: Generally bricks are formed in molds, but the engineer contented himself with making them by hand.All that day and the day following were employed in this work.The clay, soaked in water, was mixed by the feet and hands of the manipulators, and then divided into pieces of equal size.A practiced workman can make, without a machine, about ten thousand bricks in twelve hours; but in their two days work the five brickmakers on Lincoln Island had not made more than three thousand, which were ranged near each other, until the time when their complete desiccation would permit them to be used in building the oven, that is to say, in three or four days.

zh: 4月2日那天，哈丁独自测定了海岛的方向，也就是说找到日出的准确方位。前一天，他已经准确记下了太阳消逝于地平线的时间，并且也考虑了折射的因素。这天早晨，他又一次精确地记录了日出的时间。日出与日落之间相隔12小时24分钟。那么，日出以后六小时十二分钟的时候，这一天的太阳应该恰好通过子午线，这时候它所在的天空位置应该是正北方向。到了上述提到的时间，赛勒斯标记出这一点，并把和太阳形成一条直线的两棵树做标记，这样，他就能为自己的秘密工作找出永恒不变的子午线。
en: It was on the 2nd of April that Harding had employed himself in fixing the orientation of the island, or, in other words, the precise spot where the sun rose.The day before he had noted exactly the hour when the sun disappeared beneath the horizon, making allowance for the refraction.This morning he noted, no less exactly, the hour at which it reappeared.Between this setting and rising twelve hours, twenty-four minutes passed.Then, six hours, twelve minutes after its rising, the sun on this day would exactly pass the meridian and the point of the sky which it occupied at this moment would be the north.At the said hour, Cyrus marked this point, and putting in a line with the sun two trees which would serve him for marks, he thus obtained an invariable meridian for his ulterior operations.

zh: 在炉子做好的前两天里，居民们一直在收集燃料。他们砍下了林间空地附近的树枝，并捡起了所有掉在树下的树木。自从潘克洛夫有了几十枝带锋利箭头的箭后，他们打猎时也更加顺利了。是托普带回的这些箭头，它猎回了一只豪猪，这头豪猪的肉虽然很不好吃，但却非常有用，因为他的身上布满了硬刺。这些硬刺被牢固地安在箭头上，再加上些美冠鹦鹉的羽毛，射起箭来就更稳健了。记者和赫伯特很快就成为娴熟的射手了。“石窟”里因此有了各种各样的丰富猎物，有水豚、鸽子、刺鼠、松鸡等。大部分猎物都是从慈悲河左岸的森林里打来的，他们把这个森林叫做中南美鴷林，以此纪念第一次探险时，潘克洛夫和赫伯特追逐过的那只鸟。
en: The settlers employed the two days before the oven was built in collecting fuel.Branches were cut all round the glade, and they picked up all the fallen wood under the trees.They were also able to hunt with greater success, since Pencroft now possessed some dozen arrows armed with sharp points.It was Top who had famished these points, by bringing in a porcupine, rather inferior eating, but of great value, thanks to the quills with which it bristled.These quills were fixed firmly at the ends of the arrows, the flight of which was made more certain by some cockatoos’ feathers.The reporter and Herbert soon became very skilful archers.Game of all sorts in consequence abounded at the Chimneys, capybaras, pigeons, agouties, grouse, etc.The greater part of these animals were killed in the part of the forest on the left bank of the Mercy, to which they gave the name of Jacamar Wood, in remembrance of the bird which Pencroft and Herbert had pursued when on their first exploration.

zh: 这些猎物是趁新鲜的时候吃的，但他们也保存了一些水豚腿。他们先用香气宜人的叶子把水豚腿裹上，然后再用青木柴火熏烤。虽然这种食物营养丰富，可总是烤来烤去的，大家还是期待能在火炉上听到汤水沸腾的声音，但这必须等到能够做出锅来，因此，那就要等到炉子造好了。
en: This game was eaten fresh, but they preserved some capybara hams, by smoking them above a fire of green wood, after having perfumed them with sweet-smelling leaves.However, this food, although very strengthening, was always roast upon roast, and the party would have been delighted to hear some soup bubbling on the hearth, but they must wait till a pot could be made, and, consequently, till the oven was built.

zh: 这几次外出打猎时，他们都没有离开制砖厂太远。猎人们辨别出了某种体型庞大的动物新近留下的痕迹，脚爪很有力量，但是他们无法辨别是哪一类野兽。赛勒斯·哈丁建议大家小心谨慎，因为森林里可能有许多凶险的野兽。
en: During these excursions, which were not extended far from the brick-field, the hunters could discern the recent passage of animals of a large size, armed with powerful claws, but they could not recognize the species.Cyrus Harding advised them to be very careful, as the forest probably enclosed many dangerous beasts.

zh: 他说的没错。事实上，有一天，吉丁·史佩莱和赫伯特看见了一只很像美洲豹的野兽。好在这只野兽并没有攻击他们，否则他们不可能不受重伤就逃脱。吉丁·史佩莱决定，只要他能得到一件正规的武器，也就是潘克洛夫一直想要的枪，就要和这些猛兽拼战到底，使它们从岛上彻底消失。
en: And he did right.Indeed, Gideon Spilett and Herbert one day saw an animal which resembled a jaguar.Happily the creature did not attack them, or they might not have escaped without a severe wound.As soon as he could get a regular weapon, that is to say, one of the guns which Pencroft begged for, Gideon Spilett resolved to make desperate war against the ferocious beasts, and exterminate them from the island.

zh: 这些天他们并未对“石窟”做任何修缮，因为工程师希望能找到一个更加方便的居所，如有必要，他们可以自己建造一处。他们只好在通道的沙地上铺些地苔和干叶，疲倦的工人们在这些原始的床铺上睡得很沉。
en: The Chimneys during these few days was not made more comfortable, for the engineer hoped to discover, or build if necessary, a more convenient dwelling.They contented themselves with spreading moss and dry leaves on the sand of the passages, and on these primitive couches the tired workers slept soundly.

zh: 他们也计算了一下在林肯岛上所度过的日子，从那时候开始，他们定期记录。4月5日是星期三，是风暴将这些落难者们抛上海岸以后的第12天。
en: They also reckoned the days they had passed on Lincoln Island, and from that time kept a regular account.The 5th of April, which was Wednesday, was twelve days from the time when the wind threw the castaways on this shore.

zh: 4月6日，天刚刚亮，工程师就和他的同伴们在林间空地集合，他们打算在那里开始烧砖。正常来讲，这种工作应该在露天进行，而不是在窑里，确切地说，凝结的砖坯形成一个大窑，这样就可以自己烘干。他们用准备好的柴把作燃料，放在地上，并用烘干了的砖坯围住，这样就形成一个大的立方体，又在外部开了几个通气孔。这项工作持续了一整天，直到傍晚时分，他们才开始在柴把上生火。那一夜大家都没有睡，都全神贯注地照看柴火，使火持续燃烧。
en: On the 6th of April, at daybreak, the engineer and his companions were collected in the glade, at the place where they were going to perform the operation of baking the bricks.Naturally this had to be in the open air, and not in a kiln, or rather, the agglomeration of bricks made an enormous kiln, which would bake itself.The fuel, made of well-prepared fagots, was laid on the ground and surrounded with several rows of dried bricks, which soon formed an enormous cube, to the exterior of which they contrived air-holes.The work lasted all day, and it was not till the evening that they set fire to the fagots.No one slept that night, all watching carefully to keep up the fire.

zh: 烧砖的过程整整持续了48小时，获得了完满的成功。接下来必须离开这个烟雾缭绕的混乱之地，等着烧热的砖坯冷却下来，在这段时间里，纳布和潘克洛夫在赛勒斯·哈丁的带领下，来到了湖的北岸，用交错的树枝编的筐子把那里遍布的石灰石和普通的石头运了一大堆回来。这些石头经过加热分解后，生成了很浓的生石灰，再经过沸化的过程，生石灰的体积迅速膨胀。它们的质地很纯，至少和白垩或大理石经过煅烧后生产的一样纯。石灰和细沙一搅拌就成了质量上乘的灰泥。
en: The operation lasted forty-eight hours, and succeeded perfectly.It then became necessary to leave the smoking mass to cool, and during this time Neb and Pencroft, guided by Cyrus Harding, brought, on a hurdle made of interlaced branches, loads of carbonate of lime and common stones, which were very abundant, to the north of the lake.These stones, when decomposed by heat, made a very strong quicklime, greatly increased by slacking, at least as pure as if it had been produced by the calcination of chalk or marble.Mixed with sand the lime made excellent mortar.

zh: 这些不同的工作做好之后，到了4月9号，工程师就可以支配大量准备好的石灰和几千块砖头了。
en: The result of these different works was, that, on the 9th of April, the engineer had at his disposal a quantity of prepared lime and some thousands of bricks.

zh: 他们丝毫也不敢懈怠，立刻开始砌窑烧制陶器，陶器可是他们日常生活中必不可少的部分。他们没遇到什么困难就成功了。五天以后，窑里就有煤供应了，煤是工程师在红河河口朝天的一个地方发现的。第一缕轻烟从20英尺高的烟囱里冒了出来。林间的空地被改造成了一个加工厂。潘克洛夫认为这个窑里可以生产出各种现代工业产品，这么想倒也不错。
en: Without losing an instant, therefore, they began the construction of a kiln to bake the pottery, which was indispensable for their domestic use.They succeeded without much difficulty.Five days after, the kiln was supplied with coal, which the engineer had discovered lying open to the sky towards the mouth of the Red Creek, and the first smoke escaped from a chimney twenty feet high.The glade was transformed into a manufactory, and Pencroft was not far wrong in believing that from this kiln would issue all the products of modern industry.

zh: 居民们首先制成了一只普通的锅，作煮饭之用。主要的原料是粘土，哈丁又往里面加入了一些石灰和石英。这种湿粘土就成了常规的“陶土”，他们用适当形状的石头做模具，用这种土制成了碗、杯子，另外又做了一些盛水的大罐和大壶等等。这些陶器的形状很丑陋，还有些缺陷，但是经过高温焙烧以后，“石窟”的厨房里增添了许多器具，对于居民们来讲，这些器皿和最精美的釉瓷一样珍贵。在这里必须提到，潘克洛夫急切地想知道准备好的这种陶土是否配得上“陶土”的名字，于是他就做了几个大烟斗，结果很不错，可惜他没有烟草，这对潘克洛夫来讲真是巨大的损失。“烟草会有的，就像其他东西一样！”他以绝对的信心重复道。
en: In the meantime what the settlers first manufactured was a common pottery in which to cook their food.The chief material was clay, to which Harding added a little lime and quartz.This paste made regular “pipe-clay,” with which they manufactured bowls, cups molded on stones of a proper size, great jars and pots to hold water, etc.The shape of these objects was clumsy and defective, but after they had been baked in a high temperature, the kitchen of the Chimneys was provided with a number of utensils, as precious to the settlers as the most beautifully enameled china.We must mention here that Pencroft, desirous to know if the clay thus prepared was worthy of its name of pipe-clay, made some large pipes, which he thought charming, but for which, alas! he had no tobacco, and that was a great privation to Pencroft.“But tobacco will come, like everything else!” he repeated, in a burst of absolute confidence.

zh: 这项工作一直持续到4月15日，时间利用得很好。居民们全都成了陶器工人，只做陶器。当赛勒斯·哈丁认为该做铁匠活了，那他们就会变成铁匠。但是第二天是星期日，而且也是复活节，所有人都同意休工一天以示这一天的神圣。这些美国人都是有宗教信仰的，都一丝不苟地遵循着圣经的箴言，而且他们的处境只能使他们信仰万物之主。
en: This work lasted till the 15th of April, and the time was well employed.The settlers, having become potters, made nothing but pottery.When it suited Cyrus Harding to change them into smiths, they would become smiths.But the next day being Sunday, and also Easter Sunday, all agreed to sanctify the day by rest.These Americans were religious men, scrupulous observers of the precepts of the Bible, and their situation could not but develop sentiments of confidence towards the Author of all things.

zh: 4月15日傍晚，他们回到了“石窟”，带回了一些陶器，炉火已经熄灭，等有新的用途的时候，他们才重新点燃炉火。他们在归途中遇见了一件幸事，工程师发现了一种火绒的替代物。在一种多孔菌科的植物里，可以获取一种海绵状、光滑的菌肉。经过适当的加工，尤其是事先把它浸在火药里，或者是在硝酸盐或氯化钾的溶液里煮沸以后，这种菌子极易燃烧。但是以前他们没有找到这种多孔菌，也没有找到过一种可以替代它们的羊肚菌。这一天，工程师发现了一种艾草科的植物，主要品种有苦艾、香薄荷、龙蒿等等，他采集了几束，把它们递给了水手，说道：
en: On the evening of the 15th of April they returned to the Chimneys, carrying with them the pottery, the furnace being extinguished until they could put it to a new use.Their return was marked by a fortunate incident; the engineer discovered a substance which replaced tinder.It is known that a spongy, velvety flesh is procured from a certain mushroom of the genus polyporous.Properly prepared, it is extremely inflammable, especially when it has been previously saturated with gunpowder, or boiled in a solution of nitrate or chlorate of potash.But, till then, they had not found any of these polypores or even any of the morels which could replace them.On this day, the engineer, seeing a plant belonging to the wormwood genus, the principal species of which are absinthe, balm-mint, tarragon, etc., gathered several tufts, and, presenting them to the sailor, said,—

zh: “给你，潘克洛夫，这个能使你开心。”
en: “Here, Pencroft, this will please you.”

zh: 潘克洛夫仔细地看了看植物，这种植物上有许多光滑的长须，叶子上长满松软的绒毛。
en: Pencroft looked attentively at the plant, covered with long silky hair, the leaves being clothed with soft down.

zh: “这是什么，先生？”潘克洛夫问道，“是烟草吗？”
en: “What’s that, captain?” asked Pencroft.“Is it tobacco?”

zh: “不是，”哈丁答道，“是艾草，学者们称之为中国艾草，对于我们，它将是火绒。”
en: “No,” replied Harding, “it is wormwood; Chinese wormwood to the learned, but to us it will be tinder.”

zh: 等艾草晒干，尤其是工程师后来把它放在硝酸盐溶液里浸泡以后，它就为他们提供了极易燃烧的物质了。这个岛上有一些矿床，事实上也就是硝石。
en: When the wormwood was properly dried it provided them with a very inflammable substance, especially afterwards when the engineer had impregnated it with nitrate of potash, of which the island possessed several beds, and which is in truth saltpeter.

zh: 这一晚，开拓者们吃了丰盛的晚餐。纳布准备了刺鼠肉汤，一只熏水豚腿，他还在熏腿上加了些煮熟的“贝母属”块茎，这是白星海芋科的草本植物。它们很美味，而且很有营养，和英国出售的、被称为“波特兰西米”的东西类似。它们也是面包的上好替代品，林肯岛上的居民们直到现在还没有面包。
en: The colonists had a good supper that evening.Neb prepared some agouti soup, a smoked capybara ham, to which was added the boiled tubercules of the “caladium macrorhizum,” an herbaceous plant of the arum family.They had an excellent taste, and were very nutritious, being something similar to the substance which is sold in England under the name of “Portland sago”; they were also a good substitute for bread, which the settlers in Lincoln Island did not yet possess.

zh: 晚餐过后，在睡觉以前，哈丁和同伴们到沙滩上散步，这时是晚上八点，夜色很美。月亮还未升起，这已是满月后的第五天，但是地平线上已经布上了银白色的柔光，那可以称作是月亮的“曙光”。南边的苍穹顶上，围绕极地的星座在闪闪发光，其中最闪亮的就是南十字座。几天前，工程师曾在富兰克林山顶上看见过它。
en: When supper was finished, before sleeping, Harding and his companions went to take the air on the beach. it was eight o’clock in the evening; the night was magnificent.The moon, which had been full five days before, had not yet risen, but the horizon was already silvered by those soft, pale shades which might be called the dawn of the moon.At the southern zenith glittered the circumpolar constellations, and above all the Southern Cross, which some days before the engineer had greeted on the summit of Mount Franklin.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁久久凝视着这个美丽的星座，两颗一等星分别在它的顶端和基部，左边有颗二等星，右变则是一颗三等星。
en: Cyrus Harding gazed for some time at this splendid constellation, which has at its summit and at its base two stars of the first magnitude, at its left arm a star of the second, and at its right arm a star of the third magnitude.

zh: 他思考了几分钟，然后说：
en: Then, after some minutes thought—

zh: “赫伯特，”他问少年，“今天是4月15日吗？”
en: “Herbert,” he asked of the lad, “is not this the 15th of April?”

zh: “是的，上尉。”赫伯特回答。
en: “Yes, captain,” replied Herbert.

zh: “那么，如果我没记错，明天会是一年当中实际时间和平均时间完全相等的四天之一，也就是说，孩子，明天太阳会在正午12点时经过子午线，误差在几秒之内。如果天气晴好，我想我可以大致准确地计算出海岛的经度，至多有几度的误差而已。”
en: “Well, if I am not mistaken, to-morrow will be one of the four days in the year in which the real time is identical with average time; that is to say, my boy, that to-morrow, to within some seconds, the sun will pass the meridian just at midday by the clocks.If the weather is fine I think that I shall obtain the longitude of the island with an approximation of some degrees.”

zh: “不用仪器，不用六分仪吗？”吉丁·史佩莱问道。
en: “Without instruments, without sextant?” asked Gideon Spilett.

zh: “不用，”工程师答道，“而且今晚夜空晴朗，所以我今晚就要试着计算出我们所在的纬度，通过计算南十字星座的高度，也就是根据地平线上的南极点。朋友们，要知道在没有仔细地进行安置工作以前，还不能确定这片陆地是一个孤岛。我们必须尽可能精确地知道，它与美洲大陆、澳洲大陆或是太平洋主要群岛之间的距离。”
en: “Yes,” replied the engineer.“Also, since the night is clear, I will try, this very evening, to obtain our latitude by calculating the height of the Southern Cross, that is, from the southern pole above the horizon.You understand, my friends, that before undertaking the work of installation in earnest it is not enough to have found out that this land is an island; we must, as nearly as possible, know at what distance it is situated, either from the American continent or Australia, or from the principal archipelagoes of the Pacific.”

zh: “不错”，记者说，“如果我们碰巧离有人居住的海岸不到100英里，那造一只船可就要比建一所房子重要多了。”
en: “In fact,” said the reporter, “instead of building a house it would be more important to build a boat, if by chance we are not more than a hundred miles from an inhabited coast.”

zh: “因此，”哈丁说，“我要在今晚设法计算出林肯岛的纬度，明天中午我再设法计算出经度。”
en: “That is why,” returned Harding, “I am going to try this evening to calculate the latitude of Lincoln Island, and to-morrow, at midday, I will try to calculate the longitude.”

zh: 如果工程师手里有一个六分仪——能够精确测量物体之间夹角距离的仪器，这项工作就能轻而易举地完成了。今晚通过南极点的高度，明天通过经过子午线的太阳，他就能知道海岛的位置了。但是由于他们没有六分仪，他只好自己来填补这个缺陷了。
en: If the engineer had possessed a sextant, an apparatus with which the angular distance of objects can be measured with great precision, there would have been no difficulty in the operation.This evening by the height of the pole, the next day by the passing of the sun at the meridian, he would obtain the position of the island.But as they had not one he would have to supply the deficiency.

zh: 于是，哈丁回到了“石窟”。他借着火光，削了两把小平尺，然后将它们的一端连在一起，做成一副圆规，圆规的两脚可以分开或合拢。连接点是用一个结实的洋槐树刺固定的，是从柴堆里找到的。做好了仪器之后，工程师又回到了海滩。可是要测量极点的高度需要在没有云的水平线上进行，也就是要在海平线上测量，但是爪角挡住了南方的水平线，他只好去找一个更为合适的地点。最理想的场所自然要正对着南方的海岸，可是又要渡过慈悲河，这是困难所在。因此，哈丁决定在眺望岗上进行观察，这就要把高地的海拔考虑在内，他打算第二天运用基本的几何知识来计算高地的海拔。
en: Harding then entered the Chimneys.By the light of the fire he cut two little flat rulers, which he joined together at one end so as to form a pair of compasses, whose legs could separate or come together.The fastening was fixed with a strong acacia thorn which was found in the wood pile.This instrument finished, the engineer returned to the beach, but as it was necessary to take the height of the pole from above a clear horizon, that is, a sea horizon, and as Claw Cape hid the southern horizon, he was obliged to look for a more suitable station.The best would evidently have been the shore exposed directly to the south; but the Mercy would have to be crossed, and that was a difficulty.Harding resolved, in consequence, to make his observation from Prospect Heights, taking into consideration its height above the level of the sea—a height which he intended to calculate next day by a simple process of elementary geometry.

zh: 于是，居民们爬上慈悲河的左岸，向着高地的方向进发。他们站在从西北到东南方向的高地边缘，也就是沿河一带奇形怪状的岩石上。
en: The settlers, therefore, went to the plateau, ascending the left bank of the Mercy, and placed themselves on the edge which looked northwest and southeast, that is, above the curiously-shaped rocks which bordered the river.

zh: 这一带高地俯瞰着慈悲河左岸的山岗，山岗斜向爪角的尽头，一直延伸到海岛的南部。没有障碍物阻拦他们的视线，他们横扫从爪角到爬虫角整个半圆形的水平线。南边的水平线在初升月亮的光线映照下，十分清晰地显现在天际。
en: This part of the plateau commanded the heights of the left bank, which sloped away to the extremity of Claw Cape, and to the southern side of the island.No obstacle intercepted their gaze, which swept the horizon in a semi-circle from the cape to Reptile End.To the south the horizon, lighted by the first rays of the moon, was very clearly defined against the sky.

zh: 这时，南十字星座以倒置的形状呈现在观测者的眼前，主星标识出星座的底部，处于离南极较近的地方。
en: At this moment the Southern Cross presented itself to the observer in an inverted position, the star Alpha marking its base, which is nearer to the southern pole.

zh: 这个星座与南极的距离要比北极星与北极的距离远。主星大约在距离南极27度的方位上，但是赛勒斯·哈丁知道这一点，并已在计算时把这个角度考虑在内了。他也仔细地观察了主星经过正对着南极的子午线的时刻，这会使操作更加简单。
en: This constellation is not situated as near to the antarctic pole as the Polar Star is to the arctic pole.The star Alpha is about twenty-seven degrees from it, but Cyrus Harding knew this and made allowance for it in his calculation.He took care also to observe the moment when it passed the meridian below the pole, which would simplify the operation.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁把圆规的一脚对着水平线，另一脚对着主星，两只脚之间的空间就形成了主星和水平线之间的角距。为了固定所得的角度，他用刺针把一个木条横向钉在圆规的两只脚上，这样就可以恰当保留它们之间的角距了。
en: Cyrus Harding pointed one leg of the compasses to the horizon, the other to Alpha, and the space between the two legs gave him the angular distance which separated Alpha from the horizon.In order to fix the angle obtained, he fastened with thorns the two pieces of wood on a third placed transversely, so that their separation should be properly maintained.

zh: 这一步完成以后，只要再计算角度就可以了。但这还要到海平面上去观察，因为还要把水平线的俯角考虑在内，这就有必要测量一下峭壁的高度。有了这个角度就可以算出主星的高度，继而可以算出极点在水平线上的高度，即海岛的纬度，因为地球上任何一点的纬度都等于这点在水平线上的高度。
en: That done, there was only the angle to calculate by bringing back the observation to the level of the sea, taking into consideration the depression of the horizon, which would necessitate measuring the height of the cliff.The value of this angle would give the height of Alpha, and consequently that of the pole above the horizon, that is to say, the latitude of the island, since the latitude of a point of the globe is always equal to the height of the pole above the horizon of this point.

zh: 计算的事留待第二天解决，十点钟时，大家都沉沉地睡着了。
en: The calculations were left for the next day, and at ten o’clock every one was sleeping soundly.

zh: 第十四章
en: Chapter 14

zh: 第二天是4月16日，也就是复活节星期日，居民们破晓时分就走出了“石窟”去洗亚麻布衣服。工程师打算只要找到必要的原料——苏打或是碳酸钾，脂肪或是油，就制造肥皂。至于置换新衣物这个重要的问题，就要留到一个合适的时间和地点来探讨了。他们的衣服至少可以支撑六个月，因为衣服很结实，经得住体力劳动的磨损。但是一切取决于海岛是否靠近有人居住的陆地。如果天气允许，这个问题今天就能得到解决。
en: The next day, the 16th of April, and Easter Sunday, the settlers issued from the Chimneys at daybreak, and proceeded to wash their linen.The engineer intended to manufacture soap as soon as he could procure the necessary materials—soda or potash, fat or oil.The important question of renewing their wardrobe would be treated of in the proper time and place.At any rate their clothes would last at least six months longer, for they were strong, and could resist the wear of manual labor.But all would depend on the situation of the island with regard to inhabited land.This would be settled to-day if the weather permitted.

zh: 太阳从清晰的水平线升起，预示着一个晴好的天气，美丽的秋日似乎在与温暖的季节做最后的告别。
en: The sun rising above a clear horizon, announced a magnificent day, one of those beautiful autumn days which are like the last farewells of the warm season.

zh: 现在需要完成前一晚的观察了，要测量出峭壁的海拔。
en: It was now necessary to complete the observations of the evening before by measuring the height of the cliff above the level of the sea.

zh: “你不需要一个昨晚那样的仪器吗？”赫伯特问工程师。
en: “Shall you not need an instrument similar to the one which you used yesterday?” said Herbert to the engineer.

zh: “不需要，孩子，”工程师回答，“我们今天要换种方式进行，但像昨天一样精确。”
en: “No, my boy,” replied the latter, “we are going to proceed differently, but in as precise a way.”

zh: 赫伯特跟着工程师一起前往海滨，他想尽量学会每件事。潘克洛夫、纳布和记者则留在原地，干着不同的事。
en: Herbert, wishing to learn everything he could, followed the engineer to the beach.Pencroft, Neb, and the reporter remained behind and occupied themselves in different ways.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁准备了一个12英尺长的直木杆，长度是通过对比自己的身高精确地计算出来的，他对自己的身高可是知道得分毫不差。赫伯特拿着哈丁交给他的垂线，其实就是将一块普通的石头系在了质地柔韧的植物末端。他们到达的地方距海边20英尺，距高耸的峭壁近500英尺，哈丁把木杆插入沙地二英尺深，并小心地插牢，然后利用垂线使木杆和地面保持垂直。
en: Cyrus Harding had provided himself with a straight stick, twelve feet long, which he had measured as exactly as possible by comparing it with his own height, which he knew to a hair.Herbert carried a plumb-line which Harding had given him, that is to say, a simple stone fastened to the end of a flexible fiber.Having reached a spot about twenty feet from the edge of the beach, and nearly five hundred feet from the cliff, which rose perpendicularly, Harding thrust the pole two feet into the sand, and wedging it up carefully, he managed, by means of the plumb-line, to erect it perpendicularly with the plane of the horizon.

zh: 完成了这个步骤，他退后了一段距离，然后躺在沙滩上，眼睛同时看着木杆的顶端和峭壁的上沿。他用一根小棍子仔细地在观察点做记号。
en: That done, he retired the necessary distance, when, lying on the sand, his eye glanced at the same time at the top of the pole and the crest of the cliff.He carefully marked the place with a little stick.

zh: 然后他问赫伯特：“你知道最基本的几何原理吗？”
en: Then addressing Herbert—“Do you know the first principles of geometry?” he asked.

zh: “知道一点儿，上尉。”赫伯特回答，他可不想炫耀自己。
en: “Slightly, captain,” replied Herbert, who did not wish to put himself forward.

zh: “那你记得两个相似三角形的性质吗？”
en: “You remember what are the properties of two similar triangles?”

zh: “记得，”赫伯特答道，“它们的对应边成比例。”
en: “Yes,” replied Herbert; “their homologous sides are proportional.”

zh: “很好，孩子。我刚刚做了两个相似的直角三角形，第一个较小，它的三条边分别是：那根垂直的木杆和从这跟小棍子到木杆底部的距离，我的视线则是三角形的斜边；第二个三角形的三条边分别是：我们想测量高度的垂直峭壁，这根小棍子和峭壁底部之间的距离，我的视线同样形成三角形的斜边，这个斜边是第一个三角形斜边的延长线。”
en: “Well, my boy, I have just constructed two similar right-angled triangles; the first, the smallest, has for its sides the perpendicular pole, the distance which separates the little stick from the foot of the pole and my visual ray for hypothenuse; the second has for its sides the perpendicular cliff, the height of which we wish to measure, the distance which separates the little stick from the bottom of the cliff, and my visual ray also forms its hypothenuse, which proves to be prolongation of that of the first triangle.”

zh: “噢，上尉，我懂了！”赫伯特大声喊道，“小棍子和木杆之间的距离与小棍子和峭壁底部之间的距离之比，就等于木杆的高度和峭壁的高度之比。”
en: “Ah, captain, I understand!” cried Herbert.“As the distance from the stick to the pole is to the distance from the stick to the base of the cliff, so is the height of the pole to the height of the cliff.”

zh: “就是这样，赫伯特，”工程师答道，“当我们测量了前两段距离和木杆的长度，只要按照比例一算，就可以求出峭壁的高度了，这样就省去了我们直接测量的麻烦。”
en: “Just so, Herbert,” replied the engineer; “and when we have measured the two first distances, knowing the height of the pole, we shall only have a sum in proportion to do, which will give us the height of the cliff, and will save us the trouble of measuring it directly.”

zh: 两段水平距离可以通过木杆量出，木杆在沙滩以上部分的高度恰好为十英尺。
en: The two horizontal distances were found out by means of the pole, whose length above the sand was exactly ten feet.

zh: 第一段距离为15英尺，是小棍子到木杆在沙上所插位置的距离。
en: The first distance was fifteen feet between the stick and the place where the pole was thrust into the sand.

zh: 第二段为500英尺，是小棍子到峭壁底部的距离。
en: The second distance between the stick and the bottom of the cliff was five hundred feet.

zh: 完成这些测量后，赛勒斯·哈丁和少年就回石窟了。
en: These measurements finished, Cyrus Harding and the lad returned to the Chimneys.

zh: 工程师拿出一块扁平的石头，是他上次外出时带回来的，这是一种板岩，用锋利的贝壳可以很容易地在上面划出字符来。他求出了以下的比例关系：
en: The engineer then took a flat stone which he had brought back from one of his previous excursions, a sort of slate, on which it was easy to trace figures with a sharp shell.He then proved the following proportions:—

zh: 由此可以得出，花岗石峭壁的高度为333英尺。
en: From which it was proved that the granite cliff measured 333 feet in height.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁又拿出了前晚所做的仪器，圆规两脚之间的距离就是主星和水平线之间的角距。他先是把一个圆周分为360等份，然后把圆规的角度准确地落在圆周上。现在，这个角度加上主星距离南极的27度，再减去观察时所在的峭壁海拔，就得出了一个53度的角。90度减去53度就是南极到赤道的距离，也就是37度。因此，赛勒斯·哈丁得出的结论是林肯岛在南纬37度，如果把测量时的误差也考虑在内，大概是五度左右，那么海岛的位置一定是在南纬35度与40度之间。
en: Cyrus Harding then took the instrument which he had made the evening before, the space between its two legs giving the angular distance between the star Alpha and the horizon.He measured, very exactly, the opening of this angle on a circumference which he divided into 360 equal parts.Now, this angle by adding to it the twenty-seven degrees which separated Alpha from the antarctic pole, and by reducing to the level of the sea the height of the cliff on which the observation had been made, was found to be fifty-three degrees.These fifty-three degrees being subtracted from ninety degrees—the distance from the pole to the equator—there remained thirty-seven degrees.Cyrus Harding concluded, therefore, that Lincoln Island was situated on the thirty-seventh degree of the southern latitude, or taking into consideration through the imperfection of the performance, an error of five degrees, that it must be situated between the thirty-fifth and the fortieth parallel.

zh: 现在只要计算出经度，海岛的位置就可以确定了。工程师打算在这一天的中午十二点钟，在太阳经过子午线的时候尝试一下。
en: There was only the longitude to be obtained, and the position of the island would be determined, The engineer hoped to attempt this the same day, at twelve o’clock, at which moment the sun would pass the meridian.

zh: 大家决定星期日徒步旅行，或者说是远足探险，要去湖的北边和鲨鱼湾之间的地带。如果时间允许，他们就会继续去南颚角的北边探险。他们打算在沙丘上吃早饭，直到傍晚才会返回。
en: It was decided that Sunday should be spent in a walk, or rather an exploring expedition, to that side of the island between the north of the lake and Shark Gulf, and if there was time they would push their discoveries to the northern side of Cape South Mandible.They would breakfast on the downs, and not return till evening.

zh: 八点半的时候，这一小队人马沿着海峡的边缘前进。海峡对面的安全岛上，许多水鸟神情庄重地高视阔步。这些是潜水鸟，可以从其叫声中轻易辨别出来，那很像驴叫的声音。潘克洛夫只是从吃的角度来考察它们，因此当他得知这些鸟的肉虽有些黑但味道还行时，他感到很满意。
en: At half-past eight the little band was following the edge of the channel.On the other side, on Safety Islet, numerous birds were gravely strutting.They were divers, easily recognized by their cry, which much resembles the braying of a donkey.Pencroft only considered them in an eatable point of view, and learnt with some satisfaction that their flesh, though blackish, is not bad food.

zh: 他们还看见了一些巨大的两栖动物在沙地上爬行，那无疑是海豹，它们似乎已选择这个小岛作为庇护所了。这些动物是不可能从营养角度看的，因为它们的肉油腻腻的，令人恶心。然而，赛勒斯·哈丁仔细地观察着它们，也没说出他的想法，只是告诉同伴们，不久他们要去一次小岛。海滩上遍布着数不清的贝壳，其中一些贝壳一定会令贝壳学家心花怒放的，其中有雉螺、三角蛤等。但纳布有更为有用的发现，在退潮的时候，他在岩石间看见了一大片牡蛎场，离“石窟”将近五英里。
en: Great amphibious creatures could also be seen crawling on the sand; seals, doubtless, who appeared to have chosen the islet for a place of refuge.It was impossible to think of those animals in an alimentary point of view, for their oily flesh is detestable; however, Cyrus Harding observed them attentively, and without making known his idea, he announced to his companions that very soon they would pay a visit to the islet.The beach was strewn with innumerable shells, some of which would have rejoiced the heart of a conchologist; there were, among others, the phasianella, the terebratual, etc.But what would be of more use, was the discovery, by Neb, at low tide, of a large oysterbed among the rocks, nearly five miles from the Chimneys.

zh: “纳布今天可没白过。”潘克洛夫看着眼前一大片的牡蛎场喊道。
en: “Neb will not have lost his day,” cried Pencroft, looking at the spacious oyster-bed.

zh: “这可是个幸运的发现，”记者说，“据说每只牡蛎每年能产五万到六万个卵，这样我们就有取之不尽的食物供应了。”
en: “It is really a fortunate discovery,” said the reporter, “and as it is said that each oyster produces yearly from fifty to sixty thousand eggs, we shall have an inexhaustible supply there.”

zh: “只是我觉得牡蛎营养不太丰富。”赫伯特说道。
en: “Only I believe that the oyster is not very nourishing,” said Herbert.

zh: “没错，”哈丁答道，“牡蛎所含的氮很少，如果一个成年人只靠牡蛎生活，那每天至少要吃15到16打才行。”
en: “No,” replied Harding.“The oyster contains very little nitrogen, and if a man lived exclusively on them, he would have to eat not less than fifteen to sixteen dozen a day.”

zh: “好极了！”潘克洛夫说，“我们可以成打成打地吃，反正也吃不尽。我们要不要带一些当早饭？”
en: “Capital!” replied Pencroft.“We might swallow dozens and dozens without exhausting the bed.Shall we take some for breakfast?”

zh: 因为知道大家会赞成这个提议，水手和纳布不等大家回答，就捡了一大堆牡蛎。他们把牡蛎装进一个网袋里，这是纳布用木槿纤维做的，袋里原来就装了些食物。然后，他们继续爬上沙丘和大海之间的海岸。
en: And without waiting for a reply to this proposal, knowing that it would be approved of, the sailor and Neb detached a quantity of the molluscs.They put them in a sort of net of hibiscus fiber, which Neb had manufactured, and which already contained food; they then continued to climb the coast between the downs and the sea.

zh: 哈丁时不时地看看表，以便为及时观察太阳做好准备，这项工作必须在正午进行。
en: From time to time Harding consulted his watch, so as to be prepared in time for the solar observation, which had to be made exactly at midday.

zh: 海岛的这个部分全都很荒芜，一直到联合湾尽头都是如此，那里已被命名为南颚角。那里什么也看不见，尽是些沙石和贝壳，还混杂着一些熔岩的碎片。一些海鸟时常光顾这个荒凉的海岸，有海鸥、巨大的信天翁和野鸭，潘克洛夫对这些都很喜欢。他试图用箭射下几只，但是毫无收获，因为野鸭很少栖息在某处，而他又不会在海鸟飞行时射中目标。
en: All that part of the island was very barren as far as the point which closed Union Bay, and which had received the name of Cape South Mandible.Nothing could be seen there but sand and shells, mingled with debris of lava.A few sea-birds frequented this desolate coast, gulls, great albatrosses, as well as wild duck, for which Pencroft had a great fancy.He tried to knock some over with an arrow, but without result, for they seldom perched, and he could not hit them on the wing.

zh: 于是，水手又对工程师说道：
en: This led the sailor to repeat to the engineer,—

zh: “你看，上尉，如果没有一两支猎枪，我们绝不会打到任何东西！”
en: “You see, captain, so long as we have not one or two fowling-pieces, we shall never get anything!”

zh: “那是自然，潘克洛夫，”记者说，“但这就要看你的了。如果你能找来些铁做枪身，钢做撞针，硝石、炭和硫磺做火药，水银和硝酸做雷粉，铅做子弹，那么哈丁上尉就能为我们制造出一流的枪支。”
en: “Doubtless, Pencroft,” replied the reporter, “but it depends on you.Procure us some iron for the barrels, steel for the hammers, saltpeter. coal and sulphur for powder, mercury and nitric acid for the fulminate, and lead for the shot, and the captain will make us first-rate guns.”

zh: “哦！”工程师答道，“可以肯定，我们能在岛上找到这些东西，但是枪构造精细，需要特殊工具才行。所以，只能等到以后再说了！”
en: “Oh!” replied the engineer, “we might, no doubt, find all these substances on the island, but a gun is a delicate instrument, and needs very particular tools.However, we shall see later!”

zh: “那么，”潘克洛夫喊道，“为什么我们当时要把吊舱中的所有武器、所有器具，甚至是小折刀都扔掉呢？”
en: “Why,” cried Pencroft, “were we obliged to throw overboard all the weapons we had with us in the car, all our implements, even our pocket-knives?”

zh: “但如果当时不把它们扔出去，潘克洛夫，气球就要把我们扔到海底了！”赫伯特说道。
en: “But if we had not thrown them away, Pencroft, the balloon would have thrown us to the bottom of the sea!” said Herbert.

zh: “你说得很对，孩子。”水手应道。
en: “What you say is true, my boy,” replied the sailor.

zh: 水手又想到了另外一件事。“你想，”他说，“如果乔纳森·福斯特和他的伙伴们第二天早晨发现那里空空如也，气球也飞走了，该有多吃惊啊！”
en: Then passing to another idea,—“Think,” said he, “how astounded Jonathan Forster and his companions must have been when, next morning, they found the place empty, and the machine flown away!”

zh: “我可完全不关心他们怎么想。”记者说。
en: “I am utterly indifferent about knowing what they may have thought,” said the reporter.

zh: “那可都是我的主意呢！”潘克洛夫得意地说。
en: “It was all my idea, that!” said Pencroft, with a satisfied air.

zh: “多好的主意啊，潘克洛夫！”吉丁·史佩莱笑道，“它把我们全都送到这里来了。”
en: “A splendid idea, Pencroft!” replied Gideon Spilett, laughing, “and which has placed us where we are.”

zh: “我宁愿在这里，也不愿意落在南方人的手里，”水手大声喊道，“尤其是哈丁先生有幸重新回到了我们身边。”
en: “I would rather be here than in the hands of the Southerners,” cried the sailor, “especially since the captain has been kind enough to come and join us again.”

zh: “我也这么想，真的！”记者应道，“而且，我们还缺什么呢？什么都不缺。”
en: “So would I, truly!” replied the reporter.“Besides, what do we want?Nothing.”

zh: “如果不是在这里，那我们什么都缺！”潘克洛夫耸了耸肩，笑着说道，“但是，总有那么一天，我们会找到离开的法子！”
en: “If that is not—everything!” replied Pencroft, laughing and shrugging his shoulders.“But, some day or other, we shall find means of going away!”

zh: “也许，朋友们，这一天会比你们想象的来得更早，”工程师说，“如果林肯岛距离有人居住的海岛或是大陆不算太远。一个小时以后，我们就能知道是否如此了。我没有太平洋的地图，但是我的脑海里清楚地记得太平洋南部的地理情况。根据我昨天测出的纬度来看，林肯岛西边应该是新西兰，东边则是智利的海岸。但是这两个国家之间的距离至少有六千英里。因此，必须确定这个海岛在这大片海洋中的哪一点。我们马上就可以从经度上得知这一点，我希望结果会相当准确。”
en: “Sooner, perhaps, than you imagine, my friends,” remarked the engineer, “if Lincoln Island is but a medium distance from an inhabited island, or from a continent.We shall know in an hour.I have not a map of the Pacific, but my memory has preserved a very clear recollection of its southern part.The latitude which I obtained yesterday placed New Zealand to the west of Lincoln Island, and the coast of Chile to the east.But between these two countries, there is a distance of at least six thousand miles.It has, therefore, to be determined what point in this great space the island occupies, and this the longitude will give us presently, with a sufficient approximation, I hope.”

zh: “帕摩图群岛是同纬度上离我们最近的点吗？”赫伯特问道。
en: “Is not the archipelago of the Pomoutous the nearest point to us in latitude?” asked Herbert.

zh: “是的，”工程师答道，“但我们距它还有1200英里以上。”
en: “Yes,” replied the engineer, “but the distance which separates us from it is more than twelve hundred miles.”

zh: “那边呢？”纳布指着南方问道，他对这个话题兴致勃勃。
en: “And that way?” asked Neb, who followed the conversation with extreme interest, pointing to the south.

zh: “那边，什么都没有。”潘克洛夫回答。
en: “That way, nothing,” replied Pencroft.

zh: “的确什么都没有。”工程师补充道。
en: “Nothing, indeed,” added the engineer.

zh: “那么，赛勒斯，”记者问道，“如果林肯岛距离新西兰或智利不到两三千英里呢？”
en: “Well, Cyrus,” asked the reporter, “if Lincoln Island is not more than two or three thousand miles from New Zealand or Chile?”

zh: “那么，”工程师答道，“我们就不盖房子了，改为造船，就由潘克洛夫船长来指挥。”
en: “Well,” replied the engineer, “instead of building a house we will build a boat, and Master Pencroft shall be put in command—”

zh: “太好了，”水手喊道，“我早就准备好当船长了，就等你做一只可以航海的船了。”
en: “Well then,” cried the sailor, “I am quite ready to be captain—as soon as you can make a craft that’s able to keep at sea!”

zh: “如果需要，我们就造一只。”赛勒斯·哈丁回答。
en: “We shall do it, if it is necessary,” replied Cyrus Harding.

zh: 这些人遇事向来果断，但正当他们聊天的时候，观测的时间已经快到了。赛勒斯·哈丁不用任何仪器，将如何确定太阳通过海岛子午线的路线，赫伯特怎么也猜不透。
en: But while these men, who really hesitated at nothing, were talking, the hour approached at which the observation was to be made.What Cyrus Harding was to do to ascertain the passage of the sun at the meridian of the island, without an instrument of any sort, Herbert could not guess.

zh: 这时观察者们距离“石窟”大概六英里远，距工程师不可思议地获救后他们找到的那片沙丘不远。他们在这里停了下来，开始准备早餐，因为已经十一点半了。赫伯特去附近的小溪找了些淡水，用纳布准备的水壶装了回来。
en: The observers were then about six miles from the Chimneys, not far from that part of the downs in which the engineer had been found after his enigmatical preservation.They halted at this place and prepared for breakfast, for it was half-past eleven.Herbert went for some fresh water from a stream which ran near, and brought it back in a jug, which Neb had provided.

zh: 趁着准备吃饭的空当，哈丁安排好了天文观测的一切。他选了海滨一处开阔的空地，落潮以后这里的地面十分平整。这片细沙地像冰面一样平滑，没有一粒沙子格格不入。地面是否水平无关紧要，插在地上的六英尺木杆是否和地面垂直也不太要紧。相反，工程师将它斜向了南边，也就是海滨背向太阳的方向，因为必须牢记的一点是海岛位于南半球，所以林肯岛上的居民所看见的光芒四射的星球，运行的弧线是在北边的水平线上，而非南边。
en: During these preparations Harding arranged everything for his astronomical observation.He chose a clear place on the shore, which the ebbing tide had left perfectly level.This bed of fine sand was as smooth as ice, not a grain out of place.It was of little importance whether it was horizontal or not, and it did not matter much whether the stick six feet high, which was planted there, rose perpendicularly.On the contrary, the engineer inclined it towards the south, that is to say, in the direction of the coast opposite to the sun, for it must not be forgotten that the settlers in Lincoln Island, as the island was situated in the Southern Hemisphere, saw the radiant planet describe its diurnal arc above the northern, and not above the southern horizon.

zh: 现在赫伯特知道工程师打算如何确定太阳的顶点，也就是经过海岛子午线的方位，换句话说，就是确定当地的正南方。他是通过测量木杆在沙地上的投影，在没有仪器时，这是可以得到他所需要的精确结果的适合方式。
en: Herbert now understood how the engineer was going to proceed to ascertain the culmination of the sun, that is to say its passing the meridian of the island or, in other words, determine due south.It was by means of the shadow cast on the sand by the stick, a way which, for want of an instrument, would give him a suitable approach to the result which he wished to obtain.

zh: 事实上，当影子的长度最短时，应该是正午十二点，只要观察影子的末端，就可以确定影子逐渐缩短之后又开始拉长的那一瞬间。赛勒斯·哈丁把木杆偏向和太阳相对的方向，这样可以使影子长一些，因此可以更容易地看到它的变化。事实上，日晷的时针愈长，就愈容易辨别指针的移动。木杆的影子也就是日晷上的指针。时间到了，赛勒斯·哈丁跪在沙地上，把一个个小木桩插在沙地上做记号，开始记录木杆影子逐渐缩短的过程。他的同伴们弯下腰，怀着极大的兴趣观察工作的进展。记者手里拿着表，准备报出影子最短的时刻。还要说明一点，因为赛勒斯·哈丁进行测量的这一天是4月18日，真实时间和平均时间完全一致，因此吉丁·史佩莱报出的时间就是当时华盛顿的真实时间，这样一来，计算就更加简单了。这时候，随着太阳缓慢的移动，影子逐渐缩短，等到赛勒斯·哈丁觉得影子又开始伸长时，他就问道，“现在几点？”
en: In fact, the moment when this shadow would reach its minimum of length would be exactly twelve o’clock, and it would be enough to watch the extremity of the shadow, so as to ascertain the instant when, alter having successively diminished, it began to lengthen.By inclining his stick to the side opposite to the sun, Cyrus Harding made the shadow longer, and consequently its modifications would be more easily ascertained.In fact, the longer the needle of a dial is, the more easily can the movement of its point be followed.The shadow of the stick was nothing but the needle of a dial.The moment had come, and Cyrus Harding knelt on the sand, and with little wooden pegs, which he stuck into the sand, he began to mark the successive diminutions of the stick’s shadow.His companions, bending over him, watched the operation with extreme interest.The reporter held his chronometer in his hand, ready to tell the hour which it marked when the shadow would be at its shortest.Moreover, as Cyrus Harding was working on the 16th of April, the day on which the true and the average time are identical, the hour given by Gideon Spilett would be the true hour then at Washington, which would simplify the calculation.Meanwhile as the sun slowly advanced, the shadow slowly diminished, and when it appeared to Cyrus Harding that it was beginning to increase, he asked, “What o’clock is it?”

zh: “五点零一分。”吉丁·史佩莱立刻答道。他们现在只要计算出结果就可以了。这再简单不过了。由此可见，华盛顿和林肯岛的经度差大约是五个小时，也就是说，林肯岛正午的时候，华盛顿已经是下午五点钟了。现在太阳环绕地球，每过一度需要四分钟，那么也就是一小时移动15度。15度乘以5小时等于75度。
en: “One minute past five,” replied Gideon Spilett directly.They had now only to calculate the operation.Nothing could be easier.It could be seen that there existed, in round numbers, a difference of five hours between the meridian of Washington and that of Lincoln Island, that is to say, it was midday in Lincoln Island when it was already five o’clock in the evening in Washington.Now the sun, in its apparent movement round the earth, traverses one degree in four minutes, or fifteen degrees an hour.Fifteen degrees multiplied by five hours give seventy-five degrees.

zh: 那么，既然华盛顿的经度是77度3分11秒，也就是从格林尼治子午线算起的第77度。美国人和英国人都是以格林尼治为经线的起点，那么海岛一定是位于格林尼治子午线以西77度加75度的地方，也就是西经152度。
en: Then, since Washington is 77deg 3’ 11” as much as to say seventy-seven degrees counted from the meridian of Greenwich which the Americans take for their starting-point for longitudes concurrently with the English—it followed that the island must be situated seventy-seven and seventy-five degrees west of the meridian of Greenwich, that is to say, on the hundred and fifty-second degree of west longitude.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁向同伴们宣布了这个结果，并且也像计算纬度时那样，把观察时存在的误差也考虑在内。他相信他可以肯定林肯岛的位置在35度到37度之间，经度则在格林尼治子午线以西150到155度之间。
en: Cyrus Harding announced this result to his companions, and taking into consideration errors of observation, as he had done for the latitude, he believed he could positively affirm that the position of Lincoln Island was between the thirty-fifth and the thirty-seventh parallel, and between the hundred and fiftieth and the hundred and fifty-fifth meridian to the west of the meridian of Greenwich.

zh: 可以看出，他在观察过程中可能发生的误差为上下5度左右，一度合60英里，这样算来，经纬各五度的误差就相当于偏离精确位置三百英里。
en: The possible fault which he attributed to errors in the observation was, it may be seen, of five degrees on both sides, which, at sixty miles to a degree, would give an error of three hundred miles in latitude and longitude for the exact position.

zh: 但这个误差并不会对他们必须做出的判断产生影响。很明显，林肯岛离任何一个国家和岛屿都有相当远的距离，因此，试图乘坐一只不结实的小船离岛太危险了。
en: But this error would not influence the determination which it was necessary to take.It was very evident that Lincoln Island was at such a distance from every country or island that it would be too hazardous to attempt to reach one in a frail boat.

zh: 实际上，根据推算出的结果，海岛离塔西提岛和帕摩图群岛至少有1200英里，离新西兰有1800多英里，距美国西海岸4500英里以上！
en: In fact, this calculation placed it at least twelve hundred miles from Tahiti and the islands of the archipelago of the Pomoutous, more than eighteen hundred miles from New Zealand, and more than four thousand five hundred miles from the American coast!

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁回忆了一下，他无论如何也想不起在太平洋的这个部分，有什么岛屿靠近林肯岛。
en: And when Cyrus Harding consulted his memory, he could not remember in any way that such an island occupied, in that part of the Pacific, the situation assigned to Lincoln Island.

zh: 第十五章
en: Chapter 15

zh: 第二天是4月17日，水手的第一句话是对吉丁·史佩莱说的。
en: The next day, the 17th of April, the sailor’s first words were addressed to Gideon Spilett.

zh: “先生，”他问道，“我们今天干什么呢？”
en: “Well, sir,” he asked, “what shall we do to-day?”

zh: “上尉高兴干的事。”记者答道。
en: “What the captain pleases,” replied the reporter.

zh: 在那以前，工程师的同伴们已经当过制砖工人和制陶匠了，现在他们要变成冶金匠了。
en: Till then the engineer’s companions had been brickmakers and potters, now they were to become metallurgists.

zh: 前一天早饭过后，他们行至离“石窟”七英里的颚骨角。连绵的沙丘到了尽头，那里的土壤看上去好像是火山土。那里没有像眺望岗那样的峭壁，只有奇形怪状的海湾边缘，环绕着两个海角中间的狭长海湾，边缘由火山喷发出来的矿物质构成。到了这里之后，居民们开始往回走，夜色降临时回到了“石窟”。但是一想到能否离开林肯岛的问题还没有定论，他们就没有睡下。
