en: The day before, after breakfast, they had explored as far as the point of Mandible Cape, seven miles distant from the Chimneys.There, the long series of downs ended, and the soil had a volcanic appearance.There were no longer high cliffs as at Prospect Heights, but a strange and capricious border which surrounded the narrow gulf between the two capes, formed of mineral matter, thrown up by the volcano.Arrived at this point the settlers retraced their steps, and at nightfall entered the Chimneys; but they did not sleep before the question of knowing whether they could think of leaving Lincoln Island or not was definitely settled.

zh: 海岛距离帕摩图群岛有1200英里，是一段相当长的距离。小船是无法横渡的，尤其是寒冷的季节快到了。潘克洛夫意味深长地表明了这一点。即便是有必要的工具，造一艘简易的船也是一项艰巨的任务，何况开拓者们没有任何工具，他们必须先着手做锤子、斧子、锛子、锯、钻子、刨等等，这要一段时间才能完成。于是大家决定在林肯岛上过冬，他们还要找一个比“石窟”更舒服的住所，好度过冬天的几个月。
en: The twelve hundred miles which separated the island from the Pomoutous Island was a considerable distance.A boat could not cross it, especially at the approach of the bad season.Pencroft had expressly declared this.Now, to construct a simple boat even with the necessary tools, was a difficult work, and the colonists not having tools they must begin by making hammers, axes, adzes, saws, augers, planes, etc., which would take some time.It was decided, therefore, that they would winter at Lincoln Island, and that they would look for a more comfortable dwelling than the Chimneys, in which to pass the winter months.

zh: 在做其他事情前，首先必须找到铁矿，工程师曾在海岛的西北部发现铁矿的痕迹，那里的矿石很适于炼钢或炼铁。
en: Before anything else could be done it was necessary to make the iron ore, of which the engineer had observed some traces in the northwest part of the island, fit for use by converting it either into iron or into steel.

zh: 通常情况下，金属埋藏在地下，质地并不纯。它们大多会和氧气或硫化物结合在一起。赛勒斯·哈丁上次带回的两种矿物就出现了这种情况，一种是未被碳化的磁铁矿，另一种是黄铁矿，也叫硫化铁。因此，他们必须先用炭还原氧化铁，也就是除去氧，得到纯粹的铁。这个还原过程是用炭把矿石烧到很高的温度，可以用快速而又简便的加泰罗尼亚方法，这种方法的优点在于只要一道工序就能把铁矿石炼成铁；另外也可以用鼓风炉，首先熔化铁矿石，然后除掉混在铁矿石中的百分之三到四的炭，使它变成铁。
en: Metals are not generally found in the ground in a pure state.For the most part they are combined with oxygen or sulphur.Such was the case with the two specimens which Cyrus Harding had brought back, one of magnetic iron, not carbonated, the other a pyrite, also called sulphuret of iron.It was, therefore the first, the oxide of iron, which they must reduce with coal, that is to say, get rid of the oxygen, to obtain it in a pure state.This reduction is made by subjecting the ore with coal to a high temperature, either by the rapid and easy Catalan method, which has the advantage of transforming the ore into iron in a single operation, or by the blast furnace, which first smelts the ore, then changes it into iron, by carrying away the three to four per cent. of coal, which is combined with it.

zh: 现在赛勒斯·哈丁需要铁，而且他希望能尽快获取。他捡到的铁矿石本身质地很纯正，含铁量高。这是一种氧化铁，捡来时是混杂的深灰色大块，里面还有一种规则正八面结晶体形成的黑色碎末。天然磁石里就含有这种矿石，质量上乘的铁产自欧洲，瑞典和挪威大量出产此种矿石。离这个矿脉不远就是煤层，居民们已经使用这里的煤了。炼铁的原料都在周围，这样极大地方便了炼铁工作。这就是英国矿藏财富的原因，这里的煤方便了冶炼金属的工作，地下同时可以开采煤和金属进行冶炼。
en: Now Cyrus Harding wanted iron, and he wished to obtain it as soon as possible.The ore which he had picked up was in itself very pure and rich.It was the oxydulous iron, which is found in confused masses of a deep gray color; it gives a black dust, crystallized in the form of the regular octahedron.Native lodestones consist of this ore, and iron of the first quality is made in Europe from that with which Sweden and Norway are so abundantly supplied.Not far from this vein was the vein of coal already made use of by the settlers.The ingredients for the manufacture being close together would greatly facilitate the treatment of the ore.This is the cause of the wealth of the mines in Great Britain, where the coal aids the manufacture of the metal extracted from the same soil at the same time as itself.

zh: “那么，上尉，”潘克洛夫说，“我们要炼铁矿石吗？”
en: “Then, captain,” said Pencroft, “we are going to work iron ore?”

zh: “是的，朋友们，”工程师答道，“为了这个，我们先要做件你很喜欢的事，我们必须去小岛上打海豹，作为工作的开始。”
en: “Yes, my friend,” replied the engineer, “and for that—something which will please you—we must begin by having a seal hunt on the islet.”

zh: “打海豹！”水手把脸转向史佩莱问道，“炼铁需要海豹吗？”
en: “A seal hunt!” cried the sailor, turning towards Gideon Spilett.“Are seals needed to make iron?”

zh: “既然赛勒斯说需要那就需要。”记者答道。
en: “Since Cyrus has said so!” replied the reporter.

zh: 工程师已经走出了“石窟”，其他人也没给出解释，所以潘克洛夫开始准备打海豹。
en: But the engineer had already left the Chimneys, and Pencroft prepared for the seal hunt, without having received any other explanation.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁、赫伯特、吉丁·史佩莱、纳布和水手很快就在海岸的一处集合，这里是海湾退潮时的水道形成的可通行浅滩。猎人们可以涉水通过，水深不到膝盖。
en: Cyrus Harding, Herbert, Gideon Spilett, Neb, and the sailor were soon collected on the shore, at a place where the channel left a ford passable at low tide.The hunters could therefore traverse it without getting wet higher than the knee.

zh: 哈丁还是第一次登陆这个小岛，他的同伴们已经是第二次了。
en: Harding then put his foot on the islet for the first, and his companions for the second time.

zh: 他们上岸时，成百只企鹅看着他们，一点也不害怕。猎人们手里拿着棍子，本可以轻易地打死几只，但是他们不想无端屠戮，因为要紧的是不惊动海豹，此时那些海豹正躺在几锚链远以外的沙滩上。他们也没有侵犯一种样子很天真的鸟，鸟的翅膀退化成短肢，像鳍似的展开，被像鳞片一样的羽毛装饰着。居民们谨慎地向北面前行，地面上满是小洞，形成了海鸟的窝。小岛的尽头出现了黑色的大脑袋，浮在水面上，极像移动的岩石。
en: On their landing some hundreds of penguins looked fearlessly at them.The hunters, armed with sticks, could have killed them easily, but they were not guilty of such useless massacre, as it was important not to frighten the seals, who were lying on the sand several cable lengths off.They also respected certain innocent-looking birds, whose wings were reduced to the state of stumps, spread out like fins, ornamented with feathers of a scaly appearance.The settlers, therefore, prudently advanced towards the north point, walking over ground riddled with little holes, which formed nests for the sea-birds.Towards the extremity of the islet appeared great black heads floating just above the water, having exactly the appearance of rocks in motion.

zh: 这就是他们想要抓的海豹。然而，必须先等它们上岸，因为海豹的毛短而密实，躯体呈梭状，它们是出色的游泳健将，在海里捕捉它们很困难。但在陆地上，它们短小的蹼足使其只能摇摇摆摆地缓慢走动。
en: These were the seals which were to be captured.It was necessary, however, first to allow them to land, for with their close, short hair, and their fusiform conformation, being excellent swimmers, it is difficult to catch them in the sea, while on land their short, webbed feet prevent their having more than a slow, waddling movement.

zh: 潘克洛夫知道这种动物的习性，他叫大家等到海豹在沙滩上伸展开来，不久太阳就会使它们进入睡眠。那时必须截断它们的退路，敲打它们的头部。
en: Pencroft knew the habits of these creatures, and he advised waiting till they were stretched on the sand, when the sun, before long, would send them to sleep.They must then manage to cut off their retreat and knock them on the head.

zh: 猎手们藏在岩石后面，安静地等待着。
en: The hunters, having concealed themselves behind the rocks, waited silently.

zh: 一个钟头之后，海豹开始到沙滩上玩耍。他们数了数，有六只。于是，潘克洛夫和赫伯特绕过小岛的海角，以便从它们的后面进攻，截断其退路。在此期间，赛勒斯·哈丁、史佩莱和纳布从石头后面爬出来，滑行到即将开始的战斗现场。
en: An hour passed before the seals came to play on the sand.They could count half a dozen.Pencroft and Herbert then went round the point of the islet, so as to take them in the rear, and cut off their retreat.During this time Cyrus Harding, Spilett, and Neb, crawling behind the rocks, glided towards the future scene of combat.

zh: 突然间，水手的高大身躯出现了。潘克洛夫大吼一声。工程师和他的同伴们快速冲向大海和海豹之间的地带。很快就有两只海豹死在沙滩上了，剩下的几只却平安地重回大海。
en: All at once the tall figure of the sailor appeared.Pencroft shouted.The engineer and his two companions threw themselves between the sea and the seals.Two of the animals soon lay dead on the sand, but the rest regained the sea in safety.

zh: “这是我们需要的海豹，上尉。”水手边说边向工程师走去。
en: “Here are the seals required, captain!” said the sailor, advancing towards the engineer.

zh: “好极了，”哈丁应道，“我们要拿它们做风箱！”
en: “Capital,” replied Harding.“We will make bellows of them!”

zh: “风箱！”潘克洛夫喊道，“好吧，这些海豹运气不错啊！”
en: “Bellows!” cried Pencroft.“Well! these are lucky seals!”

zh: 事实上，工程师是想用这种两栖动物的皮来做炼铁时必需的鼓风机。两只海豹大小中等，身长不到六英尺。它们的头部和狗头很像。
en: It was, in fact, a blowing-machine, necessary for the treatment of the ore that the engineer wished to manufacture with the skins of the amphibious creatures.They were of a medium size, for their length did not exceed six feet.They resembled a dog about the head.

zh: 由于没有必要把这两只海豹抬回去，纳布和潘克洛夫决定就地剥皮，赛勒斯·哈丁和记者则继续探寻小岛。
en: As it was useless to burden themselves with the weight of both the animals, Neb and Pencroft resolved to skin them on the spot, while Cyrus Harding and the reporter continued to explore the islet.

zh: 水手和黑人剥得很巧妙，三个小时以后，赛勒斯·哈丁就可以处置两张海豹皮，他打算不晾晒，直接利用。
en: The sailor and the Negro cleverly performed the operation, and three hours afterwards Cyrus Harding had at his disposal two seals’ skins, which he intended to use in this state, without subjecting them to any tanning process.

zh: 居民一直等到再次退潮，才涉过海峡，回到“石窟”。
en: The settlers waited till the tide was again low, and crossing the channel they entered the Chimneys.

zh: 然后他们就把海豹皮搭在木架上，用纤维缝制，将空气保留其中，尽量使其不漏太多。赛勒斯·哈丁只有用托普的项圈做成的两片钢刀，但是他很聪明，他的同伴们也贡献了许多智慧，三天以后，开拓小队的工具库里又增添了一件鼓风机，是在加热矿石时送风用的，这是成功完成冶炼的一个不可或缺的条件。
en: The skins had then to be stretched on a frame of wood and sewn by means of fibers so as to preserve the air without allowing too much to escape.Cyrus Harding had nothing but the two steel blades from Top’s collar, and yet he was so clever, and his companions aided him with so much intelligence, that three days afterwards the little colony’s stock of tools was augmented by a blowing-machine, destined to inject the air into the midst of the ore when it should be subjected to heat—an indispensable condition to the success of the operation.

zh: 4月22日清晨，“金属时代”开始了，正如记者在笔记本里写的。如前所述，工程师已经决定在邻近煤矿和铁矿的地方开工。现在，根据他的观察，矿脉在富兰克林山东北支脉的山脚，也就是距离他们的家六英里的地方。因此，每日回到“石窟”是不可能的，于是开拓小队决定用树枝打一个棚子宿营，这样就可以夜以继日地从事这个重要的工作了。
en: On the morning of the 20th of April began the “metallic period,” as the reporter called it in his notes.The engineer had decided, as has been said, to operate near the veins both of coal and ore.Now, according to his observations, these veins were situated at the foot of the northeast spurs of Mount Franklin, that is to say, a distance of six miles from their home.It was impossible, therefore, to return every day to the Chimneys, and it was agreed that the little colony should camp under a hut of branches, so that the important operation could be followed night and day.

zh: 决定了这个问题之后，他们清晨就出发了。纳布和潘克洛夫拖着装风箱的筐子，筐里还装了大量的蔬菜和肉，他们还可以在途中添些新的食物。
en: This settled, they set out in the morning.Neb and Pencroft dragged the bellows on a hurdle; also a quantity of vegetables and animals, which they besides could renew on the way.

zh: 途中要穿过啄木鸟林，他们从东南方向斜穿进去，经过树木最茂密的地方，从西北方向出去。很有必要开一条路，将来这条道路可以直接打通眺望岗和富兰克林山之间的路程。森林中有许多美丽的植物，都是已经发现的品种。赫伯特发现了一些新品种，其中有种植物被潘克洛夫称作“假韭菜”。它们虽然比韭菜大，但也像洋葱、细香葱、青葱和芦笋一样，属于百合科。这些植物长有木质的根，做成菜很好吃，而且经过发酵以后，还能制成一种非常可口的酒。因此他们收藏了很多这种植物的根。
en: The road led through Jacamar Wood, which they traversed obliquely from southeast to northwest, and in the thickest part.It was necessary to beat a path, which would in the future form the most direct road to Prospect Heights and Mount Franklin.The trees, belonging to the species already discovered, were magnificent.Herbert found some new ones, among others some which Pencroft called “sham leeks”; for, in spite of their size, they were of the same liliaceous family as the onion, chive, shallot, or asparagus.These trees produce ligneous roots which, when cooked, are excellent; from them, by fermentation, a very agreeable liquor is made.They therefore made a good store of the roots.

zh: 斜穿森林的路程很漫长，持续了一整天，这样他们有了大量的时间来观察林中的动物和植物。托普专门寻找动物，它穿梭于草木之间，赶出各种各样的动物。赫伯特和吉丁·史佩莱用弓箭射死了两只袋鼠，以及一只既很像刺猬又很像食蚁兽的动物。说它像刺猬，是因为它可以蜷成一个球，满身刺针竖立；说它像食蚁兽，是因为它长着锋利的爪子，又细又长的嘴，末端很像鸟喙。它还有一根可伸长的舌头，上面布满小刺，可以捕食昆虫。
en: The journey through the wood was long; it lasted the whole day, and so allowed plenty of time for examining the flora and fauna.Top, who took special charge of the fauna, ran through the grass and brushwood, putting up all sorts of game.Herbert and Gideon Spilett killed two kangaroos with bows and arrows, and also an animal which strongly resembled both a hedgehog and an ant-eater.It was like the first because it rolled itself into a ball, and bristled with spines, and the second because it had sharp claws, a long slender snout which terminated in a bird’s beak, and an extendible tongue, covered with little thorns which served to hold the insects.

zh: “等它成为盘中餐时，”潘克洛夫照例问道，“它像什么呢？”
en: “And when it is in the pot,” asked Pencroft naturally, “what will it be like?”

zh: “上等的牛肉。”赫伯特答道。
en: “An excellent piece of beef,” replied Herbert.

zh: “我们也不能对它奢求过多。”水手说。
en: “We will not ask more from it,” replied the sailor,

zh: 在这次旅途中，他们看见几次野猪，但是这些野猪并没有攻击小队，这样看来,他们似乎不会遇见什么危险的猛兽了。可就在这时，记者感觉自己看到几步以外的的浓密树丛里，有一只他认为是熊的野兽在一棵树的矮枝间，他开始很镇定地把它画下来。吉丁·史佩莱是幸运的，他正思索的这只动物并不属于可怕的踟行类。这只是一只无尾熊，一般称为“懒兽”，体型和大狗差不多，身上的毛又硬又脏，脚上生着有力的爪子，能够攀爬树木，以树叶为食。他们看清这个动物之后，并没有去打扰它。吉丁·史佩莱把素描的标题“熊”擦掉，写上了“考拉”，然后大家继续赶路。
en: During this excursion they saw several wild boars, which however, did not offer to attack the little band, and it appeared as if they would not meet with any dangerous beasts; when, in a thick part of the wood, the reporter thought he saw, some paces from him, among the lower branches of a tree, an animal which he took for a bear, and which he very tranquilly began to draw.Happily for Gideon Spilett, the animal in question did not belong to the redoubtable family of the plantigrades.It was only a koala, better known under the name of the sloth, being about the size of a large dog, and having stiff hair of a dirty color, the paws armed with strong claws, which enabled it to climb trees and feed on the leaves.Having identified the animal, which they did not disturb, Gideon Spilett erased “bear” from the title of his sketch, putting koala in its place, and the journey was resumed.

zh: 下午五点钟，赛勒斯·哈丁下令停下来。现在他们已经走出了森林，来到了支撑起富兰克林山西部走向的众多支脉下。几百英尺以外的地方有红河在流动，因此他们可以就近得到大量的淡水。
en: At five o’clock in the evening, Cyrus Harding gave the signal to halt.They were now outside the forest, at the beginning of the powerful spurs which supported Mount Franklin towards the west.At a distance of some hundred feet flowed the Red Creek, and consequently plenty of fresh water was within their reach.

zh: 宿营地很快搭建起来了。不到一个小时，他们就在森林边缘的树木之间，将爬藤和树枝编在一起，再涂些粘土，搭成了一个棚子，建成了一个还算不错的住处。他们的地质勘探工作推迟到明天进行。大家开始准备晚饭，棚子前面生着熊熊燃烧的篝火，烤肉在火上转动。八点的时候，居民们留下一个人照看篝火，以防野兽潜伏在宿营地附近，其他的人已经沉沉入睡。
en: The camp was soon organized.In less than an hour, on the edge of the forest, among the trees, a hut of branches interlaced with creepers, and pasted over with clay, offered a tolerable shelter.Their geological researches were put off till the next day.Supper was prepared, a good fire blazed before the hut, the roast turned, and at eight o’clock, while one of the settlers watched to keep up the fire, in case any wild beasts should prowl in the neighborhood, the others slept soundly.

zh: 第二天是4月21日，赛勒斯·哈丁带着赫伯特去寻找古老的地层，上次他已经在这种地层里发现过铁矿石的样本。他们在红河源头的地面附近发现了一处矿脉，就在一个东北支脉的山脚下。这种矿石含有丰富的铁，被易于熔化的脉石包裹着，非常适于工程师打算采用的还原炼铁法，也就是加泰罗尼亚人用的方法，只不过像科西嘉人那样简化了。实际上，所谓的加泰罗尼亚方法需要砌个熔炉，建几个坩埚，将矿石和煤分层放好，让它变化和还原。但是赛勒斯·哈丁打算省掉这些设备，只想简单地把矿石和煤做成立方体，然后用风箱把空气吹入立方体的中心。毫无疑问，这是土八该隐和世界上第一批冶金学家所用的方法。既然亚当的子孙能够成功，而且在铁矿和燃料富足的国家都取得了好效果，那么林肯岛上的居民们也一定会成功的。
en: The next day, the 21st of April, Cyrus Harding accompanied by Herbert, went to look for the soil of ancient formation, on which he had already discovered a specimen of ore.They found the vein above ground, near the source of the creek, at the foot of one of the northeastern spurs.This ore, very rich in iron, enclosed in its fusible veinstone, was perfectly suited to the mode of reduction which the engineer intended to employ; that is, the Catalan method, but simplified, as it is used in Corsica.In fact, the Catalan method, properly so called, requires the construction of kilns and crucibles, in which the ore and the coal, placed in alternate layers, are transformed and reduced, But Cyrus Harding intended to economize these constructions, and wished simply to form, with the ore and the coal, a cubic mass, to the center of which he would direct the wind from his bellows.Doubtless, it was the proceeding employed by Tubalcain, and the first metallurgists of the inhabited world.Now that which had succeeded with the grandson of Adam, and which still yielded good results in countries which in ore and fuel, could not but succeed with the settlers in Lincoln Island.

zh: 煤和铁矿石可以轻易地在地上收集。他们先把铁矿石敲成小块，然后用手擦净弄脏它们表面的杂质。煤和铁矿石被一层层地堆起来，就像木炭工人烧他希望被碳化的柴那样。用这种方法，在鼓风机吹入的空气的影响下，煤就会转变成碳酸，然后变成氧化碳，它的作用就是还原氧化铁，也就是释放出氧气。
en: The coal, as well as the ore, was collected without trouble on the surface of the ground.They first broke the ore into little pieces, and cleansed them with the hand from the impurities which soiled their surface.Then coal and ore were arranged in heaps and in successive layers, as the charcoal-burner does with the wood which he wishes to carbonize.In this way, under the influence of the air projected by the blowing-machine, the coal would be transformed into carbonic acid, then into oxide of carbon, its use being to reduce the oxide of iron, that is to say, to rid it of the oxygen.

zh: 工程师就是这样进行的。海豹皮风箱的一端装了一根粘土做的管口，这是事先在陶器窑里制造的，然后把风箱安装在矿石堆附近。这个鼓风机是由一个木架、植物纤维绳索和一个秤锤做成的，工程师利用这个装置，把大量的空气吹到立方体里去，温度提高以后，化学反应也同时进行，到一定的时候就能冶炼出纯铁来。
en: Thus the engineer proceeded.The bellows of sealskin, furnished at its extremity with a nozzle of clay, which had been previously fabricated in the pottery kiln, was established near the heap of ore.Using the mechanism which consisted of a frame, cords of fiber and counterpoise, he threw into the mass an abundance of air, which by raising the temperature also concurred with the chemical transformation to produce in time pure iron.

zh: 这项工程很艰巨。这需要居民们全部的耐心和智慧。最后，他们终于取得了成功，成果就是一块生铁，但和海绵质地差不多，还需加以煅烧和锤炼，也就是说，必须经过打铁的过程，排除掉液化的脉石。当然，这些业余的铁匠们没有锤子，但他们的情况不比第一批冶金学家更差，因此，他们无疑只要尽力去做就好。
en: The operation was difficult.All the patience, all the ingenuity of the settlers was needed; but at last it succeeded, and the result was a lump of iron, reduced to a spongy state, which it was necessary to shingle and fagot, that is to say, to forge so as to expel from it the liquefied veinstone.These amateur smiths had, of course, no hammer; but they were in no worse a situation than the first metallurgist, and therefore did what, no doubt, he had to do.

zh: 他们给第一块生铁安装了一个把手，当锤子用，来打造花岗石砧子上的第二块铁，这样他们就打出了粗糙但很实用的铁。最终经过无数次的艰苦实验，他们终于在4月25日打出了几根铁条，并把这些铁条做成了工具，如铁橇、钳子、鹤嘴锄和铲子等等。潘克洛夫和纳布说他们是真正的珍宝。但是金属还没达到最适于使用的状态，也就是还没有变成钢。钢是铁和炭的化合物，要炼钢就要从液态铁矿石里去掉多余的炭，或是向铁里加入所缺少的炭。第一种得到钢的方法，是把金属脱碳，可以产生天然钢或是铸钢；第二种方法，是把铁碳化，可以制成经渗碳处理的钢。
en: A handle was fixed to the first lump, and was used as a hammer to forge the second on a granite anvil, and thus they obtained a coarse but useful metal.At length, after many trials and much fatigue, on the 25th of April several bars of iron were forged, and transformed into tools, crowbars, pincers, pickaxes, spades, etc., which Pencroft and Neb declared to be real jewels.But the metal was not yet in its most serviceable state, that is, of steel.Now steel is a combination of iron and coal, which is extracted, either from the liquid ore, by taking from it the excess of coal, or from the iron by adding to it the coal which was wanting.The first, obtained by the decarburation of the metal, gives natural or puddled steel; the second, produced by the carburation of the iron, gives steel of cementation.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁打算采用后一种方法炼制，因为他有质地纯正的铁。他把铁和炭粉放在坩埚里加热，坩埚是事先用粘土做的，很适合应用于此处，结果他成功了。
en: It was the last which Cyrus Harding intended to forge, as he possessed iron in a pure state.He succeeded by heating the metal with powdered coal in a crucible which had previously been manufactured from clay suitable for the purpose.

zh: 于是，他用锤子对钢进行加工，这种钢在冷热条件下有延展性。纳布和潘克洛夫在工程师的精心指导下，把钢烧红，然后突然浸到冷水里，就制成了许多韧度很好的斧头。
en: He then worked this steel, which is malleable both when hot or cold, with the hammer.Neb and Pencroft, cleverly directed, made hatchets, which, heated red-hot, and plunged suddenly into cold water, acquired an excellent temper.

zh: 其他工具也制造了出来，形状自然粗糙。其中有做刨刀、砍柴斧、手斧用的钢板，做锯和凿子用的钢块，此外还有制造铲子、鹤嘴锄、钉子等用的铁。5月7日那天，金属时期终于结束了。铁匠们回到了“石窟”，很快就有新的工作授予他们新的头衔了。
en: Other instruments, of course roughly fashioned, were also manufactured; blades for planes, axes, hatchets, pieces of steel to be transformed into saws, chisels; then iron for spades, pickaxes, hammers, nails, etc.At last, on the 5th of May, the metallic period ended, the smiths returned to the Chimneys, and new work would soon authorize them to take a fresh title.

zh: 第十六章
en: Chapter 16

zh: 那天是5月6号，相当于北半球的11月6号。天阴沉着有好几天了，现在为过冬做准备就很重要了。不过气温还不太低，如果现在把一支摄氏温度计运到林肯岛，显示的平均气温应该还会在零上十到十二度。这并不奇怪，因为林肯岛可能处于南纬35到40度之间，与北半球的西西里和希腊的气候应该很相似。但是希腊和西西里的冬季气候恶劣，冰雪交加，所以林肯岛到冬天也会有这种最恶劣的天气，准备御寒无疑是明智之举。
en: It was the 6th of May, a day which corresponds to the 6th of November in the countries of the Northern Hemisphere.The sky had been obscured for some days, and it was of importance to make preparations for the winter.However, the temperature was not as yet much lower, and a centigrade thermometer, transported to Lincoln Island, would still have marked an average of ten to twelve degrees above zero.This was not surprising, since Lincoln Island, probably situated between the thirty-fifth and fortieth parallel, would be subject, in the Southern Hemisphere, to the same climate as Sicily or Greece in the Northern Hemisphere.But as Greece and Sicily have severe cold, producing snow and ice, so doubtless would Lincoln Island in the severest part of the winter and it was advisable to provide against it.

zh: 无论如何，即使他们还没受到严寒的威胁，雨季也将要到来了，这座汪洋中的孤岛肯定会遭遇狂暴的恶劣天气，坏天气会很频繁，还可能很可怕。因此，当务之急是慎重考虑，谨慎选择一个比“石窟”更舒适的住所，而且要尽快行动。
en: In any case if cold did not yet threaten them, the rainy season would begin, and on this lonely island, exposed to all the fury of the elements, in mid-ocean, bad weather would be frequent, and probably terrible.The question of a more comfortable dwelling than the Chimneys must therefore be seriously considered and promptly resolved on.

zh: 潘克洛夫自然偏爱自己找到的住处，但是他很明白必须再找一处安身之所。“石窟”已经被海水冲刷过一次了，当时的情况大家都很清楚，如果再发生类似事件，后果就不堪设想了。
en: Pencroft, naturally, had some predilection for the retreat which he had discovered, but he well understood that another must be found.The Chimneys had been already visited by the sea, under circumstances which are known, and it would not do to be exposed again to a similar accident.

zh: “除此以外，”赛勒斯·哈丁当天和同伴们谈到这些问题的时候说：“我们还要做好防范措施。”
en: “Besides,” added Cyrus Harding, who this day was talking of these things with his companions, “we have some precautions to take.”

zh: “为什么？”岛上又没有人。”记者说道。
en: “Why?The island is not inhabited,” said the reporter.

zh: “这有可能，”工程师回答道，“尽管我们还没有探索过内陆区域，但是，如果没有人，我担心会有很多危险的野兽。我们有必要防范可能遭受的袭击，这样我们就不需要每晚守夜或是看火了。另外，朋友们，我们必须预见任何可能发生的事情。我们所在的地方正是太平洋上马来海盗经常出没的地方。”
en: “That is probable,” replied the engineer, “although we have not yet explored the interior; but if no human beings are found, I fear that dangerous animals may abound.It is necessary to guard against a possible attack, so that we shall not be obliged to watch every night, or to keep up a fire.And then, my friends, we must foresee everything.We are here in a part of the Pacific often frequented by Malay pirates—”

zh: “什么？”赫伯特说，“来到离陆地这么远的地方？”
en: “What!” said Herbert, “at such a distance from land?”

zh: “是的，孩子，”工程师回答道,“这些海盗是勇敢的水手，同时也是可怕的敌人，我们必须采取相应的措施。”
en: “Yes, my boy,” replied the engineer.“These pirates are bold sailors as well as formidable enemies, and we must take measures accordingly.”

zh: “好，”潘克洛夫回答道，“不管是两条腿的野人还是四条腿的野兽，我们都加强防备。可是，上尉，等我们把海岛彻底勘察一遍再行动不是最好吗？”
en: “Well,” replied Pencroft, “we will fortify ourselves against savages with two legs as well as against savages with four.But, captain, will it not be best to explore every part of the island before undertaking anything else?”

zh: “那样最好。”吉丁·史佩莱补充道。
en: “That would be best,” added Gideon Spilett.

zh: “我们已经在这里找洞穴，却无果而终，真不知道对面能不能找到一个洞穴。”
en: “Who knows if we might not find on the opposite side one of the caverns which we have searched for in vain here?”

zh: “对，”工程师答道，“但是朋友们，你们忘了，我们有必要在河道周围选址，从富兰克林山顶往西看，既没有小溪也没有河流。相反地，我们现在的住处位于慈恩河与格兰特河之间，这个优越性是不容忽略的。另外，这儿面向东方，不像另一面正迎着从这个半球西北方吹来的信风。
en: “That is true,” replied the engineer, “but you forget, my friends, that it will be necessary to establish ourselves in the neighborhood of a watercourse, and that, from the summit of Mount Franklin, we could not see towards the west, either stream or river.Here, on the contrary, we are placed between the Mercy and Lake Grant, an advantage which must not be neglected.And, besides, this side, looking towards the east, is not exposed as the other is to the trade-winds, which in this hemisphere blow from the northwest.”

zh: “那么，上尉，”水手答道，“让我们在湖边上建一座房子吧。现在砖头和工具都不缺。我们已经做过烧砖工、陶工、冶炼工和铁匠了，我们一定知道怎么做泥瓦匠！”
en: “Then, captain,” replied the sailor, “let us build a house on the edge of the lake.Neither bricks nor tools are wanting now.After having been brickmakers, potters, smelters, and smiths, we shall surely know how to be masons!”

zh: “是的，朋友，但是在做任何决定之前，我们必须全面考虑这个问题。一个天然的住处能省掉我们很多人力，还会是更可靠的退路，因为它不但能防备岛内敌人的袭击，也能抵御外来敌人。
en: “Yes, my friend; but before coming to any decision we must consider the matter thoroughly.A natural dwelling would spare us much work, and would be a surer retreat, for it would be as well defended against enemies from the interior as those from outside.”

zh: “对，赛勒斯，”记者回应道，“可是整个花岗石壁我们都检查过了，连一个窟窿、一条裂缝都没有！”
en: “That is true, Cyrus,” replied the reporter, “but we have already examined all that mass of granite, and there is not a hole, not a cranny!”

zh: “没有，一个也没有！”潘克洛夫补充道，“如果我们能在峭壁上选择适当的高度，掘一个住处，远离危险，那就再好不过了！住处面朝大海，有五六间房。”
en: “No, not one!” added Pencroft.“Ah, if we were able to dig out a dwelling in that cliff, at a good height, so as to be out of the reach of harm, that would be capital!I can see that on the front which looks seaward, five or six rooms—”

zh: “还有窗子透光！”赫伯特笑着说。
en: “With windows to light them!” said Herbert, laughing.

zh: “还有梯子可以爬上去！”纳布补充道。
en: “And a staircase to climb up to them!” added Neb.

zh: “你在笑，”水手大声说，“为什么？难道我的提议就办不到吗？我们不是已经有鹤嘴锄和铲子吗？哈丁上尉不是会制造火药来炸矿吗？哈丁上尉，只要我们需要火药，你就会做出来，不是吗？”
en: “You are laughing,” cried the sailor, “and why?What is there impossible in what I propose?Haven’t we got pickaxes and spades?Won’t Captain Harding be able to make powder to blow up the mine?Isn’t it true, captain, that you will make powder the very day we want it?”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁听着激情四溢的潘克洛夫讲他的奇思妙想。这么一大块花岗岩壁，即使用地雷都是巨大的工程。大自然无法在他们需要的时候提供帮助，这真令人烦恼。工程师没有回答水手的问题，而是建议更细致地检查从河口到北面峭壁尽头的拐角处一带。
en: Cyrus Harding listened to the enthusiastic Pencroft developing his fanciful projects.To attack this mass of granite, even by a mine, was Herculean work, and it was really vexing that nature could not help them at their need.But the engineer did not reply to the sailor except by proposing to examine the cliff more attentively, from the mouth of the river to the angle which terminated it on the north.

zh: 于是大家都出发了，在将近两英里的范围内作了一次极为细致的检查。但是在光秃秃、直立的峭壁上，找不到任何洞穴。野鸽在山顶上拍动着双翼，它们的巢实际上就是在峰顶上、参差不齐的花岗岩壁边缘挖的孔。
en: They went out, therefore, and the exploration was made with extreme care, over an extent of nearly two miles.But in no place in the bare, straight cliff, could any cavity be found.The nests of the rock pigeons which fluttered at its summit were only, in reality, holes bored at the very top, and on the irregular edge of the granite.

zh: 这种情况令人气恼，不管用鹤嘴锄还是炸药，打算在这个峭壁上开凿出一个够大的山洞来，都是妄想。目前的情况是，在这一带的海岸上，潘克洛夫发现了唯一的居所，也就是“石窟”，他们此时必须丢弃。
en: It was a provoking circumstance, and as to attacking this cliff, either with pickaxe or with powder, so as to effect a sufficient excavation, it was not to be thought of.It so happened that, on all this part of the shore, Pencroft had discovered the only habitable shelter, that is to say, the Chimneys, which now had to be abandoned.

zh: 勘探工作结束了，拓荒者发现自己处在峭壁的北角，这里是峭壁的终点，一个长长的斜坡一直延伸到海岸。从这里直到西边的尽头，只形成了一种斜坡，由厚厚的大团石头、泥土、沙子构成，植物、灌木和草将它们连在一起，斜坡的倾斜度只有45度。斜坡上的树木是一簇一簇的，坡上覆盖着厚厚的绿草。可是过去不远，就没有植被了，而是一片长长的沙质平原，从这些斜坡脚下一直延伸到海滩。
en: The exploration ended, the colonists found themselves at the north angle of the cliff, where it terminated in long slopes which died away on the shore.From this place, to its extreme limit in the west, it only formed a sort of declivity, a thick mass of stones, earth, and sand, bound together by plants, bushes, and grass inclined at an angle of only forty-five degrees.Clumps of trees grew on these slopes, which were also carpeted with thick grass.But the vegetation did not extend far, and a long, sandy plain, which began at the foot of these slopes, reached to the beach.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁的想法不是没有道理，他觉得溢出的湖水一定会淹没这一边。红河流过来的多余的水也必须通过一些渠道流出去。现在，工程师还没有在勘察过的海岸上发现任何水道，也就是说，从眺望岗以西的河口起还没有排水道。
en: Cyrus Harding thought, not without reason, that the overplus of the lake must overflow on this side.The excess of water furnished by the Red Creek must also escape by some channel or other.Now the engineer had not yet found this channel on any part of the shore already explored, that is to say, from the mouth of the stream on the west of Prospect Heights.

zh: 工程师现在建议同伴们爬上斜坡，通过眺望岗回到“石窟”，顺便可以勘探湖的北部和东部河岸。大家都同意这个提议，几分钟时间里，赫伯特和纳布已经爬到了上面的高地。赛勒斯·哈丁、吉丁·史佩莱和潘克洛夫迈着更加稳重的脚步跟了上去。
en: The engineer now proposed to his companions to climb the slope, and to return to the Chimneys by the heights, while exploring the northern and eastern shores of the lake.The proposal was accepted, and in a few minutes Herbert and Neb were on the upper plateau.Cyrus Harding, Gideon Spilett, and Pencroft followed with more sedate steps.

zh: 在阳光的照射下，湖面闪闪发光，通过树林依稀可见。从这里望去，这片土地非常迷人。他们欣赏着这一片树林，大饱眼福。一些老树干由于年岁久远弯了下来，投下黑色的阴影，与覆盖地面的青翠绿草形成对比。一大群羽毛亮丽的美冠鹦鹉在树枝中尖叫着，像移动的棱镜，从一个大枝跳到另一个。
en: The beautiful sheet of water glittered through the trees under the rays of the sun.In this direction the country was charming.The eye feasted on the groups of trees.Some old trunks, bent with age, showed black against the verdant grass which covered the ground.Crowds of brilliant cockatoos screamed among the branches, moving prisms, hopping from one bough to another.

zh: 居民们没有直接走到湖的北岸，而是沿着高地边缘转了一个圈，以便在左岸到达河口。这段距离大约有一英里半。很容易走过去，因为树木分布广阔，为他们留出了相当大的空隙。显然，肥沃茂盛的地带到这里就终止了，在红河和慈悲河之间的植被不会这么茂盛了。
en: The settlers instead of going directly to the north bank of the lake, made a circuit round the edge of the plateau, so as to join the mouth of the creek on its left bank.It was a detour of more than a mile and a half.Walking was easy, for the trees widely spread, left a considerable space between them.The fertile zone evidently stopped at this point, and vegetation would be less vigorous in the part between the course of the Creek and the Mercy.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和同伴们十分谨慎地在这片新土地上行走。他们的武器只有弓箭和带有锋利铁尖的棍子。然而，没有野兽出没，可能这些野兽只经常在南方茂密的丛林中出没。但是，当他们看见托普站在一条巨蛇面前的时候，还是大吃了一惊，这条大蛇有14到15英尺长。纳布用棍子一下子打死了它。赛勒斯·哈丁检查了这条蛇，告诉大家这不是毒蛇，它是钻石蛇的一种，新南威尔士的当地人饲养这种蛇。但是这里可能存在其他蛇，一咬能致人于死地，比如尾巴呈叉状的蝰蛇，它们从脚底竖起来，还有飞蛇，长着的两只耳朵使它们跑起来极快。托普吃惊过后，就急切地开始追逐起另一只爬行动物来，让大家担心起他的安全来。他的主人马上将他叫了回来。
en: Cyrus Harding and his companions walked over this new ground with great care.Bows, arrows, and sticks with sharp iron points were their only weapons.However, no wild beast showed itself, and it was probable that these animals frequented rather the thick forests in the south; but the settlers had the disagreeable surprise of seeing Top stop before a snake of great size, measuring from fourteen to fifteen feet in length.Neb killed it by a blow from his stick.Cyrus Harding examined the reptile, and declared it not venomous, for it belonged to that species of diamond serpents which the natives of New South Wales rear.But it was possible that others existed whose bite was mortal such as the deaf vipers with forked tails, which rise up under the feet, or those winged snakes, furnished with two ears, which enable them to proceed with great rapidity.Top, the first moment of surprise over, began a reptile chase with such eagerness, that they feared for his safety.His master called him back directly.

zh: 他们很快到达了红河的河口，就是水流入湖中的地方。探险者们发现了对面海岸的一个点，就是他们从富兰克林山上下山时去过的。赛勒斯·哈丁确定，从红河流入湖中的水量是相当大的。因此，大自然一定要给多余的水提供一个流出的地方。这无疑会形成一个瀑布，如果能找到它，一定会十分有用。
en: The mouth of the Red Creek, at the place where it entered into the lake, was soon reached.The explorers recognized on the opposite shore the point which they had visited on their descent from Mount Franklin.Cyrus Harding ascertained that the flow of water into it from the creek was considerable.Nature must therefore have provided some place for the escape of the overplus.This doubtless formed a fall, which, if it could be discovered, would be of great use.

zh: 这些拓荒者走的时候是分开的，但彼此隔得不是很远，他们开始沿着陡峭的湖边行走。水中到处都是鱼，潘克洛夫决定做一些钓鱼竿，来试着抓些鱼。
en: The colonists, walking apart, but not straying far from each other, began to skirt the edge of the lake, which was very steep.The water appeared to be full of fish, and Pencroft resolved to make some fishing-rods, so as to try and catch some.

zh: 他们首先绕过东北角。据推测，湖水可能就是从这里排出去的，因为湖水的最高点几乎和高地的边缘齐平。但是他们还是没有找到排水的迹象，开拓者们继续沿岸搜索，湖岸在稍微弯曲之后，逐渐降下来，与海岸线平行了。
en: The northeast point was first to be doubled.It might have been supposed that the discharge of water was at this place, for the extremity of the lake was almost on a level with the edge of the plateau.But no signs of this were discovered, and the colonists continued to explore the bank, which, after a slight bend, descended parallel to the shore.

zh: 岸这边的森林比较稀疏，只是东一簇西一簇地分布着，为小岛的景致增添了色彩。从这里可以看到格兰特湖的全景，没有任何气息打扰湖面的平静。托普用棍子敲打着灌木丛，惊起了一群群不同种类的鸟，史佩莱和赫伯特用箭瞄准它们。一只鸟被男孩射中了，倒在了沼泽的草地上。托普冲上去，拎回来一只美丽的水鸟，浑身蓝灰色，短喙，前额发达，两只翅膀有白边。这是一只黑鸭，大小和大鹧鸪差不多，属于长趾类水禽，介于涉水鸟类和蹼足类之间。但遗憾的是，这种鸟的味道实在是太不好了。但是托普在这些事情上没有主人们那么挑剔，所以大家决定把“黑鸭”留给它做晚饭。
en: On this side the banks were less woody, but clumps of trees, here and there, added to the picturesqueness of the country.Lake Grant was viewed from thence in all its extent, and no breath disturbed the surface of its waters.Top, in beating the bushes, put up flocks of birds of different kinds, which Gideon Spilett and Herbert saluted with arrows.One was hit by the lad, and fell into some marshy grass.Top rushed forward, and brought a beautiful swimming bird, of a slate color, short beak, very developed frontal plate, and wings edged with white.It was a “coot,” the size of a large partridge, belonging to the group of macrodactyls which form the transition between the order of wading birds and that of palmipeds.Sorry game, in truth, and its flavor is far from pleasant.But Top was not so particular in these things as his masters, and it was agreed that the coot should be for his supper.

zh: 居民们现在正沿着湖的东岸行进，不久就要到他们已经知道的地方了。由于没有看到任何排水道的痕迹，工程师非常惊讶。记者和水手跟他交谈的时候，他再也掩饰不住自己的惊讶心情。
en: The settlers were now following the eastern bank of the lake, and they would not be long in reaching the part which they already knew.The engineer was much surprised at not seeing any indication of the discharge of water.The reporter and the sailor talked with him, and he could not conceal his astonishment.

zh: 这时候，一直很安静的托普发出了惊讶的信号。这个机灵的畜生在海岸边走来走去，突然停住，看着水面，抬起一只爪子，似乎在指着什么看不见的猎物，继而又狂吠起来，马上又安静了。
en: At this moment Top, who had been very quiet till then, gave signs of agitation.The intelligent animal went backwards and forwards on the shore, stopped suddenly, and looked at the water, one paw raised, as if he was pointing at some invisible game; then he barked furiously, and was suddenly silent.

zh: 一开始赛勒斯·哈丁和同伴们都没有注意托普的行为，但是狗的吠声马上变得如此频繁，以至于工程师注意到了。
en: Neither Cyrus Harding nor his companions had at first paid any attention to Top’s behavior; but the dog’s barking soon became so frequent that the engineer noticed it.

zh: “这是哪里，托普？”他问道。
en: “What is there, Top?” he asked.

zh: 托普向主人跳过去，显得非常不安，然后又朝着岸边冲去。然后，它一下子跳进湖中。
en: The dog bounded towards his master, seeming to be very uneasy, and then rushed again towards the bank.Then, all at once, he plunged into the lake.

zh: “回来，托普！”赛勒斯·哈丁喊道，他不希望狗到危险的水中冒险。
en: “Here, Top!” cried Cyrus Harding, who did not like his dog to venture into the treacherous water.

zh: “那里到底发生了什么？”潘克洛夫边问边盯着湖面。
en: “What’s happening down there?” asked Pencroft, examining the surface of the lake.

zh: “托普嗅到了什么两栖动物的气味了。”赫伯特答道。
en: “Top smells some amphibious creature,” replied Herbert.

zh: “可能是一只鳄鱼。”记者说。
en: “An alligator, perhaps,” said the reporter.

zh: “我觉得不是，”哈丁回答，“鳄鱼只生活在纬度较低的地区。”
en: “I do not think so,” replied Harding.“Alligators are only met with in regions less elevated in latitude.”

zh: 与此同时，托普在主人的召唤下回来了，重新上了岸。但是它还是没法安静下来，他又跃进深草丛中，似乎在直觉的指引下追踪着某个隐形的东西，它正在水面下游动。然而，现在的湖面很平静，没有泛起一丝涟漪。居民们几次停在湖边，密切关注着湖面的情况。什么也没有出现。水中隐藏着什么秘密。
en: Meanwhile Top had returned at his master’s call, and had regained the shore: but he could not stay quiet; he plunged in among the tall grass, and guided by instinct, he appeared to follow some invisible being which was slipping along under the surface of the water.However the water was calm; not a ripple disturbed its surface.Several times the settlers stopped on the bank, and observed it attentively.Nothing appeared.There was some mystery there.

zh: 工程师也很迷惑。
en: The engineer was puzzled.

zh: “让我们将勘探进行到底。”他说。
en: “Let us pursue this exploration to the end,” said he.

zh: 半个小时之后，他们到达了湖东南角的眺望岗上。到这里为止，湖岸算是勘察完了，然而工程师还是没有找到湖水是怎样、从哪里外泄的。“这个出口肯定存在，”他重复道，“既然我们看不见，湖水肯定是通过西边的花岗岩岩壁流出去的！”
en: Half an hour after they had all arrived at the southeast angle of the lake, on Prospect Heights.At this point the examination of the banks of the lake was considered finished, and yet the engineer had not been able to discover how and where the waters were discharged.“There is no doubt this overflow exists,” he repeated, “and since it is not visible it must go through the granite cliff at the west!”

zh: “但是亲爱的赛勒斯，知道这些又有什么用呢？”吉丁·史佩莱问道。
en: “But what importance do you attach to knowing that, my dear Cyrus?” asked Gideon Spilett.

zh: “太重要了，”工程师答道，“如果湖水是由崖壁排出的，那就很可能会有山洞。要是我们把山洞里的水排出，那儿就很容易成为适宜居住的地方。”
en: “Considerable importance,” replied the engineer; “for if it flows through the cliff there is probably some cavity, which it would be easy to render habitable after turning away the water.”

zh: “可是上尉，湖水有没有可能从湖底流出？”赫伯特说，“湖水从地下通过流入大海？”
en: “But is it not possible, captain, that the water flows away at the bottom of the lake,” said Herbert, “and that it reaches the sea by some subterranean passage?”

zh: “有这种可能，”工程师回答道，“要真是那样，就是天不助我们，我们只有自己盖房子了。”
en: “That might be,” replied the engineer, “and should it be so we shall be obliged to build our house ourselves, since nature has not done it for us.”

zh: 拓荒者们刚要穿过高地回到“石窟”，就发现托普又开始焦躁起来。它狂吠不止，还没等主人阻止，它又一次跳进湖中。
en: The colonists were about to begin to traverse the plateau to return to the Chimneys, when Top gave new signs of agitation.He barked with fury, and before his master could restrain him, he had plunged a second time into the lake.

zh: 大家都跟着朝岸边奔去。狗已经游出20多英尺远，那里的水看起来并不深，赛勒斯正在喊它时，水里突然冒出一个大脑袋来。
en: All ran towards the bank.The dog was already more than twenty feet off, and Cyrus was calling him back, when an enormous head emerged from the water, which did not appear to be deep in that place.

zh: 赫伯特一眼就看出这是一只两栖动物，长着尖尖的脑袋，大大的眼睛，还有柔软的长胡须。
en: Herbert recognized directly the species of amphibian to which the tapering head, with large eyes, and adorned with long silky mustaches, belonged.

zh: “海牛！”他喊道。
en: “A lamantin!” he cried.

zh: 它并不是海牛，而是鲸类动物的一种，名叫“儒艮”，它的鼻孔长在鼻子的上方。这个庞然大物向托普冲去，托普试图逃回岸边。它的主人没办法救它，在史佩莱和赫伯特弯弓之前，托普就被儒艮抓住，拖到水下。
en: It was not a lamantin, but one of that species of the order of cetaceans, which bear the name of the “dugong,” for its nostrils were open at the upper part of its snout.The enormous animal rushed on the dog, who tried to escape by returning towards the shore.His master could do nothing to save him, and before Gideon Spilett or Herbert thought of bending their bows, Top, seized by the dugong, had disappeared beneath the water.

zh: 纳布手中拿着带铁尖的矛，打算到那危险动物的活动区域去袭击它，帮助托普。
en: Neb, his iron-tipped spear in his hand, wished to go to Top’s help, and attack the dangerous animal in its own element.

zh: “不，纳布。”工程师说，阻止了这位勇敢的仆人。
en: “No, Neb,” said the engineer, restraining his courageous servant.

zh: 在此期间，水下展开了一场搏斗，这简直是一场不可思议的搏斗，以托普现在的处境，它无法抵抗，从水面的水泡判断，这肯定是场可怕的搏斗，一定会以托普的死亡告终！但是突然间，托普从一个泡沫四溅的漩涡中冒了出来。托普被未知的力量抛到空中，离水面有十英尺，然后又落入激荡的湖水中，很快它就游到岸上，没有任何重伤，奇迹般地活了下来。
en: Meanwhile, a struggle was going on beneath the water, an inexplicable struggle, for in his situation Top could not possibly resist; and judging by the bubbling of the surface it must be also a terrible struggle, and could not but terminate in the death of the dog!But suddenly, in the middle of a foaming circle, Top reappeared.Thrown in the air by some unknown power, he rose ten feet above the surface of the lake, fell again into the midst of the agitated waters, and then soon gained the shore, without any severe wounds, miraculously saved.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和同伴们百思不得其解。同样令人惊异的是水下的搏斗似乎还在继续。毫无疑问，儒艮遭到了什么猛兽的进攻，因此才放了托普，进行自卫，但是，搏斗没持续多久。湖水被鲜血染红了，儒艮的尸体从四处扩散的鲜红色的湖水中浮了上来，很快就搁浅在湖南角的小沙滩上。拓荒者们朝它的尸体跑过去。儒艮已经死了。这是一只庞然大物，长达15到16英尺，至少有三千到四千磅重。它的颈上有一个伤口，好像被尖刀割过一样。
en: Cyrus Harding and his companions could not understand it.What was not less inexplicable was that the struggle still appeared to be going on.Doubtless, the dugong, attacked by some powerful animal, after having released the dog, was fighting on its own account.But it did not last long.The water became red with blood, and the body of the dugong, emerging from the sheet of scarlet which spread around, soon stranded on a little beach at the south angle of the lake.The colonists ran towards it.The dugong was dead.It was an enormous animal, fifteen or sixteen feet long, and must have weighed from three to four thousand pounds.At its neck was a wound, which appeared to have been produced by a sharp blade.

zh: 究竟是什么两栖动物进行了这么可怕的攻击，把凶猛的儒艮杀死呢？谁也不知道答案，哈丁和同伴们怀着对此事的极大兴趣，回到“石窟”去了。
en: What could the amphibious creature have been, who, by this terrible blow had destroyed the formidable dugong?No one could tell, and much interested in this incident, Harding and his companions returned to the Chimneys.

zh: 第十七章
en: Chapter 17

zh: 第二天是5月7号，哈丁和吉丁·史佩莱爬上了眺望岗，赫伯特和潘克洛夫则顺河而上，备些新柴火，只留下纳布在洞中准备早饭。
en: The next day, the 7th of May, Harding and Gideon Spilett, leaving Neb to prepare breakfast, climbed Prospect Heights, while Herbert and Pencroft ascended by the river, to renew their store of wood.

zh: 工程师和记者很快就到达了儒艮搁浅的那块小沙滩上。鸟群已经开始啄食这个庞然大物的肉，赛勒斯想把肥肉留给大家备用，不得不用石子将鸟群赶走。这种动物的肉可以做成盛宴，在马来群岛及其他地方，儒艮的肉专门留给当地的王公贵族。不过这是纳布的事。
en: The engineer and the reporter soon reached the little beach on which the dugong had been stranded.Already flocks of birds had attacked the mass of flesh, and had to be driven away with stones, for Cyrus wished to keep the fat for the use of the colony.As to the animal’s flesh it would furnish excellent food, for in the islands of the Malay Archipelago and elsewhere, it is especially reserved for the table of the native princes.But that was Neb’s affair.

zh: 这时，赛勒斯·哈丁又产生了新的念头。他对昨天的事有极大兴趣。他打算弄明白那场水下搏斗的秘密，查明究竟是什么动物能在儒艮身上留下这么奇怪的创伤。他站在湖边，仔细观察着，但是平静的湖面下什么也没有，湖面在初升太阳的第一道光照下波光粼粼。
en: At this moment Cyrus Harding had other thoughts.He was much interested in the incident of the day before.He wished to penetrate the mystery of that submarine combat, and to ascertain what monster could have given the dugong so strange a wound.He remained at the edge of the lake, looking, observing; but nothing appeared under the tranquil waters, which sparkled in the first rays of the rising sun.

zh: 在儒艮搁浅的海滩，湖水很浅，但是湖底从这里往下慢慢倾斜，湖中央可能相当深。整个湖就好比一个巨大的中央盆地，由来自红河的水填满。
en: At the beach, on which lay the body of the dugong, the water was tolerably shallow, but from this point the bottom of the lake sloped gradually, and it was probable that the depth was considerable in the center.The lake might be considered as a large center basin, which was filled by the water from the Red Creek.

zh: “好了，赛勒斯，”记者说，“水底好像没有什么可疑的东西。”
en: “Well, Cyrus,” said the reporter, “there seems to be nothing suspicious in this water.”

zh: “是的，我亲爱的史佩莱，”工程师回答道，“我的确不知道怎样解释昨天发生的事。”
en: “No, my dear Spilett,” replied the engineer, “and I really do not know how to account for the incident of yesterday.”

zh: “我承认，”史佩莱回答道，“儒艮受的伤至少是很奇怪，我也无法解释托普是怎么从水中被猛地抛起来的。就像有一个人，用一只强有力的胳膊将他抛起，另一只胳膊拿着匕首将儒艮杀死！”
en: “I acknowledge,” returned Spilett, “that the wound given this creature is, at least, very strange, and I cannot explain either how Top was so vigorously cast up out of the water.One could have thought that a powerful arm hurled him up, and that the same arm with a dagger killed the dugong!”

zh: “是的，”工程师沉思着回答道，“这事我有些地方不能理解。还有，亲爱的史佩莱，你能理解我是用什么方式自救的吗？我是怎么从海浪中被拖出来，又怎么被带到沙丘上的？不知道！难道这不是真的吗？现在我可以肯定，这里面一定有什么秘密，我相信，有一天我们会揭开这些秘密。我们不妨细心观察，但不必在同伴面前细谈这些奇特的事。我们先将这些话压在心头，继续我们的工作。
en: “Yes,” replied the engineer, who had become thoughtful; “there is something there that I cannot understand.But do you better understand either, my dear Spilett, in what way I was saved myself—how I was drawn from the waves, and carried to the downs?No!Is it not true?Now, I feel sure that there is some mystery there, which, doubtless, we shall discover some day.Let us observe, but do not dwell on these singular incidents before our companions.Let us keep our remarks to ourselves, and continue our work.”

zh: 大家现在还记得，工程师还没有发现多余的湖水在哪里排出，但是他知道这个地方一定存在。当在这里看见一股急流时，工程师相当惊讶。他将一些木头块扔进水流中，发现它向南边的角流去。他跟着那股急流，来到了湖的南面。
en: It will be remembered that the engineer had not as yet been able to discover the place where the surplus water escaped, but he knew it must exist somewhere.He was much surprised to see a strong current at this place.By throwing in some bits of wood he found that it set towards the southern angle.He followed the current, and arrived at the south point of the lake.

zh: 水中有一块洼地，好像水一下子漏进地缝里了似的。
en: There was there a sort of depression in the water, as if it was suddenly lost in some fissure in the ground.

zh: 哈丁将耳朵贴在与湖面平行的地面上，倾听着，他能清楚地听到水下瀑布的声响。
en: Harding listened; placing his ear to the level of the lake, he very distinctly heard the noise of a subterranean fall.

zh: “那里，”他边起身边说道，“那里就是排水的地方，湖水肯定是通过花岗岩壁里的通道和石洞汇入大海，我们可以利用这些石洞。看着吧，我一定能找到它！”
en: “There,” said he, rising, “is the discharge of the water; there, doubtless, by a passage in the granite cliff, it joins the sea, through cavities which we can use to our profit.Well, I can find it!”

zh: 工程师砍了一根很长的树枝，将叶子都剥了，将树枝插入两岸间的拐角处，他发现水下一英尺深处有一个大洞。这个洞就是他们一直寻找未果的排水口，这股急流的力量很大，工程师手中的树枝都被水流折断并消失了。
en: The engineer cut a long branch, stripped it of its leaves, and plunging it into the angle between the two banks, he found that there was a large hole one foot only beneath the surface of the water.This hole was the opening so long looked for in vain, and the force of the current was such that the branch was torn from the engineer’s hands and disappeared.

zh: “肯定就是这样了，”哈丁重复道，“这里就是湖水的出口，我要让它显现出来！”
en: “There is no doubt about it now,” repeated Harding.“There is the outlet, and I will lay it open to view!”

zh: “怎么做呢？”史佩莱问道。
en: “How?” asked Gideon Spilett.

zh: “将湖面降低三英尺。”“你怎么降低湖面呢？”
en: “By lowering the level of the water of the lake three feet.”“And how will you lower the level?”

zh: “开一个比这个更大的出口。”
en: “By opening another outlet larger than this.”

zh: “在哪里开，赛勒斯？”
en: “At what place, Cyrus?”

zh: “在最靠近岸边的地方。”
en: “At the part of the bank nearest the coast.”

zh: “但是那是一大块花岗岩呀！”史佩莱说。
en: “But it is a mass of granite!” observed Spilett.

zh: “嗯，”赛勒斯·哈丁答道，“我要炸开这片花岗岩，溢出的湖水会使水位下降，从而露出洞口来——”
en: “Well,” replied Cyrus Harding, “I will blow up the granite, and the water escaping, will subside, so as to lay bare this opening—”

zh: “我们可以炸开一个瀑布，将水倾泻在沙滩上。”记者补充道。
en: “And make a waterfall, by falling on to the beach,” added the reporter.

zh: “那我们就可以利用那个瀑布啦！”赛勒斯回答道，“来吧，来吧！”
en: “A fall that we shall make use of!” replied Cyrus.“Come, come!”

zh: 工程师催促同伴赶紧离开，记者对工程师颇有信心，他对这项工程的成功毫不怀疑。但是没有火药，也没有精制的工具，怎样才能炸开花岗岩石壁呢？工程师如此热衷的工程难道不是超出他们的能力范围吗？
en: The engineer hurried away his companion, whose confidence in Harding was such that he did not doubt the enterprise would succeed.And yet, how was this granite wall to be opened without powder, and with imperfect instruments?Was not this work upon which the engineer was so bent above their strength?

zh: 当哈丁和记者回到“石窟”中时，他们发现赫伯特和潘克洛夫正在卸木筏上的木头。
en: When Harding and the reporter entered the Chimneys, they found Herbert and Pencroft unloading their raft of wood.

zh: “樵夫的工作已经完成了，上尉，”水手边说边笑，“什么时候你需要泥瓦匠？”
en: “The woodmen have just finished, captain.” said the sailor, laughing, “and when you want masons—”

zh: “泥瓦匠倒不用，我要的是化学家。”工程师回答道。
en: “Masons,—no, but chemists,” replied the engineer.

zh: “是的，”记者补充道，“我们打算炸海岛。”
en: “Yes,” added the reporter, “we are going to blow up the island—”

zh: “炸海岛？”潘克洛夫喊道。
en: “Blow up the island?” cried Pencroft.

zh: “至少是炸一部分。”史佩莱答道。
en: “Part of it, at least,” replied Spilett.

zh: “听我说，朋友们。”工程师说道。他将自己的观察结果告诉了大家。
en: “Listen to me, my friends,” said the engineer.And he made known to them the result of his observations.

zh: 据他描述，在花岗岩壁中肯定有一个不小的石洞，它支撑着眺望岗，他打算进入洞中。要想成功，必须首先炸开排水的通道，开出一个更大口，从而使湖面水位降低。所以，必须制造炸药，在岸的其他地方炸出一个深沟。这便是哈丁打算用大自然给他的矿石要做的事情。
en: According to him, a cavity, more or less considerable, must exist in the mass of granite which supported Prospect Heights, and he intended to penetrate into it.To do this, the opening through which the water rushed must first be cleared, and the level lowered by making a larger outlet.Therefore an explosive substance must be manufactured, which would make a deep trench in some other part of the shore.This was what Harding was going to attempt with the minerals which nature placed at his disposal.

zh: 不用说，大家都热情高涨地同意了这个计划，尤其是潘克洛夫。炸开花岗岩壁、制造人工瀑布这样的大手笔都很合乎水手的胃口。他会像当泥瓦匠或制靴匠那样，立马成为化学家，因为工程师需要化学制品。只要他们需要，他什么都会做，“甚至是舞蹈家和礼仪教授”，他对纳布说道，如果那也是需要的。
en: It is useless to say with what enthusiasm all, especially Pencroft, received this project.To employ great means, open the granite, create a cascade, that suited the sailor.And he would just as soon be a chemist as a mason or bootmaker, since the engineer wanted chemicals.He would be all that they liked, “even a professor of dancing and deportment,” said he to Neb, if that was ever necessary.

zh: 纳布和潘克洛夫首先被委任负责提取儒艮身上的油脂，将肉保存，留作食用。他们对工程师深信不疑，连问题都没问就马上开始工作。几分钟以后，赛勒斯·哈丁、赫伯特及史佩莱也拖着筐子往煤层方向去了，那里有丰富的硫化铁矿石，是他们在最近的过渡土层中找到的，哈丁已经在那里找到一块标本。他们一整天都在忙着将这些矿石运到“石窟”，到了晚上，他们已经有好几吨矿石了。
en: Neb and Pencroft were first of all told to extract the grease from the dugong, and to keep the flesh, which was destined for food.Such perfect confidence had they in the engineer, that they set out directly, without even asking a question.A few minutes after them, Cyrus Harding, Herbert, and Gideon Spilett, dragging the hurdle, went towards the vein of coals, where those shistose pyrites abound which are met with in the most recent transition soil, and of which Harding had already found a specimen.All the day being employed in carrying a quantity of these stones to the Chimneys, by evening they had several tons.

zh: 第二天，也就是5月8号，工程师开始部署他的计划。这些硫化铁矿石的主要成分是煤、燧石、氧化铝以及硫化铁，其中硫化铁含量非常高，必须尽快将硫化铁分离出来，将其转化为硫酸盐。只要取得硫酸盐，就可以提取硫酸了。
en: The next day, the 8th of May, the engineer began his manipulations.These shistose pyrites being composed principally of coal, flint, alumina, and sulphuret of iron—the latter in excess—it was necessary to separate the sulphuret of iron, and transform it into sulphate as rapidly as possible.The sulphate obtained, the sulphuric acid could then be extracted.

zh: 硫酸就是他们想要获取的物质。硫酸是制造炸药最常用的物质，一个国家的制造业实力可以通过测量消费品的硫酸用量来衡量。这种酸后来对他们的用处非常大，可以用来制造蜡烛、鞣皮革等，但是这次工程师要将它留作他用。
en: This was the object to be attained.Sulphuric acid is one of the agents the most frequently employed, and the manufacturing importance of a nation can be measured by the consumption which is made of it.This acid would later be of great use to the settlers, in the manufacturing of candles, tanning skins, etc., but this time the engineer reserved it for another use.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁在“石窟”的后面选了一块非常平坦的地方。他先在地面上铺了一层树枝和削好的木柴，在上面堆了一些黄铁矿石，让一个个矿石支撑着彼此，又在上面覆盖了一层薄薄的铁矿石，这些矿石已经被提前削到果仁大小。
en: Cyrus Harding chose, behind the Chimneys, a site where the ground was perfectly level.On this ground he placed a layer of branches and chopped wood, on which were piled some pieces of shistose pyrites, buttressed one against the other, the whole being covered with a thin layer of pyrites, previously reduced to the size of a nut.

zh: 这样摆好了之后，他们就将木头点着，热量很快传到片麻岩上，片麻岩因为含有煤和硫磺，很快就燃烧起来。然后他们又添了几层碎矿石，堆成一大堆，在外面盖上土和草，中间还留有一些通气的孔，好像在把一堆木柴碳化，做成木炭似的。
en: This done, they set fire to the wood, the heat was communicated to the shist, which soon kindled, since it contains coal and sulphur.Then new layers of bruised pyrites were arranged so as to form an immense heap, the exterior of which was covered with earth and grass, several air-holes being left, as if it was a stack of wood which was to be carbonized to make charcoal.

zh: 然后他们就让转化过程自然完成，让硫化铁变成硫酸铁，铝变成硫酸铝，这过程至少需要十到十二天，硫酸铁和硫酸铝都能在水中溶解，可是其他的如燧石、焦炭和煤渣是不溶于水的。
en: They then left the transformation to complete itself, and it would not take less than ten or twelve days for the sulphuret of iron to be changed to sulphate of iron and the alumina into sulphate of alumina, two equally soluble substances, the others, flint, burnt coal, and cinders, not being so.

zh: 在进行这项化学工作的时候，赛勒斯·哈丁继续干着别的活，他们不只是带着热情工作，还有渴望。
en: While this chemical work was going on, Cyrus Harding proceeded with other operations, which were pursued with more than zeal,—it was eagerness.

zh: 纳布和潘克洛夫已经将儒艮身上的油脂取下来，装在大陶罐里了。现在需要用皂化的方法把甘油从脂肪中分离出来。要完成这项任务，需要加入小苏打或石灰。事实上，用其中任何一种或其他类似物质分解油脂，都会在形成肥皂的同时将甘油分离出来，甘油正是工程师想要的。他们不需要石灰，用石灰只能做出钙质的肥皂，不能在水中溶解，所以是没有用的。然而用小苏打就能制作出可溶解的肥皂，可供日常使用。现在，像赛勒斯·哈丁这样讲求实际的人，宁愿试着获取苏打。弄到苏打很难吗？不难，因为岸边水生植物很多，有海篷子、番杏和各种漂上岸来的鹿角菜科。他们收集了大量的植物，先将它们晾干，然后就在露天的坑洞中焚烧。一连烧了好几天，最后得到一小堆灰色的粉末，很久以来，人们都把这种物质叫做“天然苏打”。
en: Neb and Pencroft had taken away the fat from the dugong, and placed it in large earthen pots.It was then necessary to separate the glycerine from the fat by saponifying it.Now, to obtain this result, it had to be treated either with soda or lime.In fact, one or other of these substances, after having attacked the fat, would form a soap by separating the glycerine, and it was just this glycerine which the engineer wished to obtain.There was no want of lime, only treatment by lime would give calcareous soap, insoluble, and consequently useless, while treatment by soda would furnish, on the contrary, a soluble soap, which could be put to domestic use.Now, a practical man, like Cyrus Harding, would rather try to obtain soda.Was this difficult?No; for marine plants abounded on the shore, glass-wort, ficoides, and all those fucaceae which form wrack.A large quantity of these plants was collected, first dried, then burnt in holes in the open air.The combustion of these plants was kept up for several days, and the result was a compact gray mass, which has been long known under the name of “natural soda.”

zh: 有了小苏打，工程师就将其用来和脂肪化合，得到了可以溶解的肥皂和中性物质——甘油。
en: This obtained, the engineer treated the fat with soda, which gave both a soluble soap and that neutral substance, glycerine.

zh: 但是这还没有结束。为了以后着想，赛勒斯·哈丁还需要另一种物质——硝酸钾，通常叫做硝盐，或是硝石。
en: But this was not all.Cyrus Harding still needed, in view of his future preparation, another substance, nitrate of potash, which is better known under the name of salt niter, or of saltpeter.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁可以用碳酸钾来得到这种物质，通过硝酸从蔬菜渣中获取碳酸钾是很容易的。而他们手上并没有碳酸钾，如果不是大自然有幸向他们提供硝酸，而他们只用动手捡起来，那么，他可能就有一些困难了。赫伯特在富兰克林山麓发现了一个硝酸盐脉，他们只要把这种盐提纯就可以了。
en: Cyrus Harding could have manufactured this substance by treating the carbonate of potash, which would be easily extracted from the cinders of the vegetables, by azotic acid.But this acid was wanting, and he would have been in some difficulty, if nature had not happily furnished the saltpeter, without giving them any other trouble than that of picking it up.Herbert found a vein of it at the foot of Mount Franklin, and they had nothing to do but purify this salt.

zh: 这些工作持续了一个星期。在硫化铁转化成硫酸铁以前，这些工作就完成了。在接下来的几天，居民们抓紧时间砌了一个特别设置的砖炉，用来提纯将要得到的硫酸铁。到了5月18日左右，在化学转化过程快要终止的时候，所有的这些工作都完成了。几天来，吉丁·史佩莱、赫伯特、纳布和潘克洛夫在工程师的巧妙指导下，成了非常聪明的工人。在大师面前，人们最愿意听从能供己所需和最善于指导的人。
en: These different works lasted a week.They were finished before the transformation of the sulphuret into sulphate of iron had been accomplished.During the following days the settlers had time to construct a furnace of bricks of a particular arrangement, to serve for the distillation of the sulphate or iron when it had been obtained.All this was finished about the 18th of May, nearly at the time when the chemical transformation terminated.Gideon Spilett, Herbert, Neb, and Pencroft, skillfully directed by the engineer, had become most clever workmen.Before all masters, necessity is the one most listened to, and who teaches the best.

zh: 在大堆的黄铁矿经过完全加热之后，他们把得到的硫酸铁、硫酸铝、燧石、煤渣和灰烬全放在一只盛水的盆子里。他们搅拌这些混合物，等固体沉淀下来，就把水倒出，得到一种含有硫酸铁和硫酸铝的纯净溶液，其他物质保持着固体的状态，因为它们是不能溶解的。最后，蒸发了一部分液体，硫酸铁结晶沉淀下来，没有蒸发的液体中含有硫酸铝，被扔掉了。
en: When the heap of pyrites had been entirely reduced by fire, the result of the operation, consisting of sulphate of iron, sulphate of alumina, flint, remains of coal, and cinders was placed in a basinful of water.They stirred this mixture, let it settle, then decanted it, and obtained a clear liquid containing in solution sulphate of iron and sulphate of alumina, the other matters remaining solid, since they are insoluble.Lastly, this liquid being partly evaporated, crystals of sulphate of iron were deposited, and the not evaporated liquid, which contained the sulphate of alumina, was thrown away.

zh: 现在赛勒斯·哈丁手上有很多硫酸铁晶体，必须从中提取硫酸。制造硫酸需要很大成本。需要做方方面面的准备——一套专门的工具、铂金的仪器、不受酸腐蚀的铅室，其中铅室是化学转化的容器。这些东西工程师手中都没有，但是他知道波希米亚有一套简单易行的硫酸制造法，这种方法的另一个优点就是生产的硫酸浓度很高。北豪森酸就是用这种方法制成的。
en: Cyrus Harding had now at his disposal a large quantity of these sulphate of iron crystals, from which the sulphuric acid had to be extracted.The making of sulphuric acid is a very expensive manufacture.Considerable works are necessary—a special set of tools, an apparatus of platina, leaden chambers, unassailable by the acid, and in which the transformation is performed, etc.The engineer had none of these at his disposal, but he knew that, in Bohemia especially, sulphuric acid is manufactured by very simple means, which have also the advantage of producing it to a superior degree of concentration.It is thus that the acid known under the name of Nordhausen acid is made.

zh: 赛勒斯现在只剩下最后一道工序就可以得到硫酸了，就是在一个封闭的瓶子中煅烧硫酸铁结晶，然后硫酸就以蒸气的形式蒸馏出来，蒸气经过液化就可以成为硫酸了。
en: To obtain sulphuric acid, Cyrus Harding had only one operation to make, to calcine the sulphate of iron crystals in a closed vase, so that the sulphuric acid should distil in vapor, which vapor, by condensation, would produce the acid.

zh: 他们把结晶放在锅里，点着炉火，结晶就蒸馏成硫酸了。这项工程顺利地完成了，在5月20号，也就是开始工程的12天后，工程师已经制得了需要的硫酸，他希望能将其用在各种地方。
en: The crystals were placed in pots, and the heat from the furnace would distil the sulphuric acid.The operation was successfully completed, and on the 20th of May, twelve days after commencing it, the engineer was the possessor of the agent which later he hoped to use in so many different ways.

zh: 可是，他为什么想得到硫酸呢？如果只是制作硝酸，那就很简单了，因为硝石与硫酸化合之后，通过蒸馏的方法就可以获取硝酸。
en: Now, why did he wish for this agent?Simply to produce azotic acid; and that was easy, since saltpeter, attacked by sulphuric acid, gives azotic, or nitric, acid by distillation.

zh: 可是，他究竟想怎么利用硝酸呢？他的同伴们都还不清楚，因为他还没告诉他们工作成果的用途。
en: But, after all, how was he going to employ this azotic acid?His companions were still ignorant of this, for he had not informed them of the result at which he aimed.

zh: 然而，工程师的目的已经几乎达成了，再经过一道工序，他就可以取得自己费了好大力气想要得到的东西。
en: However, the engineer had nearly accomplished his purpose, and by a last operation he would procure the substance which had given so much trouble.

zh: 他拿出一些硝酸，将事先经蒸发提纯的甘油在蒸锅中混合起来，在冷却剂都没用的情况下，就得到了好几品脱的黄色混合油液。
en: Taking some azotic acid, he mixed it with glycerine, which had been previously concentrated by evaporation, subjected to the water-bath, and he obtained, without even employing a refrigerant mixture, several pints of an oily yellow mixture.

zh: 最后一道工序是赛勒斯·哈丁单独完成的，他找了个远离“石窟”的僻静之地，怕发生爆炸的危险，当他将那一小瓶油液给朋友们看时，不无得意地说道：
en: This last operation Cyrus Harding had made alone, in a retired place, at a distance from the Chimneys, for he feared the danger of an explosion, and when he showed a bottle of this liquid to his friends, he contented himself with saying,—

zh: “这就是硝化甘油！”
en: “Here is nitro-glycerine!”

zh: 就是这种可怕的产物，它的爆炸威力是普通炸药的十倍，已经引发了许多事故。但是，找到将它转化为炸药的方法后，也就是说与固体物质混在一起，如有足够渗透力来支撑它的粘土和糖，原本危险的液体就可以相对安全地使用了。但是，林肯岛的居民工作的时候，这种方法还不为人知。
en: It was really this terrible production, of which the explosive power is perhaps tenfold that of ordinary powder, and which has already caused so many accidents.However, since a way has been found to transform it into dynamite, that is to say, to mix with it some solid substance, clay or sugar, porous enough to hold it, the dangerous liquid has been used with some security.But dynamite was not yet known at the time when the settlers worked on Lincoln Island.

zh: “我们就用这种液体来炸岩石吗？”潘克洛夫怀疑地问道。
en: “And is it that liquid that is going to blow up our rocks?” said Pencroft incredulously.

zh: “对，我的朋友，”工程师回答道，“花岗岩石异常坚硬，会对爆破产生很大阻力，用这种硝化甘油可以取得理想的效果。”
en: “Yes, my friend,” replied the engineer, “and this nitro-glycerine will produce so much the more effect, as the granite is extremely hard, and will oppose a greater resistance to the explosion.”

zh: “我们什么时候能见识见识，上尉？”
en: “And when shall we see this, captain?”

zh: “就明天，等挖好埋炸药的坑就行了。”工程师回答道。
en: “To-morrow, as soon as we have dug a hole for the mine, replied the engineer.”

zh: 第二天，也就是5月21号，黎明时分，矿工们就出发到格兰特湖的东岸去了，这里距离海岸只有500英尺。在这里，湖水被坚硬的花岗岩石壁挡住了去路，高地开始顺着水体向下倾斜。因此，如果炸掉那道石壁，湖水就可以通过缺口流出去，形成一条小河，沿着倾斜的高地面向海滩冲去。因此，湖面就会大大降低，湖水流出的通道就会显露出来，这就是他们的最终目标。
en: The next day, the 21st of May, at daybreak, the miners went to the point which formed the eastern shore of Lake Grant, and was only five hundred feet from the coast.At this place, the plateau inclined downwards from the waters, which were only restrained by their granite case.Therefore, if this case was broken, the water would escape by the opening and form a stream, which, flowing over the inclined surface of the plateau, would rush on to the beach.Consequently, the level of the lake would be greatly lowered, and the opening where the water escaped would be exposed, which was their final aim.

zh: 在工程师的指挥下，潘克洛夫舞动镐头，娴熟有力地凿着花岗岩石壁。坑是挖在岸边的斜坡上，因此要比湖面低得多。这样岩石在爆炸的威力下飞散后，就有一个大的缺口供水流向外冲出了。
en: Under the engineer’s directions, Pencroft, armed with a pickaxe, which he handled skillfully and vigorously, attacked the granite.The hole was made on the point of the shore, slanting, so that it should meet a much lower level than that of the water of the lake.In this way the explosive force, by scattering the rock, would open a large place for the water to rush out.

zh: 这项工程花费了一些时间，工程师为了取得更好的爆破效果，决定至少使用七夸脱的硝化甘油。潘克洛夫和纳布轮班上阵，工程进展得很顺利，到了下午四点，炸药已经埋好了。
en: The work took some time, for the engineer, wishing to produce a great effect, intended to devote not less than seven quarts of nitro-glycerine to the operation.But Pencroft, relieved by Neb, did so well, that towards four o’clock in the evening, the mine was finished.

zh: 现在又产生了一个问题，就是怎样点着炸药。通常来说，都是先点燃雷酸盐的雷管，燃烧起来的硝化甘油就会引爆。因此，必须有一股冲力来引起爆炸，因为只是点着的话，这种物质只能燃烧，不能产生爆炸。
en: Now the question of setting fire to the explosive substance was raised.Generally, nitro-glycerine is ignited by caps of fulminate, which in bursting cause the explosion.A shock is therefore needed to produce the explosion, for, simply lighted, this substance would burn without exploding.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁一定制造了冲击雷管。在缺乏雷酸盐的情况下，他可以轻易地得到类似于棉火药的物质，因为他手中已经有硝酸了。只要把这种物质压在弹药筒中，再加上硝化甘油，就可以起到导火索的作用，引起爆炸。
en: Cyrus Harding could certainly have fabricated a percussion cap.In default of fulminate, he could easily obtain a substance similar to guncotton, since he had azotic acid at his disposal.This substance, pressed in a cartridge, and introduced among the nitro-glycerine, would burst by means of a fuse, and cause the explosion.

zh: 赛勒斯知道硝化甘油在撞击之下会产生爆炸。他决定采用这样方法，如果不成功再另找出路。
en: But Cyrus Harding knew that nitro-glycerine would explode by a shock.He resolved to employ this means, and try another way, if this did not succeed.

zh: 事实上，只要将少量的硝化甘油滴在坚硬的岩石上，再用锤子用力一击，就可以引发爆炸了。但是，敲锤的站在那里，不可能不成为爆炸的受害人。于是，哈丁想用一根纤维绳子将一块几磅重的铁块垂直吊在炸药坑洞的上面。另外一根纤维长绳，事先在硫磺中浸泡过，系在第一根绳子的中央，另一端放在离炸药几英尺以外的地面上。先把第二根绳子点着，一直等火烧到第一根绳子。当第一根绳子被烧断后，大铁块就会砸到硝化甘油上。安排妥当之后，工程师就让同伴们走到远处，他在坑中灌满了硝化甘油，一直到与坑口齐平。然后他又在岩石表面洒了几滴，这时候岩石上面的铁块已经悬好了。
en: In fact, the blow of a hammer on a few drops of nitro-glycerine, spread out on a hard surface, was enough to create an explosion.But the operator could not be there to give the blow, without becoming a victim to the operation.Harding, therefore, thought of suspending a mass of iron, weighing several pounds, by means of a fiber, to an upright just above the mine.Another long fiber, previously impregnated with sulphur, was attached to the middle of the first, by one end, while the other lay on the ground several feet distant from the mine.The second fiber being set on fire, it would burn till it reached the first.This catching fire in its turn, would break, and the mass of iron would fall on the nitro-glycerine.This apparatus being then arranged, the engineer, after having sent his companions to a distance, filled the hole, so that the nitro-glycerine was on a level with the opening; then he threw a few drops of it on the surface of the rock, above which the mass of iron was already suspended.

zh: 安放完毕后，哈丁点着了沾有硫磺的绳子，然后离开，与同伴们一起回到“石窟”。
en: This done, Harding lit the end of the sulphured fiber, and leaving the place, he returned with his companions to the Chimneys.

zh: 这根绳子估计要烧25分钟，果然，25钟后，只听见一声惊天动地的爆炸声。好像整个海岛底部都晃动起来。石块射向天空，像火山爆发一样。空气的激烈震荡产生了巨大的力量，“石窟”的岩块都颤动起来。居民们虽然离爆炸坑有两英里多远，也被掀翻在地。
en: The fiber was intended to burn five and twenty minutes, and, in fact, five and twenty minutes afterwards a most tremendous explosion was heard.The island appeared to tremble to its very foundation.Stones were projected in the air as if by the eruption of a volcano.The shock produced by the displacing of the air was such, that the rocks of the Chimneys shook.The settlers, although they were more than two miles from the mine, were thrown on the ground.

zh: 他们站起来，爬上高地，向湖岸跑去，那里肯定已经被炸开。
en: They rose, climbed the plateau, and ran towards the place where the bank of the lake must have been shattered by the explosion.

zh: 他们欢呼雀跃！他们看到花岗岩上的一个大缺口！一股白浪翻滚的急流从距离沙滩300英尺的高地上一泻千里！
en: A cheer escaped them!A large rent was seen in the granite!A rapid stream of water rushed foaming across the plateau and dashed down a height of three hundred feet on to the beach!

zh: 第十八章
en: Chapter 18

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁的计划成功了，但是他还是像往常一样，没有表现出满意之情，紧闭着嘴唇，仔细地看着，一动也不动。赫伯特简直欣喜若狂，纳布高兴得跳了起来，潘克洛夫赞许得点着大脑袋，低语道：
en: Cyrus Harding’s project had succeeded, but, according to his usual habit he showed no satisfaction; with closed lips and a fixed look, he remained motionless.Herbert was in ecstasies, Neb bounded with joy, Pencroft nodded his great head, murmuring these words,—

zh: “来看呀，我们的工程师太棒了！”
en: “Come, our engineer gets on capitally!”

zh: 硝化甘油的确显现了巨大的威力。炸开的口子很大，从开口流出来的水量至少是以前旧出口排水量的三倍。爆炸的结果是，不久后湖面将下降两英尺，甚至更多。
en: The nitro-glycerine had indeed acted powerfully.The opening which it had made was so large that the volume of water which escaped through this new outlet was at least treble that which before passed through the old one.The result was, that a short time after the operation the level of the lake would be lowered two feet, or more.

zh: 居民们回到石窟，拿了几把镐、铁头矛、纤维绳索、燧石和钢块，然后回到高地上，托普也跟着大家。
en: The settlers went to the Chimneys to take some pickaxes, iron-tipped spears, string made of fibers, flint and steel; they then returned to the plateau, Top accompanying them.

zh: 一路上，水手忍不住对工程师说：
en: On the way the sailor could not help saying to the engineer,—

zh: “上尉，用你制作的那种神奇液体，可以把整个小岛都炸飞，你觉得呢？”
en: “Don’t you think, captain, that by means of that charming liquid you have made, one could blow up the whole of our island?”

zh: “无疑，海岛、大陆、全世界都可以，”工程师答道，“只是用量多少的问题。”
en: “Without any doubt, the island, continents, and the world itself,” replied the engineer.“It is only a question of quantity.”

zh: “那么你能用硝化甘油来做弹药火器吗？”水手问道。
en: “Then could you not use this nitro-glycerine for loading firearms?” asked the sailor.

zh: “不，潘克洛夫，它太容易爆炸了。不过用它来制作棉火药，甚至普通火药是不难的，因为我们有硝酸、硝石、硫磺和炭了。可惜我们没有枪。”
en: “No, Pencroft; for it is too explosive a substance.But it would be easy to make some guncotton, or even ordinary powder, as we have azotic acid, saltpeter, sulphur, and coal.Unhappily, it is the guns which we have not got.”

zh: “啊，上尉，”水手应道，“只要有一点决心——”
en: “Oh, captain,” replied the sailor, “with a little determination—”

zh: 潘克洛夫已经把“不可能”从林肯岛的字典上抹去了。
en: Pencroft had erased the word “impossible” from the dictionary of Lincoln Island.

zh: 居民们到达眺望岗上后，就马上向炸开的旧排水口走去。这个出口现在可以通行了，因为水不再从中流出，勘探内部就变得轻而易举了。
en: The settlers, having arrived at Prospect Heights, went immediately towards that point of the lake near which was the old opening now uncovered.This outlet had now become practicable, since the water no longer rushed through it, and it would doubtless be easy to explore the interior.

zh: 几分钟后，他们已经来到湖面相对较低的一边，从这里一眼就可以看出，他们的目的达到了。
en: In a few minutes the settlers had reached the lower point of the lake, and a glance showed them that the object had been attained.

zh: 事实上，湖的这边露出了他们搜寻已久的洞口，现在这个洞已经在水面上了。湖水退去之后，留下一道狭窄的山脊，他们可以走进洞口了。这个洞口有将近20英尺宽，但高度才不到两英尺。它很像人行道边的排水沟口一样，因此居民们没有容易的通道可以走进去，但是纳布和潘克洛夫很快用镐将洞口凿到了合适的高度。
en: In fact, in the side of the lake, and now above the surface of the water, appeared the long-looked-for opening.A narrow ridge, left bare by the retreat of the water, allowed them to approach it.This orifice was nearly twenty feet in width, but scarcely two in height.It was like the mouth of a drain at the edge of the pavement, and therefore did not offer an easy passage to the settlers; but Neb and Pencroft, taking their pickaxes, soon made it of a suitable height.

zh: 然后工程师走上前，他发现开口的这边，至少是洞口上半部分的坡度最多也不过30到35度。因此是可以通行的，假如坡度没有增加，一直降到和海平面一样高的地方都不成问题。如果花岗岩石壁的内部有一些很大的洞穴，那用处可就大了。
en: The engineer then approached, and found that the sides of the opening, in its upper part at least, had not a slope of more than from thirty to thirty-five degrees.It was therefore practicable, and, provided that the declivity did not increase, it would be easy to descend even to the level of the sea.If then, as was probable, some vast cavity existed in the interior of the granite, it might, perhaps, be of great use.

zh: “那么，上尉，我们还呆着干什么？”水手问道，他已经迫不及待想要进入狭长的通道之中，“你看，托普已经在我们之前进去了！”
en: “Well, captain, what are we stopping for?” asked the sailor, impatient to enter the narrow passage.“You see Top has got before us!”

zh: “很好，”工程师回答道，“可是我们一定要看清前面的路。纳布，去砍一些带树脂的树枝来。”
en: “Very well,” replied the engineer.“But we must see our way.Neb, go and cut some resinous branches.”

zh: 湖边长着绿荫如盖的松树和其他绿树，纳布和赫伯特跑过去，很快折了些树枝回来，做成了火把。他们用燧石和钢片将火把点着，于是赛勒斯·哈丁就带领大家冒险进入黑色通道里，这里原本灌满了多余的湖水。
en: Neb and Herbert ran to the edge of the lake, shaded with pines and other green trees, and soon returned with some branches, which they made into torches.The torches were lighted with flint and steel, and Cyrus Harding leading, the settlers ventured into the dark passage, which the overplus of the lake had formerly filled.

zh: 出乎意料的是，探险者们越往里走，通道的直径越长，不一会儿，他们就可以直起身子来了。花岗岩石经过流水长年累月的冲刷，表面非常滑，有摔跤的危险。但是，居民们采取了爬山时常用的办法，用绳索将大家连在一起。幸好花岗岩的突出部分形成了规则的阶梯，这样往下走就不那么危险了。在火把的光下，岩顶挂着的水滴到处闪闪发光，探险者们猜想，岩壁分布着不计其数的钟乳石。工程师仔细查看着这块黑黑的花岗岩。里面没有一个地层，连一条缝隙都没有。这一大块岩石很结实，纹理紧密。这条通道的历史要追溯到海岛的起源了。它的形成并不是由于水一点一点将其掏空。是冥神而不是海神用他的力量造了这条通道，岩壁上火山喷发的痕迹还清晰可辨，冲刷的水流也未能将这些痕迹完全抹去。
en: Contrary to what might have been supposed, the diameter of the passage increased as the explorers proceeded, so that they very soon were able to stand upright.The granite, worn by the water for an infinite time, was very slippery, and falls were to be dreaded.But the settlers were all attached to each other by a cord, as is frequently done in ascending mountains.Happily some projections of the granite, forming regular steps, made the descent less perilous.Drops, still hanging from the rocks, shone here and there under the light of the torches, and the explorers guessed that the sides were clothed with innumerable stalactites.The engineer examined this black granite.There was not a stratum, not a break in it.The mass was compact, and of an extremely close grain.The passage dated, then, from the very origin of the island.It was not the water which little by little had hollowed it.Pluto and not Neptune had bored it with his own hand, and on the wall traces of an eruptive work could be distinguished, which all the washing of the water had not been able totally to efface.

zh: 他们往下走的速度很慢。他们冒险进入未知的深度，只感到恐惧，这条通道第一次有人类踏足。他们默默不语，陷入了沉思，考虑的事情不止一件，因为这里与海相通，一些腔肠动物或是巨大的头足类动物可能栖息在洞的内部。然而，托普一直走在小队的前头，他们可以依靠它的机智，在必要的时候它会发出警报的。
en: The settlers descended very slowly.They could not but feel a certain awe, in this venturing into these unknown depths, for the first time visited by human beings.They did not speak, but they thought; and the thought came to more than one, that some polypus or other gigantic cephalopod might inhabit the interior cavities, which were in communication with the sea.However, Top kept at the head of the little band, and they could rely on the sagacity of the dog, who would not fail to give the alarm if there was any need for it.

zh: 顺着蜿蜒的通道下行了大约有一百英尺后，一直走路的哈丁停了下来，他的同伴们也来到了他跟前。他们停住的地方要开阔一些，形成了一个大小适中的山洞。水滴从洞顶滴下来，但这并不能表明水是从岩石中渗下来的。水滴只不过是多年来岩洞中轰鸣而过的水流留下的最后残迹，这里的空气虽然有些潮湿但是却很新鲜，没有散发丝毫臭气。
en: After having descended about a hundred feet, following a winding road, Harding who was walking on before, stopped, and his companions came up with him.The place where they had halted was wider, so as to form a cavern of moderate dimensions.Drops of water fell from the vault, but that did not prove that they oozed through the rock.They were simply the last traces left by the torrent which had so long thundered through this cavity, and the air there was pure though slightly damp, but producing no mephitic exhalation.

zh: “嗯，亲爱的赛勒斯，”吉丁·史佩莱说道，“这个地方是个安全的住所，藏在岩石深处，但它不能住人。”
en: “Well, my dear Cyrus,” said Gideon Spilett, “here is a very secure retreat, well hid in the depths of the rock, but it is, however, uninhabitable.”

zh: “为什么不能住人？”水手问道。
en: “Why uninhabitable?” asked the sailor.

zh: “因为这里空间太小，光线太暗。”
en: “Because it is too small and too dark.”

zh: “难道我们不能把它凿大一些，挖空一些，再开几个窟窿透亮通风吗？”潘克洛夫回应道，他现在认为凡事皆有可能。
en: “Couldn’t we enlarge it, hollow it out, make openings to let in light and air?” replied Pencroft, who now thought nothing impossible.

zh: “我们继续向前探险吧，”赛勒斯·哈丁说道，“也许再往下一点，大自然会帮我们省下那一番力气的。”
en: “Let us go on with our exploration,” said Cyrus Harding.“Perhaps lower down, nature will have spared us this labor.”

zh: “我们才走了通道的三分之一。”赫伯特观察后说。
en: “We have only gone a third of the way,” observed Herbert.

zh: “将近三分之一，”哈丁说道，“我们从洞口往下走一百英尺——”
en: “Nearly a third,” replied Harding, “for we have descended a hundred feet from the opening, and it is not impossible that a hundred feet farther down—”

zh: “托普哪里去了？”纳布问道，打断了主人的话。
en: “Where is Top?” asked Neb, interrupting his master.

zh: 他们在岩洞中找了一会儿，但是没有找到。
en: They searched the cavern, but the dog was not there.

zh: “它很有可能是继续往前走了。”潘克洛夫说道。
en: “Most likely he has gone on,” said Pencroft.

zh: “我们跟上去吧。”哈丁说。
en: “Let us join him,” replied Harding.

zh: 他们继续往下走着。工程师仔细勘察通道的所有岔路，尽管岔路很多，他还是能轻易救讲出通向大海的大致方向。
en: The descent was continued.The engineer carefully observed all the deviations of the passage, and notwithstanding so many detours, he could easily have given an account of its general direction, which went towards the sea.

zh: 居民们又往下走了50英尺远，从深处传来的声音引起了他们的注意。他们停下来听着。声音通过通道传来，就像通过一个声管一样，清楚地传到耳朵里。
en: The settlers had gone some fifty feet farther, when their attention was attracted by distant sounds which came up from the depths.They stopped and listened.These sounds, carried through the passage as through an acoustic tube, came clearly to the ear.

zh: “那是托普在叫！”赫伯特喊道。
en: “That is Top barking!” cried Herbert.

zh: “是的，”潘克洛夫答道，“我们勇敢的狗正在狂吠呢！”
en: “Yes,” replied Pencroft, “and our brave dog is barking furiously!”

zh: “我们有铁头矛，”赛勒斯·哈丁说，“大家保持警惕，前进！”
en: “We have our iron-tipped spears,” said Cyrus Harding.“Keep on your guard, and forward!”

zh: “变得越来越有意思了。”吉丁·史佩莱低声对水手说，水手点点头。哈丁和同伴们冲过去想助狗一臂之力。托普的叫声越来越清楚，而且异常暴烈。它不会是侵犯了什么动物的巢穴，正在搏斗中吧？探险家们在难以抗拒的好奇心的驱使下，连可能遇到的危险都不顾，就又往下走了16英尺，几分钟之后，他们找到了托普。
en: “It is becoming more and more interesting,” murmured Gideon Spilett in the sailor’s ear, who nodded.Harding and his companions rushed to the help of their dog.Top’s barking became more and more perceptible, and it seemed strangely fierce.Was he engaged in a struggle with some animal whose retreat he had disturbed?Without thinking of the danger to which they might be exposed, the explorers were now impelled by an irresistible curiosity, and in a few minutes, sixteen feet lower they rejoined Top.

zh: 这里是通道的尽头，有一个又宽又大的岩洞。
en: There the passage ended in a vast and magnificent cavern.

zh: 托普来来回回地奔跑着，狂吠着。潘克洛夫和纳布挥舞着手中的火把，将洞的每一个缝隙都照遍了，与此同时，哈丁、史佩莱和赫伯特都举起自己的矛，随时准备应对可能发生的紧急情况。巨大的岩洞空空如也。居民们将每个方向都搜查遍了。里面什么也没有，没有任何动物，也没有人，然而，托普还是继续叫唤着。爱抚和恐吓都不能使它停下来。
en: Top was running backwards and forwards, barking furiously.Pencroft and Neb, waving their torches, threw the light into every crevice; and at the same time, Harding, Gideon Spilett, and Herbert, their spears raised, were ready for any emergency which might arise.The enormous cavern was empty.The settlers explored it in every direction.There was nothing there, not an animal, not a human being; and yet Top continued to bark.Neither caresses nor threats could make him be silent.

zh: “湖水一定是通过一个地方流进大海的。”工程师说。
en: “There must be a place somewhere, by which the waters of the lake reached the sea,” said the engineer.

zh: “当然，”潘克洛夫答道，“大家都要留神，不要掉到窟窿里去。”
en: “Of course,” replied Pencroft, “and we must take care not to tumble into a hole.”

zh: “走，托普，走！”哈丁喊道。
en: “Go, Top, go!” cried Harding.

zh: 托普在主人的话的刺激下，就跑到洞的尽头去了，在那里它叫得更起劲了。
en: The dog, excited by his master’s words, ran towards the extremity of the cavern, and there redoubled his barking.

zh: 他们跟上他，通过火把的光亮，看见花岗石地面上有一个规则的井口。湖水就是通过它流向海里的，但是这一次就不是倾斜的、可通行的通道了，而是一口垂直的井，要想下去冒险是不可能的。
en: They followed him, and by the light of the torches, perceived the mouth of a regular well in the granite.It was by this that the water escaped; and this time it was not an oblique and practicable passage, but a perpendicular well, into which it was impossible to venture.

zh: 他们把火把凑到井口来，但是什么也看不见。哈丁把一根点着的树枝扔下了深渊。燃烧的树脂在快速下坠的过程中越来越亮，照亮了井的内部，但是什么也没有。只听见嗤的一声，火灭了，说明树枝已经落在水里，也就是海面上。
en: The torches were held over the opening: nothing could be seen.Harding took a lighted branch, and threw it into the abyss.The blazing resin, whose illuminating power increased still more by the rapidity of its fall, lighted up the interior of the well, but yet nothing appeared.The flame then went out with a slight hiss, which showed that it had reached the water, that is to say, the level of the sea.

zh: 工程师根据树枝降落的时间，能算出井的深度，大约有90英尺。
en: The engineer, calculating the time employed in its fall, was able to calculate the depth of the well, which was found to be about ninety feet.

zh: 也就是说岩洞的地面离海平面有90英尺。
en: The floor of the cavern must thus be situated ninety feet above the level of the sea.

zh: “这里就是我们的住所。”赛勒斯·哈丁说。
en: “Here is our dwelling,” said Cyrus Harding.

zh: “但是这里有某些生物住着。”吉丁·史佩莱说道，他的好奇心还没有得到满足。
en: “But it was occupied by some creature,” replied Gideon Spilett, whose curiosity was not yet satisfied.

zh: “好吧，不管是不是两栖动物，它已经从这个井口离开了，”工程师答道，“将这个地方让给我们了。”
en: “Well, the creature, amphibious or otherwise, has made off through this opening,” replied the engineer, “and has left the place for us.”

zh: “不要紧，”水手补充道，“我真想变成托普，哪怕是一刻钟也好，它可从来都不乱叫！”
en: “Never mind,” added the sailor, “I should like very much to be Top just for a quarter of an hour, for he doesn’t bark for nothing!”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁看着他的狗，靠近他的同伴可以听见他低语道：
en: Cyrus Harding looked at his dog, and those of his companions who were near him might have heard him murmur these words,—

zh: “是的，我相信托普比我们知道的多多了。”
en: “Yes, I believe that Top knows more than we do about a great many things.”

zh: 无论如何，居民们的愿望大部分都得到了满足。上天的眷顾，再加上他们领袖的非凡智慧，已经给了他们天大的帮助。他们现在拥有了一个宽敞的岩洞，现在仅靠火把微弱的光线还不能算出山洞的大小，但是用砖头把这里隔成一个个房间是很容易的，如果不把它作为房子，至少可以把它作为一幢宽敞的公寓。流出去的水再也不会流回来了。这个地方终于空出来了。
