en: How grateful the inhabitants of Granite House then were to Heaven for having prepared for them this solid and immovable retreat!Cyrus Harding had also his legitimate share of thanks, but after all, it was Nature who had hollowed out this vast cavern, and he had only discovered it.There all were in safety, and the tempest could not reach them.If they had constructed a house of bricks and wood on Prospect Heights, it certainly would not have resisted the fury of this storm.As to the Chimneys, it must have been absolutely uninhabitable, for the sea, passing over the islet, would beat furiously against it.But here, in Granite House, in the middle of a solid mass, over which neither the sea nor air had any influence, there was nothing to fear.

zh: 在无法出门的这些天，居民们也并未闲着。
en: During these days of seclusion the settlers did not remain inactive.

zh: 储藏室里有充足的木材，他们把木材锯成木板，一点一点地完成了家具的制作。由于原材料充裕，他们做成的桌椅都是最结实的。纳布和潘克洛夫为制成这些厚重的家具感到自豪，无论别人拿什么来换，他们也不肯。
en: There was no want of wood, cut up into planks, in the storeroom, and little by little they completed their furnishing; constructing the most solid of tables and chairs, for material was not spared.Neb and Pencroft were very proud of this rather heavy furniture, which they would not have changed on any account.

zh: 接着，这些木匠们又开始成了编篮子的，而且这项新活他们完成得还不错。在湖区凸向北面的一端，他们发现了一片柳树林，那里生长着大量的紫柳。在雨季到来之前，潘克洛夫和赫伯特就已将这些用处很多的灌木砍了下来，经过仔细加工后的柳枝现在可以派上大用场了。刚开始编的几个篮子有些粗糙，但是后来工人们运用他们的聪明才智，通过回想、借鉴他们以前见过的篮子形状，并相互模仿，拓荒者的财产很快因为几个大大小小的篮子而增长了。他们把篮子放在储藏室里，纳布还挑了几个篮子，专门用来盛放收集来的根茎和南欧松子等等。
en: Then the carpenters became basket-makers, and they did not succeed badly in this new manufacture.At the point of the lake which projected to the north, they had discovered an osier-bed in which grew a large number of purple osiers.Before the rainy season, Pencroft and Herbert had cut down these useful shrubs, and their branches, well prepared, could now be effectively employed.The first attempts were somewhat crude, but in consequence of the cleverness and intelligence of the workmen, by consulting, and recalling the models which they had seen, and by emulating each other, the possessions of the colony were soon increased by several baskets of different sizes.The storeroom was provided with them, and in special baskets Neb placed his collection of rhizomes, stone-pine almonds, etc.

zh: 八月的最后一个星期，天气再度变得温和了。温度降低了一点，暴风雪也减弱了。这群拓荒者就立即出动了。海岸上的雪足有两英尺厚，但是他们在冻得硬邦邦的雪面上行走，倒也没多大困难。赛勒斯·哈丁和同伴们爬上了眺望岗。
en: During the last week of the month of August the weather moderated again.The temperature fell a little, and the tempest abated.The colonists sallied out directly.There was certainly two feet of snow on the shore, but they were able to walk without much difficulty on the hardened surface.Cyrus Harding and his companions climbed Prospect Heights.

zh: 变化真大啊！他们先前离开的树林还是一片绿色，尤其是长有大片枞树的那部分，现在全不见了，换上了统一的颜色。整个小岛，从富兰克林山顶到海岸、森林、平原、湖泊和河流，都是一片白雪皑皑。慈悲河的河水在冰面下潺潺地流过，每次涨潮和落潮的时候，水流会把冰块冲破，发出很响的碎裂声。无数的鸟儿在冰冻的湖面上拍打着翅膀。上千只鸭子、鹬、短颈野鸭和海鸥聚在一起。有瀑布流出的岩石中布满冰柱。这会让人觉得，水是从形状怪异的滴水口中流出来的，滴水口的形状像是借文艺复兴时期艺术家丰富的想象力造就的。这场暴风雪给森林带来的破坏程度还不能确定，他们必须等到覆盖森林的雪层消融后才知道。
en: What a change!The woods, which they had left green, especially in the part at which the firs predominated, had disappeared under a uniform color.All was white, from the summit of Mount Franklin to the shore, the forests, the plains, the lake, the river.The waters of the Mercy flowed under a roof of ice, which, at each rising and ebbing of the tide, broke up with loud crashes.Numerous birds fluttered over the frozen surface of the lake.Ducks and snipe, teal and guillemots were assembled in thousands.The rocks among which the cascade flowed were bristling with icicles.One might have said that the water escaped by a monstrous gargoyle, shaped with all the imagination of an artist of the Renaissance.As to the damage caused by the storm in the forest, that could not as yet be ascertained; they would have to wait till the snowy covering was dissipated.

zh: 吉丁·史佩莱、潘克洛夫和赫伯特抓住这个机会去查看他们的陷阱。因为陷阱被大雪遮住了，他们花费了一番工夫才找到。他们还必须小心翼翼，以免掉进陷阱里去，那样会很危险，而掉进自己设置的陷阱里是很丢脸的！但幸运的是，这种不快并没有发生，而且他们发现自己的陷阱完好无损。没有动物掉进陷阱里，然而周围却有大量足印，其中有一些很明显是动物的爪印。赫伯特毫不犹豫地确定，一些猫科动物从这里经过，这也印证了工程师的看法，林肯岛上有危险的野兽。这些动物无疑大多住在远西森林里，因饥饿所迫，才冒险走这么远到眺望岗觅食。或许它们已经嗅到了花岗石宫居民们的味道。“那么，这些猫科动物是什么呢？”潘克洛夫问道。“是老虎。”赫伯特回答道。“不是只有热带地区的国家才会有老虎吗？”
en: Gideon Spilett, Pencroft, and Herbert did not miss this opportunity of going to visit their traps.They did not find them easily, under the snow with which they were covered.They had also to be careful not to fall into one or other of them, which would have been both dangerous and humiliating; to be taken in their own snares!But happily they avoided this unpleasantness, and found their traps perfectly intact.No animal had fallen into them, and yet the footprints in the neighborhood were very numerous, among others, certain very clear marks of claws.Herbert did not hesitate to affirm that some animal of the feline species had passed there, which justified the engineer’s opinion that dangerous beasts existed in Lincoln Island.These animals doubtless generally lived in the forests of the Far West, but pressed by hunger, they had ventured as far as Prospect Heights.Perhaps they had smelled out the inhabitants of Granite House.“Now, what are these feline creatures?” asked Pencroft.“They are tigers,” replied Herbert.“I thought those beasts were only found in hot countries?”

zh: “在新大陆上，”少年回答道，“从墨西哥到布宜诺斯艾利斯的潘帕斯草原上都有老虎。而林肯岛和拉普拉塔地区几乎处于同一纬度，在这里会碰到老虎也就不足为奇了。”
en: “On the new continent,” replied the lad, “they are found from Mexico to the Pampas of Buenos Aires.Now, as Lincoln Island is nearly under the same latitude as the provinces of La Plata, it is not surprising that tigers are to be met with in it.”

zh: “那么，我们必须小心点它们了。”潘克洛夫答道。
en: “Well, we must look out for them,” replied Pencroft.

zh: 然而，随着温度不断升高，雪很快就融化并消失了。下了场雨后，大地披着的银色外衣就消失了。尽管天气恶劣，居民们还是存储了新的不同的东西，植物类的有南欧松子、根茎和枫树的浆汁；动物类的有兔子、刺鼠和袋鼠。为了获取这些东西，他们到森林里去了几次，发现很多树都被上次那场暴风雪吹倒了。潘克洛夫和纳布还推着车到很远的煤矿脉那里，带回来几吨燃料。他们在路上看到烧制陶器的土窑已经被大风严重摧毁了，至少有六英尺已经被吹倒了。
en: However, the snow soon disappeared, quickly dissolving under the influence of the rising temperature.Rain fell, and the sheet of white soon vanished.Notwithstanding the bad weather, the settlers renewed their stores of different things, stone-pine almonds, rhizomes, syrup from the maple-tree, for the vegetable part; rabbits from the warren, agouties, and kangaroos for the animal part.This necessitated several excursions into the forest, and they found that a great number of trees had been blown down by the last hurricane.Pencroft and Neb also pushed with the cart as far as the vein of coal, and brought back several tons of fuel.They saw in passing that the pottery kiln had been severely damaged by the wind, at least six feet of it having been blown off.

zh: 同时，他们又在花岗石宫新存储了些煤和木头，而且他们借助水流再度畅通的慈悲河，运送了几木筏的燃料。他们明白寒冷的季节并未结束。
en: At the same time as the coal, the store of wood was renewed at Granite House, and they profited by the current of the Mercy having again become free, to float down several rafts.They could see that the cold period was not ended.

zh: 他们也去“石窟”看了一回，居民们非常庆幸暴风雪侵袭的时候，他们没有住在这里。这里明显留下海水肆虐的痕迹。海水曾漫过小岛，猛烈地冲击通道，有一半的通道里满是泥土，而厚厚的海藻遮盖了岩石。当纳布、赫伯特和潘克洛夫去打猎或是收集木柴时，赛勒斯·哈丁和吉丁·史佩莱忙着修复“石窟”，他们发现炼铁炉和风箱几乎没有受到损害，它们在沙堆下一直免遭损害。
en: A visit was also paid to the Chimneys, and the settlers could not but congratulate themselves on not having been living there during the hurricane.The sea had left unquestionable traces of its ravages.Sweeping over the islet, it had furiously assailed the passages, half filling them with sand, while thick beds of seaweed covered the rocks.While Neb, Herbert, and Pencroft hunted or collected wood, Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett busied themselves in putting the Chimneys to rights, and they found the forge and the bellows almost unhurt, protected as they had been from the first by the heaps of sand.

zh: 储存的燃料也派上了用场。居民们得以抵御寒冷的天气。众所周知，在北半球，二月份的主要特点就是温度骤降。南半球也是如此，这里的八月底正是北美洲的二月份，也逃脱不了这一气候定律。
en: The store of fuel had not been made uselessly.The settlers had not done with the rigorous cold.It is known that, in the Northern Hemisphere, the month of February is principally distinguished by rapid fallings of the temperature.It is the same in the Southern Hemisphere, and the end of the month of August, which is the February of North America, does not escape this climatic law.

zh: 大约25号的时候，降雪天气转为降雨，风向转为东南，天气的寒冷突然又加剧了。据工程师的估计，温度不会高过华氏温度计水银柱标注的零下八度，而这种寒冷的天气，加上刺骨的寒风，持续了好几天，让人痛苦不堪。这群拓荒者不得不再次躲在花岗石宫里，因为不得不将正面所有的洞口严实地堵住，只留一道窄窄的缝隙供空气流通，蜡烛的消耗量相当大。为了节省蜡烛，他们经常不惜使用燃料，在石洞中只用燃烧的炉火照明。有几次，居民中有一两个人从花岗石宫下来，到冰块包围着的海滩上去，这些冰块是在海浪一次次涨潮和落潮的时候堆积形成的，但是他们很快就又爬回花岗石宫，他们双手握住梯档的时候，不仅感到疼痛，而且还很费力。由于酷寒，他们的手指一碰到梯档就仿佛灼烧一样。为了帮花岗石宫的居民们打发闲暇时光，赛勒斯·哈丁开始了一种可以在室内进行的活动。
en: About the 25th, after another change from snow to rain, the wind shifted to the southeast, and the cold became, suddenly, very severe.According to the engineer’s calculation, the mercurial column of a Fahrenheit thermometer would not have marked less than eight degrees below zero, and this intense cold, rendered still more painful by a sharp gale, lasted for several days.The colonists were again shut up in Granite House, and as it was necessary to hermetically seal all the openings of the facade, only leaving a narrow passage for renewing the air, the consumption of candles was considerable.To economize them, the cavern was often only lighted by the blazing hearths, on which fuel was not spared.Several times, one or other of the settlers descended to the beach in the midst of ice which the waves heaped up at each tide, but they soon climbed up again to Granite House, and it was not without pain and difficulty that their hands could hold to the rounds of the ladder.In consequence of the intense cold, their fingers felt as if burned when they touched the rounds.To occupy the leisure hours, which the tenants of Granite House now had at their disposal, Cyrus Harding undertook an operation which could be performed indoors.

zh: 我们知道居民们没有现成的糖，而是在枫树上割开很深的口子，从中获取汁液。他们用瓶子收集枫树的汁液，并用于烹制不同的食物。时间一久，这种液体就开始变白，成了一种浓稠的糖浆，他们对此十分满意。
en: We know that the settlers had no other sugar at their disposal than the liquid substance which they drew from the maple, by making deep incisions in the tree.They contented themselves with collecting this liquor in jars and employing it in this state for different culinary purposes, and the more so, as on growing old, this liquid began to become white and to be of a syrupy consistence.

zh: 但是还有更好的方法制作糖浆，一天，赛勒斯·哈丁宣布他们将要成为炼糖工人了。
en: But there was something better to be made of it, and one day Cyrus Harding announced that they were going to turn into refiners.

zh: “炼糖工人！”潘克洛夫回应道，“我想这是个不错的行当。”
en: “Refiners!” replied Pencroft.“That is rather a warm trade, I think.”

zh: “很不错。”工程师答道。
en: “Very warm,” answered the engineer.

zh: “很合时宜嘛！”水手道。
en: “Then it will be seasonable!” said the sailor.

zh: “炼制”这个词不需要使你脑海中浮现出有着设备和无数工人的庞大工厂。情况不是那样的！要使这种液体结晶，只需要一道极其简单的工序。把盛有糖浆的大土罐放在火上，糖浆很容易就开始蒸发，不久表面就起了一层浮渣。等到浮渣开始变厚，纳布小心地用木质的小铲子把它清除掉，这就加速了糖浆的蒸发，同时也要避免产生烧焦的味道。
en: This word refining need not awake in the mind thoughts of an elaborate manufactory with apparatus and numerous workmen.No! to crystallize this liquor, only an extremely easy operation is required.Placed on the fire in large earthen pots, it was simply subjected to evaporation, and soon a scum arose to its surface.As soon as this began to thicken, Neb carefully removed it with a wooden spatula; this accelerated the evaporation, and at the same time prevented it from contracting an empyreumatic flavor.

zh: 在热火上煮几个小时后，糖浆就变得十分浓稠，而且炼糖工人也觉得舒服多了。他们之前在厨房的炉子上制造了一些形状各异的粘土模具，这时候他们就把糖浆倒进这些模具里。第二天，糖浆就冷却了，变成糖块和糖片。这种糖颜色微红，但是却接近透明，并且味道很好。
en: After boiling for several hours on a hot fire, which did as much good to the operators as the substance operated upon, the latter was transformed into a thick syrup.This syrup was poured into clay molds, previously fabricated in the kitchen stove, and to which they had given various shapes.The next day this syrup had become cold, and formed cakes and tablets.This was sugar of rather a reddish color, but nearly transparent and of a delicious taste.

zh: 寒冷的天气一直持续到九月中旬，这群被困在花岗石宫的人开始觉得沉闷无聊了。他们几乎每天都要想办法出去，但却走不远。他们不停地修缮住处。他们一边工作一边交谈。哈丁向同伴们讲了很多东西，主要是给他们解释科学的实际应用。拓荒者们没有图书馆，然而，工程师总是一本随身携带的书，总是可以翻到他们需要的那一页，可以回答他们所有的问题，而他们也经常向这本书求教。时光就这样欢快地过去了，这些勇敢的人似乎对未来毫不畏惧。
en: The cold continued to the middle of September, and the prisoners in Granite House began to find their captivity rather tedious.Nearly every day they attempted sorties which they could not prolong.They constantly worked at the improvement of their dwelling.They talked while working.Harding instructed his companions in many things, principally explaining to them the practical applications of science.The colonists had no library at their disposal; but the engineer was a book which was always at hand, always open at the page which one wanted, a book which answered all their questions, and which they often consulted.The time thus passed away pleasantly, these brave men not appearing to have any fears for the future.

zh: 但是，所有的人都渴望看到好天气，至少这难以忍受的寒冷天气快点结束。假如他们有足够的衣物御寒，他们一定已经出去好多次了，无论是去沙丘还是去潦凫沼泽！猎物一定会很容易接近，而且捕猎的战果也一定会很丰硕。但是，赛勒斯·哈丁认为大家的健康十分重要，因为他需要他们，大家也都听从了他的建议。
en: However, all were anxious to see, if not the fine season, at least the cessation of the insupportable cold.If only they had been clothed in a way to meet it, how many excursions they would have attempted, either to the downs or to Tadorn’s Fens!Game would have been easily approached, and the chase would certainly have been most productive.But Cyrus Harding considered it of importance that no one should injure his health, for he had need of all his hands, and his advice was followed.

zh: 但是必须说明的是，因困守在花岗石宫而感到非常焦躁不安的，除了潘克洛夫，就是托普了。这只忠诚的狗觉得花岗石宫非常狭窄。它来回跑动，从一个房间跑到另一个房间，用自己的方式表明它对于被关在这里感到多么厌倦。哈丁多次注意到，每当托普走近与大海相接的黑井时，也就是储藏室后面的开口，它总是发出奇怪的嗥叫声。它围着这个被木头盖子遮住的洞来回跑。有时它甚至试图把爪子伸到盖子下面，像是想要把盖子掀起来。接着它就开始狂吠，声音里立刻显现出气愤和不安，十分怪异。
en: But it must be said, that the one who was most impatient of this imprisonment, after Pencroft perhaps, was Top.The faithful dog found Granite House very narrow.He ran backwards and forwards from one room to another, showing in his way how weary he was of being shut up.Harding often remarked that when he approached the dark well which communicated with the sea, and of which the orifice opened at the back of the storeroom, Top uttered singular growlings.He ran round and round this hole, which had been covered with a wooden lid.Sometimes even he tried to put his paws under the lid, as if he wished to raise it.He then yelped in a peculiar way, which showed at once anger and uneasiness.

zh: 托普的这一举动工程师已经观察到好几次了。
en: The engineer observed this maneuver several times.

zh: 这口井下的深渊有什么特别之处，让这只有灵性的动物如此不安？井下通着大海，这毫无疑问。会不会井下通过小岛的底部，还连着其他狭窄的通道呢？会不会有海洋怪兽时不时地来到井底喘息呢？工程师自己也不甚明白要想什么，而且不禁产生了许多奇怪的、不着边际的幻想。习惯了在科学的现实领域里深入探索的工程师，不容许自己沉溺于这一奇怪的、几乎是超自然的想象。但是，倘若那里没有什么令托普不安，这只颇有灵性的狗怎么会一直试图用嗅觉和听觉来了解这个深渊呢？而狗从来不会浪费时间，徒劳地对着月亮狂吠。赛勒斯·哈丁对托普的这一行为很是疑惑，其程度远远超过了他自己所认为的那样。
en: What could there be in this abyss to make such an impression on the intelligent animal?The well led to the sea, that was certain.Could narrow passages spread from it through the foundations of the island?Did some marine monster come from time to time, to breathe at the bottom of this well?The engineer did not know what to think, and could not refrain from dreaming of many strange improbabilities.Accustomed to go far into the regions of scientific reality, he would not allow himself to be drawn into the regions of the strange and almost of the supernatural; but yet how to explain why Top, one of those sensible dogs who never waste their time in barking at the moon, should persist in trying with scent and hearing to fathom this abyss, if there was nothing there to cause his uneasiness?Top’s conduct puzzled Cyrus Harding even more than he cared to acknowledge to himself.

zh: 不管怎样，工程师只把这些想法告诉了吉丁·史佩莱，因为他觉得不需要向其他伙伴们讲，因为这些可能只是由于托普的幻觉而产生的疑虑。
en: At all events, the engineer only communicated his impressions to Gideon Spilett, for he thought it useless to explain to his companions the suspicions which arose from what perhaps was only Top’s fancy.

zh: 寒冷的天气终于结束了。这期间也曾有过降雨、风雪、冰雹和狂风，但是这些恶劣的天气并没有持续多久。冰融化了，雪消失了，海滨、高地、慈悲河岸、森林也都再次变得畅通了。春天的到来让花岗石宫的居民们兴奋不已，不久之后，除了必须在这里吃饭、睡觉的几小时外，他们都不必呆在这里了。
en: At last the cold ceased.There had been rain, squalls mingled with snow, hailstorms, gusts of wind, but these inclemencies did not last.The ice melted, the snow disappeared; the shore, the plateau, the banks of the Mercy, the forest, again became practicable.This return of spring delighted the tenants of Granite House, and they soon only passed it in the hours necessary for eating and sleeping.

zh: 九月的后半个月里，他们经常去打猎，因而潘克洛夫再次恳求工程师制造火器，他宣称这是赛勒斯·哈丁曾经承诺过的。赛勒斯·哈丁非常清楚，没有特殊的工具，制造出一支能用的枪几乎是不可能的，因而还是推脱了，说以后再做。他像往常那样冷静地观察到，赫伯特和史佩莱已经成为技术纯熟的弓箭手，多种美味的猎物如刺鼠、袋鼠、水豚、鸽子、鸨、野鸭、鹅，总之有皮毛的动物都难逃他们的弓箭，因而他们可以再等些日子。但是倔强的水手全然不听，他不会给工程师片刻安宁，直到工程师承诺满足他的要求。就连吉丁·史佩莱也支持潘克洛夫。
en: They hunted much in the second part of September, which led Pencroft to again entreat for the firearms, which he asserted had been promised by Cyrus Harding.The latter, knowing well that without special tools it would be nearly impossible for him to manufacture a gun which would be of any use, still drew back and put off the operation to some future time, observing in his usual dry way, that Herbert and Spilett had become very skilful archers, so that many sorts of excellent animals, agouties, kangaroos, capybaras, pigeons, bustards, wild ducks, snipes, in short, game both with fur and feathers, fell victims to their arrows, and that, consequently, they could wait.But the obstinate sailor would listen to nothing of this, and he would give the engineer no peace till he promised to satisfy his desire.Gideon Spilett, however, supported Pencroft.

zh: “海岛上有没有野兽还不能确定，”他道，“如果有，我们必须想想怎么对付它们，消灭它们。这早晚会成为我们的首要任务。”
en: “If, which may be doubted,” said he, “the island is inhabited by wild beasts, we must think how to fight with and exterminate them.A time may come when this will be our first duty.”

zh: 但是这个时候，哈丁满脑子想的并不是火器的问题，而是衣物。居民们身上穿的衣服帮助他们度过了这个冬天，但是熬不过下一个冬天。他们必须不惜一切代价，获取食肉动物或反刍动物的皮毛，既然这里有许多摩弗仑羊，他们就一致同意想办法捉一群过来豢养，或许能给他们派上用场。为家畜建一个畜栏，并为鸟类建一个家禽场，简而言之，就是在岛上建一个农场，这就是他们在天气好的季节里要做的两件重要的工程。
en: But at this period, it was not the question of firearms which occupied Harding, but that of clothes.Those which the settlers wore had passed this winter, but they would not last until next winter.Skins of carnivora or the wool of ruminants must be procured at any price, and since there were plenty of musmons, it was agreed to consult on the means of forming a flock which might be brought up for the use of the colony.An enclosure for the domestic animals, a poultry-yard for the birds, in a word to establish a sort of farm in the island, such were the two important projects for the fine season.

zh: 因而，考虑到将来要做的这些事，他们应该深入到林肯岛所有未知的地方，也就是说，穿过慈悲河右岸的茂密森林，这片森林从河口一直绵延到盘蛇半岛尽头，以及海岛的整个西部地区。但是这需要在天气稳定的时候进行，于是为了这次探索能很好地进行，他们必须等上一个月的时间。
en: In consequence and in view of these future establishments, it became of much importance that they should penetrate into all the yet unknown parts of Lincoln Island, that is to say, through that thick forest which extended on the right bank of the Mercy, from its mouth to the extremity of the Serpentine Peninsula, as well as on the whole of its western side.But this needed settled weather, and a month must pass before this exploration could be profitably undertaken.

zh: 因而，他们有些不耐烦地等着，这时发生了一件事情，使得这些居民探索整个疆域的心情更加急切了。
en: They therefore waited with some impatience, when an incident occurred which increased the desire the settlers had to visit the whole of their domain.

zh: 那天是10月24号。那天，潘克洛夫去查看他的陷阱，他总是在里面放好诱饵。他在其中一个陷阱里发现了三只动物，那是很好的食材。一只母野猪和两只幼崽。
en: It was the 24th of October.On this day, Pencroft had gone to visit his traps, which he always kept properly baited.In one of them he found three animals which would be very welcome for the larder.They were a female peccary and her two young ones.

zh: 然后，潘克洛夫回到了花岗石宫，他为自己俘获这样的战利品兴奋不已，并且像往常那样大肆炫耀了一番。
en: Pencroft then returned to Granite House, enchanted with his capture, and, as usual, he made a great show of his game.

zh: “快来，我们可以大饱口福了，上尉！”他叫道，“还有你，史佩莱先生，也有你的！”
en: “Come, we shall have a grand feast, captain!” he exclaimed.“And you too, Mr. Spilett, you will eat some!”

zh: “我会很开心，”记者回答道，“但是我将要吃的是什么呢？”
en: “I shall be very happy,” replied the reporter; “but what is it that I am going to eat?”

zh: “乳猪。”
en: “Suckling-pig.”

zh: “哦，真的是乳猪吗，潘克洛夫？听你的口气，我还以为你带来的是塞满松露的小鹧鸪呢！”
en: “Oh, indeed, suckling-pig, Pencroft?To hear you, I thought that you were bringing back a young partridge stuffed with truffles!”

zh: “什么？”潘克洛夫大叫，“你的意思是看不起乳猪了？”
en: “What?” cried Pencroft.“Do you mean to say that you turn up your nose at suckling-pig?’

zh: “不是，”史佩莱淡淡地回答道，“如果没有吃腻的话。”
en: “No,” replied Gideon Spilett, without showing any enthusiasm; “provided one doesn’t eat too much”

zh: “好，好！”水手回答道，每当他打回来的猎物得不到重视的时候，他就十分不悦。“你就喜欢对着干。要是在七个月以前，我们刚登陆这块小岛那会儿，你要是看到这样的猎物，一定要高兴坏了！”
en: “That’s right, that’s right,” returned the sailor, who was not pleased whenever he heard his chase made light of.“You like to make objections.Seven months ago, when we landed on the island, you would have been only too glad to have met with such game!”

zh: “得了，得了，”记者回道，“人都是不完美的，而且永不满足。”
en: “Well, well,” replied the reporter, “man is never perfect, nor contented.”

zh: “现在，”潘克洛夫说道，“我希望纳布拿出烹调的真本事来。看啊！这两只小猪还不到三个月大！它们一定像鹌鹑那样鲜嫩！快来啊，纳布，来啊！我也亲自来做做。”
en: “Now,” said Pencroft, “I hope that Neb will distinguish himself.Look here!These two little peccaries are not more than three months old!They will be as tender as quails!Come along, Neb, come!I will look after the cooking myself.”

zh: 水手跟着纳布进了厨房，他们很快就专心地烹调起来。
en: And the sailor, followed by Neb, entered the kitchen, where they were soon absorbed in their culinary labors.

zh: 伙伴们同意他们按照自己的想法进行烹调。因而，纳布准备了一顿丰盛的晚餐——两只烤乳猪、袋鼠汤、熏火腿、南欧松子和大红香蜂草。事实上，这是他们所做的最好的食物了，但是在所有的食物中，最棒的还是美味的小猪。
en: They were allowed to do it in their own way.Neb, therefore, prepared a magnificent repast—the two little peccaries, kangaroo soup, a smoked ham, stone-pine almonds, Oswego tea; in fact, all the best that they had, but among all the dishes figured in the first rank the savory peccaries.

zh: 五点钟的时候，他们在花岗石宫的餐厅开饭了。桌子上，袋鼠汤冒着热气。他们觉得味道十分可口。
en: At five o’clock dinner was served in the dining-room of Granite House.The kangaroo soup was smoking on the table.They found it excellent.

zh: 喝完汤，他们开始吃烤乳猪了，潘克洛夫坚持要自己切，并且给每位伙伴都切了很大一块。
en: To the soup succeeded the peccaries, which Pencroft insisted on carving himself, and of which he served out monstrous portions to each of the guests.

zh: 这些乳猪是在是太好吃了，潘克洛夫津津有味地大口咀嚼，突然，他大叫了一声，接着咒骂了一句。
en: These suckling-pigs were really delicious, and Pencroft was devouring his share with great gusto, when all at once a cry and an oath escaped him.

zh: “怎么了？”赛勒斯·哈丁问道。
en: “What’s the matter?” asked Cyrus Harding.

zh: “怎么了？我的牙齿刚被硌坏了一颗！”水手答道。
en: “The matter? the matter is that I have just broken a tooth!” replied the sailor.

zh: “什么，你的小猪里面有卵石吗？”吉丁·史佩莱问道。
en: “What, are there pebbles in your peccaries?” said Gideon Spilett.

zh: “我想是的。”潘克洛夫一边回答，一边从嘴中拿出那个硌坏他一颗牙齿的东西。
en: “I suppose so,” replied Pencroft, drawing from his lips the object which had cost him a grinder!—

zh: 那不是卵石，而是一颗铅弹。
en: It was not a pebble—it was a leaden bullet.

zh: 第二部 孤岛求生
en: Part 2—Abandoned

zh: 第一章
en: Chapter 1

zh: 气球上的航行者流落到林肯岛上已有整整七个月了。这段时间，尽管他们也曾寻找调查，但并未发现岛上有其他人。岛上甚至没有一缕显示人类居住迹象的炊烟。也没有人类劳作的痕迹，以表明早期或是近段时间有人在此居住。除了他们，小岛上似乎没有其他人了，不仅如此，这群拓荒者也不得不相信小岛上从来不曾有人类居住过。然而现在，居然在一只无力伤害人的噬齿动物身上发现了一颗金属子弹，它推翻了所有推理。事实上，这颗子弹一定是由火器发射出来的，除了人类，还有谁会使用这样的武器呢？
en: It was now exactly seven months since the balloon voyagers had been thrown on Lincoln Island.During that time, notwithstanding the researches they had made, no human being had been discovered.No smoke even had betrayed the presence of man on the surface of the island.No vestiges of his handiwork showed that either at an early or at a late period had man lived there.Not only did it now appear to be uninhabited by any but themselves, but the colonists were compelled to believe that it never had been inhabited.And now, all this scaffolding of reasonings fell before a simple ball of metal, found in the body of an inoffensive rodent!In fact, this bullet must have issued from a firearm, and who but a human being could have used such a weapon?

zh: 当潘克洛夫将子弹放到桌上的时候，他的同伴们非常惊讶地盯着这颗子弹。虽然这颗子弹本身似乎微不足道，但这个时间却可能引发一系列后果，因而立即引起了他们的重视。他们此刻的惊讶程度，不亚于看到突发的超自然现象。
en: When Pencroft had placed the bullet on the table, his companions looked at it with intense astonishment.All the consequences likely to result from this incident, notwithstanding its apparent insignificance, immediately took possession of their minds.The sudden apparition of a supernatural being could not have startled them more completely.

zh: 这件令人吃惊的突发事件当然引起了赛勒斯·哈丁的思考，他毫不犹豫地说出了内心的想法。他拿着这颗子弹，翻来覆去地看，子弹在他的拇指和食指间转动着，接着，他转向潘克洛夫，问道：
en: Cyrus Harding did not hesitate to give utterance to the suggestions which this fact, at once surprising and unexpected, could not fail to raise in his mind.He took the bullet, turned it over and over, rolled it between his finger and thumb; then, turning to Pencroft, he asked,—

zh: “你确定被这颗子弹伤到的野猪不足三个月大吗？”
en: Are you sure that the peccary wounded by this bullet was not more than three months old?”

zh: “是的，上尉，”潘克洛夫回答道，“我在陷阱里发现它的时候，它还在吃奶呢。”
en: “Not more, captain,” replied Pencroft.“It was still sucking its mother when I found it in the trap.”

zh: “那么，”工程师说道，“这就说明在三个月内，有人在林肯岛上开过枪。”
en: “Well,” said the engineer, “that proves that within three months a gun-shot was fired in Lincoln Island.”

zh: “而那颗子弹，”吉丁·史佩莱补充道，“打伤了这只小动物，虽然并没有杀死它。”
en: “And that a bullet,” added Gideon Spilett, “wounded, though not mortally, this little animal.”

zh: “这毫无疑问，”赛勒斯·哈丁说道，“从这件事中我们可以推论：在我们到达之前曾有人在岛上居住过，或者他们是在最近三个月内登陆到这里。这些人是有意还是被迫来到这里的，是在海边登陆还是因为失事流落到这里的？这点只能留待以后解决了。至于他们是什么人，欧洲人还是马来西亚人，是我们种族的敌人还是朋友？我们可能无从得知；他们仍然居住在这个岛上，还是已经离开了，我们也不得而知。但是这些问题十分重要，亟待解决。”
en: “That is unquestionable,” said Cyrus Harding, “and these are the deductions which must be drawn from this incident: that the island was inhabited before our arrival, or that men have landed here within three months.Did these men arrive here voluntarily or involuntarily, by disembarking on the shore or by being wrecked?This point can only be cleared up later.As to what they were, Europeans or Malays, enemies or friends of our race, we cannot possibly guess; and if they still inhabit the island, or if they have left it, we know not.But these questions are of too much importance to be allowed to remain long unsettled.”

zh: “不！这怎么可能！这绝对不可能！”水手从桌子边一跃而起，喊道，“林肯岛上除了我们不会再有其他人了！我保证！这个小岛不是很大，如果有人曾在这里居住过，我们早就该看到他们了！”
en: “No! a hundred times no! a thousand times no!” cried the sailor, springing up from the table.“There are no other men than ourselves on Lincoln Island!By my faith!The island isn’t large and if it had been inhabited, we should have seen some of the inhabitants long before this!”

zh: “如果事实正好相反，那就太可怕了。”赫伯特说道。
en: “In fact, the contrary would be very astonishing,” said Herbert.

zh: “但是如果这只野猪出生的时候，身上就有子弹，”记者评论道，“那就更可怕了。”
en: “But it would be much more astonishing, I should think, observed the reporter, “if this peccary had been born with a bullet in its inside!”

zh: “不管怎样，”纳布严肃地说道，“如果潘克洛夫没有——”
en: “At least,” said Neb seriously, “if Pencroft has not had—”

zh: “听着，纳布，”潘克洛夫大叫道，“你觉得如果我下巴里有颗子弹，过了五六个月，我还能找不出来？它能藏在哪里？”他一边问一边张开嘴巴，给纳布看他嘴里的32颗牙齿。“看好了，纳布，如果你能在我嘴巴里找到一颗有窟窿的牙齿，我就让你拔掉六颗牙齿！”
en: “Look here, Neb,” burst out Pencroft.“Do you think I could have a bullet in my jaw for five or six months without finding it out?Where could it be hidden?” he asked, opening his mouth to show the two-and-thirty teeth with which it was furnished.“Look well, Neb, and if you find one hollow tooth in this set, I will let you pull out half a dozen!”

zh: “纳布的猜测显然是不可能的，”哈丁回答道，尽管他陷入了沉思，还是禁不住微微一笑。“毫无疑问，最多在三个月前，有人在岛上开过枪。但是我倾向于认为，在海边登陆的这些人仅仅是不久前才来到这里，或者是刚到这里。因为如果他们确实住在这里，我们在富兰克林山顶俯瞰小岛的时候，就应该看到他们，或者他们应该看到我们。所以我认为，他们可能就是这几周内被风暴抛到海岸上来的。不管怎样，我们都应当把这点弄清楚，这很重要。”
en: “Neb’s supposition is certainly inadmissible,” replied Harding, who, notwithstanding the gravity of his thoughts, could not restrain a smile.“It is certain that a gun has been fired in the island, within three months at most.But I am inclined to think that the people who landed on this coast were only here a very short time ago, or that they just touched here; for if, when we surveyed the island from the summit of Mount Franklin, it had been inhabited, we should have seen them or we should have been seen ourselves.It is therefore, probable that within only a few weeks castaways have been thrown by a storm on some part of the coast.However that may be, it is of consequence to us to have this point settled.”

zh: “我想我们应当小心行事。”记者说道。
en: “I think that we should act with caution,” said the reporter.

zh: “我的建议也是这样，”赛勒斯·哈丁回答道，“我担心有可能是马来的海盗在小岛上登陆了！”
en: “Such is my advice,” replied Cyrus Harding, “for it is to be feared that Malay pirates have landed on the island!”

zh: “上尉，”水手问道，“在出发之前，我们先造一只小船，我们就能溯流而上，而且如果我们乐意，还可以在岛内沿线航行，这个计划不错吧？我们需要做些准备。”
en: “Captain,” asked the sailor, “would it not be a good plan, before setting out, to build a canoe in which we could either ascend the river, or, if we liked, coast round the inland?It will not do to be unprovided.”

zh: “这是个好主意，潘克洛夫，”工程师回答道，“但是我们等不及了。建造一只小船至少要花费一个月的时间。”
en: “Your idea is good, Pencroft,” replied the engineer, “but we cannot wait for that.It would take at least a month to build a boat.”

zh: “是的，造艘真正的船需要这么久，”水手答道，“但是我们并不需要那种能在海上航行的船，至多五天，我就能建造一只可以在慈悲河上航行的小舟了。”
en: “Yes, a real boat,” replied the sailor; “but we do not want one for a sea voyage, and in five days at the most, I will undertake to construct a canoe fit to navigate the Mercy.”

zh: “五天，”纳布惊叫，“建造一只小船？”
en: “Five days,” cried Neb, “to build a boat?”

zh: “没错，纳布，一只印第安式的小船。”
en: “Yes, Neb; a boat in the Indian fashion.”

zh: “木头做的？”这个黑人问道，他看起来依然不相信。
en: “Of wood?” asked the Negro, looking still unconvinced.

zh: “木头做的，”潘克洛夫回答道，“更确切地说，是用树皮做。我再说一遍，上尉，五天之内一定会完工！”
en: “Of wood,” replied Pencroft, “of rather of bark.I repeat, captain, that in five days the work will be finished!”

zh: “五天内，那好，动手吧。”工程师回答道。
en: “In five days, then, be it,” replied the engineer.

zh: “但是这段时间我们必须要小心警惕。”赫伯特说道。
en: “But till that time we must be very watchful,” said Herbert.

zh: “我们确实应当小心警惕，朋友们，”哈丁回答道，“还有，我希望你们把打猎范围限定在花岗石宫附近。”
en: “Very watchful indeed, my friends,” replied Harding; “and I beg you to confine your hunting excursions to the neighborhood of Granite House.”

zh: 晚餐就这样结束了，并没有像潘克洛夫希望的那样愉快。
en: The dinner ended less gaily than Pencroft had hoped.

zh: 所以，除了这群居民外，还有其他人曾经或者正在岛上居住。正如这颗子弹的出现所证明的那样，此后这发现将成为一个不容置疑的事实，而这个发现使得拓荒者们深感不安。
en: So, then, the island was, or had been, inhabited by others than the settlers.Proved as it was by the incident of the bullet, it was hereafter an unquestionable fact, and such a discovery could not but cause great uneasiness among the colonists.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和吉丁·史佩莱睡前针对这件事情交谈了很长时间。他们问自己，这件事情会不会碰巧和工程师的不可解释的获救方式存在一些关联，以及和他们在不同时间发现的其他怪事有联系。但是，在对这个问题的正反两面进行讨论之后，赛勒斯·哈丁最后说道：
en: Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett, before sleeping, conversed long about the matter.They asked themselves if by chance this incident might not have some connection with the inexplicable way in which the engineer had been saved, and the other peculiar circumstances which had struck them at different times.However, Cyrus Harding, after having discussed the pros and cons of the question, ended by saying,—

zh: “简单地说，你想知道我的想法吗，亲爱的史佩莱？”
en: “In short, would you like to know my opinion, my dear Spilett?”

zh: “当然了，赛勒斯。”
en: “Yes, Cyrus.”

zh: “好，那就是无论我们多么仔细地勘察这个小岛，我们还是会一无所获。”
en: “Well, then, it is this: however minutely we explore the island, we shall find nothing.”

zh: 第二天，潘克洛夫开始工作了。他并不打算建造一只有甲板和船舷的船，而只是一只足以在慈悲河上划行的平底小舟，毕竟只用到达水位本来就较浅的河流发源地。把一块块树皮固定在一起，就可以造出一只轻舟了，一旦遇到天然阻碍，搬运起来也是很轻便的。潘克洛夫打算用钉子把一块块树皮固定起来，确保小舟不会透水。
en: The next day Pencroft set to work.He did not mean to build a boat with boards and planking, but simply a flat-bottomed canoe, which would be well suited for navigating the Mercy—above all, for approaching its source, where the water would naturally be shallow.Pieces of bark, fastened one to the other, would form a light boat; and in case of natural obstacles, which would render a portage necessary, it would be easily carried.Pencroft intended to secure the pieces of bark by means of nails, to insure the canoe being water-tight.

zh: 首先，要选择树皮结实而且柔韧性好的树木，以备造船之用。上一场暴风雪刮倒了许多高大的桦树，而桦树的树皮非常适合用来造船。有些树倒在地上，他们需要做的就是剥下树皮，但是因为居民们只有粗糙的工具，这项工作是最艰难的。然而，他们还是克服了所有困难。
en: It was first necessary to select the trees which would afford a strong and supple bark for the work.Now the last storm had brought down a number of large birch-trees, the bark of which would be perfectly suited for their purpose.Some of these trees lay on the ground, and they had only to be barked, which was the most difficult thing of all, owing to the imperfect tools which the settlers possessed.However, they overcame all difficulties.

zh: 水手在工程师的帮助下，争分夺秒地工作，吉丁·史佩莱和赫伯特也没有闲着。
en: While the sailor, seconded by the engineer, thus occupied himself without losing an hour, Gideon Spilett and Herbert were not idle.

zh: 他们忙着为大家供应食物。少年使用弓箭和矛的技术非常娴熟，记者不由得对这位少年产生了敬意。赫伯特还表现出了非凡的勇气和镇定自若的心态，这或许就可以称作是“智勇双全”。这两个狩猎的伙伴牢记赛勒斯·哈丁的建议，活动范围没有超出花岗石宫周围两英里之外。但是森林的边缘地区依然有大量的刺鼠、水豚、袋鼠、西貒等等，而且尽管陷阱捕获的猎物不如冬天的多，但是养兔场还是会像往常的数量一样供给食物，这或许就可以使林肯岛上的拓荒者们填饱肚子了。
en: They were made purveyors to the colony.The reporter could not but admire the boy, who had acquired great skill in handling the bow and spear.Herbert also showed great courage and much of that presence of mind which may justly be called “the reasoning of bravery.”These two companions of the chase, remembering Cyrus Harding’s recommendations, did not go beyond a radius of two miles round Granite House; but the borders of the forest furnished a sufficient tribute of agoutis, capybaras, kangaroos, peccaries, etc.; and if the result from the traps was less than during the cold, still the warren yielded its accustomed quota, which might have fed all the colony in Lincoln Island.

zh: 打猎的时候，赫伯特经常会和吉丁·史佩莱谈论子弹的事情，以及工程师由此做出的推断。一天，也就是10月26日，郝伯特说道：“史佩莱先生，如果真的有落难者登陆到这个小岛上，而他们到现在为止还没有在花岗石宫附近出现过，你不觉得非常奇怪吗？”
en: Often during these excursions, Herbert talked with Gideon Spilett on the incident of the bullet, and the deductions which the engineer drew from it, and one day—it was the 26th of October—he said—“But, Mr. Spilett, do you not think it very extraordinary that, if any castaways have landed on the island, they have not yet shown themselves near Granite House?”

zh: “如果他们还在这里，那确实很奇怪，”记者回答道，“但是如果他们已经不在这里了，那就不足为奇了！”
en: “Very astonishing if they are still here,” replied the reporter, “but not astonishing at all if they are here no longer!”

zh: “那么，你认为这些人已经离开小岛了吗？”赫伯特又问道。
en: “So you think that these people have already quitted the island?” returned Herbert.

zh: “极有可能，孩子，如果他们在这里呆的时间长一点，尤其是如果他们还在这里，总会发生一些事情暴露他们的行踪。”
en: “It is more than probable, my boy; for if their stay was prolonged, and above all, if they were still here, some accident would have at last betrayed their presence.”

zh: “但是如果他们有能力离开，”少年道，“那么他们就不会是落难者了。”
en: “But if they were able to go away,” observed the lad, “they could not have been castaways.”

zh: “不，赫伯特，或许我们至少可以把他们称作是暂时的落难者。有可能是风暴驱使他们来到这座小岛上，但是他们的船只可能并没被摧毁，于是，风暴结束后，他们就离开了。”
en: “No, Herbert; or, at least, they were what might be called provisional castaways.It is very possible that a storm may have driven them to the island without destroying their vessel, and that, the storm over, they went away again.”

zh: “我确信一件事情，”赫伯特说道，“哈丁上尉似乎害怕而不是希望岛上有其他人出现。”
en: “I must acknowledge one thing,” said Herbert, “it is that Captain Harding appears rather to fear than desire the presence of human beings on our island.”

zh: “简单地说，”记者回答道，“只有马来人会经常光顾这些海域，而那些家伙都是暴徒，我们最好躲开他们。”
en: “In short,” responded the reporter, “there are only Malays who frequent these seas, and those fellows are ruffians which it is best to avoid.”

zh: “这有可能，史佩莱先生，”赫伯特说道，“说不定哪天我们就会发现他们登陆的踪迹。”
en: “It is not impossible, Mr. Spilett,” said Herbert, “that some day or other we may find traces of their landing.”

zh: “或许是吧，孩子。一个废弃的帐篷，一堆篝火的灰烬，都可以使我们有迹可循，这就是我们下次探险要寻找的东西。”
en: “I do not say no, my boy.A deserted camp, the ashes of a fire, would put us on the track, and this is what we will look for in our next expedition.”

zh: 那天，狩猎者们是在慈悲河附近的一片树林讲这番话的，那里有许多美丽的树木。在一些树木之间，地面矗立起几乎高达200英尺的树，有一些是高大的松柏树，新西兰的土著们把它们叫做卡利松。
en: The day on which the hunters spoke thus, they were in a part of the forest near the Mercy, remarkable for its beautiful trees.There, among others, rose, to a height of nearly 200 feet above the ground, some of those superb coniferae, to which, in New Zealand, the natives give the name of Kauris.

zh: “我想到一个办法，史佩莱先生，”赫伯特说道，“如果我爬到一棵卡利松树上面，就可以看到周围广阔的地方。”
en: “I have an idea, Mr. Spilett,” said Herbert.“If I were to climb to the top of one of these kauris, I could survey the country for an immense distance round.”

zh: “这主意不错，”记者回答说，“可是你能爬到这些巨大的树上去吗？”
en: “The idea is good,” replied the reporter; “but could you climb to the top of those giants?”

zh: “至少可以试一下。”赫伯特回答说。
en: “I can at least try,” replied Herbert.

zh: 动作轻快敏捷的少年纵身一跳，跳到了离地面最近的那树枝上，树枝交错盘旋，爬上去很容易。几分钟后，他就到了树顶，树处在一望无际的翠绿平原中。
en: The light and active boy then sprang on the first branches, the arrangement of which made the ascent of the kauri easy, and in a few minutes he arrived at the summit, which emerged from the immense plain of verdure.

zh: 从这个高度望过去，他可以看到整个小岛的南部地区，从东南的爪角到西南的爬虫角。西北方向耸立着富兰克林山，遮住了很大一部分视线。
en: From this elevated situation his gaze extended over all the southern portion of the island, from Claw Cape on the southeast, to Reptile End on the southwest.To the northwest rose Mount Franklin, which concealed a great part of the horizon.

zh: 但是这个观测点的高度使得赫伯特可以看到小岛上所有未知区域，而这些地方或许就是踪迹被他们怀疑的陌生人的安身之处。
en: But Herbert, from the height of his observatory, could examine all the yet unknown portion of the island, which might have given shelter to the strangers whose presence they suspected.

zh: 少年仔细地查看着。海上什么也没有，无论是在地平线上，还是在小岛附近，都没有发现船只。但是由于浅滩的树木遮住了海岸，或许有一只小船，特别是桅杆断掉的，可能在离陆地很近的地方停泊着，而郝伯特是没有办法看到的。
en: The lad looked attentively.There was nothing in sight on the sea, not a sail, neither on the horizon nor near the island.However, as the bank of trees hid the shore, it was possible that a vessel, especially if deprived of her masts, might lie close to the land and thus be invisible to Herbert.

zh: 远西森林里也什么都看不到。森林里的树木形成了一道不可透视的屏障，绵延几平方英里，一处空隙或是开阔的地方也没有。甚至也没有办法顺着慈悲河的河道看过去，或是确定它的源头在山的哪一部分。或许还有其他的溪流也向西流去，但却看不到。
en: Neither in the forests of the Far West was anything to be seen.The wood formed an impenetrable screen, measuring several square miles, without a break or an opening.It was impossible even to follow the course of the Mercy, or to ascertain in what part of the mountain it took its source.Perhaps other creeks also ran towards the west, but they could not be seen.

zh: 然而，即便是所有的宿营痕迹都逃过赫伯特的视线，难道他会瞥不见轻烟吗？在这样清朗的天气里，即便是一缕淡淡的轻烟也可以很轻易地看出来。
en: But at last, if all indication of an encampment escaped Herbert’s sight could he not even catch a glimpse of smoke, the faintest trace of which would be easily discernible in the pure atmosphere?

zh: 有那么一瞬间，赫伯特认为他看到西边有一缕淡淡的轻烟，但是再仔细看时发现他弄错了。他睁大眼睛，向四面八方望去，他的视力很好。但是没有，确实什么也没有。
en: For an instant Herbert thought he could perceive a slight smoke in the west, but a more attentive examination showed that he was mistaken.He strained his eyes in every direction, and his sight was excellent.No, decidedly there was nothing there.

zh: 赫伯特从卡利松上下来，这两个猎人又返回花岗石宫去了。赛勒斯·哈丁听少年的讲述后，摇了摇头，什么都没有说。很明显，在没有彻底勘察这个小岛之前，在这个问题上是不能下定论的。
en: Herbert descended to the foot of the kauri, and the two sportsmen returned to Granite House.There Cyrus Harding listened to the lad’s account, shook his head and said nothing.It was very evident that no decided opinion could be pronounced on this question until after a complete exploration of the island.

zh: 两天之后，也就是10月28日，又发生了一件事，同样需要对它的解释。
en: Two days after—the 28th of October—another incident occurred, for which an explanation was again required.

zh: 赫伯特和纳布在距花岗石宫两英里的海边散步的时，很幸运地捉住了一只美丽的龟目动物。这是一只可食用的迈达斯种海龟，这是可食用的绿海龟，所以这样叫它是因为它的壳和肉都是绿色的。
en: While strolling along the shore about two miles from Granite House, Herbert and Neb were fortunate enough to capture a magnificent specimen of the order of chelonia.It was a turtle of the species Midas, the edible green turtle, so called from the color both of its shell and fat.

zh: 这只海龟在岩石间朝着大海的方向爬动的时候，被赫伯特看到了。
en: Herbert caught sight of this turtle as it was crawling among the rocks to reach the sea.

zh: “快来帮忙，纳布，快来！”他喊道。
en: “Help, Neb, help!” he cried.

zh: 纳布跑了过来。
en: Neb ran up.

zh: “多美的动物啊！”纳布说道，“但是我们要怎么捉住它呀？”
en: “What a fine animal!” said Neb; “but how are we to catch it?”

zh: “没有比这更容易的了，纳布，”赫伯特回答道，“我们只需要把这只海龟翻过来，它就跑不了了。拿起你的矛，跟着我做。”
en: “Nothing is easier, Neb,” replied Herbert.“We have only to turn the turtle on its back, and it cannot possibly get away.Take your spear and do as I do.”

zh: 这只爬虫发觉到了危险，把身体缩进了龟壳和腹甲之间。他们就看不到这只海龟的头和脚了，而海龟像块岩石一样一动也不动。
en: The reptile, aware of danger, had retired between its carapace and plastron.They no longer saw its head or feet, and it was motionless as a rock.

zh: 赫伯特和纳布就把棍子伸到这只动物的身下，一起用力，很轻易地就把它翻了过来。这只海龟长达三英尺，至少有400磅重。
en: Herbert and Neb then drove their sticks underneath the animal, and by their united efforts managed without difficulty to turn it on its back.The turtle, which was three feet in length, would have weighed at least four hundred pounds.

zh: “太好了！”纳布喊道，“这就是能使我们的朋友潘克洛夫高兴的东西。”
en: “Capital!” cried Neb; “this is something which will rejoice friend Pencroft’s heart.”

zh: 事实上，潘克洛夫一定会很开心，因为这种海龟以海草为食，龟肉味道极其鲜美。这时，海龟伸出头来，又小又扁，但是由于隐藏在长长的上颚骨下巨大的、临时的颞窝，头的后部则比较宽。
en: In fact, the heart of friend Pencroft could not fail to be rejoiced, for the flesh of the turtle, which feeds on wrack-grass, is extremely savory.At this moment the creature’s head could be seen, which was small, flat, but widened behind by the large temporal fossae hidden under the long roof.

zh: “现在要怎么处理我们的战利品呢？”纳布说道，“我们不能把它拖回花岗石宫啊！”
en: “And now, what shall we do with our prize?” said Neb.“We can’t drag it to Granite House!”

zh: “既然它不会翻身，就把它留在这里吧，”赫伯特回答道，“我们回去把推车弄来拉走它。”
en: “Leave it here, since it cannot turn over,” replied Herbert, “and we will come back with the cart to fetch it.”

zh: “这个最好的办法。”
en: “That is the best plan.”

zh: 但是为谨慎起见，赫伯特又不厌其烦地用大石头把这只海龟挡住，纳布则认为没有必要这样做。之后，两个猎人就沿着退潮之后显现出来的海滩，回到了花岗石宫。赫伯特想给潘克洛夫一个惊喜，因而对他们在沙滩上翻过来的那只“超级大海龟”只字未提。两个小时之后，他和纳布带着推车回到他们留下海龟的地方。那只“超级大海龟”却不见了！
en: However, for greater precaution, Herbert took the trouble, which Neb deemed superfluous, to wedge up the animal with great stones; after which the two hunters returned to Granite House, following the beach, which the tide had left uncovered.Herbert, wishing to surprise Pencroft, said nothing about the “superb specimen of a chelonian” which they had turned over on the sand; but, two hours later, he and Neb returned with the cart to the place where they had left it.The “superb specimen of a chelonian” was no longer there!

zh: 纳布和赫伯特面面相觑，接着他们又仔细看了看周围。海龟就是被留在这里的。少年甚至还找到了他刚用过的石头，因而确信没有弄错。
en: Neb and Herbert stared at each other first; then they stared about them.It was just at this spot that the turtle had been left.The lad even found the stones which he had used, and therefore he was certain of not being mistaken.

zh: “嗯！”纳布说道，“海龟自己就能翻过身来，对吧？”
en: “Well!” said Neb, “these beasts can turn themselves over, then?’’

zh: “看起来是这样。”赫伯特回答道，他盯着散落在沙子上的石头，根本无法理解这一切。
en: “It appears so,” replied Herbert, who could not understand it at all, and was gazing at the stones scattered on the sand.

zh: “哎，潘克洛夫要不开心了！”
en: “Well, Pencroft will be disgusted!”

zh: “哈丁上尉如果知道了，或许会觉得海龟的消失很困惑。”赫伯特想道。
en: “And Captain Harding will perhaps be very perplexed how to explain this disappearance,” thought Herbert.

zh: “听着，”纳布说道，他不想要别人知道这种不幸，“我们不要提起这件事了。”
en: “Look here,” said Neb, who wished to hide his ill-luck, “we won’t speak about it.”

zh: “恰恰相反，纳布，我们必须把这件事告诉大家。”赫伯特回答道。
en: “On the contrary, Neb, we must speak about it,” replied Herbert.

zh: 两人又推着没有派上用场的推车，回到了花岗石宫。
en: And the two, taking the cart, which there was now no use for, returned to Granite House.

zh: 他们走到工程师和水手在一起造船的地方，赫伯特叙述了刚才发生的事。
en: Arrived at the dockyard, where the engineer and the sailor were working together, Herbert recounted what had happened.

zh: “哎呀！两个傻瓜！”水手喊道，“就这样让至少50顿饭溜走了！”
en: “Oh! the stupids!” cried the sailor, “to have let at least fifty meals escape!”

zh: “但是，潘克洛夫，”纳布回答道，“海龟不见了不是我们的错，我告诉过你了，我们把它翻过来了啊！”
en: “But, Pencroft,” replied Neb, “it wasn’t our fault that the beast got away; as I tell you, we had turned it over on its back!”

zh: “那么你们还是翻得不够彻底！”倔强的水手说道。
en: “Then you didn’t turn it over enough!” returned the obstinate sailor.

zh: “不够彻底！”赫伯特喊道。
en: “Not enough!” cried Herbert.

zh: 他于是又讲了是如何小心地翼翼用石头把海龟挡住。
en: And he told how he had taken care to wedge up the turtle with stones.

zh: “那就奇怪了！”潘克洛夫回答说。
en: “It is a miracle, then!” replied Pencroft.

zh: “上尉，我认为，”赫伯特说道，“海龟要是四爪朝天，是翻不过身的，尤其是那种大海龟，对吗？”
en: “I thought, captain,” said Herbert, “that turtles, once placed on their backs, could not regain their feet, especially when they are of a large size?’

zh: “是的，孩子。”赛勒斯·哈丁回答道。
en: “That is true, my boy,” replied Cyrus Harding.

zh: “那它是怎么跑掉的？”
en: “Then how did it manage?”

zh: “你们放海龟的地方距离大海有多远？”工程师问道，他停下了手中的活，仔细考虑这件事情。
en: “At what distance from the sea did you leave this turtle?” asked the engineer, who, having suspended his work, was reflecting on this incident.

zh: “最多有15英尺。”赫伯特回答道。
en: “Fifteen feet at the most,” replied Herbert.

zh: “当时潮水很低吗？”
en: “And the tide was low at the time?”

zh: “是的，上尉。”
en: “Yes, captain.”

zh: “那么，”工程师回答道，“海龟在沙滩上翻不了身，或许在水里就可以了。当潮水冲到它的时候，它翻过来身，然后就静悄悄地游回深海了。”
en: “Well,” replied the engineer, “what the turtle could not do on the sand it might have been able to do in the water.It turned over when the tide overtook it, and then quietly returned to the deep sea.”

zh: “哎呀！我们真是傻瓜！”纳布喊道。
en: “Oh! what stupids we were!” cried Neb.

zh: “我刚才有幸就是这样说的！”水手回敬道。
en: “That is precisely what I had the honor of telling you before!” returned the sailor.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁作出的解释无疑是可以接受的。但是他自己相信这个解释的准确性吗？可能他不相信。
en: Cyrus Harding had given this explanation, which, no doubt, was admissible.But was he himself convinced of the accuracy of this explanation?It cannot be said that he was.

zh: 第二章
en: Chapter 2

zh: 10月9日那天，用树皮做的小舟完全造好了。潘克洛夫没有食言，在五天之内建造出了一只轻舟，舟体由克莱金巴树柔韧的枝条连结在一起而成。这只小舟长12英尺，重量不超过200磅。船首和船尾各有一个座位，船的中间也有一个座位以保持平衡，船上还有用来放置双桨的桨架以及掌舵的橹，这些就是船的全部。小舟的下水操作也极其简单。他们将小舟运到海边，放在花岗石宫前的沙滩上，涨潮的海水就使得小舟浮了起来。潘克洛夫立即跳进小舟里，用橹灵活地驾驶着，并宣称这只小舟正好可以满足他们的需要。
en: On the 9th of October the bark canoe was entirely finished.Pencroft had kept his promise, and a light boat, the shell of which was joined together by the flexible twigs of the crejimba, had been constructed in five days.A seat in the stern, a second seat in the middle to preserve the equilibrium, a third seat in the bows, rowlocks for the two oars, a scull to steer with, completed the little craft, which was twelve feet long, and did not weigh more than two hundred pounds.The operation of launching it was extremely simple.The canoe was carried to the beach and laid on the sand before Granite House, and the rising tide floated it.Pencroft, who leaped in directly, maneuvered it with the scull and declared it to be just the thing for the purpose to which they wished to put it.

zh: “哈哈！”水手高喊，他毫不避讳地炫耀自己的成功，“有了它，我们就可以环游——”
en: “Hurrah!” cried the sailor, who did not disdain to celebrate thus his own triumph.“With this we could go round—”

zh: “世界？”吉丁·史佩莱问道。
en: “The world?” asked Gideon Spilett.

zh: “不，是海岛。找一些石头做压舱物，竖一根桅杆，上尉以后为我们再做一面帆，我们就可以整装待发了！现在，上尉，还有你，史佩莱先生，还有你，赫伯特，还有你，纳布，你们不过来试试我们的新船吗？快来！我们得看一下能不能载动我们五个人！”
en: “No, the island.Some stones for ballast, a mast and a sail, which the captain will make for us some day, and we shall go splendidly!Well, captain—and you, Mr. Spilett; and you, Herbert; and you, Neb—aren’t you coming to try our new vessel?Come along! we must see if it will carry all five of us!”

zh: 这确实应当试一下。潘克洛夫立马就通过岩石间一个狭窄的通道将小舟带回岸边，当天大家一致同意应当试一试这只小船，沿着海岸，划行至第一个海角，即南边岩石的尽头处。
en: This was certainly a trial which ought to be made.Pencroft soon brought the canoe to the shore by a narrow passage among the rocks, and it was agreed that they should make a trial of the boat that day by following the shore as far as the first point at which the rocks of the south ended.

zh: 他们刚一上船，纳布就喊道：
en: As they embarked, Neb cried,—

zh: “你的船有点漏水啊，潘克洛夫。”
en: “But your boat leaks rather, Pencroft.”

zh: “没事的，纳布，”水手回答道，“木头会干的。两天后就一条裂缝都没有了，我们船里的水就会比酒鬼胃里的水还少。快跳进来！”
en: “That’s nothing, Neb,” replied the sailor; “the wood will get seasoned.In two days there won’t be a single leak, and our boat will have no more water in her than there is in the stomach of a drunkard.Jump in!”

zh: 他们很快就坐好了，然后潘克洛夫就开船了。天气很好，大海上风平浪静，海水像湖中狭窄区域中的湖水一样平静。因此。小船得以平稳地航行，就像是顺着慈悲河平静的水流划行一样。
en: They were soon all seated, and Pencroft shoved off.The weather was magnificent, the sea as calm as if its waters were contained within the narrow limits of a lake.Thus the boat could proceed with as much security as if it was ascending the tranquil current of the Mercy.

zh: 纳布和赫伯特各拿着一支桨，而潘克洛夫则留在船尾摇橹。
en: Neb took one of the oars, Herbert the other, and Pencroft remained in the stern in order to use the scull.

zh: 水手先是穿过海峡，接着就驶向小岛南部的海角。这时，一阵微风从南边吹来。但是，海峡里和碧蓝的大海上并未掀起滚滚的波涛。由于小船载重量较高，他们几乎感觉不到船下起伏的波浪，小船就在水面上平稳地划行着。他们在离海岸大约半英里的地方停了下来，在那里可以好好地欣赏富兰克林山。
en: The sailor first crossed the channel, and steered close to the southern point of the islet.A light breeze blew from the south.No roughness was found either in the channel or the green sea.A long swell, which the canoe scarcely felt, as it was heavily laden, rolled regularly over the surface of the water.They pulled out about half a mile distant from the shore, that they might have a good view of Mount Franklin.

zh: 过了一会，潘克洛夫又将小船驶回了河口。接着，小船就沿着海岸行驶，海岸一直延伸到尽头的海角，潦凫沼泽都被遮没了。
en: Pencroft afterwards returned towards the mouth of the river.The boat then skirted the shore, which, extending to the extreme point, hid all Tadorn’s Fens.

zh: 由于海岸线不规则，从慈悲河到海角的距离增加了，将近三英里。居民们决定划到海角的尽头处，如果需要，还可能再远一点，以便能够快速地观察一下远至爪角的海滨。
en: This point, of which the distance was increased by the irregularity of the coast, was nearly three miles from the Mercy.The settlers resolved to go to its extremity, and only go beyond it as much as was necessary to take a rapid survey of the coast as far as Claw Cape.

zh: 小舟曲折的海岸划行，避开暗礁，涨潮的海水已经开始淹没这些礁石。海崖从河口到海角渐渐地倾斜下来。它是由花岗石形成的，花岗石散乱地分布着，与眺望岗的峭壁有很大的不同，非常荒凉。看上去好像上面大量的岩石都被开采空了。这个陡峭的海角寸草不生，从森林里突出来两英尺远，就像是从一只枝繁叶茂的袖子里伸出来的巨人的手臂。
en: The canoe followed the windings of the shore, avoiding the rocks which fringed it, and which the rising tide began to cover.The cliff gradually sloped away from the mouth of the river to the point.This was formed of granite reeks, capriciously distributed, very different from the cliff at Prospect Heights, and of an extremely wild aspect.It might have been said that an immense cartload of rocks had been emptied out there.There was no vegetation on this sharp promontory, which projected two miles from the forest, and it thus represented a giant’s arm stretched out from a leafy sleeve.

zh: 在两只桨的划动下，小舟轻快无阻地前进着。吉丁·史佩莱一只手握着铅笔，另一只手拿着笔记本，用粗线条把海岸的轮廓勾勒了出来。纳布、赫伯特和潘克洛夫一边闲聊，一边查看着对于他们全新的这一部分领地，随着小舟往南划行，两个颚骨角似乎也动了起来，把联合湾包围地更紧了。
en: The canoe, impelled by the two oars, advanced without difficulty.Gideon Spilett, pencil in one hand and notebook in the other, sketched the coast in bold strokes.Neb, Herbert, and Pencroft chatted, while examining this part of their domain, which was new to them, and, in proportion as the canoe proceeded towards the south, the two Mandible Capes appeared to move, and surround Union Bay more closely.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁则一言不发，只是凝视着四周，表情充满疑虑，仿佛是在观察一个陌生的地方。
en: As to Cyrus Harding, he did not speak; he simply gazed, and by the mistrust which his look expressed, it appeared that he was examining some strange country.

zh: 在这段时间，小船划行了45分钟后到达了海角的尽头，潘克洛夫正准备返航的时候，赫伯特起身指着一个黑色的东西，说道：
en: In the meantime, after a voyage of three-quarters of an hour, the canoe reached the extremity of the point, and Pencroft was preparing to return, when Herbert, rising, pointed to a black object, saying,—

zh: “海滩那里是什么？”
en: “What do I see down there on the beach?”

zh: 大家都向他指的地方看过去。
en: All eyes turned towards the point indicated.

zh: “哎呀，”记者道，“那里是有个东西。像是一只沉船的残骸，有一半被埋在沙滩里了。”
en: “Why,” said the reporter, “there is something.It looks like part of a wreck half buried in the sand.”

zh: “啊！”潘克洛夫叫道，“我知道是什么了！”
en: “Ah!” cried Pencroft, “I see what it is!”

zh: “什么？”纳布问道。
en: “What?” asked Neb.

zh: “桶，桶，或许里面还装满东西了。”水手答道。
en: “Barrels, barrels, which perhaps are full,” replied the sailor.

zh: “靠岸，潘克洛夫！”赛勒斯道。
en: “Pull to the shore, Pencroft!” said Cyrus.

zh: 他们划了几下桨，把小舟驶入一条小河里，然后就跳上了岸。
en: A few strokes of the oar brought the canoe into a little creek, and its passengers leaped on shore.

zh: 潘克洛夫说得没错。那里果然有两只桶，半截埋在沙里，和一只大箱子紧紧地拴在一起，在搁浅之前曾借助桶的浮力支撑漂浮在水面上。
en: Pencroft was not mistaken.Two barrels were there, half buried in the sand, but still firmly attached to a large chest, which, sustained by them, had floated to the moment when it stranded on the beach.

zh: “那说明一只船在小岛的某个地方遇难了。”赫伯特说道。
en: “There has been a wreck, then, in some part of the island,” said Herbert.

zh: “很明显。”史佩莱回答道。
en: “Evidently,” replied Spilett.

zh: “但是箱子里是什么呢？”潘克洛夫大叫，像往常一样焦躁不安。“箱子里是什么？箱子锁着，没办法打开啊！嗯，或许可以用石头。”
en: “But what’s in this chest?” cried Pencroft, with very natural impatience.“What’s in this chest?It is shut up, and nothing to open it with!Well, perhaps a stone—”

zh: 接着，水手就举起了一块重重的石头，正要准备朝箱子的一边砸去，工程师一把抓住了他的手。
en: And the sailor, raising a heavy block, was about to break in one of the sides of the chest, when the engineer arrested his hand.

zh: “潘克洛夫，”他说道，“你能再忍耐一个小时吗？”
en: “Pencroft,” said he, “can you restrain your impatience for one hour only?”

zh: “但是，上尉，想想吧！或许里面有我们想要的所有东西呢！”
en: “But, captain, just think!Perhaps there is everything we want in there!”

zh: “我们一会儿会弄明白的，潘克洛夫，”工程师回答道，“但是相信我，不要砸坏这只箱子，这或许会对我们有用。我们必须把它运回花岗石宫，在那里我们可以轻易地把它打开，并且不会损坏它。这只箱子完全可以被带回去,既然它能漂到这里，应该也可以漂回河口。”
en: “We shall find that out, Pencroft,” replied the engineer; “but trust to me, and do not break the chest, which may be useful to us.We must convey it to Granite House, where we can open it easily, and without breaking it.It is quite prepared for a voyage; and since it has floated here, it may just as well float to the mouth of the river.”

zh: “你说得对,上尉，我又错了。”水手答道。
en: “You are right, captain, and I was wrong, as usual,” replied the sailor.

zh: 工程师的建议很正确。事实上，小舟可能载不动箱子里或许会有的东西，因为箱子需要借助两个空桶才能浮起来，它无疑是很重的。因而通过水的浮力把它拖回到花岗石宫前的海滩上，不失为一个更好的办法。
en: The engineer’s advice was good.In fact, the canoe probably would not have been able to contain the articles possibly enclosed in the chest, which doubtless was heavy, since two empty barrels were required to buoy it up.It was, therefore, much better to tow it to the beach at Granite House.

zh: 那么现在的问题是，这只箱子是从哪里来的呢？这个问题很重要。赛勒斯·哈丁和同伴们仔细地看了看周围，又查看了几百步外的海岸，并没有发现失事船只的其他物品或是碎片。赫伯特和纳布爬上一块高高的岩石，向海上望过去，但是什么也没有，既没有折断桅杆的大船，也没有扬帆的航船。
en: And now, whence had this chest come?That was the important question.Cyrus Harding and his companions looked attentively around them, and examined the shore for several hundred steps.No other articles or pieces of wreck could be found.Herbert and Neb climbed a high rock to survey the sea, but there was nothing in sight—neither a dismasted vessel nor a ship under sail.

zh: 但是，确定无疑的是有船只失事。或许这件事和子弹有联系？或许是有陌生人在小岛的其他什么地方登陆了？或许他们仍旧居住在那里？但是居民们不约而同都想到的一点，这些陌生人不可能是马来海盗，因为箱子很明显是美国或欧洲制造的。
en: However, there was no doubt that there had been a wreck.Perhaps this incident was connected with that of the bullet?Perhaps strangers had landed on another part of the island?Perhaps they were still there?But the thought which came naturally to the settlers was, that these strangers could not be Malay pirates, for the chest was evidently of American or European make.

zh: 大家都回到箱子旁，它异乎寻常地大。箱子是橡木做的，盖子紧紧地合着，外面用厚厚的皮革裹着，并且还用了铜钉加固。两只大桶也密封着，但是听起来，桶是空心的，并且里面没有东西。这两只桶被粗绳子绑到箱子的两边，绳结系的很有技巧，潘克洛夫一看就说这只有水手能做。箱子看起来保存得很完好，因为它是在沙滩上搁浅的，而不是在礁石堆中。不管怎样，他们经过仔细查看可以确定，这只箱子并没有在水里漂流很久，应该是最近才浮到这个海岸上来的。看上去箱子里面并没有进水，里面的东西也无疑是完好无损的。
en: All the party returned to the chest, which was of an unusually large size.It was made of oak wood, very carefully closed and covered with a thick hide, which was secured by copper nails.The two great barrels, hermetically sealed, but which sounded hollow and empty, were fastened to its sides by strong ropes, knotted with a skill which Pencroft directly pronounced sailors alone could exhibit.It appeared to be in a perfect state of preservation, which was explained by the fact that it had stranded on a sandy beach, and not among rocks.They had no doubt whatever, on examining it carefully, that it had not been long in the water, and that its arrival on this coast was recent.The water did not appear to have penetrated to the inside, and the articles which it contained were no doubt uninjured.

zh: 很明显，一只断了桅杆的船在靠近这座小岛时，抛出来了这只箱子。船上的人小心翼翼地用这种漂浮装置使箱子在水中可以浮起来，希望它能漂到陆地上，他们稍后可以找回它。
en: It was evident that this chest had been thrown overboard from some dismasted vessel driven towards the island, and that, in the hope that it would reach the land, where they might afterwards find it, the passengers had taken the precaution to buoy it up by means of this floating apparatus.

zh: “我们一会儿就把这只箱子拖回花岗石宫，”工程师道，“回去后，我们可以清点一下里面的东西，如果我们找到可能失事的船只上的生还者，我们就把箱子还给他们。如果找不到人。”
en: “We will tow this chest to Granite House,” said the engineer, “where we can make an inventory of its contents; then, if we discover any of the survivors from the supposed wreck, we can return it to those to whom it belongs.If we find no one—”

zh: “那我们就自己留着！”潘克洛夫喊道，“但是里面究竟会有什么？”
en: “We will keep it for ourselves!” cried Pencroft.“But what in the world can there be in it?”

zh: 海水已经拍打到这个箱子了，上涨的潮水无疑会使这个箱子浮起来。他们解开了绑在桶上的一部分绳子，把当作锚链把漂浮装置和小舟系到一起。接着，潘克洛夫和纳布用桨把箱子周围的沙土挖开，方便箱子移动，小船拖着箱子很快就从这个海角拐了回去，他们把这个海角叫做“遗物角”。
en: The sea was already approaching the chest, and the high tide would evidently float it.One of the ropes which fastened the barrels was partly unlashed and used as a cable to unite the floating apparatus with the canoe.Pencroft and Neb then dug away the sand with their oars, so as to facilitate the moving of the chest, towing which the boat soon began to double the point, to which the name of Flotsam Point was given.

zh: 箱子很重，在两只桶的作用下，勉强可以浮出水面。水手也时刻担心，绳结如果松开了，箱子就会沉入海底。但很幸运，他担心的事情并没有发生，他们出发后航行了一个半小时，这段时间里他们都用在划行三英里上，小船就在花岗石宫下面的海岸边了。
en: The chest was heavy, and the barrels were scarcely sufficient to keep it above water.The sailor also feared every instant that it would get loose and sink to the bottom of the sea.But happily his fears were not realized, and an hour and a half after they set out—all that time had been taken up in going a distance of three miles—the boat touched the beach below Granite House.

zh: 他们把小舟和箱子拉到沙滩上，当时正值退潮，他们所处的位置就相对较高并且很干爽。纳布则匆匆跑回家，取来一些打开箱子的工具，以尽可能把损害程度降低到最小，然后他们就可以开始清点里面的东西了。潘克洛夫则丝毫不掩饰他极度兴奋的心情。
en: Canoe and chest were then hauled up on the sands; and as the tide was then going out, they were soon left high and dry.Neb, hurrying home, brought back some tools with which to open the chest in such a way that it might be injured as little as possible, and they proceeded to its inventory.Pencroft did not try to hide that he was greatly excited.

zh: 水手首先把两只桶卸了下来，它们还很完好，以后肯定派得上用场。然后水手就用冷凿和锤子强行把锁打开，盖子翻开了。箱子内壁还附有一层锌皮，这样设置很明显是为了防止里面的东西受潮。
en: The sailor began by detaching the two barrels, which, being in good condition, would of course be of use.Then the locks were forced with a cold chisel and hammer, and the lid thrown back.A second casing of zinc lined the interior of the chest, which had been evidently arranged that the articles which it enclosed might under any circumstances be sheltered from damp.

zh: “哦！”纳布叫道，“希望是果酱！”
en: “Oh!” cried Neb, “suppose it’s jam!

zh: “我倒希望不是。”记者回答道。
en: “I hope not,” replied the reporter.

zh: “如果是——”水手小声说道。
en: “If only there was—” said the sailor in a low voice.

zh: 纳布无意中听到了，就问：“什么？”
en: “What?” asked Neb, who overheard him.

zh: “没有什么！”
en: “Nothing!”

zh: 他们把锌皮撕掉，扔到箱子的一边，依次从中拿出大量各种各样的东西，散放到沙滩上。每拿出一样新东西，潘克洛夫都会欢呼雀跃，赫伯特则在一边拍手，纳布也高兴地手舞足蹈。里面有几本书，赫伯特看到之后欣喜若狂，而纳布则拿着箱子里面的厨具狂吻了起来！
en: The covering of zinc was torn off and thrown back over the sides of the chest, and by degrees numerous articles of very varied character were produced and strewn about on the sand.At each new object Pencroft uttered fresh hurrahs, Herbert clapped his hands, and Neb danced up and down.There were books which made Herbert wild with joy, and cooking utensils which Neb covered with kisses!

zh: 简而言之，拓荒者们非常满意，因为这只箱子里面工具、武器、仪器、衣服、书籍应有尽有。下面就是吉丁·史佩莱在笔记本中列出的清单：
en: In short, the colonists had reason to be extremely satisfied, for this chest contained tools, weapons, instruments, clothes, books; and this is the exact list of them as stated in Gideon Spilett’s note-book:

zh: 工具：三把多刃小刀、两把砍柴的斧头、两把木匠用的短柄小斧头、三个刨子、两个锛子、一把镰刀或鹤嘴锄、六只凿子、两把锉刀、三把锤子、三把螺丝锥、两把螺丝钻、十袋钉子和螺丝、三把不同尺寸的锯子、两盒针。
en: —Tools:—3 knives with several blades, 2 woodmen’s axes, 2 carpenter’s hatchets, 3 planes, 2 adzes, 1 twibil or mattock, 6 chisels, 2 files, 3 hammers, 3 gimlets, 2 augers, 10 bags of nails and screws, 3 saws of different sizes, 2 boxes of needles.

zh: 武器：两只燧火枪、两根雷管、两支后膛卡宾枪、五柄木制短剑、四把军刀、两桶火药（每桶有25磅重）、14盒雷管。
en: Weapons:—2 flint-lock guns, 2 for percussion caps, 2 breach-loader carbines, 5 boarding cutlasses, 4 sabers, 2 barrels of powder, each containing twenty-five pounds; 12 boxes of percussion caps.

zh: 仪器：一个六分仪，一副双筒望远镜，一副单筒望远镜，一盒数学仪器，一个水手指南针，一只华氏温度计，一只无液气压机，一只装有照相器材、物镜、感光板和化学品等的盒子。
en: Instruments:—1 sextant, 1 double opera-glass, 1 telescope, 1 box of mathematical instruments, 1 mariner’s compass, 1 Fahrenheit thermometer, 1 aneroid barometer, 1 box containing a photographic apparatus, object-glass, plates, chemicals, etc.

zh: 衣服：两打衬衫，材质很特别，类似羊毛，但实际上是植物纤维；三打同样材质的袜子。
en: Clothes:—2 dozen shirts of a peculiar material resembling wool, but evidently of a vegetable origin; 3 dozen stockings of the same material.

zh: 器皿：一只铁罐、六只铜制炖锅、三只铁盘、十件金属餐具、两只水壶、一只便携式火炉、六把餐刀。
en: Utensils:—1 iron pot, 6 copper saucepans, 3 iron dishes, 10 metal plates, 2 kettles, 1 portable stove, 6 table-knives,

zh: 书籍：一本《圣经》、一本地图册、一本有不同波利尼西亚习语的词典、一本自然科学词典（共六册）、三令白纸、两本空白的簿册。
en: Books:—1 Bible, 1 atlas, 1 dictionary of the different Polynesian idioms, 1 dictionary of natural science, in six volumes; 3 reams of white paper, 2 books with blank pages.

zh: “依我看来，”记者在清点完所有的物品后说道，“这个箱子的主人十分讲究实际！工具、武器、仪器、衣服、器皿、书籍应有尽有！或许真的可以这样讲，他预料到会出事，而且事先已经准备好了。”
en: “It must be allowed,” said the reporter, after the inventory had been made, “that the owner of this chest was a practical man!Tools, weapons, instruments, clothes, utensils, books—nothing is wanting!It might really be said that he expected to be wrecked, and had prepared for it beforehand.”

zh: “确实是应有尽有。”赛勒斯·哈丁满腹心事地咕哝道。
en: “Nothing is wanting, indeed,” murmured Cyrus Harding thoughtfully.

zh: “我们可以肯定的是，”赫伯特补充道，“盛载这只箱子的船只不是马来西亚海盗的！”
en: “And for a certainty,” added Herbert, “the vessel which carried this chest and its owner was not a Malay pirate!”

zh: “除非，”潘克洛夫说道，“船的主人已经被海盗抓走了。”
en: “Unless,” said Pencroft, “the owner had been taken prisoner by pirates—”

zh: “那是不可能的，”记者回答道，“更大的可能是，一艘来自美国或欧洲的船只行驶到被迫进入这片区域，船上的乘客希望至少保留一些必需品，就准备了这只箱子，又把它抛下了水。”
en: “That is not admissible,” replied the reporter.“It is more probable that an American or European vessel has been driven into this quarter, and that her passengers, wishing to save necessaries at least, prepared this chest and threw it overboard.”

zh: “你是这样的看法吗，上尉？”赫伯特问道。
en: “Is that your opinion, captain?” asked Herbert.

zh: “是的，孩子，”工程师回答道，“事情或许就是这样的。可能失事的时候，或是他们预料到会出事的时候，把各种最有用的物品收集到这只箱子里，希望以后可以在岸上找到它。”
en: “Yes, my boy,” replied the engineer, “that may have been the case.It is possible that at the moment, or in expectation of a wreck, they collected into this chest different articles of the greatest use in hopes of finding it again on the coast—”

zh: “甚至包括照相器材！”水手喊道，他并不信服。
en: “Even the photographic box!” exclaimed the sailor incredulously.

zh: “至于那套器材，”哈丁回答道，“我不是很明白它有什么用，对于我们以及其他落难者来说，更加充足的衣物或是大量的弹药才是更有价值的啊！”
en: “As to that apparatus,” replied Harding, “I do not quite see the use of it; and a more complete supply of clothes or more abundant ammunition would have been more valuable to us as well as to any other castaways!”

zh: “这些仪器、工具或是书籍上有没有什么记号或是指示，能给我们说明这一点？”吉丁·史佩莱问道。
en: “But isn’t there any mark or direction on these instruments, tools, or books, which would tell us something about them?” asked Gideon Spilett.

zh: 这点可以证实一下。他们仔细查看了每件物品，尤其是书籍、仪器和武器。与一般的武器和仪器不同，这些都没有标明制造商。而且，这些武器和仪器都保存得十分完好，看起来像是从未用过的。工具和器皿也是一样，所有的都是崭新的，这就说明这些东西并不是被随机选中，然后扔进箱子里的。相反，这些东西是经过精挑细选，小心放置的。箱子里面防潮的锌皮层也可以说明这一点，这层锌皮是不可能在匆忙之中焊接好的。
en: That might be ascertained.Each article was carefully examined, especially the books, instruments and weapons.Neither the weapons nor the instruments, contrary to the usual custom, bore the name of the maker; they were, besides, in a perfect state, and did not appear to have been used.The same peculiarity marked the tools and utensils; all were new, which proved that the articles had not been taken by chance and thrown into the chest, but, on the contrary, that the choice of things had been well considered and arranged with care.This was also indicated by the second case of metal which had preserved them from damp, and which could not have been soldered in a moment of haste.

zh: 自然科学和波利尼西亚习语词典都是英文的，但是上面既没有出版商的名字，也没有出版日期。
en: As to the dictionaries of natural science and Polynesian idioms, both were English; but they neither bore the name of the publisher nor the date of publication.

zh: 圣经也是英文版的，四开本，印刷精美，并且看上去像是被经常翻阅的。
en: The same with the Bible printed in English, in quarto, remarkable from a typographic point of view, and which appeared to have been often used.

zh: 那本地图册也绘制得非常精细，收集了世界各国的地图，还有几幅根据墨卡托投影法绘制的平面球形图，地图上的名称都是用法语标注的，但是上面也没有出版日期以及出版商的名字。
en: The atlas was a magnificent work, comprising maps of every country in the world, and several planispheres arranged upon Mercator’s projection, and of which the nomenclature was in French—but which also bore neither date nor name of publisher.

zh: 因而，在这些他们可以寻找蛛丝马迹的不同物品中，无法查到什么。所以，也没有什么东西可以说明这艘船只是哪个国家的，而这艘船最近一定是到过这片海岸。
en: There was nothing, therefore, on these different articles by which they could be traced, and nothing consequently of a nature to show the nationality of the vessel which must have recently passed these shores.

zh: 但是，无论这只箱子来自哪里，对于林肯岛上的居民们来说，都是一笔财富。那时候，他们已经利用自然物产为自己创造出了所需要的一切，而且多亏了他们的聪明才智，他们顺利完成了所有的工作。这看起来难道不像是上天的奖赏吗？为他们送来了这些人类工业产品。他们一致感谢上天。
en: But, wherever the chest might have come from, it was a treasure to the settlers on Lincoln Island.Till then, by making use of the productions of nature, they had created everything for themselves, and, thanks to their intelligence, they had managed without difficulty.But did it not appear as if Providence had wished to reward them by sending them these productions of human industry?Their thanks rose unanimously to Heaven.

zh: 但是，他们中还有一个人不是很满足，那就是潘克洛夫。看来，箱子里面没有潘克洛夫明显认为重要的东西，因为他们翻到箱底的时候，潘克洛夫的欢呼声也渐渐没了热情。而且，他们清点完所有的东西时，听见潘克洛夫咕哝道：“这很好，但是你们看，箱子里没有我要的东西！”
en: However, one of them was not quite satisfied: it was Pencroft.It appeared that the chest did not contain something which he evidently held in great esteem, for in proportion as they approached the bottom of the box, his hurrahs diminished in heartiness, and, the inventory finished, he was heard to mutter these words:—“That’s all very fine, but you can see that there is nothing for me in that box!”

zh: 纳布听到了问道：
en: This led Neb to say,—

zh: “怎么了，潘克洛夫，你还想要什么？”
en: “Why, friend Pencroft, what more do you expect?”

zh: “半磅烟草，”潘克洛夫认真地回答道，“没有东西能比它使我心满意足了！”
en: “Half a pound of tobacco,” replied Pencroft seriously, “and nothing would have been wanting to complete my happiness!”

zh: 大家听后都禁不住笑了起来。
en: No one could help laughing at this speech of the sailor’s.

zh: 但是，这只箱子的出现也说明，现在该对这个小岛进行一次彻查了，这比以往任何时候都显得必要。因而，他们商量好第二天早上破晓时分出发，沿着慈悲河溯流而上，为了到达西海岸。他们担心，如果真的有落难者登陆，他们可能会缺少物资，因而非常有必要及时过去提供帮助。
en: But the result of this discovery of the chest was, that it was now more than ever necessary to explore the island thoroughly.It was therefore agreed that the next morning at break of day, they should set out, by ascending the Mercy so as to reach the western shore.If any castaways had landed on the coast, it was to be feared they were without resources, and it was therefore the more necessary to carry help to them without delay.

zh: 天黑之前，他们已经把不同物品搬回了花岗石宫，并整整齐齐地摆放在大厅里。那天是10月29日，正好是一个星期天。临睡前，郝伯特问工程师能否给他们念一段福音书。
en: During the day the different articles were carried to Granite House, where they were methodically arranged in the great hall.This day—the 29th of October—happened to be a Sunday, and, before going to bed, Herbert asked the engineer if he would not read them something from the Gospel.

zh: “很乐意啊！”赛勒斯·哈丁回答道。
en: “Willingly,” replied Cyrus Harding.

zh: 他拿起这本神圣的书，正要打开，潘克洛夫阻止了他，说道：“上尉，我有点迷信。随便翻开哪一页，念出来你看到的第一节文字。我们看看是不是跟我们的处境吻合。”
en: He took the sacred volume, and was about to open it, when Pencroft stopped him, saying,—“Captain, I am superstitious.Open at random and read the first verse which, your eye falls upon.We will see if it applies to our situation.”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁听了水手的建议，不禁微笑起来，但还是依着水手的意思，他打开了正好是夹有书签的那一页。
en: Cyrus Harding smiled at the sailor’s idea, and, yielding to his wish, he opened exactly at a place where the leaves were separated by a marker.

zh: 他立刻就注意到一个铅笔画的十字，它的位置是马太福音第七章第八节。他就念了出来，句子是这样的：
en: Immediately his eyes were attracted by a cross which, made with a pencil, was placed against the eighth verse of the seventh chapter of the Gospel of St. Matthew.He read the verse, which was this:—

zh: “请求者都能如愿以偿，寻找者都能有所收获。”
en: “For every one that asketh receiveth; and he that seeketh findeth.”

zh: 第三章
en: Chapter 3

zh: 第二天，是10月30日，大家都准备好已筹划的探险活动了，最近发生的一些事情使得这次探险极为必要。事实上，事情发展到现在，林肯岛上的居民已经不再需要帮助了，他们甚至有能力去帮助别人了。
en: The next day, the 30th of October, all was ready for the proposed exploring expedition, which recent events had rendered so necessary.In fact, things had so come about that the settlers in Lincoln Island no longer needed help for themselves, but were even able to carry it to others.

zh: 因而，他们商定沿着慈悲河溯流而上，能划多远就划多远。这样探险者们就能轻松地走完一大段路程，并且可以把他们的食品和武器运送到小岛西部的高地上。
en: It was therefore agreed that they should ascend the Mercy as far as the river was navigable.A great part of the distance would thus be traversed without fatigue, and the explorers could transport their provisions and arms to an advanced point in the west of the island.

zh: 他们不仅需要考虑应当带过去的东西，而且还需要考虑有可能要带回花岗石宫的东西。如果真如他们预料的那样，海岸曾有过失事的船只，那么，船上遗留下来的许多东西就会成为他们合法的战利品。在这种情况下，手推车就比轻舟有用多了，但是手推车十分笨重，不方便拖过去，因而也就更难使用了。潘克洛夫感到很遗憾，箱子里除了没有“他的半磅烟草”，另外还缺少两匹新泽西马，那对拓荒地来说用处多大啊！
en: It was necessary to think not only of the things which they should take with them, but also of those which they might have by chance to bring back to Granite House.If there had been a wreck on the coast, as was supposed, there would be many things cast up, which would be lawfully their prizes.In the event of this, the cart would have been of more use than the light canoe, but it was heavy and clumsy to drag, and therefore more difficult to use; this led Pencroft to express his regret that the chest had not contained, besides “his halfpound of tobacco,” a pair of strong New Jersey horses, which would have been very useful to the colony!

zh: 纳布已经包好了食物，有大块的肉，还有几加仑啤酒，也就是说，这足够他们吃三天了，而这正是哈丁预计探险活动所需要的时间。此外，他们还希望路上能够再猎获一些食物，纳布还特意带上了便携式火炉。
en: The provisions, which Neb had already packed up, consisted of a store of meat and of several gallons of beer, that is to say enough to sustain them for three days, the time which Harding assigned for the expedition.They hoped besides to supply themselves on the road, and Neb took care not to forget the portable stove.

zh: 居民们携带的工具只有两把砍柴斧，可以用它们在茂密的丛林里砍出一条道来，他们带的仪器有望远镜和袖珍罗盘。
en: The only tools the settlers took were the two woodmen’s axes, which they could use to cut a path through the thick forests, as also the instruments, the telescope and pocket-compass.

zh: 至于武器，他们选了两只燧发枪，这可能要比撞针枪对他们更有用。因为燧发枪只需要打火石，这很容易找到；而撞针枪则需要用雷管，如果经常使用，他们有限的几根雷管很快就会用完的。此外，他们还带了一支卡宾枪和一些子弹。至于火药，桶里大约有50磅，他们需要带上一小部分，但是工程师希望可以自己制造出一种炸药，这样他们就能节省一些火药了。除了火器外，他们还带了五把配有精致皮鞘的弯刀，现在一切都准备好了，居民们就可以抱着几分胜算在广袤的森林里进行探险了。
en: For weapons they selected the two flint-lock guns, which were likely to be more useful to them than the percussion fowling-pieces, the first only requiring flints which could be easily replaced, and the latter needing fulminating caps, a frequent use of which would soon exhaust their limited stock.However, they took also one of the carbines and some cartridges.As to the powder, of which there was about fifty pounds in the barrel, a small supply of it had to be taken, but the engineer hoped to manufacture an explosive substance which would allow them to husband it.To the firearms were added the five cutlasses well sheathed in leather, and, thus supplied, the settlers could venture into the vast forest with some chance of success.

zh: 潘克洛夫、赫伯特和纳布自不用说，他们有了这样的装备，高兴至极，虽然他们已经向赛勒斯·哈丁承诺过，除非万不得已，否则不会开枪。
en: It is useless to add that Pencroft, Herbert, and Neb, thus armed, were at the summit of their happiness, although Cyrus Harding made them promise not to fire a shot unless it was necessary.

zh: 早上六点的时候，小舟就从海岸启航了，所有人都上了船，包括托普，他们向慈悲河口划去。
en: At six in the morning the canoe put off from the shore; all had embarked, including Top, and they proceeded to the mouth of the Mercy.

zh: 半个小时之前，海水就已经开始上涨了。因此，再过几个小时，就会出现水流，小舟正好可以顺势而上，而等到退潮的时候，小舟溯流而上就有些困难了。潮水已经变得迅猛，而再过三天就是月圆之日，这足以使小船漂浮在水流的中心。小船就在高高的河岸之间快速前进，并且不需要划桨来加快速度。几分钟后，探险者们来到慈悲河形成的的一个拐角处，七个月前，潘克洛夫曾在这里建造了他的第一只木筏。
en: The tide had begun to come up half an hour before.For several hours, therefore, there would be a current, which it was well to profit by, for later the ebb would make it difficult to ascend the river.The tide was already strong, for in three days the moon would be full, and it was enough to keep the boat in the center of the current, where it floated swiftly along between the high banks without its being necessary to increase its speed by the aid of the oars.In a few minutes the explorers arrived at the angle formed by the Mercy and exactly at the place where, seven months before, Pencroft had made his first raft of wood.

zh: 转过这个突出的拐角之后，河面变宽了，岸边有高大的常绿枞树，河水在它们的树荫下流动。
en: After this sudden angle the river widened and flowed under the shade of great evergreen firs.

zh: 岸边的景色秀丽壮观。赛勒斯·哈丁和伙伴们不由得赞叹大自然用流水和树木轻易营造出的这一派可爱的景象。随着他们不断往前划行，森林渐渐消失在身后了。河的右岸生长着一些秀丽的榆树科树木，这些珍贵的榆树对于建筑师是很有用的，在流水的冲刷下，它们也岿然不动。河岸上还有许多植物，属于同一科目，其中有一种很特别，它的果实可以用来制作一种非常有用的油。往前再划行了一阵后，赫伯特注意到一种木通科植物，那是一种缠绕灌木，在水里浸泡之后可以制成结实的缆绳，此外还有两三棵美丽的黑檀树，上面各种花纹缠绕。
en: The aspect of the banks was magnificent.Cyrus Harding and his companions could not but admire the lovely effects so easily produced by nature with water and trees.As they advanced the forest element diminished.On the right bank of the river grew magnificent specimens of the ulmaceae tribe, the precious elm, so valuable to builders, and which withstands well the action of water.Then there were numerous groups belonging to the same family, among others one in particular, the fruit of which produces a very useful oil.Further on, Herbert remarked the lardizabala, a twining shrub which, when bruised in water, furnishes excellent cordage; and two or three ebony trees of a beautiful black, crossed with capricious veins.

zh: 小舟时不时地会在方便靠岸的地方停下，然后吉丁·史佩莱、赫伯特和潘克洛夫拿上枪，跟着托普跳上岸去。他们并没有想捕获猎物，而是发现了一些有用的植物。少年博物学家发现了一种野生的藜科菠菜，还有许多属于卷心菜一类的十字花科植物，植物完全可以移植培养，他感到非常开心。此外，还有水芹、辣根、萝卜，以及一些不足三英尺高的草茎植物，毛茸茸的茎上结着褐色的种籽。
en: From time to time, in certain places where the landing was easy, the canoe was stopped, when Gideon Spilett, Herbert, and Pencroft, their guns in their hands, and preceded by Top, jumped on shore.Without expecting game, some useful plant might be met with, and the young naturalist was delighted with discovering a sort of wild spinach, belonging to the order of chenopodiaceae, and numerous specimens of cruciferae, belonging to the cabbage tribe, which it would certainly be possible to cultivate by transplanting.There were cresses, horseradish, turnips, and lastly, little branching hairy stalks, scarcely more than three feet high, which produced brownish grains.

zh: “你这道这是什么吗？”赫伯特问水手。
en: Do you know what this plant is?” asked Herbert of the sailor.

zh: “烟草！”潘克洛夫喊道，他最喜欢的这种植物，他显然是从未见过在他烟斗之外的。
en: “Tobacco!” cried Pencroft, who evidently had never seen his favorite plant except in the bowl of his pipe.

zh: “不是，潘克洛夫，”赫伯特回答道，“这不是烟草，是芥菜。”
en: “No, Pencroft,” replied Herbert; “this is not tobacco, it is mustard.”

zh: “去它的什么芥菜！”水手回答道，“但是如果你碰巧发现了烟草，孩子，一定不能错过！”
en: “Mustard be hanged!” returned the sailor; “but if by chance you happen to come across a tobacco-plant, my boy, pray don’t scorn that!”

zh: “我们总有一天会找到的！”吉丁·史佩莱说道。
en: “We shall find it some day!” said Gideon Spilett.

zh: “好啊！”潘克洛夫喊道，“如果真有那么一天，我真不知道我们小岛上还缺什么了！”
en: “Well!” exclaimed Pencroft, “when that day comes, I do not know what more will be wanting in our island!”

zh: 他们小心翼翼地把各种不同的植物连根拔起，带到小舟上，赛勒斯·哈丁仍然在沉思。
en: These different plants, which had been carefully rooted up, were carried to the canoe, where Cyrus Harding had remained buried in thought.

zh: 记者、赫伯特和潘克洛夫就这样不停地下船上岸，有时是慈悲河的右岸，有时是左岸。
en: The reporter, Herbert, and Pencroft in this manner frequently disembarked, sometimes on the right bank, sometimes on the left bank of the Mercy.

zh: 慈悲河的左岸相对没那么陡峭，但右岸的树木更加茂密。工程师看过袖珍罗盘之后，确信河流在第一个拐角处之后明显是西南－东北走向，而且有三英里长的距离几乎都是笔直的。然而在这个拐角之后，方向似乎是改变了，慈悲河继续向西北方向延伸过去，直到富兰克林山的支脉，那是河流的源头。
en: The latter was less abrupt, but the former more wooded.The engineer ascertained by consulting his pocket-compass that the direction of the river from the first turn was obviously southwest and northeast, and nearly straight for a length of about three miles.But it was to be supposed that this direction changed beyond that point, and that the Mercy continued to the north-west, towards the spurs of Mount Franklin, among which the river rose.

zh: 有一次在岸上活动的时，吉丁·史佩莱设法活捉了四只鹑鸡。这种鸟有着长而薄的喙，细长的脖颈，短短的翅膀，而且没有尾巴。赫伯特把他们称之为鹌鹑，这很准确。他们决定把这些鹌鹑带回去，使它们成为未来家禽场上的第一批居住者。
en: During one of these excursions, Gideon Spilett managed to get hold of two couples of living gallinaceae.They were birds with long, thin beaks, lengthened necks, short wings, and without any appearance of a tail.Herbert rightly gave them the name of tinamous, and it was resolved that they should be the first tenants of their future poultry-yard.

zh: 但是直到那时，他们还没有开过枪。第一声回荡在远西森林里的枪声，是由一只美丽的小鸟引起的，它像是翠鸟。
en: But till then the guns had not spoken, and the first report which awoke the echoes of the forest of the Far West was provoked by the appearance of a beautiful bird, resembling the kingfisher.

zh: “我认识这只鸟！”潘克洛夫喊道，他的枪似乎走火了。
en: “I recognize him!” cried Pencroft, and it seemed as if his gun went off by itself.

zh: “你认识什么？”记者问道。
en: “What do you recognize?” asked the reporter.

zh: “我们第一次打猎的时候，这只鸟逃掉了，而且我们是用它的名字为那部分森林命名的。”
en: “The bird which escaped us on our first excursion, and from which we gave the name to that part of the forest.”

zh: “啄木鸟！”赫伯特喊道。
en: “A jacamar!” cried Herbert.

zh: 它确实是一只啄木鸟，羽毛闪着金属的光泽。一声枪响，小鸟掉落在地上，托普把它衔起来带回到小舟上。同时，还有六只猩猩鹦鹉也被打落到地上了。这些猩猩鹦鹉大小跟鸽子差不多，羽毛中掺杂着绿色，部分翅膀是深红色的，冠毛有道白边。这枪是少年打的，他感到很自豪。相对于啄木鸟，鹦鹉更适合作为食物，因为啄木鸟肉质比较糙。但是，要劝潘克洛夫相信，他打到的不是最好吃的鸟，是困难的一件事。上午十点的时候，小舟划到慈悲河的第二个拐角处，离河口处约有五英里。他们就在这停了下来，在大树的荫凉下吃早餐。此处河流的宽度仍有60到70英尺，河床有五到六英尺深。工程师观察了一下，注意到这里有许多支流，但是却不能通航，因为它们都不过是些小溪流。至于森林，包括啄木鸟林和远西森林，都是一望无际。无论是在森林深处还是慈悲河岸的树下，都没有出现人的踪迹。探险者们还没有发现一处可疑的踪迹。很明显，这些树木并没有被砍柴斧动过，而在缠绕的灌木丛的树干上和长草中间盘绕的树藤，也没有被开荒者的刀劈开。如果落难者已经在小岛上登陆了，他们不可能已经离开海岸，而在树林里又找不到假定的失事船只中的生还者。
