en: It was indeed a jacamar, of which the plumage shines with a metallic luster.A shot brought it to the ground, and Top carried it to the canoe.At the same time half a dozen lories were brought down.The lory is of the size of a pigeon, the plumage dashed with green, part of the wings crimson, and its crest bordered with white.To the young boy belonged the honor of this shot, and he was proud enough of it.Lories are better food than the jacamar, the flesh of which is rather tough, but it was difficult to persuade Pencroft that he had not killed the king of eatable birds.It was ten o’clock in the morning when the canoe reached a second angle of the Mercy, nearly five miles from its mouth.Here a halt was made for breakfast under the shade of some splendid trees.The river still measured from sixty to seventy feet in breadth, and its bed from five to six feet in depth.The engineer had observed that it was increased by numerous affluents, but they were unnavigable, being simply little streams.As to the forest, including Jacamar Wood, as well as the forests of the Far West, it extended as far as the eye could reach.In no place, either in the depths of the forests or under the trees on the banks of the Mercy, was the presence of man revealed.The explorers could not discover one suspicious trace.It was evident that the woodman’s axe had never touched these trees, that the pioneer’s knife had never severed the creepers hanging from one trunk to another in the midst of tangled brushwood and long grass.If castaways had landed on the island, they could not have yet quitted the shore, and it was not in the woods that the survivors of the supposed shipwreck should be sought.

zh: 因而，工程师迫切地想要到林肯岛的西海岸去，据他估计，至少还有五英里远。
en: The engineer therefore manifested some impatience to reach the western coast of Lincoln Island, which was at least five miles distant according to his estimation.

zh: 他们继续航行，慈悲河似乎不是朝着海岸流动，而是向富兰克林山流去，他们决定，只要船底有足够的水让它漂浮，就会一直乘船前行的。因为这样既可以节省体力也可以节省时间，否则，他们就不得不用斧子在密密的丛林间开辟出一条道路来。但是不久，潮水就完全不起作用了。不知是因为潮水在下降——现在已经到了退潮的时间了，还是离慈悲河口的这段距离，感觉不到潮水的作用了。因而，他们不得不划桨前行。郝伯特和纳布各拿过一支桨，潘克洛夫则在一旁摇橹。很快，森林变得越来越稀疏，树木之间的距离也越来越远，通常树是孤零零地立着。但是树木之间的距离越远，它们看起来也越好，这要得益于周围自由流通的纯净空气。
en: The voyage was continued, and as the Mercy appeared to flow not towards the shore, but rather towards Mount Franklin, it was decided that they should use the boat as long as there was enough water under its keel to float it.It was both fatigue spared and time gained, for they would have been obliged to cut a path through the thick wood with their axes.But soon the flow completely failed them, either the tide was going down, and it was about the hour, or it could no longer be felt at this distance from the mouth of the Mercy.They had therefore to make use of the oars.Herbert and Neb each took one, and Pencroft took the scull.The forest soon became less dense, the trees grew further apart and often quite isolated.But the further they were from each other the more magnificent they appeared, profiting, as they did, by the free, pure air which circulated around them.

zh: 这一地带的植物是多么秀丽啊！当然，植物学家可以根据这一地带生长的植被，毫不迟疑地指出林肯岛所在的纬度。
en: What splendid specimens of the flora of this latitude!Certainly their presence would have been enough for a botanist to name without hesitation the parallel which traversed Lincoln Island.

zh: “桉树！”赫伯特喊道。
en: “Eucalypti!” cried Herbert.

zh: 是的，那些美丽的树木确实是桉树。这种生长在较高纬度地带的大树与澳大利亚和新西兰的桉树，和林肯岛处于同一纬度。一些桉树高达200英尺。底部的树干周长约有20英尺，树皮凹凸不平，里面含有芳香的红色树胶。没有植物能比这些高大的桃金娘科树更奇妙、更珍稀了，叶片不是水平生长的，而是垂直生长的，因而向上面展开的是树的叶边，而不是叶面，这样更多的阳光就可以透过叶子照射下来。
en: They were, in fact, those splendid trees, the giants of the extratropical zone, the congeners of the Australian and New Zealand eucalyptus, both situated under the same latitude as Lincoln Island.Some rose to a height of two hundred feet.Their trunks at the base measured twenty feet in circumference, and their bark was covered by a network of farrows containing a red, sweet-smelling gum.Nothing is more wonderful or more singular than those enormous specimens of the order of the myrtaceae, with their leaves placed vertically and not horizontally, so that an edge and not a surface looks upwards, the effect being that the sun’s rays penetrate more freely among the trees.

zh: 桉树下面绿草如茵，有一群小鸟从灌木丛中飞出来，在阳光下闪闪发光，像是扑棱着翅膀的红宝石。
en: The ground at the foot of the eucalypti was carpeted with grass, and from the bushes escaped flights of little birds, which glittered in the sunlight like winged rubies.

zh: “这些像是乔木！”纳布喊道，“可是这些树有什么用处吗？”
en: “These are something like trees!” cried Neb; “but are they good for anything?”

zh: “哼！”潘克洛夫回答道，“当然这些树也算是植物中的庞然大物了，就像是人类中的巨人一样，它们没有什么用处，除了在展览会上显摆！”
en: “Pooh!” replied Pencroft.“Of course there are vegetable giants as well as human giants, and they are no good, except to show themselves at fairs!”

zh: “我想你错了，潘克洛夫，”吉丁·史佩莱回答道，“桉木现在开始非常适合用来制作箱柜。”
en: “I think that you are mistaken, Pencroft,” replied Gideon Spilett, “and that the wood of the eucalyptus has begun to be very advantageously employed in cabinet-making.”

zh: “我可以再补充一点，”赫伯特说道，“桉树所属的这一科目包括很多有用的种类：有番石榴树，它的果子可以用来做番石榴酱；丁香树，可以制作香料；石榴树，可以结石榴；桃金娘丁香树的果子可以用来酿制美酒；乌葛杨梅树含有极好的酒精成分；丁香杨梅树的树皮可以做成极好的肉桂；尤琴椒树可以用来制作牙买加辣椒；而普通的杨梅树的嫩芽和果实可以提取香料；桉树产生一种甜美的木蜜；几内亚桉树的树液发酵之后则可以酿制啤酒。总之，澳大利亚所有的橡胶树和铁皮树都属于桃金娘科，它包括46类、1300多种。
en: “And I may add,” said Herbert, “that the eucalyptus belongs to a family which comprises many useful members; the guava-tree, from whose fruit guava jelly is made; the clove-tree, which produces the spice; the pomegranate-tree, which bears pomegranates; the Eugeacia Cauliflora, the fruit of which is used in making a tolerable wine; the Ugui myrtle, which contains an excellent alcoholic liquor; the Caryophyllus myrtle, of which the bark forms an esteemed cinnamon; the Eugenia Pimenta, from whence comes Jamaica pepper; the common myrtle, from whose buds and berries spice is sometimes made; the Eucalyptus manifera, which yields a sweet sort of manna; the Guinea Eucalyptus, the sap of which is transformed into beer by fermentation; in short, all those trees known under the name of gum-trees or iron-bark trees in Australia, belong to this family of the myrtaceae, which contains forty-six genera and thirteen hundred species!”

zh: 大家听着少年滔滔不绝地讲着，他兴致勃勃地进行着小植物学讲座。赛勒斯·哈丁微笑着听着，而潘克洛夫心里也升起一种难以名状的自豪感。
en: The lad was allowed to run on, and he delivered his little botanical lecture with great animation.Cyrus Harding listened smiling, and Pencroft with an indescribable feeling of pride.

zh: “很好，赫伯特，”潘克洛夫回答道，“但是我发誓，这些大树中没有一棵是你刚才所提到过的！”
en: “Very good, Herbert,” replied Pencroft, “but I could swear that all those useful specimens you have just told us about are none of them giants like these!”

zh: “那倒是，潘克洛夫。”
en: “That is true, Pencroft.”

zh: “那就跟我说的一样了，”水手回答道，“也就是说，这些大树没什么用处！”
en: “That supports what I said,” returned the sailor, “namely, that these giants are good for nothing!”

zh: “你错了，潘克洛夫，”工程师说道，“给我们遮阴的这些大桉树是有些用的。”
en: “There you are wrong, Pencroft,” said the engineer; “these gigantic eucalypti, which shelter us, are good for something.”

zh: “什么用处？”
en: “And what is that?”

zh: “它可以保护周围居民的健康。你知道在澳大利亚和新西兰，他们是怎么称呼这种树的吗？“
en: “To render the countries which they inhabit healthy.Do you know what they are called in Australia and New Zealand?”

zh: “不知道，上尉。”
en: “No, captain.”

zh: “它们被称为热病树。”
en: “They are called ‘fever trees.’”

zh: “是因为这些树会让人发烧吗？”
en: “Because they give fevers?”

zh: “不，因为他们可以让人避免发烧！”
en: “No, because they prevent them!”

zh: “很好。我必须把这点记下来。”记者说道。
en: “Good.I must note that,” said the reporter.

zh: “那就记下来吧，亲爱的史佩莱，好像还有研究证明，桉树足以驱除瘴气。这一说法已经在中欧和北非地区的一些国家得到验证，那些地方的土壤绝对对人体有害，然而种植桉树之后，当地居民的卫生条件都已经渐渐得到了改善。有桃金娘科植物覆盖的地区，就没有断断续续的热病肆虐。这已经是不争的事实了，林肯岛对于我们这些居民来说，还真是个不错的地方。”
en: “Note it then, my dear Spilett; for it appears proved that the presence of the eucalyptus is enough to neutralize miasmas.This natural antidote has been tried in certain countries in the middle of Europe and the north of Africa where the soil was absolutely unhealthy, and the sanitary condition of the inhabitants has been gradually ameliorated.No more intermittent fevers prevail in the regions now covered with forests of the myrtaceae.This fact is now beyond doubt, and it is a happy circumstance for us settlers in Lincoln Island.”

zh: “啊，多好的小岛啊！受上帝保佑的小岛！”潘克洛夫喊道，“我跟你们说，这里什么都不缺，除了——”
en: “Ah! what an island!What a blessed island!” cried Pencroft.“I tell you, it wants nothing—unless it is—”

zh: “会有的，潘克洛夫，我们会找到的，”工程师回答说，“但是现在我们必须继续航行了，小船能在河里走多远，我们就划多远！”
en: “That will come, Pencroft, that will be found,” replied the engineer; “but now we must continue our voyage and push on as far as the river will carry our boat!”

zh: 因而，他们又向前划行了两英里，现在处在长满桉树的小岛中部，小岛这部分的树林里主要植物就是桉树。慈悲河两岸长满桉树，望不到边，河水就在高高的绿色河岸之间曲曲折折地流动。河床经常被长长的水草堵住，有时甚至是尖尖的石头，这也使得水中的航行变得非常困难。船桨现在已经划不动了，潘克洛夫不得不使用长杆撑船。同时他们也发现水位变得越来越浅，小船很快就不能划行了。太阳已经在地平线下沉了，树木在地上投下长长的影子。赛勒斯·哈丁明白，他不可能一路乘船到达小岛的西海岸，于是决定在水浅到不能继续前行的地方停下来宿营。据他估计，这里离海滨还有五六英里远，而在这片未知的丛林中长夜跋涉，距离太远了。
en: The exploration was therefore continued for another two miles in the midst of country covered with eucalypti, which predominated in the woods of this portion of the island.The space which they occupied extended as far as the eye could reach on each side of the Mercy, which wound along between high green banks.The bed was often obstructed by long weeds, and even by pointed rocks, which rendered the navigation very difficult.The action of the oars was prevented, and Pencroft was obliged to push with a pole.They found also that the water was becoming shallower and shallower, and that the canoe must soon stop.The sun was already sinking towards the horizon, and the trees threw long shadows on the ground.Cyrus Harding, seeing that he could not hope to reach the western coast of the island in one journey, resolved to camp at the place where any further navigation was prevented by want of water.He calculated that they were still five or six miles from the coast, and this distance was too great for them to attempt during the night in the midst of unknown woods.

zh: 小船穿过森林继续前行，这时，森林变得越来越茂密，而且里面似乎居住着更多的生物。因为如果水手没有看错，他想是看到了成群的猴子在树林间跳跃。有时甚至会有两三只猴子跑到离小舟很近的地方停下，盯着这群居民，丝毫没有表现出害怕，它们仿佛是头一次看到人类，还不懂得害怕他们。要是开枪打下这样一只猴子，应当是轻而易举的，而且潘克洛夫也很想开枪试一下，但是哈丁却不同意进行这样一次毫无用处的屠杀。他们应当谨慎一些，因为这些猴子，或者说是猿猴，看上去十分强壮而且极其敏捷，对它们进行不必要的侵犯毫无意义，而且这些动物很可能不会顾忌探险者们火器的威力，而对他们发起袭击。确实，水手是单纯从食物的角度来考虑这些猴子的，因为这些食草动物味道鲜美。但是既然他们已经储备了充足的食物，就没有必要去浪费他们的弹药了。
en: The boat was pushed on through the forest, which gradually became thicker again, and appeared also to have more inhabitants; for if the eyes of the sailor did not deceive him, he thought he saw bands of monkeys springing among the trees.Sometimes even two or three of these animals stopped at a little distance from the canoe and gazed at the settlers without manifesting any terror, as if, seeing men for the first time, they had not yet learned to fear them.It would have been easy to bring down one of these quadramani with a gunshot, and Pencroft was greatly tempted to fire, but Harding opposed so useless a massacre.This was prudent, for the monkeys, or apes rather, appearing to be very powerful and extremely active, it was useless to provoke an unnecessary aggression, and the creatures might, ignorant of the power of the explorers’ firearms, have attacked them.It is true that the sailor considered the monkeys from a purely alimentary point of view, for those animals which are herbivorous make very excellent game; but since they had an abundant supply of provisions, it was a pity to waste their ammunition.

zh: 将近四点的时候，他们已经很难在慈悲河上划船前行了，因为一些水生植物和岩石阻塞了他们的道路。河岸越来越高，而且他们已经离富兰克林山的支脉很近了。河水的源头应该就在不远处，因为慈悲河就是由南面山坡的水源补给的。
en: Towards four o’clock, the navigation of the Mercy became exceedingly difficult, for its course was obstructed by aquatic plants and rocks.The banks rose higher and higher, and already they were approaching the spurs of Mount Franklin.The source could not be far off, since it was fed by the water from the southern slopes of the mountain.

zh: “再过一刻钟，”水手说道，“我们就不得不停下来了，上尉。”
en: “In a quarter of an hour,” said the sailor, “we shall be obliged to stop, captain.”

zh: “好的，我们一会儿就停下，潘克洛夫，我们将找个地方宿营。”
en: “Very well, we will stop, Pencroft, and we will make our encampment for the night.”

zh: “我们离花岗石宫有多远了？”赫伯特问道。
en: “At what distance are we from Granite House?” asked Herbert.

zh: “大约有七英里吧，”工程师回答道，“把河流的弯道也计算在内，这条小河已经把我们带到西北方向了。”
en: “About seven miles,” replied the engineer, “taking into calculation, however, the detours of the river, which has carried us to the northwest.”

zh: “我们还要继续往前走吗？”记者问道。
en: “Shall we go on?” asked the reporter.

zh: “是啊，只要我们可以。”赛勒斯·哈丁回答道，“明天天一亮，我们就离开小船，我希望能在两小时内走到海滨那边，那样我们就有一整天在海岸探索了。”
en: “Yes, as long as we can,” replied Cyrus Harding.“To-morrow, at break of day, we will leave the canoe, and in two hours I hope we shall cross the distance which separates us from the coast, and then we shall have the whole day in which to explore the shore.”

zh: “好啊！”潘克洛夫回答道。
en: “Go ahead!” replied Pencroft.

zh: 但是很快船就擦到了布满石子的河底，现在河面已经不足20英尺宽了。两岸的树像是在头顶凉亭一样，光线有些阴暗。他们也听到了瀑布的声响，这就说明河流上游几百英尺处有一道天然屏障。
en: But soon the boat grated on the stony bottom of the river, which was now not more than twenty feet in breadth.The trees met like a bower overhead, and caused a half-darkness.They also heard the noise of a waterfall, which showed that a few hundred feet up the river there was a natural barrier.

zh: 过了一会儿，他们拐过河的一个急弯，透过树木看到一个小瀑布。小舟再次碰到了河底，几分钟后，小舟在右岸的一棵树干下停泊了。
en: Presently, after a sudden turn of the river, a cascade appeared through the trees.The canoe again touched the bottom, and in a few minutes it was moored to a trunk near the right bank.

zh: 那时已经将近五点钟了。落日的余晖穿过厚厚的叶片，闪烁着微光，投射在小瀑布上，使得喷射的水雾闪耀着彩虹的光芒。慈悲河就消失在前面的灌木丛里了，河的源头就隐藏在那里。多条溪流汇入河水，使它渐渐在下游成为一条普通的河流，而这里的慈悲河只是一条浅浅的、清澈的小溪。
en: It was nearly five o’clock.The last rays of the sun gleamed through the thick foliage and glanced on the little waterfall, making the spray sparkle with all the colors of the rainbow.Beyond that, the Mercy was lost in the bushwood, where it was fed from some hidden source.The different streams which flowed into it increased it to a regular river further down, but here it was simply a shallow, limpid brook.

zh: 这里景色很美，于是大家商定在这里宿营。拓荒者们下了船，很快就在树丛下点燃了一堆篝火，如果必要，赛勒斯·哈丁和伙伴们还可以在树枝上过夜。
en: It was agreed to camp here, as the place was charming.The colonists disembarked, and a fire was soon lighted under a clump of trees, among the branches of which Cyrus Harding and his companions could, if it was necessary, take refuge for the night.

zh: 他们已经饥肠辘辘了，狼吞虎咽地吃完了晚餐，剩下来要考虑的就是睡觉的问题了。但在晚上，他们听到了一阵可疑的咆哮声，于是决定在夜里燃着大火，劈啪作响的篝火可以保护他们安睡。纳布和潘克洛夫轮流看守火堆，不停地添加燃料。他们觉得看到了丛林中有些野兽的黑影在营地周围爬动，但这一夜平安地过去了，第二天是10月31日，早上五点钟的时候，他们就整装待发了。
en: Supper was quickly devoured, for they were very hungry, and then there was only sleeping to think of.But, as roarings of rather a suspicious nature had been heard during the evening, a good fire was made up for the night, so as to protect the sleepers with its crackling flames.Neb and Pencroft also watched by turns, and did not spare fuel.They thought they saw the dark forms of some wild animals prowling round the camp among the bushes, but the night passed without incident, and the next day, the 31st of October, at five o’clock in the morning, all were on foot, ready for a start.

zh: 第四章
en: Chapter 4

zh: 早上六点的时候，居民们匆匆吃过早饭，选择了一条距离最近的路，向小岛西海岸进发。要多长时间才能到达那里呢？赛勒斯·哈丁说过需要两个小时，但是这当然还要取决于他们可能遇到的实际障碍。因为途中可能需要在草丛、灌木丛以及藤蔓中开辟道路，于是他们手持斧子，携带枪支。由于昨天夜里听到野兽的咆哮声，他们采取了明智的方法，增强戒备。
en: It was six o’ clock in the morning when the settlers, after a hasty breakfast, set out to reach by the shortest way, the western coast of the island.And how long would it take to do this?Cyrus Harding had said two hours, but of course that depended on the nature of the obstacles they might meet with As it was probable that they would have to cut a path through the grass, shrubs, and creepers, they marched axe in hand, and with guns also ready, wisely taking warning from the cries of the wild beasts heard in the night.

zh: 露营的确切地点可以由富兰克林山的方位决定，由于北面不到三英里处矗立着火山，他们只得朝西南方向直走，然后到达西海岸。他们仔细地把小舟藏好，然后就出发了。潘克洛夫和纳布带了足够大家两天吃的食物。因而，他们就不需要去打猎了。工程师建议同伴们尽量不要开火，这样就不容易向海边附近的人暴露他们的行踪了。在瀑布上不远处，乳香黄连木中有灌木丛，他们第一次用斧子开辟道路，赛勒斯·哈丁则手拿罗盘，在前面带路。
en: The exact position of the encampment could be determined by the bearing of Mount Franklin, and as the volcano arose in the north at a distance of less than three miles, they had only to go straight towards the southwest to reach the western coast.They set out, having first carefully secured the canoe.Pencroft and Neb carried sufficient provision for the little band for at least two days.It would not thus be necessary to hunt.The engineer advised his companions to refrain from firing, that their presence might not be betrayed to any one near the shore.The first hatchet blows were given among the brushwood in the midst of some mastic-trees, a little above the cascade; and his compass in his hand, Cyrus Harding led the way.

zh: 森林里大部分树木的种类都是他们在湖边和眺望岗上见过的。有喜马拉雅雪杉、绿枞、木麻黄树、橡胶树、桉树、木槿、雪松和其他树，大都是中等高度，因为数量过多，影响了它们的生长。
en: The forest here was composed for the most part of trees which had already been met with near the lake and on Prospect Heights.There were deodars, Douglas firs, casuarinas, gum trees, eucalypti, hibiscus, cedars, and other trees, generally of a moderate size, for their number prevented their growth.

zh: 从出发到现在，居民们已经从构成小岛山脉系统的斜坡走下来了，到了一处干燥的土地上，但是这里植物茂盛，说明有隐蔽的地下沼泽或是溪流润泽。但是，赛勒斯·哈丁记得去往火山口的途中，除了红河和慈悲河外，并没见过其他水道。
en: Since their departure, the settlers had descended the slopes which constituted the mountain system of the island, on to a dry soil, but the luxuriant vegetation of which indicated it to be watered either by some subterranean marsh or by some stream.However, Cyrus Harding did not remember having seen, at the time of his excursion to the crater, any other watercourses but the Red Creek and the Mercy.

zh: 在探险之行的第一段路程中，他们看到成群结队的猴子，这些猴子看到他们，露出极其惊讶的神态，因为它们此前从未见过人类。吉丁·史佩莱开玩笑道，这些敏捷欢快的四足动物不知是否把他和同伴们当做它们退化的同胞了。
en: During the first part of their excursion, they saw numerous troops of monkeys who exhibited great astonishment at the sight of men, whose appearance was so new to them.Gideon Spilett jokingly asked whether these active and merry quadrupeds did not consider him and his companions as degenerate brothers.

zh: 当然，由于灌木丛、藤蔓以及树干的阻挡，他们步履维艰。而那些灵活的动物则在树枝间蹦跳穿梭，在它们的道路上畅通无阻，人类比这些身体柔软的动物是逊色多了。虽然有很多猴子，但幸运的是，它们对人类并无敌意。
en: And certainly, pedestrians, hindered at each step by bushes, caught by creepers, barred by trunks of trees, did not shine beside those supple animals, who, bounding from branch to branch, were hindered by nothing on their course.The monkeys were numerous, but happily they did not manifest any hostile disposition.

zh: 他们还看到了一些猪、刺鼠、袋鼠以及其他噬齿类动物，还有两三只树考拉，潘克洛夫很想朝它们开枪。
en: Several pigs, agoutis, kangaroos, and other rodents were seen, also two or three koalas, at which Pencroft longed to have a shot.

zh: “等着，”他说，“你们现在可以蹦跳、玩耍，等我们回来的时候再收拾你们！”
en: “But,” said he, “you may jump and play just now; we shall have one or two words to say to you on our way back!”

zh: 九点半的时候，他们前面突然出现了一道未知的河流，约有30至40英尺宽，湍急的水流冲击着河中无数的岩石，溅起泡沫。河流很深，也很清澈，但是却完全不能通航。
en: At half-past nine the way was suddenly found to be barred by an unknown stream, from thirty to forty feet broad, whose rapid current dashed foaming over the numerous rocks which interrupted its course.This creek was deep and clear, but it was absolutely unnavigable.

zh: “我们被阻断了！”纳布喊道。
en: “We are cut off!” cried Neb.

zh: “不，”赫伯特回答道，“不过是条小河而已，我们可以毫不费力地游过去。”
en: “No,” replied Herbert, “it is only a stream, and we can easily swim over.”

zh: “为什么要游过去呢？”哈丁反问道，“很明显，这条小河通向大海。我们就在这边沿着河岸走，如果它没有很快把我们带到能到海岸，那就奇怪了。前进！”
en: “What would be the use of that?” returned Harding.“This creek evidently runs to the sea.Let us remain on this side and follow the bank, and I shall be much astonished if it does not lead us very quickly to the coast.Forward!”

zh: “等一下，”记者说道，“我们要怎么称呼这条小河呢，朋友们？不要让我们的地图有不完整的地方。”
en: “One minute,” said the reporter.“The name of this creek, my friends?Do not let us leave our geography incomplete.”

zh: “对！”潘克洛夫道。
en: “All right!” said Pencroft.

zh: “孩子，你来给它命名吧。”工程师对少年说道。
en: “Name it, my boy,” said the engineer, addressing the lad.

zh: “我们等到了河口再给它命名，不是会更好吗？”赫伯特回答道。
en: “Will it not be better to wait until we have explored it to its mouth?” answered Herbert.

zh: “很好，”赛勒斯·哈丁回答道，“我们就沿着河岸走，越快越好，不要停。”
en: “Very well,” replied Cyrus Harding.“Let us follow it as fast as we can without stopping.”

zh: “再等一下！”潘克洛夫说道。
en: “Still another minute!” said Pencroft.

zh: “什么事？”记者问道。
en: “What’s the matter?” asked the reporter.

zh: “虽然我们不能打猎，但是我想捕鱼总是可以的吧。”水手说道。
en: “Though hunting is forbidden, fishing is allowed, I suppose,” said the sailor.

zh: “我们没有时间了。”工程师回答道。
en: “We have no time to lose,” replied the engineer.

zh: “噢！就五分钟！”潘克洛夫回答道，“我只要五分钟时间，这也是为了我们的早饭啊！”
en: “Oh! five minutes!” replied Pencroft, “I only ask for five minutes to use in the interest of our breakfast!”

zh: 接着，潘克洛夫趴在岸边，将胳膊伸到水中，很快就从石间抓出几十只很好的小龙虾来。
en: And Pencroft, lying down on the bank, plunged his arm into the water, and soon pulled up several dozen of fine crayfish from among the stones.

zh: “太好了！”纳布喊道，并过去帮忙。
en: “These will be good!” cried Neb, going to the sailor’s aid.

zh: “我就说嘛，这座岛上除了烟草什么都有！”潘克洛夫叹了口气，低语道。
en: “As I said, there is everything in this island, except tobacco!” muttered Pencroft with a sigh.

zh: 因为河里满是小龙虾，所以捕虾还不到五分钟时间。袋子里装满了这种甲壳动物，它们的壳是钴蓝色的。居民们继续前行。
en: The fishing did not take five minutes, for the crayfish were swarming in the creek.A bag was filled with the crustaceae, whose shells were of a cobalt blue.The settlers then pushed on.

zh: 沿着岸边行走比在森林中行走更快、更容易。他们时不时地会发现体型较大的动物的痕迹，那是它们来河边喝水时留下的，但是实际上却一只也没有看到。很明显，那只曾硌掉潘克洛夫一颗牙齿的西貒，不是在这片森林里中弹的。
en: They advanced more rapidly and easily along the bank of the river than in the forest.From time to time they came upon the traces of animals of a large size who had come to quench their thirst at the stream, but none were actually seen, and it was evidently not in this part of the forest that the peccary had received the bullet which had cost Pencroft a grinder.

zh: 同时，考虑到这湍急的河流，哈丁认为他和同伴们离西海岸的距离，比预计的要远得多。事实上，在这个时候，如果河口距离这里只有几英里的路程，上涨的潮水就会使河水回流。但是，现在并没有出现这种情况，河水依旧照常流动。工程师很是吃惊，多次查看罗盘，以确信河流的某个拐角没有把他们重新带回远西森林。
en: In the meanwhile, considering the rapid current, Harding was led to suppose that he and his companions were much farther from the western coast than they had at first supposed.In fact, at this hour, the rising tide would have turned back the current of the creek, if its mouth had only been a few miles distant.Now, this effect was not produced, and the water pursued its natural course.The engineer was much astonished at this, and frequently consulted his compass, to assure himself that some turn of the river was not leading them again into the Far West.

zh: 但是，河面渐渐变宽了，而且河水也不那么湍急了。右岸的树木和左岸一样生长紧密，要想透过它们看到什么是不可能的。但是，这片树林里显然没有人居住，因为托普并没有叫，如果附近有任何陌生人出现，这只机警的动物都会做出反应。
en: However, the creek gradually widened and its waters became less tumultuous.The trees on the right bank were as close together as on the left bank, and it was impossible to distinguish anything beyond them; but these masses of wood were evidently uninhabited, for Top did not bark, and the intelligent animal would not have failed to signal the presence of any stranger in the neighborhood.

zh: 十点半的时候，稍稍在前的赫伯特突然停了下来，赛勒斯·哈丁吃了一惊，接着听到他大喊：
en: At half-past ten, to the great surprise of Cyrus Harding, Herbert, who was a little in front, suddenly stopped and exclaimed,—

zh: “大海！”
en: “The sea!”

zh: 几分钟后，小岛的整个西海岸就展现在居民面前了。
en: In a few minutes more, the whole western shore of the island lay extended before the eyes of the settlers.

zh: 但是这里和他们被命运抛到的东海岸有着很大不同。这里没有花岗石峭壁，没有岩石，甚至也没有沙滩。森林一直延伸到海边，高大的树木有树枝垂落到海面上，被海水冲刷着。这与普通的自然形成的海岸不同，既没有广阔的沙滩，也没有成堆的岩石，而是一道美丽的边界，上面生长着许多美丽的树木。海岸比海平面要高一点，在这块由花岗石地基托起的肥沃的土壤上，美丽的森林树木似乎和小岛内陆上的一样茁壮。
en: But what a contrast between this and the eastern coast, upon which chance had first thrown them.No granite cliff, no rocks, not even a sandy beach.The forest reached the shore, and the tall trees bending over the water were beaten by the waves.It was not such a shore as is usually formed by nature, either by extending a vast carpet of sand, or by grouping masses of rock, but a beautiful border consisting of the most splendid trees.The bank was raised a little above the level of the sea, and on this luxuriant soil, supported by a granite base, the fine forest trees seemed to be as firmly planted as in the interior of the island.

zh: 拓荒者们来到了海岸上一个不重要的的小海港，这个海港勉强能容下两三只渔船。它是作为通向刚才那条新河流的海峡，奇怪的是河水并不是通过一个缓坡汇入大海，而是从40多英尺高的地方落下，这也就解释了为什么他们刚才在河上感觉不到涨潮。事实上，即便是太平洋的潮水达到顶峰的时候也无法涨到这条河的高度，而且即使再过几百万年，潮水也无法冲垮花岗岩，形成一个和大海相接的河口，这是毫无疑问的。
en: The colonists were then on the shore of an unimportant little harbor, which would scarcely have contained even two or three fishing-boats.It served as a neck to the new creek, of which the curious thing was that its waters, instead of joining the sea by a gentle slope, fell from a height of more than forty feet, which explained why the rising tide was not felt up the stream.In fact, the tides of the Pacific, even at their maximum elevation, could never reach the level of the river, and, doubtless, millions of years would pass before the water would have worn away the granite and hollowed a practicable mouth.

zh: 大家一致同意给这条小河命名叫“瀑布河”。此外，森林又向北面延伸了约两英里，那边的树木越来越稀疏，再远处，风景如画的高地几乎连接成一条南北方向的直线。相反，瀑布河与爬虫角之间的海岸上，长满了树木这些美丽的树，有的笔直，其他的垂到海面上，翻滚的海浪冲刷着它们的根部。现在，他们即将开始搜索这片海岸了，即整个盘蛇半岛。因为只有这片海岸能为落难者提供安身之处，另一侧的荒地和不毛之地肯定不予考虑。
en: It was settled that the name of Falls River should be given to this stream.Beyond, towards the north, the forest border was prolonged for a space of nearly two miles; then the trees became scarcer, and beyond that again the picturesque heights described a nearly straight line, which ran north and south.On the contrary, all the part of the shore between Falls River and Reptile End was a mass of wood, magnificent trees, some straight, others bent, so that the long sea-swell bathed their roots.Now, it was this coast, that is, all the Serpentine Peninsula, that was to be explored, for this part of the shore offered a refuge to castaways, which the other wild and barren side must have refused.

zh: 天气清朗，纳布和潘克洛夫在一个小山丘上准备早饭，在那里可以看得很远。然而，一只船也看不到，沿着海岸，目所及之处什么也没有。但是，除非对这片海岸到盘蛇半岛的尽头进行搜索后，工程师是不会理所当然地接受任何结论的。
en: The weather was fine and clear, and from a height of a hillock on which Neb and Pencroft had arranged breakfast, a wide view was obtained.There was, however, not a sail in sight; nothing could be seen along the shore as far as the eye could reach.But the engineer would take nothing for granted until he had explored the coast to the very extremity of the Serpentine Peninsula.

zh: 他们很快吃完了早饭，十一点半的时候，赛勒斯·哈丁下令启程。居民们没有在峭壁上或是沿着沙滩行进，而只能依然在树下行走，这样才能继续在海岸上搜索。
en: Breakfast was soon despatched, and at half-past eleven the captain gave the signal for departure.Instead of proceeding over the summit of a cliff or along a sandy beach, the settlers were obliged to remain under cover of the trees so that they might continue on the shore.

zh: 瀑布河与爬虫角之间的距离约有12英里。如果是在平地上不慌不忙地行走，大概四个小时就可以走完这段距离。但是现在他们需要两倍的时间，因为要绕过树木，劈开灌木丛，砍断缠绕的藤蔓。他们每走一步都被挡住，这些障碍大大延长了他们行进的时间。
en: The distance which separated Falls River from Reptile End was about twelve miles.It would have taken the settlers four hours to do this, on a clear ground and without hurrying themselves; but as it was they needed double the time, for what with trees to go round, bushes to cut down, and creepers to chop away, they were impeded at every step, these obstacles greatly lengthening their journey.

zh: 然而，依然没有什么迹象显示这里最近有船只失事。就像吉丁·史佩莱注意到的那样，事实上，失事船只的残骸有可能漂到海里去了。因为没有发现什么迹象，他们也不可以想当然地认为海边没有过遇难的船只。
en: There was, however, nothing to show that a shipwreck had taken place recently.It is true that, as Gideon Spilett observed, any remains of it might have drifted out to sea, and they must not take it for granted that because they could find no traces of it, a ship had not been castaway on the coast.

zh: 记者的观点是正确的，而且子弹事件也说明在最近的三个月内，一定有人在林肯岛上开过枪。
en: The reporter’s argument was just, and besides, the incident of the bullet proved that a shot must have been fired in Lincoln Island within three months.

zh: 已经五点钟了，居民们距盘蛇半岛的尽头处还有两英里。很明显，在到达爬虫角之后，哈丁和同伴们来不及在天黑之前返回慈悲河口的宿营地了。因而，他们需要在海角上过夜了。但幸运的是，他们不缺食物。虽然海岸上没有什么动物，但是鸟类却不少，有啄木鸟、锦鸡、角雉、松鸡、猩猩鹦鹉、鹦鹉、美冠鹦鹉、雉鸡、鸽子以及一百只其他种类的鸟。这里的树上都有鸟巢，鸟巢里满是扑棱着翅膀的鸟。
en: It was already five o’clock, and there were still two miles between the settlers and the extremity of the Serpentine Peninsula.It was evident that after having reached Reptile End, Harding and his companions would not have time to return before dark to their encampment near the source of the Mercy.It would therefore be necessary to pass the night on the promontory.But they had no lack of provisions, which was lucky, for there were no animals on the shore, though birds, on the contrary, abound—jacamars, couroucous, tragopans, grouse, lories, parrots, cockatoos, pheasants, pigeons, and a hundred others.There was not a tree without a nest, and not a nest which was not full of flapping wings.

zh: 快七点钟的时候，疲惫的探险者们到达了爬虫角。这里是海边森林的尽头，海岸也呈现出一幅海岸常有的景象：岩石、暗礁和沙子。探险者们或许能在这里找到些什么，但是黑夜降临，他们不得不推迟到第二天，再进一步探索了。
en: Towards seven o’clock the weary explorers arrived at Reptile End.Here the seaside forest ended, and the shore resumed the customary appearance of a coast, with rocks, reefs, and sands.It was possible that something might be found here, but darkness came on, and the further exploration had to be put off to the next day.

zh: 潘克洛夫和赫伯特急忙为大家寻找合适的地方宿营。在远西森林尽头处的几棵树中，少年发现了几丛密密的竹林。
en: Pencroft and Herbert hastened on to find a suitable place for their camp.Among the last trees of the forest of the Far West, the boy found several thick clumps of bamboos.

zh: “好啊，”他说，“这是有价值的发现。”
en: “Good,” said he; “this is a valuable discovery.”

zh: “有价值？”潘克洛夫问道。
en: “Valuable?” returned Pencroft.

zh: “当然了，”少年答道，“我可以这么说，潘克洛夫，竹皮如果劈成柔韧的板条，可以用来编制篮子；如果捣成浆糊，可以制作中国式的纸张；根据竹竿的大小，可以把它们制成手杖和烟管，并且还可以用来导水；大的竹子还是极好的建材，因为它们轻便、结实，而且从不会受到虫的侵害。我还要补充一点，把竹子在竹节处锯成两半，并保留竹节处的横向薄层做底，就可以做成实用的杯子了，这在中国是很常用的。不！你不会在乎这个的。但是——”
en: “Certainly,” replied Herbert.“I may say, Pencroft, that the bark of the bamboo, cut into flexible laths, is used for making baskets; that this bark, mashed into a paste, is used for the manufacture of Chinese paper; that the stalks furnish, according to their size, canes and pipes and are used for conducting water; that large bamboos make excellent material for building, being light and strong, and being never attacked by insects.I will add that by sawing the bamboo in two at the joint, keeping for the bottom the part of the transverse film which forms the joint, useful cups are obtained, which are much in use among the Chinese.No! you don’t care for that.But—”

zh: “但是什么？”
en: “But what?”

zh: “但是如果你不知道，我可以告诉你，在印度，这些竹子就和芦笋一样，是可以吃的。”
en: “But I can tell you, if you are ignorant of it, that in India these bamboos are eaten like asparagus.”

zh: “30英尺高的芦笋！”水手喊道，“好吃吗？”
en: “Asparagus thirty feet high!” exclaimed the sailor.“And are they good?”

zh: “好吃极了，”赫伯特答道，“只是他们吃的并不是30英尺高的竹竿，而是嫩芽。”
en: “Excellent,” replied Herbert.“Only it is not the stems of thirty feet high which are eaten, but the young shoots.”

zh: “太好了，孩子，太好了！”潘克洛夫回答道。
en: “Perfect, my boy, perfect!” replied Pencroft.

zh: “我还要补充一点，把嫩竹芯的髓泡在醋里，可以制成很好的泡菜。”
en: “I will also add that the pith of the young stalks, preserved in vinegar, makes a good pickle.”

zh: “越来越好了，赫伯特！”
en: “Better and better, Herbert!”

zh: “最后一点，竹子里流出的甜汁液，可以制成非常可口的饮料。”
en: “And lastly, that the bamboos exude a sweet liquor which can be made into a very agreeable drink.”

zh: “完了吗？”水手问道。
en: “Is that all?” asked the sailor.

zh: “完了！”
en: “That is all!”

zh: “这些竹子能不能做抽烟之用呢？“
en: “And they don’t happen to do for smoking?”

zh: “不能，可怜的潘克洛夫。”
en: “No, my poor Pencroft.”

zh: 赫伯特和水手不久就找到了过夜的地方。岩石上有许多空洞，这一定是由于海水在西南风的作用下，猛烈拍击岩石形成的，他们可以在此安身，躲避夜里的凉气。但是，正当他们准备进入到其中一个洞穴时，一声洪亮的咆哮引起了他们的注意。
en: Herbert and the sailor had not to look long for a place in which to pass the night.The rocks, which must have been violently beaten by the sea under the influence of the winds of the southwest, presented many cavities in which shelter could be found against the night air.But just as they were about to enter one of these caves a loud roaring arrested them.

zh: “后退！”潘克洛夫喊道，“我们的枪里只装满了小颗子弹，那些能如此大声咆哮的野兽，对子弹不会在乎，就像不在乎盐粒一样！”这时，一只雄壮的动物出现在洞口，水手一把抓住赫伯特的胳膊，将他拽到岩石的后面。
en: “Back!” cried Pencroft.“Our guns are only loaded with small shot, and beasts which can roar as loud as that would care no more for it than for grains of salt!”And the sailor, seizing Herbert by the arm, dragged him behind a rock, just as a magnificent animal showed itself at the entrance of the cavern.

zh: 这是一只大小至少和亚洲虎差不多的美洲虎，也就是说，它从头顶至尾巴头有五英尺长。它黄色的毛上有着一道道斑纹和匀称的椭圆形黑色斑点，而它的胸膛却的白色形成对比。赫伯特认出来那是老虎凶猛的的劲敌，和最大的狼的对手美洲狮一样可怕！
en: It was a jaguar of a size at least equal to its Asiatic congeners, that is to say, it measured five feet from the extremity of its head to the beginning of its tail.The yellow color of its hair was relieved by streaks and regular oblong spots of black, which contrasted with the white of its chest.Herbert recognized it as the ferocious rival of the tiger, as formidable as the puma, which is the rival of the largest wolf!

zh: 美洲虎往前走了一步，用像在燃烧的双眼盯着他，它的毛发都竖立起来，仿佛这并不是它第一次闻到人的味道。
en: The jaguar advanced and gazed around him with blazing eyes, his hair bristling as if this was not the first time he had scented men.

zh: 这时，记者从岩石后面走了出来，赫伯特以为他没有看到美洲虎，正想要冲过去，吉丁·史佩莱做了个手势，示意他在原地别动。这不是他第一次遇到老虎了，他走到离老虎有十英尺处停下，一动不动，把枪放在肩上，肌肉没有动。美洲虎正要聚集全身力气跳过来的时候，记者开枪打中了它的眼睛，很快它便倒地身亡了。
en: At this moment the reporter appeared round a rock, and Herbert, thinking that he had not seen the jaguar, was about to rush towards him, when Gideon Spilett signed to him to remain where he was.This was not his first tiger, and advancing to within ten feet of the animal he remained motionless, his gun to his shoulder, without moving a muscle.The jaguar collected itself for a spring, but at that moment a shot struck it in the eyes, and it fell dead.

zh: 赫伯特和潘克洛夫马上朝美洲虎冲了过来。纳布和哈丁也跑了过来，他们凝视了一会儿倒在地上的美洲虎，心想这美丽的皮毛用来装饰花岗石宫的大厅再好不过了。
en: Herbert and Pencroft rushed towards the jaguar.Neb and Harding also ran up, and they remained for some instants contemplating the animal as it lay stretched on the ground, thinking that its magnificent skin would be a great ornament to the hall at Granite House.

zh: “噢，史佩莱先生，我是多么羡慕又忌妒你啊！”赫伯特出于自然流露的一阵仰慕之情喊道。
en: “Oh, Mr. Spilett, how I admire and envy you!” cried Herbert, in a fit of very natural enthusiasm.

zh: “哦，孩子，”记者回答道，“你也可以做到的。”
en: “Well, my boy,” replied the reporter, “you could have done the same.”

zh: “我！这么冷静！”
en: “I! with such coolness!—”

zh: “赫伯特，你就把这只美洲虎想象成一只野兔，这样你就会尽可能冷静地朝它开枪了。”
en: “Imagine to yourself, Herbert, that the jaguar is only a hare, and you would fire as quietly as possible.”

zh: “那是，”潘克洛夫插嘴道，“它并不比一只野兔更危险！”
en: “That is,” rejoined Pencroft, “that it is not more dangerous than a hare!”

zh: “现在，”吉丁·史佩莱回答道，“既然美洲虎已经把它的窝让出来了，朋友们，我们为何不占有它过夜吧。”
en: “And now,” said Gideon Spilett, “since the jaguar has left its abode, I do not see, my friends, why we should not take possession of it for the night.”

zh: “但是可能还会有其他野兽过来啊。”潘克洛夫说道。
en: “But others may come,” said Pencroft.

zh: “在洞口点一堆火就可以了，”记者说道，“没有野兽敢跨进门口的。”
en: “It will be enough to light a fire at the entrance of the cavern,” said the reporter, “and no wild beasts will dare to cross the threshold.”

zh: “那就快进虎窝里去吧！”水手拖着老虎的尸体回答道。
en: “Into the jaguar’s house, then!” replied the sailor, dragging after him the body of the animal.

zh: 纳布把虎皮剥了下来，而他的同伴们已经从森林里捡了足够的干柴，堆在洞口。
en: While Neb skinned the jaguar, his companions collected an abundant supply of dry wood from the forest, which they heaped up at the cave.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁看到竹丛，就砍了一些竹子回来，和其他燃料混在一起。
en: Cyrus Harding, seeing the clump of bamboos, cut a quantity, which he mingled with the other fuel.

zh: 做完这些后，他们进到洞穴里面，地上散落着白骨，他们小心地在枪膛里面装上子弹，以防突然袭击。他们吃过晚饭，把洞口的那堆木柴点着，然后就躺下来休息。这时，一个正常的爆炸声，确切地讲是一连串的爆炸声，划破了寂静！那是竹子燃烧的声响，当火焰烧到竹子的时候，就会像爆竹那样发出噼里啪啦的声音。这爆炸声足以吓退那些最为大胆的野兽。
en: This done, they entered the grotto, of which the floor was strewn with bones, the guns were carefully loaded, in case of a sudden attack, they had supper, and then just before they lay down to rest, the heap of wood piled at the entrance was set fire to.Immediately, a regular explosion, or rather a series of reports, broke the silence!The noise was caused by the bamboos, which, as the flames reached them, exploded like fireworks.The noise was enough to terrify even the boldest of wild beasts.

zh: 这种炸响的方法并不是工程师发明的，根据马可·波罗记载，中亚地区的鞑靼人在很多个世纪以前，就已经用这种方法把凶猛的野兽驱赶出去。
en: It was not the engineer who had invented this way of causing loud explosions, for, according to Marco Polo, the Tartars have employed it for many centuries to drive away from their encampments the formidable wild beasts of Central Asia.

zh: 第五章
en: Chapter 5

zh: 经由他们处置，美洲虎礼貌地让出了自己的窝，于是赛勒斯·哈丁和同伴们在洞里像天真的土拨鼠一样睡了。
en: Cyrus Harding and his companions slept like innocent marmots in the cave which the jaguar had so politely left at their disposal.

zh: 太阳升起来的时候，他们一行人已经到了海角尽头的海岸上，大家注视着地平线，其中有三分之二已经显现出来了。工程师最后一次确信，海上既没有航行的船只，也没有失事船只的残骸，甚至用望远镜也没有发现什么可疑的迹象。
en: At sunrise all were on the shore at the extremity of the promontory, and their gaze was directed towards the horizon, of which two-thirds of the circumference were visible.For the last time the engineer could ascertain that not a sail nor the wreck of a ship was on the sea, and even with the telescope nothing suspicious could be discovered.

zh: 海岸上也没有发现什么，至少是在海角南面三英里内，笔直的海岸线上没有什么。而在那之外，海滨的远处都是高地，甚至从盘蛇半岛的尽头处望去，也看不到爬虫角。
en: There was nothing either on the shore, at least, in the straight line of three miles which formed the south side of the promontory, for beyond that, rising ground had the rest of the coast, and even from the extremity of the Serpentine Peninsula Claw Cape could not be seen.

zh: 小岛的南部海岸仍旧有待他们前去探索。现在他们是不是应该马上出发，利用这一整天的时间前去探索呢？
en: The southern coast of the island still remained to be explored.Now should they undertake it immediately, and devote this day to it?

zh: 这不在他们原先的计划之内。事实上，他们在慈悲河口下船的时候，就一致同意查看过西海岸后就回来，乘船经由慈悲河返回花岗石宫。哈丁原先认为，无论是一艘遇难的船只，还是一只正常航行的船舰，都能在西海岸找到容身之所。但是现在，正如他看到的那样，这里并没有理想的停泊地方，于是，他希望可以去南面继续寻找他们在西面没有找到的东西。
en: This was not included in their first plan.In fact, when the boat was abandoned at the sources of the Mercy, it had been agreed that after having surveyed the west coast, they should go back to it, and return to Granite House by the Mercy.Harding then thought that the western coast would have offered refuge, either to a ship in distress, or to a vessel in her regular course; but now, as he saw that this coast presented no good anchorage, he wished to seek on the south what they had not been able to find on the west.

zh: 吉丁·史佩莱也提议继续探险，这样他们猜测的沉船问题才有可能得到彻底解决，他问半岛的尽头距爪角有多远。
en: Gideon Spilett proposed to continue the exploration, that the question of the supposed wreck might be completely settled, and he asked at what distance Claw Cape might be from the extremity of the peninsula.

zh: “大约有30英里吧，”工程师回答道，“如果把海岸线曲折的部分也考虑进去。”
en: “About thirty miles,” replied the engineer, “if we take into consideration the curvings of the coast.”

zh: “30英里！”史佩莱回应道，“这将是很长的行进。不过，我想我们可以从南海岸返回花岗石宫。”
en: “Thirty miles!” returned Spilett.“That would be a long day’s march.Nevertheless, I think that we should return to Granite House by the south coast.”

zh: “但是，”赫伯特说，“从爪角到花岗石宫又至少有十英里。”
en: “But,” observed Herbert, “from Claw Cape to Granite House there must be at least another ten miles.

zh: “总共就是40英里了，”工程师回答道，“不要犹豫了，快动身吧。至少，我们应该到未知的海岸上查看一下，这样就不用再次探险了。”
en: “Make it forty miles in all,” replied the engineer, “and do not hesitate to do it.At least we should survey the unknown shore, and then we shall not have to begin the exploration again.”

zh: “很好，”潘克洛夫说道，“但是我们的船要怎么办呢？”
en: “Very good,” said Pencroft.“But the boat?”

zh: “它已经在慈悲河发源地呆了一天了，”吉丁·史佩莱说道，“那再呆上两天也无妨！而且，我们也没理由认为小岛上有小偷出没！”
en: “The boat has remained by itself for one day at the sources of the Mercy,” replied Gideon Spilett; “it may just as well stay there two days!As yet, we have had no reason to think that the island is infested by thieves!”

zh: “但是，”水手说道，“我一想起那只海龟的事，就觉得不能这样肯定。”
en: “Yet,” said the sailor, “when I remember the history of the turtle, I am far from confident of that.”

zh: “海龟！海龟！”记者回答道，“难道你不知道是海水把它翻过来了吗？”
en: “The turtle! the turtle!” replied the reporter.“Don’t you know that the sea turned it over?”

zh: “这谁知道呢？”工程师低语道。
en: “Who knows?” murmured the engineer.

zh: “但是——”纳布说。
en: “But,—” said Neb.

zh: 纳布很明显有话要说，但是他只张了张嘴，却什么也没有说。
en: Neb had evidently something to say, for he opened his mouth to speak and yet said nothing.

zh: “你想说什么，纳布？”工程师问道。
en: “What do you want to say, Neb?” asked the engineer.

zh: “如果我们沿着海岸回到爪角，”纳布回答说，“再次绕过爪角，就会被——”
en: “If we return by the shore to Claw Cape,” replied Neb, “after having doubled the Cape, we shall be stopped—”

zh: “被慈悲河拦住！当然了，”赫伯特回答道，“而我们既没有桥也没有船可以过河。”
en: “By the Mercy! of course,” replied Herbert, “and we shall have neither bridge nor boat by which to cross.”

zh: “但是，上尉，”潘克洛夫补充道，“在河里放上一些漂浮的树干，我们就可以毫不费力地过去了。”
en: “But, captain,” added Pencroft, “with a few floating trunks we shall have no difficulty in crossing the river.”

zh: “不要紧，”史佩莱说道，“如果我们想要轻松地到达远西森林，搭座桥会有用！”
en: “Never mind,” said Spilett, “it will be useful to construct a bridge if we wish to have an easy access to the Far West!”

zh: “一座桥！”潘克洛夫喊道，“是啊，上尉不是最好的工程师吗？如果我们需要，他可以帮我们造桥。至于今天晚上如何把你们衣不沾水地送到慈悲河的另一岸去，就看我的吧。我们还有一天的食物，而且也可以打到很多猎物。前进吧！”
en: “A bridge!” cried Pencroft.“Well, is not the captain the best engineer in his profession?He will make us a bridge when we want one.As to transporting you this evening to the other side of the Mercy, and that without wetting one thread of your clothes, I will take care of that.We have provisions for another day, and besides we can get plenty of game.Forward!”

zh: 记者的提议得到了水手的强力支持，也得到了大家的普遍认可，因为每个人都想解除心中的疑虑，从爪角回去后，这次探险就可以结束了。但是现在刻不容缓，因为40英里是一段很长的距离，而且他们也不能指望在天黑前回到花岗石宫。
en: The reporter’s proposal, so strongly seconded by the sailor, received general approbation, for each wished to have their doubts set at rest, and by returning by Claw Cape the exploration would he ended.But there was not an hour to lose, for forty miles was a long march, and they could not hope to reach Granite House before night.

zh: 早上六点的时候，他们这小队人马又出发了。为了谨慎起见，他们在枪膛里装上子弹，而托普在前面打头阵，并听话地搜寻着森林的边缘地带。
en: At six o’clock in the morning the little band set out.As a precaution the guns were loaded with ball, and Top, who led the van, received orders to beat about the edge of the forest.

zh: 在半岛尾端的海角尽头，环形的海岸线有五英里长，他们很快就搜查过了。但即便是万分仔细地查看，也没有发现任何以前或是新近登陆留下的痕迹，没有碎片残骸，没有宿营的痕迹，没有燃烧的灰烬，甚至连一只脚印也没有。
en: From the extremity of the promontory which formed the tail of the peninsula the coast was rounded for a distance of five miles, which was rapidly passed over, without even the most minute investigations bringing to light the least trace of any old or recent landings; no debris, no mark of an encampment, no cinders of a fire, nor even a footprint!

zh: 从居民们现在所处半岛的位置，可以朝西南方向看过去。离海岸25英里处就是爪角，它在清晨的薄雾中看起来有点模糊，而且由于海市蜃楼的影响，它看起来仿佛悬于陆地和大海之间。
en: From the point of the peninsula on which the settlers now were their gaze could extend along the southwest.Twenty-five miles off the coast terminated in the Claw Cape, which loomed dimly through the morning mists, and which, by the phenomenon of the mirage, appeared as if suspended between land and water.

zh: 在他们现在所处的位置与另一侧的广阔海湾之间，海岸由三部分组成：先是一块低地，边上长有树木；中间一部分的海岸比较曲折，有些突出的尖角直插入大海；最后是一片黑色的岩石，凌乱成堆，独特如画，形成了爪角。
en: Between the place occupied by the colonists and the other side of the immense bay, the shore was composed, first, of a tract of low land, bordered in the background by trees; then the shore became more irregular, projecting sharp points into the sea, and finally ended in the black rocks which, accumulated in picturesque disorder, formed Claw Cape.

zh: 小岛这一带的地形就是如此，居民们一看就立刻停了下来。
en: Such was the development of this part of the island, which the settlers took in at a glance, while stopping for an instant.

zh: “如果有船只航行到这里，”潘克洛夫说，“那肯定得迷路。到处都是沙洲和暗礁！糟糕的地方！”
en: “If a vessel ran in here,” said Pencroft, “she would certainly be lost.Sandbanks and reefs everywhere!Bad quarters!”

zh: “但是至少也会有船只的遗骸吧。”记者说道。
en: “But at least something would be left of the ship,” observed the reporter.

zh: “岩石上或许会留下木片，但是沙滩上却不会有。”水手回答道。
en: “There might be pieces of wood on the rocks, but nothing on the sands,” replied the sailor.

zh: “为什么？”
en: “Why?”

zh: “因为沙子要比岩石危险得多，他们可以吞没落在上面的一切东西。只要几天时间，一具几百吨重的船体就会完全消失在那里！”
en: “Because the sands are still more dangerous than the rocks, for they swallow up everything that is thrown on them.In a few days the hull of a ship of several hundred tons would disappear entirely in there!”

zh: “那么，潘克洛夫，”工程师问道，“如果有船只在这一带海岸失事，现在找不到任何它的遗骸的痕迹，也不足为奇吗？”
en: “So, Pencroft,” asked the engineer, “if a ship has been wrecked on these banks, is it not astonishing that there is now no trace of her remaining?”

zh: “是的，哈丁先生，加上时间和风暴的作用。但即便是这样，总该有些桅杆或是横杆抛到海浪打不着的海滩上，要不然就太奇怪了。”
en: “No, captain, with the aid of time and tempest.However, it would be surprising, even in this case, that some of the masts or spars should not have been thrown on the beach, out of reach of the waves.”

zh: “我们还是继续搜寻吧。”赛勒斯·哈丁说道。
en: “Let us go on with our search, then,” returned Cyrus Harding.

zh: 一点的时候，拓荒者们到达了华盛顿湾的另一面，他们现在已经走了20英里了。
en: At one o’clock the colonists arrived at the other side of Washington Bay, they having now gone a distance of twenty miles.

zh: 接着，他们停下来吃早饭。
en: They then halted for breakfast.

zh: 从这里开始，海岸变得曲折起来，上面布满岩石和沙洲。翻滚的巨浪拍打在海湾的岩石上，溅起泡沫，形成一道水线。从这个角度向爪角望过去，夹在森林边缘和暗礁之间的海滩十分狭窄。
en: Here began the irregular coast, covered with lines of rocks and sandbanks.The long sea-swell could be seen breaking over the rocks in the bay, forming a foamy fringe.From this point to Claw Cape the beach was very narrow between the edge of the forest and the reefs.

zh: 大量的岩石挡在海滩上，使他们现在的行走越来越艰难。花岗石峭壁也越来越高，只能看到上面绿色的树顶。
en: Walking was now more difficult, on account of the numerous rocks which encumbered the beach.The granite cliff also gradually increased in height, and only the green tops of the trees which crowned it could be seen.

zh: 他们休息了半个小时后，又开始前行，而且他们查看了岩石间的每一处。无论何时有物体吸引注意，潘克洛夫和纳布甚至冲到海浪里去。但是他们什么也没找到，是一些形状怪异的岩石欺骗了他们。但他们可以确定的是，这里有很多食用贝类，然而现在最紧要的是要在慈悲河两岸间建立方便的通行方式，并且能够完善运输条件，否则这些对于他们也没什么大用处。
en: After half an hour’s rest, the settlers resumed their journey, and not a spot among the rocks was left unexamined.Pencroft and Neb even rushed into the surf whenever any object attracted their attention.But they found nothing, some curious formations of the rocks having deceived them.They ascertained, however, that eatable shellfish abounded there, but these could not be of any great advantage to them until some easy means of communication had been established between the two banks of the Mercy, and until the means of transport had been perfected.

zh: 他们在这片海岸上没有找到任何与猜想的失事船只有关的东西，虽然任何一样有价值的东西，例如船体，很容易就会看到，任何一根桅杆和木头都有可能被冲上岸，就像在20英里之外找到的那只箱子一样。但他们还是一无所获。
en: Nothing therefore which threw any light on the supposed wreck could be found on this shore, yet an object of any importance, such as the hull of a ship, would have been seen directly, or any of her masts and spans would have been washed on shore, just as the chest had been, which was found twenty miles from here.But there was nothing.

zh: 将近三点钟的时候，哈丁和同伴们来到了一条令人心旷神怡的小溪边。这里形成了一个天然的海港，在大海上是看不到的，它通过一条窄窄的海峡和大海相连。
en: Towards three o’clock Harding and his companions arrived at a snug little creek.It formed quite a natural harbor, invisible from the sea, and was entered by a narrow channel.

zh: 小溪后面的岩石圈由于剧烈的震荡裂开了，沿着其中一个断裂口，经过一个平缓的斜坡，可以到达上面的高地，这块高地距爪角至少约有10英里，因此与眺望岗的直线距离为四英里。吉丁·史佩莱向同伴们提议，在这里休息一会儿。大家欣然同意了，因为长时间跋涉他们都饿坏了，虽然还没到往常的吃饭时间，但是大家都想块肉，补充一下能量。这顿午饭会帮助他们坚持到晚饭时间，因为他们打算回到花岗石宫再吃晚饭。几分钟后，居民们坐在一丛美丽的海松下，纳布从袋中拿出食物，大家就狼吞虎咽地吃了起来。
en: At the back of this creek some violent convulsion had torn up the rocky border, and a cutting, by a gentle slope, gave access to an upper plateau, which might be situated at least ten miles from Claw Cape, and consequently four miles in a straight line from Prospect Heights.Gideon Spilett proposed to his companions that they should make a halt here.They agreed readily, for their walk had sharpened their appetites; and although it was not their usual dinner-hour, no one refused to strengthen himself with a piece of venison.This luncheon would sustain them until their supper, which they intended to take at Granite House.In a few minutes the settlers, seated under a clump of fine sea-pines, were devouring the provisions which Neb produced from his bag.

zh: 这块高地比海平面高出50到60英尺。在上面可以看到很远的地方，但是爪角之外就只能看到联合湾。在这里也看不到小岛和眺望岗，而且也不可能看到，因为隆起的高地和树林形成的屏障遮住了北方的视野。
en: This spot was raised from fifty to sixty feet above the level of the sea.The view was very extensive, but beyond the cape it ended in Union Bay.Neither the islet nor Prospect Heights was visible, and could not be from thence, for the rising ground and the curtain of trees closed the northern horizon.

zh: 不用说，虽然探险者们可以看到广阔的海面，工程师甚至依靠望远镜来拓展视野，但是依旧没有发现船的影子。
en: It is useless to add that notwithstanding the wide extent of sea which the explorers could survey, and though the engineer swept the horizon with his glass, no vessel could be found.

zh: 当然他们也同样仔细地查看了海岸，从海水边缘到峭壁，甚至用上了仪器，可是仍然一无所获。
en: The shore was of course examined with the same care from the edge of the water to the cliff, and nothing could be discovered even with the aid of the instrument.

zh: “好吧，”吉丁·史佩莱说道，“看来我们大可安心，没有人会和我们起争执，抢林肯岛了！”
en: “Well,” said Gideon Spilett, “it seems we must make up our minds to console ourselves with thinking that no one will come to dispute with us the possession of Lincoln Island!”

zh: “但是那颗子弹，”赫伯特喊道，“不是凭空想象出来的，我想！”
en: “But the bullet,” cried Herbert.“That was not imaginary, I suppose!”

zh: “见鬼，当然不是！”潘克洛夫想起他那颗被硌掉的牙齿，大喊。
en: “Hang it, no!” exclaimed Pencroft, thinking of his absent tooth.

zh: “那这要作何结论呢？”记者问道。
en: “Then what conclusion may be drawn?” asked the reporter.

zh: “是这样，”工程师回答道，“三个月或更久之前，一艘船，主动或者被迫地，来到了这里。”
en: “This,” replied the engineer, “that three months or more ago, a vessel, either voluntarily or not, came here.”

zh: “什么！赛勒斯，你承认这艘船被吞没了，而且没有留下任何痕迹吗？”记者喊道。
en: “What! then you admit, Cyrus, that she was swallowed up without leaving any trace?” cried the reporter.

zh: “不，亲爱的史佩莱。但是你想，如果真的有人在小岛上登陆，看起来他现在同样有可能离开了。”
en: “No, my dear Spilett; but you see that if it is certain that a human being set foot on the island, it appears no less certain that he has now left it.”

zh: “嗯，如果我理解得没错，上尉，”赫伯特说道，“那艘船又离开了？”
en: “Then, if I understand you right, captain,” said Herbert, “the vessel has left again?”

zh: “显然是这样。”
en: “Evidently.”

zh: “那我们岂不是失去了一次可以返回国的机会？”纳布说道。
en: “And we have lost an opportunity to get back to our country?” said Neb.

zh: “恐怕是这样的。”
en: “I fear so.”

zh: “那好，既然失去了这次机会，我们还是继续前进吧，这也是没有办法的事。”潘克洛夫说，他忽然很想念花岗石宫那个家了。
en: “Very well, since the opportunity is lost, let us go on; it can’t be helped,” said Pencroft, who felt home-sickness for Granite House.

zh: 但他们正要起身的时候，忽然听到托普大声地吠叫，它从树林里跑了出来，嘴里衔了一块沾着污泥的脏布。
en: But just as they were rising, Top was heard loudly barking; and the dog issued from the wood, holding in his mouth a rag soiled with mud.

zh: 纳布一把抓了过来。那是一块很结实的布！
en: Neb seized it.It was a piece of strong cloth!

zh: 托普仍然在狂吠，并且不停地走来走去，仿佛是想要主人跟它到森林里去。
en: Top still barked, and by his going and coming, seemed to invite his master to follow him into the forest.

zh: “这下可以解释那颗子弹了！”潘克洛夫喊道。
en: “Now there’s something to explain the bullet!” exclaimed Pencroft.

zh: “一个落难者！”赫伯特答道。
en: “A castaway!” replied Herbert.

zh: “说不定还受伤了！”纳布说道。
en: “Wounded, perhaps!” said Neb.

zh: “或者已经死了！”记者补充道。
en: “Or dead!” added the reporter.

zh: 他们跟着托普，在森林边缘高高的松树间跑了起来。哈丁和同伴们还准备好了火器，以防不测。
en: All ran after the dog, among the tall pines on the border of the forest.Harding and his companions made ready their firearms, in case of an emergency.

zh: 他们跟着托普跑到树林里来了，但令人失望的是，他们仍然没有看到有人来过的痕迹。灌木丛和藤蔓都没有动过，他们甚至不得不用斧子劈开一条道来，就像他们曾经在森林深处那样。很难想象会有什么人曾经到过这里，但是托普仍在来回奔跑，不像是在随意寻找什么东西，而像是有心追寻它的什么想法。
en: They advanced some way into the wood, but to their great disappointment, they as yet saw no signs of any human being having passed that way.Shrubs and creepers were uninjured, and they had even to cut them away with the axe, as they had done in the deepest recesses of the forest.It was difficult to fancy that any human creature had ever passed there, but yet Top went backward and forward, not like a dog who searches at random, but like a dog being endowed with a mind, who is following up an idea.

zh: 七八分钟后，托普在一片空地上停了下来，周围都是高高的树木。居民们仔细看了看周围，但什么也没看到，灌木丛下、树林间什么都没有。
en: In about seven or eight minutes Top stopped in a glade surrounded with tall trees.The settlers gazed around them, but saw nothing, neither under the bushes nor among the trees.

zh: “怎么回事，托普？”赛勒斯·哈丁说道。
en: “What is the matter, Top?” said Cyrus Harding.

zh: 托普叫得更大声了，它在一颗高大的松树下来回蹦跳。突然潘克洛夫大叫：“噢，太好了！上尉！”
en: Top barked louder, bounding about at the foot of a gigantic pine.All at once Pencroft shouted,—“Ho, splendid! capital!”

zh: “是什么？”史佩莱问道。
en: “What is it?” asked Spilett.

zh: “我们一直是在海上或是陆地上寻找的失事船只！”
en: “We have been looking for a wreck at sea or on land!”

zh: “怎么？”
en: “Well?”

zh: “是这样，现在却在空中找到了！”
en: “Well; and here we’ve found one in the air!”

zh: 水手指着松树顶上挂着的一块大白布，托普刚才带给他们的是其中掉落下来的一小块。
en: And the sailor pointed to a great white rag, caught in the top of the pine, a fallen scrap of which the dog had brought to them.

zh: “但那不是船的残骸！”吉丁·史佩莱喊道。
en: “But that is not a wreck!” cried Gideon Spilett.

zh: “您再说一遍！”潘克洛夫回道。
en: “I beg your pardon!” returned Pencroft.

zh: “怎么？它是——”
en: “Why? is it—?”

zh: “那是我们的飞船，我们的气球遗留下来的东西，它挂在上面，就在这棵树顶上！”
en: “It is all that remains of our airy boat, of our balloon, which has been caught up aloft there, at the top of that tree!”

zh: 潘克洛夫说的没错，他激动地欢呼着，说道——
en: Pencroft was not mistaken, and he gave vent to his feelings in a tremendous hurrah, adding,—

zh: “那可是块好布呢！有了它，我们这几年就不缺亚麻布了。我们可以用它做成手帕和衬衫！哈，哈，史佩莱先生，对于树上都能长出衬衫来的小岛，你还能说些什么？”
en: “There is good cloth!There is what will furnish us with linen for years.There is what will make us handkerchiefs and shirts!Ha, ha, Mr. Spilett, what do you say to an island where shirts grow on the trees?”

zh: 这只气球在最后一次弹回空中，又降落到这个岛上，并且又给机会让他们再次找到，无论他们是想要保持气球的现状，还是想用它再次脱逃，或者是利用那质量上好的几百码棉布，这对于林肯岛上的居民来讲都无疑是一件幸运的事。因而大家都和潘克洛夫一样高兴。
en: It was certainly a lucky circumstance for the settlers in Lincoln Island that the balloon, after having made its last bound into the air, had fallen on the island and thus given them the opportunity of finding it again, whether they kept the case under its present form, or whether they wished to attempt another escape by it, or whether they usefully employed the several hundred yards of cotton, which was of fine quality.Pencroft’s joy was therefore shared by all.

zh: 但现在要做的就是从树上把残留的气球取下来，保管好，这可不是件轻松的事。纳布、赫伯特和水手爬到树顶上，想尽办法把已经瘪了的气球取了下来。
en: But it was necessary to bring down the remains of the balloon from the tree, to place it in security, and this was no slight task.Neb, Herbert, and the sailor, climbing to the summit of the tree, used all their skill to disengage the now reduced balloon.

zh: 这个过程持续了两个小时，他们不仅把带有阀门、弹簧和黄铜零件的气球取了下来，而且还有网，也就是一大团绳索，还有绳环和铁锚都弄了下来。这只气球除了下面有些破损之外，其他部分都完好无损。
en: The operation lasted two hours, and then not only the case, with its valve, its springs, its brasswork, lay on the ground, but the net, that is to say a considerable quantity of ropes and cordage, and the circle and the anchor.The case, except for the fracture, was in good condition, only the lower portion being torn.

zh: 这真是从天而降的财富啊。
en: It was a fortune which had fallen from the sky.

zh: “尽管如此，上尉，”水手说道，“如果我们决意离开这个小岛，也不会是乘气球离开，对吧？这种飞船不是我们想去哪就能去哪的，我们在这方面可是有经验了！这样吧，我们建造一艘约有20吨重的船，然后用那块布做一面主帆、一面前桅帆和一面三角帆。至于剩下的布可以用来做衣服。”
en: “All the same, captain,” said the sailor, “if we ever decide to leave the island, it won’t be in a balloon, will it?These airboats won’t go where we want them to go, and we have had some experience in that way!Look here, we will build a craft of some twenty tons, and then we can make a main-sail, a foresail, and a jib out of that cloth.As to the rest of it, that will help to dress us.”

zh: “看看再说吧，潘克洛夫，”赛勒斯·哈丁回答道，“看看再说。”
en: “We shall see, Pencroft,” replied Cyrus Harding; “we shall see.”

zh: “现在我们必须把它放到一个安全的地方。”纳布说。
en: “In the meantime, we must put it in a safe place,” said Neb.

zh: 他们当然不可能把这一大块布、绳子和索具搬回花岗石宫，因为那是相当重的，在用合适的工具运走它之前，重要的是不能再任由风雨侵蚀这个宝贝。居民们在海岸上发现了一个很大的岩石洞穴，位置很好，不会透风也不会漏雨，于是就齐力把气球拖了进去。
en: They certainly could not think of carrying this load of cloth, ropes, and cordage, to Granite House, for the weight of it was very considerable, and while waiting for a suitable vehicle in which to convey it, it was of importance that this treasure should not be left longer exposed to the mercies of the first storm.The settlers, uniting their efforts, managed to drag it as far as the shore, where they discovered a large rocky cavity, which owing to its position could not be visited either by the wind or rain.

zh: “我们需要一个储物柜，现在已经有了，”潘克洛夫说道，“但是既然我们不能上锁，谨慎起见，还是把洞口遮住。我倒不是说两条腿的小偷，而是那些四只脚掌的！”
en: “We needed a locker, and now we have one,” said Pencroft; “but as we cannot lock it up, it will be prudent to hide the opening.I don’t mean from two-legged thieves, but from those with four paws!”

zh: 六点的时候，一切都收拾好了，他们给小溪起了一个十分恰当的名字“气球港”，然后就沿着爪角继续前进。潘克洛夫和工程师讨论了许多计划，大家一致同意尽快实施。当务之急是要在慈悲河上架桥，这样就可以轻松地到达小岛的南部了。然后必须把推车拉过来，把气球运回去，因为只用小舟是带不走的。此外，他们还要建造一只甲板船，而且潘克洛夫会进一步把它装备成单桅快速帆船，这样他们就能乘船环游小岛了，还有一些诸如此类的事。
en: At six o’clock, all was stowed away, and after having given the creek the very suitable name of “Port Balloon,” the settlers pursued their way along Claw Cape.Pencroft and the engineer talked of the different projects which it was agreed to put into execution with the briefest possible delay.It was necessary first of all to throw a bridge over the Mercy, so as to establish an easy communication with the south of the island; then the cart must be taken to bring back the balloon, for the canoe alone could not carry it, then they would build a decked boat, and Pencroft would rig it as a cutter, and they would be able to undertake voyages of circumnavigation round the island, etc.

zh: 现在夜幕降临，居民们到达遗物角的时候，也就是到他们发现那只宝贵的箱子的地方时，天色已经黑了。
en: In the meanwhile night came on, and it was already dark when the settlers reached Flotsam Point, where they had found the precious chest.

zh: 遗物角和花岗石宫之间的距离有四英里，居民们沿着海岸走到慈悲河口，到达慈悲河第一个拐角的时候，已经是午夜了。
en: The distance between Flotsam Point and Granite House was another four miles, and it was midnight when, after having followed the shore to the mouth of the Mercy, the settlers arrived at the first angle formed by the Mercy.

zh: 河面有80英尺宽，很难渡过去，但先前潘克洛夫把解决这个难题的重任揽到自己身上，因而就不得不想办法做了。居民们经过一天的跋涉，已经疲惫不堪了。这次探险的行程太长了，而且把气球弄下来，更是没让手脚歇着。他们迫切地想要回到花岗石宫，吃点东西，休息一下，要是桥建好了，只需一刻钟他们就能回到家了。
en: There the river was eighty feet in breadth, which was awkward to cross, but as Pencroft had taken upon himself to conquer this difficulty, he was compelled to do it.The settlers certainly had reason to be pretty tired.The journey had been long, and the task of getting down the balloon had not rested either their arms or legs.They were anxious to reach Granite House to eat and sleep, and if the bridge had been constructed, in a quarter of an hour they would have been at home.

zh: 夜色愈加黑暗。潘克洛夫准备建造一只木筏，让大家渡过慈悲河，以兑现自己的诺言。他和纳布拿着斧子，在河边选了两棵树，朝着根部就砍了起来。
en: The night was very dark.Pencroft prepared to keep his promise by constructing a sort of raft, on which to make the passage of the Mercy.He and Neb, armed with axes, chose two trees near the water, and began to attack them at the base.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和史佩莱坐在河边坐着，等同伴们需要的时候就去帮忙，赫伯特就在一边徘徊，但并没有走很远。在河边闲逛的少年突然跑了回来，指着慈悲河，喊道：
en: Cyrus Harding and Spilett, seated on the bank, waited till their companions were ready for their help, while Herbert roamed about, though without going to any distance.All at once, the lad, who had strolled by the river, came running back, and, pointing up the Mercy, exclaimed,—

zh: “那漂的是什么？”
en: “What is floating there?”

zh: 潘克洛夫停下手中的活，看到一个难以辨认的物体在黑暗中移动。
en: Pencroft stopped working, and seeing an indistinct object moving through the gloom,—

zh: “一只小舟！”他喊道。
en: “A canoe!” cried he.

zh: 大家走近一看，都十分震惊，一只小船正顺流而下。
en: All approached, and saw to their extreme surprise, a boat floating down the current.

zh: “船啊，喂！”水手不假思索地大喊，都没想到这时最好保持沉默。
en: “Boat ahoy!” shouted the sailor, without thinking that perhaps it would be best to keep silence.

zh: 没人回答。小船继续向前漂，离他们不到12英尺的时候，水手大喊：
en: No reply.The boat still drifted onward, and it was not more than twelve feet off, when the sailor exclaimed,—

zh: “是我们自己的船！它从停泊的地方松开，顺流漂下来了。我得说它来得可真是凑巧。”
en: “But it is our own boat! she has broken her moorings, and floated down the current.I must say she has arrived very opportunely.”

zh: “我们的船？”工程师低语道。
en: “Our boat?” murmured the engineer.

zh: 潘克洛夫说得没错。那确实是他们的小舟，无疑是系船的绳子断了，它才从慈悲河发源地独自漂了过来。现在必须趁急流把小船冲离河口之前截住它，纳布和潘克洛夫巧妙地用一根长竿截住了小船。
en: Pencroft was right.It was indeed the canoe, of which the rope had undoubtedly broken, and which had come alone from the sources of the Mercy.It was very important to seize it before the rapid current should have swept it away out of the mouth of the river, but Neb and Pencroft cleverly managed this by means of a long pole.

zh: 小舟靠岸了。工程师第一个跳了进去，他检查了一下绳子，发现绳子确实是在岩石上磨断的。
en: The canoe touched the shore.The engineer leaped in first, and found, on examining the rope, that it had been really worn through by rubbing against the rocks.

zh: “嗯，”记者低声对他说，“这真是奇怪。”
en: “Well,” said the reporter to him, in a low voice, “this is a strange thing.”

zh: “确实很奇怪！”赛勒斯·哈丁回答道。
en: “Strange indeed!” returned Cyrus Harding.

zh: 不管是不是很奇怪，他们确实是很幸运。赫伯特、记者纳布和潘克洛夫也相继跳上了船。绳子无疑是磨断的，但这件事奇怪是，小船刚好是他们在这里被他们截住，要是早一刻钟或是晚一刻钟，小船说不定就被冲进大海里去了。
en: Strange or not, it was very fortunate.Herbert, the reporter, Neb, and Pencroft, embarked in turn.There was no doubt about the rope having been worn through, but the astonishing part of the affair was, that the boat should arrive just at the moment when the settlers were there to seize it on its way, for a quarter of an hour earlier or later it would have been lost in the sea.

zh: 他们现在生活的时代已经不相信鬼神了，否则他们准会认为这个小岛上有什么神灵出没，运用神力来帮助这群落难者了。
en: If they had been living in the time of genii, this incident would have given them the right to think that the island was haunted by some supernatural being, who used his power in the service of the castaways!

zh: 居民们划了几下桨，就到了慈悲河口。他们把小船拉到石窟旁边的海滩上，然后就朝花岗石宫的梯子走了过去。
en: A few strokes of the oar brought the settlers to the mouth of the Mercy.The canoe was hauled up on the beach near the Chimneys, and all proceeded towards the ladder of Granite House.

zh: 但就在那时，托普愤怒地狂吠了起来，正四下寻找第一节梯子的纳布也喊了一声。
en: But at that moment, Top barked angrily, and Neb, who was looking for the first steps, uttered a cry.

zh: 梯子不见了！
en: There was no longer a ladder!

zh: 第六章
en: Chapter 6

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁一句话也不说，站在那里。他的同伴们在黑暗中摸索着石壁前行，梯子也许是被大风吹到了地上，想着它可能掉到地上。可是，它却消失了。至于说梯子是否被风暴卷到了半空中的平台，这在黑暗中还无从考证。
en: Cyrus Harding stood still, without saying a word.His companions searched in the darkness on the wall, in case the wind should have moved the ladder, and on the ground, thinking that it might have fallen down....But the ladder had quite disappeared.As to ascertaining if a squall had blown it on the landing-place, half way up, that was impossible in the dark.

zh: “就算是玩笑，”潘克洛夫喊道，“这玩笑开得也太没劲了！要回家还找不到爬上去的梯子，对我们这些疲惫的人来说，这玩笑开得也太大了。”
en: “If it is a joke,” cried Pencroft, “it is a very stupid one!To come home and find no staircase to go up to your room by—that’s nothing for weary men to laugh at.”

zh: 纳布只能狂喊：“天哪！天哪！天哪！”
en: Neb could do nothing but cry out “Oh! oh! oh!”

zh: “我现在开始相信现林肯岛上是有怪事发生！”潘克洛夫说道。
en: “I begin to think that very curious things happen in Lincoln Island!” said Pencroft.

zh: “怪事？”吉丁·史佩莱接过话来说，“一点儿也不怪，潘克洛夫，这些再自然不过了。肯定有人趁我们不在的时候来过，他们不仅占了我们的窝，还把梯子收起来了。”
en: “Curious?” replied Gideon Spilett, “not at all, Pencroft, nothing can be more natural.Some one has come during our absence, taken possession of our dwelling and drawn up the ladder.”

zh: “有人，”水手喊道，“是谁呢？”
en: “Some one,” cried the sailor.“But who?”

zh: “除了那个开枪的猎人还会有谁？”记者接着说。
en: “Who but the hunter who fired the bullet?” replied the reporter.

zh: “哼，要是真有人在上面，”潘克洛夫说，他开始没有耐性了，“我跟他们打招呼，他们肯定会回答的。”
en: “Well, if there is any one up there,” replied Pencroft, who began to lose patience, “I will give them a hail, and they must answer.”

zh: “喂！”水手拉长声音喊了喊，洪亮的回声在悬崖和岩石之间传来传去。
en: And in a stentorian voice the sailor gave a prolonged “Halloo!” which was echoed again and again from the cliff and rocks.

zh: 居民们仔细听了听，总觉他们听到咯咯笑的声音，就是不知道是从哪里传来的。没有人回应潘克洛夫的叫喊，他又使劲地喊了好几嗓子，可是徒劳无果。
en: The settlers listened and they thought they heard a sort of chuckling laugh, of which they could not guess the origin.But no voice replied to Pencroft, who in vain repeated his vigorous shouts.

zh: 这件事真是能使最冷漠的人都觉得惊讶，而这批居民并不是这样的人。在他们所处的这种环境下，每件事都有它的重要性，而且，呆在岛上的这七个月里，他们还没有遇到过这么奇怪的事，这点是毫无疑问的。
en: There was something indeed in this to astonish the most apathetic of men, and the settlers were not men of that description.In their situation every incident had its importance, and, certainly, during the seven months which they had spent on the island, they had not before met with anything of so surprising a character.

zh: 尽管这件事的异常可能使他们都忘记了身体的疲惫，但他们还是只能呆在花岗石宫下面，不知道该怎样思考，不知道该做什么，相互问着，但是没有得到满意答案的希望，大家都开始胡乱猜想，而且一个比一个想得离奇。纳布感到悲伤，为自己不能进入厨房而非常沮丧，因为他们路上带的食物都吃完了，可他们却没法进行补充。
en: Be that as it may, forgetting their fatigue in the singularity of the event, they remained below Granite House, not knowing what to think, not knowing what to do, questioning each other without any hope of a satisfactory reply, every one starting some supposition each more unlikely than the last.Neb bewailed himself, much disappointed at not being able to get into his kitchen, for the provisions which they had had on their expedition were exhausted, and they had no means of renewing them.

zh: “朋友们，”赛勒斯·哈丁终于说道：“现在我们能做的只有一件事，那就是等到天亮，然后见机行事。不过我们要先去石窟那里。那里毕竟可以遮风挡雨，就算没有吃的，至少我们还能睡个觉。”
en: “My friends,” at last said Cyrus Harding, “there is only one thing to be done at present; wait for day, and then act according to circumstances.But let us go to the Chimneys.There we shall be under shelter, and if we cannot eat, we can at least sleep.”

zh: “可到底是谁在跟我们玩这个残酷的把戏呢？”潘克洛夫又问起来了，他还不能下定决定离开这个地方。
en: “But who is it that has played us this cool trick?” again asked Pencroft, unable to make up his mind to retire from the spot.

zh: 可不管是谁，唯一可行的方案就是遵照工程师的提议，去石窟那里等待天亮。这个时候，他们还命令托普在花岗石宫的窗户下面守着，托普一接到命令，就不发任何质疑地开始执行。因此，这只勇敢的狗在悬崖脚下留下来了，而它的主人则和同伴们在岩石中找了个栖息之所。
en: Whoever it was, the only thing practicable was to do as the engineer proposed, to go to the Chimneys and there wait for day.In the meanwhile Top was ordered to mount guard below the windows of Granite House, and when Top received an order he obeyed it without any questioning.The brave dog therefore remained at the foot of the cliff while his master with his companions sought a refuge among the rocks.

zh: 居民们虽然很累，但要说他们在石窟的沙地上睡得好是不可能的。这不仅是因为他们急着要找出发生事情的原因，不管这些只是一场意外，等天一亮，他们或许能找到答案；还是相反，这些都是某个人所为，更糟糕的是，在这里睡觉非常舒服。但是，再怎么左思右想也都白搭，目前他们住的地方被占了，他们还没法进去。
en: To say that the settlers, notwithstanding their fatigue, slept well on the sandy floor of the Chimneys would not be true.It was not only that they were extremely anxious to find out the cause of what had happened, whether it was the result of an accident which would be discovered at the return of day, or whether on the contrary it was the work of a human being; but they also had very uncomfortable beds.That could not be helped, however, for in some way or other at that moment their dwelling was occupied, and they could not possibly enter it.

zh: 花岗石宫不仅仅是他们住处，还是他们的仓库。那里存放了开拓者们所有的储物，像武器、设备、工具、火药和粮食等等。想到这些东西都可能被抢走，他们所有的工作都要重做一遍，还要制造新的武器和工具，这些都是严重的问题。他们内心非常不安，隔几分钟就有个人会去看一下托普是否在好好看着。赛勒斯·哈丁还像往常一样耐心地呆着，虽然他那坚强的意志在面对难以解释的事实时被激怒了，而且，他一让某种莫名的感觉影响了自己，心里就恼恨不已。吉丁·史佩莱也有同样的感受，他们两个人轻声谈论着难以解释的一切，再聪明、再有经验的他们这回也感到困惑了。
en: Now Granite House was more than their dwelling, it was their warehouse.There were all the stores belonging to the colony, weapons, instruments, tools, ammunition, provisions, etc.To think that all that might be pillaged and that the settlers would have all their work to do over again, fresh weapons and tools to make, was a serious matter.Their uneasiness led one or other of them also to go out every few minutes to see if Top was keeping good watch.Cyrus Harding alone waited with his habitual patience, although his strong mind was exasperated at being confronted with such an inexplicable fact, and he was provoked at himself for allowing a feeling to which he could not give a name, to gain an influence over him.Gideon Spilett shared his feelings in this respect, and the two conversed together in whispers of the inexplicable circumstance which baffled even their intelligence and experience.

zh: “这肯定是个玩笑，”潘克洛夫说，“肯定有人在背后开我们的玩笑。这样的玩笑我可不喜欢，开玩笑的那个人最好小心点，要是栽在我手里，就有他好看的！”
en: “It is a joke,” said Pencroft; “it is a trick some one has played us.Well, I don’t like such jokes, and the joker had better look out for himself, if he falls into my hands, I can tell him.”

zh: 一线曙光初现东方，拓荒者们就全副武装，回到花岗石宫下面的沙滩上。升起的太阳照在悬崖上，透过层层树叶，他们能窗户，百叶窗是关着的。
en: As soon as the first gleam of light appeared in the east, the colonists, suitably armed, repaired to the beach under Granite House.The rising sun now shone on the cliff and they could see the windows, the shutters of which were closed, through the curtains of foliage.

zh: 一切看上去都很正常，不过，当拓荒者们看到临走时关好的门大开时，他们都失声大叫了起来。
en: All here was in order; but a cry escaped the colonists when they saw that the door, which they had closed on their departure, was now wide open.

zh: 有人进入了花岗石宫，这已经是毋庸置疑的事实。
en: Some one had entered Granite House—there could be no more doubt about that.

zh: 从门口挂到平台上的上半段梯子还在原地，可下半段梯子却被提到了与门口齐平的地方。很明显，入侵者想要这样保护自己，防止意外侵袭。
en: The upper ladder, which generally hung from the door to the landing, was in its place, but the lower ladder was drawn up and raised to the threshold.It was evident that the intruders had wished to guard themselves against a surprise.

zh: 潘克洛夫又喊了一嗓子。
en: Pencroft hailed again.

zh: 可是没有人回答。
en: No reply.

zh: “这帮混蛋，”水手喊到，“他们睡得还挺香，就像在自己家里一样。喂，你们这帮强盗、土匪、盗贼、‘约翰牛’养的！”
en: “The beggars,” exclaimed the sailor.“There they are sleeping quietly as if they were in their own house.Hallo there, you pirates, brigands, robbers, sons of John Bull!”

zh: 潘克洛夫是美国佬，他要是给某人冠以“约翰牛养的”的骂名，就算是把那人侮辱到极点了。
en: When Pencroft, being a Yankee, treated any one to the epithet of “son of John Bull,” he considered he had reached the last limits of insult.

zh: 太阳已经完全升起来了，花岗石宫的整个外表也被光线照得很亮，可石宫的里面和外面一样，都是安静的。
en: The sun had now completely risen, and the whole facade of Granite House became illuminated by its rays; but in the interior as well as on the exterior all was quiet and calm.

zh: 居民们都想知道花岗石宫里是否有人居住，而梯子的位置足以表明里面有人。另外可以肯定的是，不管那些人是谁，都不能逃出去。不过，怎么才能把他们抓住呢？
en: The settlers asked if Granite House was inhabited or not, and yet the position of the ladder was sufficient to show that it was; it was also certain that the inhabitants, whoever they might be, had not been able to escape.But how were they to be got at?

zh: 然后，赫伯特想到在箭上系个绳索，他可以将箭射到挂在门口梯子上的第一个空挡。他们可以通过绳索把梯子拉到地面上来，这样从沙滩到花岗石宫的通道就重新建立了。很明显，除此之外，他们没有别的办法，只需一点技术，这个方案就可能成功。幸运的是，石窟里留下了弓箭，他们还在那里找到了许多轻的木槿绳索。潘克洛夫把绳索系在扎好羽毛的箭上。接着，赫伯特把它固定在弓上，然后仔细瞄准了梯子的下半部分。
en: Herbert then thought of fastening a cord to an arrow, and shooting the arrow so that it should pass between the first rounds of the ladder which hung from the threshold.By means of the cord they would then be able to draw down the ladder to the ground, and so re-establish the communication between the beach and Granite House.There was evidently nothing else to be done, and, with a little skill, this method might succeed.Very fortunately bows and arrows had been left at the Chimneys, where they also found a quantity of light hibiscus cord.Pencroft fastened this to a well-feathered arrow.Then Herbert fixing it to his bow, took a careful aim for the lower part of the ladder.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁、吉丁·史佩莱、潘克洛夫和纳布都往后退了几步，这样他们就能看到窗户那里的动静。记者用肩膀托起了枪支，并用枪口对准了门口。
en: Cyrus Harding, Gideon Spilett, Pencroft, and Neb drew back, so as to see if anything appeared at the windows.The reporter lifted his gun to his shoulder and covered the door.

zh: 赫伯特一拉弓箭就射出去了，箭带着绳索穿过了梯子最后的两个空档。
en: The bow was bent, the arrow flew, taking the cord with it, and passed between the two last rounds.

zh: 他成功了！
en: The operation had succeeded.

zh: 赫伯特立马抓住了绳索的另一端，当他使劲想把梯子拉下来时，一只手臂突然从岩石和门之间伸出来，抓住绳索，拖进了花岗石宫里。
en: Herbert immediately seized the end of the cord, but, at that moment when he gave it a pull to bring down the ladder, an arm, thrust suddenly out between the wall and the door, grasped it and dragged it inside Granite House.

zh: “这帮混蛋！”水手喊道，“要是给你来一枪，你就别想活了。
en: “The rascals!” shouted the sailor.“If a ball can do anything for you, you shall not have long to wait for it.

zh: “那是谁呀？”纳布问道。
en: “But who was it?” asked Neb.

zh: “是谁？你没看到吗？”
en: “Who was it?Didn’t you see?”

zh: “没有。”
en: “No.”

zh: “那是一只猴子，一只卷尾猴，一只猩猩，一只狒狒，一只大猩猩，一只猿猴。我们的住所被一群猴子给攻占了，它们趁我们不在的时候，顺着梯子爬上去的。”
en: “It was a monkey, a sapajou, an orangoutang, a baboon, a gorilla, a sagoin.Our dwelling has been invaded by monkeys, who climbed up the ladder during our absence.”

zh: 这时，似乎为了证实水手的话，两三只灵长类动物出现在窗户旁，他们把百叶窗拉开，向这里真正的主人做起了无数个可恶的鬼脸。
en: And, at this moment, as if to bear witness to the truth of the sailor’s words, two or three quadrumana showed themselves at the windows, from which they had pushed back the shutters, and saluted the real proprietors of the place with a thousand hideous grimaces.

zh: “我就知道这只是个玩笑，”潘克洛夫喊道，“不过，它们这些开玩笑的总有一个要为其他的受罚！”
en: “I knew that it was only a joke,” cried Pencroft; “but one of the jokers shall pay the penalty for the rest.”

zh: 说罢，水手端起枪支迅速瞄准其中的一只猴子，并开了枪。所有的猴子都消失了，除了受到致命伤、倒在沙滩上的那只.这只体型庞大的猴子显然属于灵长类动物的第一类。不管它是一只黑猩猩，还是猩猩，或大猩猩，他们属于类人猿，这样叫它们是因为他们长得像人类。不过，赫伯特断定它是猩猩。
en: So saying, the sailor, raising his piece, took a rapid aim at one of the monkeys and fired.All disappeared, except one who fell mortally wounded on the beach.This monkey, which was of a large size, evidently belonged to the first order of the quadrumana.Whether this was a chimpanzee, an orangoutang, or a gorilla, he took rank among the anthropoid apes, who are so called from their resemblance to the human race.However, Herbert declared it to be an orangoutang.

zh: “多好的一只畜生啊！”纳布喊道。
en: “What a magnificent beast!” cried Neb.

zh: “你要说好那就是好吧！”潘克洛夫回答说，“可我还是没看出来我们怎么才能进屋！”
en: “Magnificent, if you like,” replied Pencroft; “but still I do not see how we are to get into our house.”

zh: “赫伯特是超级棒的神射手，”记者说道，“他的弓就在这儿。他可以再试一次。”
en: “Herbert is a good marksman,” said the reporter, “and his bow is here.He can try again.”

zh: “什么！这些猴子狡猾得很，”潘克洛夫说，“他们再也不会出现在窗户那里，所以我们也射不着它们，可我一想到它们可能在房间和仓库做的坏事，我就——”
en: “Why, these apes are so cunning,” returned Pencroft; “they won’t show themselves again at the windows and so we can’t kill them; and when I think of the mischief they may do in the rooms and storehouse—”

zh: “别着急，”哈丁回答说，“这些动物不能让我们一直在海湾上。”
en: “Have patience,” replied Harding; “these creatures cannot keep us long at bay.”

zh: “直到我看到它们下到这里，否则可不敢确信，”水手说道，“上尉，你现在能知道上面有几十个吗？”
en: “I shall not be sure of that till I see them down here,” replied the sailor.“And now, captain, do you know how many dozens of these fellows are up there?”

zh: 潘克洛夫这个问题很难回答，而且要让少年再试一次已经不是一件轻而易举的事了。因为梯子的下半部分又被拉到了门里，如果再射一箭，绳子会断，而梯子还是稳当地在原地。事情着实很复杂。潘克洛夫在一旁急得暴跳如雷。目前的形势还真有点滑稽，可他一点儿也不觉得好笑。居民们肯定能将入侵者赶出去，重夺家园，可到底是什么时候？他们又该怎么做？这还都是他们不知道的问题。
en: It was difficult to reply to Pencroft, and as for the young boy making another attempt, that was not easy; for the lower part of the ladder had been drawn again into the door, and when another pull was given, the line broke and the ladder remained firm.The case was really perplexing.Pencroft stormed.There was a comic side to the situation, but he did not think it funny at all.It was certain that the settlers would end by reinstating themselves in their domicile and driving out the intruders, but when and how? this is what they were not able to say.

zh: 两个小时过去了，这些猿猴很小心地不露面，可是它们还在那里，有三四次门缝里或窗户边都会探出一个鼻子或一只爪，不过立即就会被射上一枪。
en: Two hours passed, during which the apes took care not to show themselves, but they were still there, and three or four times a nose or a paw was poked out at the door or windows, and was immediately saluted by a gun-shot.

zh: “我们藏起来吧。”工程师最后说，“兴许这些猿猴会以为我们安静地走了，那样它们可能会再次现身。史佩莱和赫伯特躲在岩石后面，对准它们可能出现的地方开火。”
en: “Let us hide ourselves,” at last said the engineer.“Perhaps the apes will think we have gone quite away and will show themselves again.Let Spilett and Herbert conceal themselves behind those rocks and fire on all that may appear.”

zh: 大伙都遵照工程师的建议，记者和少年堪称这个开拓地最棒的神射手，他们站在很好的位置上，但不在猴子的视线内。而纳布、潘克洛夫和赛勒斯·哈则爬上高地进入了森林里，他们想捕点猎物，现在是吃点早餐的时间了，可是却没有食物剩下了。
en: The engineer’s orders were obeyed, and while the reporter and the lad, the best marksmen in the colony, posted themselves in a good position, but out of the monkeys’ sight, Neb, Pencroft, and Cyrus climbed the plateau and entered the forest in order to kill some game, for it was now time for breakfast and they had no provisions remaining.

zh: 半小时后，猎人们带回了几只野鸽，他们尽可能地把鸽子烤得好吃一点。还没有出现一只猿猴。吉丁·史佩莱和赫伯特去拿自己的早餐，只留下托普在窗户下面看着。吃完东西后，他们又回到了自己的位置。
en: In half an hour the hunters returned with a few rock pigeons, which they roasted as well as they could.Not an ape had appeared.Gideon Spilett and Herbert went to take their share of the breakfast, leaving Top to watch under the windows.They then, having eaten, returned to their post.

zh: 两小时过去了，可是情况没有任何进展。这些猴子没有任何现身的迹象，它们也不大可能已经离开，但可能性更大的是，它们被同伴的死和枪声吓到了，所以退到屋子的最里面，甚至是仓库里。当他们一想到仓库里放着的那些珍贵东西，工程师反复念叨的耐心迅速变为极度的恼怒，不过这当然是有原因的。
en: Two hours later, their situation was in no degree improved.The quadrumana gave no sign of existence, and it might have been supposed that they had disappeared; but what seemed more probable was that, terrified by the death of one of their companions, and frightened by the noise of the firearms, they had retreated to the back part of the house or probably even into the store-room.And when they thought of the valuables which this storeroom contained, the patience so much recommended by the engineer, fast changed into great irritation, and there certainly was room for it.

zh: “形势明显不利，”记者说，“可最糟糕的是，还没有结束这种局面的办法。”
en: “Decidedly it is too bad,” said the reporter; “and the worst of it is, there is no way of putting an end to it.”

zh: “不管怎样，我们都得把这帮混账东西赶出去，”水手喊道，“就算有二十多个恶棍，我们也能很快打败它们，只不过，我们必须与它们进行肉搏了。来吧，没法制服它们吗？”
en: “But we must drive these vagabonds out somehow,” cried the sailor.“We could soon get the better of them, even if there are twenty of the rascals; but for that, we must meet them hand to hand.Come now, is there no way of getting at them?”

zh: “我们试着从原来湖边的入口进入花岗石宫吧。”工程师回答说。
en: “Let us try to enter Granite House by the old opening at the lake,” replied the engineer.

zh: “噢！”水手大叫起来，“我怎么没有想到。”
en: “Oh!” shouted the sailor, “and I never thought of that.”

zh: 事实上，这是他们进入花岗石宫、与入侵者搏斗并把它们赶出去的唯一办法。事实上，入口已经被他们用水泥粘住的石头墙给封住了，现在必须牺牲它，但这很容易重建。幸好，赛勒斯·哈丁还没有实施自己的计划，提升湖面，掩盖入口，因为这个工程要花些时间来做。
en: This was in reality the only way by which to penetrate into Granite House so as to fight with and drive out the intruders.The opening was, it is true, closed up with a wall of cemented stones, which it would be necessary to sacrifice, but that could easily be rebuilt.Fortunately, Cyrus Harding had not as yet effected his project of hiding this opening by raising the waters of the lake, for the operation would then have taken some time.

zh: 现在已经过了十二点，开拓者们全副武装，带上锄头和铲子离开了石窟。吩咐完托普呆在原地后，他们就从花岗石宫的窗户下面过去了，开始爬上慈悲河的左岸，这样他们就能到达眺望岗。
en: It was already past twelve o’clock, when the colonists, well armed and provided with picks and spades, left the Chimneys, passed beneath the windows of Granite House, after telling Top to remain at his post, and began to ascend the left bank of the Mercy, so as to reach Prospect Heights.

zh: 可走了不到50步，他们就听到狗在狂叫。
en: But they had not made fifty steps in this direction, when they heard the dog barking furiously.

zh: 他们又全部沿着河岸冲下去。
en: And all rushed down the bank again.

zh: 一到拐弯处，他们就发现情况有所变化。
en: Arrived at the turning, they saw that the situation had changed.
