en: During this time Spilett and Herbert hunted in the neighborhood, and they ventured deep into the still unknown parts of the Far West, their guns loaded with ball, ready for any dangerous emergency.It was a vast thicket of magnificent trees, crowded together as if pressed for room.The exploration of these dense masses of wood was difficult in the extreme, and the reporter never ventured there without the pocket-compass, for the sun scarcely pierced through the thick foliage and it would have been very difficult for them to retrace their way.It naturally happened that game was more rare in those situations where there was hardly sufficient room to move; two or three large herbivorous animals were however killed during the last fortnight of April.These were koalas, specimens of which the settlers had already seen to the north of the lake, and which stupidly allowed themselves to be killed among the thick branches of the trees in which they took refuge.Their skins were brought back to Granite House, and there, by the help of sulphuric acid, they were subjected to a sort of tanning process which rendered them capable of being used.

zh: 4月30日这天，两位神枪手又一次深入远西森林，记者走在赫伯特前面几步，他们来到了一块空地上，这里的树木比较稀疏，有几缕阳光透进来。有几株茎杆挺直浑圆、长满树枝的植物，开出了一团团像葡萄似的花朵，并且结了很小的果实，散发着香气，吉丁·史佩莱起初闻到后很惊讶。他折断了一两根茎杆，拿给少年，向他说道：
en: On the 30th of April, the two sportsmen were in the depth of the Far West, when the reporter, preceding Herbert a few paces, arrived in a sort of clearing, into which the trees more sparsely scattered had permitted a few rays to penetrate.Gideon Spilett was at first surprised at the odor which exhaled from certain plants with straight stalks, round and branchy, bearing grape-like clusters of flowers and very small berries.The reporter broke off one or two of these stalks and returned to the lad, to whom he said,—

zh: “这可能是什么，赫伯特？”
en: “What can this be, Herbert?”

zh: “史佩莱先生，”赫伯特说，“他是准能让潘克洛夫一辈子感激你的宝贝。”
en: “Well, Mr. Spilett,” said Herbert, “this is a treasure which will secure you Pencroft’s gratitude forever.”

zh: “难道是烟草？”
en: “Is it tobacco?”

zh: “是的，虽然它可能不是最好的烟，但还是烟草！”
en: “Yes, and though it may not be of the first quality, it is none the less tobacco!”

zh: “啊，好潘克洛夫！他还不得乐死啊！不过他可不能全都拿走，他得分出我们的那份。”
en: “Oh, good old Pencroft!Won’t he be pleased!But we must not let him smoke it all, he must give us our share.”

zh: “啊！我有一个主意，史佩莱先生，”赫伯特说，“先不要告诉潘克洛夫，我们可以准备好烟草，等到一个吉日把烟斗装得满满的再给他！”
en: “Ah! an idea occurs to me, Mr, Spilett,” replied Herbert.“Don’t let us say anything to Pencroft yet; we will prepare these leaves, and one fine day we will present him with a pipe already filled!”

zh: “好，赫伯特，到那天，我们可敬的伙伴在世上再也不想要什么了。”
en: “All right, Herbert, and on that day our worthy companion will have nothing left to wish for in this world.”

zh: 记者和少年装了大量的这种珍贵植物，并回到了花岗石宫，他们谨慎地偷偷溜进去，就好像潘克洛夫是最警觉和最严厉的海关官员似的。
en: The reporter and the lad secured a good store of the precious plant, and then returned to Granite House, where they smuggled it in with as much precaution as if Pencroft had been the most vigilant and severe of custom-house officers.

zh: 他们私下把这件事告诉了赛勒斯·哈丁和纳布，而水手一直都毫无怀疑，事实上，这段时间有些漫长，因为他们要把小烟叶晒干、切细，然后把它们放在滚烫的石头上烤制。这需要两个月的时间，不过一切都在潘克洛夫不知情的情况下顺利进行，因为他忙于造船，只有在休息时间才会回到花岗石宫。
en: Cyrus Harding and Neb were taken into confidence, and the sailor suspected nothing during the whole time, necessarily somewhat long, which was required in order to dry the small leaves, chop them up, and subject them to a certain torrefaction on hot stones.This took two months; but all these manipulations were successfully carried on unknown to Pencroft, for, occupied with the construction of his boat, he only returned to Granite House at the hour of rest.

zh: 有好几天，他们都看到一只巨大的动物在林肯岛附近两三英里的水里游来游去。这是一只巨鲸，明显属于南半球的族类，称为“好望角鲸鱼”。
en: For some days they had observed an enormous animal two or three miles out in the open sea swimming around Lincoln Island.This was a whale of the largest size, which apparently belonged to the southern species, called the “Cape Whale.”

zh: “要是我们能抓到它，是多么幸运的事啊！”水手喊道，“啊，要是有一艘合适的船和一副好鱼叉，我就会下‘追捕令’了，抓它再麻烦也值得。”
en: “What a lucky chance it would be if we could capture it!” cried the sailor.“Ah! if we only had a proper boat and a good harpoon, I would say ‘After the beast,’ for he would be well worth the trouble of catching!”

zh: “好吧，潘克洛夫，”哈丁说，“我还挺想看看你怎么用鱼叉。肯定会很有意思。”
en: “Well, Pencroft,” observed Harding, “I should much like to watch you handling a harpoon.It would be very interesting.”

zh: “我有点惊讶，”记者说道，“在这个纬度相对较高的地方看见鲸鱼。”
en: “I am astonished,” said the reporter, “to see a whale in this comparatively high latitude.”

zh: “怎么会这么说，史佩莱先生？”赫伯特回答说，“我们现在所处的位置正是英国和美国捕鲸者所说的太平洋中的鲸鱼田，就在这里，新西兰和南美中间的地带是南半球鲸鱼数量最多的地方。”
en: “Why so, Mr. Spilett?” replied Herbert.“We are exactly in that part of the Pacific which English and American whalemen call the whale field, and it is here, between New Zealand and South America, that the whales of the Southern Hemisphere are met with in the greatest numbers.”

zh: 潘克洛夫遗憾地叹了一口气，就回去工作了，每个水手天生就是渔夫，如果说捕鱼的乐趣与鱼的大小正好成正比，那么捕鲸员看到鲸鱼的那种心情就可想而知了。倘若这仅仅是为了乐趣也就算了！不过他们不禁想到这样一个宝贝对开拓地是多么有价值，因为鲸油、鲸肉和骨头都有很多用途。
en: And Pencroft returned to his work, not without uttering a sigh of regret, for every sailor is a born fisherman, and if the pleasure of fishing is in exact proportion to the size of the animal, one can judge how a whaler feels in sight of a whale.And if this had only been for pleasure!But they could not help feeling how valuable such a prize would have been to the colony, for the oil, fat, and bones would have been put to many uses.

zh: 这只鲸鱼现在似乎不想离开岛屿周围的这片水域。因此，当赫伯特和吉丁·史佩莱不打猎或者纳布不做饭的时候，他们就会一直呆在花岗石宫的窗户边或在眺望岗上，绝不会离开望远镜，观察鲸鱼的一举一动。鲸鱼深入到联合湾后，就从鄂角游到爪角，并激起了一片急浪，大而有力的尾巴支撑着它的身子，并推着它向前游，其速度几乎达到了每小时12海里。有时候鲸鱼会游到离岛屿很近的地方，所以一眼就能看清楚。这是一只南方鲸鱼，它全身都是黑的，头则比北方鲸鱼扁一些。
en: Now it happened that this whale appeared to have no wish to leave the waters of the island.Therefore, whether from the windows of Granite House, or from Prospect Heights, Herbert and Gideon Spilett, when they were not hunting, or Neb, unless presiding over his fires, never left the telescope, but watched all the animal’s movements.The cetacean, having entered far into Union Bay, made rapid furrows across it from Mandible Cape to Claw Cape, propelled by its enormously powerful flukes, on which it supported itself, and making its way through the water at the rate little short of twelve knots an hour.Sometimes also it approached so near to the island that it could be clearly distinguished.It was the southern whale, which is completely black, the head being more depressed than that of the northern whale.

zh: 他们还能看到鲸鱼的气孔往外喷出了很高的水汽，或者是水，奇怪的是博物学家和捕鲸员在这一点上没有达成共识。喷出来的到底是水汽还是水呢？一般人们都认为是水汽，突然遇到冷空气的水汽重新凝结，成水落下来了。
en: They could also see it throwing up from its air-holes to a great height a cloud of vapor, or of water, for, strange as it may appear, naturalists and whalers are not agreed on this subject.Is it air or is it water which is thus driven out?It is generally admitted to be vapor, which, condensing suddenly by contact with the cold air, falls again as rain.

zh: 不过，这只哺乳动物的出现使得开拓者们都没心思想别的了。鲸鱼尤其烦扰了潘克洛夫，他工作的时候都只想着这只鲸鱼了。最后他渴望得到它，就像一个得不到想要的东西的孩子一样。晚上睡觉时他说着这事情，如果他有办法攻击它，或者单桅帆船已经适合出海，他肯定会毫不犹豫地出发捕鱼。
en: However, the presence of this mammifer preoccupied the colonists.It irritated Pencroft especially, as he could think of nothing else while at work.He ended by longing for it, like a child for a thing which it has been denied.At night he talked about it in his sleep, and certainly if he had had the means of attacking it, if the sloop had been in a fit state to put to sea, he would not have hesitated to set out in pursuit.

zh: 可是开拓者们自己办不到的事，偶然的机遇却让他们心想事成了。5月3号这天，站在厨房窗户边的纳布发出喊声，说那只鲸鱼在岛屿的海滩上搁浅了。
en: But what the colonists could not do for themselves chance did for them, and on the 3rd of May shouts from Neb, who had stationed himself at the kitchen window, announced that the whale was stranded on the beach of the island.

zh: 正要去打猎的赫伯特和史佩莱放下了手里的枪，潘克洛夫扔下了斧头，哈丁和纳布跟同伴们一起冲向鲸鱼搁浅的地方。
en: Herbert and Gideon Spilett, who were just about to set out hunting, left their guns, Pencroft threw down his ax, and Harding and Neb joining their companions, all rushed towards the scene of action.

zh: 那里就是离花岗石宫三英里远的遗物角沙滩，鲸鱼在涨潮的时候搁浅了。因此，它可能很难逃离，不过最好抓紧时间，必要的话得切断它的退路。他们手里拿着鹤嘴锄和铁头杆，经过慈悲河桥，跑下河的右岸，并沿着沙滩一只向前，不到20分钟他们就来到了这个巨大的动物旁边，成群的海鸟已在鲸鱼的上空盘旋。
en: The stranding had taken place on the beach of Flotsam Point, three miles from Granite House, and at high tide.It was therefore probable that the cetacean would not be able to extricate itself easily; at any rate it was best to hasten, so as to cut off its retreat if necessary.They ran with pick-axes and iron-tipped poles in their hands, passed over the Mercy bridge, descended the right bank of the river, along the beach, and in less than twenty minutes the settlers were close to the enormous animal, above which flocks of birds already hovered.

zh: “好大的怪物啊！”纳布喊道。
en: “What a monster!” cried Neb.

zh: 纳布这么喊是很自然的，因为这头南方鲸鱼有80英尺长，在族类中算是巨大的，重量也应该不低于15万磅！
en: And the exclamation was natural, for it was a southern whale, eighty feet long, a giant of the species, probably not weighing less than a hundred and fifty thousand pounds!

zh: 此时此刻，这只搁浅的鲸鱼一动不动，也没有趁仍在涨潮的时候挣扎回水里去。
en: In the meanwhile, the monster thus stranded did not move, nor attempt by struggling to regain the water while the tide was still high.

zh: 鲸鱼已经死了，它的左侧刺入了一根鱼叉。
en: It was dead, and a harpoon was sticking out of its left side.

zh: “这么说来，这一带有捕鲸船吧？”吉丁·史佩莱直接问道。
en: “There are whalers in these quarters, then?” said Gideon Spilett directly.

zh: “啊，史佩莱先生，这证明不了什么呀！”潘克洛夫回应道，“据说鲸鱼能身上带着鱼叉游上千英里，这只鲸鱼甚至可能在大西洋北部被插到，然后死在太平洋南部，这不足为奇。”
en: “Oh, Mr. Spilett, that doesn’t prove anything!” replied Pencroft.“Whales have been known to go thousands of miles with a harpoon in the side, and this one might even have been struck in the north of the Atlantic and come to die in the south of the Pacific, and it would be nothing astonishing.”

zh: 潘克洛夫拔出了鲸鱼身上的鱼叉，念出了上面刻的字：
en: Pencroft, having torn the harpoon from the animal’s side, read this inscription on it:

zh: 玛丽亚·斯特拉，葡萄园
en: MARIA STELLA, VINEYARD

zh: “是一艘从葡萄园来的船！是从我家乡来的船！”他叫起来。“玛丽亚·斯特拉！一艘很棒的捕鲸船，没错，我对它很熟悉！啊，朋友们，从葡萄园来的船，从葡萄园来的捕鲸船！”
en: “A vessel from the Vineyard!A ship from my country!” he cried.“The ‘Maria Stella!’ A fine whaler, ‘pon my word; I know her well!Oh, my friends, a vessel from the Vineyard!—a whaler from the Vineyard!”

zh: 水手一边挥舞着鱼叉，一边情绪激动地重复着他深爱的名字——故乡的名字。
en: And the sailor brandishing the harpoon, repeated, not without emotion, the name which he loved so well—the name of his birthplace.

zh: 不过，“玛丽亚·斯特拉”应该不会来这里捡回它击中的鲸鱼，所以他们决定趁着鲸鱼还没开始腐烂把它分解。那些飞鸟盯着这个丰富的食物已经好几天了，它们决定占有鲸鱼，而且片刻也不耽误，因此大家不得不对它们连续开枪，把它们赶走。
en: But as it could not be expected that the “Maria Stella” would come to reclaim the animal harpooned by her, they resolved to begin cutting it up before decomposition should commence.The birds, who had watched this rich prey for several days, had determined to take possession of it without further delay, and it was necessary to drive them off by firing at them repeatedly.

zh: 这是一只母鲸，居民们从它身上提取了大量鲸奶，根据博物学家德芬巴赫的观点，它可以代替牛奶，的确，不论是口感、色泽，还是浓度，它和牛奶都没什么区别。
en: The whale was a female, and a large quantity of milk was taken from it, which, according to the opinion of the naturalist Duffenbach, might pass for cow’s milk, and, indeed, it differs from it neither in taste, color, nor density.

zh: 潘克洛夫以前曾经在捕鲸船上工作过，他能有条不紊地指导大家切肉，这项足以令人厌恶的工作花了三天时间，不过居民们并没有畏缩，就连吉丁·史佩莱也包括在内，正如水手所说，他最后会成为“真正的遇难英雄”。
en: Pencroft had formerly served on board a whaling-ship, and he could methodically direct the operation of cutting up, a sufficiently disagreeable operation lasting three days, but from which the settlers did not flinch, not even Gideon Spilett, who, as the sailor said, would end by making a “real good castaway.”

zh: 他们把鲸油切成了2.5英寸厚的方块，接着又将它们分成了许多小片，每片重约1000英磅，然后他们就在原地用大陶罐熬鲸油，因为他们不想把花岗石宫附近弄得都是怪味，在熬的过程中鲸油几乎减少了三分之一的重量。
en: The blubber, cut in parallel slices of two feet and a half in thickness, then divided into pieces which might weigh about a thousand pounds each, was melted down in large earthen pots brought to the spot, for they did not wish to taint the environs of Granite House, and in this fusion it lost nearly a third of its weight.

zh: 不过鲸油还是很多，光是鲸鱼的舌头就熬出了六千英磅油，下唇也有四千英镑。此时他们有了鲸鱼的脂肪，它能在很长一段时间保证硬脂和甘油的供应，另外他们还有鲸鱼骨头，虽然在花岗石宫用不上雨伞和支架，但它们肯定会有用途的。鲸鱼的上嘴唇两边有八百块很有弹性的角状片，它们是一种纤维组织，边缘就像大梳子，而上面的梳齿长达六英尺，用来咬住上千只作为食物的小动物，如小鱼和软体动物。
en: But there was an immense quantity of it; the tongue alone yielded six thousand pounds of oil, and the lower lip four thousand.Then, besides the fat, which would insure for a long time a store of stearine and glycerine, there were still the bones, for which a use could doubtless be found, although there were neither umbrellas nor stays used at Granite House.The upper part of the mouth of the cetacean was, indeed, provided on both sides with eight hundred horny blades, very elastic, of a fibrous texture, and fringed at the edge like great combs, at which the teeth, six feet long, served to retain the thousands of animalculae, little fish, and molluscs, on which the whale fed.

zh: 工作完成以后，大家都感到很满意。剩下的鲸鱼尸体就留给那群飞鸟了，它们很快就会使每片痕迹消失，然后花岗石宫的居民们又重新开始他们的日常工作。
en: The operation finished, to the great satisfaction of the operators, the remains of the animal were left to the birds, who would soon make every vestige of it disappear, and their usual daily occupations were resumed by the inmates of Granite House.

zh: 不过哈丁在回造船所之前，想做一些器械，这极大地激发了同伴们的好奇心。他选取了12块鲸鱼骨头，将它们切成六个大小一样的部分，并削尖了两端。
en: However, before returning to the dockyard, Cyrus Harding conceived the idea of fabricating certain machines, which greatly excited the curiosity of his companions.He took a dozen of the whale’s bones, cut them into six equal parts, and sharpened their ends.

zh: “这个小东西不是我发明的，俄属美洲阿留申群岛的猎人经常使用这东西。朋友们，你们看这些骨头，等到结冰的时候，我会把它们弄弯，然后用水浸湿，直到它们完全被冰盖住，这样它们就能保持弯曲的形态，在上面涂完一层油后，我会把它们扔到雪地上。那么，饥饿的野兽吞下一个这样的食饵会怎么样呢？野兽胃里的温度会使冰融化，骨头就会变直，骨尖就会把它刺穿。”
en: “This machine is not my own invention, and it is frequently employed by the Aleutian hunters in Russian America.You see these bones, my friends; well, when it freezes, I will bend them, and then wet them with water till they are entirely covered with ice, which will keep them bent, and I will strew them on the snow, having previously covered them with fat.Now, what will happen if a hungry animal swallows one of these baits?Why, the heat of his stomach will melt the ice, and the bone, springing straight, will pierce him with its sharp points.”

zh: “太厉害了！我只能说这太巧妙了！”潘克洛夫说。
en: “Well!I do call that ingenious!” said Pencroft.

zh: “这样还可以省点弹药。”赛勒斯·哈丁也开口说。
en: “And it will spare the powder and shot,” rejoined Cyrus Harding.

zh: “这比陷阱厉害多了！”纳布补充说。
en: “That will be better than traps!” added Neb.

zh: 在此期间，造船的工作依旧进行着，快到月底的时候，铺板的工序已经完成一半了。现在已经能看出船的外形十分美观，航行起来一定不错。
en: In the meanwhile the boat-building progressed, and towards the end of the month half the planking was completed.It could already be seen that her shape was excellent, and that she would sail well.

zh: 潘克洛夫以无比的热情工作，只有身体强壮的人才能经得住这样的劳苦，他的伙伴们在悄悄地为他准备慰劳品，5月31号这天，他将见到此生最大的惊喜之一。
en: Pencroft worked with unparalleled ardor, and only a sturdy frame could have borne such fatigue; but his companions were preparing in secret a reward for his labors, and on the 31st of May he was to meet with one of the greatest joys of his life.

zh: 那天吃过晚饭，潘克洛夫正要离开饭桌，觉得有一只手放在了他的肩膀上。
en: On that day, after dinner, just as he was about to leave the table, Pencroft felt a hand on his shoulder.

zh: 原来是吉丁·史佩莱，他说：
en: It was the hand of Gideon Spilett, who said,—

zh: “等一下，潘克洛夫，你别偷偷地溜走啊！你忘了你的餐后甜点了。”
en: “One moment, Master Pencroft, you mustn’t sneak off like that!You’ve forgotten your dessert.”

zh: “谢谢了，史佩莱先生，”水手说，“我要回去工作了。”
en: “Thank you, Mr. Spilett,” replied the sailor, “I am going back to my work.”

zh: “要不，喝杯咖啡吧，伙计？”
en: “Well, a cup of coffee, my friend?”

zh: “不要了。”
en: “Nothing more.”

zh: “那抽支烟呢？”
en: “A pipe, then?”

zh: 潘克洛夫跳起来了，当他看到记者递给他一只装好的烟斗，赫伯特给他送上一块燃烧的木炭时，他那一向温厚的面庞都发白了。
en: Pencroft jumped up, and his great good-natured face grew pale when he saw the reporter presenting him with a ready-filled pipe, and Herbert with a glowing coal.

zh: 水手努力想说话，但是一个字都说不出来，他抓住烟斗送到嘴里，点上火后就使劲抽了五六口。一缕芬香的青烟很快就升起来了，大家只听到潘克洛夫在烟雾中兴奋地重复道：
en: The sailor endeavored to speak, but could not get out a word; so, seizing the pipe, he carried it to his lips, then applying the coal, he drew five or six great whiffs.A fragrant blue cloud soon arose, and from its depths a voice was heard repeating excitedly,—

zh: “烟！是真烟！”
en: “Tobacco! real tobacco!”

zh: “是的，潘克洛夫，”赛勒斯·哈丁回应说，“而且还是很好的烟呢！”
en: “Yes, Pencroft,” returned Cyrus Harding, “and very good tobacco too!”

zh: “噢，我的上帝，神圣的万物主宰！”水手喊道，“现在我们岛上什么也不缺了。”
en: “O, divine Providence; sacred Author of all things!” cried the sailor.“Nothing more is now wanting to our island.”

zh: 接着潘克洛夫继续抽，抽了一口又一口。
en: And Pencroft smoked, and smoked, and smoked.

zh: “是谁找到这烟的？”他最终还是问了，“肯定是你吧，赫伯特？”
en: “And who made this discovery?” he asked at length.“You, Herbert, no doubt?”

zh: “不对，潘克洛夫，是史佩莱先生。”
en: “No, Pencroft, it was Mr. Spilett.”

zh: “史佩莱先生！”水手喊道，他抓住记者，然后把他紧紧地搂在胸前，他从未有过这样的感受。
en: “Mr. Spilett!” exclaimed the sailor, seizing the reporter, and clasping him to his breast with such a squeeze that he had never felt anything like it before.

zh: “潘克洛夫，”史佩莱终于能有一口气说话了，“你先冷静会儿。你还得谢谢赫伯特，是他认出来了这种植物，还有赛勒斯，是他制作的烟草，还有纳布，他还费尽心思保守我们的秘密。”
en: “Oh Pencroft,” said Spilett, recovering his breath at last, “a truce for one moment.You must share your gratitude with Herbert, who recognized the plant, with Cyrus, who prepared it, and with Neb, who took a great deal of trouble to keep our secret.”

zh: “啊，朋友们，你们真好，总有一天我会报答你们的，”水手说，“我们一生一世都是朋友。”
en: “Well, my friends, I will repay you some day,” replied the sailor.“Now we are friends for life.”

zh: 第十一章
en: Chapter 11

zh: 六月一到，冬天也随之来临了，这时候相当于北半球的十二月，现在最要紧的任务就是做一些保暖而结实的衣物了。
en: Winter arrived with the month of June, which is the December of the northern zones, and the great business was the making of warm and solid clothing.

zh: 畜栏里摩弗伦羊的羊毛已经剪下来了，现在他们要把这些珍贵的纺织原料织成像样的东西。
en: The musmons in the corral had been stripped of their wool, and this precious textile material was now to be transformed into stuff.

zh: 当然，赛勒斯·哈丁手头没有刷毛机、梳毛机、磨光机、绷架、绞丝机和纺织机，没有自动机器来织羊毛，也没有织布机，所以他只能不用纺织和编织，而用更加简便的方法。实际上，他提议利用羊毛纤维在强大压力下会黏在一起的特点，再采用简单的方法制作毛毡。毛毡的制作流程很简单，如果羊毛的弹性下降，就会增加保暖性。因为摩弗伦羊的羊毛都很短，所以做起毛毡来很容易。
en: Of course Cyrus Harding, having at his disposal neither carders, combers, polishers, stretchers, twisters, mule-jenny, nor self-acting machine to spin the wool, nor loom to weave it, was obliged to proceed in a simpler way, so as to do without spinning and weaving.And indeed he proposed to make use of the property which the filaments of wool possess when subjected to a powerful pressure of mixing together, and of manufacturing by this simple process the material called felt.This felt could then be obtained by a simple operation which, if it diminished the flexibility of the stuff, increased its power of retaining heat in proportion.Now the wool furnished by the musmons was composed of very short hairs, and was in a good condition to be felted.

zh: 工程师得到了伙伴们的协助，潘克洛夫也包括在内，他不得不再次放下造船的活，开始做些初步工作，这道工序的目的是去除渗透在羊毛里的多余脂肪和油质，也就是所说的兽脂。清理工作在盛满水的大桶里完成，水温要保持在70度左右，羊毛浸泡完24个小时后，再用苏打水彻底清洗，然后再用力挤干，就可以加压了，也就是可以做成结实的毛料了。这种东西当然是很粗糙的，要是拿到欧美的工业中心肯定会一文不值，但在林肯岛的市场上它可是受到高度重视。
en: The engineer, aided by his companions, including Pencroft, who was once more obliged to leave his boat, commenced the preliminary operations, the subject of which was to rid the wool of that fat and oily substance with which it is impregnated, and which is called grease.This cleaning was done in vats filled with water, which was maintained at the temperature of seventy degrees, and in which the wool was soaked for four-and-twenty hours; it was then thoroughly washed in baths of soda, and, when sufficiently dried by pressure, it was in a state to be compressed, that is to say, to produce a solid material, rough, no doubt, and such as would have no value in a manufacturing center of Europe or America, but which would be highly esteemed in the Lincoln Island markets.

zh: 这种毛料一定在很久以前就有人使用过了，事实上，最原始的毛料就是用哈丁现在打算采用的方法生产出来的。在制造压制棉毛的机器时，哈丁的工程师才能有了用武之地，他知道如何巧妙地利用海滩上瀑布的机械动力来推动水力压榨机，而这种动力至今还未被人使用过。
en: This sort of material must have been known from the most ancient times, and, in fact, the first woolen stuffs were manufactured by the process which Harding was now about to employ.Where Harding’s engineering qualifications now came into play was in the construction of the machine for pressing the wool; for he knew how to turn ingeniously to profit the mechanical force, hitherto unused, which the waterfall on the beach possessed to move a fulling-mill.

zh: 再也没有比这更简单的了。羊毛放到凹槽里后，就会有沉重的木槌交替捶打，这就是需要制作的机器。几个世纪以来，人们一直都在使用这种机器，直到压滚取代了这种设备，以前的那种捶打方法才停止使用，有规律的压滚法则取而代之。
en: Nothing could be more rudimentary.The wool was placed in troughs, and upon it fell in turns heavy wooden mallets; such was the machine in question, and such it had been for centuries until the time when the mallets were replaced by cylinders of compression, and the material was no longer subjected to beating, but to regular rolling.

zh: 在赛勒斯·哈丁的得力指导下，这个工序做得很成功。羊毛在肥皂水里浸过后，一方面有利于交织、压榨以及使羊毛变柔软，另一方面则可以避免羊毛因捶打而收缩。羊毛从压榨机里出来后就能变成厚毛毡了。羊毛的原料本来就很粗糙，严密地缠结、交织在一起后，毛料既适合做成衣服，也同样能做被褥。当然，这既不是美利诺呢绒、平纹细布、开士米羊毛、棱纹布、缎子、羊驼呢或布料，也不是法兰绒。这是“林肯毡”，林肯岛又拥有了一件工业品。开拓者们现在有暖和的衣服和厚厚的被子，能毫无畏惧地等待1866－1867年冬天的来临了。
en: The operation, ably directed by Cyrus Harding, was a complete success.The wool, previously impregnated with a solution of soap, intended on the one hand to facilitate the interlacing, the compression, and the softening of the wool, and on the other to prevent its diminution by the beating, issued from the mill in the shape of thick felt cloth.The roughnesses with which the staple of wool is naturally filled were so thoroughly entangled and interlaced together that a material was formed equally suitable either for garments or bedclothes.It was certainly neither merino, muslin, cashmere, rep, satin, alpaca, cloth, nor flannel.It was “Lincolnian felt,” and Lincoln Island possessed yet another manufacture.The colonists had now warm garments and thick bedclothes, and they could without fear await the approach of the winter of 1866-67.

zh: 6月20日这天，大家感到了严寒，潘克洛夫本来想来年春天及时把船造好，现在不得不暂停造船工作，这让他感到十分遗憾。
en: The severe cold began to be felt about the 20th of June, and, to his great regret, Pencroft was obliged to suspend his boat-building, which he hoped to finish in time for next spring.

zh: 水手很想做的就是去达抱岛进行一次探险，不过哈丁并不同意纯粹为了好奇而出海，因为这片荒芜、干燥的岩石地里显然什么也找不到。乘着相对较小的船在未知的海域里航行150海里，使他不由得心生担忧。假如他们的船出海后到不了达抱岛，也回不了林肯岛，那这只船在危机四伏的太平洋里该怎么办呢？
en: The sailor’s great idea was to make a voyage of discovery to Tabor Island, although Harding could not approve of a voyage simply for curiosity’s sake, for there was evidently nothing to be found on this desert and almost arid rock.A voyage of a hundred and fifty miles in a comparatively small vessel, over unknown seas, could not but cause him some anxiety.Suppose that their vessel, once out at sea, should be unable to reach Tabor Island, and could not return to Lincoln Island, what would become of her in the midst of the Pacific, so fruitful of disasters?

zh: 哈丁经常与潘克洛夫谈论这个计划，他发现潘克洛夫对此次出海的要求十分迫切，可潘克洛夫自己却拿不出一个充分的理由来解释他的决心。
en: Harding often talked over this project with Pencroft, and he found him strangely bent upon undertaking this voyage, for which determination he himself could give no sufficient reason.

zh: “现在，”有一天工程师这样对他说，“我不得不说你了，我的朋友，你对林肯岛总是这么赞不绝口，而且还时常说一旦不得不离开这里时，你会多么伤心，可现在你是第一个要离开这里的。”
en: “Now,” said the engineer one day to him, “I must observe, my friend, that after having said so much, in praise of Lincoln Island, after having spoken so often of the sorrow you would feel if you were obliged to forsake it, you are the first to wish to leave it.”

zh: “只是离开这里几天，”潘克洛夫回答说，“只是几天而已，上尉。去一去就回来，就看看那个小岛是什么样子！”
en: “Only to leave it for a few days,” replied Pencroft, “only for a few days, captain.Time to go and come back, and see what that islet is like!”

zh: “但是它几乎还没林肯岛这么好。”
en: “But it is not nearly as good as Lincoln Island.”

zh: “这我早就知道了。”
en: “I know that beforehand.”

zh: “那你为什么还想冒险去那里呢？”
en: “Then why venture there?”

zh: “去了解一下那里的动态。”
en: “To know what is going on in Tabor Island.”

zh: “可那里什么也没进行，也不可能有什么事发生。”
en: “But nothing is going on there; nothing could happen there.”

zh: “那谁知道呢？”
en: “Who knows?”

zh: “若是你遇到飓风呢？”
en: “And if you are caught in a hurricane?”

zh: “天气好的季节里不用担心飓风，”潘克洛夫回答说，“不过，上尉，因为我们要以防万一，那我请求你让我只带赫伯特一同前去。”
en: “There is no fear of that in the fine season,” replied Pencroft.“But, captain, as we must provide against everything, I shall ask your permission to take Herbert only with me on this voyage.”

zh: “潘克洛夫，”工程师把手放在水手的肩膀上，说道，“倘若你或这个碰巧成为我们孩子的赫伯特发生了什么不幸，你认为我们不会自责终生吗？”
en: “Pencroft,” replied the engineer, placing his hand on the sailor’s shoulder, “if any misfortune happens to you, or to this lad, whom chance has made our child, do you think we could ever cease to blame ourselves?”

zh: “哈丁上尉，”潘克洛夫带着毫不动摇的信心答道，“我们不会让你们有那样的悲伤。何况，真正要出海的时候，我们还可以再好好谈谈。我在想，当你看到我们装备严实的船，当我们乘着它环绕荒岛时，看着它怎样在海上航行——因为我们是要一起去的，我想，我也敢说，你一定会毫不犹豫地让我去。毫不隐瞒地告诉你，你的船肯定会是杰作。”
en: “Captain Harding,” replied Pencroft, with unshaken confidence, “we shall not cause you that sorrow.Besides, we will speak further of this voyage, when the time comes to make it.And I fancy, when you have seen our tight-rigged little craft, when you have observed how she behaves at sea, when we sail round our island, for we will do so together—I fancy, I say, that you will no longer hesitate to let me go.I don’t conceal from you that your boat will be a masterpiece.”

zh: “应该说是‘我们的’船，潘克洛夫。”工程师回答说，他暂时让了一步。谈话且告一段落，水手和工程师都没有让对方信服，以后他们会继续谈下去。
en: “Say ‘our’ boat, at least, Pencroft,” replied the engineer, disarmed for the moment.The conversation ended thus, to be resumed later on, without convincing either the sailor or the engineer.

zh: 快到六月底的时候，下了第一场雪。畜栏里早就预备好了大量的饲料，所以居民们就无需每天都去那里了，不过他们决定至少每星期都要有一个人去一次。
en: The first snow fell towards the end of the month of June.The corral had previously been largely supplied with stores, so that daily visits to it were not requisite; but it was decided that more than a week should never be allowed to pass without someone going to it.

zh: 他们又布置了陷阱，哈丁制造的机器也都试用过了。弄弯的鲸鱼骨头外面覆盖了一层冰，然后又涂了一层厚厚的脂肪，接着他们就把骨头放到森林的边缘，那里野兽前往湖边时经常路过的地方。
en: Traps were again set, and the machines manufactured by Harding were tried.The bent whalebones, imprisoned in a case of ice, and covered with a thick outer layer of fat, were placed on the border of the forest at a spot where animals usually passed on their way to the lake.

zh: 这个仿效阿留申群岛渔夫们的发明十分奏效，对此工程师非常满意。12只狐狸、几只野猪，甚至还有一只美洲豹，都是用这种方法抓到的，它们死在地上，胃被伸直的鲸鱼骨头给刺穿了。
en: To the engineer’s great satisfaction, this invention, copied from the Aleutian fishermen, succeeded perfectly.A dozen foxes, a few wild boars, and even a jaguar, were taken in this way, the animals being found dead, their stomachs pierced by the unbent bones.

zh: 有一件事不得不提一下，不仅是因为它本身很有趣，更是因为这是开拓者们第一次试图与外界的人类联系。
en: An incident must here be related, not only as interesting in itself, but because it was the first attempt made by the colonists to communicate with the rest of mankind.

zh: 吉丁·史佩莱好几次都在想是不是把一封信装在密封的瓶子里，海浪兴许能把它带到有人住的海滩，又或者让鸽子带信呢？
en: Gideon Spilett had already several times pondered whether to throw into the sea a letter enclosed in a bottle, which currents might perhaps carry to an inhabited coast, or to confide it to pigeons.

zh: 可是林肯岛与任何有人居住的地方都相隔1200英里，谁能希望让鸽子或瓶子跨越这么远的距离呢？这简直是开玩笑。
en: But how could it be seriously hoped that either pigeons or bottles could cross the distance of twelve hundred miles which separated the island from any inhabited land?It would have been pure folly.

zh: 但是在6月30日这天，赫伯特开枪打中了一只信天翁，它的腿受了点伤，大家把它给抓住了，不过还是费了些事。这只鸟非常美丽，两翼之间的距离有十英尺，它几乎能飞越像太平洋那样宽广的海洋。
en: But on the 30th of June the capture was effected, not without difficulty, of an albatross, which a shot from Herbert’s gun had slightly wounded in the foot.It was a magnificent bird, measuring ten feet from wing to wing, and which could traverse seas as wide as the Pacific.

zh: 赫伯特原本想留住这只大鸟，因为它的伤很快会痊愈，他想着就能驯服它了，不过史佩莱向他解释了一番，他们不能忽视这次机会，利用这位信使尝试与太平洋的其他岛屿取得联系。因为如果这只信天翁来自于有人居住的地方，毫无疑问，一旦放走了它，它就会马上飞回那里。
en: Herbert would have liked to keep this superb bird, as its wound would soon heal, and he thought he could tame it; but Spilett explained to him that they should not neglect this opportunity of attempting to communicate by this messenger with the lands of the Pacific; for if the albatross had come from some inhabited region, there was no doubt but that it would return there so soon as it was set free.

zh: 吉丁·史佩莱有时会显现出记者的修养，也许在他心中，很想有机会能将居民在林肯岛上的历险写成一篇激动人心的文章发出去。倘若这篇文章能寄到可敬的约翰·贝内特编辑手里，对于《纽约先驱报》的记者以及刊登这篇文章的报纸销量来说，这会是多大的成功啊！
en: Perhaps in his heart Gideon Spilett, in whom the journalist sometimes came to the surface, was not sorry to have the opportunity of sending forth to take its chance an exciting article relating the adventures of the settlers in Lincoln Island.What a success for the authorized reporter of the New York Herald, and for the number which should contain the article, if it should ever reach the address of its editor, the Honorable James Bennett!

zh: 吉丁·史佩莱写好一篇简短的报道，放到了结实、防水的袋子里，并附上了几句话，恳请捡到袋子的人把它寄到《纽约先驱报》。由于信天翁习惯在海面上停歇，所以袋子被系在了它的脖子上，而不是脚上，随后他们就把这个快速的空中信差放飞了，看着它消失在朦胧的西方，开拓者们心里都有些许激动。
en: Gideon Spilett then wrote out a concise account, which was placed in a strong waterproof bag, with an earnest request to whoever might find it to forward it to the office of the New York Herald.This little bag was fastened to the neck of the albatross, and not to its foot, for these birds are in the habit of resting on the surface of the sea; then liberty was given to this swift courier of the air, and it was not without some emotion that the colonists watched it disappear in the misty west.

zh: “它会去哪里呢？”潘克洛夫问道。
en: “Where is he going to?” asked Pencroft.

zh: “飞往新西兰。”赫伯特回答说。
en: “Towards New Zealand,” replied Herbert.

zh: “祝你一路顺风。”水手喊道，其实他本人对这种通讯方式并没有抱太大期望。
en: “A good voyage to you,” shouted the sailor, who himself did not expect any great result from this mode of correspondence.

zh: 随着冬天的来临，花岗石宫内部的工作又开始了，大家有的缝衣服或者干别的，有的就把气囊上多得用不完的料子拿来制作船帆。
en: With the winter, work had been resumed in the interior of Granite House, mending clothes and different occupations, among others making the sails for their vessel, which were cut from the inexhaustible balloon-case.

zh: 七月的时候，天气异常寒冷，不过居民们并不缺少木材或煤炭。赛勒斯·哈丁在餐厅又搭建了一个壁炉，他们就在那里度过了一个个漫长的冬夜。他们一边工作一边交谈，手里没活的时候就读书，大家都在这段时间获益良多。
en: During the month of July the cold was intense, but there was no lack of either wood or coal.Cyrus Harding had established a second fireplace in the dining-room, and there the long winter evenings were spent.Talking while they worked, reading when the hands remained idle, the time passed with profit to all.

zh: 美味的晚饭过后，在有蜡烛照亮、煤炭取暖的屋子里，居民们喝着热气腾腾的接骨木咖啡，嘴里的烟斗吹出芳香的烟，听着外面怒吼的狂风，这对居民们来说着实是种享受。如果说远离家乡且与外界毫无沟通办法的人还能有乐趣，那么居民们的乐趣可谓是无所欠缺了。他们经常谈起自己的祖国和离开他们的朋友，还有美利坚合众国的伟大，它的影响力可是与日俱增的。赛勒斯·哈丁非常关心国家大事，他谈到许多往事、个人见解以及对未来的看法，这让大家都感到饶有兴致。
en: It was real enjoyment to the settlers when in their room, well lighted with candles, well warmed with coal, after a good dinner, elderberry coffee smoking in the cups, the pipes giving forth an odoriferous smoke, they could hear the storm howling without.Their comfort would have been complete, if complete comfort could ever exist for those who are far from their fellow-creatures, and without any means of communication with them.They often talked of their country, of the friends whom they had left, of the grandeur of the American Republic, whose influence could not but increase; and Cyrus Harding, who had been much mixed up with the affairs of the Union, greatly interested his auditors by his recitals, his views, and his prognostics.

zh: 这引得史佩莱在一天偶然说道：
en: It chanced one day that Spilett was led to say—

zh: “不过，亲爱的赛勒斯，既然你预言所有工商业都会不断发展，那么它们会不会早晚面临完全停止的危机呢？”
en: “But now, my dear Cyrus, all this industrial and commercial movement to which you predict a continual advance, does it not run the danger of being sooner or later completely stopped?”

zh: “停止！因为什么？”
en: “Stopped!And by what?”

zh: “因为煤炭缺失，它可称得上是最宝贵的矿产。”
en: “By the want of coal, which may justly be called the most precious of minerals.”

zh: “不错，它的确是最宝贵的，”工程师回答说，“大自然似乎正想通过产生钻石来证明这一点，因为钻石只是煤炭的结晶。”
en: “Yes, the most precious indeed,” replied the engineer; “and it would seem that nature wished to prove that it was so by making the diamond, which is simply pure carbon crystallized.”

zh: “上尉，你不会是想说，”潘克洛夫插嘴说，“我们炉子里烧的都是以煤炭的形态出现的钻石吗？”
en: “You don’t mean to say, captain,” interrupted Pencroft, “that we burn diamonds in our stoves in the shape of coal?”

zh: “不是，朋友。”哈丁回答说。
en: “No, my friend,” replied Harding.

zh: “不过，”吉丁·史佩莱接着说，“你不否认煤炭早晚有一天会全部用光吧？”
en: “However,” resumed Gideon Spilett, “you do not deny that some day the coal will be entirely consumed?”

zh: “嗨！煤炭的矿藏还很多，十万个矿工每年才从中挖出几亿英担，到现在为止还没采完。”
en: “Oh! the veins of coal are still considerable, and the hundred thousand miners who annually extract from them a hundred millions of hundredweights have not nearly exhausted them.”

zh: “随着煤的消耗量不断增加，”吉丁·史佩莱回答说，“可以预见的是，十万名矿工很快变成二十万，开采量会翻倍。”
en: “With the increasing consumption of coal,” replied Gideon Spilett, “it can be foreseen that the hundred thousand workmen will soon become two hundred thousand, and that the rate of extraction will be doubled.”

zh: “那是当然，不过欧洲的煤矿采用新机器后，很快就被更全面地开发，这些矿产开采完后，美洲和澳洲的煤矿还能维持很长一段时间的产业消耗。”
en: “Doubtless; but after the European mines, which will be soon worked more thoroughly with new machines, the American and Australian mines will for a long time yet provide for the consumption in trade.”

zh: “可以维持多长一段时间？”记者问道。
en: “For how long a time?” asked the reporter.
“For at least two hundred and fifty or three hundred years.”

zh: “我们对此可以放心，不过我们的下一代就前景堪忧了！”潘克洛夫说。
en: “That is reassuring for us, but a bad look-out for our great-grandchildren!” observed Pencroft.

zh: “他们会发现别的东西。”赫伯特说。
en: “They will discover something else,” said Herbert.

zh: “但愿如此吧，”史佩莱回答说，“因为要是没有煤，就没有机器，没有机器也就没有铁路、蒸汽机、工厂以及现代文明不可或缺的一切！”
en: “It is to be hoped so,” answered Spilett, “for without coal there would be no machinery, and without machinery there would be no railways, no steamers, no manufactories, nothing of that which is indispensable to modern civilization!”

zh: “不过他们会发现什么呢？”潘克洛夫问道，“你能猜到吗，上尉？”
en: “But what will they find?” asked Pencroft.“Can you guess, captain?”

zh: “差不多能吧，朋友。”
en: “Nearly, my friend.”

zh: “那他们会烧什么来替代煤呢？”
en: “And what will they burn instead of coal?”

zh: “水。”哈丁回答说。
en: “Water,” replied Harding.

zh: “水！”潘克洛夫喊道，“把水当作蒸汽机和引擎的燃料！用水烧水！”
en: “Water!” cried Pencroft, “water as fuel for steamers and engines! water to heat water!”

zh: “是的，不过水已经分解成了原有的元素，”赛勒斯·哈丁回答说，“而且无疑是通过电来分解的，到时候水就成为了一种强大而可操控的力量，所有伟大的发现也都会因为某些难以解释的规律，同时相互契合并变得完善起来。是的，朋友们，我相信早晚有一天水会变成燃料，水的构成元素氢和氧将会分开或是同时使用，它们会成为光和热的无尽之源，这种力量是煤也无法企及的。早晚有一天，蒸汽船的藏煤室和火车的给煤车里就不再装煤，而是装载这两种压缩气体，它们在炉子里燃烧时会产生强大的热能。所以说，没有什么好担心的。只要地球上有人居住，它就会满足人类的需求，只要我们不缺乏植物、动物和矿物，那么我们就不会缺少光或热。我相信，当煤矿用完的时候，我们会用水来加热取暖。水会成为未来的煤。”
en: “Yes, but water decomposed into its primitive elements,” replied Cyrus Harding, “and decomposed doubtless, by electricity, which will then have become a powerful and manageable force, for all great discoveries, by some inexplicable laws, appear to agree and become complete at the same time.Yes, my friends, I believe that water will one day be employed as fuel, that hydrogen and oxygen which constitute it, used singly or together, will furnish an inexhaustible source of heat and light, of an intensity of which coal is not capable.Some day the coalrooms of steamers and the tenders of locomotives will, instead of coal, be stored with these two condensed gases, which will burn in the furnaces with enormous calorific power.There is, therefore, nothing to fear.As long as the earth is inhabited it will supply the wants of its inhabitants, and there will be no want of either light or heat as long as the productions of the vegetable, mineral or animal kingdoms do not fail us.I believe, then, that when the deposits of coal are exhausted we shall heat and warm ourselves with water.Water will be the coal of the future.”

zh: “我很想亲眼看到。”水手说。
en: “I should like to see that,” observed the sailor.

zh: “你出生得太早了，潘克洛夫。”纳布说，整个交谈中他就说了这么一句话。
en: “You were born too soon, Pencroft,” returned Neb, who only took part in the discussion by these words.

zh: 不过，打断整个交谈的不是纳布的话，而是托普再次发出的奇怪吼叫声，上次工程师就因为这个声音感到困惑。内部通道的尽头有一口井，此时的托普边叫边绕着井口奔跑。
en: However, it was not Neb’s speech which interrupted the conversation, but Top’s barking, which broke out again with that strange intonation which had before perplexed the engineer.At the same time Top began to run round the mouth of the well, which opened at the extremity of the interior passage.

zh: “托普为什么会那样叫呢？”潘克洛夫问道。
en: “What can Top be barking in that way for?” asked Pencroft.

zh: “贾普怎么也那样叫起来？”赫伯特也问道。
en: “And Jup be growling like that?” added Herbert.

zh: 事实上，猩猩也和狗一样表现出明显的躁动，而且，奇怪的是，两个动物表现出的不是愤怒，而是不安。
en: In fact the orang, joining the dog, gave unequivocal signs of agitation, and, singular to say, the two animals appeared more uneasy than angry.

zh: “很明显，”吉丁·史佩莱说，“这口井直接与大海相通，一些海里的动物时不时会来井底呼吸。”
en: “It is evident,” said Gideon Spilett, “that this well is in direct communication with the sea, and that some marine animal comes from time to time to breathe at the bottom.”

zh: “这很明显，”水手说，“再也没有比这更好的解释了。安静，托普！”潘克洛夫转身对狗说：“还有你，贾普，回到自己的房间去！”
en: “That’s evident,” replied the sailor, “and there can be no other explanation to give.Quiet there, Top!” added Pencroft, turning to the dog, “and you, Jup, be off to your room!”

zh: 猩猩和狗都安静下来了。贾普上床睡觉了，而托普却依然呆在屋里，整个晚上它每隔一会儿就会发出低沉的吼声。对于这个话题再没有深入的交谈，不过工程师依旧为此事而皱着眉头。
en: The ape and the dog were silent.Jup went off to bed, but Top remained in the room, and continued to utter low growls at intervals during the rest of the evening.There was no further talk on the subject, but the incident, however, clouded the brow of the engineer.

zh: 七月剩下的日子不是霜就是雨。气温没有去年冬天低，最冷的时候也有华氏8度。不过,虽然今年冬天没有那么冷，但暴风雪却很多，而且海潮还时常威胁着“石窟”的安全。有时候，巨浪就像被潜流给掀起来了一样,猛烈地拍打着花岗石宫的墙壁，轰隆作响。
en: During the remainder of the month of July there was alternate rain and frost.The temperature was not so low as during the preceding winter, and its maximum did not exceed eight degrees Fahrenheit.But although this winter was less cold, it was more troubled by storms and squalls; the sea besides often endangered the safety of the Chimneys.At times it almost seemed as if an under-current raised these monstrous billows which thundered against the wall of Granite House.

zh: 居民们倚在窗户边，看着滚滚巨浪敲打在下面的岩石上，他们不禁为大海这种无力的愤怒的壮观景象感到叹为观止。波涛在闪亮的泡沫中翻滚，整个海滩都消失在了狂澜中，悬崖似乎从海中冒出来，浪花上升到100多英尺的高度。
en: When the settlers, leaning from their windows, gazed on the huge watery masses breaking beneath their eyes, they could not but admire the magnificent spectacle of the ocean in its impotent fury.The waves rebounded in dazzling foam, the beach entirely disapppearing under the raging flood, and the cliff appearing to emerge from the sea itself, the spray rising to a height of more than a hundred feet.

zh: 在这样的风暴里，冒险外出是困难的，甚至是危险的，因为经常有树被吹倒，不过，开拓者们向来都每个星期去一次畜栏。所幸的是，这块圈地有富兰克林山的东南山脉作为屏障，飓风侵袭不到这里，大树、棚屋和栅栏都得以保存，但是眺望岗上的家禽场由于直面东边吹来的强风，遭受了很大的损害。鸽棚的屋顶被吹走了两次，栅栏也被刮倒了。所有这些都需要重新修整，还要比以前更结实，因为林肯岛显然处在太平洋最危险的一个地方。看起来它似乎形成了大旋风的中心点，狂风从四面八方吹向它，就像鞭子不断抽打陀螺，只不过这个陀螺是静止的，而鞭子却在不停地围着它转。八月的第一个星期，天气变得温和了很多，大气也恢复了原来似乎永远失去的宁静。不过平静过后，天气又变得十分寒冷，温度计的指针都降到了华氏零下八度。
en: During these storms it was difficult and even dangerous to venture out, owing to the frequently falling trees; however, the colonists never allowed a week to pass without having paid a visit to the corral.Happily, this enclosure, sheltered by the southeastern spur of Mount Franklin, did not greatly suffer from the violence of the hurricanes, which spared its trees, sheds, and palisades; but the poultry-yard on Prospect Heights, being directly exposed to the gusts of wind from the east, suffered considerable damage.The pigeon-house was twice unroofed and the paling blown down.All this required to be remade more solidly than before, for, as may be clearly seen, Lincoln Island was situated in one of the most dangerous parts of the Pacific.It really appeared as if it formed the central point of vast cyclones, which beat it perpetually as the whip does the top, only here it was the top which was motionless and the whip which moved.During the first week of the month of August the weather became more moderate, and the atmosphere recovered the calm which it appeared to have lost forever.With the calm the cold again became intense, and the thermometer fell to eight degrees Fahrenheit, below zero.

zh: 8月3日，居民们实践了他们谈论了好多天的远足，那就是进入林肯岛东南部，到达潦凫沼地。许多水禽到这里过冬，猎人们看得好馋。这里有很多野鸭、鹬、短颈野鸭和，大家一致决定花一天时间专门捕捉它们。
en: On the 3rd of August an excursion which had been talked of for several days was made into the southeastern part of the island, towards Tadorn Marsh.The hunters were tempted by the aquatic game which took up their winter quarters there.Wild duck, snipe, teal and grebe abounded there, and it was agreed that a day should be devoted to an expedition against these birds.

zh: 不光是吉丁·史佩莱和赫伯特，就连潘克洛夫和纳布也加入到此次远足的队伍了。赛勒斯·哈丁斯说有工作要做，没有加入他们，独自留在了花岗石宫。
en: Not only Gideon Spilett and Herbert, but Pencroft and Neb also took part in this excursion.Cyrus Harding alone, alleging some work as an excuse, did not join them, but remained at Granite House.

zh: 猎人们答应天黑前回来，为了到达潦凫沼地，就顺着气球港的方向进发，托普和贾普也和他们在一起。他们一过慈悲河桥，工程师就把桥提起来然后回去了，他打算进行一项工作，而他也只想自己单独完成。
en: The hunters proceeded in the direction of Port Balloon, in order to reach the marsh, after having promised to be back by the evening.Top and Jup accompanied them.As soon as they had passed over the Mercy Bridge, the engineer raised it and returned, intending to put into execution a project for the performance of which he wished to be alone.

zh: 这个工作就是仔细查看井的内部，井口与花岗石宫的通道在同一水平面上，由于它曾经为格兰特湖输送了水，所以它与大海连通。
en: Now this project was to minutely explore the interior well, the mouth of which was on a level with the passage of Granite House, and which communicated with the sea, since it formerly supplied a way to the waters of the lake.

zh: 为什么托普会经常围着这个井口转呢？某种不安的感觉似乎使它靠近这口井时，为什么它会发出如此奇怪的吼叫声呢？为什么贾普会和托普一样焦躁呢？这口井除了通向大海外还有别的支路吗？它是不是能延伸到岛屿的其他地方？这些都是赛勒斯·哈丁想要知道的。于是，他决定趁伙伴们都不在的时候探索一下井里，现在机会正摆在他面前。
en: Why did Top so often run round this opening?Why did he utter such strange barks when a sort of uneasiness seemed to draw him towards this well?Why did Jup join Top in a sort of common anxiety?Had this well branches besides the communication with the sea?Did it spread towards other parts of the island?This is what Cyrus Harding wished to know.He had resolved, therefore, to attempt the exploration of the well during the absence of his companions, and an opportunity for doing so had now presented itself.

zh: 利用绳梯下到井底就很容易，这个梯子自从升降梯弄好后就没有再用过了。工程师把绳梯拿到直径近六英尺的井口，把绳梯的上端紧紧地系在井口后，他就把另一端放到了井里。然后，他点了一盏灯，手里拿好一把左轮枪，腰间别了一把弯刀，接着就下井了。
en: It was easy to descend to the bottom of the well by employing the rope ladder which had not been used since the establishment of the lift.The engineer drew the ladder to the hole, the diameter of which measured nearly six feet, and allowed it to unroll itself after having securely fastened its upper extremity.Then, having lighted a lantern, taken a revolver, and placed a cutlass in his belt, he began the descent.

zh: 井里空空的，什么也没有，不过周围到处都是突出的尖石，敏捷的动物很可能会顺着这些尖石爬到井口。
en: The sides were everywhere entire; but points of rock jutted out here and there, and by means of these points it would have been quite possible for an active creature to climb to the mouth of the well.

zh: 工程师想到了这点，他用灯的光仔细地查看了这些尖石，不过他找不到任何痕迹或缺损之处能证明，它们曾在最近或是过去的任何时间被当成阶梯使用过。赛勒斯·哈丁又往下走了点，他将灯举起来往四处照。
en: The engineer remarked this; but although he carefully examined these points by the light of his lantern, he could find no impression, no fracture which could give any reason to suppose that they had either recently or at any former time been used as a staircase.Cyrus Harding descended deeper, throwing the light of his lantern on all sides.

zh: 他还是没有看到任何可疑的东西。
en: He saw nothing suspicious.

zh: 工程师下到了最后一档，这时他到达了水面，此时的水面非常平静。不论是这个水面还是井里的其他地方，都没有任何可以通往悬崖内部的通道。哈丁用刀柄敲了敲井壁，墙上发出的声音听起来很结实。这是很结实的花岗岩，没有任何动物能从中打出一条通道。海滩的岩石层下有一条将井底与大海相连的沟渠，要游到井底，然后再爬到井口必须经过这条沟渠，只有水生动物才能做到这点。至于说这条沟渠的终点在哪里，位于海岸的何处，以及在水下有多深，这些问题还不能回答。
en: When the engineer had reached the last rounds he came upon the water, which was then perfectly calm.Neither at its level nor in any other part of the well, did any passage open, which could lead to the interior of the cliff.The wall which Harding struck with the hilt of his cutlass sounded solid.It was compact granite, through which no living being could force a way.To arrive at the bottom of the well and then climb up to its mouth it was necessary to pass through the channel under the rocky subsoil of the beach, which placed it in communication with the sea, and this was only possible for marine animals.As to the question of knowing where this channel ended, at what point of the shore, and at what depth beneath the water, it could not be answered.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁查看完后，就爬上去把梯子收好，盖上井盖，回到餐厅深思，他一边走一边在自言自语：
en: Then Cyrus Harding, having ended his survey, re-ascended, drew up the ladder, covered the mouth of the well, and returned thoughtfully to the diningroom, saying to himself,—

zh: “我什么也没有看到，可是那里肯定有什么东西！”
en: “I have seen nothing, and yet there is something there!”

zh: 第十二章
en: Chapter 12

zh: 晚上那些打猎者回来了，他们玩得很尽兴，不夸张地说，收获颇丰，事实上，他们四个人是满载而归。托普脖子上挂着一串短颈野鸭，贾普身上挂着一圈鹬。
en: In the evening the hunters returned, having enjoyed good sport, and being literally loaded with game; indeed, they had as much as four men could possibly carry.Top wore a necklace of teal and Jup wreaths of snipe round his body.

zh: “这里，主人，”纳布大声喊，“我们有事情做了！把这些东西储存起来，做成馅饼，我们就有可喜的储藏了！但是我必须找个人帮助我。我要依靠你了，潘克洛夫。”
en: “Here, master,” cried Neb; “here’s something to employ our time!Preserved and made into pies we shall have a welcome store!But I must have some one to help me.I count on you, Pencroft.”

zh: “不行，纳布，”水手回答，“我还有船上的索具要完成和照看，你必须自己做了。”
en: “No, Neb,” replied the sailor; “I have the rigging of the vessel to finish and to look after, and you will have to do without me.”

zh: “你呢，赫伯特先生？”
en: “And you, Mr. Herbert?”

zh: “我明天必须去畜栏，纳布。”少年回答。
en: “I must go to the corral to-morrow, Neb,” replied the lad.

zh: “那么就是你了，史佩莱先生，你愿意帮助我吗？”
en: “It will be you then, Mr. Spilett, who will help me?”

zh: “我愿意，纳布，我会帮你，”记者说，“但是，我要提醒你，如果你将你的烹饪秘诀透漏给我，我会公布的。”
en: “To oblige you, Neb, I will,” replied the reporter; “but I warn you that if you disclose your receipts to me, I shall publish them.”

zh: “什么时候都可以，史佩莱先生，”纳布回答，“什么时候都可以。”
en: “Whenever you like, Mr. Spilett,” replied Neb; “whenever you like.”

zh: 第二天，吉丁·史佩莱就成了纳布的助手了，在他的厨房实验室里工作。工程师已经把自己昨天探索的结果告诉了他，在这一点上，记者与哈丁持相同观点，虽然他还没找到什么，但是秘密是仍旧要去发现的！
en: And so the next day Gideon Spilett became Neb’s assistant and was installed in his culinary laboratory.The engineer had previously made known to him the result of the exploration which he had made the day before, and on this point the reporter shared Harding’s opinion, that although he had found nothing, a secret still remained to be discovered!

zh: 寒霜又持续了一周，居民们除了去照料禽场外就没有离开过花岗岩宫。住所里充满了令人谗涎欲滴的香味，这香味是从纳布和记者娴熟的工作中发出来的。但是，他们并没有把捕获的所有猎物都做成储藏食品。猎物在严寒中可以保存得十分完好，因此他们吃新鲜的野鸭和其他野禽，并断言这比世界上所有其他的水禽都要好吃。
en: The frost continued for another week, and the settlers did not leave Granite House unless to look after the poultry-yard.The dwelling was filled with appetizing odors, which were emitted from the learned manipulation of Neb and the reporter.But all the results of the chase were not made into preserved provisions; and as the game kept perfectly in the intense cold, wild duck and other fowl were eaten fresh, and declared superior to all other aquatic birds in the known world.

zh: 这一周，赫伯特技巧娴熟地用着水手的针，帮助潘克洛夫完成了船帆的工作。绳索也不缺了。由于找到了索具和气球，他们从网上弄来的绳索质量都很好，水手把它们全部用上了。船帆上系了结实的螺栓索，还剩下很多，都做了升降索、桅索和帆脚索等等。在潘克洛夫的指导下，赛勒斯·哈丁利用转动的车床做了一些滑车。因此，在船造好以前，索具就完全准备好了。潘克洛夫还做了一面国旗，这对每个真正的美国人来说都很珍贵，上面有他们光荣的合众国的星条。上面的颜色是从某些用作染料的植物中得来的，这些植物在岛上很丰富。国旗上有着光辉灿烂的37颗星，代表着合众国的37个州，除此之外，水手又加上了第38颗，代表“林肯州”，因为他认为这个岛已经归入伟大的合众国了。“就算事实上没有归入，在心里已经归入了！”他说。
en: During this week, Pencroft, aided by Herbert, who handled the sailmaker’s needle with much skill, worked with such energy that the sails of the vessel were finished.There was no want of cordage.Thanks to the rigging which had been discovered with the case of the balloon, the ropes and cables from the net were all of good quality, and the sailor turned them all to account.To the sails were attached strong bolt ropes, and there still remained enough from which to make the halyards, shrouds, and sheets, etc.The blocks were manufactured by Cyrus Harding under Pencroft’s directions by means of the turning lathe.It therefore happened that the rigging was entirely prepared before the vessel was finished.Pencroft also manufactured a flag, that flag so dear to every true American, containing the stars and stripes of their glorious Union.The colors for it were supplied from certain plants used in dyeing, and which were very abundant in the island; only to the thirty-seven stars, representing the thirty-seven States of the Union, which shine on the American flag, the sailor added a thirty-eighth, the star of “the State of Lincoln,” for he considered his island as already united to the great republic.“And,” said he, “it is so already in heart, if not in deed!”

zh: 在此期间，他们把国旗升在花岗岩宫中间的窗户上，居民们向它欢呼三声以示敬意。
en: In the meantime, the flag was hoisted at the central window of Granite House, and the settlers saluted it with three cheers.

zh: 这时候，寒冷的季节即将结束，第二个冬季似乎要在没有任何异常事件中过去了，可是，在8月11日的晚上，眺望岗的高地几乎遭到完全的破坏。
en: The cold season was now almost at an end, and it appeared as if this second winter was to pass without any unusual occurrence, when on the night of the 11th of August, the plateau of Prospect Heights was menaced with complete destruction.

zh: 忙碌了一天后，开拓者们睡得很熟，第二天早晨接近四点钟的时候，他们突然被托普的叫声惊醒了。
en: After a busy day the colonists were sleeping soundly, when towards four o’clock in the morning they were suddenly awakened by Top’s barking.

zh: 这次狗不是在靠近井口的地方叫，而是在门口叫，它用前爪挠门，好像要把它打开。同时，贾普也发出尖叫声。
en: The dog was not this time barking near the mouth of the well, but at the threshold of the door, at which he was scratching as if he wished to burst it open.Jup was also uttering piercing cries.

zh: “嘿，托普！”纳布喊道，他是第一个被惊醒的。但是狗继续叫，还比之前更凶猛了。
en: “Hello, Top!” cried Neb, who was the first awake.But the dog continued to bark more furiously than ever.

zh: “现在是怎么回事？”哈丁问。
en: “What’s the matter now?” asked Harding.

zh: 所有人都急忙穿上衣服，冲到窗口，把窗户打开。
en: And all dressing in haste rushed to the windows, which they opened.

zh: 下面是一片冰雪，微光下看起来有些灰暗。居民们什么也看不见，但是他们听到黑暗中传来一种异常的叫喊声。很明显，有一群动物侵入了海滩，只是他们还看不清。
en: Beneath their eyes was spread a sheet of snow which looked gray in the dim light.The settlers could see nothing, but they heard a singular yelping noise away in the darkness.It was evident that the beach had been invaded by a number of animals which could not be seen.

zh: “那是些什么动物啊？”潘克洛夫喊道。
en: “What are they?” cried Pencroft.

zh: “狼、美洲豹，或是大猩猩？”纳布回答说。
en: “Wolves, jaguars, or apes?” replied Neb.

zh: “他们几乎到达高地了。”记者说。
en: “They have nearly reached the plateau,” said the reporter.

zh: “还有我们的家禽场，”赫伯特大声叫道，“我们的菜园！”
en: “And our poultry-yard,” exclaimed Herbert, “and our garden!”

zh: “它们是从哪儿过来的呢？”潘克洛夫问。
en: “Where can they have crossed?” asked Pencroft.

zh: “它们一定是从岸边桥上过来的，”工程师回答说，“肯定是谁忘记把桥拉起来了。”
en: “They must have crossed the bridge on the shore,” replied the engineer, “which one of us must have forgotten to close.”

zh: “是的，”史佩莱说，“我忘了把桥扯起来了。”
en: “True,” said Spilett, “I remember having left it open.”

zh: “你干的好事，史佩莱先生。”水手大喊。
en: “A fine job you have made of it, Mr. Spilett,” cried the sailor.

zh: “事已定局，无法挽回，”赛勒斯·哈丁回答，“我们最好商量一下该怎么办。”
en: “What is done cannot be undone,” replied Cyrus Harding.“We must consult what it will now be best to do.”

zh: 哈丁和他的同伴不停地互相说着话，有的问，有的答。可以肯定的是，那些动物已经跨过桥了，并且已经侵袭到海岸了，不论它们是什么东西，都能够登上慈悲河左岸，到达眺望岗。因此，他们必须尽快赶上去阻止这些动物，必要的时候还要和它们拼一场。
en: Such were the questions and answers which were rapidly exchanged between Harding and his companions.It was certain that the bridge had been crossed, that the shore had been invaded by animals, and that whatever they might be they could by ascending the left bank of the Mercy reach Prospect Heights.They must therefore be advanced against quickly and fought with if necessary.

zh: “可是，这些野兽是什么呢？”他们听到叫声比先前更响，又问了一遍这个问题。这些喊叫声使赫伯特吃了一惊,他记得第一次去红河发源地的时候，听到过这种声音。
en: “But what are these beasts?” was asked a second time, as the yelpings were again heard more loudly than before.These yelps made Herbert start, and he remembered having heard them before during his first visit to the sources of the Red Creek.

zh: “它们是山狐狸！”他喊道。
en: “They are colpeo foxes!” he exclaimed.

zh: “冲上去！”水手大喊。
en: “Forward!” shouted the sailor.

zh: 所有人都拿起手斧、卡宾枪和左轮枪防卫自己，跑进升降梯，很快就到海岸了。
en: And all arming themselves with hatchets, carbines, and revolvers, threw themselves into the lift and soon set foot on the shore.

zh: 山狐狸是很危险的动物，它们数目众多，因饥饿而烦躁不安。尽管如此，这些开拓者还是毫不犹豫地把自己置身于这群动物中，发射出第一排子弹，黑暗中明显地发出几点亮光，吓得攻击者后退了。
en: Colpeos are dangerous animals when in great numbers and irritated by hunger, nevertheless the colonists did not hesitate to throw themselves into the midst of the troop, and their first shots vividly lighting up the darkness made their assailants draw back.

zh: 主要的问题就是要阻止这些盗贼到达高地，否则菜园和家禽场就要任凭他们的摆布，巨大的、可能是不能挽回的损失就难免成为结局，尤其是对麦田来说。可是，它们只能通过慈悲河的左岸入侵高地，只要守住这条河流和花岗岩峭壁之间的狭窄的堤岸，就足以把山狐狸阻挡住。
en: The chief thing was to hinder these plunderers from reaching the plateau, for the garden and the poultry-yard would then have been at their mercy, and immense, perhaps irreparable mischief, would inevitably be the result, especially with regard to the corn-field.But as the invasion of the plateau could only be made by the left bank of the Mercy, it was sufficient to oppose the colpeos on the narrow bank between the river and the cliff of granite.

zh: 大家都明白这一点，在赛勒斯·哈丁的指导下，他们到达了指定地点，此时，这些山狐狸在幽暗中凶猛地乱窜。哈丁、吉丁·史佩莱、赫伯特、潘克洛夫和纳布形成一条坚不可摧的防线。托普张开他那可怕的大口，站在开拓者们前面，后面跟着贾普，他手里挥动着一根有节的棍棒，挥舞起来就像拿着球棒似的。
en: This was plain to all, and, by Cyrus Harding’s orders, they reached the spot indicated by him, while the colpeos rushed fiercely through the gloom.Harding, Gideon Spilett, Herbert, Pencroft and Neb posted themselves in impregnable line.Top, his formidable jaws open, preceded the colonists, and he was followed by Jup, armed with knotty cudgel, which he brandished like a club.

zh: 外面漆黑一片，只有当他们开枪时，才能借着左轮枪的闪光看到那些攻击者，它们至少有一百只，眼睛通红，就像热炭。
en: The night was extremely dark, it was only by the flashes from the revolvers as each person fired that they could see their assailants, who were at least a hundred in number, and whose eyes were glowing like hot coals.

zh: “绝不能让它们过来！”潘克洛夫大声叫。
en: “They must not pass!” shouted Pencroft.

zh: “它们过不来的！”工程师应道。
en: “They shall not pass!” returned the engineer.

zh: 但是，如果它们没有过来，并不是它们不想试着过来。后面的山狐狸推动着最前面的，居民们也用左轮枪和手斧与它们进行着不断的格斗。有几只山狐狸已经被打死在地上了，但是它们的数目似乎没有减少，也许它们的增援力量正在不断地向桥上涌来。
en: But if they did not pass it was not for want of having attempted it.Those in the rear pushed on the foremost assailants, and it was an incessant struggle with revolvers and hatchets.Several colpeos already lay dead on the ground, but their number did not appear to diminish, and it might have been supposed that reinforcements were continually arriving over the bridge.

zh: 开拓者们很快就只好和它们近距离搏斗了，他们伤了几处，不过庆幸的是伤势很轻。一只山狐狸像山猫似的跳到纳布的后背上，赫伯特用左轮枪一枪把它打死，救出了纳布。托普真的狂怒了，它冲过去咬住狐狸的喉咙，立马勒死它们。贾普勇敢地挥舞着他手中的武器，他们想要它呆在后面是白费力气。毫无疑问，它生来目光就很敏锐，能够透过昏暗看见东西，因此，它总是到战斗最激烈的地方去，还不时地发出嘶嘶尖叫声，表示它非常兴奋。
en: The colonists were soon obliged to fight at close quarters, not without receiving some wounds, though happily very slight ones.Herbert had, with a shot from his revolver, rescued Neb, on whose back a colpeo had sprung like a tiger cat.Top fought with actual fury, flying at the throats of the foxes and strangling them instantaneously.Jup wielded his weapon valiantly, and it was in vain that they endeavored to keep him in the rear.Endowed doubtless with sight which enabled him to pierce the obscurity, he was always in the thick of the fight uttering from time to time—a sharp hissing sound, which was with him the sign of great rejoicing.

zh: 有时候，它会走出很远，借助左轮枪的闪光，才看见它被五、六只山狐狸包围着，而它却沉着应战。
en: At one moment he advanced so far, that by the light from a revolver he was seen surrounded by five or six large colpeos, with whom he was coping with great coolness.

zh: 不过，搏斗终于结束了，经过了足足两个小时的激战，居民们才取得了胜利！第一道白天来临的迹象无疑决定了入侵者的败退，它们越过桥梁，向北窜去，纳布立即跑过去把桥拉起来。等晨曦充分照亮战场的时候，居民们数了数散布在岸上的死狐狸，多达50只。
en: However, the struggle was ended at last, and victory was on the side of the settlers, but not until they had fought for two long hours!The first signs of the approach of day doubtless determined the retreat of their assailants, who scampered away towards the North, passing over the bridge, which Neb ran immediately to raise.When day had sufficiently lighted up the field of battle, the settlers counted as many as fifty dead bodies scattered about on the shore.

zh: “贾普！”潘克洛夫大喊，“贾普哪里去了？”贾普不见了。它的朋友纳布喊它的名字，这是它第一次没有回应朋友的喊声。
en: “And Jup!” cried Pencroft; “where is Jup?”Jup had disappeared.His friend Neb called him, and for the first time Jup did not reply to his friend’s call.

zh: 大家都动身去找贾普，人人都在发抖，害怕在尸堆里发现它，他们把染红积雪的尸体清到一边。最后，在狐狸堆中间发现了贾普，这些死狐狸的下巴破裂，身体支离破碎，表明这个勇猛的动物用可怕的棍子与它们进行了一场搏斗。
en: Everyone set out in search of Jup, trembling lest he should be found among the slain; they cleared the place of the bodies which stained the snow with their blood.Jup was found in the midst of a heap of colpeos whose broken jaws and crushed bodies showed that they had to do with the terrible club of the intrepid animal.

zh: 可怜的贾普手里还握着一截破棍子，但是没有了武器后，它寡不敌众，胸部受了几处重伤。
en: Poor Jup still held in his hand the stump of his broken cudgel, but deprived of his weapon he had been overpowered by numbers, and his chest was covered with severe wounds.

zh: “它还活着。”纳布在它身边弯下腰，喊道。
en: “He is living,” cried Neb, who was bending over him.

zh: “我们要救活它，”水手回答，“我们要把它当作自己人一样护理它。”
en: “And we will save him,” replied the sailor.“We will nurse him as if he was one of ourselves.”

zh: 贾普好像听得懂似的，把头靠在潘克洛夫的肩膀上，好像在感谢他。水手自己也受了伤，不过伤势不重，他的同伴也是这样的情况。多亏了他们的火器，他们几乎总能使攻击者无法靠近，因此，只有这只猩猩的情形比较严重。
en: It appeared as if Jup understood, for he leaned his head on Pencroft’s shoulder as if to thank him.The sailor was wounded himself, but his wound was insignificant, as were those of his companions; for thanks to their firearms they had been almost always able to keep their assailants at a distance. it was therefore only the orang whose condition was serious.

zh: 纳布和潘克洛夫抬着贾普，把它放在升降梯里，它的嘴里不时地发出轻微的呻吟声。大家轻轻地把它升到花岗石宫。之后，他们从其中一个床上拿了一个垫子，让它躺在上面，又十分小心地清洗它的伤口。贾普似乎没有受到巨大的创伤，但是由于失血过多，身体非常虚弱，伤口包扎好以后，很快又发起高烧来。大家让它躺了下来，饮食安排得非常严格，就像纳布所说的，对待它就像对待“一个真正的人一样”。他们给它喝了几杯清凉饮料，这些成分是从花岗石宫的植物草药箱子里获得的。贾普刚开始还有些焦躁不安，但是渐渐地它的呼吸就均匀了，大家也让它安静地睡着。托普时常蹑手蹑脚地，可以这样说，过来探访它的朋友，似乎对大家给予它的关心很满意。贾普的一只手搭在床边上，托普非常同情地舔着它的手。
en: Jup, carried by Neb and Pencroft, was placed in the lift, and only a slight moan now and then escaped his lips.He was gently drawn up to Granite House.There he was laid on a mattress taken from one of the beds, and his wounds were bathed with the greatest care.It did not appear that any vital part had been reached, but Jup was very weak from loss of blood, and a high fever soon set in after his wounds had been dressed.He was laid down, strict diet was imposed, “just like a real person,” as Neb said, and they made him swallow several cups of a cooling drink, for which the ingredients were supplied from the vegetable medicine chest of Granite House.Jup was at first restless, but his breathing gradually became more regular, and he was left sleeping quietly.From time to time Top, walking on tip-toe, as one might say, came to visit his friend, and seemed to approve of all the care that had been taken of him.One of Jup’s hands hung over the side of his bed, and Top licked it with a sympathizing air.

zh: 他们利用白天的时间，将死狐狸拖到远西森林里去，并把它们深深地埋葬在那里。
en: They employed the day in interring the dead, who were dragged to the forest of the Far West, and there buried deep.

zh: 这次的袭击差一点造成严重的后果，这给居民们一个教训。从这以后，他们睡前必须确保有人把桥拉起，不会受到侵犯。
en: This attack, which might have had such serious consequences, was a lesson to the settlers, who from this time never went to bed until one of their number had made sure that all the bridges were raised, and that no invasion was possible.

zh: 他们非常焦急地等了好几天后，贾普开始好转了。由于它身体结实，已经度过难关，烧也退了，吉丁·史佩莱略微懂得医术，他告诉大家它已经脱离了危险。8月16日，贾普开始进食了。纳布给它做了几份小小的甜美佳肴，“病人”还吃得津津有味，因为要说贾普有什么宠物的缺点，就是有点贪吃，纳布也从未给它纠正这个缺点。
en: However, Jup, after having given them serious anxiety for several days, began to recover.His constitution brought him through, the fever gradually subsided, and Gideon Spilett, who was a bit of a doctor, pronounced him quite out of danger.On the 16th of August, Jup began to eat.Neb made him nice little sweet dishes, which the invalid devoured with great relish, for if he had a pet failing it was that of being somewhat of a gourmend, and Neb had never done anything to cure him of this fault.

zh: “怎么办呢？”他对吉丁·史佩莱说，他有时会规劝纳布不要把猩猩宠坏了。“除了味觉上的享受外，可怜的贾普没有其他的乐趣，我非常愿意能够在这方面给它的服务一些回报！”
en: “What would you have?” said he to Gideon Spilett, who sometimes expostulated with him for spoiling the ape.“Poor Jup has no other pleasure than that of the palate, and I am only too glad to be able to reward his services in this way!”

zh: 在床上躺了十天后，8月21日，贾普起床了。它的伤口已经痊愈了，显然，不用很长时间它就能恢复一贯的力气和敏捷了。像所有复原期的病人一样，它的胃口特别大，记者让它想吃多少就吃多少，因为他相信，这个猩猩有抑制自己进食过多的本能，而这种本能是有理性的人类所缺乏的。纳布看到他学生的食欲恢复后，感到很高兴。
en: Ten days after taking to his bed, on the 21st of August, Master Jup arose.His wounds were healed, and it was evident that he would not be long in regaining his usual strength and agility.Like all convalescents, he was tremendously hungry, and the reporter allowed him to eat as much as he liked, for he trusted to that instinct, which is too often wanting in reasoning beings, to keep the orang from any excess.Neb was delighted to see his pupil’s appetite returning.

zh: “尽情地吃吧，我的贾普，”他说，“不要省着，你为我们流了血，我要做的最起码的事情就是让你恢复健康！”
en: “Eat away, my Jup,” said he, “and don’t spare anything; you have shed your blood for us, and it is the least I can do to make you strong again!”

zh: 8月25日，大家听见纳布在呼喊他们。
en: On the 25th of August Neb’s voice was heard calling to his companions.

zh: “上尉、史佩莱先生、赫伯特先生、潘克洛夫，过来！快过来！”
en: “Captain, Mr. Spilett, Mr. Herbert, Pencroft, come! come!”

zh: 开拓者们当时都在餐厅里，听到纳布的喊声后，起身到贾普的房间里。
en: The colonists, who were together in the dining-room, rose at Neb’s call, who was then in Jup’s room.

zh: “发生什么事了？”记者问。
en: “What’s the matter?” asked the reporter.

zh: “看啊。”纳布大声笑着回答。他们看到什么了呢？原来小贾普在花岗岩宫的过道处，像个顽童似的盘腿而坐，镇静而又严肃地吸着烟！
en: “Look,” replied Neb, with a shout of laughter.And what did they see?Master Jup smoking calmly and seriously, sitting crosslegged like a Turk at the entrance to Granite House!

zh: “我的烟斗，”潘克洛夫喊道，“他拿走了我的烟斗！喂，我的好贾普，我把它当礼物送给你了！抽吧，老兄，抽吧！”
en: “My pipe,” cried Pencroft.“He has taken my pipe!Hello, my honest Jup, I make you a present of it!Smoke away, old boy, smoke away!”

zh: 贾普庄重地吐着烟雾，它似乎感到非常满意。哈丁对这件事情似乎并不感到吃惊，他列举了几个例子，说明驯服的猩猩会吸烟已经变得很常见了。
en: And Jup gravely puffed out clouds of smoke which seemed to give him great satisfaction.Harding did not appear to be much astonished at this incident, and he cited several examples of tame apes, to whom the use of tobacco had become quite familiar.

zh: 但是从今天起，贾普就有了自己的烟斗，就是水手原来的那个，挂在它房间里，靠近储存烟草的地方。贾普自己装满烟，用燃烧的火炭点着，似乎自己成为了猿猴中最幸福的。忠实的贾普和可敬的水手之间本来友谊就很深厚，现在又有了共同的爱好，不难理解，他们的友谊进一步加深了。
en: But from this day Master Jup had a pipe of his own, the sailor’s ex-pipe, which was hung in his room near his store of tobacco.He filled it himself, lighted it with a glowing coal, and appeared to be the happiest of quadrumana.It may readily be understood that this similarity of tastes of Jup and Pencroft served to tighten the bonds of friendship which already existed between the honest ape and the worthy sailor.

zh: “也许它真的是个人，”有时候潘克洛夫对纳布说，“如果有一天，你听见它和我们说话，你会感到吃惊吗？”
en: “Perhaps he is really a man,” said Pencroft sometimes to Neb.“Should you be surprised to hear him beginning to speak to us some day?”

zh: “我保证，不会，”纳布回答，“让我感到惊讶的是，它之前一直没和我们说话，它现在就差说话了。”
en: “My word, no,” replied Neb.“What astonishes me is that he hasn’t spoken to us before, for now he wants nothing but speech!”

zh: “如果有一天它对我说，‘潘克洛夫，我们换一下烟斗吧’，我会觉得很有意思。”
en: “It would amuse me all the same,” resumed the sailor, “if some fine day he said to me, ‘Suppose we change pipes, Pencroft’.”

zh: “是啊，”纳布回答，“可惜它生来就是个哑巴！”
en: “Yes,” replied Neb, “what a pity he was born dumb!”

zh: 九月初，冬季结束，大家又开始急切地开始工作了。造船工作进展得很迅速，甲板已经完全铺好，船身内部用蒸气熏弯的肋条牢固地连接起来，符合模具的所有目的。
en: With the month of September the winter ended, and the works were again eagerly commenced.The building of the vessel advanced rapidly, she was already completely decked over, and all the inside parts of the hull were firmly united with ribs bent by means of steam, which answered all the purposes of a mold.

zh: 由于并不缺乏木头，潘克洛夫向工程师提议，给船身做一个双层的内壁，确保船身更牢固些。
en: As there was no want of wood, Pencroft proposed to the engineer to give a double lining to the hull, to insure the strength of the vessel.

zh: 哈丁也不知道他们将来会遇到什么情况，就同意了水手的意见，将船建造得尽量结实些。9月15日，船的内部和甲板全部完工了。为了填充漏缝，他们用干海藻作为填絮，用锤子把它们凿到木板之间的空隙中。他们又从森林中的松树上弄来了大量的松脂，煮沸后，将它们盖在上面封住。
en: Harding, not knowing what the future might have in store for them, approved the sailor’s idea of making the craft as strong as possible.The interior and deck of the vessel was entirely finished towards the 15th of September.For calking the seams they made oakum of dry seaweed, which was hammered in between the planks; then these seams were covered with boiling tar, which was obtained in great abundance from the pines in the forest.

zh: 这只船操作起来很简单。他们首先在石灰上把一块块沉重的花岗岩砌成压舱物，这些东西重12000磅。
en: The management of the vessel was very simple.She had from the first been ballasted with heavy blocks of granite walled up, in a bed of lime, twelve thousand pounds of which they stowed away.

zh: 他们又在压舱物上放了一个甲板，内部分成两个船舱，船舱内有两条长凳，也可以用来做橱柜。桅杆的底部支撑着两个船舱之间的隔板，通过两个舱口就可以到达甲板。
en: A deck was placed over this ballast, and the interior was divided into two cabins; two benches extended along them and served also as lockers.The foot of the mast supported the partition which separated the two cabins, which were reached by two hatchways let into the deck.

zh: 潘克洛夫没费多大劲，就找到了一棵适合做桅杆的树。他选择了一棵没有节的、很直的小枞树，只要把桅杆的底部砍成方的，顶部砍成圆的就可以了。桅杆、船舵和船身的铁工都是在“石窟”里锻造的，虽然粗糙，但很结实。最终，在十月的第一个星期，帆架、桅杆、帆杠、圆杆和桨等都做好了，大家一致同意环岛做一次试航，以确定船在海上的航行性能，以及能够利用它航行的距离。
en: Pencroft had no trouble in finding a tree suitable for the mast.He chose a straight young fir, with no knots, and which he had only to square at the step, and round off at the top.The ironwork of the mast, the rudder and the hull had been roughly but strongly forged at the Chimneys.Lastly, yards, masts, boom, spars, oars, etc., were all furnished by the first week in October, and it was agreed that a trial trip should be taken round the island, so as to ascertain how the vessel would behave at sea, and how far they might depend upon her.

zh: 在这期间，一切必要的工作都没有被忽视。摩佛仑羊和山羊增添了很多小羊羔，又必须给它们吃住，所以就扩大了畜栏。开拓者们也到过牡蛎场、养兔场、煤矿区和铁矿区，还去过一直没有探索过的远西森林，那里的猎物很丰富。他们发现了一些当地的植物，这些植物适合立即使用，于是增加了花岗岩宫的蔬菜储备种类。
en: During all this time the necessary works had not been neglected.The corral was enlarged, for the flock of musmons and goats had been increased by a number of young ones, who had to be housed and fed.The colonists had paid visits also to the oyster bed, the warren, the coal and iron mines, and to the till then unexplored districts of the Far West forest, which abounded in game.Certain indigenous plants were discovered, and those fit for immediate use contributed to vary the vegetable stores of Granite House.

zh: 这些是番杏科植物，其中有一些和好望角上的那些相似，它们长着可食的肉质叶子，其他的结着籽，里面含有一种淀粉。
en: They were a species of ficoide, some similar to those of the Cape, with eatable fleshy leaves, others bearing seeds containing a sort of flour.

zh: 10月10日，船下水了。造船工作圆满成功，潘克洛夫喜气洋洋、容光焕发。船上的索具装置完毕，用滑轮把船推到水边，在移民们的欢呼声中，船随着上涨的潮水浮了起来，尤其是潘克洛夫，在这个时候一点都不谦虚。另外，他的重要性不止造完这艘船，因为在这之后，他还要指挥这个船。经过大家一致的同意，他获得了“船长”的称号。为了使潘克洛夫船长满意，现在有必要给这艘船起个名字，经过反复的讨论，大家都同意用“乘风破浪”这个名字。上涨的潮水一把“乘风破浪”浮起来，大家就看到船在水中很平稳，航行起来也很容易。不过，试航工作决定就在当天举行，他们要远离海岸作一次短途旅行。天气晴朗，风平浪静，特别是接近南部海岸一带，因为当时风从西北方向吹来。
en: On the 10th of October the vessel was launched.Pencroft was radiant with joy, the operation was perfectly successful; the boat completely rigged, having been pushed on rollers to the water’s edge, was floated by the rising tide, amid the cheers of the colonists, particularly of Pencroft, who showed no modesty on this occasion.Besides his importance was to last beyond the finishing of the vessel, since, after having built her, he was to command her.The grade of captain was bestowed upon him with the approbation of all.To satisfy Captain Pencroft, it was now necessary to give a name to the vessel, and, after many propositions had been discussed, the votes were all in favor of the “Bonadventure.”As soon as the “Bonadventure” had been lifted by the rising tide, it was seen that she lay evenly in the water, and would be easily navigated.However, the trial trip was to be made that very day, by an excursion off the coast.The weather was fine, the breeze fresh, and the sea smooth, especially towards the south coast, for the wind was blowing from the northwest.

zh: “全体上船。”潘克洛夫大喊。但是首先他们必须吃早饭，他们认为最好在船上备用一些食物，因为这次航行有可能延迟到晚上。
en: “All hands on board,” shouted Pencroft; but breakfast was first necessary, and it was thought best to take provisions on board, in the event of their excursion being prolonged until the evening.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁同样也急于试一下这艘船，因为这船的模型是他想出来的，虽然根据水手的意见，修改了其中几个部分。但是，他并不像潘克洛夫那样对船有信心，水手后来没有提到达抱岛航行的事情，哈丁希望他已经放弃了这个想法。的确，他非常不愿意让他的两三个伙伴乘着这个载重不超过15吨的小船到那么远的地方去冒险。
en: Cyrus Harding was equally anxious to try the vessel, the model of which had originated with him, although on the sailor’s advice he had altered some parts of it, but he did not share Pencroft’s confidence in her, and as the latter had not again spoken of the voyage to Tabor Island, Harding hoped he had given it up.He would have indeed great reluctance in letting two or three of his companions venture so far in so small a boat, which was not of more than fifteen tons’ burden.

zh: 十点半的时候，大家都上了船，包括托普和贾普，赫伯特把锚拔了出来，它深深陷入靠近慈悲河口的沙里。他们扬起了船帆，桅杆上的林肯号国旗在空中飘扬，由潘克洛夫驾驶的“乘风破浪”号径自驶向海里。
en: At half-past ten everybody was on board, even Top and Jup, and Herbert weighed the anchor, which was fast in the sand near the mouth of the Mercy.The sail was hoisted, the Lincolnian flag floated from the masthead, and the “Bonadventure,” steered by Pencroft, stood out to sea.

zh: 船顺着从联合湾吹来的风向前行驶，用潘克洛夫的话说就是，它有跑得异常飞快的脚后跟，所以船的主人们看到这种情形，感到非常满意。绕过遗物角和爪角后，船长快速转变方向，使船沿着荒岛的南部海岸航行。这时候可以看出，船刚好在风的的五个方位内顺利航行。船上全体人员都很高兴，他们有艘好船，必要的时候，会给他们很大的帮助。如果天气良好，加上阵阵清风，航海一定会很顺利。
en: The wind blowing out of Union Bay she ran before it, and thus showed her owners, much to their satisfaction, that she possessed a remarkably fast pair of heels, according to Pencroft’s mode of speaking.After having doubled Flotsam Point and Claw Cape, the captain kept her close hauled, so as to sail along the southern coast of the island, when it was found she sailed admirably within five points of the wind.All hands were enchanted, they had a good vessel, which, in case of need, would be of great service to them, and with fine weather and a fresh breeze the voyage promised to be charming.

zh: 潘克洛夫现在使船离岸行驶，距离气球港有三四英里。这时候，大家看到了海岛的全貌。海岛呈现出全新的景象，沿岸地带，从爪角到爬虫角，景色变化不一，森林里枞树的深绿色与其他树木的鲜绿色形成对比，俯瞰一切，富兰克林山高耸的顶峰还覆盖着皑皑白雪。
en: Pencroft now stood off the shore, three or four miles across from Port Balloon.The island then appeared in all its extent and under a new aspect, with the varied panorama of its shore from Claw Cape to Reptile End, the forests in which dark firs contrasted with the young foliage of other trees and overlooked the whole, and Mount Franklin whose lofty head was still whitened with snow.

zh: “太漂亮了！”赫伯特大喊。
en: “How beautiful it is!” cried Herbert.

zh: “是的，我们的岛屿既漂亮又舒适，”潘克洛夫说，“我爱它就像爱我那可怜的母亲。我们刚来时贫困潦倒，现在，我们这五个从天而降的人还有什么缺的呢？”
en: “Yes, our island is beautiful and good,” replied Pencroft.“I love it as I loved my poor mother.It received us poor and destitute, and now what is wanting to us five fellows who fell on it from the sky?”

zh: “什么都不缺，”纳布回答，“什么都不缺，船长。”
en: “Nothing,” replied Neb; “nothing, captain.”

zh: 这两个勇敢的人大喊三声，向他们的海岛表示敬意！
en: And the two brave men gave three tremendous cheers in honor of their island!

zh: 这段时间，吉丁·史佩莱一直倚靠着桅杆，为展现在他眼前的全景绘制草图。
en: During all this time Gideon Spilett, leaning against the mast, sketched the panorama which was developed before his eyes.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁默默地注视着。
en: Cyrus Harding gazed on it in silence.

zh: “嗯，哈丁上尉，”潘克洛夫问，“你觉得我们的船怎么样啊？”
en: “Well, Captain Harding,” asked Pencroft, “what do you think of our vessel?”

zh: “好像航行得很好。”工程师回答。
en: “She appears to behave well,” replied the engineer.

zh: “好！现在你认为它能够作一定距离的航行吗？”
en: “Good!And do you think now that she could undertake a voyage of some extent?”

zh: “什么航行，潘克洛夫？”
en: “What voyage, Pencroft?”

zh: “比如说，去达抱岛。”
en: “One to Tabor Island, for instance.”

zh: “我的朋友，”哈丁回答说，“如果情况紧急，确有必要，我们会毫不犹豫地信任‘乘风破浪’号，作更远的航行，不过你知道让你们去达抱岛，我是很不放心的，因为根本没有必要非去不可。”
en: “My friend,” replied Harding, “I think that in any pressing emergency we need not hesitate to trust ourselves to the ‘Bonadventure’ even for a longer voyage; but you know I should see you set off to Tabor Island with great uneasiness, since nothing obliges you to go there.”

zh: “每个人都想了解一下自己的邻居，”水手说，他还是固执己见。“达抱岛是我们的邻居，而且是唯一的邻居！出于礼貌，我们至少也应该去拜访一次。”
en: “One likes to know one’s neighbors,” returned the sailor, who was obstinate in his idea.“Tabor Island is our neighbor, and the only one!Politeness requires us to go at least to pay a visit.”

zh: “哎呀，”史佩莱说，“我们的朋友潘克洛夫怎么突然间特别讲究礼节了啊！”
en: “By Jove,” said Spilett, “our friend Pencroft has become very particular about the proprieties all at once!”

zh: “我对任何事情都一点不讲究。”水手反驳说，他因为工程师的反对而非常生气，但是他又不想让工程师替他担忧。
en: “I am not particular about anything at all,” retorted the sailor, who was rather vexed by the engineer’s opposition, but who did not wish to cause him anxiety.

zh: “想一下，潘克洛夫，”哈丁继续说，“你不能一个人去达抱岛。”
en: “Consider, Pencroft,” resumed Harding, “you cannot go alone to Tabor Island.”

zh: “我只需要一个同伴就够了。”
en: “One companion will be enough for me.”

zh: “就算是这样，”工程师说，“你这样做，来林肯岛的五个居民就有减少两个的危险。”
en: “Even so,” replied the engineer, “you will risk depriving the colony of Lincoln Island of two settlers out of five.”

zh: “六个居民，”潘克洛夫回答，“你忘记贾普了。”
en: “Out of six,” answered Pencroft; “you forget Jup.”

zh: “是七个，”纳布补充说，“托普也应该算上。”
en: “Out of seven,” added Neb; “Top is quite worth another.”

zh: “这个航行根本没有危险，上尉。”潘克洛夫回答说。
en: “There is no risk at all in it, captain,” replied Pencroft.

zh: “还是有可能的，潘克洛夫，可是我再重复一遍，这样冒险是没有必要的。”
en: “That is possible, Pencroft; but I repeat it is to expose ourselves uselessly.”

zh: 固执的水手没有回答，谈话也暂停下来，他决定以后再继续谈论这个问题。可是，他毫不怀疑，接下来要发生的事情会帮助他，并且使最初不过是一种饱受怀疑的突发奇想变成了一件不得不做的事情。
en: The obstinate sailor did not reply, and let the conversation drop, quite determined to resume it again.But he did not suspect that an incident would come to his aid and change into an act of humanity that which was at first only a doubtful whim.

zh: 离岸航行一会儿后，“乘风破浪”又继续向着气球港的方向驶去。重要的是要弄清楚沙洲和礁石之间的海峡，必要时要设置浮标，因为小溪将用来作为港口。
en: After standing off the shore the “Bonadventure” again approached it in the direction of Port Balloon.It was important to ascertain the channels between the sandbanks and reefs, that buoys might be laid down since this little creek was to be the harbor.

zh: 他们离海岸不超过半英里，必须迎着风抢风而行。由于一部分微风被高地挡住了，“乘风破浪”号的航行速度非常慢，帆也很少鼓起来。海面平静得像镜子一样，海风吹过时，才偶尔荡起丝丝涟漪。
en: They were not more than half a mile from the coast, and it was necessary to tack to beat against the wind.The “Bonadventure” was then going at a very moderate rate, as the breeze, partly intercepted by the high land, scarcely swelled her sails, and the sea, smooth as glass, was only rippled now and then by passing gusts.

zh: 赫伯特一直站在船头，指挥着船在海峡中航行的路线，突然，他大喊：
en: Herbert had stationed himself in the bows that he might indicate the course to be followed among the channels, when all at once he shouted,—

zh: “向着风行驶，潘克洛夫，向着风！”
en: “Luff, Pencroft, luff!”

zh: “怎么回事，”水手回答说，“有礁石吗？”
en: “What’s the matter,” replied the sailor; “a rock?”

zh: “不——等一会儿，”赫伯特说，“我看得不是很清楚。再向着风，现在往右。”
en: “No—wait,” said Herbert; “I don’t quite see.Luff again—right—now.”

zh: 赫伯特一边说，一遍侧身，把手伸进水中，捞出一样东西，叫道：
en: So saying, Herbert, leaning over the side, plunged his arm into the water, and pulled it out, exclaiming,—

zh: “一个瓶子！”
en: “A bottle!”

zh: 他手里拿着一个塞着软木塞的瓶子，拣起这个瓶子的地方离海岸只有几锚链远。
en: He held in his hand a corked bottle which he had just seized a few cables’ length from the shore.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁拿过瓶子。他一言不发，拔开瓶塞，从里面拿出一张潮湿的纸，上面写着：
en: Cyrus Harding took the bottle.Without uttering a single word he drew the cork, and took from it a damp paper, on which were written these words:—

zh: “落难者……达抱岛：西经153度，南纬37度11分。”
en: “Castaway....Tabor island: 153deg W. long., 37deg 11’ S. lat.”

zh: 第十三章
en: Chapter 13

zh: “一个遇难者!”潘克洛夫喊道，“流落到达抱岛上了，离我们不到200英里！啊，哈丁上尉，现在你不会反对我去了吧。”
en: “A castaway!” exclaimed Pencroft; “left on this Tabor Island not two hundred miles from us!Ah, Captain Harding, you won’t now oppose my going.”

zh: “是的，潘克洛夫，”赛勒斯·哈丁回答说，“你尽快出发吧。”
en: “No, Pencroft,” replied Cyrus Harding; “and you shall set out as soon as possible.”

zh: “明天怎样？”
en: “To-morrow?”

zh: “就明天吧！”
en: “To-morrow!”

zh: 工程师手里还拿着从瓶子中取出的纸。他沉思了一会，然后接着说：
en: The engineer still held in his hand the paper which he had taken from the bottle.He contemplated it for some instants, then resumed,

zh: “朋友们，从这张纸上，从它的措辞上，我们可以得出以下结论：第一，达抱岛上的这个遇难者具有相当丰富的航海知识，因为他给出的达抱岛经纬度与我们测量出来的完全一样，并且他连大约的分度也算出来了；第二，他不是英国人就是美国人，因为上面的文字是英文。”
en: “From this document, my friends, from the way in which it is worded, we may conclude this: first, that the castaway on Tabor Island is a man possessing a considerable knowledge of navigation, since he gives the latitude and longitude of the island exactly as we ourselves found it, and to a second of approximation; secondly, that he is either English or American, as the document is written in the English language.”

zh: “这完全符合逻辑，”史佩莱回答，“这落难者的出现，解释了我们岛上海岸边那个箱子的由来。既然有遇难者，就一定有遇难的船只。潘克洛夫想要造这船，并且就在今天试航，对于这个落难者来说，不管他是谁，都是他的运气，因为如果再晚一天，瓶子有可能撞碎在岩石上。
en: “That is perfectly logical,” answered Spilett; “and the presence of this castaway explains the arrival of the case on the shores of our island.There must have been a wreck, since there is a castaway.As to the latter, whoever he may be, it is lucky for him that Pencroft thought of building this boat and of trying her this very day, for a day later and this bottle might have been broken on the rocks.”

zh: “的确，”赫伯特说，“碰巧的是，‘乘风破浪’号正好从瓶子漂浮的地方经过！”
en: “Indeed,” said Herbert, “it is a fortunate chance that the ‘Bonadventure’ passed exactly where the bottle was still floating!”

zh: “你觉得这件事奇怪吗？”哈丁问潘克洛夫。
en: “Does not this appear strange to you?” asked Harding of Pencroft.

zh: “似乎是运气好，仅此而已，”水手回答，“上尉，你发现这件事奇怪的地方了吗？瓶子总是要漂到一个地方的，其他地方和这里不一样吗？”
en: “It appears fortunate, that’s all,” answered the sailor.“Do you see anything extraordinary in it, captain?The bottle must go somewhere, and why not here as well as anywhere else?”

zh: “也许你是对的，潘克洛夫，”工程师说，“不过……”
en: “Perhaps you are right, Pencroft,” replied the engineer; “and yet—”

zh: “可是，”赫伯特说，“也不能证明瓶子已经在海上漂了很久了。”
en: “But,” observed Herbert, “there’s nothing to prove that this bottle has been floating long in the sea.”

zh: “是啊，”吉丁·史佩莱说，“这张纸好像是最近才写的。你怎么看呢，赛勒斯？”
en: “Nothing,” replied Gideon Spilett, “and the document appears even to have been recently written.What do you think about it, Cyrus?”

zh: 谈话的时候，潘克洛夫并没有闲着。他掉转船头，扬起船帆，飞速向爪角驶去。
en: During this conversation Pencroft had not remained inactive.He had put the vessel about, and the “Bonadventure,” all sails set, was running rapidly towards Claw Cape.

zh: 每个人都在想着达抱岛上的那个落难者。他们救他还来得及吗？对这群开拓者的生活来说，这可是一件大事！他们自己本来就是落难者，但换作是其他人，恐怕就不会如此幸运了，他们的责任就是去救他。
