en: Every one was thinking of the castaway on Tabor Island.Should they be in time to save him?This was a great event in the life of the colonists!They themselves were but castaways, but it was to be feared that another might not have been so fortunate, and their duty was to go to his succor.

zh: 他们绕过爪角，大约四点钟的时候，“乘风破浪”号在慈悲河口抛锚了。
en: Claw Cape was doubled, and about four o’clock the “Bonadventure” dropped her anchor at the mouth of the Mercy.

zh: 也就是当天晚上，他们制定了新的远征安排。看来，得由潘克洛夫和赫伯特承担这次航行，因为他们懂得怎样行船。如果第二天，也就是10月10日出发，10月13日就能到达，因为以目前的风向来看，航行150英里的路程用不了48个小时。在岛上呆一天，回来需要三四天，因此，他们希望在10月17号再回到林肯岛。天气晴朗，温度上升，风向似乎也稳定，一切都有利于这两个勇敢的人远离海岛的进行人道援助。
en: That same evening the arrangements for the new expedition were made.It appeared best that Pencroft and Herbert, who knew how to work the vessel, should undertake the voyage alone.By setting out the next day, the 10th of October, they would arrive on the 13th, for with the present wind it would not take more than forty-eight hours to make this passage of a hundred and fifty miles.One day in the island, three or four to return, they might hope therefore that on the 17th they would again reach Lincoln Island.The weather was fine, the barometer was rising, the wind appeared settled, everything then was in favor of these brave men whom an act of humanity was taking far from their island.

zh: 大家一致决定，赛勒斯·哈丁、纳布和吉丁·史佩莱留在花岗岩宫，但是史佩莱提出了反对意见，他没有忘记作为《纽约先驱报》记者的任务，他表示自己宁愿游过去，也不愿错过这样一个机会，于是大家同意他参加这次航行。
en: Thus it had been agreed that Cyrus Harding, Neb, and Gideon Spilett should remain at Granite House, but an objection was raised, and Spilett, who had not forgotten his business as reporter to the New York Herald, having declared that he would go by swimming rather than lose such an opportunity, he was admitted to take a part in the voyage.

zh: 晚上，大家都忙着往船上搬运东西，有铺盖、器皿、武器、弹药、指南针以及够吃一周的粮食，这些工作很快完成后，开拓者们就上到花岗岩宫去了。
en: The evening was occupied in transporting on board the “Bonadventure,” articles of bedding, utensils, arms, ammunition, a compass, provisions for a week; this being rapidly done, the colonists ascended to Granite House.

zh: 第二天清晨五点钟，大家互相告别，心中都有些依依不舍，潘克洛夫扬起风帆，向爪角驶去，他们必须绕过爪角，为了向西南方前进。
en: The next day, at five o’clock in the morning, the farewells were said, not without some emotion on both sides, and Pencroft setting sail made towards Claw Cape, which had to be doubled in order to proceed to the southwest.

zh: 已经离岸四分之一英里了，“乘风破浪”号上的乘客看见花岗岩宫的高地上还有两个人在和他们挥手，这两人是赛勒斯·哈丁和纳布。
en: The “Bonadventure” was already a quarter of a mile from the coast when the passengers perceived on the heights of Granite House two men waving their farewells; they were Cyrus Harding and Neb.

zh: “朋友们，”史佩莱喊道，“这是15个月来，我们第一次分开。”
en: “Our friends,” exclaimed Spilett, “this is our first separation in fifteen months.”

zh: 潘克洛夫、记者和赫伯特也向他们挥手，不一会儿，花岗岩宫就消失在爪角高高的岩后面了。
en: Pencroft, the reporter and Herbert waved in return, and Granite House soon disappeared behind the high rocks of the Cape.

zh: 这一天上午，“乘风破浪”号还在林肯岛的南部海岸一带行驶，很快林肯岛看起来就像是一个绿色的篮子，富兰克林山从中间耸起。从远处看，高度不是很高，吸引不住过往船只的注意。走了大约一个小时，就过了爬虫角，虽然只是在约十英里的地方。
en: During the first part of the day the “Bonadventure” was still in sight of the southern coast of Lincoln Island, which soon appeared just like a green basket, with Mount Franklin rising from the center.The heights, diminished by distance, did not present an appearance likely to tempt vessels to touch there.Reptile End was passed in about an hour, though at a distance of about ten miles.

zh: 现在，再也看不到一直延伸到富兰克林山脊的西海岸了，三个小时后，林肯岛最后的景象也沉在水平线以下了。
en: At this distance it was no longer possible to distinguish anything of the Western Coast, which stretched away to the ridges of Mount Franklin, and three hours after the last of Lincoln Island sank below the horizon.

zh: “乘风破浪”号航行得很好。它在波浪上跳动，快速在航线上前进。潘克洛夫升起前桅的风帆，依靠指南针，直线行驶。赫伯特时不时得和他轮流掌舵，少年的手非常牢固，水手挑不出一点毛病来。
en: The “Bonadventure” behaved capitally.Bounding over the waves she proceeded rapidly on her course.Pencroft had hoisted the foresail, and steering by the compass followed a rectilinear direction.From time to time Herbert relieved him at the helm, and the lad’s hand was so firm that the sailor had not a point to find fault with.

zh: 吉丁·史佩莱一会儿和这个说说话，一会儿和那个说说，必要的时候，他会帮着照看下绳索，潘克洛夫船长对他的船员非常满意。
en: Gideon Spilett chatted sometimes with one, sometimes with the other, if wanted he lent a hand with the ropes, and Captain Pencroft was perfectly satisfied with his crew.

zh: 傍晚时分，一弯新月出现在暮色中，很快就落下去了，直到16日，才能看到上玄月。夜色苍茫，但繁星满天，第二天一定是好天气。
en: In the evening the crescent moon, which would not be in its first quarter until the 16th, appeared in the twilight and soon set again.The night was dark but starry, and the next day again promised to be fine.

zh: 潘克洛夫小心地降下风帆，他不想在满帆的情况下遭到暴风的突袭。夜晚很安静，这个预防措施可能是没有必要的，但是潘克洛夫是一个谨慎的水手，不能因此责怪他。
en: Pencroft prudently lowered the foresail, not wishing to be caught by a sudden gust while carrying too much canvas; it was perhaps an unnecessary precaution on such a calm night, but Pencroft was a prudent sailor and cannot be blamed for it.

zh: 记者睡了半夜。潘克洛夫和赫伯特轮流掌舵，每两小时换一次班。水手相信赫伯特就像相信自己一样，少年的冷静和判断证明他的自信是正确的。潘克洛夫像船长一样指挥着舵手，赫伯特从来没有让“乘风破浪”号航行时有任何偏差。夜晚很快就过去了，10月12日的白天也是这样。他们严格按照东南方向行驶。如果“乘风破浪”号不遇到一些未知的海流，那么它将正好处在达抱岛的视线之内。
en: The reporter slept part of the night.Pencroft and Herbert took turns for a spell of two hours each at the helm.The sailor trusted Herbert as he would himself, and his confidence was justified by the coolness and judgment of the lad.Pencroft gave him his directions as a commander to his steersman, and Herbert never allowed the “Bonadventure” to swerve even a point.The night passed quickly, as did the day of the 12th of October.A south-easterly direction was strictly maintained.Unless the “Bonadventure” fell in with some unknown current she would come exactly within sight of Tabor Island.

zh: 在他们当时一路经过的海面上，一片荒凉。偶尔有大的信天翁或军舰鸟在射程范围内飞行，吉丁·史佩莱特就想，这是否是他上次用来给《纽约先驱报》带信的那只？在达抱岛和林肯岛之间的海域，似乎只有这些鸟经常在这一带飞行。
en: As to the sea over which the vessel was then sailing, it was absolutely deserted.Now and then a great albatross or frigate bird passed within gunshot, and Gideon Spilett wondered if it was to one of them that he had confided his last letter addressed to the New York Herald.These birds were the only beings that appeared to frequent this part of the ocean between Tabor and Lincoln Islands.

zh: “可是，”赫伯特说，“这个时候，捕鲸船经常到南太平洋一带。事实上，这个地方再荒凉不过了。”
en: “And yet,” observed Herbert, “this is the time that whalers usually proceed towards the southern part of the Pacific.Indeed I do not think there could be a more deserted sea than this.”

zh: “并不像你说的那么荒凉。”潘克洛夫说。
en: “It is not quite so deserted as all that,” replied Pencroft.

zh: “你是什么意思？”记者问。
en: “What do you mean?” asked the reporter.

zh: “我们现在在海上。难道你把我们的船当作遇难的船，把我们当作是海豚了吗？
en: “We are on it.Do you take our vessel for a wreck and us for porpoises?”

zh: 潘克洛夫一边说着，一边大笑。
en: And Pencroft laughed at his joke.

zh: 傍晚时候，他们估计，自“乘风破浪”号离开林肯岛以来，也就是说在36个小时内，他们行驶了120海里，它的时速是3海里到4海里之间。此刻风很小，而且有可能很快就要停下来。尽管这样，如果他们估计准确并且航线正确，明天早上破晓的时候，他们就能看到达抱岛。
en: By the evening, according to calculation, it was thought that the “Bonadventure” had accomplished a distance of a hundred and twenty miles since her departure from Lincoln Island, that is to say in thirty-six hours, which would give her a speed of between three and four knots an hour.The breeze was very slight and might soon drop altogether.However, it was hoped that the next morning by break of day, if the calculation had been correct and the course true, they would sight Tabor Island.

zh: 这一夜，吉丁·史佩莱、赫伯特和潘克洛夫都没有睡。他们期待着明天的到来，心里难免有些激动。他们这次冒险充满未知数！他们是不是要靠近达抱岛了呢？他们要救的那个遇难者还在这个岛上吗？这个人是谁？他的出现会不会打破这个开拓地一向的团结呢？另外，他愿不愿意换个困守的地方呢？毫无疑问，这些问题第二天都能找到答案，然而他们却静不下心来。第二天黎明，所有人都注视着西边的地平线。
en: Neither Gideon Spilett, Herbert, nor Pencroft slept that night.In the expectation of the next day they could not but feel some emotion.There was so much uncertainty in their enterprise!Were they near Tabor Island?Was the island still inhabited by the castaway to whose succor they had come?Who was this man?Would not his presence disturb the little colony till then so united?Besides, would he be content to exchange his prison for another?All these questions, which would no doubt be answered the next day, kept them in suspense, and at the dawn of day they all fixed their gaze on the western horizon.

zh: “陆地！”早上大约六点钟的时候，潘克洛夫大喊。
en: “Land!” shouted Pencroft at about six o’clock in the morning.

zh: 潘克洛夫不可能错，显然那边就是陆地。想象一下，“乘风破浪”号上的小队船员们有多么高兴。再过几个小时，他们就可以登上这个岛屿的海滩了！
en: And it was impossible that Pencroft should be mistaken, it was evident that land was there.Imagine the joy of the little crew of the “Bonadventure.”In a few hours they would land on the beach of the island!

zh: 达抱岛海岸很低，仅比海平面高出一点，现在离他们还有不到15海里。
en: The low coast of Tabor Island, scarcely emerging from the sea, was not more than fifteen miles distant.

zh: “乘风破浪”号的头部直接对着达抱岛行驶，位置稍微偏向岛的南部，太阳从东方升起，光辉洒在一两个海角上。
en: The head of the “Bonadventure,” which was a little to the south of the island, was set directly towards it, and as the sun mounted in the east, its rays fell upon one or two headlands.

zh: “这个岛要比林肯岛小得多，”赫伯特说，“大概和我们的岛屿一样，都是由海底地震形成的。”
en: “This is a much less important isle than Lincoln Island,” observed Herbert, “and is probably due like ours to some submarine convulsion.”

zh: 晚上十一点的时候，“乘风破浪”号离海岸不到两海里了，潘克洛夫一边寻找适合登陆的地方，一边小心翼翼地在陌生的海面上行驶。现在可以看清楚整个岛屿了，也可以看到岛上丛生的橡胶树以及其他种类的大树，这些品种与林肯岛上的那些一样。但是，令人惊讶的是岛上没有一缕显示人类居住的炊烟，整个岛上看起来没有人居住的迹象。
en: At eleven o’clock the “Bonadventure” was not more than two miles off, and Pencroft, while looking for a suitable place at which to land, proceeded very cautiously through the unknown waters.The whole of the island could now be surveyed, and on it could be seen groups of gum and other large trees, of the same species as those growing on Lincoln Island.But the astonishing thing was that no smoke arose to show that the island was inhabited, no signal whatever appeared on the shore!

zh: 然而，纸条上写得很清楚，这里有一个落难的人，而且这个人一定在密切注意着。
en: And yet the document was clear enough; there was a castaway, and this castaway should have been on the watch.

zh: 这时候，“乘风破浪”号穿过礁石，驶入弯弯曲曲的海峡，潘克洛夫十分小心地注意着每一个弯曲部分。他让赫伯特掌舵，自己站在船头，观察着海水，手握升降索，随时准备降帆。吉丁·史佩莱用望眼镜焦急地看了一下海面，可是什么都没有发现。
en: In the meanwhile the “Bonadventure” entered the winding channels among the reefs, and Pencroft observed every turn with extreme care.He had put Herbert at the helm, posting himself in the bows, inspecting the water, while he held the halliard in his hand, ready to lower the sail at a moment’s notice.Gideon Spilett with his glass eagerly scanned the shore, though without perceiving anything.

zh: 大约十二点的时候，“乘风破浪”号的船身终于碰到陆地了。水手们抛下船锚，收起帆，然后这小队船员登陆。
en: However, at about twelve o’clock the keel of the “Bonadventure” grated on the bottom.The anchor was let go, the sails furled, and the crew of the little vessel landed.

zh: 毫无疑问，这就是达抱岛，因为根据最新的海图，在新西兰和美洲之间这一带的海域，没有其他的岛屿了。
en: And there was no reason to doubt that this was Tabor Island, since according to the most recent charts there was no island in this part of the Pacific between New Zealand and the American Coast.

zh: 他们把船牢牢地系好，这样船就没有被落潮冲走的危险了，然后潘克洛夫和他的同伴们全副武装，跳上海岸，打算爬到半英里外海拔250英尺到300英尺的地方去。
en: The vessel was securely moored, so that there should be no danger of her being carried away by the receding tide; then Pencroft and his companions, well armed, ascended the shore, so as to gain an elevation of about two hundred and fifty or three hundred feet which rose at a distance of half a mile.

zh: “从山顶上看，”史佩莱说，“毫无疑问，我们能够看到这个岛的全景，这会极大地方便我们寻找。”
en: “From the summit of that hill,” said Spilett, “we can no doubt obtain a complete view of the island, which will greatly facilitate our search.”

zh: 赫伯特回答说：“哈丁上尉在林肯岛上做的第一件事就是爬上富兰克林山，这里也是如此。”
en: “So as to do here,” replied Herbert, “that which Captain Harding did the very first thing on Lincoln Island, by climbing Mount Franklin.”

zh: “确实如此，”记者说，“这也是最好的计划。”
en: “Exactly so,” answered the reporter, “and it is the best plan.”

zh: 因此，这些探险者们一边说着，一边沿着山脚下的一块空地前进。成群的石鸽子和海燕在他们周围来回飞旋，它们与林肯岛上的那些相似。在左边林间空地的树下，他们能够听到灌木丛中沙沙的声音，看到小草来回摆动，这些迹象表明树林中有胆小的动物，但还是没有一丝迹象表明有人居住在这个岛上。
en: While thus talking the explorers had advanced along a clearing which terminated at the foot of the hill.Flocks of rock-pigeons and sea-swallows, similar to those of Lincoln Island, fluttered around them.Under the woods which skirted the glade on the left they could hear the bushes rustling and see the grass waving, which indicated the presence of timid animals, but still nothing to show that the island was inhabited.

zh: 到达山脚下后，潘克洛夫、史佩莱和赫伯特几分钟就爬了上去，惴惴不安地注视着地平线。
en: Arrived at the foot of the hill, Pencroft, Spilett, and Herbert climbed it in a few minutes, and gazed anxiously round the horizon.

zh: 他们所在的小岛，圆周不超过六英里，边缘的海角、海岬，或是海湾、溪流不多，形状就像一个拉长的椭圆。岛的四周，只有荒凉的大海延伸到地平线的尽头。看不见任何陆地甚至船只。
en: They were on an islet, which did not measure more than six miles in circumference, its shape not much bordered by capes or promontories, bays or creeks, being a lengthened oval.All around, the lonely sea extended to the limits of the horizon.No land nor even a sail was in sight.

zh: 这个小岛虽然树木丛生，但地理特征却不像林肯岛那样丰富，林肯岛上有一部分寸草不生、一片荒凉，其他地方却土地肥沃、资源丰富。相反，这里一片翠绿，中间会升起两、三座不是很高的小山。椭圆形小岛的侧面，有水流从广阔的草地中流出，又通过西部一个狭窄的出口落入大海。
en: This woody islet did not offer the varied aspects of Lincoln Island, arid and wild in one part, but fertile and rich in the other.On the contrary this was a uniform mass of verdure, out of which rose two or three hills of no great height.Obliquely to the oval of the island ran a stream through a wide meadow falling into the sea on the west by a narrow mouth.

zh: “地方太小了。”赫伯特说。
en: “The domain is limited,” said Herbert.

zh: “是啊，”潘克洛夫又回答说，“对我们来说太小了。”
en: “Yes,” rejoined Pencroft: “It would have been too small for us.”

zh: “另外，”记者说，“这看上去好像没有人居住。”
en: “And moreover,” said the reporter, “it appears to be uninhabited.”

zh: “的确是这样，”赫伯特回答说，“这里没有一样东西能够显露出有人存在。”
en: “Indeed,” answered Herbert, “nothing here betrays the presence of man.”

zh: “我们继续往下走，接着寻找吧。”潘克洛夫说。
en: “Let us go down,” said Pencroft, “and search.”

zh: 水手和他的两个同伴回到了海岸上，也就是他们离开“乘风破浪”号的地方。
en: The sailor and his two companions returned to the shore, to the place where they had left the “Bonadventure.”

zh: 在探索岛的内部以前，他们决定徒步游览这个小岛，这样一个地点都不会遗漏在他们的调查中。海滩很容易走，只是在某些地方，有大岩石挡住他们的道路，但是他们很容易就绕过了。这些探险者们向南走，途中惊动了无数的海鸟和成群的海豹，它们看到远处有陌生人出现，就马上钻到海里去了。
en: They had decided to make the tour of the island on foot, before exploring the interior; so that not a spot should escape their investigations.The beach was easy to follow, and only in some places was their way barred by large rocks, which, however, they easily passed round.The explorers proceeded towards the south, disturbing numerous flocks of sea-birds and herds of seals, which threw themselves into the sea as soon as they saw the strangers at a distance.

zh: “那边那些野兽可不是第一次见到人类。”记者说。它们怕人，因此他们一定对人类有所了解。
en: “Those beasts yonder,” observed the reporter, “do not see men for the first time.They fear them, therefore they must know them.”

zh: 出发一小时后，他们走到了这个小岛的南端，最南端以一个锋利的海角为尾，之后他们又沿着西海岸向北方前进，海岸上一半是沙子一半是岩石，后面的边界上是茂密的树林。
en: An hour after their departure they arrived on the southern point of the islet, terminated by a sharp cape, and proceeded towards the north along the western coast, equally formed by sand and rocks, the background bordered with thick woods.

zh: 这里没有一个地方显示人居住过的痕迹，也没有人的脚印在小岛的海岸上，他们用了四个小时，在海岸上走了个遍。
en: There was not a trace of a habitation in any part, not the print of a human foot on the shore of the island, which after four hours’ walking had been gone completely round.

zh: 至少可以说这非常不同寻常，他们也不得不相信，达抱岛以前没有人居住，以后也不会再有人居住。或许这个纸条已经写了几个月或者几年了，这种情况下，落难者可能已经回到了自己的国家，也可能不幸死去了。
en: It was to say the least very extraordinary, and they were compelled to believe that Tabor Island was not or was no longer inhabited.Perhaps, after all the document was already several months or several years old, and it was possible in this case, either that the castaway had been enabled to return to his country, or that he had died of misery.

zh: 潘克洛夫、史佩莱以及赫伯特或多或少猜测出几种可能，他们急匆匆地在“乘风破浪”号上吃了饭，以便能够在夜晚来临前继续远足。晚上五点的时候，他们就结束了，进入了树林。
en: Pencroft, Spilett, and Herbert, forming more or less probable conjectures, dined rapidly on board the “Bonadventure” so as to be able to continue their excursion until nightfall.This was done at five o’clock in the evening, at which hour they entered the wood.

zh: 大量的动物在他们接近时就逃散了，可以说它们主要是山羊和猪，很显然这些动物都是欧洲品种。
en: Numerous animals fled at their approach, being principally, one might say, only goats and pigs, which were obviously European species.

zh: 毫无疑问，是某个捕鲸船把他们带到这个岛上的，它们的数量也迅速增加。赫伯特决定捉一两只活的带回林肯岛。
en: Doubtless some whaler had landed them on the island, where they had rapidly increased.Herbert resolved to catch one or two living, and take them back to Lincoln Island.

zh: 已经毫无疑问的是，人类在某个时间已经来过这个小岛，而且更明显的是，森林中的小路看起来被踩踏过，还有砍伐的树枝，每到一处都有人类用手动过的痕迹。但是，这些树木已经腐烂了，也许是很多年前砍伐的，斧子砍过的痕迹上还有天鹅绒状的苔藓，路上的小草也长高了，变浓密了，所以很难找到道路。
en: It was no longer doubtful that men at some period or other had visited this islet, and this became still more evident when paths appeared trodden through the forest, felled trees, and everywhere traces of the hand of man; but the trees were becoming rotten, and had been felled many years ago; the marks of the axe were velveted with moss, and the grass grew long and thick on the paths, so that it was difficult to find them.

zh: “可是，这证明了不仅已经有人登陆了这个小岛，并且他们已经在这儿住了一段时间。”吉丁·史佩莱说，“那么，这些人到底是谁？他们还有多少人留在这里呢？”
en: “But,” observed Gideon Spilett, “this not only proves that men have landed on the island, but also that they lived on it for some time.Now, who were these men?How many of them remain?”

zh: “那张纸条上说就只有一个落难者。”赫伯特说。
en: “The document,” said Herbert, “only spoke of one castaway.”

zh: “嗯，如果他还在这个岛上，那就不可能找不到他。”潘克洛夫说。
en: “Well, if he is still on the island,” replied Pencroft, “it is impossible but that we shall find him.”

zh: 他们继续探索。水手和他的同伴们自然地顺着与小岛斜对角的小路前进，他们只得沿着流入大海的河流前行。
en: The exploration was continued.The sailor and his companions naturally followed the route which cut diagonally across the island, and they were thus obliged to follow the stream which flowed towards the sea.

zh: 如果这些动物是欧洲品种，如果这些工程是人手的杰作，那无可置疑地证明了人类已经踏足这个小岛，几种蔬菜的样本也证明了这一点。很显然，在空地中的某个地方，土壤中已经种上了厨房里烹调用的植物，很可能是在同样久远的时代。
en: If the animals of European origin, if works due to a human hand, showed incontestably that men had already visited the island, several specimens of the vegetable kingdom did not prove it less.In some places, in the midst of clearings, it was evident that the soil had been planted with culinary plants, at probably the same distant period.

zh: 接下来令赫伯特高兴的是，他认出来那是土豆、菊苣、掌叶大黄、胡萝卜、卷心菜和萝卜，收集它们的种子足够丰富林肯岛的土地。
en: What, then, was Herbert’s joy, when he recognized potatoes, chicory, sorrel, carrots, cabbages, and turnips, of which it was sufficient to collect the seed to enrich the soil of Lincoln Island.

zh: “太好，真开心！”潘克洛夫大喊，“这适合纳布，同样也适合我们。即使我们没有找到落难者，至少我们的航行也不会毫无意义，上帝会奖赏我们的。”
en: “Capital, jolly!” exclaimed Pencroft.“That will suit Neb as well as us.Even if we do not find the castaway, at least our voyage will not have been useless, and God will have rewarded us.”

zh: “肯定是的，”吉丁·史佩莱特回答，“可是，从我们找到的这些植物栽植的状态来看，我担心这个岛已经有一段时间没有人居住了。”
en: “Doubtless,” replied Gideon Spilett, “but to see the state in which we find these plantations, it is to be feared that the island has not been inhabited for some time.”

zh: “确实是这样，不管这个人是谁，他不会将如此重要的农作物置之不理的！”赫伯特回答。
en: “Indeed,” answered Herbert, “an inhabitant, whoever he was, could not have neglected such an important culture!”

zh: “是的，”潘克洛夫说，“落难者已经走了。”
en: “Yes,” said Pencroft, “the castaway has gone.”

zh: “我们只能这样假设了。”
en: “We must suppose so.”

zh: “我们只好认为纸条是很久以前写的了，是吗？”
en: “It must then be admitted that the document has already a distant date?”

zh: “当然了。”
en: “Evidently.”

zh: “这个瓶子是在海上漂流了很长时间才到达林肯岛的。”
en: “And that the bottle only arrived at Lincoln Island after having floated in the sea a long time.”

zh: “那有什么不可呢？”潘克洛夫回应，“可是天就要黑了，我认为现在最好放弃寻找。”
en: “Why not?” returned Pencroft.“But night is coming on,” added he, “and I think that it will be best to give up the search for the present.”

zh: “我们先回船吧，明天我们重新开始。”记者说。
en: “Let us go on board, and to-morrow we will begin again,” said the reporter.

zh: 这是最明智的做法，当他们要走的时候，赫伯特指着树林中杂乱的一堆，大喊：
en: This was the wisest course, and it was about to be followed when Herbert, pointing to a confused mass among the trees, exclaimed,—

zh: “一所房子！”
en: “A hut!”

zh: 三个人立刻一起向房子冲去。暮色中，他们只能看出房屋是用木板钉成的，上面盖着一层厚厚的防水布。
en: All three immediately ran towards the dwelling.In the twilight it was just possible to see that it was built of planks and covered with a thick tarpaulin.

zh: 潘克洛夫快步冲过去，推开半掩的门。
en: The half-closed door was pushed open by Pencroft, who entered with a rapid step.

zh: 房子里空无一人！
en: The hut was empty!

zh: 第十四章
en: Chapter 14

zh: 潘克洛夫、赫伯特和吉丁·史佩莱在黑暗中保持着沉默。
en: Pencroft, Herbert, and Gideon Spilett remained silent in the midst of the darkness.

zh: 潘克洛夫大声喊叫起来。
en: Pencroft shouted loudly.

zh: 没有人回应。
en: No reply was made.

zh: 接着，水手打出了火光，点燃了一根小树枝。火光亮了一分钟，借着亮光，他们发现房子里完全是空的。房间后面是一个简陋的壁炉，上面带有些许冷煤渣，煤渣上支起一抱干木柴。潘克洛夫将燃烧的树枝扔了过去，木柴发出噼里啪啦的声音，接着就发出一道明亮的火光。
en: The sailor then struck a light and set fire to a twig.This lighted for a minute a small room, which appeared perfectly empty.At the back was a rude fireplace, with a few cold cinders, supporting an armful of dry wood.Pencroft threw the blazing twig on it, the wood crackled and gave forth a bright light.

zh: 水手和他的两个同伴看到一张不整齐的床，上面有一条潮湿并发黄的被单，说明这个床已经很长时间没有人用了。壁炉的角落里,有两个布满铁锈的水壶和一口推翻的锅。衣柜里有几件发霉的水手服，桌子上有一个锡碟和一本《圣经》，不过因潮湿已经侵蚀；角落里有一些工具：一把铁锹，一把镐，两支鸟枪，有一支已经断了；在像一个架子的木板上，摆着一桶仍没有动过的火药，一桶弹药，还有几盒雷管，这些东西上面都落了一层厚厚的灰尘，也许是很多年来堆积下来的。
en: The sailor and his two companions then perceived a disordered bed, of which the damp and yellow coverlets proved that it had not been used for a long time.In the corner of the fireplace were two kettles, covered with rust, and an overthrown pot.A cupboard, with a few moldy sailor’s clothes; on the table a tin plate and a Bible, eaten away by damp; in a corner a few tools, a spade, pickaxe, two fowling-pieces, one of which was broken; on a plank, forming a shelf, stood a barrel of powder, still untouched, a barrel of shot, and several boxes of caps, all thickly covered with dust, accumulated, perhaps, by many long years.

zh: “没有一个人在这儿。”记者说。
en: “There is no one here,” said the reporter.

zh: “没有人。”潘克洛夫回答。
en: “No one,” replied Pencroft.

zh: “这个房子已经很多年没有人居住了。”赫伯特说。
en: “It is a long time since this room has been inhabited,” observed Herbert.

zh: “是的，很长时间了！”记者应答。
en: “Yes, a very long time!” answered the reporter.

zh: “史佩莱先生，”潘克洛夫说，“我认为我们就不要回到船上了，在这个小屋住一晚会很不错。”
en: “Mr. Spilett,” then said Pencroft, “instead of returning on board, I think that it would be well to pass the night in this hut.”

zh: “你说得对，潘克洛夫，”吉丁·史佩莱回答，“如果房屋的主人回来了，那最好不过了！也许他发现地方被人占了不会不高兴。”
en: “You are right, Pencroft,” answered Gideon Spilett, “and if its owner returns, well! perhaps he will not be sorry to find the place taken possession of.”

zh: “他不会回来的。”水手边摇头边说。
en: “He will not return,” said the sailor, shaking his head.

zh: “你认为他已经离开这个岛了吗？”记者问。
en: “You think that he has quitted the island?” asked the reporter.

zh: “如果他离开了这个岛，他就会带走他的武器和工具。”潘克洛夫应道，“你知道对于遇难者来说，这些物品的价值，因为这是失事船只最后剩下的东西了。不会的！不会的！”水手用一种确信的语气反复说，“不会的，他还没有离开这个岛！”如果他乘自己造的船逃离了，他也不太有可能将这些不可缺少、又是必备的物品留在这里。不会的！他还在岛上！”
en: “If he had quitted the island he would have taken away his weapons and his tools,” replied Pencroft.“You know the value which castaways set on such articles as these the last remains of a wreck.No! no!” repeated the sailor, in a tone of conviction; “no, he has not left the island!If he had escaped in a boat made by himself, he would still less have left these indispensable and necessary articles.No! he is on the island!”

zh: “活着？”赫伯特问。
en: “Living?” asked Herbert.

zh: “活着或者死了。可是如果他死了，我想他并没有埋葬自己，所以我们至少可以找到他的遗体！”
en: “Living or dead.But if he is dead, I suppose he has not buried himself, and so we shall at least find his remains!”

zh: 最后他们决定在这个废弃的住所里度过这个夜晚，在角落里找到的一堆木柴足够取暖用了。门关上了，潘克洛夫、赫伯特和史佩莱呆在那里，坐在一个长凳上，彼此之间话很少，但是想的很多。他们的思绪天马行空，任何事情都可以进入他们的想象或期待。他们热切地听着外面的声音。门可能会突然被推开，有一个人会出现在他们面前，他们一点儿也不会吃惊。尽管这个小屋的一切透露着被遗弃的迹象，他们会向这个人，这位遇难者，这位素不认识却等待已久的朋友，伸出手去，与他击掌。
en: It was then agreed that the night should be passed in the deserted dwelling, and a store of wood found in a corner was sufficient to warm it.The door closed, Pencroft, Herbert and Spilett remained there, seated on a bench, talking little but wondering much.They were in a frame of mind to imagine anything or expect anything.They listened eagerly for sounds outside.The door might have opened suddenly, and a man presented himself to them without their being in the least surprised, notwithstanding all that the hut revealed of abandonment, and they had their hands ready to press the hands of this man, this castaway, this unknown friend, for whom friends were waiting.

zh: 可是，他们没有听到任何声音，门也没有开。时间就这样过去了。
en: But no voice was heard, the door did not open.The hours thus passed away.

zh: 对于水手和同伴来说，这个夜晚看起来是多么漫长啊！赫伯特自己睡了两个小时，在他这个年龄，睡觉是必须的。他们三个人都迫不及待地想继续前一天的探索，去寻找这个小岛上最隐蔽的幽深处。潘克洛夫的推理合情合理，几乎可以得到确认的是，既然房屋无人居住，而工具、器皿、武器仍在那里，那么主人一定已经死亡了。因此，他一致同意应该寻找他的尸体，至少给他举行一个基督葬礼。
en: How long the night appeared to the sailor and his companions!Herbert alone slept for two hours, for at his age sleep is a necessity.They were all three anxious to continue their exploration of the day before, and to search the most secret recesses of the islet!The inferences deduced by Pencroft were perfectly reasonable, and it was nearly certain that, as the hut was deserted, and the tools, utensils, and weapons were still there, the owner had succumbed.It was agreed, therefore, that they should search for his remains, and give them at least Christian burial.

zh: 天亮了，潘克洛夫和同伴马上继续考察这个住所。这个房子肯定建在了一个很优越的环境里，房子后面是一座小山，被五、六棵庞大的桉树遮盖着。房子前面穿过树林就是一大块空地，是用斧子砍出来的，这样视野就可以延伸到大海。草地是由破碎的木栅栏围起来的，草地那边就是海岸，海岸左边就是河流的出口。
en: Day dawned; Pencroft and his companions immediately proceeded to survey the dwelling.It had certainly been built in a favorable situation, at the back of a little hill, sheltered by five or six magnificent gum-trees.Before its front and through the trees the axe had prepared a wide clearing, which allowed the view to extend to the sea.Beyond a lawn, surrounded by a wooden fence falling to pieces, was the shore, on the left of which was the mouth of the stream.

zh: 这个小屋是用木板建成的，很容易看出这些木板是从船身或者甲板上取来的。很可能有一只失去航行能力的船只被丢在这个岛的海岸上，船上至少有一位船员侥幸还生，并且这个人利用手中拥有的工具，用船的残骸建了这个房子。
en: The hut had been built of planks, and it was easy to see that these planks had been obtained from the hull or deck of a ship.It was probable that a disabled vessel had been cast on the coast of the island, that one at least of the crew had been saved, and that by means of the wreck this man, having tools at his disposal, had built the dwelling.

zh: 事实变得更加明显，当吉丁·史佩莱围绕这个房子走了一圈后，他看见在一块木板上——可能是失事船只上的一块锚——写着这些字母，已经有一半被抹掉了。
en: And this became still more evident when Gideon Spilett, after having walked around the hut, saw on a plank, probably one of those which had formed the armor of the wrecked vessel, these letters already half effaced:

zh: BR—TAN—A
en: BR—TAN—A

zh: “大不列颠，”潘克洛夫喊道，记者这样称呼它，“许多船只都叫这个名字，我还说不上来这船究竟来自英国还是美国。”
en: “Britannia,” exclaimed Pencroft, whom the reporter had called; “it is a common name for ships, and I could not say if she was English or American!”

zh: “这并不重要，潘克洛夫！”
en: “It matters very little, Pencroft!”

zh: “确实是不怎么重要，”水手回答说，“如果船上有船员还活着，我们就该救这个生还者，不管他是哪个国家的人。但是，在我们再次寻找之前，我们先登上‘乘风破浪’号吧。”
en: “Very little indeed,” answered the sailor, “and we will save the survivor of her crew if he is still living, to whatever country he may belong.But before beginning our search again let us go on board the ‘Bonadventure’.”

zh: 一说到这个船，潘克洛夫就有一种不安。难道这个岛有人居住了吗，难道已经有人拥有了这个岛吗？但这个想法太不合理，他不禁耸了耸肩。无论如何，水手是不会为上船吃早餐而感到遗憾的。他们走过的路并不长，只有一英里。他们开始继续行走，眼睛盯着树木和丛林，里面有成百只山羊和猪在逃窜。
en: A sort of uneasiness had seized Pencroft upon the subject of his vessel.Should the island be inhabited after all, and should some one have taken possession of her?But he shrugged his shoulders at such an unreasonable supposition.At any rate the sailor was not sorry to go to breakfast on board.The road already trodden was not long, scarcely a mile.They set out on their walk, gazing into the wood and thickets through which goats and pigs fled in hundreds.

zh: 离开房子20分钟后，潘克洛夫和同伴就到达了小岛的西海岸，同时看见“乘风破浪”号被锚牢牢牵住，深深陷在沙中。
en: Twenty minutes after leaving the hut Pencroft and his companions reached the western coast of the island, and saw the “Bonadventure” held fast by her anchor, which was buried deep in the sand.

zh: 潘克洛夫忍不住满足地叹息。毕竟，这艘船是他的孩子，当它没发生什么事情的时候，父亲总会为孩子担心的。
en: Pencroft could not restrain a sigh of satisfaction.After all this vessel was his child, and it is the right of fathers to be often uneasy when there is no occasion for it.

zh: 他们返回到船上，吃了早饭，这样就没必要到很晚的时候吃饭了。吃完饭后，他们又继续探索，十分小心。事实上，很有可能这个岛上唯一的居民已经死去。因此，潘克洛夫和他的同伴寻找的更多的是一个死人的痕迹，而不是活人的踪迹。可是他们的搜索毫无结果，当天中午，他们在小岛上茂密的树林中毫无目的地寻找。几乎可以肯定的是，如果遇难者死去了，现在也不会留下任何身体的痕迹，可能某种野兽已经把最后一根骨头都吞下去了。
en: They returned on board, breakfasted, so that it should not be necessary to dine until very late; then the repast being ended, the exploration was continued and conducted with the most minute care.Indeed, it was very probable that the only inhabitant of the island had perished.It was therefore more for the traces of a dead than of a living man that Pencroft and his companions searched.But their searches were vain, and during the half of that day they sought to no purpose among the thickets of trees which covered the islet.There was then scarcely any doubt that, if the castaway was dead, no trace of his body now remained, but that some wild beast had probably devoured it to the last bone.

zh: “我们在明天拂晓出发。”潘克洛夫和他的两个同伴说，这时候大约两点钟，他们在一丛杉树的树阴下休息了几分钟。
en: “We will set off to-morrow at daybreak,” said Pencroft to his two companions, as about two o’clock they were resting for a few minutes under the shade of a clump of firs.

zh: “我想我们可以毫无顾虑地拿走属于遇难者的那些器皿。”赫伯特补充说。
en: “I should think that we might without scruple take the utensils which belonged to the castaway,” added Herbert.

zh: “我也是这样想的，”吉丁·史佩莱说，“这些武器和工具可以补充花岗岩宫的储备。火药和子弹的供应同样是很重要的。”
en: “I think so, too,” returned Gideon Spilett, “and these arms and tools will make up the stores of Granite House.The supply of powder and shot is also most important.”

zh: “是的，”潘克洛夫应道，“可是我们绝不能忘记要捉一两对那样的猪，林肯岛上没有这样的。”
en: “Yes,” replied Pencroft, “but we must not forget to capture a couple or two of those pigs, of which Lincoln Island is destitute.”

zh: “也不能忘记收集那些种子，”赫伯特补充说，“这样我们就可以种出新旧世界的各种蔬菜。”
en: “Nor to gather those seeds,” added Herbert, “which will give us all the vegetables of the Old and the New Worlds.”

zh: “也许最好的办法就是在达抱岛上多呆一天，这样就可以收集所有对我们有用的东西了。”记者说。
en: “Then perhaps it would be best,” said the reporter, “to remain a day longer on Tabor Island, so as to collect all that may be useful to us.”

zh: “不，史佩莱先生，”潘克洛夫回答，“我要求你明天破晓时出发。我觉得风向似乎有可能转向西方，来的时候我们是顺风，回去的时候也会是顺风。”
en: “No, Mr. Spilett,” answered Pencroft, “I will ask you to set off to-morrow at daybreak.The wind seems to me to be likely to shift to the west, and after having had a fair wind for coming we shall have a fair wind for going back.”

zh: “那我们就不要浪费时间了。”赫伯特站起来说。
en: “Then do not let us lose time,” said Herbert, rising.

zh: “我们不会浪费时间的，”潘克洛夫说，“你，赫伯特，去采集那些种子，你比我们懂得多。你采集种子的时候，史佩莱先生和我前去猎猪，虽然没有托普，我希望我们总会想办法捉到几头的！”
en: “We won’t waste time,” returned Pencroft.“You, Herbert, go and gather the seeds, which you know better than we do.While you do that, Mr. Spilett and I will go and have a pig hunt, and even without Top I hope we shall manage to catch a few!”

zh: 于是，赫伯特就走上了通向小岛上农作物生产地的小路，而水手和记者进入了树林。
en: Herbert accordingly took the path which led towards the cultivated part of the islet, while the sailor and the reporter entered the forest.

zh: 很多种类的猪在他们面前逃窜，异常活跃，似乎是不想让他们靠近自己。
en: Many specimens of the porcine race fled before them, and these animals, which were singularly active, did not appear to be in a humor to allow themselves to be approached.

zh: 可是，经过了一个小时的追捕后，猎人们仅仅捉住了躺在草丛中的一对。此时，他们听到从小岛北部传来的阵阵叫声的回响，叫声中夹杂着恐怖的喊叫声，这不可能是人类发出的叫声。
en: However, after an hour’s chase, the hunters had just managed to get hold of a couple lying in a thicket, when cries were heard resounding from the north part of the island. The cries were mingled terrible yells, in which there was nothing human.

zh: 潘克洛夫和吉丁·史佩莱马上站起来，两头猪此时也开始逃跑，可是，水手此刻已经准备好绳子绑它们了。
en: Pencroft and Gideon Spilett were at once on their feet, and the pigs by this movement began to run away, at the moment when the sailor was getting ready the rope to bind them.

zh: “那是赫伯特的声音。”记者说。
en: “That’s Herbert’s voice,” said the reporter.

zh: “快跑！”潘克洛夫大喊。
en: “Run!” exclaimed Pencroft.

zh: 水手和史佩莱立即朝着叫声传来的地方全速跑去。
en: And the sailor and Spilett immediately ran at full speed towards the spot from whence the cries proceeded.

zh: 他们理应加速，因为在空地旁边的小路拐角处，他们看到男孩被摔在了地上，一个凶猛的东西，显然是只大猩猩，就要对他造成巨大伤害了。
en: They did well to hasten, for at a turn of the path near a clearing they saw the lad thrown on the ground and in the grasp of a savage being, apparently a gigantic ape, who was about to do him some great harm.

zh: 潘克洛夫和吉丁·史佩莱在一分钟内要做的事情，就是冲向这个怪物，将他摔在地上，把赫伯特从他手中夺过来，然后把他紧紧地绑起来。水手有巨大的力气，记者也很有力，尽管怪物进行反抗，但是他们还是把他牢牢地拴住，这样他就不能动了。
en: To rush on this monster, throw him on the ground in his turn, snatch Herbert from him, then bind him securely, was the work of a minute for Pencroft and Gideon Spilett.The sailor was of Herculean strength, the reporter also very powerful, and in spite of the monster’s resistance he was firmly tied so that he could not even move.

zh: “你没有受伤吧，赫伯特？”史佩莱问。
en: “You are not hurt, Herbert?” asked Spilett.

zh: “没，没有！”
en: “No, no!”

zh: “啊，要是这大猩猩伤着他，可就糟了！”潘克洛夫喊道。
en: “Oh, if this ape had wounded him!” exclaimed Pencroft.

zh: “可他不是只大猩猩。”赫伯特回答。
en: “But he is not an ape,” answered Herbert.

zh: 听到这些话，潘克洛夫和吉丁·史配莱看着躺在地上的这个异常的东西。事实上，那不是只大猩猩，而是一个人，一个男人。可是这是怎样的一个人！他就是可以用所有恐怖词语描绘的野人，更可怕的是，他似乎还是最为野蛮的那一种。
en: At these words Pencroft and Gideon Spilett looked at the singular being who lay on the ground.Indeed it was not an ape; it was a human being, a man.But what a man!A savage in all the horrible acceptation of the word, and so much the more frightful that he seemed fallen to the lowest degree of brutishness!

zh: 他头发蓬乱，不加修整的胡须长到胸部，整个身子几乎全是裸露的，只有一块破布围在腰部。他两只眼睛带有狂怒的神情，双手很大，指甲非常长，皮肤是红褐色，双脚硬得就像是用牛角做的，这样一个可怜的生物还是能被称作人类。可是，也完全可以问他身体内是否有灵魂，或者只有残忍的本能才在他身体内存活下来！
en: Shaggy hair, untrimmed beard descending to the chest, the body almost naked except a rag round the waist, wild eyes, enormous hands with immensely long nails, skin the color of mahogany, feet as hard as if made of horn, such was the miserable creature who yet had a claim to be called a man.But it might justly be asked if there were yet a soul in this body, or if the brute instinct alone survived in it!

zh: “你很肯定这是个人，或者他曾经是个人吗？”潘克洛夫问记者。
en: “Are you quite sure that this is a man, or that he has ever been one?” said Pencroft to the reporter.

zh: “哎呀！我对此十分肯定。”史佩莱说。
en: “Alas! there is no doubt about it,” replied Spilett.

zh: “那这一定是那个落难者吗？”赫伯特问。
en: “Then this must be the castaway?” asked Herbert.

zh: “是的，”吉丁·史佩莱说，“可是这个不幸的人身上已经没有人类的东西了！”
en: “Yes,” replied Gideon Spilett, “but the unfortunate man has no longer anything human about him!”

zh: 记者说出了事实。显然，如果这个落难者曾经是一个文明人，那么是孤独将他变成野人，甚至更糟的是，也许是树林中的一个正常人。阵阵嘶哑的声音透过牙齿从他的喉咙中传出来，他的牙齿很锋利，就像野兽那用来撕裂生肉的牙齿一样。
en: The reporter spoke the truth.It was evident that if the castaway had ever been a civilized being, solitude had made him a savage, or worse, perhaps a regular man of the woods.Hoarse sounds issued from his throat between his teeth, which were sharp as the teeth of a wild beast made to tear raw flesh.

zh: 他一定是很久以前就丧失了记忆，长时间以来，他也已经忘记了怎样使用他的枪支和工具，甚至他也已不知道怎样生火了！可以看出来，他很活跃，也很有力气，他在身体素质得到发展的同时，道德品质却受到了损害。吉丁·史佩莱和他说话。他似乎听不懂，甚至是不去听。看着他的双眼，记者认为能看到他尚未完全泯灭的理性。然而，这个囚禁的人并没有挣扎，也并没有试图去挣脱捆绑。他曾经同为人类，难道现在他被人类伙伴的出现制服了？难道他在脑中的某个部分找到了短暂的回忆，让他想起自己是人类？如果把他放开，他会试着逃走还是会留下来？他们不知道，也不去尝试，在专心地注视着这个悲惨的生物后，说道：
en: Memory must have deserted him long before, and for a long time also he had forgotten how to use his gun and tools, and he no longer knew how to make a fire!It could be seen that he was active and powerful, but the physical qualities had been developed in him to the injury of the moral qualities.Gideon Spilett spoke to him.He did not appear to understand or even to hear.And yet on looking into his eyes, the reporter thought he could see that all reason was not extinguished in him.However, the prisoner did not struggle, nor even attempt to break his bonds.Was he overwhelmed by the presence of men whose fellow he had once been?Had he found in some corner of his brain a fleeting remembrance which recalled him to humanity?If free, would he attempt to fly, or would he remain?They could not tell, but they did not make the experiment; and after gazing attentively at the miserable creature,—

zh: “不管他是谁，”吉丁·史佩莱说，“不管他有可能是谁，也不管他会变成什么样，我们的任务就是将他带回林肯岛。”
en: “Whoever he may be,” remarked Gideon Spilett, “whoever he may have been, and whatever he may become, it is our duty to take him with us to Lincoln Island.”

zh: “对，对！”赫伯特回应，“也许经过细心照顾，我们会唤起他的一点智慧。”
en: “Yes, yes!” replied Herbert, “and perhaps with care we may arouse in him same gleam of intelligence.”

zh: “灵魂没有死，”记者说，“将上帝创造的生物从野蛮中拯救出来，是一件非常令人满意的事情。”
en: “The soul does not die,” said the reporter, “and it would be a great satisfaction to rescue one of God’s creatures from brutishness.”

zh: 潘克洛夫怀疑地摇着头。
en: Pencroft shook his head doubtfully.

zh: “不管怎样，我们必须尝试一下，”记者说，“人性促使我们这样做。”
en: “We must try at any rate,” returned the reporter; “humanity commands us.”

zh: 这确实是作为基督徒和文明人的责任。三人都是这样想的，因此，他们也深知赛勒斯·哈丁会同意他们这样做的。
en: It was indeed their duty as Christians and civilized beings.All three felt this, and they well knew that Cyrus Harding would approve of their acting thus.

zh: “我们要给他松绑吗？”水手问。
en: “Shall we leave him bound?” asked the sailor.

zh: “如果解开他的双脚，也许他能够走路。”赫伯特说。
en: “Perhaps he would walk if his feet were unfastened,” said Herbert.

zh: “我们试一下。”潘克洛夫回答。
en: “Let us try,” replied Pencroft.

zh: 他们将绑住囚禁者双脚的绳子切断，但是胳膊还是绑得紧紧的。他自己站了起来，也没有表现出要逃跑的意思。他用坚定的眼睛向这三个向他靠近的人投射犀利的目光，但是丝毫没有表示出，他回忆起自己和他们是同类，或者至少曾是这样。嘶嘶声还是不断地从唇间发出来，他外表狂野，可是他并没有试图反抗。
en: The cords which shackled the prisoner’s feet were cut off, but his arms remained securely fastened.He got up by himself and did not manifest any desire to run away.His hard eyes darted a piercing glance at the three men, who walked near him, but nothing denoted that he recollected being their fellow, or at least having been so.A continual hissing sound issued from his lips, his aspect was wild, but he did not attempt to resist.

zh: 他们听从了记者的建议，将这个不幸的人带到了小屋。也许看到这些属于他的东西，他就会有些印象。也许一个火花就足以恢复他模糊的心智，重新点燃他迟钝的心灵。那个房子并不远。几分钟后，他们就到了那里，可是俘虏记不起任何事情，看起来他已经丧失了所有意识。
en: By the reporter’s advice the unfortunate man was taken to the hut.Perhaps the sight of the things that belonged to him would make some impression on him!Perhaps a spark would be sufficient to revive his obscured intellect, to rekindle his dulled soul.The dwelling was not far off.In a few minutes they arrived there, but the prisoner remembered nothing, and it appeared that he had lost consciousness of everything.

zh: 对这个可怜生命的野蛮程度，他们只能作出这样的猜测：他被困在这个小岛上的时间要追溯到非常遥远的过去，到这里以后，孤独将一个理性的人变成现在的状态。
en: What could they think of the degree of brutishness into which this miserable being had fallen, unless that his imprisonment on the islet dated from a very distant period and after having arrived there a rational being solitude had reduced him to this condition.

zh: 记者认为，也许他看到火后会有些变化，于是，美丽的火焰马上在壁炉里燃烧起来，连动物也被吸引了过来。刚开始，炉火似乎引起了这个不幸的人的注意，可是转过身后，眼睛里智慧的光芒也逐渐消失了。很明显，他们没有事情可做了，至少眼下要做的就是将他带到“乘风破浪”号上去。这些完成后，由潘克洛夫负责在那里看管他。
en: The reporter then thought that perhaps the sight of fire would have some effect on him, and in a moment one of those beautiful flames, that attract even animals, blazed up on the hearth.The sight of the flame seemed at first to fix the attention of the unhappy object, but soon he turned away and the look of intelligence faded.Evidently there was nothing to be done, for the time at least, but to take him on board the “Bonadventure.”This was done, and he remained there in Pencroft’s charge.

zh: 赫伯特和史佩莱又返回去完成他们的工作，几小时后他们回到岸上，手中拿着器皿和枪支，很多蔬菜和种子，一些猎物和四头猪。
en: Herbert and Spilett returned to finish their work; and some hours after they came back to the shore, carrying the utensils and guns, a store of vegetables, of seeds, some game, and two couple of pigs.

zh: 所有人登船后，“乘风破浪”号准备好启锚，乘早潮出海。
en: All was embarked, and the “Bonadventure” was ready to weigh anchor and sail with the morning tide.

zh: 他们把囚犯放在了船首的客舱，他很安静地呆在那里，一句话也不说，很明显是又聋又哑。
en: The prisoner had been placed in the fore-cabin, where he remained quiet, silent, apparently deaf and dumb.

zh: 潘克洛夫给他东西吃，他却将送到他面前的熟肉推开了，毫无疑问，熟肉不适合他。可是，当水手把赫伯特杀死的一只鸭子递给他时，他像一个野兽似的扑上去，贪婪地吞咽着。
en: Pencroft offered him something to eat, but he pushed away the cooked meat that was presented to him and which doubtless did not suit him.But on the sailor showing him one of the ducks which Herbert had killed, he pounced on it like a wild beast, and devoured it greedily.

zh: “你认为他会恢复意识吗？”潘克洛夫问。“我们对他的照顾产生作用，这不是没有可能的，因为是孤独将他变成现在这个样子，从今以后他不会再孤独了。”
en: “You think that he will recover his senses?” asked Pencroft.“It is not impossible that our care will have an effect upon him, for it is solitude that has made him what he is, and from this time forward he will be no longer alone.”

zh: “毫无疑问，这个可怜的人处于这样的状态一定很久了。”赫伯特说。
en: “The poor man must no doubt have been in this state for a long time,” said Herbert.

zh: “可能吧。”吉丁·史佩莱回答。
en: “Perhaps,” answered Gideon Spilett.

zh: “他大约多大？”男孩问。
en: “About what age is he?” asked the lad.

zh: “很难说，”记者回答，“因为他浓密的胡须遮盖了脸部，要看到他的相貌是不可能的，不过他年纪不小了，我想他大概有50岁。”
en: “It is difficult to say,” replied the reporter, “for it is impossible to see his features under the thick beard which covers his face, but he is no longer young, and I suppose he might be about fifty.”

zh: “史佩莱先生，你有没有注意到他的眼睛陷得有多深啊？”赫伯特问。
en: “Have you noticed, Mr. Spilett, how deeply sunk his eyes are?” asked Herbert.

zh: “是的，赫伯特，不过我必须补充一点，跟他的外表相比，他的眼睛更像人类的眼睛。”
en: “Yes, Herbert, but I must add that they are more human than one could expect from his appearance.”

zh: “可是，我们会看到，”潘克洛夫回答，“我急于想知道，哈丁上尉看到我们带来的这个野人会怎么想。我们本来要寻找的是一个人，我们带回来的却是一个怪兽！不过，我们已经尽力了。”
en: “However, we shall see,” replied Pencroft, “and I am anxious to know what opinion Captain Harding will have of our savage.We went to look for a human creature, and we are bringing back a monster!After all, we did what we could.”

zh: 夜晚过去了，他们不知道囚犯有没有睡觉，但是不管怎样，虽然他没有被绑，但是他没有动。他就像是一个野蛮的动物，捉住他时，起初看起来很震惊，后来又变野蛮了。
en: The night passed, and whether the prisoner slept or not could not be known, but at any rate, although he had been unbound, he did not move.He was like a wild animal, which appears stunned at first by its capture, and becomes wild again afterwards.

zh: 第二天是10月15日，天刚亮，天气就发生了变化，这是潘克洛夫预测到的。风向已经转向西北，有利于“乘风破浪”号的返航，但同时风力加大了，这样可能会使航行变得更加困难。
en: At daybreak the next morning, the 15th of October, the change of weather predicted by Pencroft occurred.The wind having shifted to the northwest favored the return of the “Bonadventure,” but at the same time it freshened, which might render navigation more difficult.

zh: 早上五点的时候，船起锚了。潘克洛夫从主帆上取下一张帆，将船开向东北方，这样就能直航行至林肯岛。
en: At five o’clock in the morning the anchor was weighed.Pencroft took a reef in the mainsail, and steered towards the north-east, so as to sail straight for Lincoln Island.

zh: 航行的第一天没有发生任何事情。这个囚犯呆在船首的客舱里，保持沉默，因为他以前是个水手，似乎船只的运动可能会在他身上产生有益的反应。他之前的职业会使一些记忆回到他的大脑吗？尽管这有可能，但是他仍然保持安静，惊讶却不沮丧。
en: The first day of the voyage was not marked by any incident.The prisoner remained quiet in the fore-cabin, and as he had been a sailor it appeared that the motion of the vessel might produce on him a salutary reaction.Did some recollection of his former calling return to him?However that might be, he remained tranquil, astonished rather than depressed.

zh: 第二天风力加大了，大多是从北方吹来的，因此，这对“乘风破浪”号不是一个有利的方向了。很快，潘克洛夫不得不收起风帆，但是他一句话也没说，他开始担心海里的状况，经常转动着船头。可以肯定的是，如果风力不减，到达林肯岛的时间要比到达抱岛的时间要长。
en: The next day the wind increased, blowing more from the north, consequently in a less favorable direction for the “Bonadventure.”Pencroft was soon obliged to sail close-hauled, and without saying anything about it he began to be uneasy at the state of the sea, which frequently broke over the bows.Certainly, if the wind did not moderate, it would take a longer time to reach Lincoln Island than it had taken to make Tabor Island.

zh: 实际上，到17号早上，“乘风破浪”号在海上已经航行了48个小时了，可是没有迹象表明船已经靠近小岛了。而且，由于船速不稳定，不可能估算出船只穿过的距离，也不能确定估测的方向。
en: Indeed, on the morning of the 17th, the “Bonadventure” had been forty-eight hours at sea, and nothing showed that she was near the island.It was impossible, besides, to estimate the distance traversed, or to trust to the reckoning for the direction, as the speed had been very irregular.

zh: 24个小时后，他们还没有看见小岛。海风迎面吹来，掀起了巨大的海浪。所有的帆都收起来了，也时常抢风航行。在18号，一股海浪完全掠过了“乘风破浪”号，要不是船员们作好预防措施，在甲板上卧倒，他们就给海浪卷走了。
en: Twenty-four hours after there was yet no land in sight.The wind was right ahead and the sea very heavy.The sails were close-reefed, and they tacked frequently.On the 18th, a wave swept completely over the “Bonadventure”; and if the crew had not taken the precaution of lashing themselves to the deck, they would have been carried away.

zh: 这种情况下，潘克洛夫和他的同伴们都忙于放松自己，却从囚犯那里获得了意外的帮助。囚犯从船舱里出来，就好像他水手的本能突然回来了，他用一根桅杆在船侧戳了个洞，这样甲板上装满的水就流出去了。船上的水排净后，他又一言不发地回到舱里。潘克洛夫、吉丁·史佩莱和赫伯特非常吃惊，也没有管他。
en: On this occasion Pencroft and his companions, who were occupied with loosing themselves, received unexpected aid from the prisoner, who emerged from the hatchway as if his sailor’s instinct had suddenly returned, broke a piece out of the bulwarks with a spar so as to let the water which filled the deck escape.Then the vessel being clear, he descended to his cabin without having uttered a word.Pencroft, Gideon Spilett, and Herbert, greatly astonished, let him proceed.

zh: 他们的情形确实很严峻，水手有理由相信他已经迷失再一片汪洋之中了，也不可能再回到航线上了。
en: Their situation was truly serious, and the sailor had reason to fear that he was lost on the wide sea without any possibility of recovering his course.

zh: 当天的夜晚又黑又冷。不过，大约11点的时候，风力降下来了，海水也退了，船只航行起来也不那么费力了，船速急速上升。
en: The night was dark and cold.However, about eleven o’clock, the wind fell, the sea went down, and the speed of the vessel, as she labored less, greatly increased.

zh: 潘克洛夫、史佩莱和赫伯特都没有想过要睡上一个小时。他们警觉地看着外面，因为，林肯岛可能就在不远处，也许破晓时就能看到了，也许“乘风破浪”号被水流带动，漂流得太多，他们已无法调整航线了。潘克洛夫极度不安，但是他没有绝望，因为他有一颗勇敢的心。他手握船桅，焦急地希望用目光穿透四周的黑暗。
en: Neither Pencroft, Spilett, nor Herbert thought of taking an hour’s sleep.They kept a sharp look-out, for either Lincoln Island could not be far distant and would be sighted at daybreak, or the “Bonadventure,” carried away by currents, had drifted so much that it would be impossible to rectify her course.Pencroft, uneasy to the last degree, yet did not despair, for he had a gallant heart, and grasping the tiller he anxiously endeavored to pierce the darkness which surrounded them.

zh: 大约早上两点钟的时候，他大声喊道：
en: About two o’clock in the morning he started forward,—

zh: “光！光！”他大声喊。
en: “A light! a light!” he shouted.

zh: 实际上，这道明亮的光好像是在东北方20海里处。林肯岛就在那里，这堆火很显然是赛勒斯·哈丁点燃的，为他们的航行指引了方向。潘克洛夫偏向北方太多，因此他改变路线，转向有火的方向，火在海平线上熊熊燃烧，就像一颗一等星一样明亮。
en: Indeed, a bright light appeared twenty miles to the northeast.Lincoln Island was there, and this fire, evidently lighted by Cyrus Harding, showed them the course to be followed.Pencroft, who was bearing too much to the north, altered his course and steered towards the fire, which burned brightly above the horizon like a star of the first magnitude.

zh: 第十五章
en: Chapter 15

zh: 第二天，也就是10月20日早上七点，在海上航行四天后，“乘风破浪”号静静地滑向慈悲河出口处的沙滩。
en: The next day, the 20th of October, at seven o’clock in the morning, after a voyage of four days, the “Bonadventure” gently glided up to the beach at the mouth of the Mercy.

zh: 由于天气恶劣，同伴们迟迟未归，赛勒斯·哈丁和纳布变得非常不安。天刚破晓，他们就爬上眺望岗的高地，终于看见了在归航途中多时的船只。
en: Cyrus Harding and Neb, who had become very uneasy at the bad weather and the prolonged absence of their companions, had climbed at daybreak to the plateau of Prospect Heights, and they had at last caught sight of the vessel which had been so long in returning.

zh: “感谢上帝！他们在那儿！”赛勒斯·哈丁大喊。
en: “God be praised! there they are!” exclaimed Cyrus Harding.

zh: 纳布很高兴，他开始转着圈跳起舞来，边拍掌边喊：“哦！我的主人！”这场表扬比最精彩的演讲还要动人。
en: As to Neb in his joy, he began to dance, to twirl round, clapping his hands and shouting, “Oh! my master!”A more touching pantomime than the finest discourse.

zh: 清点了“乘风破浪”号甲板上的人后，工程师首先想到的是，潘克洛夫没有找到达抱岛上的那个落难者，要不就是这个不幸的人无论如何也不愿离开那个岛，再换一个监狱。
en: The engineer’s first idea, on counting the people on the deck of the “Bonadventure,” was that Pencroft had not found the castaway of Tabor Island, or at any rate that the unfortunate man had refused to leave his island and change one prison for another.

zh: 事实上，只有潘克洛夫、吉丁·史佩莱和赫伯特三人在“乘风破浪”号的甲板上。
en: Indeed Pencroft, Gideon Spilett, and Herbert were alone on the deck of the “Bonadventure.”

zh: 船触地的时候，工程师和纳布正在沙滩上等待，在乘客跳上沙滩之前，哈丁说：“我们因你们的迟归感到非常不安，朋友们！你们有没有遇到什么麻烦啊？”
en: The moment the vessel touched, the engineer and Neb were waiting on the beach, and before the passengers had time to leap on to the sand, Harding said: “We have been very uneasy at your delay, my friends!Did you meet with any accident?”

zh: “没有，”吉丁·史佩莱回答说，“相反，一切进行得非常顺利。我们会把所有的经过讲给你听。”
en: “No,” replied Gideon Spilett; “on the contrary, everything went wonderfully well.We will tell you all about it.”

zh: “不过，”工程师说，“你们的搜索没有成功，因为只有你们三个人，和你们走的时候数目一样！”
en: “However,” returned the engineer, “your search has been unsuccessful, since you are only three, just as you went!”

zh: “不对，上尉，”水手回答，“我们是四个人。”
en: “Excuse me, captain,” replied the sailor, “we are four.”

zh: “你们找到那个落难者了？”
en: “You have found the castaway?”

zh: “是的。”
en: “Yes.”

zh: “你们把他带回来了？”
en: “And you have brought him?”

zh: “是的。”
en: “Yes.”

zh: “活着？”
en: “Living?”

zh: “是的。”
en: “Yes.”

zh: “那他在哪里？他是谁？”
en: “Where is he?Who is he?”

zh: “他是，”记者回答，“或者说他曾经是人！赛勒斯，这就是我们能告诉你的全部。”
en: “He is,” replied the reporter, “or rather he was a man!There, Cyrus, that is all we can tell you!”

zh: 他们向工程师讲述了在航海行程中发生的事情，他们是在什么样的环境下进行搜索的，岛上唯一的住所是怎样被长时间地抛弃的，这个看似不再属于人类的落难者最后是怎么捉住的。
en: The engineer was then informed of all that had passed during the voyage, and under what conditions the search had been conducted; how the only dwelling in the island had long been abandoned; how at last a castaway had been captured, who appeared no longer to belong to the human species.

zh: “这才是重点，”潘克洛夫补充说，“我不知道将他带到这个地方来是不是妥当。”
en: “And that’s just the point,” added Pencroft, “I don’t know if we have done right to bring him here.”

zh: “你做的当然对，潘克洛夫。”工程师立即回答。
en: “Certainly you have, Pencroft,” replied the engineer quickly.

zh: “不过这个不幸的生物已经没有意识了！”
en: “But the wretched creature has no sense!”

zh: “目前可能是这样，”赛勒斯·哈丁回答，“可是就在几个月前，这个不幸的生物就是一个人，就像你和我。谁又会知道我们这些幸存者在这个岛上经历长期孤独后，会变成什么样子？孤单是极其不幸的事情，我们必须相信，孤独可以迅速摧毁理性，因为你们找到的这个可怜的生物就处于这样的状态。”
en: “That is possible at present,” replied Cyrus Harding, “but only a few months ago the wretched creature was a man like you and me.And who knows what will become of the survivor of us after a long solitude on this island?It is a great misfortune to be alone, my friends; and it must be believed that solitude can quickly destroy reason, since you have found this poor creature in such a state!”

zh: “可是，上尉，”赫伯特问，“是什么让你认为这个不幸的人仅是在几个月前开始变野蛮的呢？”
en: “But, captain,” asked Herbert, “what leads you to think that the brutishness of the unfortunate man began only a few months back?”

zh: “因为我们找到的那张纸条是最近才写的，”工程师回答，“并且只有落难者才能写。”
en: “Because the document we found had been recently written,” answered the engineer, “and the castaway alone can have written it.”

zh: “我总觉得，”吉丁·史佩莱说，“这张纸条不会是这个人死去的同伴写的吧。”
en: “Always supposing,” observed Gideon Spilett, “that it had not been written by a companion of this man, since dead.”

zh: “那是不可能的事情，我亲爱的史佩莱。”
en: “That is impossible, my dear Spilett.”

zh: “为什么？”记者问。
en: “Why so?” asked the reporter.

zh: “因为若是那样，纸条上当时写的应该是两个落难者，”哈丁回答，“而上面只提到一个。”
en: “Because the document would then have spoken of two castaways,” replied Harding, “and it mentioned only one.”

zh: 赫伯特简单叙述了航行的经过，重点讲述了这个奇怪的事实，风暴大作的时候，囚徒的脑子突然灵光一现，成为一名水手。
en: Herbert then in a few words related the incidents of the voyage, and dwelt on the curious fact of the sort of passing gleam in the prisoner’s mind, when for an instant in the height of the storm he had become a sailor.

zh: “嗯，赫伯特，”工程师回答，“你很重视这个事实是正确的。这个不幸的人不是不可救药的，是绝望把他变成现在的这个样子。不过，在这里他找到了他的同伴，既然他还有灵魂，我们就要拯救这个灵魂！”
en: “Well, Herbert,” replied the engineer, “you are right to attach great importance to this fact.The unfortunate man cannot be incurable, and despair has made him what he is; but here he will find his fellow-men, and since there is still a soul in him, this soul we shall save!”

zh: 令工程师感到很遗憾、令纳布感到很吃惊的是，把达抱岛上的这个落难者从“乘风破浪”号船头的舱中带出来之后，一踏上陆地，他就想要逃跑。
en: The castaway of Tabor Island, to the great pity of the engineer and the great astonishment of Neb, was then brought from the cabin which he occupied in the fore part of the “Bonadventure”; when once on land he manifested a wish to run away.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁走上前去，以充满权威的姿态，将手放在他的肩膀上，无限温柔地看着他。这个不幸的人马上服从了上级的意愿，渐渐地冷静下来，眼睛也垂了下来，同时也低下了头，不再反抗。
en: But Cyrus Harding approaching, placed his hand on his shoulder with a gesture full of authority, and looked at him with infinite tenderness.Immediately the unhappy man, submitting to a superior will, gradually became calm, his eyes fell, his head bent, and he made no more resistance.

zh: “可怜的家伙！”工程师低声说。
en: “Poor fellow!” murmured the engineer.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁用心地观察他。从他的外表看，这个可怜的人身上已经没有人的特征了，和记者一样，哈丁注意到他的表情中有一种难以说明的智慧。
en: Cyrus Harding had attentively observed him.To judge by his appearance this miserable being had no longer anything human about him, and yet Harding, as had the reporter already, observed in his look an indefinable trace of intelligence.

zh: 他认为这个落难者，确切地说，正如他的同伴们所说，这个陌生人应该住在花岗石宫的一个房间里，在那里他逃不出去。他们毫不费力地将他带到那里，他们希望经过细心的照顾，某天他有可能成为林肯岛居民的同伴。
en: It was decided that the castaway, or rather the stranger as he was thenceforth termed by his companions, should live in one of the rooms of Granite House, from which, however, he could not escape.He was led there without difficulty, and with careful attention, it might, perhaps, be hoped that some day he would be a companion to the settlers in Lincoln Island.

zh: 纳布匆匆准备了早饭，因为记者、赫伯特和潘克洛夫饿得要命。吃早饭的时候，赛勒斯·哈丁详细听了一下他们去小岛探索的航程中发生的所有事情的细节。在有一点上，他与朋友意见一致，那就是，通过大不列颠这个名称，他们猜想这个陌生人不是英国人就是美国人；另外，从那浓密的胡子、又长又乱的头发来看，工程师可以看出盎格鲁—撒克逊人的典型特征。
en: Cyrus Harding, during breakfast, which Neb had hastened to prepare, as the reporter, Herbert, and Pencroft were dying of hunger, heard in detail all the incidents which had marked the voyage of exploration to the islet.He agreed with his friends on this point, that the stranger must be either English or American, the name Britannia leading them to suppose this, and, besides, through the bushy beard, and under the shaggy, matted hair, the engineer thought he could recognize the characteristic features of the Anglo-Saxon.

zh: “不过，顺便提一下，”吉丁·史佩莱对赫伯特说，“你从未告诉我们你是怎么遇到这个野人的，要不是我们及时赶到救你，你会被他勒死，除此之外我们一无所知！”
en: “But, by the bye,” said Gideon Spilett, addressing Herbert, “you never told us how you met this savage, and we know nothing, except that you would have been strangled, if we had not happened to come up in time to help you!”

zh: “说实话，”赫伯特说，“很难说清楚那是怎么发生的。我想，当时我正忙着收集植物，就听到一个声音，就像从一棵很高的树上掉下来的雪崩一样。我几乎来不及查看四周。这个不幸的人，毫无疑问就藏在树上，说时迟，那时快，他一下子向我扑来，要不是史佩莱先生和潘克洛夫——”
en: “Upon my word,” answered Herbert, “it is rather difficult to say how it happened.I was, I think, occupied in collecting my plants, when I heard a noise like an avalanche falling from a very tall tree.I scarcely had time to look round.This unfortunate man, who was without doubt concealed in a tree, rushed upon me in less time than I take to tell you about it, and unless Mr. Spilett and Pencroft—”

zh: “我的孩子！”赛勒斯·哈丁说，“你冒了一个巨大的危险，但是，也许不这样，这个可怜的生物仍藏在你们的搜查范围之外，我们也不会有一个新的伙伴。”
en: “My boy!” said Cyrus Harding, “you ran a great danger, but, perhaps, without that, the poor creature would have still hidden himself from your search, and we should not have had a new companion.”

zh: “那么，赛勒斯，你想成功地改造这个人吗？”记者问。
en: “You hope, then, Cyrus, to succeed in reforming the man?” asked the reporter.

zh: “不错。”工程师回答。
en: “Yes,” replied the engineer.

zh: 吃过早饭，哈丁和同伴就离开了花岗岩宫，回到了海滩上。他们各自忙着卸载“乘风破浪”号上面的货物，工程师检查了武器和工具，并没有看到能够帮助他们确定这个陌生人身份的东西。
en: Breakfast over, Harding and his companions left Granite House and returned to the beach.They there occupied themselves in unloading the “Bonadventure,” and the engineer, having examined the arms and tools, saw nothing which could help them to establish the identity of the stranger.

zh: 他们认为，在岛上捉住的猪对林肯岛来说非常有益，他们将这些动物带到猪圈，很快它们就变得自在起来。
en: The capture of pigs, made on the islet, was looked upon as being very profitable to Lincoln Island, and the animals were led to the sty, where they soon became at home.

zh: 有两个桶，里面分别装着火药和弹药，还有一盒雷管，这些都很受欢迎。他们一致同意在花岗石宫或上岩洞里建一个火药库，在那里不用担心爆炸。可是，还要继续使用棉花火药，因为这种物质产生非常好的效果，没有理由替换成普通的药粉。
en: The two barrels, containing the powder and shot, as well as the box of caps, were very welcome.It was agreed to establish a small powder-magazine, either outside Granite House or in the Upper Cavern, where there would be no fear of explosion.However, the use of pyroxyle was to be continued, for this substance giving excellent results, there was no reason for substituting ordinary powder.

zh: 当船上的卸载工作完成的时候，潘克洛夫说：
en: When the unloading of the vessel was finished,—

zh: “上尉，我认为将我们的‘乘风破浪’号放在一个安全的地方比较妥当。”
en: “Captain,” said Pencroft, “I think it would be prudent to put our ‘Bonadventure’ in a safe place.”

zh: “难道停在慈悲河口不安全吗？”赛勒斯·哈丁问。
en: “Is she not safe at the mouth of the Mercy?” asked Cyrus Harding.

zh: “是的，上尉。”水手回答，“有一半时间它是搁浅在沙上的，这样会磨损的。你也知道，这艘船很有名，在我们返程时遇到了暴风雨，影响了航行，可是它表现极好。”
en: “No, captain,” replied the sailor.“Half of the time she is stranded on the sand, and that works her.She is a famous craft, you see, and she behaved admirably during the squall which struck us on our return.”

zh: “不能让它浮在河上吗？”
en: “Could she not float in the river?”

zh: “毫无疑问，上尉，可以。不过，那里没有可以遮蔽的地方，一旦刮起东风，我担心‘乘风破浪’号就会受到海浪的冲击。”
en: “No doubt, captain, she could; but there is no shelter there, and in the east winds, I think that the ‘Bonadventure’ would suffer much from the surf.”

zh: “那么，你会把它停在哪里呢，潘克洛夫？”
en: “Well, where would you put her, Pencroft?”

zh: “停在气球港。”水手说，“那个小港周围是岩石，我觉得这似乎就是我们要找的海港。”
en: “In Port Balloon,” replied the sailor.“That little creek, shut in by rocks, seems to me to be just the harbor we want.”

zh: “不会太远吧？”
en: “Is it not rather far?”

zh: “不！离花岗岩宫不过三英里，有一条很好的直道可以把我们带到那里！”
en: “Pooh! it is not more than three miles from Granite House, and we have a fine straight road to take us there!”

zh: “那就这样做吧，潘克洛夫，并将你的‘乘风破浪’号带过去，”工程师回答，“我宁愿它得到我们更多及时的保护。如果我们还有时间，就必须为它建一个小港。”
en: “Do it then, Pencroft, and take your ‘Bonadventure’ there,” replied the engineer, “and yet I would rather have her under our more immediate protection.When we have time, we must make a little harbor for her.”

zh: “太好了！”潘克洛夫喊道，“港上还有灯塔、码头和船坞！啊！真的，上尉，和你在一起，一切都变得很容易了。”
en: “Famous!” exclaimed Pencroft.“A harbor with a lighthouse, a pier, and dock!Ah! really with you, captain, everything becomes easy.”

zh: “是的，我勇敢的潘克洛夫，”工程师回答，“但是依情况而定。但是，你帮助了我，在我们所有的工作中，你做的抵得上三个人做的。”
en: “Yes, my brave Pencroft,” answered the engineer, “but on condition, however, that you help me, for you do as much as three men in all our work.”

zh: 赫伯特和水手再次登上“乘风破浪”号，然后拔起锚，升起帆，海风吹着它迅速驶向爪角。两小时后，船就停靠在了气球港宁静的水面上。
en: Herbert and the sailor then re-embarked on board the “Bonadventure,” the anchor was weighed, the sail hoisted, and the wind drove her rapidly towards Claw Cape.Two hours after, she was reposing on the tranquil waters of Port Balloon.

zh: 陌生人在花岗岩宫度过的最初的日子里，是否使他们有理由相信他野蛮的性格变得温顺了？他那昏暗的心灵深处是否燃烧着明亮的火光？简而言之，他的灵魂是否回到躯体了呢？
en: During the first days passed by the stranger in Granite House, had he already given them reason to think that his savage nature was becoming tamed?Did a brighter light burn in the depths of that obscured mind?In short, was the soul returning to the body?

zh: 是的，可以肯定的是，在这种程度上，赛勒斯·哈丁和记者想知道这个不幸的人的理性是否已经完全消失。首先，由于他过惯了在达抱岛上享受的户外生活，习惯了无拘无束的自由，这个陌生人显得闷闷不乐、愤怒，他们担心他有可能从花岗岩宫的某个窗户跳到沙滩上。不过，慢慢地，他变得冷静了一些，他也因此得到了更多的活动自由。
en: Yes, to a certainty, and to such a degree, that Cyrus Harding and the reporter wondered if the reason of the unfortunate man had ever been totally extinguished.At first, accustomed to the open air, to the unrestrained liberty which he had enjoyed on Tabor Island, the stranger manifested a sullen fury, and it was feared that he might throw himself onto the beach, out of one of the windows of Granite House.But gradually he became calmer, and more freedom was allowed to his movements.

zh: 他们有理由去期待，期待很多。陌生人已经忘记了他食肉的本能，与在岛上他吃的食物相比，他接受的野性食物要少一些，而且给他熟肉，他也没有产生在“乘风破浪”号上表现的排斥情绪。赛勒斯·哈丁趁他睡觉的时候，剪掉了他的头发和乱糟糟的胡子。他的头发和胡子有点像鬃毛，这使他看起来就像个野人。他们把盖在他身上的破布拿走后，穿的也较得体了。由于大家的照顾，陌生人恢复了更为像人的面貌，他的双眼似乎变得更加温和了。肯定地说，过去这个人脸上罩着智慧的光芒时，他一定是很俊俏的。
en: They had reason to hope, and to hope much.Already, forgetting his carnivorous instincts, the stranger accepted a less bestial nourishment than that on which he fed on the islet, and cooked meat did not produce in him the same sentiment of repulsion which he had showed on board the “Bonadventure.”Cyrus Harding had profited by a moment when he was sleeping, to cut his hair and matted beard, which formed a sort of mane and gave him such a savage aspect.He had also been clothed more suitably, after having got rid of the rag which covered him.The result was that, thanks to these attentions, the stranger resumed a more human appearance, and it even seemed as if his eyes had become milder.Certainly, when formerly lighted up by intelligence, this man’s face must have had a sort of beauty.

zh: 哈丁每天总要亲自陪他度过几个小时。他靠近陌生人，做着各种各样的工作，为的是吸引他的注意力。实际上，火花就足以照亮那颗心灵，大脑中闪过的一点回忆就可以唤回他的理智。遇到暴风雨的时候，“乘风破浪”号上发生的事情就证明了这点！工程师还特意大声说话，从听觉和视觉两个器官来同时穿透他那麻痹心智的深处。有时候是这个伙伴，有时候是另一个，有时候是所有的人和他一起做这种工作。他们的谈话内容大多与航海有关，任何水手听到后都会感兴趣的。
en: Every day, Harding imposed on himself the task of passing some hours in his company.He came and worked near him, and occupied himself in different things, so as to fix his attention.A spark, indeed, would be sufficient to reillumine that soul, a recollection crossing that brain to recall reason.That had been seen, during the storm, on board the “Bonadventure!The engineer did not neglect either to speak aloud, so as to penetrate at the same time by the organs of hearing and sight the depths of that torpid intelligence.Sometimes one of his companions, sometimes another, sometimes all joined him.They spoke most often of things belonging to the navy, which must interest a sailor.

zh: 有时候，这个陌生人会对他们所说的话表示一点关注，于是，居民们很快就相信他能听懂一部分。有时他的脸色显得极度悲伤，这说明他精神上遭受了打击，这不会弄错，因为从他的表情上可以看得出来。可是，有时候，即使他们几乎认为他就要开口说话了，但是他还是没有说。不管怎样，这个可怜的动物非常安静，也非常悲伤！
en: At times, the stranger gave some slight attention to what was said, and the settlers were soon convinced that he partly understood them.Sometimes the expression of his countenance was deeply sorrowful, a proof that he suffered mentally, for his face could not be mistaken; but he did not speak, although at different times, however, they almost thought that words were about to issue from his lips.At all events, the poor creature was quite quiet and sad!

zh: 可是，他的冷静会不会仅仅是表面上的呢？他的悲伤会不会是因为孤独造成的呢？现在什么都不确定。呆在一定的环境中，他只能看到一定的物体，接触的总是开拓者，这些他很快就习惯了。他什么都不缺，对好的食物、好的衣服没有欲望，自然地，他的自然本性也就慢慢地改变了。可是，他心中已经有了这种新生活的意识吗？或者用一个极为适合他的词来说，他是不是会像畜生对他的主人那样变得“驯服”了？这个问题很重要，赛勒斯·哈丁急于得到答案，他又不想粗鲁地对待这个弱者。他能慢慢地恢复吗？
en: But was not his calm only apparent?Was not his sadness only the result of his seclusion?Nothing could yet be ascertained.Seeing only certain objects and in a limited space, always in contact with the colonists, to whom he would soon become accustomed, having no desires to satisfy, better fed, better clothed, it was natural that his physical nature should gradually improve; but was he penetrated with the sense of a new life? or rather, to employ a word which would be exactly applicable to him, was he not becoming tamed, like an animal in company with his master?This was an important question, which Cyrus Harding was anxious to answer, and yet he did not wish to treat his invalid roughly!Would he ever be a convalescent?

zh: 工程师每时每刻都在注意着他！如果可以这样形容，他是如此注意他的灵魂！他多想去抓住它！居民们都带着真实的同情注意着哈丁对其进行治疗的每一个阶段。他们也在人性方面帮助他，并且所有人都和哈丁一样，很快就满怀希望和信心，可能只有潘克洛夫有些怀疑。
en: How the engineer observed him every moment!How he was on the watch for his soul, if one may use the expression!How he was ready to grasp it!The settlers followed with real sympathy all the phases of the cure undertaken by Harding.They aided him also in this work of humanity, and all, except perhaps the incredulous Pencroft, soon shared both his hope and his faith.

zh: 如上所说，陌生人很平静，他甚至会表示出对工程师的依赖，很明显，他已经感受到了哈丁对他的影响。赛勒斯·哈丁决定在他身上下工夫，将他带到另一个地点，从他以前眼睛习惯注视的大海，转移到树林的边缘，也许森林会让他想起生活多年的地方的事情。
en: The calm of the stranger was deep, as has been said, and he even showed a sort of attachment for the engineer, whose influence he evidently felt.Cyrus Harding resolved then to try him, by transporting him to another scene, from that ocean which formerly his eyes had been accustomed to contemplate, to the border of the forest, which might perhaps recall those where so many years of his life had been passed!

zh: “可是，”吉丁·史佩莱说，“一旦他获得自由，我们能期待他不会逃走吗？”
en: “But,” said Gideon Spilett, “can we hope that he will not escape, if once set at liberty?”

zh: “我们必须试一下。”工程师说。
en: “The experiment must be tried,” replied the engineer.

zh: “好！”潘克洛夫说，“那个家伙出去后，呼吸到新鲜空气，他就会撒开两腿尽快地跑掉！”
en: “Well!” said Pencroft.“When that fellow is outside, and feels the fresh air, he will be off as fast as his legs can carry him!”

zh: “我不这样认为。”哈丁回答。
en: “I do not think so,” returned Harding.

zh: “我们就尝试一下吧。”史佩莱说。
en: “Let us try,” said Spilett.

zh: “那就试一下吧。”工程师回答。
en: “We will try,” replied the engineer.

zh: 那天是10月30日，至此，达抱岛上的遇难者作为囚徒在花岗岩宫里呆了九天了。这一天很暖和，明媚的阳光发出光芒，照耀着这个小岛。赛勒斯·哈丁和潘克洛夫进入了陌生人的房间，只看见他躺在窗边，注视着天空。
en: This was on the 30th of October, and consequently the castaway of Tabor Island had been a prisoner in Granite House for nine days.It was warm, and a bright sun darted its rays on the island.Cyrus Harding and Pencroft went to the room occupied by the stranger, who was found lying near the window and gazing at the sky.

zh: “过来，我的朋友。”工程师对他说。
en: “Come, my friend,” said the engineer to him.

zh: 陌生人马上站了起来。他的眼睛注视着赛勒斯·哈丁，并跟在他的后面，而水手跟在他俩的后面，对试验的结果不抱什么希望。
en: The stranger rose immediately.His eyes were fixed on Cyrus Harding, and he followed him, while the sailor marched behind them, little confident as to the result of the experiment.

zh: 到了门口，哈丁和潘克洛夫让他在升降梯就座，纳布、赫伯特和吉丁·史佩莱已在花岗石宫前等着他们。升降梯下滑了，一会儿，所有人都聚集在了沙滩上。
en: Arrived at the door, Harding and Pencroft made him take his place in the lift, while Neb, Herbert, and Gideon Spilett waited for them before Granite House.The lift descended, and in a few moments all were united on the beach.

zh: 居民们离开了陌生人一段距离，为了让他自由行动。
en: The settlers went a short distance from the stranger, so as to leave him at liberty.

zh: 接着，他朝向海边走了几步，面部充满生气，容光焕发，可是，他丝毫没有想要逃跑。他注视着被小岛阻断的、细小的海浪，在沙滩上留下道道涟漪。
en: He then made a few steps toward the sea, and his look brightened with extreme animation, but he did not make the slightest attempt to escape.He was gazing at the little waves which, broken by the islet, rippled on the sand.

zh: “这只是大海，”吉丁·史佩莱说，“可能不会引起他想要逃跑的念头！”
en: “This is only the sea,” observed Gideon Spilett, “and possibly it does not inspire him with any wish to escape!”

zh: “是的，”哈丁回答，“我们必须把他带到树林旁边的高地上。在那儿试验会更有决定性。”
en: “Yes,” replied Harding, “we must take him to the plateau, on the border of the forest.There the experiment will be more conclusive.”

zh: “而且，他也逃不走，”纳布说，“因为桥已经拉起来了。”
en: “Besides, he could not run away,” said Neb, “since the bridge is raised.”

zh: “啊！”潘克洛夫说，“这不是一个会受像甘油河阻挡的人！他只要一跳，就能立即过去！”
en: “Oh!” said Pencroft, “that isn’t a man to be troubled by a stream like Creek Glycerine!He could cross it directly, at a single bound!”

zh: “我们很快就知道了。”哈丁满意地回答，眼睛始终没有从患者身上离开。
en: “We shall soon see,” Harding contented himself with replying, his eyes not quitting those of his patient.

zh: 于是，他们就把他带到慈悲河口，所有人都爬上了河流的左岸，来到了眺望岗。
en: The latter was then led towards the mouth of the Mercy, and all climbing the left bank of the river, reached Prospect Heights.

zh: 这里生长着林中最美丽的树木，树叶让微风吹得微微晃动。到达现场后，陌生人好像在贪婪地呼吸着大气里沁人心脾的芬芳，从胸中呼出了长长的一口气。
en: Arrived at the spot on which grew the first beautiful trees of the forest, their foliage slightly agitated by the breeze, the stranger appeared greedily to drink in the penetrating odor which filled the atmosphere, and a long sigh escaped from his chest.

zh: 居民们一直跟在他后面，如果他有任何逃走的动作，就准备把他抓住！
en: The settlers kept behind him, ready to seize him if he made any movement to escape!

zh: 事实上，这个可怜的人正要跳进横在他和森林之间的小河里，他一瞬间把腿弯下来，像是要跳，但是，几乎马上又退了回来，半蹲着，一大颗泪珠从他眼里掉了下来。
en: And, indeed, the poor creature was on the point of springing into the creek which separated him from the forest, and his legs were bent for an instant as if for a spring, but almost immediately he stepped back, half sank down, and a large tear fell from his eyes.

zh: “啊！”赛勒斯·哈丁大喊，“你又变成人了，因为你会流泪了！”
en: “Ah!” exclaimed Cyrus Harding, “you have become a man again, for you can weep!”

zh: 第十六章
en: Chapter 16

zh: 是的！这个不幸的人流泪了！一些回忆肯定闪过他的大脑，用赛勒斯·哈丁的话说，从那些眼泪可以看出，他再次变成一个人了。
en: Yes! the unfortunate man had wept!Some recollection doubtless had flashed across his brain, and to use Cyrus Harding’s expression, by those tears he was once more a man.

zh: 开拓者们让他在高地上独自呆了一会儿，他们退到不远处，这样他可能就感觉自己是自由的了，但是他不认为自己利用了这次自由，哈丁很快就把他带回花岗石宫了。在这件事发生两天后，陌生人似乎渐渐地想要融入他们的共同生活了。明显地，他在听别人说话，也听得懂，但也很明显的是，他很奇怪地坚决不和开拓者们说话。因为有天晚上，潘克洛夫站在他的房间门口听，只听到他说出了这样的话：
en: The colonists left him for some time on the plateau, and withdrew themselves to a short distance, so that he might feel himself free; but he did not think of profiting by this liberty, and Harding soon brought him back to Granite House.Two days after this occurrence, the stranger appeared to wish gradually to mingle with their common life.He evidently heard and understood, but no less evidently was he strangely determined not to speak to the colonists; for one evening, Pencroft, listening at the door of his room, heard these words escape from his lips:—

zh: “不！这里！我！决不！”
en: “No! here!I! never!”

zh: 水手将这些话传达给了同伴。
en: The sailor reported these words to his companions.

zh: “他一定在那里经历了痛苦而神秘的往事！”哈丁说。
en: “There is some painful mystery there!” said Harding.

zh: 陌生人开始使用劳动工具在菜园里工作了。当他停下手中的活时，他就会独处沉思，这在他是常有的事。可是，遵从工程师的建议，大家没有打扰他，显然他是愿意保持孤独的。如果居民中有人要靠近他，他就会后退，喘起气来胸脯一耸一耸的，好像负担很重似的。
en: The stranger had begun to use the laboring tools, and he worked in the garden.When he stopped in his work, as was often the case, he remained retired within himself, but on the engineer’s recommendation, they respected the reserve which he apparently wished to keep.If one of the settlers approached him, he drew back, and his chest heaved with sobs, as if overburdened!

zh: 是悔恨把他打击成这样的吗？他们不得不这样想，有一天，吉丁·史佩莱禁不住说：
en: Was it remorse that overwhelmed him thus?They were compelled to believe so, and Gideon Spilett could not help one day making this observation,—

zh: “他之所以不说，恐怕是因为事情过于严重而说不出口！”
en: “If he does not speak it is because he has, I fear, things too serious to be told!”

zh: 他们必须耐心地等待。
en: They must be patient and wait.

zh: 几天后，也就是11月3日，在高原上工作的陌生人停了下来，手中的铁锹也掉落到地上。在不远处一直观察他的哈丁看见，泪水再次从他眼中淌了出来。一种无法抗拒的同情之心让他走向这个不幸的人，并轻轻地触摸他的手臂。
en: A few days later, on the 3rd of November, the stranger, working on the plateau, had stopped, letting his spade drop to the ground, and Harding, who was observing him from a little distance, saw that tears were again flowing from his eyes.A sort of irresistible pity led him towards the unfortunate man, and he touched his arm lightly.

zh: “我的朋友！”他说。
en: “My friend!” said he.

zh: 陌生人试图避开他的目光，当赛勒斯·哈丁试图去抓他的手时，他却快速缩回去了。
en: The stranger tried to avoid his look, and Cyrus Harding having endeavored to take his hand, he drew back quickly.

zh: “我的朋友，”哈丁用更坚定的口吻说，“我希望你看着我！”
en: “My friend,” said Harding in a firmer voice, “look at me, I wish it!”

zh: 陌生人看着工程师，似乎在哈丁的力量下屈服了，就好像物体在磁石的影响之下。他想要逃跑。不过，他的表情突然一变。他的眼睛闪着亮光。许多话争着从他的嘴里迸出来。他再也抑制不住自己了！最后，他把手臂折在一起，用低沉的嗓音问赛勒斯·哈丁：“你们是谁？”
en: The stranger looked at the engineer, and seemed to be under his power, as a subject under the influence of a mesmerist.He wished to run away.But then his countenance suddenly underwent a transformation.His eyes flashed.Words struggled to escape from his lips.He could no longer contain himself!At last he folded his arms; then, in a hollow voice,—“Who are you?” he asked Cyrus Harding.

zh: “落难者，和你一样，”工程师感慨万分地回答，“我们将你带到这里来，带到你的同胞中来了。”
en: “Castaways, like you,” replied the engineer, whose emotion was deep.“We have brought you here, among your fellow-men.”

zh: “我的同胞……我没有！”
en: “My fellow-men!....I have none!”

zh: “你就在朋友们中间。”
en: “You are in the midst of friends.”

zh: “朋友！对我！我的朋友！”陌生人双手捂着脸大喊，“不——绝不——走开！走开！”
en: “Friends!—for me! friends!” exclaimed the stranger, hiding his face in his hands.“No—never—leave me! leave me!”

zh: 他接着冲向面向大海的高地边缘，一动不动地在那里呆了很久。
en: Then he rushed to the side of the plateau which overlooked the sea, and remained there a long time motionless.

zh: 哈丁重新回到他的同伴中间，并向他们讲述了刚才发生的事情。
en: Harding rejoined his companions and related to them what had just happened.

zh: “是的！这个人一生准有一个谜，”吉丁·史佩莱说，“他好像是个经过忏悔重新进入社会的人。”
en: “Yes! there is some mystery in that man’s life,” said Gideon Spilett, “and it appears as if he had only re-entered society by the path of remorse.”

zh: “我不知道我们带过来的是个什么样的人，”水手说，“他有秘密——”
en: “I don’t know what sort of a man we have brought here,” said the sailor.“He has secrets—”

zh: “我们要尊重他的秘密，”赛勒斯·哈丁很快打断他们说，“如果他犯了什么罪，他也已经用非常痛苦的方式弥补了，在我们眼中，他是无罪的。”
en: “Which we will respect,” interrupted Cyrus Harding quickly.“If he has committed any crime, he has most fearfully expiated it, and in our eyes he is absolved.”

zh: 陌生人独自在海岸上逗留了两个小时，显然，在回忆的影响下，他回想起了自己过去的所有生活——无疑是忧郁的过去。开拓者们寸步不离地跟着他，但是并不想打扰他独处。然而，两个小时后，他似乎是下定决心，过来找赛勒斯·哈丁。他的眼睛因为刚才流泪而变红了，不过他不再哭泣了。他的面部表情极度谦卑。他好像很焦虑、胆怯、惭愧，眼睛一直盯着地面。
en: For two hours the stranger remained alone on the shore, evidently under the influence of recollections which recalled all his past life—a melancholy life doubtless—and the colonists, without losing sight of him, did not attempt to disturb his solitude.However, after two hours, appearing to have formed a resolution, he came to find Cyrus Harding.His eyes were red with the tears he had shed, but he wept no longer.His countenance expressed deep humility.He appeared anxious, timorous, ashamed, and his eyes were constantly fixed on the ground.

zh: “先生，”他对哈丁说，“你和你的同伴，是英国人吗？”
en: “Sir,” said he to Harding, “your companions and you, are you English?”

zh: “不是，”工程师回答说，“我们是美国人。”
en: “No,” answered the engineer, “we are Americans.”

zh: “啊！”陌生人说，然后又低声咕哝说，“我更喜欢听到这一点！”
en: “Ah!” said the stranger, and he murmured, “I prefer that!”

zh: “那你呢，我的朋友？”工程师说。
en: “And you, my friend?” asked the engineer.

zh: “英国人。”他急切地回答。
en: “English,” replied he hastily.

zh: 好像这几个词语很难说出口，他退回到海滩上，在瀑布和慈悲河口之间极其不安地走来走去。
en: And as if these few words had been difficult to say, he retreated to the beach, where he walked up and down between the cascade and the mouth of the Mercy, in a state of extreme agitation.

zh: 后来，过了一会儿，他走近赫伯特，停了下来，压低了嗓子，问道：
en: Then, passing one moment close to Herbert, he stopped and in a stifled voice,—

zh: “是哪个月了？”
en: “What month?” he asked.

zh: “12月。”赫伯特回答。
en: “December,” replied Herbert.

zh: “哪一年？”
en: “What year?”

zh: “12年了！12年了！”他大喊。
en: “Twelve years! twelve years!” he exclaimed.

zh: 接着他突然离开了赫伯特。
en: Then he left him abruptly.

zh: 赫伯特将他们之间的对话告诉了其他开拓者。
en: Herbert reported to the colonists the questions and answers which had been made.

zh: “这个不幸的人，”吉丁·史佩莱说，“早就忘了年月！”
en: “This unfortunate man,” observed Gideon Spilett, “was no longer acquainted with either months or years!”

zh: “是！”赫伯特接着说，“我们在小岛上找到他的时候，他已经在那儿呆了12年了！”
en: “Yes!” added Herbert, “and he had been twelve years already on the islet when we found him there!”

zh: “12年！”哈丁说，“啊！一段罪恶的生活之后，忍受12年的孤独，这可能会摧残一个人的理智！”
en: “Twelve years!” rejoined Harding.“Ah! twelve years of solitude, after a wicked life, perhaps, may well impair a man’s reason!”

zh: “我认为，”潘克洛夫说，“这个人不是在达抱岛上遇难的，而是因为犯了罪被放逐到那里的。”
en: “I am induced to think,” said Pencroft, “that this man was not wrecked on Tabor Island, but that in consequence of some crime he was left there.”

zh: “你说的没错，潘克洛夫，”记者回答，“如果真是这样，那些把他留在岛上的人，可能有一天会再回来把他带走的！”
en: “You must be right, Pencroft,” replied the reporter, “and if it is so it is not impossible that those who left him on the island may return to fetch him some day!”

zh: “那时候，他们就再找不到他了。”赫伯特说。
en: “And they will no longer find him,” said Herbert.

zh: “不过，”潘克洛夫说，“他们一定会回来，那么——”
en: “But then,” added Pencroft, “they must return, and—”

zh: “我的朋友，”赛勒斯·哈丁说，“在我们进一步了解以前，就不要再讨论这个问题了。我认为这个不幸的人受到了折磨，他已经用最可怕的方式弥补了自己的过失——不管他犯了什么样的过失，并且想释放自己的愿望令他苦闷。我们不要强迫他说出自己的过去！他肯定会告诉我们的，等我们知道以后，我们就知道怎样做是最好的了。他能告诉我们，是否他盼着终有一天能够回到自己的祖国，不过，我对此表示怀疑。”
en: “My friends,” said Cyrus Harding, “do not let us discuss this question until we know more about it.I believe that the unhappy man has suffered, that he has severely expiated his faults, whatever they may have been, and that the wish to unburden himself stifles him.Do not let us press him to tell us his history!He will tell it to us doubtless, and when we know it, we shall see what course it will be best to follow.He alone besides can tell us, if he has more than a hope, a certainty, of returning some day to his country, but I doubt it!”

zh: “为什么？”记者问。
en: “And why?” asked the reporter.

zh: “因为如果他确信自己有一天会被解救，那么他就会等着解救时间的到来，而不会将纸条扔到大海里去了。不，更有可能的是，他被判终生留在那个小岛上，他也绝不会期望再次见到他的同伴！”
en: “Because that, in the event of his being sure of being delivered at a certain time, he would have waited the hour of his deliverance and would not have thrown this document into the sea.No, it is more probable that he was condemned to die on that islet, and that he never expected to see his fellow-creatures again!”

zh: “不过，”水手说，“还有一件事情我不明白。”
en: “But,” observed the sailor, “there is one thing which I cannot explain.”

zh: “是什么事情？”
en: “What is it?”

zh: “如果这个人在达抱岛上呆了12年了，我们完全可以认为，在我们发现他的时候，他已经变成野人好几年了！”
en: “If this man had been left for twelve years on Tabor Island, one may well suppose that he had been several years already in the wild state in which we found him!”

zh: “这很有可能。”赛勒斯·哈丁回答说。
en: “That is probable,” replied Cyrus Harding.

zh: “他写那张纸条也一定是多年以前了吧！”
en: “It must then be many years since he wrote that document!”

zh: “毫无疑问。”但那张纸条看起来是最近写的！
en: “No doubt,” and yet the document appears to have been recently written!

zh: “而且，你是怎么知道装着纸条的瓶子，不是经过好几年从达抱岛漂到林肯岛上的呢？”
en: “Besides, how do you know that the bottle which enclosed the document may not have taken several years to come from Tabor Island to Lincoln Island?”

zh: “这并不是完全不可能。”记者回答。
en: “That is not absolutely impossible,” replied the reporter.

zh: “它会不会在这个小岛的海岸上很长时间了呢？”
en: “Might it not have been a long time already on the coast of the island?”

zh: “不可能，”潘克洛夫说，“因为他当时是漂着的。我们也不能认为，这个瓶子在海岸上停留了一段时间后，还会被海水冲走，因为南海岸全是岩石，在那里肯定会被撞得粉碎的！”
en: “No,” answered Pencroft, “for it was still floating.We could not even suppose that after it had stayed for any length of time on the shore, it would have been swept off by the sea, for the south coast is all rocks, and it would certainly have been smashed to pieces there!”

zh: “的确是这样。”赛勒斯·哈丁若有所思地说。
en: “That is true,” rejoined Cyrus Harding thoughtfully.

zh: “还有，”水手接着说，“如果这张纸条是很多年前的，如果在那个瓶子里被封了好几年了，那也会因潮湿而被损坏的。现在情形完全不是那样，我们发现的时候，它完好无损。”
en: “And then,” continued the sailor, “if the document was several years old, if it had been shut up in that bottle for several years, it would have been injured by damp.Now, there is nothing of the kind, and it was found in a perfect state of preservation.”

zh: 水手的推理非常合理，同时也指出一个无法理解的事实，那就是当开拓者发现这个瓶子的时候，这个纸条好像是最近才写上去的。另外，上面给出了达抱岛正确的经度和纬度，这意味着与普通的水手相比，写纸条的人懂得更全面的水文知识。
