en: The sailor’s reasoning was very just, and pointed out an incomprehensible fact, for the document appeared to have been recently written, when the colonists found it in the bottle.Moreover, it gave the latitude and longitude of Tabor Island correctly, which implied that its author had a more complete knowledge of hydrography than could be expected of a common sailor.

zh: “这里面还有一些是无法解释的，”工程师说，“但是我们不能急着让我们的同伴开口。”我的朋友，当他想说的时候，我们准备倾听就可以了！”
en: “There is in this, again, something unaccountable,” said the engineer, “but we will not urge our companions to speak.When he likes, my friends, then we shall be ready to hear him!”

zh: 接下来的几天，陌生人一句话也没说，也没有离开过高原的区域。他一直不停地工作，一刻也不浪费，一分钟也不休息，不过他总是在一个僻静的地方。吃饭时他从不去花岗石宫，虽然大家几次叫他去，但是他只是满足于吃一些生蔬菜。傍晚时候，他不回给他指定的房间，而是呆在几丛树下。天气不好时，他就蹲在岩石的缝隙中。因此，他还是和以前在达抱岛上的生活方式一样，当时他只把森林当住所。所有劝说他要改善生活的努力都是徒劳的，所以开拓者们只好耐心地等待着。当这个时刻临近的时候，他似乎是受良心不由自主的驱使，作出了可怕的坦白。
en: During the following days the stranger did not speak a word, and did not once leave the precincts of the plateau.He worked away, without losing a moment, without taking a minute’s rest, but always in a retired place.At meal times he never came to Granite House, although invited several times to do so, but contented himself with eating a few raw vegetables.At nightfall he did not return to the room assigned to him, but remained under some clump of trees, or when the weather was bad crouched in some cleft of the rocks.Thus he lived in the same manner as when he had no other shelter than the forests of Tabor Island, and as all persuasion to induce him to improve his life was in vain, the colonists waited patiently.And the time was near, when, as it seemed, almost involuntarily urged by his conscience, a terrible confession escaped him.

zh: 11月10日，大约晚上八点的时候，天快黑了，当时大家都聚在平台上，陌生人出其不意地出现在居民们的面前。他的眼睛发出奇异的光芒，并且他又恢复到最糟糕的日子里野蛮的一面。
en: On the 10th of November, about eight o’clock in the evening, as night was coming on, the stranger appeared unexpectedly before the settlers, who were assembled under the veranda.His eyes burned strangely, and he had quite resumed the wild aspect of his worst days.

zh: 在一种强烈的感情影响下，他的牙齿在打颤，就像一个发烧的病人一样，赛勒斯·哈丁和他的同伴看到这个场景后，大吃一惊。他怎么了？看到同类，他忍受不了吗？他厌烦回到文明的生存方式吗？他还怀念以前的原始生活吗？看起来是这样的，很快他们就听到他用不连贯的句子表达自己，说道：
en: Cyrus Harding and his companions were astounded on seeing that, overcome by some terrible emotion, his teeth chattered like those of a person in a fever.What was the matter with him?Was the sight of his fellow-creatures insupportable to him?Was he weary of this return to a civilized mode of existence?Was he pining for his former savage life?It appeared so, as soon he was heard to express himself in these incoherent sentences:—

zh: “我为什么会在这里？你们有什么权利把我从我的小岛带到这里？你们认为我和你们之间有任何关系吗？你们知道我是谁，知道我做过什么吗，知道我为什么一个人在那里吗？是谁告诉你们我不是被遗弃在那里的，不是被判令老死在那里的？你们知道我的过去吗？你们怎么知道我没有偷盗，没有谋杀，我不是一个恶棍，一个被诅咒的人，只适合像野兽那样生活的人，远离一切的人，说——你们知道吗？”
en: “Why am I here?....By what right have you dragged me from my islet?....Do you think there could be any tie between you and me?....Do you know who I am—what I have done—why I was there—alone?And who told you that I was not abandoned there—that I was not condemned to die there?....Do you know my past?....How do you know that I have not stolen, murdered—that I am not a wretch—an accursed being—only fit to live like a wild beast, far from all—speak—do you know it?”

zh: 开拓者们静静地听着，没有打断这个悲惨的人说的话，可以说，他失去了控制，断断续续进行了坦白。哈丁想要让他冷静下来，向他走近，可是他快速退回去了。
en: The colonists listened without interrupting the miserable creature, from whom these broken confessions escaped, as it were, in spite of himself.Harding wishing to calm him, approached him, but he hastily drew back.

zh: “不！不！”他大喊，“只问一句，我是自由的吗？”
en: “No! no!” he exclaimed; “one word only—am I free?”

zh: “你是自由的。”工程师回答。
en: “You are free,” answered the engineer.

zh: “那么，再见！”他叫喊，像个疯子似的逃走了。
en: “Farewell, then!” he cried, and fled like a madman.

zh: 纳布、潘克洛夫和赫伯特也跑向树林边缘，但是却没有带回那个野人。
en: Neb, Pencroft, and Herbert ran also towards the edge of the wood—but they returned alone.

zh: “我们必须让他一个人呆一会儿！”赛勒斯·哈丁说。
en: “We must let him alone!” said Cyrus Harding.

zh: “他不会再回来了！”潘克洛夫喊。
en: “He will never come back!” exclaimed Pencroft.

zh: “他会回来的。”工程师回答。
en: “He will come back,” replied the engineer.

zh: 好几天过去了，可是，哈丁总有强烈的预感，这个不幸的人迟早会回来的。
en: Many days passed; but Harding—was it a sort of presentiment?—presentiment in the fixed idea that sooner or later the unhappy man would return.

zh: “这是他的野性最后一次发作，”他说，“悔恨又触动了他，再过孤独生活会压制他的野性。
en: “It is the last revolt of his wild nature,” said he, “which remorse has touched, and which renewed solitude will terrify.”

zh: 同时，眺望角和畜栏里所有的工作都照旧进行，哈丁打算在那里建一个农场。毋庸置疑，赫伯特从达抱岛上采集来的种子已经小心地种上了。这样，高地变成了一个巨大的菜园，布局良好，并受到他们的精心照料，所以居民们的手从来没有闲过。总是有做不完的工作要做。可食用的东西数量增加了，扩大简单的园地也变得有必要了，园地有可能长成常规的菜地，取代草地。好在大量的草长在了小岛的其他地方，不用担心野驴会跑到这里来食草。还有，将眺望岗变成一个菜园是很值得的，因为这个菜园由很深的护河带保护着，并且将菜园搬到草地上，就没必要防御灵长类动物和四足兽来掠夺它。
en: In the meanwhile, works of all sorts were continued, as well on Prospect Heights as at the corral, where Harding intended to build a farm.It is unnecessary to say that the seeds collected by Herbert on Tabor Island had been carefully sown.The plateau thus formed one immense kitchen-garden, well laid out and carefully tended, so that the arms of the settlers were never in want of work.There was always something to be done.As the esculents increased in number, it became necessary to enlarge the simple beds, which threatened to grow into regular fields and replace the meadows.But grass abounded in other parts of the island, and there was no fear of the onagers being obliged to go on short allowance.It was well worth while, besides, to turn Prospect Heights into a kitchen-garden, defended by its deep belt of creeks, and to remove them to the meadows, which had no need of protection against the depredations of quadrumana and quadrapeds.

zh: 11月15日是第三次收获的日子。18个月前，他们只种了一粒小麦，现在麦田变得多么广阔啊！第二次种下的60万粒种子,这次产了4000蒲式耳，也就是5亿粒麦了！
en: On the 15th of November, the third harvest was gathered in.How wonderfully had the field increased in extent, since eighteen months ago, when the first grain of wheat was sown!The second crop of six hundred thousand grains produced this time four thousand bushels, or five hundred millions of grains!

zh: 这块开拓地谷物丰富，每年仅种十蒲式耳就足以产出够人类和野兽食用的作物了。收获完成后，11月最后两星期，他们投入到把庄稼变成人类的食物的工作中。实际上，他们有了小麦，但这不是面粉，因此有必要建一个磨坊。赛勒斯·哈丁本可以利用第二个流入慈悲河的瀑布产生动力，第一个瀑布已经用作了制毡厂的动力，但是，经过协商后，他们决定在眺望岗上建一个简单的风磨。现在建造的这个与以前建的那个一样简单，而且可以确定的是，由于高地面对海上吹来的微风，那里风是不缺的。
en: The colony was rich in corn, for ten bushels alone were sufficient for sowing every year to produce an ample crop for the food both of men and beasts.The harvest was completed, and the last fortnight of the month of November was devoted to the work of converting it into food for man.In fact, they had corn, but not flour, and the establishment of a mill was necessary.Cyrus Harding could have utilized the second fall which flowed into the Mercy to establish his motive power, the first being already occupied with moving the felting mill, but, after some consultation, it was decided that a simple windmill should be built on Prospect Heights.The building of this presented no more difficulty than the building of the former, and it was moreover certain that there would be no want of wind on the plateau, exposed as it was to the sea breezes.

zh: “不用说，”潘克洛夫说，“在这块场地上，这个风磨会更有活力，效果会很好！”
en: “Not to mention,” said Pencroft, “that the windmill will be more lively and will have a good effect in the landscape!”

zh: 他们开始认真工作，为磨坊的框架和机械选择木材。他们在湖的北边找到几块大石头，可以轻而易举地变成磨石。至于风翼，气囊上那些用不完的布料充当了必要的材料。
en: They set to work by choosing timber for the frame and machinery of the mill.Some large stones, found at the north of the lake, could be easily transformed into millstones, and as to the sails, the inexhaustible case of the balloon furnished the necessary material.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁设计出他的模型，磨坊地址选在靠近湖岸的地方，家禽饲养场靠右一点的位置。结实的木料支撑着一个转轴，框架就安装在那个转轴上，这样，它就可以根据风向和上面所有的机械一同旋转了。工作进展得很迅速。纳布和潘克洛夫成了技术熟练的木匠，他们只要按照工程师给他们的模型做就可以了。
en: Cyrus Harding made his model, and the site of the mill was chosen a little to the right of the poultry-yard, near the shore of the lake.The frame was to rest on a pivot supported with strong timbers, so that it could turn with all the machinery it contained according as the wind required it.The work advanced rapidly.Neb and Pencroft had become very skilful carpenters, and had nothing to do but to copy the models provided by the engineer.

zh: 一会儿，他们就在选定的地点竖起一个圆柱形的盒子来，形状像一个胡椒瓶，屋顶尖尖的。用来做过帆的四根风翼被铁夹牢固地定在中央轴上，这样就与中央轴形成一个固定的角度。内部的各个部分包括：一个盒子，用于放两块磨石，一块是固定的，另一块是活动的；一只漏斗，这是一只大的、正方形的水槽，上宽下窄，可以让谷物漏到石头上；一个振荡槽，用来把麦粒灌入磨眼；最后是筛粉机，经过筛选过程，可以筛出面粉留下皮，这些都轻而易举地造好了。工具很好用，并且工作也不难，事实上，磨坊上的机械非常简单。这只是时间的问题。
en: Soon a sort of cylindrical box, in shape like a pepper-pot, with a pointed roof, rose on the spot chosen.The four frames which formed the sails had been firmly fixed in the center beam, so as to form a certain angle with it, and secured with iron clamps.As to the different parts of the internal mechanism, the box destined to contain the two millstones, the fixed stone and the moving stone, the hopper, a sort of large square trough, wide at the top, narrow at the bottom, which would allow the grain to fall on the stones, the oscillating spout intended to regulate the passing of the grain, and lastly the bolting machine, which by the operation of sifting, separates the bran from the flour, were made without difficulty.The tools were good, and the work not difficult, for in reality, the machinery of a mill is very simple.This was only a question of time.

zh: 每个人都在忙着建造磨坊，12月1日，磨坊完工了。和往常一样，潘克洛夫对自己的工作很满意，他确信这个装置是十分完美的。
en: Every one had worked at the construction of the mill, and on the 1st of December it was finished.As usual, Pencroft was delighted with his work, and had no doubt that the apparatus was perfect.

zh: “现在刮一阵好风，”他说，“我们就会很好地磨出第一次收的麦子！”
en: “Now for a good wind,” said he, “and we shall grind our first harvest splendidly!”

zh: “合适的风向，肯定是，”工程师回答，“但是不要太多，潘克洛夫。”
en: “A good wind, certainly,” answered the engineer, “but not too much, Pencroft.”

zh: “呸！我们的风车只会转得更快！”
en: “Pooh! our mill would only go the faster!”

zh: “没有必要让它转那么快。”赛勒斯·哈丁回答，“由经验得知，风翼在一分钟旋转的次数是风在一秒钟走的英尺数的六倍时，磨坊的工作量最大。如果一阵和缓的风每秒走24英尺，就可以让风翼在一分钟内转16圈，不需要转更多圈。”
en: “There is no need for it to go so very fast,” replied Cyrus Harding.“It is known by experience that the greatest quantity of work is performed by a mill when the number of turns made by the sails in a minute is six times the number of feet traversed by the wind in a second.A moderate breeze, which passes over twenty-four feet to the second, will give sixteen turns to the sails during a minute, and there is no need of more.”

zh: “一点儿不错！”赫伯特喊，“一阵和煦的清风从东北方向吹来，很快就可以为我们完成工作了。”
en: “Exactly!” cried Herbert, “a fine breeze is blowing from the northeast, which will soon do our business for us.”

zh: 没有理由延迟这个磨坊的落成典礼，因为居民们急切地想品尝林肯岛上的第一片面包。这天早上，他们磨了两三蒲式耳小麦，第二天吃早餐时，花岗石宫的桌子上就摆上了一大块面包，虽然经过发酵，但也许不够松软。每个人都吃得津津有味，这是很容易理解的。
en: There was no reason for delaying the inauguration of the mill, for the settlers were eager to taste the first piece of bread in Lincoln Island.On this morning two or three bushels of wheat were ground, and the next day at breakfast a magnificent loaf, a little heavy perhaps, although raised with yeast, appeared on the table at Granite House.Every one munched away at it with a pleasure which may be easily understood.

zh: 在此期间，陌生人一直没有出现。吉丁·史佩莱和赫伯特在花岗岩石附近的森林里找了好几次，都没有碰到他，也没有发现他的踪迹。大家因为他长期不归而感到非常不安。可以肯定的是，先前生活在达抱岛上的野人，不可能为怎样在森林中生存而困惑，但可怕的是，如果他已经恢复了他的习惯，如果这种自由的生活让他野蛮的本性复发，那可怎么办？然而，哈丁利用某种预感，毫无疑问，总坚持说这个逃跑的人会回来的。
en: In the meanwhile, the stranger had not reappeared.Several times Gideon Spilett and Herbert searched the forest in the neighborhood of Granite House, without meeting or finding any trace of him.They became seriously uneasy at this prolonged absence.Certainly, the former savage of Tabor island could not be perplexed how to live in the forest, abounding in game, but was it not to be feared that he had resumed his habits, and that this freedom would revive in him his wild instincts?However, Harding, by a sort of presentiment, doubtless, always persisted in saying that the fugitive would return.

zh: “是的，他会回来的！”他很有信心地重复着这句话，他的同伴却并不赞同。“这个不幸的人在达抱岛上的时候，他知道自己是孤独的！而在这里，他知道伙伴们在等着他！既然他讲了他过去生活的一部分，那么这个可怜的忏悔者会回来讲完完整的经历，到那时候，他就属于我们的一员了！”
en: “Yes, he will return!” he repeated with a confidence which his companions could not share.“When this unfortunate man was on Tabor Island, he knew himself to be alone!Here, he knows that fellow-men are awaiting him!Since he has partially spoken of his past life, the poor penitent will return to tell the whole, and from that day he will belong to us!”

zh: 接下来的事情证实了赛勒斯·哈丁的预言。12月3日，赫伯特离开了高原，到湖的南岸钓鱼去了。他没有带武器，也没有采取任何防御措施，因为小岛的这一带没有出现过危险动物。
en: The event justified Cyrus Harding’s predictions.On the 3rd of December, Herbert had left the plateau to go and fish on the southern bank of the lake.He was unarmed, and till then had never taken any precautions for defense, as dangerous animals had not shown themselves on that part of the island.

zh: 在这期间，潘克洛夫和纳布在家禽饲养场工作，哈丁和记者正在“石窟”里忙着制作苏打，因为储存的肥皂已经用完了。
en: Meanwhile, Pencroft and Neb were working in the poultry-yard, while Harding and the reporter were occupied at the Chimneys in making soda, the store of soap being exhausted.

zh: 突然，有叫喊声回响：
en: Suddenly cries resounded,—

zh: “救命啊！救命啊！”
en: “Help! help!”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和记者因为离得太远，没有听到喊声。潘克洛夫和纳布匆忙离开饲养场，冲向湖边。
en: Cyrus Harding and the reporter, being at too great a distance, had not been able to hear the shouts.Pencroft and Neb, leaving the poultry-yard in all haste, rushed towards the lake.

zh: 在此之前，陌生人已经穿过了高原和树林之间的甘油河，纵身跃上了对岸，谁也没有想到这个陌生人竟会从这里出现在他们面前。
en: But before then, the stranger, whose presence at this place no one had suspected, crossed Creek Glycerine, which separated the plateau from the forest, and bounded up the opposite bank.

zh: 赫伯特和凶猛的美洲豹面对着面，那只豹与在爬虫角杀死的那只差不多。突然受到惊吓，他背靠着一棵树站在那里，这时候，野兽弓起身子，想要扑过去。
en: Herbert was there face to face with a fierce jaguar, similar to the one which had been killed on Reptile End.Suddenly surprised, he was standing with his back against a tree, while the animal gathering itself together was about to spring.

zh: 可是，陌生人手中只有一把刀子，没有别的武器，他冲向这个可怕的动物，野兽转身迎上新的敌人。
en: But the stranger, with no other weapon than a knife, rushed on the formidable animal, who turned to meet this new adversary.

zh: 搏斗的过程很短。陌生人拥有惊人的力量和活力。他伸出一只强大的手，一下子掐住了美洲豹的喉咙，就像用钳子夹着一样，但是没有阻止这个野兽用爪子撕他的肉，他用另一只手直接将刀子插进那野兽的心脏。
en: The struggle was short.The stranger possessed immense strength and activity.He seized the jaguar’s throat with one powerful hand, holding it as in a vise, without heeding the beast’s claws which tore his flesh, and with the other he plunged his knife into its heart.

zh: 美洲豹倒下去了。陌生人一脚踢开它的尸体，刚要离开，这时候居民们都到了战斗场地，赫伯特抱住他，大喊：
en: The jaguar fell.The stranger kicked away the body, and was about to fly at the moment when the settlers arrived on the field of battle, but Herbert, clinging to him, cried,—

zh: “不，不！你不能走！”
en: “No, no! you shall not go!”

zh: 哈丁朝陌生人走去，当他看到哈丁走近时，他皱起了眉头。鲜血透过撕裂的衬衫淌了出来，但他没有在意。
en: Harding advanced towards the stranger, who frowned when he saw him approaching.The blood flowed from his shoulder under his torn shirt, but he took no notice of it.

zh: “我的朋友，”赛勒斯·活动说，“我们欠你一个人情。你冒着生命危险救了我们的小男孩！”
en: “My friend,” said Cyrus Harding, “we have just contracted a debt of gratitude to you.To save our boy you have risked your life!”

zh: “我的生命！”陌生人嘟哝着说，“那有什么价值可言？一文不值！”
en: “My life!” murmured the stranger.“What is that worth?Less than nothing!”

zh: “你受伤了？”
en: “You are wounded?”

zh: “没关系。”
en: “It is no matter.”

zh: “你能把手伸给我吗？”
en: “Will you give me your hand?”

zh: 赫伯特正打算去抓住这只刚才救过自己的手，陌生人突然合起双臂，他的胸膛在起伏，脸色沉了下来，似乎是想要逃走，但是经过一番激烈的自我斗争，他用急促的口气说道：
en: And as Herbert endeavored to seize the hand which had just saved him, the stranger folded his arms, his chest heaved, his look darkened, and he appeared to wish to escape, but making a violent effort over himself, and in an abrupt tone,—

zh: “你们是谁？”他问，“说给我听听吧？”
en: “Who are you?” he asked, “and what do you claim to be to me?”

zh: 他还是第一次要求开拓者们讲述他们的历史。也许等他们讲了历史过后，他就会讲述他自己的历史。
en: It was the colonists’ history which he thus demanded, and for the first time.Perhaps this history recounted, he would tell his own.

zh: 哈丁用几句话讲述了自从离开里士满后发生的事情：他们是怎样设法生存的，以及他们现在手头拥有的资源。
en: In a few words Harding related all that had happened since their departure from Richmond; how they had managed, and what resources they now had at their disposal.

zh: 陌生人聚精会神地听着。
en: The stranger listened with extreme attention.

zh: 接下来，工程师向他介绍了他们是谁——吉丁·史佩莱、赫伯特、潘克洛夫、纳布和他自己。他又接着讲了他们来到林肯岛后，感到最快乐的事情就是，乘着船从达抱岛归来，并且他们能有一个新伙伴。
en: Then the engineer told who they all were, Gideon Spilett, Herbert, Pencroft, Neb, himself, and, he added, that the greatest happiness they had felt since their arrival in Lincoln Island was on the return of the vessel from Tabor Island, when they had been able to include among them a new companion.

zh: 听到这些话后，陌生人的脸变红了，头低到了胸膛，从他的面部表情可以看出他很困惑。
en: At these words the stranger’s face flushed, his head sunk on his breast, and confusion was depicted on his countenance.

zh: “现在你知道我们是什么人了，”赛勒斯·哈丁接着说，“我们可以握手了吗？”
en: “And now that you know us,” added Cyrus Harding, “will you give us your hand?”

zh: “不，”陌生人用沙哑的声音说，“不！你们是诚实的人！而我——”
en: “No,” replied the, stranger in a hoarse voice; “no!You are honest men!And I—”

zh: 第十七章
en: Chapter 17

zh: 陌生人说的最后一句话证实了开拓者的猜测。也许在大家看来，有些痛苦的过去可以弥补，但是，他的良心并没有宽恕自己。不管怎样，这个内疚的人感到懊悔，他后悔了，他的新朋友本想诚恳地和他们寻找的那只手相握，可是，他却觉得自己不配跟这些诚实的人握手！不过，离开和美洲豹搏斗的场地后，他没有回到森林，从那天起，他也没有走出花岗石宫的范围。
en: These last words justified the colonists’ presentiment.There had been some mournful past, perhaps expiated in the sight of men, but from which his conscience had not yet absolved him.At any rate the guilty man felt remorse, he repented, and his new friends would have cordially pressed the hand which they sought; but he did not feel himself worthy to extend it to honest men!However, after the scene with the jaguar, he did not return to the forest, and from that day did not go beyond the enclosure of Granite House.

zh: 他生命中到底有什么秘密呢？陌生人是否会在某一天说出来？只有时间能够证明了。无论如何，他们一致同意不应再问他这个秘密，他们要显得毫无疑虑的样子和他生活在一起。
en: What was the mystery of his life?Would the stranger one day speak of it?Time alone could show.At any rate, it was agreed that his secret should never be asked from him, and that they would live with him as if they suspected nothing.

zh: 有一些日子，他们的生活照旧继续。赛勒斯·哈丁和吉丁·史佩莱共同工作，有时候是当化学家，有时候是做实验家。记者除了和赫伯特一起打猎外，从来没有离开过工程师，因为让小男孩一个人在树林里漫步是很不明智的，警戒是非常有必要的。纳布和潘克洛夫有时候在马房和家禽饲养场，有时在畜栏，不算上花岗石宫的工作，他们从来都不会没有活干。
en: For some days their life continued as before.Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett worked together, sometimes chemists, sometimes experimentalists.The reporter never left the engineer except to hunt with Herbert, for it would not have been prudent to allow the lad to ramble alone in the forest; and it was very necessary to be on their guard.As to Neb and Pencroft, one day at the stables and poultry-yard, another at the corral, without reckoning work in Granite House, they were never in want of employment.

zh: 陌生人一个人忙着，他又恢复了以前的生活：进餐时间从不出现，睡在高地的树下，从不与同伴交往。看来，他真的不能忍受那些救过他的人所生活的社会！
en: The stranger worked alone, and he had resumed his usual life, never appearing at meals, sleeping under the trees in the plateau, never mingling with his companions.It really seemed as if the society of those who had saved him was insupportable to him!

zh: “可是，”潘克洛夫说，“为什么他要人类同胞去救他呢？他为什么将纸条扔进大海呢？”
en: “But then,” observed Pencroft, “why did he entreat the help of his fellow-creatures?Why did he throw that paper into the sea?”

zh: “他会告诉我们原因的。”赛勒斯·哈丁总是那样回答。
en: “He will tell us why,” invariably replied Cyrus Harding.

zh: “那会是什么时候？”
en: “When?”

zh: “也许比你想的要早，潘克洛夫。”
en: “Perhaps sooner than you think, Pencroft.”

zh: 果然，他要坦白的日子已经不远了。
en: And, indeed, the day of confession was near.

zh: 12月10日，也就是他回到花岗石宫一星期后，哈丁看见陌生人向他走来，用平静而又谦卑的声音说：“先生，我有事求你。”
en: On the 10th of December, a week after his return to Granite House, Harding saw the stranger approaching, who, in a calm voice and humble tone, said to him: “Sir, I have a request to make of you.”

zh: “说吧，”工程师回答说，“但是，首先我要问你一个问题。”
en: “Speak,” answered the engineer, “but first let me ask you a question.”

zh: 听到这话后，陌生人变得满脸通红，他想要后退。赛勒斯·哈丁明白这个内疚的人脑子里正在想什么，他肯定是在担心工程师会问他的过去。
en: At these words the stranger reddened, and was on the point of withdrawing.Cyrus Harding understood what was passing in the mind of the guilty man, who doubtless feared that the engineer would interrogate him on his past life.

zh: 哈丁拖住了他。
en: Harding held him back.

zh: “朋友，”他说，“我们不仅是你的同伴，而且还是你的朋友。我希望你相信这一点，现在该我听你说了。”
en: “Comrade,” said he, “we are not only your companions but your friends.I wish you to believe that, and now I will listen to you.”

zh: 陌生人用手捂住了双眼。他突然哆嗦起来，有那么几分钟，说不出一个字。
en: The stranger pressed his hand over his eyes.He was seized with a sort of trembling, and remained a few moments without being able to articulate a word.

zh: “先生，”他最后说，“我过来是想求你帮我个忙。”
en: “Sir,” said he at last, “I have come to beg you to grant me a favor.”

zh: “什么事？”
en: “What is it?”

zh: “离这里四五英里的地方，你们有一个养家畜的畜栏。这些动物需要有人照顾。你能不能让我和它们住在一起啊？”
en: “You have, four or five miles from here, a corral for your domesticated animals.These animals need to be taken care of.Will you allow me to live there with them?”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁十分同情地注视着这个不幸的人，片刻过后，才说：
en: Cyrus Harding gazed at the unfortunate man for a few moments with a feeling of deep commiseration; then,—

zh: “我的朋友，那个畜栏只能勉强适合住牲口。”
en: “My friend,” said he, “the corral has only stables hardly fit for animals.”

zh: “对我来说已经很好了，先生。”
en: “It will be good enough for me, sir.”

zh: “我的朋友，”哈丁回答，“我们不会限制你做任何事情。你想要住在畜栏，那就去吧。不过，我们随时欢迎你来花岗石宫。但是你想住在畜栏，那么我们就做一下必要的整理，让你在那儿住得舒舒服服的。”
en: “My friend,” answered Harding, “we will not constrain you in anything.You wish to live at the corral, so be it.You will, however, be always welcome at Granite House.But since you wish to live at the corral we will make the necessary arrangements for your being comfortably established there.”

zh: “不要在意，我自己会安排得很好的。”
en: “Never mind that, I shall do very well.”

zh: “我的朋友，”哈丁回答，他总是故意用这个诚挚的称呼，“关于这件事怎么做最好，你必须让我们决定。”
en: “My friend,” answered Harding, who always intentionally made use of this cordial appellation, “you must let us judge what it will be best to do in this respect.”

zh: “谢谢您，先生。”陌生人边说边后退。
en: “Thank you, sir,” replied the stranger as he withdrew.

zh: 工程师接着就将陌生人向他提出的要求告诉了同伴，他们一致同意在畜栏里建一个木屋，将里面布置得尽可能舒服些。
en: The engineer then made known to his companions the proposal which had been made to him, and it was agreed that they should build a wooden house at the corral, which they would make as comfortable as possible.

zh: 也就是那一天，开拓者们准备了必要的工具对畜栏进行修补，不到一周，这个房子就只等房客入住了。这所房屋建在离棚屋约20英尺的地方，从里面很容易看到羊群，羊的数目已经超过80了。他们制作了一些家具：一张床，一张桌子，一条长凳，一只碗橱和柜子；他们还带去一支枪、一些弹药和工具。
en: That very day the colonists repaired to the corral with the necessary tools, and a week had not passed before the house was ready to receive its tenant.It was built about twenty feet from the sheds, and from there it was easy to overlook the flock of sheep, which then numbered more than eighty.Some furniture, a bed, table, bench, cupboard, and chest were manufactured, and a gun, ammunition, and tools were carried to the corral.

zh: 可是，陌生人还没有看到他的新住所的一切，他让居民们在那里工作的时候不用管自己，而他自己在高地上忙着，肯定是想自己完成最后的工作。事实上，由于他的劳动成果，整个地面都翻了一遍，时机一到，就可以耕种了。
en: The stranger, however, had seen nothing of his new dwelling, and he had allowed the settlers to work there without him, while he occupied himself on the plateau, wishing, doubtless, to put the finishing stroke to his work.Indeed, thanks to him, all the ground was dug up and ready to he sowed when the time came.

zh: 畜栏的所有布置工作在12月20日全部完成。工程师通知陌生人，他的住所准备好迎接他入住了，陌生人回答说他当天晚上就去住。
en: It was on the 20th of December that all the arrangements at the corral were completed.The engineer announced to the stranger that his dwelling was ready to receive him, and the latter replied that he would go and sleep there that very evening.

zh: 当天晚上，开拓者们聚集在花岗石宫的餐厅里。八点的时候，他们的同伴要离开了。他们不想因为他们的存在而麻烦他，强迫说再见的必要性，可能会让他感到难受，因此，他们把陌生人一个人留在那里，上到了花岗石宫。
en: On this evening the colonists were gathered in the diningroom of Granite House.It was then eight o’clock, the hour at which their companion was to leave them.Not wishing to trouble him by their presence, and thus imposing on him the necessity of saying farewells which might perhaps be painful to him, they had left him alone and ascended to Granite House.

zh: 此刻，他们在房间里谈了几分钟，就听到门口有轻轻的敲门声。几乎是同时，陌生人走了进来，没有任何开场白：
en: Now, they had been talking in the room for a few minutes, when a light knock was heard at the door.Almost immediately the stranger entered, and without any preamble,—

zh: “先生们，”他说，“在我离开你们之前，告诉你们我的故事是应该的。我告诉你们吧。”
en: “Gentlemen,” said he, “before I leave you, it is right that you should know my history.I will tell it you.”

zh: 这些简单的话语深深感动了赛勒斯·哈丁和他的同伴们。工程师站了起来。
en: These simple words profoundly impressed Cyrus Harding and his companions.The engineer rose.

zh: “我们没有要求什么，我的朋友，”他说，“你可以保持沉默。”
en: “We ask you nothing, my friend,” said he; “it is your right to be silent.”

zh: “说出来是我的职责。”
en: “It is my duty to speak.”

zh: “那就坐下来说吧。”
en: “Sit down, then.”

zh: “不用，我站着。”
en: “No, I will stand.”

zh: “我们准备听你说了。”哈丁回答。
en: “We are ready to hear you,” replied Harding.

zh: 陌生人就站在房间的一个角落，那里比较阴暗。他光着头，双臂合着，交叉在胸前，他就以这样一种姿势，用沙哑的声音说的，说起话来就像有人强迫他说似的，听话的人并没有马上打断他，他说了下面这些话：
en: The stranger remained standing in a corner of the room, a little in the shade.He was bareheaded, his arms folded across his chest, and it was in this posture that in a hoarse voice, speaking like some one who obliges himself to speak, he gave the following recital, which his auditors did not once interrupt:—

zh: “1854年12月20日，一条蒸汽游艇停靠在了 澳大利亚西海岸的百奴衣角，那里的纬度是37度，这游艇属于一个苏格兰贵族格里那凡爵士。这艘游艇上有格里那凡爵士和他的妻子，一个英国陆军少校，一个法国地理学家，一个年轻的女孩和一个年轻的男孩。最后那两个是格兰特船长的孩子，一年前，他的‘大不列颠’号连同船上的货物和船员都失踪了。‘邓肯’由约翰·孟格尓船长指挥，上面配备了15个水手。
en: “On the 20th of December, 1854, a steam-yacht, belonging to a Scotch nobleman, Lord Glenarvan, anchored off Cape Bernouilli, on the western coast of Australia, in the thirty-seventh parallel.On board this yacht were Lord Glenarvan and his wife, a major in the English army, a French geographer, a young girl, and a young boy.These two last were the children of Captain Grant, whose ship, the ‘Britannia,’ had been lost, crew and cargo, a year before.The ‘Duncan’ was commanded by Captain John Mangles, and manned by a crew of fifteen men.

zh: “游艇那时在澳大利亚海岸停下来，原因是这样的：六个月前，‘邓肯’号上的人在爱尔兰海上捡到一个瓶子，里面有一张纸条，纸上写着英文、德文和法文。这张纸条大意是说，‘大不列颠’号失事后，仍有三个人幸存下来，他们是格兰特船长和两个水手，这三个人在某个岛上找到避难所，纸条上注明着海岛的纬度，可是写着经度的地方被海水侵蚀了，已经认不出来了。
en: “This is the reason the yacht at this time lay off the coast of Australia.Six months before, a bottle, enclosing a document written in English, German, and French, had been found in the Irish Sea, and picked up by the ‘Duncan.’ This document stated in substance that there still existed three survivors from the wreck of the ‘Britannia,’ that these survivors were Captain Grant and two of his men, and that they had found refuge on some land, of which the document gave the latitude, but of which the longitude, effaced by the sea, was no longer legible.

zh: “这个纬度是南纬37度11分，经度不知，因此，如果他们顺着大陆和大海上方的37度寻找，他们就一定会到达格兰特船长和他的两个同伴所在的地点。英国海军部对于搜寻工作犹豫不决，格里那凡爵士下定决心要想尽一切办法找回船长。他联系了玛丽和罗伯特·格兰特，这两个孩子也加入了他的队伍。‘邓肯’号游艇是为远航而装备的，贵族的家人和船长的孩子也想加入。‘邓肯’号从格拉斯哥出发，驶向大西洋，途中经过麦哲伦海峡，穿过太平洋，远至巴塔戈尼亚。根据纸条之前的解释，他们认为格兰特船长被印第安人掳去了。
en: “This latitude was 37deg 11’ south; therefore, the longitude being unknown, if they followed the thirty-seventh parallel over continents and seas, they would be certain to reach the spot inhabited by Captain Grant and his two companions.The English Admiralty having hesitated to undertake this search, Lord Glenarvan resolved to attempt everything to find the captain.He communicated with Mary and Robert Grant, who joined him.The ‘Duncan’ yacht was equipped for the distant voyage, in which the nobleman’s family and the captain’s children wished to take part, and the ‘Duncan,’ leaving Glasgow, proceeded towards the Atlantic, passed through the Straits of Magellan, and ascended the Pacific as far as Patagonia, where, according to a previous interpretation of the document, they supposed that Captain Grant was a prisoner among the Indians.

zh: “‘邓肯’号让乘客在巴塔戈尼亚的西海岸登陆，再将船开到科连特斯角的东岸接他们。格里那凡爵士沿着37度纬线穿过了巴塔戈尼亚，但是却没有发现船长的踪迹。12月13日，他再次上船，为了继续在海洋上寻找。
en: “The ‘Duncan’ disembarked her passengers on the western coast of Patagonia, and sailed to pick them up again on the eastern coast at Cape Corrientes.Lord Glenarvan traversed Patagonia, following the thirty-seventh parallel, and having found no trace of the captain, he re-embarked on the 13th of November, so as to pursue his search through the Ocean.

zh: “在特里斯特德阿丘纳和阿姆斯特丹岛毫无收获后，就像我说过的，‘邓肯’就位于航线上，并于1854年12月20日到达澳大利亚西海岸上的百奴衣角。
en: “After having unsuccessfully visited the islands of Tristan d’Acunha and Amsterdam, situated in her course, the ‘Duncan,’ as I have said, arrived at Cape Bernouilli, on the Australian coast, on the 20th of December, 1854.

zh: “格里那凡爵士想要像横越美洲一样穿越澳大利亚，于是，他在那里登陆了。距离海岸几英里的地方建了一个农场，这个农场属于一个爱尔兰人，他对旅行者很热情。格里那凡爵士告诉了这个爱尔兰人他到这些地方的原因，还问他是否知道叫‘大不列颠’的英国三桅船，不到两年前，它在澳大利亚西海岸一带失踪。
en: “It was Lord Glenarvan’s intention to traverse Australia as he had traversed America, and he disembarked.A few miles from the coast was established a farm, belonging to an Irishman, who offered hospitality to the travelers.Lord Glenarvan made known to the Irishman the cause which had brought him to these parts, and asked if he knew whether a three-masted English vessel, the ‘Britannia,’ had been lost less than two years before on the west coast of Australia.

zh: “爱尔兰人从未听说过有船失事，不过令旁观者非常吃惊的是，他的一个仆人走上前说：
en: “The Irishman had never heard of this wreck, but, to the great surprise of the bystanders, one of his servants came forward and said,—

zh: “‘阁下，谢天谢地！如果船长格兰特还活着，他现在一定还在澳大利亚的海岸上。’
en: “‘My lord, praise and thank God!If Captain Grant is still living, he is living on the Australian shores.’

zh: “‘你是谁？’格里那凡爵士问。
en: “‘Who are you?’ asked Lord Glenarvan.

zh: “‘和您一样，是苏格兰人，阁下，’那个人说，‘我是格兰特船长手下的一个水手——大不列颠的落难者之一。’
en: “‘A Scotchman like yourself, my lord,’ replied the man; ‘I am one of Captain Grant’s crew—one of the castaways of the “Britannia.”’

zh: “这个人叫艾尔顿。就像他的纸条上写的那样，事实上，他是‘大不列颠’船上的副水手长。不过，他在船触礁的时候就和格兰特船长分开了，他一直认为船长和所有的水手都丧生了，而他——艾尔顿，是‘大不列颠’上唯一的幸存者。
en: “This man was called Ayrton.He was, in fact, the boatswain’s mate of the ‘Britannia,’ as his papers showed.But, separated from Captain Grant at the moment when the ship struck upon the rocks, he had till then believed that the captain with all his crew had perished, and that he, Ayrton, was the sole survivor of the ‘Britannia.’

zh: “‘只是，’他接着说，‘船失踪的地方不是在西海岸，而是在澳大利亚的东岸。如果格兰特船长还活着，就像纸条上说的那样，他被当地人囚禁了，我们应该到东海岸上去寻找。’
en: “‘Only,’ he added, ‘it was not on the west coast, but on the east coast of Australia that the vessel was lost, and if Captain Grant is still living, as his document indicates, he is a prisoner among the natives, and it is on the other coast that he must be looked for.’

zh: “这个人说起话来很坦诚，也很自信，他的话不用怀疑。他已经服侍这个爱尔兰人一年多了，这也证明了他的忠实可靠。因此，格里那凡爵士相信这个人是忠诚的，根据他的建议，他决定顺着南纬37度，跨越澳大利亚。格里那凡爵士、他的妻子、两个孩子、陆军少校、法国地理学家、孟格尓船长和几个水手组成了一个小团队，由艾尔顿指挥。‘邓肯’号在汤姆·奥斯汀大副的控制下，驶向了墨尔本，在那里等候格里那凡爵士的安排。
en: “This man spoke in a frank voice and with a confident look; his words could not be doubted.The irishman, in whose service he had been for more than a year, answered for his trustworthiness.Lord Glenarvan, therefore, believed in the fidelity of this man and, by his advice, resolved to cross Australia, following the thirty-seventh parallel.Lord Glenarvan, his wife, the two children, the major, the Frenchman, Captain Mangles, and a few sailors composed the little band under the command of Ayrton, while the ‘Duncan,’ under charge of the mate, Tom Austin, proceeded to Melbourne, there to await Lord Glenarvan’s instructions.

zh: “他们在 1854年12月23日启程。
en: “They set out on the 23rd of December, 1854.

zh: “我看是时候说艾尔顿是个叛徒了。实际上，他是‘大不列颠’上的副水手长，不过，后来与船长有了争议，于是他就想煽动船员叛变，并将船占为己有。1852年4月8日，格兰特船长让他在澳大利亚西海岸下了船，将他丢在那里，然后起航了，按照海上的规矩，这样做是正确的。
en: “It is time to say that Ayrton was a traitor.He was, indeed, the boatswain’s mate of the ‘Britannia,’ but, after some dispute with his captain, he endeavored to incite the crew to mutiny and seize the ship, and Captain Grant had landed him, on the 8th of April, 1852, on the west coast of Australia, and then sailed, leaving him there, as was only just.

zh: “所以，这个卑鄙的的人对‘大不列颠’号遇难的事情一无所知，他只是从格里那凡的描述中听来的。自从被抛弃后，他就以本·乔伊斯的名义成为了一群逃犯的头子。他胆敢坚持船失事的地方是在东海岸，目的是将格里那凡爵士带往那个方向，希望将他和船分开，得到‘邓肯’号，并将游艇作为太平洋上的海盗船。
en: “Therefore this wretched man knew nothing of the wreck of the ‘Britannia’; he had just heard of it from Glenarvan’s account.Since his abandonment, he had become, under the name of Ben Joyce, the leader of the escaped convicts; and if he boldly maintained that the wreck had taken place on the east coast, and led Lord Glenarvan to proceed in that direction, it was that he hoped to separate him from his ship, seize the ‘Duncan,’ and make the yacht a pirate in the Pacific.”

zh: 说到这里，陌生人停了一会儿。他声音有些颤抖，但是他接着说：
en: Here the stranger stopped for a moment.His voice trembled, but he continued,—

zh: “远征开始了，并穿过了澳大利亚。他们非倒霉不可，因为艾尔顿，也就是本·乔伊斯，可以这样称呼他，给他们做向导。而那群囚犯有时在船的前面，有时跟在船的后面，他告诉他们必须怎么做。
en: “The expedition set out and proceeded across Australia.It was inevitably unfortunate, since Ayrton, or Ben Joyce, as he may be called, guided it, sometimes preceded, sometimes followed by his band of convicts, who had been told what they had to do.

zh: “这期间，‘邓肯’号已经被送往墨尔本维修去了。接下来必须要做的就是让格里那凡爵士命令游船离开墨尔本，到澳大利亚东岸，在那里很容易得到这艘船。船快要靠岸的时候，艾尔顿在没有其他资源的广阔树林里找到一封信，上面要求他将这封信带给‘邓肯’号上的大副，信上命令这艘游艇马上到东岸进行维修，再到吐福湾，也就是说，在远征停止的地方开始几天的航程。在那里，艾尔顿同意见他的帮凶，拿到这封信两天后，就到达了墨尔本。
en: “Meanwhile, the ‘Duncan’ had been sent to Melbourne for repairs.It was necessary, then, to get Lord Glenarvan to order her to leave Melbourne and go to the east coast of Australia, where it would be easy to seize her.After having led the expedition near enough to the coast, in the midst of vast forests with no resources, Ayrton obtained a letter, which he was charged to carry to the mate of the ‘Duncan’—a letter which ordered the yacht to repair immediately to the east coast, to Twofold Bay, that is to say a few days’ journey from the place where the expedition had stopped.It was there that Ayrton had agreed to meet his accomplices, and two days after gaining possession of the letter, he arrived at Melbourne.

zh: “到目前为止，这个恶棍邪恶的计划一直是成功的。他可以将‘邓肯’号带到吐福湾，在那里，逃犯们很容易就能获得这船。把上面的船员都杀掉后，本·乔伊斯就会成为这片海域上的主人。不过，感谢上帝阻止了这些可怕的计划的实现。
en: “So far the villain had succeeded in his wicked design.He would be able to take the ‘Duncan’ into Twofold Bay, where it would be easy for the convicts to seize her, and her crew massacred, Ben Joyce would become master of the seas.But it pleased God to prevent the accomplishment of these terrible projects.

zh: “艾尔顿到达墨尔本后，将信交给大副汤姆·奥斯汀，他看完信后马上起航，可是令艾尔顿愤怒和失望的是，第二天他发现大副没有乘着船去澳大利亚的东海岸——吐福湾，而是去了新西兰的东岸。他想要阻止他，但是奥斯汀让他看了一下信！事实上，由于法国地理学家神助的错误，上面提到的新西兰东岸才是目的地。
en: “Ayrton, arrived at Melbourne, delivered the letter to the mate, Tom Austin, who read it and immediately set sail, but judge of Ayrton’s rage and disappointment, when the next day he found that the mate was taking the vessel, not to the east coast of Australia, to Twofold Bay, but to the east coast of New Zealand.He wished to stop him, but Austin showed him the letter!...And indeed, by a providential error of the French geographer, who had written the letter, the east coast of New Zealand was mentioned as the place of destination.

zh: “艾尔顿所有的计划都变成了泡影！他变得狂怒起来。他们给他戴上了铁铐。他们又把他带到了新西兰海岸，他不知道他的同犯的结果会怎样，也不知道格里那凡爵士的结果会怎样。
en: “All Ayrton’s plans were frustrated!He became outrageous.They put him in irons.He was then taken to the coast of New Zealand, not knowing what would become of his accomplices, or what would become of Lord Glenarvan.

zh: “‘邓肯’号在海岸边一直行驶着，直到3月3日。当天，艾尔顿就听到了炮声。原来是‘邓肯’号开的炮，很快格里那凡爵士和同伴们又回到了船上。
en: “The ‘Duncan’ cruised about on this coast until the 3rd of March.On that day Ayrton heard the report of guns.The guns on the ‘Duncan’ were being fired, and soon Lord Glenarvan and his companions came on board.

zh: “这就是事情的经过。
en: “This is what had happened.

zh: “经历了千难万险后，格里那凡爵士终于完成了旅程，到达了澳大利亚东海岸的吐福湾。他给墨尔本打了个电报，说‘邓肯’号不在此地！回电说：‘邓肯号18号立即起航。目的地不详。’
en: “After a thousand hardships, a thousand dangers, Lord Glenarvan had accomplished his journey, and arrived on the east coast of Australia, at Twofold Bay.‘Not “Duncan!”’ He telegraphed to Melbourne.They answered, ‘“Duncan” sailed on the 18th instant.Destination unknown.’

zh: “格里那凡爵士只有一个结果，这艘真正的游艇已经落入了本·乔伊斯的手中，并且成了一只海盗船！
en: “Lord Glenarvan could only arrive at one conclusion; that his honest yacht had fallen into the hands of Ben Joyce, and had become a pirate vessel!

zh: “但是，格里那凡爵士不会放弃。他很勇敢，而且很慷慨。他登上一艘商船，驶向新西兰西海岸，沿着37度纬线行驶，却没有发现格兰特船长的任何踪迹。不过，让他吃惊的是，可能是神的旨意，他竟然在东岸找到了‘邓肯’号，由大副掌控，他已经在那儿等了他五个星期了！
en: “However, Lord Glenarvan would not give up.He was a bold and generous man.He embarked in a merchant vessel, sailed to the west coast of New Zealand, traversed it along the thirty-seventh parallel, without finding any trace of Captain Grant; but on the other side, to his great surprise, and by the will of Heaven, he found the ‘Duncan,’ under command of the mate, who had been waiting for him for five weeks!

zh: “这天是1855年3月3日。格里那凡爵士现在就在船上，但艾尔顿也在上面。他站在贵族的面前，想要从这个恶棍嘴中得到他所知道的格兰特船长的一切情况。艾尔顿拒绝说话。格里那凡爵士又告诉他，进入第一个港口后，他就会将他交给英国当局。艾尔顿还是保持沉默。
en: “This was on the 3rd of March, 1855.Lord Glenarvan was now on board the ‘Duncan,’ but Ayrton was there also.He appeared before the nobleman, who wished to extract from him all that the villain knew about Captain Grant.Ayrton refused to speak.Lord Glenarvan then told him, that at the first port they put into, he would be delivered up to the English authorities.Ayrton remained mute.

zh: “‘邓肯’号继续沿着南纬37度行驶。同时，格里那凡夫人承担了击退恶棍的抵抗的任务。
en: “The ‘Duncan’ continued her voyage along the thirty-seventh parallel.In the meanwhile, Lady Glenarvan undertook to vanquish the resistance of the ruffian.

zh: “最后，她的影响起作用了，不过，艾尔顿向她提出了交代实情的交换条件，就是格里那凡爵士可以把他留在太平洋的某个岛上，而不能把他交给英国当局。格里那凡爵士决定不惜任何代价获得船长的信息，于是就同意了。
en: “At last, her influence prevailed, and Ayrton, in exchange for what he could tell, proposed that Lord Glenarvan should leave him on some island in the Pacific, instead of giving him up to the English authorities.Lord Glenarvan, resolving to do anything to obtain information about Captain Grant, consented.

zh: “于是艾尔顿就讲述了他的所有生活，可以确定的是，自从格兰特船长将他留在澳大利亚海岸上的那一天起，他就什么也不知道了。
en: “Ayrton then related all his life, and it was certain that he knew nothing from the day on which Captain Grant had landed him on the Australian coast.

zh: “不过，格里那凡爵士信守了他给出的承诺。‘邓肯’号继续航行，之后到达了达抱岛。那也就是艾尔顿登陆的地方，也就是在那个地方，他们找到了格兰特船长和另外两个水手，正好是在南纬37度上，这真是个奇迹。
en: “Nevertheless, Lord Glenarvan kept the promise which he had given.The ‘Duncan’ continued her voyage and arrived at Tabor Island.It was there that Ayrton was to be landed, and it was there also that, by a veritable miracle, they found Captain Grant and two men, exactly on the thirty-seventh parallel.

zh: “于是，这个囚犯就取代了他们在这个遗弃的小岛上的位置，当他离开游船的时候，格里那凡爵士说：
en: “The convict, then, went to take their place on this desert islet, and at the moment he left the yacht these words were pronounced by Lord Glenarvan:—

zh: “在这里，艾尔顿，你将远离所有的陆地，也不可能和人类联系。‘邓肯’号将你丢在这个小岛上，你是不可能逃出的。你将独自在这里，在上帝的眼睛之下，他会看到你的内心深处，但是你不会失踪，也不会被忘记，就像格兰特船长一样。你不值得被人们记住，然而人们会记得你的。我知道你在哪里，艾尔顿，我也知道到哪里找到你。我永远不会忘记这件事的！
en: “Here, Ayrton, you will be far from any land, and without any possible communication with your fellow-creatures.You can-not escape from this islet on which the ‘Duncan’ leaves you.You will be alone, under the eye of a God who reads the depths of the heart, but you will be neither lost nor forgotten, as was Captain Grant.Unworthy as you are to be remembered by men, men will remember you.I know where you are Ayrton, and I know where to find you.I will never forget it!

zh: “‘邓肯’号扬起帆，很快就消失了。时间是1855年3月18日。
en: “And the ‘Duncan,’ making sail, soon disappeared.This was 18th of March, 1855.

zh: （我简要讲述的故事出自《格兰特船长的孩子们》，这本著作肯定有些读者读过。他们会注意到我讲述的某些日期与书中不符，不过，以后他们会明白我为什么不在一开始就说出真正的日期。）
en: (The events which have just been briefly related are taken from a work which some of our readers have no doubt read, and which is entitled, “Captain Grant’s children.”They will remark on this occasion, as well as later, some discrepancy in the dates; but later again, they will understand why the real dates were not at first given.)

zh: “艾尔顿是独自一人，但是他不缺少弹药、武器、工具和种子。
en: “Ayrton was alone, but he had no want of either ammunition, weapons, tools, or seeds.

zh: “囚犯拥有的这个房子，是老实的格兰特船长建造的。他只能生活在孤独中，来赎清他所犯下的罪行。
en: “At his, the convict’s disposal, was the house built by honest Captain Grant.He had only to live and expiate in solitude the crimes which he had committed.

zh: “绅士们，他忏悔了，他为自己犯下的罪恶感到羞愧，也很痛苦！他对自己说，如果某天有人将他从这个小岛带走，他也必须配得上和他们一同返回！这个可怜的人经受了怎样的痛苦啊！他是怎样通过努力工作来稳定情绪的！他是怎么通过祈祷来改造自己的！两年、三年就这样继续着，但是，艾尔顿因孤独而自卑，他经常期待着有船只出现在地平线上，并问自己赎罪的时间是否很快就结束了，他承受了别人没有承受过的痛苦！啊！对于一颗被悔恨苦苦折磨的心来说，这种孤独是多么可怕！
en: “Gentlemen, he repented, he was ashamed of his crimes and was very miserable!He said to himself, that if men came some day to take him from that islet, he must be worthy to return among them!How he suffered, that wretched man!How he labored to recover himself by work!How he prayed to be reformed by prayer!For two years, three years, this went on, but Ayrton, humbled by solitude, always looking for some ship to appear on the horizon, asking himself if the time of expiation would soon be complete, suffered as none other suffered!Oh! how dreadful was this solitude, to a heart tormented by remorse!

zh: “不过，毫无疑问的是，老天对这个不幸的人的惩罚还不够，因为他感觉到自己渐渐变成了一个野人！他感觉到自己慢慢地养成了野性！
en: “But doubtless Heaven had not sufficiently punished this unhappy man, for he felt that he was gradually becoming a savage!He felt that brutishness was gradually gaining on him!

zh: “他说不出是否是两三年的孤独让他变成这样的，不过，他最后还是变成了你找到的这个可怜家伙！
en: “He could not say if it was after two or three years of solitude, but at last he became the miserable creature you found!

zh: “我不说你们也知道了，绅士们，我就是本·乔伊斯。”
en: “I have no need to tell you, gentlemen, that Ayrton, Ben Joyce, and I, are the same.”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和同伴在他讲完后站了起来。他们受感动的程度无法用语言形容！展现在他们面前的是多么大的痛苦、忧伤和绝望啊！
en: Cyrus Harding and his companions rose at the end of this account.It is impossible to say how much they were moved!What misery, grief, and despair lay revealed before them!

zh: “艾尔顿，”哈丁站起来说，“你曾经是个罪孽深重的人，可是老天肯定认为你已经赎罪了！你被再次带到人类同胞中间，就证明了这一点。艾尔顿，你已经得到了宽恕！现在，你愿意成为我们的同伴吗？”
en: “Ayrton,” said Harding, rising, “you have been a great criminal, but Heaven must certainly think that you have expiated your crimes!That has been proved by your having been brought again among your fellow-creatures.Ayrton, you are forgiven!And now you will be our companion?”

zh: 艾尔顿后退了几步。
en: Ayrton drew back.

zh: “让我们握握手吧！”工程师说。
en: “Here is my hand!” said the engineer.

zh: 艾尔顿抓住哈丁伸向他的手，眼泪夺眶而出。
en: Ayrton grasped the hand which Harding extended to him, and great tears fell from his eyes.

zh: “你愿意和我们住一起吗？”赛勒斯·哈丁问。
en: “Will you live with us?” asked Cyrus Harding.

zh: “哈丁船长，让我再独处一段时间吧，”艾尔顿回答，“让我独自住在畜栏的小屋里吧！”
en: “Captain Harding, leave me some time longer,” replied Ayrton, “leave me alone in the hut in the corral!”

zh: “随你便，艾尔顿。”赛勒斯·哈丁回答。艾尔顿正要离开，工程师又问了他一个问题：
en: “As you like, Ayrton,” answered Cyrus Harding.Ayrton was going to withdraw, when the engineer addressed one more question to him:—

zh: “还有一句话，我的朋友。既然你想一个人住这里，那为什么你又将纸条扔进大海，让我们按照你的踪迹寻找呢？”
en: “One word more, my friend.Since it was your intention to live alone, why did you throw into the sea the document which put us on your track?”

zh: “纸条？”艾尔顿重复说，他似乎不知道哈丁说的意思。
en: “A document?” repeated Ayrton, who did not appear to know what he meant.

zh: “是的，我们找到一张封在瓶里的纸条，上面写着达抱岛的精确位置！”
en: “Yes, the document which we found enclosed in a bottle, giving us the exact position of Tabor Island!”

zh: 艾尔顿将手放在额头上想了一会儿，然后说；“我从来没有把什么纸条扔进大海里！”他回答。
en: Ayrton passed his hand over his brow, then after having thought, “I never threw any document into the sea!” he answered.

zh: “从来没有？”潘克洛夫喊道。
en: “Never?” exclaimed Pencroft.

zh: “从来没有！”
en: “Never!”

zh: 艾尔顿鞠了一躬，走到门口，然后离开了。
en: And Ayrton, bowing, reached the door and departed.

zh: 第十八章
en: Chapter 18

zh: 赫伯特冲到门口，看见艾尔顿拉动升降机的绳子，消失在黑暗中，他回到屋里，叫了一声：“可怜的人！”
en: “Poor man!” said Herbert, who had rushed to the door, but returned, having seen Ayrton slide down the rope on the lift and disappear in the darkness.

zh: “他会回来的。”赛勒斯·哈丁说。
en: “He will come back,” said Cyrus Harding.

zh: “现在过来，上尉，”潘克洛夫喊道，“这是怎么回事呢？怎么！难道不是艾尔顿把瓶子丢进大海的吗？那究竟是谁干的呢？”
en: “Come, now, captain,” exclaimed Pencroft, “what does that mean?What! wasn’t it Ayrton who threw that bottle into the sea?Who was it then?”

zh: 不错，如果必须提个问题，那就是这一个。
en: Certainly, if ever a question was necessary to be made, it was that one!

zh: “是他扔的，”纳布答道，“只是这个不幸的人当时处在半疯状态。”
en: “It was he,” answered Neb, “only the unhappy man was half-mad.”

zh: “是的！”赫伯特说，“他已经意识不到自己都干过些什么了。”
en: “Yes!” said Herbert, “and he was no longer conscious of what he was doing.”

zh: “这个问题只能这样解释，朋友们，”哈丁立刻回答说，“现在我才明白艾尔顿怎么能够准确地指出达抱岛的位置，原来在他被留在岛上之前发生的事情使他知道这一切。”
en: “It can only be explained in that way, my friends,” replied Harding quickly, “and I understand now how Ayrton was able to point out exactly the situation of Tabor Island, since the events which had preceded his being left on the island had made it known to him.”

zh: “但是，”潘克洛夫指出，“如果他写纸条时还没有变成野蛮人，又如果纸条是他在七八年前扔进大海的，那它怎么会没因潮湿而损坏呢？”
en: “However,” observed Pencroft, “if he was not yet a brute when he wrote that document, and if he threw it into the sea seven or eight years ago, how is it that the paper has not been injured by damp?”

zh: “这表明，”赛勒斯·史哈丁答道，“艾尔顿只是最近才丧失理智的，可他自己却认为很早就这样了。”
en: “That proves,” answered Cyrus Harding, “that Ayrton was deprived of intelligence at a more recent time than he thinks.”

zh: “当然应该是这样，”潘克洛夫说，“不然事情就没法解释了。”
en: “Of course it must be so,” replied Pencroft, “without that the fact would be unaccountable.”

zh: “确实没法解释。”工程师回答说，他似乎不想再继续谈下去了。
en: “Unaccountable indeed,” answered the engineer, who did not appear desirous to prolong the conversation.

zh: “不过，艾尔顿说了实话吗？”水手问道。
en: “But has Ayrton told the truth?” asked the sailor.

zh: “是的，”记者回答说，“他讲的故事完全是真实的。当时报纸对格里那凡爵士负责的游艇远航以及远航结果的报道，我记得很清楚。”
en: “Yes,” replied the reporter.“The story which he has told is true in every point.I remember quite well the account in the newspapers of the yacht expedition undertaken by Lord Glenarvan, and its result.”

zh: “艾尔顿说的是实话，”哈丁补充道，“不要对此怀疑，潘克洛夫，这对他来说很痛苦。一个人能这样指责自己，说的肯定是实话！”
en: “Ayrton has told the truth,” added Harding.“Do not doubt it, Pencroft, for it was painful to him.People tell the truth when they accuse themselves like that!”

zh: 翌日，12月21日，开拓者们下到海滩，爬上高地，发现艾尔顿并不在那里。他昨天夜里才回到了畜栏的屋子里，居民们觉得最好还是不要去打扰他。同情无法做到的事，时间一定能做到。
en: The next day—the 21st of December—the colonists descended to the beach, and having climbed the plateau they found nothing of Ayrton.He had reached his house in the corral during the night and the settlers judged it best not to agitate him by their presence.Time would doubtless perform what sympathy had been unable to accomplish.

zh: 于是赫伯特、潘克洛夫和纳布重新做起了他们平日的工作。这一天，由于哈丁和记者要做同样的事情，所以呆在“石窟”的工场里。
en: Herbert, Pencroft, and Neb resumed their ordinary occupations.On this day the same work brought Harding and the reporter to the workshop at the Chimneys.

zh: “你知道吗？亲爱的赛勒斯，”吉丁·史佩莱说，“昨天你所作的关于瓶子的解释，根本无法使我满意！怎么可以认为这个不幸的人写了纸条，把瓶子扔进海里，自己却一点也不记得呢？”
en: “Do you know, my dear Cyrus,” said Gideon Spilett, “that the explanation you gave yesterday on the subject of the bottle has not satisfied me at all!How can it be supposed that the unfortunate man was able to write that document and throw the bottle into the sea without having the slightest recollection of it?”

zh: “所以也不是他把瓶子扔进海里的，亲爱的史佩莱。”
en: “Nor was it he who threw it in, my dear Spilett.”

zh: “那么，你认为——”　　“我什么也不认为，什么也不知道！”赛勒斯·哈丁打断他说，“我只能把这件事算到那些至今还无法解释的事情中去！”
en: “You think then—”“I think nothing, I know nothing!” interrupted Cyrus Harding.“I am content to rank this incident among those which I have not been able to explain to this day!”

zh: “说实在的，赛勒斯，”史佩莱说，“这些事情太不可思议了！你的获救，沙滩上搁浅的箱子，托普的冒险经历，最后还有这只瓶子……难道我们永远都无法得到这些谜团的答案吗？”
en: “Indeed, Cyrus,” said Spilett, “these things are incredible!Your rescue, the case stranded on the sand, Top’s adventure, and lastly this bottle...Shall we never have the answer to these enigmas?”

zh: “不会的！”工程师很快地答道，“不会，即使要深入小岛的内部！”
en: “Yes!” replied the engineer quickly, “yes, even if I have to penetrate into the bowels of this island!”

zh: “也许机遇会给我们提供打开这个秘密的钥匙！”
en: “Chance will perhaps give us the key to this mystery!”

zh: “机遇！史佩莱！我不相信机遇，也不相信这世界上有什么神秘的事。这里发生的每一件不可思议的事都有原因，我一定要找出这些原因。不过同时，我们需要工作、观察。”
en: “Chance!Spilett!I do not believe in chance, any more than I believe in mysteries in this world.There is a reason for everything unaccountable which has happened here, and that reason I shall discover.But in the meantime we must work and observe.”

zh: 一月来临了。1867年也就开始了。大家继续辛勤地进行着夏季的工作。接连好几天，赫伯特和史佩莱都去畜栏劳动，确定艾尔顿已经在为他准备好的房子里住下来了。他忙着照料那些托付给他的大量畜群，这样，同伴们就不必三天两头地跑去畜栏了。不过，为了不让艾尔顿长久孤寂，居民们还是经常去看望他。
en: The month of January arrived.The year 1867 commenced.The summer occupations were assiduously continued.During the days which followed, Herbert and Spilett having gone in the direction of the corral, ascertained that Ayrton had taken possession of the habitation which had been prepared for him.He busied himself with the numerous flock confided to his care, and spared his companions the trouble of coming every two or three days to visit the corral.Nevertheless, in order not to leave Ayrton in solitude for too long a time, the settlers often paid him a visit.

zh: 由于工程师和吉丁·史佩莱还心存疑虑，因此海岛的这部分地区必须有一个人监视着，这也相当重要。如果任何事情意外发生，艾尔顿都不能忽视，要通知花岗石宫里的居民们。
en: It was not unimportant either, in consequence of some suspicions entertained by the engineer and Gideon Spilett, that this part of the island should be subject to a surveillance of some sort, and that Ayrton, if any incident occurred unexpectedly, should not neglect to inform the inhabitants of Granite House of it.

zh: 然而，有时会有突发事件发生，并且需要迅速报告给工程师。除了跟林肯岛上神秘事件有关的事实之外，还有许多其他情形也需要居民们立刻解决，比如发现船只经过、西海岸有船只遇难，以及可能出现的海盗登陆等。
en: Nevertheless it might happen that something would occur which it would be necessary to bring rapidly to the engineer’s knowledge.Independently of facts bearing on the mystery of Lincoln Island, many others might happen, which would call for the prompt interference of the colonists,—such as the sighting of a vessel, a wreck on the western coast, the possible arrival of pirates, etc.

zh: 因此，赛勒斯·哈丁决定要让畜栏和花岗岩宫之间能时刻保持联系。
en: Therefore Cyrus Harding resolved to put the corral in instantaneous communication with Granite House.

zh: 1月10号这一天，他把自己的计划告诉了伙伴们。
en: It was on the 10th of January that he made known his project to his companions.

zh: “什么！你打算怎么做呢，上尉？”潘克洛夫问道，“你不会突然想到安装一台电报机吧？”
en: “Why! how are you going to manage that, captain?” asked Pencroft.“Do you by chance happen to think of establishing a telegraph?”

zh: “我正是这么想的。”工程师回答说。
en: “Exactly so,” answered the engineer.

zh: “用电的吗？”赫伯特大声问。
en: “Electric?” cried Herbert.

zh: “用电的，”赛勒斯·哈丁答道，“我们有制造电池所需的所有材料，最难办的就是拉伸铁丝，不过我想，用一台拉模板就可以做成。”
en: “Electric,” replied Cyrus Harding.“We have all the necessary materials for making a battery, and the most difficult thing will be to stretch the wires, but by means of a drawplate I think we shall manage it.”

zh: “好啊，这样一来，”水手接着说，“我将绝不会对我们有一天能坐上火车失去希望！”
en: “Well, after that,” returned the sailor, “I shall never despair of seeing ourselves some day rolling along on a railway!”

zh: 于是大家开始工作，他们从最困难的事情着手，倘若不能成功，也就不必再制造电池和其他附件了。
en: They then set to work, beginning with the most difficult thing, for, if they failed in that, it would be useless to manufacture the battery and other accessories.

zh: 前面已经说过，林肯岛的铁质十分优良，因而非常适合用来拉制铁丝。哈丁先制作了一个拉模板，也就是一块钢板，上面刺有大小不一的圆锥形洞孔，一个个洞可以使铁丝逐渐达到所要求的韧性。工程师打算利用瀑布作为动力，所以就在离大瀑布只有几英尺的地上埋下一个结实的架子，然后把淬过火的钢板用稳固的方法固定在架子上。事实上，缩绒机也在那里，尽管现在并没有投入使用，只要有强大的力量推动它的主轴，就可以把铁丝卷在上面，用来拉伸铁丝。这是一项细致的工作，必须非常细心。居民们事先把铁做成又长又细的铁棍，两端用锉刀锉尖，然后把铁棍插入拉模板最大的洞里，再用主轴一边卷一边拉成25到30英尺的长度，松开后，依次在较小的洞孔里重复同样的操作。最后，工程师得到了长度为40到50英尺的铁丝，把这些铁丝拴紧，就可以很容易地铺设在畜栏和花岗石宫边缘之间五英里的距离上。
en: The iron of Lincoln Island, as has been said, was of excellent quality, and consequently very fit for being drawn out.Harding commenced by manufacturing a drawplate, that is to say, a plate of steel, pierced with conical holes of different sizes, which would successively bring the wire to the wished-for tenacity.This piece of steel, after having been tempered, was fixed in as firm a way as possible in a solid framework planted in the ground, only a few feet from the great fall, the motive power of which the engineer intended to utilize.In fact as the fulling-mill was there, although not then in use, its beam moved with extreme power would serve to stretch out the wire by rolling it round itself.It was a delicate operation, and required much care.The iron, prepared previously in long thin rods, the ends of which were sharpened with the file, having been introduced into the largest hole of the drawplate, was drawn out by the beam which wound it round itself, to a length of twenty-five or thirty feet, then unrolled, and the same operation was performed successively through the holes of a less size.Finally, the engineer obtained wires from forty to fifty feet long, which could be easily fastened together and stretched over the distance of five miles, which separated the corral from the bounds of Granite House.

zh: 这项工作几天就完成了，事实上，安装好了机械以后，赛勒斯·哈丁就让伙伴们去拉铁丝，而他自己则忙着去制造电池了。
en: It did not take more than a few days to perform this work, and indeed as soon as the machine had been commenced, Cyrus Harding left his companions to follow the trade of wiredrawers, and occupied himself with manufacturing his battery.

zh: 在当前的情况下，需要制造一种恒流电池。大家知道，现代电池通常由炭精、锌和铜做成。工程师一点铜也没有，尽管他寻遍了林肯岛，也没能找到铜的一丝踪迹，因此只能不用它了。炭精就是煤气厂里的煤脱氢后，在蒸馏器里留下坚硬石墨，就可以得到了，不过还需要建一种特殊设备，这要花大力气。至于锌，大家可能会想起在遗物角捡到的那只箱子，箱子里面就衬着这种金属，现在派上这种用场再合适不过了。
en: It was necessary to obtain a battery with a constant current.It is known that the elements of modern batteries are generally composed of retort coal, zinc, and copper.Copper was absolutely wanting to the engineer, who, notwithstanding all his researches, had never been able to find any trace of it in Lincoln Island, and was therefore obliged to do without it.Retort coal, that is to say, the hard graphite which is found in the retorts of gas manufactories, after the coal has been dehydrogenized, could have been obtained, but it would have been necessary to establish a special apparatus, involving great labor.As to zinc, it may be remembered that the case found at Flotsam Point was lined with this metal, which could not be better utilized than for this purpose.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁经过一番深思熟虑，决定制作一种非常简单的电池，这种只用锌作原材料的电池，与贝克雷尔在1820年发明的电池相仿。其他材料，如硝酸和钾碱，工程师手头上就有。
en: Cyrus Harding, after mature consideration, decided to manufacture a very simple battery, resembling as nearly as possible that invented by Becquerel in 1820, and in which zinc only is employed.The other substances, azotic acid and potash, were all at his disposal.

zh: 这种电池是通过硝酸和钾碱相互作用而成，具体步骤如下：制作一定数量的玻璃瓶，装上硝酸。工程师用塞子堵住瓶口，一根玻璃管子穿过瓶塞通到瓶子底部，通过用布包好的黏土，玻璃管浸入硝酸里。工程师事先把各种植物烧成灰烬，提取钾碱溶液，然后将该溶液从管子上端倒入，这样，硝酸和钾碱就可以通过黏土相互作用。　　之后，赛勒斯·哈丁取出两个锌片，一片浸入硝酸中，另一片放入钾碱溶液里。这两片锌片之间用一根金属线连接起来，立刻产生了一股电流，电流从瓶子里的锌片传到管子里的锌片。这样，管子里的锌片就成了电池的正极，而瓶子里的锌片则成为电池的负极。因此，把每个瓶子产生的电流集中起来，就足够用来运行电报机了。这就是赛勒斯·哈丁制造的巧妙而简单的设备，它可以使花岗石宫和畜栏之间建立起电报通讯。
en: The way in which the battery was composed was as follows, and the results were to be attained by the reaction of acid and potash on each other.A number of glass bottles were made and filled with azotic acid.The engineer corked them by means of a stopper through which passed a glass tube, bored at its lower extremity, and intended to be plunged into the acid by means of a clay stopper secured by a rag.Into this tube, through its upper extremity, he poured a solution of potash, previously obtained by burning and reducing to ashes various plants, and in this way the acid and potash could act on each other through the clay.Cyrus Harding then took two slips of zinc, one of which was plunged into azotic acid, the other into a solution of potash.A current was immediately produced, which was transmitted from the slip of zinc in the bottle to that in the tube, and the two slips having been connected by a metallic wire the slip in the tube became the positive pole, and that in the bottle the negative pole of the apparatus.Each bottle, therefore, produced as many currents as united would be sufficient to produce all the phenomena of the electric telegraph.Such was the ingenious and very simple apparatus constructed by Cyrus Harding, an apparatus which would allow them to establish a telegraphic communication between Granite House and the corral.

zh: 居民们从2月6日开始，在通往畜栏的路上竖电线杆，电线杆上都装有玻璃绝缘体，用来支撑电线。几天以后，电线拉好了，电流的传输速度可达每秒两万英里。
en: On the 6th of February was commenced the planting along the road to the corral, of posts furnished with glass insulators, and intended to support the wire.A few days after, the wire was extended, ready to produce the electric current at a rate of twenty thousand miles a second.

zh: 工程师制造了两套电池，一套放在花岗石宫，另一套放在畜栏。因为畜栏有必要和花岗石宫通讯，同样，花岗石宫和畜栏通讯也是有用的。
en: Two batteries had been manufactured, one for Granite House, the other for the corral; for if it was necessary the corral should be able to communicate with Granite House it might also be useful that Granite House should be able to communicate with the corral.

zh: 至于收报机和发报机，制造起来很简单。在花岗石宫和畜栏，电线缠绕在一块磁铁上，即缠在一块绕有线圈的软铁上。这样，两个站点之间就建立通讯了，电流从正极出发，通过电线，经过磁铁时，磁铁暂时磁化，然后电流从地下流回负极。电流一旦中断，磁铁就会立刻失去磁性。只要在磁铁的前面放置一片软铁，电流通过时就会吸住它，而电流中断时，它就会掉下来。铁片的运转成功后，哈丁很容易地就能将它安在一个圆盘的指针上，圆盘上标有字母，这样，两地之间就可以联系了。
en: As to the receiver and manipulator, they were very simple.At the two stations the wire was wound round a magnet, that is to say, round a piece of soft iron surrounded with a wire.The communication was thus established between the two poles; the current, starting from the positive pole, traversed the wire, passed through the magnet which was temporarily magnetized, and returned through the earth to the negative pole.If the current was interrupted, the magnet immediately became unmagnetized.It was sufficient to place a plate of soft iron before the magnet, which, attracted during the passage of the current, would fall back when the current was interrupted.This movement of the plate thus obtained, Harding could easily fasten to it a needle arranged on a dial, bearing the letters of the alphabet, and in this way communicate from one station to the other.

zh: 2月12日，一切工作都完成了。这天，哈丁通过电线发送电流，问畜栏那边是否一切正常，过了一会儿，就从艾尔顿那里收到了令人满意的答复。潘克洛夫欣喜若狂，从此，他每天早晚都发电报去畜栏，往往都能收到回电。
en: All was completely arranged by the 12th of February.On this day, Harding, having sent the current through the wire, asked if all was going on well at the corral, and received in a few moments a satisfactory reply from Ayrton.Pencroft was wild with joy, and every morning and evening he sent a telegram to the corral, which always received an answer.

zh: 这种通讯方式有两个实在的好处：第一，他们可以确认艾尔顿是否在畜栏；第二，艾尔顿就不至于完全孤单了。此外，赛勒斯·哈丁还是每星期都去看他，艾尔顿也时不时地来花岗石宫，每次他来，都受到热烈的欢迎。
en: This mode of communication presented two very real advantages: firstly, because it enabled them to ascertain that Ayrton was at the corral; and secondly, that he was thus not left completely isolated.Besides, Cyrus Harding never allowed a week to pass without going to see him, and Ayrton came from time to time to Granite House, where he always found a cordial welcome.

zh: 美好的季节就在日常工作中过去了。开拓队的资源，特别是蔬菜和粮食，一天天地增多，从达抱岛带回来的植物也都完全种活了。
en: The fine season passed away in the midst of the usual work.The resources of the colony, particularly in vegetables and corn, increased from day to day, and the plants brought from Tabor Island had succeeded perfectly.

zh: 眺望岗的高地上也呈现出一派令人鼓舞的景象。第四次收割又是一次大丰收，想必没有人会去计算收割下来的麦粒有没有四千亿粒了。虽然潘克洛夫曾打算这么干，但是工程师告诉他，即使一分钟能数三百粒，一个小时能数到九千，那也几乎要花上5500年才能完成这项工作，老实的水手想了想，觉得最好还是放弃这个想法。
en: The plateau of Prospect Heights presented an encouraging aspect.The fourth harvest had been admirable and it may be supposed that no one thought of counting whether the four hundred thousand millions of grains duly appeared in the crop.However, Pencroft had thought of doing so, but Cyrus Harding having told him that even if he managed to count three hundred grains a minute, or nine thousand an hour, it would take him nearly five thousand five-hundred years to finish his task, the honest sailor considered it best to give up the idea.

zh: 天气很好，白天气温高，可到了晚上，海面上吹来的微风调和了大气中的热量，为花岗石宫的居民提供了凉爽的夜晚。在此期间，也有几场暴风雨，虽然持续时间不长，但来势异常迅猛，席卷了整个林肯岛。一连好几个小时，闪电不断，雷声不绝于耳。
en: The weather was splendid, the temperature very warm in the day time, but in the evening the sea-breezes tempered the heat of the atmosphere and procured cool nights for the inhabitants of Granite House.There were, however, a few storms, which, although they were not of long duration, swept over Lincoln Island with extraordinary fury.The lightning blazed and the thunder continued to roll for some hours.

zh: 这一时期，这块小小的开拓地非常兴旺。
en: At this period the little colony was extremely prosperous.

zh: 家禽场里的家禽迅速繁殖，居民们就以过剩的家禽为食，但还是有必要把家禽的数量减少到适度的水平。猪已经下崽了，不难理解，为了照料它们，纳布和潘克洛夫花了大量时间。那对野驴也生了两头漂亮的小驴，赫伯特在吉丁·史佩莱的指导下，成了优秀的骑手，他们两人经常骑着野驴出门，他们也把野驴套在车上，有时往花岗石宫运送木柴和煤炭，有时运送工程师所需要的各种矿产。
en: The tenants of the poultry-yard swarmed, and they lived on the surplus, but it became necessary to reduce the population to a more moderate number.The pigs had already produced young, and it may be understood that their care for these animals absorbed a great part of Neb and Pencroft’s time.The onagers, who had two pretty colts, were most often mounted by Gideon Spilett and Herbert, who had become an excellent rider under the reporter’s instruction, and they also harnessed them to the cart either for carrying wood and coal to Granite House, or different mineral productions required by the engineer.

zh: 在这期间，他们深入远西森林，进行了几次探险。探险者们去那里探险，不用担心酷热，因为阳光很难穿透他们头顶上浓密的枝叶。他们就这样造访了慈悲河的整个左岸，沿着这个河岸就是从畜栏通往瀑布河口的道路。
en: Several expeditions were made about this time into the depths of the Far West Forests.The explorers could venture there without having anything to fear from the heat, for the sun’s rays scarcely penetrated through the thick foliage spreading above their heads.They thus visited all the left bank of the Mercy, along which ran the road from the corral to the mouth of Falls River.

zh: 不过在这几次探险中，居民们总是小心谨慎，全副武装，因为他们好几次都碰上了野蛮、凶猛的野猪，而且还经常要和它们进行一番搏斗。在这个季节里，他们还和美洲豹进行过激烈的战斗。吉丁·史佩莱对美洲豹有特别的恨意，他的学生赫伯特的恨意仅次于他。由于他们都武装好了，也就不再惧怕碰上这种野兽了。赫伯特非常勇猛，而记者则惊人地冷静。20多张美丽的豹皮已经装饰了花岗石宫的餐厅，如果继续下去，林肯岛上的美洲豹很快就会绝种，而这正是猎手们追求的目标。
en: But in these excursions the settlers took care to be well armed, for they met with savage wild boars, with which they often had a tussle.They also, during this season, made fierce war against the jaguars.Gideon Spilett had vowed a special hatred against them, and his pupil Herbert seconded him well.Armed as they were, they no longer feared to meet one of those beasts.Herbert’s courage was superb, and the reporter’s sang-froid astonishing.Already twenty magnificent skins ornamented the dining-room of Granite House, and if this continued, the jaguar race would soon be extinct in the island, the object aimed at by the hunters.

zh: 有时候，工程师也参与远征，去岛上的未知区域，每到一处，他都非常仔细地观察。在这广袤森林的繁茂处，他搜寻的不是这些兽迹，而是看有没有其他的踪迹，但没有出现任何令人怀疑的东西。托普和贾普也陪他一起来到这里，它们的行为也表示这里没有什么奇怪的东西，不过托普倒是不止一次地朝井口吠个不停，工程师曾下井勘探过，并没有什么结果。
en: The engineer sometimes took part in the expeditions made to the unknown parts of the island, which he surveyed with great attention.It was for other traces than those of animals that he searched the thickets of the vast forest, but nothing suspicious ever appeared.Neither Top nor Jup, who accompanied him, ever betrayed by their behavior that there was anything strange there, and yet more than once again the dog barked at the mouth of the well, which the engineer had before explored without result.

zh: 这期间，吉丁·史佩莱在赫伯特的协助下，用在大箱子里找到的摄影装置，在岛上风景最美的地方拍了好几张照片，在此之前，还未曾使用过它。
en: At this time Gideon Spilett, aided by Herbert, took several views of the most picturesque parts of the island, by means of the photographic apparatus found in the cases, and of which they had not as yet made any use.

zh: 这个装置十分完整，物镜也很强大。印相片所需要的器材有：涂玻璃感光片的火棉胶，使它能够感光的硝酸银，定影用的亚硝酸钠，浸印能产生正片校样的相纸的氯化铵，以及用于浸相纸的醋酸钠和氯化金，一样都不缺。甚至连印相纸也有，一切都准备好了，在把底片放进印相框之前，只需要把印相纸放在硝酸银的溶液里浸泡几分钟。
en: This apparatus, provided with a powerful object-glass, was very complete.Substances necessary for the photographic reproduction, collodion for preparing the glass plate, nitrate of silver to render it sensitive, hyposulfate of soda to fix the prints obtained, chloride of ammonium in which to soak the paper destined to give the positive proof, acetate of soda and chloride of gold in which to immerse the paper, nothing was wanting.Even the papers were there, all prepared, and before laying in the printing-frame upon the negatives, it was sufficient to soak them for a few minutes in the solution of nitrate of silver.

zh: 记者和他的助手不久便成了非常熟练的摄影师，他们拍了一些漂亮的风景照，例如，以远处的富兰克林山为背景，从眺望岗上拍的林肯岛全景，慈悲河口如画般地被环绕在高高的岩石丛中，以山的支脉为背景的林间空地和畜栏，爪角和残骸角上奇特的地势，等等。
en: The reporter and his assistant became in a short time very skilful operators, and they obtained fine views of the country, such as the island, taken from Prospect Heights with Mount Franklin in the distance, the mouth of the Mercy, so picturesquely framed in high rocks, the glade and the corral, with the spurs of the mountain in the background, the curious development of Claw Cape, Flotsam Point, etc.

zh: 摄影师们也没有忘记给岛上所有的居民拍照，一个也没有落下。
en: Nor did the photographers forget to take the portraits of all the inhabitants of the island, leaving out no one.

zh: “我们大家都有份。”潘克洛夫说道。
en: “It multiplies us,” said Pencroft.

zh: 看见自己那张十分逼真的照片挂在花岗岩石的墙上，水手非常高兴，他不自觉地停在这个展览前面，仿佛驻足在百老汇挂件最多的商店橱窗前一样。
en: And the sailor was enchanted to see his own countenance, faithfully reproduced, ornamenting the walls of Granite House, and he stopped as willingly before this exhibition as he would have done before the richest shop-windows in Broadway.

zh: 然而必须承认，拍得最成功的一张照片，无疑要数贾普那张。贾普一本正经地坐着，庄重的神情难以描绘，照片简直和真的一样。
en: But it must be acknowledged that the most successful portrait was incontestably that of Master Jup.Master Jup had sat with a gravity not to be described, and his portrait was lifelike!

zh: “它看起来好像正要露齿而笑！”潘克洛夫叫道。
en: “He looks as if he was just going to grin!” exclaimed Pencroft.

zh: 如果贾普对此还不满意，那它就太难取悦了，不过它相当高兴，带着一丝深情端详着自己的照片，看上去有几分自负。
en: And if Master Jup had not been satisfied, he would have been very difficult to please; but he was quite contented and contemplated his own countenance with a sentimental air which expressed some small amount of conceit.

zh: 三月的到来终止了夏季的严热。有些时候下雨，但还是很温暖。这里的三月份相当于北半球的九月，天气并不如人们所期望的那么美好。也许这表明严寒的冬季会提前到来。
en: The summer heat ended with the month of March.The weather was sometimes rainy, but still warm.The month of March, which corresponds to the September of northern latitudes, was not so fine as might have been hoped.Perhaps it announced an early and rigorous winter.

zh: 21日早晨，大家几乎认为已经看到了初雪——它已经显露面貌了。事实上，赫伯特一大早从花岗岩石的一扇窗前往外望去，忽然大叫起来：
en: It might have been supposed one morning—the 21 st—that the first snow had already made its appearance.In fact Herbert looking early from one of the windows of Granite House, exclaimed,—

zh: “瞧啊！岛上覆盖着雪！”
en: “Hallo! the islet is covered with snow!”

zh: “这时候下雪？”记者一边问，一边向少年走去。
en: “Snow at this time?” answered the reporter, joining the boy.

zh: 不久伙伴们都走了过来，但他们只能肯定一点，那就是不仅是小岛，连花岗石宫下面的整个海滩，都盖着一层白雪。
en: Their companions were soon beside them, but could only ascertain one thing, that not only the islet but all the beach below Granite House was covered with one uniform sheet of white.

zh: “肯定是雪！”潘克洛夫说。
en: “It must be snow!” said Pencroft.

zh: “或确切地说，是像雪一样的东西！”纳布回应道。
en: “Or rather it’s very like it!” replied Neb.

zh: “可温度计上显示的是58度！”吉丁·史佩莱指出。
en: “But the thermometer marks fifty-eight degrees!” observed Gideon Spilett.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁一声不响地注视着这层白雪，在一年的这个时候，温度又这么高，他确实不知道该如何解释这个现象。
en: Cyrus Harding gazed at the sheet of white without saying anything, for he really did not know how to explain this phenomenon, at this time of year and in such a temperature.

zh: “天啊！”潘克洛夫叫了起来，“我们的庄稼都要冻死了！”
en: “By Jove!” exclaimed Pencroft, “all our plants will be frozen!”

zh: 水手正打算下去，敏捷的贾普已经抢在他前面，滑到沙滩上去了。
en: And the sailor was about to descend, when he was preceded by the nimble Jup, who slid down to the sand.

zh: 可是，猩猩还没有落地，大片的雪花飞扬起来，在空中化成无数的絮片，几分钟内把阳光也遮挡住了。
en: But the orang had not touched the ground, when the snowy sheet arose and dispersed in the air in such innumerable flakes that the light of the sun was obscured for some minutes.

zh: “是鸟！”赫伯特叫道。
en: “Birds!” cried Herbert.

zh: 原来真是大群的海鸟，浑身的羽毛洁白耀眼。成千上万只海鸟栖息在小岛和海岸上，直到它们消失在远方的时候，开拓者们很惊讶，好像他们置身在转换的情境中，在仙女的魔杖一触之下，冬天变成了夏天。只可惜这变化太突然了，记者和少年都没来得及打下一只这样的鸟来，因而也无法辨别鸟的种类。
en: They were indeed swarms of sea-birds, with dazzling white plumage.They had perched by thousands on the islet and on the shore, and they disappeared in the distance, leaving the colonists amazed as if they had been present at some transformation scene, in which summer succeeded winter at the touch of a fairy’s wand.Unfortunately the change had been so sudden, that neither the reporter nor the lad had been able to bring down one of these birds, of which they could not recognize the species.

zh: 几天后是3月26日，这些落难者从空中被抛到林肯岛已经整整两年了。
en: A few days after came the 26th of March, the day on which, two years before, the castaways from the air had been thrown upon Lincoln Island.

zh: 第十九章
en: Chapter 19

zh: 已经两年了！开拓者们已经两年没有和他们的同胞取得任何联系了！他们没有文明世界的消息，流落在这荒岛上，仿佛完全处在天上最微小的星球上。
en: Two years already! and for two years the colonists had had no communication with their fellow-creatures!They were without news from the civilized world, lost on this island, as completely as if they had been on the most minute star of the celestial hemisphere!

zh: 现在他们的祖国会发生什么事呢？故乡的情景常常浮现在他们眼前，当他们离开的时候，故乡正饱受内战之苦，也许南方的叛徒还在流着血呢！对他们来说，这是最痛心的事，他们经常谈论这些，但他们毫不怀疑，北军为美利坚合众国的荣誉而战的事业终将取得胜利。
en: What was now happening in their country?The picture of their native land was always before their eyes, the land torn by civil war at the time they left it, and which the Southern rebellion was perhaps still staining with blood!It was a great sorrow to them, and they often talked together of these things, without ever doubting however that the cause of the North must triumph, for the honor of the American Confederation.

zh: 在这两年里，他们从未见到过有船只驶过海岛，至少连帆影也没看见过。显然林肯岛不在通常的航线上，并且也没有人知道有这样一个岛——这一点可以从地图上得到证明——这里虽没有港口，船只也可能来这里补充淡水储备。一眼望去，林肯岛周围的海面上一片荒芜，开拓者们只能依靠自己重新回到祖国。
en: During these two years not a vessel had passed in sight of the island; or, at least, not a sail had been seen.It was evident that Lincoln Island was out of the usual track, and also that it was unknown,—as was besides proved by the maps,—for though there was no port, vessels might have visited it for the purpose of renewing their store of water.But the surrounding ocean was deserted as far as the eye could reach, and the colonists must rely on themselves for regaining their native land.

zh: 不过，还有一个得救的机会，在四月第一周的一天，开拓者们聚集在花岗石宫的餐厅里，讨论这个机会。
en: However, one chance of rescue existed, and this chance was discussed one day on the first week of April, when the colonists were gathered together in the dining-room of Granite House.

zh: 他们谈到了美国，谈起了故乡，觉得再看到故乡的希望很渺茫。
en: They had been talking of America, of their native country, which they had so little hope of ever seeing again.

zh: “毫无疑问，我们只有一个办法，”史佩莱说，“只有这个办法可以离开林肯岛，那就是造一艘足够大的船，可以在海上航行几百英里。依我看来，既然能造小船，造大船应该也不难！”
en: “Decidedly we have only one way, said Spilett, “one single way for leaving Lincoln Island, and that is, to build a vessel large enough to sail several hundred miles.It appears to me, that when one has built a boat it is just as easy to build a ship!”

zh: “有了大船，我们就可以去帕摩图群岛了，”赫伯特补充道，“就像我们去达抱岛一样容易。”
en: “And in which we might go to the Pomoutous,” added Herbert, “just as easily as we went to Tabor Island.”

zh: “我不反对，”潘克洛夫说，在有关航海的问题上，他总是起决定性的作用，“尽管近海航行和远洋航行不完全一样，但这件事我并不反对。在我们去达抱岛的途中，不管小船遇到多大的狂风，我们清楚海岸就在不远处，但1200海里可是一段相当长的航程，而离我们最近的陆地至少也有这样长的距离！”
en: “I do not say no,” replied Pencroft, who had always the casting vote in maritime questions; “I do not say no, although it is not exactly the same thing to make a long as a short voyage!If our little craft had been caught in any heavy gale of wind during the voyage to Tabor Island, we should have known that land was at no great distance either way; but twelve hundred miles is a pretty long way, and the nearest land is at least that distance!”

zh: “潘克洛夫，在这种情况下，你不想冒险吗？”记者问道。
en: “Would you not, in that case, Pencroft, attempt the adventure?” asked the reporter.

zh: “只要大家愿意，我可以尝试任何风险，史佩莱先生，”水手答道，“你们知道，我是个不会退缩的人！”
en: “I will attempt anything that is desired, Mr. Spilett,” answered the sailor, “and you know well that I am not a man to flinch!”

zh: “而且，别忘了，我们现在又多了一名水手。”纳布提醒道。
en: “Remember, besides, that we number another sailor amongst us now,” remarked Neb.

zh: “谁呀？”潘克洛夫问。
en: “Who is that?” asked Pencroft.

zh: “艾尔顿。”
en: “Ayrton.”

zh: “要是他愿意加入就好了。”潘克洛夫说。
en: “If he will consent to come,” said Pencroft.

zh: “废话！”记者接着说，“如果艾尔顿还住在达抱岛，格里那凡爵士的游艇开来了，你想他会拒绝离开吗？”
en: “Nonsense!” returned the reporter; “do you think that if Lord Glenarvan’s yacht had appeared at Tabor Island, while he was still living there, Ayrton would have refused to depart?”

zh: “朋友们，你们忘了，”此时赛勒斯·哈丁说道，“艾尔顿住在岛上的最后几年已丧失了理智。但问题不在那里。问题在于我们能不能把获救的希望放在苏格兰游船归来上。既然格里那凡爵士曾答应过艾尔顿，等到他认为赎清罪恶的时候，就会来接他离开达抱岛，那么我相信他会回来的。”
en: “You forget, my friends,” then said Cyrus Harding, “that Ayrton was not in possession of his reason during the last years of his stay there.But that is not the question.The point is to know if we may count among our chances of being rescued, the return of the Scotch vessel.Now, Lord Glenarvan promised Ayrton that he would return to take him off from Tabor Island when he considered that his crimes were expiated, and I believe that he will return.”

zh: “对，”记者说，“我还要补充一点，爵士很快就会回来，因为艾尔顿被丢弃在岛上已经12年了。”
en: “Yes,” said the reporter, “and I will add that he will return soon, for it is twelve years since Ayrton was abandoned.”

zh: “好！”潘克洛夫说，“我同意你说的，爵士会回来，而且很快就会来。但他的船会停靠在哪里呢？是达抱岛，而不是林肯岛。”
en: “Well!” answered Pencroft, “I agree with you that the nobleman will return, and soon too.But where will he touch?At Tabor Island, and not at Lincoln Island.”

zh: “这更可以肯定了，”赫伯特说，“因为地图上根本就没有标出林肯岛。”
en: “That is the more certain,” replied Herbert, “as Lincoln Island is not even marked on the map.”

zh: “所以，朋友们，”工程师说，“我们应该采取必要的预防措施，让达抱岛上的人知道我们和艾尔顿在林肯岛。”
en: “Therefore, my friends,” said the engineer, “we ought to take the necessary precautions for making our presence and that of Ayrton on Lincoln Island known at Tabor Island.”

zh: “当然，”记者说，“这很好办，只要在格兰特船长和艾尔顿住过的棚子里留下一张字条，写明我们这个岛的位置，格里那凡爵士和他的船员肯定会发现的。”
en: “Certainly,” answered the reporter, “and nothing is easier than to place in the hut, which was Captain Grant’s and Ayrton’s dwelling, a notice which Lord Glenarvan and his crew cannot help finding, giving the position of our island.”

zh: “真遗憾，”水手说，“我们第一次去达抱岛的时候，就忘记了采取这个防范措施。”
en: “It is a pity,” remarked the sailor, “that we forgot to take that precaution on our first visit to Tabor Island.”

zh: “我们当时怎么会想到要这样做呢？”赫伯特回答说，“那时候我们还不清楚艾尔顿的历史，也不知道有一天可能有人来接走他，现在知道了他的故事，可又错过了季节，不允许我们无法再回到达抱岛了。”
en: “And why should we have done it?” asked Herbert.“At that time we did not know Ayrton’s history; we did not know that any one was likely to come some day to fetch him, and when we did know his history, the season was too advanced to allow us to return then to Tabor Island.”

zh: “是的，”哈丁说，“现在太迟了，只好把这个航行推迟到明年春天。”
en: “Yes,” replied Harding, “it was too late, and we must put off the voyage until next spring.”

zh: “不过，要是苏格兰游船在那之前已经来了……”潘克洛夫说。
en: “But suppose the Scotch yacht comes before that,” said Pencroft.

zh: “这不大可能，”工程师回答道，“因为格里那凡爵士不会在冬季进行远洋冒险的。或者他已经回过达抱岛，但由于艾尔顿和我们在一起，也就是说，在过去的五个月里，他又离开了；或者他会晚些时候才来，这样等十月天气一好转，我们就有足够时间去达抱岛，留一张字条在那里。”
en: “That is not probable,” replied the engineer, “for Lord Glenarvan would not choose the winter season to venture into these seas.Either he has already returned to Tabor Island, since Ayrton has been with us, that is to say, during the last five months and has left again; or he will not come till later, and it will be time enough in the first fine October days to go to Tabor Island, and leave a notice there.”

zh: “我们必须考虑，”纳布说道，“假如‘邓肯’号在几个月前刚回过那里，那就太不走运了！”
en: “We must allow,” said Neb, “that it will be very unfortunate if the ‘Duncan’ has returned to these parts only a few months ago!”

zh: “但愿事实不是那样，”赛勒斯·哈丁说，“但愿上天不要剥夺我们剩下的最佳机会。”
en: “I hope that it is not so,” replied Cyrus Harding, “and that Heaven has not deprived us of the best chance which remains to us.”

zh: “我想，”记者提出，“不管怎样，我们去过达抱岛后，就会知道该怎么办，因为如果游船已经去过那里，他们一定会留下一些到访过的痕迹。”
en: “I think,” observed the reporter, “that at any rate we shall know what we have to depend on when we have been to Tabor Island, for if the yacht has returned there, they will necessarily have left some traces of their visit.”

zh: “那是肯定的，”工程师回答说，“因此，朋友们，既然我们有这次回国的机会，就应该耐心等待，如果失去了这次机会，我们再看最好该做什么。”
en: “That is evident,” answered the engineer.“So then, my friends, since we have this chance of returning to our country, we must wait patiently, and if it is taken from us we shall see what will be best to do.”

zh: “无论怎样，”潘克洛夫说，“我们都清楚，如果我们真的离开了林肯岛，那绝不是因为我们在这里住得不舒服。”
en: “At any rate,” remarked Pencroft, “it is well understood that if we do leave Lincoln Island, it will not be because we were uncomfortable there!”

zh: “你说得对，潘克洛夫，”工程师说，“这只是因为在岛上，我们远离了一个人在世界上最珍爱的一切：家庭、朋友和祖国！”
en: “No, Pencroft,” replied the engineer, “it will be because we are far from all that a man holds dearest in the world, his family, his friends, his native land!”

zh: 事情就这样定下后，居民们就不再提造大船去北方的太平洋群岛，或是去西方的新西兰，而只是忙于一些日常工作，为了在花岗石宫度过第三个冬天。
en: Matters being thus decided, the building of a vessel large enough to sail either to the Archipelagoes in the north, or to New Zealand in the west, was no longer talked of, and they busied themselves in their accustomed occupations, with a view to wintering a third time in Granite House.

zh: 不过，他们还是一致同意，在暴风天气到来之前，驾驶小船进行一次环岛航行。居民们还没有彻底考察整个海岸，从瀑布河口到颚角西岸和北岸，以及颚骨角之间像鲨鱼嘴张开的狭长海湾，对这些地带的情况了解得都不完整。
en: However, it was agreed that before the stormy weather came on, their little vessel should be employed in making a voyage round the island.A complete survey of the coast had not yet been made, and the colonists had but an imperfect idea of the shore to the west and north, from the mouth of Falls River to the Mandible Capes, as well as of the narrow bay between them, which opened like a shark’s jaws.

zh: 这次出海的计划是潘克洛夫提出来的，赛勒斯·哈丁对此完全赞同，因为他很想亲自看看他的这部分领地。
en: The plan of this excursion was proposed by Pencroft, and Cyrus Harding fully acquiesced in it, for he himself wished to see this part of his domain.

zh: 天气变幻莫测，不过气压表没有因突然变化而波动，因此他们可以依靠这种过得去的天气。然而，在四月的第一个星期，气压计急剧下降后，五六天的狂风之后，又重新升高了。然后气压表的指针停留在二十九又十分之九英寸的高度上，天气看起来很适合航海。
en: The weather was variable, but the barometer did not fluctuate by sudden movements, and they could therefore count on tolerable weather.However, during the first week of April, after a sudden barometrical fall, a renewed rise was marked by a heavy gale of wind, lasting five or six days; then the needle of the instrument remained stationary at a height of twenty-nine inches and nine-tenths, and the weather appeared propitious for an excursion.

zh: 出发的日子定在4月16号，停靠在气球港的“乘风破浪”号装足了食物，准备作一次为期不短的航行。
en: The departure was fixed for the 16th of April, and the “Bonadventure,” anchored in Port Balloon, was provisioned for a voyage which might be of some duration.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁把这次探险的计划也告诉了艾尔顿，并建议他也加入，可艾尔顿更愿意留在岛上，最后决定大伙不在时，艾尔顿必须到花岗石宫来。贾普奉命留下来陪艾尔顿，他没有提出抗议。
en: Cyrus Harding informed Ayrton of the projected expedition, and proposed that he should take part in it, but Ayrton preferring to remain on shore, it was decided that he should come to Granite House during the absence of his companions.Master Jup was ordered to keep him company, and made no remonstrance.

zh: 4月16日清晨，全体开拓者，包括托普，都上船了。微风从南面吹来，“乘风破浪”号离开气球港，抢风转变航向，为了到达爬虫角。林肯岛的周长为90英里，从气球港到爬虫角之间的南岸长20英里。由于刮的是迎头风，因此必须靠近海岸行驶。
