en: On the morning of the 16th of April all the colonists, including Top, embarked.A fine breeze blew from the south-west, and the “Bonadventure” tacked on leaving Port Balloon so as to reach Reptile End.Of the ninety miles which the perimeter of the island measured, twenty included the south coast between the port and the promontory.The wind being right ahead it was necessary to hug the shore.

zh: 他们花了一整天的时间才到达爬虫角，由于船离开气球港后，只碰到两个小时的退潮，因此，他们花了六个小时和潮水作斗争，开出路来。绕过爬虫角的时候，已经是傍晚了。
en: It took the whole day to reach the promontory, for the vessel on leaving port had only two hours of ebb tide and had therefore to make way for six hours against the flood.It was nightfall before the promontory was doubled.

zh: 水手建议工程师收缩两帆，继续慢速前行。但哈丁更希望在离岸几锚链远的地方停泊，以便明天白天勘察这部分海岸。同时，因为他们急于仔细勘察海岸，大家也一致同意夜间停航，而且只要天气条件允许，就尽量把船停靠在岸边。
en: The sailor then proposed to the engineer that they should continue sailing slowly with two reefs in the sail.But Harding preferred to anchor a few cable-lengths from the shore, so as to survey that part of the coast during the day.It was agreed also that as they were anxious for a minute exploration of the coast they should not sail during the night, but would always, when the weather permitted it, be at anchor near the shore.

zh: 他们就在爬虫角下边过了一夜，风停了，四周万籁俱寂。除了水手以外，“乘风破浪”号上的旅客都不像在花岗石宫的房间里那样睡得安稳，不过他们终究还是睡了。第二天，天刚蒙蒙亮，潘克洛夫就起航了，只要保持左舷抢风航行，就可以沿着西岸前行。
en: The night was passed under the promontory, and the wind having fallen, nothing disturbed the silence.The passengers, with the exception of the sailor, scarcely slept as well on board the “Bonadventure” as they would have done in their rooms at Granite House, but they did sleep however.Pencroft set sail at break of day, and by going on the larboard tack they could keep close to the shore.

zh: 开拓者们对这一片美丽的森林海岸很熟悉，尽管他们曾经徒步来这里探索过，然而再次看到时，大家还是赞叹不已。他们尽量沿着岸边行驶，以便观察每件事物，只是要时刻小心，不要撞到海面上到处漂浮的树干。他们也好几次停下船，让吉丁·史佩莱拍些优美的风景照。
en: The colonists knew this beautiful wooded coast, since they had already explored it on foot, and yet it again excited their admiration.They coasted along as close in as possible, so as to notice everything, avoiding always the trunks of trees which floated here and there.Several times also they anchored, and Gideon Spilett took photographs of the superb scenery.

zh: 将近中午时分，“乘风破浪”号抵达瀑布河口。在左岸，可以看到稀疏的树木，而在三英里以外，只有西面山的支脉之间独立地长着一簇一簇树木，荒芜的山脊倾斜下来，一直延伸到海岸一带。
en: About noon the “Bonadventure” arrived at the mouth of Falls River.Beyond, on the left bank, a few scattered trees appeared, and three miles further even these dwindled into solitary groups among the western spurs of the mountain, whose arid ridge sloped down to the shore.

zh: 海岸南部和北部的反差多大啊！相比之下，一边是树木葱郁，土壤肥沃，而另一边则是崎岖不平，荒凉贫瘠。就如在某些国家里，人们把后者称为“铁海岸”，它那荒芜杂乱的外形，似乎表明这是在远古时代的地质海里，由仍是液体的玄武岩突然产生结晶而形成的。如果当初居民们先是降落在这部分岛上，他们肯定会被这些巨大的石头吓到。他们从富兰克林山顶上眺望时，由于站得太高，无法看到此海岸险恶的一面，但从海上看，它呈现出荒凉的一面，也许世界的任何角落都无法与它比拟。
en: What a contrast between the northern and southern part of the coast!In proportion as one was woody and fertile so was the other rugged and barren!It might have been designated as one of those iron coasts, as they are called in some countries, and its wild confusion appeared to indicate that a sudden crystallization had been produced in the yet liquid basalt of some distant geological sea.These stupendous masses would have terrified the settlers if they had been cast at first on this part of the island!They had not been able to perceive the sinister aspect of this shore from the summit of Mount Franklin, for they overlooked it from too great a height, but viewed from the sea it presented a wild appearance which could not perhaps be equaled in any corner of the globe.

zh: “乘风破浪”号沿着海岸行驶了半英里。可以轻易看出，岸上尽是大小不一的一块块岩石，高度从20英尺到300英尺不等，形状也各不相同，有的圆如塔，有的棱柱如尖顶，有的锥体如方尖石碑，还有如同工厂大烟囱的圆锥形。即使是北冰洋上的冰山，也未必有这种千姿百态的凌人气派！这边是横跨岩石的桥，那边是如海浪般的拱门，目光都无法看透其深度；这边巨大的拱形洞穴呈现出不朽的气派，那边竖立着一排排的石柱、尖塔和拱门，任何一个哥特式的大教堂都不曾有这样的景致。这些自然界巧夺天工的作品，远比人们的想象力丰富，它们在这八九英里的壮丽海滨地带延伸着。
en: The “Bonadventure” sailed along this coast for the distance of half a mile.It was easy to see that it was composed of blocks of all sizes, from twenty to three hundred feet in height, and of all shapes, round like towers, prismatic like steeples, pyramidal like obelisks, conical like factory chimneys.An iceberg of the Polar seas could not have been more capricious in its terrible sublimity!Here, bridges were thrown from one rock to another; there, arches like those of a wave, into the depths of which the eye could not penetrate; in one place, large vaulted excavations presented a monumental aspect; in another, a crowd of columns, spires, and arches, such as no Gothic cathedral ever possessed.Every caprice of nature, still more varied than those of the imagination, appeared on this grand coast, which extended over a length of eight or nine miles.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和他的同伴们带着惊奇的心情，注视着这一切，几乎沉醉其中。虽然他们都默不作声，可托普却没被这种心情困扰，它叫了几声，从玄武岩的峭壁那边传来一声声回音。工程师甚至发现这狗的叫声有些奇怪，就和它在花岗石宫的井口发出的叫声类似。
en: Cyrus Harding and his companions gazed, with a feeling of surprise bordering on stupefaction.But, although they remained silent, Top, not being troubled with feelings of this sort, uttered barks which were repeated by the thousand echoes of the basaltic cliff.The engineer even observed that these barks had something strange in them, like those which the dog had uttered at the mouth of the well in Granite House.

zh: “我们靠近些吧。”他说。
en: “Let us go close in,” said he.

zh: 于是，“乘风破浪”号尽可能靠着石头遍布的海岸航行。也许那里有某个值得勘探的洞穴呢？可哈丁什么也没发现，既没有洞穴，也没有一个裂缝可供任何一样东西藏身，因为峭壁的底部被海浪冲刷着。不久，托普就停止了吠叫，船仍与海岸保持几锚链的距离，继续前行。
en: And the “Bonadventure” sailed as near as possible to the rocky shore.Perhaps some cave, which it would be advisable to explore, existed there?But Harding saw nothing, not a cavern, not a cleft which could serve as a retreat to any being whatever, for the foot of the cliff was washed by the surf.Soon Top’s barks ceased, and the vessel continued her course at a few cables-length from the coast.

zh: 在岛的西北部，海岸又变得平坦而多沙了。在一片低洼的沼泽地上，到处生长着一些树木，开拓者们也曾到这里勘探过，与刚才所见的荒凉的海岸形成鲜明对比，这里出现的无数水鸟又一次呈现出生命的气息。当晚，“乘风破浪”号就在小岛北面靠近陆地的一个小海湾停了下来，此处的海水非常深。这一夜过得非常平静，随着白天最后一道光的消失，微风也停息了，第二天破晓，才又吹起来。
en: In the northwest part of the island the shore became again flat and sandy.A few trees here and there rose above a low, marshy ground, which the colonists had already surveyed, and in violent contrast to the other desert shore, life was again manifested by the presence of myriads of water-fowl.That evening the “Bonadventure” anchored in a small bay to the north of the island, near the land, such was the depth of water there.The night passed quietly, for the breeze died away with the last light of day, and only rose again with the first streaks of dawn.

zh: 由于上岸容易，开拓地一贯的猎手，也就是赫伯特和吉丁·史佩莱，就去游逛了约两个小时，带回来好几串野鸭和鹬。托普表现极佳，多亏了它的热心和机敏，一只猎物也没有丢失。
en: As it was easy to land, the usual hunters of the colony, that is to say, Herbert and Gideon Spilett, went for a ramble of two hours or so, and returned with several strings of wild duck and snipe.Top had done wonders, and not a bird had been lost, thanks to his zeal and cleverness.

zh: 早上八点钟，“乘风破浪”号起航了，由于正赶上顺风，而且风势逐渐加大，它飞快地直奔北颚角。
en: At eight o’clock in the morning the “Bonadventure” set sail, and ran rapidly towards North Mandible Cape, for the wind was right astern and freshening rapidly.

zh: “不过，”潘克洛夫指出，“如果猛烈的风从西面刮来，我不会感到奇怪。昨天太阳下山时，西面地平线红彤彤的一片，今天早上又出现了马尾云，这不是好兆头。”
en: “However,” observed Pencroft, “I should not be surprised if a gale came up from the west.Yesterday the sun set in a very red-looking horizon, and now, this morning, those mares-tails don’t forbode anything good.”

zh: 马尾云是一种卷云，它们散布在离海面不到5000英尺的高空。这种云看起来像一片片轻柔的原棉，通常预示天气将要发生突变。
en: These mares-tails are cirrus clouds, scattered in the zenith, their height from the sea being less than five thousand feet.They look like light pieces of cotton wool, and their presence usually announces some sudden change in the weather.

zh: “那好，”哈丁说，“我们把帆尽量都升起来，赶快到鲨鱼湾去避一避。我想‘乘风破浪’号在那里会很安全。”
en: “Well,” said Harding, “let us carry as much sail as possible, and run for shelter into Shark Gulf.I think that the ‘Bonadventure’ will be safe there.”

zh: “太棒了，”潘克洛夫说，“而且北边的海岸尽是沙子，看起来非常没意思。”
en: “Perfectly,” replied Pencroft, “and besides, the north coast is merely sand, very uninteresting to look at.”

zh: “我不会感到遗憾，”工程师接着说，“不但今天要呆在鲨鱼湾，明天也是，那里值得仔细勘探一番。”
en: “I shall not be sorry,” resumed the engineer, “to pass not only to-night but to-morrow in that bay, which is worth being carefully explored.”

zh: “我想我们不得不那样做，不管我们愿不愿意，”潘克洛夫说，“因为西边的天空看起来非常险恶。坏天气马上要来了！”
en: “I think that we shall be obliged to do so, whether we like it or not,” answered Pencroft, “for the sky looks very threatening towards the west.Dirty weather is coming on!”

zh: “不管怎样，我们去颚骨角总是顺风的。”记者说道。
en: “At any rate we have a favorable wind for reaching Cape Mandible,” observed the reporter.

zh: “风倒是顺风，”水手说，“不过进入海湾时，必须抢风行驶，但愿能够顺利通过这个陌生的海域。”
en: “A very fine wind,” replied the sailor; “but we must tack to enter the gulf, and I should like to see my way clear in these unknown quarters.”

zh: “这部分海域礁石不少，”赫伯特补充道，“如果根据我们在鲨鱼湾南岸所看到的情况。”
en: “Quarters which appear to be filled with rocks,” added Herbert, “if we judge by what we saw on the south coast of Shark Gulf.”

zh: “潘克洛夫，”赛勒斯·哈丁说，“按你想的最好方案做吧，我们把它交给你了。”
en: “Pencroft,” said Cyrus Harding, “do as you think best, we will leave it to you.”

zh: “放心吧，上尉，”水手说，“如果没必要，我不会去冒险！我宁愿让刀子刺进我的肋骨，也决不让礁石进入我的‘乘风破浪’号！”
en: “Don’t make your mind uneasy, captain,” replied the sailor, “I shall not expose myself needlessly!I would rather a knife were run into my ribs than a sharp rock into those of my ‘Bonadventure!’”

zh: 潘克洛夫所说的肋骨，就是船浸在水下的那部分，他把它看得比自己的皮肉还重要。
en: That which Pencroft called ribs was the pan of his vessel under water, and he valued it more than his own skin.

zh: “几点钟了？”潘克洛夫问道。
en: “What o’clock is it?” asked Pencroft.

zh: “十点钟。”吉丁·史佩莱回答说。
en: “Ten o’clock,” replied Gideon Spilett.

zh: “上尉，我们离颚角还有多远？”
en: “And what distance is it to the Cape, captain?”

zh: “大概还有15英里。”工程师回答说。
en: “About fifteen miles,” replied the engineer.

zh: “也就是两个半小时的事情，”水手说，“十二点到一点之间，我们应该可以到达颚骨角附近了。糟糕的是，那时候正赶上退潮，海水要从海湾向外流出。既不顺风也不顺水，恐怕很难进湾。”
en: “That’s a matter of two hours and a half,” said the sailor, “and we shall be off the Cape between twelve and one o’clock.Unluckily, the tide will be turning at that moment, and will be ebbing out of the gulf.I am afraid that it will be very difficult to get in, having both wind and tide against us.”

zh: “加上今天又是满月，”赫伯特指出，“四月的潮水势头很猛。”
en: “And the more so that it is a full moon to-day,” remarked Herbert, “and these April tides are very strong.”

zh: “那么，潘克洛夫，”哈丁问道，“你能不能把船停在颚骨角附近呢？”
en: “Well, Pencroft,” asked Harding, “can you not anchor off the Cape?”

zh: “趁着天气没有变坏，在靠近陆地的地方抛锚！”水手大叫道，“上尉，你在想什么？我们非搁浅不可！”
en: “Anchor near land, with bad weather coming on!” exclaimed the sailor.“What are you thinking of, captain?We should run aground, of a certainty!”

zh: “那么，你打算怎么办？”
en: “What will you do then?”

zh: “我要设法在海上一直呆到涨潮，也就是到晚上七点左右，如果那时还有光亮，我就想办法驶进海湾；否则，我们只好整夜断断续续地行驶，等到明天太阳升起的时候再进海湾。”
en: “I shall try to keep in the offing until the flood, that is to say, till about seven in the evening, and if there is still light enough I will try to enter the gulf; if not, we must stand off and on during the night, and we will enter to-morrow at sunrise.”

zh: “我已经对你说过了，潘克洛夫，这件事情我们就交给你了。”哈丁说。
en: “As I told you, Pencroft, we will leave it to you,” answered Harding.

zh: “唉！”潘克洛夫说，“海岸上要是有一座灯塔，对水手来说就方便多了。”
en: “Ah!” said Pencroft, “if there was only a lighthouse on the coast, it would be much more convenient for sailors.”

zh: “是的，”赫伯特说，“这一次可没有体贴的工程师为我们点火，引我们入港了！”
en: “Yes,” replied Herbert, “and this time we shall have no obliging engineer to light a fire to guide us into port!”

zh: “说实话，亲爱的赛勒斯，”史佩莱说，“我们还没有谢过你呢，但老实说，要是没有那堆火，我们绝不能——”
en: “Why, indeed, my dear Cyrus,” said Spilett, “we have never thanked you; but frankly, without that fire we should never have been able—”

zh: “火？”哈丁听了记者的话后，非常惊讶地问道。
en: “A fire?” asked Harding, much astonished at the reporter’s words.

zh: “上尉，我们指的是，”潘克洛夫回答说，“上次我们回林肯岛的最后几个小时里，我们在‘乘风破浪’号上非常担心，要不是你在10月18日夜里的防范措施，在眺望岗上点燃火堆，我们就可能开到林肯岛的上风头去了。”
en: “We mean, captain,” answered Pencroft, “that on board the ‘Bonadventure’ we were very anxious during the few hours before our return, and we should have passed to windward of the island, if it had not been for the precaution you took of lighting a fire the night of the 19th of October, on Prospect Heights.”

zh: “是的，是的！那是我想出的好主意！”工程师说。
en: “Yes, yes!That was a lucky idea of mine!” replied the engineer.

zh: “而这一次，”水手接着说，“除非艾尔顿想到这一点，否则就不会有人帮我们这个小忙了！”
en: “And this time,” continued the sailor. “unless the idea occurs to Ayrton, there will be no one to do us that little service!”

zh: “不会了！不会有人了！”赛勒斯·哈丁回答说。
en: “No!No one!” answered Cyrus Harding.

zh: 几分钟后，工程师看只剩他自己和记者在船头，便俯下身来，低声对记者说：
en: A few minutes after, finding himself alone in the bows of the vessel, with the reporter, the engineer bent down and whispered,—

zh: “史佩莱，如果在这个世界上有一件可以肯定的事，那就是在10月19日的夜晚，我绝没有在眺望岗或是岛上其他任何地方点过火！”
en: “If there is one thing certain in this world, Spilett, it is that I never lighted any fire during the night of the 19th of October, neither on Prospect Heights nor on any other part of the island!”

zh: 第二十章
en: Chapter 20

zh: 潘克洛夫的预感很少会错，事情正如他所预料的那样发生了。风力逐渐加大，很快就从清新的微风变成了正常的狂风，也就是说，风速达到每小时40至45英里，在这种情况下，海面上的船只都会收帆行驶。接近六点钟的时候，“乘风破浪”号到了海湾，但那时潮势变了，船无法入港。于是，他们只好与海岸保持一定距离，因为即使潘克洛夫想进慈悲河口，他也办不到了。他把三角帆作为暴风帆升到主桅的顶上，使船头对着陆地，把船停了下来。
en: Things happened as Pencroft had predicted, he being seldom mistaken in his prognostications.The wind rose, and from a fresh breeze it soon increased to a regular gale; that is to say, it acquired a speed of from forty to forty-five miles an hour, before which a ship in the open sea would have run under close-reefed topsails.Now, as it was nearly six o’clock when the “Bonadventure” reached the gulf, and as at that moment the tide turned, it was impossible to enter.They were therefore compelled to stand off, for even if he had wished to do so, Pencroft could not have gained the mouth of the Mercy.Hoisting the jib to the mainmast by way of a storm-sail, he hove to, putting the head of the vessel towards the land.

zh: 虽然风势很猛，但幸好有陆地挡着，海浪并不大。因此大家不必担心常常对小船造成危险的海浪了。“乘风破浪”号的压舱情况良好，绝不会翻船，不过，如果大量的海水落到甲板上，而船板又经受不住它们，船就会受损。作为一名优秀的水手，潘克洛夫对一切可能发生的事故都作好了防备。当然，他对自己的这艘船非常有信心，不过他还是怀着几分焦虑的心情，等待着明天。
en: Fortunately, although the wind was strong the sea, being sheltered by the land, did not run very high.They had then little to fear from the waves, which always endanger small craft.The “Bonadventure” would doubtlessly not have capsized, for she was well ballasted, but enormous masses of water falling on the deck might injure her if her timbers could not sustain them.Pencroft, as a good sailor, was prepared for anything.Certainly, he had great confidence in his vessel, but nevertheless he awaited the return of day with some anxiety.

zh: 这天夜里，赛勒斯·哈丁和吉丁·史佩莱没有机会交谈，不过工程师在记者耳旁说的那些话，以及似乎支配林肯岛的这股神秘力量，都值得讨论一番。吉丁·史佩莱不断想着荒岛海岸上出现火光这又一件不可思议的事情。他确确实实看见了那火光！他的同伴，赫伯特和潘克洛夫，和他一样也看见了！这火光使他们在漆黑的夜里辨别出林肯岛的位置，他们从不怀疑火是工程师点燃的，而现在赛勒斯·哈丁却明确表示他绝没有做过这件事！史佩莱决定等“乘风破浪”号一回去，就马上重提此事，并催促赛勒斯·哈丁把这些奇怪的事实告诉伙伴们。也许大家会作出决定，共同对林肯岛的每个部分进行一次彻底的搜查。
en: During the night, Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett had no opportunity for talking together, and yet the words pronounced in the reporter’s ear by the engineer were well worth being discussed, together with the mysterious influence which appeared to reign over Lincoln Island.Gideon Spilett did not cease from pondering over this new and inexplicable incident, the appearance of a fire on the coast of the island.The fire had actually been seen!His companions, Herbert and Pencroft, had seen it with him!The fire had served to signalize the position of the island during that dark night, and they had not doubted that it was lighted by the engineer’s hand; and here was Cyrus Harding expressly declaring that he had never done anything of the sort!Spilett resolved to recur to this incident as soon as the “Bonadventure” returned, and to urge Cyrus Harding to acquaint their companions with these strange facts.Perhaps it would be decided to make in common a complete investigation of every part of Lincoln Island.

zh: 不管怎样，这天晚上，在海湾入口处陌生的海岸上，没有任何火光，而小船就整夜停泊在海面上。
en: However that might be, on this evening no fire was lighted on these yet unknown shores, which formed the entrance to the gulf, and the little vessel stood off during the night.

zh: 当东方的海平面上晨曦初照时，风势也稍稍减弱了些，并且改变了两个方位，这使得潘克洛夫可以轻而易举地把船驶进窄小的港湾。早上接近七点的时候，“乘风破浪”号经受住风浪，朝着北颚角的方向，进入海峡，滑到这片水域中，这里四面都是千奇百怪的熔岩峭壁。
en: When the first streaks of dawn appeared in the western horizon, the wind, which had slightly fallen, shifted two points, and enabled Pencroft to enter the narrow gulf with greater ease.Towards seven o’clock in the morning, the “Bonadventure,” weathering the North Mandible Cape, entered the strait and glided on to the waters, so strangely enclosed in the frame of lava.

zh: “嗯，”潘克洛夫说，“这个海湾的航道真好，一整个舰队也能轻易停下！”
en: “Well,” said Pencroft, “this bay would make admirable roads, in which a whole fleet could lie at their ease!”

zh: “特别奇怪的是，”哈丁指出，“这海湾是由两波大量的熔岩形成，因为有连续两次火山喷发的积累。结果海湾的四周都被遮挡住了，我相信，即使是在暴风雨最猛烈的天气，这里的海水也会像湖面一样平静。”
en: “What is especially curious,” observed Harding, “is that the gulf has been formed by two rivers of lava, thrown out by the volcano, and accumulated by successive eruptions.The result is that the gulf is completely sheltered on all sides, and I believe that even in the stormiest weather, the sea here must be as calm as a lake.”

zh: “当然，”水手接着说，“由于这里的风只能从两个海角的狭窄通道吹进来，而且，北边的海角还遮挡着南边的海角，这样狂风就难以长驱直入了。我敢说，我们的‘乘风破浪’号在这里可以从今年年底停到明年年底，甚至锚也一动不动！”
en: “No doubt,” returned the sailor, “since the wind has only that narrow entrance between the two capes to get in by, and, besides, the north cape protects that of the south in a way which would make the entrance of gusts very difficult.I declare our ‘Bonadventure’ could stay here from one end of the year to the other, without even dragging at her anchor!”

zh: “对它而言，这个港湾相当大！”记者说。
en: “It is rather large for her!” observed the reporter.

zh: “不错！史佩莱先生，”水手回答说，“我承认对‘乘风破浪’号来说，这个港湾是太大了，但如果美国的舰队想在太平洋上找一个港口，我想找不到比这更好的地方了！”
en: “Well!Mr. Spilett,” replied the sailor, “I agree that it is too large for the ‘Bonadventure,’ but if the fleets of the Union were in want of a harbor in the Pacific, I don’t think they would ever find a better place than this!”

zh: “现在我们在鲨鱼的嘴里呢。”纳布说道，他暗指海湾的形状。
en: “We are in the shark’s mouth,” remarked Nab, alluding to the form of the gulf.

zh: “正是在它的嘴中间，老实的纳布！”赫伯特回答说，“不过，你不会担心它会闭上嘴，把我们关在里面吧？”
en: “Right into its mouth, my honest Nab!” replied Herbert, “but you are not afraid that it will shut upon us, are you?”

zh: “不会的，赫伯特先生，”纳布答道，“但是我不大喜欢这个港湾！它的样子很凶恶！”
en: “No, Mr. Herbert,” answered Neb, “and yet this gulf here doesn’t please me much!It has a wicked look!”

zh: “好呀！”潘克洛夫大叫道，“我正考虑要把这个港湾献给美国，纳布却对它嗤之以鼻！”
en: “Hallo!” cried Pencroft, “here is Neb turning up his nose at my gulf, just as I was thinking of presenting it to America!”

zh: “不过，不管怎样，这里的水够深吗？”工程师问道，“对‘乘风破浪’号来说水够深了，对我们的装甲军舰却不一定够。”
en: “But, at any rate, is the water deep enough?” asked the engineer, “for a depth sufficient for the keel of the ‘Bonadventure’ would not be enough for those of our iron-clads.”

zh: “这很容易证实。”潘克洛夫回答道。
en: “That is easily found out,” replied Pencroft.

zh: 于是，水手用一根长绳绑上一块铁，作为铅垂线，进行测量。这根绳子长约50英寻，全放下去以后，还碰不到底。
en: And the sailor sounded with a long cord, which served him as a lead-line, and to which was fastened a lump of iron.This cord measured nearly fifty fathoms, and its entire length was unrolled without finding any bottom.

zh: “瞧，”潘克洛夫叫道，“我们的装甲舰可以来这里了！绝对不会搁浅的！”
en: “There,” exclaimed Pencroft, “our iron-clads can come here after all!They would not run aground!”

zh: “的确，”吉丁·史佩莱说，“这个港湾是正常的深渊，不过，考虑到海岛是由于火山爆发而形成的，那么港湾的海底有如此深的凹陷也就不足为奇了。”
en: “Indeed,” said Gideon Spilett, “this gulf is a regular abyss, but, taking into consideration the volcanic origin of the island, it is not astonishing that the sea should offer similar depressions.”

zh: “人们也会说，”赫伯特说，“这里的峭壁非常陡峭，我相信在峭壁脚下，即使潘克洛夫用比刚才的那一根长出五六倍的绳子去测量，也不会触到海底的。”
en: “One would say too,” observed Herbert, “that these cliffs were perfectly perpendicular; and I believe that at their foot, even with a line five or six times longer, Pencroft would not find bottom.”

zh: “这都很好，”记者说道，“但是，我必须向潘克洛夫指出，这个港湾缺少一样非常重要的东西！”
en: “That is all very well,” then said the reporter, “but I must point out to Pencroft that his harbor is wanting in one very important respect!”

zh: “什么东西，史佩莱先生？”
en: “And what is that, Mr. Spilett?”

zh: “一个开口，一种通向海岛内部的豁口。我找不到一个可以登陆的地方。”确实，陡峭的熔岩峭壁没有一处地方适合登陆。峭壁形成一道难以逾越的屏障，使人想起挪威的峡湾，只是这里更显荒凉。“乘风破浪”号尽量靠近峭壁前行，但找不到一块突出的地方，可使乘客们离开甲板。
en: “An opening, a cutting of some sort, to give access to the interior of the island.I do not see a spot on which we could land.”And, in fact, the steep lava cliffs did not afford a single place suitable for landing.They formed an insuperable barrier, recalling, but with more wildness, the fiords of Norway.The “Bonadventure,” coasting as close as possible along the cliffs, did not discover even a projection which would allow the passengers to leave the deck.

zh: 潘克洛夫自我安慰地说，如果需要，用炸药就可以在峭壁上炸出一个缺口，但是，这时候在港湾里，他显然也无计可施，于是把船驶向海峡，下午两点左右，他们穿出了港湾。
en: Pencroft consoled himself by saying that with the help of a mine they could soon open out the cliff when that was necessary, and then, as there was evidently nothing to be done in the gulf, he steered his vessel towards the strait and passed out at about two o’clock in the afternoon.

zh: “啊！”纳布满意地舒了一口气。
en: “Ah!” said Nab, uttering a sigh of satisfaction.

zh: 在这条巨大的鲨鱼嘴里，这个老实的黑人真是感到不自在。
en: One might really say that the honest Negro did not feel at his ease in those enormous jaws.

zh: 从颚骨角到慈悲河口不过八英里。“乘风破浪”号船头朝着花岗石宫，一阵顺风鼓起船帆，它就飞快地沿着海岸向前驶去。
en: The distance from Mandible Cape to the mouth of the Mercy was not more than eight miles.The head of the “Bonadventure” was put towards Granite House, and a fair wind filling her sails, she ran rapidly along the coast.

zh: 驶过巨大的熔岩，不久就到了千姿百态的沙丘地带，工程师就是在这里莫名其妙地得救的，这一带常常有成千上万的海鸟飞来。
en: To the enormous lava rocks succeeded soon those capricious sand dunes, among which the engineer had been so singularly recovered, and which seabirds frequented in thousands.

zh: 大约四点钟，潘克洛夫离开海岛左边的点，进入海岛与海岸之间的那条海峡，五点钟的时候，“乘风破浪”号就在慈悲河口的沙滩上抛锚了。
en: About four o’clock, Pencroft leaving the point of the islet on his left, entered the channel which separated it from the coast, and at five o’clock the anchor of the “Bonadventure” was buried in the sand at the mouth of the Mercy.

zh: 开拓者们和他们的住处阔别了三天。艾尔顿在沙滩上等候他们，贾普也欢天喜地地跟来迎接，嘴里还发出满意的、低沉的呼噜声。
en: The colonists had been absent three days from their dwelling.Ayrton was waiting for them on the beach, and Jup came joyously to meet them, giving vent to deep grunts of satisfaction.

zh: 现在岛上的海岸全都勘探过了，没有发现任何可疑的地方。如果有什么神秘的生物在这里居住，只可能隐藏在盘蛇半岛浓密的森林之中，居民们只有那里还没有搜查过。
en: A complete exploration of the coast of the island had now been made, and no suspicious appearances had been observed.If any mysterious being resided on it, it could only be under cover of the impenetrable forest of the Serpentine Peninsula, to which the colonists had not yet directed their investigations.

zh: 吉丁·史佩莱和工程师讨论了这些事，决定让伙伴们注意岛上发生过的怪事，而最近发生的这件事最令人费解。
en: Gideon Spilett discussed these things with the engineer, and it was agreed that they should direct the attention of their companions to the strange character of certain incidents which had occurred on the island, and of which the last was the most unaccountable.

zh: 不过，提到海岸上有不知名者点燃火堆的事情，哈丁禁不住又要问记者那个问了二十遍的问题：
en: However, Harding, returning to the fact of a fire having been kindled on the shore by an unknown hand, could not refrain from repeating for the twentieth time to the reporter,—

zh: “你确信看到火光了吗？会不会是火山的局部喷发，或是什么流星呢？”
en: “But are you quite sure of having seen it?Was it not a partial eruption of the volcano, or perhaps some meteor?”

zh: “不是，赛勒斯，”记者回答说，“千真万确是人点的火。不信你可以问潘克洛夫和赫伯特。他们和我都看到了，他们可以证实我说的话。”
en: “No, Cyrus,” answered the reporter, “it was certainly a fire lighted by the hand of man.Besides; question Pencroft and Herbert.They saw it as I saw it myself, and they will confirm my words.”

zh: 结果，又过了几天，4月25日晚上，当居民们都聚集在眺望岗上的时候，赛勒斯·哈丁开始跟大家说：
en: In consequence, therefore, a few days after, on the 25th of April, in the evening, when the settlers were all collected on Prospect Heights, Cyrus Harding began by saying,—

zh: “朋友们，我认为我有责任让你们注意到岛上发生的一些事情，我将乐意听取你们对这些问题的看法。这些事情，说起来真是不可思议……”
en: “My friends, I think it my duty to call your attention to certain incidents which have occurred in the island, on the subject of which I shall be happy to have your advice.These incidents are, so to speak, supernatural—”

zh: “不可思议！”水手吐了一口烟，大声说道，“难道我们的小岛会是不可思议的吗？”
en: “Supernatural!” exclaimed the sailor, emitting a volume of smoke from his mouth.“Can it be possible that our island is supernatural?”

zh: “不，潘克洛夫，不过可以肯定，它是神秘的，”工程师回答道，“除非你能解释史佩莱和我至今还弄不明白的问题。”
en: “No, Pencroft, but mysterious, most certainly,” replied the engineer; “unless you can explain that which Spilett and I have until now failed to understand.”

zh: “你说吧，上尉。”水手说。
en: “Speak away, captain,” answered the sailor.

zh: “那好，”于是工程师说道，“你知道我掉进大海以后，在岛上距离海边四分之一英里的地方被找到，而我对自己竟被移动了这件事毫无知觉，你们知道是什么原因吗？”
en: “Well, have you understood,” then said the engineer, “how was it that after falling into the sea, I was found a quarter of a mile into the interior of the island, and that, without my having any consciousness of my removal there?”

zh: “除非你当时失去了知觉……”潘克洛夫说。
en: “Unless, being unconscious—” said Pencroft.

zh: “这是说不通的。”工程师说，“还有，我再问你，你说托普怎么会发现你们的住处呢？那离我躺着的山洞可是有五英里远！”
en: “That is not admissible,” replied the engineer.“But to continue.Have you understood how Top was able to discover your retreat five miles from the cave in which I was lying?”

zh: “狗的本能……”赫伯特说。
en: “The dog’s instinct—” observed Herbert.

zh: “这种本能也太奇怪了！”记者接着说，“尽管那天夜里风雨肆虐，可托普来到石窟时，身上竟然是干的，而且没有一点污泥！”
en: “Singular instinct!” returned the reporter, “since notwithstanding the storm of rain and wind which was raging during that night, Top arrived at the Chimneys, dry and without a speck of mud!”

zh: “我们接着说下去，”工程师又说，“你们说我们的狗在和儒艮搏斗后，怎么会被莫名奇妙地抛出湖面？”
en: “Let us continue,” resumed the engineer.“Have you understood how our dog was so strangely thrown up out of the water of the lake, after his struggle with the dugong?”

zh: “不明白！我承认，一点也不明白，”潘克洛夫回答道，“还有儒艮身上的那个伤口，好像是被一种利器刺伤的，这件事也无法弄明白。”
en: “No!I confess, not at all,” replied Pencroft, “and the wound which the dugong had in its side, a wound which seemed to have been made with a sharp instrument; that can’t be understood, either.”

zh: “我们接着说下去，”哈丁说，“朋友们，一颗子弹是怎么进入小野猪身体的；没有船只遇难的痕迹，怎么会有一只箱子恰巧幸运地搁浅在沙滩上；我们第一次在海上航行时，怎么会那么巧出现那只装着纸条的瓶子；为什么在缆绳断了之后，我们的小船会在我们需要的时候，顺着慈悲河水向下流，漂到我们身边来；为什么猿猴入侵后，绳梯会那么及时地从花岗石宫上面放下来；最后，为什么艾尔顿一口咬定从没写过的纸条会落入我们手中？”
en: “Let us continue again,” said Harding.“Have you understood, my friends, how that bullet got into the body of the young peccary; how that case happened to be so fortunately stranded, without there being any trace of a wreck; how that bottle containing the document presented itself so opportunely, during our first sea-excursion; how our canoe, having broken its moorings, floated down the current of the Mercy and rejoined us at the very moment we needed it; how after the ape invasion the ladder was so obligingly thrown down from Granite House; and lastly, how the document, which Ayrton asserts was never written by him, fell into our hands?”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁一件不漏地把岛上发生过的怪事一一列举出来，赫伯特、纳布和潘克洛夫都面面相觑，无言以对，因为这一连串的事件第一次被集中起来，这确实使他们惊讶到了极点。
en: As Cyrus Harding thus enumerated, without forgetting one, the singular incidents which had occurred in the island, Herbert, Neb, and Pencroft stared at each other, not knowing what to reply, for this succession of incidents, grouped thus for the first time, could not but excite their surprise to the highest degree.

zh: “我敢赌咒发誓，”潘克洛夫说，“上尉，你说得对，所有这些事都难以解释！”
en: “‘Pon my word,” said Pencroft at last, “you are right, captain, and it is difficult to explain all these things!”

zh: “好吧，朋友们，”工程师又说，“最近又添了一件事情，和以前那些事一样离奇！”
en: “Well, my friends,” resumed the engineer, “a last fact has just been added to these, and it is no less incomprehensible than the others!”

zh: “什么事，上尉？”赫伯特马上问道。
en: “What is it, captain?” asked Herbert quickly.

zh: “潘克洛夫，你们从达抱岛回来的时候，”工程师接着说，“你说过林肯岛上出现过火光，是这样吗？”
en: “When you were returning from Tabor Island, Pencroft,” continued the engineer, “you said that a fire appeared on Lincoln Island?”

zh: “确实如此。”水手答道。
en: “Certainly,” answered the sailor.

zh: “你肯定看见那堆火了吗？”
en: “And you are quite certain of having seen this fire?”

zh: “就像我现在看见你一样肯定。”
en: “As sure as I see you now.”

zh: “赫伯特，你也看见了吗？”
en: “You also, Herbert?”

zh: “怎么了，上尉，”赫伯特叫道，“那火光就像一等星那样灿烂夺目！”
en: “Why, captain,” cried Herbert, “that fire was blazing like a star of the first magnitude!”

zh: “会不会是一颗星呢？”工程师追问道。
en: “But was it not a star?” urged the engineer.

zh: “不是，”潘克洛夫回答说，“当时天上布满了厚厚的云层，而且不管怎么说，星星不可能那么靠近地平线。史佩莱先生和我们一样也看见了，他可以证实我们的话。”
en: “No,” replied Pencroft, “for the sky was covered with thick clouds, and at any rate a star would not have been so low on the horizon.But Mr. Spilett saw it as well as we, and he will confirm our words.”

zh: “我再补充一句，”记者说，“那火光非常亮，如同射出一道闪电。”
en: “I will add,” said the reporter, “that the fire was very bright, and that it shot up like a sheet of lightning.”

zh: “是的，是的！一点也不错，”赫伯特说道，“火堆的位置肯定是在花岗石宫的高岗上。”
en: “Yes, yes! exactly,” added Herbert, “and it was certainly placed on the heights of Granite House.”

zh: “好吧，朋友们，”赛勒斯·哈丁说，“10月19日那天夜里，纳布和我都没有在海岸上点过火。”
en: “Well, my friends,” replied Cyrus Harding, “during the night of the 19th of October, neither Neb nor I lighted any fire on the coast.”

zh: “你没有点过火！”潘克洛夫极度惊讶，连话也说不下去了。
en: “You did not!” exclaimed Pencroft, in the height of his astonishment, not being able to finish his sentence.

zh: “我们没有离开过花岗石宫，”赛勒斯·哈丁回答说，“如果海岸有火光出现，那一定是别人点的，而不是我们！”
en: “We did not leave Granite House,” answered Cyrus Harding, “and if a fire appeared on the coast, it was lighted by another hand than ours!”

zh: 潘克洛夫、赫伯特和纳布全都惊呆了。这不可能是幻觉，10月19日夜里，他们确实亲眼目睹了火光。是的，他们不得不承认其中有神秘之处！有一股无法解释的力量——显然对开拓者们有利，会及时地在林肯岛上出发挥作用，这极大地激起了他们的好奇心。会不会有什么东西藏在最隐蔽的地方呢？必须不惜一切代价证实这一点。
en: Pencroft, Herbert, and Neb were stupefied.No illusion could be possible, and a fire had actually met their eyes during the night of the 19th of October.Yes! they had to acknowledge it, a mystery existed!An inexplicable influence, evidently favorable to the colonists, but very irritating to their curiosity, was executed always in the nick of time on Lincoln Island.Could there be some being hidden in its profoundest recesses?It was necessary at any cost to ascertain this.

zh: 哈丁还提醒同伴们注意，当托普和贾普在花岗石宫那口与大海相通的井口旁徘徊时，就表现怪异，他还告诉大家，自己曾下井搜索过，但没有发现什么可疑的东西。最后，由于这次谈话，他们作出决定，一旦天气再次转好，开拓地全体成员就去全面搜索整个海岛。
en: Harding also reminded his companions of the singular behavior of Top and Jup when they prowled round the mouth of the well, which placed Granite House in communication with the sea, and he told them that he had explored the well, without discovering anything suspicious.The final resolve taken, in consequence of this conversation, by all the members of the colony, was that as soon as the fine season returned they would thoroughly search the whole of the island.

zh: 可是，自从这一天起，潘克洛夫就显得忧心忡忡。他似乎感觉，这个他原来当成私有财产的海岛现在不完全属于自己了，他要和另一个主人共有，并且不管愿不愿意，他觉得自己受到此人的支配。纳布和他经常谈论起这些无法解释的事情，由于他们两人生性喜欢神奇古怪之事，所以不免相信有某种超自然的力量在统治着林肯岛。
en: But from that day Pencroft appeared to be anxious.He felt as if the island which he had made his own personal property belonged to him entirely no longer, and that he shared it with another master, to whom, willing or not, he felt subject.Neb and he often talked of those unaccountable things, and both, their natures inclining them to the marvelous, were not far from believing that Lincoln Island was under the dominion of some supernatural power.

zh: 此时，随着五月的到来，也就是相当于北半球的十一月，坏天气也来了。今年的冬天看起来会提前，而且会很冷。因此，过冬的准备工作刻不容缓地进行了起来。
en: In the meanwhile, the bad weather came with the month of May, the November of the northern zones.It appeared that the winter would be severe and forward.The preparations for the winter season were therefore commenced without delay.

zh: 但是，不管这个冬天多么严酷，开拓者们还是作了很好的准备过冬。他们有大量的毛毡衣服，到时候，会有大量的摩弗仑羊，可以提供制作这种保暖织物所必需的充足羊毛。
en: Nevertheless, the colonists were well prepared to meet the winter, however hard it might be.They had plenty of felt clothing, and the musmons, very numerous by this time, had furnished an abundance of wool necessary for the manufacture of this warm material.

zh: 不用说，大家也给艾尔顿准备了这种舒适的衣服。赛勒斯·哈丁建议，他到花岗岩石宫和大家一起度过糟糕的季节，在这里住会比在畜栏里好些，艾尔顿答应等畜栏的最后一些工作结束后，就立刻搬过来。四月中旬，他搬过来了。自那以后，艾尔顿就过起了集体生活，并且在各种场合都发挥了作用，不过他还是一副谦恭、忧郁的样子，从不参与到同伴的欢乐中。
en: It is unnecessary to say that Ayrton had been provided with this comfortable clothing.Cyrus Harding proposed that he should come to spend the bad season with them in Granite House, where he would be better lodged than at the corral, and Ayrton promised to do so, as soon as the last work at the corral was finished.He did this towards the middle of April.From that time Ayrton shared the common life, and made himself useful on all occasions; but still humble and sad, he never took part in the pleasures of his companions.

zh: 居民们在林肯岛上的第三个冬天，大部分都是在花岗石宫内度过的。有过好几次猛烈而可怕的狂风暴雨，似乎都要震动他们的基石了。滔天巨浪险些要盖过整个海岛，毫无疑问，只要是停泊在海岸边的船只，一定会被撞个粉碎。在这样的风暴里，上涨的慈悲河水有两次差点把桥梁冲垮，每当海水冲击海滩时，堤岸上的桥都淹没在冒着白沫的水浪中，因此必须加固桥身。
en: For the greater part of this, the third winter which the settlers passed in Lincoln Island, they were confined to Granite House.There were many violent storms and frightful tempests, which appeared to shake the rocks to their very foundations.Immense waves threatened to overwhelm the island, and certainly any vessel anchored near the shore would have been dashed to pieces.Twice, during one of these hurricanes, the Mercy swelled to such a degree as to give reason to fear that the bridges would be swept away, and it was necessary to strengthen those on the shore, which disappeared under the foaming waters, when the sea beat against the beach.

zh: 大家都认为，这种暴风雨，比得上夹着雨雪的龙卷风，一定会对眺望岗的高地造成巨大的损失。特别是磨坊和家禽养殖场，也会遭受严重损失。开拓者们不得不经常去做一些抢修工作，否则家禽的安全会面临极大的威胁。
en: It may well be supposed that such storms, comparable to water-spouts in which were mingled rain and snow, would cause great havoc on the plateau of Prospect Heights.The mill and the poultry-yard particularly suffered.The colonists were often obliged to make immediate repairs, without which the safety of the birds would have been seriously threatened.

zh: 在天气最恶劣的时候，有几只美洲豹和成群结队的猿猴闯到高地的边缘，大家很担心，这些灵活胆大的动物会为饥饿所驱使，利用河水冰封提供的便捷通道走过来。如果没有人经常守护，农作物和家畜难免要遭殃，而且还必须常常开枪，让这些危险的来访者不敢靠近。所以这个冬天，开拓者们要干的活很多，不算户外的工作，在花岗石宫内的整理工作常常就非常多。
en: During the worst weather, several jaguars and troops of quadrumana ventured to the edge of the plateau, and it was always to be feared that the most active and audacious would, urged by hunger, manage to cross the stream, which besides, when frozen, offered them an easy passage.Plantations and domestic animals would then have been infallibly destroyed, without a constant watch, and it was often necessary to make use of the guns to keep those dangerous visitors at a respectful distance.Occupation was not wanting to the colonists, for without reckoning their out-door cares, they had always a thousand plans for the fitting up of Granite House.

zh: 碰上下霜的日子，他们也去广阔的漆凫沼泽打了几次猎。这里有无数的野鸭、鹬、短颈野鸭和其他水禽，吉丁·史佩莱和赫伯特在托普和贾普的协助下，百发百中。猎人们到这一带猎场去很容易，不管是跨过慈悲河桥，通过气球港的那条路到那里，还是从遗物角绕过峭壁，猎人们离花岗石宫都不会超过两三英里的距离。
en: They had also some fine sporting excursions, which were made during the frost in the vast Tadorn Marsh.Gideon Spilett and Herbert, aided by Jup and Top, did not miss a shot in the midst of myriads of wild-duck, snipe, teal, and others.The access to these hunting-grounds was easy; besides, whether they reached them by the road to Port Balloon, after having passed the Mercy Bridge, or by turning the rocks from Flotsam Point, the hunters were never distant from Granite House more than two or three miles.

zh: 冬季着实严寒的四个月，也就是六、七、八、九月，就这样度过了。不过，总而言之，花岗石宫并未受到酷寒天气太大的影响。畜栏也是如此，由于它不像高地那样暴露在外，部分又受到富兰克林山的遮蔽，风暴被森林和海岸上高大的岩壁遮挡后，到达这里时已经很微弱了。因此，畜栏的损失很小，10月期间，艾尔顿回去了几天，凭着他勤快利落的双手，很快就完成了修缮工作。
en: Thus passed the four winter months, which were really rigorous, that is to say, June, July, August, and September.But, in short, Granite House did not suffer much from the inclemency of the weather, and it was the same with the corral, which, less exposed than the plateau, and sheltered partly by Mount Franklin, only received the remains of the hurricanes, already broken by the forests and the high rocks of the shore.The damages there were consequently of small importance, and the activity and skill of Ayrton promptly repaired them, when some time in October he returned to pass a few days in the corral.

zh: 这个冬天并没有发生什么新的怪事。虽然潘克洛夫和纳布密切注意着最微不足道的事情，他们也把这些事情和神秘的原因联系起来，然而还是没有发生任何怪诞的事情。托普和贾普也不再在井口边嗥叫，也没有任何不安的表现。因此，这一系列神奇的事件似乎中断了，不过晚上在花岗石宫里，大家还是经常谈论起这些事，而且还是决定要彻底搜查全岛，甚至是那些最难以搜索的部分也不放过。但此时，发生了一件最重大的事情，使得赛勒斯·哈丁和伙伴们暂时改变了计划，此事也许会产生可怕的后果。
en: During this winter, no fresh inexplicable incident occurred.Nothing strange happened, although Pencroft and Neb were on the watch for the most insignificant facts to which they attached any mysterious cause.Top and Jup themselves no longer growled round the well or gave any signs of uneasiness.It appeared, therefore, as if the series of supernatural incidents was interrupted, although they often talked of them during the evenings in Granite House, and they remained thoroughly resolved that the island should be searched, even in those parts the most difficult to explore.But an event of the highest importance, and of which the consequences might be terrible, momentarily diverted from their projects Cyrus Harding and his companions.

zh: 时间是十月份。美好的季节转眼间已来临。大自然在复苏，森林边缘那些常绿的针叶树中，山龙眼、喜马拉雅杉和其他一些树已经抽出了新绿。
en: It was the month of October.The fine season was swiftly returning.Nature was reviving; and among the evergreen foliage of the coniferae which formed the border of the wood, already appeared the young leaves of the banksias, deodars, and other trees.

zh: 大家也许还记得，吉丁·史佩莱和赫伯特已经多次拍摄林肯岛的风景照。
en: It may be remembered that Gideon Spilett and Herbert had, at different times, taken photographic views of Lincoln Island.

zh: 10月17日下午，将近三点的时候，赫伯特被天空的魅力吸引着，他想拍一张眺望岗对面联合湾的照片，范围从颚骨角一直到爪角。
en: Now, on the 17th of this month of October, towards three o’clock in the afternoon, Herbert, enticed by the charms of the sky, thought of reproducing Union Bay, which was opposite to Prospect Heights, from Cape Mandible to Claw Cape.

zh: 地平线非常清晰，大海像湖面一样平静，轻柔的微风吹过，泛起小小的涟漪，阳光照射下，到处闪烁着银光。
en: The horizon was beautifully clear, and the sea, undulating under a soft breeze, was as calm as the waters of a lake, sparkling here and there under the sun’s rays.

zh: 照相机放置在花岗石宫餐厅的一个窗台上，因此能俯瞰海岸和整个海湾。赫伯特像往常一样操作，底片感光以后，他就去室内的一个阴暗角落，用存放在那里的化学物将它固定。
en: The apparatus had been placed at one of the windows of the dining-room at Granite House, and consequently overlooked the shore and the bay.Herbert proceeded as he was accustomed to do, and the negative obtained, he went away to fix it by means of the chemicals deposited in a dark nook of Granite House.

zh: 赫伯特回到亮处，仔细检查底片，发现底片的海平线上，有一个几乎难以察觉的小黑点。他反复地洗，想把这一小点东西除去，可是洗不掉。
en: Returning to the bright light, and examining it well, Herbert perceived on his negative an almost imperceptible little spot on the sea horizon.He endeavored to make it disappear by reiterated washing, but could not accomplish it.

zh: “这是镜头上的一个污点。”他这样想。
en: “It is a flaw in the glass,” he thought.

zh: 可是由于好奇心的驱使，他从望远镜上取下一个倍数很大的透镜，打算仔细察看这个小黑点。
en: And then he had the curiosity to examine this flaw with a strong magnifier which he unscrewed from one of the telescopes.

zh: 不过，他刚刚看了一眼就大叫起来，透镜险些从手中掉了下去。
en: But he had scarcely looked at it, when he uttered a cry, and the glass almost fell from his hands.

zh: 赫伯特立即跑到赛勒斯·哈丁的房里，把底片和放大镜递给工程师，并把底片上的小黑点指给他看。
en: Immediately running to the room in which Cyrus Harding then was, he extended the negative and magnifier towards the engineer, pointing out the little spot.

zh: 哈丁细看了一下，然后抓起望远镜，冲向窗口。
en: Harding examined it; then seizing his telescope he rushed to the window.

zh: 望远镜慢慢扫过水平线，最后停在要找的那一点上，赛勒斯·哈丁放下望远镜，只说了一个字：
en: The telescope, after having slowly swept the horizon, at last stopped on the looked-for spot, and Cyrus Harding, lowering it, pronounced one word only,—
“A vessel!”

zh: 事实上，有一只船在视线之内，在离林肯岛不远的地方！
en: And in fact a vessel was in sight, off Lincoln Island!

zh: 第三部 海岛的秘密
en: Part 3—The Secret of the Island

zh: 第一章
en: Chapter 1

zh: 这群遇难者从气球上被抛到林肯岛已经两年半了，在这期间，他们和外界没有取得任何联系。有一次，记者将写有他们境遇的一封密信系在一只鸟的身上，试图以此与有人居住的外界取得联系，可这要碰运气，不能对它抱很大的希望。艾尔顿独自一人加入到移民小队中，当时的情况前面已经提到过了。然而，10月17日这天，在这杳无人迹的海面上，却有另一伙人出乎意料地出现在岛上移民的视线范围内。
en: It was now two years and a half since the castaways from the balloon had been thrown on Lincoln Island, and during that period there had been no communication between them and their fellow-creatures.Once the reporter had attempted to communicate with the inhabited world by confiding to a bird a letter which contained the secret of their situation, but that was a chance on which it was impossible to reckon seriously.Ayrton, alone, under the circumstances which have been related, had come to join the little colony.Now, suddenly, on this day, the 17th of October, other men had unexpectedly appeared in sight of the island, on that deserted sea!

zh: 这一点毫无疑问！那里有一艘船！不过它是继续前进，还是要靠岸呢？几个小时之后，移民们一定就可以知道答案了。
en: There could be no doubt about it!A vessel was there!But would she pass on, or would she put into port?In a few hours the colonists would definitely know what to expect.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和赫伯特立刻把吉迪恩·史佩莱、潘克洛夫和纳布叫到了花岗石宫的餐厅，并把发生的事情告诉了他们。潘克洛夫抓起望远镜，迅速扫视了一下地平线，然后把目光停留在他们所指的那一点上，也就是照片底片上那个几乎看不见的小点。
en: Cyrus Harding and Herbert having immediately called Gideon Spilett, Pencroft, and Neb into the dining-room of Granite House, told them what had happened.Pencroft, seizing the telescope, rapidly swept the horizon, and stopping on the indicated point, that is to say, on that which had made the almost imperceptible spot on the photographic negative,—

zh: “见鬼！真是一艘船！”他喊道，说话的语气显得并不十分满意。
en: “I’m blessed but it is really a vessel!” he exclaimed, in a voice which did not express any great amount of satisfaction.

zh: “它要开向我们这里吗？”吉迪恩·史佩莱问道。
en: “Is she coming here?” asked Gideon Spilett.

zh: “现在还很难说，”潘克洛夫回答，“因为海平面上只露出桅杆，根本看不见船身。”
en: “Impossible to say anything yet,” answered Pencroft, “for her rigging alone is above the horizon, and not a bit of her hull can be seen.”

zh: “该怎么办呢？”少年问。
en: “What is to be done?” asked the lad.

zh: “等等看。”哈丁回答说。
en: “Wait,” replied Harding.

zh: 在很长一段时间里，岛上的移民们都沉默不语，他们沉浸在由此事所引起的各种思想、情感、恐惧和希望中，这是他们来到林肯岛以后发生的最重要的事件。当然，这些移民们的情况与那些被抛弃在孤岛上的遇难者不一样，后者为了能艰难地生存下去，经常要同残酷的大自然作斗争，因为想要回归家园的渴望而饱受折磨。尤其是潘克洛夫和纳布，他们立即感到既快乐、又富有，如果真的要离开孤岛，他们一定会深感遗憾。再说，他们已经习惯了这种新的生活，并且依靠自己的智慧，给这片土地带来了文明。但无论如何，这艘船带来了来自大陆的消息，甚至有可能来自他们的祖国。它将要给他们带来同伴，因此，可以想象，在他们看见船的时候，内心该是多么激动啊！
en: And for a considerable time the settlers remained silent, given up to all the thoughts, and the emotions, all the fears, all the hopes, which were aroused by this incident—the most important which had occurred since their arrival in Lincoln Island.Certainly, the colonists were not in the situation of castaways abandoned on a sterile islet, constantly contending against a cruel nature for their miserable existence, and incessantly tormented by the longing to return to inhabited countries.Pencroft and Neb, especially, who felt themselves at once so happy and so rich, would not have left their island without regret.They were accustomed, besides, to this new life in the midst of the domain which their intelligence had as it were civilized.But at any rate this ship brought news from the world, perhaps even from their native land.It was bringing fellow-creatures to them, and it may be conceived how deeply their hearts were moved at the sight!

zh: 潘克洛夫不时拿起望远镜，靠在窗口。他从那儿仔细地观察着那艘船，船在东面20海里的地方。移民们还没有办法发信号。无论是升旗、开枪还是点燃火把，船上的人都看不见也听不着。不过，可以肯定的是，孤岛上高耸的富兰克林山一定逃不过船上眺望哨的视线。可是，这艘船为什么要到这儿来呢？难道只是偶然来到这里的吗？在地图上，除了达抱岛以外，太平洋的这个地区没有任何其他陆地，而达抱岛本身也不在往来于波利尼西亚群岛、新西兰和美国海岸之间船只的航线上。每个人都在这样问自己，赫伯特突然做出回答。
en: From time to time Pencroft took the glass and rested himself at the window.From thence he very attentively examined the vessel, which was at a distance of twenty miles to the east.The colonists had as yet, therefore, no means of signalizing their presence.A flag would not have been perceived; a gun would not have been heard; a fire would not have been visible.However, it was certain that the island, overtopped by Mount Franklin, could not escape the notice of the vessel’s lookout.But why was the ship coming there?Was it simple chance which brought it to that part of the Pacific, where the maps mentioned no land except Tabor Island, which itself was out of the route usually followed by vessels from the Polynesian Archipelagoes, from New Zealand, and from the American coast?To this question, which each one asked himself, a reply was suddenly made by Herbert.

zh: “该不会是‘邓肯’号吧？”他大声说。
en: “Can it be the ‘Duncan’?” he cried.

zh: 前面已经说过，“邓肯”号是格里那凡爵士的游船，曾把艾尔顿遗弃在小岛上，日后还会回来把他接回去。达抱岛和林肯岛相隔并不很远，因此，在林肯岛上可以看见驶向达抱岛的船只。（两者之间的经线距离只有150英里，纬线距离则只有70英里。）
en: The “Duncan,” as has been said, was Lord Glenarvan’s yacht, which had left Ayrton on the islet, and which was to return there someday to fetch him.Now, the islet was not so far distant from Lincoln Island, but that a vessel, standing for the one, could pass in sight of the other.A hundred and fifty miles only separated them in longitude, and seventy in latitude.

zh: “我们必须通知艾尔顿，”吉迪恩·史佩莱说，“立刻把他喊来。只有他才能认出那只船是不是‘邓肯’号。”
en: “We must tell Ayrton,” said Gideon Spilett, “and send for him immediately.He alone can say if it is the ‘Duncan.’”

zh: 大家一致同意，于是记者走到联系畜栏和花岗石宫的电报机旁，发了一份电报：“速来。”
en: This was the opinion of all, and the reporter, going to the telegraphic apparatus which placed the corral in communication with Granite House, sent this telegram:—“Come with all possible speed.”

zh: 几分钟后，铃响了。
en: In a few minutes the bell sounded.

zh: 艾尔顿回答：“我就来。”
en: “I am coming,” replied Ayrton.

zh: 接着，移民们继续观察那艘船。
en: Then the settlers continued to watch the vessel.

zh: “如果它是‘邓肯’号，”赫伯特说，“艾尔顿肯定能轻而易举地认出来，因为他在这艘船上呆过一段时间。”
en: “If it is the ‘Duncan,’” said Herbert, “Ayrton will recognize her without difficulty, since he sailed on board her for some time.”

zh: “如果艾尔顿真的认出了它，”潘克洛夫补充道，“一定会激动万分！”
en: “And if he recognizes her,” added Pencroft, “it will agitate him exceedingly!”

zh: “是的，”赛勒斯·哈丁回答说，“现在艾尔顿已经有资格回到‘邓肯’号上去了，老天保佑它真的是格里那凡爵士的游船，否则除此之外的任何船只都令我怀疑。这一带海面上经常有坏人出没，我总担心会有来自马来的海盗光顾我们的小岛，”
en: “Yes,” answered Cyrus Harding; “but now Ayrton is worthy to return on board the ‘Duncan,’ and pray Heaven that it is indeed Lord Glenarvan’s yacht, for I should be suspicious of any other vessel.These are ill-famed seas, and I have always feared a visit from Malay pirates to our island.”

zh: “我们可以保卫小岛。”赫伯特叫道。
en: “We could defend it,’, cried Herbert.

zh: “那当然，孩子，”工程师微笑着说，“不过要是用不着保卫，那就更好了。”
en: “No doubt, my boy,” answered the engineer smiling, “but it would be better not to have to defend it.”

zh: “这种想法是没有必要的，”史佩莱说，“既然连最新的地图上都没有标出林肯岛，那么航海者们一定不知道它的存在。要是一艘船突然发现了新陆地，肯定会有充分的理由试着去勘探一番，而不会避开它离去，你说是不是，赛勒斯？”
en: “A useless observation,” said Spilett.“Lincoln Island is unknown to navigators, since it is not marked even on the most recent maps.Do you think, Cyrus, that that is a sufficient motive for a ship, finding herself unexpectedly in sight of new land, to try and visit rather than avoid it?”

zh: “当然。”潘克洛夫回答。
en: “Certainly,” replied Pencroft.

zh: “我也这么认为，”工程师补充说，“甚至可以这样说：任何一位船长都有责任勘察所有尚未被发现的陆地或岛屿，而林肯岛正属于这种情况。”
en: “I think so too,” added the engineer.“It may even be said that it is the duty of a captain to come and survey any land or island not yet known, and Lincoln Island is in this position.”

zh: “那么，”潘克洛夫说，“如果这艘船来了，并且就在离我们岛几链远的地方下锚，我们该怎么办？”
en: “Well,” said Pencroft, “suppose this vessel comes and anchors there a few cables-lengths from our island, what shall we do?”

zh: 这个突如其来的问题一时无人作答。不过，赛勒斯·哈丁考虑了一会之后，便和往常一样，用平静的语气答道：
en: This sudden question remained at first without any reply.But Cyrus Harding, after some moments’ thought, replied in the calm tone which was usual to him,—

zh: “朋友们，怎么办？应该这么办：我们要和船上的人取得联系，然后乘着它离开这座我们以美国的名义占有的岛屿。将来，我们要和那些愿意跟随我们的人回来，正式对它进行开发，为美利坚合众国在太平洋的这个地区奉献一个有用的基地！”
en: “What we shall do, my friends?What we ought to do is this:—we will communicate with the ship, we will take our passage on board her, and we will leave our island, after having taken possession of it in the name of the United States.Then we will return with any who may wish to follow us to colonize it definitely, and endow the American Republic with a useful station in this part of the Pacific Ocean!”

zh: “哇！”潘克洛夫叫道，“我们送给祖国的这份礼物可不小啊！对小岛的开发已经接近完工，岛上的每一部分都命了名，这里有天然港口、淡水、道路、电报设备、船坞和一些制造厂，只差把林肯岛标在地图上了！”
en: “Hurrah!” exclaimed Pencroft, “and that will be no small present which we shall make to our country!The colonization is already almost finished; names are given to every part of the island; there is a natural port, fresh water, roads, a telegraph, a dockyard, and manufactories; and there will be nothing to be done but to inscribe Lincoln Island on the maps!”

zh: “可是，如果有人趁我们不在的时候占领了它怎么办？”吉迪恩·史佩莱说。
en: “But if anyone seizes it in our absence?” observed Gideon Spilett.

zh: “该死！”水手喊道，“我宁可一个人留下来保卫它，　相信我潘克洛夫吧，我是不会让他们就像从鼓起来的口袋中偷取手表一样，从我手中抢走小岛的。”
en: “Hang it!” cried the sailor.“I would rather remain all alone to guard it: and trust to Pencroft, they shouldn’t steal it from him, like a watch from the pocket of a swell!”

zh: 整整一个小时，大家还无法确定这艘船会不会朝林肯岛驶来。它近了点，但究竟是沿着什么方向航行的呢？这一点潘克洛夫也不能断定。不过，由于这时刮的是东北风，这艘船很可能是右舷抢风行驶。此外，向林肯岛开来恰巧是顺风，海面上又是风平浪静，所以尽管地图上没有标出浅滩的位置，它仍可以放心大胆地开过来。
en: For an hour it was impossible to say with any certainty whether the vessel was or was not standing towards Lincoln Island.She was nearer, but in what direction was she sailing?This Pencroft could not determine.However, as the wind was blowing from the northeast, in all probability the vessel was sailing on the starboard tack.Besides, the wind was favorable for bringing her towards the island, and, the sea being calm, she would not be afraid to approach although the shallows were not marked on the chart.

zh: 四点左右——也就是接到邀请后的一个小时——艾尔顿来到了花岗石宫。他走进餐厅，说：
en: Towards four o’clock—an hour after he had been sent for—Ayrton arrived at Granite House.He entered the dining-room saying,—

zh: “有什么吩咐，先生们？”
en: “At your service, gentlemen.”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁照例向他伸出手来，把他领到窗口。
en: Cyrus Harding gave him his hand, as was his custom to do, and, leading him to the window,—

zh: “艾尔顿，”他说，“我们请你到这来有一件重要的事情。岛的附近有一艘船。”
en: “Ayrton,” said he, “we have begged you to come here for an important reason.A ship is in sight of the island.”

zh: 起初艾尔顿的脸色略微一变，不一会儿，眼神暗淡下来，接着，他把身体探出窗外，扫视了一下水平线，可什么也没看见。
en: Ayrton at first paled slightly, and for a moment his eyes became dim; then, leaning out the window, he surveyed the horizon, but could see nothing.

zh: “用望远镜仔细看一看吧，”史佩莱说，“艾尔顿，也许是‘邓肯’号为了接你回家再次来到这片海域。”
en: “Take this telescope,” said Spilett, “and look carefully, Ayrton, for it is possible that this ship may be the ‘Duncan’ come to these seas for the purpose of taking you home again.”

zh: “‘邓肯’号！”艾尔顿喃喃地说，“来了吗？”他不由自主地说完最后这句话，然后双手抱头。
en: “The ‘Duncan!’” murmured Ayrton.“Already?”This last word escaped Ayrton’s lips as if involuntarily, and his head drooped upon his hands.

zh: 难道他认为在荒岛上独居了12年还不足以弥补自己的罪过吗？不论在他自己还是别人的眼里，这位悔过的罪人，难道还不觉得已经得到宽恕了吗？
en: Did not twelve years’ solitude on a desert island appear to him a sufficient expiation?Did not the penitent yet feel himself pardoned, either in his own eyes or in the eyes of others?

zh: “不，”他说，“不！不会是‘邓肯’号！”
en: “No,” said he, “no! it cannot be the ‘Duncan’!”

zh: “再看看，艾尔顿，”工程师说，“我们必须事先知道将会发生什么事。”
en: “Look, Ayrton,” then said the engineer, “for it is necessary that we should know beforehand what to expect.”

zh: 艾尔顿拿起望远镜，朝大家所指的方向看去。他一动不动，默不作声地对着地平线看了好几分钟，然后说：
en: Ayrton took the glass and pointed it in the direction indicated.During some minutes he examined the horizon without moving, without uttering a word.Then,—

zh: “确实是一艘船，但我认为它不是‘邓肯’号。”
en: “It is indeed a vessel,” said he, “but I do not think she is the ‘Duncan.’”

zh: “为什么你认为不是呢？”吉迪恩·史佩莱问道。
en: “Why do you not think so?” asked Gideon Spilett.

zh: “因为‘邓肯’号是一艘蒸汽游船，而我在这艘船的上方和四周却连一点烟都看不见。”
en: “Because the ‘Duncan’ is a steam-yacht, and I cannot perceive any trace of smoke either above or near that vessel.”

zh: “也许它正张着帆在航行，”潘克洛夫说，“它现在的方向恰巧是顺风，离陆地这么远，它或许迫切想节省一点煤。”
en: “Perhaps she is simply sailing,” observed Pencroft.“The wind is favorable for the direction which she appears to be taking, and she may be anxious to economize her coal, being so far from land.”

zh: “也许你说得对，潘克洛夫先生，”艾尔顿回答说，“这艘船可能把火熄了。我们只能等它驶近一点，到时候就可以知道将要发生什么了。”
en: “It is possible that you may be right, Mr. Pencroft,” answered Ayrton, “and that the vessel has extinguished her fires.We must wait until she is nearer, and then we shall soon know what to expect.”

zh: 说完，艾尔顿就在房间的一个角落里坐了下来，保持沉默。移民们又谈起这艘陌生的船，但艾尔顿没有参与谈话。大家都已经没有心思继续工作。吉迪恩·史佩莱和潘克洛夫显得尤为紧张，他俩走来走去，一刻也坐不住。赫伯特则感到好奇。只有纳布和往常一样保持着镇定。他的祖国难道不是他的主人所在地方吗？至于工程师，他陷入了沉思，在他心里，与其说是盼望这艘船来，还不如说是害怕它来。这时候，船离岛又近了些。从望远镜里，他们可以看清这是一艘双桅船，而不是太平洋海盗们常用的那种马来帆船。所以，人们有理由相信工程师的担心看来是多余的，这艘船在海岛附近出现并不会为他们带来值得担心的危险。
en: So saying, Ayrton sat down in a corner of the room and remained silent.The colonists again discussed the strange ship, but Ayrton took no part in the conversation.All were in such a mood that they found it impossible to continue their work.Gideon Spilett and Pencroft were particularly nervous, going, coming, not able to remain still in one place.Herbert felt more curiosity.Neb alone maintained his usual calm manner.Was not his country that where his master was?As to the engineer, he remained plunged in deep thought, and in his heart feared rather than desired the arrival of the ship.In the meanwhile, the vessel was a little nearer the island.With the aid of the glass, it was ascertained that she was a brig, and not one of those Malay proas, which are generally used by the pirates of the Pacific.It was, therefore, reasonable to believe that the engineer’s apprehensions would not be justified, and that the presence of this vessel in the vicinity of the island was fraught with no danger.

zh: 潘克洛夫经过一番仔细检查，确定这是一艘双桅船，它正借助右舷风，鼓足所有的风帆，对着海岸斜驶过来。艾尔顿也证实了这一点。可是，照这样的方向行驶，双桅船很快就会消失在爪角后面，因为现在刮的是西南风，要对它进行观察，就必须登上气球港附近华盛顿湾的高地。而让人生气的是，这时已是傍晚五点钟，苍茫的暮色很快就会使观察变得异常艰难。
en: Pencroft, after a minute examination, was able positively to affirm that the vessel was rigged as a brig, and that she was standing obliquely towards the coast, on the starboard tack, under her topsails and top-gallant-sails.This was confirmed by Ayrton.But by continuing in this direction she must soon disappear behind Claw Cape, as the wind was from the southwest, and to watch her it would be then necessary to ascend the height of Washington Bay, near Port Balloon—a provoking circumstance, for it was already five o’clock in the evening, and the twilight would soon make any observation extremely difficult.

zh: “天黑了我们该怎么办？”吉迪恩·史佩莱问道。“要不要点起一堆火，好让他们知道在海岸这我们的存在？”
en: “What shall we do when night comes on?” asked Gideon Spilett.“Shall we light a fire, so as to signal our presence on the coast?”

zh: 这个问题事关重大，尽管工程师心里还有一种不祥的预感，但还是同意这么做。在夜间，这艘船也许会消失，会一去不复返，一旦它走了，还会有其他船只再到林肯岛附近来吗？谁能预见移民们的未来呢？
en: This was a serious question, and yet, although the engineer still retained some of his presentiments, it was answered in the affirmative.During the night the ship might disappear and leave for ever, and, this ship gone, would another ever return to the waters of Lincoln Island?Who could foresee what the future would then have in store for the colonists?

zh: “不错，”记者说，“不管它是什么船，我们都要让船上的人知道岛上有人居住。要是错过这个送上门来的机会，也许会造成永久的后悔。”
en: “Yes,” said the reporter, “we ought to make known to that vessel, whoever she may be, that the island is inhabited.To neglect the opportunity which is offered to us might be to create everlasting regrets.”

zh: 于是大家决定让纳布和潘克洛夫去气球港，等天黑后，就在那里点燃一大堆火，火光一定会引起双桅船的注意。
en: It was therefore decided that Neb and Pencroft should go to Port Balloon, and that there, at nightfall, they should light an immense fire, the blaze of which would necessarily attract the attention of the brig.

zh: 可是，正当纳布和水手准备离开花岗石宫的时候，那艘船改变了方向，径直朝联合湾驶来。这是一艘好船，很快就靠近了海岸。于是，纳布和潘克洛夫暂时留了下来，大家把望远镜交给艾尔顿，让他最后确认这艘船到底是不是“邓肯”号。苏格兰游船——“邓肯”号也是一艘双桅船。现在，船离海岛只有五英里了，问题就是要看清它的两根桅杆之间有没有烟囱。
en: But at the moment when Neb and the sailor were preparing to leave Granite House, the vessel suddenly altered her course, and stood directly for Union Bay.The brig was a good sailer, for she approached rapidly.Neb and Pencroft put off their departure, therefore, and the glass was put into Ayrton’s hands, that he might ascertain for certain whether the ship was or was not the “Duncan.”The Scotch yacht was also rigged as a brig.The question was, whether a chimney could be discerned between the two masts of the vessel, which was now at a distance of only five miles.

zh: 海平面还很清晰。观察起来很容易，艾尔顿很快放下望远镜，说：
en: The horizon was still very clear.The examination was easy, and Ayrton soon let the glass fall again, saying—

zh: “这不是‘邓肯’号！绝不是它！”
en: “It is not the ‘Duncan’!It could not be!”

zh: 潘克洛夫重新把这艘双桅船锁定在望远镜的视线里，只见船的吨位有三百到四百吨，船身完美狭长，樯帆齐整，结构精巧，这一定是一艘航海的快船。可它究竟是哪个国家的呢？这还很难说。
en: Pencroft again brought the brig within the range of the telescope, and could see that she was of between three and four hundred tons burden, wonderfully narrow, well-masted, admirably built, and must be a very rapid sailer.But to what nation did she belong?That was difficult to say.

zh: “不过，”水手接着说，“船顶上飘着一面旗，只是我看不清它的颜色。”
en: “And yet,” added the sailor, “a flag is floating from her peak, but I cannot distinguish the colors of it.”

zh: “半个小时后就可以确定了。”记者说，“此外，那艘船的船长显然有上岸的打算，因此，今天，最晚不超过明天，我们就可以认识他了。”
en: “In half an hour we shall be certain about that,” answered the reporter.“Besides, it is very evident that the intention of the captain of this ship is to land, and, consequently, if not today, to-morrow at the latest, we shall make his acquaintance.”

zh: “这个倒无所谓！”潘克洛夫说，“最好能知道我们将要和什么样的人打交道，要是能认出船上旗帜的颜色该多好啊！”
en: “Never mind!” said Pencroft.“It is best to know whom we have to deal with, and I shall not be sorry to recognize that fellow’s colors!”

zh: 说这些话的时候，水手的双眼始终没有离开望远镜。夜色开始降临，海上的风也随之减弱。双桅船的旗帜卷成一团，更加难以辨认了。
en: And, while thus speaking, the sailor never left the glass.The day began to fade, and with the day the breeze fell also.The brig’s ensign hung in folds, and it became more and more difficult to observe it.

zh: “这不是美国国旗，”潘克洛夫不时地说，“也不是英国国旗，否则上面的红颜色很容易看出来。也不是法国国旗或德国国旗，也不是俄国的白旗，也不是西班牙的黄旗。好像是一面单色旗。让我想一想：在这一带海面上，经常会遇见哪种旗？智利旗吗？——那是三色的。巴西旗？——那是绿色的。日本旗？——那是黑黄两色的，而这面旗——”
en: “It is not the American flag,” said Pencroft from time to time, “nor the English, the red of which could be easily seen, nor the French or German colors, nor the white flag of Russia, nor the yellow of Spain.One would say it was all one color.Let’s see: in these seas, what do we generally meet with?The Chilean flag?—but that is tri-color.Brazilian?—it is green.Japanese?—it is yellow and black, while this—”

zh: 这时候，一阵微风把这面陌生的旗吹开了。艾尔顿抓起水手放下来的望远镜，举到眼前，然后以嘶哑的声音喊道：
en: At that moment the breeze blew out the unknown flag.Ayrton seizing the telescope which the sailor had put down, put it to his eye, and in a hoarse voice,—

zh: “是黑旗！”
en: “The black flag!” he exclaimed.

zh: 的确，双桅船的桅杆上飘扬着一面阴森森的旗帜，现在大家完全有理由把它看做一艘可疑的船只了！
en: And indeed the somber bunting was floating from the mast of the brig, and they had now good reason for considering her to be a suspicious vessel!

zh: 这么说，工程师的预感是对的？这是一艘海盗船吗？它是不是在太平洋这一带海上出没，并且和在这里横行的马来船争霸呢？它到林肯岛附近的海岸来干什么？他们认为这是一座无名荒岛，准备在这里窝藏劫来的赃物吗？还是打算在海岛沿岸寻找一个过冬的港口？难道移民们的这片净土注定要成为一个肮脏之所、一个太平洋海盗的巢穴了吗？
en: Had the engineer, then, been right in his presentiments?Was this a pirate vessel?Did she scour the Pacific, competing with the Malay proas which still infest it?For what had she come to look at the shores of Lincoln Island?Was it to them an unknown island, ready to become a magazine for stolen cargoes?Had she come to find on the coast a sheltered port for the winter months?Was the settlers’ honest domain destined to be transformed into an infamous refuge—the headquarters of the piracy of the Pacific?

zh: 这些念头不由自主地出现在移民们的脑海里。此外，被升起的船旗的颜色所代表的意义已经毋庸置疑。那是海盗的旗子！要是当初那些罪犯的罪恶阴谋得逞的话，那么‘邓肯’号也会挂上这种旗子！大家立刻开始商量对策。
en: All these ideas instinctively presented themselves to the colonists’ imaginations.There was no doubt, besides, of the signification which must be attached to the color of the hoisted flag.It was that of pirates!It was that which the “Duncan” would have carried, had the convicts succeeded in their criminal design!No time was lost before discussing it.

zh: “朋友们，”赛勒斯·哈丁说，“也许这艘船只是想巡视一下岛的海岸。也许船员根本不会上岸。这也是可能的。不管怎样，我们必须尽量把自己隐藏起来。眺望岗上的风车太容易被看到了。艾尔顿和纳布去把风翼拆下来。同时，花岗石宫的窗户也要用厚厚的树枝遮住。火也要全部熄灭，总之，不要暴露任何岛上有人的痕迹。”
en: “My friends,” said Cyrus Harding, “perhaps this vessel only wishes to survey the coast of the island.Perhaps her crew will not land.There is a chance of it.However that may be, we ought to do everything we can to hide our presence here.The windmill on Prospect Heights is too easily seen.Let Ayrton and Neb go and take down the sails.We must also conceal the windows of Granite House with thick branches.All the fires must be extinguished, so that nothing may betray the presence of men on the island.”

zh: “我们的船怎么办？”赫伯特问道。
en: “And our vessel?” said Herbert.

zh: “噢，”潘克洛夫回答说，“它藏在气球港呢，我不相信这些无赖能找到它！”
en: “Oh,” answered Pencroft, “she is sheltered in Port Balloon, and I defy any of those rascals there to find her!”

zh: 工程师的命令立刻得到了执行。纳布和艾尔顿爬上了高地，采取了必要的措施，以掩盖任何岛上有人居住的迹象。当他们在进行这项工作的时候，其他人从啄木鸟林的边缘捡回了许多树枝和藤条，从远处看，它们像是天然的树叶，花岗石宫的窗户就这样伪装起来了。同时，枪支弹药也安置妥当了，随时可以用来应付突然袭击。
en: The engineer’s orders were immediately executed.Neb and Ayrton ascended the plateau, and took the necessary precautions to conceal any indication of a settlement.While they were thus occupied, their companions went to the border of Jacamar Wood, and brought back a large quantity of branches and creepers, which would at some distance appear as natural foliage, and thus disguise the windows in the granite cliff.At the same time, the ammunition and guns were placed ready so as to be at hand in case of an unexpected attack.

zh: 当所有这些设施都安置妥当以后——
en: When all these precautions had been taken,—

zh: 哈丁说：“朋友们，”他的声音暴露了他内心的情感，“假如这些混蛋想占领林肯岛，我们一定要保卫它，对吗？”
en: “My friends,” said Harding, and his voice betrayed some emotion, “if the wretches endeavor to seize Lincoln Island, we shall defend it—shall we not?”

zh: “对，赛勒斯，”记者回答说，“必要的时候，我们不惜牺牲生命来保卫它！”
en: “Yes, Cyrus,” replied the reporter, “and if necessary we will die to defend it!”

zh: 工程师向伙伴们伸出手来，大家热烈地握紧他的手。艾尔顿还是一个人呆在角落里，没有和大家一起握手。作为一名昔日的罪犯，也许他认为自己还没有资格这样做！
en: The engineer extended his hand to his companions, who pressed it warmly.Ayrton remained in his corner, not joining the colonists.Perhaps he, the former convict, still felt himself unworthy to do so!

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁明白艾尔通的心里的想法，就走到他身边。
en: Cyrus Harding understood what was passing in Ayrton’s mind, and going to him—

zh: “你呢，艾尔顿，”他问道，“你会怎么办？”
en: “And you, Ayrton,” he asked, “what will you do?”

zh: “尽我的义务。”艾尔顿回答。
en: “My duty,” answered Ayrton.

zh: 说完他站到窗边，透过树枝往外看。
en: He then took up his station near the window and gazed through the foliage.

zh: 这时是七点半。太阳早在20分钟前就消失在了花岗石宫的后面。接着，东方的海平面逐渐模糊起来。这时候，双桅船继续向联合湾驶去。它绕过爪角之后，便顺着上涨的潮流往北而去，现在，它正对着眺望岗的高地，离联合湾不到两英里。到了这个距离，甚至可以说已经进入了宽广的海湾，因为如果在爪角和颚骨角之间划一条直线，那么这条直线正穿过船右舷的后侧部分。
en: It was now half-past seven.The sun had disappeared twenty minutes ago behind Granite House.Consequently the Eastern horizon was becoming obscured.In the meanwhile the brig continued to advance towards Union Bay.She was now not more than two miles off, and exactly opposite the plateau of Prospect Heights, for after having tacked off Claw Cape, she had drifted towards the north in the current of the rising tide.One might have said that at this distance she had already entered the vast bay, for a straight line drawn from Claw Cape to Cape Mandible would have rested on her starboard quarter.

zh: 这艘船是否打算深入海湾？这是第一个问题。船一旦进入了海湾，会不会在那里抛锚？这是第二个问题。它是否会仅仅满足于巡视一下海岸，不让船员们上岸就离开？再过一个小时，他们就能知道答案了。移民们目前只能等待。
en: Was the brig about to penetrate far into the bay?That was the first question.When once in the bay, would she anchor there?That was the second.Would she not content herself with only surveying the coast, and stand out to sea again without landing her crew?They would know this in an hour.The colonists could do nothing but wait.

zh: 看了这艘可疑的船只所悬挂的黑旗之后，赛勒斯·哈丁深感忧虑。迄今为止，他和伙伴们的工作都非常顺利，这艘船的到来会不会对此正好构成威胁？双桅船的水手们毫无疑问只能是一群海盗，他们是不是曾经来过这里，因此在靠岸的时候才挂起黑旗呢？他们会不会曾经侵占过这个小岛呢？这样的话，某些至今无法解释的怪事也许就能水落石出了。在岛上那些尚未勘探的地方，会不会还有海盗的同伙准备与双桅船上的海盗联系呢？
en: Cyrus Harding had not seen the suspected vessel hoist the black flag without deep anxiety.Was it not a direct menace against the work which he and his companions had till now conducted so successfully?Had these pirates—for the sailors of the brig could be nothing else—already visited the island, since on approaching it they had hoisted their colors.Had they formerly invaded it, so that certain unaccountable peculiarities might be explained in this way?Did there exist in the as yet unexplored parts some accomplice ready to enter into communication with them?

zh: 哈丁暗自思考着这些问题，却不知如何回答；但他觉得，这艘双桅船的到来，只会对移民们的安全带来严重的威胁。
en: To all these questions which he mentally asked himself, Harding knew not what to reply; but he felt that the safety of the colony could not but be seriously threatened by the arrival of the brig.

zh: 不管怎样，他和他的同伴们决心抵抗到底。目前知道以下这些信息是很重要的：这些海盗的人数多不多？他们的装备是不是比移民们优良？可是如何获取这些消息呢？
en: However, he and his companions were determined to fight to the last gasp.It would have been very important to know if the pirates were numerous and better armed than the colonists.But how was this information to he obtained?

zh: 夜晚来临了。新月已经消失。小岛和海面被一片漆黑笼罩着。海平面上盖着厚重的乌云，透不过一丝光线。风也随着暮色消失了。树叶的沙沙声和岸边潺潺的水声也听不见了。双桅船上的灯光全部熄灭了，因此一点也看不见它，即使它还在小岛附近，却无法断定它的行踪了。
en: Night fell.The new moon had disappeared.Profound darkness enveloped the island and the sea.No light could pierce through the heavy piles of clouds on the horizon.The wind had died away completely with the twilight.Not a leaf rustled on the trees, not a ripple murmured on the shore.Nothing could be seen of the ship, all her lights being extinguished, and if she was still in sight of the island, her whereabouts could not be discovered.

zh: “哎！谁知道呢？”潘克洛夫说，“也许这艘该死的船会在夜里开走，明天黎明时分我们就找不到它了。”
en: “Well! who knows?” said Pencroft.“Perhaps that cursed craft will stand off during the night, and we shall see nothing of her at daybreak.”

zh: 这时，黑暗中突然闪过一道亮光，接着传来一声炮响，仿佛是在回答水手的话。
en: As if in reply to the sailor’s observation, a bright light flashed in the darkness, and a cannon-shot was heard.

zh: 船还在那里，而且船上有大炮。
en: The vessel was still there and had guns on board.

zh: 从看见闪光到听见炮声，中间有六秒钟的间隔。
en: Six seconds elapsed between the flash and the report.

zh: 因此，双桅船距离海岸大约有一又四分之一海里。
en: Therefore the brig was about a mile and a quarter from the coast.

zh: 这时，大家听见了铁链从链孔里放出来的哗哗声。
en: At the same time, the chains were heard rattling through the hawse-holes.

zh: 船在花岗石宫的视线内抛锚了！
en: The vessel had just anchored in sight of Granite House!

zh: 第二章
en: Chapter 2

zh: 海盗们的企图已经很明显了。他们在离岛不远的地方下了锚，显然是打算第二天乘小艇登上海滩。
en: There was no longer any doubt as to the pirates’ intentions.They had dropped anchor at a short distance from the island, and it was evident that the next day by means of their boats they purposed to land on the beach!

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和同伴们随时准备行动，但是，尽管他们下定了决心，也不能轻举妄动。如果海盗们上岸后不深入岛内进行视察，那么他们也许还可以隐藏起来。这些海盗也许只是想从慈悲河里取一些淡水，这样的话，他们也可能发现不了离河口一英里半的那座桥和“石窟”那里的工厂。
en: Cyrus Harding and his companions were ready to act, but, determined though they were, they must not forget to be prudent.Perhaps their presence might still be concealed in the event of the pirates contenting themselves with landing on the shore without examining the interior of the island.It might be, indeed, that their only intention was to obtain fresh water from the Mercy, and it was not impossible that the bridge, thrown across a mile and a half from the mouth, and the manufactory at the Chimneys might escape their notice.

zh: 但是，为什么要在船顶上挂起那面旗呢？为什么又要开那一炮呢？毫无疑问，这是一种纯粹的示威，不然就表示占领孤岛的一种行为。哈丁现在知道，船上的装备十分精良。那么林肯岛上的移民们有什么武器可以对付海盗们的大炮呢？只不过有几杆滑膛枪而已。
en: But why was that flag hoisted at the brig’s peak?What was that shot fired for?Pure bravado doubtless, unless it was a sign of the act of taking possession.Harding knew now that the vessel was well armed.And what had the colonists of Lincoln Island to reply to the pirates’ guns?A few muskets only.

zh: “不管怎样，”赛勒斯·哈丁指出，“我们这里所在的位置牢不可破。花岗石宫的出口隐蔽在芦苇和杂草丛中，敌人是发现不了的，因此他们就不可能闯进来。”
en: “However,” observed Cyrus Harding, “here we are in an impregnable position.The enemy cannot discover the mouth of the outlet, now that it is hidden under reeds and grass, and consequently it would be impossible for them to penetrate into Granite House.”

zh: “可是我们的农场该怎么办？还有家禽场、畜栏，和所有这一切！”潘克洛夫跺着脚嚷道。“要不了几个小时，他们就能把这一切都给毁了！”
en: “But our plantations, our poultry-yard, our corral, all, everything!” exclaimed Pencroft, stamping his foot.“They may spoil everything, destroy everything in a few hours!”

zh: “是的，一切都会被毁灭的，潘克洛夫，”哈丁回答说，“可我们没有任何办法可以阻止他们。”
en: “Everything, Pencroft,” answered Harding, “and we have no means of preventing them.”

zh: “问题在于他们人多不多，”记者说，“如果他们只有十来个人，我们可以阻止他们，但要是有四十、五十甚至更多人的话……”
en: “Are they numerous? that is the question,” said the reporter.“If they are not more than a dozen, we shall be able to stop them, but forty, fifty, more perhaps!”

zh: “哈丁队长，”艾尔顿一边说，一边朝工程师走去，“你能答应让我离开一下吗？”
en: “Captain Harding,” then said Ayrton, advancing towards the engineer, “will you give me leave?”

zh: “什么事，朋友？”
en: “For what, my friend?”

zh: “让我到船上去打探一下敌人的实力。”
en: “To go to that vessel to find out the strength of her crew.”

zh: “可是，艾尔顿……”工程师犹豫不决地回答，“这样做会有生命危险……”
en: “But Ayrton—” answered the engineer, hesitating, “you will risk your life—”

zh: “为什么不试一试呢，先生？”
en: “Why not, sir?”

zh: “这不是你分内的事情。”
en: “That is more than your duty.”

zh: “分外的事我也应该做。”艾尔顿答道。
en: “I have more than my duty to do,” replied Ayrton.

zh: “你打算坐小船去接近那艘船吗？”吉迪恩·史佩莱问。
en: “Will you go to the ship in the boat?” asked Gideon Spilett.

zh: “不，先生，我泅水过去。坐船去会被发现的，而光一个人去则可以从风浪之中潜水过去。”
en: “No, sir, but I will swim.A boat would be seen where a man may glide between wind and water.”

zh: “你可知道，双桅船离海岸有一又四分之一英里呢！”赫伯特说道。
en: “Do you know that the brig is a mile and a quarter from the shore?” said Herbert.

zh: “我水性很好，赫伯特先生。”
en: “I am a good swimmer, Mr. Herbert.”

zh: “我要提醒你，这样做有生命危险。”工程师说。
en: “I tell you it is risking your life,” said the engineer.

zh: “没关系，”艾尔顿回答说，“哈丁队长，请同意我的请求。在我看来，这也许是我重新做人的一次机会！”
en: “That is no matter,” answered Ayrton.“Captain Harding, I ask this as a favor.Perhaps it will be a means of raising me in my own eyes!”

zh: “去吧，艾尔顿。”工程师答道，他明白，如果他拒绝，会深深伤害这位已经改邪归正的前罪犯。
en: “Go, Ayrton,” replied the engineer, who felt sure that a refusal would have deeply wounded the former convict, now become an honest man.

zh: “我陪你去。”潘克洛夫说。
en: “I will accompany you,” said Pencroft.

zh: “你不信任我！”艾尔顿立刻说。
en: “You mistrust me!” said Ayrton quickly.

zh: 然后又谦卑地叹了一口气：
en: Then more humbly,—
“Alas!”

zh: “不！不！”哈丁带着鼓励的口吻说，“不是这样的，艾尔顿，潘克洛夫并没有不信任你。你误解了他的话。”
en: “No! no!” exclaimed Harding with animation, “no, Ayrton, Pencroft does not mistrust you.You interpret his words wrongly.”

zh: “不错，”水手回答说，“我只是想把艾尔顿送到小岛上。尽管不太可能，但也许那些混蛋中已经有人上岸了，真要是这样，要阻止他报信，两个人就不算多了。既然艾尔顿提出要上船，那就让他一个人去，我留在小岛上等他。”事情谈妥之后，艾尔顿便准备出发了。他的计划很大胆，但幸好有夜色的保护，还是有可能取得成功。只要艾尔通能到达船边，抓住主链，他就可以侦查出海盗的人数，或许还能偷听到他们的企图。
en: “Indeed,” returned the sailor, “I only propose to accompany Ayrton as far as the islet.It may be, although it is scarcely possible, that one of these villains has landed, and in that case two men will not be too many to hinder him from giving the alarm.I will wait for Ayrton on the islet, and he shall go alone to the vessel, since he has proposed to do so.”These things agreed to, Ayrton made preparations for his departure.His plan was bold, but it might succeed, thanks to the darkness of the night.Once arrived at the vessel’s side, Ayrton, holding on to the main chains, might reconnoiter the number and perhaps overhear the intentions of the pirates.

zh: 艾尔顿和潘克洛夫在同伴们的陪同下，来到了下面的海滩上。艾尔顿脱掉衣服，在身上抹了一层油，以免受冻，因为海水还很凉。事实上，也许他将不得不在水里呆上好几个小时。
en: Ayrton and Pencroft, followed by their companions, descended to the beach.Ayrton undressed and rubbed himself with grease, so as to suffer less from the temperature of the water, which was still cold.He might, indeed, be obliged to remain in it for several hours.

zh: 这时候，潘克洛夫和纳布去几百英尺远的慈悲河河滩上搬停靠在那里的小船。他们回来时，艾尔顿已经准备好要出发了。他把衣服搭在肩膀上，移民们都跑过来和他握手。
en: Pencroft and Neb, during this time, had gone to fetch the boat, moored a few hundred feet higher up, on the bank of the Mercy, and by the time they returned, Ayrton was ready to start.A coat was thrown over his shoulders, and the settlers all came round him to press his hand.

zh: 接着艾尔顿和潘克洛夫就把船开走了。
en: Ayrton then shoved off with Pencroft in the boat.

zh: 晚上十点半，这两位冒险家消失在夜色之中。他们的同伴则回到“石窟”那，等待他们归来。
en: It was half-past ten in the evening when the two adventurers disappeared in the darkness.Their companions returned to wait at the Chimneys.

zh: 小船顺利度过海峡，在对面的小岛上靠了岸。他们做这一切的时候非常小心，生怕海盗们会在这一带游荡。不过经过一番仔细侦察，他们确信岛上没有其他人。于是，艾尔顿在潘克洛夫前面，迅速穿过小岛，惊动了那些在石洞里的鸟儿们；接着，艾尔顿毫不犹豫地跳进海里，无声无息地朝双桅船游去，船上刚刚亮起几盏灯，指明了它的确切位置。潘克洛夫蹲在石缝中，等待同伴归来。
en: The channel was easily traversed, and the boat touched the opposite shore of the islet.This was not done without precaution, for fear lest the pirates might be roaming about there.But after a careful survey, it was evident that the islet was deserted.Ayrton then, followed by Pencroft, crossed it with a rapid step, scaring the birds nestled in the holes of the rocks; then, without hesitating, he plunged into the sea, and swam noiselessly in the direction of the ship, in which a few lights had recently appeared, showing her exact situation.As to Pencroft, he crouched down in a cleft of the rock, and awaited the return of his companion.

zh: 这时候，艾尔顿在水中奋力向前游，没有发出丝毫声响。他只把头露出水面，两眼盯着双桅船那黑暗的船身，那里可以看见船上的灯光映在水中。他所想到的只是履行自己的承诺，完成任务，而他将要面临的危险——无论是来自船上，还是来自常有鲨鱼出没的海中——他都丝毫没有想到。水流带着他前进，很快就离开了海岸。半小时后，艾尔顿在无人看见和听到的情况下到了船边，抓住了船的主链。他吸了一口气，攀着铁链,一直爬上了船头的顶端。那里晾着几条水手裤。他穿上一条。然后站稳脚跟，听了起来。双桅船上的人都没有睡。反而在说笑唱歌。有时还夹杂着谩骂，最让艾尔顿震惊的是这几句话：
en: In the meanwhile, Ayrton, swimming with a vigorous stroke, glided through the sheet of water without producing the slightest ripple.His head just emerged above it and his eyes were fixed on the dark hull of the brig, from which the lights were reflected in the water.He thought only of the duty which he had promised to accomplish, and nothing of the danger which he ran, not only on board the ship, but in the sea, often frequented by sharks.The current bore him along and he rapidly receded from the shore.Half an hour afterwards, Ayrton, without having been either seen or heard, arrived at the ship and caught hold of the main-chains.He took breath, then, hoisting himself up, he managed to reach the extremity of the cutwater.There were drying several pairs of sailors’ trousers.He put on a pair.Then settling himself firmly, he listened.They were not sleeping on board the brig.On the contrary, they were talking, singing, laughing.And these were the sentences, accompanied with oaths, which principally struck Ayrton:—

zh: “我们抢来的这艘船真是太棒了！”
en: “Our brig is a famous acquisition.”

zh: “它开得真快！不愧叫‘飞快’号！”
en: “She sails well, and merits her name of the ‘Speedy.’”

zh: “诺福克的海军船队没有一只能追得上它。”
en: “She would show all the navy of Norfolk a clean pair of heels.”

zh: “船长万岁！”
en: “Hurrah for her captain!”

zh: “鲍勃·哈维万岁！”
en: “Hurrah for Bob Harvey!”

zh: 当艾尔顿从谈话的只言片语中听到鲍勃·哈维这个名字，艾尔通想起了他过去在澳大利亚的一个同伴，这个人是个胆大包天的水手，现在还在继续干罪恶的勾当。了解了这一点，就可以理解艾尔顿听到这段话的心情了。鲍勃·哈维在诺福克岛的海岸上抢夺了这艘双桅船，当时船上满载着各种武器、弹药、器皿和各种工具，朝三明治群岛的一个岛屿驶去。鲍勃·哈维和他的同伴们抢到这艘船以后，就由罪犯变成了海盗，这帮匪徒出没在太平洋上，毁坏船只，屠杀船员，只怕比马来海盗还要残忍。
en: What Ayrton felt when he overheard this fragment of conversation may be understood when it is known that in this Bob Harvey he recognized one of his old Australian companions, a daring sailor, who had continued his criminal career.Bob Harvey had seized, on the shores of Norfolk Island this brig, which was loaded with arms, ammunition, utensils, and tools of all sorts, destined for one of the Sandwich Islands.All his gang had gone on board, and pirates after having been convicts, these wretches, more ferocious than the Malays themselves, scoured the Pacific, destroying vessels, and massacring their crews.

zh: 罪犯们一边开怀畅饮，一边大声地讲述着他们的“战绩”，从他们的话中，艾尔顿得知：“飞快号”现在的船员全都是从诺福克岛上逃出来的英国囚犯。
en: The convicts spoke loudly, they recounted their deeds, drinking deeply at the same time, and this is what Ayrton gathered.The actual crew of the “Speedy” was composed solely of English prisoners, escaped from Norfolk Island.

zh: 现在不妨介绍一下诺福克岛的情况。在澳大利亚以东，南纬29度2分，东经165度42分的地方，有一个方圆六海里的小岛，岛上的最高峰名叫皮特山，海拔一千一百英尺。这座小岛就是诺福克岛，曾经是为了关押英国监狱里最冥顽不化的罪犯们所建设的一处地方。当时岛上有500名罪犯，他们必须接受铁一般的纪律和可怕的惩罚，此外还有150名士兵看管，这150名士兵都听从总督的命令。很难想象有比这群恶棍更坏的人聚集在一起的情况了。尽管他们受到严密的监视，但有时候还是有人得以逃跑——虽然这种情况并不多见，他们突袭船只，然后抢过来，在波里尼西亚群岛一带到处骚扰。
en: Here it may be well to explain what this island was.In 29deg 2’ south latitude, and 165deg 42’ east longitude, to the east of Australia, is found a little island, six miles in circumference, overlooked by Mount Pitt, which rises to a height of 1,100 feet above the level of the sea.This is Norfolk Island, once the seat of an establishment in which were lodged the most intractable convicts from the English penitentiaries.They numbered 500, under an iron discipline, threatened with terrible punishments, and were guarded by 150 soldiers, and 150 employed under the orders of the governor.It would be difficult to imagine a collection of greater ruffians.Sometimes,—although very rarely,—notwithstanding the extreme surveillance of which they were the object, many managed to escape, and seizing vessels which they surprised, they infested the Polynesian Archipelagoes.

zh: 这就是鲍勃·哈维和他的同伙们所干的勾当。　也是艾尔顿曾经想干的事情。鲍勃·哈维抢夺了停在诺福克岛附近的“飞快号”，屠杀了船上的船员。一年来，在他的指挥下，这艘船在太平洋上大肆劫掠，现在他是一个海盗，而且是艾尔顿的旧相识！
en: Thus had Bob Harvey and his companions done.Thus had Ayrton formerly wished to do.Bob Harvey had seized the brig “Speedy,” anchored in sight of Norfolk Island; the crew had been massacred; and for a year this ship had scoured the Pacific, under the command of Harvey, now a pirate, and well known to Ayrton!

zh: 罪犯们大部分都聚集在船尾的舱里，但也有几个躺在甲板上大声说话。
en: The convicts were, for the most part, assembled under the poop; but a few, stretched on the deck, were talking loudly.

zh: 他们一边狂喊着饮酒，一边继续谈话。艾尔顿得知“飞快号”是偶然来到了林肯岛附近，鲍勃·哈维还从未上岸；但正如赛勒斯·哈丁所预料的那样，他在航行途中发现了这块连地图上都没有标记的陌生陆地时，便打算上岸勘察一番，如果合适，就把它当作双桅船的基地。
en: The conversation still continued amid shouts and libations.Ayrton learned that chance alone had brought the “Speedy” in sight of Lincoln Island; Bob Harvey had never yet set foot on it; but, as Cyrus Harding had conjectured, finding this unknown land in his course, its position being marked on no chart, he had formed the project of visiting it, and, if he found it suitable, of making it the brig’s headquarters.

zh: 至于“飞快号”船顶的黑旗和模仿战舰降旗时鸣放的礼炮，这纯粹是海盗们的示威行为。决不是什么信号，因为这些罪犯和林肯岛之间不存在任何联系。
en: As to the black flag hoisted at the “Speedy’s” peak, and the gun which had been fired, in imitation of men-of-war when they lower their colors, it was pure piratical bravado.It was in no way a signal, and no communication yet existed between the convicts and Lincoln Island.

zh: 现在，移民们的领地正被巨大的危险所威胁。岛上有淡水补给站和港口，经过移民们的开发，各种资源也变得更有价值，还有可供藏身的花岗石宫，这一切对罪犯们来说，显然是再便利不过了。一旦小岛落入他们之手，就会成为一个绝好的藏身之所，而且，正因为无人知晓，也许在很长一段时间里，都能保证他们逍遥法外，平安无事。同样明显的是，他们是不会重视移民们的生命的，而鲍勃·哈维和他的同伙考虑的头号事情，就是毫不留情地杀死他们。赛勒斯·哈丁和他的同伴们甚至都无法选择逃跑或隐藏，因为罪犯们打算在岛上住下来，即便是“飞快号”出海打劫的时候，也有可能留几个人在岛上看守。所以，移民们必须战斗，必须把这些恶棍消灭干净，他们根本不值得同情，对他们采取任何手段都不过分。艾尔顿这样想着，他清楚，赛勒斯·哈丁一定和他的想法一样。
