en: The settlers’ domain was now menaced with terrible danger.Evidently the island, with its water, its harbor, its resources of all kinds so increased in value by the colonists, and the concealment afforded by Granite House, could not but be convenient for the convicts; in their hands it would become an excellent place of refuge, and, being unknown, it would assure them, for a long time perhaps, impunity and security.Evidently, also, the lives of the settlers would not be respected, and Bob Harvey and his accomplices’ first care would be to massacre them without mercy.Harding and his companions had, therefore, not even the choice of flying and hiding themselves in the island, since the convicts intended to reside there, and since, in the event of the “Speedy” departing on an expedition, it was probable that some of the crew would remain on shore, so as to settle themselves there.Therefore, it would be necessary to fight, to destroy every one of these scoundrels, unworthy of pity, and against whom any means would be right.So thought Ayrton, and he well knew that Cyrus Harding would be of his way of thinking.

zh: 可是，抵抗并取得最后胜利是否可能呢？这就要看船上的装备和人数了。
en: But was resistance and, in the last place, victory possible?That would depend on the equipment of the brig, and the number of men which she carried.

zh: 艾尔顿决定不惜任何代价弄清这一点，他上船一个小时候后，喧嚷声逐渐消失，许多罪犯已经烂醉如泥了，船上的灯也已经熄灭，“飞快号”一片漆黑，于是艾尔顿毫不犹豫地冒险爬上了甲板。他抓住船头，翻过斜桅，爬到前甲板上。艾尔顿从横七竖八躺着的罪犯们中间穿过，在船上绕了一圈，发现“飞快号”上装备有四门大炮，可以发射八至十磅的炮弹。他用手摸了摸，还发现这些都是后膛炮。这是一种新式火炮，操纵简单，威力巨大。
en: This Ayrton resolved to learn at any cost, and as an hour after his arrival the vociferations had begun to die away, and as a large number of the convicts were already buried in a drunken sleep, Ayrton did not hesitate to venture onto the “Speedy’s” deck, which the extinguished lanterns now left in total darkness.He hoisted himself onto the cutwater, and by the bowsprit arrived at the forecastle.Then, gliding among the convicts stretched here and there, he made the round of the ship, and found that the “Speedy” carried four guns, which would throw shot of from eight to ten pounds in weight.He found also, on touching them that these guns were breech-loaders.They were therefore, of modern make, easily used, and of terrible effect.

zh: 甲板上躺着十来个人，但可以想象得到，一定还有更多人睡在船舱里。何况艾尔顿从他们的谈话中得知，船上大约有50个人。对林肯岛上的六个移民来说，这们多的人可够他们对付的了！不过，多亏艾尔通的奋不顾身，赛勒斯·哈丁不会手足无措，他可以知道敌人的实力，并且会做出相应的部署。
en: As to the men lying on the deck, they were about ten in number, but it was to be supposed that more were sleeping down below.Besides, by listening to them, Ayrton had understood that there were fifty on board.That was a large number for the six settlers of Lincoln Island to contend with!But now, thanks to Ayrton’s devotion, Cyrus Harding would not be surprised, he would know the strength of his adversaries, and would make his arrangements accordingly.

zh: 艾尔顿已经完成任务，只要回去向同伴们报告就行了，他准备到船头去，从那里下水。但是，正如他说的那样，分外的事他也要做，他的脑海里突然产生一个英勇的念头：牺牲自己的生命，来挽救林肯岛和岛上的移民们。显然，赛勒斯·哈丁无法抵抗这50个歹徒，他们的武器精良，可以集中主力直捣花岗石宫，也可以把移民们围困起来饿死，无论采取哪种方法，他们都能够达到目的。这时候，艾尔顿想起了他的救命恩人们——那些让他重获新生，变得诚实的人，那些对他恩重如山的人。但是，他们就要被无情地杀害了，他们的劳动成果将遭到毁坏，他们的岛屿将要变成海盗的巢穴！他对自己说：造成这么多不幸的罪魁祸首是他自己，因为他的老伙伴鲍勃·哈维只不过是实现了他过去的计划而已，想到这里，他不禁毛骨悚然。他的脑子里有一个不可抗拒的念头：炸毁双桅船，炸死船上所有的人。虽然他自己也会在爆炸中死去，但总算尽到了自己的责任。
en: There was nothing more for Ayrton to do but to return, and render to his companions an account of the mission with which he had charged himself, and he prepared to regain the bows of the brig, so that he might let himself down into the water.But to this man, whose wish was, as he had said, to do more than his duty, there came an heroic thought.This was to sacrifice his own life, but save the island and the colonists.Cyrus Harding evidently could not resist fifty ruffians, all well armed, who, either by penetrating by main force into Granite House, or by starving out the besieged, could obtain from them what they wanted.And then he thought of his preservers—those who had made him again a man, and an honest mm, those to whom he owed all—murdered without pity, their works destroyed, their island turned into a pirates’ den!He said to himself that he, Ayrton, was the principal cause of so many disasters, since his old companion, Bob Harvey, had but realized his own plans, and a feeling of horror took possession of him.Then he was seized with an irresistible desire to blow up the brig and with her, all whom she had on board.He would perish in the explosion, but he would have done his duty.

zh: 艾尔顿没有犹豫。要找到火药库并不困难，它通常在船的后半部分。对于一艘从事海盗勾当的船来说，火药是不会缺乏的，只需要一点火星，就足以瞬间将它炸毁。
en: Ayrton did not hesitate.To reach the powder-room, which is always situated in the after-part of a vessel, was easy.There would be no want of powder in a vessel which followed such a trade, and a spark would be enough to destroy it in an instant.

zh: 艾尔顿小心翼翼地沿着中舱甲板走去，那里躺着很多人，他们大多是喝醉了酒，而不是真正睡着的。主桅的底部亮着一盏灯，周围支着一个枪架，上面有各种武器。
en: Ayrton stole carefully along the between-decks, strewn with numerous sleepers, overcome more by drunkenness than sleep.A lantern was lighted at the foot of the mainmast, round which was hung a gun-rack, furnished with weapons of all sorts.

zh: 艾尔顿从枪架上拿了一支左轮手枪，并且确认子弹已经上了膛。有了它就足以完成破坏工作了。于是他直奔船尾，到后舱下面的火药库去。
en: Ayrton took a revolver from the rack, and assured himself that it was loaded and primed.Nothing more was needed to accomplish the work of destruction.He then glided towards the stern, so as to arrive under the brig’s poop at the powder-magazine.

zh: 甲板上光线很暗，要想走过去，而不被那些半醉半醒的罪犯绊倒，可不是件容易的事，每当绊到那些罪犯，他们不是张口谩骂，就是伸脚踢人。因此，艾尔顿一再被迫停下脚步。不过最后，他总算来到了后舱的隔板前，找到了火药库的门。
en: It was difficult to proceed along the dimly lighted deck without stumbling over some half-sleeping convict, who retorted by oaths and kicks.Ayrton was, therefore, more than once obliged to halt.But at last he arrived at the partition dividing the aftercabin, and found the door opening into the magazine itself.

zh: 除了把门砸开，艾尔顿没有其他办法，于是他就开始动手了。干这活儿难免发出一些声响，因为要砸开一把挂锁。不过，艾尔顿臂力过人，一下子拧坏了挂锁，库门开了。
en: Ayrton, compelled to force it open, set to work.It was a difficult operation to perform without noise, for he had to break a padlock.But under his vigorous hand, the padlock broke, and the door was open.

zh: 这时候，突然有一只手搭在艾尔顿的肩上。
en: At that moment a hand was laid on Ayrton’s shoulder.

zh: “你在这儿做什么？”一个尾随着他而来的人厉声问道，那个人站在影子里，立刻把灯光照在艾尔顿的脸上。
en: “What are you doing here?” asked a tail man, in a harsh voice, who, standing in the shadow, quickly threw the light of a lantern in Ayrton’s face.

zh: 艾尔顿退后几步。借着一闪而过的灯光，他认出了自己昔日的同伴鲍勃·哈维，不过对方并没有认出他来，他以为艾尔顿早就死了。
en: Ayrton drew beck.In the rapid flash of the lantern, he had recognized his former accomplice, Bob Harvey, who could not have known him, as he must have thought Ayrton long since dead.

zh: “你在这儿做什么？”鲍勃·哈维抓住艾尔顿的裤腰带，又问了一遍。
en: “What are you doing here?” again said Bob Harvey, seizing Ayrton by the waistband.

zh: 但是艾尔顿没有回答，他挣脱鲍勃·哈维的手，试图冲进火药库。只要朝这些火药桶的中间开上一枪，一切就全都结束了！
en: But Ayrton, without replying, wrenched himself from his grasp and attempted to rush into the magazine.A shot fired into the midst of the powder-casks, and all would be over!

zh: “快来人，伙计们！”鲍勃·哈维喊道。
en: “Help, lads!” shouted Bob Harvey.

zh: 有两三个海盗被喊醒了，他们跳起身来，向艾尔顿扑去，想把他扳倒在地。艾尔顿奋力挣脱。他朝他们开了两枪，两个罪犯倒下了，可是他自己也因为躲闪不及，肩膀上被砍了一刀。
en: At his shout two or three pirates awoke, jumped up, and, rushing on Ayrton, endeavored to throw him down.He soon extricated himself from their grasp.He fired his revolver, and two of the convicts fell, but a blow from a knife which he could not ward off made a gash in his shoulder.

zh: 艾尔顿明白他的计划已无法实现了。鲍勃·哈维关上火药库的大门，甲板上又是一片混乱，海盗们全都惊醒过来了。艾尔顿必须保全自己，和赛勒斯·哈丁他们并肩作战。因此他只能夺路而逃。
en: Ayrton perceived that he could no longer hope to carry out his project.Bob Harvey had reclosed the door of the powder-magazine, and a movement on the deck indicated a general awakening of the pirates.Ayrton must reserve himself to fight at the side of Cyrus Harding.There was nothing for him but flight!

zh: 但是，还能逃得了吗？这是个问题，不过艾尔顿已经下定决心，要不惜一切代价回到同伴那里去。
en: But was flight still possible?It was doubtful, yet Ayrton resolved to dare everything in order to rejoin his companions.

zh: 艾尔顿的枪里只剩下四颗子弹。他开了两枪，一枪是朝鲍勃·哈维开的，不过没有打中，即使打中了，最多也只是轻伤，艾尔顿利用敌人稍稍后退的工夫，冲上扶梯，往甲板跑去。经过照明灯的时候，他用枪托把灯打灭了。于是周围漆黑一片，这对他逃跑十分有利。这时候，两三个海盗被惊醒了，正从扶梯上跑下来。
en: Four barrels of the revolver were still undischarged.Two were fired—one, aimed at Bob Harvey, did not wound him, or at any rate only slightly, and Ayrton, profiting by the momentary retreat of his adversaries, rushed towards the companion-ladder to gain the deck.Passing before the lantern, he smashed it with a blow from the butt of his revolver.A profound darkness ensued, which favored his flight.Two or three pirates, awakened by the noise, were descending the ladder at the same moment.

zh: 艾尔顿开了第五枪，打倒了其中一个，其他人还不知道发生了什么事情，立刻四散躲避。艾尔通两步跳上甲板，三秒钟后，一个海盗刚要掐住他的脖子，他把最后一颗子弹打在了海盗的脸上，然后越过舷墙，纵身跳进了大海。
en: A fifth shot from Ayrton laid one low, and the others drew back, not understanding what was going on.Ayrton was on deck in two bounds, and three seconds later, having discharged his last barrel in the face of a pirate who was about to seize him by the throat, he leaped over the bulwarks into the sea.

zh: 艾尔顿划了还不到六下，子弹就像冰雹似的向他周围打来。
en: Ayrton had not made six strokes before shots were splashing around him like hail.

zh: 听到船上传来的枪声，躲在小岛岩石下的潘克洛夫会怎么想呢？还有蹲在“石窟”里的哈丁、记者、赫伯特和纳布，心里又会怎么想呢？他们背着枪，冲到海滩上，随时准备抵抗敌人的攻击。
en: What were Pencroft’s feelings, sheltered under a rock on the islet!What were those of Harding, the reporter, Herbert, and Neb, crouched in the Chimneys, when they heard the reports on board the brig!They rushed out on to the beach, and, their guns shouldered, they stood ready to repel any attack.

zh: 他们对此深信不疑！海盗们发现了艾尔顿，并把他杀死了，也许这些恶棍还要趁夜黑到岛上来呢！
en: They had no doubt about it themselves!Ayrton, surprised by the pirates, had been murdered, and, perhaps, the wretches would profit by the night to make a descent on the island!

zh: 他们在极度不安中度过了半个小时。枪声已经停止了，但艾尔顿和潘克洛夫都还没有回来。难道小岛已经被占领了吗？是不是应该赶快去援救艾尔顿和潘克洛夫？可怎么救援呢？这时候正在涨潮，根本渡不过海峡。再说小船也不在这里！不难想象，哈丁和他的同伴们该是多么焦急！
en: Half an hour was passed in terrible anxiety.The firing had ceased, and yet neither Ayrton nor Pencroft had reappeared.Was the islet invaded?Ought they not to fly to the help of Ayrton and Pencroft?But how?The tide being high at that time, rendered the channel impassable.The boat was not there!We may imagine the horrible anxiety which took possession of Harding and his companions!

zh: 终于，将近十二点半的时候，小船载着他们两人靠岸了。艾尔顿的肩膀受了轻伤，潘克洛夫则安然无恙，大家张开双臂，迎接他们的归来。
en: At last, towards half-past twelve, a boat, carrying two men, touched the beach.It was Ayrton, slightly wounded in the shoulder, and Pencroft, safe and sound, whom their friends received with open arms.

zh: 所有人立刻躲进了“石窟”。艾尔顿把事情的经过讲了一遍，还说到了他企图把双桅船炸毁的计划。
en: All immediately took refuge in the Chimneys.There Ayrton recounted all that had passed, even to his plan for blowing up the brig, which he had attempted to put into execution.

zh: 大家都握住了艾尔通的手，而艾尔顿也毫不掩饰他们的处境非常危险。海盗们惊动了。他们知道林肯岛上有人居住。他们会全副武装，蜂拥而至。他们无法无天、肆无忌惮。移民们要是落入他们之手，就别指望他们大发慈悲！
en: All hands were extended to Ayrton, who did not conceal from them that their situation was serious.The pirates had been alarmed.They knew that Lincoln Island was inhabited.They would land upon it in numbers and well armed.They would respect nothing.Should the settlers fall into their hands, they must expect no mercy!

zh: “好吧，我们拼了！”记者说。
en: “Well, we shall know how to die!” said the reporter.

zh: “我们进去观望吧。”工程师回答说。
en: “Let us go in and watch,” answered the engineer.

zh: “我们有机会逃脱吗，队长？”水手问道。
en: “Have we any chance of escape, captain?” asked the sailor.

zh: “有的，潘克洛夫。”
en: “Yes, Pencroft.”

zh: “嗯！六对五十！”
en: “Hum! six against fifty!”

zh: “对！六个！不包括……”
en: “Yes! six! without counting—”

zh: “谁？”潘克洛夫问。
en: “Who?” asked Pencroft.

zh: 赛勒斯没有回答，只是向上指了指。
en: Cyrus did not reply, but pointed upwards.

zh: 第三章
en: Chapter 3

zh: 这一夜平安无事地过去了。移民们保持着高度警惕，一直没有离开“石窟”这个阵地中各自的岗位。至于海盗那一方，似乎没有任何上岸的企图。自从他们向艾尔顿开了最后一枪以后，就再也没开过枪了，甚至没有一点声音可以说明双桅船还在小岛附近。也许它想到将不得不和对手交战，所以已经拔锚起航，离开海岸了吧。
en: The night passed without incident.The colonists were on the qui vive, and did not leave their post at the Chimneys.The pirates, on their side, did not appear to have made any attempt to land.Since the last shots fired at Ayrton not a report, not even a sound, had betrayed the presence of the brig in the neighborhood of the island.It might have been fancied that she had weighed anchor, thinking that she had to deal with her match, and had left the coast.

zh: 但是，事实并非如此，破晓的时候，移民们透过清晨的薄雾，可以看见一团朦胧的影子。那就是“飞快号”。
en: But it was no such thing, and when day began to dawn the settlers could see a confused mass through the morning mist.It was the “Speedy.”

zh: “朋友们，”工程师说，“我认为，我们最好在大雾完全散开之前做好下面这些准备。雾可以使海盗看不见我们，这样，我们的行动就不会引起他们的注意。最重要的是，要让那些罪犯们以为岛上有很多居民，足以抵抗他们。因此，我建议把我们的人分成三组。第一组留在‘石窟’，第二组去慈悲河口防守。至于第三组，我认为最好安排在小岛上，以便阻止，至少也能拖延任何登陆的企图。我们有两支步枪和四支滑膛枪可用。每个人都能武装起来，我们有的是弹药，不必节省火力。我们既不怕双桅船上的滑膛枪，也不怕它的大炮。它们能把这些岩石怎么样呢？只要我们不从花岗石宫的窗口向外开枪，海盗们就想不到朝那里开炮，也不会给那里造成无可挽回的损失。我担心的是不得不和他们进行肉搏，因为罪犯的人数很多。所以，我们一定要设法阻止他们登陆，但又不能暴露自己。因此，大家不要节省弹药。要不停地射击，但要瞄准了以后再开枪。我们每个人要打死八到十个敌人，一定要把他们都消灭！”
en: “These, my friends,” said the engineer, “are the arrangements which appear to me best to make before the fog completely clears away.It hides us from the eyes of the pirates, and we can act without attracting their attention.The most important thing is, that the convicts should believe that the inhabitants of the island are numerous, and consequently capable of resisting them.I therefore propose that we divide into three parties.The first of which shall be posted at the Chimneys, the second at the mouth of the Mercy.As to the third, I think it would be best to place it on the islet, so as to prevent, or at all events delay, any attempt at landing.We have the use of two rifles and four muskets.Each of us will be armed, and, as we are amply provided with powder and shot, we need not spare our fire.We have nothing to fear from the muskets nor even from the guns of the brig.What can they do against these rocks?And, as we shall not fire from the windows of Granite House, the pirates will not think of causing irreparable damage by throwing shell against it.What is to be feared is, the necessity of meeting hand-to-hand, since the convicts have numbers on their side.We must therefore try to prevent them from landing, but without discovering ourselves.Therefore, do not economize the ammunition.Fire often, but with a sure aim.We have each eight or ten enemies to kill, and they must be killed!”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁把情况讲得很清楚，他的语气很镇定，就像是在调度一件工作，而不是在指挥一场战斗。他的同伴们都默默地同意了这个部署。现在要做的，只是在雾散尽之前各就各位。纳布和潘克洛夫立刻到花岗石宫，拿来了大量弹药。吉迪恩·史佩莱和艾尔顿都是射击高手，各自拿了一支射程有将近一英里的步枪。四支滑膛枪则分给了哈丁、纳布、潘克洛夫和赫伯特。
en: Cyrus Harding had clearly represented their situation, although he spoke in the calmest voice, as if it was a question of directing a piece of work and not ordering a battle.His companions approved these arrangements without even uttering a word.There was nothing more to be done but for each to take his place before the fog should be completely dissipated.Neb and Pencroft immediately ascended to Granite House and brought back a sufficient quantity of ammunition.Gideon Spilett and Ayrton, both very good marksmen, were armed with the two rifles, which carried nearly a mile.The four other muskets were divided among Harding, Neb, Pencroft, and Herbert.

zh: 各人的阵地是如下这样布置的：
en: The posts were arranged in the following manner:—

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和赫伯特埋伏在“石窟”附近，负责把守花岗石宫下面的海岸。
en: Cyrus Harding and Herbert remained in ambush at the Chimneys, thus commanding the shore to the foot of Granite House.

zh: 吉迪恩·史佩莱和纳布埋伏在慈悲河口的乱石丛中，河上的吊桥已经扯起来了，他们负责阻止任何人乘船渡河或在对岸登陆。
en: Gideon Spilett and Neb crouched among the rocks at the mouth of the Mercy, from which the drawbridges had been raised, so as to prevent any one from crossing in a boat or landing on the opposite shore.

zh: 艾尔顿和潘克洛夫划小船渡过海峡，在小岛上分别占据一个阵地。这样，火力同时从四个不同的地点发射，就会让罪犯们认为岛上不但有许多居民，而且防守严密。
en: As to Ayrton and Pencroft, they shoved off in the boat, and prepared to cross the channel and to take up two separate stations on the islet.In this way, shots being fired from four different points at once, the convicts would be led to believe that the island was both largely peopled and strongly defended.

zh: 如果艾尔顿和潘克洛夫无法阻止海盗们登陆，而且眼看就要被海盗们的小船切断退路，那他们应该乘船回到岸上来，到情况最紧急的地点去。
en: In the event of a landing being effected without their having been able to prevent it, and also if they saw that they were on the point of being cut off by the brig’s boat, Ayrton and Pencroft were to return in their boat to the shore and proceed towards the threatened spot.

zh: 在出发去各自的阵地之前，移民们最后一次相互握手。
en: Before starting to occupy their posts, the colonists for the last time wrung each other’s hands.

zh: 潘克洛夫成功地充分抑制住自己的感情，拥抱了他的孩子赫伯特，然后他们就分开了。
en: Pencroft succeeded in controlling himself sufficiently to suppress his emotion when he embraced Herbert, his boy! and then they separated.

zh: 不一会儿，哈丁和赫伯特一路，以及记者和纳布那一路，都消失在了岩石后面，五分钟后，艾尔顿和潘克洛夫也顺利渡过了海峡，登上了小岛，隐藏在东岸的裂石中。
en: In a few moments Harding and Herbert on one side, the reporter and Neb on the other, had disappeared behind the rocks, and five minutes later Ayrton and Pencroft, having without difficulty crossed the channel, disembarked on the islet and concealed themselves in the clefts of its eastern shore.

zh: 他们都没有被发现，因为连他们自己也只能隐约看到雾中的双桅船。
en: None of them could have been seen, for they themselves could scarcely distinguish the brig in the fog.

zh: 这时候是早上六点半。
en: It was half-past six in the morning.

zh: 不久雾就逐渐散开了，船的中桅从烟雾里露了出来。大片的烟雾在海面上滚动了几分钟，接着就被出现的微风迅速吹散了。
en: Soon the fog began to clear away, and the topmasts of the brig issued from the vapor.For some minutes great masses rolled over the surface of the sea, then a breeze sprang up, which rapidly dispelled the mist.

zh: “飞快号”完全显露了出来，它的锚链上系着一根绳索，船头朝北，左舷对着海岛。正如哈丁估计的那样，它距离海岸不超过一又四分之一英里。
en: The “Speedy” now appeared in full view, with a spring on her cable, her head to the north, presenting her larboard side to the island.Just as Harding had calculated, she was not more than a mile and a quarter from the coast.

zh: 那面阴森森的黑旗仍在船顶飘着。
en: The sinister black flag floated from the peak.

zh: 工程师从望远镜中看到，船上的四门大炮全都对着海岛。显然，只要一声令下，它们随时准备开火。
en: The engineer, with his telescope, could see that the four guns on board were pointed at the island.They were evidently ready to fire at a moment’s notice.

zh: 这时候，“飞快号”一点动静也没有。只见三十来个海盗在甲板上走动着。有几个在船尾，另外有两个站在桅索中间，手中举着小型望远镜，正在仔细观察海岛。
en: In the meanwhile the “Speedy” remained silent.About thirty pirates could be seen moving on the deck.A few more on the poop; two others posted in the shrouds, and armed with spyglasses, were attentively surveying the island.

zh: 显然，鲍勃·哈维和他的同伙们都对昨天夜里发生在双桅船上的事感到难以理解。那个半裸的男人强行打开了火药库的门，和他们进行了搏斗，并且用自己的左轮手枪向他们开了六枪，打死了一人，打伤了两个，最后这个人被打死了吗？他泅水回到岸上去了吗？他是从哪里来的？他有什么目的？难道他真像鲍勃·哈维所想的那样，想炸毁双桅船吗？这些问题一定足以使罪犯们摸不着头脑。不过有一点他们可以肯定，那就是“飞快号”前面的那座无名海岛上有人居住，而且那里可能有许多移民已经准备好保卫它了。可是，不论是海岸上还是山岗上，他们连一个人都看不到。海滩上似乎完全没有人。至少没有任何房屋的痕迹。难道居民们都逃到小岛深处去了吗？海盗船长也许就是这样想的，并且，毫无疑问，作为一个谨慎的人，在让他的部下去冒险之前，他希望先侦察一下岛上的情况。
en: Certainly, Bob Harvey and his crew would not be able easily to give an account of what had happened during the night on board the brig.Had this half-naked man, who had forced the door of the powder-magazine, and with whom they had struggled, who had six times discharged his revolver at them, who had killed one and wounded two others, escaped their shot?Had he been able to swim to shore?Whence did he come?What had been his object?Had his design really been to blow up the brig, as Bob Harvey had thought?All this must be confused enough to the convicts’ minds.But what they could no longer doubt was that the unknown island before which the “Speedy” had cast anchor was inhabited, and that there was, perhaps, a numerous colony ready to defend it.And yet no one was to be seen, neither on the shore, nor on the heights.The beach appeared to be absolutely deserted.At any rate, there was no trace of dwellings.Had the inhabitants fled into the interior?Thus probably the pirate captain reasoned, and doubtless, like a prudent man, he wished to reconnoiter the locality before he allowed his men to venture there.

zh: 一个半小时过去了，双桅船还是没有任何进攻或登陆的迹象。鲍勃·哈维显然是在犹豫不决。即使是用倍数最大的望远镜，他也看不到一个埋伏在岩石中的移民。虽然遮盖花岗石宫窗口的绿枝和爬藤，在光秃秃的岩石上十分显眼，但这也许根本就没有引起他的注意。的确，他怎么想得到在这样高的地方，会有人在坚硬的花岗石中间挖出一座房屋来呢？从爪角到颚骨角，包括整个联合湾在内，没有任何迹象能使他认为岛上有人或可能有人。
en: During an hour and a half, no indication of attack or landing could be observed on board the brig.Evidently Bob Harvey was hesitating.Even with his strongest telescopes he could not have perceived one of the settlers crouched among the rocks.It was not even probable that his attention had been awakened by the screen of green branches and creepers hiding the windows of Granite House, and showing rather conspicuously on the bare rock.Indeed, how could he imagine that a dwelling was hollowed out, at that height, in the solid granite?From Claw Cape to the Mandible Capes, in all the extent of Union Bay, there was nothing to lead him to suppose that the island was or could be inhabited.

zh: 八点钟的时候，移民们终于看见“飞快号”上有行动了。一艘小艇放了下来，七个人跳了进去。他们都带着滑膛枪；一个人掌舵，四个人划桨，另外两个人身体弯成弓形跪在船头，侦察岛上的动静，随时准备开火。他们的目的很明显，是要做一次侦察，而不是登陆，否则的话，来的人会更多。海盗们从他们的了望台上可以看到，海岸由一个小岛掩护着，两者之间有一条宽约半英里的海峡。但是，根据小艇行驶的方向，赛勒斯·哈丁明显看出，他们并不打算进入海峡，而是要在小岛上登陆。
en: At eight o’clock, however, the colonists observed a movement on board the “Speedy.”A boat was lowered, and seven men jumped into her.They were armed with muskets; one took the yoke-lines, four others the oars, and the two others, kneeling in the bows, ready to fire, reconnoitered the island.Their object was no doubt to make an examination but not to land, for in the latter case they would have come in larger numbers.The pirates from their look-out could have seen that the coast was sheltered by an islet, separated from it by a channel half a mile in width.However, it was soon evident to Cyrus Harding, on observing the direction followed by the boat, that they would not attempt to penetrate into the channel, but would land on the islet.

zh: 潘克洛夫和艾尔顿各自躲在狭窄的岩石缝里，看着小艇径直朝他们驶来，等着它进入射程以内。
en: Pencroft and Ayrton, each hidden in a narrow cleft of the rock, saw them coming directly towards them, and waited till they were within range.

zh: 小艇小心翼翼地前进着。罪犯们隔很长时间才划一次桨。现在可以看见，一个罪犯手里拿着铅垂线，想要测量受慈悲河水冲刷的海峡有多深。这表明鲍勃·哈维打算将双桅船尽量靠近海岸。船上的三十来个海盗分散在索具中间，注视着小艇的动向，并试图发现能让他们安全上岸的界标。小艇在距小岛不到两链远的地方停下来了。掌舵的罪犯站起身来，寻找着最适合上岸的地方。
en: The boat advanced with extreme caution.The oars only dipped into the water at long intervals.It could now be seen that one of the convicts held a lead-line in his hand, and that he wished to fathom the depth of the channel hollowed out by the current of the Mercy.This showed that it was Bob Harvey’s intention to bring his brig as near as possible to the coast.About thirty pirates, scattered in the rigging, followed every movement of the boat, and took the bearings of certain landmarks which would allow them to approach without danger.The boat was not more than two cables-lengths off the islet when she stopped.The man at the tiller stood up and looked for the best place at which to land.

zh: 这时候听见两声枪响。一缕轻烟从小岛的岩石中间袅袅上升。掌舵和测量水深的海盗仰面倒在了小艇里。艾尔顿和潘克洛夫的子弹同时击中了他们。
en: At that moment two shots were heard.Smoke curled up from among the rocks of the islet.The man at the helm and the man with the lead-line fell backwards into the boat.Ayrton’s and Pencroft’s balls had struck them both at the same moment.

zh: 几乎与此同时，又听见一声更大的炮响，双桅船的船舷喷出一团烟雾，一颗炮弹落在艾尔顿和潘克洛夫藏身的岩石顶上，炸得碎石横飞，不过两名枪手都没有受伤。
en: Almost immediately a louder report was heard, a cloud of smoke issued from the brig’s side, and a ball, striking the summit of the rock which sheltered Ayrton and Pencroft, made it fly in splinters, but the two marksmen remained unhurt.

zh: 小艇上的海盗们爆发出可怕的叫骂声，立刻继续将小艇向前驶来。另一个海盗接替了掌舵的位置，其他人则奋力快速划桨。不过，出乎意料的是，小艇不但没有掉头回去，反而沿着海岸驶来，打算绕过小岛的南端。海盗们拼命划着桨，想逃出步枪的射程。
en: Horrible imprecations burst from the boat, which immediately continued its way.The man who had been at the tiller was replaced by one of his comrades, and the oars were rapidly plunged into the water.However, instead of returning on board as might have been expected, the boat coasted along the islet, so as to round its southern point.The pirates pulled vigorously at their oars that they might get out of range of the bullets.

zh: 他们就这样一直把小艇划到距离遗物角岸边五链以内的地方，然后绕了半圈，继续在双桅船大炮的掩护下，向慈悲河口驶去。
en: They advanced to within five cables-lengths of that part of the shore terminated by Flotsam Point, and after having rounded it in a semicircular line, still protected by the brig’s guns, they proceeded towards the mouth of the Mercy.

zh: 他们的意图显然是想进入海峡，切断岛上移民的退路，这样一来，无论小岛上有多少人，他们都将处于小艇和双桅船两船火力夹击的十分不利的位置。
en: Their evident intention was to penetrate into the channel, and cut off the colonists posted on the islet, in such a way, that whatever their number might be, being placed between the fire from the boat and the fire from the brig, they would find themselves in a very disadvantageous position.

zh: 小艇朝这个方向前进了十五分钟。周围万籁俱寂，海面上也风平浪静。
en: A quarter of an hour passed while the boat advanced in this direction.Absolute silence, perfect calm reigned in the air and on the water.

zh: 虽然潘克洛夫和艾尔顿知道有被切断退路的危险，但他们没有离开阵地，他们不愿在敌人和“飞快号”的炮火前暴露自己；同时他们也相信守卫在河口的纳布和吉迪恩·史佩莱，以及埋伏在“石窟”附近岩石丛中的赛勒斯·哈丁和赫伯特会援助他们。
en: Pencroft and Ayrton, although they knew they ran the risk of being cut off, had not left their post, both that they did not wish to show themselves as yet to their assailants, and expose themselves to the “Speedy’s” guns, and that they relied on Neb and Gideon Spilett, watching at the mouth of the river, and on Cyrus Harding and Herbert, in ambush among the rocks at the Chimneys.

zh: 在开第一枪后二十分钟，小艇已经到了离慈悲河不到两链远的地方。这时候正开始涨潮，由于海峡十分狭窄，水势依然非常湍急，把海盗们的小艇冲到了河口，他们只是通过奋力划桨，才得以把小艇保持在海峡的中央。但是，当他们驶进慈悲河口阵地的射程内，立刻遭到两颗子弹的迎击，又有两个人倒下了。纳布和史佩莱的子弹都没有落空。
en: Twenty minutes after the first shots were fired, the boat was less than two cables-lengths off the Mercy.As the tide was beginning to rise with its accustomed violence, caused by the narrowness of the straits, the pirates were drawn towards the river, and it was only by dint of hard rowing that they were able to keep in the middle of the channel.But, as they were passing within good range of the mouth of the Mercy, two balls saluted them, and two more of their number were laid in the bottom of the boat.Neb and Spilett had not missed their aim.

zh: 双桅船对着冒烟的阵地又开了一炮，但除了打碎几块石头外，没有任何收获。
en: The brig immediately sent a second ball on the post betrayed by the smoke, but without any other result than that of splintering the rock.

zh: 现在小艇上只剩下三个完好无损的人了。顺着水流，它像箭一般冲过了海峡，来到哈丁和赫伯特的阵地面前，他们两人认为还不到射程之内，就没开枪，小艇上的人划着仅剩的双桨，绕过小岛的北端，回到双桅船那里去了。
en: The boat now contained only three able men.Carried on by the current, it shot through the channel with the rapidity of an arrow, passed before Harding and Herbert, who, not thinking it within range, withheld their fire, then, rounding the northern point of the islet with the two remaining oars, they pulled towards the brig.

zh: 到目前为止，移民们还没什么可抱怨的。可他们的敌人却显然遇到了最坏的情况。他们已经有四个人即使没死，也受了重伤；相反，移民们非但没有受伤，而且弹无虚发。要是海盗们继续这样进攻，还打算利用小艇登陆的话，那么，他们只能是一个一个地被杀掉。
en: Hitherto the settlers had nothing to complain of.Their adversaries had certainly had the worst of it.The latter already counted four men seriously wounded if not dead; they, on the contrary, unwounded, had not missed a shot.If the pirates continued to attack them in this way, if they renewed their attempt to land by means of a boat, they could be destroyed one by one.

zh: 现在大家明白工程师的部署是多么有利了。海盗们会以为对手人多势众，装备精良，想要取胜没那么容易。
en: It was now seen how advantageous the engineer’s arrangements had been.The pirates would think that they had to deal with numerous and well-armed adversaries, whom they could not easily get the better of.

zh: 小艇和海潮搏斗了半个小时，才靠上了“飞快号”。小艇上的海盗和伤员回到船上时，传来了一阵可怕的嚎叫，接着又毫无结果地开了两三炮。
en: Half an hour passed before the boat, having to pull against the current, could get alongside the “Speedy.”Frightful cries were heard when they returned on board with the wounded, and two or three guns were fired with no results.

zh: 但是，现在又有十来个气得发疯的罪犯跳上小艇，也许他们还没有从前一夜的畅饮中清醒过来。同时，又放下第二艘小艇，里面坐着八个人，第一只小艇径直朝小岛扑去，企图赶走岛上的移民，而第二艘则打算强行进入慈悲河口。
en: But now about a dozen other convicts, maddened with rage, and possibly by the effect of the evening’s potations, threw themselves into the boat.A second boat was also lowered, in which eight men took their places, and while the first pulled straight for the islet, to dislodge the colonists from thence the second maneuvered so as to force the entrance of the Mercy.

zh: 这种情况对潘克洛夫和艾尔顿显然极为不利，他们知道非回到岛上不可了。
en: The situation was evidently becoming very dangerous for Pencroft and Ayrton, and they saw that they must regain the mainland.

zh: 但是，他们仍然等到第一艘小艇进入射程范围，然后准确地开了两枪，使艇上的人陷入一片混乱。潘克洛夫和艾尔通这才离开了各自的岗位，他们冒着来自十几支滑膛枪的枪林弹雨，以最快的速度穿过小岛，跳进小船，在第二艘小艇到达南端的时候渡过了海峡，藏到“石窟”里去了。
en: However, they waited till the first boat was within range, when two well-directed balls threw its crew into disorder.Then, Pencroft and Ayrton, abandoning their posts, under fire from the dozen muskets, ran across the islet at full speed, jumped into their boat, crossed the channel at the moment the second boat reached the southern end, and ran to hide themselves in the Chimneys.

zh: 他们刚同赛勒斯·哈丁和赫伯特会合，海盗们就占据了小岛各处。几乎与此同时，慈悲河口的阵地上也传来了枪声，第二艘小艇也迅速向那里靠拢。船上的八个人当中，有两个遭到了吉迪恩·史佩莱和纳布的致命打击而负伤，而小船本身则因失去控制，撞上了礁石，在慈悲河口处，小船就被撞破了。但是，那六个幸存的罪犯把滑膛枪举过头顶，以防浸水，登上了河的右岸。他们发现自己暴露在埋伏阵地的火力范围之内，于是就拼命朝枪弹打不到的遗物角逃去了。
en: They had scarcely rejoined Cyrus Harding and Herbert, before the islet was overrun with pirates in every direction.Almost at the same moment, fresh reports resounded from the Mercy station, to which the second boat was rapidly approaching.Two, out of the eight men who manned her, were mortally wounded by Gideon Spilett and Neb, and the boat herself, carried irresistibly onto the reefs, was stove in at the mouth of the Mercy.But the six survivors, holding their muskets above their heads to preserve them from contact with the water, managed to land on the right bank of the river.Then, finding they were exposed to the fire of the ambush there, they fled in the direction of Flotsam Point, out of range of the balls.

zh: 实际情况是这样的：小岛上有十二名罪犯，其中有几个肯定是受伤了，但他们还有一艘小艇。六名罪犯上了孤岛，但他们无法到花岗石宫去，因为吊桥已经被扯起来了，他们过不了河。
en: The actual situation was this: on the islet were a dozen convicts, of whom some were no doubt wounded, but who had still a boat at their disposal; on the island were six, but who could not by any possibility reach Granite House, as they could not cross the river, all the bridges being raised.

zh: “嘿，”潘克洛夫冲进“石窟”，大声叫道，“嘿，队长！你认为现在该怎么办？”
en: “Hallo,” exclaimed Pencroft as he rushed into the Chimneys, “hallo, captain!What do you think of it, now?”

zh: “我想，”工程师回答说，“战斗现在进入了一个新的局面，因为罪犯们不会这么傻，会甘愿处于对他们不利的境地！”
en: “I think,” answered the engineer, “that the combat will now take a new form, for it cannot be supposed that the convicts will be so foolish as to remain in a position so unfavorable for them!”

zh: “他们渡不过海峡的，”水手说，“有艾尔顿和史佩莱先生的步枪挡在那里。你知道，这些步枪可以打到一英里以外的地方！”
en: “They won’t cross the channel,” said the sailor.“Ayrton and Mr. Spilett’s rifles are there to prevent them.You know that they carry more than a mile!”

zh: “当然，”赫伯特答道，“但是，两支步枪怎么能对抗双桅船上的大炮呢？”
en: “No doubt,” replied Herbert; “but what can two rifles do against the brig’s guns?”

zh: “嗯，我想，双桅船还没有开进海峡吧！”潘克洛夫说。
en: “Well, the brig isn’t in the channel yet, I fancy!” said Pencroft.

zh: “但要是它开进来了呢？”哈丁说。
en: “But suppose she does come there?” said Harding.

zh: “那不可能，要是那样做，它可能要冒着搁浅，甚至沉没的风险！”
en: “That’s impossible, for she would risk running aground and being lost!”

zh: “还是有可能的，”艾尔顿说，“罪犯们会乘着涨潮把船开进海峡，哪怕是冒着在落潮时船会搁浅的风险，那时候，在它的炮火下，我们的阵地就守不住了。”
en: “It is possible,” said Ayrton.“The convicts might profit by the high tide to enter the channel, with the risk of grounding at low tide, it is true; but then, under the fire from her guns, our posts would be no longer tenable.”

zh: “打败他们！”潘克洛夫叫道，“这帮恶棍似乎真的在准备起锚了。”
en: “Confound them!” exclaimed Pencroft, “it really seems as if the blackguards were preparing to weigh anchor.”

zh: “也许我们只好躲到‘花岗石宫’里去了！”赫伯特评论道。
en: “Perhaps we shall be obliged to take refuge in Granite House!” observed Herbert.

zh: “我们得再等一会儿！”赛勒斯·哈丁说。
en: “We must wait!” answered Cyrus Harding.

zh: “可史佩莱先生和纳布怎么办？”潘克洛夫问道。
en: “But Mr. Spilett and Neb?” said Pencroft.

zh: “他们知道什么时候应该来和我们会合的准备好，艾尔顿。现在该轮到你和史佩莱的步枪上场了。”
en: “They will know when it is best to rejoin us.Be ready, Ayrton.It is yours and Spilett’s rifles which must speak now.”

zh: 果不其然。“飞快号”开始起锚了，它显然打算驶进小岛。潮水还要上涨一个半小时，退潮的水流也已经减弱，在这种情况下，双桅船前进起来非常容易。不过，潘克洛夫不同意艾尔顿的看法，他认为双桅船不敢开进海峡。
en: It was only too true.The “Speedy” was beginning to weigh her anchor, and her intention was evidently to approach the islet.The tide would be rising for an hour and a half, and the ebb current being already weakened, it would be easy for the brig to advance.But as to entering the channel, Pencroft, contrary to Ayrton’s opinion, could not believe that she would dare to attempt it.

zh: 这时候，占领了小岛的海盗们逐渐来到对面的海岸上，和主岛只一峡之隔了。
en: In the meanwhile, the pirates who occupied the islet had gradually advanced to the opposite shore, and were now only separated from the mainland by the channel.

zh: 海盗们只有滑膛枪，因此伤不了埋伏在“石窟”和慈悲河口的移民，他们想不到移民们配有远射程的步枪，因此以为自己还没有暴露在对方的火力之下。于是，他们不加掩护地搜查小岛，巡视海岸。
en: Being armed with muskets alone, they could do no harm to the settlers, in ambush at the Chimneys and the mouth of the Mercy; but, not knowing the latter to be supplied with long-range rifles, they on their side did not believe themselves to be exposed.Quite uncovered, therefore, they surveyed the islet, and examined the shore.

zh: 他们的幻想很快就破灭了。艾尔顿和吉迪恩·史佩莱的步枪开火了，无疑给罪犯们带来了最不幸的消息，其中两个仰面倒了下去。
en: Their illusion was of short duration.Ayrton’s and Gideon Spilett’s rifles then spoke, and no doubt imparted some very disagreeable intelligence to two of the convicts, for they fell backwards.

zh: 于是，所有的罪犯们都惊慌失措。其余的十个人甚至顾不上带上伤亡的伙伴，便逃到小岛的另一边了，跌跌撞撞地爬上来时乘坐的小艇，拼命划走了。
en: Then there was a general helter-skelter.The ten others, not even stopping to pick up their dead or wounded companions, fled to the other side of the islet, tumbled into the boat which had brought them, and pulled away with all their strength.

zh: “又少了八个！”潘克洛夫喊道，“的确，史佩莱先生和艾尔顿同时开枪，简直好像听了口令似的！”
en: “Eight less!” exclaimed Pencroft.“Really, one would have thought that Mr. Spilett and Ayrton had given the word to fire together!”

zh: “先生们，”艾尔顿一边给步枪装子弹，一边说，“情况更加严重了。双桅船准备启动了！”
en: “Gentlemen,” said Ayrton, as he reloaded his gun, “this is becoming more serious.The brig is making sail!”

zh: “它在起锚呢！”潘克洛夫叫道。
en: “The anchor is weighed!” exclaimed Pencroft.

zh: “是的，它已经启动了。”
en: “Yes, and she is already moving.”

zh: 事实上，他们已经能够清楚地听见绞盘的声音了。“飞快号”先是被锚拉住的，等起锚以后，它就开始向岸边漂过来了。风从海面上吹来，船上张起了三角帆和前桅帆，并逐渐向主岛逼近。
en: In fact, they could distinctly hear the creaking of the windlass.The “Speedy” was at first held by her anchor; then, when that had been raised, she began to drift towards the shore.The wind was blowing from the sea; the jib and the foretopsail were hoisted, and the vessel gradually approached the island.

zh: 大家从慈悲河和“石窟”这两个阵地上观察双桅船，他们的身子虽然纹丝不动，心里却十分激动。要是在这么短的距离内暴露在双桅船的火炮底下，而无法给予有效的回击，那移民们的处境该会多可怕？他们怎样才能阻止海盗们登陆呢？
en: From the two posts of the Mercy and the Chimneys they watched her without giving a sign of life, but not without some emotion.What could be more terrible for the colonists than to be exposed, at a short distance, to the brig’s guns, without being able to reply with any effect?How could they then prevent the pirates from landing?

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁充分意识到这一点，他思考着对策。他必须很快作出决定。可是该怎样决定呢？撤到花岗石宫里困守，凭着那里充足的食物储备，坚持几个星期，甚至是几个月吗？这样固然可以！但以后呢？海盗们还是会成为孤岛的主人，他们会恣意蹂躏它，总有一天，他们终将报复被困在花岗石宫里的人。
en: Cyrus Harding felt this strongly, and he asked himself what it would be possible to do.Before long, he would be called upon for his determination.But what was it to be?To shut themselves up in Granite House, to be besieged there, to remain there for weeks, for months even, since they had an abundance of provisions?So far good!But after that?The pirates would not the less be masters of the island, which they would ravage at their pleasure, and in time, they would end by having their revenge on the prisoners in Granite House.

zh: 不过，他们还有一线希望，那就是——鲍勃·哈维也许不会冒险把船开进海峡，而只是停在小岛外面。这样的话，双桅船离海岸还有半英里远，隔着这段距离开炮，造成的损失不会太大。
en: However, one chance yet remained; it was that Bob Harvey, after all, would not venture his ship into the channel, and that he would keep outside the islet.He would be still separated from the coast by half a mile, and at that distance his shot could not be very destructive.

zh: “决不会的！”潘克洛夫不停地说，“要是鲍勃·哈维是一名出色的水手，他就决不会到海峡里来！他清楚地知道一旦退潮，双桅船就会有危险！没有了船，他该怎么办呢？”
en: “Never!” repeated Pencroft, “Bob Harvey will never, if he is a good seaman, enter that channel!He knows well that it would risk the brig, if the sea got up ever so little!And what would become of him without his vessel?”

zh: 这时候，双桅船已经靠近小岛了，看得出它正努力向下驶去。风力很小，海潮的力量也大大减弱了，鲍勃·哈维可以随心所欲地操纵他的船。
en: In the meanwhile the brig approached the islet, and it could be seen that she was endeavoring to make the lower end.The breeze was light, and as the current had then lost much of its force, Bob Harvey had absolute command over his vessel.

zh: 由于先前小艇走过这条航线，这就便于侦察海峡，于是它大胆地开进了海峡。
en: The route previously followed by the boats had allowed her to reconnoiter the channel, and she boldly entered it.

zh: 现在海盗们的意图非常明显：他打算把舷侧炮火对准“石窟”，开炮还击那些打死他们同伙的枪弹。
en: The pirate’s design was now only too evident; he wished to bring her broadside to bear on the Chimneys and from there to reply with shell and ball to the shot which had till then decimated her crew.

zh: 不一会儿，“飞快号”就来到了小岛顶端，轻松地绕了过去，船上扯起主帆，吃足了风，朝慈悲河口驶来。
en: Soon the “Speedy” reached the point of the islet; she rounded it with ease; the mainsail was braced up, and the brig hugging the wind, stood across the mouth of the Mercy.

zh: “这些恶棍！他们来了！”潘克洛夫叫道。
en: “The scoundrels! they are coming!” said Pencroft.

zh: 这时候，纳布和吉迪恩·史佩莱回到了赛勒斯·哈丁、艾尔顿、水手和赫伯特这里。
en: At that moment, Cyrus Harding, Ayrton, the sailor, and Herbert, were rejoined by Neb and Gideon Spilett.

zh: 记者和他的同伴认为应该放弃慈悲河的阵地，因为在那里他们没有任何办法可以对付双桅船，于是他们就明智地撤退了。在即将采取决定性行动的时候，移民们最好还是团结在一起。吉迪恩·史佩莱和纳布躲在岩石后面跑了回来，遭到了一阵射击，不过毫发无损。
en: The reporter and his companion had judged it best to abandon the post at the Mercy, from which they could do nothing against the ship, and they had acted wisely.It was better that the colonists should be together at the moment when they were about to engage in a decisive action.Gideon Spilett and Neb had arrived by dodging behind the rocks, though not without attracting a shower of bullets, which had not, however, reached them.

zh: “史佩莱！纳布！”工程师喊道，“你们没有受伤吧？”
en: “Spilett!Neb!” cried the engineer.“You are not wounded?”

zh: “没有，”记者回答说，“只是子弹跳起来擦伤了点儿！但那该死的船已经开进了海峡！”
en: “No,” answered the reporter, “a few bruises only from the ricochet!But that cursed brig has entered the channel!”

zh: “是的，”潘克洛夫答道，“再过十分钟，它就会停在花岗石宫前面了！”
en: “Yes,” replied Pencroft, “and in ten minutes she will have anchored before Granite House!”

zh: “你有什么计划吗，赛勒斯？”记者问道。
en: “Have you formed any plan, Cyrus?” asked the reporter.

zh: “趁现在还来得及，我们必须躲到花岗石宫里去，罪犯们看不见我们。”
en: “We must take refuge in Granite House while there is still time, and the convicts cannot see us.”

zh: “我同意，”吉迪恩·史佩莱说，“可一旦被困在里面……”
en: “That is, my opinion, too,” replied Gideon Spilett, “but once shut up—”

zh: “我们到时候再见机行事吧。”工程师说。
en: “We must be guided by circumstances,” said the engineer.

zh: “那就赶快走吧！”记者说。
en: “Let us be off, then, and make haste!” said the reporter.

zh: “队长，要我和艾尔顿留在这里吗？”水手问道。
en: “Would you not wish, captain, that Ayrton and I should remain here?” asked the sailor.

zh: “留下来又有什么用呢，潘克洛夫？”哈丁回答说。“不。我们不要分开！”
en: “What would be the use of that, Pencroft?” replied Harding.“No.We will not separate!”

zh: 现在一秒钟都不能耽搁了。移民们离开了“石窟”。弯曲的岩石遮挡着他们，使他们没有被双桅船上的人发现，不过从两三声枪响和子弹打在岩石上的声音可以判断，“飞快号”离他们已经不远了。
en: There was not a moment to be lost.The colonists left the Chimneys.A bend of the cliff prevented them from being seen by those in the brig, but two or three reports, and the crash of bullets on the rock, told them that the “Speedy” was at no great distance.

zh: 仅一分钟的工夫，移民们就跳进升降机，上升到“花岗石宫'的门口，然后冲进了大厅。前一天晚上，托普和贾普就被关在了这里。
en: To spring into the lift, hoist themselves up to the door of Granite House, where Top and Jup had been shut up since the evening before, to rush into the large room, was the work of a minute only.

zh: 他们回来得正是时候，移民们透过树枝，可以看见“飞快号”在缭绕的烟雾中驶进了海峡。枪声不停地响着，四门大炮朝已经无人把守的慈悲河阵地和“石窟”盲目地轰击。岩石被炸得四处横飞，每开一炮，海盗们就要欢呼一阵。幸亏哈丁想到把窗户遮蔽起来，所以大家还能指望”花岗石宫“不遭到炮击，可这时候，一颗炮弹射穿了门，打进走廊里来。
en: It was quite time, for the settlers, through the branches, could see the “Speedy,” surrounded with smoke, gliding up the channel.The firing was incessant, and shot from the four guns struck blindly, both on the Mercy post, although it was not occupied, and on the Chimneys.The rocks were splintered, and cheers accompanied each discharge.However, they were hoping that Granite House would be spared, thanks to Harding’s precaution of concealing the windows when a shot, piercing the door, penetrated into the passage.

zh: “我们被发现了！”潘克洛夫喊道。
en: “We are discovered!” exclaimed Pencroft.

zh: 也许移民们还没有被发现，但可以肯定的是：鲍勃·哈维认为遮蔽在这部分峭壁上的树枝有些可疑，有必要朝它开上一炮。紧接着，他又加强了进攻，第二颗炮弹撕开了树枝的伪装，使花岗石壁上的洞口暴露无遗。
en: The colonists had not, perhaps, been seen, but it was certain that Bob Harvey had thought proper to send a ball through the suspected foliage which concealed that part of the cliff.Soon he redoubled his attack, when another ball having torn away the leafy screen, disclosed a gaping aperture in the granite.

zh: 移民们陷入了绝境。他们的撤退已经被发现了。他们既无法阻挡这些炮弹，又不能保护这片石壁——在炮火的攻击下，碎石在他们周围飞溅四射。现在他们只能躲到花岗石宫的上层甬道里去，任凭自己的住所遭炮火的摧残。这时，突然传来一声巨响，接着便是一阵凄惨的叫声。
en: The colonists’ situation was desperate.Their retreat was discovered.They could not oppose any obstacle to these missiles, nor protect the stone, which flew in splinters around them.There was nothing to be done but to take refuge in the upper passage of Granite House, and leave their dwelling to be devastated, when a deep roar was heard, followed by frightful cries!

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和同伴们忙冲到窗边……
en: Cyrus Harding and his companions rushed to one of the windows—

zh: 只见双桅船被一股势不可挡的水柱掀了起来，然后一分为二，不到十秒钟，就和船上的罪犯们一起沉入了海里！
en: The brig, irresistibly raised on a sort of water-spout, had just split in two, and in less than ten seconds she was swallowed up with all her criminal crew!

zh: 第四章
en: Chapter 4

zh: “船爆炸了！”赫伯特喊。
en: “She has blown up!” cried Herbert.

zh: “真的！炸了！就像艾尔顿真的点着了火药一样！”潘克洛夫从窗口那边过来，跟纳布和少年一齐跳进了升降梯。
en: “Yes! blown up, just as if Ayrton had set fire to the powder!” returned Pencroft, throwing himself into the lift together with Neb and the lad.

zh: “究竟是怎么回事？”吉迪恩·史佩莱问，这个意想不到的突发事件让他感到非常吃惊。
en: “But what has happened?” asked Gideon Spilett, quite stunned by this unexpected catastrophe.

zh: “嗯！这下我们就会知道了……”工程师立即说。
en: “Oh! this time, we shall know—” answered the engineer quickly.

zh: “知道什么……”
en: “What shall we know?—”

zh: “再等等吧！再等等！走吧，史佩莱。重要的是海盗都被歼灭了！”
en: “Later! later!Come, Spilett.The main point is that these pirates have been exterminated!”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁催促着通讯记者和艾尔顿，三人跟着潘克洛夫、纳布和赫伯特一块儿来到了海滩。
en: And Cyrus Harding, hurrying away the reporter and Ayrton, joined Pencroft, Neb, and Herbert on the beach.

zh: 整艘双桅船被炸得面目全非　，连桅杆也看不见。当时船被水柱抛到空中，往一边倒下去，然后就这样沉没了，显然是因为一些地方漏水很严重。不过，这一带的海峡至多有20英尺深，所以，沉船的船帮肯定能在水浅的地方露出来。
en: Nothing could be seen of the brig, not even her masts.After having been raised by the water-spout, she had fallen on her side, and had sunk in that position, doubtless in consequence of some enormous leak.But as in that place the channel was not more than twenty feet in depth, it was certain that the sides of the submerged brig would reappear at low water.

zh: 沉船上的一些东西漂浮在水面上，其中有一只木筏，上面搁着不用的圆材，还有家禽笼子——里面的家禽还是活的——箱子和木桶，这些都从舱口漂出来，慢慢浮到了水面上。可是，沉船的残骸，不管是甲板上的厚板材，还是船体的木材，却一丁点儿也看不到，这让人觉得飞快号的突然失踪实在太不可思议。
en: A few things from the wreck floated on the surface of the water, a raft could be seen consisting of spare spars, coops of poultry with their occupants still living, boxes and barrels, which gradually came to the surface, after having escaped through the hatchways, but no pieces of the wreck appeared, neither planks from the deck, nor timber from the hull,—which rendered the sudden disappearance of the “Speedy” perfectly inexplicable.

zh: 不过，两根折断的桅杆还是挣脱了左右支索的纠缠，漂了上来，桅杆上头还挂着帆，有的卷着边，有的伸展开来。艾尔顿和潘克洛夫等不及潮水把沉船上的财物冲上来，就跳进小船，想把沉船的残骸拖上海岸或是小岛。可是，正当他们要划船离开的时候，吉丁·史佩莱的一个问题却把他们问住了。
en: However, the two masts, which had been broken and escaped from the shrouds and stays came up, and with their sails, some furled and the others spread.But it was not necessary to wait for the tide to bring up these riches, and Ayrton and Pencroft jumped into the boat with the intention of towing the pieces of wreck either to the beach or to the islet.But just as they were shoving off, an observation from Gideon Spilett arrested them.

zh: “在慈悲河右岸登陆的那六个罪犯上哪儿去了？”吉迪恩·史佩莱说。
en: “What about those six convicts who disembarked on the right bank of the Mercy?” said he.

zh: 大伙确实得提防一下，那六个罪犯乘的船虽然已经被岩石撞了个稀碎，可他们已经在遗物角上岸了。
en: In fact, it would not do to forget that the six men whose boat had gone to pieces on the rocks had landed at Flotsam Point.

zh: 大伙儿往那个方向望去。一个罪犯也看不到。或许，这帮家伙看见他们的船在海峡里沉没了，便逃到荒岛的内陆去了。
en: They looked in that direction.None of the fugitives were visible.It was probable that, having seen their vessel engulfed in the channel, they had fled into the interior of the island.

zh: “我们以后再去对付那帮家伙，”哈丁说,“那帮罪犯身上有武器，因此遇上他们依然是件很危险的事，不过，现在我们和他们都是六个人，每一方都有一半赢的把握。先着手去办眼下最要紧的事吧。”
en: “We will deal with them later,” said Harding.“As they are armed, they will still be dangerous; but as it is six against six, the chances are equal.To the most pressing business first.”

zh: 艾尔顿和潘克洛夫奋力朝沉船划去。
en: Ayrton and Pencroft pulled vigorously towards the wreck.

zh: 海面很平静，因为两天前才是新月，所以潮水非常高。至少还要过一个小时，双桅船的船体才能从海峡的水面露出来。
en: The sea was calm and the tide very high, as there had been a new moon but two days before.A whole hour at least would elapse before the hull of the brig could emerge from the water of the channel.

zh: 艾尔顿和潘克洛夫用绳子绑住桅杆和圆材，然后把绳子的一头带到海岸上来。移民们一块儿使劲，终于把沉船的残骸拉了上来。接下来，艾尔顿和潘克洛夫又划着小船把漂在水面上的笼子、木桶、箱子打捞上来，然后立马把这些东西送回了“石窟”。
en: Ayrton and Pencroft were able to fasten the masts and spars by means of ropes, the ends of which were carried to the beach.There, by the united efforts of the settlers the pieces of wreck were hauled up.Then the boat picked up all that was floating, coops, barrels, and boxes, which were immediately carried to the Chimneys.

zh: 几具尸体也浮出了水面。艾尔顿认出当中一个就是鲍勃·哈维，他指着那具尸体，激动地对同伴说道：
en: Several bodies floated also.Among them, Ayrton recognized that of Bob Harvey, which he pointed out to his companion, saying with some emotion,—

zh: “我以前也和这个家伙一样，潘克洛夫。”
en: “That is what I have been, Pencroft.”

zh: “可是你现在不一样了，勇敢的艾尔顿！”水手热情地回应。
en: “But what you are no longer, brave Ayrton!” returned the sailor warmly.

zh: 令人觉得奇怪的是，只有寥寥几具尸体漂在水面上。他们数了数，统共才有五六具，这些尸体就要被水流冲到大海里了。很可能还没等罪犯们逃出去，船就朝一边沉了，因此大部分的人都被压在了下面。现在，水流就要把这些可悲的人的尸体冲到大海里了，这倒是给移民们省去了一件伤心的麻烦事——免得还要在荒岛上找什么角落把尸体埋起来。
en: It was singular enough that so few bodies floated.Only five or six were counted, which were already being carried by the current towards the open sea.Very probably the convicts had not had time to escape, and the ship lying over on her side, the greater number of them had remained below.Now the current, by carrying the bodies of these miserable men out to sea, would spare the colonists the sad task of burying them in some corner of their island.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和同伴们花了两个钟头的时间，把圆材拖到沙地上来，又把船上完好无损的帆展开来晒干。因为大伙儿都在一门心思地干活，所以很少交谈，但他们的脑子却被这样那样的想法占据着。
en: For two hours, Cyrus Harding and his companions were solely occupied in hauling up the spars on to the sand, and then in spreading the sails which were perfectly uninjured, to dry.They spoke little, for they were absorbed in their work, but what thoughts occupied their minds!

zh: 拥有这艘双桅船，或者说，拥有船上装载的所有物品，是一笔无比巨大的财富。的确，一艘船就好比一个小世界，殖民地的仓库因此又会增加大量有用的物品。它简直跟在遗物角发现的箱子差不多了。
en: The possession of this brig, or rather all that she contained, was a perfect mine of wealth.In fact, a ship is like a little world in miniature, and the stores of the colony would be increased by a large number of useful articles.It would be, on a large scale, equivalent to the chest found at Flotsam Point.

zh: “还有，”潘克洛夫说，“为什么不让双桅船重新浮起来呢？如果船只是漏水，我们可以把它修补一下，这艘船有三四百吨重，比我们的‘乘风破浪号’可强多了！我们可以乘着它到很远的地方去！想去哪里，就去哪里！哈丁队长，我一定要和艾尔顿检查一下这艘船。它值得我们费功夫！”
en: “And besides,” thought Pencroft, “why should it be impossible to refloat the brig?If she has only a leak, that may be stopped up; a vessel from three to four hundred tons, why she is a regular ship compared to our ‘Bonadventure’!And we could go a long distance in her!We could go anywhere we liked!Captain Harding, Ayrton and I must examine her!She would be well worth the trouble!”

zh: 事实上，要是双桅船仍然可以航行的话，移民者回到祖国的机会将大大增加。不过，大伙儿还得等潮水落得很低的时候，才能找到这个重要问题的答案，因为到那时才能把双桅船船身的每一部分检查一遍。
en: In fact, if the brig was still fit to navigate, the colonists’ chances of returning to their native land were singularly increased.But, to decide this important question, it was necessary to wait until the tide was quite low, so that every part of the brig’s hull might be examined.

zh: 把财物安全地转移到岸上后，哈丁和同伴们决定花点时间解决一下早饭。大伙儿几乎都要饿昏了。幸亏食品室隔得不远，而且纳布又是一个手脚麻利的厨师。于是，他们就在“石窟”附近吃了早饭，吃饭的过程中——可以猜得到——他们谈的尽是移民队神奇获救的这次事件。
en: When their treasures had been safely conveyed on shore, Harding and his companions agreed to devote some minutes to breakfast.They were almost famished; fortunately, the larder was not far off, and Neb was noted for being an expeditious cook.They breakfasted, therefore, near the Chimneys, and during their repast, as may be supposed, nothing was talked of but the event which had so miraculously saved the colony.

zh: “实在太神奇了，”潘克洛夫不停地说，“我们必须得承认，那帮混蛋被炸得正是时候！‘花岗石宫’当时就快要被侵占了！”
en: “Miraculous is the word,” repeated Pencroft, “for it must be acknowledged that those rascals blew up just at the right moment!Granite House was beginning to be uncomfortable as a habitation!”

zh: “你能想一下，潘克洛夫，”通讯记者问，“这是怎么发生的，或者，是什么引起爆炸的？”
en: “And can you guess, Pencroft,” asked the reporter, “how it happened, or what can have occasioned the explosion?”

zh: “哦！史佩莱先生，这个再简单不过了，”潘克洛夫答道，“罪犯们的船可不像军舰那么有纪律！他们可不是水手。显然，火药库的门一直开着，在那帮罪犯不停地开火的时候，哪个粗心的或者笨拙的家伙就这样把船给炸了！”
en: “Oh!Mr. Spilett, nothing is more simple,” answered Pencroft.“A convict vessel is not disciplined like a man-of-war!Convicts are not sailors.Of course the powder-magazine was open, and as they were firing incessantly, some careless or clumsy fellow just blew up the vessel!”

zh: “哈丁队长，”赫伯特说，“我感到吃惊的是，爆炸的作用只有这么大。爆炸声音并不大，而且，只炸坏了几块船板和肋材。船看起来像是被撞沉的，而不是被炸毁的。”
en: “Captain Harding,” said Herbert, “what astonishes me is that the explosion has not produced more effect.The report was not loud, and besides there are so few planks and timbers torn out.It seems as if the ship had rather foundered than blown up.”

zh: “那让你觉得吃惊吗，孩子？”工程师问。
en: “Does that astonish you, my boy?” asked the engineer.

zh: “是的，队长。”
en: “Yes, captain.”

zh: “它同样让我觉得吃惊，赫伯特，”哈丁回答，“不过，等我们看了双桅船的船体以后，自然就能对这个问题作出解释了。”
en: “And it astonishes me also, Herbert,” replied he, “but when we visit the hull of the brig, we shall no doubt find the explanation of the matter.”

zh: “怎么，队长，”潘克洛夫说，“你不会以为‘飞快号’只是被撞沉的，就像一艘船撞到了礁石一样？”
en: “Why, captain,” said Pencroft, “you don’t suppose that the ‘Speedy’ simply foundered like a ship which has struck on a rock?”

zh: “如果海峡里有礁石，”纳布说，“为什么不可能呢？”
en: “Why not,” observed Neb, “if there are rocks in the channel?”

zh: “胡扯，纳布，”潘克洛夫反驳，“你没看见船沉的那一刻。我清清楚楚地看见，就在双桅船沉没之前的一刹那，一个巨大的海浪把它顶了起来，接着船就往左舷的一侧倒下去了。如果只是触礁，那它就会一声不响地沉入海底，正常的船就该这样。”
en: “Nonsense, Neb,” answered Pencroft, “you did not look at the right moment.An instant before she sank, the brig, as I saw perfectly well, rose on an enormous wave, and fell back on her larboard side.Now, if she had only struck, she would have sunk quietly and gone to the bottom like an honest vessel.”

zh: “那是因为它不是一艘正常的船！”纳布回嘴。
en: “It was just because she was not an honest vessel!” returned Neb.

zh: “好了，我们很快就知道是怎么一回事了，潘克洛夫。”工程师说。
en: “Well, we shall soon see, Pencroft.” said the engineer.

zh: “很快就知道了，”水手跟着说道，“不过，我敢用脑袋担保，海峡中绝对没有礁石。嘿，队长，坦白一点讲，你的意思是说这件事情有些奇怪？”
en: “We shall soon see,” rejoined the sailor, “but I would wager my head there are no rocks in the channel.Look here, captain, to speak candidly, do you mean to say that there is anything marvelous in the occurrence?”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁没有回答。
en: Cyrus Harding did not answer.

zh: “不管怎么样，”吉迪恩·史佩莱发话了，“触礁也好，爆炸也好，潘克洛夫，有一点你得承认，那就是事情发生的正是时候！”
en: “At any rate,” said Gideon Spilett, “whether rock or explosion, you will agree, Pencroft, that it occurred just in the nick of time!”

zh: “这倒是，”水手说，“可是问题不在这儿啊。我是问哈丁队长，他有没有觉得这件事情有些神奇的地方。”
en: “Yes! yes!” replied the sailor, “but that is not the question.I ask Captain Harding if he sees anything supernatural in all this.”

zh: “我不知道，潘克洛夫，”工程师回答，“我只能这样回答你。”
en: “I cannot say, Pencroft,” said the engineer.“That is all the answer I can make.”

zh: 潘克洛夫对这个回答一点儿也不满意。他坚持是“爆炸”，而且不肯放弃这个想法。他打死也不会同意，像海滩一样，底下铺着一层细沙的海峡中——水浅的时候，他还经常从这涉水经过呢——会有什么未知的礁石！
en: A reply which did not satisfy Pencroft at all.He stuck to “an explosion,” and did not wish to give it up.He would never consent to admit that in that channel, with its fine sandy bed, just like the beach, which he had often crossed at low water, there could be an unknown rock.

zh: 况且，双桅船沉没的时候，水位很高，就是说，即使潮水退下有礁石露出来，水量也足够把船举着“越”过任何石头。所以，那样的话，不可能有撞击。船并没有触礁。它就是爆炸了。
en: And besides, at the time the brig foundered, it was high water, that is to say, there was enough water to carry the vessel clear over any rocks which would not be uncovered at low tide.Therefore, there could not have been a collision.Therefore, the vessel had not struck.So she had blown up.

zh: 必须承认，水手的分析不无道理。
en: And it must be confessed that the sailor’s arguments were reasonable.

zh: 将近一点半的时候，移民们登上小船去看沉船了。可惜的是，双桅船的两只小船没能保留下来：有一只，前面已经说过，在慈悲河河口被撞得粉碎，完全报废了；另外一只在双桅船沉没的时候消失了，再没露出来，肯定是被撞碎了。
en: Towards half-past one, the colonists embarked in the boat to visit the wreck.It was to be regretted that the brig’s two boats had not been saved; but one, as has been said, had gone to pieces at the mouth of the Mercy, and was absolutely useless; the other had disappeared when the brig went down, and had not again been seen, having doubtless been crushed.

zh: “飞快号”的船身才开始慢慢露出水面。船往一边倾斜着，剧烈的震动把压舱的底货震了出来，压断了桅杆，整条船的龙骨都看得见。一种令人费解的、可怕的水下活动倾覆了船身，同时，海里还冒出了一个巨大的水柱。
en: The hull of the “Speedy” was just beginning to issue from the water.The brig was lying right over on her side, for her masts being broken, pressed down by the weight of the ballast displaced by the shock, the keel was visible along her whole length.She had been regularly turned over by the inexplicable but frightful submarine action, which had been at the same time manifested by an enormous water-spout.

zh: 移民们划着小船围着双桅船船身观察。随着潮水的退下，虽说他们还没弄明白失事的原因，但至少也确定了其产生的后果。
en: The settlers rowed round the hull, and in proportion as the tide went down, they could ascertain, if not the cause which had occasioned the catastrophe, at least the effect produced.

zh: 靠近船头的部分，在离船艄七八英尺的地方，双桅船两侧的龙骨遭到了严重的毁坏。两边各开着一条至少20英尺长的大口子，根本堵不上。船底的铜包板和木板不见了，无疑被炸成了碎末，除此之外，就连用来连接的肋材、铁螺丝和木钉也都不见了。一股无法言说的蛮力把副龙骨从整个船身到船尾剥离了下来，短纵梁上的龙骨本身也裂开了好几处，整个龙骨已经完全折断了。
en: Towards the bows, on both sides of the keel, seven or eight feet from the beginning of the stem, the sides of the brig were frightfully torn.Over a length of at least twenty feet there opened two large leaks, which would be impossible to stop up.Not only had the copper sheathing and the planks disappeared, reduced, no doubt, to powder, but also the ribs, the iron bolts, and treenalls which united them.From the entire length of the hull to the stern the false keel had been separated with an unaccountable violence, and the keel itself, torn from the carline in several places, was split in all its length.

zh: “我看，”潘克洛夫叫道，“这艘船恐怕很难再浮起来喽。”
en: “I’ve a notion!” exclaimed Pencroft, “that this vessel will be difficult to get afloat again.”

zh: “压根就不可能。”艾尔顿说。
en: “It will be impossible,” said Ayrton.

zh: “无论如何，”吉迪恩·史佩莱对水手说，“如果真的发生了爆炸，那它实在是产生了奇怪的后果！它没有炸坏甲板和水线以上部分，却炸裂了船身的底部！这些大口子看起来并不像火药库炸的，反而更像是礁石撞的。”
en: “At any rate,” observed Gideon Spilett to the sailor, “the explosion, if there has been one, has produced singular effects!It has split the lower part of the hull, instead of blowing up the deck and topsides!These great rents appear rather to have been made by a rock than by the explosion of a powder-magazine.”

zh: “海峡里没有礁石！”水手反驳，“我可以承认你说的任何事情，惟独除了礁石这件。”
en: “There is not a rock in the channel!” answered the sailor.“I will admit anything you like, except the rock.”

zh: “我们想法子进到船里边吧，”工程师说，“到那时可能就知道它遭到破坏的原因了。”
en: “Let us try to penetrate into the interior of the brig,” said the engineer; “perhaps we shall then know what to think of the cause of her destruction.”

zh: 这是最好的办法了，而且，大伙儿都同意把船上装载的财物清点一下，好好安排一下它们存放的地方。
en: This was the best thing to be done, and it was agreed, besides, to take an inventory of all the treasures on board, and to arrange their preservation.

zh: 现在很容易就能进到双桅船里面了。潮水在继续下退，甲板上可以走人了。压仓的底货是一些沉重的铁块，船身有好几个地方都被戳破了。海水从船身的窟窿流出来，发出哗哗的响声。
en: Access to the interior of the brig was now easy.The tide was still going down and the deck was practicable.The ballast, composed of heavy masses of iron, had broken through in several places.The noise of the sea could be heard as it rushed out at the holes in the hull.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和同伴们手里拿着短柄小斧，沿着破烂的甲板往前走着。各种各样的箱子拦住了他们的去路，因为箱子浸水的时间很短，里面的东西可能还完好无损。
en: Cyrus Harding and his companions, hatchets in hand, advanced along the shattered deck.Cases of all sorts encumbered it, and, as they had been but a very short time in the water, their contents were perhaps uninjured.

zh: 接下来，移民们忙着把船上的货物安全地存放起来。潮水再度涨潮还要几个小时，移民们必须最大限度地利用这点时间。艾尔顿和潘克洛夫在船身的入口处找到了索具，用它把木桶和箱子吊了起来。大伙儿把货物装进小船，运到岸边，接着又回来运送各种物品，打算以后再进行整理。
en: They then busied themselves in placing all this cargo in safety.The water would not return for several hours, and these hours must be employed in the most profitable way.Ayrton and Pencroft had, at the entrance made in the hull, discovered tackle, which would serve to hoist up the barrels and chests.The boat received them and transported them to the shore.They took the articles as they came, intending to sort them afterwards.

zh: 总的来说，移民们欣喜万分，因为他们很快发现，双桅船上装载着各种各样的货物，包括五花八门的物件、器皿、制成品和工具，堪比中太平洋小岛上进行大规模沿海贸易的商船。不管想要什么，他们大概都可以在里面找到一些，大伙儿都一致认为这些东西正是林肯岛上的移民队所需要的。
en: At any rate, the settlers saw at once, with extreme satisfaction, that the brig possessed a very varied cargo—an assortment of all sorts of articles, utensils, manufactured goods, and tools—such as the ships which make the great coasting-trade of Polynesia are usually laden with.It was probable that they would find a little of everything, and they agreed that it was exactly what was necessary for the colony of Lincoln Island.

zh: 然而，赛勒斯·哈丁吃惊地默默观察到，不管失事的原因是什么，正如前面所交待的，双桅船的船身遭到了重创，就连船的内部装置，尤其是靠近船艄的部分，也都被毁坏了。隔板和支柱都遭到了破坏，就好像是什么威力巨大的炮弹在双桅船内部爆炸过。移民们把箱子移开，在甲板上走来走去变得轻松多了。这些箱子不是很难移动的沉重的大件，而是简单的小件，上面标明起装载物的字迹已经模糊不清。
en: However—and Cyrus Harding observed it in silent astonishment—not only, as has been said, had the hull of the brig enormously suffered from the shock, whatever it was, that had occasioned the catastrophe, but the interior arrangements had been destroyed, especially towards the bows.Partitions and stanchions were smashed, as if some tremendous shell had burst in the interior of the brig.The colonists could easily go fore and aft, after having removed the cases as they were extricated.They were not heavy bales, which would have been difficult to remove, but simple packages, of which the stowage, besides, was no longer recognizable.

zh: 移民们这时到了船尾，这里原来是舵楼甲板。按照艾尔顿的指引，他们应该在这儿寻找火药库。赛勒斯·哈丁认为，火药库没有爆炸，或许会留下几桶火药，而且火药一向有金属外壳包着，可能不会受潮。
en: The colonists then reached the stern of the brig—the part formerly surmounted by the poop.It was there that, following Ayrton’s directions, they must look for the powder-magazine.Cyrus Harding thought that it had not exploded; that it was possible some barrels might be saved, and that the powder, which is usually enclosed in metal coverings might not have suffered from contact with the water.

zh: 事情确实是这样。他们从子弹堆里找到20桶火药，桶里都衬着铜皮。亲眼看到这一切的潘克洛夫被说服了：“飞快号”的沉没绝不是因为爆炸。而且，放置火药库的那部分船身遭受的损失反而最小。
en: This, in fact, was just what had happened.They extricated from among a large number of shot twenty barrels, the insides of which were lined with copper.Pencroft was convinced by the evidence of his own eyes that the destruction of the “Speedy” could not be attributed to an explosion.That part of the hull in which the magazine was situated was, moreover, that which had suffered least.

zh: “或许不是炸沉的，”倔强的水手说，“可是至于说是触礁，海峡里可是一块石头也没有！”
en: “It may be so,” said the obstinate sailor; “but as to a rock, there is not one in the channel!”

zh: “那么，船到底是怎么沉的呢？”赫伯特问道。
en: “Then, how did it happen?” asked Herbert.

zh: “我不知道，”潘克洛夫回答，“连哈丁队长都不知道，别人怎么会知道，而且，以后也不会有人弄明白了。”
en: “I don’t know,” answered Pencroft, “Captain Harding doesn’t know, and nobody knows or ever will know!”

zh: 这些调查花了移民们几个小时的时间，这时，潮水开始上涨了。目前，工作必须先放一放。大伙儿不担心双桅船被海水冲走，因为它像抛了锚似的，已经牢牢地固定在那儿了。
en: Several hours had passed during these researches, and the tide began to flow.Work must be suspended for the present.There was no fear of the brig being carried away by the sea, for she was already fixed as firmly as if moored by her anchors.

zh: 因此，他们可以放心地等到第二天再接着工作，可是，双桅船本身已经不能“起死回生”，最好的办法是赶紧把船身剩余的部分抢救出来，因为船可能会很快地被海峡里的流沙吞没。
en: They could, therefore, without inconvenience, wait until the next day to resume operations; but, as to the vessel itself, she was doomed, and it would be best to hasten to save the remains of her hull, as she would not be long in disappearing in the quicksands of the channel.

zh: 现在是傍晚五点钟。移民们都辛苦劳作了一天。吃晚饭时，大家的胃口都很好，吃过饭，尽管很累，可大家还是忍不住要把“飞快号”上的装货箱子打开检查一下。
en: It was now five o’clock in the evening.It had been a hard day’s work for the men.They ate with good appetite, and notwithstanding their fatigue, they could not resist, after dinner, their desire of inspecting the cases which composed the cargo of the “Speedy.”

zh: 大部分箱子里装的都是衣服，可以想象，它们很受岛上的移民们欢迎。这些衣服够整个移民队穿了，有够所有人穿衣的亚麻布，和够所有人穿的鞋子。
en: Most of them contained clothes, which, as may be believed, was well received.There were enough to clothe a whole colony—linen for every one’s use, shoes for every one’s feet.

zh: “我们太富有了！”潘克洛夫喊，“可我们到底要怎么处理所有这些？”
en: “We are too rich!” exclaimed Pencroft, “But what are we going to do with all this?”

zh: 水手还看见了一桶桶的火药、佩枪、棉花包、耕作用具、木匠、细木匠和铁匠的工具，还有一盒子一盒子的各种各样的种子，由于在水里的时间很短，这些种子一点儿也没受潮。水手每看到一样东西，就高兴地欢呼一阵。啊，要是在两年前，这些东西该是多么珍贵！现在，即使勤劳的移民们已经有了工具，这些财富也依然有用得上的地方。
en: And every moment burst forth the hurrahs of the delighted sailor when he caught sight of the barrels of gunpowder, firearms and sidearms, balls of cotton, implements of husbandry, carpenter’s, joiner’s, and blacksmith’s tools, and boxes of all kinds of seeds, not in the least injured by their short sojourn in the water.Ah, two years before, how these things would have been prized!And now, even though the industrious colonists had provided themselves with tools, these treasures would find their use.

zh: 花岗石宫的储藏室还有不少空间，可要赶在天黑之前把所有的东西存放好，是不可能的了。同时，移民们还得提醒自己，“飞快号”上的六个逃犯已经上了岛，他们极有可能是一群穷凶极恶的匪徒，大伙儿地好好提防着这几个人。尽管慈悲河上的桥已被扯了下来，罪犯们怎么可能被一条河流或小溪挡住去路，一旦被逼得走投无路，这帮人可是什么事情都干得出来。
en: There was no want of space in the store-rooms of Granite House, but that daytime would not allow them to stow away the whole.It would not do also to forget that the six survivors of the “Speedy’s” crew had landed on the island, for they were in all probability scoundrels of the deepest dye, and it was necessary that the colonists should be on their guard against them.Although the bridges over the Mercy were raised, the convicts would not be stopped by a river or a stream and, rendered desperate, these wretches would be capable of anything.

zh: 移民们不久将会研究出最好要采取什么计划，同时，他们得保护好堆放在“石窟”附近的箱子和物件，于是，到了晚上，大家轮流站岗放哨。
en: They would see later what plan it would be best to follow; but in the meantime it was necessary to mount guard over cases and packages heaped up near the Chimneys, and thus the settlers employed themselves in turn during the night.

zh: 然而，到了早上，罪犯们并没有发动任何袭击。贾普和托普在花岗石宫脚下守着，一有动静，会马上发出警报。接下来的三天——10月的19、20、21号——移民们都在忙着抢救每一样有价值的，或者但凡有点用途的物品，不管是货物也好，还是船上的索具也好，都被留了下来。退潮的时候，他们往岸上拖物品，涨潮时，他们则把抢救出来的东西存放好。船身的铜包板有很大一部分被剥离了下来，船身日渐下沉。可是，艾尔顿和潘克洛夫赶在重物从船底露出沉入泥沙之前，潜入海峡水底，捞上来了双桅船的锚链、压仓的铁块，甚至还有四门炮，这些都是利用空桶把它们浮起来，然后带到岸边的。
en: The morning came, however, without the convicts having attempted any attack.Master Jup and Top, on guard at the foot of Granite House, would have quickly given the alarm.The three following day—the 19th, 20th, and 21st of October—were employed in saving everything of value, or of any use whatever, either from the cargo or rigging of the brig.At low tide they overhauled the hold—at high tide they stowed away the rescued articles.A great part of the copper sheathing had been torn from the hull, which every day sank lower.But before the sand had swallowed the heavy things which had fallen through the bottom, Ayrton and Pencroft, diving to the bed of the channel, recovered the chains and anchors of the brig, the iron of her ballast, and even four guns, which, floated by means of empty casks, were brought to shore.

zh: 可以看到移民队的军火库和花岗石宫的储藏室都因为沉船而获得了扩充。潘克洛夫总是热衷于种种“宏图构想”，这时，已经说到要造一个炮台来控制海峡和慈悲河口了。他打算用这四门炮，阻止任何舰队侵犯林肯岛的水域，不管他们有多强大！
en: It may be seen that the arsenal of the colony had gained by the wreck, as well as the storerooms of Granite House.Pencroft, always enthusiastic in his projects, already spoke of constructing a battery to command the channel and the mouth of the river.With four guns, he engaged to prevent any fleet, “however powerful it might be,” from venturing into the waters of Lincoln Island!

zh: 同时，当双桅船只剩下一个没用的船身时，天气变得很恶劣，船一下子就被彻底摧毁了。赛勒斯·哈丁本来还想把船身炸开，用来收拾一下岸上剩下的东西，可是，从东北方刮来的一股强风和大海上的狂潮让他不得不放弃这个想法，节省点火药。
en: In the meantime, when nothing remained of the brig but a useless hulk, bad weather came on, which soon finished her.Cyrus Harding had intended to blow her up, so as to collect the remains on the shore, but a strong gale from the northeast and a heavy sea compelled him to economize his powder.

zh: 事实上，23号夜里，船身整个都粉碎了，一些残骸被卷到了岸边。
en: In fact, on the night of the 23rd, the hull entirely broke up, and some of the wreck was cast up on the beach.

zh: 至于船上的文件，就更不必说了。尽管哈丁仔仔细细地搜找了尾楼的抽屉，可还是什么都没找到。海盗们显然把任何有关船长或“飞快号”的主人的材料都销毁了，而且，船尾也没有漆着港口的名称，因此没法判断出船的国籍。不过，通过观察双桅船的两只小船的形状，艾尔顿和潘克洛夫相信，双桅船是英国制造的。
en: As to the papers on board, it is useless to say that, although he carefully searched the lockers of the poop, Harding did not discover any trace of them.The pirates had evidently destroyed everything that concerned either the captain or the owners of the “Speedy,” and, as the name of her port was not painted on her counter, there was nothing which would tell them her nationality.However, by the shape of her boats Ayrton and Pencroft believed that the brig was of English build.

zh: 事故发生一周后——与其说是事故，倒不如称之为一次幸运的、尽管令人费解的、使移民们得到保护的事件——即使在退潮的时候，也看不见双桅船了。船的残骸消失了，花岗石宫因为得到了船上几乎所有的物品，而变得富足起来。
en: A week after the castrophe—or, rather, after the fortunate, though inexplicable, event to which the colony owed its preservation—nothing more could be seen of the vessel, even at low tide.The wreck had disappeared, and Granite House was enriched by nearly all it had contained.

zh: 然而，笼罩着这次奇怪的毁灭事件的神秘气氛本来可能一直都不会散去，直到11月30号，纳布在海滩上散步时，发现了一块铁筒的厚片，上面看得出爆炸过的痕迹。厚片的边缘打着卷儿，残缺不全，就像是遭到了什么爆炸性物体的破坏。
en: However, the mystery which enveloped its strange destruction would doubtless never have been cleared away if, on the 30th of November, Neb, strolling on the beach, had not found a piece of a thick iron cylinder, bearing traces of explosion.The edges of this cylinder were twisted and broken, as if they had been subjected to the action of some explosive substance.

zh: 纳布把这个金属厚片带回来交给主人，哈丁当时正和同伴们呆在“石窟”的工厂里。
en: Neb brought this piece of metal to his master, who was then occupied with his companions in the workshop of the Chimneys.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁专注地检查了厚片，然后，对潘克洛夫说，
en: Cyrus Harding examined the cylinder attentively, then, turning to Pencroft,—

zh: “朋友，你一直坚持认为，”他说道，“‘飞快号’不是撞沉的，是吧？”
en: “You persist, my friend,” said he, “in maintaining that the ‘Speedy’ was not lost in consequence of a collision?”

zh: “是的，队长，”水手回答，“你我都知道海峡里没有石头。”
en: “Yes, captain,” answered the sailor.“You know as well as I do that there are no rocks in the channel.”

zh: “那能否认为，船是撞上了这块铁片呢？”工程师一边说，一边把残缺不全的铁筒给他看。
en: “But suppose she had run against this piece of iron?” said the engineer, showing the broken cylinder.

zh: “什么，这么点破铁！”潘克洛夫完全不相信地喊道。
en: “What, that bit of pipe!” exclaimed Pencroft in a tone of perfect incredulity.

zh: “朋友们，”哈丁接着说道，“你们记得船沉没前，有一个水柱把船抛起来了？”
en: “My friends,” resumed Harding, “you remember that before she foundered the brig rose on the summit of a regular waterspout?”

zh: “是的，队长。”赫伯特回答。
en: “Yes, captain.” replied Herbert.

zh: “好，你们想知道是什么产生的水柱吗？就是这个。”工程师举着破铁筒子说。
en: “Well, would you like to know what occasioned that waterspout?It was this,” said the engineer, holding up the broken tube.

zh: “这个？”潘克洛夫回答道。
en: “That?” returned Pencroft.

zh: “是的！这个铁筒是水雷的残余！”
en: “Yes!This cylinder is all that remains of a torpedo!”

zh: “水雷！”工程师的同伴们叫道。
en: “A torpedo!” exclaimed the engineer’s companions.

zh: “那是谁把水雷放在那儿的？”不愿让步的潘克洛夫又问。
en: “And who put the torpedo there?” demanded Pencroft, who did not like to yield.

zh: “我只能告诉你，那个人不是我，”赛勒斯·哈丁回答，“可是它确实被放在那儿，你可以判断出它那无比巨大的能量！”
en: “All that I can tell you is, that it was not I,” answered Cyrus Harding; “but it was there, and you have been able to judge of its incomparable power!”

zh: 第五章
en: Chapter 5

zh: 因此，这样一来，一切都可以归因于海底水雷的爆炸。赛勒斯·哈丁不可能弄错，因为在南北统一战争期间，他曾经试制过这种可怕的毁灭性武器。这个铁筒里装着炸药，比如甘油、苦味酸或其他相同性质的物品，就是因为铁筒爆炸了，海峡中的水流才掀成一个圆盖，双桅船的船底才炸裂，船于是立刻沉没了，船身受到的破坏非常严重，再也浮不起来了。一个水雷能像摧毁一艘渔船一样，轻而易举地摧毁一艘装甲舰，“飞快号”又岂在话下！
en: So, then, all was explained by the submarine explosion of this torpedo.Cyrus Harding could not be mistaken, as, during the war of the Union, he had had occasion to try these terrible engines of destruction.It was under the action of this cylinder, charged with some explosive substance, nitro-glycerine, picrate, or some other material of the same nature, that the water of the channel had been raised like a dome, the bottom of the brig crushed in, and she had sunk instantly, the damage done to her hull being so considerable that it was impossible to refloat her.The “Speedy” had not been able to withstand a torpedo that would have destroyed an ironclad as easily as a fishing-boat!

zh: 是的！一切都可以解释了，除了一个问题——海峡中怎么会有水雷？
en: Yes! all was explained, everything—except the presence of the torpedo in the waters of the channel!

zh: “朋友们，那么，”赛勒斯·哈丁说，“我们可以不用再怀疑，岛上还有一个神秘的人物，或许他跟我们一样，遇难后被遗弃在荒岛上，我说这些，是希望艾尔顿也能了解在这两年所发生的种种奇怪的事情。我想象不出这位好心的陌生人到底是谁，有好多次都是他从中干预帮了我们，这让我们感到非常幸运。我也无法明白，他屡次帮助我们，却依然不露面的目的何在？不过，他倒是确确实实给了我们很大的帮助，而且，也只有一个具备天大的本事的人才能这样做。我们大家，包括艾尔顿，都要感谢他，因为我从气球上掉下来后，如果是这位陌生人把我从海里救出来的话，那么，显然也是他写了那个纸条，然后把瓶子放进海峡中，让我们知道了同伴的处境。另外，也是他引着那只箱子，把它放在了遗物角，让我们得到了所需的一切；是他在小岛的高地上点着了火把，使你们得以安全着陆；是他打了西貒一枪；也是他把水雷放在海峡中，炸毁了双桅船；一句话，所有那些我们解释不了的事情，都是这位神秘人所做的。因此，不管他是谁，是船遇难了也好，还是流放在小岛上也好，我们都要感激他，不然，就成了忘恩负义的人了。我们欠他的人情，希望有一天能够报答他。”
en: “My friends, then,” said Cyrus Harding, “we can no longer be in doubt as to the presence of a mysterious being, a castaway like us, perhaps, abandoned on our island, and I say this in order that Ayrton may be acquainted with all the strange events which have occurred during these two years.Who this beneficent stranger is, whose intervention has, so fortunately for us, been manifested on many occasions, I cannot imagine.What his object can be in acting thus, in concealing himself after rendering us so many services, I cannot understand: But his services are not the less real, and are of such a nature that only a man possessed of prodigious power, could render them.Ayrton is indebted to him as much as we are, for, if it was the stranger who saved me from the waves after the fall from the balloon, evidently it was he who wrote the document, who placed the bottle in the channel, and who has made known to us the situation of our companion.I will add that it was he who guided that chest, provided with everything we wanted, and stranded it on Flotsam Point; that it was he who lighted that fire on the heights of the island, which permitted you to land; that it was he who fired that bullet found in the body of the peccary; that it was he who plunged that torpedo into the channel, which destroyed the brig; in a word, that all those inexplicable events, for which we could not assign a reason, are due to this mysterious being.Therefore, whoever he may be, whether shipwrecked, or exiled on our island, we shall be ungrateful, if we think ourselves freed from gratitude towards him.We have contracted a debt, and I hope that we shall one day pay it.”

zh: “亲爱的赛勒斯，你说得对，”吉迪恩·史佩莱说，　“是的，岛上的什么地方藏着一个几乎无所不能的人，这个人的力量对我们有很大的好处。我还要补充一点儿，如果我们承认实际生活中真的有超自然的事情发生，那这位陌生人似乎就真的具备一种近乎超自然的力量。是不是他从花岗石宫的井里听到了我们的谈话，因而知道了我们的全盘计划？是不是他在小船首次航行时，把瓶子扔给我们的？是不是他把托普从湖里扔出来，杀了儒艮？也是他——所有的事情都让我们相信——在其他人都无能为力的情况下，把你从海里救出来的吧？如果都是他，那他简直拥有一种无所不能的能力了。”
en: “You are right in speaking thus, my dear Cyrus,” replied Gideon Spilett.“Yes, there is an almost all-powerful being, hidden in some part of the island, and whose influence has been singularly useful to our colony.I will add that the unknown appears to possess means of action which border on the supernatural, if in the events of practical life the supernatural were recognizable.Is it he who is in secret communication with us by the well in Granite House, and has he thus a knowledge of all our plans?Was it he who threw us that bottle, when the vessel made her first cruise?Was it he who threw Top out of the lake, and killed the dugong?Was it he, who as everything leads us to believe, saved you from the waves, and that under circumstances in which any one else would not have been able to act?If it was he, he possesses a power which renders him master of the elements.”

zh: 通讯记者的分析合乎情理，大伙儿也都是这样想的。
en: The reporter’s reasoning was just, and every one felt it to be so.

zh: “是的，”赛勒斯·哈丁接着说道，“如果我们可以肯定是一个人在帮助我们，那我也认为这个人具备一种超凡的能力。现在还剩下一个谜，不过，等到我们找到这个人，谜底也就自然解开了。那么，现在的问题是，我们是应该尊重这位慷慨人士的隐居身份，还是应该竭尽全力把他找出来？你们对此是怎么看的？”
en: “Yes,” rejoined Cyrus Harding, “if the intervention of a human being is not more questionable for us, I agree that he has at his disposal means of action beyond those possessed by humanity.There is a mystery still, but if we discover the man, the mystery will be discovered also.The question, then, is, ought we to respect the incognito of this generous being, or ought we to do everything to find him out?What is your opinion on the matter?”

zh: “我觉得，”潘克洛夫说，“不管是谁，他都是一个勇敢的人，我佩服他！”
en: “My opinion,” said Pencroft, “is that, whoever he may be, he is a brave man, and he has my esteem!”

zh: “话虽不错，”哈丁说，“不过，潘克洛夫，你没回答我的问题。”
en: “Be it so,” answered Harding, “but that is not an answer, Pencroft.”

zh: “哈丁先生，”纳布这时说，“我认为，我们可以尽量寻找你说的这位陌生人，不过，除非他自己乐意露面，不然，我们是找不到他的。”
en: “Master,” then said Neb, “my idea is, that we may search as long as we like for this gentleman whom you are talking about, but that we shall not discover him till he pleases.”

zh: “说得不错，纳布。”潘克洛夫听了说。
en: “That’s not bad, what you say, Neb,” observed Pencroft.

zh: “我同意纳布的说法，”吉迪恩·史佩莱说，“但我们不能因此就不尝试寻找。不管能不能找到这个神秘的人，我们至少得尽到找他的一份心意。”
en: “I am of Neb’s opinion,” said Gideon Spilett, “but that is no reason for not attempting the adventure.Whether we find this mysterious being or not, we shall at least have fulfilled our duty towards him.”

zh: “孩子，你呢，说说你的看法。”工程师转向赫伯特，问道。
en: “And you, my boy, give us your opinion,” said the engineer, turning to Herbert.

zh: “啊，”赫伯特满脸写着兴奋，嚷道，“他先是救了您，现在又救了我们大家，我真想谢谢他！”
en: “Oh,” cried Herbert, his countenance full of animation, “how I should like to thank him, he who saved you first, and who has now saved us!”

zh: “当然，孩子，”潘克洛夫说，“我和大伙儿都想谢谢他。我不是个好奇的人，可是，要是能和这个陌生人见上一面，就算挖掉我一只眼睛我也愿意！我觉得，他一定长得帅极了，个子高高的，身体很壮实，留着好看的胡子，色彩光泽的头发，还有，他一定坐在云彩上，手里拿着一个大球！”
en: “Of course, my boy,” replied Pencroft, “so would I and all of us.I am not inquisitive, but I would give one of my eyes to see this individual face to face!It seems to me that he must be handsome, tall, strong, with a splendid beard, radiant hair, and that he must be seated on clouds, a great ball in his hands!”

zh: “好了，潘克洛夫，”史佩莱说，“你描述的是造物主的形象吧。”
en: “But, Pencroft,” answered Spilett, “you are describing a picture of the Creator.”

zh: “或许吧，史佩莱先生，”水手回答，“可他在我想象中就是这幅模样！”
en: “Possibly, Mr. Spilett,” replied the sailor, “but that is how I imagine him!”

zh: “你呢，艾尔顿？”工程师问。
en: “And you, Ayrton?” asked the engineer.

zh: “哈丁队长，”艾尔顿回答，“在这个问题上，我没有更好的意见。不管你做什么，都肯定是最好不过的。要是想要我加入你们一块儿寻找的话，我随时乐意跟随。”
en: “Captain Harding,” replied Ayrton, “I can give you no better advice in this matter.Whatever you do will be best; when you wish me to join you in your researches, I am ready to follow you.

zh: “谢谢你，艾尔顿，”赛勒斯·哈丁说，“可是，我想从你那听到一个更为直接的回答。你是我们的伙伴；为了我们，你已经冒过好几次生命危险了。因此，我们做任何一个重要的决定时，都应该听一听每个人——自然也包括你——的意见。所以，说说吧。”
en: “I thank you, Ayrton,” answered Cyrus Harding, “but I should like a more direct answer to the question I put to you.You are our companion; you have already endangered your life several times for us, and you, as well as the rest, ought to be consulted in the matter of any important decision. Speak, therefore.”

zh: “哈丁队长，”艾尔顿说，“我认为我们应该竭尽所能，找到这位陌生的恩人。也许他一个人孤零零的。也许他在受苦。也许他需要开启一种新的生活。我，就像你所说的，也应该还他一份人情。是他——只能是他——到达抱岛去过，在那里发现了你们知道的苦命人，然后想法子让你们知道那儿有一个不幸的人等着拯救。因此，多亏了他，我才重新变回了一个人。是的，我永远也不会忘记他！”
en: “Captain Harding,” replied Ayrton, “I think that we ought to do everything to discover this unknown benefactor.Perhaps he is alone.Perhaps he is suffering.Perhaps he has a life to be renewed.I, too, as you said, have a debt of gratitude to pay him.It was he, it could be only he who must have come to Tabor Island, who found there the wretch you knew, and who made known to you that there was an unfortunate man there to be saved.Therefore it is, thanks to him, that I have become a man again.No, I will never forget him!”

zh: “那么，就这么决定了，”赛勒斯·哈丁说，“我们会尽快开始寻找，不放过岛上的任何一个角落。就连岛上最隐秘的地方，我们也要去搜一搜，希望这位陌生的朋友知道我们的目的后，能原谅我们！”
en: “That is settled, then,” said Cyrus Harding.“We will begin our researches as soon as possible.We will not leave a corner of the island unexplored.We will search into its most secret recesses, and will hope that our unknown friend will pardon us in consideration of our intentions!”

zh: 几天以来，移民们都在积极地忙着翻晒干草和收获。在实行他们的计划——探索荒岛上的未知领域——之前，他们希望把所有能做的工作都做完。而且，现在，从达抱岛上带回来的各种蔬菜也到了该收获的时候。移民们把所有东西都储藏了起来，幸亏花岗石宫足够大，简直可以把岛上的所有财富存放在里面。他们把收获下来的东西整整齐齐地存放在那儿，可以相信，地方很安全，坏人和野兽都发现不了。
en: For several days the colonists were actively employed in haymaking and the harvest.Before putting their project of exploring the yet unknown parts of the island into execution, they wished to get all possible work finished.It was also the time for collecting the various vegetables from the Tabor Island plants.All was stowed away, and happily there was no want of room in Granite House, in which they might have housed all the treasures of the island.The products of the colony were there, methodically arranged, and in a safe place, as may be believed, sheltered as much from animals as from man.

zh: 有厚实的花岗石壁作保护，完全不必担心受潮。移民们用鹤嘴锄和火药把上甬道的许多天然石洞扩大了，花岗石宫因此成了一个大仓库，里面存着所有的粮食、武器、工具和闲置的器皿——总之，移民队的所有储备都在里面了。
en: There was no fear of damp in the middle of that thick mass of granite.Many natural excavations situated in the upper passage were enlarged either by pick-axe or mine, and Granite House thus became a general warehouse, containing all the provisions, arms, tools, and spare utensils—in a word, all the stores of the colony.

zh: 从双桅船上得来的大炮都是上好的军械，在潘克洛夫的请求下，移民们用索具和辘轳把它们吊进了花岗石宫，还在窗户间开了炮眼，很快，就可以在花岗石壁上看见亮光光的炮口了。在这个高度上，他们可以俯瞰整个联合湾。这儿就好比一个小直布罗陀，任何在小岛抛锚的船只都不可避免地暴露在这个空中炮台的射程以内。
en: As to the guns obtained from the brig, they were pretty pieces of ordnance, which, at Pencroft’s entreaty, were hoisted by means of tackle and pulleys, right up into Granite House; embrasures were made between the windows, and the shining muzzles of the guns could soon be seen through the granite cliff.From this height they commanded all Union Bay.It was like a little Gibraltar, and any vessel anchored off the islet would inevitably be exposed to the fire of this aerial battery.

zh: “队长，”潘克洛夫一天说，这一天是11月8号，“既然我们的防御工事已经做好了，不如试试大炮的射程呀。”
