en: “Captain,” said Pencroft one day, it was the 8th of November, “now that our fortifications are finished, it would be a good thing if we tried the range of our guns.”

zh: “你觉得有用吗？”工程师问。
en: “Do you think that is useful?” asked the engineer.

zh: “不但有用，而且有必要！不然，怎么会知道提供给我们的那些超级棒的炮弹能打多远？”
en: “It is more than useful, it is necessary!Without that how are we to know to what distance we can send one of those pretty shot with which we are provided?”

zh: “试试吧，潘克洛夫，”工程师说，“不过，我想，试的时候，我们应该留着普通火药，用火棉代替，反正那东西我们有的是。”
en: “Try them, Pencroft,” replied the engineer.“However, I think that in making the experiment, we ought to employ, not the ordinary powder, the supply of which, I think, should remain untouched, but the pyroxyle which will never fail us.”

zh: “这些大炮受得了火棉的爆炸吗？”通讯记者问，他和潘克洛夫一样，迫切地想要试验一下花岗石宫的大炮。
en: “Can the cannon support the shock of the pyroxyle?” asked the reporter, who was not less anxious than Pencroft to try the artillery of Granite House.

zh: “我相信可以。不过，”工程师又说，“我们还是要小心点。”和工程师想的一样，这些大炮全都制作精良，都是用锻钢造的一种后膛炮，因此应该能装大量的火药，射程也应该很远。其实，考虑到实际效果，炮弹的射程应该尽可能的延长，而只有以极快的初速度打出炮弹时，才可能获得这种力量。
en: “I believe so.However,” added the engineer, “we will be prudent.”The engineer was right in thinking that the guns were of excellent make.Made of forged steel, and breech-loaders, they ought consequently to be able to bear a considerable charge, and also have an enormous range.In fact, as regards practical effect, the transit described by the ball ought to be as extended as possible, and this tension could only be obtained under the condition that the projectile should be impelled with a very great initial velocity.

zh: “初速度跟使用的火药量是成正比的，”哈丁对同伴们说，“在制造这些大炮的时候，是否使用了抵抗系数最高的金属材料关乎着一切，而钢铁毫无疑问就是所有金属中抵抗系数最高的。因此，我有理由相信，我们的大炮能安全地经受住爆炸气体的膨胀，从而给出精彩的实验结果。”
en: “Now,” said Harding to his companions, “the initial velocity is in proportion to the quantity of powder used.In the fabrication of these pieces, everything depends on employing a metal with the highest possible power of resistance, and steel is incontestably that metal of all others which resists the best.I have, therefore, reason to believe that our guns will bear without risk the expansion of the pyroxyle gas, and will give excellent results.”

zh: “等我们试过以后，就可以更确定了！”潘克洛夫说。
en: “We shall be a great deal more certain of that when we have tried them!” answered Pencroft.

zh: 四门大炮都保存得很好，这个自不必说。自打从水里捞出来后，水手就一直非常细心地看管它们。他给大炮擦拭，上油，磨光，清洗零件，在上面不知花了多长时间！现在这些大炮闪亮如新，就像美利坚海军保卫舰上的一样。
en: It is unnecessary to say that the four cannons were in perfect order.Since they had been taken from the water, the sailor had bestowed great care upon them.How many hours he had spent, in rubbing, greasing, and polishing them, and in cleaning the mechanism!And now the pieces were as brilliant as if they had been on board a frigate of the United States Navy.

zh: 于是，在这一天，移民队的全体成员，贾普和托普也包括在内，共同见证了四门大炮相继被试验。他们用火棉代替普通火药，考虑到火棉的爆炸威力——前面交代过——是普通火药的四倍，他们把炮弹做成了圆锥筒形。
en: On this day, therefore, in presence of all the members of the colony, including Master Jup and Top, the four cannon were successively tried.They were charged with pyroxyle, taking into consideration its explosive power, which, as has been said, is four times that of ordinary powder: the projectile to be fired was cylindroconic.

zh: 潘克洛夫站在那里，拿着火绳的末端，随时准备发射。
en: Pencroft, holding the end of the quick-match, stood ready to fire.

zh: 哈丁一声令下，他开炮了。炮弹飞过小岛，落到了大海里，没法精确计算出距离。
en: At Harding’s signal, he fired.The shot, passing over the islet, fell into the sea at a distance which could not be calculated with exactitude.

zh: 第二门大炮瞄准了遗物角尽头的岩石，炮弹打在了离花岗石宫将近有三英里的一块尖尖的石头上，打得碎片乱飞。这一炮是赫伯特瞄准并发射的，他很是为自己的第一炮感到自豪。潘克洛夫比他还自豪呢！这一炮打得这么漂亮，这份荣耀可是属于他亲爱的赫伯特啊。
en: The second gun was pointed at the rocks at the end of Flotsam Point, and the shot striking a sharp rock nearly three miles from Granite House, made it fly into splinters.It was Herbert who had pointed this gun and fired it, and very proud he was of his first shot.Pencroft only was prouder than he!Such a shot, the honor of which belonged to his dear boy.

zh: 第三炮把目标定在联合湾北边的沙丘，炮弹打在四英里以外的沙石上，然后又弹了起来，落在大海里，溅起一片水花。
en: The third shot, aimed this time at the downs forming the upper side of Union Bay, struck the sand at a distance of four miles, then having ricocheted: was lost in the sea in a cloud of spray.

zh: 打第四炮时，赛勒斯·哈丁想要试一下最多能射多远，就稍微多装了一点炮弹。因为怕爆炸，所有人都退到了一边，用一根长绳拉着点火。
en: For the fourth piece Cyrus Harding slightly increased the charge, so as to try its extreme range.Then, all standing aside for fear of its bursting, the match was lighted by means of a long cord.

zh: 接着听到了一声震耳欲聋的爆炸声，不过，大炮完好无损。移民们冲到窗户边，看见炮弹擦过离花岗石宫几乎有五英里的颚骨角的岩石，消失在鲨鱼湾里了。
en: A tremendous report was heard, but the piece had held good, and the colonists rushing to the windows, saw the shot graze the rocks of Mandible Cape, nearly five miles from Granite House, and disappear in Shark Gulf.

zh: “太棒了，队长，”潘克洛夫欢呼道，声音大得简直可以跟爆炸声相媲美，“你觉得我们的炮台怎么样？太平洋上的海盗还胆敢出现在花岗石宫前面！现在，没有我们的允许，谁都不能在那儿登陆！”
en: “Well, captain,” exclaimed Pencroft, whose cheers might have rivaled the reports themselves, “what do you say of our battery?All the pirates in the Pacific have only to present themselves before Granite House!Not one can land there now without our permission!”

zh: “相信我，潘克洛夫，”工程师说，“这样的实验还是不做的好。”
en: “Believe me, Pencroft,” replied the engineer, “it would be better not to have to make the experiment.”

zh: “为什么，”水手说，“那应该怎么对付现在在岛上游荡的那六个坏蛋？难道就由着他们糟蹋我们的森林、田地和农场？这些海盗就是十足的美洲豹，我认为我们应该毫不犹豫地用大炮对付他们！你觉得呢，艾尔顿？”潘克洛夫转向他的同伴，说道。
en: “Well,” said the sailor, “what ought to be done with regard to those six villains who are roaming about the island?Are we to leave them to overrun our forests, our fields, our plantations?These pirates are regular jaguars, and it seems to me we ought not to hesitate to treat them as such!What do you think, Ayrton?” added Pencroft, turning to his companion.

zh: 艾尔顿起先犹豫了一下，没有回答，赛勒斯·哈丁对潘克洛夫不假思索地提出这么一个问题感到非常抱歉。不过让他非常感动的是，艾尔顿最后谦卑地回答道：
en: Ayrton hesitated at first to reply, and Cyrus Harding regretted that Pencroft had so thoughtlessly put this question.And he was much moved when Ayrton replied in a humble tone,—

zh: “我以前也是只美洲豹，潘克洛夫先生。我没权利发言。”
en: “I have been one of those jaguars, Mr. Pencroft. I have no right to speak.”

zh: 然后他慢慢地走开了。
en: And with a slow step he walked away.

zh: 潘克洛夫恍然大悟。
en: Pencroft understood.

zh: “我真是个畜生！”他叫起来，“可怜的艾尔顿！他在这儿，和我们一样有发言权！”
en: “What a brute I am!” he exclaimed.“Poor Ayrton! He has as much right to speak here as any one!”

zh: “没错，”吉迪恩·史佩莱说，“但他愈是沉默，我们愈发尊重他，我们应该尊重他追忆伤心往事的感受。”
en: “Yes,” said Gideon Spilett, “but his reserve does him honor, and it is right to respect the feeling which he has about his sad past.”

zh: “当然，史佩莱先生，”水手回答，“你不必担心，我以后不会这样做了。我宁肯咬断自己的舌头，也不想带给艾尔顿一丁点伤害！可是话说回来。在我看来，这些流氓不配我们可怜，应该尽早把他们从岛上清除掉。”
en: “Certainly, Mr. Spilett,” answered the sailor, “and there is no fear of my doing so again.I would rather bite my tongue off than cause Ayrton any pain!But to return to the question.It seems to me that these ruffians have no right to any pity, and that we ought to rid the island of them as soon as possible.”

zh: “这是你的主意，潘克洛夫？”工程师问。
en: “Is that your opinion, Pencroft?” asked the engineer.

zh: “我就是这么想的。”
en: “Quite my opinion.”

zh: “在他们对我们再采取什么不利的行动之前，你就想毫不留情地去搜捕他们吗？”
en: “And before hunting them mercilessly, you would not wait until they had committed some fresh act of hostility against us?”

zh: “难道他们做的还不够？”潘克洛夫发问，他不明白哈丁的这些顾虑。
en: “Isn’t what they have done already enough?” asked Pencroft, who did not understand these scruples.

zh: “他们或许会转变性情！”哈丁说，“忏悔也说不定呀。”
en: “They may adopt other sentiments!” said Harding, “and perhaps repent.”

zh: “他们能忏悔！”水手叫道，耸了耸肩。
en: “They repent!” exclaimed the sailor, shrugging his shoulders.

zh: “潘克洛夫，想想艾尔顿吧！”赫伯特拉住水手的手说，“他不是改邪归正了嘛！”
en: “Pencroft, think of Ayrton!” said Herbert, taking the sailor’s hand.“He became an honest man again!”

zh: 潘克洛夫一一望了望自己的同伴。他从没想到，自己的提议会遭到反对。这帮混蛋是跟鲍勃·哈维的帮凶一块儿上岸的，那些人可是杀害“飞快号”全体船员的凶手啊，和他们和平共处，性情耿直的潘克洛夫可接受不了，在他看来，这群人就好比洪水猛兽，必须毫不迟疑毫不留情地把他们消灭掉。
en: Pencroft looked at his companions one after the other.He had never thought of his proposal being met with any objection.His rough nature could not allow that they ought to come to terms with the rascals who had landed on the island with Bob Harvey’s accomplices, the murderers of the crew of the “Speedy,” and he looked upon them as wild beasts which ought to be destroyed without delay and without remorse.

zh: “算了！”他说，“谁都跟我作对！你们竟然对那帮混蛋发起善心来了！好吧，但愿我们以后不要后悔！”
en: “Come!” said be.“Everybody is against me!You wish to be generous to those villains!Very well; I hope we mayn’t repent it!”

zh: “如果我们一直小心防卫，”赫伯特说，“会有什么危险呢？”
en: “What danger shall we run,” said Herbert, “if we take care to be always on our guard?”

zh: “嗯。”通讯记者说，他还没说过自己的看法，“他们有六个人，而且都装备精良。如果他们各自潜伏在一个角落，朝我们每人放一枪，就会立马成为小岛的主人！”
en: “Hum!” observed the reporter, who had not given any decided opinion.“They are six and well armed.If they each lay hid in a corner, and each fired at one of us, they would soon be masters of the colony!”

zh: “那为什么他们没这么做呢？”赫伯特问，“显然是因为他们没兴趣这么做。况且，我们也是六个人。”
en: “Why have they not done so?” said Herbert.“No doubt because it was not their interest to do it.Besides, we are six also.”

zh: “好吧，好吧！”潘克洛夫说，什么也说服不了他，“我们就让这些好人做他们想做的事吧，不必再为他们操心了！”
en: “Well, well!” replied Pencroft, whom no reasoning could have convinced.“Let us leave these good people to do what they like, and don’t think anything more about them!”

zh: “好了，潘克洛夫，”纳布说，“不要把自己装成那么坏的一个人！假使那些不幸的人中的一个现在就在你的面前，完全在你的大炮的射程以内，你也不会开炮的。”
en: “Come, Pencroft,” said Neb, “don’t make yourself out so bad as all that!Suppose one of these unfortunate men were here before you, within good range of your guns, you would not fire.”

zh: “我会像打一条疯狗一样，一炮把他打死，纳布。”潘克洛夫冷冷地说。
en: “I would fire on him as I would on a mad dog, Neb,” replied Pencroft coldly.

zh: “潘克洛夫，”工程师说，“你一直都很听从我的意见，那在这个问题上，你能听我的话吗？”
en: “Pencroft,” said the engineer, “you have always shown much deference to my advice; will you, in this matter, yield to me?”

zh: “我可以照您的意思去做，哈丁队长。”水手嘴里这样回答着，心里并不服气。
en: “I will do as you please, Captain Harding,” answered the sailor, who was not at all convinced.

zh: “很好，我们再等等，除非他们先攻击我们，否则我们决不攻击他们。”
en: “Very well, wait, and we will not attack them unless we are attacked first.”

zh: 于是，虽然潘克洛夫认为这样做没什么好处，大伙儿对海盗的态度最终还是达成了一致。他们不会主动进攻，而是要采取防守的做法。毕竟，荒岛面积很大，还很肥沃。如果这些坏人的心底还存有一丝丝良知的话，他们或许还有改邪归正的希望。他们不想在这种环境里开始新生吗？不管怎么样，就是单纯出于人道主义，也应该等一等。移民们不会再像以前一样，来去无所顾忌了。以前，他们只需提防凶猛的野兽，可是现在，六个或许再恶劣不过的罪犯正游荡在他们的岛上。这自然是个严肃的问题，而且，如果移民们的胆子小一点，这就等于失去了安全的保障！不管怎样！眼下，移民们有理由反对潘克洛夫的意见。可是将来他们会是对的吗？这一点还需拭目以待。
en: Thus their behavior towards the pirates was agreed upon, although Pencroft augured nothing good from it.They were not to attack them, but were to be on their guard.After all, the island was large and fertile.If any sentiment of honesty yet remained in the bottom of their hearts, these wretches might perhaps be reclaimed.Was it not their interest in the situation in which they found themselves to begin a new life?At any rate, for humanity’s sake alone, it would be right to wait.The colonists would no longer as before, be able to go and come without fear.Hitherto they had only wild beasts to guard against, and now six convicts of the worst description, perhaps, were roaming over their island.It was serious, certainly, and to less brave men, it would have been security lost!No matter!At present, the colonists had reason on their side against Pencroft.Would they be right in the future?That remained to be seen.

zh: 第六章
en: Chapter 6

zh: 不过，移民们眼下的头等大事，就是照先前决定的那样，对全岛做一次探险。这样做主要有两个目的：其一，寻找那个神秘的陌生人，因为现在大家都确信他就在岛上；其二，了解一下海盗们的情况，看看他们藏在哪里，过着怎样的日子，还有，这帮家伙有什么值得害怕的地方。赛勒斯·哈丁希望能立即出发；可是因为这次探险可能会持续好几天，所以最好还是把各种必需品和工具装在车上，以便安排宿营。一只野驴又伤了腿，暂时不能拉车，还得过几天才能痊愈。于是，出发的日期推迟了一个礼拜，定在11月20号。这个纬度的11月相当于北半球的五月，因此，正是好天气。太阳进入了南回归线，是一年中白昼最长的时候。因此，这个时候对计划的这次探险很有利，即使两个主要的目的实现不了，移民们也会从中获得很多发现，尤其是自然物产方面的发现，因为哈丁提议去探索一下远西的一直延伸到盘蛇半岛尽头的密林。
en: However, the chief business of the colonists was to make that complete exploration of the island which had been decided upon, and which would have two objects: to discover the mysterious being whose existence was now indisputable, and at the same time to find out what had become of the pirates, what retreat they had chosen, what sort of life they were leading, and what was to be feared from them.Cyrus Harding wished to set out without delay; but as the expedition would be of some days duration, it appeared best to load the cart with different materials and tools in order to facilitate the organization of the encampments.One of the onagers, however, having hurt its leg, could not be harnessed at present, and a few days’ rest was necessary.The departure was, therefore, put off for a week, until the 20th of November.The month of November in this latitude corresponds to the month of May in the northern zones.It was, therefore, the fine season.The sun was entering the tropic of Capricorn, and gave the longest days in the year.The time was, therefore, very favorable for the projected expedition, which, if it did not accomplish its principal object, would at any rate be fruitful in discoveries, especially of natural productions, since Harding proposed to explore those dense forests of the Far West, which stretched to the extremity of the Serpentine Peninsula.

zh: 距离出发的日子还有9天，大伙儿都同意利用这段时间，把眺望岗上的工作做完。
en: During the nine days which preceded their departure, it was agreed that the work on Prospect Heights should be finished off.

zh: 而且，艾尔顿也需要回畜栏去照料一下饲养的牲畜。大伙儿决定让他在那儿呆两天，等把马厩的饲料准备充足后，再回花岗石宫。
en: Moreover, it was necessary for Ayrton to return to the corral, where the domesticated animals required his care.It was decided that he should spend two days there, and return to Granite House after having liberally supplied the stables.

zh: 艾尔顿出发前，哈丁考虑到岛上没有以前安全了，问他是否想再找一个人和他一块儿去。艾尔顿说不需要，因为他一个人能应付得了那里的活儿，况且，他什么危险也不怕。要是畜栏或周边发生什么事情，他会立即给花岗石宫发电报，提醒移民们。
en: As he was about to start, Harding asked him if he would not like one of them to accompany him, observing that the island was less safe than formerly.Ayrton replied that this was unnecessary, as he was enough for the work, and that besides he apprehended no danger.If anything occurred at the corral, or in the neighborhood, he could instantly warn the colonists by sending a telegram to Granite House.

zh: 9号清晨，艾尔通驾着一只野驴，拉着马车，天一亮就动身了。过了两个钟头，他打电报回来说畜栏里平安无事。
en: Ayrton departed at dawn on the 9th, taking the cart drawn by one onager, and two hours after, the electric wire announced that he had found all in order at the corral.

zh: 在这两天中，哈丁忙着实行一个计划，好让花岗石宫免于受到任何突然袭击。格兰特湖南端原有的出口早已被堵上了，被长出的草木盖住了一部分，现在必须把它全部挡起来。这个再容易不过了，因为只要让湖水涨上两三英尺，就可以把出口完全淹没。现在，为了抬升水位，他们只得在湖的两个缺口处各建一个水坝，因为湖水就是通过这两个缺口流入甘油河与瀑布河的。
en: During these two days Harding busied himself in executing a project which would completely guard Granite House against any surprise.It was necessary to completely conceal the opening of the old outlet, which was already walled up and partly hidden under grass and plants, at the southern angle of Lake Grant.Nothing was easier, since if the level of the lake was raised two or three feet, the opening would be quite beneath it.Now, to raise this level they had only to establish a dam at the two openings made by the lake, and by which were fed Creek Glycerine and Falls River.

zh: 两个水坝宽不过八英尺，高不过三英尺，移民们干劲十足，很快就用结实的石块垒起来了。
en: The colonists worked with a will, and the two dams which besides did not exceed eight feet in width by three in height, were rapidly erected by means of well-cemented blocks of stone.

zh: 水坝造好后，外人绝对猜不到湖的下面还藏着一个地下通道，湖水以前就是从那儿流出去的。
en: This work finished, it would have been impossible to guess that at that part of the lake, there existed a subterranean passage through which the overflow of the lake formerly escaped.

zh: 当然，供应花岗石宫蓄水池用水以及为升降梯提供能量的小溪还小心地保留着，保证不断水。只要把升降梯升上去，这个安全又舒适的藏身所就能免遭任何突袭了。
en: Of course the little stream which fed the reservoir of Granite House and worked the lift, had been carefully preserved, and the water could not fail.The lift once raised, this sure and comfortable retreat would be safe from any surprise.

zh: 这项工作这么快就做完了，还剩点时间，潘克洛夫、吉迪恩·史佩莱和赫伯特想要去一次气球港。水手急着看一下，罪犯们是不是已经到过“乘风破浪号”停泊的小海湾了。
en: This work had been so quickly done, that Pencroft, Gideon Spilett, and Herbert found time to make an expedition to Port Balloon, The sailor was very anxious to know if the little creek in which the “Bonadventure” was moored, had been visited by the convicts.

zh: “这些先生是在南岸登陆的，”他说，“如果他们沿着海滨走，有可能会发现小海湾，那样的话，我们的‘乘风破浪号’就惨了。”
en: “These gentlemen,” he observed, “landed on the south coast, and if they followed the shore, it is to be feared that they may have discovered the little harbor, and in that case, I wouldn’t give half-a-dollar for our ‘Bonadventure.’”

zh: 潘克洛夫的担忧并非毫无根据，看起来，大伙儿都特别想去一趟气球港。11月10号，吃过晚饭，水手和同伴们要动身了，每个人都装备得很完善。潘克洛夫大摇大摆地把两颗子弹分别装进他的步枪的两个枪管里，还摇晃着头，好像是在说，无论谁——管他是人还是猛兽——要是离他太近，不会有任何好处的。吉迪恩·史佩莱和赫伯特也带上枪，大概三点的时候，三个人离开了花岗石宫。
en: Pencroft’s apprehensions were not without foundation, and a visit to Port Balloon appeared to be very desirable.The sailor and his companions set off on the 10th of November, after dinner, well armed.Pencroft, ostentatiously slipping two bullets into each barrel of his rifle, shook his head in a way which betokened nothing good to any one who approached too near him, whether “man or beast,” as he said.Gideon Spilett and Herbert also took their guns, and about three o’clock all three left Granite House.

zh: 纳布跟着他们走到慈悲河拐弯的地方，等到他们过了河，就把桥扯了起来。大伙儿商量好，回来的时候，就放一声枪，一听到这个信号，纳布就会过来，把连接河两岸的桥放下。
en: Neb accompanied them to the turn of the Mercy, and after they had crossed, he raised the bridge.It was agreed that a gunshot should announce the colonists’ return, and that at the signal Neb should return and reestablish the communication between the two banks of the river.

zh: 这一小队直接沿着通往小岛南岸的小路前进。虽然不过是三英里半的路程，吉迪恩·史佩莱和同伴们却走了俩小时。他们沿途细细地查看了小路附近、密林以及达抱沼地。可是，连逃犯的影子也没看到，显然，这帮家伙并没有发现移民的人数和移民们掌握的防御措施，因此现在藏在岛上一些不容易被发现的地方。
en: The little band advanced directly along the road which led to the southern coast of the island.This was only a distance of three miles and a half, but Gideon Spilett and his companions took two hours to traverse it.They examined all the border of the road, the thick forest, as well as Tabor Marsh.They found no trace of the fugitives who, no doubt, not having yet discovered the number of the colonists, or the means of defense which they had at their disposal, had gained the less accessible parts of the island.

zh: 到了气球港，看见“乘风破浪号”安然无事地浮在狭窄的海湾上，潘克洛夫非常满意。气球港周围有高高的岩石作掩护，隐蔽得很好，因此，不管是从陆地上，还是大海里，都很难发现它。
en: Arrived at Port Balloon, Pencroft saw with extreme satisfaction that the “Bonadventure” was tranquilly floating in the narrow creek.However, Port Balloon was so well hidden among high rocks, that it could scarcely be discovered either from the land or the sea.

zh: “快过来，”潘克洛夫叫，“那帮混蛋还没来过这儿。俗话说，‘深山有虎豹’，罪犯们一定藏到远西森林里去了。”
en: “Come,” said Pencroft, “the blackguards have not been there yet.Long grass suits reptiles best, and evidently we shall find them in the Far West.”

zh: “这真是万幸啊，不然，要是他们发现了‘乘风破浪号’，一定会乘着它离开，那样我们就再也回不了达抱岛了。”赫伯特说道。
en: “And it’s very lucky, for if they had found the ‘Bonadventure’,” added Herbert, “they would have gone off in her, and we should have been prevented from returning to Tabor Island.”

zh: “确实是这样，”通讯记者说，“我们应该在那座岛上留一张纸条，上面写上林肯岛的位置以及艾尔顿现在的住址，以防那艘苏格兰游船回来接他。”
en: “Indeed,” remarked the reporter, “it will be important to take a document there which will make known the situation of Lincoln Island, and Ayrton’s new residence, in case the Scotch yacht returns to fetch him.”

zh: “好了，‘乘风破浪号’随时在这儿待命，史佩莱先生。”水手说，“它和它的船员一接到通知立马就能出发！”
en: “Well, the ‘Bonadventure’ is always there, Mr. Spilett,” answered the sailor.“She and her crew are ready to start at a moment’s notice!”

zh: “潘克洛夫，我觉得等我们的全岛探险结束以后，再去干这件事情吧。如果我们找到了那个陌生人，不管是林肯岛，还是达抱岛，他很有可能都了如指掌。不要忘记肯定是他写了那张纸条，或许他还知道游船什么时候回来！”
en: “I think, Pencroft, that that is a thing to be done after our exploration of the island is finished.It is possible after all that the stranger, if we manage to find him, may know as much about Tabor Island as about Lincoln Island.Do not forget that he is certainly the author of the document, and he may, perhaps, know how far we may count on the return of the yacht!”

zh: “可是，”潘克洛夫叫道，“他究竟是谁啊？这个朋友知道我们，我们却对他一无所知！如果他只是个遇难后被抛弃在岛上的人，那他为什么要把自己藏起来呀？我们是老实人，我想，谁都不会讨厌老实人吧。他是不是自愿来到岛上的？要是哪天想离开的话，他就能离开吗？他是不是还在岛上？他还要继续呆下去吗？”
en: “But!” exclaimed Pencroft, “who in the world can he be?The fellow knows us and we know nothing about him!If he is a simple castaway, why should he conceal himself!We are honest men, I suppose, and the society of honest men isn’t unpleasant to any one.Did he come here voluntarily?Can he leave the island if he likes?Is he here still?Will he remain any longer?”

zh: 潘克洛夫、吉迪恩·史佩莱和赫伯特一面交谈着，一面走上“乘风破浪号”,检查一下船的甲板。水手仔细看了一下系锚缆的系缆桩——
en: Chatting thus, Pencroft, Gideon Spilett, and Herbert got on board and looked about the deck of the “Bonadventure.”All at once, the sailor having examined the bitts to which the cable of the anchor was secured,—

zh: 他突然喊起来：“啊呀，太奇怪了！”
en: “Hallo,” he cried, “this is queer!”

zh: “怎么了，潘克洛夫？”通讯记者问。
en: “What is the matter, Pencroft?” asked the reporter.

zh: “你看，这个结不是我打的！”
en: “The matter is, that it was not I who made this knot!”

zh: 潘克洛夫指着一根把缆绳系在系缆桩上的绳子。
en: And Pencroft showed a rope which fastened the cable to the bitt itself.

zh: “什么，结不是你打的？”吉迪恩·史佩莱问道。
en: “What, it was not you?” asked Gideon Spilett.

zh: “不是！我可以发誓。这是一个平结，我打的可都是活扣。”
en: “No!I can swear to it.This is a reef knot, and I always make a running bowline.”

zh: “你肯定记错了，潘克洛夫。”
en: “You must be mistaken, Pencroft.”

zh: “我没有记错！”水手说，“我的手不自觉地就系成活扣，一个人的手是不会出错的！”
en: “I am not mistaken!” declared the sailor.“My hand does it so naturally, and one’s hand is never mistaken!”

zh: “那么，难道罪犯们上过船？”赫伯特问。
en: “Then can the convicts have been on board?” asked Herbert.

zh: “那我不清楚，”潘克洛夫回答，“可是有一点很确定，就是有人拔过锚，又把它抛了下去！看看这儿，这儿还有一个证据！锚缆被抽了出来，卷索不在锚链孔里了。我再说一遍，有人用过我们的船了！”
en: “I know nothing about that,” answered Pencroft, “but what is certain, is that some one has weighed the ‘Bonadventure’s’ anchor and dropped it again!And look here, here is another proof!The cable of the anchor has been run out, and its service is no longer at the hawse-hole.I repeat that some one has been using our vessel!”

zh: “可是，要是那些罪犯用过，他们会把船抢走，或者干脆乘着船逃跑。”
en: “But if the convicts had used her, they would have pillaged her, or rather gone off with her.”

zh: “逃跑！逃到哪儿——逃到达抱岛？”潘克洛夫回答道，“你觉得，他们会坐着这么小吨位的船去冒险？”
en: “Gone off! where to—to Tabor Island?” replied Pencroft.“Do you think, they would risk themselves in a boat of such small tonnage?”

zh: “另外，他们还不一定知道有那个小岛呢。”通讯记者附和道。
en: “We must, besides, be sure that they know of the islet,” rejoined the reporter.

zh: “不管他们知道还是不知道，”水手说，“就像我生在葡萄园，名字叫潘克洛夫一样没错，我们的‘乘风破浪号’已经在我们不在的情况下，被别人航行过了！”
en: “However that may be,” said the sailor, “as sure as my name is Bonadventure Pencroft, of the Vineyard, our ‘Bonadventure’ has sailed without us!”

zh: 水手很确定，吉迪恩·史佩莱和赫伯特都提不出质疑。很明显，自从潘克洛夫把特船带到气球港后，船多多少少被人移动过。至于说水手，他有百分之百的把握，有人拔过锚，然后又把锚抛了下去。那么，要不是乘船航行，做这两道工序还有什么目的？
en: The sailor was positive that neither Gideon Spilett nor Herbert could dispute his statement.It was evident that the vessel had been moved, more or less, since Pencroft had brought her to Port Balloon.As to the sailor, he had not the slightest doubt that the anchor had been raised and then dropped again.Now, what was the use of these two maneuvers, unless the vessel had been employed in some expedition?

zh: “可是，我们在岛上怎么没看见‘乘风破浪号’经过呢？”通讯记者说，他急切地想把每一个可能驳斥上面的观点的事实说出来。
en: “But how was it we did not see the ‘Bonadventure’ pass in the sight of the island?” observed the reporter, who was anxious to bring forward every possible objection.

zh: “怎么，史佩莱先生，”水手回答，“他们只需要在夜里顺风顺水的时候动身，用不了两个钟头，就开出海岛的视线喽。”
en: “Why, Mr. Spilett,” replied the sailor, “they would only have to start in the night with a good breeze, and they would be out of sight of the island in two hours.”

zh: “好吧，”吉迪恩·史佩莱又说，“我还有问题：那些罪犯们使用‘乘风破浪号’有什么目的，还有，用完以后，他们为什么又把船开回港口？”
en: “Well,” resumed Gideon Spilett, “I ask again, what object could the convicts have had in using the ‘Bonadventure,’ and why, after they had made use of her, should they have brought her back to port?”

zh: “好了，史佩莱先生，”水手回答，“我们得把这些问题归于无法解释的那一类，就不要再费脑筋了。最主要的是‘乘风破浪号’在这儿，它现在还在这儿。一旦罪犯们第二次把它劫走——那太倒霉了——我们就别指望在这儿再找到它！”
en: “Why, Mr. Spilett,” replied the sailor, “we must put that among the unaccountable things, and not think anything more about it.The chief thing is that the ‘Bonadventure’ was there, and she is there now.Only, unfortunately, if the convicts take her a second time, we shall very likely not find her again in her place!”

zh: “潘克洛夫，这样的话，”赫伯特说，“把船带到‘花岗石宫’去，岂不最好？”
en: “Then, Pencroft,” said Herbert, “would it not be wisest to bring the ‘Bonadventure’ off to Granite House?”

zh: “也好也不好，”潘克洛夫回答，“或者干脆就不行。慈悲河河口不适合船只停泊，那里的潮水太猛。”
en: “Yes and no,” answered Pencroft, “or rather no.The mouth of the Mercy is a bad place for a vessel, and the sea is heavy there.”

zh: “那把船停在“石窟”脚下的沙滩上如何？”
en: “But by hauling her up on the sand, to the foot of the Chimneys?”

zh: “那样也许倒不错，”潘克洛夫回答，“不管怎么样，既然我们得离开‘花岗石宫’做一次远途探险，我觉得‘乘风破浪号’在我们不在的时候留在这儿会更安全一点儿，在清除岛上的那些混蛋以前，我们最好还是把船放在这里。”“我正是这么想的，”通讯记者说，“无论如何，天气恶劣的时侯，藏在这儿总比暴露在慈悲河河口好。”
en: “Perhaps yes,” replied Pencroft.“At any rate, since we must leave Granite House for a long expedition, I think the ‘Bonadventure’ will be safer here during our absence, and we shall do best to leave her here until the island is rid of these blackguards.”“That is exactly my opinion,” said the reporter.“At any rate in the event of bad weather, she will not be exposed here as she would be at the mouth of the Mercy.”

zh: “可是，如果罪犯们再次光顾怎么办？”赫伯特说。
en: “But suppose the convicts pay her another visit,” said Herbert.

zh: “好了，孩子，”潘克洛夫说，“如果他们看到船不在这儿，用不了多久就会在‘花岗石宫’的沙滩上找到它的！况且，我们不在的时候，他们可以毫不费力地把船劫走！所以，我和史佩莱先生的观点一样，就是必须把船留在气球港。不过，要是回来的时候，我们还没把那伙混蛋从岛上清除掉，谨慎起见，我们还是把船带到‘花岗石宫’，直到再也不用担心有什么不速之客的时候再说。”
en: “Well, my boy,” replied Pencroft, “not finding her here, they would not be long in finding her on the sands of Granite House, and, during our absence, nothing could hinder them from seizing her!I agree, therefore, with Mr. Spilett, that she must be left in Port Balloon.But, if on our return we have not rid the island of those rascals, it will be prudent to bring our boat to Granite House, until the time when we need not fear any unpleasant visits.”

zh: “就这么决定了。我们走吧。”通讯记者说。
en: “That’s settled.Let us be off,” said the reporter.

zh: 潘克洛夫、赫伯特和吉迪恩·史佩莱回到花岗石宫以后，把全部经过都告诉了工程师，工程师对他们对目前以及将来的安排都表示赞同。他还对水手许诺，要研究一下小岛和海岸之间的海峡，看看能不能利用水坝在那里建一个人工港。这样的话，“乘风破浪号”就等于放在移民们的眼皮子底下了，随时可以照管它，必要的时候，甚至可以把它锁起来。
en: Pencroft, Herbert, and Gideon Spilett, on their return to Granite House, told the engineer all that had passed, and the latter approved of their arrangements both for the present and the future.He also promised the sailor that he would study that part of the channel situated between the islet and the coast, so as to ascertain if it would not be possible to make an artificial harbor there by means of dams.In this way, the “Bonadventure” would be always within reach, under the eyes of the colonists, and if necessary, under lock and key.

zh: 当天晚上，他们给艾尔顿打了一个电报，让他从畜栏带两只山羊回来，纳布想使它们适应高地的水土。非常奇怪的是，这次电报发出后，艾尔顿没有像往常一样，回复收到电报。这不免令工程师觉得诧异。不过，也许艾尔顿那时正好不在畜栏，甚至他已经在回花岗石宫的路上了。事实上，艾尔顿已经在畜栏呆了两天，大家原先决定，他应该在10号晚上或者最晚11号早晨回来。于是，移民们在眺望岗上等待着艾尔顿。纳布和赫伯特甚至在桥边守望着，打算等他们的同伴一出现，就把吊桥放下。
en: That evening a telegram was sent to Ayrton, requesting him to bring from the corral a couple of goats, which Neb wished to acclimatize to the plateau.Singularly enough, Ayrton did not acknowledge the receipt of the despatch, as he was accustomed to do.This could not but astonish the engineer.But it might be that Ayrton was not at that moment in the corral, or even that he was on his way back to Granite House.In fact, two days had already passed since his departure, and it had been decided that on the evening of the 10th or at the latest the morning of the 11th, he should return.The colonists waited, therefore, for Ayrton to appear on Prospect Heights.Neb and Herbert even watched at the bridge so as to be ready to lower it the moment their companion presented himself.

zh: 然而，一直到晚上十点，艾尔顿还没回来。于是，移民们决定最好再打一个电报，要求对方立即回复。
en: But up to ten in the evening, there were no signs of Ayrton.It was, therefore, judged best to send a fresh despatch, requiring an immediate reply.

zh: 可是，花岗石宫的电报铃却一直没有响。
en: The bell of the telegraph at Granite House remained mute.

zh: 移民们坐立不安起来。出了什么事吗？艾尔顿不在畜栏了吗，还是他仍然在那儿，但是不能自由行动了呢？他们能在这么黑的夜里赶往畜栏吗？
en: The colonists’ uneasiness was great.What had happened?Was Ayrton no longer at the corral, or if he was still there, had he no longer control over his movements?Could they go to the corral in this dark night?

zh: 大伙儿商议了一下。有人想去，有人说再等一等。
en: They consulted.Some wished to go, the others to remain.

zh: “可是，”赫伯特说，“或许电报装置出了什么故障，所以接收不了电报了呢？”
en: “But,” said Herbert, “perhaps some accident has happened to the telegraphic apparatus, so that it works no longer?”

zh: “有可能。”通讯记者说。
en: “That may be,” said the reporter.

zh: “等到明天早上吧。”赛勒斯·哈丁说，“确实有可能艾尔顿没收到我们的电报，或者我们干脆没收到他的。”
en: “Wait till to-morrow,” replied Cyrus Harding.“It is possible, indeed, that Ayrton has not received our despatch, or even that we have not received his.”

zh: 大家等待着，心情自然非常焦急。
en: They waited, of course not without some anxiety.

zh: 第二天，11月11号，天刚亮，哈丁又打了一个电报，还是没有回答。
en: At dawn of day, the 11th of November, Harding again sent the electric current along the wire and received no reply.

zh: 他又试了一次，结果还是一样。
en: He tried again: the same result.

zh: “去畜栏！”他说。
en: “Off to the corral,” said he.

zh: “带好武器！”潘克洛夫补充道。
en: “And well armed!” added Pencroft.

zh: 大伙儿马上想到，花岗石宫不能没人，纳布应该留下来。纳布把同伴们送到甘油河畔后，把吊桥扯了起来；然后在一棵树后等待着同伴们或是艾尔顿的归来。
en: It was immediately decided that Granite House should not be left alone and that Neb should remain there.After having accompanied his friends to Creek Glycerine, he raised the bridge; and waiting behind a tree he watched for the return of either his companions or Ayrton.

zh: 如果海盗们露面了，想要强行过河，他会开枪阻止他们，万不得已的时候，他还能逃回花岗石宫，只要把升降梯升起来，他就安全了。
en: In the event of the pirates presenting themselves and attempting to force the passage, he was to endeavor to stop them by firing on them, and as a last resource he was to take refuge in Granite House, where, the lift once raised, he would be in safety.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁、吉迪恩·史佩莱、赫伯特和潘克洛夫赶往畜栏，如果找不到艾尔顿，他们就到附近的森林里去找。
en: Cyrus Harding, Gideon Spilett, Herbert, and Pencroft were to repair to the corral, and if they did not find Ayrton, search the neighboring woods.

zh: 早上六点的时候，工程师和三个同伴过了甘油河，纳布藏在河左岸的一个长满龙血树的小土丘后面。
en: At six o’clock in the morning, the engineer and his three companions had passed Creek Glycerine, and Neb posted himself behind a small mound crowned by several dragon trees, on the left bank of the stream.

zh: 移民们离开眺望岗的高地后，径直踏上了通往畜栏的小路。他们扛着枪，一有哪怕一丁点儿对他们不利的事情，就会随时开枪。两只步枪和两只滑膛枪都装满了弹药。
en: The colonists, after leaving the plateau of Prospect Heights, immediately took the road to the corral.They shouldered their guns, ready to fire on the slightest hostile demonstration.The two rifles and the two guns had been loaded with ball.

zh: 小路两边都是浓密的森林，罪犯们在里面藏身轻而易举，而且他们还有武器，因此确实很难对付。
en: The wood was thick on each side of the road and might easily have concealed the convicts, who owing to their weapons would have been really formidable.

zh: 移民们快步走着，没有人说话。托普在他们前面，时而在路上跑，时而钻进林子里，不过，它一路上都很安静，看起来没有遇到什么奇怪的事情。他们相信这只忠诚的狗绝不会让他们受到惊吓，而是稍稍感觉到危险，就会大叫起来的。
en: The colonists walked rapidly and in silence.Top preceded them, sometimes running on the road, sometimes taking a ramble into the wood, but always quiet and not appearing to fear anything unusual.And they could be sure that the faithful dog would not allow them to be surprised, but would bark at the least appearance of danger.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和同伴们沿着路旁连接畜栏和花岗石宫的电线向前走着。走了差不多两英里，他们还没有发现任何解释疑问的地方。电线杆好好地竖在那儿，电线也照常拉着。然而，这时候工程师发现电线看起来松松的，到了第74号电线杆时，赶在前面的赫伯特突然停住了脚步，喊道：
en: Cyrus Harding and his companions followed beside the road the wire which connected the corral with Granite House.After walking for nearly two miles, they had not as yet discovered any explanation of the difficulty.The posts were in good order, the wire regularly extended.However, at that moment the engineer observed that the wire appeared to be slack, and on arriving at post No.74, Herbert, who was in advance stopped, exclaiming,—

zh: “电线断了！”
en: “The wire is broken!”

zh: 同伴们赶紧上前去，来到孩子站住的地方。电线杆被连根拔起，倒在路上。这个就是解释疑问的意想不到的答案。显然，畜栏没收到花岗石宫发来的电报，同样，花岗石宫也收不到畜栏打出的电报。
en: His companions hurried forward and arrived at the spot where the lad was standing.The post was rooted up and lying across the path.The unexpected explanation of the difficulty was here, and it was evident that the despatches from Granite House had not been received at the corral, nor those from the corral at Granite House.

zh: “不是风刮倒电线杆的。”潘克洛夫观察后说。
en: “It wasn’t the wind that blew down this post,” observed Pencroft.

zh: “不是风，”吉迪恩·史佩莱回答，“根部周围的土都被挖起来了，是有人把电线杆拔了出来。”
en: “No,” replied Gideon Spilett.“The earth has been dug up round its foot, and it has been torn up by the hand of man.”

zh: “而且，电线也断了。”赫伯特指着被掐断的电线补充道。
en: “Besides, the wire is broken,” added Herbert, showing that the wire had been snapped.

zh: “是刚弄断的吗？”哈丁问。
en: “Is the fracture recent?” asked Harding.

zh: “嗯，”赫伯特回答，“肯定是不久之前才弄断的。”
en: “Yes,” answered Herbert, “it has certainly been done quite lately.”

zh: “到畜栏去！赶紧去畜栏！”水手叫。
en: “To the corral! to the corral!” exclaimed the sailor.

zh: 移民们现在才走了花岗石宫和畜栏之间一半的路程，离畜栏还有两英里半。他们奋力向前，速度比原来快了一倍。
en: The colonists were now half way between Granite House and the corral, having still two miles and a half to go.They pressed forward with redoubled speed.

zh: 确实，大伙儿担心畜栏发生了什么严重的意外。毫无疑问，艾尔顿可能打过电报，只是他们没收到，不过，同伴们如此担忧并不是因为这个，而是因为一件更加令人费解的事情，即：艾尔顿答应在昨天晚上回来，结果却没有没有回来。总之，畜栏和花岗石宫的所有通信中断并非无意为之，若不是那些罪犯，谁还能有意破坏他们之间的通讯？
en: Indeed, it was to be feared that some serious accident had occurred in the corral.No doubt, Ayrton might have sent a telegram which had not arrived, but this was not the reason why his companions were so uneasy, for, a more unaccountable circumstance, Ayrton, who had promised to return the evening before, had not reappeared.In short, it was not without a motive that all communication had been stopped between the corral and Granite House, and who but the convicts could have any interest in interrupting this communication?

zh: 移民们急匆匆地赶路，心里充满了忧虑。他们衷心地喜欢这个新来的同伴。他们会不会发现他被以前的党羽亲手杀害了呢？
en: The settlers hastened on, their hearts oppressed with anxiety.They were sincerely attached to their new companion.Were they to find him struck down by the hands of those of whom he was formerly the leader?

zh: 他们很快达到了通向一条小河岸边的道路旁，河水是从红河流出来的，浇灌了畜栏的牧场。这时，大伙儿放慢了步子，以免在必须决斗的时候，喘不过气来。他们的手指都扣着枪的扳机。大伙儿注视着两旁的密林。托普发出低吼声，好像是预告要有不幸的事情发生。
en: Soon they arrived at the place where the road led along the side of the little stream which flowed from the Red Creek and watered the meadows of the corral.They then moderated their pace so that they should not be out of breath at the moment when a struggle might be necessary.Their guns were in their hands ready cocked.The forest was watched on every side.Top uttered sullen groans which were rather ominous.

zh: 终于，畜栏的木栅栏从树木中显现出来。看不到什么遭到破坏的迹象。门像往常一样关着。死寂笼罩着畜栏。既听不见平日咩咩的羊叫，也听不见艾尔顿的声音。
en: At last the palisade appeared through the trees.No trace of any damage could be seen.The gate was shut as usual.Deep silence reigned in the corral.Neither the accustomed bleating of the sheep nor Ayrton’s voice could be heard.

zh: “我们进去。”塞勒斯·哈丁说。
en: “Let us enter,” said Cyrus Harding.

zh: 工程师往前走，他的同伴们在二十步以外跟着他，时刻警惕着，一有动静，就立即开枪。
en: And the engineer advanced, while his companions, keeping watch about twenty paces behind him, were ready to fire at a moment’s notice.

zh: 哈丁拔开里面的门闩，刚要推进去，这时，托普大声叫起来。只听“砰”一声，紧接着是一声惨叫。
en: Harding raised the inner latch of the gate and was about to push it back, when Top barked loudly.A report sounded and was responded to by a cry of pain.

zh: 一颗子弹打中了赫伯特，他直挺挺地倒在地上。
en: Herbert, struck by a bullet, lay stretched on the ground.

zh: 第七章
en: Chapter 7

zh: 一听到赫伯特的惨叫声，潘克洛夫连忙冲上去，手里的枪都丢到了地上。
en: At Herbert’s cry, Pencroft, letting his gun fall, rushed towards him.

zh: “他们把他打死了！”他喊着，“我的孩子！他们把他打死了！”
en: “They have killed him!” he cried.“My boy!They have killed him!”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和吉迪恩·史佩莱也跑向赫伯特。
en: Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett ran to Herbert.

zh: 通讯记者俯下身子，想听听这个可怜的孩子还有没有心跳。
en: The reporter listened to ascertain if the poor lad’s heart was still beating.

zh: “他还活着，”他说，“不过，我们必须得把他送回——”
en: “He lives,” said he, “but he must be carried—”

zh: “回‘花岗石宫’？那不可能！”工程师回答。
en: “To Granite House? that is impossible!” replied the engineer.

zh: “那么，抬到畜栏里去！”潘克洛夫说。
en: “Into the corral, then!” said Pencroft.

zh: “等等。”哈丁说。
en: “In a moment,” said Harding.

zh: 他绕过木栅栏的左角。就在那里，他看见一个罪犯正举着枪对准自己，一枪开来，子弹打穿了他的帽子。几秒钟后，还没等罪犯开第二枪，哈丁就用匕首刺中了他的心脏，这一刀可比枪打的还准，罪犯立马倒下了。
en: And he ran round the left corner of the palisade.There he found a convict, who aiming at him, sent a ball through his hat.In a few seconds, before he had even time to fire his second barrel, he fell, struck to the heart by Harding’s dagger, more sure even than his gun.

zh: 在这时候，吉迪恩·史佩莱和水手翻过栅栏，跳到畜栏里面，拉开里门的门杠，冲进空屋去，很快，可怜的赫伯特就躺在了艾尔顿的床上。不一会儿，哈丁也来到了赫伯特的身边。
en: During this time, Gideon Spilett and the sailor hoisted themselves over the palisade, leaped into the enclosure, threw down the props which supported the inner door, ran into the empty house, and soon, poor Herbert was lying on Ayrton’s bed.In a few moments, Harding was by his side.

zh: 看见赫伯特没了知觉，水手悲痛欲绝。
en: On seeing Herbert senseless, the sailor’s grief was terrible.

zh: 他先是抽泣，继而嚎啕大哭，还把脑袋往墙上撞。
en: He sobbed, he cried, he tried to beat his head against the wall.

zh: 工程师和通讯记者都安抚不了他。他们自己也悲痛地难以自已，说不出话来。
en: Neither the engineer nor the reporter could calm him.They themselves were choked with emotion.They could not speak.

zh: 不过，他们知道还得靠他们，把眼前受苦的这个可怜的孩子从死神手里救出来。吉迪恩·史佩莱稍懂医药，不然，怎么会历经众多劫难却依然大难不死？他什么都知道一点儿，有几次，他还被安排医治刀伤和枪伤。在赛勒斯·哈丁的帮助下，他开始对赫伯特进行抢救。
en: However, they knew that it depended on them to rescue from death the poor boy who was suffering beneath their eyes.Gideon Spilett had not passed through the many incidents by which his life had been checkered without acquiring some slight knowledge of medicine.He knew a little of everything, and several times he had been obliged to attend to wounds produced either by a sword-bayonet or shot.Assisted by Cyrus Harding, he proceeded to render the aid Herbert required.

zh: 通讯记者一上来就大吃一惊，因为赫伯特躺在那儿，完全不省人事，一是由于出血过多，二是由于受到的巨大的冲击，子弹力量很猛，打中了一块骨头，造成了强烈的震荡。
en: The reporter was immediately struck by the complete stupor in which Herbert lay, a stupor owing either to the hemorrhage, or to the shock, the ball having struck a bone with sufficient force to produce a violent concussion.

zh: 赫伯特面色惨白，脉搏若隐若现，要隔很长时间史佩莱才能感觉到它跳动一次，似乎几乎就要停止了。
en: Herbert was deadly pale, and his pulse so feeble that Spilett only felt it beat at long intervals, as if it was on the point of stopping.

zh: 症状非常危急。
en: These symptoms were very serious.

zh: 大伙儿把赫伯特的胸膛露出来，用在冷水中浸过的手帕为他止了血。
en: Herbert’s chest was laid bare, and the blood having been stanched with handkerchiefs, it was bathed with cold water.

zh: 大伙儿快看见伤口了——在胸膛以下第三根与第四根肋骨之间有一个椭圆形的窟窿。这就是赫伯特身上被子弹击中的地方。
en: The contusion, or rather the contused wound appeared,—an oval below the chest between the third and fourth ribs.It was there that Herbert had been hit by the bullet.

zh: 然后，赛勒斯·哈丁和吉迪恩·史佩莱把可怜的孩子的身体翻过来，翻身的时候，赫伯特发出一声微弱的呻吟，大伙儿差一点以为这是他将死之前的叹息了。
en: Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett then turned the poor boy over; as they did so, he uttered a moan so feeble that they almost thought it was his last sigh.

zh: 他的后背还有一处伤口，背上满是血，子弹就是从这儿打穿出去的。
en: Herberts back was covered with blood from another contused wound, by which the ball had immediately escaped.

zh: “感谢上帝！”通讯记者说，“子弹没有在身体里，我们不必把它取出来了。”
en: “God be praised!” said the reporter, “the ball is not in the body, and we shall not have to extract it.”

zh: “有没有伤着心脏？”哈丁问。
en: “But the heart?” asked Harding.

zh: “子弹没有打到心脏，不然，赫伯特早死了！”
en: “The heart has not been touched; if it had been, Herbert would be dead!”

zh: “死了！”潘克洛夫呻吟了一声。
en: “Dead!” exclaimed Pencroft, with a groan.

zh: 水手只听见通讯记者说的最后这两个字了。
en: The sailor had only heard the last words uttered by the reporter.

zh: “没有，潘克洛夫，”赛勒斯·哈丁对他说道，“没有！他没死。他的脉搏还在跳动。他不是还呻吟了一声？不过，为了你的孩子着想，让自己冷静下来。我们必须非常镇静。”
en: “No, Pencroft,” replied Cyrus Harding, “no!He is not dead.His pulse still beats.He has even uttered a moan.But for your boy’s sake, calm yourself.We have need of all our self-possession.”

zh: “不要让我们沉不住气，朋友。”
en: “Do not make us lose it, my friend.”

zh: 潘克洛夫什么也没说，他的反应是，大滴的泪珠从他的脸颊上滚落下来。
en: Pencroft was silent, but a reaction set in, and great tears rolled down his cheeks.

zh: 这时，吉迪恩·史佩莱努力集中精力，继续对赫伯特进行医治。仔细检查了一遍以后，他确定了子弹是从前胸第七根和第八根肋骨间打进去的，然后从后面第三根和第四根肋骨间穿了出来。但是，子弹在这个过程中造成什么破坏？它伤到了那些重要的器官？专业的外科医生立刻回答这些问题都有困难，何况是通讯记者了。
en: In the meanwhile, Gideon Spilett endeavored to collect his ideas, and proceed methodically.After his examination he had no doubt that the ball, entering in front, between the seventh and eighth ribs, had issued behind between the third and fourth.But what mischief had the ball committed in its passage?What important organs had been reached?A professional surgeon would have had difficulty in determining this at once, and still more so the reporter.

zh: 不过，有一点他很清楚，就是必须阻止伤口发炎造成血脉不通，然后同伤口——或许是致命的——引发的局部炎症和高烧作斗争！现在，要用什么来止血和消炎呢？怎样才能阻止伤口发炎呢？
en: However, he knew one thing, this was that he would have to prevent the inflammatory strangulation of the injured parts, then to contend with the local inflammation and fever which would result from the wound, perhaps mortal!Now, what styptics, what antiphiogistics ought to be employed?By what means could inflammation be prevented?

zh: 不管怎样，最要紧的事是立刻把两处伤口包扎起来。为防止赫伯特再次出血，吉迪恩·史佩莱认为不必再用温水洗一遍伤口，也不必挤压伤口。赫伯特流了很多血，身体因为失血过多已经变得很虚弱。
en: At any rate, the most important thing was that the two wounds should be dressed without delay.It did not appear necessary to Gideon Spilett that a fresh flow of blood should be caused by bathing them in tepid water, and compressing their lips.The hemorrhage had been very abundant, and Herbert was already too much enfeebled by the loss of blood.

zh: 因此，通讯记者认为最好简单地用冷水擦拭一下两处伤口。
en: The reporter, therefore, thought it best to simply bathe the two wounds with cold water.

zh: 大伙儿把赫伯特侧翻过来，朝左边躺着，让他保持着这个姿势。
en: Herbert was placed on his left side, and was maintained in that position.

zh: “不能再动他。”吉迪恩·史佩莱说，“这样躺着最有助于他后背和前胸的伤口排脓，他现在需要绝对的休息。”
en: “He must not be moved.” said Gideon Spilett.“He is in the most favorable position for the wounds in his back and chest to suppurate easily, and absolute rest is necessary.”

zh: “什么！我们不能把他送回‘花岗石宫’吗？”潘克洛夫问。
en: “What! can’t we carry him to Granite House?” asked Pencroft.

zh: “不行，潘克洛夫。”通讯记者回答。
en: “No, Pencroft,” replied the reporter.

zh: “我要让那帮混蛋血债血还！”水手大声说，威胁地挥舞着拳头。
en: “I’ll pay the villains off!” cried the sailor, shaking his fist in a menacing manner.

zh: “潘克洛夫！”赛勒斯·哈丁说。
en: “Pencroft!” said Cyrus Harding.

zh: 吉迪恩·史佩莱继续检查起受伤的孩子的身体。赫伯特依然脸色惨白得令人害怕，通讯记者非常忧虑。
en: Gideon Spilett had resumed his examination of the wounded boy.Herbert was still so frightfully pale, that the reporter felt anxious.

zh: “赛勒斯，”他说道，“我不是个外科医生。我现在很茫然。你得给我建议，以你的经验协助我！”
en: “Cyrus,” said he, “I am not a surgeon.I am in terrible perplexity.You must aid me with your advice, your experience!”

zh: “鼓起勇气来，我的朋友，”工程师紧紧地握着通讯记者的手，说道，“冷静地判断。脑子里就想一件事：一定要救活赫伯特！”
en: “Take courage, my friend,” answered the engineer, pressing the reporter’s hand.“Judge coolly.Think only of this: Herbert must be saved!”

zh: 这几句话让吉迪恩·史佩莱恢复了镇静。他刚才因为感到肩上沉重的责任，一度灰心丧气，慌张起来。他紧挨床坐着。赛勒斯·哈丁站在旁边。潘克洛夫把自己的衬衫撕破了，机械地做着包扎要用的软麻布。
en: These words restored to Gideon Spilett that self-possession which he had lost in a moment of discouragement on feeling his great responsibility.He seated himself close to the bed.Cyrus Harding stood near.Pencroft had torn up his shirt, and was mechanically making lint.

zh: 史佩莱向赛勒斯·哈丁解释说，他认为他应该首先把血止住，而不是把两处伤口缝合，或使它们快点结疤，因为子弹打穿了内脏，不能让脓液积聚在胸腔内。
en: Spilett then explained to Cyrus Harding that he thought he ought first of all to stop the hemorrhage, but not close the two wounds, or cause their immediate cicatrization, for there had been internal perforation, and the suppuration must not be allowed to accumulate in the chest.

zh: 哈丁完全同意，于是通讯记者决定，先把伤口包起来，不用立即缝合。
en: Harding approved entirely, and it was decided that the two wounds should be dressed without attempting to close them by immediate coaptation.

zh: 那么，现在，移民们有没有灵药来对付可能出现的炎症呢？
en: And now did the colonists possess an efficacious agent to act against the inflammation which might occur?

zh: 有！他们有一种灵药，大自然慷慨地赐予了他们。他们有冷水，这是治疗伤口发炎的最管用的镇静剂，对付危急病症的最有疗效的灵药，现在的医生没有一个不在用它。此外，冷水还有一个好处，它能使伤口得到彻底的休息，能在所有过早地包扎伤口的情况下保护伤口，这点很有用，因为根据经验，受伤最初的几天，伤口与空气接触是很危险的。
en: Yes.They had one, for nature had generously lavished it.They had cold water, that is to say, the most powerful sedative that can be employed against inflammation of wounds, the most efficacious therapeutic agent in grave cases, and the one which is now adopted by all physicians.Cold water has, moreover, the advantage of leaving the wound in absolute rest, and preserving it from all premature dressing, a considerable advantage, since it has been found by experience that contact with the air is dangerous during the first days.

zh: 吉迪恩·史佩莱和赛勒斯·哈丁用他们简单而有条理的思维这样推断着，他们做的不输给最优秀的外科医生。他们把用软麻布做的敷布敷在可怜的赫伯特的两处伤口上，不断地用冷水把布浸湿。
en: Gideon Spilett and Cyrus Harding reasoned thus with their simple good sense, and they acted as the best surgeon would have done.Compresses of linen were applied to poor Herbert’s two wounds, and were kept constantly wet with cold water.

zh: 水手一开始就在小木屋里生了一把火，屋里各种生活必需品都一应俱全。大伙儿用槭糖、各种药草——就是赫伯特在格兰特湖边找到的那些种子——熬了一些可以振奋精神的汤水，他们喂赫伯特喝下去，孩子一点儿知觉也没有。他发着高烧，一整天过去了，他还是没醒过来。
en: The sailor had at first lighted a fire in the hut, which was not wanting in things necessary for life.Maple sugar, medicinal plants, the same which the lad had gathered on the banks of Lake Grant, enabled them to make some refreshing drinks, which they gave him without his taking any notice of it.His fever was extremely high, and all that day and night passed without his becoming conscious.

zh: 赫伯特命悬一线，而且这根线随时都可能断了。第二天，11月12号，哈丁和同伴们重新燃起了一线希望。赫伯特经过长时间的昏迷后，醒过来了。他睁开眼睛，认出了赛勒斯·哈丁、通讯记者和潘克洛夫。他说了两三个字。他不知道发生了什么事。大伙儿把事情的经过告诉了他，史佩莱恳求他绝对不要动，跟他说已经没有生命危险，伤口过几天就会痊愈的。赫伯特几乎再没受什么苦，因为伤口常用冷水擦拭，所以没有发炎。排脓进行得很正常，体温也没有上升，大伙儿现在希望这次可怕的枪伤不会带来任何灾难。潘克洛夫觉得他的心也慢慢放下来了。他就像一个慈爱的修女，像一个坐在爱子床边的母亲。
en: Herbert’s life hung on a thread, and this thread might break at any moment.The next day, the 12th of November, the hopes of Harding and his companions slightly revived.Herbert had come out of his long stupor.He opened his eyes, he recognized Cyrus Harding, the reporter, and Pencroft.He uttered two or three words.He did not know what had happened.They told him, and Spilett begged him to remain perfectly still, telling him that his life was not in danger, and that his wounds would heal in a few days.However, Herbert scarcely suffered at all, and the cold water with which they were constantly bathed, prevented any inflammation of the wounds.The suppuration was established in a regular way, the fever did not increase, and it might now be hoped that this terrible wound would not involve any catastrophe.Pencroft felt the swelling of his heart gradually subside.He was like a sister of mercy. like a mother by the bed of her child.

zh: 赫伯特又开始打瞌睡，不过，这次他是自然地进入了梦乡。
en: Herbert dozed again, but his sleep appeared more natural.

zh: “再跟我说一遍你有信心，史佩莱先生，”潘克洛夫说，“再说一遍你能救活赫伯特！”
en: “Tell me again that you hope, Mr. Spilett,” said Pencroft.“Tell me again that you will save Herbert!”

zh: “是，我们能把他救活！”通讯记者说，“伤势很严重，有可能子弹都打穿了肺，不过，肺部的穿孔不会危及生命。”
en: “Yes, we will save him!” replied the reporter.“The wound is serious, and, perhaps, even the ball has traversed the lungs, but the perforation of this organ is not fatal.”

zh: “上帝保佑你！”潘克洛夫说。
en: “God bless you!” answered Pencroft.

zh: 可以相信，在这二十四小时里，移民们一直呆在畜栏里，心思全花在了照顾赫伯特上面。他们既没有考虑万一罪犯们回来，他们会面临什么样的危险，也没考虑将来要采取什么预防措施。
en: As may be believed, during the four-and-twenty hours they had been in the corral, the colonists had no other thought than that of nursing Herbert.They did not think either of the danger which threatened them should the convicts return, or of the precautions to be taken for the future.

zh: 但这天，当潘克洛夫坐在病床前照顾病人时，赛勒斯·哈丁和通讯记者商议着眼下最好怎么办。
en: But on this day, while Pencroft watched by the sick-bed, Cyrus Harding and the reporter consulted as to what it would be best to do.

zh: 他们首先查看了一遍畜栏。连艾尔顿的影子也没看见。是不是这个不幸的人让以前的党羽拖走了？是不是他反抗过，但在打斗中敌不过那帮家伙儿？最后这个假设很有可能。吉迪恩·史佩莱爬上栅栏的时候，曾清清楚楚地看见一个罪犯沿着富兰克林山南边的支脉逃跑，托普朝着他冲过去了。慈悲河河口的岩石曾撞坏了罪犯们的小船，也把他们的企图撞得灰飞烟灭，这个逃跑的罪犯就是他们当中的一员。另外，密斯刺死的那个罪犯，还躺在围栏外面，自然也是鲍勃·哈维的手下。
en: First of all they examined the corral.There was not a trace of Ayrton.Had the unhappy man been dragged away by his former accomplices?Had he resisted, and been overcome in the struggle?This last supposition was only too probable.Gideon Spilett, at the moment he scaled the palisade, had clearly seen some one of the convicts running along the southern spur of Mount Franklin, towards whom Top had sprung.It was one of those whose object had been so completely defeated by the rocks at the mouth of the Mercy.Besides, the one killed by Harding, and whose body was found outside the enclosure, of course belonged to Bob Harvey’s crew.

zh: 畜栏倒是没有遭到任何破坏。门关着，牲畜也没有逃散到森林中去。他们在屋子里和栅栏里边都没有看到任何打斗或者遭到破坏的迹象。唯独艾尔顿的武器和他一块儿消失了。
en: As to the corral, it had not suffered any damage.The gates were closed, and the animals had not been able to disperse in the forest.Nor could they see traces of any struggle, any devastation, either in the hut, or in the palisade.The ammunition only, with which Ayrton had been supplied, had disappeared with him.

zh: “那个不幸的人被突袭了，”哈丁说，“他是一个会保护自己的人，肯定是最后抵挡不住了。”
en: “The unhappy man has been surprised,” said Harding, “and as he was a man to defend himself, he must have been overpowered.”

zh: “嗯，恐怕正是这样。”通讯记者说，“那么，毫无疑问，罪犯们发现畜栏里应有尽有，就在这儿住下了，只是看见我们来了才逃跑的。同样显而易见的是，这时艾尔顿不管是死是活，并不在这儿！”
en: “Yes, that is to be feared!” said the reporter.“Then, doubtless, the convicts installed themselves in the corral where they found plenty of everything, and only fled when they saw us coming.It is very evident, too, that at this moment Ayrton, whether living or dead, is not here!”

zh: “我们到森林里去搜索，”工程师说，“把那帮无耻的混蛋从岛上清除出去。潘克洛夫当时想要像猎捕猛兽那样追击罪犯们，他的预感是正确的。要是早那么做，所有不幸的事根本不会发生！”
en: “We shall have to beat the forest,” said the engineer, “and rid the island of these wretches.Pencroft’s presentiments were not mistaken, when he wished to hunt them as wild beasts.That would have spared us all these misfortunes!”

zh: “是啊，”通讯记者说，“现在可是他们逼得我们冷酷无情的！”
en: “Yes,” answered the reporter, “but now we have the right to be merciless!”

zh: “不管怎样，”工程师说，“我们要继续呆在畜栏里等上一段时间，等到能把赫伯特安全地送回‘花岗石宫’再行动。”
en: “At any rate,” said the engineer, “we are obliged to wait some time, and to remain at the corral until we can carry Herbert without danger to Granite House.”

zh: “可是纳布呢？”通讯记者问。
en: “But Neb?” asked the reporter.

zh: “纳布很安全。”
en: “Neb is in safety.”

zh: “可是，要是他因为我们迟迟未归而不安起来，会不会冒险过来呢？”
en: “But if, uneasy at our absence, he would venture to come?”

zh: “他不能来！”赛勒斯·哈丁立即说，“他会在路上被杀死的！”
en: “He must not come!” returned Cyrus Harding quickly.“He would be murdered on the road!”

zh: “可是，他很可能会来找我们会合的。”
en: “It is very probable, however, that he will attempt to rejoin us!”

zh: “唉，要是电报机还能用，我们就可以给他提个醒了。现在却办不到！我们也不能把潘克洛夫和赫伯特单独留在这儿。好吧，我一个人回一趟‘花岗石宫’。”
en: “Ah, if the telegraph still acted, he might be warned!But that is impossible now!As to leaving Pencroft and Herbert here alone, we could not do it!Well, I will go alone to Granite House.”

zh: “不行，不行！赛勒斯，”通讯记者听了说，“你不能暴露你自己！你的勇气不会起到任何作用。那帮混蛋们显然在关注着畜栏里的一举一动，他们就藏在周围的密林里，要是你离开的话，让我们伤心的不幸的事很快就会由一件变成两件！”
en: “No, no!Cyrus,” answered the reporter, “you must not expose yourself!Your courage would be of no avail.The villains are evidently watching the corral, they are hidden in the thick woods which surround it, and if you go we shall soon have to regret two misfortunes instead of one!”

zh: “可是纳布怎么办？”工程师又说，“他现在整整24小时没收到关于我们的消息了！”他一定会来的！”
en: “But Neb?” repeated the engineer.“It is now four-and-twenty hours since he has had any news of us!He will be sure to come!”

zh: “而且他不会像我们一样小心提防那些罪犯，”史佩莱补充道，“他们会杀了他的！”
en: “And as he will be less on his guard than we should be ourselves,” added Spilett, “he will be killed!”

zh: “难道真的没有办法警告他吗？”
en: “Is there really no way of warning him?”

zh: 当工程师考虑的时候，他的目光落在了托普身上，托普走来走去，好像是在说：
en: While the engineer thought, his eyes fell on Top, who, going backwards and forwards seemed to say,—

zh: “我不是在这儿吗？”
en: “Am not I here?”

zh: “托普！”赛勒斯·哈丁叫道。
en: “Top!” exclaimed Cyrus Harding.

zh: 听到主人叫它，它跳起身来。
en: The animal sprang at his master’s call.

zh: “对，托普可以去。”通讯记者说，他明白了工程师的意思。
en: “Yes, Top will go,” said the reporter, who had understood the engineer.

zh: “我们不能去的地方，托普能去！他能把畜栏的消息带到‘花岗石宫’，也能把那儿的消息带回给我们！”
en: “Top can go where we cannot!He will carry to Granite House the news of the corral, and he will bring back to us that from Granite House!”

zh: “快点！”哈丁说，“赶快！”
en: “Quick!” said Harding.“Quick!”

zh: 史佩莱赶紧从他的笔记本上撕下一页，在上面写道：
en: Spilett rapidly tore a leaf from his note-book, and wrote these words:—

zh: “赫伯特受伤了。我们在畜栏。你要小心。不要离开‘花岗石宫’。罪犯在附近出现过吗？让托普把回复带回来。”
en: “Herbert wounded.We are at the corral.Be on your guard.Do not leave Granite House.Have the convicts appeared in the neighborhood?Reply by Top.”

zh: 这张只写着寥寥数语的纸条包含了纳布应该知道的一切，同时也问出了移民们想要知道的一切。他们把纸条折起来，记在托普颈部一个显眼的地方。
en: This laconic note contained all that Neb ought to know, and at the same time asked all that the colonists wished to know.It was folded and fastened to Top’s collar in a conspicuous position.

zh: “托普，我的托普，”工程师一边说，一边爱抚着这只畜生，“纳布，托普！纳布！去吧，去吧！”
en: “Top, my dog,” said the engineer, caressing the animal, “Neb, Top!Neb!Go, go!”

zh: 听到这些话，托普来回乱跳。他明白工程师的意思，知道大家要他怎么做。他熟悉到畜栏的路，用不了一个钟头，它就能走完这条路，有些地方，不管是赛勒斯·史密斯还是通讯记者经过的时候，都会冒着危险，然而，托普可以不被察觉地从草丛中或树林里穿过。
en: Top bounded at these words.He understood, he knew what was expected of him.The road to the corral was familiar to him.In less than an hour he could clear it, and it might be hoped that where neither Cyrus Harding nor the reporter could have ventured without danger, Top, running among the grass or in the wood, would pass unperceived.

zh: 工程师走到畜栏门前，打开门。
en: The engineer went to the gate of the corral and opened it.

zh: “纳布，托普！纳布！”工程师重复了一遍，又指了指通向花岗石宫的方向。
en: “Neb, Top!Neb!” repeated the engineer, again pointing in the direction of Granite House.

zh: 托普往前冲去，几乎立刻就看不见踪影了。
en: Top sprang forwards, then almost immediately disappeared.

zh: “他会到那儿的！”通讯记者说。
en: “He will get there!” said the reporter.

zh: “是的，而且它还会回来，这只忠实的狗！”
en: “Yes, and he will come back, the faithful animal!”

zh: “几点了？”吉迪恩·史佩莱问。
en: “What o’clock is it?” asked Gideon Spilett.
“Ten.”

zh: “再过一个钟头，他可能就回来了。我们在这守着它回来。”
en: “In an hour he may be here.We will watch for his return.”

zh: 他们把畜栏门关上。工程师和通讯记者又回到屋里来。赫伯特还没有醒。潘克洛夫不停地把敷布浸湿。史佩莱看见这时候自己没什么可做的，就忙着准备一些富有营养的食物，同时留心看着靠山的围栏，以防罪犯从那里袭击。
en: The gate of the corral was closed.The engineer and the reporter re-entered the house.Herbert was still in a sleep.Pencroft kept the compresser always wet.Spilett, seeing there was nothing he could do at that moment, busied himself in preparing some nourishment, while attentively watching that part of the enclosure against the hill, at which an attack might be expected.

zh: 移民们焦急地等待着托普归来。将近11点的时候，塞勒斯·哈丁和通讯记者手里拿着步枪，站在门后，准备一听到狗叫就开门。
en: The settlers awaited Top’s return with much anxiety.A little before eleven o’clock, Cyrus Harding and the reporter, rifle in hand, were behind the gate, ready to open it at the first bark of their dog.

zh: 他们相信，如果托普平安到达了‘花岗石宫’，纳布一定会立即让它回来的。
en: They did not doubt that if Top had arrived safely at Granite House, Neb would have sent him back immediately.

zh: 两个人在那儿呆了差不多有十分钟，突然听到了一声枪响，紧接着是不停的狗叫声。
en: They had both been there for about ten minutes, when a report was heard, followed by repeated barks.

zh: 工程师打开门，看见林子里100英尺远的地方有烟，他朝那里开了一枪。
en: The engineer opened the gate, and seeing smoke a hundred feet off in the wood, he fired in that direction.

zh: 托普几乎立刻跳进了畜栏，他们赶紧关上门。
en: Almost immediately Top bounded into the corral, and the gate was quickly shut.

zh: “托普，托普！”工程师用手捧住狗的忠实的脑袋，叫道。
en: “Top, Top!” exclaimed the engineer, taking the dog’s great honest head between his hands.

zh: 托普的脖子上系着一张纸条，上面是纳布写的几个大字，赛勒斯·哈丁念道：“‘花岗石宫’附近没有海盗。我不会乱动。可怜的赫伯特！”
en: A note was fastened to his neck, and Cyrus Harding read these words, traced in Neb’s large writing:—“No pirates in the neighborhood of Granite House.I will not stir.Poor Mr. Herbert!”

zh: 第八章
en: Chapter 8

zh: 这么说，罪犯们还在附近监视着畜栏，看来他们下决心要把移民们一个接一个地杀掉。移民们只有像对付野兽一样对付他们。但是大伙儿还要加倍小心，因为现在这帮混蛋占据了有利的一面：他们躲在暗处，而移民处在明处；他们可以突袭移民，自己却不会遭到意外的袭击。因此哈丁为在畜栏居住作了安排，畜栏里的存粮还能维持相当长的一段时间。艾尔顿的屋里各种生活必需品都有，罪犯们被移民的到来吓跑了，还没顾得上抢走屋里的东西。或许正如吉迪恩·史佩莱所想的那样，事情的所有经过是这样的：
en: So the convicts were still there, watching the corral, and determined to kill the settlers one after the other.There was nothing to be done but to treat them as wild beasts.But great precautions must be taken, for just now the wretches had the advantage on their side, seeing, and not being seen, being able to surprise by the suddenness of their attack, yet not to be surprised themselves.Harding made arrangements, therefore, for living in the corral, of which the provisions would last for a tolerable length of time.Ayrton’s house had been provided with all that was necessary for existence, and the convicts, scared by the arrival of the settlers, had not had time to pillage it.It was probable, as Gideon Spilett observed, that things had occurred as follows:

zh: 六个罪犯上了岛之后，沿着南部海岸走，他们从盘蛇半岛的海岸这边一直穿到海岸那边，不愿意冒险进入远西森林，后来到了瀑布河口。他们从那里沿着河道的右岸走，最后可能到了富兰克林山的支脉下，很自然地在那儿找到了藏身之处。他们可能没有多久就发现了畜栏，当时畜栏里没有人。在那儿，他们正式地住下了，等待时机来实施他们可怕的阴谋。艾尔顿的到来让他们吃了一惊，不过，他们最终想法子打败了那个不幸的人儿，那么，接下来的事情就不难想象了！
en: The six convicts, disembarking on the island, had followed the southern shore, and after having traversed the double shore of the Serpentine Peninsula, not being inclined to venture into the Far West woods, they had reached the mouth of Falls River.From this point, by following the right bank of the watercourse, they would arrive at the spurs of Mount Franklin, among which they would naturally seek a retreat, and they could not have been long in discovering the corral, then uninhabited.There they had regularly installed themselves, awaiting the moment to put their abominable schemes into execution.Ayrton’s arrival had surprised them, but they had managed to overpower the unfortunate man, and—the rest may be easily imagined!

zh: 现在，罪犯只剩下五个是不错，可他们一个个都是全副武装，就在森林里游荡。冒险进入森林就等于把自己暴露在敌人的袭击之下，对于他们的袭击，既无法防御，又不能阻止。
en: Now, the convicts,—reduced to five, it is true, but well armed,—were roaming the woods, and to venture there was to expose themselves to their attacks, which could be neither guarded against nor prevented.

zh: “再等等！只能这样做了！”赛勒斯·哈丁又说道。“等到赫伯特痊愈了，我们就在岛上进行一次全方位的作战，让这些罪犯们赎罪。这是我们这次大探险的目的，同时……”
en: “Wait!There is nothing else to be done!” repeated Cyrus Harding.“When Herbert is cured, we can organize a general battle of the island, and have satisfaction of these convicts.That will be the object of our grand expedition at the same time—”

zh: “我们还要寻找那个神秘的保护者，”吉迪恩·史佩莱接着工程师的话说道，“而且，亲爱的赛勒斯，必须承认，这一次在我们最需要他的保护的时候，他却没有出手相助！”
en: “As the search for our mysterious protector,” added Gideon Spilett, finishing the engineer’s sentence.“An, it must be acknowledged, my dear Cyrus, that this time his protection was wanting at the very moment when it was most necessary to us!”

zh: “谁知道呢？”工程师回答。
en: “Who knows?” replied the engineer.

zh: “什么意思？”通讯记者问。
en: “What do you mean?” asked the reporter.

zh: “我们还没到走投无路的时候，亲爱的史佩莱，说不定我们强大的保护者会在接下来的哪个时候对我们伸出援手呢。但是那不是眼前的问题。把赫伯特救活才最重要。”
en: “That we are not at the end of our trouble yet, my dear Spilett, and that his powerful intervention may have another opportunity of exercising itself.But that is not the question now.Herbert’s life before everything.”

zh: 这是移民们最担心的事。几天过去了，令人高兴的是那个可怜的孩子的状况没有恶化。冷水一直保持着合适的温度，因此，伤口一点儿也没发炎。通讯记者甚至似乎认为，这种含有少量硫——因为周边有火山——的水质，对伤口痊愈有一个更直接的作用。伤口化脓少了很多，在同伴们始终如一的照顾下，赫伯特活过来了，烧也退了。此外，移民们严格控制他的饮食，结果他的身体变得非常虚弱，说不定还会有什么严重的后果；但是他并不需要振奋精神的饮料，而且，绝对的休息对他来说尤其有好处。塞勒斯·哈丁、吉迪恩·史佩莱和潘克洛夫都能很熟练地为孩子包扎伤口了。屋子里所有的亚麻布料都派上了用场。赫伯特的伤口上敷着敷布和软麻布，包得不松不紧，以便伤口愈合，而且没有炎症反应。通讯记者包扎的时候格外小心，他很明白其中的重要性，一再地跟同伴们说——很多外科医生都愿意承认这一点——包扎好伤口远比成功做完一次手术难得多。
en: This was the colonists’ saddest thought.Several days passed, and the poor boy’s state was happily no worse.Cold water, always kept at a suitable temperature, had completely prevented the inflammation of the wounds.It even seemed to the reporter that this water, being slightly sulphurous,—which was explained by the neighborhood of the volcano, had a more direct action on the healing.The suppuration was much less abundant, and thanks to the incessant care by which he was surrounded!—Herbert returned to life, and his fever abated.He was besides subjected to a severe diet, and consequently his weakness was and would be extreme; but there was no want of refreshing drinks, and absolute rest was of the greatest benefit to him.Cyrus Harding, Gideon Spilett, and Pencroft had become very skilful in dressing the lad’s wounds.All the linen in the house had been sacrificed.Herbert’s wounds, covered with compresses and lint, were pressed neither too much nor too little, so as to cause their cicatrization without effecting any inflammatory reaction.The reporter used extreme care in the dressing, knowing well the importance of it, and repeating to his companions that which most surgeons willingly admit, that it is perhaps rarer to see a dressing well done than an operation well performed.

zh: 十天以后，11月22号，赫伯特的身体好多了。他开始进食一些有营养的食物。
en: In ten days, on the 22nd of November, Herbert was considerably better.He had begun to take some nourishment.

zh: 他的脸上又有了血色，睁着亮晶晶的眼睛对着照顾他的同伴微笑。尽管潘克洛夫费尽力气，不停地在讲，把最稀奇古怪的故事说给他听，好不让他有机会开口，但他还是说了几句话。赫伯特向潘克洛夫问起艾尔顿，他以为艾尔顿在畜栏里，看到他不在自己身边，觉得很吃惊。不过，水手为了不让赫伯特难过，告诉他艾尔顿已经回去和纳布一起保护花岗石宫了，以使他安心。
en: The color was returning to his cheeks, and his bright eyes smiled at his nurses.He talked a little, notwithstanding Pencroft’s efforts, who talked incessantly to prevent him from beginning to speak, and told him the most improbable stories.Herbert had questioned him on the subject of Ayrton, whom he was astonished not to see near him, thinking that he was at the corral.But the sailor, not wishing to distress Herbert, contented himself by replying that Ayrton had rejoined Neb, so as to defend Granite House.

zh: “哼！”潘克洛夫说，“这帮强盗！他们不配得到一丝一毫的关心！队长原先还想善待他们，使他们改邪归正！我也会善待他们的，不过，是用子弹善待他们！”
en: “Humph!” said Pencroft, “these pirates! they are gentlemen who have no right to any consideration!And the captain wanted to win them by kindness!I’ll send them some kindness, but in the shape of a good bullet!”

zh: “他们再没露面吗？”赫伯特问。
en: “And have they not been seen again?” asked Herbert.

zh: “没有，我的孩子，”水手回答，“不过，我们会把他们找出来的，等到你康复了，我们就看看那帮只会在背后捅刀子伤人的胆小鬼，敢不敢和我们面对面相见！”
en: “No, my boy,” answered the sailor, “but we shall find them, and when you are cured we shall see if the cowards who strike us from behind will dare to meet us face to face!”

zh: “我的身体还很弱呢，我的潘克洛夫！”
en: “I am still very weak, my poor Pencroft!”

zh: “没事！你的体力会慢慢恢复的！子弹穿过胸膛又怎么了？不过是一个玩笑！我看过很多这样的事了，没什么大不了的！”
en: “Well! your strength will return gradually!What’s a ball through the chest?Nothing but a joke!I’ve seen many, and I don’t think much of them!”

zh: 事情最终看起来进行得很顺利，如果不出现并发症，赫伯特肯定会康复。可是如果他的情况恶化，比方说，如果有子弹留在了他身体里，或者如果不得不对他进行截肢，那移民们该怎么办？
en: At last things appeared to be going on well, and if no complication occurred, Herbert’s recovery might be regarded as certain.But what would have been the condition of the colonists if his state had been aggravated,—if, for example, the ball had remained in his body, if his arm or his leg had had to be amputated?

zh: “不，”史佩莱不止一次地说，“一想到这种可能性，我就忍不住发抖！”
en: “No,” said Spilett more than once, “I have never thought of such a contingency without shuddering!”

zh: “但是，如果需要动手术的话，”哈丁有一天对他说，“你不会迟疑吧？”
en: “And yet, if it had been necessary to operate,” said Harding one day to him, “you would not have hesitated?”

zh: “不会的，赛勒斯！”吉迪恩·史佩莱说，“不过感谢上帝，赫伯特并没有出现并发症！”
en: “No, Cyrus!” said Gideon Spilett, “but thank God that we have been spared this complication!”

zh: 在以往许多其他的推断分析中，移民们都常常依靠简单而又良好的思维，这次，多亏他们丰富的知识，他们又一次成功了！可是，会不会有那么一天，连他们的科学知识也不管用了呢？他们孤零零地在这个荒岛上。现在，每个社会阶层的人们都是相互依赖的。赛勒斯·哈丁很清楚这一点，有时他会想，会不会发生一种他们无力解决的情况？而且在他看来，他和他的同伴们直到目前都很幸运，现在却进入了一段不太走运的时期。在他们逃出里士满后的这两年半里，可以说他们是事事顺心。荒岛给他们提供了丰富的矿藏、植物和动物，而且大自然不断地施与他们东西，他们依靠科学知识将其加以利用。
en: As in so many other conjectures, the colonists had appealed to the logic of that simple good sense of which they had made use so often, and once more, thanks to their general knowledge, it had succeeded!But might not a time come when all their science would be at fault?They were alone on the island.Now, men in all states of society are necessary to each other.Cyrus Harding knew this well, and sometimes he asked if some circumstance might not occur which they would be powerless to surmount.It appeared to him besides, that he and his companions, till then so fortunate, had entered into an unlucky period.During the two years and a half which had elapsed since their escape from Richmond, it might be said that they had had everything their own way.The island had abundantly supplied them with minerals, vegetables, animals, and as Nature had constantly loaded them, their science had known how to take advantage of what she offered them.

zh: 因此，移民们过得无比幸福。而且，有些时候，一股难以解释的力量还会对他们伸出援手！……可是，所有这一切都只是暂时的。
en: The wellbeing of the colony was therefore complete.Moreover, in certain occurrences an inexplicable influence had come to their aid!...But all that could only be for a time.

zh: 总之，赛勒斯·哈丁相信命运开始和他们做对了。
en: In short, Cyrus Harding believed that fortune had turned against them.

zh: 的确，罪犯们的船来过荒岛的沿海一带，虽然海盗可以说是被神秘地消灭掉了，但是至少还有六个家伙死里逃生了。他们上了岛，现在要抓到活着那五个是几乎不可能的事。艾尔顿一定被这些恶棍们杀害了，他们拿着武器，第一枪就险些要了赫伯特的命。这是不是移民们遭受的第一次厄运呢？哈丁常常这样问自己。通讯记者也是如此，而且，他还觉得此前不断帮他们转危为安的那股奇怪又灵验的力量，现在也不见了。是不是那个神秘的人——不管他是谁，而且他肯定在岛上呆过——离开了荒岛？他是不是也束手无策了呢？
en: In fact, the convicts’ ship had appeared in the waters of the island, and if the pirates had been, so to speak, miraculously destroyed, six of them, at least, had escaped the catastrophe.They had disembarked on the island, and it was almost impossible to get at the five who survived.Ayrton had no doubt been murdered by these wretches, who possessed firearms, and at the first use that they had made of them, Herbert had fallen, wounded almost mortally.Were these the first blows aimed by adverse fortune at the colonists?This was often asked by Harding.This was often repeated by the reporter; and it appeared to him also that the intervention, so strange, yet so efficacious, which till then had served them so well, had now failed them.Had this mysterious being, whatever he was, whose existence could not be denied, abandoned the island?Had he in his turn succumbed?

zh: 这些问题是没办法回答的。不过，不能因为哈丁和他的同伴考虑到这些问题，就以为他们绝望了。他们远远没有绝望。相反，他们直面当前的处境，分析一切机会，作好准备来应对一切情况，勇敢而坚定地迎接未来。如果厄运还要再次打击他们，就会发现他们已经准备就绪，要放手一搏了。
en: No reply was possible to these questions.But it must not be imagined that because Harding and his companions spoke of these things, they were men to despair.Far from that.They looked their situation in the face, they analyzed the chances, they prepared themselves for any event, they stood firm and straight before the future, and if adversity was at last to strike them, it would find in them men prepared to struggle against it.

zh: 第九章
en: Chapter 9

zh: 受伤的孩子慢慢康复了。大伙儿现在只盼着他身体好转，可以把他送回花岗石宫。不管畜栏盖得有多好，里面的东西有多齐全，还是不如花岗石宫住着舒适、健康。况且，畜栏没有花岗石宫安全，尽管移民们很警惕，还是一直担心罪犯们会突然袭击这儿。相反，花岗石宫建在坚不可摧、难以到达的峭壁之间，他们在里面没有什么可担心的，任何袭击都注定会失败。因此，大伙儿焦急地等待着赫伯特身体恢复到一定程度，以便在不引起伤口恶化的前提下把他安全地送回去。尽管通过啄木鸟林之间的通讯还很困难，他们还是做了这个决定。
en: The convalescence of the young invalid was regularly progressing.One thing only was now to be desired, that his state would allow him to be brought to Granite House.However well built and supplied the corral house was, it could not be so comfortable as the healthy granite dwelling.Besides, it did not offer the same security, and its tenants, notwithstanding their watchfulness, were here always in fear of some shot from the convicts.There, on the contrary, in the middle of that impregnable and inaccessible cliff, they would have nothing to fear, and any attack on their persons would certainly fail.They therefore waited impatiently for the moment when Herbert might be moved without danger from his wound, and they were determined to make this move, although the communication through Jacamar Wood was very difficult.

zh: 他们没有纳布的消息，不过对于这一点，大家倒是不担心。那个勇敢的黑人坚守在花岗石宫里，是不会受到袭击的。大家没有再派托普回去，因为那样不会有任何好处，只会把这只忠诚的狗暴露在敌人的枪口下，让移民丧失一个得力的助手。
en: They had no news from Neb, but were not uneasy on that account.The courageous Negro, well entrenched in the depths of Granite House, would not allow himself to be surprised.Top had not been sent again to him, as it appeared useless to expose the faithful dog to some shot which might deprive the settlers of their most useful auxiliary.

zh: 于是，虽然他们急切地想回花岗石宫和纳布会合，但还是等待着。工程师看见自己的兵力分散，给了海盗们可乘之机，觉得非常苦恼。自从艾尔顿消失以后，他们就只剩四个人和敌人对抗，因为赫伯特不能算在内。勇敢的孩子非常担心这一点，他心里明白自己给大家带来了麻烦。
en: They waited, therefore, although they were anxious to be reunited at Granite House.It pained the engineer to see his forces divided, for it gave great advantage to the pirates.Since Ayrton’s disappearance they were only four against five, for Herbert could not yet be counted, and this was not the least care of the brave boy, who well understood the trouble of which he was the cause.

zh: 11月29号，赛勒斯·哈丁、吉迪恩·史佩莱和潘克洛夫趁着赫伯特睡着了听不见他们说话，详细地讨论了在他们现在的情况下，应该如何对付海盗的问题。
en: The question of knowing how, in their condition, they were to act against the pirates, was thoroughly discussed on the 29th of November by Cyrus Harding, Gideon Spilett, and Pencroft, at a moment when Herbert was asleep and could not hear them.

zh: “朋友们”，在他们谈过纳布以及无法和他通信的问题以后，通讯记者说，“我和你们的想法一样，觉得要从通往畜栏的路走回去，就等于冒着被枪击中却来不及还击的危险。不过，你们不觉得现在最好的办法是公开地去搜捕那帮混蛋？”
en: “My friends,” said the reporter, after they had talked of Neb and of the impossibility of communicating with him, “I think,—like you, that to venture on the road to the corral would be to risk receiving a gunshot without being able to return it.But do you not think that the best thing to be done now is to openly give chase to these wretches?”

zh: “我正是这么想的，”潘克洛夫说，“我相信我们大家决不是能被子弹吓到的人，至于我，要是哈丁队长同意了，我随时都可以冲进林子里去。真是，该死，不是可以一个抵一个嘛！”
en: “That is just what I was thinking,” answered Pencroft.“I believe we’re not fellows to be afraid of a bullet, and as for me, if Captain Harding approves, I’m ready to dash into the forest!Why, hang it, one man is equal to another!”

zh: “可你抵得了五个吗？”工程师问。
en: “But is he equal to five?” asked the engineer.

zh: “我和潘克洛夫一块儿去，”通讯记者说，“我们两个全副武装，再带上托普——”
en: “I will join Pencroft,” said the reporter, “and both of us, well-armed and accompanied by Top—”

zh: “亲爱的史佩莱，还有你，潘克洛夫，”哈丁说，“让我们来冷静地分析一下。如果罪犯们藏在岛上的一处地方，如果我们知道那个地方，要做的只是把他们从那儿赶出去，那么我会主动出击；可是，与之相反，现在我们不是得处处担心，他们一定会先向我们开枪的吗？”
en: “My dear Spilett, and you, Pencroft,” answered Harding, “let us reason coolly.If the convicts were hid in one spot of the island, if we knew that spot, and had only to dislodge them, I would undertake a direct attack; but is there not occasion to fear, on the contrary, that they are sure to fire the first shot?”

zh: “好了，队长，”潘克洛夫大声说，“子弹也不一定总能打中目标啊。”
en: “Well, captain,” cried Pencroft, “a bullet does not always reach its mark.”

zh: “赫伯特就被打中了，潘克洛夫，”工程师回答，“况且，如果你们都离开畜栏，那这里就只剩我一个人防守了。你们认为罪犯们看不见你们离开畜栏吗？难道他们不会先放你们进入森林，再趁着这里只剩下我和一个受伤的孩子袭击畜栏吗？”
en: “That which struck Herbert did not miss, Pencroft,” replied the engineer.“Besides, observe that if both of you left the corral I should remain here alone to defend it.Do you imagine that the convicts will not see you leave it, that they will not allow you to enter the forest, and that they will not attack it during your absence, knowing that there is no one here but a wounded boy and a man?”

zh: “你说得对，队长，”潘克洛夫满腔气愤地说，“你说得对，他们知道畜栏里什么都有，为了再次霸占畜栏会无所不为的；你一个人肯定敌不过他们。”
en: “You are right, captain,” replied Pencroft, his chest swelling with sullen anger.“You are right; they will do all they can to retake the corral, which they know to be well stored; and alone you could not hold it against them.”

zh: “唉，要是我们在‘花岗石宫’就好了！”
en: “Oh, if we were only at Granite House!”

zh: “要是我们在‘花岗石宫’的话，”工程师说，“情形就不一样了。在那儿，我就不用担心把赫伯特留给一个人照顾，而让另外三个人去荒岛上的森林里搜寻了。可是现在我们是在畜栏，最好还是呆在这儿，直到我们大伙儿能一块儿离开的时候再说。”
en: “If we were at Granite House,” answered the engineer, “the case would be very different.There I should not be afraid to leave Herbert with one, while the other three went to search the forests of the island.But we are at the corral, and it is best to stay here until we can leave it together.”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁的分析无可辩驳，他的同伴们非常明白这一点。
en: Cyrus Harding’s reasoning was unanswerable, and his companions understood it well.

zh: “要是艾尔顿还在的话多好！”吉迪恩·史佩莱说，“可怜的家伙！他回到集体中间生活不过是这么短的一段时间。”
en: “If only Ayrton was still one of us!” said Gideon Spilett.“Poor fellow! his return to social life will have been but of short duration.”

zh: “谁说他一定死了。”潘克洛夫用一种古怪的腔调补充了一句。
en: “If he is dead,” added Pencroft, in a peculiar tone.

zh: “那么，潘克洛夫，你是希望那帮恶棍没有把他杀了？”吉迪恩·史佩莱说。
en: “Do you hope, then, Pencroft, that the villains have spared him?” asked Gideon Spilett.

zh: “如果对他们有利，他们不会杀死他的。”
en: “Yes, if they had any interest in doing so.”

zh: “什么！你认为艾尔顿一看见过去的同伴，就忘记了我们对他所做的一切……”
en: “What! you suppose that Ayrton finding his old companions, forgetting all that he owes us—”

zh: “谁知道是不是呢？”水手也觉得自己的这个假设可耻，吞吞吐吐地说不出口。
en: “Who knows?” answered the sailor, who did not hazard this shameful supposition without hesitating.

zh: “潘克洛夫，”哈丁拉住水手的胳膊说，“那是你的一个坏念头，如果你坚持这样说，我会很难过的。我敢为艾尔顿的忠诚打包票。”
en: “Pencroft,” said Harding, taking the sailor’s arm, “that is a wicked idea of yours, and you will distress me much if you persist in speaking thus.I will answer for Ayrton’s fidelity.”

zh: “我也敢。”通讯记者很快跟着说。
en: “And I also,” added the reporter quickly.

zh: “好吧，好吧，队长，我错了，”潘克洛夫说，“这确实是我的一个坏念头，什么根据都没有。可是我能怎么做呀？我现在晕头转向的。困在畜栏这儿快把我烦死了，我从没像现在这样心烦意乱过。”
en: “Yes, yes, captain, I was wrong,” replied Pencroft; “it was a wicked idea indeed that I had, and nothing justifies it.But what can I do?I’m not in my senses.This imprisonment in the corral wearies me horribly, and I have never felt so excited as I do now.

zh: “耐心一点，潘克洛夫。”工程师说，“亲爱的史佩莱，你觉得还要再过多久才能把赫伯特送回‘花岗石宫’去呢？”
en: “Be patient, Pencroft,” replied the engineer.“How long will it be, my dear Spilett, before you think Herbert may be carried to Granite House?”

zh: “那个很难说，赛勒斯，”通讯记者回答，“因为稍一大意，就可能造成严重后果。不过他在慢慢好起来，如果他的体力继续恢复的话，那么从现在算起，再过八天——好了，我们再等等看吧。”
en: “That is difficult to say, Cyrus,” answered the reporter, “for any imprudence might involve terrible consequences.But his convalescence is progressing, and if he continues to gain strength, in eight days from now—well, we shall see.”

zh: 八天！移民们回花岗石宫的日子会因此推迟到12月初。现在春天已经过去两个月了。天气很好，气温也升得很高了。岛上森林里的树木长得枝繁叶茂，马上就到了收获农作物的季节了。因此，等到他们回到眺望岗的高地，除了按照计划对全岛进行一次探险以外，剩下的就是干繁重的农活了。
en: Eight days!That would put off the return to Granite House until the first days of December.At this time two months of spring had already passed.The weather was fine, and the heat began to be great.The forests of the island were in full leaf, and the time was approaching when the usual crops ought to be gathered.The return to the plateau of Prospect Heights would, therefore, be followed by extensive agricultural labors, interrupted only by the projected expedition through the island.

zh: 因此，完全可以看出来，对移民们来说，这样困在畜栏里对他们损失非常大。
en: It can, therefore, be well understood how injurious this seclusion in the corral must have been to the colonists.

zh: 他们现在不得不在现实的需要面前低头，然而他们的内心非常焦急。
en: But if they were compelled to bow before necessity, they did not do so without impatience.

zh: 有一两次，通讯记者冒险到路上去，巡视一下栅栏周围。托普跟着他，吉迪恩·史佩莱扣着扳机，一有紧急情况就随时开枪。
en: Once or twice the reporter ventured out into the road and made the tour of the palisade.Top accompanied him, and Gideon Spilett, his gun cocked, was ready for any emergency.

zh: 他没有遭遇什么意外，也没有发现任何可疑的迹象。如果有一点危险，他的狗也会警告他。既然托普没有叫，就可以因此下结论，至少此刻没有什么值得害怕的，罪犯们可能藏在岛上别的什么地方。
en: He met with no misadventure and found no suspicious traces.His dog would have warned him of any danger, and, as Top did not bark, it might be concluded that there was nothing to fear at the moment at least, and that the convicts were occupied in another part of the island.

zh: 然而，11月27号，吉迪恩·史佩莱第二次巡察时，他向着山的南部，冒险往林子里走了四分之一英里，这时他觉得托普闻到什么了。托普不再是一副漫不经心的样子，他跑前跑后，在野草和灌木丛中间来回穿梭，好像闻到了什么可疑的目标。
en: However, on his second sortie, on the 27th of November, Gideon Spilett, who had ventured a quarter of a mile into the woods, towards the south of the mountain, remarked that Top scented something.The dog had no longer his unconcerned manner; he went backwards and forwards, ferreting among the grass and bushes as if his smell had revealed some suspicious object to him.

zh: 吉迪恩·史佩莱一边跟着它，鼓励它，用自己的声音使它兴奋，一边高度警惕着四周，藏在一棵树后，准备随时开枪。托普不可能闻到了人的气味，不然，他早就阴沉沉地低声怒吼了。现在它没有发出吼叫声，可见附近并没有危险，也没有危险即将到来的迹象。
en: Gideon Spilett followed Top, encouraged him, excited him by his voice, while keeping a sharp look-out, his gun ready to fire, and sheltering himself behind the trees.It was not probable that Top scented the presence of man, for in that case, he would have announced it by half-uttered, sullen, angry barks.Now, as he did not growl, it was because danger was neither near nor approaching.

zh: 这样将近过了五分钟，托普还在四处翻找着，通讯记者小心地跟在后面，突然，托普向一处长势茂盛的灌木丛冲去，从里面叼出一块破布。
en: Nearly five minutes passed thus, Top rummaging, the reporter following him prudently when, all at once, the dog rushed towards a thick bush, and drew out a rag.

zh: 这块布上面沾着污迹，破破烂烂的，史佩莱立即把它带回畜栏。移民们仔细地检查了破布，发现这是从艾尔顿的马甲上撕下来的一块毛毡，是花岗石宫工厂生产出来的独一无二的产品。
en: It was a piece of cloth, stained and torn, which Spilett immediately brought back to the corral.There it was examined by the colonists, who found that it was a fragment of Ayrton’s waistcoat, a piece of that felt, manufactured solely by the Granite House factory.

zh: “你看，潘克洛夫，”哈丁说，“可怜的艾尔顿反抗过。罪犯们硬把他拖走了！现在你还怀疑他的忠诚吗？”
en: “You see, Pencroft,” observed Harding, “there has been resistance on the part of the unfortunate Ayrton.The convicts have dragged him away in spite of himself!Do you still doubt his honesty?”

zh: “不，队长，”水手回答，“我早就为我对他的怀疑感到懊悔了！不过，我觉得从这件事中，可以知道点什么。”
en: “No, captain,” answered the sailor, “and I repented of my suspicion a long time ago!But it seems to me that something may be learned from the incident.”

zh: “什么？”通讯记者问。
en: “What is that?” asked the reporter.

zh: “艾尔顿并没有在畜栏里被杀害！既然他反抗过，那么罪犯们拽着他走的途中，他都一直没有死！因此，或许，他现在还活着！”
en: “It is that Ayrton was not killed at the corral!That they dragged him away living, since he has resisted.Therefore, perhaps, he is still living!”

zh: “的确，这有可能。”一直沉思的工程师说。
en: “Perhaps, indeed,” replied the engineer, who remained thoughtful.

zh: 艾尔顿的同伴们现在可以抱着这个希望了。确实，他们之前都相信，艾尔顿在畜栏里遭到突袭后，像赫伯特那样被一枪打倒了。但是如果罪犯们一开始没有杀他，如果他们把他活着带到到岛上其他的什么地方，那么是不是可以认为他现在还是他们的俘虏呢？甚至，或许罪犯当中有一个认出了艾尔顿是逃犯头目，澳洲人本·乔伊斯的昔日同伙。谁知道他们会不会妄想让艾尔顿再回到他们当中去呢？如果能让他叛变，他将对他们很有用处的。
en: This was a hope, to which Ayrton’s companions could still hold.Indeed, they had before believed that, surprised in the corral, Ayrton had fallen by a bullet, as Herbert had fallen.But if the convicts had not killed him at first, if they had brought him living to another part of the island, might it not be admitted that he was still their prisoner?Perhaps, even, one of them had found in Ayrton his old Australian companion Ben Joyce, the chief of the escaped convicts.And who knows but that they had conceived the impossible hope of bringing back Ayrton to themselves?He would have been very useful to them, if they had been able to make him turn traitor!

zh: 畜栏里的移民觉得这件事对他们是有利，找到艾尔顿看起来也不再是件不可能的事了。在艾尔顿这方面来说，如果他只是一个俘虏，那他一定会竭尽所能从那帮混蛋的魔爪里逃出来，到那时，移民就多了一个强大的帮手！
en: This incident was, therefore, favorably interpreted at the corral, and it no longer appeared impossible that they should find Ayrton again.On his side, if he was only a prisoner, Ayrton would no doubt do all he could to escape from the hands of the villains, and this would be a powerful aid to the settlers!

zh: “不管怎样，”吉迪恩·史佩莱说，“要是艾尔顿能侥幸逃出来，他会直接回‘花岗石宫’去，因为他还不知道罪犯们实施的这次让赫伯特受伤的谋杀行动，因此也决不会想到我们会被困在畜栏里。”
