en: “At any rate,” observed Gideon Spilett, “if happily Ayrton did manage to escape, he would go directly to Granite House, for he could not know of the attempted assassination of which Herbert has been a victim, and consequently would never think of our being imprisoned in the corral.”

zh: “嗯。但愿他在那儿，就在‘花岗石宫’里！”潘克洛夫大声说，“但愿我们也在那儿！因为，就算那帮混蛋对我们的屋子做不了什么，可他们能把我们的高地、农场和家禽场洗劫一空呀！”
en: “Oh!I wish that he was there, at Granite House!” cried Pencroft, “and that we were there, too!For, although the rascals can do nothing to our house, they may plunder the plateau, our plantations, our poultry-yard!”

zh: 潘克洛夫已经变成了一个彻头彻尾的庄稼汉，满心系着自己的庄稼。但是，必须说赫伯特比任何人都急切地想回花岗石宫，因为他知道那儿有多么地需要移民。是他把大家困在畜栏里！因此，他满脑子全想着一件事——离开畜栏，什么时候离开？他相信自己经得起从这儿到花岗石宫的旅途颠簸。他深信在自己那间能够看到大海，闻到海的气息的房间里，他的体力会恢复得更快的！
en: Pencroft had become a thorough farmer, heartily attached to his crops.But it must be said that Herbert was more anxious than any to return to Granite House, for he knew how much the presence of the settlers was needed there.And it was he who was keeping them at the corral!Therefore, one idea occupied his mind—to leave the corral, and when!He believed he could bear removal to Granite House.He was sure his strength would return more quickly in his room, with the air and sight of the sea!

zh: 他催了吉迪恩·史佩莱好几次，然而史佩莱始终没有决定动身，他的理由很充分，因为赫伯特的伤口才刚刚好了一半，怕在途中再次裂开。
en: Several times he pressed Gideon Spilett, but the latter, fearing, with good reason, that Herbert’s wounds, half healed, might reopen on the way, did not give the order to start.

zh: 然而，赛勒斯·哈丁和他的两个同伴最终因为发生的一件事情听从了孩子的意愿，只有上帝知道这个决定可能带给他们伤心与懊悔。
en: However, something occurred which compelled Cyrus Harding and his two friends to yield to the lad’s wish, and God alone knew that this determination might cause them grief and remorse.

zh: 那是11月29号，晚上七点钟。三个移民正在赫伯特的房间里交谈，这时，他们听见了赫伯特急促的叫声。
en: It was the 29th of November, seven o’clock in the evening.The three settlers were talking in Herbert’s room, when they heard Top utter quick barks.

zh: 哈丁、潘克洛夫和史佩莱抓起他们的枪就往屋外面跑。托普在栅栏底下又蹦又叫，不过它看起来是因为高兴，而不是生气。
en: Harding, Pencroft, and Spilett seized their guns and ran out of the house.Top, at the foot of the palisade, was jumping, barking, but it was with pleasure, not anger.

zh: “有人来了！”
en: “Some one is coming.”
“Yes.”

zh: “不是敌人！”
en: “It is not an enemy!”

zh: “或许是纳布？”
en: “Neb, perhaps?”

zh: “是不是艾尔顿呢？”
en: “Or Ayrton?”

zh: 还没等工程师和同伴们把话说完，一个身体就越过栅栏，落进了畜栏里。
en: These words had hardly been exchanged between the engineer and his two companions when a body leaped over the palisade and fell on the ground inside the corral.

zh: 原来是贾普，贾普亲自来了，托普立即向它表示最热情的欢迎。
en: It was Jup, Master Jup in person, to whom Top immediately gave a most cordial reception.

zh: “贾普！”潘克洛夫叫道。
en: “Jup!” exclaimed Pencroft.

zh: “是纳布派它来找我们的。”通讯记者说。
en: “Neb has sent him to us,” said the reporter.

zh: “那么，”工程师接着说，“它身上一定带着什么纸条。”
en: “Then,” replied the engineer, “he must have some note on him.”

zh: 潘克洛夫赶紧跑到猩猩身边。当然，如果纳布要告诉主人什么重要的事情，没有比贾普更快速、更让人放心的信使了，移民们，甚至托普都没法经过的地方，它都能走过去。
en: Pencroft rushed up to the orang.Certainly if Neb had any important matter to communicate to his master he could not employ a more sure or more rapid messenger, who could pass where neither the colonists could, nor even Top himself.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁说得没错。贾普的脖子上绑着一个小袋子，里面装着纳布写的一张小纸条。
en: Cyrus Harding was not mistaken.At Jup’s neck hung a small bag, and in this bag was found a little note traced by Neb’s hand.

zh: 当哈丁和同伴们看到下面这些话后，可想而知，他们有多绝望：
en: The despair of Harding and his companions may be imagined when they read these words:—

zh: “星期五，早上六点钟。
en: “Friday, six o’clock in the morning.

zh: “高地遭到罪犯侵略。
en: “Plateau invaded by convicts.

zh: 纳布。”
en: “Neb.”

zh: 大家你看看我，我看看你，一句话也没说，然后又进了屋子。他们该怎么做呢？罪犯们在眺望岗！那意味着灾难、劫掠、毁灭！
en: They gazed at each other without uttering a word, then they re-entered the house. what were they to do?The convicts on Prospect Heights! that was disaster, devastation, ruin.

zh: 赫伯特一看见工程师、通讯记者和潘克洛夫又进来了，就猜到他们的处境可能变坏了，当看到贾普时，他确信花岗石宫遭遇了什么不幸的威胁。
en: Herbert, on seeing the engineer, the reporter, and Pencroft re-enter, guessed that their situation was aggravated, and when he saw Jup, he no longer doubted that some misfortune menaced Granite House.

zh: “哈丁队长，”他说，“我必须要离开；我经得起路上的颠簸劳累。我必须要离开。”
en: “Captain Harding,” said he, “I must go; I can bear the journey.I must go.”

zh: 吉迪恩·史佩莱走到赫伯特身边，看了看他，然后说道：
en: Gideon Spilett approached Herbert; then, having looked at him,—

zh: “那么我们现在就动身！”
en: “Let us go, then!” said he.

zh: 至于说把赫伯特放在担架上抬着还是放进艾尔顿驾来的马车里，大家很快作出了决定。把受伤的孩子放在担架上抬着可能对他来说更轻松一些，不过那样得要要两个人抬担架，如果移民们在路上遭遇袭击的话，就又少了两支枪来防卫。相反，他们为什么不用大车，从而把所有人手都腾出来呢？他们可以把赫伯特现在铺的垫子铺在车里，小心翼翼地前进，这样大车不是就不会颠簸了吗？这是可以办到的。
en: The question was quickly decided whether Herbert should be carried on a litter or in the cart which had brought Ayrton to the corral.The motion of the litter would have been more easy for the wounded lad, but it would have necessitated two bearers, that is to say, there would have been two guns less for defense if an attack was made on the road.Would they not, on the contrary, by employing the cart leave every arm free?Was it impossible to place the mattress on which Herbert was lying in it, and to advance with so much care that any jolt should be avoided?It could be done.

zh: 大车拉过来了。潘克洛夫给野驴套上挽具。赛勒斯·哈丁和通讯记者把赫伯特连同垫子一块儿抬起来，放在大车最里面。天气很好。明媚的太阳光从树丛中斑驳射过。
en: The cart was brought.Pencroft harnessed the onager.Cyrus Harding and the reporter raised Herbert’s mattress and placed it on the bottom of the cart.The weather was fine.The sun’s bright rays glanced through the trees.

zh: “拿好枪了吗？”赛勒斯·哈丁问。
en: “Are the guns ready?” asked Cyrus Harding.

zh: 每个人都准备好了。工程师和潘克洛夫各自带着一支双管枪，吉迪恩·史佩莱扛着他的步枪，大家都只等着出发了。
en: They were.The engineer and Pencroft, each armed with a double-barreled gun, and Gideon Spilett carrying his rifle, had nothing to do but start.

zh: “你舒服吗，赫伯特？”工程师问。
en: “Are you comfortable, Herbert?” asked the engineer.

zh: “啊，队长，”孩子回答，“放心吧，我不会死在路上的！”
en: “Ah, captain,” replied the lad, “don’t be uneasy, I shall not die on the road!”

zh: 看得出来，可怜的孩子一面这样说，一面聚集起所有的力量，靠着坚强的意志力，让他虚弱的身体振作起来。
en: While speaking thus, it could be seen that the poor boy had called up all his energy, and by the energy of a powerful will had collected his failing strength.

zh: 工程师感到心里一阵难受。他还犹豫着要不要下令出发；然而那样会把赫伯特推向绝望——也许会杀了他。
en: The engineer felt his heart sink painfully.He still hesitated to give the signal for departure; but that would have driven Herbert to despair—killed him perhaps.

zh: “走吧！”哈丁说。
en: “Forward!” said Harding.

zh: 畜栏的门打开了。贾普和托普懂得什么时候该保持沉默，他们跑在前面。大车出来后，门关上了，潘克洛夫牵着驴，慢慢地往前走去。
en: The gate of the corral was opened.Jup and Top, who knew when to be silent, ran in advance.The cart came out, the gate was reclosed, and the onager, led by Pencroft, advanced at a slow pace.

zh: 如果大家不选择从畜栏直接通往花岗石宫的这条小路，而是走另外一条路，当然会安全一些，不过，驴车却会碰上更大的困难，不得不从树底下穿过去。因此，尽管罪犯们对这条路了如指掌，大家还是得沿着原路前进。
en: Certainly, it would have been safer to have taken a different road than that which led straight from the corral to Granite House, but the cart would have met with great difficulties in moving under the trees.It was necessary, therefore, to follow this way, although it was well known to the convicts.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和吉迪恩·史佩莱一人走在车的一边，准备一遇到袭击，就随时反击。然而，罪犯们不可能已经离开了眺望岗高地。
en: Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett walked one on each side of the cart, ready to answer to any attack.However, it was not probable that the convicts would have yet left the plateau of Prospect Heights.

zh: 很明显，罪犯们一在那儿出现，纳布就写好纸条送过来了。纸条上写的时间是早上六点钟。机灵的猩猩习惯了经常来畜栏，几乎不出四十五分钟，就能从五英里以外的花岗石宫赶过来。因此，他们在路上不会遇到什么危险，如果要开枪，大概也是到了花岗石宫附近的时候。然而，移民们都保持着高度警惕。贾普拿着棍子，和托普时而走在前面，时而钻进路旁的林子里探索，没有发出什么表示危险的信号。
en: Neb’s note had evidently been written and sent as soon as the convicts had shown themselves there.Now, this note was dated six o’clock in the morning, and the active orang, accustomed to come frequently to the corral, had taken scarcely three quarters of an hour to cross the five miles which separated it from Granite House.They would, therefore, be safe at that time, and if there was any occasion for firing, it would probably not be until they were in the neighborhood of Granite House.However, the colonists kept a strict watch.Top and Jup, the latter armed with his club, sometimes in front, sometimes beating the wood at the sides of the road, signalized no danger.

zh: 潘克洛夫驾着马车缓慢地前进着。他们是七点半离开畜栏的。一个钟头后，他们已经走了四英里，路上没有发生任何事故。路上静悄悄的，跟慈悲河和格兰特湖之间的那整片啄木鸟森林没什么两样。没有什么值得警惕的。森林还像移民们刚到荒岛上那天一样死寂。
en: The cart advanced slowly under Pencroft’s guidance.It had left the corral at half-past seven.An hour after, four out of the five miles had been cleared, without any incident having occurred.The road was as deserted as all that part of the Jacamar Wood which lay between the Mercy and the lake.There was no occasion for any warning.The wood appeared as deserted as on the day when the colonists first landed on the island.

zh: 他们就快到高地了。再走一英里，就能看见甘油河上的吊桥了。赛勒斯·哈丁猜测吊桥还在原来的地方；假使罪犯们过了桥，渡过包围高地的小溪，他们会采取预防措施，再把吊桥放下来，以便留条后路。
en: They approached the plateau.Another mile and they would see the bridge over Creek Glycerine.Cyrus Harding expected to find it in its place; supposing that the convicts would have crossed it, and that, after having passed one of the streams which enclosed the plateau, they would have taken the precaution to lower it again, so as to keep open a retreat.

zh: 终于，从树木间的一个空隙可以看见海平面了。但驴车继续前进着，护送它的人谁也不想把它抛弃。
en: At length an opening in the trees allowed the sea-horizon to be seen.But the cart continued its progress, for not one of its defenders thought of abandoning it.

zh: 这时潘克洛夫突然勒住了野驴，用粗哑的嗓音叫道：
en: At that moment Pencroft stopped the onager, and in a hoarse voice,—

zh: “啊！这帮混蛋！”
en: “Oh! the villains!” he exclaimed.

zh: 他指着从磨坊、棚屋和家禽场的屋舍升起的一团浓烟。
en: And he pointed to a thick smoke rising from the mill, the sheds, and the buildings at the poultry-yard.

zh: 一个人在烟雾中慢慢移动着。那是纳布。
en: A man was moving about in the midst of the smoke.It was Neb.

zh: 他的同伴们喊了一声。他听见了，朝大家跑过来。
en: His companions uttered a shout.He heard, and ran to meet them.

zh: 罪犯们破坏了高地，差不多半小时前已经离开了。
en: The convicts had left the plateau nearly half-an-hour before, having devastated it!

zh: “赫伯特呢？”纳布问。
en: “And Mr. Herbert?” asked Neb.

zh: 吉迪恩·史佩莱回到马车旁边来。
en: Gideon Spilett returned to the cart.

zh: 赫伯特已经昏迷了过去。
en: Herbert had lost consciousness!

zh: 第十章
en: Chapter 10

zh: 殖民者们不再考虑那些罪犯给“花岗岩宫”带来的威胁以及高地上覆盖的废墟。赫伯特危在旦夕，他的状况比其他的事情都重要。这次移动他会不会引发什么致命的内伤呢？通讯记者不敢妄下结论，但是他和他的同伴们对结果几乎已经不抱什么希望了。小车到了河道拐弯的地方。他们用树枝做成了一副担架，然后把不省人事的赫伯特连同垫子一起放在了上面。十分钟以后，赛勒斯·哈丁、史佩莱和潘克洛夫来到了悬崖脚下，留下纳布一个人把车推到眺望岗的高地上去。升降机开始上升，不久赫伯特就躺在了花岗石宫里他自己的床上了。
en: Of the convicts, the dangers which menaced Granite House, the ruins with which the plateau was covered, the colonists thought no longer.Herbert’s critical state outweighed all other considerations.Would the removal prove fatal to him by causing some internal injury?The reporter could not affirm it, but he and his companions almost despaired of the result.The cart was brought to the bend of the river.There some branches, disposed as a liner, received the mattress on which lay the unconscious Herbert.Ten minutes after, Cyrus Harding, Spilett, and Pencroft were at the foot of the cliff, leaving Neb to take the cart on to the plateau of Prospect Heights.The lift was put in motion, and Herbert was soon stretched on his bed in Granite House.

zh: 他们花了多少工夫才使他苏醒过来！他醒来时发现躺在自己的房间里不禁露出了笑容，但是因为太过虚弱，他想低声说句话都力不从心。吉迪恩·史佩莱检查了他原本就没有完全愈合的伤口。他怕它们再度破裂。所幸他的担心是多余的。由此看来，他怎么会出现虚脱的现象呢？赫伯特的病情怎么会恶化到这种地步呢？这时，少年由于高烧而昏睡了过去，通讯记者和潘克洛夫一直守在他的床边。这期间，哈丁把畜栏里发生的事情原原本本地告诉了纳布，纳布也向他的主人讲述了高地上出现的状况。
en: What cares were lavished on him to bring him back to life!He smiled for a moment on finding himself in his room, but could scarcely even murmur a few words, so great was his weakness.Gideon Spilett examined his wounds.He feared to find them reopened, having been imperfectly healed.There was nothing of the sort.From whence, then, came this prostration? why was Herbert so much worse?The lad then fell into a kind of feverish sleep, and the reporter and Pencroft remained near the bed.During this time, Harding told Neb all that had happened at the corral, and Neb recounted to his master the events of which the plateau had just been the theater.

zh: 那些罪犯只在前一天夜里在森林边上的甘油河附近出现过。当时纳布正在家禽场附近监视，他发现其中的一个海盗正打算渡河，便毫不犹豫地朝他开了一枪。可是，因为周围太黑了，他也不知道有没有打中那个人。无论如何，这一枪是不足以把这伙罪犯吓跑的，纳布刚好来得及爬到花岗石宫里面去，至少在那里他是安全的。
en: It was only during the preceding night that the convicts had appeared on the edge of the forest, at the approaches to Creek Glycerine.Neb, who was watching near the poultry-yard, had not hesitated to fire at one of the pirates, who was about to cross the stream; but in the darkness he could not tell whether the man had been hit or not.At any rate, it was not enough to frighten away the band, and Neb had only just time to get up to Granite House, where at least he was in safety.

zh: 可是，到了那儿，他又能干什么呢？眼瞅着那些罪犯就要破坏高地了，怎么才能阻止他们呢？纳布有没有什么法子通知他的主人呢？另外，畜栏里的人当时处在什么样的状况下呢？赛勒斯·哈丁和他的同伴们在11月11号动身，现在已经是29号了。也就是说，自从纳布得到唯一一条由托普送来的消息到现在，已经19天了。那条坏消息告诉他：艾尔顿失踪了，赫伯特身负重伤，工程师、通讯记者和水手都被困在了畜栏里！
en: But what was he to do there?How prevent the devastations with which the convicts threatened the plateau?Had Neb any means by which to warn his master?And, besides, in what situation were the inhabitants of the corral themselves?Cyrus Harding and his companions had left on the 11th of November, and it was now the 29th.It was, therefore, nineteen days since Neb had had other news than that brought by Top—disastrous news: Ayrton disappeared, Herbert severely wounded, the engineer, reporter, and sailor, as it were, imprisoned in the corral!

zh: 该怎么办呢？可怜的纳布不禁问自己。他并不为自己担心，因为那些罪犯是没法到花岗石宫上来的。可是他们搭建的屋子、种植的作物和所有的布置都要任凭海盗们糟蹋了！要是能让赛勒斯·哈丁来决定应该做什么就好了，至少让他知道可能遇到的危险也好啊。
en: What was he to do? asked poor Neb.Personally he had nothing to fear, for the convicts could not reach him in Granite House.But the buildings, the plantations, all their arrangements at the mercy of the pirates!Would it not be best to let Cyrus Harding judge of what he ought to do, and to warn him, at least, of the danger which threatened him?

zh: 纳布想到可以利用贾普，于是就写了一张字条让它带着。他知道猩猩非常聪明，这一点已经被证实过很多次了。因为他们经常在它面前说起“畜栏”，因此贾普知道这个词的意思，此外，它经常陪着潘克洛夫驾着小车到畜栏去，这一点大家或许还记得。天还没亮。机灵的猩猩会知道如何偷偷地穿过树林的。再者说，就算被罪犯发现了，他们肯定会把它当做一只普通的猩猩罢了。
en: Neb then thought of employing Jup, and confiding a note to him.He knew the orang’s great intelligence, which had been often put to the proof.Jup understood the word corral, which had been frequently pronounced before him, and it may be remembered, too, that he had often driven the cart thither in company with Pencroft.Day had not yet dawned.The active orang would know how to pass unperceived through the woods, of which the convicts, besides, would think he was a native.

zh: 纳布没有犹豫。他写好了字条，把它系在了贾普的脖子上，然后把猩猩带到了花岗石宫的门口，从那儿引出了一根长绳子一直搭到了地面上；然后，他将这几个字重复了好几遍：
en: Neb did not hesitate.He wrote the note, he tied it to Jup’s neck, he brought the ape to the door of Granite House, from which he let down a long cord to the ground; then, several times he repeated these words,—

zh: “贾普，贾普！畜栏，畜栏！”
en: “Jup Jup! corral, corral!”

zh: 猩猩明白了他的意思，抓住绳子，敏捷地滑到了沙滩上，随即消失在黑暗中，没有引起罪犯们的丝毫注意。
en: The creature understood, seized the cord, glided rapidly down the beach, and disappeared in the darkness without the convicts’ attention having been in the least excited.

zh: “你做得很好，纳布，”哈丁说，“但是如果不通知我们，你可能会做得更好！”
en: “You did well, Neb,” said Harding, “but perhaps in not warning us you would have done still better!”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁之所以这么说是因为他想到了赫伯特，这次迁移严重地影响了他的复原。
en: And, in speaking thus, Cyrus Harding thought of Herbert, whose recovery the removal had so seriously checked.

zh: 纳布讲完了。那些罪犯没有在沙滩上出现过。他们摸不清岛上住了多少人，也许他们还以为有一大群人驻守在花岗石宫呢。他们肯定记得，在双桅船发起进攻时，无论是从高处的山石，还是低处的山石，都有很多的枪弹向他们射过来，他们毫无疑问不想暴露他们自己。但眺望岗的高地却是大敞四开的，没有花岗石宫的炮火做掩护。于是，他们爬了上去，肆无忌惮地破坏起来，抢劫、放火、捣毁一切，直到移民们回来之前半小时才离开了那里，当时他们还以为移民们还被困在畜栏里呢。
en: Neb ended his account.The convicts had not appeared at all on the beach.Not knowing the number of the island’s inhabitants, they might suppose that Granite House was defended by a large party.They must have remembered that during the attack by the brig numerous shot had been fired both from the lower and upper rocks, and no doubt they did not wish to expose themselves.But the plateau of Prospect Heights was open to them, and not covered by the fire of Granite House.They gave themselves up, therefore, to their instinct of destruction,—plundering, burning, devastating everything,—and only retiring half an hour before the arrival of the colonists, whom they believed still confined in the corral.

zh: 他们走了之后，纳布急忙跑了出来。他冒着暴露自己甚至中弹的危险，爬上高地，试图扑灭笼罩在家禽场的建筑物上的火焰，虽然没有起到什么作用，但他还是坚持和大火抗争，直到马车出现在森林的边缘处时才停了下来。
en: On their retreat, Neb hurried out.He climbed the plateau at the risk of being perceived and fired at, tried to extinguish the fire which was consuming the buildings of the poultry-yard, and had struggled, though in vain, against it until the cart appeared at the edge of the wood.

zh: 这就是事情前前后后的经过。对于林肯岛上的移民来说，这些罪犯们的存在永远都是一个危险的隐患。一直以来他们都生活在快乐中，可是从现在开始，他们却可能还会遭受更大的不幸。
en: Such had been these serious events.The presence of the convicts constituted a permanent source of danger to the settlers in Lincoln Island, until then so happy, and who might now expect still greater misfortunes.

zh: 史佩莱和赫伯特、潘克洛夫留在花岗石宫里，赛勒斯·哈丁在纳布的陪同之下，要亲自去查看一下这次受灾的程度。
en: Spilett remained in Granite House with Herbert and Pencroft, while Cyrus Harding, accompanied by Neb, proceeded to judge for himself of the extent of the disaster.

zh: 好在罪犯们没有到花岗石宫的脚下来。要不然“石窟”处的工场恐怕就会难逃一劫了。可是即便“石窟”遭到破坏，所受的损失和眺望岗比起来，还是比较容易弥补的。哈丁和纳布朝着慈悲河走去，爬上河的左岸，没有发现罪犯们的任何踪迹，在河的对岸和森林的深处也没有找到任何可疑的迹象。
en: It was fortunate that the convicts had not advanced to the foot of Granite House.The workshop at the Chimneys would in that case not have escaped destruction.But after all, this evil would have been more easily reparable than the ruins accumulated on the plateau of Prospect Heights.Harding and Neb proceeded towards the Mercy, and ascended its left bank without meeting with any trace of the convicts; nor on the other side of the river, in the depths of the wood, could they perceive any suspicious indications.

zh: 如此看来，他们大致有了两种推断，一种是在花岗石宫的移民们走在从畜栏回来的路上时，被罪犯们发现了；另一种推断是在罪犯们破坏了高地之后，他们就沿着慈悲河，进入啄木鸟林深处，因此没有注意到移民们回来了。
en: Besides, it might be supposed that in all probability either the convicts knew of the return of the settlers to Granite House, by having seen them pass on the road from the corral, or, after the devastation of the plateau, they had penetrated into Jacamar Wood, following the course of the Mercy, and were thus ignorant of their return.

zh: 如果第一种推断成立，那么他们肯定又回到畜栏那边去了，因为现在那儿没有人防守，却有很多宝贵的东西。
en: In the former case, they must have returned towards the corral, now without defenders, and which contained valuable stores.

zh: 如果第二种推断是真的，那么他们肯定回到了他们安身的地方，在那儿伺机再次发动进攻。
en: In the latter, they must have regained their encampment, and would wait on opportunity to recommence the attack.

zh: 因此，要防范他们并不是不可能的。但是任何进一步肃清岛上罪犯的计划现在都因为赫伯特的病情变得很困难。的确，以他们的全部力量，勉强能应付这伙罪犯，可是眼下谁也不能离开花岗石宫。
en: It was, therefore, possible to prevent them, but any enterprise to clear the island was now rendered difficult by reason of Herbert’s condition.Indeed, their whole force would have been barely sufficient to cope with the convicts, and just now no one could leave Granite House.

zh: 工程师和纳布到了高地。到处都是一片荒凉的景象。田地都被践踏了，眼看即将颗粒饱满的麦穗倒在地上。其他的作物也遭到了同样的破坏。
en: The engineer and Neb arrived on the plateau.Desolation reigned everywhere.The fields had been trampled over; the ears of wheat, which were nearly full-grown, lay on the ground.The other plantations had not suffered less.

zh: 菜园也被破坏了。所幸他们可以依靠花岗石宫里保存的一些种子弥补这次的损失。
en: The kitchen-garden was destroyed.Happily, Granite House possessed a store of seed which would enable them to repair these misfortunes.

zh: 大火烧毁了家禽场的围墙和建筑物以及驴棚。一些受惊的动物在高地上走来走去。着火时躲在湖面上的飞禽已经回到了它们已经习惯了的地方，在河岸边戏水。一切都需要重新建设。
en: As to the wall and buildings of the poultry-yard and the onagers stable, the fire had destroyed all.A few terrified creatures roamed over the plateau.The birds, which during the fire had taken refuge on the waters of the lake, had already returned to their accustomed spot, and were dabbling on the banks.Everything would have to be reconstructed.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁的脸色比平日苍白了不少，此时他很难按捺心中的怒火，可是他一句话也没有说。他又看了看被破坏了的田地和废墟处还在冒着的烟，然后回花岗石宫去了。
en: Cyrus Harding’s face, which was paler than usual, expressed an internal anger which he commanded with difficulty, but he did not utter a word.Once more he looked at his devastated fields, and at the smoke which still rose from the ruins, then he returned to Granite House.

zh: 接下来的几天是移民们在这荒岛上所度过的最为悲痛的日子了！赫伯特显然变得更加虚弱。他经历的严重的生理失调留下了后患，一种更为严重的疾病正在威胁着他的状况。吉迪恩·史佩莱担心赫伯特已经没有足够的力气和不断恶化的病情作斗争！
en: The following days were the saddest of any that the colonists had passed on the island!Herbert’s weakness visibly increased.It appeared that a more serious malady, the consequence of the profound physiological disturbance he had gone through, threatened to declare itself, and Gideon Spilett feared such an aggravation of his condition that he would be powerless to fight against it!

zh: 事实上，赫伯特一直处在持续的近乎昏迷的状态中，并开始出现了神经错乱的症状。移民们手头唯一的药品就是清凉的饮料。目前他烧得还不是很严重，可是过不了多久，他可能每隔一段时间就会发热。12月6号那天，吉迪恩·史佩莱第一次发现了这种状况。
en: In fact, Herbert remained in an almost continuous state of drowsiness, and symptoms of delirium began to manifest themselves.Refreshing drinks were the only remedies at the colonists’ disposal.The fever was not as yet very high, but it soon appeared that it would probably recur at regular intervals.Gideon Spilett first recognized this on the 6th of December.

zh: 可怜的少年,他的手指、鼻子和耳朵已经变得惨白，起初他的身体只是微微颤抖，浑身起了鸡皮疙瘩，还在哆嗦。他的脉搏微弱而不规则，皮肤特别干燥，口渴的状况也在不断加剧。后来很快来了一阵痉挛；他的脸开始发热，浑身通红，脉搏加快，然后在出了一身大汗之后，热度好像也随之降了下来。这一阵发作持续了差不多五个钟头。
en: The poor boy, whose fingers, nose, and ears had become extremely pale, was at first seized with slight shiverings, horripilations, and tremblings.His pulse was weak and irregular, his skin dry, his thirst intense.To this soon succeeded a hot fit; his face became flushed; his skin reddened; his pulse quick; then a profuse perspiration broke out after which the fever seemed to diminish.The attack had lasted nearly five hours.

zh: 吉迪恩·史佩莱一直都没有离开赫伯特，很明显赫伯特染上了间歇热。必须不惜一切代价，在他病情恶化之前，医治好他的高烧。
en: Gideon Spilett had not left Herbert, who, it was only too certain, was now seized by an intermittent fever, and this fever must be cured at any cost before it should assume a more serious aspect.

zh: “要想把他的病治好，”史佩莱对赛勒斯·哈丁说，“我们需要找到退热药。”
en: “And in order to cure it,” said Spilett to Cyrus Harding, “we need a febrifuge.”

zh: “退热药……”工程师回答道，“可是我们既没有奎宁皮，也没有硫酸奎宁啊。”
en: “A febrifuge—” answered the engineer.“We have neither Peruvian bark, nor sulphate of quinine.”

zh: “不错，”吉迪恩·史佩莱说，“不过湖边有很多柳树，说不定我们可以用柳树皮替代奎宁皮。”
en: “No,” said Gideon Spilett, “but there are willows on the border of the lake, and the bark of the willow might, perhaps, prove to be a substitute for quinine.”

zh: “那我们抓紧时间赶快试试吧。”赛勒斯·哈丁回答。
en: “Let us try it without losing a moment,” replied Cyrus Harding.

zh: 的确，柳树皮和七叶树皮、冬青树叶、蛇根草等，已经被合理地当做了奎宁皮的代用品。虽然它不像奎宁皮那么名贵，但显然很有必要试一试。因为他们没有办法提取它的精华，只好不经过加工就拿来直接使用。
en: The bark of the willow has, indeed, been justly considered as a succedaneum for Peruvian bark, as has also that of the horse-chestnut tree, the leaf of the holly, the snake-root, etc.It was evidently necessary to make trial of this substance, although not so valuable as Peruvian bark, and to employ it in its natural state, since they had no means for extracting its essence.

zh: 赛勒斯·史密斯从一种黑柳树上削下了几片树皮，带回到花岗石宫，把它们捣成碎末，当天晚上就让赫伯特吃了下去。
en: Cyrus Harding went himself to cut from the trunk of a species of black willow, a few pieces of bark; he brought them back to Granite House, and reduced them to a powder, which was administered that same evening to Herbert.

zh: 这一夜过去了，没有出现什么重大的变化。赫伯特的神志有些昏迷，可是夜里没有再次发烧，第二天体温也没有升高。
en: The night passed without any important change.Herbert was somewhat delirious, but the fever did not reappear in the night, and did not return either during the following day.

zh: 潘克洛夫的心中再一次出现了希望。吉迪恩·史佩莱什么也没有说。也许他并不是每天都发烧，而是要隔一天发作一次,可能下一天就会再一次发作。因此，他心急火燎地等待着下一天的到来。
en: Pencroft again began to hope.Gideon Spilett said nothing.It might be that the fever was not quotidian, but tertian, and that it would return next day.Therefore, he awaited the next day with the greatest anxiety.

zh: 有一点可以看得出来，在这段时间里，赫伯特完全陷入了虚脱状态，他的头部无力且眩晕。另一个症状使通讯记者惊恐万分。赫伯特的肝脏开始充血了，而且很快他的神志更加不清醒，显然他的大脑也受到了影响。
en: It might have been remarked besides that during this period Herbert remained utterly prostrate, his head weak and giddy.Another symptom alarmed the reporter to the highest degree.Herbert’s liver became congested, and soon a more intense delirium showed that his brain was also affected.

zh: 吉迪恩·史佩莱对这个新的并发症毫无对策。他把工程师拉到一旁。
en: Gideon Spilett was overwhelmed by this new complication.He took the engineer aside.

zh: “这是一种恶性疟疾。”他说。
en: “It is a malignant fever,” said he.

zh: “恶性疟疾！”哈丁叫道，“你弄错了，史佩莱。恶性疟疾是不可能自己产生的，一定要事先有这种病菌的存在才能发病。”
en: “A malignant fever!” cried Harding.“You are mistaken, Spilett.A malignant fever does not declare itself spontaneously; its germ must previously have existed.”

zh: “我没弄错，”通讯记者说，“赫伯特肯定是在荒岛的沼泽地带感染上这种病菌的。他已经发作了一次；如果他再发作一次，而我们又没有办法阻止第三次发作，他就没救了。”
en: “I am not mistaken,” replied the reporter.“Herbert no doubt contracted the germ of this fever in the marshes of the island.He has already had one attack; should a second come on and should we not be able to prevent a third, he is lost.”

zh: “可是柳树皮不管用吗？”
en: “But the willow bark?”

zh: “那不顶用，”通讯记者回答，“如果不用奎宁，恶性疟疾的第三次发作通常都是致命的。”
en: “That is insufficient,” answered the reporter, “and the third attack of a malignant fever, which is not arrested by means of quinine, is always fatal.”

zh: 幸亏潘克洛夫没有听到他们的谈话，否则他一定会疯了。
en: Fortunately, Pencroft heard nothing of this conversation or he would have gone mad.

zh: 可以想象得出，12月7号白天和接下来的一整夜，工程师和通讯记者心里会有多么着急。
en: It may be imagined what anxiety the engineer and the reporter suffered during the day of the 7th of December and the following night.

zh: 将近中午的时候，恶性疟疾第二次发作。这次发病相当可怕。赫伯特觉得自己瘫痪下去了。他把胳膊伸向赛勒斯·哈丁，伸向史佩莱，伸向潘克洛夫。他还这么年轻，怎么能就这样死去！这个场面实在是令人心碎。他们只好把潘克洛夫打发到别的地方去。
en: Towards the middle of the day the second attack came on.The crisis was terrible.Herbert felt himself sinking.He stretched his arms towards Cyrus Harding, towards Spilett, towards Pencroft.He was so young to die!The scene was heart-rending.They were obliged to send Pencroft away.

zh: 痉挛持续了五个钟头。赫伯特显然已经经不起第三次发作了。
en: The fit lasted five hours.It was evident that Herbert could not survive a third.

zh: 这一夜是如此可怕。在神志昏迷时，赫伯特含含糊糊地说了几句话，听得他的同伴们心都碎了。他和罪犯们斗争，叫唤着艾尔顿，不断地恳求那个神秘的人——那个强大却不知名的保卫者——他的形象已经印在了赫伯特的脑海里。说完他耗尽了体力，又一次陷入了虚脱状态。有几次吉迪恩·史佩莱以为这个可怜的少年已经死了。
en: The night was frightful.In his delirium Herbert uttered words which went to the hearts of his companions.He struggled with the convicts, he called to Ayrton, he poured forth entreaties to that mysterious being,—that powerful unknown protector,—whose image was stamped upon his mind; then he again fell into a deep exhaustion which completely prostrated him.Several times Gideon Spilett thought that the poor boy was dead.

zh: 第二天是12月8号，一整天赫伯特都处在昏迷的痉挛状态中。他那骨瘦如柴的双手紧紧地抓着床单。他们又给他吃了一些捣碎的树皮，可通讯记者对此并没有报什么希望。
en: The next day, the 8th of December, was but a succession of the fainting fits.Herbert’s thin hands clutched the sheets.They had administered further doses of pounded bark, but the reporter expected no result from it.

zh: “如果明天早上之前我们还没有给他找到更为有效的退热药，”通讯记者说，“赫伯特就死定了。”
en: “If before tomorrow morning we have not given him a more energetic febrifuge,” said the reporter, “Herbert will be dead.”

zh: 夜幕降临了——这恐怕是这个善良、勇敢、聪明的少年的最后一个晚上了。以他的年纪来说，他在各个方面都很出众，大家都像对待自己的孩子一样爱护着他。唯一能够治疗这种可怕的恶性疟疾的药品，唯一能够战胜疾病的特效药，在这个林肯岛上却是找不到的。
en: Night arrived—the last night, it was too much to be feared, of the good, brave, intelligent boy, so far in advance of his years, and who was loved by all as their own child.The only remedy which existed against this terrible malignant fever, the only specific which could overcome it, was not to be found in Lincoln Island.

zh: 12月8号夜里，赫伯特精神错乱得更加严重。他的肝脏充血已经达到可怕的程度，大脑也受到了感染，他已经认不出任何一个人了。
en: During the night of the 8th of December, Herbert was seized by a more violent delirium.His liver was fearfully congested, his brain affected, and already it was impossible for him to recognize any one.

zh: 等到病情第三次发作时，病魔肯定会把他带走的，他还能活到第二天吗？恐怕不能了。他的体力已经耗尽了，在发烧的间歇期间，他像个死人一样躺在那里。
en: Would he live until the next day, until that third attack which must infallibly carry him off?It was not probable.His strength was exhausted, and in the intervals of fever he lay as one dead.

zh: 夜里将近三点的时候，赫伯特发出一声尖叫。他的身体好像要被极度的痉挛撕裂了似的。纳布当时离他不远，听到他的叫声吓了一跳，赶忙跑到他的同伴们所在的房间。
en: Towards three o’clock in the morning Herbert uttered a piercing cry.He seemed to be torn by a supreme convulsion.Neb, who was near him, terrified, ran into the next room where his companions were watching.

zh: 这时，托普也莫名其妙地大叫起来。
en: Top, at that moment, barked in a strange manner.

zh: 所有人急忙冲进屋去，试图让这个垂死的少年平静下来。这时赫伯特快要滚下了床，史佩莱抓住他的胳膊，感到他的脉搏正在逐渐加快。
en: All rushed in immediately and managed to restrain the dying boy, who was endeavoring to throw himself out of his bed, while Spilett, taking his arm, felt his pulse gradually quicken.

zh: 当时是清晨五点。正在升起的太阳开始照进花岗石宫的窗户。它预示着这将会是一个晴朗的日子，然而，这却是可怜的赫伯特的最后一天了！
en: It was five in the morning.The rays of the rising sun began to shine in at the windows of Granite House.It promised to be a fine day, and this day was to be poor Herbert’s last!

zh: 一束阳光照在床边的桌子上。
en: A ray glanced on the table placed near the bed.

zh: 突然，潘克洛夫手指着桌子，大叫了一声。
en: Suddenly Pencroft, uttering a cry, pointed to the table.

zh: 桌子上放着一个长方形的小盒子，盒子的封皮上写着几个字：“硫酸奎宁”。
en: On it lay a little oblong box, of which the cover bore these words:—“SULPHATE OF QUININE.”

zh: 第十一章
en: Chapter 11

zh: 吉迪恩·史佩莱拿起盒子，把它打开。盒子里面装着大概200格令的白色粉末，他蘸了一点尝了尝。粉末极度的苦味打消了所有的怀疑，这确实是经过提炼的宝贵的奎宁——最有效的退热药。
en: Gideon Spilett took the box and opened it.It contained nearly two hundred grains of a white powder, a few particles of which he carried to his lips.The extreme bitterness of the substance precluded all doubt; it was certainly the precious extract of quinine, that pre-eminent antifebrile.

zh: 必须让赫伯特吃下这种药粉，一刻也不能耽搁。至于它的来历，不妨以后再去讨论。
en: This powder must be administered to Herbert without delay.How it came there might be discussed later.

zh: “来点咖啡！”史佩莱说。
en: “Some coffee!” said Spilett.

zh: 不一会儿，纳布端过来一杯温热的咖啡。吉迪恩·史佩莱往里面加了大概18格令的奎宁。他们顺利地让赫伯特喝下了这种混合液体。
en: In a few moments Neb brought a cup of the warm infusion.Gideon Spilett threw into it about eighteen grains of quinine, and they succeeded in making Herbert drink the mixture.

zh: 在恶性疟疾第三次发作之前，他们还有一点时间。他们多么希望这段时间一直延长下去，疾病再也不会发作了！
en: There was still time, for the third attack of the malignant fever had not yet shown itself.How they longed to be able to add that it would not return!

zh: 这里还必须强调一点，此刻每个人的心里都再次充满希望。那股神秘的力量又发挥了作用，就在这个大家已经绝望的紧要关头。
en: Besides, it must be remarked, the hopes of all had now revived.The mysterious influence had been again exerted, and in a critical moment, when they had despaired of it.

zh: 一个钟头之后，赫伯特平静了很多。现在移民们可以讨论一下这件事情了。这一次，陌生人的介入比以往更加明显。可是，他在夜里怎么能进入花岗石宫呢？这一点着实不可思议，事实上，岛上这位天才的行为和他本人一样神秘莫测。这一天，他们每隔三个钟头就让赫伯特吃一次硫酸奎宁。
en: In a few hours Herbert was much calmer.The colonists could now discuss this incident.The intervention of the stranger was more evident than ever.But how had he been able to penetrate during the night into Granite House?It was inexplicable, and, in truth, the proceedings of the genius of the island were not less mysterious than was that genius himself.During this day the sulphate of quinine was administered to Herbert every three hours.

zh: 第二天，赫伯特的病情明显好转了。当然，他还没有脱离危险，间歇热一般都会复发，而且一旦复发就会很危险，但大家对他的照顾无微不至，此外，他们手头还有特效药，同时，毫无疑问，那个送药的人也在不远的地方！每个人的心里都再次出现了希望。
en: The next day some improvement in Herbert’s condition was apparent.Certainly, he was not out of danger, intermittent fevers being subject to frequent and dangerous relapses, but the most assiduous care was bestowed on him.And besides, the specific was at hand; nor, doubtless, was he who had brought it far distant!And the hearts of all were animated by returning hope.

zh: 这次他们的希望没有落空。十天之后，也就是12月20号，赫伯特开始复原了。
en: This hope was not disappointed.Ten days after, on the 20th of December, Herbert’s convalescence commenced.

zh: 他的身体依旧很虚弱，并且他被大家严格地限制饮食，但他再也没有发过高烧。可怜的少年特别顺从地遵守了所有对他的规定！他是多么希望痊愈！
en: He was still weak, and strict diet had been imposed upon him, but no access of fever supervened.And then, the poor boy submitted with such docility to all the prescriptions ordered him!He longed so to get well!

zh: 潘克洛夫像是一个从深渊底部被救上来的人似的，高兴得近乎发狂了。预计病情第三次发作的时间过去之后，他紧紧地抱着通讯记者，近乎将其窒息。从那一刻开始，他常常把通讯记者叫做史佩莱医生。
en: Pencroft was as a man who has been drawn up from the bottom of an abyss.Fits of joy approaching delirium seized him.When the time for the third attack had passed by, he nearly suffocated the reporter in his embrace.Since then, he always called him Dr. Spilett.

zh: 然而，他们还是没有发现真正的医生。
en: The real doctor, however, remained undiscovered.

zh: “我们一定会找到他！”水手一再地说。
en: “We will find him!” repeated the sailor.

zh: 可以肯定，不管这个人是谁，一旦找到了他，潘克洛夫都应当为他送上一个热烈的拥抱！
en: Certainly, this man, whoever he was, might expect a somewhat too energetic embrace from the worthy Pencroft!

zh: 12月已经结束，1867年也随之逝去。在这一年的年底，林肯岛的移民们遭受了严峻的考验。1868年年初，天气晴朗炎热，温度像热带地区一样高，幸而有海风送来丝丝凉爽。赫伯特正在逐渐恢复健康，他的床就放在花岗石宫的一个窗口附近，他可以呼吸含着臭氧的新鲜空气，这对于恢复健康是大有好处的。他的食欲也跟着恢复了，纳布为他精心准备了多少美味可口的菜肴啊！
en: The month of December ended, and with it the year 1867, during which the colonists of Lincoln Island had of late been so severely tried.They commenced the year 1868 with magnificent weather, great heat, and a tropical temperature, delightfully cooled by the sea-breeze.Herbert’s recovery progressed, and from his bed, placed near one of the windows of Granite House, he could inhale the fresh air, charged with ozone, which could not fail to restore his health.His appetite returned, and what numberless delicate, savory little dishes Neb prepared for him!

zh: “能吃到这么多好吃的，谁都想发烧了！”潘克洛夫说。
en: “It is enough to make one wish to have a fever oneself!” said Pencroft.

zh: 在这段时间里，罪犯们一直没有在花岗石宫附近出现过。他们也没有任何艾尔顿的消息，虽然工程师和赫伯特依旧对重新找到他抱有希望，他们的同伴们却都相信这个不幸的人已经死了。不管怎样，这个疑问不会存在太久的，一旦少年康复了，他们就可以远征了。远征的结果将会有非常重大的意义。但是他们或许还要等上一个月，因为要向罪犯们讨还血债，移民们的全部力量都要出动。
en: During all this time, the convicts did not once appear in the vicinity of Granite House.There was no news of Ayrton, and though the engineer and Herbert still had some hopes of finding him again, their companions did not doubt but that the unfortunate man had perished.However, this uncertainty could not last, and when once the lad should have recovered, the expedition, the result of which must be so important, would be undertaken.But they would have to wait a month, perhaps, for all the strength of the colony must be put into requisition to obtain satisfaction from the convicts.

zh: 不过，赫伯特的健康恢复得很快。肝脏已经不再充血，伤口看上去也完全愈合了。
en: However, Herbert’s convalescence progressed rapidly.The congestion of the liver had disappeared, and his wounds might be considered completely healed.

zh: 1月里，眺望岗的高地上完成了重要的工作，虽然工作的内容近乎相同，就是把遭劫后遗留下来的庄稼，不管是谷物还是蔬菜，都尽可能地贮藏起来。他们把麦粒和植物聚集在一起，留到即将到来的半个季度重新播种。至于家禽场的围墙和驴棚的重建工作，赛勒斯·哈丁打算先等等。当他和他的同伴们出去追踪罪犯的时候，罪犯们很可能再次到高地扫荡，给他们机会再次破坏这里，实在是没有必要。等到把岛上的罪犯们肃清之后，他们可以着手重建工作。在1月的第二个星期里，少年开始下床了，起初他每天起来一个钟头，后来是两个钟头，再后来是三个钟头。由于他原本身强体健，体力很快恢复了。今年他十八岁。身材很高，将来定会长成一位仪表堂堂的男子汉。从这个时候起，他的健康，虽然还需要休养——这是史佩莱医生严格要求的——恢复得特别快。月底的时候，赫伯特已经可以在眺望岗和海滩上散步了。
en: During the month of January, important work was done on the plateau of Prospect Heights; but it consisted solely in saving as much as was possible from the devastated crops, either of corn or vegetables.The grain and the plants were gathered, so as to provide a new harvest for the approaching half-season.With regard to rebuilding the poultry-yard, wall, or stables, Cyrus Harding preferred to wait.While he and his companions were in pursuit of the convicts, the latter might very probably pay another visit to the plateau, and it would be useless to give them an opportunity of recommencing their work of destruction. when the island should be cleared of these miscreants, they would set about rebuilding.The young convalescent began to get up in the second week of January, at first for one hour a day, then two, then three.His strength visibly returned, so vigorous was his constitution.He was now eighteen years of age.He was tall, and promised to become a man of noble and commanding presence.From this time his recovery, while still requiring care,—and Dr. Spilett was very strict,—made rapid progress.Towards the end of the month, Herbert was already walking about on Prospect Heights, and the beach.

zh: 他和潘克洛夫、纳布一起洗过几次海水浴，对他的恢复有很大的好处。赛勒斯·哈丁觉得该定下出发的日期了，于是就定在了2月15号动身。在一年中的这个时节，夜晚非常晴朗，这对于全方位地搜索这个小岛非常有利。
en: He derived, from several sea-baths, which he took in company with Pencroft and Neb, the greatest possible benefit.Cyrus Harding thought he might now settle the day for their departure, for which the 15th of February was fixed.The nights, very clear at this time of year, would be favorable to the researches they intended to make all over the island.

zh: 于是他们开始进行远征必要的准备工作，这一点非常重要，因为移民们已经下定了决心，不达到双重目标，他们决不回花岗石宫——一方面他们要歼灭罪犯，如果艾尔顿没有死，还要把他营救出来；另一方面他们要找出真正掌握着移民们的命运的那个人。
en: The necessary preparations for this exploration were now commenced, and were important, for the colonists had sworn not to return to Granite House until their twofold object had been achieved; on the one hand, to exterminate the convicts, and rescue Ayrton, if he was still living; on the other, to discover who it was that presided so effectually over the fortunes of the colony.

zh: 在林肯岛上，从爪角到颚骨角之间的整个东海岸、宽阔的潦凫沼泽、格兰特湖的周围、通往畜栏和慈悲河的啄木鸟林、慈悲河和红河流域，以及富兰克林山的支脉，也就是建畜栏的地方，移民们已经有了彻底的了解。
en: Of Lincoln Island, the settlers knew thoroughly all the eastern coast from Claw Cape to the Mandible Capes, the extensive Tadorn Marsh, the neighborhood of Lake Grant, Jacamar Wood, between the road to the corral and the Mercy, the courses of the Mercy and Red Creek, and lastly, the spurs of Mount Franklin, among which the corral had been established.

zh: 还有一些地方，比如从爪角到爬虫角之间华盛顿湾的宽阔海岸、西海岸上的森林和沼泽、一直延绵到鲨鱼湾港口的看不到尽头的沙丘等，尽管知道得还不那么彻底，但也已经探索过了。但是覆盖盘蛇半岛的森林、慈悲河右边的整个区域、瀑布河的左岸。支撑富兰克林山麓东、西、北三面支脉和山谷的荒野，他们还都没有探索过，毫无疑问，这些地方会有很多可以藏身的秘密之地。如此说来，岛上还有上百万英亩的土地没有被他们探索过。
en: They had explored, though only in an imperfect manner, the vast shore of Washington Bay from Claw Cape to Reptile End, the woody and marshy border of the west coast, and the interminable downs, ending at the open mouth of Shark Gulf.But they had in no way surveyed the woods which covered the Serpentine Peninsula, all to the right of the Mercy, the left bank of Falls River, and the wilderness of spurs and valleys which supported three quarters of the base of Mount Franklin, to the east, the north, and the west, and where doubtless many secret retreats existed.Consequently, many millions of acres of the island had still escaped their investigations.

zh: 因此，他们决定开始远征，深入到远西地带去，连通慈悲河右边的整个区域一起搜索。
en: It was, therefore, decided that the expedition should be carried through the Far West, so as to include all that region situated on the right of the Mercy.

zh: 也许直接到畜栏去是个更好的方法，因为罪犯们很可能再次躲到那里去了，不管是为了劫掠，还是为了安身。可是现在罪犯们可能已经把畜栏破坏了，想去阻止他们已经来不及了；也可能他们还坚守在里面，如果是这样的话，等到他们回来的时候再把他们赶走也不迟。
en: It might, perhaps, be better worth while to go direct to the corral, where it might be supposed that the convicts had again taken refuge, either to pillage or to establish themselves there.But either the devastation of the corral would have been an accomplished fact by this time, and it would be too late to prevent it, or it had been the convicts’ interest to entrench themselves there, and there would be still time to go and turn them out on their return.

zh: 于是，经过了一番讨论之后，移民们决定采取第一个计划：穿过森林，到爬虫角去。他们用短柄小斧开辟出一条十六七英里长的道路，使花岗石宫一直通到半岛的末端。
en: Therefore, after some discussion, the first plan was adhered to, and the settlers resolved to proceed through the wood to Reptile End.They would make their way with their hatchets, and thus lay the first draft of a road which would place Granite House in communication with the end of the peninsula for a length of from sixteen to seventeen miles.

zh: 手推车完好无损。野驴在休息好了之后，可以参加到远征中。食品、露营用具、便携火炉和各种器皿都已经装在了手推车上，他们又从已经相当完善的花岗石宫的兵器库里仔细地挑选了一些武器和火药。但是，有一点必须牢记，罪犯们也许正在森林里游荡，走在茂密的森林中，很可能会被冷枪击中。因此，这一小队移民们决定集体行动，无论以什么样的理由，谁都不准掉队。
en: The cart was in good condition.The onagers, well rested, could go a long journey.Provisions, camp effects, a portable stove, and various utensils were packed in the cart, as also weapons and ammunition, carefully chosen from the now complete arsenal of Granite House.But it was necessary to remember that the convicts were, perhaps, roaming about the woods, and that in the midst of these thick forests a shot might quickly be fired and received.It was therefore resolved that the little band of settlers should remain together and not separate under any pretext whatever.

zh: 大家还决定，花岗石宫里一个人也不留。托普和贾普也都随同一起参加远征，这个很难进入的住处不需要有人留守。2月14号是出发的前夕，移民们休息了一整天，并向造物主表达了一番感恩之情。虽然赫伯特已经完全恢复了，但是他的身体还是有些虚弱，于是他们就在手推车上给他留出了一个空位。赛勒斯·哈丁为了防止花岗石宫遭到侵犯，在第二天拂晓时分采取了一些必要的措施。过去用来攀登的梯子被拿到了“石窟”，他们把它深深地埋在了沙子里，留到日后他们回来时用，因为升降梯已经被他们拆成了一块一块的零部件，整套装置一点也没有留下。最后只剩下潘克洛夫一个人在花岗石宫里完成这项工作。干完之后，他沿着一根下端被人拉着的两股的绳子荡了下来，接着把绳子扯下，就这样断绝了高处的平台和海滩之间的交通。
en: It was also decided that no one should remain at Granite House.Top and Jup themselves were to accompany the expedition; the inaccessible dwelling needed no guard.The 14th of February, eve of the departure, was consecrated entirely to repose, and—thanksgiving addressed by the colonists to the Creator.A place in the cart was reserved for Herbert, who, though thoroughly convalescent, was still a little weak.The next morning, at daybreak, Cyrus Harding took the necessary measures to protect Granite House from any invasion.The ladders, which were formerly used for the ascent, were brought to the Chimneys and buried deep in the sand, so that they might be available on the return of the colonists, for the machinery of the lift had been taken to pieces, and nothing of the apparatus remained.Pencroft stayed the last in Granite House in order to finish this work, and he then lowered himself down by means of a double rope held below, and which, when once hauled down, left no communication between the upper landing and the beach.

zh: 这一天天气十分晴朗。
en: The weather was magnificent.

zh: “今天可真暖和！”通讯记者笑着说。
en: “We shall have a warm day of it,” said the reporter, laughing.

zh: “噗！史佩莱医生！”潘克洛夫说，“我们应该走在树阴底下，这样连太阳都看不见！”
en: “Pooh!Dr. Spilett,” answered Pencroft, “we shall walk under the shade of the trees and shan’t even see the sun!”

zh: “前进！”工程师说。
en: “Forward!” said the engineer.

zh: 手推车停在了“石窟”前面的海滩上。通讯记者让赫伯特上了车，要他在旅途的前几个钟头坐在他的位置上，少年只好听医生的吩咐。
en: The cart was waiting on the beach before the Chimneys.The reporter made Herbert take his place in it during the first hours at least of the journey, and the lad was obliged to submit to his doctor’s orders.

zh: 纳布牵着野驴往前走。赛勒斯·哈丁、通讯记者和水手走在车的前面。托普高兴地蹦蹦跳跳。赫伯特在车上给贾普腾了个位子，贾普毫不客气地坐了上去。动身的时刻到了，一小队人马出发了。
en: Neb placed himself at the onagers’ heads.Cyrus Harding, the reporter, and the sailor, walked in front.Top bounded joyfully along.Herbert offered a seat in his vehicle to Jup, who accepted it without ceremony.The moment for departure had arrived, and the little band set out.

zh: 小车首先绕过了慈悲河口的拐角，接着沿着左岸往上走了一英里，跨过桥，到了通向气球港的路，然后移民们从路口往右走，进入了茂密的森林，这里就是远西地带了。
en: The cart first turned the angle of the mouth of the Mercy, then, having ascended the left bank for a mile, crossed the bridge, at the other side of which commenced the road to Port Balloon, and there the explorers, leaving this road on their left, entered the cover of the immense woods which formed the region of the Far West.

zh: 最初的两英里，树木稀少，小车还可以顺利通行；只是有时需要砍断一些爬藤和灌木，但这一段路途中，移民们没有遇到什么严重的障碍。
en: For the first two miles the widely scattered trees allowed the cart to pass with ease; from time to time it became necessary to cut away a few creepers and bushes, but no serious obstacle impeded the progress of the colonists.

zh: 浓密的枝叶在地上形成了树阴，似乎在向人们致谢。喜马拉雅雪杉、花旗松、木麻黄树、山茂、桉树、龙血树和其他许多有名的品种，在目之所及的地方，一棵连着一棵。岛上的各种鸟类在这里应有尽有——松鸡、啄木鸟、野鸡、吸蜜鹦鹉以及唧唧喳喳叫个不停的美冠鹦鹉、鹦鹉和长尾鹦鹉。看到人群走了过来，刺豚鼠、袋鼠和水豚飞也似的逃走了，这一切都勾起了移民们的回忆，让他们想到了来到岛上以后第一次打猎时的情景。
en: The thick foliage of the trees threw a grateful shade on the ground.Deodars, Douglas firs, casuarinas, banksias, gum-trees, dragon-trees, and other well-known species, succeeded each other far as the eye could reach.The feathered tribes of the island were all represented—grouse, jacamars, pheasants, lories, as well as the chattering cockatoos, parrots, and paroquets.Agouties, kangaroos, and capybaras fled swiftly at their approach; and all this reminded the settlers of the first excursions they had made on their arrival at the island.

zh: “不过，”赛勒斯·哈丁说，“我发现这些动物，不管是飞禽还是走兽，都比以前胆小了。这么看来，罪犯们最近肯定是从这里走过，我们一定能找到他们的踪迹的。”
en: “Nevertheless,” observed Cyrus Harding, “I notice that these creatures, both birds and quadrupeds, are more timid than formerly.These woods have, therefore, been recently traversed by the convicts, and we shall certainly find some traces of them.”

zh: 果不其然，他们找到了几处小队人马最近通过这里时留下的痕迹，有的地方的树枝被折断了，大概是为了做记号；有的地方留下了一些灰烬，粘土地上还有一些脚印，但是找不到任何宿营留下的痕迹。
en: And, in fact, in several places they could distinguish traces, more or less recent, of the passage of a band of men—here branches broken off the trees, perhaps to mark out the way; there the ashes of a fire, and footprints in clayey spots; but nothing which appeared to belong to a settled encampment.

zh: 工程师已经劝告他的同伴们停止打猎了。也许罪犯们正在森林里游荡，枪声很可能会惊动了他们。另外，要打猎的话势必就要离开小车一段距离，留下它没人看管是十分危险的。
en: The engineer had recommended his companions to refrain from hunting.The reports of the firearms might give the alarm to the convicts, who were, perhaps, roaming through the forest.Moreover, the hunters would necessarily ramble some distance from the cart, which it was dangerous to leave unguarded.

zh: 到了后半天，他们离开花岗石宫大概六英里了，前进的道路变得困难了很多。为了穿过茂密的树林，他们不得不砍倒一些树。在进入这样的地方之前，哈丁总是很小心地让托普和贾普先进去，它们总是忠实地完成他们的任务。如果狗和猩猩没有做出任何警告地回来，显然前面一段路就没有什么危险，既没有罪犯，也没有野兽。这两只来自动物世界的生灵凶残的本性不相上下。第一天晚上，移民们在离花岗石宫九英里左右的一条汇入慈悲河的溪流旁边安营扎寨，之前他们一直不知道有这条小溪，显然它的水路系统使附近的土壤变得十分肥沃。移民们胃口大开，于是便饱餐了一顿，然后安排如何平安地过夜。如果工程师只需要应付野兽，比如美洲豹或其他兽类，那么他只需要在帐篷周围点上篝火就足以防御他们的进攻；可是这样一来，罪犯们不但不会被吓跑，反而会被吸引过来，于是他还是决定把自己包围在漆黑的夜色之中。
en: In the afterpart of the day, when about six miles from Granite House, their progress became much more difficult.In order to make their way through some thickets, they were obliged to cut down trees.Before entering such places Harding was careful to send in Top and Jup, who faithfully accomplished their commission, and when the dog and orang returned without giving any warning, there was evidently nothing to fear, either from convicts or wild beasts, two varieties of the animal kingdom, whose ferocious instincts placed them on the same level.On the evening of the first day the colonists encamped about nine miles from Granite House, on the border of a little stream falling into the Mercy, and of the existence of which they had till then been ignorant; it evidently, however, belonged to the hydiographical system to which the soil owed its astonishing fertility.The settlers made a hearty meal, for their appetites were sharpened, and measures were then taken that the night might be passed in safety.If the engineer had had only to deal with wild beasts, jaguars or others, he would have simply lighted fires all around his camp, which would have sufficed for its defense; but the convicts would be rather attracted than terrified by the flames, and it was, therefore, better to be surrounded by the profound darkness of night.

zh: 他们精心地组织守夜。大家一致同意两个人一组共同守夜，每隔两个小时换一组。尽管赫伯特提出想要守夜，大家还是没有答应。潘克洛夫和吉迪恩·史佩莱一组，工程师和纳布一组，轮流在帐篷周围看守。
en: The watch was, however, carefully organized.Two of the settlers were to watch together, and every two hours it was agreed that they should be relieved by their comrades.And so, notwithstanding his wish to the contrary, Herbert was exempted from guard.Pencroft and Gideon Spilett in one party, the engineer and Neb in another, mounted guard in turns over the camp.

zh: 然而，夜晚不过只有几个钟头。与其说黑暗是因为没有太阳而造成的，还不如说是由于枝叶太过浓密造成的。森林里的寂静被不时传来的美洲豹的吼声和猿猴的叫声打破了，贾普似乎特别不喜欢听猴子叫。这一夜平安无事地过去了，第二天是2月15号，大家继续在森林中穿行，虽然不时会遇到一些困难，但是枯燥乏味却一路相随。这一天他们走了不到六英里，因为他们每走一步都要用短柄小斧开路。
en: The night, however, was but of few hours.The darkness was due rather to the thickness of the foliage than to the disappearance of the sun.The silence was scarcely disturbed by the howling of jaguars and the chattering of the monkeys, the latter appearing to particularly irritate Master Jup.The night passed without incident, and on the next day, the 15th of February, the journey through the forest, tedious rather than difficult, was continued.This day they could not accomplish more than six miles, for every moment they were obliged to cut a road with their hatchets.

zh: 移民们就像定居在这里的人一样，仅仅砍倒一些小树，而把那些高大且美丽的树留了下来，这样做还有一个原因就是砍倒大树需要花费许多劳动力。可是这样一来，开辟出的道路格外弯曲，一个接一个的弯路延长了他们的路程。
en: Like true settlers, the colonists spared the largest and most beautiful trees, which would besides have cost immense labor to fell, and the small ones only were sacrificed, but the result was that the road took a very winding direction, and lengthened itself by numerous detours.

zh: 这一天赫伯特发现了很多以前在岛上没有遇到过的植物种类，比如叶子像喷泉似的四面散开的桫椤，还有上面长着野驴很喜欢吃的长荚和一种香甜可口的果肉的刺槐。在那里，移民们还发现了几丛高大的贝壳杉。它们的树干是圆柱形的，高达200尺，顶上有一簇锥形的树叶。贝壳松是新西兰的万树之王，和黎巴嫩的杉树一样有名。
en: During the day Herbert discovered several new specimens not before met with in the island, such as the tree-fern, with its leaves spread out like the waters of a fountain, locust-trees, on the long pods of which the onagers browsed greedily, and which supplied a sweet pulp of excellent flavor.There, too, the colonists again found groups of magnificent kauries, their cylindrical trunks, crowded with a cone of verdure, rising to a height of two hundred feet.These were the tree-kings of New Zealand, as celebrated as the cedars of Lebanon.

zh: 至于动物，除了猎人们已经见过的那些以外，他们没有发现什么新的种类。然而，虽然不能靠近，他们却看见了两只澳大利亚特有的大飞禽，一种名叫鸸鹋的食火鸡，身高五英尺，长着棕色的羽毛，属于涉水鸟类。托普撒开四条腿，拼命地追赶它们，但是鸸鹋跑得特别快，轻而易举地就把它甩在了后面。
en: As to the fauna, there was no addition to those species already known to the hunters.Nevertheless, they saw, though unable to get near them, a couple of those large birds peculiar to Australia, a sort of cassowary, called emu, five feet in height, and with brown plumage, which belong to the tribe of waders.Top darted after them as fast as his four legs could carry him, but the emus distanced him with ease, so prodigious was their speed.

zh: 至于罪犯们留下的踪迹，他们又发现了一些。在一处很明显是近期熄灭的余烬周围，移民们发现了一些脚印，并进行了仔细的检查。他们一一测量了脚印的长度和宽度，很容易就辨别出了这些是五个人留下的脚印。这五个罪犯肯定在这里露营过。如果有第六个人的脚印，那肯定是艾尔顿留下的，可是他们经过仔细的检查，并没有发现第六个人的脚印。
en: As to the traces left by the convicts, a few more were discovered.Some footprints found near an apparently recently extinguished fire were attentively examined by the settlers.By measuring them one after the other, according to their length and breadth, the marks of five men’s feet were easily distinguished.The five convicts had evidently camped on this spot; but,—and this was the object of so minute an examination,—a sixth footprint could not be discovered, which in that case would have been that of Ayrton.

zh: “艾尔顿没有和他们在一起！”赫伯特说。
en: “Ayrton was not with them!” said Herbert.

zh: “没错，”潘克洛夫答道，“如果他没有和他们在一起，那么一定是已经被罪犯们杀了！这些恶棍连个窝都没有，不然我们就能据此像追老虎一样追他们了！”
en: “No,” answered Pencroft, “and if he was not with them, it was because the wretches had already murdered him! but then these rascals have not a den to which they may be tracked like tigers!”

zh: “没错，”通讯记者说，“他们大概在到处游荡，目的在于有一天能成为这个岛的主人！”
en: “No,” replied the reporter, “it is more probable that they wander at random, and it is their interest to rove about until the time when they will be masters of the island!”

zh: “岛上的主人！”水手大声地说，“岛上的主人！……”他重复着，好像被人用手牢牢地抓住了喉咙一样，说不出话来。然后他的声音平静了一些，“你知道吗，哈丁队长，”他说，“我的枪里装的是一颗什么子弹？”
en: “The masters of the island!” exclaimed the sailor; “the masters of the island!...” he repeated, and his voice was choked, as if his throat was seized in an iron grasp.Then in a calmer tone, “Do you know, Captain Harding,” said he, “what the ball is which I have rammed into my gun?”

zh: “不知道，潘克洛夫！”
en: “No, Pencroft!”

zh: “就是那颗射穿了赫伯特的胸膛的子弹，我跟你保证，它一定会击中目标！”
en: “It is the ball that went through Herbert’s chest, and I promise you it won’t miss its mark!”

zh: 但是，这个合理的报复不能使艾尔顿死而复生。在检查了地上留下的脚印之后，唉，他们不能不得出结论，他们必须放弃任何与他再次相见的念头了。
en: But this just retaliation would not bring Ayrton back to life, and from the examination of the footprints left in the ground, they must, alas! conclude that all hopes of ever seeing him again must be abandoned.

zh: 那天晚上，他们在距离花岗石宫十四英里的地方安营扎寨。赛勒斯·哈丁估算出，还有不到五英里，他们就能到爬虫角了。
en: That evening they encamped fourteen miles from Granite House, and Cyrus Harding calculated that they could not be more than five miles from Reptile Point.

zh: 果然，第二天他们到达了半岛的尽头，他们已经纵穿了整个森林，但是没有发现任何迹象表明罪犯们在那里藏身，也没有找到那个神秘的陌生人的住处。
en: And indeed, the next day the extremity of the peninsula was reached, and the whole length of the forest had been traversed; but there was nothing to indicate the retreat in which the convicts had taken refuge, nor that, no less secret, which sheltered the mysterious unknown.

zh: 第十二章
en: Chapter 12

zh: 第二天，2月18号，移民们打算搜索从爬虫角到瀑布河沿岸一带的森林地区。移民们可以对这片森林进行彻底的搜索，因为这里地处盘蛇半岛的两岸之间，宽度只有三到四英里。这里的树木不仅高大，而且枝繁叶茂，这足以证明这里的土壤要比荒岛其他的地方肥沃很多。人们也许会以为,这里是从美洲或非洲迁移到这个温带地区来的一片原始森林。这使他们得出结论，这些高大的植物所生长的地方的土壤一定比较热。这里的土壤表层潮湿，但内部由于火山烈焰而温度升高；这种温度在温带气候里是不可能出现的。这一带最为常见的树木是高大的贝壳松和尤加利树。
en: The next day, the 18th of February, was devoted to the exploration of all that wooded region forming the shore from Reptile End to Falls River.The colonists were able to search this forest thoroughly, for, as it was comprised between the two shores of the Serpentine Peninsula, it was only from three to four miles in breadth.The trees, both by their height and their thick foliage, bore witness to the vegetative power of the soil, more astonishing here than in any other part of the island.One might have said that a corner from the virgin forests of America or Africa had been transported into this temperate zone.This led them to conclude that the superb vegetation found a heat in this soil, damp in its upper layer, but warmed in the interior by volcanic fires, which could not belong to a temperate climate.The most frequently occurring trees were knaries and eucalypti of gigantic dimensions.

zh: 当然移民们的目的可不仅仅在于欣赏这些参天大树。他们知道，在这方面，林肯岛已经完全可以列入到最初被称为“快乐群岛”的加纳利的第一流岛屿的行列了。可现在，唉！林肯岛已经不完全归他们所有了，已经有其他人侵占了它，污染了它的海岸，他们必须把这些罪消灭，一个不留。
en: But the colonists’ object was not simply to admire the magnificent vegetation.They knew already that in this respect Lincoln Island would have been worthy to take the first rank in the Canary group, to which the first name given was that of the Happy Isles.Now, alas! their island no longer belonged to them entirely; others had taken possession of it, miscreants polluted its shores, and they must be destroyed to the last man.

zh: 尽管他们检查得非常仔细，可并没有在西海岸上发现任何蛛丝马迹。没有脚印，没有折断的树枝，也没有被遗弃的帐篷。
en: No traces were found on the western coast, although they were carefully sought for.No more footprints, no more broken branches, no more deserted camps.

zh: “这一点我倒不觉得奇怪，”赛勒斯·哈丁对他的同伴们说，“罪犯们最初在遗物角附近登上小岛，在穿过漆凫沼泽之后，立刻进入远西森林。然后他们几乎是沿着我们离开‘花岗石宫’后所走的同样的路线前进。这就可以解释我们在森林里发现的那些踪迹。可是罪犯们到达海岸之后，很快就发现那里没有适合他们居住的地方，就在那时，他们决定再次往北走，于是就找到了畜栏。”
en: “This does not surprise me,” said Cyrus Harding to his companions.“The convicts first landed on the island in the neighborhood of Flotsam Point, and they immediately plunged into the Far West forests, after crossing Tadorn Marsh.They then followed almost the same route that we took on leaving Granite House.This explains the traces we found in the wood.But, arriving on the shore, the convicts saw at once that they would discover no suitable retreat there, and it was then that, going northwards again, they came upon the corral.”

zh: “说不准他们已经回到了那里。”潘克洛夫说。
en: “Where they have perhaps returned,” said Pencroft.

zh: “我不这么认为，”工程师回答道，“他们自然会认为我们要往那个方向寻找他们。对他们来说，畜栏只不过是个仓库，而不是可以长期居住的地方。”
en: “I do not think so,” answered the engineer, “for they would naturally suppose that our researches would be in that direction.The corral is only a storehouse to them, and not a definitive encampment.”

zh: “我同意赛勒斯的观点，”通讯记者说，“我想，罪犯们一定是把他们的老窝扎在富兰克林山的支脉之间了。”
en: “I am of Cyrus’ opinion,” said the reporter, “and I think that it is among the spurs of Mount Franklin that the convicts will have made their lair.”

zh: “那么，队长，我们径直去畜栏！”潘克洛夫大声地说，“我们一定要把他们杀光！到目前为止，我们完全是在浪费时间！”
en: “Then, captain, straight to the corral!” cried Pencroft.“We must finish them off, and till now we have only lost time!”

zh: “不，我的朋友，”工程师说，“你忘了我们还想知道远西森林里有没有什么住所。我们的远征有两个目的，潘克洛夫。一方面我们固然要严惩罪犯，另一方面，我们还要感激别人。”
en: “No, my friend,” replied the engineer; “you forget that we have a reason for wishing to know if the forests of the Far West do not contain some habitation.Our exploration has a double object, Pencroft.If, on the one hand, we have to chastise crime, we have, on the other, an act of gratitude to perform.”

zh: “说得对，队长，”水手说，“可是怎么都一样，在我看来，如果那位先生不愿意露面，我们是不会找到他的。”
en: “That was well said, captain,” replied the sailor, “but, all the same, it is my opinion that we shall not find the gentleman until he pleases.”

zh: 实际上，潘克洛夫一语中的，道破了所有人的想法。陌生人的住处大概和他本人一样神秘莫测。
en: And truly Pencroft only expressed the opinion of all.It was probable that the stranger’s retreat was not less mysterious than was he himself.

zh: 那天晚上，他们把小车停在了瀑布河的河口，和往常一样搭起帐篷，轮流守夜。赫伯特现在已经和他生病之前一样，又是一个健康而强壮的少年了。这种户外的生活，既有海上吹来的微风，又有林间新鲜的空气，对他的恢复有很大的好处。现在他不再坐在车上，而是走在了队伍的最前面。
en: That evening the cart halted at the mouth of Falls River.The camp was organized as usual, and the customary precautions were taken for the night.Herbert, become again the healthy and vigorous lad he was before his illness, derived great benefit from this life in the open air, between the sea breezes and the vivifying air from the forests.His place was no longer in the cart, but at the head of the troop.

zh: 转天，2月19号，移民们离开了海岸——在那里，河口的上面，各种形状的玄武岩石堆砌在一起，形成了一个奇特的图案——沿着河的左岸爬了上去。他们之前从畜栏走到西海岸的时候，已经把这条路其中的一部分铺平了。现在移民们离富兰克林山还有大概六英里。
en: The next day, the 19th of February, the colonists, leaving the shore, where, beyond the mouth, basalts of every shape were so picturesquely piled up, ascended the river by its left bank.The road had been already partly cleared in their former excursions made from the corral to the west coast.The settlers were now about six miles from Mount Franklin.

zh: 工程师的计划是这样的：仔细地查看形成河床的山谷，小心地朝畜栏附近靠近；如果畜栏被人占领了，就用武力把它夺过来，如果没有人，他们就守在那里，把它作为探索富兰克林山的前进据点。
en: The engineer’s plan was this:—To minutely survey the valley forming the bed of the river, and to cautiously approach the neighborhood of the corral; if the corral was occupied, to seize it by force; if it was not, to entrench themselves there and make it the center of the operations which had for their object the exploration of Mount Franklin.

zh: 移民们一致通过了这个计划，因为他们已经迫不及待地想要收回整个小岛的所有权。
en: This plan was unanimously approved by the colonists, for they were impatient to regain entire possession of their island.

zh: 一道狭窄的峡谷把富兰克林山两座最大的支脉划分开，他们沿着这道峡谷前进。河岸上长满了树木，到了高处的山坡上，树木就变得十分稀少了。这一带地势高低不平，非常适合打埋伏，因此他们前进时特别小心。托普和贾普在两边茂密的灌木丛上跳来跳去，赛着谁更聪明谁更灵活。溪流的岸上没有任何迹象可以说明近来常有人经过这里，没有任何迹象可以说明有罪犯在这里出现或是靠近过这里。傍晚五点钟的时候，小车停在了离栅栏差不多600英尺的地方。栅栏藏在了围成半圆形的树后面。
en: They made their way then along the narrow valley separating two of the largest spurs of Mount Franklin.The trees, crowded on the river’s bank, became rare on the upper slopes of the mountain.The ground was hilly and rough, very suitable for ambushes, and over which they did not venture without extreme precaution.Top and Jup skirmished on the flanks, springing right and left through the thick brushwood, and emulating each other in intelligence and activity.But nothing showed that the banks of the stream had been recently frequented—nothing announced either the presence or the proximity of the convicts.Towards five in the evening the cart stopped nearly 600 feet from the palisade.A semicircular screen of trees still hid it.

zh: 现在有必要去侦察一下畜栏，看看那里是不是已经被别人侵占。罪犯们很可能埋伏在那里，在光天化日之下，如果大摇大摆地走过去，很可能会像可怜的赫伯特一样，将自己暴露在恶棍们的枪口之下。所以最好还是等到夜幕降临再说。
en: It was necessary to reconnoiter the corral, in order to ascertain if it was occupied.To go there openly, in broad daylight, when the convicts were probably in ambush, would be to expose themselves, as poor Herbert had done, to the firearms of the ruffians.It was better, then, to wait until night came on.

zh: 然而，吉迪恩·史佩莱却认为不能再耽搁，应该立刻侦查通往畜栏的路，潘克洛夫也已经急不可耐，自告奋勇地陪他一起去。
en: However, Gideon Spilett wished without further delay to reconnoiter the approaches to the corral, and Pencroft, who was quite out of patience, volunteered to accompany him.

zh: “不，朋友们，”工程师说，“等到夜里吧。我绝不会允许你们其中的任何一个在白天暴露了自己。”
en: “No, my friends,” said the engineer, “wait till night.I will not allow one of you to expose himself in open day.”

zh: “可是，队长……”水手依旧不死心。
en: “But, captain—” answered the sailor, little disposed to obey.

zh: “我求求你，潘克洛夫。”工程师说。
en: “I beg of you, Pencroft,” said the engineer.

zh: “好吧！”水手说，他换了一种途径宣泄心中的愤怒，用海上生活的人们常用的最难听的话，辱骂那伙罪犯。
en: “Very well!” replied the sailor, who vented his anger in another way, by bestowing on the convicts the worst names in his maritime vocabulary.

zh: 于是，移民们留守在小车旁边，小心翼翼地观察着森林周围的动静。
en: The colonists remained, therefore, near the cart, and carefully watched the neighboring parts of the forest.

zh: 三个钟头就这样过去了。风已经小了，大树下面一片寂静。即便是折断一根小树枝，脚踩到干枯的树叶上，还是身子从草地上滑过发出的声音，都可以毫不费力听得清清楚楚。一切都很安静。就连托普都趴在草地上，把头搁在爪子上，没有表现出一点不安的样子。八点钟的时候，天色已经很晚了，这种条件十分有利于侦查。吉迪恩·史佩莱表示他已经做好准备，和潘克洛夫一起出发。赛勒斯·哈丁同意了。他们把托普和贾普留在工程师、赫伯特和纳布身边，因为在不恰当时刻的一声咆哮或者尖叫，都会引起罪犯们的警觉。
en: Three hours passed thus.The wind had fallen, and absolute silence reigned under the great trees.The snapping of the smallest twig, a footstep on the dry leaves, the gliding of a body among the grass, would have been heard without difficulty.All was quiet.Besides, Top, lying on the grass, his head stretched out on his paws, gave no sign of uneasiness.At eight o’clock the day appeared far enough advanced for the reconnaissance to be made under favorable conditions.Gideon Spilett declared himself ready to set out accompanied by Pencroft.Cyrus Harding consented.Top and Jup were to remain with the engineer, Herbert, and Neb, for a bark or a cry at a wrong moment would give the alarm.

zh: “不要大意，”哈丁对通讯记者和潘克洛夫说，“你们不需要占领畜栏，只要弄清楚它是不是已经被人占领了。”
en: “Do not be imprudent,” said Harding to the reporter and Pencroft, “you have not to gain possession of the corral, but only to find out whether it is occupied or not.”

zh: “好的。”潘克洛夫说。
en: “All right,” answered Pencroft.

zh: 于是他们两个出发了。
en: And the two departed.

zh: 大树枝繁叶茂，树下一片漆黑，三四十英尺之外，就什么都看不见了。通讯记者和潘克洛夫极为小心地往前走，一听到可疑的声音就立刻停下来。
en: Under the trees, thanks to the thickness of their foliage, the obscurity rendered any object invisible beyond a radius of from thirty to forty feet.The reporter and Pencroft, halting at any suspicious sound, advanced with great caution.

zh: 他们彼此保持着一小段距离，这样可以减小成为射击目标的几率。老实说，他们随时都等待着听到枪声。离开小车五分钟之后，吉迪恩·史佩莱和潘克洛夫到达了森林边缘的空地前面，过了空地就是畜栏的栅栏了。
en: They walked a little distance apart from each other so as to offer a less mark for a shot.And, to tell the truth, they expected every moment to hear a report.Five minutes after leaving the cart, Gideon Spilett and Pencroft arrived at the edge of the wood before the clearing beyond which rose the palisade.

zh: 他们停了下来。在这片没有树的空地上，还有几缕隐隐约约的光线。30英尺远的地方就是畜栏的大门，看上去是关着的。想要从森林到达栅栏，必须要通过这中间的30英尺，如果借用弹道学上的一个名词，这段距离就是“危险区”。事实上，不管是谁闯进“危险区”都有可能被从栅栏后面射出的子弹击倒。吉迪恩·史佩莱和水手都不是临阵脱逃的人，但是他们深知，一个不小心，不但自己会首先成为牺牲品，还会牵连到他们的同伴。如果他们被杀了，哈丁、纳布和赫伯特能逃脱得了吗？
en: They stopped.A few straggling beams still fell on the field clear of trees.Thirty feet distant was the gate of the corral, which appeared to be closed.This thirty feet, which it was necessary to cross from the wood to the palisade, constituted the dangerous zone, to borrow a ballistic term: in fact, one or more bullets fired from behind the palisade might knock over any one who ventured on to this zone.Gideon Spilett and the sailor were not men to draw back, but they knew that any imprudence on their part, of which they would be the first victims, would fall afterwards on their companions.If they themselves were killed, what would become of Harding, Neb, and Herbert?

zh: 潘克洛夫认为罪犯们肯定已经在畜栏里住下了，而现在自己又离畜栏这么近，一想到这里，他就按捺不住心里的兴奋，想要往前走。通讯记者一手把他紧紧地抓住了。
en: But Pencroft, excited at feeling himself so near the corral where he supposed the convicts had taken refuge, was about to press forward, when the reporter held him back with a grasp of iron.

zh: “过不了多久天就能黑透了，”史佩莱凑到水手的耳边，悄声地说，“到那时再行动。”
en: “In a few minutes it will be quite dark,” whispered Spilett in the sailor’s ear, “then will be the time to act.”

zh: 潘克洛夫焦躁不安地握着枪托，尽量克制心中的激动，一面等待时机，一面诅咒。
en: Pencroft, convulsively clasping the butt-end of his gun, restrained his energies, and waited, swearing to himself.

zh: 不久之后，最后一道光线消失了。黑暗好像从浓密的森林中间袭来，笼罩在整片空地上。富兰克林山就像一道竖立在西边水平线上的巨大的屏幕。在纬度较低的地方，黑夜总是来得这么快。到了该行动的时候了。
en: Soon the last of the twilight faded away.Darkness, which seemed as if it issued from the dense forest, covered the clearing.Mount Franklin rose like an enormous screen before the western horizon, and night spread rapidly over all, as it does in regions of low latitudes.Now was the time.

zh: 通讯记者和潘克洛夫已经到了森林的边缘，目光一刻不离地盯着栅栏。看上去畜栏里一个人也没有。栅栏的顶部形成了一条线，比周围的阴影处还要黑一些，旁边没有任何东西阻挡。然而，如果罪犯们在那里，他们一定会派一个人在那里看守，以防遭到突然袭击。
en: The reporter and Pencroft, since posting themselves on the edge of the wood, had not once lost sight of the palisade.The corral appeared to be absolutely deserted.The top of the palisade formed a line, a little darker than the surrounding shadow, and nothing disturbed its distinctness.Nevertheless, if the convicts were there, they must have posted one of their number to guard against any surprise.

zh: 史佩莱抓住他的同伴的手，一起朝着畜栏匍匐前进，随时准备开枪。
en: Spilett grasped his companion’s hand, and both crept towards the corral, their guns ready to fire.

zh: 他们来到了畜栏的大门，周围一片漆黑，一道光线也没有。
en: They reached the gate without the darkness being illuminated by a single ray of light.

zh: 潘克洛夫想推开门，但正如通讯记者和他想象的那样，门是关着的。不过，水手能确认外边的门闩没有闩上。因此，可以得出结论，罪犯们就在畜栏里，他们八成把大门从里面闩上了，从外面是推不开的。
en: Pencroft tried to push open the gate, which, as the reporter and he had supposed, was closed.However, the sailor was able to ascertain that the outer bars had not been put up.It might, then, be concluded that the convicts were there in the corral, and that very probably they had fastened the gate in such a way that it could not be forced open.

zh: 吉迪恩·史佩莱和潘克洛夫听了一会儿。
en: Gideon Spilett and Pencroft listened.

zh: 栅栏里面什么声音都没有。摩弗仑羊和山羊肯定在牲口棚里睡着了，丝毫没有打破夜晚的宁静。
en: Not a sound could be heard inside the palisade.The musmons and the goats, sleeping no doubt in their huts, in no way disturbed the calm of night.

zh: 通讯记者和水手什么也没听见，他们自己思忖着，要不要翻过栅栏到畜栏里面去。但是这样做就违反了赛勒斯·哈丁的指示。
en: The reporter and the sailor hearing nothing, asked themselves whether they had not better scale the palisades and penetrate into the corral.This would have been contrary to Cyrus Harding’s instructions.

zh: 的确，这样冒险可能会成功，但也可能会失败。现在，如果罪犯们还没有怀疑，如果他们一点也不知道移民们远征搜索他们，那样的话，是有突袭的机会的。如果轻率地翻过栅栏会不会错失这样的机会呢？
en: It is true that the enterprise might succeed, but it might also fail.Now, if the convicts were suspecting nothing, if they knew nothing of the expedition against them, if, lastly, there now existed a chance of surprising them, ought this chance to be lost by inconsiderately attempting to cross the palisades?

zh: 这并不是通讯记者的想法。他觉得最好还是等到所有的移民们都聚集在一起之后，再尝试进入畜栏。有一点是可以肯定的，他们可以到达栅栏而且没有被发现，另外，畜栏看上去并没有人把守。这一点已经弄清楚了，他们就应该回到小车那里和大家进行商讨去了。
en: This was not the reporter’s opinion.He thought it better to wait until all the settlers were collected together before attempting to penetrate into the corral.One thing was certain, that it was possible to reach the palisade without being seen, and also that it did not appear to be guarded.This point settled, there was nothing to be done but to return to the cart, where they would consult.

zh: 潘克洛夫大概也同意了这个决定，因为通讯记者转身回森林的时候，他没有反对，而是跟了回来。
en: Pencroft probably agreed with this decision, for he followed the reporter without making any objection when the latter turned back to the wood.

zh: 几分钟以后，工程师了解了目前的状况。
en: In a few minutes the engineer was made acquainted with the state of affairs.

zh: “好吧，”他思考了一会儿，然后说，“我现在有理由相信，罪犯们不在畜栏里。”
en: “Well,” said he, after a little thought, “I now have reason to believe that the convicts are not in the corral.”

zh: “我们很快就会知道了，”潘克洛夫说，“等我们翻过栅栏以后。”
en: “We shall soon know,” said Pencroft, “when we have scaled the palisade.”

zh: “去畜栏，朋友们！”赛勒斯·哈丁说。
en: “To the corral, my friends!” said Cyrus Harding.

zh: “我们把小车留在森林里吗？”纳布问。
en: “Shall we leave the cart in the wood?” asked Neb.

zh: “不，”工程师回答，“它可是我们的军火和粮食车，有必要的时候，它还能成为我们的堑壕。”
en: “No,” replied the engineer, “it is our wagon of ammunition and provisions, and, if necessary, it would serve as an entrenchment.”

zh: “那么，前进！”吉迪恩·史佩莱说。
en: “Forward, then!” said Gideon Spilett.

zh: 小车出了森林，悄悄地朝栅栏驶去。现在夜色非常黑暗，周围还是和刚才潘克洛夫和通讯记者爬过空地时一样的寂静。他们走在厚厚的杂草上，一点声音都没有。移民们保持警惕，时刻准备开枪。贾普听从潘克洛夫的话，呆在了后面。纳布用绳子拴着托普，好阻止它往前跑。
en: The cart emerged from the wood and began to roll noiselessly towards the palisade.The darkness was now profound, the silence as complete as when Pencroft and the reporter crept over the ground.The thick grass completely muffled their footsteps.The colonists held themselves ready to fire.Jup, at Pencroft’s orders, kept behind.Neb led Top in a leash, to prevent him from bounding forward.

zh: 空地很快就在眼前了。一个人都没有。小队毫不犹豫地移动到栅栏那里。在很短的时间里他们就走过了“危险区”。纳布把缰绳拴在了野驴头上。工程师、通讯记者、赫伯特和潘克洛夫走到门口，看看门到底是不是从里面关着。门是开着的！
en: The clearing soon came in sight.It was deserted.Without hesitating, the little band moved towards the palisade.In a short space of time the dangerous zone was passed.Neb remained at the onagers’ heads to hold them.The engineer, the reporter, Herbert, and Pencroft, proceeded to the door, in order to ascertain if it was barricaded inside.It was open!

zh: “这下你们怎么解释？”工程师向水手和史佩莱问道。
en: “What do you say now?” asked the engineer, turning to the sailor and Spilett.

zh: 他们两个都愣住了。
en: Both were stupefied.

zh: “我敢发誓，”潘克洛夫说，“刚才这扇门绝对是关着的！”
en: “I can swear,” said Pencroft, “that this gate was shut just now!”

zh: 移民们犹豫起来了。潘克洛夫和通讯记者来侦察的时候，罪犯们在畜栏里面吗？毫无疑问，如果当时门是关着的，那么肯定是他们把门打开了。他们现在还在里面，还是有一个罪犯刚出去呢？
en: The colonists now hesitated.Were the convicts in the corral when Pencroft and the reporter made their reconnaissance?It could not be doubted, as the gate then closed could only have been opened by them.Were they still there, or had one of their number just gone out?

zh: 所有的问题都同时出现在移民们的脑海里，但是这些问题要怎么来回答呢？
en: All these questions presented themselves simultaneously to the minds of the colonists, but how could they be answered?

zh: 赫伯特已经往栅栏里面走了几步，就在那时候又突然退了出来，抓住了哈丁的手。
en: At that moment, Herbert, who had advanced a few steps into the enclosure, drew back hurriedly, and seized Harding’s hand.

zh: “怎么了？”工程师问。
en: “What’s the matter?” asked the engineer.

zh: “有光！”
en: “A light!”

zh: “屋子里？”
en: “In the house?”

zh: “是的！”
en: “Yes!”

zh: 五个人一起冲了过去。果然，穿过面前的窗户，他们看见有一道微弱的光线在闪动着。赛勒斯·哈丁果断地做了决定。“这是我们唯一的机会，”他对同伴们说，“赶上罪犯们聚集在这个屋子里，没有产生任何怀疑！他们在我们的控制之下！前进！”移民们穿过栅栏，手里拿着已经准备好的枪。小车留在了外面，由贾普和托普看管，它们已经被谨慎地拴在了车上。
en: All five advanced and indeed, through the window fronting them, they saw glimmering a feeble light.Cyrus Harding made up his mind rapidly.“It is our only chance,” said he to his companions, “of finding the convicts collected in this house, suspecting nothing!They are in our power!Forward!”The colonists crossed through the enclosure, holding their guns ready in their hands.The cart had been left outside under the charge of Jup and Top, who had been prudently tied to it.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁、潘克洛夫和吉迪恩·史佩莱在一边，赫伯特和纳布在另一边，在漆黑冷清的畜栏里沿着栅栏往前走。
en: Cyrus Harding, Pencroft, and Gideon Spilett on one side, Herbert and Neb on the other, going along by the palisade, surveyed the absolutely dark and deserted corral.

zh: 不久之后他们就到了关着的房门附近。
en: In a few moments they were near the closed door of the house.

zh: 哈丁向同伴们做了个手势，叫他们不要动，自己朝着被屋里微弱的光线照亮的窗户靠近。
en: Harding signed to his companions not to stir, and approached the window, then feebly lighted by the inner light.

zh: 他朝屋里张望了一下。
en: He gazed into the apartment.

zh: 桌子上面点着一盏灯。桌子旁边是艾尔顿以前睡的床。
en: On the table burned a lantern.Near the table was the bed formerly used by Ayrton.

zh: 床上躺着一个人。
en: On the bed lay the body of a man.

zh: 突然，赛勒斯·哈丁退了回来，用沙哑的声音喊道：“艾尔顿！”
en: Suddenly Cyrus Harding drew back, and in a hoarse voice,—“Ayrton!” he exclaimed.

zh: 移民们立刻破门而入，冲到了屋子里。
en: Immediately the door was forced rather than opened, and the colonists rushed into the room.

zh: 艾尔顿好像睡着了。从他的脸色可以看出，他经受了长期而残酷的折磨。他的手腕和脚踝上都有大片的伤痕。
en: Ayrton appeared to be asleep.His countenance showed that he had long and cruelly suffered.On his wrists and ankles could be seen great bruises.

zh: 哈丁朝他弯下了身。
en: Harding bent over him.

zh: “艾尔顿！”工程师抓着他的胳膊大声地叫，他们实在是没有预料到会在这种情况下找到他。
en: “Ayrton!” cried the engineer, seizing the arm of the man whom he had just found again under such unexpected circumstances.

zh: 听到喊声，艾尔顿睁开了眼，先是看了看哈丁，又看了看其他的人。
en: At this exclamation Ayrton opened his eyes, and, gazing at Harding, then at the others,—

zh: “你们！”他叫道，“是你们吗？”
en: “You!” he cried, “you?”

zh: “艾尔顿！艾尔顿！”哈丁重复地叫着。
en: “Ayrton!Ayrton!” repeated Harding.

zh: “这是在哪儿？”
en: “Where am I?”

zh: “在畜栏的房子里！”
en: “In the house in the corral!”

zh: “就我们俩？”
en: “Alone?”

zh: “是的！”
en: “Yes!”

zh: “可是他们会回来的！”艾尔顿大声说，“保护好自己！保护好自己！”
en: “But they will come back!” cried Ayrton.“Defend yourselves! defend yourselves!”

zh: 他耗尽了体力，晕了过去。
en: And he fell back exhausted.

zh: “史佩莱，”工程师大声说，“我们随时都可能遭到进攻。把小车拉到畜栏里来。然后，闩上门，所有人都回到这儿来。
en: “Spilett,” exclaimed the engineer, “we may be attacked at any moment.Bring the cart into the corral.Then, barricade the door, and all come back here.”

zh: 潘克洛夫、纳布和通讯记者急忙去执行工程师的命令。一刻也不能耽搁。说不定现在小车已经落到罪犯们的手上了！
en: Pencroft, Neb, and the reporter hastened to execute the engineer’s orders.There was not a moment to be lost.Perhaps even now the cart was in the hands of the convicts!

zh: 通讯记者和他的两个同伴很快就穿过畜栏，到了栅栏门口。这时托普正在后面愠怒地叫着。
en: In a moment the reporter and his two companions had crossed the corral and reached the gate of the palisade behind which Top was heard growling sullenly.

zh: 工程师暂时离开了艾尔顿，走到外面准备开枪。赫伯特就在他的旁边。他们都在观察畜栏上方的支脉顶峰处的动静。如果罪犯们埋伏在那里，他们可以把移民们一个接一个地都打死。
en: The engineer, leaving Ayrton for an instant, came out ready to fire.Herbert was at his side.Both surveyed the crest of the spur overlooking the corral.If the convicts were lying in ambush there, they might knock the settlers over one after the other.

zh: 这时候，月亮从东方升起来了，悬挂在森林的黑幕上空，一抹白色的月光洒在栅栏里面。畜栏里面茂盛的树木、浇灌它的小溪和遍地的野草，一时间都被照亮了。从山的那边看，房屋和一部分栅栏在月光照映下白得很显眼。大门对面的栅栏处还黑着。不久之后，一团黑漆漆的东西出现了。小车出现在月光照射的范围内，当同伴们关门上闩时，赛勒斯·哈丁能听到门发出的声音。
en: At that moment the moon appeared in the east, above the black curtain of the forest, and a white sheet of light spread over the interior of the enclosure.The corral, with its clumps of trees, the little stream which watered it, its wide carpet of grass, was suddenly illuminated.From the side of the mountain, the house and a part of the palisade stood out white in the moonlight.On the opposite side towards the door, the enclosure remained dark.A black mass soon appeared.This was the cart entering the circle of light, and Cyrus Harding could hear the noise made by the door, as his companions shut it and fastened the interior bars.

zh: 但是，就在那一刻，托普挣脱了束缚，开始愤怒地狂叫，冲向了畜栏的后面，也就是房子的右边。
en: But, at that moment, Top, breaking loose, began to bark furiously and rush to the back of the corral, to the right of the house.

zh: “准备开枪，朋友们！”哈丁大声地说。
en: “Be ready to fire, my friends!” cried Harding.

zh: 移民们举起了枪，随时准备射击。
en: The colonists raised their pieces and waited the moment to fire.

zh: 托普还在不停地叫，贾普朝托普跑去，也发出尖锐的叫声。
en: Top still barked, and Jup, running towards the dog, uttered shrill cries.

zh: 移民们跟着贾普，来到了大树遮挡下的小溪边。在皎洁的月光下，他们看到了什么？五具尸体，四仰八叉地躺在河岸上！
en: The colonists followed him, and reached the borders of the little stream, shaded by large trees.And there, in the bright moonlight, what did they see?Five corpses, stretched on the bank!

zh: 他们正是四个月之前，在林肯岛上登陆的那伙罪犯！
en: They were those of the convicts who, four months previously, had landed on Lincoln Island!

zh: 第十三章
en: Chapter 13

zh: 这到底是怎么回事？是谁杀了这些罪犯？是艾尔顿吗？不会啊，刚才他还担心罪犯们会回来呢！
en: How had it happened? who had killed the convicts?Was it Ayrton?No, for a moment before he was dreading their return.

zh: 但是艾尔顿现在陷入了深度昏迷中，不太可能把他叫起来。自从刚才说完了那几句话，他就失去了知觉，一动不动地躺在床上。
en: But Ayrton was now in a profound stupor, from which it was no longer possible to rouse him.After uttering those few words he had again become unconscious, and had fallen back motionless on the bed.

zh: 移民们百思不得其解，感到非常纳闷。由于极度兴奋，他们在艾尔顿的房间里等了整整一夜，再也没有回到躺着罪犯们的尸体的地方去。很可能艾尔顿也不能解释这些尸体是怎么回事，因为他连自己在畜栏里都不知道。但是至少他能给大家讲讲这个恐怖的场面发生之前的情况。第二天，艾尔顿从昏迷状态中苏醒过来。在分别了104天之后，看到他几乎安然无恙，同伴们发自内心地表现出极度的喜悦。
en: The colonists, a prey to a thousand confused thoughts, under the influence of violent excitement, waited all night, without leaving Ayrton’s house, or returning to the spot where lay the bodies of the convicts.It was very probable that Ayrton would not be able to throw any light on the circumstances under which the bodies had been found, since he himself was not aware that he was in the corral.But at any rate he would be in a position to give an account of what had taken place before this terrible execution.The next day Ayrton awoke from his torpor, and his companions cordially manifested all the joy they felt, on seeing him again, almost safe and sound, after a hundred and four days separation.

zh: 艾尔顿简短地讲述了事情的经过——至少是讲了他所知道的一切。
en: Ayrton then in a few words recounted what had happened, or, at least, as much as he knew.

zh: 去年的11月10号，也就是他到达畜栏的第二天晚上，罪犯们翻过栅栏，突袭了他。他们把他绑了起来，堵住他的嘴，然后把他带到富兰克林山麓的一个黑暗的山洞里，那儿就是他们的巢穴。
en: The day after his arrival at the corral, on the 10th of last November, at nightfall, he was surprised by the convicts, who had scaled the palisade.They bound and gagged him; then he was led to a dark cavern, at the foot of Mount Franklin, where the convicts had taken refuge.

zh: 他们决定把他杀死。第二天，他们正准备杀他的时候，其中的一个罪犯认出了他，并叫出了他在澳洲出生时使用过的名字。如果是艾尔顿，他们肯定会毫不犹豫地把他杀了！可眼前这个人是彭·觉斯，他们把他留了下来！
en: His death had been decided upon, and the next day the convicts were about to kill him, when one of them recognized him and called him by the name which he bore in Australia.The wretches had no scruples as to murdering Ayrton!They spared Ben Joyce!

zh: 但是，从这一刻开始，艾尔顿要直面他过去的同谋的强求。他们希望他能重新入伙，依靠他的帮助，进入他们至今仍未能接近的花岗石宫，占领那里，杀死那里的移民们，成为这个岛的主人！
en: But from that moment Ayrton was exposed to the importunities of his former accomplices.They wished him to join them again, and relied upon his aid to enable them to gain possession of Granite House, to penetrate into that hitherto inaccessible dwelling, and to become masters of the island, after murdering the colonists!

zh: 艾尔顿的态度始终坚定不移。这个昔日的罪犯，现在已经悔过自新并得到了宽恕；他宁可牺牲自己的性命，也不愿背叛他的同伴们。艾尔顿被绑着手脚，堵着嘴，在这个山洞里被密切监视了四个月。
en: Ayrton remained firm.The once convict, now repentant and pardoned, would rather die than betray his companions.Ayrton—bound, gagged, and closely watched—lived in this cave for four months.

zh: 虽然，在到达这个岛上不久，罪犯们就发现了畜栏，并且，从那时候起，他们一直依靠艾尔顿储存的食物生存，但是他们始终没有住在畜栏里。
en: Nevertheless the convicts had discovered the corral a short time after their arrival in the island, and since then they had subsisted on Ayrton’s stores, but did not live at the corral.

zh: 11月11号，移民们的到来让其中的两个匪徒大吃一惊，他们朝赫伯特开枪，其中的一个跑了回去，向其他的罪犯们夸耀说自己打死了岛上的一个居民，可是他却是一个人回来的。前面已经说过了，他的同伴被赛勒斯·哈丁用匕首杀死了。
en: On the 11th of November, two of the villains, surprised by the colonists’ arrival, fired at Herbert, and one of them returned, boasting of having killed one of the inhabitants of the island; but he returned alone.His companion, as is known, fell by Cyrus Harding’s dagger.

zh: 可以想象得出，艾尔顿得知赫伯特牺牲的消息时，有多么的不安和绝望。现在只剩下四个移民了，而他们似乎还处在罪犯们的魔爪之下。这件事情之后，在移民们因赫伯特养伤而耽搁在畜栏里的这段时间里，海盗们一直没有离开山洞，甚至在他们掠夺了眺望岗的高地之后，为了谨慎起见，他们还是没有放弃这里。
