en: Ayrton’s anxiety and despair may be imagined when he learned the news of Herbert’s death.The settlers were now only four, and, as it seemed, at the mercy of the convicts.After this event, and during all the time that the colonists, detained by Herbert’s illness, remained in the corral, the pirates did not leave their cavern, and even after they had pillaged the plateau of Prospect Heights, they did not think it prudent to abandon it.

zh: 这时候，他们变本加厉地折磨艾尔顿。由于他整天都被绑着，手上和脚上到现在还有绳子留下的血痕。看上去是没有什么逃走的可能性了，眼下他最希望的就是赶紧被处死。
en: The ill-treatment inflicted on Ayrton was now redoubled.His hands and feet still bore the bloody marks of the cords which bound him day and night.Every moment he expected to be put to death, nor did it appear possible that he could escape.

zh: 这种情况一直持续到了二月份的第三个礼拜。罪犯们很少离开他们的老巢，仅仅是有的时候到荒岛的内陆或南岸一带打过几次猎，但是他们一直在等待着有利的时机。
en: Matters remained thus until the third week of February.The convicts, still watching for a favorable opportunity, rarely quitted their retreat, and only made a few hunting excursions, either to the interior of the island, or the south coast.

zh: 在这之后艾尔顿一直没有听到关于他的同伴们的消息，他已经不再奢望见他们一面了。最后，这个不幸的人被折磨得日渐虚弱，陷入了虚脱状态，视觉和听觉都严重地减退了。也就是说，从那时起的两天以来发生的所有事情他都一无所知。
en: Ayrton had no further news of his friends, and relinquished all hope of ever seeing them again.At last, the unfortunate man, weakened by ill-treatment, fell into a prostration so profound that sight and hearing failed him.From that moment, that is to say, since the last two days, he could give no information whatever of what had occurred.

zh: “但是，哈丁队长，”他补充道，“既然我被囚禁在那个山洞里，我怎么会到畜栏里来呢？”
en: “But, Captain Harding,” he added, “since I was imprisoned in that cavern, how is it that I find myself in the corral?”

zh: “罪犯们又怎么会死在栅栏里面呢？”工程师反问道。
en: “How is it that the convicts are lying yonder dead, in the middle of the enclosure?” answered the engineer.

zh: “死了！”艾尔顿不顾身体的虚弱，从床上半撑起身子大叫道。
en: “Dead!” cried Ayrton, half rising from his bed, notwithstanding his weakness.

zh: 同伴们扶着他。他想要爬起来，在同伴们的帮助下，他下了床。于是他们一同向小溪边上走去。
en: His companions supported him.He wished to get up, and with their assistance he did so.They then proceeded together towards the little stream.

zh: 这时天已经大亮了。
en: It was now broad daylight.

zh: 就在河边上，躺着五个罪犯的尸体，从他们的样子看上去应该是刚被打死不久。
en: There, on the bank, in the position in which they had been stricken by death in its most instantaneous form, lay the corpses of the five convicts!

zh: 艾尔顿愣住了。哈丁和他的同伴们看着他，一句话也没有说。纳布和潘克洛夫按照工程师的手势，去检查那些已经已经被冻得僵直的尸体。
en: Ayrton was astounded.Harding and his companions looked at him without uttering a word.On a sign from the engineer, Neb and Pencroft examined the bodies, already stiffened by the cold.

zh: 尸体上并没有什么明显的伤痕。
en: They bore no apparent trace of any wound.

zh: 经过仔细的检查，潘克洛夫才发现第一具尸体的额头上、第二具尸体的胸膛上、第三具尸体的后背上、第四具尸体的肩膀上各有一个小红点。这是一种很难被发现的创伤，他们还很难推测出到底是怎么形成的。
en: Only, after carefully examining them, Pencroft found on the forehead of one, on the chest of another, on the back of this one, on the shoulder of that, a little red spot, a sort of scarcely visible bruise, the cause of which it was impossible to conjecture.

zh: “他们就是在这里被打中的！”赛勒斯·哈丁说。
en: “It is there that they have been struck!” said Cyrus Harding.

zh: “可是用的是什么样的武器呢？”通讯记者大声地问道。
en: “But with what weapon?” cried the reporter.

zh: “这种武器的效果就像闪电一样，不过我们还不知道它的秘密！”
en: “A weapon, lightning-like in its effects, and of which we have not the secret!”

zh: “那是谁打的呢？”潘克洛夫问。
en: “And who has struck the blow?” asked Pencroft.

zh: “岛上的复仇者，”哈丁回答，“艾尔顿，就是他把你带到这儿来的。他又一次发挥了他的威力，这一路上他总是在我们遇到解决不了的问题时帮助我们，又总是在帮了我们之后避开我们。”
en: “The avenging power of the island,” replied Harding, “he who brought you here, Ayrton, whose influence has once more manifested itself, who does for us all that which we cannot do for ourselves, and who, his will accomplished, conceals himself from us.”

zh: “那么，我们去找他吧！”潘克洛夫叫道。
en: “Let us make search for him, then!” exclaimed Pencroft.

zh: “是的，我们会去找他，”哈丁说，“可是，在他愿意让我们见到他之前，我们是没有办法找到这个创造了这么多奇迹的伟大人物的！”
en: “Yes, we will search for him,” answered Harding, “but we shall not discover this powerful being who performs such wonders, until he pleases to call us to him!”

zh: 这种让他们的行动变得一点用处都没有的看不见的保护让工程师又烦恼又着急。这种相形见绌的情况往往会伤害一个人的自尊心。用拒绝别人感恩的方法来表明自己的慷慨，这也包含了一种瞧不起受惠人的成分，因此，在赛勒斯·哈丁心中，在某种程度上，这样反而在某种程度上降低了这一切的价值。
en: This invisible protection, which rendered their own action unavailing, both irritated and piqued the engineer.The relative inferiority which it proved was of a nature to wound a haughty spirit.A generosity evinced in such a manner as to elude all tokens of gratitude, implied a sort of disdain for those on whom the obligation was conferred, which in Cyrus Harding’s eyes marred, in some degree, the worth of the benefit.

zh: “我们去找吧，”他接着说，“但愿有一天我们能够向这位高傲的保护者证明，他说做的一切并不是为了一群忘恩负义的人！要是我们能够报答他，能够轮到我们为他做点什么，即使要付出生命的代价，我又有什么理由不答应呢？”
en: “Let us search,” he resumed, “and God grant that we may some day be permitted to prove to this haughty protector that he has not to deal with ungrateful people!What would I not give could we repay him, by rendering him in our turn, although at the price of our lives, some signal service!”

zh: 从这一天开始，林肯岛上的居民们的思想就完全被寻找这个人占据着。所有的事情都激励他们去探索这个谜题的答案，这个答案只有可能是一个被赋予了真正的不可思议的能力，甚至某种程度上是超凡能力的人的名字。
en: From this day, the thoughts of the inhabitants of Lincoln Island were solely occupied with the intended search.Everything incited them to discover the answer to this enigma, an answer which would only be the name of a man endowed with a truly inexplicable, and in some degree superhuman power.

zh: 几分钟之后，移民们回到了屋子里。在他们的照料下，艾尔顿的精神和体力很快就恢复了很多。纳布和潘克洛夫把罪犯们的尸体运到了离畜栏不远处的森林里，并深埋起来。
en: In a few minutes, the settlers re-entered the house, where their influence soon restored to Ayrton his moral and physical energy.Neb and Pencroft carried the corpses of the convicts into the forest, some distance from the corral, and buried them deep in the ground.

zh: 他们向艾尔顿讲述了在他被囚禁的这段时间里发生的所有事情。他这才知道赫伯特遭受的危险和移民们经历的种种考验。移民们原本已经对再次见到艾尔顿不抱有什么希望了，他们以为罪犯们已经残忍地把他杀死了。
en: Ayrton was then made acquainted with the facts which had occurred during his seclusion.He learned Herbert’s adventures, and through what various trials the colonists had passed.As to the settlers, they had despaired of ever seeing Ayrton again, and had been convinced that the convicts had ruthlessly murdered him.

zh: “现在，”赛勒斯·哈丁讲完了之后接着说，“我们还有一件事要办。我们的任务只完成了一半，虽然以后我们不必再害怕那群罪犯，但是我们重新成为这个岛的主人并不是依靠我们自己的力量实现的。”
en: “And now,” said Cyrus Harding, as he ended his recital, “a duty remains for us to perform.Half of our task is accomplished, but although the convicts are no longer to be feared, it is not owing to ourselves that we are once more masters of the island.”

zh: “好吧！”吉迪恩·史佩莱说，“我们去搜索富兰克林山支脉那一带复杂的地区吧。我们不会放过任何一个山谷或洞穴！啊！假如有一位通讯记者发现了这个秘密，朋友们，这个人一定是正在和你们说话的我！”
en: “Well!” answered Gideon Spilett, “let us search all this labyrinth of the spurs of Mount Franklin.We will not leave a hollow, not a hole unexplored!Ah! if ever a reporter found himself face to face with a mystery, it is I who now speak to you, my friends!”

zh: “如果找不到那位恩人，我们就不回‘花岗石宫’。”赫伯特说。
en: “And we will not return to Granite House until we have found our benefactor,” said Herbert.

zh: “是的，”工程师说，“凡是人力能达到的，我们都要去做。但是我要重申的是，在他愿意见我们之前，恐怕我们是不会找到他的。”
en: “Yes,” said the engineer, “we will do all that it is humanly possible to do, but I repeat we shall not find him until he himself permits us.”

zh: “我们就呆在畜栏里吗？”潘克洛夫问。
en: “Shall we stay at the corral?” asked Pencroft.

zh: “是的，”哈丁回答，“这里有足够的粮食，而且又正好是我们要搜索的范围的中心。再有，在必要的时候，大车可以让我们迅速回到‘花岗石宫’。”
en: “We shall stay here,” answered Harding.“Provisions are abundant, and we are here in the very center of the circle we have to explore.Besides, if necessary, the cart will take us rapidly to Granite House.”

zh: “好！”水手说，“不过我还要提醒一件事。”
en: “Good!” answered the sailor.“Only I have a remark to make.”

zh: “什么事？”
en: “What is it?”

zh: “现在正值好季节，我们不能忘了我们还要航海。”
en: “Here is the fine season getting on, and we must not forget that we have a voyage to make.”

zh: “航海？”吉迪恩·史佩莱问。
en: “A voyage?” said Gideon Spilett.

zh: “是啊，去达抱岛，”潘克洛夫回答说，“必须给那里送个信儿，告诉他们我们这个岛的位置，还要说明艾尔顿在这儿以便苏格兰游船来这儿把他接走。说不定现在已经来不及了，谁知道呢？”
en: “Yes, to Tabor Island,” answered Pencroft.“It is necessary to carry a notice there to point out the position of our island and say that Ayrton is here in case the Scotch yacht should come to take him off.Who knows if it is not already too late?”

zh: “可是，潘克洛夫，”艾尔顿问道，“你打算怎么航海呢？”
en: “But, Pencroft,” asked Ayrton, “how do you intend to make this voyage?”

zh: “用‘乘风破浪号’。”
en: “In the ‘Bonadventure.’”

zh: “‘乘风破浪号’！”艾尔顿大声地说，“早就不复存在了。”
en: “The ‘Bonadventure!’” exclaimed Ayrton.“She no longer exists.”

zh: “我的‘乘风破浪号’不存在了？”潘克洛夫从座位上跳了起来，大声叫道。
en: “My ‘Bonadventure’ exists no longer!” shouted Pencroft, bounding from his seat.

zh: “不在了，”艾尔顿说，“八天之前，罪犯们在小港湾里发现了它，乘着它出海，后来……”
en: “No,” answered Ayrton.“The convicts discovered her in her little harbor only eight days ago, they put to sea in her—”

zh: “怎么样了？”潘克洛夫心跳得厉害，一个劲儿追问。
en: “And?” said Pencroft, his heart beating.

zh: “因为没有鲍勃·哈维掌舵，他们撞到了石头上，把船撞得粉碎。”
en: “And not having Bob Harvey to steer her, they ran on the rocks, and the vessel went to pieces.”

zh: “啊！这些强盗、土匪、不知廉耻的家伙！”潘克洛夫大骂起来。
en: “Oh, the villains, the cutthroats, the infamous scoundrels!” exclaimed Pencroft.

zh: “潘克洛夫，”赫伯特拉着水手的手，对他说，“我们可以再造一艘新的‘乘风破浪号’——比以前那艘更大的。我们有所有的铁器，双桅船上面的整套锁具都可以拿来随便用。”
en: “Pencroft,” said Herbert, taking the sailor’s hand, “we will build another ‘Bonadventure’—a larger one.We have all the ironwork—all the rigging of the brig at our disposal.”

zh: “可是，你知道吗，”潘克洛夫说，“想要建一艘三四十吨的船，至少要花上五六个月呢！”
en: “But do you know,” returned Pencroft, “that it will take at least five or six months to build a vessel of from thirty to forty tons?”

zh: “我们可以充分利用时间，”通讯记者说，“看来我们必须放弃今年去达抱岛的念头了。”
en: “We can take our time,” said the reporter, “and we must give up the voyage to Tabor Island for this year.”

zh: “唉，我的‘乘风破浪号’！我可怜的‘乘风破浪号’！”潘克洛夫得知他一向引以为豪的船被毁了，他的心几乎要碎了。
en: “Oh, my ‘Bonadventure!’ my poor ‘Bonadventure!’” cried Pencroft, almost broken-hearted at the destruction of the vessel of which he was so proud.

zh: 对于移民们来说，失去“乘风破浪号”的确是一件值得惋惜的事情。他们都觉得应该尽快弥补这一损失。这个问题决定之后，他们现在开始搜索这个岛上最隐蔽的地方了。
en: The loss of the “Bonadventure” was certainly a thing to be lamented by the colonists, and it was agreed that this loss should be repaired as soon as possible.This settled, they now occupied themselves with bringing their researches to bear on the most secret parts of the island.

zh: 2月19号破晓时分，他们出发去探险，前后一共经历了一个星期。山麓的支脉和无数的分支使整个山区地带形成了错综复杂的谷地和丘陵。显然峡谷的深处，甚至也许连富兰克林山的内部也包括在内，都是他们要搜索的区域。如果有人想在这个岛上找到一个别人发现不了的住处，没有比这里更合适的地方了。这些山谷的地形实在是太复杂了，赛勒斯·哈丁只好严格地按顺序搜查。
en: The exploration was commenced at daybreak on the 19th of February, and lasted an entire week.The base of the mountain, with its spurs and their numberless ramifications, formed a labyrinth of valleys and elevations.It was evident that there, in the depths of these narrow gorges, perhaps even in the interior of Mount Franklin itself, was the proper place to pursue their researches.No part of the island could have been more suitable to conceal a dwelling whose occupant wished to remain unknown.But so irregular was the formation of the valleys that Cyrus Harding was obliged to conduct the exploration in a strictly methodical manner.

zh: 移民们首先到了通向火山南部的山谷，瀑布河一开始就是从这里流过的。艾尔顿把大家带到了罪犯们藏身的山洞，在没有回到畜栏之前，他就是在这里被监禁的。山洞还是和艾尔顿离开的时候一样。他们发现那里有不少的火药和粮食，都是罪犯们从别的地方搬来然后储藏在这里的。
en: The colonists first visited the valley opening to the south of the volcano, and which first received the waters of Falls River.There Ayrton showed them the cavern where the convicts had taken refuge, and in which he had been imprisoned until his removal to the corral.This cavern was just as Ayrton had left it.They found there a considerable quantity of ammunition and provisions, conveyed thither by the convicts in order to form a reserve.

zh: 整个山谷位于山洞旁边，被枞树和其他的树木覆盖着。他们全都搜了一遍，走过西南支脉的拐角处，移民们进入了一条细长的峡谷，这里的景致和分布着奇形怪状的玄武石柱的海岸十分接近。这里树木稀疏，乱石取代了荒草。山羊和魔弗仑羊在岩石间跳跃。从这里开始就是岛上荒芜的区域了。虽然富兰克林山麓向各处分散出了很多的山谷，但是可以看得出，这里的峡谷和畜栏那里的山谷一样，遍布着树木和牧草的只有三座。畜栏的山谷西面是瀑布河河谷，东面是红河河谷。这两股溪流由附近山里的泉水汇合而成，滋润了山南一带肥沃的土地。细水流到下游之后，和许多支流汇聚在一起形成了河流。慈悲河则是由啄木鸟林中充足的泉水直接汇合形成的，这种泉水流向各处，形成无数溪流，浇灌了盘蛇半岛上的土地。
en: The whole of the valley bordering on the cave, shaded by fir and other trees, was thoroughly explored, and on turning the point of the southwestern spur, the colonists entered a narrower gorge similar to the picturesque columns of basalt on the coast.Here the trees were fewer.Stones took the place of grass.Goats and musmons gambolled among the rocks.Here began the barren part of the island.It could already be seen that, of the numerous valleys branching off at the base of Mount Franklin, three only were wooded and rich in pasturage like that of the corral, which bordered on the west on the Falls River valley, and on the east on the Red Creek valley.These two streams, which lower down became rivers by the absorption of several tributaries, were formed by all the springs of the mountain and thus caused the fertility of its southern part.As to the Mercy, it was more directly fed from ample springs concealed under the cover of Jacamar Wood, and it was by springs of this nature, spreading in a thousand streamlets, that the soil of the Serpentine Peninsula was watered.

zh: 眼下，这三条水量充足的河谷，哪一条都有可能成为独居者的藏身之处，因为生活必须的一切在这里应有尽有。移民们将它们都搜查了一遍，可是没有发现任何地方有人的存在。
en: Now, of these three well-watered valleys, either might have served as a retreat to some solitary who would have found there everything necessary for life.But the settlers had already explored them, and in no part had they discovered the presence of man.

zh: 这位独居者和他的住所会不会在那些荒芜的峡谷深处、乱石丛中、北部崎岖的溪谷里或是熔岩流经的地方呢？
en: Was it then in the depths of those barren gorges, in the midst of the piles of rock, in the rugged northern ravines, among the streams of lava, that this dwelling and its occupant would be found?

zh: 富兰克林山的北部有两条很宽阔却不是很深的山谷，里面没有任何植被，只有铺在谷底的熔岩和零乱散布的各种岩石，包括火山岩石和大块矿石。这一地区需要长时间的仔细搜查。这里有上千个山洞，虽然不适合居住，但是非常隐蔽，很难进入。
en: The northern part of Mount Franklin was at its base composed solely of two valleys, wide, not very deep, without any appearance of vegetation, strewn with masses of rock, paved with lava, and varied with great blocks of mineral.This region required a long and careful exploration.It contained a thousand cavities, comfortless no doubt, but perfectly concealed and difficult of access.

zh: 移民们甚至进入那些可以追溯到火山爆发时期的黑暗的地道，一直走到深山里。地道里面还有火焰熏黑的痕迹。他们摇晃着火把，穿过黑暗的走廊，连最小的洞隙处都不放过。他们还查看了那些不是很深的地道，但里面一片黑暗和寂静。这些古老的地道看来从没有人走过，这里的石块也没有人移动过——它们都保持着荒岛在海底时火山把它们喷射出水面时的样子。
en: The colonists even visited dark tunnels, dating from the volcanic period, still black from the passage of the fire, and penetrated into the depths of the mountain.They traversed these somber galleries, waving lighted torches; they examined the smallest excavations; they sounded the shallowest depths, but all was dark and silent.It did not appear that the foot of man had ever before trodden these ancient passages, or that his arm had ever displaced one of these blocks, which remained as the volcano had cast them up above the waters, at the time of the submersion of the island.

zh: 然而，虽然这些地道看上去非常荒凉和阴暗，赛勒斯·哈丁必须承认这里并不是一点声音都没有。
en: However, although these passages appeared to be absolutely deserted, and the obscurity was complete, Cyrus Harding was obliged to confess that absolute silence did not reign there.

zh: 他们到达一个足有几百英尺深的、直通深山内部的阴暗洞底时，工程师被一个低沉的隆隆声吓了一跳，由于有岩石的回响，声音变得更大了。
en: On arriving at the end of one of these gloomy caverns, extending several hundred feet into the interior of the mountain, he was surprised to hear a deep rumbling noise, increased in intensity by the sonorousness of the rocks.

zh: 陪同他的吉迪恩·史佩莱也听到了远处传来的隆隆声，这说明地下的火复燃了。他们俩听了很久，都认为地底下正在发生着某些化学变化。
en: Gideon Spilett, who accompanied him, also heard these distant mutterings, which indicated a revivification of the subterranean fires.Several times both listened, and they agreed that some chemical process was taking place in the bowels of the earth.

zh: “这么说火山没有完全熄灭？”通讯记者问。
en: “Then the volcano is not totally extinct?” said the reporter.

zh: “可能在我们上次探索火山口之后，”赛勒斯·哈丁说，“发生了一些变化。任何一座被认为已经熄灭的火山，都可能再次大规模爆发的。”
en: “It is possible that since our exploration of the crater,” replied Cyrus Harding, “some change has occurred.Any volcano, although considered extinct, may evidently again burst forth.”

zh: “可是，如果富兰克林山再次爆发，”史佩莱问，“林肯岛会不会有什么危险呢？”
en: “But if an eruption of Mount Franklin occurred,” asked Spilett, “would there not be some danger to Lincoln Island?”

zh: “我想不会的，”通讯记者回答说，“火山口好比安全阀，它的存在就使得烟和岩浆从这里喷出来，就像之前那样，从这条出口出去。”
en: “I do not think so,” answered the reporter.“The crater, that is to say, the safety-valve, exists, and the overflow of smoke and lava, would escape, as it did formerly, by this customary outlet.”

zh: “除非岩浆朝着岛上富饶的地区又冲出一条新的路！”
en: “Unless the lava opened a new way for itself towards the fertile parts of the island!”

zh: “亲爱的史佩莱，”赛勒斯·哈丁说，“为什么它不会沿着原来的路呢？”
en: “And why, my dear Spilett,” answered Cyrus Harding, “should it not follow the road naturally traced out for it?”

zh: “火山的性子是反复无常的。”通讯记者说。
en: “Well, volcanoes are capricious,” returned the reporter.

zh: “注意，”工程师说，“富兰克林山的斜度使水朝我们现在探索的山谷里留。要想改变水流的方向，必须发生一次地震来改变山的重心。”
en: “Notice,” answered the engineer, “that the inclination of Mount Franklin favors the flow of water towards the valleys which we are exploring just now.To turn aside this flow, an earthquake would be necessary to change the mountain’s center of gravity.”

zh: “可是目前恐怕随时都有可能发生地震。”吉迪恩·史佩莱说。
en: “But an earthquake is always to be feared at these times,” observed Gideon Spilett.

zh: “随时，”工程师说，“特别是当地下的力量停歇了很长一段时间，刚开始复活，可能遇到一些障碍。所以，亲爱的史佩莱，火山爆发对我们来说是件很严重的事情，最好它还是不要让它产生复活的念头。但是我们不能阻止它，是不是？万一它真的爆发了，我想眺望岗也不会遭到太严重的威胁。眺望岗和富兰克林山之间的地势很低，如果岩浆朝湖水的方向流过来，它一定会落在沙丘和鲨鱼湾附近的地带的。”
en: “Always,” replied the engineer, “especially when the subterranean forces begin to awake, as they risk meeting with some obstruction, after a long rest.Thus, my dear Spilett, an eruption would be a serious thing for us, and it would be better that the volcano should not have the slightest desire to wake up.But we could not prevent it, could we?At any rate, even if it should occur, I do not think Prospect Heights would he seriously threatened.Between them and the mountain, the ground is considerably depressed, and if the lava should ever take a course towards the lake, it would be cast on the downs and the neighboring parts of Shark Gulf.”

zh: “我们还没看见山顶上有预示着火山要喷发的烟呢。”吉迪恩·史佩莱说。
en: “We have not yet seen any smoke at the top of the mountain, to indicate an approaching eruption,” said Gideon Spilett.

zh: “没错，”哈丁说，“火山口连一丝烟雾都没有冒出来，我昨天刚刚仔细地看过山顶了。但是随着时间的推移，喷火口下部可能会堆积一些岩石、岩烬和凝结了的熔岩，它们随时都可能把我刚才所说的阀门堵住。可是，经过第一次猛烈的爆发之后，所有的障碍都排出了，我向你保证，亲爱的史佩莱，无论是好比锅炉的我们的荒岛，还是好比烟囱的火山，都不会因为气体的压力而爆炸的。不过，我还是要重复一遍，火山最好还是不要爆发。”
en: “No,” answered Harding, “not a vapor escapes from the crater, for it was only yesterday that I attentively surveyed the summit.But it is probable that at the lower part of the chimney, time may have accumulated rocks, cinders, hardened lava, and that this valve of which I spoke, may at any time become overcharged.But at the first serious effort, every obstacle will disappear, and you may be certain, my dear Spilett, that neither the island, which is the boiler, nor the volcano, which is the chimney, will burst under the pressure of gas.Nevertheless, I repeat, it would be better that there should not be an eruption.”

zh: “可是我们没有听错啊，”通讯记者说，“火山的内部确实传来了隆隆声！”
en: “And yet we are not mistaken,” remarked the reporter.“Mutterings can be distinctly heard in the very bowels of the volcano!”

zh: “你说得没错，”工程师说着又仔细地听了听，“这是毫无疑问的。里面正发生着骚动。我们既不能估计它的力量，又无法推测它带来的后果。”
en: “You are right,” said the engineer, again listening attentively.“There can be no doubt of it.A commotion is going on there, of which we can neither estimate the importance nor the ultimate result.”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和吉迪恩·史佩莱从地道出来，和同伴们会合之后，把这些情况告诉了他们。
en: Cyrus Harding and Spilett, on coming out, rejoined their companions, to whom they made known the state of affairs.

zh: “很好！”潘克洛夫说，“火山想作怪了！要是它乐意，就让它试试吧！会有人来制服它的！”
en: “Very well!” cried Pencroft, “The volcano wants to play his pranks!Let him try, if he likes!He will find his master!”

zh: “谁？”纳布问。
en: “Who?” asked Neb.

zh: “我们那位好心肠的天才，纳布，我们那位好心肠的天才一定会把火山的嘴堵起来，如果它敢张嘴的话！”
en: “Our good genius, Neb, our good genius, who will shut his mouth for him, if he so much as pretends to open it!”

zh: 可以看得出，水手对这位荒岛的守护神有绝对的信心。到现在为止，这种神秘的力量已经发挥了很多次了，而且每一次都是通过一种莫名其妙的方式表现出来。确实，他的力量似乎不受任何限制。另外，他还懂得怎样避开移民们最仔细的搜查，尽管他们费尽了心机，尽管他们对于这次探索的热情已经到了执着的程度，他们还是没法找到这个神秘人物的住处。
en: As may be seen, the sailor’s confidence in the tutelary deity of his island was absolute, and, certainly, the occult power, manifested until now in so many inexplicable ways, appeared to be unlimited; but also it knew how to escape the colonists’ most minute researches, for, in spite of all their efforts, in spite of the more than zeal,—the obstinacy,—with which they carried on their exploration, the retreat of the mysterious being could not be discovered.

zh: 从2月19号到2月20号，他们搜查了林肯岛的整个北部地区，连最隐蔽的角落也没有放过。移民们甚至把每块岩石都敲打了一遍。他们的搜查一直延伸到山的边缘。他们来到削平了的火山锥顶，也就是第一排岩石的终点处，然后又来到上面巨大的帽子形状的山脊上，底下就是火山口。
en: From the 19th to the 20th of February the circle of investigation was extended to all the northern region of Lincoln Island, whose most secret nooks were explored.The colonists even went the length of tapping every rock.The search was extended to the extreme verge of the mountain.It was explored thus to the very summit of the truncated cone terminating the first row of rocks, then to the upper ridge of the enormous hat, at the bottom of which opened the crater.

zh: 他们不仅仅做了这些。他们还搜查了深渊处，那里已经没有火了，但在它的深处却传来了清晰的隆隆声。然而，没有任何迹象表明火山将要爆发——既没有烟雾，岩石也不烫。不管是在那里，还是在富兰克林山的其他地方，移民们都没有发现任何他们要找的那个人的踪迹。
en: They did more; they visited the gulf, now extinct, but in whose depths the rumbling could be distinctly heard.However, no sign of smoke or vapor, no heating of the rock, indicated an approaching eruption.But neither there, nor in any other part of Mount Franklin, did the colonists find any traces of him of whom they were in search.

zh: 他们搜查的下一站是沙丘。尽管想要到达鲨鱼湾的平地极其困难，他们还是从下到上、仔仔细细地检查了高耸的海湾里的熔岩峭壁。没有人！什么都没有！
en: Their investigations were then directed to the downs.They carefully examined the high lava-cliffs of Shark Gulf from the base to the crest, although it was extremely difficult to reach even the level of the gulf.No one!—nothing!

zh: 总之，这两句话概括了他们的白费力气和徒劳无功，说明了赛勒斯·哈丁和他的同伴们失望至极，甚至有点恼怒了。
en: Indeed, in these three words was summed up so much fatigue uselessly expended, so much energy producing no results, that somewhat of anger mingled with the discomfiture of Cyrus Harding and his companions.

zh: 现在是时候考虑往回走了，因为这种搜索是不能无限期地拖延下去的。移民们都十分肯定地认为这个神秘的人并不住在荒岛的表面上，于是他们的脑海中出现了各种各样的大胆想象。特别是潘克洛夫和纳布，他们认为这件事情不仅神秘，而且让他们想到了超脱凡人的境界。
en: It was now time to think of returning, for these researches could not be prolonged indefinitely.The colonists were certainly right in believing that the mysterious being did not reside on the surface of the island, and the wildest fancies haunted their excited imaginations.Pencroft and Neb, particularly, were not contented with the mystery, but allowed their imaginations to wander into the domain of the supernatural.

zh: 2月25号，移民们回到了花岗石宫。他们用双股的绳索把弓箭射到了门槛上，重新建立了住宅和地面之间的联系。
en: On the 25th of February the colonists re-entered Granite House, and by means of the double cord, carried by an arrow to the threshold of the door, they re-established communication between their habitation and the ground.

zh: 一个月之后，也就是3月25号，是他们来到林肯岛的三周年纪念日。
en: A month later they commemorated, on the 25th of March, the third anniversary of their arrival on Lincoln Island.

zh: 第十四章
en: Chapter 14

zh: 他们已经从里士满逃出来三年了。在这三年里，他们曾无数次地谈到过心中念念不忘的祖国！
en: Three years had passed away since the escape of the prisoners from Richmond, and how often during those three years had they spoken of their country, always present in their thoughts!

zh: 他们深信内战已经结束了，对于他们来说，北军的正义事业是不可能不获得胜利的。但是，这场可怕的战争中都发生过什么事情呢？有多少人为此付出了血的代价？他们的朋友中有多少在这场战争中牺牲了性命？他们经常谈起这些问题，但是目前他们还不能预知何时才能被允许重新回到祖国。要是能回去一趟，哪怕仅仅是几天也好，再和有人居住的世界恢复社交联系，在故乡和林肯岛之间建立交通，然后在这个他们发现的小岛上度过他们一生中最长、也许是最幸福的时光（而这一切都取决于他们的祖国），这难道真的是一个不可能实现的理想吗？
en: They had no doubt that the civil war was at an end, and to them it appeared impossible that the just cause of the North had not triumphed.But what had been the incidents of this terrible war?How much blood had it not cost?How many of their friends must have fallen in the struggle?They often spoke of these things, without as yet being able to foresee the day when they would be permitted once more to see their country.To return thither, were it but for a few days, to renew the social link with the inhabited world, to establish a communication between their native land and their island, then to pass the longest, perhaps the best, portion of their existence in this colony, founded by them, and which would then be dependent on their country, was this a dream impossible to realize?

zh: 要实现这个理想，只有两种途径：要么有船到林肯岛附近来，要么移民们自己造一艘坚固的船，能够航行到离他们最近的陆地上。
en: There were only two ways of accomplishing it—either a ship must appear off Lincoln Island, or the colonists must themselves build a vessel strong enough to sail to the nearest land.

zh: “只有等我们那位好心肠的天才为我们提供回到祖国的工具了。”潘克洛夫说。
en: “Unless,” said Pencroft, “our good genius, himself provides us with the means of returning to our country.”

zh: 的确，即使现在有人告诉潘克洛夫和纳布，有一艘三百吨重的大船在鲨鱼湾或者气球港等着他们，他们也丝毫不会感到奇怪。在他们的脑子里，似乎没有什么事情是不可能发生的。
en: And, really, had any one told Pencroft and Neb that a ship of 300 tons was waiting for them in Shark Gulf or at Port Balloon, they would not even have made a gesture of surprise.In their state of mind nothing appeared improbable.

zh: 可是赛勒斯·哈丁却不那么有信心，他劝他们面对现实，特别是在造船的问题上，更要现实一点，这确实是一件十分紧急的任务，因为他们要尽快把写明艾尔顿的新地址的信件送到达抱岛上去。
en: But Cyrus Harding, less confident, advised them to confine themselves to fact, and more especially so with regard to the building of a vessel—a really urgent work, since it was for the purpose of depositing, as soon as possible, at Tabor Island a document indicating Ayrton’s new residence.

zh: “乘风破浪号”已经不复存在了，造一艘新船至少要六个月的时间。现在冬天就要来了，在下一年春天到来之前，他们不能航海。
en: As the “Bonadventure” no longer existed, six months at least would be required for the construction of a new vessel.Now winter was approaching, and the voyage would not be made before the following spring.

zh: “在天气转暖之前我们有足够的时间把一切都准备好。”工程师在和潘克洛夫商量这些问题的时候说，“我觉得吧，朋友，既然我们不得不重新造一艘船，最好还是造得大一点儿。我们不能确定苏格兰游船有没有到达抱岛。可能在几个月之前，它到过那里，没有发现艾尔顿的踪迹又离开了那里。最好能造一艘大船，在必要的时候，我们就能乘着它到波利尼西亚群岛或新西兰，这样做不好吗？你觉得怎么样？”
en: “We have time to get everything ready for the fine season,” remarked the engineer, who was consulting with Pencroft about these matters.“I think, therefore, my friend, that since we have to rebuild our vessel it will be best to give her larger dimensions.The arrival of the Scotch yacht at Tabor Island is very uncertain.It may even be that, having arrived several months ago, she has again sailed after having vainly searched for some trace of Ayrton.Will it not then he best to build a ship which, if necessary, could take us either to the Polynesian Archipelago or to New Zealand?What do you think?”

zh: “队长，”水手说，“我觉得无论大船还是小船都能造。木材和工具都不少，只是时间的问题。”
en: “I think, captain,” answered the sailor; “I think that you are as capable of building a large vessel as a small one.Neither the wood nor the tools are wanting.It is only a question of time.”

zh: “造一艘250到300吨的船要几个月？”哈丁问道。
en: “And how many months would be required to build a vessel of from 250 to 300 tons?” asked Harding.

zh: “至少七八个月，”潘克洛夫答道，“而且别忘了，冬天快到了，在严寒的时候很难做木工活。我们必须为可能出现的拖延多算出几个星期的时间。如果能在下个十一月之前把船造好，我们就很幸运了。”
en: “Seven or eight months at least,” replied Pencroft.“But it must not be forgotten that winter is drawing near, and that in severe frost wood is difficult to work.We must calculate on several weeks delay, and if our vessel is ready by next November we may think ourselves very lucky.”

zh: “好，”赛勒斯·哈丁说，“到那时正是航海的好时候，无论是去达抱岛，还是去更远的地方，那个季节对任何航行都是适合的。”
en: “Well,” replied Cyrus Harding, “that will be exactly the most favorable time for undertaking a voyage of any importance, either to Tabor Island or to a more distant land.”

zh: “那就这么定了吧，队长，”水手说，“你去设计图样，工人时刻准备开工。我想艾尔顿可以成为一个得力的助手。”
en: “So it will, captain,” answered the sailor.“Make out your plans then; the workmen are ready, and I imagine that Ayrton can lend us a good helping hand.”

zh: 移民们商量了之后，通过了工程师的方案，的确，这是最好的办法了。造一艘二三百吨的船确实需要花费很大的劳力，但是此前的成功经验让移民们充满了信心。
en: The colonists, having been consulted, approved the engineer’s plan, and it was, indeed, the best thing to be done.It is true that the construction of a ship of from two to three hundred tons would be great labor, but the colonists had confidence in themselves, justified by their previous success.

zh: 于是赛勒斯·哈丁着手设计船的图样，制作船的模型。在这段时间里，他的同伴们去砍伐树木，把木材运来做肋材、船骨和铺板。远西森林里有最好的橡树和榆树。他们在上次远征时打开的通道的基础上开辟出一条可以通行的道路，并把它称作远西路。木材都被运到了“石窟”里，造船厂就设在那儿。由于开辟这条路的时候，需要选择树木，所以道路曲曲弯弯，不过这样一来，也方便了他们去盘蛇半岛的大部分地区。
en: Cyrus Harding then busied himself in drawing the plan of the vessel and making the model.During this time his companions employed themselves in felling and carting trees to furnish the ribs, timbers, and planks.The forest of the Far West supplied the best oaks and elms.They took advantage of the opening already made on their last excursion to form a practicable road, which they named the Far West Road, and the trees were carried to the Chimneys, where the dockyard was established.As to the road in question, the choice of trees had rendered its direction somewhat capricious, but at the same time it facilitated the access to a large part of the Serpentine Peninsula.

zh: 有一点非常重要，他们必须加快伐树和锯木料的进度，因为湿木料是不能用的，而要使它们干燥需要一段时间。因此，木工们在整个四月都忙得不可开交，只有春分刮大风的时候受到了一些影响。贾普动作灵活，给他们很多帮助，它一会儿上树系绳子，一会儿用它结实的肩膀搬运砍下来的树干。
en: It was important that the trees should be quickly felled and cut up, for they could not be used while yet green, and some time was necessary to allow them to get seasoned.The carpenters, therefore, worked vigorously during the month of April, which was troubled only by a few equinoctial gales of some violence.Master Jup aided them dexterously, either by climbing to the top of a tree to fasten the ropes or by lending his stout shoulders to carry the lopped trunks.

zh: 他们把所有木材都堆在了“石窟”旁边的大棚子里以留用。
en: All this timber was piled up under a large shed, built near the Chimneys, and there awaited the time for use.

zh: 四月份的天气相当晴朗，和北半球的十月差不多。与此同时，他们也在积极地进行着其他工作。不久之后，眺望岗的高地上连一丝被破坏过的痕迹都没有了。磨坊已经重新建好了，家禽场里也盖起了新的建筑。因为禽类的数量大幅度增加，他们必须扩大这些建筑。现在厩房里有五只野驴，除了一只小驴外，其他四只已经被训练得很好，既肯拉车，又肯让人骑。移民们现在有一张犁，两只野驴常常像约克州和肯特基州的耕牛一样拉犁。移民们分工协作，不知疲惫。还有谁能比他们更健康呢？他们为未来提出上千条计划时，花岗石宫的夜晚活跃着怎样的欢乐啊！
en: The month of April was tolerably fine, as October often is in the northern zone.At the same time other work was actively continued, and soon all trace of devastation disappeared from the plateau of Prospect Heights.The mill was rebuilt, and new buildings rose in the poultry-yard.It had appeared necessary to enlarge their dimensions, for the feathered population had increased considerably.The stable now contained five onagers, four of which were well broken, and allowed themselves to be either driven or ridden, and a little colt.The colony now possessed a plow, to which the onagers were yoked like regular Yorkshire or Kentucky oxen.The colonists divided their work, and their arms never tired.Then who could have enjoyed better health than these workers, and what good humor enlivened the evenings in Granite House as they formed a thousand plans for the future!

zh: 现在艾尔顿和大家无论哪方面都步调一致，再也不提他回畜栏去住的话了。但是他还是很伤心，话也很少，虽然经常和同伴们一起工作，却不像大家那么开心。但是在紧急情况时，他却是一个难得的工人——强壮、熟练、灵巧、聪明。每个人都很尊重他、爱护他，这一点他不可能感觉不到。
en: As a matter of course Ayrton shared the common lot in every respect, and there was no longer any talk of his going to live at the corral.Nevertheless he was still sad and reserved, and joined more in the work than in the pleasures of his companions.But he was a valuable workman at need—strong, skilful, ingenious, intelligent.He was esteemed and loved by all, and he could not be ignorant of it.

zh: 在这期间，他们并没有对畜栏置之不理。每隔一天，他们之中的一个人都会驾车或骑驴去那里照看摩弗仑羊和山羊并带回纳布需要的羊奶。一路上还有机会打猎。因此，比起其他人，到畜栏去得最勤的是赫伯特和吉迪恩·史佩莱，他们带着上好的猎枪，由托普在前面带路。花岗石宫里也因此从没有断过野味，大的有水豚、刺鼠、袋鼠和野猪，小的有野鸭、山鸡、松鸡、啄木鸟和鹬。养兔场和蛤蜊场的产品、捉来的海龟、游到慈悲河的美味的鲑鱼、高地上的蔬菜和森林里的野果，各种食物极其丰盛，主厨纳布一个人几乎都保管不过来了。
en: In the meanwhile the corral was not abandoned.Every other day one of the settlers, driving the cart or mounted on an onager, went to look after the flock of musmons and goats and bring back the supply of milk required by Neb.These excursions at the same time afforded opportunities for hunting.Therefore Herbert and Gideon Spilett, with Top in front, traversed more often than their companions the road to the corral, and with the capital guns which they carried, capybaras, agouties, kangaroos, and wild pigs for large game, ducks, grouse, jacamars, and snipe for small game, were never wanting in the house.The produce of the warren, of the oyster-bed, several turtles which were taken, excellent salmon which came up the Mercy, vegetables from the plateau, wild fruit from the forest, were riches upon riches, and Neb, the head cook, could scarcely by himself store them away.

zh: 当然，畜栏和花岗石宫之间的电报线已经修好了，如果有人去了畜栏后必须留在那里过夜，就会通过电报取得联系。此外，现在岛上已经安全了，他们至少不必担心受到人类的袭击了。
en: The telegraphic wire between the corral and Granite House had of course been repaired, and it was worked whenever one or other of the settlers was at the corral and found it necessary to spend the night there.Besides, the island was safe now and no attacks were to be feared, at any rate from men.

zh: 然而，发生过的事情有可能会再次发生。他们要经常提防着有海盗或是逃犯流窜到这里。有可能鲍勃·哈维的同伴或党羽知道他的秘密计划，他们可能会受到诱惑想要效仿他。因此，移民们仔细地观察荒岛附近的海面，每天都用望远镜瞭望联合湾和华盛顿湾之间的海面。他们去畜栏的时候，也会检查西边的海面，不敢有丝毫怠慢。他们还会爬到支脉上，这样就可以看到西边海平面的绝大部分了。
en: However, that which had happened might happen again.A descent of pirates, or even of escaped convicts, was always to be feared.It was possible that companions or accomplices of Bob Harvey had been in the secret of his plans, and might be tempted to imitate him.The colonists, therefore, were careful to observe the sea around the island, and every day their telescope covered the horizon enclosed by Union and Washington Bays. when they went to the corral they examined the sea to the west with no less attention, and by climbing the spur their gaze extended over a large section of the western horizon.

zh: 他们没有发现任何可疑的东西，但是小心防备还是很有必要的。
en: Nothing suspicious was discerned, but still it was necessary for them to be on their guard.

zh: 一天晚上，工程师向他的同伴们宣布了为畜栏修筑防御工事所构思的计划。为了谨慎起见，他认为应该加高栅栏并在侧面建一个木屋，在必要的时候，移民们可以用它来防御敌人。因为拥有极好的位置条件，可以说花岗石宫是坚不可摧的；因此，不管是什么样的海盗，只要他们一登陆，一准儿会把畜栏和那里的建筑物、贮藏物资和牲畜当作目标。如果移民们不得已被困在里面，他们也能够保护自己不受任何威胁。这是一个值得考虑的计划，但是他们要等到转年春天才能实行这个计划。
en: The engineer one evening imparted to his friends a plan which he had conceived for fortifying the corral.It appeared prudent to him to heighten the palisade and to flank it with a sort of blockhouse, which, if necessary, the settlers could hold against the enemy.Granite House might, by its very position, be considered impregnable; therefore the corral with its buildings, its stores, and the animals it contained, would always be the object of pirates, whoever they were, who might land on the island, and should the colonists be obliged to shut themselves up there they ought also to be able to defend themselves without any disadvantage.This was a project which might be left for consideration, and they were, besides, obliged to put off its execution until the next spring.

zh: 5月15号前后，他们把新船的龙骨造好了，放在造船所里；不久之后，船首材和船尾材也已经用榫头分别接在了龙骨的两头，几乎垂直地立了起来。用优质的橡木制成的长达110英尺的龙骨上面可以架一根宽25英尺的船中央横梁。但是，在严寒和恶劣天气到来之前，木匠们能做的也只有这些了。接下来的一周里，他们装好了第一批船尾的肋材，然后就不得不暂时停止工作。
en: About the 15th of May the keel of the new vessel lay along the dockyard, and soon the stem and stern-post, mortised at each of its extremities, rose almost perpendicularly.The keel, of good oak, measured 110 feet in length, this allowing a width of five-and-twenty feet to the midship beam.But this was all the carpenters could do before the arrival of the frosts and bad weather.During the following week they fixed the first of the stern timbers, but were then obliged to suspend work.

zh: 在这个月的最后几天，天气已经变得非常糟糕了。大风从东面吹来，有时像暴风一样猛烈。工程师有些担心造船所的棚子，可是，他却不能把它盖在花岗石宫周围的其他地方，因为小岛不能完全挡住冲向海岸的疯狂的海水，在暴风雨猛烈的时候，波涛甚至会一直冲到花岗石壁的脚下。
en: During the last days of the month the weather was extremely bad.The wind blew from the east, sometimes with the violence of a tempest.The engineer was somewhat uneasy on account of the dockyard shed—which besides, he could not have established in any other place near to Granite House—for the islet only imperfectly sheltered the shore from the fury of the open sea, and in great storms the waves beat against the very foot of the granite cliff.

zh: 所幸这些顾虑并没有成为现实。大风转向了东南方向，遗物角把整个花岗石宫的海滩遮挡起来。
en: But, very fortunately, these fears were not realized.The wind shifted to the southeast, and there the beach of Granite House was completely covered by Flotsam Point.

zh: 参加造船工作的人中，潘克洛夫和艾尔顿是最有热情的，他们总是尽可能地坚持工作。他们不介意狂风吹过头顶，也不在乎暴雨淋湿身体，不管天气好坏，他们总是抡起锤子干活。但是，这场雨过后紧跟着就是一阵严寒，木头的纤维变得像铁一样坚硬，加工起来非常困难。6月10号前后，造船的工作不得不全部暂停了。
en: Pencroft and Ayrton, the most zealous workmen at the new vessel, pursued their labor as long as they could.They were not men to mind the wind tearing at their hair, nor the rain wetting them to the skin, and a blow from a hammer is worth just as much in bad as in fine weather.But when a severe frost succeeded this wet period, the wood, its fibers acquiring the hardness of iron, became extremely difficult to work, and about the 10th of June shipbuilding was obliged to be entirely discontinued.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和他的同伴们都不能忽略的是，林肯岛上的冬季特别寒冷。寒冷的程度可以和新英格兰各州相比，这几个州和林肯岛几乎处于同一纬度。在北半球，至少是在美洲的英国属地和美国北部地区，这种现象可以解释为北极附近地势平坦，没有突起的地方阻挡北风；但是在林肯岛，这个理由就不充分了。
en: Cyrus Harding and his companions had not omitted to observe how severe was the temperature during the winters of Lincoln Island.The cold was comparable to that experienced in the States of New England, situated at almost the same distance from the equator.In the northern hemisphere, or at any rate in the part occupied by British America and the north of the United States, this phenomenon is explained by the flat conformation of the territories bordering on the pole, and on which there is no intumescence of the soil to oppose any obstacle to the north winds; here, in Lincoln Island, this explanation would not suffice.

zh: “人们甚至已经注意到，”有一天哈丁对他的同伴们说，“纬度相同的岛屿和沿海地区不会像内陆那么冷。比如，我经常听说，伦巴第的冬天并不比苏格兰的冬天暖和，这是因为在冬天的时候苏格兰附近的海洋会把在夏天吸收的热量散发出来。岛屿得益于这种影响，所以情况往往会好一些。”
en: “It has even been observed,” remarked Harding one day to his companions, “that in equal latitudes the islands and coast regions are less tried by the cold than inland countries.I have often heard it asserted that the winters of Lombardy, for example, are not less rigorous than those of Scotland, which results from the sea restoring during the winter the heat which it received during the summer.Islands are, therefore, in a better situation for benefiting by this restitution.”

zh: “那么，哈丁队长，”赫伯特问，“为什么林肯岛不符合一般规律呢？”
en: “But then, Captain Harding,” asked Herbert, “why does Lincoln Island appear to escape the common law?”

zh: “这很难解释，”工程师回答道，“不过，我猜想这是由于林肯岛位于南半球造成的。孩子，你知道的，南半球比北半球要冷。”
en: “That is difficult to explain,” answered the engineer.“However, I should be disposed to conjecture that this peculiarity results from the situation of the island in the Southern Hemisphere, which, as you know, my boy, is colder than the Northern Hemisphere.”

zh: “是的，”赫伯特说，“南太平洋的冰山与北太平洋相比，出现在纬度较低的地方。”
en: “Yes,” said Herbert, “and icebergs are met with in lower latitudes in the south than in the north of the Pacific.”

zh: “没错，”潘克洛夫说，“我在捕鲸船上当水手的时候，就曾经在合恩角看见过冰山。”
en: “That is true,” remarked Pencroft, “and when I have been serving on board whalers I have seen icebergs off Cape Horn.”

zh: “林肯岛上这么冷，”吉迪恩·史佩莱说，“也许就是因为附近不远的地方有浮冰或是冰山吧。”
en: “The severe cold experienced in Lincoln Island,” said Gideon Spilett, “may then perhaps be explained by the presence of floes or icebergs comparatively near to Lincoln Island.”

zh: “你的想法确实很有道理，亲爱的史佩莱，”赛勒斯·哈丁说，“很显然这里的冬天这么冷是因为我们靠近冰山。我还要请你们注意一个完全属于物理上的原因，它同样可以解释为什么南半球要比北半球冷。事实上，夏季的时候，太阳距离南半球比较近，因此在冬季自然就要远一些。这就解释了为什么冬夏两季的温度会如此悬殊。如果我们觉得林肯岛上的冬天特别冷，反过来我们也不要忘了，这里的夏天特别热。”
en: “Your opinion is very admissible indeed, my dear Spilett,” answered Cyrus Harding, “and it is evidently to the proximity of icebergs that we owe our rigorous winters.I would draw your attention also to an entirely physical cause, which renders the Southern colder than the Northern Hemisphere.In fact, since the sun is nearer to this hemisphere during the summer, it is necessarily more distant during the winter.This explains then the excess of temperature in the two seasons, for, if we find the winters very cold in Lincoln Island, we must not forget that the summers here, on the contrary, are very hot.”

zh: “但是，麻烦您解释一下，队长，”潘克洛夫皱着眉头说，“为什么我们的半球气候这样悬殊呢？这不公平！”
en: “But why, if you please, captain,” asked Pencroft, knitting his brows, “why should our hemisphere, as you say, be so badly divided?It isn’t just, that!”

zh: “潘克洛夫，”工程师笑着回答，“不管公平不公平，我们只能接受它。之所以会这样悬殊，这是因为：地球环绕太阳的轨道并不是圆形的，而是椭圆形，因为它必须符合力学定律。当地球处于椭圆形的轨道上离太阳最远的一个极点时，它就在远日点上；而另外一个离太阳最近的极点就是近日点。现在，南半球正处在冬季，是离太阳最远的时候，所以，这一带地区最为寒冷。没有任何东西可以阻止这一点。潘克洛夫，不管人类的学识有多么的丰富，也绝不能改变上帝创造的宇宙的规律。”
en: “Friend Pencroft,” answered the engineer, laughing, “whether just or not, we must submit to it, and here lies the reason for this peculiarity.The earth does not describe a circle around the sun, but an ellipse, as it must by the laws of rational mechanics.Now, the earth occupies one of the foci of the ellipse, and so at one point in its course is at its apogee, that is, at its farthest from the sun, and at another point it is at its perigee, or nearest to the sun.Now it happens that it is during the winter of the southern countries that it is at its most distant point from the sun, and consequently, in a situation for those regions to feel the greatest cold.Nothing can be done to prevent that, and men, Pencroft, however learned they may be, can never change anything of the cosmographical order established by God Himself.”

zh: “但是，”潘克洛夫补充道，“我们已经对这个世界了解得够多的了。队长，如果要把人们所知道的一切写成一本书，这本书会有多大啊！”
en: “And yet,” added Pencroft, “the world is very learned. what a big book, captain, might be made with all that is known!”

zh: “可是要把人们不知道的事情写成一本书，要比你说的那本大得多！”哈丁回答道。
en: “And what a much bigger book still with all that is not known!” answered Harding.

zh: 不管是什么原因，最终六月份依旧还是那么寒冷，移民们只好成天呆在花岗石宫里。啊！这种被监禁的生活对于他们，特别是对吉迪恩·史佩莱来说是多么的厌烦啊！
en: At last, for one reason or another, the month of June brought the cold with its accustomed intensity, and the settlers were often confined to Granite House.Ah! how wearisome this imprisonment was to them, and more particularly to Gideon Spilett.

zh: “喂，”有一天他对纳布说，“不管你去了哪儿，如果你能大发慈悲给我订份报纸，我一定把未来的所有财产都给你，绝不反悔！真的，对我来说最开心的事情就是每天早上能知道前一天发生在各地的事情！”
en: “Look here,” said he to Neb one day, “I would give you by notarial deed all the estates which will come to me some day, if you were a good enough fellow to go, no matter where, and subscribe to some newspaper for me!Decidedly the thing that is most essential to my happiness is the knowing every morning what has happened the day before in other places than this!”

zh: 纳布笑了起来。
en: Neb began to laugh.

zh: “老实说，”他说，“我现在考虑的唯一一件事就是我的日常工作！”
en: “’Pon my word,” he replied, “the only thing I think about is my daily work!”

zh: 实际上，室内和室外都有很多工作要做。
en: The truth was that indoors as well as out there was no want of work.

zh: 经过三年坚持不懈的努力工作，林肯岛上移民们的生活现在已经达到鼎盛时期。被毁坏的双桅船成了他们新的财富来源。除了可以装备正在建造中的新船的整套索具之外，各种各样的器皿和工具、武器和弹药、衣服和用具都储藏在了花岗石宫的库房里。他们甚至不需要重新生产那种十分粗糙的材料了。尽管移民们在第一个冬天里饱受严寒的折磨，但是不管现在天气多么糟糕，他们都不必害怕了。他们有许多的亚麻制品，但他们依旧很节省。赛勒斯·哈丁从氯化钠，也就是海盐中，轻而易举地提取出小苏打和氯。小苏打很容易变成碳酸钠，氯可以制成氯化钙，工程师把它们用在各种家庭用途上，特别是用它们漂白亚麻布。此外，他们和古时候的家族人员一样，一年中最多洗四次衣服。这里应该补充一点，吉迪恩·史佩莱在等待邮差给他送报纸的同时，还和潘克洛夫一道充当了洗衣工的角色。
en: The colony of Lincoln Island was now at its highest point of prosperity, achieved by three years of continued hard work.The destruction of the brig had been a new source of riches.Without speaking of the complete rig which would serve for the vessel now on the stocks, utensils and tools of all sorts, weapons and ammunition, clothes and instruments, were now piled in the storerooms of Granite House.It had not even been necessary to resort again to the manufacture of the coarse felt materials.Though the colonists had suffered from cold during their first winter, the bad season might now come without their having any reason to dread its severity.Linen was plentiful also, and besides, they kept it with extreme care.From chloride of sodium, which is nothing else than sea salt, Cyrus Harding easily extracted the soda and chlorine.The soda, which it was easy to change into carbonate of soda, and the chlorine, of which he made chloride of lime, were employed for various domestic purposes, and especially in bleaching linen.Besides, they did not wash more than four times a year, as was done by families in the olden times, and it may be added, that Pencroft and Gideon Spilett, while waiting for the postman to bring him his newspaper, distinguished themselves as washermen.

zh: 冬季的六月、七月和八月就这样过去了。这几个月天气极其寒冷，温度计上显示的气温平均不到华氏8度。可见温度比去年冬天低了。但是，花岗石宫里的炉火烧得是多旺啊！花岗石壁被熏成一条条细长的条纹，像斑马身上的花纹一样。他们不用节约木柴，因为离他们几步远的地方就出产木柴。另外，在造船的时候剩下的一些碎木片使他们能够节省一些煤。相比之下，煤的运输更为困难。
en: So passed the winter months, June, July, and August.They were severe, and the average observations of the thermometer did not give more than eight degrees of Fahrenheit.It was therefore lower in temperature than the preceding winter.But then, what splendid fires blazed continually on the hearths of Granite House, the smoke marking the granite wall with long, zebra-like streaks!Fuel was not spared, as it grew naturally a few steps from them.Besides, the chips of the wood destined for the construction of the ship enabled them to economize the coal, which required more trouble to transport.

zh: 人和牲畜都平安无事。必须承认，小贾普有点怕冷。这大概是它唯一的弱点，移民们很有必要给它做一件厚厚的长袍。它是一个多好的仆人啊！聪明、热心、不知疲倦、慎重、不爱说话，它完全有资格被推举为新旧世界猿猴类里的模范！
en: Men and animals were all well.Master Jup was a little chilly, it must be confessed.This was perhaps his only weakness, and it was necessary to make him a well-padded dressing-gown.But what a servant he was, clever, zealous, indefatigable, not indiscreet, not talkative, and he might have been with reason proposed as a model for all his biped brothers in the Old and New Worlds!

zh: “说到它，”潘克洛夫说，“既然它有四只手，它当然应该把工作干得更好！”
en: “As for that,” said Pencroft, “when one has four hands at one’s service, of course one’s work ought to be done so much the better!”

zh: 实际上，这个聪明的生灵确实干得不错。
en: And indeed the intelligent creature did it well.

zh: 从上次在山的附近进行搜查到现在，已经有七个月了。在这段时间里，包括气候转好的九月，他们没有听到任何关于荒岛上的天才的消息。他的力量没有通过任何方式显现出来。事实上，也不需要他发挥他的力量，因为这里没有发生过什么让移民们头痛的事情。
en: During the seven months which had passed since the last researches made round the mountain, and during the month of September, which brought back fine weather, nothing was heard of the genius of the island.His power was not manifested in any way.It is true that it would have been superfluous, for no incident occurred to put the colonists to any painful trial.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁甚至注意到，即便陌生人真的利用花岗岩跟花岗石宫的移民取得了联系，即便托普曾经凭借直觉也感觉出这一点，但在这段时间里，却没有什么其他的迹象。托普不再咆哮了，猩猩也不再觉得不安了。这两个朋友——它们确实是朋友——既不到井口处徘徊，也不像工程师最初见到它们时那样发出奇怪的叫声和哀怨声了。但是，他能相信关于这个谜题他能了解的就只有这些，他永远也不能找到答案？他能肯定以后再也不会遇到什么事件紧急到能让这个神秘的人出现吗？有谁能预知将来发生的事情呢？
en: Cyrus Harding even observed that if by chance the communication between the unknown and the tenants of Granite House had ever been established through the granite, and if Top’s instinct had as it were felt it, there was no further sign of it during this period.The dog’s growling had entirely ceased, as well as the uneasiness of the orang.The two friends—for they were such—no longer prowled round the opening of the inner well, nor did they bark or whine in that singular way which from the first the engineer had noticed.But could he be sure that this was all that was to be said about this enigma, and that he should never arrive at a solution?Could he be certain that some conjuncture would not occur which would bring the mysterious personage on the scene? who could tell what the future might have in reserve?

zh: 严冬终于过去了。然而，在大地回春的最初几天发生了一件事，很可能会引发严重的后果。
en: At last the winter was ended, but an event, the consequences of which might be serious occurred in the first days of the returning spring.

zh: 9月7号，赛勒斯·哈丁观察火山口的时候发现山顶上烟雾缭绕，第一缕蒸汽升向天空。
en: On the 7th of September, Cyrus Harding, having observed the crater, saw smoke curling round the summit of the mountain, its first vapors rising in the air.

zh: 第十五章
en: Chapter 15

zh: 听到工程师的警告，移民们立即放下手里的工作，默默地注视着富兰克林山的顶峰。
en: The colonists, warned by the engineer, left their work and gazed in silence at the summit of Mount Franklin.

zh: 火山复活了，蒸汽穿过火山口底部的矿物层升了起来。但是，地下的火会引起猛烈的爆炸吗？这是谁也无法预测的。不过，就算有火山爆发的可能，也不大可能整个林肯岛都要受灾。火山里流出来的熔岩并不一定都会带来灾难，而且通过山坡北面上的一条条凝结了的熔岩来判断，这个荒岛肯定已经经受过这样的考验了。此外，根据火山口的形状——它的开口位于上面的边缘地带——可以断定，熔岩应该会被喷到岛上富饶地区对面的那部分区域。
en: The volcano had awoke, and the vapor had penetrated the mineral layer heaped at the bottom of the crater.But would the subterranean fires provoke any violent eruption?This was an event which could not be foreseen.However, even while admitting the possibility of an eruption, it was not probable that the whole of Lincoln Island would suffer from it.The flow of volcanic matter is not always disastrous, and the island had already undergone this trial, as was shown by the streams of lava hardened on the northern slopes of the mountain.Besides, from the shape of the crater—the opening broken in the upper edge—the matter would be thrown to the side opposite the fertile regions of the island.

zh: 然而，过去的情况不一定能够回答未来的问题。在火山的顶峰，经常会出现这样的情况，原来的火山口堵塞了，新的火山口打开了。这样的情况在南北两个半球都曾经出现过——埃得纳火山、波波卡提佩特峰和奥里萨巴火山就是这样，在火山爆发的前夕，所有的担心都不是多余的。实际上，往往伴随着火山爆发发生的地震足以改变火山的内部结构并为岩浆打开一条条新的出路。
en: However, the past did not necessarily answer for the future.Often, at the summit of volcanoes, the old craters close and new ones open.This had occurred in the two hemispheres—at Etna, Popocatepetl, at Orizabaand on the eve of an eruption there is everything to be feared.In fact, an earthquake—a phenomenon which often accompanies volcanic eruption—is enough to change the interior arrangement of a mountain, and to open new outlets for the burning lava.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁向伙伴们解释了这些情况。他毫不夸张地向大家陈述了各种利弊。总之，无论事情怎么发展，他们都没有办法阻止。除非地面因地震发生摇动，要不然花岗石宫的安全大概不会遭到威胁。但是，如果从富兰克林山的南面开出一个新的火山口，畜栏就要面临着严重的危险了。
en: Cyrus Harding explained these things to his companions, and, without exaggerating the state of things, he told them all the pros and cons.After all, they could not prevent it.It did not appear likely that Granite House would be threatened unless the ground was shaken by an earthquake.But the corral would be in great danger should a new crater open in the southern side of Mount Franklin.

zh: 从这一天开始，山顶的烟一直没有消失，移民们甚至可以看到，虽然没有夹杂着火焰，但是喷出来的烟却是越来越高，越来越浓了。特别是在中央火山口较低的地方，这种情况更为突出。
en: From that day the smoke never disappeared from the top of the mountain, and it could even be perceived that it increased in height and thickness, without any flame mingling in its heavy volumes.The phenomenon was still concentrated in the lower part of the central crater.

zh: 不管怎样，随着气候逐渐好转，他们继续工作。他们尽量加快造船的进度。赛勒斯·哈丁利用岸上的瀑布，建起了一个水力锯木机，如此一来，他们很快就把树干锯成了铺板和托梁。这套装置的机械原理和挪威使用的简易锯木机一样简单。先用一个水平的机械装置移动木块，再用一个垂直的机械装置移动钢锯——这就是所有的必要部件了。工程师用一个轮子、两个滚筒和几个滑轮把它正确地装配起来。到了九月底，纵帆船的骨架已经在造船所里完成了。肋材也几乎全都完成了，全部的船骨暂时被细绳支撑着，船的轮廓大致可以看得出来了。这艘纵帆船的船头很尖，后边的部分又细又长，显然非常适合远航。但是铺板的工作还需要一段相当长的时间才能完成。好在海盗的双桅船爆炸之后，他们把上面所有的铁器都保留了下来。潘克洛夫和艾尔顿从铺板和破损的肋材上拔下一些螺丝钉和大量的铜钉。这样一来，他们就可以少做很多铁活了，但是还有很多木工活要做。
en: However, with the fine days work had been continued.The building of the vessel was hastened as much as possible, and, by means of the waterfall on the shore, Cyrus Harding managed to establish an hydraulic sawmill, which rapidly cut up the trunks of trees into planks and joists.The mechanism of this apparatus was as simple as those used in the rustic sawmills of Norway.A first horizontal movement to move the piece of wood, a second vertical movement to move the saw—this was all that was wanted; and the engineer succeeded by means of a wheel, two cylinders, and pulleys properly arranged.Towards the end of the month of September the skeleton of the vessel, which was to be rigged as a schooner, lay in the dockyard.The ribs were almost entirely completed, and, all the timbers having been sustained by a provisional band, the shape of the vessel could already be seen.The schooner, sharp in the bows, very slender in the after-part, would evidently be suitable for a long voyage, if wanted; but laying the planking would still take a considerable time.Very fortunately, the iron work of the pirate brig had been saved after the explosion.From the planks and injured ribs Pencroft and Ayrton had extracted the bolts and a large quantity of copper nails.It was so much work saved for the smiths, but the carpenters had much to do.

zh: 因为要在高地上进行收割，晾晒牧草和收获不同的农作物，造船的工作暂停了一个星期。这项工作结束之后，所有的时间都用来完成纵帆船的建造。每到晚上，工人们都是筋疲力尽。为了不浪费时间，他们改变了吃饭的时间——十二点吃中午饭，天黑之后再吃晚饭。然后他们再爬上花岗石宫睡觉。
en: Shipbuilding was interrupted for a week for the harvest, the haymaking, and the gathering in of the different crops on the plateau.This work finished, every moment was devoted to finishing the schooner.When night came the workmen were really quite exhausted.So as not to lose any time they had changed the hours for their meals; they dined at twelve o’clock, and only had their supper when daylight failed them.They then ascended to Granite House, when they were always ready to go to bed.

zh: 然而，有的时候他们会谈起一些有意思的话题，这就推迟了睡觉的时间。他们谈到将来，每每说到如果可以乘纵帆船到有人居住的地方可能会改变他们现在的情况，他们总是很高兴。但是，在谈论这些计划的时候，再次回到林肯岛的想法总是占上风。他们永远不会放弃这片领地，因为他们花了太多的心血成功地把它建立起来，一旦与美国取得联系，他们就可以得到新的动力。尤其是潘克洛夫和纳布，他们特别希望能够在林肯岛上过一辈子。
en: Sometimes, however, when the conversation bore on some interesting subject the hour for sleep was delayed for a time.The colonists then spoke of the future, and talked willingly of the changes which a voyage in the schooner to inhabited lands would make in their situation.But always, in the midst of these plans, prevailed the thought of a subsequent return to Lincoln Island.Never would they abandon this colony, founded with so much labor and with such success, and to which a communication with America would afford a fresh impetus.Pencroft and Neb especially hoped to end their days there.

zh: “赫伯特，”水手说，“你永远都不会抛弃林肯岛，是不是？”
en: “Herbert,” said the sailor, “you will never abandon Lincoln Island?”

zh: “永远都不会，潘克洛夫，特别是如果你也打定主意要留在这里。”
en: “Never, Pencroft, and especially if you make up your mind to stay there.”

zh: “我早就打定主意了，孩子，”潘克洛夫说，“我会等你。你把你的妻子和孩子带到这儿来，我会把你的孩子们教育成快乐的小家伙！”
en: “That was made up long ago, my boy,” answered Pencroft.“I shall expect you.You will bring me your wife and children, and I shall make jolly chaps of your youngsters!”

zh: “就这么定了！”纳布红着脸，边笑边说。
en: “That’s agreed,” replied Herbert, laughing and blushing at the same time.

zh: “还有你，哈丁队长，”潘克洛夫满腔热忱地接着说，“你还是这个岛的领袖！啊，这里能容得下多少居民？至少一万人！”
en: “And you, Captain Harding,” resumed Pencroft enthusiastically, “you will be still the governor of the island!Ah, how many inhabitants could it support?Ten thousand at least!”

zh: 他们就以这种方式谈论着，让潘克洛夫滔滔不绝地往下说。最后通讯记者真的办了一份报纸——《林肯岛先驱新报》！
en: They talked in this way, allowing Pencroft to run on, and at last the reporter actually started a newspaper—the New Lincoln Herald!

zh: 人们的心就是这样的。从事一项永久不衰的、即使在他死后还能万古长存的事业的愿望正是人类能成为万物之主的原因。正是由于这种信念，人类才在全世界建立起自己的统治、证明了自己的力量。
en: So is man’s heart.The desire to perform a work which will endure, which will survive him, is the origin of his superiority over all other living creatures here below.It is this which has established his dominion, and this it is which justifies it, over all the world.

zh: 除此之外，谁知道贾普和托普是不是也对它们的未来怀有理想呢。
en: After that, who knows if Jup and Top had not themselves their little dream of the future.

zh: 艾尔顿暗暗地告诉自己，他希望能够再次见到格里那凡爵士，让他知道自己已经彻底悔过自新。
en: Ayrton silently said to himself that he would like to see Lord Glenarvan again and show himself to all restored.

zh: 10月15号晚上，谈话的时间比平常要长一些。已经九点了。强忍了半天之后，大家还是打出长长的呵欠，这说明已经到了休息的时间了。潘克洛夫正要走向床边，餐厅里的电铃突然响了起来。
en: One evening, on the 15th of October, the conversation was prolonged later than usual.It was nine o’clock.Already, long badly concealed yawns gave warning of the hour of rest, and Pencroft was proceeding towards his bed, when the electric bell, placed in the dining-room, suddenly rang.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁、吉迪恩·史佩莱、赫伯特、艾尔顿、潘克洛夫、纳布，所有人都在场。也就是说他们谁也没有到畜栏去。
en: All were there, Cyrus Harding, Gideon Spilett, Herbert, Ayrton, Pencroft, Neb.Therefore none of the colonists were at the corral.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁站了起来。同伴们你看看我，我看看你，几乎不敢相信自己的耳朵。
en: Cyrus Harding rose.His companions stared at each other, scarcely believing their ears.

zh: “这是怎么回事？”纳布叫道，“难道是魔鬼在打铃吗？”
en: “What does that mean?” cried Neb.“Was it the devil who rang it?”

zh: 没有人回答。
en: No one answered.

zh: “在这种暴风雨的天气里，”赫伯特说，“会不会是电流的感应……”
en: “The weather is stormy,” observed Herbert.“Might not its influence of electricity—”

zh: 赫伯特没有把话说完。所有人的目光都转向了工程师，他否定地摇了摇头。
en: Herbert did not finish his phrase.The engineer, towards whom all eyes were turned, shook his head negatively.

zh: “我们等一等，”吉迪恩·史佩莱说，“不管是谁，如果要告诉我们什么信号，他一定会再发的。”
en: “We must wait,” said Gideon Spilett.“If it is a signal, whoever it may be who has made it, he will renew it.”

zh: “可是你认为是谁呢？”纳布大声地说。
en: “But who do you think it is?” cried Neb.

zh: “谁？”潘克洛夫回答，“除了他……”
en: “Who?” answered Pencroft, “but he—”

zh: 水手的话被又一声铃响打断了。
en: The sailor’s sentence was cut short by a new tinkle of the bell.

zh: 哈丁走到电报机的旁边，把他的疑问通过电报发给畜栏：
en: Harding went to the apparatus, and sent this question to the corral:—

zh: “你想要什么？”
en: “What do you want?”

zh: 过了一会儿，指针在字码表上来回移动，向花岗石宫里的移民们给出了回答：
en: A few moments later the needle, moving on the alphabetic dial, gave this reply to the tenants of Granite House:—

zh: “马上来畜栏。”
en: “Come to the corral immediately.”

zh: “总算来了！”哈丁大声说。
en: “At last!” exclaimed Harding.

zh: 是啊！总算来了！谜底马上就要揭开了。在强烈的兴趣的鼓舞下，移民们的疲劳消失得干干净净，这种兴趣催促着他们赶紧到畜栏去，他们彻底打消了休息的念头。他们一句话都没说，很快就离开了花岗石宫，来到海滩上。只有贾普和托普留在那里，这次可以不用它们陪着去了。
en: Yes!At last!The mystery was about to be unveiled.The colonists’ fatigue had disappeared before the tremendous interest which was about to urge them to the corral, and all wish for rest had ceased.Without having uttered a word, in a few moments they had left Granite House, and were standing on the beach.Jup and Top alone were left behind.They could do without them.

zh: 夜色非常昏暗。新月和太阳一起消失了。据赫伯特观察，大量的乌云在低空形成了厚厚的穹顶，一丝星光都透不过来。远处的暴风雨中划过几道闪电，照亮了水平线。
en: The night was black.The new moon had disappeared at the same time as the sun.As Herbert had observed, great stormy clouds formed a lowering and heavy vault, preventing any star rays.A few lightning flashes, reflections from a distant storm, illuminated the horizon.

zh: 有可能几个小时之后，岛上就会到处都是雷声了。这个晚上的天气非常恶劣。
en: It was possible that a few hours later the thunder would roll over the island itself.The night was very threatening.

zh: 但是，不管夜色多浓，都不能妨碍他们找到那条无比熟悉的通往畜栏的路。
en: But however deep the darkness was, it would not prevent them from finding the familiar road to the corral.

zh: 他们爬上慈悲河的左岸，来到高地，跨过甘油河上的桥，在森林里前进。
en: They ascended the left bank of the Mercy, reached the plateau, passed the bridge over Creek Glycerine, and advanced through the forest.

zh: 他们怀着无比兴奋的心情加快了步伐。毫无疑问，现在他们就要揭晓这个让他们猜测了很久的谜题的答案了，也就是那个神秘的人的名字。他和移民们的生活有着多么大的关系，帮助他们的时候是多么的慷慨，他的行动是多么的强大有力啊！如果这位陌生人没有和他们共处在一起，不了解最细小的情况，没有听过他们在花岗石宫里说的所有的话，他怎么能总是在最危急的时刻有所行动呢？
en: They walked at a good pace, a prey to the liveliest emotions.There was no doubt but that they were now going to learn the long-searched-for answer to the enigma, the name of that mysterious being, so deeply concerned in their life, so generous in his influence, so powerful in his action!Must not this stranger have indeed mingled with their existence, have known the smallest details, have heard all that was said in Granite House, to have been able always to act in the very nick of time?

zh: 每个人心里都有无数个疑团，大家快速前进。头顶上的树枝浓密，他们都看不清路的边界了。森林里一点声音都没有。在这种气压很低的环境里，飞禽走兽都一动不动的，安静极了。连吹动树叶的微风都没有。只能听见移民的脚步在坚实的地面上发出的回响。
en: Every one, wrapped up in his own reflections, pressed forward.Under the arch of trees the darkness was such that even the edge of the road could not be seen.Not a sound in the forest.Both animals and birds, influenced by the heaviness of the atmosphere, remained motionless and silent.Not a breath disturbed the leaves.The footsteps of the colonists alone resounded on the hardened ground.

zh: 在第一个小时的前十五分钟，只有潘克洛夫的话打破了周围的寂静：
en: During the first quarter of an hour the silence was only interrupted by this remark from Pencroft:—

zh: “我们应该带一个火把。”
en: “We ought to have brought a torch.”

zh: 工程师回答道：
en: And by this reply from the engineer:—

zh: “我们可以在畜栏里找一个。”
en: “We shall find one at the corral.”

zh: 九点十二分时，哈丁和他的同伴们离开花岗石宫。从慈悲河到畜栏一共五英里，九点四十七分时，他们走完了三英里。
en: Harding and his companions had left Granite House at twelve minutes past nine.At forty-seven minutes past nine they had traversed three out of the five miles which separated the mouth of the Mercy from the corral.

zh: 这时，荒岛上方亮起了闪电，照亮了黑暗的森林。电光十分耀眼，照得他们睁不开眼睛。显然，暴风雨很快就要来了。
en: At that moment sheets of lightning spread over the island and illumined the dark trees.The flashes dazzled and almost blinded them.Evidently the storm would not be long in bursting forth.

zh: 闪电渐渐地越来越亮，间隔也越来越短。远处的雷声在空中隆隆作响。环境令人窒息。
en: The flashes gradually became brighter and more rapid.Distant thunder growled in the sky.The atmosphere was stifling.

zh: 移民们好像被一股不可抗拒的力量推动着，快速地前进着。
en: The colonists proceeded as if they were urged onwards by some irresistible force.

zh: 十点钟时，一道耀眼的闪电让他们看见了畜栏的栅栏，他们到达大门的时候，狂风暴雨接踵而至。
en: At ten o’clock a vivid flash showed them the palisade, and as they reached the gate the storm burst forth with tremendous fury.

zh: 很快他们就穿过了畜栏，哈丁来到小屋前。
en: In a minute the corral was crossed, and Harding stood before the hut.

zh: 电报是从畜栏里发出来的，因此大概房子已经被陌生人占领了。然而，并没有灯光从窗户射出来。
en: Probably the house was occupied by the stranger, since it was from thence that the telegram had been sent.However, no light shone through the window.

zh: 工程师敲了一下门。
en: The engineer knocked at the door.

zh: 没有回应。
en: No answer.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁打开门，移民们走了进去，屋里一片漆黑。纳布划了一根火柴，点着了灯笼，灯光照亮了屋子的每个角落。
en: Cyrus Harding opened the door, and the settlers entered the room, which was perfectly dark.A light was struck by Neb, and in a few moments the lantern was lighted and the light thrown into every corner of the room.

zh: 一个人都没有。一切都保持着他们离开时候的样子。
en: There was no one there.Everything was in the state in which it had been left.

zh: “我们是被幻觉蒙蔽了吗？”赛勒斯·哈丁低声说。
en: “Have we been deceived by an illusion?” murmured Cyrus Harding.

zh: 不！这不可能！电报清清楚楚地说：
en: No! that was not possible!The telegram had clearly said,—

zh: “马上来畜栏。”
en: “Come to the corral immediately.”

zh: 他们走到专门用来放电报机的桌子旁边。一切井然有序——电池好好地装在匣子里，电报机依旧保持着原来的样子。
en: They approached the table specially devoted to the use of the wire.Everything was in order—the pile on the box containing it, as well as all the apparatus.

zh: “最后一个来这儿的是谁？”工程师问。
en: “Who came here the last time?” asked the engineer.

zh: “是我，队长。”艾尔顿回答。
en: “I did, captain,” answered Ayrton.

zh: “那是在……”
en: “And that was—”

zh: “四天之前。”
en: “Four days ago.”

zh: “啊！一张字条！”赫伯特指着桌子上的一张纸，大声叫道。
en: “Ah! a note!” cried Herbert, pointing to a paper lying on the table.

zh: 纸上用英文写着这些话：
en: On this paper were written these words in English:—

zh: “沿着新电线一直走。”
en: “Follow the new wire.”

zh: “走吧！”哈丁大声说。这时他明白了，电报并不是从畜栏发出来的，而是通过一根附加在原来的电线上面的新电线，从神秘的住处直接和花岗石宫联系上的。
en: “Forward!” cried Harding, who understood that the despatch had not been sent from the corral, but from the mysterious retreat, communicating directly with Granite House by means of a supplementary wire joined to the old one.

zh: 纳布拿着点亮的灯，大家一起离开畜栏。这时候暴风雨来势凶猛。闪电和雷声的间隙特别短暂。不断冒出烟雾的火山顶不时被闪电照亮。
en: Neb took the lighted lantern, and all left the corral.The storm then burst forth with tremendous violence.The interval between each lightning-flash and each thunder-clap diminished rapidly.The summit of the volcano, with its plume of vapor, could be seen by occasional flashes.

zh: 在畜栏的房屋和栅栏之间到处都找不到电报线。工程师径直跑到第一根电线杆旁边，在闪电的照射下，看见一根新线从绝缘物上一直拖到地面。
en: There was no telegraphic communication in any part of the corral between the house and the palisade; but the engineer, running straight to the first post, saw by the light of a flash a new wire hanging from the isolator to the ground.

zh: “在这儿呢！”他说。
en: “There it is!” said he.

zh: 这根电线拖在地面上，像海下的电缆似的被一层绝缘物体包裹着，这样电流就能在里面自由通过。它似乎穿过森林和富兰克林山的南部支脉，朝着西面一直延伸。
en: This wire lay along the ground, and was surrounded with an isolating substance like a submarine cable, so as to assure the free transmission of the current.It appeared to pass through the wood and the southern spurs of the mountain, and consequently it ran towards the west.

zh: “跟着它走！”赛勒斯·哈丁说。
en: “Follow it!” said Cyrus Harding.

zh: 移民们立刻沿着电线急速往前走。
en: And the settlers immediately pressed forward, guided by the wire.

zh: 雷声继续轰鸣，淹没了他们说话的声音。不过，大家都在尽快往前走，顾不上说话了。
en: The thunder continued to roar with such violence that not a word could be heard.However, there was no occasion for speaking, but to get forward as fast as possible.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和他的同伴们爬上畜栏所在的山谷和瀑布河谷之间突起的支脉，从最狭窄的地方跨过瀑布河。电线有时被放在了较低的树枝上，有时拖在地面上，指引着他们前进的方向。工程师认为电线可能会把他们带到山谷的尽头，那里也就是陌生人的住处了。
en: Cyrus Harding and his companions then climbed the spur rising between the corral valley and that of Falls River, which they crossed at its narrowest part.The wire, sometimes stretched over the lower branches of the trees, sometimes lying on the ground, guided them surely.The engineer had supposed that the wire would perhaps stop at the bottom of the valley, and that the stranger’s retreat would be there.

zh: 然而事实并不是这样。他们不得不爬上西南支脉，再下到贫瘠的高地上，那里的尽头是奇形怪状的、荒凉的玄武岩峭壁。移民们时不时地要弯下腰去摸索电线。现在已经毫无疑问了，电线直接通向大海。他们苦苦寻觅而不得的住处，一定就在那些岩石的深处。
en: Nothing of the sort.They were obliged to ascend the south-western spur, and re-descend on that arid plateau terminated by the strangely-wild basalt cliff.From time to time one of the colonists stooped down and felt for the wire with his hands; but there was now no doubt that the wire was running directly towards the sea.There, to a certainty, in the depths of those rocks, was the dwelling so long sought for in vain.

zh: 天空像着了火似的，不断闪烁着电光。几道闪电打在了浓烟环绕的火山顶上。看上去火山好像在喷火一样。快到十一点的时候，移民们到达了从西面俯瞰大洋的高耸的峭壁上。这时刮起了风。五百英尺之下，海浪在咆哮着。
en: The sky was literally on fire.Flash succeeded flash.Several struck the summit of the volcano in the midst of the thick smoke.It appeared there as if the mountain was vomiting flame.At a few minutes to eleven the colonists arrived on the high cliff overlooking the ocean to the west.The wind had risen.The surf roared 500 feet below.

zh: 哈丁估计他们从畜栏出来之后已经走了一英里半了。
en: Harding calculated that they had gone a mile and a half from the corral.

zh: 电线沿着狭窄的山谷较为陡峭的一边，就在这个地方进入了岩石堆。移民们冒着被摇摇欲坠的岩石砸中的危险顺着电线往前走，随时都有可能掉到海里。尤其是下坡特别困难，但是他们没有顾及到这些危险；他们身不由己，一种不可抗拒的力量就像吸铁石似的，引着他们朝那个神秘的地方走去。
en: At this point the wire entered among the rocks, following the steep side of a narrow ravine.The settlers followed it at the risk of occasioning a fall of the slightly-balanced rocks, and being dashed into the sea.The descent was extremely perilous, but they did not think of the danger; they were no longer masters of themselves, and an irresistible attraction drew them towards this mysterious place as the magnet draws iron.

zh: 即使在大白天，这样的峡谷都是很难通行的，他们竟然不知不觉地沿着它走了下去。
en: Thus they almost unconsciously descended this ravine, which even in broad daylight would have been considered impracticable.

zh: 当他们在亮光中穿行时，岩石滚落，像火球一样闪耀。哈丁走在最前面——艾尔顿走在最后面。他们一步一步往前走，一会儿摔倒在湿滑的岩石上，一会儿挣扎着站起来继续往前爬行。
en: The stones rolled and sparkled like fiery balls when they crossed through the gleams of light.Harding was first—Ayrton last.On they went, step by step.Now they slid over the slippery rock; then they struggled to their feet and scrambled on.

zh: 最终电线到了海滩的岩石堆。移民们已经到了玄武岩峭壁的底部了。
en: At last the wire touched the rocks on the beach.The colonists had reached the bottom of the basalt cliff.

zh: 这里出现了一条狭窄的分水岭，和海面保持着平行的水平方向。移民们沿着电线，在分水岭上往前走。走了不到一百步，分水岭平缓地下降到和海面同一高度。
en: There appeared a narrow ridge, running horizontally and parallel with the sea.The settlers followed the wire along it.They had not gone a hundred paces when the ridge by a moderate incline sloped down to the level of the sea.

zh: 工程师抓住电线，发现它消失在海浪之下。
en: The engineer seized the wire and found that it disappeared beneath the waves.

zh: 他的同伴们个个目瞪口呆。
en: His companions were stupefied.

zh: 他们十分失望，几乎快要绝望地大叫起来！难道他们要钻到水底下去找什么海底洞穴吗？以他们当时兴奋的状态，他们应该会毫不犹豫地这样做。
en: A cry of disappointment, almost a cry of despair, escaped them!Must they then plunge beneath the water and seek there for some submarine cavern?In their excited state they would not have hesitated to do it.

zh: 工程师拦住他们。
en: The engineer stopped them.

zh: 他把同伴们带到一个石洞里，就在那儿——
en: He led his companions to a hollow in the rocks, and there—

zh: “我们必须等一等，”他说，“现在潮水很高。等到潮水落下去，就会有路了。”
en: “We must wait,” said he.“The tide is high.At low water the way will be open.”

zh: “但是你怎么知道的……”潘克洛夫问。
en: “But what can make you think-” asked Pencroft.

zh: “如果我们到不了他那儿，他就不会叫我们来了！”
en: “He would not have called us if the means had been wanting to enable us to reach him!”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁的语气里充满了信心，谁也没有提出反对。再者说，他的说法也合乎逻辑。水位降低的时候，峭壁底部就会出现一条可以通行的道路，尽管现在它被海水淹没了。他们还要等上一段时间。移民们安静地蜷缩在一个很深的山洞里。这时，大雨倾泻而下。雷声在岩石间发出响亮的回音。
en: Cyrus Harding spoke in a tone of such thorough conviction that no objection was raised.His remark, besides, was logical.It was quite possible that an opening, practicable at low water, though hidden now by the high tide, opened at the foot of the cliff.There was some time to wait.The colonists remained silently crouching in a deep hollow.Rain now began to fall in torrents.The thunder was re-echoed among the rocks with a grand sonorousness.

zh: 移民们的情绪非常高涨。他们的脑海中出现了成百上千个稀奇古怪的念头。他们期望见到一个高大的、超出常人的神灵，只有这种形象才能与他们心目中的岛上神秘天才吻合。
en: The colonists’ emotion was great.A thousand strange and extraordinary ideas crossed their brains, and they expected some grand and superhuman apparition, which alone could come up to the notion they had formed of the mysterious genius of the island.

zh: 午夜时分，哈丁拿着灯，下到海滩上去查探。
en: At midnight, Harding carrying the lantern, descended to the beach to reconnoiter.

zh: 果然不出工程师所料，水下露出一个巨大的洞口。就在那儿，电线拐了一个直角，进入开阔的港湾。
en: The engineer was not mistaken.The beginning of an immense excavation could be seen under the water.There the wire, bending at a right angle, entered the yawning gulf.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁回到他的同伴那儿，轻描淡写地说：
en: Cyrus Harding returned to his companions, and said simply,—

zh: “再过一个钟头，洞里就可以通行了。”
en: “In an hour the opening will be practicable.”

zh: “那里真的有洞吗？”潘克洛夫问。
en: “It is there, then?” said Pencroft.

zh: “你还怀疑这一点？”哈丁反问。
en: “Did you doubt it?” returned Harding.

zh: “可是洞里的水位一定很高。”赫伯特说。
en: “But this cavern must be filled with water to a certain height,” observed Herbert.

zh: “要么洞里的水完全干了，”哈丁回答，“那样我们就可以徒步走进去，要么就是没有完全干，但是会有供我们使用的交通工具。”
en: “Either the cavern will be completely dry,” replied Harding, “and in that case we can traverse it on foot, or it will not be dry, and some means of transport will be put at our disposal.”

zh: 一个钟头过去了。大家都冒雨沿着分水岭下到了海面上。这时候洞口已经有八英尺露出水面了。它看上去像桥拱似的，下面就是澎湃的海水。
en: An hour passed.All climbed down through the rain to the level of the sea.There was now eight feet of the opening above the water.It was like the arch of a bridge, under which rushed the foaming water.

zh: 工程师身体前倾，看见了一个黑色的物体在水面上漂浮着。他把它拉过来。那是一艘小船，系在洞里突出的石头上。船身被铁皮包裹着，底部还放着两把桨。
en: Leaning forward, the engineer saw a black object floating on the water.He drew it towards him.It was a boat, moored to some interior projection of the cave.This boat was iron-plated.Two oars lay at the bottom.

zh: “跳上去！”哈丁说。
en: “Jump in!” said Harding.

zh: 移民们立刻上了船。纳布和艾尔顿划着桨，潘克洛夫掌着舵。赛勒斯·哈丁拿着灯，在船头照路。
en: In a moment the settlers were in the boat.Neb and Ayrton took the oars, Pencroft the rudder.Cyrus Harding in the bows, with the lantern, lighted the way.

zh: 小船首先穿过一个椭圆形的突然升高的洞顶，但是周围实在是太黑了，灯光又很微弱，他们无法确定洞的宽度、长度、高度和深度。这个玄武岩的石洞里一点声音都没有。外面的声音，哪怕是隆隆作响的雷声都无法透过厚厚的石壁传到洞里来。
en: The elliptical roof, under which the boat at first passed, suddenly rose; but the darkness was too deep, and the light of the lantern too slight, for either the extent, length, height, or depth of the cave to be ascertained.Solemn silence reigned in this basaltic cavern.Not a sound could penetrate into it, even the thunder peals could not pierce its thick sides.

zh: 世界上的很多地方都有这样的巨大石洞，这些天然的地穴的历史可以追溯到地球的地质时代。有的石洞被海水填满了，有的里面包含着一整个湖泊。赫布利底群岛中的史泰法岛上的芬加尔洞窟、布列塔尼半岛上的杜瓦尔那内港的莫尔加洞窟、科西嘉岛博尼法西奥港的洞窟、挪威来福德洞窟以及肯特基州的500英尺高、20多英里长的巨大的曼莫斯洞窟都是这样的洞窟。在世界上的很多地方，大自然都开凿了这样的洞窟以供人们欣赏。
en: Such immense caves exist in various parts of the world, natural crypts dating from the geological epoch of the globe.Some are filled by the sea; others contain entire lakes in their sides.Such is Fingal’s Cave, in the island of Staffa, one of the Hebrides; such are the caves of Morgat, in the bay of Douarnenez, in Brittany, the caves of Bonifacio, in Corsica, those of Lyse-Fjord, in Norway; such are the immense Mammoth caverns in Kentucky, 500 feet in height, and more than twenty miles in length!In many parts of the globe, nature has excavated these caverns, and preserved them for the admiration of man.

zh: 移民们现在探索的洞窟会不会一直通向荒岛的中心呢？小船又弯弯曲曲地往前走了一刻钟，工程师不时发出简短的指令，为潘克洛夫指方向。
en: Did the cavern which the settlers were now exploring extend to the center of the island?For a quarter of an hour the boat had been advancing, making detours, indicated to Pencroft by the engineer in short sentences, when all at once,—

zh: “再往右一点！”他命令道。
en: “More to the right!” he commanded.

zh: 小船改变了航道，沿着右侧的石壁前进。工程师想看看电线是否一直延伸到这里。
en: The boat, altering its course, came up alongside the right wall.The engineer wished to see if the wire still ran along the side.

zh: 电线就架在身边的岩石上。
en: The wire was there fastened to the rock.

zh: “前进！”哈丁说。
en: “Forward!” said Harding.

zh: 两把桨推着小船在黑暗的水里往前走。
en: And the two oars, plunging into the dark waters, urged the boat onwards.

zh: 他们又划了一刻钟，从洞口到这里肯定有半英里了，这时又听哈丁说：
en: On they went for another quarter of an hour, and a distance of half-a-mile must have been cleared from the mouth of the cave, when Harding’s voice was again heard.

zh: “停下！”
en: “Stop!” said he.

zh: 小船停了下来，移民们看见一道明亮的光线照亮了这个在荒岛内部开凿的巨大的石洞，他们从来没有想到过会有这样一个地方。
en: The boat stopped, and the colonists perceived a bright light illuminating the vast cavern, so deeply excavated in the bowels of the island, of which nothing had ever led them to suspect the existence.

zh: 玄武岩石柱支撑着高达上百英尺的圆形拱顶。这些成千上万的奇怪的石柱从地球形成的最初时期依靠自然的力量竖立起来，上面有许多不规则的穹窿和奇形怪状的花边。玄武岩的石柱一个接着一个，高度从40英尺到50英尺不等。尽管洞外海水汹涌澎湃，洞里的水却平静地冲刷着石柱的底部。工程师指出明亮的光源，光线照遍所有的岩石，倾泻在石壁之上。
en: At a height of a hundred feet rose the vaulted roof, supported on basalt shafts.Irregular arches, strange moldings, appeared on the columns erected by nature in thousands from the first epochs of the formation of the globe.The basalt pillars, fitted one into the other, measured from forty to fifty feet in height, and the water, calm in spite of the tumult outside, washed their base.The brilliant focus of light, pointed out by the engineer, touched every point of rocks, and flooded the walls with light.

zh: 在光线的照耀下，水面泛起明亮的波光，小船看上去像是在两面闪耀的地带之间漂浮着。中心光源向四周发射出光芒，清清楚楚地照亮了洞里的每个角落和每块突出的岩石。这种光的性质移民们不可能弄错。从它那银白的颜色不难看出，光是从电源处发出来的。它是这个洞的太阳，照亮了整个洞窟。
en: By reflection the water reproduced the brilliant sparkles, so that the boat appeared to be floating between two glittering zones.They could not be mistaken in the nature of the irradiation thrown from the glowing nucleus, whose clear rays were shattered by all the angles, all the projections of the cavern.This light proceeded from an electric source, and its white color betrayed its origin.It was the sun of this cave, and it filled it entirely.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁做了一个手势，双桨又开始划动了，有规律地溅起的水花像珠宝一样。小船朝着光源的方向推进，现在他们和那里之间的距离已经不到半锚链了。
en: At a sign from Cyrus Harding the oars again plunged into the water, causing a regular shower of gems, and the boat was urged forward towards the light, which was now not more than half a cable’s length distant.

zh: 在这里水面的宽度大概有350英尺，在耀眼的光源上面，可以看见一面巨大的玄武岩石壁，完全堵住了那边的路。这部分的洞窟很宽，海水形成了一个小湖。电光把洞顶、石壁、尽头的悬崖、所有的棱柱和尖顶都照得灿烂夺目，好像光是从它们身上发出来的。
en: At this place the breadth of the sheet of water measured nearly 350 feet, and beyond the dazzling center could be seen an enormous basaltic wall, blocking up any issue on that side.The cavern widened here considerably, the sea forming a little lake.But the roof, the side walls, the end cliff, all the prisms, all the peaks, were flooded with the electric fluid, so that the brilliancy belonged to them, and as if the light issued from them.

zh: 湖中心漂浮着一个长长的、雪茄烟形状的物体，它安静地、一动不动地浮在水面上。光从它的两侧射出来，就好像是从两个烧得白热的火炉里发出来似的。这个东西的外形像一只巨大的鲸鱼，大约有250英尺长，高出水面10到12英尺。
en: In the center of the lake a long cigar-shaped object floated on the surface of the water, silent, motionless.The brilliancy which issued from it escaped from its sides as from two kilns heated to a white heat.This apparatus, similar in shape to an enormous whale, was about 250 feet long, and rose about ten or twelve above the water.

zh: 小船慢慢地向它靠近，赛勒斯·哈丁站在船头。他凝视着，兴奋得不能自已。然后，他突然抓住通讯记者的胳膊：
en: The boat slowly approached it, Cyrus Harding stood up in the bows.He gazed, a prey to violent excitement.Then, all at once, seizing the reporter’s arm,—

zh: “是他！一定是他！”他叫道，“他……”
en: “It is he!It can only be he!” he cried, “he!—”

zh: 然后，他坐回到自己的位置上，低声地说了一个名字，只有吉迪恩·史佩莱听到他说了什么。
en: Then, falling back on the seat, he murmured a name which Gideon Spilett alone could hear.

zh: 显然通讯记者知道这个名字，因为他听了之后，反应很奇怪，然后他用沙哑的声音说：
en: The reporter evidently knew this name, for it had a wonderful effect upon him, and he answered in a hoarse voice,—

zh: “他！那个逃犯！”
en: “He! an outlawed man!”

zh: “是他！”哈丁说。
en: “He!” said Harding.

zh: 按照工程师的命令，小船逐渐靠近这个奇怪的漂浮物。船被停在了它的左边，一道光线穿过厚厚的玻璃从这里射了出来。
en: At the engineer’s command the boat approached this singular floating apparatus.The boat touched the left side, from which escaped a ray of light through a thick glass.

zh: 哈丁和他的同伴们登上平台。那里有一个打开的舱口。大家一同朝那儿冲下去。
en: Harding and his companions mounted on the platform.An open hatchway was there.All darted down the opening.

zh: 梯子的底部连着的甲板被电灯照亮。甲板的尽头有一扇关着的门，哈丁把门打开。
en: At the bottom of the ladder was a deck, lighted by electricity.At the end of this deck was a door, which Harding opened.

zh: 这是一间装饰得富丽堂皇的房间，移民们迅速穿了过去，来到隔壁的书房。从书房上方明亮的天花板上投下一片光辉。
en: A richly-ornamented room, quickly traversed by the colonists, was joined to a library, over which a luminous ceiling shed a flood of light.

zh: 书房的尽头有一扇同样也是关着的大门，工程师把它打开。
en: At the end of the library a large door, also shut, was opened by the engineer.

zh: 这是一间宽敞的大厅——这里像博物馆似的，各种珍贵的矿物质成品、艺术品和令人惊奇的工业品呈现在移民们眼前，让他们觉得自己好像突然间到了魅力之境。
en: An immense saloon—a sort of museum, in which were heaped up, with all the treasures of the mineral world, works of art, marvels of industry—appeared before the eyes of the colonists, who almost thought themselves suddenly transported into a land of enchantment.

zh: 他们看见在一张高贵的沙发上躺着一个人，那个人似乎没有察觉到他们的到来。
en: Stretched on a rich sofa they saw a man, who did not appear to notice their presence.

zh: 然后哈丁开口了。让他的同伴们极为惊讶的是，他说了下面的话：
en: Then Harding raised his voice, and to the extreme surprise of his companions, he uttered these words,—

zh: “尼摩船长，是你叫我们来的！我们来了！”
en: “Captain Nemo, you asked for us!We are here.—”

zh: 第十六章
en: Chapter 16

zh: 听了这几句话以后，倚在沙发上的人站了起来。电灯的灯光照在他的脸上，他相貌俊朗，高高的额头，眼神熠熠有光，胡须雪白，头发浓密，一直垂到肩膀上。
en: At these words the reclining figure rose, and the electric light fell upon his countenance; a magnificent head, the forehead high, the glance commanding, beard white, hair abundant and falling over the shoulders.

zh: 他的一只手还撑在刚才起身时靠的沙发垫上。他表现得十分平静。很明显，由于患病，他的体力已经渐渐衰弱了。但他的声音还是那么有力，他十分惊讶地用英语说道：
en: His hand rested upon the cushion of the divan from which he had just risen.He appeared perfectly calm.It was evident that his strength had been gradually undermined by illness, but his voice seemed yet powerful, as he said in English, and in a tone which evinced extreme surprise,—

zh: “先生，我没有名字。”
en: “Sir, I have no name.”

zh: “可是，我认识你！”赛勒斯·哈丁回答道。
en: “Nevertheless, I know you!” replied Cyrus Harding.

zh: 尼摩船长用尖锐的眼光盯着工程师，好像要吃了他一样。
