en: Captain Nemo fixed his penetrating gaze upon the engineer, as though he were about to annihilate him.

zh: 然后，他又靠回到沙发的垫子上。
en: Then, falling back amid the pillows of the divan,—

zh: “即便如此，现在还有什么关系？”他低声地说，“我就要死了！”
en: “After all, what matters now?” he murmured; “I am dying!”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁走到船长身边，吉迪恩·史佩莱握住他的手——从手的温度看，他在发高烧。艾尔顿、潘克洛夫、赫伯特和纳布在大厅远处的角落里恭恭敬敬地站着。这个华丽的大厅里充满了电灯灯光。
en: Cyrus Harding drew near the captain, and Gideon Spilett took his hand—it was of a feverish heat.Ayrton, Pencroft, Herbert, and Neb stood respectfully apart in an angle of the magnificent saloon, whose atmosphere was saturated with the electric fluid.

zh: 这时，尼摩船长把手缩回去，示意工程师和通讯记者坐下。
en: Meanwhile Captain Nemo withdrew his hand, and motioned the engineer and the reporter to be seated.

zh: 大家都怀着深切激动的心情看着他。在他们面前的就是被大家尊为“岛上的天才”的那个人，这个强大的保护者，他在不同的场合，一次次对他们进行救援，而且每次救援都那么有效，他们欠下这位恩人多少恩情！在他们眼前的只不过是一个人，一个快要死的人，而此前潘克洛夫和纳布还以为会发现一个超自然的圣人！
en: All regarded him with profound emotion.Before them they beheld that being whom they had styled the “genius of the island,” the powerful protector whose intervention, in so many circumstances, had been so efficacious, the benefactor to whom they owed such a debt of gratitude!Their eyes beheld a man only, and a man at the point of death, where Pencroft and Neb had expected to find an almost supernatural being!

zh: 可是，塞勒斯·哈丁是怎么认出尼摩船长的呢？为什么尼摩听到塞勒斯说出这个名字时突然站起身来呢？尼摩船长以为谁也不知道他的名字。
en: But how happened it that Cyrus Harding had recognized Captain Nemo? why had the latter so suddenly risen on hearing this name uttered, a name which he had believed known to none?—

zh: 船长又重新躺回沙发上，他把头枕在一只胳膊上，望着坐在旁边的工程师。
en: The captain had resumed his position on the divan, and leaning on his arm, he regarded the engineer, seated near him.

zh: “你知道我过去的名字，先生？”他问道。
en: “You know the name I formerly bore, sir?” he asked.

zh: “是的，”赛勒斯·哈丁回答道，“还有这只神奇的潜水艇的名字……”
en: “I do,” answered Cyrus Harding, “and also that of this wonderful submarine vessel—”

zh: “‘诺第留斯号’吗？”船长淡淡地笑了笑。
en: “The ‘Nautilus’?” said the captain, with a faint smile.

zh: “是的，是‘诺第留斯号’。”
en: “The ‘Nautilus.’”

zh: “可是你……你知道我是谁吗？”
en: “But do you—do you know who I am?”

zh: “我知道。”
en: “I do.”

zh: “我与世隔绝已经很多年了。我在海底度过了漫长的30年，这是我找到的唯一自由的地方！是谁出卖了我的秘密呢？”
en: “It is nevertheless many years since I have held any communication with the inhabited world; three long years have I passed in the depth of the sea, the only place where I have found liberty!Who then can have betrayed my secret?”

zh: “是一个不受您约束的人，尼摩船长，所以，您不能责备他背叛您。”
en: “A man who was bound to you by no tie, Captain Nemo, and who, consequently, cannot be accused of treachery.”

zh: “是16年前偶然来到我船上的那个法国人吗？”
en: “The Frenchman who was cast on board my vessel by chance sixteen years since?”

zh: “是的。”
en: “The same.”

zh: “他和他的两个同伴并没有在大漩涡里遇难，当时‘诺第留斯号’正在漩涡中间挣扎？”
en: “He and his two companions did not then perish in the maelstrom, in the midst of which the ‘Nautilus’ was struggling?”

zh: “他们逃脱了，而且还写了一本叫《海底两万里》的书，书里写了您的历史。”
en: “They escaped, and a book has appeared under the title of ‘Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea,’ which contains your history.”

zh: “那只是我一生中的几个月的历史！”船长冲动地打断了他的话。
en: “The history of a few months only of my life!” interrupted the captain impetuously.

zh: “是的，”赛勒斯·哈丁回答道，“但是这几个月的奇怪生活已经足够让人们了解您。”
en: “It is true,” answered Cyrus Harding, “but a few months of that strange life have sufficed to make you known.”

zh: “我是个罪人，这是毫无疑问的。”尼摩船长说，他的唇边露出一丝傲慢的微笑。“是的，一个反叛者，也许是一个与人类为敌的反叛者！”
en: “As a great criminal, doubtless!” said Captain Nemo, a haughty smile curling his lips.“Yes, a rebel, perhaps an outlaw against humanity!”

zh: 工程师没有说话。
en: The engineer was silent.

zh: “是吗，先生？”
en: “Well, sir?”

zh: “不应该由我来评判您，尼摩船长，”塞勒斯·哈丁回答道，“至少是关于您过去的生活。我和世界上其他人一样，不知道您选择这种奇怪生活方式的动机是什么。在不知道原因之前，我不能加以评判。但是，我知道的是，我们上了林肯岛之后，不断有人对我们伸出援手保护我们，正是有了这个善良、慷慨、万能的人，我们才能活下来，而这个善良、慷慨、万能的人就是您，尼摩船长！”
en: “It is not for me to judge you, Captain Nemo,” answered Cyrus Harding, “at any rate as regards your past life.I am, with the rest of the world, ignorant of the motives which induced you to adopt this strange mode of existence, and I cannot judge of effects without knowing their causes; but what I do know is, that a beneficent hand has constantly protected us since our arrival on Lincoln Island, that we all owe our lives to a good, generous, and powerful being, and that this being so powerful, good and generous, Captain Nemo, is yourself!”

zh: “是我。”船长简短地说。
en: “It is I,” answered the captain simply.

zh: 工程师和通讯记者站起身来。伙伴们也靠拢过来，他们内心的感激之情就要通过动作和言语表达出来。
en: The engineer and the reporter rose.Their companions had drawn near, and the gratitude with which their hearts were charged was about to express itself in their gestures and words.

zh: 尼摩船长做了一个手势阻止了他们，他的声音表明，他无法掩饰激动的情绪。
en: Captain Nemo stopped them by a sign, and in a voice which betrayed more emotion than he doubtless intended to show.

zh: “等你们把故事听完吧。”他说。
en: “Wait till you have heard all,” he said.

zh: 船长用短短几句话，讲述了他的往事。
en: And the captain, in a few concise sentences, ran over the events of his life.

zh: 他的叙述很短，然而他却不得不振奋起最后的全部精力把故事讲完。十分明显，他在和极度虚弱的身体做斗争。好几次，赛勒斯·哈丁都恳求他休息一会儿，但是他摇了摇头，好像再没有明天一样。当通讯记者提出要为他医治时，
en: His narrative was short, yet he was obliged to summon up his whole remaining energy to arrive at the end.He was evidently contending against extreme weakness.Several times Cyrus Harding entreated him to repose for a while, but he shook his head as a man to whom the morrow may never come, and when the reporter offered his assistance,—

zh: “没用了”，他说，“我已时日不多。”
en: “It is useless,” he said; “my hours are numbered.”

zh: 尼摩船长是印度的达卡王子，本德尔汗德君王的儿子，当时本德尔汗德还保持独立。他十岁那年，他的父亲把他送到欧洲去接受全面的教育，希望将来他能凭借自己的才干和学识，领导长期落后的祖国赶上欧洲国家。
en: Captain Nemo was an Indian, the Prince Dakkar, son of a rajah of the then independent territory of Bundelkund.His father sent him, when ten years of age, to Europe, in order that he might receive an education in all respects complete, and in the hopes that by his talents and knowledge he might one day take a leading part in raising his long degraded and heathen country to a level with the nations of Europe.

zh: 达卡王子天资聪颖，从十岁到三十岁，他积累了各方面知识，在科学、文学和艺术方面都有很深的造诣。
en: From the age of ten years to that of thirty Prince Dakkar, endowed by Nature with her richest gifts of intellect, accumulated knowledge of every kind, and in science, literature, and art his researches were extensive and profound.

zh: 他游历了整个欧洲。他的出身和财富使得到处有人逢迎追捧。但是，世间的欢愉并不能引起他的兴趣。他虽然年轻，又富有各种优势，但他总是非常严肃，甚至是忧郁。他的求知欲十分强烈，他内心强烈希望能成为一个伟大而强有力的领导者，领导自由而文明的人民。
en: He traveled over the whole of Europe.His rank and fortune caused him to be everywhere sought after; but the pleasures of the world had for him no attractions.Though young and possessed of every personal advantage, he was ever grave—somber even—devoured by an unquenchable thirst for knowledge, and cherishing in the recesses of his heart the hope that he might become a great and powerful ruler of a free and enlightened people.

zh: 然而，长久以来，他对科学的热爱胜过了其他的情感。他成了一个被艺术深深打动的艺术家，懂得各种高深科学的哲学家和通晓欧洲宫廷政策的政治家。对于那些从表面上观察他的人来说，人们也许会认为他是一个世界主义者，求知若渴却轻视行动；一个富有的旅行者，孤傲清高，不断地从一个地方走到另一个地方却没有祖国。
en: Still, for long the love of science triumphed over all other feelings.He became an artist deeply impressed by the marvels of art, a philosopher to whom no one of the higher sciences was unknown, a statesman versed in the policy of European courts.To the eyes of those who observed him superficially he might have passed for one of those cosmopolitans, curious of knowledge, but disdaining action; one of those opulent travelers, haughty and cynical, who move incessantly from place to place, and are of no country.

zh: （事实上，尼摩船长的故事已经出版在那本名为《海底两万里》的书中。前文提到艾尔顿的冒险经历时，在日期方面存在的偏差可以在这里得到印证。在这点上，读者应该参照已出版那本书上的注释。）
en: (The history of Captain Nemo has, in fact, been published under the title of “Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea.”Here, therefore, will apply the observation already made as to the adventures of Ayrton with regard to the discrepancy of dates.Readers should therefore refer to the note already published on this point.)

zh: 然而，这位艺术家、哲学家仍然心怀旧时的希望。
en: This artist, this philosopher, this man was, however, still cherishing the hope instilled into him from his earliest days.

zh: 1849年达卡王子回到本德尔汗德。他娶了一个印度贵族女人，她和他一样有着狂热的追求。他们生了两个孩子，夫妇两个都十分喜爱他们。但是家庭的幸福并没有阻止他寻找实现目标的道路。他等待着时机。最后，正如他想像的那样，机会来了。
en: Prince Dakkar returned to Bundelkund in the year 1849.He married a noble Indian lady, who was imbued with an ambition not less ardent than that by which he was inspired.Two children were born to them, whom they tenderly loved.But domestic happiness did not prevent him from seeking to carry out the object at which he aimed.He waited an opportunity.At length, as he vainly fancied, it presented itself.

zh: 在同样雄心勃勃、却不够明智、不够谨慎的其他王子的煽动下，印度人民认为他们可以成功起来反抗英国统治者，这些使他们脱离了混乱、战争与灾祸，并在他们的国家建立了和平和繁荣的统治者。由于他们的无知与迷信，他们沦为狡猾的领导者的工具。
en: Instigated by princes equally ambitious and less sagacious and more unscrupulous than he was, the people of India were persuaded that they might successfully rise against their English rulers, who had brought them out of a state of anarchy and constant warfare and misery, and had established peace and prosperity in their country.Their ignorance and gross superstition made them the facile tools of their designing chiefs.

zh: 1857年，印度士兵爆发了武装起义。达卡王子坚信他实现长期理想的机会到了，很快便投入到起义之中。他立刻把他的才能和财富投入到这项事业中。他身先士卒，战斗在最前线。他和那些不幸的下层人民和被误导的狂热分子一起冒着生命危险战斗。他参加过二十次战斗，负过十次伤，随时做好了牺牲的准备。最终，血腥的叛变被平息了，这场残暴的起义结束了。
en: In 1857 the great sepoy revolt broke out.Prince Dakkar, under the belief that he should thereby have the opportunity of attaining the object of his long-cherished ambition, was easily drawn into it.He forthwith devoted his talents and wealth to the service of this cause.He aided it in person; he fought in the front ranks; he risked his life equally with the humblest of the wretched and misguided fanatics; he was ten times wounded in twenty engagements, seeking death but finding it not, but at length the sanguinary rebels were utterly defeated, and the atrocious mutiny was brought to an end.

zh: 英国在印度的势力从未遭到这样的打击。而且，如果印度士兵像他们希望的那样得到外界的援助，英国在亚洲的影响和霸权也许会成为过去。
en: Never before had the British power in India been exposed to such danger, and if, as they had hoped, the sepoys had received assistance from without, the influence and supremacy in Asia of the United Kingdom would have been a thing of the past.

zh: 那时候，达卡王子的名字家喻户晓。他公开作战，毫不躲藏。当局悬赏要他的头颅，但是他设法逃脱了。
en: The name of Prince Dakkar was at that time well known.He had fought openly and without concealment.A price was set upon his head, but he managed to escape from his pursuers.

zh: 文明永远不会倒退，自然规律推动着文明前进。印度士兵被打败了，以前印度君王统治的土地又沦陷到英国的统治下。
en: Civilization never recedes; the law of necessity ever forces it onwards.The sepoys were vanquished, and the land of the rajahs of old fell again under the rule of England.

zh: 达卡王子没有实现他所追求的献身，回到本德尔汗德的深山中。他一个人在那里生活。希望破灭后他极度失望，对人类的一切表示厌恶，对文明世界也充满了仇恨。他变卖了他的财产，召集了20个最忠诚的伙伴，在某一天悄无声息的消失了。
en: Prince Dakkar, unable to find that death he courted, returned to the mountain fastnesses of Bundelkund.There, alone in the world, overcome by disappointment at the destruction of all his vain hopes, a prey to profound disgust for all human beings, filled with hatred of the civilized world, he realized the wreck of his fortune, assembled some score of his most faithful companions, and one day disappeared, leaving no trace behind.

zh: 那么，他到哪里去寻找在人间找不到的自由了呢？在波浪下，在深海中，在人们找不到的地方。
en: Where, then, did he seek that liberty denied him upon the inhabited earth?Under the waves, in the depths of the ocean, where none could follow.

zh: 这位勇士变成了一位科学家。他在太平洋一个荒岛上建立了造船所，然后按照他的设计建造了一艘潜水船。他利用了一种未来会被人们发现的方法来有效地利用了无穷的电力。电的来源取之不尽，他用电供应他的浮力装置所需，并且作为动力、照明和发热的工具。大海有数不清的宝藏，有无数的鱼类、无数的海藻和庞大的哺乳动物。大海里不仅有大自然供应的一切，而且还有人类丢在海底的东西。这些宝藏充分满足了王子和他的同伴们的需要。于是他最热心的渴求实现了，他再也不和外界联系了。他给他的潜水船命名为“诺第留斯号”，他自称尼摩船长，消失在海底。
en: The warrior became the man of science.Upon a deserted island of the Pacific he established his dockyard, and there a submarine vessel was constructed from his designs.By methods which will at some future day be revealed he had rendered subservient the illimitable forces of electricity, which, extracted from inexhaustible sources, was employed for all the requirements of his floating equipage, as a moving, lighting, and heating agent.The sea, with its countless treasures, its myriads of fish, its numberless wrecks, its enormous mammalia, and not only all that nature supplied, but also all that man had lost in its depths, sufficed for every want of the prince and his crew—and thus was his most ardent desire accomplished, never again to hold communication with the earth.He named his submarine vessel the “Nautilus,” called himself simply Captain Nemo, and disappeared beneath the seas.

zh: 多年以来，这个怪人从南极到北极，游遍了各个大洋。作为被人世间遗弃的人，他在这些未知的地方搜集到无数的珍宝。1702年，西班牙的大帆船在维哥湾丧失的数百万财产成了他用之不尽的财富。他常常用这笔财富匿名资助那些为民族独立而斗争的国家。
en: During many years this strange being visited every ocean, from pole to pole.Outcast of the inhabited earth in these unknown worlds he gathered incalculable treasures.The millions lost in the Bay of Vigo, in 1702, by the galleons of Spain, furnished him with a mine of inexhaustible riches which he devoted always, anonymously, in favor of those nations who fought for the independence of their country.

zh: （这指的是干地奥提人的起义，他们很大程度上得到了尼摩船长的资助。）
en: (This refers to the resurrection of the Candiotes, who were, in fact, largely assisted by Captain Nemo.)

zh: 然而，长久以来，他一直和外界隔绝。直到1866年11月6日的夜间，有三个人来到他的船上。他们中还有一个是法国教授，一个是仆人，还有一个加拿大的渔民。这三个人是在“诺第留斯号”和美国的“亚伯拉罕·林肯号”战舰相撞时落到他的船上的，当时美国战舰正在追逐“诺第留斯号”。
en: For long, however, he had held no communication with his fellow-creatures, when, during the night of the 6th of November, 1866, three men were cast on board his vessel.They were a French professor, his servant, and a Canadian fisherman.These three men had been hurled overboard by a collision which had taken place between the “Nautilus” and the United States frigate “Abraham Lincoln,” which had chased her.

zh: 尼摩船长从这位教授这里得知，“诺第留斯号”有时被人们当作庞大的鲸鱼类哺乳动物，有时被当作一支携带海盗的潜水船，人们在各个海域上搜寻它。
en: Captain Nemo learned from this professor that the “Nautilus,” taken now for a gigantic mammal of the whale species, now for a submarine vessel carrying a crew of pirates, was sought for in every sea.

zh: 他本来可以把这三个人送回大洋的，是命运把他们从大洋里送到了船上，接触到他的神秘生活。他没有这么做，反而将他们当犯人一样囚禁起来。他们在这里呆了七个月，在海底航行了两万海里。他们亲眼见到了旅行中所有的奇迹。
en: He might have returned these three men to the ocean, from whence chance had brought them in contact with his mysterious existence.Instead of doing this he kept them prisoners, and during seven months they were enabled to behold all the wonders of a voyage of twenty thousand leagues under the sea.

zh: 这三个人都不知道尼摩船长的历史。1867年6月22日，他们乘着“诺第留斯号”上的一只小船成功逃脱了。但是当时“诺第留斯号”在挪威海岸附近卷入了大漩涡的中心，船长很自然地认为这三个逃跑的人肯定会被可怕的漩涡卷走，丧身深海里了。他不知道那个法国人和他的两个伙伴竟然奇迹般地被抛上海岸，罗佛敦群岛上的渔民救了他们。他们回到法国后，出版了一本书，叙述了七个月来在“诺第留斯号”上惊险离奇的航海经过。这些故事出版后，一度引起广大读者的好奇心。
en: One day, the 22nd of June, 1867, these three men, who knew nothing of the past history of Captain Nemo, succeeded in escaping in one of the “Nautilus’s” boats.But as at this time the “Nautilus” was drawn into the vortex of the maelstrom, off the coast of Norway, the captain naturally believed that the fugitives, engulfed in that frightful whirlpool, found their death at the bottom of the abyss.He was unaware that the Frenchman and his two companions had been miraculously cast on shore, that the fishermen of the Lofoten Islands had rendered them assistance, and that the professor, on his return to France, had published that work in which seven months of the strange and eventful navigation of the “Nautilus” were narrated and exposed to the curiosity of the public.

zh: 这件事情发生后的很长一段时间里，尼摩船长继续游历于各个海洋之中。但是，他的同伴一个个相继死去，在太平洋的珊瑚礁上找到了长眠之地。后来，这群生活在深海的人只剩下尼摩船长一位孤独的幸存者。
en: For a long time alter this, Captain Nemo continued to live thus, traversing every sea.But one by one his companions died, and found their last resting-place in their cemetery of coral, in the bed of the Pacific.At last Captain Nemo remained the solitary survivor of all those who had taken refuge with him in the depths of the ocean.

zh: 这时候他已经六十岁了。虽然孤身一人，他还是成功将“诺第留斯号”开进了海底的一个石洞，过去他常常把这样的石洞当作港湾。
en: He was now sixty years of age.Although alone, he succeeded in navigating the “Nautilus” towards one of those submarine caverns which had sometimes served him as a harbor.

zh: 这些港口中，有一个就在林肯岛的海底下，当时它已成为“诺第留斯号”的藏身之处。
en: One of these ports was hollowed beneath Lincoln Island, and at this moment furnished an asylum to the “Nautilus.”

zh: 船长在尼摩岛已经住了六个年头。他已经不再航海，而是静静等待死亡。那时候他应该重新回到他昔日的伙伴之中去了，也是在那时，他偶然看到载着南方军的俘虏的气球从天空降落下来。他穿着潜水衣在离岛的海岸几锚链的海底行走，这时工程师正好掉到海里。在同情心的驱使下，船长救了塞勒斯·哈丁。
en: The captain had now remained there six years, navigating the ocean no longer, but awaiting death, and that moment when he should rejoin his former companions, when by chance he observed the descent of the balloon which carried the prisoners of the Confederates.Clad in his diving dress he was walking beneath the water at a few cables’ length from the shore of the island, when the engineer had been thrown into the sea.Moved by a feeling of compassion the captain saved Cyrus Harding.

zh: 他最开始的想法就是远离这五个掉下来的人。但是玄武岩由于火山的影响升出了水面，堵住了他避难的海港，他再也不能从地窟穿行了。虽然水的深度可以让轻便的小船穿出洞口，但是却不能满足“诺第留斯号”进出，因为它吃水很深。
en: His first impulse was to fly from the vicinity of the five castaways; but his harbor refuge was closed, for in consequence of an elevation of the basalt, produced by the influence of volcanic action, he could no longer pass through the entrance of the vault.Though there was sufficient depth of water to allow a light craft to pass the bar, there was not enough for the “Nautilus,” whose draught of water was considerable.

zh: 因此，尼摩船长只得留下来。他偷偷观察着这些被扔到荒岛上一无所有的人们，但是他不愿意让他们发现自己。后来，当他看到这些人很诚实、充满活力又彼此关爱时，他开始对他们的努力产生兴趣。他不由自主地了解了他们所有的秘密。穿上潜水衣，他可以很容易到达花岗石宫内部的井底，沿着凸出的岩石爬到上面的井口处。他听到他们回忆往事，讨论现在和将来。他从他们那里得知，美国国内因为废除奴隶制的问题爆发了大规模的内战。这些人在岛上表现出来的崇高行为值得尼摩船长改变对人的看法。
en: Captain Nemo was compelled, therefore, to remain.He observed these men thrown without resources upon a desert island, but had no wish to be himself discovered by them.By degrees he became interested in their efforts when he saw them honest, energetic, and bound to each other by the ties of friendship.As if despite his wishes, he penetrated all the secrets of their existence.By means of the diving dress he could easily reach the well in the interior of Granite House, and climbing by the projections of rock to its upper orifice he heard the colonists as they recounted the past, and studied the present and future.He learned from them the tremendous conflict of America with America itself, for the abolition of slavery.Yes, these men were worthy to reconcile Captain Nemo with that humanity which they represented so nobly in the island.

zh: 尼摩船长救了赛勒斯·哈丁。他把托普从湖里救出来，又把它带回“石窟”。他在箱子里放了很多对他们很有用的东西放在遗物角，把平底船送回慈悲河。在大猩猩进攻花岗石宫的时候，他把绳梯从上面扔下来，把纸条装在瓶子里，好让他们知道艾尔顿在达抱岛上，把水雷放在海峡底下，引起海峡底下，引起双桅船的爆炸。他还给他们送酸奎宁，把赫伯特从死亡边缘挽救回来。最后，他还用电弹打死了罪犯，他掌握这种电弹的秘密，用它来猎捕海底动物的。这样，许多看似神奇的事情就解释清楚了。这一切都证明了船长的慷慨和才能。
en: Captain Nemo had saved Cyrus Harding.It was he also who had brought back the dog to the Chimneys, who rescued Top from the waters of the lake, who caused to fall at Flotsam Point the case containing so many things useful to the colonists, who conveyed the canoe back into the stream of the Mercy, who cast the cord from the top of Granite House at the time of the attack by the baboons, who made known the presence of Ayrton upon Tabor Island, by means of the document enclosed in the bottle, who caused the explosion of the brig by the shock of a torpedo placed at the bottom of the canal, who saved Herbert from certain death by bringing the sulphate of quinine; and finally, it was he who had killed the convicts with the electric balls, of which he possessed the secret, and which he employed in the chase of submarine creatures.Thus were explained so many apparently supernatural occurrences, and which all proved the generosity and power of the captain.

zh: 然而，这位厌恶人类的贵族愿意给他保护的人们更多的贡献。他还要给他们提出有用的建议。然而，他的心跳逐渐微弱，已经接近死亡。就像我们所知道的那样，他用一根从畜栏通到诺第留斯号的电线，把花岗石宫的人们邀请到这里来。要是他早知道塞勒斯·哈丁知道他的历史，用尼摩船长称呼他，也许他就不会邀请他们来了。
en: Nevertheless, this noble misanthrope longed to benefit his proteges still further.There yet remained much useful advice to give them, and, his heart being softened by the approach of death, he invited, as we are aware, the colonists of Granite House to visit the “Nautilus,” by means of a wire which connected it with the corral.Possibly he would not have done this had he been aware that Cyrus Harding was sufficiently acquainted with his history to address him by the name of Nemo.

zh: 船长对他的一生做了一个总结。然后赛勒斯·哈丁开口讲话了。他回忆了过去发生的事情，这些事情给了他们极大的帮助。他以大家和自己的名义向这位慷慨的恩人表示感谢。
en: The captain concluded the narrative of his life.Cyrus Harding then spoke; he recalled all the incidents which had exercised so beneficent an influence upon the colony, and in the names of his companions and himself thanked the generous being to whom they owed so much.

zh: 但是尼摩船长并不关心这些。他的思绪似乎被一个想法吸引着，他没有握工程师伸过来的手。
en: But Captain Nemo paid little attention; his mind appeared to be absorbed by one idea, and without taking the proffered hand of the engineer,—

zh: “现在，先生，您现在知道我的历史了，您来评判一下吧！”
en: “Now, sir,” said he, “now that you know my history, your judgment!”

zh: 说到这，船长显然是暗示一件重要的事，就是落在他船上的三个陌生人亲眼看到的事情。这件事，那个法国教授把它写进了书里，引起了深远而可怕的影响。在教授和他的两个同伴逃脱前不久，“诺第留斯号”在北大西洋受到一艘巡洋舰的追逐，最后它像一只攻城车，一样毫不留情地把巡洋舰撞沉了。
en: In saying this, the captain evidently alluded to an important incident witnessed by the three strangers thrown on board his vessel, and which the French professor had related in his work, causing a profound and terrible sensation.Some days previous to the flight of the professor and his two companions, the “Nautilus,” being chased by a frigate in the north of the Atlantic had hurled herself as a ram upon this frigate, and sunk her without mercy.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁明白船长的暗示，他沉默了。
en: Cyrus Harding understood the captain’s allusion, and was silent.

zh: “那是敌人的巡洋舰，”尼摩船长大声喊道，这一刻，他又变成达卡王子了，“是敌人的巡洋舰！是它先攻击我的——我被挤在一个狭窄的海湾里——巡洋舰挡住了我的去路，于是，我就把它击沉了！”
en: “It was an enemy’s frigate,” exclaimed Captain Nemo, transformed for an instant into the Prince Dakkar, “an enemy’s frigate!It was she who attacked me—I was in a narrow and shallow bay—the frigate barred my way—and I sank her!”

zh: 接着，他沉默了一会儿接着说：
en: A few moments of silence ensued; then the captain demanded,—

zh: “先生，您是怎么看待我的一生的？”
en: “What think you of my life, gentlemen?”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁向昔日的王子伸出了手，严肃地回答道：“先生，您的错误在于，您认为过去的事情可以重来，与必然的进步抗争。对于这样的错误，有人赞美，有人指责，但只有上帝才能评判是非。一个错误地坚持自己信仰的人可能是我们的敌人，但他仍然会得到我们的尊重。您的错误是我们所崇敬的，您的名字丝毫不畏惧历史的评判。历史从不谴责英雄的荒唐之事，只会谴责它所带来的后果。”
en: Cyrus Harding extended his hand to the ci-devant prince and replied gravely, “Sir, your error was in supposing that the past can be resuscitated, and in contending against inevitable progress.It is one of those errors which some admire, others blame; which God alone can judge.He who is mistaken in an action which he sincerely believes to be right may be an enemy, but retains our esteem.Your error is one that we may admire, and your name has nothing to fear from the judgment of history, which does not condemn heroic folly, but its results.”

zh: 这位老人的胸膛激动地起伏着，他抬起手指向天空——
en: The old man’s breast swelled with emotion, and raising his hand to heaven,—

zh: “那我是错还是对呢？”他喃喃地说。
en: “Was I wrong, or in the right?” he murmured.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁回答：“所有伟大的行动都来自上帝，又回归上帝。尼摩船长，您拯救了我们，我们会永远怀念您的。”
en: Cyrus Harding replied, “All great actions return to God, from whom they are derived.Captain Nemo, we, whom you have succored, shall ever mourn your loss.”

zh: 赫伯特走近船长，跪下身来，亲吻他的手。
en: Herbert, who had drawn near the captain, fell on his knees and kissed his hand.

zh: 这个奄奄一息的老人眼里闪着泪水。“我的孩子，”他说，“愿上帝保佑你！”
en: A tear glistened in the eyes of the dying man.“My child,” he said, “may God bless you!”

zh: 第十七章
en: Chapter 17

zh: 白天来临了。但是光线丝毫照不到洞窟的深处。这时候正在涨潮，堵住了洞窟口。但是，从“诺第留斯号”的天窗里射出去的一束长长的人造光和原来一样光彩熠熠，浮船周围碧波闪闪。
en: Day had returned.No ray of light penetrated into the profundity of the cavern.It being high-water, the entrance was closed by the sea.But the artificial light, which escaped in long streams from the skylights of the “Nautilus” was as vivid as before, and the sheet of water shone around the floating vessel.

zh: 尼摩船长躺回到沙发上，十分疲倦。把他搬到花岗石宫的想法是没用的，因为他早已表达过他的心愿，那就是留在“诺第留斯号”上和那些无价之宝呆在一起，等待即将到来的死亡。
en: An extreme exhaustion now overcame Captain Nemo, who had fallen back upon the divan.It was useless to contemplate removing him to Granite House, for he had expressed his wish to remain in the midst of those marvels of the “Nautilus” which millions could not have purchased, and to wait there for that death which was swiftly approaching.

zh: 经过很长一段时间的虚脱，他几乎完全失去了知觉。赛勒斯·哈丁和吉迪恩·史佩莱小心地观察这个垂死之人的状况。很明显，他的体力在渐渐衰退。他的身躯，曾经一度强壮，然而此刻，却成了一个安放即将逝去的灵魂的脆弱的躯壳。他的全部生命力都集中在心脏和头脑里。
en: During a long interval of prostration, which rendered him almost unconscious, Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett attentively observed the condition of the dying man.It was apparent that his strength was gradually diminishing.That frame, once so robust, was now but the fragile tenement of a departing soul.All of life was concentrated in the heart and head.

zh: 工程师和通讯记者低声商量了一下。还能为这个垂死的人做些什么吗？即使不能救他的命，能不能让他多活几天呢？尼摩船长说过自己的病已是回天乏术了，他毫不畏惧地、平静地等待着死亡。
en: The engineer and reporter consulted in whispers.Was it possible to render any aid to the dying man?Might his life, if not saved, be prolonged for some days?He himself had said that no remedy could avail, and he awaited with tranquillity that death which had for him no terrors.

zh: “我们什么也做不了。”吉迪恩·史佩莱说。
en: “We can do nothing,” said Gideon Spilett.

zh: “可是，是什么把他推向了死亡？”潘克洛夫问。
en: “But of what is he dying?” asked Pencroft.

zh: “生命自然而然衰退了。”通讯记者回答道。
en: “Life is simply fading out,” replied the reporter.

zh: “不过，”水手说，“要是我们把他挪到外面，让他晒晒太阳，呼吸一下新鲜空气，他或许就康复了。”
en: “Nevertheless,” said the sailor, “if we move him into the open air, and the light of the sun, he might perhaps recover.”

zh: “不，潘克洛夫，”工程师答道，“这些尝试都没用。况且，尼摩船长绝不会同意离开他的船。他已经在‘诺第留斯’号生活了三十年，他也希望死在这里。”
en: “No, Pencroft,” answered the engineer, “it is useless to attempt it.Besides, Captain Nemo would never consent to leave his vessel.He has lived for a dozen years on board the ‘Nautilus,’ and on board the ‘Nautilus’ he desires to die.”

zh: 毫无疑问，尼摩船长一定听到了塞勒斯·哈丁的回答，他轻轻抬起了身子，用更加微弱但始终清楚的声音说道：
en: Without doubt Captain Nemo heard Cyrus Harding’s reply, for he raised himself slightly, and in a voice more feeble, but always intelligible,—

zh: “你说的对，先生，”他说，“我要死在这里……这是我的愿望。因此，我对你有一个请求。”
en: “You are right, sir,” he said.“I shall die here—it is my wish; and therefore I have a request to make of you.”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和他的伙伴都凑到长沙发边上来了。他们把坐垫调到舒适的位置，好让这个垂死的人更舒服些。
en: Cyrus Harding and his companions had drawn near the divan, and now arranged the cushions in such a manner as to better support the dying man.

zh: 他们看到他的眼睛在大厅里的珍宝间游离，电灯的光线透过天花板上的花玻璃照亮了整个大厅。他依次观察着隔板上的美丽挂毯上的图画，那些图画出自意大利、佛兰达斯、法国和西班牙顶级画家之手；雕像座上的大理石像和铜像；‪靠着隔板后半部分华丽的风琴；养着最为珍奇水生生物的鱼缸——里面有海藻、植虫、极其名贵的珍珠项圈；最后，他的目光停留在这个博物馆的人字墙上，上面刻着题铭，那是“诺第留斯号”的一句箴言：
en: They saw his eyes wander over all the marvels of this saloon, lighted by the electric rays which fell from the arabesques of the luminous ceiling.He surveyed, one after the other, the pictures hanging from the splendid tapestries of the partitions, the chef-d’oeuvres of the Italian, Flemish, French, and Spanish masters; the statues of marble and bronze on their pedestals; the magnificent organ, leaning against the after-partition; the aquarium, in which bloomed the most wonderful productions of the sea—marine plants, zoophytes, chaplets of pearls of inestimable value; and, finally, his eyes rested on this device, inscribed over the pediment of the museum—the motto of the “Nautilus”—

zh: “动中之动。”
en: “Mobilis in mobile.”

zh: 他眼神中透露出喜爱之情，最后一次停留在这些艺术和自然的珍品上。多年来，他居住在大海深处，他的目光也仅限于这些珍品。
en: His glance seemed to rest fondly for the last time on these masterpieces of art and of nature, to which he had limited his horizon during a sojourn of so many years in the abysses of the seas.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁尊重船长，并没有打扰他的沉思，而是等待他开口说话。
en: Cyrus Harding respected the captain’s silence, and waited till he should speak.

zh: 几分钟后，毫无疑问，这几分钟里，他回顾了自己的一生，尼摩船长转过身来对移民们说：
en: After some minutes, during which, doubtless, he passed in review his whole life, Captain Nemo turned to the colonists and said,

zh: “各位先生，你们认为对我负有什么义务吗？”
en: “You consider yourselves, gentlemen, under some obligations to me?”

zh: “船长，相信我们，我们愿意用我们的生命来延长您的生命。”
en: “Captain, believe us that we would give our lives to prolong yours.”

zh: “那么，答应我，”尼摩船长接着说，“帮我实现最后的愿望，你们就算报答了我为你们所做的一切了。”
en: “Promise, then,” continued Captain Nemo, “to carry out my last wishes, and I shall be repaid for all I have done for you.”

zh: “我们答应。”赛勒斯·哈丁说。
en: “We promise,” said Cyrus Harding.

zh: 这个许诺把他自己和伙伴们都包括在内了。
en: And by this promise he bound both himself and his companions.

zh: “先生们，”船长继续说，“明天我就要死了。”
en: “Gentlemen,” resumed the captain, “to-morrow I shall be dead.”

zh: 赫伯特正要喊出声，船长做了一个手势，阻止了他。
en: Herbert was about to utter an exclamation, but a sign from the captain arrested him.

zh: “明天我就要死了，我不需要其他坟墓，只求留在‘诺第留斯号’上，这就是我的坟墓！我所有的朋友们都长眠于大海的深处，他们安息之地亦是我安息之地。”
en: “To-morrow I shall die, and I desire no other tomb than the ‘Nautilus.’ It is my grave!All my friends repose in the depths of the ocean; their resting-place shall be mine.”

zh: 大家安静地听着这些话。
en: These words were received with profound silence.

zh: “请尊重我的意愿，”他接着说，“‘诺第留斯号’困在这个洞穴里，洞穴的出口堵住了。但是，虽然没有办法出去，至少船沉在这个深渊里，可以埋葬我的遗骨。”
en: “Pay attention to my wishes,” he continued.“The ‘Nautilus’ is imprisoned in this grotto, the entrance of which is blocked up; but, although egress is impossible, the vessel may at least sink in the abyss, and there bury my remains.”

zh: 移民们恭敬地听着这位垂死的人的话。
en: The colonists listened reverently to the words of the dying man.

zh: “哈丁先生，明天我死了之后，”船长继续说道，“你和你的伙伴们就离开‘诺第留斯号’，让所有珍宝同我一起消亡。达卡王子的历史你们已经知道了，我只留给你们一样东西。那边的保险箱里装着价值连城的钻石。大部分都是我作为丈夫和父亲时候的纪念品，当时我认为很有乐趣。里面还有一些我和我的朋友们在深海中搜集到的珍珠。将来你们可以好好利用这些珍宝。在像您和您的伙伴这样的人手中，哈丁船长，钱不会成为罪恶的源泉。升天后我还会参加你们的事业，我相信你们的事业会繁荣发展起来。”
en: “To-morrow, after my death, Mr. Harding,” continued the captain, “yourself and companions will leave the ‘Nautilus,’ for all the treasures it contains must perish with me.One token alone will remain with you of Prince Dakkar, with whose history you are now acquainted.That coffer yonder contains diamonds of the value of many millions, most of them mementoes of the time when, husband and father, I thought happiness possible for me, and a collection of pearls gathered by my friends and myself in the depths of the ocean.Of this treasure at a future day, you may make good use.In the hands of such men as yourself and your comrades, Captain Harding, money will never be a source of danger.From on high I shall still participate in your enterprises, and I fear not but that they will prosper.”

zh: 由于极度虚弱，他稍微休息了一会儿，然后接着说：
en: After a few moments’ repose, necessitated by his extreme weakness, Captain Nemo continued,—

zh: “明天你们把保险箱带走，离开这个大厅，关上门。然后你们登到‘诺第留斯号’的甲板上，把主舱口放下来，把船完全关好。”
en: “To-morrow you will take the coffer, you will leave the saloon, of which you will close the door; then you will ascend on to the deck of the ‘Nautilus,’ and you will lower the mainhatch so as entirely to close the vessel.”

zh: “我们会这样做的，船长。”赛勒斯·哈丁回答。
en: “It shall be done, captain,” answered Cyrus Harding.

zh: “很好。然后你们就登上来时乘坐的那只小船。但是，在离开‘诺第留斯号’之前，先到船尾把吃水线上的两个大活塞打开。海水灌进贮水槽后，‘诺第留斯号’就会逐渐沉到水底，躺在大海的深处了。”
en: “Good.You will then embark in the canoe which brought you hither; but, before leaving the ‘Nautilus,’ go to the stern and there open two large stop-cocks which you will find upon the water-line.The water will penetrate into the reservoirs, and the ‘Nautilus’ will gradually sink beneath the water to repose at the bottom of the abyss.”

zh: 船长理解了赛勒斯·哈丁的表情，接着补充道：
en: And comprehending a gesture of Cyrus Harding, the captain added,—

zh: “没有什么可害怕的！你们只不过是埋葬一具尸体而已！”
en: “Fear nothing!You will but bury a corpse!”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和他的同伴们都没有敢向尼摩船长提出任何建议。船长已经说出了最后的心愿，他们除了照办，别无其他事情可做。
en: Neither Cyrus Harding nor his companions ventured to offer any observation to Captain Nemo.He had expressed his last wishes, and they had nothing to do but to conform to them.

zh: “你们答应我了是吗，先生们？”尼摩船长又问道。
en: “I have your promise, gentlemen?” added Captain Nemo.

zh: “是的，船长。”工程师回答。
en: “You have, captain,” replied the engineer.

zh: 船长打了一个手势，向这些移民表示感谢，并且请求让他自己呆几个小时。吉迪恩·史佩莱想在他身旁陪他以防万一，但是这位垂死的人拒绝了。他说：“我能活到明天，先生。”
en: The captain thanked the colonists by a sign, and requested them to leave him for some hours.Gideon Spilett wished to remain near him, in the event of a crisis coming on, but the dying man refused, saying, “I shall live until to-morrow, sir.”

zh: 大家离开大厅，经过书房和餐厅，来到前面的机房。机房里装有电动仪器，这套仪器不仅供应光热用电，还为“诺第留斯号”提供机械动力。
en: All left the saloon, passed through the library and the dining-room, and arrived forward, in the machine-room where the electrical apparatus was established, which supplied not only heat and light, but the mechanical power of the “Nautilus.”

zh: “诺第留斯号”是一个杰作，而其内部又包含着许多杰作。工程师惊呆了。
en: The “Nautilus” was a masterpiece containing masterpieces with itself, and the engineer was struck with astonishment.

zh: 移民们登上平台，平台高出水平面七八英尺。在那里，他们发现了一块厚厚的玻璃凸透镜，里面有一个大圆孔，亮光从凸透镜里射出去。圆孔后面很明显是装舵轮的仓库。当舵手驾驶“诺第留斯号”在海底航行时，就可以在这里操控方向。并且，电灯的光线可以照得很远。
en: The colonists mounted the platform, which rose seven or eight feet above the water.There they beheld a thick glass lenticular covering, which protected a kind of large eye, from which flashed forth light.Behind this eye was apparently a cabin containing the wheels of the rudder, and in which was stationed the helmsman, when he navigated the “Nautilus” over the bed of the ocean, which the electric rays would evidently light up to a considerable distance.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和他的伙伴们沉默了一会儿，刚才所看到和听到的都给他们留下了深刻的印象。一想到他们和这个多次帮助他们的人认识了只有几个小时，现在他就在死亡的边缘，他们的心被深深地触动了。
en: Cyrus Harding and his companions remained for a time silent, for they were vividly impressed by what they had just seen and heard, and their hearts were deeply touched by the thought that he whose arm had so often aided them, the protector whom they had known but a few hours, was at the point of death.

zh: 无论后人如何评判这个传奇人物和他于人类生活之外的一生，达卡王子的形象都会永远留在记忆深处，不会褪去。
en: Whatever might be the judgment pronounced by posterity upon the events of this, so to speak, extra-human existence, the character of Prince Dakkar would ever remain as one of those whose memory time can never efface.

zh: “多么了不起的一个人！”潘克洛夫说，“有没有可能他曾在海底生活？我觉得也许他在那儿得到的宁静也不会比别处多多少！”
en: “What a man!” said Pencroft.“Is it possible that he can have lived at the bottom of the sea?And it seems to me that perhaps he has not found peace there any more than elsewhere!”

zh: “‘诺第留斯号’，”艾尔顿说，“可能能带我们离开林肯岛，到有人居住的地方去。”
en: “The ‘Nautilus,’” observed Ayrton, “might have enabled us to leave Lincoln Island and reach some inhabited country.”

zh: “天啊！”潘克洛夫喊道，“我绝不会冒险坐这样的船。在海上航行还可以，但是在海下，我决不干！”
en: “Good Heavens!” exclaimed Pencroft, “I for one would never risk myself in such a craft.To sail on the seas, good, but under the seas, never!”

zh: “我相信，潘克洛夫，”通讯记者回答道，“驾驶像‘诺第留斯号’这样的潜水船应该很容易。我们应该很快就能熟悉它的习性。海底既没有风暴，也不必担心撞船。在水面下几英尺的地方，海水和湖水一样平静。”
en: “I believe, Pencroft,” answered the reporter, “that the navigation of a submarine vessel such as the ‘Nautilus’ ought to be very easy, and that we should soon become accustomed to it.There would be no storms, no lee-shore to fear.At some feet beneath the surface the waters of the ocean are as calm as those of a lake.”

zh: “也许可能，”水手回答说，“但是我宁愿冒着狂风乘一支装备齐全的船航行。船应该在海面上航行，而不是海底。”
en: “That may be,” replied the sailor, “but I prefer a gale of wind on board a well-found craft.A vessel is built to sail on the sea, and not beneath it.”

zh: “我的朋友们，”工程师说，“讨论也没用，至少不用讨论‘诺第留斯号’的问题。‘诺第留斯号’不是我们的，我们没有权利处理它。并且我们也不能驾驶它。现在的事实是，‘诺第留斯号’根本驶不出洞外，因为洞窟的出口已经被上升的玄武岩堵死了。尼摩船长的愿望是想和它一起被埋葬。他的愿望就是我们的法律，我们一定要帮他实现。”
en: “My friends,” said the engineer, “it is useless, at any rate as regards the ‘Nautilus,’ to discuss the question of submarine vessels.The ‘Nautilus’ is not ours, and we have not the right to dispose of it.Moreover, we could in no case avail ourselves of it.Independently of the fact that it would be impossible to get it out of this cavern, whose entrance is now closed by the uprising of the basaltic rocks, Captain Nemo’s wish is that it shall be buried with him.His wish is our law, and we will fulfil it.”

zh: 一段长时间的谈话后，赛勒斯·哈丁和他的伙伴们到了“诺第留斯号”的内部。他们在那里吃了一些东西，又回到大厅里了。
en: After a somewhat prolonged conversation, Cyrus Harding and his companions again descended to the interior of the “Nautilus.”There they took some refreshment and returned to the saloon.

zh: 尼摩船长已经从虚脱状态中恢复过来了，他的眼睛发出原有的光芒。他的嘴角甚至露出了一丝微笑。
en: Captain Nemo had somewhat rallied from the prostration which had overcome him, and his eyes shone with their wonted fire.A faint smile even curled his lips.

zh: 移民们围坐在他身边。
en: The colonists drew around him.

zh: “先生们，”船长说，“你们是既勇敢又诚实的人。你们为共同的福祉奉献着。我常常观察你们的行为。过去我尊敬你们，现在仍然尊重你们！把您的手递给我，哈丁先生。”
en: “Gentlemen,” said the captain, “you are brave and honest men.You have devoted yourselves to the common weal.Often have I observed your conduct.I have esteemed you—I esteem you still!Your hand, Mr. Harding.”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁把手伸向船长，船长热情地握住他的手。
en: Cyrus Harding gave his hand to the captain, who clasped it affectionately.

zh: “很好！”他轻声说道。
en: “It is well!” he murmured.

zh: 他接着说道：
en: He resumed,—

zh: “关于我的事已经说得够多了。我该谈谈你们和你们现在居住的林肯岛的问题了。你们现在想离开这个岛吗？”
en: “But enough of myself.I have to speak concerning yourselves, and this Lincoln Island, upon which you have taken refuge.You now desire to leave it?”

zh: “我们还会再回来的，船长！”潘克洛夫很快地说。
en: “To return, captain!” answered Pencroft quickly.

zh: “还会再回来吗，潘克洛夫？”船长面带微笑地说着。“我知道，真的，我知道你对这个岛的热爱。由于你们的帮助，这个岛才成了现在这个样子。这个岛对于你们来说是个天堂！”
en: “To return, Pencroft?” said the captain, with a smile.“I know, it is true, your love for this island.You have helped to make it what it now is, and it seems to you a paradise!”

zh: “船长，我们的计划是，”塞勒斯·哈丁打断说，“我们打算让这个岛隶属于美国，它在太平洋的位置极为重要，我们要建立一个海港。”
en: “Our project, captain,” interposed Cyrus Harding, “is to annex it to the United States, and to establish for our shipping a port so fortunately situated in this part of the Pacific.”

zh: “你们在为你们的祖国考虑，先生们，”船长接着说，“你们的劳动是为了国家的繁荣和荣誉。你们是对的。一个人就应该在自己的祖国生活，在自己的祖国死去！而我却只能远离故土、客死异乡了。”
en: “Your thoughts are with your country, gentlemen,” continued the captain; “your toils are for her prosperity and glory.You are right.One’s native land!—there should one live! there die!And I die far from all I loved!”

zh: “您还有什么最后的心愿要转达，”工程师激动地说，“有什么纪念品要送给您留在印度深山中的朋友吗？”
en: “You have some last wish to transmit,” said the engineer with emotion, “some souvenir to send to those friends you have left in the mountains of India?”

zh: “没有了，哈丁船长。我没有什么朋友了！我是我们这一群人中最后一个，我认识的人都以为我早死了。——还是回到你们的话题吧。孤独与与世隔绝是痛苦的，没有谁能够忍受得了。我曾经认为可以独自生活！因此，你们应该尝试一切办法离开林肯岛，重新回到生养你们的故乡。我注意到那些坏蛋已经把你们造的船毁掉了。”
en: “No, Captain Harding; no friends remain to me!I am the last of my race, and to all whom I have known I have long been as are the dead.—But to return to yourselves.Solitude, isolation, are painful things, and beyond human endurance.I die of having thought it possible to live alone!You should, therefore, dare all in the attempt to leave Lincoln Island, and see once more the land of your birth.I am aware that those wretches have destroyed the vessel you have built.”

zh: “我们打算造一只船，”吉迪恩·史佩莱说，“大到足以把我们送到最近的陆地上的船。假使我们成功了，早晚我们还是会回到林肯岛。我们眷恋这个地方，因为这里有许多无法抹去的记忆。”“其中就包括在这里我们认识了尼摩船长。”塞勒斯·哈丁说。
en: “We propose to construct a vessel,” said Gideon Spilett, “sufficiently large to convey us to the nearest land; but if we should succeed, sooner or later we shall return to Lincoln Island.We are attached to it by too many recollections ever to forget it.”“It is here that we have known Captain Nemo,” said Cyrus Harding.

zh: “这是我们唯一能建造家园的地方！”赫伯特补充说道。
en: “It is here only that we can make our home!” added Herbert.

zh: “我要长眠于此，如果……”船长说道。
en: “And here shall I sleep the sleep of eternity, if—” replied the captain.

zh: 他没有把话说完，停顿了一会儿后，他简单地说道：
en: He paused for a moment, and, instead of completing the sentence, said simply,—

zh: “哈丁先生，我想和您……单独说几句话！”
en: “Mr. Harding, I wish to speak with you—alone!”

zh: 工程师的伙伴们尊重他的愿望，都出去了。
en: The engineer’s companions, respecting the wish, retired.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁只和尼摩船长单独呆了几分钟，很快就把伙伴们叫进来。但是这位垂死之人跟他吐露的秘密，他却只字未提。
en: Cyrus Harding remained but a few minutes alone with Captain Nemo, and soon recalled his companions; but he said nothing to them of the private matters which the dying man had confided to him.

zh: 吉迪恩·史佩莱十分精心地照顾着船长。很明显，他的精力已经严重不足，没有力量与虚弱的身体抗争了。
en: Gideon Spilett now watched the captain with extreme care.It was evident that he was no longer sustained by his moral energy, which had lost the power of reaction against his physical weakness.

zh: 这一天过去了，没有发生什么变化。移民们一刻也没有离开“诺第留斯号”。夜晚降临了，虽然洞窟里分不清黑夜与白昼。
en: The day closed without change.The colonists did not quit the “Nautilus” for a moment.Night arrived, although it was impossible to distinguish it from day in the cavern.

zh: 尼摩船长并没有觉得痛苦，但是很明显，他的身体在逐步衰退。由于临近死亡，他那高贵的面容变得苍白，但他十分平静。他嘴里不时发出一些分辨不清的话语，说的是他遇到的各种经历。显然，他的生命在慢慢逝去，四肢已经发冷了。
en: Captain Nemo suffered no pain, but he was visibly sinking.His noble features, paled by the approach of death, were perfectly calm.Inaudible words escaped at intervals from his lips, bearing upon various incidents of his checkered career.Life was evidently ebbing slowly and his extremities were already cold.

zh: 他不时地和站在身旁的移民说话，冲他们微笑，这一丝的微笑一直保持到他死后。
en: Once or twice more he spoke to the colonists who stood around him, and smiled on them with that last smile which continues after death.

zh: 最后，午夜刚过，尼摩船长竭尽全力把两臂交叉在胸前，好像打算在死后保持这个姿势一样。
en: At length, shortly after midnight, Captain Nemo by a supreme effort succeeded in folding his arms across his breast, as if wishing in that attitude to compose himself for death.

zh: 一点钟的时候，只有他的眼神里还有一点生气。曾经明亮的眼眸中现在闪现了垂死的光芒。然后，他喃喃地低语：“上帝，我的祖国！”说完就安静地死去了。
en: By one o’clock his glance alone showed signs of life.A dying light gleamed in those eyes once so brilliant.Then, murmuring the words, “God and my country!” he quietly expired.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁，弯下腰为他合上眼睛。这位昔日的达卡王子，如今却连尼摩船长也不是了。
en: Cyrus Harding, bending low closed the eyes of him who had once been the Prince Dakkar, and was now not even Captain Nemo.

zh: 赫伯特和潘克洛夫大声地啜泣。艾尔顿也流下了泪水。纳布像一尊雕塑似的，一动不动地跪在通讯记者身旁。
en: Herbert and Pencroft sobbed aloud.Tears fell from Ayrton’s eyes.Neb was on his knees by the reporter’s side, motionless as a statue.

zh: 然后，赛勒斯·哈丁把手放在死者的头上，庄严地说：“愿他的灵魂与上帝同在！”然后，他转向他的朋友们接着说：“让我们为我们失去的人祷告吧！”
en: Then Cyrus Harding, extending his hand over the forehead of the dead, said solemnly, “May his soul be with God!”Turning to his friends, he added, “Let us pray for him whom we have lost!”

zh: 几个小时后，移民们履行了诺言，实现了船长的临终遗愿。
en: Some hours later the colonists fulfilled the promise made to the captain by carrying out his dying wishes.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和他的伙伴们带着装有亿万财宝的保险箱—这是恩人留给他们的唯一纪念品——离开了“诺第留斯号”。
en: Cyrus Harding and his companions quitted the “Nautilus,” taking with them the only memento left them by their benefactor, the coffer which contained wealth amounting to millions.

zh: 神奇的大厅依然灯火通明，他们小心地关上厅门。他们严密地关上了通向甲板的铁门，这样“诺第留斯号”就可以保证滴水不漏。
en: The marvelous saloon, still flooded with light, had been carefully closed.The iron door leading on deck was then securely fastened in such a manner as to prevent even a drop of water from penetrating to the interior of the “Nautilus.”

zh: 然后，移民们跳上了停靠在潜水船旁边的小船。
en: The colonists then descended into the canoe, which was moored to the side of the submarine vessel.

zh: 这时候，小船划到“诺第留斯号”的船尾。在那儿，吃水线附近有两个大旋塞，连接着贮水槽，以便于使船下沉。
en: The canoe was now brought around to the stern.There, at the water-line, were two large stop-cocks communicating with the reservoirs employed in the submersion of the vessel.

zh: 大旋塞打开了，海水充满贮水槽。“诺第留斯号”缓慢下沉，渐渐在海面上消失了。
en: The stop-cocks were opened, the reservoirs filled, and the “Nautilus,” slowly sinking, disappeared beneath the surface of the lake.

zh: 但是移民们却无法一直看着它在波涛下沉没。强烈的光芒照亮了透明的海水，洞窟逐渐变得黑暗。最后，大片的电光消失了，不一会儿，“诺第留斯号”——现在是尼摩船长的棺材——沉在海底深处了。
en: But the colonists were yet able to follow its descent through the waves.The powerful light it gave forth lighted up the translucent water, while the cavern became gradually obscure.At length this vast effusion of electric light faded away, and soon after the “Nautilus,” now the tomb of Captain Nemo, reposed in its ocean bed.

zh: 第十八章
en: Chapter 18

zh: 天刚刚亮的时候，移民们又默默地回到洞窟的出口处，为了纪念尼摩船长，他们把洞窟命名为“达卡洞”。现在正是落潮的时候，他们毫不费劲地从拱形洞口下边穿过去，海水冲刷着船的右侧。
en: At break of day the colonists regained in silence the entrance of the cavern, to which they gave the name of “Dakkar Grotto,” in memory of Captain Nemo.It was now low-water, and they passed without difficulty under the arcade, washed on the right by the sea.

zh: 他们把小船停在这里，小心地保护着它，使它免受波浪的冲击。为了保险起见，潘克洛夫、纳布和艾尔顿又把船拉回洞窟一侧的一个小沙滩上，船在这里没有受损的危险。
en: The canoe was left here, carefully protected from the waves.As additional precaution, Pencroft, Neb, and Ayrton drew it up on a little beach which bordered one of the sides of the grotto, in a spot where it could run no risk of harm.

zh: 暴风雨在夜间停止了。最后几声低沉的雷声在西方消失了。雨住了，但是天空仍然阴云密布。总体来说，十月份是南半球春季的第一个月，但是这个月的天气看不出有好转的迹象。风向从一个罗盘方位转向另一个方位，这表明稳定的天气是没有指望了。
en: The storm had ceased during the night.The last low mutterings of the thunder died away in the west.Rain fell no longer, but the sky was yet obscured by clouds.On the whole, this month of October, the first of the southern spring, was not ushered in by satisfactory tokens, and the wind had a tendency to shift from one point of the compass to another, which rendered it impossible to count upon settled weather.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和他的伙伴们离开“达卡洞”，来到了畜栏。一路上，纳布和赫伯特小心地把由尼摩船长从畜栏拉到洞窟的电线收起来，也许将来会派上用场。
en: Cyrus Harding and his companions, on leaving Dakkar Grotto, had taken the road to the corral.On their way Neb and Herbert were careful to preserve the wire which had been laid down by the captain between the corral and the grotto, and which might at a future time be of service.

zh: 一路上，移民们都很少讲话。10月15日夜晚发生的种种事情在他们的脑海中留下了深刻的印象。那个有效地帮助了他们的陌生人，那个他们想象中具有超自然力量的人——尼摩船长——已经不复存在了。他和他的“诺第留斯号”已经长埋于深渊中。对他们每个人来说，都觉得比以往更加孤独了。他们一度期待的力量已经不复存在了。吉迪恩·史佩莱，甚至塞勒斯·哈丁都免不了有这种感觉。因此，他们去畜栏的路上都一直保持沉默。
en: The colonists spoke but little on the road.The various incidents of the night of October 15th had left a profound impression on their minds.The unknown being whose influence had so effectually protected them, the man whom their imagination had endowed with supernatural powers, Captain Nemo, was no more.His “Nautilus” and he were buried in the depths of the abyss.To each one of them their existence seemed even more isolated than before.They had been accustomed to count upon the intervention of that power which existed no longer, and Gideon Spilett, and even Cyrus Harding, could not escape this impression.Thus they maintained a profound silence during their journey to the corral.

zh: 将近早上九点的时候，移民们回到了花岗石宫。
en: Towards nine in the morning the colonists arrived at Granite House.

zh: 大家原来就一致同意要积极推进造船的进程。这次，赛勒斯·哈丁在造船工作上投入了比以往更多的时间和劳动。未来是不可能预料的。显然，如果能够拥有一艘大船，可以在恶劣的天气出航，而且在必要的时候还可以供他们长期远航，那对这些移民来说，真是有极大的好处了。船造好之后，即使移民们仍不打算离开林肯岛，为了到达太平洋波利尼西亚群岛的任何一个小岛或者新西兰的海岸，他们至少也要到达达抱岛去，把关于艾尔顿的消息留在那里。这个打算是不可或缺的，因为苏格兰快艇很可能重新回到这一片海域。这一点应该高度重视，丝毫不能忽略。
en: It had been agreed that the construction of the vessel should be actively pushed forward, and Cyrus Harding more than ever devoted his time and labor to this object.It was impossible to divine what future lay before them.Evidently the advantage to the colonists would be great of having at their disposal a substantial vessel, capable of keeping the sea even in heavy weather, and large enough to attempt, in case of need, a voyage of some duration.Even if, when their vessel should be completed, the colonists should not resolve to leave Lincoln Island as yet, in order to gain either one of the Polynesian Archipelagoes of the Pacific or the shores of New Zealand, they might at least, sooner or later, proceed to Tabor Island, to leave there the notice relating to Ayrton.This was a precaution rendered indispensable by the possibility of the Scotch yacht reappearing in those seas, and it was of the highest importance that nothing should be neglected on this point.

zh: 于是，工作重新开始了。赛勒斯·哈丁、潘克洛夫和艾尔顿在纳布、吉迪恩·史佩莱和赫伯特的帮助下，除非有其他必要的事情不可避免才暂时中断，其他时候都不停地工作着。新船在五个月内完工相当重要。也就是说，如果他们想在秋分暴风阻碍航行之前到达达抱岛，三月初就得把船造好。因此，工匠们一刻也不敢耽搁。并且，他们不需要制造绳索，因为‘飞快号’的绳索都完好地保存了下来，他们只需要制造船身就可以了。
en: The works were then resumed.Cyrus Harding, Pencroft, and Ayrton, assisted by Neb, Gideon Spilett, and Herbert, except when unavoidably called off by other necessary occupations, worked without cessation.It was important that the new vessel should be ready in five months—that is to say, by the beginning of March—if they wished to visit Tabor Island before the equinoctial gales rendered the voyage impracticable.Therefore the carpenters lost not a moment.Moreover, it was unnecessary to manufacture rigging, that of the “Speedy” having been saved entire, so that the hull only of the vessel needed to be constructed.

zh: 1868年年底的时候，他们忙着做这项重要的工作，几乎无暇顾及其他事情。两个半月后，肋材装好了，第一批铺板也放好了。这时候已经能很明显看出赛勒斯·哈丁的设计值得赞赏，这艘船在海里一定可以很好地航行。
en: The end of the year 1868 found them occupied by these important labors, to the exclusion of almost all others.At the expiration of two months and a half the ribs had been set up and the first planks adjusted.It was already evident that the plans made by Cyrus Harding were admirable, and that the vessel would behave well at sea.

zh: 潘克洛夫竭尽全力地工作，甚至其他木匠放下斧头拿起猎枪去打猎时，他都要发牢骚。无论如何，为了度过冬天，花岗石宫里必须储备一些东西。但是这并不能使潘克洛夫满意。工人们一离开造船所，这位勇敢而忠实的水手就不满意。每当这种事情发生时，他就满腹牢骚，为了发泄怨气，他就一个人干六个人的活。
en: Pencroft brought to the task a devouring energy, and would even grumble when one or the other abandoned the carpenter’s axe for the gun of the hunter.It was nevertheless necessary to keep up the stores of Granite House, in view of the approaching winter.But this did not satisfy Pencroft.The brave, honest sailor was not content when the workmen were not at the dockyard. when this happened he grumbled vigorously, and, by way of venting his feelings, did the work of six men.

zh: 整个夏天，天气都非常不好。有几天，天热得无法忍受。空气里满是雷电，只有狂风暴雨过后，空气才会清爽一些。几乎没有哪天听不见远处的雷鸣声。雷鸣声不断地响，像在不停地低声咕哝一般，这正是地球的赤道地区特有的现象。
en: The weather was very unfavorable during the whole of the summer season.For some days the heat was overpowering, and the atmosphere, saturated with electricity, was only cleared by violent storms.It was rarely that the distant growling of the thunder could not be heard, like a low but incessant murmur, such as is produced in the equatorial regions of the globe.

zh: 1869年1月1日刮起了特大暴风雨，岛上不时响起雷声。很多大树被闪电劈倒和击中。湖的南岸有很多高大的榆树为家禽场遮荫，其中的一棵也被劈倒了。这种现象和地心的变化有没有关联呢？大气的活动与地球内部的运动有没有什么联系呢？赛勒斯·哈丁认为是有关系的，因为暴风雨发生的同时，火山也开始有复活的迹象。
en: The 1st of January, 1869, was signalized by a storm of extreme violence, and the thunder burst several times over the island.Large trees were struck by the electric fluid and shattered, and among others one of those gigantic nettle-trees which had shaded the poultry-yard at the southern extremity of the lake.Had this meteor any relation to the phenomena going on in the bowels of the earth?Was there any connection between the commotion of the atmosphere and that of the interior of the earth?Cyrus Harding was inclined to think that such was the case, for the development of these storms was attended by the renewal of volcanic symptoms.

zh: 1月3日天刚刚亮的时候，赫伯特爬上眺望岗的高地给一头野驴套缰绳的时候，发现一大团帽子形状的烟雾从火山顶上冒出。
en: It was on the 3rd of January that Herbert, having ascended at daybreak to the plateau of Prospect Heights to harness one of the onagers, perceived an enormous hat-shaped cloud rolling from the summit of the volcano.

zh: 赫伯特马上告诉了移民们，移民们听到后立刻和他一起观察起富兰克林山的山顶。
en: Herbert immediately apprised the colonists, who at once joined him in watching the summit of Mount Franklin.

zh: “啊！”潘克洛夫大声叫道，“这次可不是水汽了！依我看，这个大家伙不满足只是呼吸，它还要抽烟！”
en: “Ah!” exclaimed Pencroft, “those are not vapors this time!It seems to me that the giant is not content with breathing; he must smoke!”

zh: 水手的这个比喻准确地表达了火山口发生的变化。三个月以来，火山口一直在喷水汽，水汽时而浓时而淡，但一直只是内部矿物质沸腾所引起的。但现在，水汽被浓烟所取代。浓烟像一根灰色的柱子，底部宽三百多英尺，上升到山顶上方七八百英尺的高空时，浓烟散开，呈巨大的蘑菇状。
en: This figure of speech employed by the sailor exactly expressed the changes going on at the mouth of the volcano.Already for three months had the crater emitted vapors more or less dense, but which were as yet produced only by an internal ebullition of mineral substances.But now the vapors were replaced by a thick smoke, rising in the form of a grayish column, more than three hundred feet in width at its base, and which spread like an immense mushroom to a height of from seven to eight hundred feet above the summit of the mountain.

zh: “烟囱里有火了。”吉迪恩·史佩莱说。
en: “The fire is in the chimney,” observed Gideon Spilett.

zh: “我们没法扑灭！”赫伯特接过话说。
en: “And we can’t put it out!” replied Herbert.

zh: “应该把这座火山清除掉。”纳布十分认真地说道。
en: “The volcano ought to be swept,” observed Neb, who spoke as if perfectly serious.

zh: “说得好，纳布！”潘克洛夫大声笑道，“那么，这项工作由你负责，没问题吧？”
en: “Well said, Neb!” cried Pencroft, with a shout of laughter; “and you’ll undertake the job, no doubt?”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁仔细观察富兰克林山里冒出来的浓烟，甚至是倾听，似乎想听到远处有隆隆声。刚才他向前走了几步，然后，他又回到同伴们跟前，说：
en: Cyrus Harding attentively observed the dense smoke emitted by Mount Franklin, and even listened, as if expecting to hear some distant muttering.Then, turning towards his companions, from whom he had gone somewhat apart, he said,—

zh: “事实是，我的朋友们，我们不能欺骗自己，现在要发生重大的变化了。火山内部不只是沸腾状态了，而是已经着了火。毫无疑问，我们就要受到正在爆发的火山的威胁了。”
en: “The truth is, my friends, we must not conceal from ourselves that an important change is going forward.The volcanic substances are no longer in a state of ebullition, they have caught fire, and we are undoubtedly menaced by an approaching eruption.”

zh: “那么，船长，”潘克洛夫说，“我们将会看到火山爆发。要是爆发得好，我们就为它鼓掌。我认为没有必要为这件事继续担心。
en: “Well, captain,” said Pencroft, “we shall witness the eruption; and if it is a good one, we’ll applaud it.I don’t see that we need concern ourselves further about the matter.”

zh: “也许是吧，”赛勒斯·哈丁回答说，“因为古老的岩浆出口现在还开着。正因为如此，喷出来的岩浆迄今一直向北面流。可是……”
en: “It may be so,” replied Cyrus Harding, “for the ancient track of the lava is still open; and thanks to this, the crater has hitherto overflowed towards the north.And yet—”

zh: “可是，既然火山爆发对我们没有任何好处，最好还是不要爆发。”通讯记者说。
en: “And yet, as we can derive no advantage from an eruption, it might be better it should not take place,” said the reporter.

zh: “谁知道呢？”水手说，“也许火山里有什么有价值的东西，要是喷出来，我们还可以好好利用一下！”
en: “Who knows?” answered the sailor.“Perhaps there may be some valuable substance in this volcano, which it will spout forth, and which we may turn to good account!”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁摇摇头，看那神情，好像预料到这个突如其来的现象不会有好结果似的。他不像潘克洛夫那样把火山爆发的结果看得那么轻松。即使因为火山口的位置的原因，岩浆不会直接威胁岛上的森林和已经开发的地方，但火山爆发后还是会引起其他后果。事实上，火山爆发常常会引发地震活动。而且林肯岛地质情况各种各样，一边是玄武岩，一边又成了花岗岩，北边是岩浆凝结成的岩石，南边是肥沃的土地。这些物质不可能互相紧密连接，因此有崩裂的危险。虽然因为这个原因，熔浆扩散出来可能不会造成严重的后果，但是如果由于地质结构的运动而使整个岛震动起来，后果将很严重。
en: Cyrus Harding shook his head with the air of a man who augured no good from the phenomenon whose development had been so sudden.He did not regard so lightly as Pencroft the results of an eruption.If the lava, in consequence of the position of the crater, did not directly menace the wooded and cultivated parts of the island, other complications might present themselves.In fact, eruptions are not unfrequently accompanied by earthquakes; and an island of the nature of Lincoln Island, formed of substances so varied, basalt on one side, granite on the other, lava on the north, rich soil on the south, substances which consequently could not be firmly attached to each other, would be exposed to the risk of disintegration.Although, therefore, the spreading of the volcanic matter might not constitute a serious danger, any movement of the terrestrial structure which should shake the island might entail the gravest consequences.

zh: “我好像，”艾尔顿把耳朵贴在地上听了一会儿说道，“我好像听到了低沉的隆隆声，就像一辆拉着铁条的马车发出的声音。”
en: “It seems to me,” said Ayrton, who had reclined so as to place his ear to the ground, “it seems to me that I can hear a dull, rumbling sound, like that of a wagon loaded with bars of iron.”

zh: 移民们认真地听了听，确信艾尔顿并没有搞错。隆隆的响声中还夹杂着地下的轰鸣声，两种声音一起形成了一种强的节奏，又慢慢消失，好像地球的深处经过了一阵暴风雨，又逐渐过去了一般。但是他们听不到什么所谓的爆炸声。因此可以这样下结论：水汽和浓烟可以从中央管道自由地排放出去，安全阀门很大，不容易产生震动，也不会发生爆炸。
en: The colonists listened with the greatest attention, and were convinced that Ayrton was not mistaken.The rumbling was mingled with a subterranean roar, which formed a sort of rinforzando, and died slowly away, as if some violent storm had passed through the profundities of the globe.But no explosion properly so termed, could be heard.It might therefore be concluded that the vapors and smoke found a free passage through the central shaft; and that the safety-valve being sufficiently large, no convulsion would be produced, no explosion was to be apprehended.

zh: “那么，好了！”潘克洛夫说，“我们不回去工作吗？让富兰克林山自己冒烟、轰鸣、吼叫或喷火去吧！我们没有理由在这闲耗！来吧，艾尔顿、纳布、赫伯特、哈丁队长、史佩莱先生，今天我们大家都必须开始我们的工作！我们现在要去安装内龙骨了，十二双手也不嫌多。两个月内，我们新的‘乘风破浪号’——我们还用原来的名字命名好不好？——在气球港上漂浮！因此，我们一个小时也不能浪费！”
en: “Well, then!” said Pencroft, “are we not going back to work?Let Mount Franklin smoke, groan, bellow, or spout forth fire and flame as much as it pleases, that is no reason why we should be idle!Come, Ayrton, Neb, Herbert, Captain Harding, Mr. Spilett, every one of us must turn to at our work to-day!We are going to place the keelson, and a dozen pair of hands would not be too many.Before two months I want our new ‘Bonadventure’—for we shall keep the old name, shall we not?—to float on the waters of Port Balloon!Therefore there is not an hour to lose!”

zh: 在潘克洛夫的号召下，所有移民都去造船所安装内龙骨了。内龙骨木料很厚，构成船的下部，把船身的肋材牢牢地固定在一起。这是一项艰巨的工作，每个人都参与其中。
en: All the colonists, their services thus requisitioned by Pencroft, descended to the dockyard, and proceeded to place the keelson, a thick mass of wood which forms the lower portion of a ship and unites firmly the timbers of the hull.It was an arduous undertaking, in which all took part.

zh: 1月3日这一整天他们都在工作，没有再想火山的问题。再说，花岗石宫的海滩上也看不到富兰克林山。但有一两次，太阳运动的过程中，本来十分晴朗的天空却被阴影遮住了。这说明有一股浓烟从太阳和林肯岛之间经过。岸上吹的风把水汽都刮到西边去了。塞勒斯·哈丁和吉迪恩·史佩莱注意到了天空中这些阴暗的现象。他们不时地讨论着火山爆发的现象肯定在进一步发展，但是他们的工作并没有中止。但是无论从哪个角度看，船都应该尽快造好，尽量不要拖延。如果发生了变故，移民们的安全在很大程度上就可以由这艘船来保障。也许某一天这艘船会成为他们唯一的避难所也说不定。
en: They continued their labors during the whole of this day, the 3rd of January, without thinking further of the volcano, which could not, besides, be seen from the shore of Granite House.But once or twice, large shadows, veiling the sun, which described its diurnal arc through an extremely clear sky, indicated that a thick cloud of smoke passed between its disc and the island.The wind, blowing on the shore, carried all these vapors to the westward.Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett remarked these somber appearances, and from time to time discussed the evident progress of the volcanic phenomena, but their work went on without interruption.It was, besides, of the first importance from every point of view, that the vessel should be finished with the least possible delay.In presence of the eventualities which might arise, the safety of the colonists would be to a great extent secured by their ship.Who could tell that it might not prove some day their only refuge?

zh: 晚饭后，赛勒斯·哈丁、吉迪恩·史佩莱和赫伯特又登上了眺望岗的高地。天已经黑了。在昏暗的环境下可以看到火山口上升的水汽和烟雾里是否夹带了火焰或火山里喷出的白热物体。
en: In the evening, after supper, Cyrus Harding, Gideon Spilett, and Herbert again ascended the plateau of Prospect Heights.It was already dark, and the obscurity would permit them to ascertain if flames or incandescent matter thrown up by the volcano were mingled with the vapor and smoke accumulated at the mouth of the crater.

zh: “火山口着火了！”赫伯特喊道。他比同伴们都积极，第一个跑到了高地上。
en: “The crater is on fire!” said Herbert, who, more active than his companion, first reached the plateau.

zh: 富兰克林山离他们大概有六英里远。现在它像一个巨大的火把，山顶被一团烟火所围绕。山顶上的浓烟夹杂着大概是岩烬和熔渣的东西，所以在黑暗的夜色中发出的光显得很微弱。但是整个岛上弥漫着红光，红光中屹立着山顶高处朦胧的树影。大片的水汽在天空中散开，使天空变得很模糊，只能依稀看到几颗星星在闪烁。
en: Mount Franklin, distant about six miles, now appeared like a gigantic torch, around the summit of which turned fuliginous flames.So much smoke, and possibly scoriae and cinders were mingled with them, that their light gleamed but faintly amid the gloom of the night.But a kind of lurid brilliancy spread over the island, against which stood out confusedly the wooded masses of the heights.Immense whirlwinds of vapor obscured the sky, through which glimmered a few stars.

zh: “变化太快了！”工程师说道。
en: “The change is rapid!” said the engineer.

zh: “这并不稀奇，”通讯记者说，“火山复活已经很久了。你大概还记得，塞勒斯，我们第一次看见冒水汽是满山寻找尼摩船长住处的时候。如果我没有记错的话，那天应该是10月15日左右。”
en: “That is not surprising,” answered the reporter.“The reawakening of the volcano already dates back some time.You may remember, Cyrus, that the first vapors appeared about the time we searched the sides of the mountain to discover Captain Nemo’s retreat.It was, if I mistake not, about the 15th of October.”

zh: “是的，”赫伯特回答说，“两个半月以前！”
en: “Yes,” replied Herbert, “two months and a half ago!”

zh: “地下的火已经燃烧了十个星期了，”吉迪恩·史佩莱接着说，“火山爆发到现在这个强度也不足为奇！”
en: “The subterranean fires have therefore been smoldering for ten weeks,” resumed Gideon Spilett, “and it is not to be wondered at that they now break out with such violence!”

zh: “你觉得地面在震动？”赛勒斯·哈丁问道。
en: “Do not you feel a certain vibration of the soil?” asked Cyrus Harding.

zh: “是的，”吉迪恩·史佩莱回答说，“但是这和地震还有很大区别。”
en: “Yes,” replied Gideon Spilett, “but there is a great difference between that and an earthquake.”

zh: “我不确定我们遭受地震的威胁了，”赛勒斯·哈丁回答说，“愿上帝保佑我们不要遭受地震！现在还不是地震，现在的震动是由于地心的火焰发热的缘故。地壳就像锅炉的外壳，大家都知道，在蒸汽的压力下，锅身就会像金属片一样发响。现在出现的就是这种情况。”
en: “I do not affirm that we are menaced with an earthquake,” answered Cyrus Harding, “may God preserve us from that!No; these vibrations are due to the effervescence of the central fire.The crust of the earth is simply the shell of a boiler, and you know that such a shell, under the pressure of steam, vibrates like a sonorous plate.it is this effect which is being produced at this moment.”

zh: “多么美丽的火焰啊！”赫伯特喊道。
en: “What magnificent flames!” exclaimed Herbert.

zh: 这时候，一串火花从火山口里喷出来。虽然隔着水汽，还是可以看到火花的亮光。弯曲的火舌和成千上万的火花飞向各个方向。有的飞出了烟雾外，驱散了烟雾，只留下一团炽热的粉末。还不时发出一连串的爆炸声，像一排在扫射的机关枪似的。
en: At this instant a kind of bouquet of flames shot forth from the crater, the brilliancy of which was visible even through the vapors.Thousands of luminous sheets and barbed tongues of fire were cast in various directions.Some, extending beyond the dome of smoke, dissipated it, leaving behind an incandescent powder.This was accompanied by successive explosions, resembling the discharge of a battery of machine-guns.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁、通讯记者和赫伯特在高地上呆了一个小时后，走下海滩回到花岗石宫去了。工程师出神地思考着，吉迪恩·史佩莱在担心火山的爆发，是不是会直接或间接地为他们立刻带来危险。
en: Cyrus Harding, the reporter, and Herbert, after spending an hour on the plateau of Prospect Heights, again descended to the beach, and returned to Granite House.The engineer was thoughtful and preoccupied, so much so, indeed, that Gideon Spilett inquired if he apprehended any immediate danger, of which the eruption might directly or indirectly be the cause.

zh: “可能是，也可能不是。”赛勒斯·哈丁回答说。
en: “Yes, and no,” answered Cyrus Harding.

zh: “不过，”通讯记者接着说，“可能发生在我们身上最不幸的事，不就是能把这座岛掀翻的地震吗？现在，我认为这倒不足为惧，因为水汽和岩浆能自由地喷出去。”
en: “Nevertheless,” continued the reporter, “would not the greatest misfortune which could happen to us be an earthquake which would overturn the island?Now, I do not suppose that this is to be feared, since the vapors and lava have found a free outlet.”

zh: “不错，”赛勒斯·哈丁回答道，“我并不害怕因为地下气体膨胀而引起的一般的地震。但是其他的原因引起的地震可能会引起极大的灾难。”
en: “True,” replied Cyrus Harding, “and I do not fear an earthquake in the sense in which the term is commonly applied to convulsions of the soil provoked by the expansion of subterranean gases.But other causes may produce great disasters.”

zh: “怎么会这样呢，亲爱的赛勒斯？”
en: “How so, my dear Cyrus?’

zh: “我也不能肯定。我得好好考虑一下。我必须去山里看看。过几天我就了解多一些了。”
en: “I am not certain.I must consider.I must visit the mountain.In a few days I shall learn more on this point.”

zh: 吉迪恩·史佩莱不再说话了。尽管火山在爆发，而且愈演愈烈，爆炸的回声传遍整个岛，但是花岗石宫的移民们还是美美地睡着了。
en: Gideon Spilett said no more, and soon, in spite of the explosions of the volcano, whose intensity increased, and which were repeated by the echoes of the island, the inhabitants of Granite House were sleeping soundly.

zh: 1月4日、5日、6日三天过去了。移民们辛勤地继续造船。工程师没有做进一步的解释，只是竭尽全力地投入到工作中。这时候富兰克林山被一片阴云笼罩，火焰中喷出一些白热的岩石，有的喷出来以后又掉到火山口里面去了。这使得潘克洛夫只是把这件事当玩笑一样看待，他看见以后喊道：
en: Three days passed by—the 4th, 5th, and 6th of January.The construction of the vessel was diligently continued, and without offering further explanations the engineer pushed forward the work with all his energy.Mount Franklin was now hooded by a somber cloud of sinister aspect, and, amid the flames, vomiting forth incandescent rocks, some of which fell back into the crater itself.This caused Pencroft, who would only look at the matter in the light of a joke, to exclaim,—

zh: “啊！这个大家伙在玩魔术，它是个魔术师。”
en: “Ah! the giant is playing at cup and ball; he is a conjurer.”

zh: 事实上，喷出来的东西又掉进深渊去了。虽然岩浆在内部的压力下已经上涨起来，但似乎还没有上升到火山口那么高。但是无论如何，可以看到东北方向有一部分的缺口，但岩浆还没有从那里向北部山坡流去。
en: In fact, the substances thrown up fell back again in to the abyss, and it did not seem that the lava, though swollen by the internal pressure, had yet risen to the orifice of the crater.At any rate, the opening on the northeast, which was partly visible, poured out no torrent upon the northern slope of the mountain.

zh: 然而，尽管造船的工作十分紧迫，但是移民们必须要到岛上各处完成其他工作。首先必须要去畜栏，因为摩佛仑羊和山羊都在那里，必须给这些动物喂些饲料。大家安排艾尔顿第二天，也就是1月7日去畜栏。因为他一个人去忙就足够了，并且他对那儿的工作很熟悉。但是潘克洛夫和其他的移民吃惊地听到工程师对艾尔顿说：
en: Nevertheless, however pressing was the construction of the vessel, other duties demanded the presence of the colonists on various portions of the island.Before everything it was necessary to go to the corral, where the flocks of musmons and goats were enclosed, and replenish the provision of forage for those animals.It was accordingly arranged that Ayrton should proceed thither the next day, the 7th of January; and as he was sufficient for the task, to which he was accustomed, Pencroft and the rest were somewhat surprised on hearing the engineer say to Ayrton—

zh: “既然明天你要去畜栏，那么我陪你一起去吧。”
en: “As you are going to-morrow to the corral I will accompany you.”

zh: “但是，哈丁队长，”水手喊道，“我们没有多长时间了，如果你也去的话，我们就缺两双手了！”
en: “But, Captain Harding,” exclaimed the sailor, “our working days will not be many, and if you go also we shall be two pair of hands short!”

zh: “我们明天就回来，”赛勒斯·哈丁回答说，“但是我必须去畜栏。我必须了解一下火山爆发到什么地步了。”
en: “We shall return to-morrow,” replied Cyrus Harding, “but it is necessary that I should go to the corral.I must learn how the eruption is progressing.”

zh: “火山爆发！又是火山爆发！”潘克洛夫不满地答道，“的确，火山爆发是一件重要的事！”但我并不在乎。”
en: “The eruption! always the eruption!” answered Pencroft, with an air of discontent.“An important thing, truly, this eruption!I trouble myself very little about it.”

zh: 不管水手的意见如何，工程师决定第二天去畜栏的事情还是定下来了。赫伯特想和赛勒斯·哈丁一起去，但是他不想因为自己的离开而使潘克洛夫恼怒。
en: Whatever might be the sailor’s opinion, the expedition projected by the engineer was settled for the next day.Herbert wished to accompany Cyrus Harding, but he would not vex Pencroft by his absence.

zh: 第二天天一亮，赛勒斯·哈丁和艾尔顿坐上两匹野驴拉的大车，飞快地向畜栏方向驶去。
en: The next day, at dawn, Cyrus Harding and Ayrton, mounting the cart drawn by two onagers, took the road to the corral and set off at a round trot.

zh: 大片的烟雾从森林上飘过，富兰克林山的火山口不断往烟雾中增加烟尘。很显然，这些在空气中弥漫的烟雾里有很多杂质。由奇怪的不透明的颜色和重量可以知道，那些烟雾不仅仅从火山里出来。这些岩烬呈粉尘状，像是被磨成粉末状的浮石。它们和像细微的淀粉粒一样的灰色灰尘，形成厚厚的一层，在空中悬浮着。这些灰尘非常轻，它们能在空中飘好几个月。1783年冰岛火山爆发后，火山灰弥漫在大气中有一年之久，就连太阳光线都很难穿透。
en: Above the forest were passing large clouds, to which the crater of Mount Franklin incessantly added fuliginous matter.These clouds, which rolled heavily in the air, were evidently composed of heterogeneous substances.It was not alone from the volcano that they derived their strange opacity and weight.Scoriae, in a state of dust, like powdered pumice-stone, and grayish ashes as small as the finest feculae, were held in suspension in the midst of their thick folds.These ashes are so fine that they have been observed in the air for whole months.After the eruption of 1783 in Iceland for upwards of a year the atmosphere was thus charged with volcanic dust through which the rays of the sun were only with difficulty discernible.

zh: 在一般情况下，这些粉状物会降落到地面，而现在就是这种状况。赛勒斯·哈丁和艾尔顿快到达畜栏的时候，天空忽然下起一种像细火药面似的黑色的雪，转眼间地上就变了样子。树和草都不见了，上面覆盖着一层几英寸厚的灰。非常幸运的是，风从东北方向吹来，大部分的烟都刮到海上去了。
en: But more often this pulverized matter falls, and this happened on the present occasion.Cyrus Harding and Ayrton had scarcely reached the corral when a sort of black snow like fine gunpowder fell, and instantly changed the appearance of the soil.Trees, meadows, all disappeared beneath a covering several inches in depth.But, very fortunately, the wind blew from the northeast, and the greater part of the cloud dissolved itself over the sea.

zh: “这种情况真是少见，哈丁队长。”艾尔顿说。
en: “This is very singular, Captain Harding,” said Ayrton.

zh: “情况很严重，”工程师回答，“这种粉末状的浮石和这些矿物质灰尘表明火山下的深处正在发生重大的变化。”
en: “It is very serious,” replied the engineer.“This powdered pumice-stone, all this mineral dust, proves how grave is the convulsion going forward in the lower depths of the volcano.”

zh: “但是什么也不能做吗？”
en: “But can nothing be done?”

zh: “除了看着这种现象发展下去，没有其他办法。因此，艾尔顿，你在畜栏做你必须做的工作。我要爬上红河发源地以外的地方，去看看山北面的情况。然后……”
en: “Nothing, except to note the progress of the phenomenon.Do you, therefore, Ayrton, occupy yourself with the necessary work at the corral.In the meantime I will ascend just beyond the source of Red Creek and examine the condition of the mountain upon its northern aspect.Then—”

zh: “然后如何，哈丁队长？”
en: “Well, Captain Harding?”

zh: “然后我们去‘达卡洞’。我要去检查一下那里的情况。无论如何我会在两个小时内回来找你。”
en: “Then we will pay a visit to Dakkar Grotto.I wish to inspect it.At any rate I will come back for you in two hours.”

zh: 艾尔顿去畜栏了。他在等着工程师到来的同时，忙着照料摩弗伦羊和山羊。羊群似乎察觉到了火山即将爆发的迹象，显得有些不安。
en: Ayrton then proceeded to enter the corral, and, while awaiting the engineer’s return, busied himself with the musmons and goats which seemed to feel a certain uneasiness in presence of these first signs of an eruption.

zh: 与此同时，赛勒斯·哈丁爬上东部支脉的山顶，又经过红河，来到他和他的同伴们第一次探索时发现的硫磺泉的地方。
en: Meanwhile Cyrus Harding ascended the crest of the eastern spur, passed Red Creek, and arrived at the spot where he and his companions had discovered a sulphurous spring at the time of their first exploration.

zh: 所有东西都变得太多了！现在已经不是一股烟而是十三股烟，好像地底下有活塞在使劲儿推着似的。很明显，地球上这部分地壳受到了可怕的压力。大气里充斥着各种气体，还夹杂着混合了水蒸汽的碳酸气。赛勒斯·哈丁感觉他脚下的火山凝灰岩在颤动，这些在平地上铺成的凝灰岩是由岩烬粉末长期凝结形成的硬石块。但是他并没有发现任何新的岩浆的痕迹。
en: How changed was everything!Instead of a single column of smoke he counted thirteen, forced through the soil as if violently propelled by some piston.It was evident that the crust of the earth was subjected in this part of the globe to a frightful pressure.The atmosphere was saturated with gases and carbonic acid, mingled with aqueous vapors.Cyrus Harding felt the volcanic tufa with which the plain was strewn, and which was but pulverized cinders hardened into solid blocks by time, tremble beneath him, but he could discover no traces of fresh lava.

zh: 当他把富兰克林山的北山坡全部查看过一遍后，更加肯定这一点了。烟柱和火焰从火山口里冒出,岩烬像冰雹一样落在地上。但是岩浆一点也没有流出火山口，这就证明了火山物质还没有上涨到中央管口的最上方。
en: The engineer became more assured of this when he observed all the northern part of Mount Franklin.Pillars of smoke and flame escaped from the crater; a hail of scoriae fell on the ground; but no current of lava burst from the mouth of the volcano, which proved that the volcanic matter had not yet attained the level of the superior orifice of the central shaft.

zh: “可是我宁愿岩浆已经上涨到最上方了，”赛勒斯·哈丁自言自语说道，“至少，我就可以知道岩浆是按照原来的路线流动的。谁敢说它不会开辟一条新路呢？但是危险并不在那儿！尼摩船长已经很清楚地预见到了！不，危险不在那儿！”
en: “But I would prefer that it were so,” said Cyrus Harding to himself.“At any rate, I should then know that the lava had followed its accustomed track. who can say that it may not take a new course?But the danger does not consist in that!Captain Nemo foresaw it clearly!No, the danger does not lie there!”

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁大步走向宽阔的堤道，堤道围着狭窄的鲨鱼湾。现在他可以在这边细细致致地检查岩浆流动的古老通道。他确定，最近的一次火山喷发发生在很久很久以前。
en: Cyrus Harding advanced towards the enormous causeway whose prolongation enclosed the narrow Shark Gulf.He could now sufficiently examine on this side the ancient channels of the lava.There was no doubt in his mind that the most recent eruption had occurred at a far-distant epoch.

zh: 然后，他又由原路返回，一路上仔细地听着地下的隆隆声，像一直持续的闷雷声一般，偶尔被几声震耳欲聋的爆炸声打断。早上九点钟的时候，他到达了畜栏。
en: He then returned by the same way, listening attentively to the subterranean mutterings which rolled like long-continued thunder, interrupted by deafening explosions.At nine in the morning he reached the corral.

zh: 艾尔顿正在等他。
en: Ayrton awaited him.

zh: “牲口已经照顾好了，哈丁队长。”艾尔顿说。
en: “The animals are cared for, Captain Harding,” said Ayrton.

zh: “好，艾尔顿。”
en: “Good, Ayrton.”

zh: “它们好像很不安，哈丁队长。”
en: “They seem uneasy, Captain Harding.”

zh: “是的，直觉告诉它们，直觉从不欺骗人。”
en: “Yes, instinct speaks through them, and instinct is never deceived.”

zh: “你准备好了吗？”
en: “Are you ready?”

zh: “带一盏灯，艾尔顿，”工程师回答说，“我们立即出发。”
en: “Take a lamp, Ayrton,” answered the engineer; “we will start at once.”

zh: 艾尔顿按照吩咐做了。卸下缰绳的野驴，在畜栏里游荡。从外面关上门后，赛勒斯·哈丁带着艾尔顿走上了通往西海岸的狭窄的小路。
en: Ayrton did as desired.The onagers, unharnessed, roamed in the corral.The gate was secured on the outside, and Cyrus Harding, preceding Ayrton, took the narrow path which led westward to the shore.

zh: 他们走过的土地上到处是烟雾中落下的粉尘。森林里没有野兽出没。甚至连鸟也飞走了。有时候微风扬起地上的烟灰，这两个人被扬起的满是尘土的旋风包围，彼此谁也看不见谁。他们小心翼翼地用手帕遮住眼睛和嘴，以免烟灰进入眼睛和嘴中。
en: The soil they walked upon was choked with the pulverized matter fallen from the cloud.No quadruped appeared in the woods.Even the birds had fled.Sometimes a passing breeze raised the covering of ashes, and the two colonists, enveloped in a whirlwind of dust, lost sight of each other.They were then careful to cover their eyes and mouths with handkerchiefs, for they ran the risk of being blinded and suffocated.

zh: 有了这些障碍，赛勒斯·哈丁和艾尔通是不可能走太快的。并且，空气不流通，好像已经燃烧了一部分氧气，使得呼吸很困难了。每走一百步，他们就得停下来喘喘气。因此，十点多钟的时候，工程师和他的伙伴才到达由巨大的玄武岩和斑岩形成的荒岛西北岸山石顶峰。
en: It was impossible for Cyrus Harding and Ayrton, with these impediments, to make rapid progress.Moreover, the atmosphere was close, as if the oxygen had been partly burned up, and had become unfit for respiration.At every hundred paces they were obliged to stop to take breath.It was therefore past ten o’clock when the engineer and his companion reached the crest of the enormous mass of rocks of basalt and porphyry which composed the northwest coast of the island.

zh: 艾尔顿和赛勒斯·哈丁开始向陡坡下面走去，几乎是一步一步按照那个暴雨之夜去“达卡洞”的路走的。大白天里，下坡路不像上次那么危险。而且，光亮的岩石上覆盖着一层烟灰，这使得他们的脚步要稳得多。
en: Ayrton and Cyrus Harding commenced the descent of this abrupt declivity, following almost step for step the difficult path which, during that stormy night, had led them to Dakkar Grotto.In open day the descent was less perilous, and, besides, the bed of ashes which covered the polished surface of the rock enabled them to make their footing more secure.

zh: 他们很快就到达了海岸尽头约40英尺高的分水岭。赛勒斯·哈丁想起来这座高高的分水岭是逐渐倾斜到海里去的。虽然目前潮水很低，但还是看不见海滩。掺杂着火山灰的波浪很浑浊，不断拍打着玄武岩石。
en: The ridge at the end of the shore, about forty feet in height, was soon reached.Cyrus Harding recollected that this elevation gradually sloped towards the level of the sea.Although the tide was at present low, no beach could he seen, and the waves, thickened by the volcanic dust, beat upon the basaltic rocks.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和艾尔顿毫不费力就找到了“达卡洞”的入口。他们在进入洞口前的最后一块岩石边停留了一会儿。
en: Cyrus Harding and Ayrton found without difficulty the entrance to Dakkar Grotto, and paused for a moment at the last rock before it.

zh: “铁皮船应该在那儿。”工程师说。
en: “The iron boat should be there,” said the engineer.

zh: “在这儿呢，哈丁队长。”艾尔顿说着把存放在拱门底下的小船拉过来。
en: “It is here, Captain Harding,” replied Ayrton, drawing towards him the fragile craft, which was protected by the arch of the vault.

zh: “上船，艾尔顿！”
en: “On board, Ayrton!”

zh: 两个人上了船。微微的水波把小船带到洞窟里的低拱门之下。在那儿，艾尔顿用火刀和火石点着了灯。然后他拿起桨来，把灯放在船头，这样灯光就能往前照射了。塞勒斯·哈丁掌起舵，在阴暗的洞窟里驾驶。
en: The two colonists stepped into the boat.A slight undulation of the waves carried it farther under the low arch of the crypt, and there Ayrton, with the aid of flint and steel, lighted the lamp.He then took the oars, and the lamp having been placed in the bow of the boat, so that its rays fell before them, Cyrus Harding took the helm and steered through the shades of the grotto.

zh: “诺第留斯号”不再用它的电光照射洞窟了。船上的灯光也许还没有熄灭，但没有一线光从尼摩船长长眠的深渊里照射上来。
en: The “Nautilus” was there no longer to illuminate the cavern with its electric light.Possibly it might not yet be extinguished, but no ray escaped from the depths of the abyss in which reposed all that was mortal of Captain Nemo.

zh: 这盏灯发出的光尽管很微弱，但是还能够指引工程师沿着洞窟的墙壁慢慢前进。在圆拱形的顶下，至少是在靠外面的这一部分是死一般的静寂。不一会儿，赛勒斯·哈丁就清楚地听到山内部传来的隆隆声了。
en: The light afforded by the lamp, although feeble, nevertheless enabled the engineer to advance slowly, following the wall of the cavern.A deathlike silence reigned under the vaulted roof, or at least in the anterior portion, for soon Cyrus Harding distinctly heard the rumbling which proceeded from the bowels of the mountain.

zh: “那是从火山里传出来的。”他说。
en: “That comes from the volcano,” he said.

zh: 除了这些声音外，他们很快闻到一种强烈的气味，从这种强烈的气味得知这里在发生着化学变化。工程师和他的伙伴在这种带着硫磺味的水蒸汽中几乎要窒息。
en: Besides these sounds, the presence of chemical combinations was soon betrayed by their powerful odor, and the engineer and his companion were almost suffocated by sulphurous vapors.

zh: “尼摩船长担心的就是这个，”赛勒斯·哈丁低语着，脸色也开始变了，“尽管这样，我们还是必须到洞的最里面去。”
en: “This is what Captain Nemo feared,” murmured Cyrus Harding, changing countenance.“We must go to the end, notwithstanding.”

zh: “向前！”艾尔顿说着，弯下腰拾起双桨，划船走向洞窟的尽头。
en: “Forward!” replied Ayrton, bending to his oars and directing the boat towards the head of the cavern.

zh: 进洞口25分钟后，小船到达了洞窟的尽头。
en: Twenty-five minutes after entering the mouth of the grotto the boat reached the extreme end.

zh: 这时赛勒斯·哈丁站起身来，把灯光照射在洞窟的墙上。这堵墙隔开了洞窟和火山的中央管道。这堵墙有多厚呢？也许有十英尺，也许有一百英尺—都不好说。但是地底下的响声太清楚了，据此可以猜想这堵墙不会太厚。
en: Cyrus Harding then, standing up, cast the light of the lamp upon the walls of the cavern which separated it from the central shaft of the volcano.What was the thickness of this wall?It might be ten feet or a hundred feet—it was impossible to say.But the subterranean sounds were too perceptible to allow of the supposition that it was of any great thickness.

zh: 工程师检查了墙的下部后，把灯绑在桨上，又开始查看墙高处的玄武石。
en: The engineer, after having explored the wall at a certain height horizontally, fastened the lamp to the end of an oar, and again surveyed the basaltic wall at a greater elevation.

zh: 就在那儿，墙上有很多难以看清的缝隙，缝隙里冒出刺鼻的水蒸汽，扩散在洞窟的空气里。墙上还有几处大裂缝，有的一直裂到离水面两三英尺的地方。
en: There, through scarcely visible clefts and joinings, escaped a pungent vapor, which infected the atmosphere of the cavern.The wall was broken by large cracks, some of which extended to within two or three feet of the water’s edge.

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁沉思了片刻。然后他低声说道：
en: Cyrus Harding thought for a brief space.Then he said in a low voice,—

zh: “是的！船长是对的！危险就在这儿，而且很可怕！”
en: “Yes! the captain was right!The danger lies there, and a terrible danger!”

zh: 艾尔顿一句话也没有说。但是通过赛勒斯·哈丁的一个手势，他又划起桨来。半个小时后，他和工程师又回到“达卡洞”的入口处。
en: Ayrton said not a word, but, upon a sign from Cyrus Harding, resumed the oars, and half an hour later the engineer and he reached the entrance of Dakkar Grotto.

zh: 第十九章
en: Chapter 19

zh: 赛勒斯·哈丁和艾尔顿在畜栏呆了一天一夜，安顿好了一切，第二天，也就是1月8日，他们又回到了花岗石宫。
en: The next day, the 8th day of January, after a day and night passed at the corral, where they left all in order, Cyrus Harding and Ayrton arrived at Granite House.

zh: 工程师立即召集所有的同伴，通知他们林肯岛马上面临着威胁，任何人都没有力量使他们脱离危险。
en: The engineer immediately called his companions together, and informed them of the imminent danger which threatened Lincoln Island, and from which no human power could deliver them.

zh: “朋友们，”他说着，声音里流露出激动之情，“我们的岛并不是那种可以和地球共存亡的岛。它很快就要毁灭了，毁灭的原因就隐藏在岛的里面，而且无法挽救。”
en: “My friends,” he said, and his voice betrayed the depth of his emotion, “our island is not among those which will endure while this earth endures.It is doomed to more or less speedy destruction, the cause of which it bears within itself, and from which nothing can save it.”

zh: 移民们面面相觑，最后都看着工程师。他们还不太明白他的意思。
en: The colonists looked at each other, then at the engineer.They did not clearly comprehend him.

zh: “你解释一下吧，赛勒斯！”吉迪恩·史佩莱说。
en: “Explain yourself, Cyrus!” said Gideon Spilett.
